column2: Your editorial "Insuring More Autos" has appeared in the Memphis Commercial Appeal in the guest writer's column. As a former New Yorker and present TIMES subscriber I am taking the liberty of questioning the thoroughness of your treatment of the subject-matter of compulsory liability insurance for automobile drivers.

CLEVELAND, April 24 (AP) -- The first European freighter of the season is due to dock here tomorrow, but shipping sources still are holding off predictions on foreign trade in the Great Lakes this season.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 24 -- Civil Defense authorities warned motorists today that the Queens-Nassau border would be closed to traffic for ten minutes Saturday morning sometime between 8:45 and 9:15 during the air-raid drill in Nassau. Long Island trains will not be affected.

Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, indicated in a speech here last night that he would support a Republican for President if the Republican stood firmly for maintenance of the national credit and a sound currency and the Democratic candidate did not.

The question of whether the Communist party seeks to overthrow the Government of the United States by force and violence or by constitutional means emerged yesterday as the key issue in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders.
A Geiger counter went berserk yesterday at Columbia University, starting an atomic radiation rumor that rippled as far as Washington and Rochester.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Mental illness strikes seven times as often as cancer during the most productive years of a person's life, Dr. Robert H. Felix, Director of the National Mental Health Institute, the nation's official mental health agency, reported tonight.

TRENTON, April 24 -- The ousting of former Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City as Democratic National Committeeman, a position he had held for thirty years, and an appeal to the Democrats by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, a Republican, for a campaign this year that "would not give aid and comfort to the enemy" highlighted the annual state conventions of the Democratic and Republican parties here today.

WESTVILLE, N. J., April 24 -- Thirty families living along the banks of Big Timber Creek were still barricaded tonight in a quarantine clamped down yesterday after a case of spotted fever meningitis had been discovered.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- A Congressional investigation of the Administration's policies and practices in the dissemination of news information was proposed today in a resolution introduced by Senator Blair Moody, Democrat of Michigan.

Paris showed its influence on the fashions selected by Russeks for midsummer in New York when the Fifth Avenue store presented a collection at the luncheon hour yesterday in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel. Many of the styles were those which the store has been endorsing since the imports arrived from the last couture openings.
TOKYO, Friday, April 25 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,230, for Thursday's operations:
LONDON, April 24 (Reuters) -- The United States, Canada and Australia are seeking higher prices for their wheat at the London wheat conference, a reliable source said today.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The Mutual Security Agency turned over to the Justice Department today accusations that three oil companies made overcharges totalling about $50,000,000 on shipments financed with foreign aid funds.

Alexander Kadison's letter in your issue of April 11 assumes that New York City's present upland water supply is pure at the source. This is not the fact. The water is polluted. The pollution increases as the population of the watershed grows. Only heavy chemical treatment and long periods of coagulation and sedimentation in storage reservoirs render it safe to drink.

Amended price controls permitting some pass-through of manufacturers' price increases and requiring pass-through of decreases will apply to wholesale and retail sale of paper products beginning Monday, New York Regional Office of Price Stabilization announced yesterday.

LONDON, April 24 -- The United States, Britain and Italy have reached substantial agreement on giving Italy a large share in the day to day administration of Trieste's Zone A, which is governed by the United States and Britain.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- A 165-page bill designed to revise sharply and codify the decades-old jumble of immigration, naturalization and nationality laws resisted today attempts in the House of Representatives to make it weaker or stronger.

The Electoral College, to which the writers of the Constitution gave the right of independent choice, has become such an anachronism that only one passage in the recent Supreme Court opinions dealing with its independent character got any public attention.

A 27-year-old Brooklyn longshoreman has "admitted" stealing the weapon that was used to murder Arnold L. Schuster, the salesman whose identification of William Sutton led to the arrest of the bank robber, Aaron E. Koota, a special assistant district attorney, revealed yesterday.

BONN, Germany, April 24 -- A conference between the Soviet Union and the three Western powers on Germany's reunification in freedom was advocated today by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in an exhaustive defense of his policy, which stressed his conviction that Germany must, and some day would, be reunited in freedom.
BUENOS AIRES, April 23 (UP) -- President Juan D. Peron charged today that foreign interests were masterminding a campaign of rumors against his Government in Argentina.

The distribution of contraceptives would do more to improve the world's living standards than the development of President Truman's Point Four program, William Vogt, national director of Planned Parenthood Federation of America, said yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS N. Y., April 24 -- A group of North African nationalists demanded today that Secretary General Trygve Lie call on the United States and Britain to stop sending military or financial aid to France until the settlement of the Tunisian situation.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 37 additional battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 9 killed, 25 wounded and 3 injured. The following were listed from New York and Connecticut (none from New Jersey):

Industrialists are fooling themselves if they believe a change in the Washington Administration will solve current labor-management problems, Walter H. Wheeler Jr., president of Pitney-Bowes, Inc., Stamford, Conn., mailing meter concern, declared here yesterday.

LONDON, April 24 -- The stock markets presented a firm front today. British Government securities more than regained yesterday's losses and industrial shares generally held firm, with textiles making a particularly good showing.

J. I. Case Company, manufacturer of farm machinery, is offering to its stockholders today rights to subscribe to 377,058 new shares of common stock at $24.50 a share in a transaction underwritten by fifty-four investment houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co. and Clark, Dodge Co. The offer will expire May 12.

Wealth of the Ford Foundation, richest public trust in the world, became still greater in 1951 as the nonprofit organization completed the first full calendar year of its active program designed to advance peace, freedom and human welfare.
AKRON, April 24 -- Harold E. Stassen opened his campaign for Presidential delegates in Ohio tonight by pursuing Senator Robert A. Taft on three issues of foreign policy and three on domestic policy.

TOKYO, Friday, April 25 -- Secret negotiations between United Nations and Communist representatives at Panmunjom over an exchange of war prisoners in an armistice in Korea broke up today with no date set for a renewal of the talks.

Strike threats involving approximately 40,000 workers in the East Coast shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Todd Shipyards Corporation were dissipated yesterday as the shipworkers' union announced forty-five-day postponements of the settlement deadlines.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 10 to 24 points higher yesterday than on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce today established iron and steel scrap quotas for the second quarter of this year at 11,000 tons above the level fixed for the first quarter.
GENEVA, April 24, -- Western Europe is well on its way to meeting 1953 targets for steel production, the Economic Commission for Europe's steel division reported today.

CINCINNATI, April 24 -- Cures of tuberculosis of the larynx and of the tongue through treatment with the new drug, isonicotonic acid hydrazide, and its derivatives, have been observed by Dr. Martin M. Fisher of Sea View and Kings County Hospital, New York, he said here today.

The Rotex Metal Company has leased the one-story factory building at 1065-67 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, from Abraham N. Friedman. Colony Realty was the broker. The building contains 4,400 square feet of space and there is a yard space of 1,900 square feet.

PARIS, April 24 -- The French have proposed that when the European Defense Community treaty is signed the United States, Britain and France should make a joint statement saying that any violation of the treaty would be considered a threat to peace calling for consultation as provided in Article 4 of the North Atlantic Treaty.

JACKSON, Mich., April 24 (UP) -- Following are the backgrounds of the two psychopaths whom Warden Fox, the prison psychologist, congratulated on their leadership of the Jackson prison revolt that defied the State of Michigan for five days:

Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres today. "Red Mountain," a Technicolor drama of the Old West starring Alan Ladd, Lizabeth Scott and Arthur Kennedy and produced by Hal Wallis for Paramount, is at the Globe. John Ireland, Jeff Corey and James Bell head the supporting cast.

Village Green, a fifty-two-family garden apartment colony at 95 North Broadway, White Plains, N. Y., has been purchased by a syndicate represented by the Investors Funding Corporation of New York, Jerome Dansker, president.
MONTREAL, April 24 (AP) -- Sid Smith, 26-year-old Toronto Maple Leafs left-winger, is the winner of the National Hockey League's Lady Byng Memorial Trophy for the 1951-52 season.

The stock market again was placed under severe pressure yesterday by selling in oils. Although there was a considerable recovery in the afternoon, little of the extreme damage was repaired, despite a major lift in railroads.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Federal District Judge David A. Pine, weighing a plea to nullify the Government's seizure of the steel industry, indicated a strong doubt today of the President's power to take private property in the absence of specific authorization by law.

LOS ANGELES, April 24 -- The roster of defendants in the three-month Communist conspiracy trial in Federal Court here was reduced to fourteen today with the severance of the case of Mary Bernadette Doyle because of ill health.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft said tonight that if he were President he might have seized the steel mills in the labor dispute that involves them, but only after getting approval and authority from Congress.

High Dive of the King Ranch beat Mrs. John Rutherfurd's Donor in the Sunnyside at Jamaica yesterday. There were three other horses in the mile-and-a-sixteenth event, but the 21,905 fans had eyes only for this pair at the finish, most of them hoping that the favored Donor would close fast to gain the victory.

Greater volume in most of the operations of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., has been responsible for the gain in net earnings from $37,000,000 in the first 1951 quarter to $41,000,000 in the March quarter just ended, B. Brewster Jennings, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

Columbia University further explained yesterday its refusal to recognize striking cafeteria workers as members of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., by expressing the fear that further unionization of employes would lead to a loss of its independence in operating the school.
An amicable settlement of eviction proceedings against fourteen tenants in three Washington Square buildings appeared in sight last night.

PARIS, April 24 -- The speech on the Saar made to the Bonn Parliament by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer yesterday was interpreted here today as marking a retreat from the position Dr. Adenauer had taken in Paris March 20 in agreeing to negotiate with the French for a permanent settlement of the Saar question.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The annual analysis "Women in the Public Service," issued today by the Women's Division of the Republican National Committee, presents a statistical picture of how far women have gone in politics.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 -- Had the powerful atomic bomb that burst over Nevada in Tuesday's test been exploded above Central Park and Harlem there might have been 500,000 casualties, Lieut. Gen. C. R. Huebner, New York's Civil Defense Director, said here today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 24 -- Write-in votes for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower at Ohio's May 6 primary election are prohibited by state law, Attorney General C. William O'Neill ruled today.

Soft sheer dresses, selected with summer in mind, were presented yesterday in a fashion show at the Busman Theatre by Bonwit Teller. Emphasis was on beautiful cottons dramatized by embroidery, woven satin stripes, sequins, soutache and passementrie.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., April 24 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation started an inquiry today of two bomb scares that the General Electric Company said had cost 7,950 man-hours of electronic tube production.
ALBANY, April 24 (AP) -- The New York State Council of Churches contended today that "perjured testimony and judicial license" was making New York "the poor man's Reno."

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 24 -- Denying again that communism existed in the public schools here, the Board of Education of District 1 refused today to embark on censorship of textbooks, library volumes, faculty members and assembly speakers.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Truman declared today that the United States was trying to regain positive military strength, of the degree attained in World War II, to prevent or neutralize imperialistic Soviet moves.
PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- More rain and falling temperature made the Dodgers' first trip to this city a total loss, tonight's game also having been called off.

Unless he had been peeking from his center-field office window, Leo Durocher did not see his Giants blow a 3-run lead and lose to the Braves by 6 -- 3 in ten innings yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Durocher had been banished for the first time this year.
Harold Kern has been appointed controller and Joseph L. Condon Jr. assistant general sales manager, of the Bostwick Laboratories, Inc., Bridgeport, Conn.

WEATHER and stream conditions have a definite effect on the trout fisherman's pleasure, but seldom on his intentions, The majority of those who call to get information on stream conditions listen to discouraging reports, then announce, "Well, guess I'll make the trip anyway."

KODIAK, Alaska, April 24 (AP) -- The Navy patrol bomber stranded on an ice island near the North Pole since April 5 landed at Thule, Greenland, safely today, the Seventeenth Naval District Headquarters here said.

Several administrative changes in the General Motors Corporation, effective next Thursday, were announced yesterday by C. E. Wilson, president. John J. Cronin, general manager of the Fisher Body division since September, 1948, and a vice president of G. M., was elected as executive in charge of the parent company's manufacturing staff.
PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Harold E. Stassen's political funds are almost as low as his political prestige, but he is not pulling out of the Presidential race -- at least not yet.

The two-story taxpayer at the southwest corner of Seventy-first Avenue and Austin Street in Forest Hills, Queens, containing twelve stores on the ground floor, has been purchased by an investing client of Dreyer Traub, attorneys, in a transaction negotiated by the Advance Realty Company as broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. The property, on a plot 100 by 260 feet, was held at $800,000.

TYRUS RAYMOND COBB undoubtedly shocked and horrified some modern baseball fans with his magazine articles on the "good old days" when he related how skillfully the pitchers cheated a generation ago. However, such offerings as the spitball, the emery ball, the shine ball and the like were legal then.

Handsome specimens of artichoke and eggplant are among the most attractive offerings at the vegetable counter this week-end. It is the peak of the season for the 'chokes, most of which are coming from California, where the crop has been especially good this year.

ROME, April 24 -- Speaking to several hundred delegates who had participated in the thirteenth congress of the World Union of Organizations of Catholic Women, Pope Pius today called upon women throughout the world to participate in the "arduous but sublime task of laboring for peace."

The American Retail Federation is taking a poll of its fifty-four national and state member retail associations to determine whether most retailers want consumer product price controls suspended or terminated after June 30. The association indicated yesterday that the current "referendum" was forced by the Wage Stabilization Board's recent decision in the steel dispute coupled with "general economic conditions" under which most consumer products are selling well below established ceilings.

A small group of Handmacher Weathervane suits, exclusive with Abraham Straus in Brooklyn, were modeled informally last evening on the store's fifth floor. The trim classic lines and meticulous tailoring for which these suits are known prevailed in the six styles which were featured.

The pitfalls that still dot the road to European unification are revealed again by the new flare-up between France and Germany over the Saar. As a result, the direct negotiations over this troublesome issue, begun between the two countries last month, have broken down and both sides have adopted even more uncompromising positions than before.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Truman and Millard Caldwell, Federal Civil Defense Administrator, joined to warn the country today that organization against enemy air attack on vital centers in the United States was lagging.
Central Park was a welcome mat yesterday for Abraham Schweizer, a blind refugee from Poland, and his guide dog, Dora.

The Columbia University Glee Club, directed by Carl A. Lambert, gave a concert last night in Town Hall. The group of sixty-five is a superbly trained and disciplined organization, with admirable diction, excellent balance and resonant tone.
Alfred M. Erlich has become manager of the foreign securities department of Hayden, Stone Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange.

Efforts by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, to improve waterfront conditions in this port, as suggested by an impartial state board of inquiry, appeared to have bogged down yesterday when the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., continued its refusal to cooperate.
Jackie, a young but lassitudinous circus lion, won more than an hour of freedom by escape from his cage in Madison Square Garden basement yesterday, but frittered it away in dreamy brooding.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- European countries, which "muffed" their first post-war opportunity to trade with South America, are making strong new bids to edge the United States out of its dominant position as South America's supplier, Charles E. Beard, executive vice president of Braniff International Airways, Inc., said today.

The Western Union Telegraph Company, strikebound since April 3 when 31,000 employes walked off their jobs, reported yesterday that it was now handling 40 per cent of its normal revenues as "thousands" returned to work. However, the company would give no specific figures. The Commercial Telegraphers Union, A. F. L., has ridiculed these company reports.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended April 19 were 1 per cent below sales in the same period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Figures from the board's weekly report on sales by cities follow, in terms of percentage changes from corresponding periods of 1951:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24 -- Over the vigorous opposition of the Soviet delegation, the executive board of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund approved today the unfreezing of a balance of $6,762,000, allocated a few years ago for relief work on the mainland of China.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Daniel C. Gainey, manager of the Washington Stassen-for-President campagn, said today that he thought General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower had the "best chance" to win the Republican Presidential nomination.

The many problems now confronting the brand advertiser can best be met by using the newspaper as an advertising medium, it was said yesterday by Henry Slamin, president of the American Association of Newspaper Representatives.
MIAMI BEACH, April 24 (UP) -The police seized five persons here and in Charleston, S. C., today for an alleged $100,000 bad check swindle carried out by a troupe of nightclub entertainers.

FRANKFURT, Germany, April 24 -- The hearing by a special committee of the United States House of Representatives on the Katyn Forest massacre of World War II developed today into a discussion of, and, by inference, an attempted attack on, the objectivity of the court during the Nuremberg trials -- to the obvious delight of German spectators.

MEXICO CITY, April 24 -- A growing tension and uneasiness have penetrated the Mexican political atmosphere as a result of the attitude of President Miguel Aleman toward the forthcoming national elections.

Harry Gross, convicted Brooklyn bookmaker, will testify next Wednesday at a retrial of eighteen policemen on disciplinary charges growing out of alleged protection of Gross' multimillion-dollar gambling business, Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- "Nabucco," the opera that set Verdi squarely on the road to fame and fortune, was produced here tonight at the resonant old Academy of Music by the Philadelphia Civic Grand Opera Company. A production of this work is a rare event even in Italy, and it occurs once in a lifetime, if that often, in this country.
LONDON, April 24 (AP) -- Higher exports enabled Britain to cut her overseas trade deficit by nearly a third in the first quarter of this year.

Mayor Impellitteri's proposed 1952-53 budget of $1,469,265,101 was unanimously adopted yesterday by the Board of Estimate, which did not change a single figure in the Mayor's schedules. It was the largest budget in the city's history, the sixth in a row to pass the billion-dollar mark and the first since adoption of the present City Charter in 1938 to be accepted by the board without amendment.
LONDON, April 24 (AP) -- Jane Russell can go ahead now and adopt little Tommy Kavanagh, but a court warned today nobody else should try to get a baby from Britain as she had done.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 24 -Attorneys for the Syracuse Post-Standard began legal action today to compel Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, to answer a series of questions that he declined to answer in a pre-trial examination of his $500,000 libel suit against the newspaper.
Five of the art shows here deserve special attention by the gallery-goer.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 24 -- Juan Lechin, the Minister of Mines and Petroleum, today accused Bolivia's big tin companies of sabotaging their mining efforts and promised that the new Government would have plans drawn for nationalizing the mines within a month.

Gertrude Lawrence, who has publicly portrayed a school-mistress in the Broadway musical, "The King and I," for thirteen months, raised yesterday the curtain of secrecy that has surrounded her in the part of a real-life teacher for nearly seven months.
Investment buying of small apartment properties featured realty deals reported in Manhattan yesterday.
ONAWA, Iowa, April 24 -- The Department of Agriculture sold 460,000 bushels of flood-damaged Government corn today at forty-seven cents a bushel. Good-grade market corn is figured at $1.65 a bushel.

STEUBENVILLE, April 24 -- Mrs. Estes Kefauver, in the absence of her husband, opened the Tennessee Senator's Ohio primary campaign here today, shaking hands with hundreds of well- wishers and addressing public meetings in three industrial towns.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- Ephraim S. London argued before the Supreme Court today that motion pictures disseminated ideas, just as magazines and newspapers did, and should not be subject to advance censorship.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24 -- The United States estimated today that if its plan for a world military census were put into operation in good faith the size and location of atomic stock-piles would be revealed within one or two years.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 24 (AP) -- A well-scrubbed turkey, ready for the oven and neatly wrapped in cellophane, was the center of attraction in United States District Court here today.

There are 37,515 children between the ages of 6 and 21 in this city who are delinquent or have behavior problems threatening delinquency, according to the first report, issued yesterday, of the New York City Youth Board.

In spring a young man's fancy turns, it is said, but in 4-year-old Eric Neil Werny of 32-37 Jordan Street, Bayside, Queens, it's to trains. When he heard the whistle yesterday the results were a police alarm and a delay to a Long Island Rail Road train.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24 -- Jerry Wald, executive producer of the Wald-Krasna producing unit at R. K. O., is looking for an actress who not only will have the professional ability but also the nerve to go along with him in his proposed one-character film, appropriately titled "One Woman."

New York bank loans to business dropped $114,000,000 last week, marking the largest reduction in any week since April, 1949. The decline, largely the result of seasonal influences, brought the total contraction during the past four weeks to $297,000,000, against a decrease of $123,000,000 in the similar period last year.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -President Truman signed emergency legislation today providing $25,000,000 more for relief of the flood-stricken Missouri River Valley area.

There is a direct connection between the rejection of the plan for a Central African federation by the Negro delegates to London and the repressive racist measures of Prime Minister Malan's Government in South Africa. The British proposal for a grouping of the protectorate of Nyasaland and the two Rhodesias was promising and it had gone far enough to lead to the meeting in London which was to have drawn up a draft constitution.

GENEVA, April 24 -- There are a number of signs of growing economic realism in Europe. They may be swallows too far ahead of spring, but in Europe's recently dominant mood of despondency about its economic prospects such signs are not to be either ignored or deplored.

The fatal shooting of a longshoreman last Friday night in a waterfront bar and grill was described yesterday in the Court of General Sessions as an "execution in cold blood" as two more material witnesses were each held in bail of $50,000. A total of five material witnesses are now being held.

A national outcry would doubtless be raised if Congress should pass a bill simply handing over to the states of California, Texas and Louisiana a multibillion-dollar asset that now belongs to the people of all the United States. Yet that is, in effect, just what both houses of Congress have already done in approving two different versions of a quitclaim bill resigning to the states all federal rights to vast offshore oil deposits.

Increasing demands by American producers for restriction of imports were condemned yesterday By Willard L. Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, as a blow to economic progress of the free world and an aid to Communist propaganda.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 24 -- The Nationalist Government's bill making Parliament itself the final court of appeal is a coup d'etat and tantamount to converting South Africa into a totalitarian state, if the legislation can be enforced, in the opinion of the conservative Johannesburg Star.

Strange things have been happening to Latin-American free currency markets this week, according to Pick's World Currency Report. The Brazilian cruzeiro, which stood at 33 1/4 for $1 on Monday, was at 34 1/2 or 35 yesterday. The Argentine peso moved in three days from 23.60 to 25.50 for $1.

TOKYO, April 24 (UP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway said today that Communist forces were capable of launching a surprise major attack on Japan from the Soviet Union, Manchuria or Korea, but he pledged that "Japan can and will be defended against any attack."

" American Inventory," the Sunday-afternoon program presented by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation in association with the N. B. C. Television Network, undertook something different this week -- a sort of Kentucky mountain version of "Romeo and Juliet."

The heads of the two largest steel-producing companies, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, and Eugene G. Grace, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Company, attacked President Truman yesterday for his seizure of the industry last April 8.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- The State Department today admitted distributing thousands of pamphlets win General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's picture but denied they were political promotion.

CLEVELAND, April 24 (AP) -- Dr. Le Roy H. Sloan of Chicago, professor at the University of Illinois College of Medicine, was chosen president-elect of the American College of Physicians today. He will take office next year.
KANSAS CITY, April 24 (AP) -Kansas City stood the strain today as the upper Missouri River's greatest flood surged past on its way to the sea.

Your editorial "Roadblock in Korea" squarely stated the moral reasons why the United Nations should never compromise its stand in Korea by forcibly returning Chinese and North Korean prisoners to the Communists. Mrs. Geraldine Fitch in her letter of April 17 also brought out our reasons of self-interest in honoring our word, pledged in the leaflets that induced prisoners to surrender.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, proposed today that Boston be made the terminal for European air travel to relieve congestion at New York and Washington.

JACKSON, Mich., April 24 -- Rioting convicts surrendered at Southern Michigan Prison today and released eight guards held as hostages. The 171 die-hard convicts won an eleven-point reform program in the five-day mutiny.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 24 -- The United States supports "without qualification" efforts by the International Labor Organization to improve the conditions of South American workers, Philip M. Kaiser, the United States Assistant Secretary of Labor, told the I. L. O. regional conference in Quitandinha today.

While Sal Chiaramonte held the Beavers to two hits during the first six innings, Fordham accumulated a six-run lead and went on to defeat the City College baseball team, 9 to 3, at Rose Hill yesterday.
Lieut. Gen. C. R. Huebner, director of the New York State Civil Defense Commission, issued an urgent appeal last night for at least 70,000 additional volunteer aircraft spotters.

Julius Kayser Co. has purchased a substantial stock interest in Naigai Kabushiki Kaisha of Tokyo, it was announced yesterday by T. H. Mueller, president. He said hosiery, gloves and lingerie, bearing the Kayser trademark, would be manufactured in Japan for distribution in the Far East.

A Cleveland engineering company that made a detailed survey of the Sanitation Department recommended yesterday a series of changes designed to increase its efficiency and reduce its costs, but said the frequency of garbage collections was entirely adequate and should not be changed except where specific local conditions warranted it.

Your editorial reference to the Soviet commemoration of Leonardo da Vinci calls attention to a Communist practice which puts our "materialistic capitalist" Governments to shame, although they invariably pervert facts into propaganda.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 -Methodist ministers may soon be permitted to smoke, if the voting record of delegates attending the church's quadrennial general conference here is a reliable barometer of future actions.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 24 (AP) -- Gushing Oil, Sam Wilson Jr.'s big Kentucky Derby hope, splashed through the slop, rain and gloom of the chilly Keeneland race track today to win the $31,150 Blue Grass Stakes by a length over fast-closing Cold Command.

Liquidation of May coffee contracts in preparation for first notice day today was the feature of trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The market was firm at the close but at about its lows for the day, down 28 to 45 points. Volume was 46,750 bags.

JACKSON, Mich., April 24 (AP) -- Vernon Fox, assistant deputy warden, an advocate of fewer prison guards and more psychiatric treatment of convicts, gave fulsome praise to the surrendering mutineers of Southern Michigan Prison heroes today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 24 -- The Yugoslav Government is preparing to stage in Belgrade its biggest post-war May Day military parade, which will have as a feature samples of the new equipment received under the United States military assistance program.

MOSCOW, April 24 -- Diplomats felt certain tonight that when and if any meeting of the Chiefs of State ever assembled to discuss global problems the Soviet Union would insist on the right of Red China's Mao Tse-tung to a place at the council table.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- John F. Floberg, Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air led off today what was expected to be a concerted campaign by top Navy leaders to gain public support for construction of a second 60,000-ton aircraft carrier.
BERLIN, April 24 (AP) -- About 25,000 Communist blue shirts stormed West Berlin's frontier tonight in a professed peace rally that resulted in a few cracked heads and fourteen arrests.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- A little-used section of the Taft-Hartley Law is available for the prosecution of racketeer-led labor unions that are making a reappearance in New York, officials here pointed out today. A union leader who takes a "pay-off" and an employer who pays him are liable to fines and imprisonment up to $10,000 and one year.

The Greater Weekly Associates, publisher-owned and operated organization that solicits national advertising for its member newspapers, opened its annual three-day conference yesterday at the Statler Hotel. The group, made up of 220 newspapers, now handles 600 separate national accounts.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Members of the Armed Forces stationed outside their home states would be assured of the opportunity to vote on candidates for Federal office in November under terms of an Administration bill introduced today in the House and Senate.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- President Truman defended the refusal of W. Averell Harriman today to quit as foreign aid chief while camapaigning for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

Manager Leo Durocher of the Giants in an angry mood said yesterday that President Warren Giles of the National League "should throw his rule book out the window because the umpires don't abide by it anyway."

JACKSON, Mich., April 24 (AP) -- Out of Cell Block 15, which was the fortress of southern Michigan's surrendering mutineers, came today an authentic but anonymous story of how the rebellion got under way through trickery.

DETROIT, April 24 -- A panel of six high school students, appearing on THE NEW YORK TIMES Youth Forum here today, expressed the belief that industry had failed in its contribution to world peace because it placed too much importance on profits.

TANGIER, April 24 -- Unless the Paris agreement of 1945 establishing a provisional regime for Tangier is declared no longer valid, the Soviet Union has the right to participate in the administration of this international zone and block, by its veto, any decision of the Control Committee, which is the local supreme authority.
An apartment project of pioneering type will rise on a large site in Queens as the result of an unusual financing deal just arranged.
NEWARK, April 24 -- The North Newark branch of the National State Bank was held up this afternoon by three, or possibly four, armed robbers who escaped with $30,000.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York yesterday filed plans for a sixteen-story office building to house its new headquarters at 732-36 Lexington Avenue, 124-30 East Fifty-ninth Street and 129 East Fifty-eighth Street. The architect is H. I. Feldman who estimated the cost at $1,750,000.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Andrew Mellon Memorial Fountain set at the apex of Washington's Federal Triangle, was tested today in a wind-blown and rainy preview.

HOUSTON, Texas, April 24 -- A resolution denouncing excessive Federal liquor taxes as "illogical, unreasonable and inimical to the public interest" was adopted here today by the National Conference of State Liquor Administrators.

Reflecting the rise in sales, Standard Oil Company of California estimated its net income in the first three months this year increased to $41,791,386 from $38,401,948 for the corresponding March quarter a year ago.

WLIMINGTON, Del., April 24 (AP) -- First quarter earnings of the Diamond Match Company declined to 60 cents a share from the year-ago level of $2 a share, Howard F. Holman, chairman, told stockholders today. Sales for the first quarter were $22,194,000, compared with $28,712,000 for the first three months of 1951.

That list of twenty buildings in New York City especially recommended for preservation by the Municipal Art Society and the New York Chapter of the Society of Architectural Historians at their dinner the other day is notable for several reasons.

Frank Hague, whose political career now seems as definitely end carrer now seems as definitely ended as his connection with the Democratic National Committee, was a prototype of the American political boss. For three decades his influence extended not only throughout his own state of New Jersey but into the higher reaches of national maneuvering for power.

Five defense attorneys began yesterday to pay for their harassing, unlawyer-like conduct during the nine-month trial of the eleven convicted Communist leaders. They surrendered in Federal Court to start prison sentences for contempt of court.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared tonight that the exchange of prisoners of war was at issue in the Korean truce negotiations because the United Nations believed in "the worth of the individual" and the Communists did not.
CALDWELL, N. J., April 24 -Mrs. Gordon Park of Glen Ridge won the Women's Metropolitan opening Class A one-day golf tournament, New Jersey division, over the Green Brook Country Club course today.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 24 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, virtually recovered from a five-day attack of streptococcal infection of his throat, had as his luncheon guest at his Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, here today Lord Tedder, Chancellor of Cambridge University and his air commander in World War II.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., April 24 -- Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune, one of the leading Negro educators in the United States, spoke here tonight at a privately sponsored meeting after her scheduled address at a school was canceled by the Board of Education on action instigated by the Englewood Anti-Communist League.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 24 (AP) -- Frank Strafaci and Mal Galletta, both of New York State; Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, and Harry Haverstick Jr. of Lancaster, Pa., today knocked the South completely out of the North and South amateur golf tournament.

A sad event which occurred day before yesterday is just as sad as though it had occurred only yesterday. By following this principle to its logical extreme we may conclude that what seems to have happened to a brontosaurus near Glen Rose, Tex., about 120,001,952 years ago is none the less sad because of the time that has elapsed.

The recent tapering off in construction of new housing in New York City, the sizable drift of population to the suburbs, and the desirability of strengthening the city's appeal as a place to live, rear children and do business all point to the need for new and stimulating ideas.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- The annual home-coming "circus" at the Tilden Technical High School ended ahead of schedule tonight when a student chemical experiment exploded and injured twenty-one persons, none seriously. Ironically, efforts to help a woman who had fainted resulted in a louder explosion that aroused the neighborhood.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- The annual home-coming "circus" at the Tilden Technical High School ended ahead of schedule tonight when a student chemical experiment exploded and injured twenty-one persons, none seriously. Ironically, efforts to help a woman who had fainted resulted in a louder explosion that aroused the neighborhood.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, said here today that he was "profoundly worried" about the ability of private colleges to survive in the face of such current economic pressures as high taxes and "ruinous inflation."

An admitted fixer of college basketball games who is scheduled to be sentenced this morning in Bronx County Court was arrested yesterday on a forgery charge alleging he swindled a brokerage house of almost $10,000 in the last three weeks.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 24 -- South Africa's great parliamentary debate fell off momentarily today to collateral issues, and there was time to consider the deep meaning of the crisis.

Butter, margarine, eggs, fowl, two popular beef cuts, several varieties of salt and fresh water fish and a market basketful of fresh vegetables show lower price tags for the family food shopper this week-end.

NEWARK, April 25 -- The dispute between Chief Magistrate Samuel E. Cooper and Acting Magistrate J. Bernard Johnson over the right to preside in Fourth Precinct Court during a week's absence of Magistrate LeRoy J. D'Aloia on vacation was compromised temporarily today with an agreement to share the litigants.

A bronze plaque in recognition of his high type of citizenship and his service to the city, state and nation was presented yesterday to Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan on behalf of the Community Councils of the City of New York, Inc., at the annual meeting of its recreation committee.
Love Peace, a 45-year-old disciple of Father Divine, told the Brooklyn police yesterday that she routed two hold-up men from her employer's home by quoting the Gospel and saying prayers.

MANILA, April 25 (UP) -- The Philippine (Amateur Athletic Federation said today that it would protest the decision that would limit Olympic basketball contestants to sixteen teams and force the Philippine team to play an elimination series before the official tournament.

Popular weight-reducing diets that grossly restrict fat may not only be harmful, but they may even slow the pace of weight reduction. This is one of two new theories on dieting advanced recently by Dr. Julius Pomeranze, an instructor at New York Medical College.

Anthony J. Verruso, a 32-year-old textile cloth cutter, told United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn yesterday that he was forced to steal and cash Government checks because he needed the money to support two wives.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 25 (AP) -- United States and Bermuda yachtsmen shared the honors today as the Bermuda sailors won the clinching race for the Amorita cup while American forces won on the sea and at the protest table to capture the Aberfeldy Cup for Luders Sixteens.
BERLIN, April 25 -- More than 100 refugee journalists from Eastern Europe met here today to discuss common tactics to be used against present regimes in their homelands.
The Manhattan Opera Guild, under the direction of Theodore Katz, last evening offered at Town Hall a concert version of Tchaikovsky's opera, "Pique-Dame" ("The Queen of Spades").

PITTSBURGH, April 25 (AP) -The lack of strategic manganese ore, essential metal in steel production, may be solved by the discovery of large deposits in Maine, the United States Bureau of Mines said today.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Stockholders of Montgomery Ward Co. met today to hear a report that first quarter net earnings will be down 47 per cent and sales 11 per cent from a year ago. Sewell Avery was re-elected chairman with two others to the board of directors for three-year terms.

The bona fide labor movement, employers and Government law-enforcement agencies are reported deeply concerned because of a rash of racketeer-infested unions that have cropped up in recent months in the metropolitan area. Labor racketeering may arise from a variety of causes.
OSLO, Norway, April 25 (AP) -- The Defense Department presented to Parliament today a record budget of 1,290,000,000 kroner ($184,285,000).

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -The Senate Appropriations Committee has recommended $1,786,004,800 for Government labor agencies and the Federal Security Agency for the year beginning July 1. This figure compares with $1,983,410,861 requested by the Administration and $1,783,242,968 voted by the House.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 25 -- About 12,000 miners and other employes in the copper mines of the Chuquicamata and Potrerillos workings of the United States-owned Anaconda Company went on strike for higher pay early today, shortly before the Government settled a near-crippling strike in the nitrates-producing industry.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court today refused to grant bail to Ronald Virgil Johnson of Los Angeles, who is fighting induction into the Army.

MEXICO CITY, April 25 -- All timber exports from the State of Chihuahua and other timber producing areas of northwestern Mexico have been banned for the next two years in preparation for the construction of a cellulose plant for the manufacture of newsprint.

Harry Gross, the Brooklyn bookmaker, has named twelve more policemen as having been on his payroll to protect his multimillion-dollar business, it was disclosed yesterday. That makes thirty members of the Police Department against whom the imprisoned gambler is apparently willing at last to testify in departmental trials.

It was yesterday but it could have been six years ago. The scene and the participants were the same. As to the results -- well, Joseph Komisky, a 31-year-old longshoreman on parole from a five-to-fifteen-year prison term, admitted they would be as doleful.

CHICAGO, April 25 (UP) -- Federal anti-trust agents today filed criminal informations charging two New York concerns and four individuals with conspiracy to corner 1949 egg futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

BONN, Germany, April 25 (Reuters) -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today lost control of the West German upper house -- the Bundesrat -- by the formation of an anti-Adenauer coalition in a new but as yet unnamed southwest state.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., April 25 (AP) -- Two grandchildren of Homer Ramsdell, who died in 1894, have become owners of the Newburgh Beacon Ferry through a settlement of his estate.

Surrogate William T. Collins signed an order yesterday directing the Chase National Bank and Mrs. Anna Kennedy Burke, executors of the estate of Mrs. Hetty Sylvia Ann Howland Green Wilks, to make a partial payment of $57,000,000 to the sixty-three charita

LANSING, Mich., April 25 -- An investigation into the five-day mutiny of 171 hardened convicts at the Southern Michigan Prison at Jackson will begin here tomorrow at a conference between Gov. G. Mennen Williams and Austin MacCormick, executive director of the Osborne Association, national penal reform society.

A panic-stricken man was seriously injured last night when he jumped out of an upper-story window to escape a smoky fire that routed twenty families in a five-story tenement at 344 West 122d Street and caused minor injuries to a woman tenant and two police rescuers.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- A new cross-departmental humanities program for Princeton, calling for additional endowment funds of $5,000,000 and geared to meet the shortcomings of modern liberal education, was announced here tonight by the university president, Dr. Harold W. Dodds.

That handy invention the match is observing its 125th birthday anniversary this year. The basic principle involved in producing fire on a splint is more than twice as old as the match itself, but, as often is the case, the gap between principle and application was -- it seems to us now -- extraordinarily wide.

WATERTOWN, Mass., April 25 -- Maj. Gen. Elbert L. Ford, Army Chief of Ordnance, said today that development of titanium as a substitute for steel by the Watertown Metallurgical Laboratories promised to cut the weight of weapons by about 40 per cent.
CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- The Cubs parlayed extra-base power and Bob Kelly's five-hit pitching to whip Cincinnati, 7 -- 3, and break their second-place tie with the Reds.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 25 -Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, assailed today President Truman's seizure of the steel industry as a move that would wipe out profits and at the same time strike a fatal blow to collective bargaining.

The Fine Textile Manufacturing Company of New York has leased the one-story building at 708-30 Twenty-third Street in Union City, N. J., from the New York Corporation and will occupy it for the manufacture of curtains. The Murrimac Realty Company and the Kurtz Realty Company were the brokers.

A parcel of 150 lots at Oceanside Road and Mott Street in Oceanside, L. I., has been sold by J. Maller and associates to Ocean Hill Homes for improvement with fifty dwellings. Arthur Miles was the broker. The same broker, in conjunction with the Herman Kaplan Company, negotiated the purchase of 150 lots at Park Lane and Connecticut Avenue in Massapequa by Rose Bunzen, builders, who plan to construct fifty houses.

ATLANTA, April 25 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia formally opened his active campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination tonight by telling 3,000 cheering Southerners that "party political leaders everywhere" were beginning to regard his candidacy as one that could lead to victory in next November's general election.

HANOVER, N. H., April 25 -- Alpha Theta chapter of Theta Chi Fraternity at Dartmouth College announced early today that it would eliminate the color line from its membership requirements, even at the risk of losing its national charter.

The Gallant Fox Handicap will be the lure at the Jamaica Race Track today. The $60,000 added event has attracted sixteen starters, and if all go the purse will total $73,500, the largest disbursement of the metropolitan season to date. The winner will draw $51.800.

Eric M. Butler has been appointed vice president and secretary of International Utilities Corporation. Oliver B. Resch has been named treasurer and assistant secretary and William F. Egan has been appointed asistant secretary and assistant treasurer.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 25 (AP) -- The head of the Eastern Milk Producers Cooperative Association indicated today that his organization would seek a hearing on the New York milk pool's action in shutting off payments from the producer settlement fund.

In a novel attempt to help overcome the serious shortage of nurses in municipal institutions, Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced a month ago today that it wasn't too late for women over 40 to begin nursing careers.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, April 25 (UP) -- The Ford Motor Company, Detroit, and the Thompson Wire Company, Boston, have voluntarily settled suits against them for infringement of patents with payments approximately $400,000, it was announced today.

President Truman's seizure of the steel industry was condemned yesterday by the Greater Weekly Associates, an organization of 220 leading weekly newspapers. In addition, the President's comments on seizure of the press were denounced as "irresponsible."

Four art organizations with aggregate memberships of nearly 6,000 opened yesterday a new round in the battle between conservative and "modern" elements in the art world that began in February, when a committee of the National Sculpture Society criticized the Metropolitan Museum of Art for furthering "mediocre left-wing work."

Babies sicken and die of loneliness just as quickly as they sicken and die because of improper feeding, a psychiatrist reported here yesterday morning at the Eastern States Health Education Conference at the New York Academy of Medicine.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 25 -- Benjamin V. Cohen and Jacob A. Malik, the United States and Soviet representatives, today resumed their dispute over the United States proposal for a United Nations arms census.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent over the week ended April 22, to 111.3 per cent of the 1947-49 average, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The index was 3.2 per cent below the level of January, 1951 -the month during which the G. C. P. R. became effective, and 0.9 per cent below the latest available comprehensive index -- March, 1952.
TRENTON, April 25 (AP) -- The appointment of a three-member committee was announced today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to undertake an investigation of New Jersey's prison and parole systems.
" Driftwood," a book of poems by Conne Gates, is the only book published today. Issued by William-Frederick in a paper-backed edition, it sells for 75 cents.

The Greater New York Hospital Association elected Dr. Henry N. Pratt, director of New York Hospital, as its president at a meeting in the Commerce and Industry Building, 233 Broadway. He succeeds Fred Heffinger, superintendent of Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital.
At the price of some confusion, upward of 60,000,000 Americans will begin tomorrow to see more of the sun as Daylight Saving Time goes into effect.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Net income of Butler Brothers declined to $51,395 in the quarter ended March 31 from $519,233, or 37 cents a common share, a year ago, Bert R. Prall, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

BONN, Germany, April 25 -- Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of the Social Democratic party, second largest political organization in West Germany, called today for a four-power meeting as soon as possible to discuss the holding of all-German elections as a first step toward the reunification of this country.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 25 -Most of the major areas of economic activity, subject to the discretion of public officials making expenditures for defense, foreign aid and construction, are influenced by the control of credit, Dr. Robert A. Love, director of the evening and extension division of the City College School of Business, said here today.
A $120,000 treble damage suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court by the producers of "Women of Twilight," charging the United Scenic Artists, Local 829, with violating the anti-trust laws.

A modern "Johnny Appleseed" with horizons far broader than his legendary Ohio River counterpart sailed into New York harbor yesterday for a brief pause in his one-man crusade to help feed the hungry of the world.
CLEVELAND, April 25 -- The Hamburg-Chicago Lines Konsul Sartori became today the first freighter flying a foreign flag to dock at Cleveland this year.

Charles Odell, chief of counseling of the United States Department of Labor, said yesterday that there was a great need for closer cooperation between the armed forces, schools and colleges and employment groups vocational guidance of youths facing military service.

QUEBEC, April 25 (Canadian Press) -- H. J. Symington, chairman of the board, said at the annual meeting of Price Brothers Co., Ltd., today that production cost increases cannot all be met by adding to the consumer price of newsprint.

The railroads sparked a recovery in the stock market yesterday, Trading in the carriers dominated dealings, and several of the important units managed increases well over a point. Soft spots continued to appear in the oils, but the motors, televisions, steels and airlines responded sympathetically to the upturn in the carriers.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that purchase agreements would be available to cotton producers for the first time this year under the upland patent price-support program.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Truman today requested Senator Burnet R. Maybank, Democrat of South Carolina, to seek the removal of an enactment that deprived Federal employes of the right to accumulate up to sixty days of annual leave.

The New York State Central School District, composed of Schaghticoke, Pittstown and Easton in Rensselaer and Washington Counties, sold yesterday $1,005,000 of bonds due from 1953 to 1981 to a banking syndicate headed by Marine Trust Company of Western New York at a bid of 100.55 for interest of 2 1/4 per cent.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 25 -- South Africa's united front against Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist government -- the United and Labor parties and the war veterans organization Torch Commando held an orderly and unmolested demonstration tonight in Capetown's main public plaza.
OTTAWA, April 25 (Canadian Press) -- For the first time since 1946, Canada has been invited to send observers to an American atomic explosion, Paul Martin, Health Minister, disclosed today.

The lack of morality in politics and social relations in the United States provides the Kremlin with a continuous supply of ammunition for its psychological warfare against democracy, Dr. George S. Counts, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, warned last night.

PARIS, April 25 (AP) -- Budge Patty of Los Angeles reached the final round of the French tennis tournament today by defeating Irvin Dorfman of New York, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3. Dorfman obviously was tired from his exertions yesterday when he won two singles matches.

In his annual bulletin J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the F. B. I., reports an increase in crime throughout the United States of 5.1 per cent in 1951. The increase was slightly larger in the urban areas. This analysis shows that on an average day of last year 5,157 major crimes were committed in this country.

THIS is the "long-shot" season for the varmint hunters, for although the short, green grass of the pastures makes "Marmota monax" quite easy to spot, it also provides the wary woodchuck with an opportunity to locate the stalker and reach the sanctuary of his burrow before the intruder arrives within easy range.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24 -- Three small states -- Syria, Thailand and Uruguay -- persuaded a United Nations committee today to hold off action on a series of complaints against the South African Government's administration of its neighboring mandate of South-West Africa.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Charles S. Davis, chairman of Borg-Warner Corporation, at the annual meeting in Chicago today called on the company's 20,000 stockholders to appoint themselves evangelists to point out the dangers in the Administration's "arbitrary, tyrannical" attitude toward free enterprise.
Local rowing followers will turn out today for the only college cup regatta of the season on the Harlem.

BERLIN, April 25 -- Sixty-five Germans who allegedly deserted the French Foreign Legion in Indo-China or were captured by the Vietminh forces, were presented last night at a dramatic ceremony in East Berlin.

CHATEAUROUX AIR BASE, France, April 25 -- Twenty-four hours around the clock a team of 4,000 French contract workers, using the most modern French and German equipment, is hurrying to completion here what will be the biggest United States air base of its kind on the European continent.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Army Medical Service this month not only accepted its first women internes but also called for more women in all categories. Brig. Gen. S. B. Hays, Acting Surgeon General, made this statement today:

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 25 (AP) -- Archie Durham, 19, of Pasadena (Calif.) City College scored a surprising victory in the long horse event to win the first title at the National A. A. U. gymnastic championships.

Bobby Dykes, 153 1/2 pounds, Miami, outpointed Ted Murray, 147, Long Island City, in the ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The crowd of 1,649, which paid $3,876, saw the Florida fighter give a smooth performance as he gained a unanimous decision.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 -The West Coast, once a hotbed of anti-Oriental feeling, greeted with little opposition today the news that the House had voted to make all Asians eligible for naturalization.

In a broadcast to the German people Chancellor Adenauer has again declared his determination to proceed with Germany's integration with the West, and agreed with the Western Powers in holding that a new Big Four conference on German unification would be advisable only if the Soviets should meet the Western conditions. In this statement, however, he touched on one point which has received little attention thus far.

Action was deferred yesterday on a dividend on the capital stock of Follansbee Steel Corporation because of the "uncertainty of the general economic situation in the steel industry." The company has been paying 50 cents at quarterly intervals.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Yogi Berra's influence on the fortunes of the Yankees is expected to be indicated tomorrow night if the elements permit. For the squat backstop from St. Louis' Hill District today notified Manager Casey Stengel he was prepared to undertake his first championship game of the season.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 25 (AP) -- Frank Strafaci of Flushing, L. I., won his fourth successive 1-up match today, a 36-hole squeaker from Harry Haverstick Jr. of Lancaster, Pa., and joined Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, in the final of the North and South amateur golf tournament.

Michael Tippett is supposed to be one of the more promising of the younger British composers, but in America his reputation is only by word of mouth. Last night's performance by the Columbia University Chorus under Jacob Avshalomoff of "A Child of Our Time" presented a chance to hear a large-scale Tippett work and draw some first-hand conclusions.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 25 -- Rioting, allegedly directed by the Communists, caused millions of dollars of damage yesterday in the city of Uberaba. It was reported halted tonight with troops on guard.

CHICAGO, April 25 (UP) -- A 701-page deposition from Irenee du Pont denying anti-trust charges made by the Federal Government in its civil suit against E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and others was filed in Federal court today.

Both West Europe and exile leaders are today more impressed by the statesmanship of the American founding fathers than Europe ever was in the past. With American assistance West European nations seem to be making a determined effort to create a spirit of genuine fellowship and to tackle in common their economic, political and defense issues.

Reflecting the rise in gross operating income of the Sinclair Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries for the first three months this year, net income increased to $20,969,671 after taxes and all charges from $18,396,905 a year ago.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., April 25 (UP) -- Barbara Romack, 19-year-old Sacramento, Calif., star won the California State Women's Amateur Golf championship today as she overwhelmed Mrs. Ruth McCullah, Los Angeles, 5 and 3.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, announced yesterday that the Democratic State Committee would meet on Thursday in the Biltmore Hotel to elect delegates and alternates-at-large to the Democratic National Convention.

LONDON, April 25 -- The Economist, Britain's most influential weekly, joined the considerable body of opinion in this country favoring Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther over Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway as General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's successor.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 -- One of the most controversial issues facing the Methodist Church, a projected reorganization and "streamlining" of the basic structure of the denomination, was debated for more than three hours today by delegates attending the church's quadrennial general conference. The debate will be continued tomorrow.

Close on the heels of the news that the secret talks on prisoner exchange in Korea had apparently broken down completely came the word that a full-dress negotiating session had been asked by the United Nations and agreed to by the Communists. There have been seventeen sessions of the prisoner sub-group.
NEWARK, April 25 (AP) -- Edward James Smythe, one of the defendants in a wartime mass sedition trial, received a one-year suspended sentence today for using the mails to defraud.

BALBOA, C. Z., April 25 -- A general shake-up of high officials of the Panama Canal was confirmed here today after the appointment of Gen. John S. Seybold as Governor of the Canal Zone to succeed Brig. Gen. Francis K. Newcomer, who has retired from the Army.

LONDON, April 25 -- With a special grant of 336,000 ($940,800) from the Nuffield Foundation and the Government a team of astrophysicists at Manchester University is building a radio telescope 265 feet in diameter for the new science of radio or "blind" astronomy in which Britain claims world pre-eminence.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- A House investigating subcommittee reported today that restrictive trade practices in the automotive industry had unnecessarily cost the Government "untold millions of dollars" for military procurement.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -- Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, told a group of Connecticut copper workers today that "Communist leadership" of their national union had "befogged" their unemployment problems by attacks on the United Nations and the war in Korea.

NEW DELHI, India, April 25 -- Leaders of the Communist group in the new Parliament have invited other non-Congress party members to meet here May 13 on the Communists' proposal to form a "united" democratic group that would seek official recognition as the chief opposition party.

The Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, by a vote of 10 to 9 in a total membership of a thirty, has recommended to the Board of Estimate a long-range water supply policy that would include the making of a study and analysis of the Hudson River as a future source of drinking water.
DETROIT, April 25 (AP) -- A 1951 net loss of $12,300,000 was reported today by Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

A plan for examining maintenance jobs before they are performed has brought about improvements in effectiveness of more than 50 per cent, it was reported yesterday by Hugh A. Bogle, supervisor of management engineering of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Wilmington, Del.

The Metropolitan Golf Association's schedule of twenty - two tournaments for 1952 was made public yesterday. Several of the championships previously had been designated, including the district amateur event which will be played at the Ridgewood Country Club, Ridgewood, N. J., July 23-27.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Representative Clare Hoffman suggested today that an "advisory censor" be supplied to President Truman to check what he said before he said it.

Although there are many facts available on the variables that affect people's buying habits, some manufacturers have given only "lip service" to careful planning of sales and advertising. This was charged yesterday by Allen B. Sikes, field director of the Bureau

PITTSBURGH, April 25 (UP) -A 24-year-old farmer who beat off a hunger-crazed tiger who was attacking another man was one of sixteen persons cited today by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission for extraordinary bravery in saving human life.

NORWALK, Ohio, April 25 -Senator Estes Kefauver, who caught up with his Ohio primary campaign caravan today after an overnight delay in Richmond, Va., caused by unfavorable flying weather, assailed the Republican Party in a speech here tonight

ALBANY, April 25 -- The Board of Regents today approved two bond issues totaling $2,600,000 for the construction of five elementary schools in the town of Oyster Bay, L. I. Approval was required because the issues will bring indebtedness of the two districts above 10 per cent of the valuation of their real property.

QUITO, Ecuador, April 25 (UP) -- Leaders of the three principal Opposition parties refused today to cooperate with President Galo Plaza Lasso in organizing a coalition Cabinet in preparation for the Presidential election, June 1.

ROME, April 25 -- A Jesuit priest, Alighiero Tondi, vice-director of the Institute of Higher Religious Culture attached to the Pontifical Gregorian University in Rome, announced today his conversion to communism.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 26 -- A fiery powder blast in a gun turret on the United States heavy cruiser St. Paul killed all thirty seamen inside the turret as the warship stood off the Korean east coast Monday pounding Red targets, the Navy announced today. It was called the worst naval disaster in twenty-two months of Korean warfare.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (AP) -- A black market in potatoes that may be costing consumers as much as much as $150,000 a week has been uncovered here, the head of the area Office of Price Stabilization said today.

The taxpayer at 513 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Samuel Rivkin to an investing client of Robert Netter, attorney. The property is assessed at $50,000 and was sold subject to mortgages of $33,000. Hyman Leff and Max Kleiman were the brokers.
Nineteen-year-old Gerald Lippman of 335 Remsen Avenue, Brooklyn, had no difficulty yesterday morning in cashing a check for $1,117, but this is a fact to give comfort only to two hoodlums.

The attitude of Communists toward war with the Soviet Union was explored briefly yesterday during the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders who are charged with conspiring to advocate and teach the overthrow of the Government of the United States by force and violence.

Two new Universal-International films will be shown as a double-feature program on Wednesday at Loew's Metropolitan Theatre in Brooklyn, prior to general release. Shortly thereafter they will be seen in sixty-two film houses in the metropolitan area, the company has announced.

CLEVELAND, April 25 (AP) -Harry Simpson drove in two runs that tied the game and then scored the winning run on Luke Easter's fly in the ninth inning as the Indians beat the White Sox, 5 -- 4, today before 4,677 shivering spectators.

Federal troops will join civilian marchers on Fifth Avenue today in the fifth annual Loyalty Day parade that has been heralded as the biggest anti-Communist demonstration in American history by its sponsors, the Veterans of Foreign Wars, New York County Council.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., April 25 (AP) -- Mrs. De Leslie Allen of Buffalo was elected president today of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, succeeding Mrs. James M. Skinner of Philadelphia. Mrs. Horace E. Wilson of Amarillo, Tex., was elected secretary.

This week-end the Premier of Turkey, accompanied by the Foreign Minister and the head of the army, is paying a state visit to Greece. Comment in Athens and Ankara stresses that this is not a mere courtesy visit or even a gesture to symbolize the close relations that have developed in recent years between the two countries guarding the eastern gate of the Mediterranean.
LONDON, April 25 -- Prime Minister Churchill predicted today that in three or four years "world peace will be more secure and British solvency firmly established."
Mark S. Walters has been appointed manager of the coffee department in New Orleans for W. R. Grace Co., industrial and trading company.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Two recently retired high-ranking Air Force generals told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee today that the Air Force should have overriding priority in allotment of defense funds. They testified that spending for "balanced" forces among the three armed services was unwise until the nation's atomic striking force and its air defense of continental United States were up to strength.

MILWAUKEE, April 25 (UP) -George Obenauer of Buffalo, N. Y., was elected president of the American Bowling Congress and Frank Baker, Milwaukee, was retained as secretary-treasurer at the annual convention today.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Truman today formally requested Congress to revoke the "false economy" of the House in slashing flood control funds April 2 from a proposed $660,000,000 to $472,000,000.
Strikes by the three railway operating unions resulted in a net loss of $2,548,169 in March for the New York Central System, in contrast to a profit of $1,407,359 in March, 1951.
LONDON, April 25 -- Industrial prices closed with another fairly long list of rises on the stock markets here today despite small reaction in late dealings.
A tendency to broaden the powers of the Federal Government was shown yesterday by student legislators participating in Hunter College's eighth Model Congress.
DES MOINES, April 25 (AP) -The University of Kansas' four-mile relay team today dominated the opening of the Drake Relays by establishing an American college record.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Wheat prices showed further recovery today from yesterday's low spots, indicating lighter liquidating pressure, while there was evidence of a broader general demand. Other grains also showed an absence of heavy pressure, while shorts appeared willing to take profits on the setbacks.

A 30-year-old New Jersey doctor, whose patients and neighbors contend they need his services and don't want him inducted into the Army, finished a three-day medical examination yesterday at Governors Island.
Two group shows by avant garde Americans, an exhibition by a contemporary French painter, and one by a blithe abstractionist are among the rewarding art gallery events this week.

WICHITA, Kan., April 25 (AP) -- Files of the National Cooperative Refinery Association were ordered into Federal Court today in a receivers' recovery suit against W. H. Black, former president of Black-Marshall Oil Company. Federal District Judge Delmas C. Hill directed counsel for the cooperative at McPherson, Kan., to produce pertinent correspondence.

ROME, Ga., April 25 (AP) -- Superior Court Judge H. E. Nichols prepared a contempt of court citation today against the editor and managing editor of The Atlanta Constitution for their refusal to publish a photograph of a record of a traffic case in Floyd County.

Prayer for Russia Day, dedicated to special religious services for the conversion of Russia to Christianity and dedicated also to world peace, was held yesterday at Manhattan College. More than 2,000 students in De LaSalle Chapel heard the Rev. Leopold L. S. Braun, who was pastor of the last Catholic church in Moscow before he fled the Soviet Union in 1945, say that "70 per cent of the Russian people still believe in God."

Events today: Centenary Singers and Lafayette College Choir, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Snjolaug Sigurdson, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 3; Dorothy White, pianist-singer, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 3; Maria Munster, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; "Madame Butterfly," City Center, 8:15; Yiddish Culture Chorus, Town Hall, 8:30; Ruth Miller, soprano, and Victor Feliccia, baritone, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:30.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 25 -Deputy Attorney General Simon L. Fisch of Newark was assigned today to head the state's investigation into "official corruption" in Atlantic County. He succeeds Samuel L. Allcorn of Montclair, who resigned recently because of ill health.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today the next ten days should bring considerable relief from the potato shortage that has been particularly noticeable in the Midwest.

Trading in cottonseed oil totaled 38,130 tons -- 1,271 lots -- and 83,250 bags of coffee were transferred yesterday in one of the strongest markets of recent date. Only rubber showed a definite down trend.

The 100th anniversary of the arrival of the Passionist Fathers in North America will be celebrated today, tomorrow and Monday at the Passionist Monastery of the Immaculate Conception at 86-45 Edgerton Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens.

Those who have included the refurbishing of lampshades on their spring-cleaning agendas may find advice on laundering such items helpful. Tips on washing lampshades constructed of a variety of materials are included in a report received from the Association of American Soap and Glycerine Producers, Inc.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade state, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers:

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday, with closing prices 7 points lower to 9 points higher. New crop months showed relatively more strength than old crop months.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -Senators were told today that three Nebraska and Wyoming irrigation districts wanted to sell their power interests because of increased production costs, diminishing net revenue and the Government's low-cost public power program.

New York's two National League clubs were hurt more at the gate than they were in the standing when the Dodgers' first visit to the Polo Grounds since last fall was put off until today because of yesterday's rain.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -- The Army issued a call today for 10,000 draftees in June and 31,000 in July. It said that Selective Service quotas would be about as large as the July call for the rest of the summer.

Deficits incurred by New York City's rapid transit system and motor traffic congestion here are part of a single problem in urban transportation that can be solved only by consolidating all of the city's transportation facilities -- subways, bus lines and bridges -- under a single operating authority. William A. Reid, former chairman of the Board of Transportation, declared here yesterday.

Studies of athletes, musicians, scientists, dancers, artists and similar specialtists indicate that, in an overwhelming majority of instances, the individuals investigated had settled on their major interests before they were 14 years old. Many had done so before they were 10 and some, before they were 6.

General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente reserved decision yesterday on motions to dismiss first degree murder indictments against Al Keshner, 42-year-old garment manufacturer, and Jacob Mayron, 59, a truckman.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The United States agreed today to resume military aid to Iran after a lapse of almost four months.
