WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Senate Agricultural Committee tried unsuccessfully today to unravel conflicting testimony on an alleged attempt by two Government officials, now deceased, and a grain broker to "shake down" V. M. Harris, a Kansas elevator man, for a share of his profits on a grain storage deal.
CEDAR GROVE, N. J., April 25 (AP) -- Umpire Douglas (Scotty) Robb, fined and disciplined this week by the National League president, Warren Giles, denied at his home tonight he planned to resign.

The Western Electric Company and the Communications Workers of America, C. I. O., reached an agreement yesterday covering 6,000 distribution employes and ending the last of a series of strikes that had beset the country's telephone system.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., transacted total net sales of $298,522,252 in the fiscal year ended with January -- an increase of $7,445,365, or 2.6 per cent over the previous year's volume -- but earnings were sharply lower, Bernard F. Gimbel, president, revealed in the annual report issued to stockholders yesterday.

The Sanitation Department has a budget for 1952-53 of $58,448,767, of which nearly $46,000,000 is for personal service, or manpower. The department is one of the most surveyed and most criticized of all city agencies. Every citizen automatically appoints himself an expert on traffic and on garbage-collection and street-cleaning problems.
TOKYO, Saturday, April 26 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,231, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. (4 P. M., Friday, Eastern standard time):

Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires defeated Samuel Reshevsky of New York for the first time in their eighteen-game chess series when play was resumed yesterday, according to a report received from Mexico City. The game began Thursday night.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -The Defense Department said today only a limited number of Navy personnel would serve the full nine-month extension of duty recently ordered by President Truman for all service enlistments.

A publication that Soviet Russia hastily withdrew from circulation outside its own borders shortly after it was issued in 1939 has provided basic information useful to our State Department and encyclopedia editors.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- By a standing vote of 206 to 68, the House of Representatives passed today a bill to overhaul and codify immigration and deportation laws and to abolish racial barriers to citizenship. The measure would make all Asians eligible for naturalization.

Bareheaded and thinly clad, a 63-year-old man crouched shivering early yesterday morning in the shelter of a Brooklyn doorway. A cold rain had begun to fall at 7 A. M. and the man whimpered and muttered incoherently. A passerby, his sympathies aroused by the old man's plight, tried to question him, but the answers were unintelligible.

The driver of a northbound Lexington Avenue bus that had no passengers, two pedestrians and a woman in a drug store were injured at 8:30 o'clock last night when the machine skidded on the rain-drenched street and glanced off the store at 103d Street and Lexington Avenue.

PUCCINI'S life was grand opera. The composer of "Boheme," "Tosca," "Madama Butterfly'' and the singularly un-Wisterian "Girl of the Golden West" loved, feasted and despaired with flamboyant dash and relish. He lived in sin and gave melody to piety. It took excruciating labor for him to complete one of his masterpieces -- but he generally managed to have a fine time no matter what was afoot in Europe or America.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -President Truman said today that one of the most important factors making America great "has been the freedom with which Americans have been able to get the facts and express them."

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- In weather that possibly was the worst in the 58-year history of the nation's senior baton-passing carnival, Michigan's world record-breaking distance medley quartet today slogged through mud, rain and cold to capture the first major title of the Pennsylvania Relays.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, April 25 (AP) -- The belief arose today that the Mississippi River flood had done about all the damage it was going to do. Tonight the crest had passed Dubuque, where a 22.7-foot reading was taken this morning.

Representatives of 10,000 taverns and 2,600 liquor package stores met yesterday to oppose a proposed 25 per cent license fee increase which, they said, "would force at least some of our members into bankruptcy." The meeting was held in the offices of the United Restaurant and Liquor Dealers of Manhattan to map strategy for their presentation to the Finance Committee of the City Council, which will hold a hearing on Monday.

A Yorkville property that had been held by the seller for many years passed to new control with the purchase by Martin Fried of the four-story house for six families at 1633 Second Avenue, southwest corner of Eighty-fifth Street, from Rebecca Guberman.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 25 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio said tonight that he believed in states' rights and appealed to the Democrats of the South to get on his Republican bandwagon.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., April 25 -- Mrs. Anthony Dreyspool of Rye Wood won low-gross honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association opening Class B one-day tournament over the Innis Arden course today.

The educational program of the Fragrance Foundation, Inc., is directed toward the untapped market of 28,000,000 women who do not use fragrance products but do use lipstick, Mrs. Miriam Gibson French, executive director of the group, said this week at the third annual meeting here.
LONDON, April 25 -- The men of Parliament today backed -with misgivings -- a bill to give more money and rights to wives at the expense of their husbands.

BOSTON, April 24 (AP) -- Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., has reported net income after provision for Federal taxes for the three months ended March 31 was $1,953,771, equal to 87 cents a common share. In the similar period a year ago net income was $3,515,155, or $2.34 a share. Net sales for the recent three months were reported totaling $55,967,461.
The Waterman Steamship Corporation has developed the use of dictation equipment for on-the-spot interviews when an accident occurs on the corporation's property.

SAIGON, Indo-China, April 25 -- The Vietminh command is believed in French military quarters to be having difficulty obtaining suitable recruits to maintain the strength of its main five-division striking force in Tongking. One reason for the tenacious way the Communist-led Vietminh Army is trying to maintain its positions in the Tongking Delta is believed to be its need for fighting men.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 25 (AP) -The Minneapoli Lakers closed out the long pro season tonight by taking the National Basketball Association crown, beating the New York Knickerbockers, 82 to 65. A $7,500 player jackpot went with the victory in the seventh game of the play-off series It was the Lakers' fourth N. B. A. title in five years.
HARTFORD, Conn., April 25 -John M. Bailey of Hartford, Democratic State Chairman, suggested today that the Democratic state platform should contain a plank pledging court reform.

Smiling Bear, a full-blooded Hopi Indian chief, did a war dance on the welcome mat of his Brooklyn home yesterday in protest against the continued presence of his brother-in-law, Young Blood, Young Blood's wife, Little Feather, and their 3-year-old daughter, Blue Corn.
PITTSBURGH, April 25 (AP) -Gerry Staley, 28-year-old curveball artist, pitched the Cardinals to a 6 -- 4 triumph over the Pirates today to become the first three-game winner in the National League.

DUBLIN, April 25 (AP) -- The first invasion of Europe by an American amateur boxing team got off to a bad start tonight when the Chicago Golden Gloves squad dropped a 6-4 decision to an Irish championship unit.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 25 -- The Yugoslav Foreign Ministry let it be known tonight that it regarded as inadequate the $100,000,000 economic assistance program for the fiscal year of 1952-53 that was reported here to have been agreed upon in Washington last week by representatives of the United States, British and French Governments.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 25 -- The United Nations was informed officially today that the latest attempt to settle the long Indian-Pakistani dispute over Kashmir had ended without solving the basic problem of how the princely state was to be turned from an armed camp to a demilitarized country ready for a peaceful plebiscite.

Walter C. Heck, who formerly held the box office concession at Carnegie Hall, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on a charge of having defrauded the Government of $147,502 in admission taxes.

Elizabeth Kelly has purchased the dwelling at 429 Forty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, from Paul J. Connolly, Flood Brothers were the brokers in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.
CHICAGO, April 25 (UP) -- An executive of the United States Steel Corporation said today that the steel industry would submit to the Government a plan for "complete abandonment" of controls.

A new shoe business that specializes in matching shoes to the costume opened recently under the title of Simone "Shoes-to-Match," 39 West Thirty-second Street. This service was evolved by Henriette Simone, after nineteen years of shoe-designing and an accumulation of requests and inquiries from friends.

MUNSAN, Korea, April 25 -The fact that an unexpectedly large number of prisoners held by the Allies were determined not to return to Communist territory upset what was close to a quick solution of the prisoner-of-war problem at the Korean armistice negotiations.

BOSTON, April 25 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts, national campaign manager for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, asserted today that he would not accept any appointive or Cabinet post in the event the general were elected President.

In witness to the "revolutionary" aspect of modern art in Europe, however, the statement quoted from an editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 11, 1944, which read, in part: "Revolutionary art will often go hand-in-hand with social and political revolution as long as the revolution is in opposition or still engaged in consolidating its victory.

Dr. C. J. Blanford, milk marketing administrator in this area, announced yesterday that he had suspended payments from the New York milk pool's settlement fund to three dairy cooperative associations supplying milk to this city. They received $69,533 last year.

SANTIAGO, April 25 (AP) -- The nitrate workers, their strike settled at a meeting of President Gonzales Videla, representatives of the Anglo - Lautaro Nitrate Company and union agents, planned to return to their jobs Monday.

CARTERET, N. J., April 25 -Four steel pellets containing radium valued at $200,000 were returned today to the Foster-Wheeler Corporation, manufacturers of marine equipment, by three young boys who believed they were fishing sinkers.
Another in the long series of proposed mergers to bring the airline pattern into conformity with the new high-capacity and high-speed aircraft was made public yesterday.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 26--United Nations and Communist negotiators agreed today to a new full-dress meeting of the delegations discussing an armistice in the Korea war. The move followed the breakdown yesterday of secret sessions of staff officers to arrange an exchange of prisoners following a cease-fire.

Admiral William M. Fechteler, Chief of Naval Operations, said here yesterday that he was "deeply and seriously concerned" about the fact that the appropriations bill as passed by the House of Representatives had eliminated provision for building a second aircraft carrier of 60,000 tons displacement similar to the Forrestal, now under construction.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- A leader of the candy industry warned the "sales-minded" members of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors yesterday that "in these days of stiff competition for space on the retailers counters and with so much self-service, the package must serve as a perpetual salesman at the point of purchase."

ODESSA, Tex., April 25 -- A young Texas woman lay near death here today while her father and brother stood at her hospital room door to prevent anyone from giving her a blood transfusion, which doctors say she needs.

The operating results of Bethlehem Steel Corporation, first of the major steel producing companies in the United States to report for the first quarter of this year, indicates the sharp inroads made by generally higher operating costs. Net sales for the three months to March 31, 1952, increased to $466,371,498, against $426,402,695 in the same period a year ago.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, April 25 (AP) -- The Ruhr added up its losses from the dismantling of war industry today and listed them as 2,426,000,000 Deutsche marks ($577,388,000).

LONDON, April 25 -- Lord Mancroft, a Conservative member of the House of Lords, apologized to the House of Commons today for a "flippant aside" reflecting on the dignity of the House and especially of its women members.

A dispatch to this newspaper from Cambodia indicates some of the problems and difficulties involved in preserving the great cultural heritage at Angkor. The present archaeologist-curator is 76 years old, and after half a lifetime at Angkor would like to retire to France.

The purchase of two city blocks in Flushing, Queens, by the Salvation Army for eventual improvement with a new Booth Memorial Home and Hospital was announced yesterday by Commissioner Donald McMillan, eastern territorial commander of the organization.

Lumber wholesalers in the six New England states, New York and Pennsylvania are dissatisfied with dollars-and-cents mill ceilings on Northeastern white pine set by the Office of Price Stabilization yesterday. Both yard and office wholesalers agree that top legal prices are too high.
LOS ANGELES, April 25 -- The first clash between court and counsel in the three-month Communist trial here marked Federal Court proceedings today and led to one of two unsuccessful mistrial motions.
May I quote from an editorial in your newspaper on April 22: "If you are eligible to vote you should make every effort to do so, for to vote is both an obligation and a privilege of citizenship."
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- On this very rainy day Mrs. Truman whose just-restored home is the daily mecca of sight-seers, motored twenty miles to see a newly restored pre-Revolutionary mansion.
Three of the men involved in a conspiracy to fix Manhattan College basketball games in the 1949-50 and 1950-51 seasons were sentenced to penitentiary terms in Bronx County Court yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (AP) -- Benjamin Franklin was actually "scooped" on the first demonstration of the idea that lightning was electrical -- but American history books do not show it, a Harvard scientific historian said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 25 -- Plans for the formation in the film colony of a coalition political group to work against the Congressional aspirations of Representative Donald Jackson, incumbent Republican, and Jack Tenney, Republican State Senator, who is making a bid for Congress, will be set in motion at a meeting to be held here Sunday night.

Broadcast engineers refused yesterday to cross the picket lines of striking cafeteria workers at Columbia University, forcing the relocation of tomorrow's Contemporary American Music Festival concert to a downtown studio.
The following is a round-up of new items that may be of use about the house.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway formally thanked the Japanese people tonight for the "good faith and diligence" with which they had cooperated with the United States occupation forces.

FRANKFURT, Germany, April 25 (Reuters) -- A Russian witness at the Katyn massacre investigation today said the Polish officer victims were brought under Russian secret police escort by train to a near-by station and marched off into the forest where their bodies were found in April, 1943.

The general welfare committee of the City Council reserved decision yesterday, after a brief and sparsely attended public hearing, on a bill to increase taxicab fares for the first time since the present rates were enacted in 1933.
HARRISBURG, Pa., April 25 (AP) -- Gov. John S. Fine said today the Republican Presidential race had narrowed down to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

The removal of price controls on shoes and leather products, as was recently ordered on cattlehides, kips and calfskins, would result in a downward adjustment of retail prices and speed savings to consumers, the Tanners Council of America asserted yesterday.
ROME, April 25 -- Sixteen parties, divided into six groups, have presented slates of candidates for the municipal elections that will be held in Rome on May 25.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- This has been national fishpole week at the United States Patent Office. Perhaps the outstanding item among many aids for the fisherman is a casting rod that gives him a mechanical arm. The invention, covered by Patent No. 2,593,885 issued to Harry A. James of Joplin, Mo., comprises a rod in two parts joined by a pivot.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Department of Justice rested its case in court today for seizure of the steel mills with the argument that although the Constitution limited Congress and the judiciary, it did not limit the power of the Executive Branch to meet all emergencies.

Members of the New York Com-I mittee of the Frontier NursingI Service will give a rummage cock-I tail party on Thursday afternoon/ in the home of Mr. and Mrs. R.I McAllister Lloyd, 215 East Sev-l enty-second Street. The event will} benefit the publi health work con-I I ducted by the organization in the Kentucky mountains.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 26 -- Residents of this 104-year-old city today filed, in somewhat overawed fashion, through an Elizbethan drawing room to view centuries-old furnishings, paintings and art objects.

WHAT'S wrong with higher education in America? The answer of this book by Baker Brownell, Professor of Philosophy at Northwestern, is that the colleges have turned their backs on the normal human community.

IN the Magazine Section of this paper today are pictures of Lever House, New York's most recently completed office building. In this reviewer's opinion, this building, which carries to a new point of refinement the Le Corbusier-Mies van der Rohe style of steel skeleton with glass curtain-wall, is the most handsome and best example of modern architecture in New York.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Although use of a new operating band by radio amateurs may interfere with television reception, the Federal Communications Commission said it had received no protests.

IT s easy to laugh at Johnnie Ray, the newest wonder among popular singers, just as it is a comforting self-indulgence to feel thoroughly superior to the vast audience which, in a matter of months, has lifted him from obscurity to dominance in the night clubs and on records.

Time and the ruthless demands of the modern age have caught up with the heavily traveled Manhattan Bridge, first opened to the public in 1909, so that now the span needs a full-scale investigation of its structural condition, Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen said yesterday.

IN one of the most ardent endorsements ever put to paper, Charles Algernon Swinburne once wrote: "For absolute power of composition, for faultless balance and blameless rectitude of design, there is, unquestionably, no creation of Shakespeare's hand that will bear comparison with 'Much Ado About Nothing.'"
If it stops raining for a couple of hours, the Giants and Dodgers will attempt to get in a ball game today at 2:30 P. M. at the Polo Grounds. They were thwarted again yesterday by the weather.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 -- By an overwhelming margin, shipwrights and machinists in West Coast shipyards have voted to free themselves from a master agreement binding shipbuilding plants and workers since the employment peak days of World War II.

THE plot of this novel by a former wireless operator is essentially a simple one. In 1961, a great transatlantic liner survives a cataclysmic storm to discover that all of civilization has been engulfed in a general land subsidence.

SINCE the current star at the Palace is generally acceptable, the rest of the bill can be appreciated, too. The current star is the blonde and bustling Betty Hutton, who takes the audience into her confidence, throws her hands and feet around the stage at random and, using the word literally, sweats out a number of songs at the top of her voice, considerably augmented by the microphone.

CRITICS of literature have the same essential function as teachers of literature: this is not to direct the judgment of the audience, but to assist that audience in those disciplines of reading on which any meaningful judgment must rest.

ONLY a few of our Presidents have given us the benefit of publishing their recollections after completing their terms of office. The latest addition to the ranks of Theodore Roosevelt and Calvin Coolidge is Herbert Hoover, who here presents the second volume of his memoirs.

Crewmen of the Portuguese freighter Monte Brasil took to lifeboats in a dense fog and heavy seas last night after the vessel and an American cargo ship, the Cape Martin, collided off the Jersey coast. The Portuguese ship was down at the bow, according to Coast Guard and radio reports.

TOKYO. THE Imperial Hotel bloomed with Japanese national flags -- a red sun on a white ground and known in Pacific wartime days as "old red meatball." Red and white bunting trickled down the lava stone facade of that lowslung building opposite the Imperial Palace in downtown Tokyo, while upstairs in the redecorated "Peacock Room," Japanese celebrated the return of the Imperial to its former owners.

LONDON, April 26 -- A compromise between the British Government's views and the attitude of the white settlers in Nyasaland and Northern and Southern Rhodesia on the rights and representation of Negroes has been the most important achievement thus far in the conference to draft a federation plan for these three Central African territories.

In almost every field of endeavor there is a man who is known as a "worrier," the kind of a fellow who "takes life too seriously" in the opinion of his coworkers. Such a man is Bernard Waldman, president of the Modern Merchandising Bureau, Inc.

TECHNICIANS of the North West German Radio network, planning to establish regular television transmission schedules this fall, have issued assurances intended to quiet worried parents, school teachers and church leaders who have been reading disquieting reports about the effects of television in the United States.

JUST as some wise and cautious people make it a practice to visit their doctors from time to time for those check-ups which happily assure them that they are continuing in admirable health, it is wise to put the movies on the table now and again and give them a going-over to determine what condition they are in.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, said today he had received letters telling "of money paid under the Government-controlled table for favors" involving the Office of Alien Property.

The fourth annual John H. Finley lecture series on "The Newspaper and Society" will be held at City College on May 13 and 14, it was announced today by Prof. Edgar Johnson, chairman of the Department of English.
TOKYO, Sunday, April 27 -- A session of the full delegations negotiating for an armistice in the Korean war was canceled this morning shortly before it was scheduled to begin.

Mrs. Leopold Stokowski, the former Gloria Vanderbilt who was in 1934 the central figure in a celebrated court contest in which her mother and her aunt, Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney, fought for her custody, is following in her aunt's footsteps as a patron of the arts.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- A Senate Labor subcommittee accused the Southern textile industry today of a "widespread conspiracy" to destroy unions and charged that employers have used the Taft-Hartley Act for "union busting."

The value of Connecticut's exports of finished products and semi-manufactures in 1951 totaled $274,200,000, an increase of 53.8 per cent over the $178,200,000 estimated for the preceding year, the State Development Commission reports.

FOUR years ago, on our summer place in the country, some leaves were accidentally kicked aside to reveal a small, flourishing patch of arbutus. As we cleared the brush from our six acres, we gave special attention to the arbutus bed.

THE great and fascinating background of this novel is the Communist coup d'etat in Czechoslovakia and the struggle between American and Communist intelligence services. As a Czech diplomat who quit the service of the Communist regime in 1949. Egon Hostovsky undoubtedly knows his subject.

FORTUNATELY or not, most novels about India must inevitably be stacked against the mighty forces of "Kim" and "A Passage to India" or both. Most often, as in the case of this second novel by the author of "Nightrunners of Bengal," the challengers receive a swift comeuppance.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- Accelerated defense spending in the Midwest has served to offset part of the lag in consumer goods production in the area, with the exception of those Seventh District cities in which automobile manufacture or parts production has predominated.

NEWARK, April 26 -- The Graphic Arts Emergency Council of Essex County, labor-management group of more than fifty employing printers and representatives of the Allied Printing Trades Unions, called today for a state-wide labor-management conference.

At the Technion, Israel's Institute of Technology in Haifa, it has been discovered that the Hot Springs of Tiberias, a spa, are radioactive. The springs contain a relatively high concentration of the radioactive gas radon. Speculation now centers on the possibility that there may be uranium or other radioactive ores in the Tiberias area.

The first step in planning a shrub border is to determine the outline of the bed on the ground. If the planting is to be at a distance, bordered by an expanse of lawn, a series of long smooth curves as shown in plan will be pleasanter than short curves or straight lines.

SUMMER came to Maui in Hawaii, as to all school children everywhere, with a wealth of play and promise. When the Dorn family appeared from the United States mainland on their schooner, Maui learned to sail the little dinghy, and, in turn, taught Bo and Ellen to swim.

BONN, April 26 -- Like the poor, the Saar is always with us. Since 1949, when the Federal Republic of Germany was established, it has been with us so continuously, it has created so many headlines, it has given so many politicians a chance to wave the flag that there is a danger that the importance of the Saar issue both to Europe and to France and Germany will be overlooked.

The new 9,315-gross-ton Japanese freighter Panama Maru of the Osaka Shosen Kaisha Ltd. is en route to the United States on her maiden voyage, according to word received here by the American Hawaiian Steamship Company, general agents.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The tumult has gone from the Administration's drive to purge the Government of evil men and their evil deeds, but the shouting has not died away. There will be plenty of talk about the corruption issue at least until the November elections.

AS the chorus of modern despair grows louder, more writers look to the past for the definition of hope. Ethel Simon turns to fourteenth - century Britain for her narrative of invincible faith. In this somber, primitive world, shaken by such terrors as the Black Death, witchcraft, leprosy, famine, divine wrath and the devil's curse, she sets out to trace the frailty and the endurance of man's dreams.

Picturesque and historic gardens in Westchester County will be opened to the public on May 27 for the spring garden tour in aid of the New York Botanical Garden. The tour includes transportation by bus, luncheon at the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club and tea late in the afternoon at Penwood, the country place of Mr. and Mrs. Carll Tucker in Mount Kisco.

Kenneth Tynan's supercilious article, "Why London Likes Our Musicals" (April 13), simply enrages me. This glorification of the American musical is rapidly degenerating into a cult which threatens to stifle that which if professes to praise.

ATLANTA, April 26 -- Despite restrictions on many building materials the amount of new construction awards in the Southeast took a decided upturn last month. Contracts valued at a total of $183,174,000 were let in the district in March. That figure was 35 per cent higher than the February total and 11 per cent greater than the dollar value of contracts let in March, 1951.

BOSTON, April 26 (AP) -- After Manager Eddie Sawyer shook up his batting order, the Phillies pounded out ten hits during a heavy drizzle today before 1,893 fans, to give Robin Roberts an 8-0 shut-out over the Braves.

THE spring crop of popular-priced picture books is as colorful as ever and, on the whole, more interesting in content than most of the recent titles in this field. Kathryn Jackson's "Wheels" is a brief, rhymed enumeration of things on wheels, from roller skates to a grocery cart, from a hook and ladder truck to a merry-go-round, with spirited illustrations by Leonard Weisgard.

LAST winter I acquired an apartment with a so-called terrace. At least, it was advertised as such. Actually the "terrace" consisted of nothing wore than the roof on one room of the apartment below. It was covered with bulging and cracked linoleum, had an iron fence on one side to separate it from the apartment next door, and a southern exposure.

Two thousand revolting members of seven longshoremen's locals voted unanimously last night to establish an Independent Committee for Longshoremen for the Port of Brooklyn in defiance of Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The coming national election campaign will neither prove nor disprove Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's charges of Communist infiltration of the Government, but it does signal busy days ahead for the controversial Republican from Wisconsin.

ROME, April 26 -- Italian sources said today that Marshal Tito had embarked on a vast and well-organized campaign to force the Italian part of the population from Zone B of the Trieste Free Territory, the zone that is administered by Yugoslavia.
In her recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, Snjolaug Sigurdson again showed that she was a sensitive and well-trained pianist with an affinity toward smaller forms.

Recent figures from Japan reveal that foreign investments in that country since June, 1950, are represented by 67,227,000 shares in Japanese corporations. Of these 63,000,000 shares were bought to participate in company management, the balance for income.

Al Parsells, eight-goal star from Tallman, N. Y., reserved his best for the last game. At Squadron A last night Parsells became the highest scorer for a single season in the history of the game at the Madison Avenue armory when he hit nine goals to lead his Ramapo Polo Club to a 13-7 decision over Long Island as the 1951-52 indoor season ended.

THE 100 master drawings, old and new, at the Schaeffer Gallery make up such a brilliant and distinguished company that it is no easy task to pick out single examples as being finer than others. When the level of quality is high, as it is here, individual taste for a period or an artist can be the only criterion of judgment.

A FRENCH citizen of Austrian birth, Jean Rounault, was working on a French newspaper in Rumania, when, in 1945, the Russians decided to deport all men and women of "German origin." To the Russian bureaucracy, this meant simply anyone who had either been born in a German-speaking county, or who had a name which to them sounded "Germanic."

GENEVA, April 26 -- The big risk facing European countries forced for the first time since war to deal with an important unemployment problem in textile and a few other consumer goods industries, as monetary experts see it, is that they will attempt to freeze a distribution of labor that is essentially uneconomic.

MIAMI, April 26 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee appears to have gained ground in recent days in his bid for Florida's favor as a Democratic Presidential nominee, reducing somewhat the substantial natural political advantages of his opponent, Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, leader of the powerful Southern bloc in Congress.

THIS biography of Henry Irving by his grandson, Laurence Irving, will seem long only to those whose passion for the theatre has become tame. The true theatre lover will eat it up. If he is a man of conscience he will also weep.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 26 -- The Palais de Chaillot annex in Paris, which was built last summer with such speed and enthusiasm for the 1951 session of the United Nations General Assembly, has now been taken over by the Secretariat of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

The National Broadcasting Company, which presented Gian-Carlo Menotti's "Amahl and the Night Visitors" during the current season, will offer two or three new operas by American composers during 1952-53. It may also include Richard Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier" among the eight operas it has scheduled.
A letter in your issue of April 13 by Mortimer Cohen takes issue with gore Landau's "Peace May Be In Moslem Hands" (April 6).

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Senator Robert A. Taft's campaign manager, David S. Ingalls, reported today that the Senator had polled 142,207 more votes than General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in the seven Republican Presidential preference primaries held so far.

TEL AVIV (By Wireless). AS they begin their fifth year of independence, the people of Israel may read both the greatness of their past and their mission for the future in the hot and whirling sands of the Negeb (which Literally means "south"), in its barren black and yellow mountains, in its wadis, parched in summer and roaring in winter and also in its grassy plains.

IT would appear to anyone who once played auction bridge and who now plays contract bridge that the "hold-up play" has all but vanished from the game. We used to have need of it on fully half the no-trump hands. Now it may occur only once or twice in an evening's play.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 26 -- A campaign to raise $1,000,000 for building expansion will be started by the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Connecticut, the oldest in the United States, tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Department of Justice relied heavily today on its state-of-emergency plea to persuade United States District Judge David A. Pine that President Truman's seizure of the steel industry should not be upset.

Pointing to the possibility of additional increases in the cost of medical education, Dr. William S. Carlson, president of the State University of New York, called yesterday for more generous support of medical schools by private donations and the community at large.

Fifteen assistant professors and instructors at Northwestern University will work this summer on private research projects under grants-in-aid of $1,200 each from the university, which will relieve them from all teaching duties. The fifteen were selected from more than fifty applicants, the awards being based upon past performance of the teachers and the importance of their projects.

LOUISVILLE, April 26 -- Churchill Downs opened its seventy-eighth annual spring race meeting today. About 20,000 customers were in the old horse park, and there was plenty of elbow room. A week from today there'll be five times that many customers, and the one best bet of the day is that there'll be no elbow room.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, asked the Senate today to restore $3,619,797,858 of the military funds cut by the House of Representatives and to eliminate a rider imposing a $46,000,000,000 ceiling on defense expenditures in the fiscal year that starts in July.

BOSTON, April 26 -- Enthusiasm generated by developments this year in both major political parties is expected to induce upward of 275,000 Massachusetts voters to participate in next Tuesday's Presidential preference primary. Some estimates on the turnout range as high as 500,000.

The public schools today see the need for an education that helps children to mature as human beings and individual citizens. Making this growth possible is one of the great aims of the modern spirit of education.
Collections of city real estate taxes for the fiscal year 1951-52 totaled $363,600,874 up to the close of business on April 7, or $9,327,438 more than a year ago.

JASPER, Tex., April 26 (UP) -- Martin Dies, chairman of the first House Committee on Un-American Activities from 1938 to 1945, announced today that he would run for the newly created office of Congressman at Large from Texas "to finish the job."

TODAY the United Nations is the target of a great deal of criticism. It is called a powerless debating society, a mere forum for propaganda. It is censured for not having dealt effectively with the cause of most of the world's present troubles, the deep conflict between Soviet Russia and the free world.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. -- A family drove into a gas station on the outskirts of town here the other day and the man at the wheel, in the tone of awesome expectancy formerly reserved for the community's large and colorful repertoire of gambling devices, inquired: "Where's that pile of atom bombs ?"

MINEOLA, L. I., April 26 -- The simulated atomic bomb blast in Nassau County today and the highly controversial beef stew served as part of the exercise were both highly successful, although the stew was adjudged to be on the bland side.
WHEN I dropped in at my neighborhood bistro on Ninth Street the other evening I found Mrs. Samgrass abstractedly rubbing the bar with a damp cloth and simultaneously glancing at The Villager.

THE Screen Writers Guild, and the rest of Hollywood for that matter, was boiling with excitement last week as the result of a Los Angeles Superior Court decision denying the Guild's petition to force Howard Hughes and R. K. O.-Radio Pictures to submit to arbitration the issue of screen writing credit involving Paul Jarrico.

GENEVA, April 26 -- As the original four-year term of the Marshall Plan approaches its end, the cynics who told Europe that the United States would never follow through on the programs it had initiated seem, to a growing number of Europeans, to have been right.
DUBUQUE, Iowa, April 26 (UP) -- Mississippi River floodwaters poured through the lowlands of Dubuque, a city without dikes, today, and routed more than 1,000 persons from their homes.

MR. MIKHAIL KORIAKOV'S interesting review of "A World Apart" contains one startling misstatement. If he will reread Dostoevsky's "The House of the Dead" he will surely find that Dostoevsky does not say that in his day the convicts' "only torture was captivity."

ZURICH, April 26 -- The nations of Western Europe now appear to be forming somewhat reluctantly the opinion that what was originally and wishfully described as a Soviet "peace offensive" is in reality, as Secretary of State Acheson said a week ago, merely a new endeavor to sow discord among the democracies.

Pulse-takers on both sides of the labor-management operating table were trying last week to decide whether collective bargaining was alive or dead. The uncertainty rose out of President Truman's seizure of the steel mills and the lugubrious record of stalled negotiations and ineffectual Government peace efforts that preceded it.

AKRON, Ohio, April 26 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennesee, carrying his Ohio campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination into this rubber industry center, made a major bid for labor's support today by urging that the Taft-Hartley Act be "rewritten in large part" because it hampered unions in collective bargaining.
SEOUL, Korea, April 26 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Frank F. Everest said today that a "very small percentage" of American airmen in Korea had expressed a fear of flying in the last six months.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 26 -- Accusations that the United States is resorting to bacterial and atomic warfare in Korea are increasing in Communist China despite denials, the Rev. Dr. Hugh W. Plubbard of this city, a Congregational missionary in China since 1912, said in a letter received here this week by his brother, Crescens,

NINE more Budd Rail-Diesel cars will go into service today, a tenth tomorrow and still another early in May on three Eastern roads. This will mark the biggest increase in the use of this stainless steel, self-propelled unit since the Budd Company introduced it three years ago.

STAMFORD, April 26 -- Republican voters in Stamford, Greenwich, Westport and Norwalk will have a chance Monday to express their preference for the Republican Presidential nominee when the annual party caucuses are held. Arrangements for the popularity poll, which will be advisory only, have been made by town Republican committees.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 27 (UP) -- Seven years of occupation for a defeated Japan end at 10:30 P. M. tomorrow [9:30 A. M. Eastern daylight saving time], and this nation once again will be restored to full sovereignty and independence.

Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, said yesterday at Winchester, Va., that a statement he made here on Thursday had created an "erroneous impression" about his position in the Presidential election.

A new attempt to prevent Harry Gross, convicted bookmaker, from testifying next week against eighteen policemen accused of corruption, either by trying to bribe members of his family or by threatening them with violence, was reported yesterday.

A BRAND-NEW life began for Emily when she walked into the house at 33 Bunn Street and found a room of her own. Emily had moved about so much with her family that she was shy about meeting new people, but the very next day she brought the girls on the block into her room to play.

IN his second novel. Anthony gives us a strange blending of implausible love story and unconvincing political allegoroy. We begin with the love story. Walter Jackson, an architect, a married man with two children, is suddenly and overwhelmingly attracted by a girl he sees on a London bus.

CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix -- Although St. Croix is only thirty-five minutes by air from its sister islands, St. Thomas and St. John, this largest of the American Virgin Islands will surprise the visitor arriving from bustling St. Thomas.

Top executives in big corporations have too much to do. They work nights and week-ends so much they have no time for overall planning. This is the conclusion made public last week by the American Management Association as the result of a survey among both big and little companies.

Arthur Summerfield of Flint, chairman of Michigan's forty-six delegates to the Republican National Convention, returned yesterday from Paris after inviting General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, to speak in Michigan prior to the convention.
The territories of Alaska and Hawaii would be admitted as states of the Union if the student members of the Model Congress, which held its final session at Hunter College yesterday, had their way.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 26 -- Declaring that there was no substitute for collective bargaining, Matthew A. Kelly, secretary, Union Employers Section, Printing Industry of America, Inc., of Washington, said today "it is dangerous for either labor or management to turn to the Government to solve their differences as they are now doing."

TEN New Yorkers Won awards in the "Photographs With Captions" section of the Freedom Foundation 1951 Awards announced last week. Winners of the second-place awards, who received $200 each, were Robert L. Brooks, Percy J. Hussakof, Karl F. Kunkel, Dorothy Louise Norris and Arthur Sasse.

WHEN Americans first took to rock gardening there was no one in this country who could assist either with advice or by example. Consequently everyone leaned heavily on the English, so that this new phase of gardening was slanted heavily in the direction taken by gardeners on the "tight little isle."

Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio picked up delegate strength yesterday in Arizona, Arkansas, Utah and Virginia state nominating conventions. General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower gained strong support in Colorado and Georgia.

The bond market has a new look. After a year of almost uninterrupted occupancy of storm cellars following the withdrawal of Federal Reserve System fixed-price support, market prices are looking up again hopefully, but tentatively.

MIAMI, April 26 -- A pretty blonde and her husky companion whizzed through the Atlantic to a new world water-skiing distance record today, barely escaping tragedy when twenty-foot waves dunked them in the shark-infested seas sixty miles from Miami.
RICHMOND, Calif., April 26 -- Patty Berg of Minneapolis set a world record for women golfers today as she toured the Richmond Country Club in 30, 34 -- 64.

I LUXEMOURG. Apt41 2g--4en-I eral of the Amy Dwight D. Eisenhower, who will relinquish his post !as Supreme Allied Commander inI 'Europe on June 1, flew from Paris :today to the capital of this tiny duchy.

Spartan Valor, the Jersey-bred colt owned by William Helis Jr., had them all shouting paeans of praise at the conclusion of the Gallant Fox Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. The 35,356 fans who braved a most unpleasant atmosphere felt amply rewarded as they saw the 4-year-old son of Attention register a smashing victory in the mile and three-sixteenths fixture that carried a gross value of $69,900.

Before we get too busy with other seasonal matters there are a few questions to consider. If a woodchuck in April is happy to eat meadow grass and wild herbs, why in June must he have garden peas, string-bean tips and burgeoning lettuce? Why do the biggest violets grow in the boggiest part of the bog?
TOKYO, Sunday, April 27 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,232, for Saturday's operations:

CLEVELAND, Aril 25 -- With better weather prevailing, shopping held up well in the week after Easter and sales of new automobiles were the best of the year. More than 1,200 new cars were sold, which is about as many as are available under present conditions.
Alex Preutz of Brooklyn has it all over most people when it comes to tracking things down.

Last March the news came from Mexico that near Santa Maria Tepexan, a village that lies a half hour by automobile from Mexico City, stone weapons had been found near the bones of a mammoth. The discovery dovetails neatly with one of a human skeleton made five years ago near the same spot by Dr. Helmut de Terra.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 26 (UP) -- Bob Stout, 26-year-old Philadelphia school teacher, earned the No. 1 berth on Uncle Sam's Olympic gymnastic team tonight by taking the all-around title in a major upset.

Reports reaching this department indicate an increasing interest in religious study and increased religious emphasis in some institutions of higher learning. Two universities, both New England institutions, indicate the trend -- Yale University and Boston University.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 26 -- Leaders of the trucking industry in this area traced a direct connection today between the recent seizure of the steel industry by the Federal Government and the taking over of their lines by the Office of Defense Transportation during the war.

DES MOINES, April 26 -- Illinois' record-breaking triumph in the university two-mile relay shared the spotlight with twice-victorious Kansas runners today in the finals of the forty-third Drake Relays.

John A. Cahill, chairman of the combined public utilities committee of the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., and the Midtown Realty Owners Association, Inc., issued a statement yesterday commenting on an Albany dispatch headed "Submetering Ban Upheld on Appeal," published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 24.

In passing judgment on the action of President Truman in "directing the Secretary of Commerce to take possession of the steel mills" it is essential that we recognize the vital distinction between the powers of the President during peacetime and his powers during war.

MOSCOW, April 26 (AP) -- Igor Moessev, ballet master and head of the State Ensemble of Folk Dancing, yesterday called for overhauling of the classical Russian ballet. He took four columns in the Literary Gazette for a stinging criticism of classical ballet, which has a tremendous following in the Soviet Union.

Warnings that an alliance of big business with corrupt politicians was as dangerous to the welfare of the American people as the threat of totalitarianism were voiced yesterday by speakers at the closing sessions of the forty-seventh annual conference of the League for Industrial Democracy.

ALMOST four years after the ejection of the Communist party of Yugoslavia from the Soviet-led Cominform, the origins and consequences of this striking event are still obscure at many points. Did the break arise from the obtuseness of Soviet bureaucrats and their failure to appraise correctly the inner cohesiveness of the Communist party of Yugoslavia?

Nelson A. Rockefeller, who knows as much about Latin America as any "Yanqui," said in a speech he made to the Women's National Republican Club on Tuesday that "disunity and unrest in many parts of Latin America are far more widespread and serious than most people in the United States realize."

NOT intended for those who think of handwriting analysis much as they think of reading palms, this is probably the most useful and important introduction in English to the study of handwriting as an indicator of personality.

POUND RIDGE, N. Y., April 26 -- The Hiram Halle Memorial Library, a converted 150-year-old schoolhouse, was dedicated today as this Westchester town's first circulating library and as a cultural center for the 500 families of the community.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 26 -- The free labor forces of the American countries have won a "great victory" over the "peronist" elements, in the opinion of United States labor representatives at the current fifth regional conference of the American states that belong to the International Labor Organization.
BERLIN, April 26 -- The congress of refugee journalists from Eastern Europe meeting here urged the West today to turn a cold shoulder to trade overtures from the Soviet Union.
The Board of Estimate has approved a proposal to permit part of Brooklyn's War Memorial Building to be used as a children's indoor recreation center.

NO slap-dash job of cannibalizing previous anthologies, "Tomorrow, the Stars" is an original collection of literate and entertaining stories. Robert A. Heinlein has chosen sound examples of the best work of such able craftsmen as Kuttner, Asimov, Kornbluth, Merril, Tucker and others.

Twenty thousand New Yorkers braved a steady rain yesterday to march down Fifth Avenue in the fifth annual Loyalty Day parade. Led for the first time by 1,000 Federal troops, the parade was an assertion by free men of their faith in democracy and their enmity toward the subject armies of communism, both in uniform and in the subversive's mufti.
ROME, April 26 (AP) -- Italy's war-damaged optical and precision mechanics industries, now rebuilt, expanded and modernized, are bidding strongly for world markets in this highly competitive field.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: The heavy insect infestation predicted for this year shows up first on trees. A few squirts from a sprayer filled with DDT gets rid of the little tent caterpillar nests that form in a few hours. Don't burn these nests in the trees. Forceful hosing with water cleans up red spider before they start on evergreens with a yellow appearance.

THE religious and political turmoil of eighteenth and early nineteenth-century Europe did much to hasten the settlement of America Among the many who left Europe for religious reasons was Father Charles Nerinckx, a Belgian priest, who came to the United States in 1804 and spent the remaining years of his life in arduous and fruitful missionary labor on the American frontier.

The House of Representatives has completed its action on the appropriation for the administration of our Trust Territory in the Pacific and the measure is now in the Senate. The upper house will do well to look closely at the measure as adopted with a view to needed amendment.
FEW perennials can challenge the performance and year-around attractiveness of coralbells. It is a charming garden plant that is easily grown and long - lasting. The bloom is fine for cutting, too.

Daylight saving time became effective at 2 A. M. today in New York State and at midnight in New Jersey. In twenty-one other states and the District of Columbia, 60,000,000 Americans moved, or should have moved, their clocks forward one hour to gain 154 hours of daylight, returning to standard time on Sunday, Sept. 28.

BRIDGWATER, England, April 26 -- Rear Admiral Ernest William Leir, 70 years old, onetime aide de camp to King George V, was fined $56 and costs today for hitting a minister on the nose because the admiral objected to a sermon.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 26 (AP) -- Bert Darrell of Bermuda, sailing his International one-design yacht, Teaser, won the King Edward VIII Cold Cup today.

THE scant attention often given less-tender cuts of meat undoubtedly results from a rather general lack of knowledge of how to choose and use them Certainly it is not a question of price, for they are much more economical than the more popular steaks, chops and roasts.

The importance of giving college students an awareness of community problems and the means of solving them was emphasized yesterday by speakers at the first annual Eastern College Conference for Functional Education.

Handmacher-Vogel, Inc., one of the country's largest producers of women's coats and suits, expects a further rise in total dollar volume this year, according to Alvin Handmacher, president Spring suit business shows an increase over last year, and plans call for an upswing in production for the fall season, Mr. Handmacher said last week.

Cases of heavy drinking among industry workers are so few and well controlled that executives consider them neither a major problem nor a threat to national production. The loss suffered by industry from alcoholism among workers has long been a point of disagreement. Drys have been inclined to exaggerate and over-emphasize the problem, whereas members of the liquor industry have termed it practically inconsequential.

A warning against unscrupulous reupholstery concerns that advertise services at "ridiculously low prices" with no intention of selling at those prices was voiced yesterday by the Better Business Bureau.

Regarding the paragraph in "Emphatically Embarrassing" (April 13) about the raid of a hotel room in Cedar Rapids in which four cases of illegal whisky were found apparently in preparation for a convention of the Iowa Sheriffs Association, the rest of this tale is amusing.

DETROIT, April 26 -- Art Houtteman had a no-hitter within his grasp with two out in the ninth inning today when he threw a fast ball that was "supposed to sink." It didn't sink, and Harry Simpson lined it to left for a single. But the Tigers snapped their eight-game losing streak by beating the Indians, 13 -- 0.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 26 -- On orders from New Delhi, the Indian delegation has issued a warning that the United Nations may disintegrate if the great powers refuse to allow the world organization to consider disputes brought up by the smaller countries.

IN her first novel, Mary Bancroft writes nostalgically of a rebellious little girl growing up in the proper atmosphere of Cambridge, Mass. The Dana house had all the comforts and luxuries money could buy, but Kathy preferred sitting out in the stables with Nolan, her grandfather's coachman.

ON moral grounds this book will be attacked as a "crime manual." Although some of the methods are dated, a novice in crime could absorb much criminal know-how in a half-dozen fields, plus a few details about planning and executing a prison escape.
SPRING GREEN, Wis., April 26 (AP) -- An unwatched grass fire destroyed the center section of Frank Lloyd Wright's famed "Hillside School at Taliesin" in south central Wisconsin late today.

The Army Medical Service has taken another step in the use of the skills of women. Three brilliant young women medical graduates are being admitted to Army hospitals as internes. This is the first time that this has happened, although there already are sixteen women physicians on active duty in the Army.

MOST Irishmen are born actors. That was one good reason for going to Ireland to make a feature based on Ian Niall's book, "No Resting Place," a story of the wandering tinkers and their continual struggle against the conventions of society.

FRANKFURT, Germany, April 26 (AP) -- Two Michigan members of a United States Congressional committee investigating the Katyn forest massacre tangled today over General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's attitude toward that World War II atrocity.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 -- Department store sales in the Twelfth District varied sharply in the week ending April 16. Salt Lake City's loss was almost offset by Spokane's gain while other key cities showed gains and losses which gave the district as a whole an even break against the 1951 sales figures.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Truman will play "guide" next Saturday when for the first time a country-wide audience gets an inside look at the renovated White House through television.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 -- Two San Francisco Presbyterian congregations -- one entirely Negro, the other entirely white -- are forming a single church under a Negro pastor.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 -- Seventy-two perplexed California shoppers have gone to market looking for a Democratic Presidential candidate. They are eager for a bargain but they profess to have a fair amount of sales resistance.

This week's best-seller list on Page 8 of the Book Review Section carries news of a publishing phenomenon as rare as a total solar eclipse. Making its first appearance on the list, in tenth place, is "Under the Sea-Wind," which was first published back in 1941 and has recently been reissued by Oxford University Press.

AFTER last Sunday evening's telecast of "Foursquare Court" over the A. B. C. network, there hardly can be further complaint about the squeamishness of television in dealing with touchy social issues. For what assuredly was the first time in TV's relatively brief history a former prostitute appeared before the cameras and explained in detail what had been her way of life.

NURSERYMEN say that the demand for elm trees has fallen off in recent years because of the spread of Dutch elm disease and its devastating toll of this favorite tree in many areas. Elms are still being planted by optimistic tree wardens, but there are interesting and rather sharp differences of opinion among arborists and landscape architects as to the best trees to plant, either to supplement the elms or to serve a similar purpose.

SAUDI ARABIA'S Royal Embassy at Washington has released the design of half-qirsh brown, 1q green, 3q purple, 10q red and 20q blue stamps which commemorate the opening of the $50,000,00 rail line which runs inland 350 miles from Dammam on the Persian Gulf to the capital city of Riyadh.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., April 26 (AP) -- Senator Taft ridiculed theI United Nations tonight as a complete failure at enforcing peace and called for a revised organizationI based on international law ratherI than "control of the world by five[ great nations."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 (AP) -- Henry Von Morpurgo was convicted today of taking approximately $90,000 from Sister Kenny Polio Foundation collections after promoting them by the careless use of such names as Bing Crosby.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 26 -- Boulder Brook Club's annual spring horse show, attracting a combined entry of close to 1,000, opened its two-day stand today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 26 -- The United States will accuse the Chinese Communists next week of an organized campaign of narcotics peddling in the Far East, with United Nations troops as one of the chief targets.

Several debutantes of this season are aiding in plans for the performance of "The Chase" on the night of May 8 at the Playhouse which has been taken over to raise funds for the Children's Village. Miss Clare Lundbeck heads the debutante committee for the forthcoming event, and Miss Janet Gelder is co-chairman.

Buyers of ready-to-wear items concentrated on summer purchases in the wholesale market here last week, resident buying offices reported. Stores took advantage of special purchases and unusual values which caused a firming of prices in several markets.

The English-Speaking Union of the United States has named eight journalists and broadcasters as recipients of "1951 Better Understanding Awards" for contributions to greater understanding of mutual problems and interests of the United States and Commonwealth countries.

Dr. John J. Meng, Professor of History at Hunter College, has been appointed to the newly created position of Dean of Administration of the college, the Board of Higher Education has announced. He will take office on Sept. 1.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- The St. Louis Browns withered under Joe Dobson's brilliant three-hit pitching today and bowed to the Chicago White Sox, 5 -- 0. The setback cost them the American League lead. The Boston Red Sox, whose game at Philadelphia was rained out, took over first place with a 9-2 record. The Browns have won seven and lost two.

In the tight Republican race between Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft, attention last week centered on the two key states of New York and Pennsylvania which held their primaries Tuesday.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 26 -- While the revolutionary Cabinet's assertions that it is a constitutional government were being challenged, the new Government's police officials announced today the arrest of fifteen persons, including many formerly important Bolivian political personalities.

International exchange programs have increased during the past year in a vital effort toward world peace. The annual report of the Institute of International Education, issued last week, shows that not only more people, but more kinds of people, are involved in such programs now than ever before.

BEAR MOUNTAIN -- The summit of Bear Mountain is now accessible to motorists for the first time since the 1945 rains washed out parts of the scenic Perkins Memorial Drive. The reconstructed mountain road and the new beach at Sebago Lake, with accommodations for 10,000 bathers, are the major prizes the Palisades Interstate Park Commission has pulled out of its 1952 bag for holidayers in the Bear Mountain and Harriman Park sections.

The recent editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES captioned "New Barriers for Old" contends that the Walter McCarran bills, which codify and revise all immigration and naturalization laws, are "utterly inadequate as reform measures."

THOSE who have read only the Churchillian prose of the war memoirs and the prepared speeches, delivered without interruption, of public occasions have missed one of the more entertaining facets of expression of the Prime Minister of Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations opened a campaign today for a "sound and constructive" Missouri Valley program to overcome the "irresponsible neglect of the resources of the region."

BONN, Germany, April 26 -- Further cooperation between Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union and the Free Democratic party, the second largest member of the Government coalition, is seriously endangered by the Government's loss of control of the Bundesrat or upper house of Parliament.

THE New York Forest Preserve "question," arising from a proposal that the policies for the management of these be studied with the possibility of revision, has something in common with a volcano that may remain inactive but is never extinct and can erupt on short notice upon the exertion of new pressures.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 -- More young men are studying for the Christian ministry than ever before in the history of the Methodist Church, it was reported here today to the denomination's quadrennial general conference.
LONDON, April 26 (AP) -- The Manchester United team, which is soon to tour the United States, won the English League soccer championship today by trouncing Arsenal, 6 -- 1.

Members of the alumnae associations of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart and the Sacred Heart Academies of Ninety-first Street, New York, Greenwich and Noroton, Conn., will give a tea dance on the afternoon and early evening of May 15 in the St. Regis Roof.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 26 -- Frank Stranahan prevailed over Frank Strafaci, par and the weather today to win his third North and South amateur golf championship in seven years, with an 8 and 7 victory in the rain-soaked 36-hole final.

IN the work of the big Cezanne exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum which continues to draw visitors by the thousands, the newly opened exhibition of selected oils and water-colors by the late Arthur Dove at the Downtown helps to furnish illuminating background and perspective on the modern movement, particularly on the more expressionist and abstract phases so much in evidence at the present time.

ST. LOUIS, April 26 (AP) -- Del Rice's third hit of the game drove Steve Bilko in with the winning run tonight in the eleventh inning as the Cardinals broke the Cubs' three-game winning streak, 4 to 3.

HARTFORD. Conn.. April 26-- /%fr. and Mrs. Samuel Yaffo have ]announced the engagement and ]approaching marriage of their ]daughter, Adele Deborah, to Justin ICohen, son of Mrs. Joseph Cohen' IOf Springfield, Mass., and the late [Mr. Cohen. The wedding will take] Iplace June 1.

The fourth anniversary of the establishing of Israel was commemorated yesterday morning at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street, in a sermon by Rabbi Israel Goldstein and an address by Arie Ben-Tovim, Consul of Israel here.

BIOGRAPHER of Bach and Ravel, Madeleine Goss now fills a volume with thirty-seven profiles, each devoted to an American composer. The pieces are fairly detailed and accurate recountings of their subjects' lives, activities and attitudes. Each one begins with a capsule judgment: Douglas Moore is "ear-minded"; Virgil Thomson is "highly trained"; Roger Sessions is a "composer's composer''; George Antheil is the "bad boy of music"; Aaron Copland and Roy Harris are "American" composers.

ATHENS, April 26 -- Premier Adnan Menderes and Foreign Minister Fuad Koprulu of Turkey, accompanied by top-ranking military and diplomatic officials, arrived in Athens today for a five-day visit as guests of the Greek Government. They will take part in talks that diplomatic observers consider a sequel to the recent joint military discussions in Ankara.

INTERNATIONAL travel for cultural purposes has been seriously curtailed for many Europeans because of currency restrictions in effect in their countries. A recent survey by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization showed that potential travelers, compelled to rely on the normal tourist allowances enforced by their nations, are frequently obliged to give up plans to visit other countries on cultural missions of one sort or another.

The Season of the Spade is upon the earth. The warming sun of the lengthening day has unbuckled the frost grip. The ground is pliable, both to man's steel blade and nature's hungry and probing root. The yearning to plant and replenish runs strong, even as does the thaw-swollen brook and stream.

MISLED by detective stories and radio and television programs in which crime detection moves inexorably from bloodstain or laundry mark to culprit, the general public is apt to underestimate the importance of "information," which actually accounts for most of the arrests made by law-enforcement agencies.

ACCIDENTS and fatalities are decreasing as mileage increases on the Pennsylvania Turnpike -- a commendable combination attributed in substantial measure to more intelligent driving by the majority of motorists, particularly commercial operators.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 26 -- State-wide Republican party caucuses on Monday night, when delegates to the state convention on May 26-27 will be chosen, will determine control of the Republican party in Connecticut.

SHIRLEY BOOTH has finally made a Hollywood movie, "Come Back, Little Sheba," based on a play in which she starred on Broadway in 1950. This is a notable event in the career of the actress who is considered to be about as good as the New York stage has to offer in roles of the unlacquered human comedy.

MEXICO CITY, April 26 -- Police announced today that last Saturday's shooting affray on Avenida Insurgentes in which a minor official of the ruling party of Revolutionary Institutions (P. R. I.) died was the result of a drunken brawl and had nothing to do with politics.

THE COLUMBIA LIPPINCOTT GAZETTEER is a book about 130,000 different places -- cities, countries, rivers, villages, mountains, lakes, bays, national monuments, battlefields, military posts, seaports and reclamation projects.
LONDON, April 26 (Reuters) -- Manchester United today took the English League championship for the first time since 1911. United had been runner-up four times since the war.
ALHAMBRA, Calif., April 26 (UP) -- Mrs. Nabuko Coronel, a war bride, was on her way to her new home here today, assured by her neighbors-to-be that she is welcome in the United States.

BEFORE long the put-put of the power mower and the clatter of the hand model will be heard throughout the countryside. For grass is growing greener and taller and this is the signal to get out the mower.

The social and esthetic problems confronting the contemporary painter will be the subject of a lecture, "In Search of a Muse," by Ralph L. Wickiser, head of the Louisiana State University Fine Arts Department, on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

A LARGE Roman Catholic Irish family in Buffalo is ably described in this novel by a Catholic writer. The time is the Twenties -- a decade of temptation in which Roger Dooley tries the morals of his characters.

WITH U. S. TWENTY-SEVENTH REGIMENT in Korea, April 17 -- Huddled in bunkers and trenches, tens of thousands of United States soldiers are trying to wait out death in Korea while the armistice talks drag.

TOMMY'S Aunt Alverta said that giraffes were a very unhandy size, and the zoo keeper said that Gwendolyn was always moping. Still, Tommy had own reasons for wanting a giraffe, and he rented Gwendolyn for one week, after which she was put on the city payroll.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 26 -- Cornell started a new season today on placid Onondaga Lake by serving notice on the rowing world that it has an Olympic contender.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., April 26 -- Marvadel Thorn's Rambler, 1 1/2-year-old Labrador retriever owned by Mr. and Mrs. J. Gould Remick of Cedarhurst, was the winner of the derby stake that began the spring trials of the Labrador Retriever Club today.

PROVIDENCE April 26 (AP) -- Brown today defeated Dartmouth in the first game of an Eastern Intercollegiate league doubleheader, 8 -- 5, then lost the second, 5 -- 2. The latter was called because of darkness after five innings.

A MIXED shrub border should not have too much of an assortment. Four different kinds are plenty for most plantings. A variety from each group shown in the plan on this page will provide the different heights and shapes needed to make an interesting pattern.
SAIGON, Indo-China, April 26 -- France's economic position in Indo-China will be at stake at a conference in Paris, for which delegates from the three Indo-Chinese states are now assembling.
CHICAGO, April 26 (AP) -- Feed grains led a general retreat in cereals on the Board of Trade today. Oats weakened most, largely on news that more Canadian oats were being shipped to Buffalo.

FREEDOM is the hero of "The Fourteenth of October" and Wulf, the Saxon boy who is the chief character, is a wolf of uncompromise. The author's undeceived eye for beauty and her passion for moral beauty have produced a Bayeux tapestry, pertinent to the thought of a free world -- fraught with precepts which could save us. A gallant book.

THREE shows departed from the local boards last night, two more go tonight, and the annual warm weather lull is beginning to engulf the theatre. A little earlier than usual, perhaps, but on the basis of what has been shown this season, not too surprising.

Banks are pressed by a scarcity of suitable employes, despite the fact that the national manpower shortage otherwise has eased. Faced with an annual turnover of more than 25 per cent, against a peacetime "normal" of about 10 per cent, banks must find about 100,000 new workers each year, and the problem has led to a re-examination of established personnel policies.

Art Houtteman of the Tigers shut out the Indians, 13 -- 0, with one hit yesterday. Harry Simpson got the lone safety for Cleveland with two out in the ninth inning. The White Sox trounced the Browns, 5 -- 0.
CHICAGO, Apirl 26 -- The Illinois Congress of Parents and Teachers, at its fiftieth convention today, refused to indorse world-wide disarmament as a step to abolish wars.

MANHASSET, L. I., April 26 -- Members of society in the North Shore colonies of Great Neck, Manhasset and Roslyn have joined forces to present a spring festival for the benefit of the North Shore Hospital on May 11 on the polo field of the John Hay Whitney estate on Northern Boulevard.

" CHILDREN may dare. Drivers beware," is the slogan for a campaign launched this month by the National Safety Council and aimed at cutting down the number of accidents involving children, bicycles and automobiles. Analyses of accident statistics indicate that in the great majority of cases it was the operator of the bike, not the auto driver, who was violating some traffic law.

WHITEVILLE, N. C., April 26 -- Twenty-five alleged members of the Ku Klux Klan will go on trial in Columbus County Superior Court here Monday on charges growing out of an investigation of night floggings in the county.

NEWARK, April 26 -- Delegates from thirty-two branches will attend the twenty-fifth annual meeting of the New Jersey Division of the American Association of University Women at Trenton State Teachers College on Saturday. Mrs. J. Albert Prochazka of Roselle Park is the Jersey president.

ORLANDO, Fla., April 26 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, opening his campaign for votes in Florida's Presidential preferential primary, today charged his opponent in the contest, Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, with being "a spokesman for a superstate program and director of a super-political organization."

Caution blanketed financial markets last week. With the steel wage-price controversy still raging and fears of further inflation rising, traders moved hesitantly. Security and commodity markets weakened early in the week, but gained strength in later dealings and wound up with only minor price changes.

TONIGHT will see the final performance by Martha Graham and her company at the Juilliard School, in a series which has served the double purpose of bringing Miss Graham brilliantly back into the field after two years of only sporadic action, and of establishing the Juilliard as a hopeful (if inconveniently located) producing center for modern dance.

DOVER, Del., April 26 -- The 120 delegates chosen to the Republican State Convention at the party's primary today will meet here next Wednesday to name Delaware's twelve delegates to the G. O. P. National Convention.
A substantial tide of business protests arose last week that may drown Government attempts at continued price control of consumer products.

Dr. Charles E. Dutchess rose before the Industrial Medical Association the other day to plead anew for the man who is forced by convention to retire at the age of 65, yet is able to do a full day's work. Though it had a familiar ring, his plea was worth hearing again; for the time is not far off when we shall have to consider the plight of the supposedly superannuated.

Rosie the Riveter is on the way out. So is Willie the Welder. Aircraft are now being built on designs which eliminate the bits and pieces which during World War II, and after, were little changed from the days of the Wright brothers.

Purchases of the Treasury's E-type savings bonds in $25 and $50 amounts are becoming increasingly important in the officially sponsored savings program, according to a survey by the Institute of Life Insurance.

RECENT historians of the Confederacy have been obsessed with the causes of Southern defeat, including the absence of railways and salt and the presence of state-rightism and desertion. This volume explains how the Confederate ordnance department almost won the war for the South.

TWO aviation "firsts" that will have a radical and lasting influence on commercial airline operations will be marked late next week. It is hardly too much to say that the two events together signal the beginning of a new era in air passenger travel.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Rain today again prevented the season's first clash here of the Yankees and the Senators and, as a consequence of the postponement of two night games, forced a change in the Bombers' plans.
CINCINNATI, April 26 (AP) -- A seive-like Pittsburgh defense let in seven unearned runs today and the Reds took a 9 to 2 decision over the Pirates in the opener of a three-game series here.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 26 (AP) -- Harvard launched its 100th rowing season and Harvey Love's varsity head-coaching career by sweeping three races from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today in mile and three-quarter upstream races on the Charles River.

PARIS, April 26 -- The official view here is that, in insisting upon German unity and upon its discussion between the Western powers and the Soviet Union, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of the Bonn Republic did not change his foreign policy.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 26 -- Last Tuesday's nuclear detonation -- high in the air over the cactus and sagebrush of the Atomic Energy Commission's Nevada proving ground -- opened another new chapter in atomic development and in the art of war.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 26 -- The critical phase in Israel's ten-week old "new economic policy" was marked this week by angry recriminations between the Government and most of labor movement on the one hand and free enterprise supporters on the other.

AN extraordinary volume, "Napoleon at St. Helena" has a history as fascinating as the tale it tells. It is the account of Napoleon's last five months of life, and it has the double interest of being written (at least in many of its parts) with the penetrating realism of a modern novelist and of coming to us after it had lain hidden for 130 years.
