THE word "hedge" can be broadly defined as a "living wall." If its purpose is interpreted in this manner, a hedge can be one of the most useful tools in the hands of the landscape designer or home gardener. Its most important uses are as enclosures, screens, partitions, edgings and barriers.

ANEW $9,000,000 tunnel and ramps costing $4,600,000 will go into service a week from tomorrow at the Manhattan end of the George Washington Bridge to make travel between northern New Jersey, Queens and Long Island immeasurably smoother for thousands of motorists.

Giovanni Ficarotta is getting tired of being the ping-pong ball in a three-year table tennis match between Italy and the United States. So is the American Export Lines, which has lost $1,200 in the no-decision contest.

TOKYO, April 26 -- There is a lot of scuttlebutt going the rounds about peace coming at last to Korea but to the frontline infantryman whose hands are clammy on his rifle stock and o the jet flier bruised against his shoulder straps in a sound-swift dive through the twelve-gun sprays of Chinese cannon bursts the war is still on.

THE reasons for a barrier at the edge of a property are as varied as the families of home owners. But in the suburbs of large cities hedges and fences nearly always achieve one of two purposes -- privacy or improvement of the landscape design.
Early American furniture and clocks, paperweights and other collector's pieces will be auctioned on Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 26 -- Mrs. Georgina Campbell Manville, estranged eighth wife of Tommy Manville, asbestos fortune heir, was killed today in an automobile collision near here. The 33-year-old British-born woman was driving alone to breakfast with her husband at his home in New Rochelle.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 26 -- Victorious over Yale in their opening regatta of the season last week, Navy's crews, considered among the more powerful units in the East, today swept the river for the second time by defeating Princeton on the Severn.

GOURDS are coming back into favor again, and with good reason. They are fun, and the fruits make lasting decorations for winter months. Contrary to popular opinion, the home gardener can raise them successfully in relatively limited space.

LONDON -- Though the late King George is mourned in British hearts, there is little visible mourning in London. Peers, M. P.'s, members of the Court and of the armed forces still wear black ties. Anyone else who does so should be regarded with suspicion: he is hoping to be thought a courtier.

The 100th anniversary tea of St. Luke's Home for Aged Women will be held on Thursday afternoon at the headquarters of the institution at 2914 Broadway. Mrs. M. Lawrence Havey and Mrs. Noyes Hamilton are co-chairmen of the centennial committee in charge of the plans for the fete.
A pharmacist of Cardiff, Wales, in suing for divorce, testified that his 220-pound wife put him down and sat on him when they had an argument.

The fundamental debate over the powers of the Presidency reverberated through the nation last week with ever-growing scope and impact. Harry S. Truman, the man who a month ago announced that he would not seek re-election next fall, was as deep in political contention as at any time in his seven years and sixteen days in the White House.

DIVINITY has been compared, at one time or another, to an interesting variety of vocations. In one period the crafts predominate: God performs the work of a gardener, a shepherd, or a potter. Again, the arts and professions may seem more fitting, and men assimilate Him to a commander of armies, an architect, or a mathematical physicist.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Maine members of Congress today asked Senator Kenneth McKellar, Democrat of Tennessee, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, to restore to the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill funds that had been eliminated by the House for the Maritime training program.

NEWARK, N. J., April 26 -- Archibald Alexander, who resigned recently as Under Secretary of the Department of Defense to campaign as Democratic candidate for Senator from New Jersey, said today in an address at the closing convention luncheon of the New Jersey Society of Professional Engineers that he foresaw the eclipse of the "career soldier in the United States Amy."

DAVEL'S "Bolero" is copyrighted and the sheet music is available from only one authorized publisher. Yet the piece has been issued on records by at least five American companies; and anyone else is at liberty to record it on the payment of a statutory royalty of 2c per record manufactured.

Cotton prices were irregular last week within a relatively narrow trading range. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed the week 50 points lower to 22 above the level of the week before, which in turn registered net declines of 58 to 101 points from the previous period.

There has appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES, under a Vienna dateline, a summarized report of the First International Conference for the Defense of Children. The final resolution adopted by this Communist-dominated body contains much high-sounding language about children in distress, hungry children, child victims of "bacteriological warfare in Korea."

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- Manhattan's fleet sprinters and quarter-milers dominated the scene today as the fifty-eighth annual Pennsylvania Relays came to a sodden close for 10,000 hardy track and field enthusiasts at Franklin Field, which was all but submerged after four days of ceaseless rain.

THE thirteen Columbia disks that contain all nine Beethoven symphonies and the four by Brahms are, in their way, a miniature history of recording up to about 1940. All, as nearly everybody by now knows, are conducted by the late Felix Weingartner, one of the great musicians of his generation.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- Government hopes for ending the three-year-old railroad wage and working rules battle grew today as the White House announced that John R. Steelman, Acting Defense Mobilizer, had reopened intensified mediation efforts.
Your correspondent Miss Gladys Holmes (April 20) reproves your author, Peter Kihss, "Man Against the Locust," (April 6), for his literal reading of the New Testament. Mr. Kihss, however, is right.

NEW YORK's amateur photographic community last week heard a fresh voice from California in its current attempt to resolve the "creative photograph" issue in the camera clubs. Interest in the controversy has been waning of late, a fact that was reflected in a smaller attendance than was expected at the talk by Edward B. Kaminski of Los Angeles in which this popular West Coast teacher of the creative approach explained his views and showed pictures.

TANGIER, April 25 -- The Spanish Government was understood today to have informed the major Western powers, including the United States, that it would shelve its demand for denunciation of the 1945 Paris agreement on Tangier if key administrative posts Spain held under the 1923 statute were returned to her.

IN a small room high above the stage of Carnegie Hall, a stocky man with a bald head and more bounce than any 66-year-old ought to have was clearing out a steel locker. Maurice Van Praag, retiring as personnel manager of the Philharmonic-Symphony, was sorting out the mementos accumulated in thirty-six years with the orchestra.

LEVER HOUSE, the spectacular office building in New York which seems almost to float in space, will be opened officially on Tuesday. The $6,000,000, twenty-four-story structure, headquarters of the soap, food and cosmetics business of Lever Brothers Company, was designed by Skidmore, Owings Merrill both to provide efficient office space and, by its architectural distinction, to do a public relations job for the company and its divisions which are the building's sole occupants.

In her article, "Jefferson's Ideals: A Challenge to Us" (April 13), Barbara Ward is, I think, unduly critical of the "realists." Like most worldimprovers, she credits the world's ills to the mismanagement of statesmen and politicians, accusing them of being too realistic and not willing enough to give idealism its chance.
The expected spring upturn in industrial activity has not appeared. In fact, a trend to level off, noted in March, appears to be canceled.

IN this allegorical novel John Cowper Powys uses the tribal and religious conflicts of fifth-century North Wales to satirize all oppressors. Showing his ardent belief in equality and individual liberty (as he did adeptly in "The Meaning of Culture") Powys presents some arresting ideas through his principal characters.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 26 -- Although limited to three hits. Army eked out a 4-3 triumph over Yale in an Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball game at Yale Field today. Rain, which fell throughout the opener, washed out the finale of the scheduled doubleheader.

LAID in the sheep-raising country of North Dakota, "Big Mutt" successfully combines a moving dog story with exciting adventure. Among present-day sheepherders the ability to ride a horse, shoot fast and straight, train a dog and track down a wolf is as necessary now as a hundred years ago.

LAUREL, Md., April 26 (UP) -- Tuscany. Mrs. Samuel M. Pistorio's hard-luck colt, made it two for two in 1952 as he splashed to a half-length victory over Carolyn K. Stable's Hi Billee in today's $11,100 Rowe Memorial Handicap at Laurel Park.

THERE has been a privately-owned National Theatre on the site facing Pennsylvania Avenue since 1835 but it is safe to say that no event in its 117 years has whipped up the same anticipation as Ethel Merman's appearance in "Call Me Madam" for four weeks starting May 5.

Lagging a fortnight behind the beginning of the major league season, a baseball exhibition called "Play Ball!" will open to the public on Wednesday at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street.

A constant succession of bloom from early spring until late fall is not enough for a successful garden. Accent plants are also required to give points of dramatic interest against the background of colorful mass plantings.

IN 1939 John Dos Passos published a novel called "Adventures of a Young Man," which told of Glenn Spotswood's intense and ultimately fatal involvement with the Communist party. Four years later, in "Number One," he portrayed a Southern politician, a kind of Huey Long, one of whose supporters and victims turned out to be Tyler Spotswood, Glenn's older alcoholic brother.

The 1952 Presidential election in this country is far more important to the peoples of the Western world than their own national elections, Arnold J. Toynbee, British historian, said here last week after his arrival on the Caronia. He was interviewed at the English-Speaking Union, 19 East Fifty-fourth Street.

Forty-six wide-gauge coal-burning locomotives, originally built for the Soviet Union at an estimated total cost of $3,910,000 under World War II lend-lease operations, will be offered for sale as Army surplus to the highest bidder, beginning tomorrow, the First Army announced here yesterday.
Co-author with Elliott Nugent of "The Male Animal," being revived Wednesday at the City Center. The comedy was a hit of the 1939-40 season, playing for 243 performances.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The two men who have figured most prominently in the court room scene now considering President Truman's emergency seizure of the steal industry are quiet, soft-spoken, conservative in both personal and professional demeanor and relatively unknown outside their juridical and legal circles.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., April 26 -- The Army Signal Corps has announced the development of a new lightweight telephone that can record the softest whisper, yet is sufficiently rugged to withstand the pounding of heavy artillery shock waves on the battlefield.

ALTHOUGH all the materials of a business upturn are handy, the spark is lacking. People are in a cautious mood, and purchasing agents, acting to keep the pipelines of industry filled, are reducing their buying accordingly.

THE easy way to travel in Spain is with a car, a Spanish-speaking chauffeur of proven ability, and a legacy from Uncle Edward. The car insures the tourist against discomfort in rickety trains and crowded buses.

GALLUP, N. M. -- Thousands of transcontinental motorists cross New Mexico each year on U. S. 66, the major east-west trunkline which cuts across the Southwest from Oklahoma City and through Amarillo, Tex., Albuquerque and Gallup, N. M., and Flagstaff, Ariz., to Los Angeles.

Amidst the furor created by the many candidates seeking the highest office in the country, Parker Brothers, Salem, Mass., has started retail distribution of a game in which the players attempt to elect themselves president.
The Fossils, an organization of present and former amateur printers, writers and publishers, held its annual meeting last night at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.

Last week the Hydrographic Department of the Admiralty announced in London that the research vessel H.M.S. Challenger had dropped a weighted wire to 5,872 fathoms (35,232 feet) in the vicinity of latitude 11 degrees 20 minutes north and longitude 142 degrees 16 minutes east on a first traverse in June of last year and to 5,940 fathoms (35,640 feet) about a mile and a half to the southeast during a second traverse in October.

The Contemporary American Music Festival of the Air, which this year is being presented by Columbia University in collaboration with the Columbia Broadcasting System, opened with a half-hour broadcast yesterday afternoon at 5 o'clock. The broadcast originated in Washington, where the Budapest String Quartet played Griffes' "Two Sketches Based on Indian Themes" and Quincy Porter's String Quartet No. 8.

Within the last ten days three dramatic prison riots have thrilled newspaper readers, newsreel audiences and television watchers. They were not attempts to escape but struggles within the prisons. Rarely before have such riots been so large or well publicized.

The stock market extended its recovery selectively yesterday and closed irregularly higher in the largest Saturday session of the month. Railroad issues, joined by some motor shares, led the advance, while the steel group continued to lag.

THE substance of this novel is history: the occupation of Poland during World War II, first by the Nazis then by the Soviets. On the surface it is the story of the Kolbecks, a patriotic clan of army officers who were the dynasty of Poland; their struggle to survive under both conquerors. But the real story is the purging power of suffering.

EVERY year about this time we toy with the idea of doing something on baseball but nothing ever comes of it. (Do baseball writers go through the same torture about publishing?) This year we salute the opening of the season by discussing several new books whose common syndrome seems to be a drive toward total functionalism.

SPRING bloom is about ten days to two weeks ahead of schedule, according to Dr. Norman Childers of Rutgers University. In the orchards at the experimental farm of the State University of New Jersey in New Brunswick, the peach blossoms were already falling by the middle of last week, and the red apple buds needed only three or four days of warm sunshine to open.

JERRY COLEMAN and Phil Rizzuto were standing near the batting cage at the Stadium one day last week, watching Yogi Berra with amusement. The injured catcher presumably was taking a workout in the vicinity of second base during the hitting drill. He stood with arms folded, as mobile and spry as a fire hydrant.

FORT BENNING, Ga. THE Rangers -- born in the days of 1812 as tough frontiersmen of the Old West -- live again today at this training center, and the leaven of their toughness is spreading throughout the Army.

POSTMASTER General Jesse M. Donaldson made available last week the design of the 3-cent blue stamp to be issued on June 13 for the 175th anniversary of the arrival of the Marquis de Lafayette in this country.

The opening speaker at the Congress of the Free Press, which today concludes a three-day meeting in Berlin, made the startling statement that only 11 per cent of the journalists who worked in Eastern Europe before the war are still practicing their profession there. Some of the others are no doubt dead, or retired for normal reasons.

PARIS, April 26 -- Premier Anoine Pinay launched the economy phase of his program to defend the franc today when the Cabinet approved cuts affecting all departments of the Government except defense for a total of 110,000,000,000 francs ($314,285,000).

ON the dedication page of "Fabulous Bawd," the story of Saratoga Springs, is the line. "This is dedicated to the horses who, alone in Saratoga over the years, have remained honest." This dedication is in character with the book.

The 52 Association of New York, Inc., will give five parties this week for wounded servicemen and disabled veterans. Tomorrow night the society will take patients from Mitchell Air Base Hospital to dinner at the Grand Street Boys Association and then to boxing bouts at St. Nicholas Arena.

TUNIS, Tunisia, April 26 (UP) -- Several student agitators were injured and a number arrested, and three school buildings damaged or defaced in anti-French "incidents" in this strategic North African protectorate today.

BOSTON, April 26 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio tonight accused Gov. Sherman Adams of New Hampshire, a supporter of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, of "direct lies and deliberate misrepresentations" of the Senator's position.

LOUIS deROCHEMONT ASSOCIATES, which has trained its cameras on a wide variety of subjects, now will essay the life of Martin Luther. The company, it became known the other day, has been engaged by Lutheran Church Productions, Inc., to make a dramatic feature covering the religious leader's history from the time he became a monk in 1505 to the 1530 Augsburg Confession.

President Truman may not have intended to suggest any comparison between United States Presidents and dictators ruling over less fortunate countries, but he succeeded in doing just this in his press conference on Thursday. It was not one of Mr. Truman's best days.
OPERA in English in an unprecedented scale will be a distinguishing characteristic of the Metropolitan repertory next season.

POPULARLY known as bleeding heart, dicentras are a good investment for any garden. They take care of themselves, are hardy, long lived and send forth sprays of dainty flowers. Bleeding heart may be planted in early spring or fall, in either a sunny perennial border or in a half-shaded location.

ALBANY, April 26 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the Richmond Hill Savings Bank, 115-20 Jamaica Avenue, Richmond Hill, has received approval for a temporary change in the location of its branch office from the southwest corner of Hillside Avenue and 256th Street to 249-20 Hillside Avenue, Queens.
PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -- Two visitors from Massachusetts, which is rarely represented here, captured the major schoolboy honors today at the rain-splashed fifty-eighth annual Pennsylvania Relays.
GLADYS GOODDING, organist at Madison Square Garden and Ebbets Field, is in the interesting position of being known to countless television viewers who have never seen her in action.

THERE are some mistakes in Christopher Morley's pleasant notice of John Masefield's "So Long to Learn." W. B. Yeats never lived in "Holborn Buildings," for the sufficient reason that there is no such street or alley in London.

BALTIMORE, April 26 (AP) -- A combination of sure-footed horse and expert horseman. Pine Pep and Mike Smithwick, overcame the worst racing conditions in two decades today to retire the Maryland Hunt Challenge Cup.

Department store sales were about 7 per cent below dollar volume level of the comparable week of last year A main reason lay in statistical comparison with a week last year, in which an extra bulge of buying appeared on high-value items.

The Weather Bureau, the Army Engineers and the Geological Survey are actively engaged along the Missouri River in obtaining a true record of water discharge and in determining the relation of river height to quantity of water. If floods are to be accurately forecast, the determination of discharge is vitally important because the predicted rate of discharge must be translated into stage or flood height.

LUXEMBOURG, April 26 -- The Schuman plan for pooling the steel and coal production of six European countries is scheduled to come up for discussion at the beginning of May in the Chamber of Deputies of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg.

NEWARK, Del. WHEN the nation needs Army tanks -- as it does now quite pressingly -- it is used to turning to a very small group of men, probably numbering less than twenty, who are top specialists in this complicated field. In peacetime these men build automobiles or locomotives and their centers of operation are such famous cities as Detroit, Cleveland and Schenectady.

Since March 6 the breakfast routines of thousands of Brooklyn families have been interrupted by the early visits of traveling journeymen new to the local scene. They are among the 3,000 mechanics converting nearly 1,000,000 appliances of Brooklyn Union Gas Company customers from manufactured to natural gas.

Tides have turned. The sport of speedboating, which has had so many bickerings, rumpuses, defections and divorces, especially during the past year, now has an instance of a happy, amicable marriage between two warring factions. There is sweetness and light again.

MILWAUKEE, April 26 (UP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers, newly crowned champions of the pro basketball world, picked big Clyde Lovellette at the National Basketball Association draft meeting tonight despite his protests that he'd rather play elsewhere.

THE A. W. MELLON Educational and Charitable Trust has put up a whopping sum to finance an international festival of contemporary music in Pittsburgh this fall. It will be held in conjunction with the International Art Exhibit of the Carnegie Institute and there is hope that, like that famous art show, it will become a biennial affair.

WHETHER a fence is being put up for practical reasons or purely decorative purposes, it provides plenty of space on which to grow certain plants. And since the type of fencing often sets the pace for the kind of plants to be used on or near it, some thought should be given to this factor before the fence is selected.

While high-level shipping activity, stimulated by the war in Korea and aid shipments to Europe, resulted in increased use last year of the over-all facilities of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, fewer seamen had need of its hotel service.

LIMA, Peru -- The Fourth Inter-American Tourism Conference ended here last week its eight-day round of committee and general meetings with a sizable record of achievement. Out of the eighty-nine resolutions submitted by five committees, the conference passed seventy - one.

AT the top of the finely specialized occupation of Eastern assistant motion picture director is George Ackerson, a six-foot one-inch, 200-pound veteran who has been practicing his individualized vocation in and around New York for the past thirty years.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- The National Geographic Society entered a field of long-standing dispute and confusion today by giving exact boundaries to the Near East, the Middle East and the Far East.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The State Department reported tonight that it would broadcast six Russian "slave labor" songs around the world on May Day, next Thursday.

Beaten a year ago by Yale by a tenth of a second, Pennsylvania led home the Elis by eight-tenths of a second yesterday in another exciting Blackwell Cup rowing race on the Harlem. Columbia came in third.

THE great symphonies of Haydn can be conducted in a wide variety of styles, as is evidenced by a number of recent recordings. Most of the readings are good, and which the hearer will prefer is likely to be a matter of individual taste.
The long-standing intergovernmental squabble on shipping subsidies enters a new phase this week under the scrutiny of a special committee of the House of Representatives.

THE songbirds might all have been brooded and hatched in the human heart. They are typical of its highest aspirations, and nearly the whole gamut of human passion and emotion is expressed more or less fully in their varied songs.

AS an extension of its recently completed "Inside Our Schools" series, WNBT plans to examine the work of the music departments of five and possibly six of New York City's High Schools on successive Saturday afternoons from 12 noon to 1 o'clock beginning this week.

AT 12:01 A.M. Thursday an airplane will (as the aviation writers like to say) roar down the runway at Idlewild International Airport and soar off into the night carrying the first load of air-coach passengers ever to fly to Europe.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., April 26 -- Raymond Walsh of Springfield finished with a total of six blue ribbons as the two-day horse show of the Trail Club of Essex County ended tonight. Walsh, who never before had captured a first prize, took two firsts last night and added four in the afternoon and evening sessions today.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 26 (UP) -- Temperamental Art Larsen of San Francisco, the defender, ousted top-seeded Vic Seixas in a five-set semi-final in the River Oaks invitation tennis tournament today, finding time between his expert lob shots to scold news photographers and lecture the noisy gallery.
THIS is one of those fat, old-fashioned novels one can snuggle up to, whose portly covers promise hours of cozy reading, with a story you can get your teeth into and a cast you can live with.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that the nation had fewer but larger farms than in 1920.

LANSING, Mich., April 26 -- The State Legislature will meet in special session Thursday to consider emergency legislation in connection with the five-day mutiny of 171 convicts at the Southern Michigan Prison at Jackson.

BALLET THEATRE is making history as the first ballet company to appear as the stage show of a movie theatre. It is performing four times a day at the Warner, along with an Errol Flynn picture, presenting the high spots of '"Princess Aurora" and all of "Rodeo."
Cumulative voting for directors, long the bane of corporate management, is forcing its way to the forefront under the guidance of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The steel industry turned back the pages of history more than 700 years in search of arguments to support its court fight against Government seizure of the steel mills.

Firemen were called to the Columbia University campus at 6:41 A. M. yesterday to extinguish a fire in a trash storage room in Low Memorial Library. The university said it suffered $100 damages, caused mostly by water.

THE author of the recently published novel, "Shiloh," is an attractive, tough-minded fellow of 35. Shelby Foote is his name and his grandfather fought at Shiloh. He himself was born and raised in Greenville, Miss., and attended the University of North Carolina.

The annual Olga Samaroff Memorial Concert under the auspices of the Olga Samaroff Foundation, Inc., will be held on May 8 at the Town Hall. Mrs. Theodore Steinway heads the executive committee for the event, proceeds from which will be used to provide assistance to talented young pianists through grants-in-aid for living expenses and extra-curricular cultural activities.

THOUGH economists have written thousands of books for each other and for their students, few have attempted the difficult task of writing basic economic theory for the intelligent layman. This has created some controversy.

TOTALITARIAN states of Left and Right alike have agreed consistently on at least one tenet: that the detective story is a revolting and even dangerous product of decadent bourgeois societies. And many decadent bourgeois critics, particularly Howard Haycraft and this reviewer, have pointed out why the whodunit can flourish only in a free society: because the identity of the murderer must be important, as a matter of absolute justice, to both detective and reader.

Leaders of a particular industry are not necessarily born to the business. Take Joseph B. Hall for instance. He was a Chicago real estate man in the late Twenties when he began looking beyond the immediate needs and problems of his business.

In Panmunjom last week the United Nations ran smack up against the possibility that no agreement would be reached on the key armistice issue -- exchange of prisoners. This possibility arose when the Communists learned that nearly half the prisoners in U. N. hands opposed repatriation to China or North Korea.
CHICAGO, April 26 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States today set forth its 1952 policies, aimed chief at what it called "increasing government encroachment" into fields traditionally belonging to private enterprise.

A man who joined in the chase of a hold-up suspect through Times Square crowds early this morning was shot by the thug, who had failed in an attempt to hold up the box office of the Victory Theatre, 209 West Forty-second Street.

" MY days of dissipation and absurdity are past. I am now pursuing the road to propriety." So Boswell wrote to his friend Temple from Utrecht in April, 1764. "I am forming into a character which may do honour to the ancient family which I am born to represent."

The past fortnight has produced an exciting number of scientific events. At the Yucca Flats in Nevada this week, scientists unleashed the sixteenth atomic explosion in the United States. Earlier in New York, at a meeting of the American Association of Immunologists, a great step forward in the eventual development of a vaccine against poliomyelitis was announced.

Events tonight: Adolphe Frezin, cellist, Town Hall, 8:30 o'clock; Betty June Cooper, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30 o'clock; Schneider Quartet, Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A.., 8:40; Springtime Serenade, benefit concert for the Dalcroze School of Music. Waldorf-Astoria, 8:45; Janice Gerton, contralto, Little Theatre, West Side Y. M. C. A., 8:30.
NORFOLK, Va., April 27 (AP) -- Atlantic First Headquarters released tonight the following list of sixty-one survivors, with their serial numbers and ranks, of the destroyer-minesweeper Hobson:

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 27 -The Venezuelan labor delegation to the current American conference of the International Labor Organization at Quitandinha, near here, is expected to find itself in difficulties, when its members go home, for their pledge to fight for the workers' freedom in Venezuela.

Two world premieres marked the conclusion of the two-day Contemporary American Music Festival of the Air, sponsored jointly by Columbia University and the Columbia Broadcasting System. Alexei Haieff's Piano Concerto and Roger Goeb's Third Symphony were broadcast yesterday afternoon, over a coast-to-coast hookup, on an hour-long program starting at 3 o'clock.

SAIGON, Indo-China, April 27 -The Vietnamese National Army will soon form its first regimental combat team, Gen. Nguyen Van Hinh, the army's new commanding general, revealed today. The combat team, or mobile group in French Army parlance, will operate in the main Tongking theatre of the Indo-China war.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 27 -- Last year Sweden, some of the Arab states, and certain neutralist circles in Western Europe informally asked Switzerland to explain the theory and practice of neutrality. They discovered the Swiss technique rather difficult to emulate.

TOKYO, Monday, April 28 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida, in a message on the eve of Japanese independence today, warned the newly sovereign nation against Communist designs to "conquer the world through insidious propaganda and infiltration, and by force."

PARK RIDGE, N. J., April 27 -- Erected in part by the labor of members, the new building of the First Congregational Church here was dedicated today. The Rev. Dr. Stanley U. North, former minister of the church and now general secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the Congregational Church, made the dedicatory address.
ALBANY, April 27 -- State Comptroller J. Raymond McGovern announced today that $62,720,000 worth of housing bonds will be sold by the state May 6.

MONTEREY, Calif., April 27 -- The Monterey Drama Festival wound up a week-long run here today under the auspices of the American National Theatre and Academy, and the general consensus marked it a successful spur to the little theatre movement in California.
Denim, that strong, sturdy cotton material that started out as a utility fabric and later crept into the sportswear field, emerges this season as a high-fashion fabric.

During the past year -- marked by continuation of the war in Korea and a freak winter at sea -- more merchant seamen than ever before turned to the Seamen's Church Institute, at 25 South Street, New York 4, for the facilities provided by this "shore home." The Institute provided for every conceivable need for the seafarers, who stem from every part of the world and represent all races and faiths.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A cut of $1,000,000,000 in foreign aid appeared likely tonight as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee was summoned to vote tomorrow on the amount to be authorized for the Mutual Security Program for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

The 100th anniversary of the arrival in this country of the Passionist Fathers, a Roman Catholic religious order, was commemorated yesterday morning at the Passionist Monastery of the Immaculate Conception at 86-45 Edgerton Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens, with 700 persons attending.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 27 (AP) -- Amid glittering trappings and with pomp and ceremony, Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi opened Iran's seventeenth Majlis (Parliament) today with a plea for greater social justice and equality. The legislators then recessed until May 8

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, chairman of the Senate preparedness subcommittee, declared today that reservists -- including the fourteen Air Force "stay-down" fliers -- "have been treated very unfairly."
No right-minded American can accept with equanimity the seizure of the steel industry by the President.

TOKYO, Monday, April 28 -- The Communist Command in Korea used the period of the armistice negotiations to make a substantial increase in its armies, building up a ground force of more than three quarters of a million men, well armed and behind powerful fortifications, and an air strength of more than 1,500 aircraft based in Manchuria, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's headquarters said yesterday.

The national administrative committee of the American Jewish Congress unanimously went on record yesterday in expressing "deepest concern" over the passage of the Walter omnibus immigration bill by Congress. It called upon the Senate to defeat the companion measure, the McCarran bill.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 27 -- Asserting that a labor movement of the United States type has no appeal to Bolivian workers, this country's new Minister of Labor, German Butron, said Bolivian unions "won't copy anyone in solving the problems of the working class."

HARRY Zaratzian, violist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, who was the guiding spirit in a program of Armenian chamber music last season, gave his first solo recital in this city yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 27 -- Peg's Pride, from Teddy Gussenhoven's Hutchinson Stable of Closter, N. J., retired the Wee-3 Challenge Trophy with a third straight leg by winning the open jumper championship, which capped two long days of judging tonight in the Boulder Brook Club's spring horse show.

A 35-year-old man, the victim of a Times Square shooting that followed an attempt by two men to hold up a film theatre soon after Saturday midnight, was in a critical condition last night in St. Clare's Hospital. His alleged assailant was held in $20,000 bail on charges of felonious assault, robbery and violation of the Sullivan Law.

THE NEW YORK TIMES and Lucy Freeman should be thanked, certainly appreciated by the community and particularly by parents, for having boldly and baldly posed the problem of juvenile delinquency in our nation. Juvenile delinquency is more than a problem. It is a menace.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -- The two Navy ships that collided in the Atlantic last night both had distinguished records in World War II and had survived some of the bitterest sea fighting in history.

ROME, April 27 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi, speaking in Naples today, declared himself confident that the Christian Democratic party and its allies would issue victorious from the provincial and municipal elections that are to be held on May 25 in central and southern Italy.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- A rapid increase in bank embezzlements has Federal officials gravely concerned.

The disclosure by Public Works Commissioner Zurmuhlen that he has asked the Board of Estimate to let him hire David B. Steinman, engineer, to make an $80,000 structural study of the Manhattan Bridge is further evidence of the constant attention that our city's facilities, particularly those built many years ago, need to keep them abreast of the demands constantly being made upon them.

The Guggenheim Memorial Concerts, featuring the Goldman Band, will open in Central Park on Wednesday evening, June 18, and continue for eight weeks. Programs will be given on Sunday, Monday, Wednesday and Friday nights in Central Park and on Thursday and Saturday nights in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

There is little sign of a let-up in the number of art shows in the galleries, although May is almost here. The biggest exhibition of the week is the sixtieth annual showing of the National Association of Women Artists, which will open on Saturday at the National Academy Galleries.
" Apathy masquerading in the guise of tolerance" was criticized yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken in his sermon at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122nd Street.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, called today for a change in the Senate rule that another Senator used last week to make him sit down during a hot debate on President Truman's steel seizure.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., April 27 -- A California Labrador retriever competing in the east for the first time won the open all-age stake that was the main event of the Labrador Retriever Club's spring trials today. He was F. T. Ch. Slo-Poke Smokey of Dairy Hill, a 5-year-old dog owned and handled by Andrieus A. Jones of San Mateo.

The only real question before the world today "is not whether we will have world government but whether we will have it before Western civilization is destroyed," Donald Harrington, minister of the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, declared yesterday.

HOUSTON, April 27 (UP) -- Gardner Mulloy plucked another tennis plum today by downing tenacious Art Larsen in the final of the River Oaks invitation tournament. The 39-year-old Miami star then teamed with Dick Savitt of Orange, N. J., for the doubles championship.
The city's Traffic Department is dwindling steadily in importance and prestige and is operating with a staff so short that it cannot keep up with routine tasks.

MILAN, Italy, April 27 -- Leaving all previous records far behind, the Thirtieth Milan Samples Fair of 1952 has attracted far more exhibitors and buyers from other countries than any of its predecessors or any other international trade fair.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The rescue operations following the sinking of the Hobson were hampered by the dark, and by foul weather.
PRINCETON, April 27 -- Dr. Julian P. Boyd, librarian of Princeton University since 1940 and editor of "The Papers of Thomas Jefferson," has been appointed a professor in the department of history.

Cab Calloway, bandleader, who has been dubbed "King of Hi De Ho," is thinking of portraying Sportin' Life in the forthcoming Blevins Davis-Robert Breen revival of "Porgy and Bess," according to a reliable source. The report could not be verified yesterday.

Creditors seeking to build cash reserves for March 15 income tax payments showed a tendency to ignore discounts during the first quarter, according to a survey just completed by the Credit Research Foundation of the National Association of Credit Men.

Plans for the erection of a six-story apartment building to house thirty-six families in the Greenwich Village section of Manhattan have been announced by a client of Nathan, Mannheimer, Asche Winer, attorneys, who has purchased for the purpose the property at 79 Bedford Street, 31 Commerce Street and 69 Barrow Street.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 27 (AP) -- The Torch Commando warned Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan tonight it would meet "action with action" if his Nationalist regime moved against it or illegally tampered with the Union's Constitution.

DETROIT, April 27 (UP) -- An error by center fielder Harry Simpson, whose single deprived Art Houtteman of a no-hitter yesterday, enabled the Detroit Tigers to score an unearned run in the first inning today and defeat the Cleveland Indians, 1 -- 0.
The New York City Opera Company last night ended its six-week 1952 spring season with a performance of "La Boheme" at the City Center.
Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio held a slight margin last night over General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in their contest for delegates to the Republican Presidential nominating convention.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 27 -- United States-Yugoslav relations are expected to go through a delicate period in the coming months. A number of problems have arisen that will require that the Americans state their position in the clearest possible terms.

TAIPEI, April 27 (Reuters) -- Final agreement on a peace treaty between Nationalist China and Japan was reached at a full-dress meeting of the delegations lasting an hour. The final touches were put to the treaty and to supplementary documents agreed on during the negotiations.

The whole elaborate edifice the Western Powers have built up to "contain" Germany is in danger of collapse. That is not too exaggerated a view of the flare-up of fear and suspicion in France and Germany that threatens to delay action to integrate the Bonn Republic into the Western community.

The Christian church is relevant to our time, Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan of the New York Protestant Episcopal Diocese declared yesterday afternoon at the Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, at a celebration of its 100th anniversary. The congregation numbered 800.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Japanese peace treaty, which comes into effect tomorrow, was hailed today as a wise settlement and criticized as a possible source of future peril to the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period April 19 to 25 are given in the appended tabulation:

CINCINNATI, April 27 (AP) -- The surprising Cincinnati Reds took undisputed possession of second place in the National League today when Ken Raffensberger and Frank Hiller pitched them to 8-to- 2 and 1-to-0 victories over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
ROME, April 27 (AP) -- Fascism's followers massed 50,000 strong in the heart of Rome today to jeer at democracy and communism in a scene unduplicated since the Allied armies overthrew Mussolini.

While parishioners attended 8 A. M. mass at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church, 627 East 187th Street, the Bronx, yesterday, an unemployed young man threatened to jump from the church steeple but was dissuaded after an hour by taunts as to his courage.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- There's nothing wrong with the Yankees that Joe DiMaggio couldn't cure -- if he were available.
BOSTON, April 27 (AP) -- Some 400 persons attended a meeting of the American National Theatre and Academy today for the purpose of bringing New England -- to be known as Region 15 -- into the group.
It was quite a day for old Lenox Hill yesterday. The hospital (incorporated in 1861)created a new position -- that of director -- and got a new director and a new superintendent.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today it made a $12,500,000 profit on its lending operations in the first nine months of the current fiscal year, compared with $11,500,000 a year ago.

A group of 600 young artists unveiled their work to the public yesterday in the Fourth Annual Art Show, arranged by the Catholic Youth Organization, at 130 East Twenty-second Street. Some of the artists were so young that they skipped into the exhibit holding their mothers' hands.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a letter from C. S. Jones of Washington Crossing, Pa., to President Truman asking about the steel seizure, and the President's reply:

GLOUCESTER, Mass., April 27 -- Sailing smartly through the drizzle with her lower sails set, the ninety-foot brigantine Yankee ended an eighteen-month cruise around the world this afternoon by arriving at the State Fish Pier on schedule.

AMSTERDAM, April 27 -- The stock market here was depressed last week by such adverse factors as the flood of personal and corporation tax assessments that led to liquidation of assets, together with less favorable reports from industry, the disappointing trend in the freight market and the irregular tone on Wall Street, which has caused selling of dollar securities.

CINCINNATI, April 27 -- Corruption in government and economic aid to foreign countries are the dominant issues of the 1952 Presidential campaign, the League of Women Voters asserted today on the eve of its national convention here.

The new Mariner class high-speed, national defense cargo ships, thirty-five of which are under construction for Government account, are to be spread around by the Maritime Administration, with consideration to all maritime unions and all steamship companies.

There is sometimes a grimly comic element in the grotesque system of cultural terror which prevails in the Soviet Union. One of them should be better known in this country, particularly among students in our institutions of higher learning.
Stanislaw Moniuszko's little-known opera, "Halka," was performed at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon to a capacity audience.

PARIS, April 27 (AP) -- Budge Patty, the experienced tennis traveler, had too much finesse for Enrique Morea of Argentina today and handily defeated the South American in the final of the international tennis championships, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1.

Samuel Zolin has been appointed vice president and treasurer of the Copper Alloy Foundry Company, Hillside, N. J. He has at one time or another handled or directed practically every operation in the plant.

A promise that firemen and other city employes "will soon be able to build for your families and for yourselves the kind of homes and the kind of life" that will engender self-respect was made yesterday by Rudolph Halley, president of the City Council.
MEDFORD, L. I., April 27 -- The North Ocean Avenue underpass on the Long Island Rail Road's main line west of here, believed to be the smallest on the railroad, soon will be history.

A two-year progress report on the Citizenship Education Project of Teachers College, Columbia University, indicated yesterday that high school students were learning good citizenship more effectively by practical experience than by formal study.

CHICAGO, April 27 (UP) -- The Chicago White Sox beat the St. Louis Browns, 7 to 6, on a fourteenth inning single by Minnie Minoso today and then held a 3 to 1 lead when the second part of the double-header was called by darkness at the end of five innings.

A squad of thirteen players, accompanied by Erno Schwarcz, manager of the American Coccer League, left Idlewild Airport by plane last night for the British Isles, where the Americans will play the Scottish All-Stars in Glasgow Wednesday and the Irish All-Stars in Dublin Friday.

Eddie Brannick has devoted most of his youth and all of his adult life to the Giants. From office boy to secretary he has served the organization through forty-six years, working with the late John McGraw, Bill Terry, Mel Ott and currently Leo Durocher.
New accoutrements for spring dining tables are displayed in a group of eleven table settings that will go on view today at Altman's.

At 9:30 this morning our state of war with Japan comes officially to an end. Our treaty of peace comes formally into effect. Thus we give outward recognition to a change that has already been largely consummated. Today is a turning point in many practical matters; it is not a turning point in ideas.

The Portuguese cargo ship Monte Brasil, which was in collision with the United States freighter Cape Martin in a dense fog on Saturday night fifteen miles off the New Jersey coast, was reported proceeding under her own power to Chester, Pa., last night despite the existence of a large hole in her No. 2 hold.

The Aluminum Company of America and subsidiaries reported yesterday sales and operating revenues of $138,726,812 for the three months ended March 31, 1952. Consolidated net income after taxes for this period was $11,749,459.

A new edition of T. S. Eliot's "Murder in the Cathedral" will be published by Harcourt, Brace on May 5. An expanded and illustrated film edition of the verse drama, it will contain forty-eight pages of stills from the movie which opened in New York a month ago, sixty-nine black-and-white drawings and six pages of color.

BERLIN, April 27 -- As the parting shot of its three-day congress here, the Federation of Refugee Journalists From Eastern Europe broadcast today an appeal declaring that a "policy of liberation" was the only way to save the world from communism.

Home construction by private builders showed a gain in March of 1 per cent in this state after fourteen consecutive months of decline, State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman reported yesterday. Permits were issued last month for 6,542 new dwelling units, compared with 6,483 in March of last year.

The four talented young singers who appeared late yesterday after noon at Town Hall as Aristo Artists lived up to the standards of their predecessors, who have been presented under the same title in annual programs by George Leyden Colledge, with Alice Wightman as the joint accompanist.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The second of the three recent air disasters that brought death and fear to the residents of Elizabeth, N. J., was listed officially today as a mystery that had defied three months of intensive investigation.

Undoubtedly the worst thing about staying up too late at night is that the night invariably is followed by the next day. This is a truly bleak affair, reminiscent of a rainy week-end at a seaside resort or the headquarters of the loser on the day which follows the November elections.

LONDON, April 27 -- Publication of the Government's Economic Survey for 1952 and launching of the British Electricity Loan of 150,000,000, which is a Government operation to finance the nationalized electricity industry, produced little effect last week on the stock market here.

One more year without remedial action against corrupt conditions may spell the doom of the Port of New York, the Rev. John M. Corridan told staff members of the State Workmen's Compensation Board yesterday.

A tract of fifty-five acres in Morris Plains, N. J., has been sold by Sun-Valley, Inc., to Wedgewood Acres, Inc., which will continue the development of the property on which several houses had been built by the seller. George Mintz Co., brokers in the transaction, will act as sales agent for the property.
TAIPEI, Formosa, April 27 -- A separate treaty of peace between Japan and Nationalist China was completed tonight. It will be signed at a ceremony here tomorrow afternoon.

Confidence that Harry Gross would keep his promise to testify at the departmental trial of eighteen policemen beginning Wednesday was expressed yesterday by Assistant Corporation Counsel Victor J. Herwitz.

TAMPA, Fla., April 27 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia said today that if he received the Democratic Presidential nomination and the national party platform recommended compulsory fair employment practices legislation, then he would "declare flatly that I am not bound by any such proposal."

MARTINSBURG, W. Va., April 27 -- What was once scrub farmland and rolling hills in the northern end of this county is rapidly being converted by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. into what will be, a year from now, a bustling industry.

JIM MUTRIE was an impressive figure of a man. He wore a top hat and a frock coat. A majestic handle-bar mustache added to his grandeur. He sported a cane and rode in hansom cabs. This was 1885 and Mutrie was the manager of a professional baseball team in the National League which was known as "the New Yorks."
Ten new films, including importations from England and France, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
Have you ever seen blind children happy at play? It is truly a wonderful and heart-warming sight.
CLINTON, Iowa, April 27 (UP) -- The Mississippi River flood crest rolled past Clinton today, backing up water in sewers over a 125-block area.

Government seizure of private property is a "willful violation of the commandment 'Thou shalt not steal'," the Rev. Dr. Harold C. DeWindt said yesterday morning in his sermon at the West-Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.
OTTAWA, April 27 -- Queen Juliana of the Netherlands and her husband, Prince Bernhard, left for home tonight in a Dutch airlines plane after a four-week tour of the United States and Canada.
Davis Catterall, cotton textile converters and manufacturers of handkerchiefs, tenth floor in 1410 Broadway, southeast corner of Thirty-ninth St -- H. Clayton Smith Co, brokers.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Committee on the Present Danger told Congress today that an effective Mutual Security Program would save the nation $12,000,000,000 in defense expenditures in two years but that administrative changes were needed to get the most from this country's aid dollars.
ST. LOUIS, April 27 (UP) -- Frankie Baumholtz smashed a three-run double in the eighth inning today to propel the Cubs to a 6-to-3 victory over the Cardinals.

A. F. Klaveness Co., Norwegian shipowners and operators, have constructed twelve vessels in the last six years in an effort to recoup their war losses and are building five more. Four of the craft are cargo-passenger ships and the fifth is a tanker.

Francis Poulenc's "Stabat Mater" received its American premiere last night when Robert Shaw conducted it at Carnegie Hall in the sixth concert of his series devoted to choral masterworks. He performed the fine work with the same forces that he has led in other programs of the series, the Collegiate Chorale, the Robert Shaw Chorale and the R. C. A. Victor Symphony.
LOS ANGELES, April 27 -- With experts from Yugoslavia, Spain and Canada competing, the Hollywood international invitation chess tournament was started here today.

ODESSA, Tex., April 27 (UP) -- The father and brothers of a critically injured woman were arrested today when they tried to prevent a doctor from giving her a blood transfusion that she had requested.
ROME, April 27 -- American Communists were under secret orders in 1936 to infiltrate the Roman Catholic priesthood, Bishop Fulton J. Sheen said today.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Defense planners said today they were going ahead with the program of releasing more steel for construction, automobiles and other consumer goods, but added they were keeping a close watch on the steel crisis.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, April 28 (AP) -- Grenade-hurling Communist soldiers, supported by a heavy mortar barrage, stormed Allied positions on the central front early today, but failed to budge United Nations troops. The attack came northeast of Kumhwa.

The American Radio Relay League, organization of amateur radio operators, has taken a wise and constructive step by bringing out into the open the possibility of interference with television reception when "hams" begin transmitting on their new band of 21 megacycles on Thursday.

Senator Estes Kefauver, candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, said last night that the world needed intelligent leadership and looked to the United States for it but that we could not base that leadership solely on military strength.

A project to encourage private investment for economic rehabilitation and development of the Highlands of Scotland was announced here over the week-end, with support and endorsement of prominent business leaders.

WASHINGTON CROSSING, Pa., April 27 -- The C. S. Jones, whose letter to President Truman on the steel seizure was answered by the President today, identified himself tonight as Charles S. (Casey) Jones, World War I aviator and pioneer in the aeronautics industry.

PARIS, April 27 -- Officials declined to issue comparative tabulations to interpret the results of the preliminary Senatorial elections, which were held today in half the departments of France and the overseas territories.

Rowing under miserable conditions, the New York Athletic Club A crew captured the feature race in 7:06.6 at the regatta conducted by the Winged Foot Club in Pelham Bay Lagoon off Travers Island yesterday.

Perhaps the reason the economist stands no higher than he does today is that there is always some courageous (pig-headed) and inspired (lucky) unbeliever to prove him wrong. There is plenty of evidence for this thesis in two books* on this desk today.
TRENTON, April 27 -- The effectiveness of New Jersey's civil defense preparedness will be tested on an unannounced day and hour this week, with public participation on a scale never before attempted.

Cooper Union has awarded Irving Rossi Fellowships in finance and industrial management to two members of the 1952 graduating class, Albert J. Nash and George Tishkewitz. They are civil engineering students.
A cobalt teletherapy machine for the treatment of cancer will be installed in Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx.

The eight-week feud between Joseph P. Ryan, lifetime president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., and Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, Brooklyn dock boss, appeared to be approaching a crisis yesterday after a mass meeting Saturday night at which 2,000 Anastasia followers threatened to bolt the union.

It was Charles F. Murphy, the leader of Tammany Hall, who said it, and the time was the late summer of 1913. The papers had just published a story that had shaken the political world to its foundations -- the story of the impeachment of New York's Governor, William Sulzer.

HADERA, Israel, April 27 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion tugged at the lever of a tire press in the pilot plant of the unfinished Alliance Tire and Rubber Company factory here this afternoon. A few minutes later he received the result of his labors -- the first rubber tire known to have been made in Israel.

PITTSBURGH, April 27 -- The steel operating rate last week advanced 3 1/2 points to 100.5 per cent. That rate completed the rebound to a level close to that which prevailed before seizure of the steel industry. It was believed probable that the rate will fluctuate between 100 per cent and 102 per cent.
LONDON, April 27 (UP) -- Britain will have to look to home production and Scandinavia for any increase in her supply of newsprint, according to a correspondent of the Financial Times.
The Electric Bond and Share Company proposes to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a plan to achieve final compliance with the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
A plastic window shade and equipment for hanging draperies are some of the new accessories for the window now available here.

New York patriotic organizations observed yesterday the 130th anniversary of the birth of Gen. Ulysses S. Grant with a parade, oratory and the placing of wreaths at his tomb at Riverside Drive and 123d Street.

Burnt biscuits and bad coffee can quickly make a man regret his "I do's." This was the sage warning given by Mrs. Lily Haxworth Wallace to the 1952 crop of June brides. Culinary artist and teacher for more than half a century, Mrs. Wallace urges every girl with a middle-aisle gleam in her eyes to learn how to cook.

In its first change of ownership in more than twenty-five years, the apartment house for forty-eight families on plot 80 by 140 feet at 974 Sheridan Avenue, corner of East 164th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Edward C. Baumert and family to the Daat Realty Corporation for investment.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -- Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, said today that Russia had about 20,000 front-line combat planes and an equal number in reserve, while the United States had only 13,000 to 15,000 in each category.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 26 -- Eighteen young executives who show unusual promise for industrial leadership have been awarded Alfred P. Sloan fellowships, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced today. The winners, selected in a nation-wide competition, will receive grants up to $3,720 for one year of study of the economic, social and management problems of industrial administration.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 -- Christianity was warned here tonight against seeking "power and favor" through governmental means.

The United States Department of Agriculture has centralized its local and regional Production and Marketing Administration offices at 139 Centre Street. The new telephone number for all sections is REctor 2-3100.
Returned from his vacation, Mayor Impellitteri has one appointment coming up that is fraught with public interest. The term of James Marshall on the Board of Education is expiring.

Yesterday's rain was as gentle and unstrained as the quality of mercy, but if it was twice blessed, both of these blessings probably came from the sea lions in their quadrangular retreat at the Central Park Zoo. It was not the kind of rain to get anyone really angry, but it did have an insinuating persistence.

Under excellent conditions, records were smashed right and left in the Drake Relays last week-end, but the Penn Relays at Philadelphia fell victim to the atrocious weather that swept through the East and made outstanding performances on the cinders almost out of the question.

The Gotham Orchestra, conducted by Milton Rosenstock, was heard last night in Town Hall. As generally the case, its enterprising conductor selected an off-the-path program, with only one relatively familiar work -- Franck's Symphonic Variations, played by Doris Frerichs.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Fairly large investment buying developed in wheat and other grains late last week following sharp declines on heavy long liquidation. This buying stimulated considerable short profit-taking, making for a more two-sided market.

RICHMOND, Calif., April 27 (UP) -- Patty Berg of Minneapolis, who set a world record of 64 for eighteen holes yesterday, took ten strokes more for the same distance today, but retained her 36-hole lead in the $3,000 Richmond Women's Open Golf tournament.

JACKSON, Mich., April 27 -- Vernon B. Fox, the prison psychologist who negotiated the end of a five-day mutiny of 171 convicts here last Thursday, was out of his job today as assistant deputy warden of the Southern Michigan Prison.

A Brooklyn church said to be a century old is among four buildings acquired recently by the Navy Yard District Boys Club, it was announced yesterday. The church is reported to have housed the first Methodist congregation in the borough.
TOKYO, Monday, April 28 (AP) -Eighth Army tactical summary 42, for Sunday's operations:

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -- Government mediators held out hope today for last-minute settlement of the national oil dispute as a coalition of unions mapped plans for an industry-wide strike Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The National Labor-Management Council on Foreign Trade Policy today charged that the executive branch of the Federal Government, seeking to break down tariff restrictions between the United States and its European Allies, was encroaching on powers of Congress.

NEW DELHI, India, April 27 -- Indian Army troops have undertaken a survey of the strategic Himalayan passes that connect the neighboring kingdom of Nepal with Communist-occupied Tibet, an official source revealed today.

Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday that he would ask the Board of Estimate soon for a supplementary appropriation of $775,000 to enable his office to increase and expedite the collection of special city taxes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 27 -- "Julius Caesar," under consideration at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer since 1949, will be put before the cameras this summer with John Houseman in charge as producer of the Shakespearean drama.
BONN, Germany, April 27 (AP) -- Socialists of West Germany, Britain and France today urged the Western Big Three to enter immediate talks with the Russians over Germany's future.
Fourteen years ago, a group of this city's voluntary hospitals, health and welfare agencies rep resenting service to all races, creeds and boroughs, banded together.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President Truman said today the powers of the President were derived from, and limited by, the Constitution, but he felt the Constitution did not require him to "endanger our national safety by letting all the steel mills shut down in this critical time."

The appointment of the Trylon Realty Company as renting agent for the new shopping center under construction at Hillside and Braddock Avenues in the Bell Park Manor garden apartment development in Bellerose, Queens, has been announced by Sam Minskoff Sons, Inc., builders and owners.

WOODBURY, Conn., April 27 -- A warning that the church must assert itself in combating present-day "decay in public and private morals" was sounded here today by the Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Connecticut in opening the diocese's $1,000,000 building expansion campaign.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The destroyer - minesweeper Hobson sank after colliding with the aircraft carrier Wasp last night, and the Navy announced late today that 176 men were missing.

A charge that the city, in applying for a new commercial television channel here, may be engaged in "a selfish speculation" to get another channel and thus enhance the value of the Municipal Broadcasting System "for possible future sale," was voiced yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Following are excerpts from the opposing briefs in the steel seizure case before the United States District Court of the District of Columbia:

No sermon from any pulpit can "carve the likeness of Christ" on other souls as deeply as an individual life that is truly Christian, the Rev. Edward M. Connors of the St. Patrick's Cathedral staff declared at solemn mass there yesterday. Cardinal Spellman presided.

LONDON, April 27 -- A blazing United States F-84 Thunderjet hurtled from the sky over the placid village of St. Peter's in Southeast England today and crashed on a little bank building in the main street.

Dr. Frank Graham, United Nations negotiator in the Kashmir dispute, surely deserves some sort of medal for a record in persistent mediation. The patience of the East is an expected phenomenon, but nobody could have expected an ex-Senator from North Carolina to go on talking in circles month after month, making infinitesimal progress, journeying back and forth between India and U. N. headquarters, and then cheerfully to suggest still another try.

Barring an unexpected wave of selling of British sterling last Tuesday, originating in London, the end result of the week's business was a fractional hardening of the pound in moderately active trading.

THE second volume of the Boswell papers, "Boswell in Holland 1763-1764,"* is published today. The news about it, unfortunately, is that it cannot compare in interest with the first, "Boswell's London Journal 1762-1763. There are two reasons for this. The first and more important is that most of Boswell's journal for the time covered in this second volume is lost.
MILWAUKEE, April 28 (UP) -- The maxim that American Bowling Congress champions seldom repeat held true today when three failed to retain their crowns in the pin marathon.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 28 -- A Congress of Industrial Organizations leader told members of a barbers' union today that they should put in a good word for labor when they chat with customers.

LONDON, April 28 -- Announcement that General Ridgway would be General Eisenhower's successor as Supreme Commander of Allied Forces in Europe will be well received in Britain. The fact that Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther is to remain in the same post he held under General Eisenhower will go far toward allaying such fears as existed about a dual break in the continuity of command both in Europe and in the Far East.
RICHMOND, Calif., April 28 (UP) Patty Berg, firing an even-par 72, won the $3,000 Richmond women's open golf tournament today by four strokes with a 54-hole total of 210.

LONDON, April 28 (Canadian Press) -- Continental Oil Company of Delaware and Hudson's Bay Company today announced new steps concerning exploration and development of the Hudson's Bay Company's oil and gas acreage. Their announcement said:

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Following are texts of statements by President Truman, Japanese Premier Shigeru Yoshida and John Foster Dulles read today at ceremonies bringing into force the Japanese peace and security treaties. Mr. Truman's statement was read by Secretary of State Dean Acheson, and Premier Yoshida's by Ryuji Takeuchi, Japanese diplomatic representative here:

Domestic economic problems beset the stock market yesterday with greater intensity than in recent months. The argument over the validity of the steel industry seizure by the Government remained the greatest drag on any show of enthusiasm. The threatened tie-up in the oil industry added to the confused state of mind.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development plans to borrow $50,000,000 on long-term bonds in the American market in mid-May and is going to sell the issue through a negotiated underwriting. Announcement of the bank's plans was made here yesterday by Eugene R. Black, president.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today a $1,000,000,000 cut "across the board" in the Administration's $7,900 000,000 Mutual Security Authorization Bill. It cut all money ceilings in the measure by 12.66 per cent. The vote was 9 to 3.

Making his way between horses in the stretch, Teaneck Flash of the Spring Hill Farm gained the victory in the Springboard at the Jamaica Race Track yesterday. A getaway-day crowd of 21,985 saw the 4-year-old son of Selalbeda respond to Jackey Albert Widman's commands to run away from four others in the six-furlong dash, taking first place by three and a half lengths.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The 27,100-ton aircraft carrier Wasp was coming home tonight with sixty-one survivors from the destroyer-minesweeper Hobson, which she cut in two in a mid-Atlantic collision Saturday night. Missing -- and apparently lost -- were 176 members of the Hobson's crew.

CINCINNATI, April 28 -- A meeting for all Presidential candidates to be staged Thursday by the League of Women Voters of the United States at its convention here will have six speakers on top issues, but they will not include Senator Robert Taft, it seemed certain today.

BALTIMORE, April 28 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said today that he favored giving United States aid to foreign nations because, while "many of the peoples of the world would be glad to have liberty they are more interested in their next meal."
OTTAWA, April 28 -- (Canadian Press) -- An international agreement may be one of the topics discussed at a meeting of seventeen countries here next month.

Jacques Griffe, Paris couturier who is steadily gaining fame, had the distinction of getting his early training in the atelier of the great Vionnet, where he was modeliste. He worked under Mme. Vionnet's guidance for seven years.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, reported today after a talk with President Truman on the constitutional issue raised by seizure of the steel industry that the President would "rest his case with the courts of the land."

A busy week of theatregoing gets under way tonight, when the first of four scheduled Broadway attractions makes its debut. It is "Hook 'n Ladder," described as a new farce comedy by Charles Horner and Henry Miles. It deals with a trio of salespeople bent on selling a small town much-needed fire apparatus.

CAMDEN, N. J., April 28 (UP) -- The New Jersey racing season opens tomorrow when Garden State Park launches its 25-day meeting with a field of thirteen two-year-old colts and geldings entered in the $10,000 William Penn Stakes at five furlongs.
TAIPEI, Formosa, April 28 -- After almost ten weeks of negotiation, Nationalist China and Japan signed a treaty of peace here today ending the state of war between them.

It now appears that neither President Truman nor the Government lawyers in the hearings before Judge Pine intended to say that the President is above or outside the Constitution. How could he be? The office of the President was created by the Constitution, its duties and responsibilities were specified and its limitations were clearly implied.

Sudden suspension by Chile of its system of permitting importation of numerous items without import license brought protests yesterday from exporters caught with goods unshipped or in preparation for shipment.
BOSTON, April 28 -- Three bacteriologists reported today that at least in the laboratory they had found it possible to prevent disease strains from becoming resistant to antibiotics.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- National headquarters of the Eisenhower-for-President movement has authorized a final direct primary test with Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in South Dakota's last-in-the-nation Republican primary, which is expected to draw 100,000 voters June 3.

The tenth game of the chess match between Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires ended in a draw -- the third of the series -- after twenty-nine moves, according to a report from Mexico City yesterday.
Allied Chemical Dye Corporation had a net income of $9,814,664, after all charges, including $13,280,029 for taxes, the March quarter report announced yesterday.

Directors of Sears, Roebuck Co. at their meeting here yesterday elected several key executives and elevated Theodore V. Houser to the new post of vice chairman of the board of directors. Mr. Houser, vice president in charge of merchandising for the mail order concern for twelve years, will share in policy and administrative matters heretofore handled by Gen. R. E. Wood chairman of the board of directors, and Fowler B. McConnell, president.

Tables and chests, designed to blend in with the "Pacifica" look in decorating, make up one of the new Mansion House groups of furniture that will be on view at California House. The showroom, which deals through decorators, opens today at 45 West Thirty-third Street.

YONKERS, April 28 -- True Indiana, a 5-year-old gelding, died tonight, apparently of a heart attack, during the first race at Yonkers Raceway. Driven by Jimmy Jordan, the pacer reared out of control the first time around the paddock turn and crashed into the rail where he died.

TAMPA, Fla., April 28 -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, and two key members of his Florida campaign strategy staff jointly appealed to voters today to measure the Presidential candidacy of Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee against a "background" of what they described as left-wing sympathies and slavish following of President Truman.

Three new films will arrive in first-run theatres today. At the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse, the attraction is "The Prize," a French-made comedy with Bourvil, Jacqueline Pagnol and Mireille Perrey. Jean Boyer directed the Classic Pictures release from a script by Marcel Pagnol and the Guy de Maupassant story, "Le Rosier De Madame Husson."
John R. Inglis of the Fairview Country Club, White Plains, N.Y., was elected president of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association for the twenty-fifth time yesterday.
A conflict of "labor versus labor" seems to be moving toward a showdown in the Port of New York and as such will have important repercussions on the entire community.

BONN, Germany, April 28 -- An Allied spokesman expressed the "official hope" shared by Allied high commissioners and the Federal Government that the contractual agreement by which Western Germany is to be granted near sovereignty would be ready for signature by May 20.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, April 28 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, campaigning today in his home state for the Republican Presidential nomination, contended that national security could be purchased for $20,000,000,000 less than the projected military budget of $65,000,000,000 in 1953 and 1954.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Assistant Attorney General H. Graham Morison said today that minor children were properly included as defendants in the Government's anti-trust suit against the wealthy du Pont family.

Albert Goldman, acting Postmaster of New York since September, 1934, and Postmaster since January, 1935, announced yesterday his retirement, which under postal regulations would have been automatic next July 16, his seventieth birthday.
PARIS, April 28 -- At the midseason opening, Lanvin-Castillo propose for the Paris season the elegance of untrimmed crepe growns, simple cartwheel sailors and equally simple long gloves.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Gov. Earl Warren of California lined up against Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio on Far Eastern foreign policy issues today and condemned tactics he attributed to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

BOSTON, April 28 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio will meet on even terms tomorrow in the Massachussets Presidential preference primary, with write-in votes alone determining their popularity as prospective candidates among Republican voters.

A Chinese Communist newspaper, its president and its former managing editor were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury as part of an "international racket" involving murder, extortion and torture in which American Chinese have been mulcted of millions of dollars for Red China.

THE only angling news for the week-end comes from outside the "weather" belt. Although some trout fishermen in this area defied the elements and the resulting high, discolored waters, the results were almost uniformly negative.
PARIS, April 28 (AP) -- Text of the North Atlantic Council Communique announcing the appointment of Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway as successor to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower:

SAN JUAN, P.
