R., April 28 -- This American outpost of democracy in the Caribbean is carry-with a social consciousness, the ing on an industrial revolution thirty-fifth annual convention of the International Association of Governmental Labor Officials was told here today by Fernando Sierra Berdecia, Commissioner of Labor of Puerto Rico.
FORT WORTH, Tex., April 28 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Samuel E. Anderson, Eighth Air Force commander, has upheld the two-year court-martial sentence given to First Lieut. Verne Goodwin for refusing to fly.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The texts of a letter from Soviet Ambassdor Alexander Panyushkin and of a Soviet statement denouncing the Japanese peace treaty, which went into effect today:

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 28 -- The Marine Corps took the stage in the current atomic warfare maneuvers today, and laid pointed emphasis on the view that, from a tactical standpoint, nuclear missiles were essentially just another weapon to back up the foot soldier.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The forming constitutional crisis over the President's seizure of the steel industry will not come to a head if Mr. Truman accepts the ultimate court's decision in the controversy, as he told Senator Humphrey today that he will. And the bulk of the President's record lends assurance that his position in this respect will not change.

Lever House, on the west side of Park Avenue between Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets, will be formally opened today at ceremonies led by Mayor Impellitteri. It is something strikingly new in office-building architecture for that area, twenty-four floors of glass and stainless steel.
It seems incredible but it's true. Three million persons -- one out of every three in New York -- are served directly by the 423 agencies participating in the Greater New York Fund.

JERSEY CITY, April 28 -- Eighteen longshoremen and two women were named in an indictment handed up today by the special Hudson County grand jury investigating waterfront conditions. It charged them with conspiracy to commit a crime.

A major new effort to aid 10,000 Chinese refugee intellectuals now mostly in Hong Kong, both for their own sakes and as leaders of a future Free China, opened a public drive last night with an initial appeal for $1,000,000.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- A witness accused the Military today of getting around regulations providing that low bidders get defense contracts.

NEW DELHI, India, April 28 -- India officially terminated her technical state of war with Japan today. This step and the simultaneous opening of diplomatic relations at the embassy level constitute what leading Indians regard as an important development toward the future balance of power in Asia to neutralize possible Chinese Communist expansionism.
NORFOLK, Va., April 28 (UP) -- Text of the report of Capt. B. C. McCaffree, commanding officer of the aircraft carrier Wasp to Atlantic Fleet headquarters here:

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, declared today that the House of Representatives action to limit defense expenditures to $46,000,000,000 in the next fiscal year would have a devastating effect on the entire defense program.

Dr. Peter M. Murray, noted Negro physician, was nominated for vice president of the Medical Society of the County of New York, largest component unit of the American Medical Association, at a meeting of the society last night at the New York Academy of Medicine.
Increasing difficulty in maintaining collections of living creatures was noted yesterday in the fifty-sixth annual report of the New York Zoological Society.

James H. Sheils, Commissioner of Investigation, admitted yesterday that his department was studying "statistical information" from the Board of Transportation to find out whether there had been a wholesale disappearance of fuel oil purchased for use in city-operated buses.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 29 -- Japan became a sovereign and independent nation again last night after her unconditional surrender in the war in the Pacific and more than six years of foreign military occupation.
ABOARD U. S. S. O'HARE, in Mid-Atlantic, April 27 -- A tempestuous sea strewn with wreckage. Empty lifejackets rolling in an oil slick. The body of a chief petty officer tossing in the raging waters.
AGANA, Guam, April 28 (UP) -- Two pretty stowaways looked for jobs on this war base island today after riding 6,000 miles in a B-29.
The Greater New York Fund opened its 1952 campaign for $9,000,000 at an employes' division dinner last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The fifteenth annual appeal will run through May.

LOUISVILLE, April 28 -- Calumet Farm's Hill Gail, the colt that Eddie Arcaro calls "a big, country-runnin' dude," heads a line-up of a dozen three-year-olds entered for tomorrow's fifteenth edition of the $10,000 added Derby Trial at Churchill Downs.
Walter B. Guinan has been appointed director of sales and merchandising for Karastan, the rug and carpet division of Fieldcrest Mills, a division of Marshall Field Co., Inc.

The articles of William S. White on the situation in South Africa are excellent for the ground they cover. It seems to me, however, that Mr. White has not emphasized two basic issues that should have larger place for a better understanding of the critical tensions now convulsing that country. These issues are land and labor.

The Department of Sanitation, outraged by "the shameful disregard of the Sanitary Code" by careless New Yorkers, outlined plans yesterday for a summer-long law enforcement and educational crusade against street littering.

Gen. Matthew Bunker Ridgway, newly appointed Supreme Commander, Allied Powers in Europe, is, at 57, a lifetime soldier whose experience combines numerous combat commands with a wide range of diplomatic activity.

WHEN Steve O'Neill was operating the equivalent of a two-man pitching staff in Detroit several years ago, there was an early spring which was much like this one as far as weather was concerned. The large Mr. O'Neill was not a bit distressed.
After reading your editorial about the closing of Yenching University at Peiping, China, one cannot help but ask some questions related thereto.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today restored the authority of its thirty-one regional offices across the country to make business loans up to $50,000.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- John Foster Dulles, taking farewell of the office where he had served as a special consultant to the Secretary of State, expressed "gratification" today at the conclusion of a treaty of peace between Japan and the Chinese Nationalist Government.

LONDON, April 28 -- Investors interest in three new large capital issues together with the approaching end of the bookkeeping account effected a general marking down of share prices on the London stock market today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The effect of the $1,000,000,000 cut voted by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today in the $7,900,000,000 Mutual Security Program is shown in the following comparison of amounts proposed with those approved, by major items:

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today the Federal Government had failed to prove its charges that a nonprofit medical and hospital insurance plan sponsored by the Oregon State Medical Society had violated the Sherman Antitrust Law.

A strike by 130 laborers employed by the New York Trap Rock Company of Haverstraw, N. Y., threatened yesterday to curtail sharply highway and building construction in the state by reducing the supply of broken stone used in mixing concrete.

Two visiting Englishmen who were charged with having ridden their mounts recklessly along the bridle paths of Prospect Park, Brooklyn, were acquitted in Flatbush Magistrate's Court yesterday when the police and the magistrate showed a marked lack of equestrian knowledge. The charge was dismissed "in the interest of international friendship."

PARIS, April 28 -- Fourteen North Atlantic Treaty nations, acting through their Permanent Council established in Paris, agreed unanimously today to appoint Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Commander in Chief of the United Nations Command in Korea, to succeed General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as Supreme Allied Commander, Europe.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The constitutionality of the released time program through which New York City public school pupils may be freed from classes one hour weekly for religious instruction away from school property was upheld by the Supreme Court in a 6-to-3 ruling today.

Net income of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad for the first three months of 1952 was 122 per cent above that of a year ago, according to the report released yesterday. For the three months ended March 31, net income amounted to $5,626,509, against $2,534,657 a year earlier.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, 25 to 52 points net lower on active months than on last Friday.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would receive bids May 6 on $4,340,000 of notes dated June 2 and due Dec. 1. The proceeds from the sale will be used for the temporary financing of two state-aided projects, the Frederick Douglass Houses in Manhattan and the Marlboro Houses in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Alexander Panyushkin, the Soviet Ambassador, injected a harsh note of discord into the theme of peace and harmony that dominated the formal return of Japan to free and independent status today.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- Federal Judge Walter J. La Buy refused today to dismiss an indictment against seven town officials of Cicero charging them with violating the civil rights of a Negro who sought to move into the town, a Chicago suburb. He set May 19 for trial.

The Montana - Dakota Utilities Company, which operates a natural gas and electric public utility business in Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota and Wyoming, reported yesterday the highest quarterly operating revenues and net income, after taxes, in its history.

HANOVER, Germany, April 28 -- The increasing pressure in West Germany to smash the present restrictions on trade with Iron Curtain countries is evident here. However, many of the leaders at the Industries Fair, which opened yesterday, indicated they were being driven to seek trade with the East by political as much as by economic motives.

The heads of the five line organizations of the Police Department agreed yesterday to seek a restraining order today in Supreme Court to prevent Commissioner George P. Monaghan from proceeding with departmental re-trial of eighteen policemen accused of taking gambling graft from Harry Gross, the convicted bookmaker.

Announcement was made last night of the formation of a new "committee" in respect to one phase of China's problems. 'Unlike some of the others, this group is entirely non-political. It is not trying to influence legislation or to make policy. It will try, merely, to give some badly needed help to some distinguished and deserving human beings.

After subjecting New Yorkers to a shut-in-week-end, the almost continuous rain that fell since 8:45 P. M. Thursday ended at 1:15 P. M. yesterday. The dreary fall measured a total precipitation of 3.63 inches. While it effectively ended the danger of further forest fires that had been crackling in this and other northeastern states, urbanites drew small consolation from that thought.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The White House joined the North Atlantic Treaty Council today in a simultaneous announcement of the appointment of Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway as Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers in Europe, succeeding General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

There was an account, the other day, of a new world's record. The United Press reported it solemnly from Purmerend, the Netherlands, where Nice Klijzing puffed on a pipe for 92 minutes 18 seconds without relighting. This bettered by 4 minutes 15 seconds the previous world's record held by Paul T. Staniola of Flint, Mich.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 28 -- Federal Judge Ben Harrison today set aside a jury verdict awarding back salaries totaling $84,300 to Adrian Scott, writer-producer, in a breach of contract action against R. K. O. Radio Pictures, but upheld the jury's award of $20,000 to Ring Lardner Jr., the scenarist, in a similar suit against the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 28 (AP) -- Doris Hart of Miami, Fla., defending titleholder, and Wimbledon singles champion, scored an easy first-round victory in the British hard-court tennis championships today.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 28 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist Government was accused tonight by the United party Opposition in Parliament of having brought a large number of reserves of the national police force to the Capetown area.

MINDEN, Germany, April 28 -- After a decade of close association, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower bade farewell to the British Army as a soldier in a simple and moving ceremony here today. He praised the British as the guardians of Western civilization against close "possible attacks."
You are to be congratulated on your editorial of April 22 on the Bolivian situation. It was comforting to see that for once the blame was not placed entirely on the Bolivian people.
A new chapter of history opened in the Orient yesterday as the Japanese peace treaty came into effect.

Waterfront figures watched with unusual interest yesterday the progress of the feud between Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, Brooklyn dock boss, and Joseph P. Ryan, lifetime president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L.

Louis F. Budenz took the stand yesterday in United States District Court as the first witness in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders on charges that they had conspired to advo- and teach the overthrow of the Government of the United States by force and violence.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Supreme Court upheld today the right of Illinois to pass a "group libel" law prohibiting the publication, dissemination or display of any "lithograph, moving picture, play, drama, or sketch" that would expose citizens of any race, creed or color "to contempt, derision or obloquy."

WHITEVILLE, N. C., April 28 -- A special venire of 150 New Hanover County citizens was ordered today to appear in Superior Court here tomorrow for the trial of twenty-seven Columbus County white men charged in four Ku Klux Klan flogging cases.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 29 -- The United Nations Command proposed to the Communists yesterday an "over-all solution" for the deadlocked armistice negotiations in the Korean war, but veiled its terms under an agreement with the Chinese and North Korean delegates at Panmunjom for secrecy on the proceedings.

A fugitive warrant for the arrest on perjury charges of William (Bill) Spivey, former All-America basketball center at the University of Kentucky, was dispatched last night to Lexington, Ky., a few hours after four alleged fixers had been accused of offering the player and a teammate $5,000 to rig a game played at the 1950 Sugar Bowl Tournament in New Orleans.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a statement by President Truman on the shift of command at Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, his message to Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, the new commander in Europe, and a statement on the appointment of Gen. Mark W. Clark to succeed General Ridgway in the Far East:

Phil Harris, the bandleader, a member of Jack Benny's radio troupe since 1936, will be replaced next fall by Bob Crosby, it was announced yesterday by Mr. Benny and the Columbia Broadcasting System, the network carrying the program.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 28 -- The Israeli Government has informed the Bonn Government through Dr. Nahum Goldmann in London that it will continue negotiations on reparations only if the West German Government gives assurances of the seriousness of its intentions and of a real desire to reach an honorable settlement.

Three top taxes of Mayor Impellitteri's fiscal program were denounced by twenty-eight business, union labor and civic spokesmen at a four-and-one-half hour public hearing in City Hall yesterday as ruinous to the city's automobile dealers, retail liquor tradesmen and cigarette retailers, respectively.

On April 14 THE NEW YORK TIMES reported: "Stiff Curb Sought on Park Vandalism." The story noted that Commissioner Moses would soon seek the enactment of a local law designed to curb vandalism in the city's parks and playgrounds. It was reported that the proposed law would make parents of children committing vandalism subject to a fine commensurate with the damage done, but limited to $25 in any one instance.

The important decision as to who is to succeed General Eisenhower has been made, and the mantle of the Supreme Commander of the Allied Forces in Europe has fallen on General Matthew Ridgway, now American Commander in the Far East and United Nations Commander for Korea.
The chief worry of large and small business is not any "threat" each poses for the other, but "government," R. Stafford Edwards, president of the Edwards Company, Norwalk, Conn., asserted yesterday.
The Wisconsin varsity eight that made history by winning the intercollegiate championship on the Ohio River at Marietta last June is coming East Saturday to row Navy on the Severn at Annapolis.
Most commodity futures prices moved higher here yesterday but, except for cottonseed oil, volume was generally low.

HARTFORD, Conn., Tuesday, April 29 -- Republican party caucuses in 160 of Connecticut's 169 cities and towns showed an overwhelming support early today for the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for President.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 28 -- This city took off on a mild political binge today when its registered Republicans turned out for a Presidential preference poll designed to keep peace locally among the adherents of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft.
GENEVA, April 28 - Switzerland has contributed $69,000 to the United Nations Emergency Refugee Fund.

The period of depressed business in the cotton textile industry is about over, according to a bulletin released yesterday by the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute, Inc. All factors point to recovery, the institute said, even though low prices and hesitant buying are still apparent.

The right of the Government to institute retroactive pay increases for certain of its employes and then order private companies who used their services to pay additional compensation for work done three to six months earlier is being questioned by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., April 28 -- A National Education Association official said today that 139 residents of Cortland, N. Y., had petitioned the association to investigate the school system in the upstate community.

Women's work of the Reformed Church in America was celebrated yesterday in the annual spring meeting of the Women's Missionary Work and in a pageant portraying the history of the women in the church since 1875.

A two-count civil anti-trust suit was filed yesterday in Federal court by the Government against the National Screen Service Corporation of 1600 Broadway and eight major motion picture producing and distributing companies.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Evidence that growth is regulated by a built-in, automatic growth-control mechanism that acts in a specific manner for each tissue and organ in the body was presented this morning at the opening of the annual meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.

Melvin H. Osterman, a delegate to the Republican National Convention from the Twentieth Congressional District, on Manhattan's West Side, called on Mrs. Preston Davie yesterday to resign her post as chairman of the women's auxiliary of the New York Republican County Committee.

A program for a sound defense of the United States based on true economy has been outlined in a report to Congress by the group of citizens comprising the Committee on the Present Danger. This program is to help Western Europe build up its own defenses, as contemplated by the $7,900,000,000 mutual security program, and to do so in a more efficient and effective manner than has been done heretofore.
SALT LAKE CITY, April 28 (UP) -- Cooler weather eased Salt Lake City's flood today, but muddy water poured through breaks in street canals onto industrial residential property.
Jewelry valued at $2,700 was stolen last night from Sheik Asad A1 Facih, Saudi-Arabian Ambassador to the United States, by a burglar who broke into his East Side hotel suite with a jimmy.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The United States, Britain and France have drafted a note to Moscow asking the Soviet Government to clarify its proposals for the election of an all-German Government. The note is expected to be delivered to the Kremlin within the next few days.

Delays of up to thirty-four minutes in the morning rush hour yesterday plagued the Long Island Rail Road, the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad and the I. R. T. division of the subway. There seemed to be no connection between the disrupted schedules beyond coincidence.
LONDON, April 28 -- Queen Elizabeth II has set Tuesday, June 2, 1953, as her coronation day, it was announced from Buckingham Palace tonight.

The right of the city to bar two nudist magazines from newsstand sale was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Thomas L. J. Corcoran, who ruled that their indiscriminate sale contributed to juvenile delinquency and sex crimes.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) -- D. A. Hulcy, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, today blamed the American people for permitting President Truman to set the precedent of seizing the steel industry.

Members of the Barnard Thrift Shop committee have arranged a series of rummage teas for the benefit of the Barnard College Scholarship Fund, the first of which will be held this afternoon in the home of Mrs. Carl Gerdau at 770 Park Avenue.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., April 28 -- Student-teacher teams from forty schools named for top honors in the $100,000 general and school awards program of Freedom Foundation will take part in a freedom pilgrimage at this historic shrine on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

Fifteen of the seventeen defendant investment banking houses in the anti-trust trial before Judge Harold R. Medina declared yesterday that they did not object to the Government's adding to its monopoly-conspiracy complaint the separate charge that the defendants maintained prices illegally in the the syndicated sale of securities.

CLEVELAND, April 28 -- Emil Rieve, president of the Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., told the union's biennial convention here today that he saw no chance that a Congress friendly to labor would be elected this year.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 29 (AP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway said today he was accepting appointment as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe "with full realization of the great task ahead of me."

A "marathon meeting" that has kept more than 300 maintenance and clerical employes of the Kings County Lighting Company, supplier of gas to 120,000 Brooklyn families, from their jobs since last Wednesday has resolved itself into a three-cornered battle among the local union, the international union and the company.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 28 -- Cecil B. DeMille, the veteran producer-director of motion picture spectacles, tonight lashed out at the "tremendous" burden of taxation in announcing the dissolution of Cecil B. DeMille Productions, Inc., which for many years has been affiliated with the Paramount Pictures Corporation.

MUCH have I traveled in the realms of fiction and many doomed, damned heroines have I seen; but never have I met one more miserable than Diane Lattimer, heroine of George Mandel's sensational first novel, "Flee the Angry Strangers."* Other authors have made us well acquainted with alcoholics and nymphomaniacs, with madwomen and degenerates.

HAVANA, April 28 -- The Advisory Council composed of eighty members recently appointed by President Fulgencio Batista held its first meeting this afternoon in the auditorium of the Ministry of Education.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 28 -- Belgium has sent to the Netherlands a new note described here as opening the way for a renewed effort to clear obstacles to the realization of the proposed Benelux (Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg) economic union.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- Wheat futures showed a firmer tone today, following the sharp setback of Saturday, there being more apprehension over continued dry weather with comparatively high temperatures in western Canada and our Northwest.
W. C. Snyder Jr., president of the Blaw-Knox Company, Pittsburgh, will serve also as chairman of the board of directors, it was announced yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 -- By unanimous vote, trustees of this city's War Memorial refuse today to permit Paul Robeson, the baritone, to use the opera house for a recital on May 22.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Navy tentatively listed today the following men aboard the destroyer-minesweeper Hobson, which sank Saturday, as missing.

Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, told a student assembly at Yeshiva University yesterday that he favored the legalization of gambling, provided that gangsterism could be eradicated first.
It is to the interest of the American people that Israel be economically and politically strong, Vice President Alben W. Barkley said in an address here last night.
VANCOUVER, April 28 (Canadian Press) -- Fiirefighters today brought under control an oil fire raging in the engine room and No. 3 hold of the Dutch freighter Dongedyk.

BONN, Germany, April 28 (AP) -- Surprise raids by West German counter-espionage agents today smashed a Communist spy ring with tentacles reported to have reached into Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's office, official sources said.

ST. LOUIS, April 28 (AP) -- Bill Veeck and his St. Louis Browns, who always welcome festive occasions, today marked the return of Japanese independence by sending two farm club ball players to Japanese professional baseball.
Olivia de Havilland, star of the current revival of "Candida," was guest of honor at the Drama Desk's monthly luncheon meeting yesterday at Rosoff's Restaurant.

SAIGON, Indo-China, April 28 -- Communist-led Vietminh regular forces in south Vietnam have been reduced in the last eighteen months from four regiments to four battalions, a French Headquarters spokesman estimated here today.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Japan attained a formal state of peace and sovereign equality with ten nations today, as well as a mutual security partnership with the United States.

ORANGE, N. J., April 28 -- An audience of 1,100 filled the auditorium of the Orange High School tonight for a performance of Verdi's "Requiem," the biggest undertaking of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra in the thirty years of its existence.

PITTSBURG, April 28 (AP) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation increased wages of 15,000 non-union employes today and offered the same cost-of-living pay rise to four union that represent 75,000 more workers.

The Supreme Court's decision upholding the released time program for pupils in New York State "places the final stamp of approval" on the plan, Andrew G. Clauson Jr., president of the City Board of Education, declared yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, April 28 -- Tired but beaming, Queen Juliana returned today from her four-week trip to the United States and Canada. On hand at Schiphol Airport to greet her and Prince Bernhard as they landed from a K. L. M.

TULSA, April 28 -- The board of directors of Warren Petroleum Corporation declared a dividend of 30 cents a share today on the corporation's common stock, payable on June 2 to stockholders of record at close of business May 15. This is the thirty-fifth consecutive dividend payment by the corporation.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 (AP) -- Harry (Kid) Matthews of Seattle, third ranking contender for the light heavyweight title, moved into the heavyweight ranks tonight to knock out George Kaplan of Brooklyn in the first round of their scheduled ten-round fight at Winterland.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- James E. Black, president of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, told Congress today it should keep a tight rein on the construction of power lines for the Reclamation Bureau's Central Valley Project in California.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 28 -- Scandinavian gourmets said today that the anti-smorgasbord ruling of the Connecticut State Health Department was "an infringement against gastronomical democracy."

Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein reserved decision yesterday on a motion by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., to compel Columbia University to recognize the union as bargaining agent for striking cafeteria workers.
Jerry Coleman, Yankees' second baseman, who will report to the Marines Friday, will be honored by his team-mates today as the world champions return to the Stadium to open a thirteen-game home stand.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Army formally brought court-martial charges today against Maj. Gen. Robert W. Grow, the former United States Military Attache in Moscow whose diary fell into Soviet hands and became a tool of Communist anti-American propaganda.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Deposits in Montana said to contain 80 per cent of the nation's known crome ore will be developed for production of chrome concentrates needed for defense.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 -- One of the thorniest issues facing the quadrennial general conference of the Methodist Church was resolved amicably here today with the establishment of a thirty-two-member coordinating council empowered to review all problems affecting the smooth functioning of the church's boards and agencies.

LONDON, April 28 -- Assurances of fair-trading practices in the competition for world trade were given to Britain today by the Japanese Charge d'Affaires as the peace treaty with Japan came into force.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Joseph Applebaum, wealthy New York wine maker, denied under oath today before House tax investigators that Joseph D. Nunan Jr., while Commissioner of Internal Revenue, gave him "unusually preferred treatment" in the award of Federal licenses.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) -- The Supreme Court today rejected the appeal of Mrs. Iva Toguri D'Aquino, the "Tokyo Rose" of World War II, who now must serve a ten-year prison term for treasonable broadcasts over Radio Tokyo.

A special boon to the working girl who commutes as well as the one who wishes to freshen up before she meets her date is the Pamper House, which will open on Wednesday. Located in the concourse of the Sinclair Oil Building Fifth Avenue and Forty-eight Street, it will be open from A. M. to 8 P. M. Monday through Saturday.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of the majority opinion written by Justice Douglas, and excerpts from the dissenting opinions of Justices Black, Jackson and Frankfurter in the New York State released time case, in which the Supreme Court affirmed, 6 to 3, the right of the state to release students from school for religious instruction:
TOKYO, April 28 (AP) -- Headquarters communique 1233, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Monday (5 P. M. Sunday, Eastern daylight time):

A new Federal law that, among other things, prohibits druggists from refilling prescriptions for restricted drugs without checking back with physicians, was welcomed as "helpful" yesterday by Assistant Health Commissioner Jerome Trichter.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 28 -- Since the command of United Nations forces in Korea is vested in the United States, and was not assigned to an individual general, no action will be required here to confirm the appointment of Gen. Mark W. Clark to succeed Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway.
Economists have been wrong about the economy because they have not considered industrial research, Sumner H. Slichter declared last night at a dinner in the Statler Hotel.

Retailers and others are readily cooperating with the efforts of the Armed Forces Day Committee to work up interest in Armed Forces Day, May 17, according to Corp. Howard Cooper, 514th Troop Carrier Wing of the Air Corps. The corporal has been lent to the committee for the promotion, which has its theme "Unity-Strength-Freedom."

Several new elements were added yesterday to the general celebration of the coming into force of the peace treaty with Japan, which twenty-nine nations have signed. Nationalist China and Japan signed a separate peace treaty. India, by official declaration, terminated her state of war with Japan.

Mayor Impellitteri's conduct of city affairs has left unfulfilled the hopes and expectations of the voters who elected him as an independent eighteen months ago, Milton M. Bergerman, president of the Citizens Union, declared last night at the organization's fifty-fifth annual dinner at the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Senate took up its first regular funds bill of the session today and staged a cut-deeper economy drive. It voted to reduce by $50,000,000 more the $3,442,280,000 that its appropriations committee had recommended for the Treasury and Post Office departments for the fiscal year starting July 1.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) -- Many of the ill-fated crew of the Hobson were on their first voyage. Most apparently were below decks and never had a chance for life. It was believed that only a few were able to grab life jackets and abandon ship in the darkness.

Perhaps television has caused it. Maybe it's the increasing trend toward practical but pretty attire for casual living. In any event, shorts and slacks are being, replaced by pants of an in-between length. Call them what you will -- breiks, pedal pushers, coolie, matador or harem pants -- the pants story is not one to be ignored at the moment.

New York's oldest Chinese restaurant under the management of the same family had a birthday party the other night. Sixty-five guests from the press, radio and television met at Lee's at Mott and Pell Streets in Chinatown, to celebrate the establishment's sixtieth anniversary and to meet the new proprietor, Calvin Coolidge Lee.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Metropolitan Opera Company brought grand opera back to the nation's capital tonight for the first time in twenty-one years.

SOLOTHURN, Switzerland, April 29 -- Switzerland's policy of absolute neutrality depends to a major degree on her ability to defend herself. Like so many other things Swiss, the Army is a paradox. It is simultaneously among the largest and smallest in present day Europe.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Government made public today the most optimistic report on supplies of basic materials it has been able to issue since the outbreak of the Korean War. Officials of the Defense Production Administration, which keeps a check on available quantities of critical materials, said all categories of basic materials, except metals and some miscellaneous items, had shown a "marked easing" in supply since early March.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 29 -- Now that the market for Government securities is on a free basis the Treasury should refrain from including the full terms of impending financing in a single announcement and should instead approach the market in two steps, like private borrowers.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Treasury Department stepped up its multi - billion - dollar savings bond program today with generally higher interest rates and an accelerated redemption schedule designed to increase the Government's "share" in mounting private savings throughout the country.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 29 (AP) -- Doris Hart and Shirley Fry swept to second-round victories in the women's singles of the British hard courts tennis championships today.
BERLIN, April 29 (Reuters) -- The text of the Allied protest to the Russians about the attack today on a French airliner:

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (UP) -- Al Rosen hit three home runs and Rookie Jim Fridley had six hits in six times at bat tonight as the Indians broke their batting famine to rout the Athletics, 21 -- 9, before 7,858 fans at Shibe Park.
Declines in major commodity prices did not extend to all futures markets yesterday. Both sugar and coffee were higher and rubber was mixed.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 29 -- The Police Commissioner, Maj. Gen. J. A. Brink, confirmed today that the Government was "moving a certain number of police for special duty to Capetown," where Parliament resumes debate on the South African constitutional crisis tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Col. Harry S. Truman has formally retired from the Army "by authority of the President."
CHICAGO, April 29 -- The Inland Steel Company does not plan to apply for a price increase offered it and other steel companies by the Office of Price Stabilization.

MOSCOW, April 28 -- Any possibility of an investigation by the International Red Cross of Communist charges that the United States had employed bacteriological warfare in Korea and North China was removed today by Pravda.

Declining volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange reduced the institution's net profit for the first 1952 quarter to $72,776, against $226,186 in the corresponding 1951 quarter, Keith Funston, the president, reported yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 29 -- Paramount will make a musical in Technicolor out of "Poppa's Delicate Condition," the novel by Corinne Griffith in which the silent screen luminary reminisces about her childhood in Texas. Burton Lane, composer of the music for "Finian's Rainbow," will make his debut as a motion-picture producer with "Poppa's Delicate Condition" and also will write the score for the film.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 -- There's no doubt about it now. The favorite for Saturday's $100,000-added Kentucky Derby is Calumet Farm's Hill Gail.
CLEVELAND, April 29 -- An immediate shutdown of the nation's steel mills was ordered at 5 P. M. today by Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O.

The struggle for free trade unionism in Latin America seems to be making some progress. The reports about the fifth regional conference of American member states of the International Labor Organization, now meeting in Brazil, are encouraging. Only the Argentines and their supporters are challenging the movement toward free unions, and they do not seem to be making progress at this meeting.

LONDON, April 29 -- The British Government did what was best in the ultimate interests of the Bamangwato tribe in Bechuanaland protectorate when it permanently deposed Seretse Khama as chief, the Marquess of Salisbury, Commonwealth Relations Secretary, told the House of Lords today.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Two bills appropriating $5,180,000,000 toward Government expenditures that might exceed $75,000,000,000 during the fiscal year starting July 1 were passed by voice votes in the Senate today. Only a handful of Senators participated.

PITTSBURGH, April 29 -- Plants in this steel capital of the nation were closing rapidly tonight, with supervisory personnel trying to protect materials and equipment as the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., complied with the orders of their leaders to strike.

CAIRO, April 29 -- Egypt is urgently seeking extraordinary measures to deal with its increasing economic and unemployment crisis. A general committee of the textile industry -- the only major Egyptian industry and the only large industry in the Arab-speaking world -- will meet tomorrow to try to deal with a threatened collapse.

Spokesmen for Staten Island commuters appealed yesterday to the city to take over three lines of the Staten Island Transit Railway Company in the face of a threatened abandonment of passenger service by June 15.

Although net operating revenues of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries, for the twelve months ended March 31, were 5 per cent above the level of the preceding twelve months, increased taxes and operating expenses prevented net income from keeping pace.

The steel situation kept the stock market within a restricted range yesterday, although on balance prices leaned to the higher side. The market recovered a good part of the earlier losses to finish with a loss of 0.66 point.

The New York Stock Exchange took a plunge yesterday and landed in the motion picture business. It previewed its new educational film, "What Makes Us Tick" and at the same time announced that 400 copies in 16mm. and eight copies in 35mm. are available with out charge for public showing.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 29 -- Men and women undergraduates, heretofore four miles apart, will share one campus and curriculum in a coeducational College of Arts and Science, the University of Rochester announced today.

PARIS, April 29 -- A Paris court awarded symbolic damages today of three anti-Communist refugees in their libel suit against two Communist writers, but also criticized the propaganda motives of the plaintiffs in bringing the action.

CINCINNATI, April 29 -- Sal Maglie combined his rare mound skill with a lesser-known talent as a hitter tonight as the Giants launched their first Western trip of the year with a 2-1 victory over Luke Sewell's red-hot Reds.

Dark Peter of the Harborvale Stables surprised an opening-day crowd of 20,727 by taking the Toboggan Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Next to the outsider in the field of eight, the 4-year-old son of Piping Rock held on valiantly to beat the favored Crafty Admiral by a half-length in the six-furlong fixture on the Widener course.

A blunt warning to Anthony Anastasia, Brooklyn dock boss and leader of a local revolt in the International Longshoremen's Association, that any attempt by him or his followers to call a strike would be opposed by the Maritime Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor with its "full force and power" was issued yesterday.
PARIS, April 29 (AP) -- The touring American Golden Gloves team from Chicago, beaten by the Irish last week, fought to a 5-5 deadlock with a French all-star group tonight.

BERLIN, April 29 -- Two Soviet jet fighters attacked a French airliner en route from Frankfurt to Berlin today, injuring two of the passengers and seriously damaging the plane. The incident occurred over the Soviet zone of Germany in one of the three air corridors linking Berlin with the West.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- The International Materials Conference said today it would have to divide up key metals in 1952 in spite of encouraging production increases.

CAMDEN, N. J., April 29 (UP) -- Fort Salonga, S. P. Steckler's grey colt who swept his three starts at Laurel Park, today defeated eleven 2-year-olds in the eleventh renewal of the $12,850 William Penn Stakes, opening feature of Garden State Park's twenty-five-day meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Franklin D. Roosevelt and Wendell L. Willkie wanted to form a new political party uniting "liberal elements" in Democratic and Republican ranks, but death intervened and prevented them from doing anything' about it.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 29 (AP) -- "Our J-57 Turbo Wasp might prove to be the power plant to give us the advantage of the Russian-made jets," H. Mansfield Horner, president of United Aircraft Corporation, said in answer to a question put to him by one of more than 250 shareholders attending the annual meeting of the company today.

Many parties will be given today at the annual fashion show and luncheon in behalf of the Travelers Aid Society of New York in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre. Mrs. Carl Forsch heads the arrangements committee for the event, and among her aides are Miss Caroline L. McAuslan and Mrs. Gavin Brackenridge.

A cooperative system for strengthening export controls that ban shipment of strategic goods behind the Iron Curtain, agreed upon recently by the United States and ten Western European countries, will go into effect tomorrow.
In his comment on my letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES former United States Ambassador to Poland Arthur Bliss Lane calls attention to "a serious error of fact" committed by me.

If Government officials have the welfare of wage earners at heart they will put a stop to the outcry against profits, "in which they probably have been even more vociferous than the acknowledged spokesmen for labor," the Guaranty Trust Company declares in its monthly survey, to be published today.

Horton Foote, a writing fellow from Texas, who is represented on Broadway by "The Chase," had better watch his plots or he is going to have a posse of Yankee television viewers after him. On the "Television Playhouse" at 9 o'clock last Sunday over N. B. C., in a play called "The Travelers," he exhibited a better knowledge of Texans in Texas than Texans in New York.

Diana Craig, mezzo-soprano from Englewood, N. J., made her New York debut last night at Town Hall in an ambitious program that included lieder by Brahms and Wolf, an aria from "Mignon," Tchaikovsky's "Adieu, forets" and Dido's famous lament, "When I Am Laid in Earth," from Purcell's "Dido and Aeneas."
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm prices increased two-thirds of 1 per cent between mid-March and mid-April.
John J. Murray, director of the union's District 16, however, gave Jones Laughlin workers orders to get out as quickly as possible.

Works of art that might have been made for a discriminating Tom Thumb have been brought together from the far corners of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in an exhibition opening today for small art lovers.

The past twenty years of New and Fair Deal Administrations have witnessed, whether premeditated or not, a steady weakening of the underpinnings of the Constitution of the United States. On occasions, such as the attempted packing of the Supreme Court by Franklin Roosevelt, and the precipitate action of President Truman in Korea, prescribed Presidential powers were exceeded.
Calypso fashions from Bermuda, designed by Polly Hornburg for Cabana Beachwear, were shown at a press preview yesterday at Bonwit Teller's.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 29 -- By a vote of 10 to 0, with five abstentions, the United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs approved today a joint United States-French resolution recommending to Governments that national legislation for the control of narcotic drugs be extended to cover synthetic products as rapidly as introduced.

The basketball and football teams of the University of Kentucky were described yesterday as "the acme of commercialism and over-emphasis" by General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit in a sixty-three page report that revealed several meetings between Adolph Rupp, the school's basketball coach, and Ed Curd, a bookmaker termed the "Frank Erickson of Kentucky."

National advertising still is as potent a force in American life as, for instance, baseball. Printers Ink will report in its next issue that March national advertising expenditures were 16 per cent greater than in the comparable month last year although they dropped 2 per cent from February.
The state of Israel, on the fourth anniversary of its founding, was saluted last night as a friend and ally of the United States and a bulwark against the spread of communism in the Middle East.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman approved yesterday a contract between Lester T. Doyle, trustee of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit System, and Hell Gate Wreckers, Inc., for the removal of seventy-eight miles of abandoned street-car tracks from Bronx streets. It is expected that 12,700 tons of high grade steel scrap will be salvaged for the defense program.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- Curt Simmons, three weeks out of the Army, made a smooth comeback to big league baseball today with a seven-hit performance which gave the Phils an 8-2 victory over the Cubs.

Possible measures for obtaining additional city revenues through devices other than the nuisance taxes proposed by Mayor Impellitteri will be sought by the Democratic members of the City Council in a conference with Controller Lazarus Joseph to be held at Mr. Joseph's Municipal Building office tomorrow morning at 11 o'clock.

Discovery of a new way of sending radio signals through the air that holds promise of revolutionizing long-distance communication and conceivably might open the door to international tele vision became known yesterday.

MIAMI, April 29 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, carrying his campaign for Presidential popularity support into Florida's metropolitan voting stronghold, warned tonight that American freedoms were endangered equally by "quack nostrums advanced in the name of liberalism" and "demagogues who degrade the American system of fair-play with slander and name-calling."

A recent count among the 300,000 students in the city's high schools showed only thirty identified users of narcotics, compared with 154 known cases a year ago, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, reported yesterday. The new count however, listed 114 "suspected" cases since September, compared with thirty-five "suspected'' users previously.

NEWARK, April 29 -- The country's first unannounced state-wide air raid alert involving public participation was staged in New Jersey this morning. It lasted only ten minutes, but it was of sufficient duration to give Civil Defense, Army, Air Force and public officials their first chance to gauge the public's knowledge and response to a surprise alert.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refuse today to order a special port cost study in connection with a controversy between the ports of Baltimore and Philadelphia, and the Port of New York, over the right of the New York port to have equal rates on export grain from Buffalo.
Methods of making the reckless driver a marked man on the highways were discussed yesterday at a meeting of the Regional Committee on Traffic Regulation and Control at the Roosevelt Hotel.

NEW DELHI, India, April 29 -- India's sensibilities, which are always tender during the onset of the long "hot" season, when tempers rise with temperatures, are being rasped this week by three developments close to home.
BERLIN, April 29 -- The Soviet Union has decided to return to German control sixty-six major industrial plants in East Germany, the official East German news agency announced today.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 29 (AP) -- A Supreme Court jury awarded tonight $7,800 to a Syracuse trucking concern owner and five of his drivers in their suits against a state police lieutenant who, they charged, "assaulted" them when he arrested them.
Sixty-three checks totaling about $57,000,000 had been sent yesterday to the welfare and educational organizations named in the will of Mrs. Hetty Sylvia Ann Howland Green Wilks.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- A seven-count indictment against Dr. Herman N. Bundesen, president of the Chicago Board of Health now on leave of absence, charging him with nionfeasance and malfeasance in office in connection with this city's recent horse meat scandals was thrown out of Criminal Court today.

The Long Island Golf Association will open its season with the playing of the William D. Richardson Memorial tournament over the Seawane Harbor course, May 8 to 10. Gordon Stott of North Hills, tournament chairman, made the announcement yesterday.

TETUAN, Spanish Morocco, April 27 -- Arab nationalist leaders in the Spanish Protectorate of Morocco said today they were reorganizing political parties that were banned many years ago and were preparing to publish a newspaper that would fight for their ultimate goal of complete independence.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Nathan P. Feinsinger, chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board, told a House committee today "there can be no question" about the board's legal right to recommend a union shop for the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- Representative Thomas J. Lane, Democrat of Massachusetts, introduced a resolution today demanding a "full and complete" Congressional investigation of the tragic mid-Atlantic collision of the United State minesweeper Hobson and the aircraft carrier Wasp.

Disturbed market conditions in the textile industry in 1951 were reflected in an increase in the number of arbitration cases, it was said yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Federation of Textiles. The group, representing 80 per cent of the capacity of the rayon weaving industry, reported 291 cases involving goods valued at $3,200,000 instituted through its offices in 1951, compared to 241 cases on goods valued at $2,500,000 in the previous year.

As a medical corpsman who saw nine months of combat duty in Korea, Sgt. Robert P. Cromer, 23 years old, of 481 Allen Avenue, Oceanside, L. I., learned the vital need for blood to save the lives of the wounded. Home on a thirty-day leave, he has volunteered to recruit blood donors for the Nassau County chapter of the Red Cross.

Although it stopped raining here yesterday and the sun even broke through the clouds in the late afternoon, the local shutdown on baseball activity continued. Deeming the Stadium turf too sodden and the temperature too low, the Yankees called off their scheduled contest with the Browns.

The application of the Bloomfield Steamship Company of Houston, Tex., for an operating subsidy was opposed yesterday by the Lykes Brothers Company, Inc., whose steamship services include both trade routes sought by Bloomfield.

CAIRO, April 29 -- Egypt, fighting an increasingly severe economic depression as a result of the cotton slump, is in the process of dicovering how costly is the type of xenophobia that culminated in the great riots of Jan. 26.

An all-industry public relations program designed to acquaint the public with the effects of excessive taxation on sales of liquor and on tax yields will begin immediately, according to Thomas J. Donovan. He will become chief executive of Licensed Beverage Industries, Inc., tomorrow.

TO keep everyone happy, it is apparent that the New York Conservation Department should take immediate steps to set ten miles of State-owned streams apart for worm and spinner fishing only, a step that should silence effectively those who have been complaining about the allocation of ten miles of streams to fly fishermen.

LONDON, April 29 -- The Colonial Secretary, Oliver Lyttelton, ruling out today a Central African government made up exclusively of Africans or of Europeans, invoked instead the vision of partnership between them. He was speaking in a House of Commons debate on African objections to the federation of Nyasaland and Northern Rhodesia with Southern Rhodesia.

CLEVELAND, April 29 -- The seventh biennial convention of the Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., called upon Congress today to establish a thirty-five-hour work week to ease unemployment in the textile industry. A resolution unanimously adopted by the 2,000 convention delegates said the shorter work schedule should be effected with no cut in the pay workers now get for working forty hours.

JACKSON, Mich., April 29 (AP) -- Four more prison guards quit their jobs today and Vernon Fox, assistant deputy warden and prison psychologist, said he would fight for his at the state prison of Southern Michigan.

The City of Cincinnati, Ohio, borrowed $19,600,000 in the public market yesterday through the sale of bonds due from 1953 to 1992 at an interest cost of 1.7344 per cent. The issue was sold at sealed bidding to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100 with a premium of $100 for 1 3/4s and 1 1/2s.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 29 -- Inflationary tendencies in many countries of Asia and the Far East appeared to have lessened during the third quarter of 1951, due to the change in the balance of payments, the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East reported in its Economic Bulletin, released today from headquarters in Bangkok.
PITTSBURGH, April 29 (AP) -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corp. disclosed today it was trimming $6,965,000 off its 1952 expansion program because of what Ben Moreell, chairman, calls a "profit squeeze."

The double-decked Stratocruiser Good Hope, of Pan American World Airways, due here from Buenos Aires at 6 o'clock last night, disappeared while flying over northern Brazil yesterday. The plane had been scheduled to make a stop at Port-of-Spain, Trinidad, at 9:20 A. M. yesterday but no word had been received last night of the fate of it or its forty-one passengers and nine crew members.

HANOVER, Germany, April 29 -- The industrial power of West Germany is breathtakingly illustrated at the Hanover Fair. There are spectacular exhibits by 793 machinery concerns, 774 electrical equipment manufacturers and a host of other producers of machine tools, precision tools, rubber, chemicals, motors and a profound variety of consumer goods.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 29 -- Lieut. Gen. Dushan Kveder of the Yugoslav General Staff has warned the Italian Government that it must face the fact that northern Ialy could not be defended against a Soviet attack without Yugoslavia's cooperation and that the chances of obtaining such cooperation were being endangered by Rome's hostile policy toward Belgrade.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- Harold Franklin, an official of Local 600 of the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., at Detroit, refused to tell the House Un-American Activities Committee today whether he ever was a member of the Communist party.

The point of emphasis in the discussions of the Atlantic Council in Lisbon at the end of February was that 1952 is "the year of the turn." This was not one man's view or one nation's view. The statesmen of fourteen countries reported that the cold war, as it appeared from their respective capitals, was developing at an accelerated pace.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- United States District Judge David A. Pine ruled today that President Truman's seizure of the steel-making industry was an illegal act.

PARIS, April 29 -- Discovery of a secret terrorist association in Tunisia serving the nationalist cause against French dominance of the country and allegedly supported by a daughter of the nations ruler was reported tonight in dispatches from Tunis.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, said today that three wealthy men had obtained Bureau of Internal Revenue rulings authorizing them to write off for tax purposes loans made to the New York State Democratic Committee upon which they could not collect in full.

ROME, April 29 (UP) -- Pope Pius charged Chinese Communist authorities today with making "lying indictments" of Roman Catholic missionaries who have been imprisoned or expelled from China in recent months.
Prices of cotton futures turned barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and active months closed 25 to 92 points net lower than on Monday.

WITH U. S. TWENTY-SEVENTH REGIMENT, in Korea, April 19 -- Under a new holiday plan, troops in the foxholes and bunkers of this regiment's front line get a day off near the front after they have put in fourteen days of duty.
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 30 (AP) -- United Nations Command Headquarters Communique 1235, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday (5 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern Daylight times):
PARIS, April 29 -- Schiaparelli's midsummer collection, in sky blue, cream pink and orange sherbert, contrasting with somber moss greens, navy or black, is stimulating for the way fabrics are used.

A price cut on lead, the first reduction on a widely used nonferrous metal from the General Ceiling Price Regulations level put in effect in January, 1951, was made yesterday by a major custom smelter.

Delicate in both pattern and colorings are various new wallpapers in the Hobe Erwin Editions on view in the newly decorated showroom of Jones Erwin, Inc., 15 East Fifty-seventh Street. The papers are available through decorators.

ATHENS, April 29 -- Reviewing his eighteen months of administering Marshall Plan funds to Greece, Roger D. Lapham, chief of the Mutual Security Agency mission said today that "in some cases the Greek Government has done all it could to better the country's economic position and in some cases it has not." He said he had spoken in the same sense at Kalamata, a provincial town in the southern Peloponnesus Saturday.

Mrs. W. Palmer Dixon heads the executive committee for the Straw Hat Party, the annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation, which will be held on the night of June 4 in the St. Regis Roof. The occasion will mark the preopening of the St. Regis Roof.

BOSTON, Wednesday, April 30 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower emerged today with a ringing endorsement from Massachusetts voters, Republican and Democratic alike, for the Presidential nomination in the Commonwealth's preferential primary.

The election of Mrs. S. Felton Posey as president of the Junior League of the City of New York, Inc., took place yesterday at the annual membership meeting at the clubhouse, 130 East Eightieth Street.

DENVER, Wednesday, April 30 -- More than 90,000 oil workers began a nation-wide strike today against the petroleum industry. An industry spokesman said the walkout could put every motorist in the nation on foot within a few days.

TOKYO, April 29 (UP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway may leave Tokyo in time to confer with General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in Paris before the latter returns to the United States, it was believed here today.

LOUISVILLE, April 29 -- The sun shone bright on old Kentucky homes today and a recent escapee from New York's rains found the sunshine a most refreshing change. The day was a scorcher and Churchill Downs glistened. Even the barns on the far side of the track were resplendent in new coats of green paint and the grass in the infield was such a rich green that it looked painted, too.

LONDON, April 29 -- Dullness in most sections of the Stock Exchange today was relieved by the firmness of foreign bonds, among which German and Japanese issues were notably strong after early hesitancy.

Stockholders at the American Can Company at their annual meeting here yesterday approved a four-for-one split of the preferred stock, a two-for-one split of the common and a distribution of one share of new common for each share held after the split, having the effect of a four-for-one split of both preferred and common.
There was a strange sight on fashionable East Sixty-seventh Street last night.

Reporting on operations of the International Business Machines Corporation, Thomas J. Watson, board chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday that incoming orders for regular products continued at a high level for the 1952 first quarter.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- For a second time in two days the Senate inserted in an appropriation bill today this stipulation:

Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres today. "Macao," an R. K. O. adventure with Robert Mitchum, Jane Russell, William Bendix, Thomas Gomez and Gloria Grahame, is at the Paramount Josef von Sternberg directed and Alex Gottlieb produced from a script by Bernard C. Schoenfeld and Stanley Rubin and a story by Bob Williams.

Howard S. Cullman, one of the incorporators of the New York City Center of Music and Drama and its treasurer since its inception in 1943, submitted his resignation to a meeting of the board yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- An Eisenhower supporter charged today that the Taft camp was "juggling figures" and using "New Deal arithmetic" to show that Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio was a bigger vote puller than General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.
Mayor Impellitteri proclaimed the month of May as United Jewish Appeal Month at a dinner last night at the Pierre Hotel celebrating the fourth anniversary of Israel's independence.

Homeless alcoholics here will have their first real chance in fifty years for rehabilitation under the city's program at Hart Island, Julius Isaacs, former city magistrate and member of the committee on alcoholism of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City, said yesterday.

Louis F. Budenz, testifying in Federal court yesterday, named nine of the sixteen secondary Communist party leaders charged with conspiring to advocate and teach the overthrow of the United States Government by force and violence as having been active at party functions he attended.

Thirty-four Neotropical toads, eight paradox frogs and a 9-foot-long South American boa constrictor, that arrived Monday at the Bronx Zoo from the New York Zoological Society's department of tropical research in Trinidad, were placed on exhibit yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, April 29 (AP) -- Lefty Warren Spahn allowed the Pirates only five hits tonight as he pitched the Braves to a 5-1 triumph over the National League cellar team. It was Spahn's first victory of the season. The defeat was the tenth in a row for the Pirates.

Unstable conditions caused by the threat of war will require increased voluntary social service, Dr. Eduard C. Lindeman, professor emeritus of social philosophy at Columbia University, declared yesterday.

Two graduate fellowships, the Emily James Putnam award for creative writing, a graduate scholarship and fourteen other prizes were awarded yesterday at the second annual Barnard College honors assembly. Dean Millicent C. McIntosh presided.

The electric blender or liquidizer, which has been assuming increasing importance as a kitchen tool since its advent in the late Thirties, is the subject now of a complete cook book. "Electric Blender Recipes," by Mabel Stegner (M. Barrows Co., $3) is a compilation of more than 500 ways to utilize the appliance in dishes that range from soups and salad dressings, through desserts, hot breads, cakes and pies.
LAUREL, Md., April 29 (AP) -- Jess Linthicum gained an easy victory in the Olney Purse today to give Nick Shuk, the meeting's leading rider, his fourth success of the day.

Operating revenues and net profit of the Phillips Petroleum Company and its subsidiaries for the three months ended on March 31 increased 21 per cent and 24 per cent, respectively, above the levels attained in the corresponding period of 1951, according to the report released yesterday.

The light, sculptured look in furniture is again evidenced in a group of occasional tables designed by Erno Fabry. Included are a lamp table, a nest of tables, end and cocktail tables. These pieces are available through decorators at Fabry Associates, 6 East Fifty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Reaction here to the Federal District Court decision temporarily enjoining the President's seizure of the steel industry was generally one of approval. Comment for the most part, however, was available only from persons who had been critical of the President's action.

CINCINNATI, April 29 -- The civil rights question, rejected as part of the League of Women Voters' program at its last biennial, was revived today as 950 delegates opened discussion on what the league should include in its work for the coming two years.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 -- Unification of the Methodist and Protestant Episcopal Churches in this country was viewed here today as a distinct possibility within the foreseeable future.

" History of the Marine Corps Aviation in World War II," a new work by Robert Sherrod, will be published by Combat Forces Press of Washington, D. C., on May 22. The day marks the fortieth anniversary of the birth of Marine Aviation, on which Lieut. A. A. Cunningham was designated Marine aviator No. 1.

TAIPEI, Formosa, April 29 -- The newly concluded peace treaty between Nationalist China and Japan produced waves of general satisfaction in Formosa today. Some criticism of the bilateral pact is expected in the Legislative Yuan, Nationalist China's Parliament, but the general consensus is that the ratification process is likely to be simpler in Taipei than in Tokyo.

We are all thankful for Dean Pike's forthright St. George Day statements in the current controversy on religion and the schools for two reasons. First, thoughtful people will have the opportunity to weigh the arguments only when they are brought out in the open. Second, the heat generated over the issue will not likely degenerate into a Catholic vs. Protestant dichotomy.

The editorial of April 24 on "Soviet Trade" recalls the experience with the Nazi regime in Germany in its early days. The Germans at that time needed cotton, and figured that they could get it on their own terms from us because of overproduction in the depression years.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 29 -- President Klement Gottwald of Czechoslovakia has expelled more than 6,000 Stalinists from the Communist party in an underground struggle to preserve his country from being subjugated by the Soviet Union, according to an article that will appear in a forthcoming issue of the Yugoslav periodical "International Affairs."

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 30 -- Armistice negotiations in the Korean war remained in recess today while the Communist delegation studied the over-all proposal of the United Nations to settle all remaining issues jointly.

Joseph Ireland, arrested on a charge of stealing $64,000 in jewels from a lobby showcase in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, was sentenced yesterday to an indeterminate term up to three years in the City Penitentiary on Riker's Island. General Sessions Judge Harold A. Stevens told the prisoner that when his term was completed he must return to his native Canada.

At the close of the first act of "Hook 'n Ladder," which was put on at the Royale last evening, George Jean Nathan rose with considerable elegance and silence and went home. At the close of the second act another critic tried to slip away without being observed by his colleagues.

More than $75,000,000 in municipal and private funds has gone into shoreside reconstruction and rehabilitation in the Port of New York in the last two years, Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, declared yesterday. He said this was an improvement record unmatched by any port in the world.
Earnings of Federated Department Stores, Inc., in the year ended Feb. 2 amounted to $13,297,133, or $3.81 a share, against $5.34 a share in the preceding year, the company reported yesterday.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina said yesterday that statements in a Securities and Exchange Commission release had turned out to be wrong "time and time again," and that he had therefore decided not to read any more S. E. C. releases during the course of the trial of the investment banking group.

PARIS, April 29 -- Premier Antoine Pinay said today that the first results of his drive to defend the franc were beginning to appear and would develop with the steady growth of public confidence. He made these remarks in an address before the French Association of Economic Geography.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Gov. Val Peterson of Nebraska, whose home-state Republican Presidential preferential primary went to Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio by a plurality margin, today endorsed General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The conviction of Dr. Edward A. Rumely, executive secretary of the Committee for Constitutional Government, for contempt of Congress was upset by the United States Court of Appeals in a 2-to-1 decision today.

The cavernous interior of Madison Square Garden was dim yesterday morning. The candy-cane trim on the stands was pale against the dark tiers of empty seats. The trapezes looped down from the shadowy rafters in a ghostly confusion of white curves.

The Government is seeking treble damages of $221,708 from the Iritox Chemical Company of 62 West Forty-sixth Street on charges of exceeding Office of Price Stabilization ceiling prices in the sale of crude sulphur, the New York district office of the O. P. S. announced yesterday.

The Fifth Avenue Association has urged License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey to seek an amendment of the local law to limit special sales in stores to sixty days. This would reduce by one half the time now permitted for such sales.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A committee of the American Federation of American Scientists will report to an annual meeting here this week that United States visa restrictions have prevented or "indefinitely delayed" the visits of more than 200 foreign scientists in the last year and one-half.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Administration felt tonight that Federal Judge David A. Pine's decision in the steel industry seizure would, if allowed to stand, forever bind Presidents in time of emergency. Therefore, the case will be pushed to the Supreme Court.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 29 -- Sophomore Phil Walker, making his first varsity start, held Princeton to four hits as Seton Hall topped the Tigers, 4 -- 1, today on University Field. The victory was Seton Hall's fourth without a defeat.

A dapple-gray horse was led on to the speaker's dais in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. The animal represented the equine half of a horse-and-buggy presented to Dr. Frank L. Boyden, headmaster of the Deerfield Academy of Deerfield, Mass., to honor him for fifty years in that post.

Herbert Matthews' current reports from Latin America are so incisive and well balanced as to entitle him to warm thanks from students of that area. Without minimizing the clear and present threat of communism in the Caribbean world, he renders needed service by reminding us of the no less grave threat of the irresponsible tyrannies that are increasing in number and arrogance, clouding our hopes for a company of free nations in this hemisphere.

Leaders in work for and with New York City children yesterday opposed enactment of a law proposed by Parks Commissioner Robert Moses that would seek to prevent vandalism in parks by penalizing parents of children guilty of destructive activity in the parks.

Because of the sharp increase in traffic accidents in the city, Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan issued orders yesterday to all members of the force to join in a special highway safety campaign.

COBLENZ, Germany, April 29 -- Gen. Roger Noiret, Commander of the French forces in West Germany, promised General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today that his countrymen were ready to "do our duty to the greatest extremity necessary."

ROME, Ga., April 29 (UP) -- The editor and managing editor of The Atlanta Constitution today were found guilty of contempt of court in connection with a series of news stories on traffic safety and sentenced to serve twenty days in jail.
GARY, Ind., April 29 (UP) -- Pickets appeared immediately at steel plants in this area late today after Philip Murray ordered a strike.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of Federal Judge David A. Pine's ruling today in the steel seizure case:

COBLENZ, Germany, April 29 -- Gen. Roger Noiret, Commander of the French forces in West Germany, promised General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today that his countrymen were ready to "do our duty to the greatest extremity necessary."

ROME, Ga., April 29 (UP) -- The editor and managing editor of The Atlanta Constitution today were found guilty of contempt of court in connection with a series of news stories on traffic safety and sentenced to serve twenty days in jail.
GARY, Ind., April 29 (UP) -- Pickets appeared immediately at steel plants in this area late today after Philip Murray ordered a strike.

Proposals for the formation of a citizens' committee to plan for the celebration next year of the 300th anniversary of the incorporation of this city as New Amsterdam were made yesterday by speakers at a luncheon of the Greater New York Civic Center Association.

An American-built airliner flying for a French company and carrying seventeen persons was attacked yesterday by two Soviet jet fighters in the middle of the Allied air lanes leading into Berlin. Its fuselage was riddled by cannon and machine-gun bullets, two of its passengers were wounded, and only the skill of the pilot and an opportune cloud bank saved the plane from complete destruction.
Pan American World Airways here made public last night the following list of crew members and of passengers booked aboard its Stratocruiser missing between Rio de Janeiro and Port-of-Spain, Trinidad:

Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires yesterday won the eleventh game of his eighteen-contest chess match with Samuel Reshevsky of New York, according to a report from Mexico City. The former United States champion, who again had the black side of a King's Pawn opening, chosen for the third time by his rival, appeared to be ill at ease in warding off the attack which Najdorf built up.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Price Stabilizer Ellis Arnall testified today that upon the insistence of President Truman he had "offered" a steel price increase of $4.50 a ton to the industry, but no action was taken on it.

The makings of many a fine rhubarb were set before the baseball public at the Museum of the City of New York yesterday with the opening of an exhibit called "Play Ball!" To the baseball fan -- a person of firm convictions -- almost any of the 500 exhibits may contain a challenge that must be met.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A fight for economy in the Federal Government was urged on the country's business men today at the annual meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Reports that new truce terms had been offered the Communists in Korea checked the buying of grains today and also increased selling pressure all along the line. Some foreign buying of new crop wheat deliveries was reported in the early trade, but no export sales were reported.

President Harold W. Dodds of Princeton University has spotlighted a fundamental national problem by laying bare the anatomy of the financial difficulties in which private colleges and universities now find themselves. Each million dollars of endowment funds, he points out, now has only about half the purchasing power it had two decades ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 -- In a case closely watched by the State Department because of international ramifications, Judge Daniel R. Shoemaker of the State Superior Court directed the city and county of San Francisco today to pay the Federal Government $26,512, plus interest, collected in taxes on the German Consulate General here from 1941 to 1947.

The week-long strike of more than 300 maintenance and clerical employes of the Kings County Lighting Company, suppliers of gas to 120,000 Brooklyn homes, was called off for thirty days yesterday afternoon pending a State Supreme Court ruling on a jurisdictional dispute between a local union and its parent organization.

Quite recently 250 head of Texas cattle left Houston for Cuba as the first step in plans to combat the world's growing meat shortage through the export of Texas-style cowpunching. In May another 250 head will embark for Queensland, Australia. More cattle, horses, men and equipment will follow monthly.

It seems only yesterday that a certain young man with a mighty reluctance was directing his steps on a pre-autumnal morning toward a newly reopened school. One has been made aware of the true measure of time passed, however; one has received what no doubt will be the first of several reminders that school does not go on forever, that come summer its books will be put away and its doors closed.

Use of a sticker device as an alternative to parking meters to limit the time motorists may park legally in designated areas is being studied by the city.
