The sticker, described by the developers as a "Park-A-Tab," has "sufficient advantages to warrant further investigation" but apparently is not suited for speedy enforcement, according to Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.

John F. Froehlich Jr., a 45-year-old farmer of Woodbury Road, Hicksville, L. L, was sentenced yesterday to a year and a day in a Federal penitentiary by Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Brooklyn Federal Court for tax evasion. Froehlich had pleaded guilty on Jan. 30 to a charge of cheating the Government out of $90,905 in income taxes for 1946.

Unexpected forms and an unusual surface technique characterize a new group of jewel-toned enamels by Joseph Oil now on exhibition at Ernst Schwadron, 757 Madison Avenue. Some of the objects made from colored enamel used over brass include lamp bases, candlesticks, candelabra, bowls, ash trays and a cigarette box.

Three American Chinese and two Communist-controlled Hong Kong banks have been named as additional defendants in a Federal indictment charging violation of the Trading with the Enemy Act in which American Chinese were induced to pour millions of dollars illegally into Red China, United States Attorney Myles J. Lane announced yesterday.

A stay of trial for eighteen policemen who are accused of having accepted graft from Harry Gross, the convicted bookmaker, was granted yesterday in Supreme Court by Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan. The departmental trial had been scheduled to begin today in Brooklyn Police Headquarters.

MEDFORD, Mass., April 29 -- The election of Dr. Katharine R. Jeffers as dean of Jackson College, the department of women at Tufts College, was announced today by Leonard Carmichael, president. She will succeed Dr. Edith L. Bush, sister of Vannevar Bush, who retires at the close of the current academic year.
ABOARD U. S. S. BOXER, Off Korea, April 29 -- A cool sailor averted possible tragedy on this carrier recently by sticking his finger in a live bomb to keep it from exploding.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 -- Leaders of an "anti-Warren" ticket of candidates for Republican national convention delegates were accused today by Eisenhower campaign strategists of using the name of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in an "unauthorized way" in California.
Dedicated to comedy, the City Center's six-week spring season of three fortnightly revivals will be ushered in at 8 o'clock this evening with "The Male Animal."

ST. LOUIS, Wednesday, April 30 -- Shortly after 12:30 this morning the Dodgers completed a 4-1 triumph over the Cardinals before 20,384 patient fans who had sat in darkness for more than two hours before the night game could be started.

Morale among workers in the General Electric Company has improved since the concern undertook to educate them in the workings of the business system, Howard W. Bennett, manager of economic education, said yesterday. He spoke before the "Selling Shares in American" conference now being held at the Statler Hotel under the auspices of the Investment Dealers' Digest.

Federal District Judge David A. Pine, in ordering the restoration of the status quo in the steel industry, has dealt courageously with a great constitutional question. This question is, How far do the powers of the President extend? The question could not be answered by assertion on one side nor by denial on the other side.
Cornelia Otis Skinner received yesterday afternoon the Fourteenth Annual Barter Theatre Award for "the best performance given by an American-born actor during the current New York season."

Deliveries of defense material by the General Motors Corporation in the first quarter this year failed to offset the decline in civilian product sales, with the result that March quarter sales and earnings dropped below those of a year ago.

A nation-wide syndicate of underwriters headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and Dominick Dominick, will offer to investors today $11,475,000 of new capital stock of Canadian Fund, Inc., a new investment company organized to furnish diversified investment in Canada.

Many members of society, recently returned from the South, attended the opening program of the Westchester Racing Association at Belmont Park this afternoon. The circular dining room in the old Manice House and the restaurant in the turf and field enclosure at the track were filled with luncheon parties by noon.

A $90,000,000 sinking fund debentures Issue of the Aluminum Company of Canada. Ltd., has been registered with the Securities and Exchange Comission, the company announced yesterday. The issue, due 1970, is intended for public offering through a nationwide group of underwriters headed by The First Boston Corporation.

IN a chateau in Vaud, Switzerland, there lives an Englishwoman who lost, or threw away, her first name many years ago and calls herself only by her last one, Bryher. In her time she has been a publisher, a writer on films, a novelist and a friend of many of the most distinguished writers of this century. Bryher's first novel to be published in this country is now available.

Four years ago today by the Hebrew calendar David Ben-Gurion in the city of Tel Aviv read a declaration proclaiming the independence of the State of Israel, "based on the principles of liberty, justice and peace." For many months the new nation was not to enjoy that peace.
TEL AVIV, Israel, April 29 -- Israel, short of food, crowded with penniless immigrants and surrounded by enemies, began the celebration of the fourth anniversary of her independence with joy today.

Francis J. Sinnott was re-elected chairman of the Kings County Democratic Executive Committee for a two-year term yesterday at a meeting of the newly elected members of the committee in the Jefferson Building, 4-5 Court Square, Brooklyn.
BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., April 29 (AP) -- James A. Leary, Saratoga Republican leader, was expelled from the courtroom today during an outburst in the Saratoga gambling and corruption inquiry.

Despite record shipments in the first quarter the United States Steel Corporation, largest producer in the Government-seized industry, reported yesterday a decline in net income because of higher taxes, wages and other expenses.
The New York Plant and Flower Guild yesterday "opened a gate to a world unknown for children who live amid brick and stone."

Fashions for the fuller figure, ranging from size 18 to 60, were previewed for the press at Lane Bryant yesterday. Impressed with the fact that one of every four women in the country wears size 18 or larger, this store strives to combine figure flattery with important fashion notes of the day.

PARIS, April 30 -- Patou continues the middy theme this mid-season. Though buttoning down the center, the silhouette of a straight jacket that clings to the hips is that of a middy. But often there is the compromise of a belt holding the middy fullness into the waistline even though a cuff encircles the hips.

The Divine Providence Temporary Shelter for Children will be the beneficiary of an entertainment, known as the Maytime Fashion Festival, and card party to be held on the evening of May 9 in the Garden of the Ambassador.

Basketball Coach Adolph Rupp of the University of Kentucky said yesterday that he was "willing for the citizens of Kentucky to be the judge" about a charge made by General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit that Mr. Rupp had "aided and abetted immoral subsidization" of star players on his team.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Defense leaders warned today that a Congressional limit on the spending of already appropriated funds would curtail the delivery of fighting equipment for the nation's combat forces.

The former Mayor of an Illinois coalfield hamlet was arrested here yesterday as a fugitive from a charge that he had murdered two of his constituents last November, set fire to their home and dug up their hoard of buried coins.

LIVERPOOL, England, April 30 (Reuters) -- Tugs whistled a welcome and stevedores cheered as the veteran Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Australia slid into this Merseyside port today. The tribute marked the end of her last voyage.
CHICAGO, April 30 -- Officials of the International Trade Fair said here today that the exposition, scheduled to open Aug. 2 after two previous postponements, had been canceled.

The little woman came into her own yesterday at the Pierre Hotel when B. Altman Co., presented a showing of Varden petites, designed and scaled for the shorter figure. For the large percentage of women who are five feet five and under the answer is found in charming suits of cotton and silk shantung and pretty frocks of linen and chiffon chambray.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 30 -- Motion pictures were hailed today as being the "best ambassadors of all" in creating goodwill among nations by Dr. Roger Manvell, director of the British Film Academy. He presented the academy's scrolls for outstanding film achievement to Walt Disney for "Beaver Valley," voted the best documentary of 1951, and to Stephen Bosustow for the cartoon short, "Gerald McBoing-Boing."

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- New studies indicating that the spread of polymyelitis during summer months is linked to increasing humidity, and not temperature alone, were presented here today during closing sessions of the annual meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.

With the Presidential election scheduled for November, the United Church Women of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. will this summer and fall "seek righteousness for the nation."

As a physician called to the scene of many an automobile accident, and who has seen the dead and maimed victims of careless driving, I have for years stated that no car should be allowed on the road without sufficient liability coverage.

BALTIMORE, April 30 (AP) -- Undefeated Johnny Saxton, 21-year-old New York welterweight, knocked out Bobby Lee of Baltimore in the seventh round of their scheduled ten rounder in the Coliseum tonight.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier again yesterday and active months closed 13 to 38 points net lower than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- Ten Government officials were summoned today to appear before a House Judiciary subcommittee next week to explain the Justice Department's handling of a surplus tanker case involving Newbold Morris, who was ousted as corruption hunter.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 30 -- All Cabinet Ministers had a police guard around their homes tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended April 23:
American medicine is proud of the part it has played in increasing the lifespan in the United States, according to Dr. John W. Cline, president of the American Medical Association.

Albert Goldman, nearing the statutory age of 70, has retired as Postmaster of New York after more than a quarter of a century in public office and a lifetime of service to his community. His life is a New York success story. Born in Manhattan, he attended the public schools, did not go to college, but started work for the New York Edison Company in the Bronx at $6 a week.
DOVER, Del., April 30 -- An uncommitted twelve-member delegation with a definite pro-Taft tilt was elected today to represent Delaware at the Republican National Convention in Chicago July 7.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today virtually wiped out Senator Robert A. Taft's lead among delegates selected for the Republican National Convention after a landslide write-in victory in Massachusetts that demonstrated his vote appeal among both Republicans and Democrats.

The muddled steel situation invited both caution and considerable selling in the stock market yesterday. Volume held low and losses far outnumbered gains, leaving the composite rate 1.82 points below Tuesday's final level. Oddly enough, the steel stocks showed only a slight shading.

NEWMARKET, England, April 30 (AP) -- Thunderhead II, a French-bred colt racing for the first time in England, scored a five-length victory today in the 2,000 Guineas, first of the English 3-year-old classics.
PITTSBURGH, April 30 (AP) -- The Pirates broke their ten-game losing streak with an 11-5 victory over the Braves today, but had to offset three Boston home runs to do it.

General Kveder of the Yugoslav General Staff has delivered a lecture and a warning to Italians to be good -- or else! He points out in an article in the magazine Thirty Days that since the end of the Second World War Italy cannot be defended from a Communist-bloc attack without Yugoslavia's cooperation.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 30 -- Engineering experts of Pakistan and India have left for Washington in response to a suggestion of Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, that they should meet and evolve a plan for comprehensive utilization of waters of the Indus basin.
PARIS, April 30 -- The European Payments Union, considered one of the major achievements of United States policy toward the unity of Western Europe, has entered its long expected crisis.

There is an old saying that the proper time to plant the garden is when the oak leaf has passed the stage of budding and has become as big as the ear of a squirrel. It is a nice thought, since the oak and the squirrel have so much in common.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Net income of the Inland Steel Company in the first quarter of 1952 was 25 per cent lower than in the first three months of 1951, Edward L. Ryerson, chairman, and Clarence B. Randall, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting today.

In the last paragraph of W. S. White's report from Capetown on recent developments in the South African constitutional controversy (NEW YORK TIMES of April 23) it is stated that the Government's Court Bill establishing Parliament itself as the new "higher court" would set up something that, "so far as is known, has no example in parliamentary government."
BERLIN, April 30 (UP) -- Following is the text of today's Allied protest to the Russians on the Soviet jet fighter attack on a French airliner yesterday:

Banking syndicates will offer to investors today new issues of securities totaling more than $37,000,000 The offerings include public utility company first mortgage bonds, railroad equipment trust certificates and common stock of an oil company.
BOSTON, April 30 (AP) -- Ted Williams said his second baseball farewell in ten years with a two-run homer that gave the Red Sox a 5-3 victory over the Tigers today.

BOSTON, April 30 -- Results of yesterday's Presidential preferential primary showed today that both the Republican and Democratic voters of Massachusetts had given General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower his greatest political triumph to date.

LONDON, April 30 -- The National Executive Committee of the Labor party voted unanimously today in favor of British participation in a Four-power conference, including the Soviet Union, to discuss the possibility of free elections in Germany.

The Third Avenue Transit Corporation, which has been close to liquidation a number of times since it filed a bankruptcy petition nearly three years ago, notified Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman yesterday that it expected to have an operating profit of $1,674,500 this year.

HOBOKEN, N. J., April 30 -- Eighty-seven persons held an unusual reunion tonight aboard the Holland-America liner Ryndam at the Fifth Street pier here. They were part of the 400-member Ryndam University World Cruise group that had gone around the world in eight and a half months twenty-five years ago to travel as they studied.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., April 30 -- Television, which has often been accused of luring children from their homework and offsetting the work of the schools, indicated today that it could make a valuable contribution to education in the classroom.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Strike news and other outside developments overshadowed ordinary trade news in the grain market today, causing further sharp declines. The impact of the steel and oil industry walkouts was not especially sharp in the early trading, but as the session wore along and the markets showed little inclination to recover, selling increased, and long liquidation was again in evidence later in the day.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 30 -- Asserting that inflationary trends are "menacing security and happiness on the home front," a resolution presented here today at the fifty-eighth annual convention of the New Jersey State Federation of Womens Clubs asked the women to pledge themselves to accept austerity and self-control as weapons "in the struggle between the forces of democratic freedom and communistic slavery."

IT'S a pity a few copies of Robert Vogeler's impressive and unanswerable new book, "I Was Stalin's Prisoner,"* weren't parachuted into the recent Soviet trade clambake at Moscow. They would have broken up the show spectacularly. For this is the most memorable and revealing volume we have had on what can happen to American business men behind the Iron Curtain.

CAIRO, April 30 -- Several hundred young men assembled before the office of Premier Ahmed Naguib El Hilaly Pasha today, presented themselves as "young Wafdists" and cheered the Premier. They shouted such slogans as "The Young Wafd is for Hilaly and reform."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 -- In the opinion of Sol Rutchick, trainer of last year's Kentucky Derby winner, Count Turf, there'll be a 4-to-5 favorite in Saturday's seventy-eighth Derby. The favorite, of course, is Calumet Farm's Hill Gail.

The cooperation of industrial and labor groups in the training of students in the city's vocational high schools was praised yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri at an "Industry Day" luncheon in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 30 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley expressed a belief here today that the right of a President to seize an industry during an emergency will be defined by Congress.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in April declined from the preceding month and was the smallest for a corresponding month since 1949. Sales fell below the million-share mark in two full days' sessions for the first time since last July, the smallest being 984,310 shares last Monday.
HACKENSACK, N. J., April 30 -- Michael Orecchio was found guilty tonight of having allowed gambling to flourish while he was chief of detectives in Bergen County.
MUSKOGEE, Okla., April 30 -- Candidates for Muskogee County Sheriff today included:

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- Admiral Lynde D. McCormick, commander of the United States Atlantic Fleet, named a naval court of inquiry today to investigate the tragic collision of the destroyer-minesweeper Hobson and the aircraft carrier Wasp.

CAIRO, April 30 -- Egypt's flies have emerged triumphant from a three-year battle with the Rockefeller Foundation, which was cast in the role of the champion of modern science. The house fly is charged with accounting for most of the 50 per cent of Egyptian babies who die before they reach the age of 5.

The Cancer Crusade will be continued through May 31, John Reed Kilpatrick, president of the New York City Cancer Committee, announced yesterday at a meeting of the campaign's commerce and industry division at the Statler Hotel.

Consolidated net income of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago, one of the nation's major independent operating utilities, totaled $11,142,838 in the first quarter of this year, Charles Y. Freeman, chairman, told stockholders yesterday.
Do you not want to remind the American people that there is soon to be a chance to reconsider the Charter of the United Nations and perhaps to improve it in the light of experience?

TORONTO, April 30 (Canadian Press) -- Nickel production in the free world will total about 375,000,000 pounds a year when expansion programs are completed, Dr. John F. Thompson, chairman and president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., said at the annual meeting today.

The departmental trial of eighteen policemen accused of abetting the $20,000,000 bookmaking business of Harry Gross was set yesterday for next Monday morning pending the outcome of a legal move by the defendants to prevent the trial.

A small collection of summer frocks designed by Jacques Fath and made in America for Joseph Halpert are being shown at Lord Taylor. They are distinguished by cool, airy charm. Skirts spread with the semi-fullness of unpressed pleats, moving easily and gracefully.

TOKYO, Thursday, May 1 -- The Communists remained silent today on the secret over-all proposal by the United Nations Command for a settlement of the remaining issues involved in an armistice in Korea. For the first time since last November no meeting of any kind was held in the roadside tents at Panmunjom while the enemy delegation studied the Allied plan.

Seven sergeants of the New York City Transiit Police were promoted yesterday to the rank of lieutenant by the Board of Transportation. Previously, captains and lieutenants assigned to the transit lines had been lent by the Police Department.

CLEVELAND, April 30 -- An internal feud in the Textile Workers Union of America was brought to a head today when George Baldanzi, executive vice president of the union, was nominated to oppose Emil Rieve, president, in tomorrow's election.

A trade association official who testified at a morning session of the Senate Finance Committee this week, reports having had the sensation of talking to himself. At the start of the session, which concerned the Customs Simplification Bill, only one Senator was present.

The annual report of Pan American World Airways, mailed to stockholders yesterday, revealed the largest gross revenues in the company's history. Its nonmail gross of $153,855,000 was 27 per cent above that of last year. With mail revenue, the company grossed $188,560,000.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A loan of $30,000,000 to Australia, through purchase of a like amount of pounds for dollars, was announced today by the International Monetary Fund. The money is to be at the disposal of the Government up to Sept. 30 when the purchase must be completed.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 -- A vigorous defense of the controversial Methodist Federation for Social Action was voiced today by Bishop Francis J. McConnell, retired, one-time resident Bishop of the New York area of the Methodist Church.

CINCINNATI, April 30 -- With Larry Jansen tossing a sparkling three-hitter, the second in a row for a Giant hurler, and Davey Williams pacing the attack with four blows, Leo Durocher's National League champions apparently convinced the Reds today that the honeymoon on the American Rhine is about over.

PARIS, April 30 -- Jurists of the six countries of the Schuman Plan for merging Europe's steel and coal and of the European Army plan agreed here today to meet in Strasbourg at the end of May to discuss forming a constituent assembly for the six countries involved.
PITTSBURGH, April 30 -- The national steel strike remained in effect tonight despite a court ruling temporarily restoring the mills to Government possession.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The House Rules Committee has approved a resolution authorizing the House Interstate Commerce Committee to investigate the moral content of radio and television programs.

The election of Austin S. Igleheart as president of the Economic Club of New York was announced yesterday. Mr. Igleheart, who is president of the General Foods Corporation, succeeds Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American World Airways, who has served two terms.

PARIS, April 30 -- Madeleine Vramant continues her circular silhouette even to Mother Hubbard beach frocks that swing from the shoulders. In cherry or turquoise butcher linen without opening, they have shepherdess necklines and no sleeves.

The largest number of alien deportations in a single week for the last three or four years -- 268 -- got under way here yesterday, in what the Immigration and Naturalizaiton Service reported was an accelerated program directed by Commissioner Argyle R. Mackey.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury Snyder tonight announced the first big step in a program designed to raise almost $10,000,000,000 in deficit financing to pay for the defense build-up this year.

Bonds called for payment in April before maturity totaled $17,036,000, the smallest monthly figure since September, 1949, when $5,239,000 was retired. The April total compared with $230,970,000 in the preceding month, when retirement of $211,620,000 in Triborough Bridge and Tunnel bonds swelled the total, and with $134,523,000 in April, 1951.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 30 (AP) -- Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., and Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, the only two American entries, advanced to the quarter-final round of the British hard courts tennis championships today without losing a set.

FRANKFURT, Germany, April 30 -- Encouraged by a striking improvement in the Allied military forces in West Germany and elated by the steady progress of his own political fortunes, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower left here today after having said his last good-by to a United States army in the field.

The Military Sea Transportation Service, Navy Department, Atlantic Area, has presented the highest cash award ever made under its beneficial suggestion system to an employe, Neil McGilvery, first assistant engineer of the United States naval ship Henry Gibbins, for his new idea on how to handle stretcher patients when hoisted aboard ships of the agency's fleets.

BOULDER CITY, Nev., April 30 -- The final segment of the generation-old plan for the utilization of Hoover Dam was realized today when a switch was thrown diverting a portion of its power to Arizona. Up to now, Hoover power has gone only to Nevada and California.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The fabulous Austrian art collection which has been on tour in this country for the last two and a half years, is being loaded aboard a Navy vessel at Philadelphia for return to Europe.

LAUREL, Md., April 30 (UP) -- Nick Shuk completed a brilliant, thirty-three-day riding performance today as he closed the combined Laurel-Bowie meeting by piloting Ella K. Bryson's Wise Scholar to a six-length triumph in the twenty-second running of the $9,680 Bowie Kindergarten Stakes for 2-year-olds.

Action by the Foreign Assets Control Division of the Treasury Department to discourage further importation of articles suspected of having originated, wholly or in part, in Communist China caused resentment yesterday among affected importers.

The Soviet Union is obtaining large quantities of good quality uranium ore from German areas originally occupied by United States troops at the end of World War II, a recently escaped high Soviet official connected with these mines has revealed.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that the free world was "fortunate" that men of the caliber of Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, new Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, and Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, his chief of staff, were directing the military forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 30 -- Without a negative vote but with Canada and the United Kingdom abstaining, thirteen members of the United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs today agreed to recommend to the Economic and Social Council an extended field investigation into the coca leaf problem in Peru and Bolivia.

The inevitable collapse of Russia's Communist regime was prediceted last night by Admiral Alan G. Kirk, former Ambassador to the Soviet Union. He recommended a sympathetic understanding of the Russian people for the sake of their ultimate freedom and our own.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 30 -- The key first article in the United Nations' planned treaty on economic and social rights was approved here today by the Human Rights Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- Federal Judge Alan K. Grim cited Bishop Viorel D. Trifa of the Rumanian Orthodox Episcopate of America today for criminal contempt of court. Also cited were four men who had participated in the decision to consecrate and install the bishop here last Sunday despite a temporary injunction by Judge Grim against holding the ceremonies.

CINCINNATI, April 30 -- The League of Women Voters convention applauded today a plea by a South Carolina woman for Electoral College reform to improve the methods of choosing Presidents and Vice Presidents.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The Army announced today that its next inspector general would be Maj. Gen. Daniel Noce, now Chief of Staff of the United States European command in Germany. He will succeed Maj. Gen. Louis A. Craig, who is retiring June 1 after thirty-nine years' military service.

Crisp summer fashions were previewed for the press yesterday by Namm-Loeser's in Brooklyn. Featured were beach ensembles, spectator coordinates, trim cotton town suits, and sheer bouffant dance dresses that will be presented in a fashion show tonight at 6 o'clock in the store.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 -- Most folks think of racing in terms of the Whitneys, Vanderbilts, Wrights, Wideners and the like. They think of Plain Ben Jones, John Gaver and other famous trainers. They think of Man o' War and Citation and Count Fleet. They think only of the aristocrats.

Greater love for tea hath no man than that he should enjoy it at breakfast. Or at least so it seems to most of us with the morning coffee habit. One who starts every day with a big pot of tea, who has been described as a gourmet's gourmet, complained the other day that the fine Chinese teas have lost quality.

LAKE SEBAGO, N. Y., April 30 -- The new Sebago Beach development, a miniature Jones Beach at the southwest tip of the Harriman section of the Palisades Interstate Park, was opened for inspection today.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A bill to give both Congress and the President the emergency power to enjoin strikes in key industries for at least eighty days was introduced in the House of Representatives today. It set off immediate controversy, but was promised prompt consideration by the Committee on the Armed Services.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 -- Walking naked through the rain, if rain does indeed accompany or immediately follow an atomic bombing, was recommended today to Californians in a report adopted by the Commonwealth Club.

Supplies of gasoline in the country will last for about three months at present rates of consumption, provided that the oil strike does not spread. Even if every refinery in the country should close down, there are supplies for fifty-three days.

The first low-fare, tourist-class airline service between the United States and Europe got under way early this morning with planes of Trans World Airlines and El Al Israel Airlines leaving New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, for London and Paris. Both planes had every seat booked.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously sent its version of President Truman's foreign-aid bill to the floor today.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson asserted today that the United States was determined that William N. Oatis, Associated Press correspondent imprisoned in Czechoslovakia, be released and would not rest until he was.

The Walter bill revising and codifying our immigration and naturalization laws has been approved by the House of Representatives by a three-to-one vote, to the consternation of many Americans who are convinced that both this measure and its companion piece in the Senate, the McCarran bill, represent an illiberal and harmful approach to a most important subject.
HUNTINGTON, W. Va., April 30 (AP) -- A high school baseball player died early today, hours after he shrugged off being hit by a pitch.
PARIS, April 30 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower scratched his head thoughtfully today over his victory in the Massachusetts Republican primary and said:
TEL AVIV, Israel, April 30 -- The greatest display of military might in Palestine since the British departed was the high point of Israel's fourth independence anniversary celebrations today.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, April 30 (AP) -- Directors of Portsmouth Steel Corporation today voted against a dole of some $10,000,000 to stockholders in favor of possible future reinvestment of the money. The company conducted a tally of stockholder's proxy votes for and against the dole.
The so-called "mutiny" of a number of Air Force Reserve officers who have refused flying duty has obscured a more basic and far more serious development that strikes at the heart of air power.

BONN, Germany, April 30 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer asserted today that it was because of the United States that pressure had been imposed on the Allies and West Germany to conclude speedily the contractual agreement to replace the Occupation Statute.
Long Island's shoppers soon will be saying "Charge it" to many of the Nassau County merchants who previously have been unable to offer credit facilities.
BUFFALO, N. Y., April 30 (AP) -- The Most Rev. Joseph A. Burke was enthroned today as ninth Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Buffalo.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 30 -- United States and Brazilian officials are working intensively to find a settlement of questions of exporting profits made in Brazil by foreign concerns. New Brazilian rules providing more satisfactory conditions for foreign investors are expected to be published within a fortnight, but no details are yet available.

Israel's fourth anniversary as a nation was celebrated with colorful ceremonies at Ebbets Field last night under the auspices of the State of Israel $500,000,000 Bond Issue. Speakers at the fete emphasized Israel's strategic position in the Middle East because of her adherence to democratic ideals and principles and stressed the need for consolidating her economy.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson renewed today his appeal for the reduction of trade barriers between the United States and other free countries, which he said was needed if they "are to build the kind of economic and military strength we need for our security."
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The United States Court of Appeals, by a 5 to 4 vote restored Government control of the steel mills tonight to permit an appeal to the Supreme Court.
TOKYO, Thursday, May 1 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique 1,236, for Wednesday's operations:
New financing in April showed a sharp increase from a year ago. Public offerings of new bonds were the largest for any month since 1926; stock offerings the biggest for an April in six years.

GLASGOW, April 30 (Reuters) -- In English Soccer League games today, Tottenham Hotspur, last year's champion, finished second to Manchester United in this year's championship by defeating Chelsea, 2 -- 0.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 30 (AP) -- The Federal Director of Price Operations said yesterday the Office of Price Stabilization intends to "hold the line" on crude oil prices.

ROME, April 30 -- Under the headline "An Episode of Double Dealing," the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano referred for the first time today to what it called the "sad case of the unhappy apostate Alighiero Tondi."
Art objects acquired recently by the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be shown, starting today, in a summer-long exhibition in the Recent Accessions Room.

The most popular style in men's suits is the natural shoulder model, according to a survey conducted by Men's' Wear Magazine, a Fairchild publication. Sales of this model accounted for 37 per cent of last fall's business, while the broad shoulder drape model followed with 35 per cent and the "American Lounge" with 28 per cent.

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- Outfielder Bob Addis doubled in the twelfth inning with two out to score Bob Ramazzotti with the winning run today as the Cubs downed the Phillies, 9 -- 8, and took undisputed possession of second place in the National League.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- There is no time that can be described as ideal for a steel strike, but this particular walkout at this particular time is calculated to cause more trouble in the field of foreign policy than almost any other imaginable.

ROME, April 30 -- No appreciable progress is believed to have been made thus far by Admiral William M. Fechteler toward solving the problem of creating a single North Atlantic Treaty Organization naval command in the Mediterranean. Admiral Fechteler, United States Chief of Naval Operations, has had talks with top naval officials in Paris and Rome and plans to visit Amsterdam and London, before returning to Washington next week.
PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP) -- The District Attorney's office said today that a man had been held under bail for seventeen months, charged with a robbery that three others had admitted.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The President of the United States, according to Judge Pine of the Federal District Courts, must have the authority of a specific Congressional statute for executive actions that abrogate the constitutional guarantees of private rights under the cover of a proclamation that a national emergency exists and a statement that the security of the nation requires them.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The White House has declined to surrender the uncensored private diaries and personal papers of the late James V. Forrestal, former Secretary of Defense, to the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

TORONTO, April 30 (Canadian Press) -- Basic television advertising rates in Toronto will be $1,600 an hour and in Montreal $500 an hour, A. D. Dunton, chairman of the board of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, announced today.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, May 1 (AP) -- Artillery fire roared along the Western Korean battle front today and United Nations ground forces were alert for any Communist May Day tricks.

Isidore Nagler, a vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., for the last twenty-three years, was elected last night general manager of the union's New York Cloak Joint Board, with which 60,000 cloakmakers are affiliated.

Members of the Colonial Dames of America held their annual luncheon, meeting and election of officers yesterday at the Pierre. Mrs. Madison H. Lewis was reelected president of the organization, which was founded in 1890 and comprises women of Colonial ancestry.

Fred Fisher, 34-year-old ex-patrolman turned bookmaker, took first place "honors" in Federal Court yesterday and Judge John W. Clancy promptly awarded him three months in prison and a $1,000 fine for the distinction.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., April 30 -- Letters sent by the Bowery Savings Bank to thousand of small homeowners in this area whose mortgages it holds, asking them to increase their escrow deposits by $3 a month to meet anticipated increases in town and school taxes, aroused indignation among town officials today.

BERLIN, April 30 -- In a new and stronger protest concerning yesterday's Soviet attack on a passenger-laden French airliner, the three Western powers rejected today the Soviet version of the incident.
Commodity future price movements were mixed yesterday. Hides, cocoa and coffee were higher. Rubber and tin were lower. Sugar, wool and vegetable oils moved irregularly.

For the benefit of those who had not noticed the Weather Bureau reported yesterday that last month was "unusually wet and cloudy" with the total precipitation of 5.80 inches the greatest in any April since 1909, when 5.93 fell.

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., April 30 -- The special grand jury investigating gambling and corruption in Saratoga County returned seventeen-count indictment today against Dr. Arthur J. Leonard, Democratic leader.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States, in annual meeting here, called today for a constitutional amendment limiting the taxing powers of Congress.

Expansion of Roosevelt Hospital to include complete facilities for psychiatric care was approved yesterday by the hospital's board of trustees. This will make the hospital the only general hospital in New York to have such a program. The only other hospital in the United States that gives psychiatric care to both children and adults is that at the University of Michigan.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 30 -- Columbia's baseball team scored five runs in the first inning and went on to defeat Rutgers, 11 -- 8, on windswept University Heights field today. It was the Scarlet's fifth loss after winning four straight and marked Columbia's fifth triumph against three defeats and one tie.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 2,025,000 barrels last week, the largest drop since the week ended July 14, 1951, when gasoline stocks fell 2,636,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, turned down today Arizona's plan for state-Federal aid to the permanently and totally disabled because it barred participation by Indians who live on Government reservations.
BOSTON, April 30 (AP) -- A new kind of microscopic atom bomb for cancer was announced to the Society of American Bacteriologists today.

A proposed contract for the city's purchase of the Rockaway Beach Division of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road for $8,500,000 has been approved by the Board of Transportation and William Wyer, trustee for the railroad.

I notice that Dr. Gallup says that the Democrats need only the South and four other big states to win the Presidential election this fall. He says that the South and four big states like New York, California, Illinois and Massachusetts have a majority of the electoral votes.

ST. LOUIS, April 30 -- Manager Eddie Stanky tonight inserted himself in the starting line-up for the first time this season and his Cardinals broke a three-game losing streak by routing the first-place Dodgers, 14 -- 2, before 15,901 fans.

THE first week-end in May always brings brighter prospects for the fisherman, both on salt and fresh water, and although there is something of a Delphic touch in the report of the weater forecaster, it cannot dim the possibilities for good fishing.

Donors to the Red Cross blood program contributed 1,339 pints on Tuesday, bringing to 24,764 pints the total collected in the first twenty-nine days of April, it was announced yesterday. The largest amount collected Tuesday -- 438 pints -- came from personnel and students of Columbia University, who gave 840 pints in the two days a bloodmobile visited the campus.

PARIS, April 30 (AP) -- The "Masterpieces of the Twentieth Century," a festival of music, art and literature designed to show the wares of Western culture, opened tonight with only a couple of dissonant notes.

Bad weather yesterday afternoon caused the temporary abandonment of the air search for the Stratocruiser Good Hope, last reported at 2:15 A. M. Tuesday flying at 14,250 feet over north central Brazil.

A nose, a nose and half a length separated the first four in the fifty-fourth running of the $10,000-added Fashion Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park. Leroy Hetzel's Countess Jane, scoring her third straight, emerged on top, the third choice paying $9 for $2 for outnosing Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Home-Made.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- House tax investigators sought vainly today to discover how James B. E. Olson, former Alcohol Tax Unit supervisor at New York, could spend more than $213,000 during a four-year period from 1947 through 1950 when his known income was only $178,000.

More than 163,000 dog licenses have been issued in the city since Jan. 1, an increase of 10,000 over the first four months of 1951, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Federal income tax liabilities of American corporations rose $4,700,000,000 above 1950 to a record total of $20,100,000,000 last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today in one of its regular studies of the working capital of corporations. The rise in tax liability reflected the higher tax rates effective during the year, as well as the excess profits tax.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. "The Atomic City," a Paramount adventure featuring Gene Barry, Lydia Clarke and Lee Aaker, is at the Mayfair. Jerry Hopper directed and Joseph Sistrom produced from a screen play written by Sidney Boehm.

Mayor Impellitteri officially opened yesterday the 1952 fund campaign of the United Cerebral Palsy organization here at a ceremony in City Hall. He lit a Beacon of Hope, which he said "symbolizes the hope held forth for New York's 32,000 cerebral palsy sufferers."
FRANKFURT, Germany, April 25 (By Air Mail) -- When the United States displaced persons law expires in June, at least 6,000 visas intended for war orphans in Europe will remain unused.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 30 -- Premier Marshal Tito announced tonight that Yugoslavia was prepared to place approximately 2,000,000 men in the field in the event of another war.

Senator George W. Malone, Republican of Nevada, made a strong plea for the retention of "the form of government that Washington admonished us to maintain" in addressing a noon ceremony yesterday on the steps of the Sub-treasury, held in commemoration of the 163d anniversary of George Washington's inauguration on that site.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (UP) -- Little Bobby Shantz, supported by Elmer Valo's three-run homer, pitched the Athletics to a 3-to-1 victory over the Indians tonight to snap the A's seven-game losing streak.

NEWARK, April 30 -- A ceremony marking the shipment of the 3,000,000th ton of military equipment under the Mutual Defense Assistance program was held on the flight deck of the aircraft carrier Tripoli this afternoon at Port Newark.

Consolidated net sales of the United States Rubber in the first three months this year showed a substantial increase over a year ago, but net profit declined to $6,247,733 from $9,076,755, H. E. Humphreys Jr., chairman, reported in the quarterly statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.

LONDON, April 30 -- The deadlock between Britain and Egypt over the future of the Sudan appeared as insoluble as ever today at the conclusion of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's ten days of consultations here with British representatives in both areas.

New counsel for William W. Remington, 34-year-old former Government economist facing a second perjury trial, filed motions yesterday in Federal Court for the dismissal of two perjury indictments. Arguments on the motions will be heard Monday.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Edward G. Robinson, stage and movie actor, heard himself called a "sucker" for Communist front organizations today and he took it with a broad smile.

HOBOKEN, N. J., April 30 -- John H. Schmidt, a teller in the Hudson Trust Company's Fourteenth Street branch here has declined to accept a $9,000-a-year life income from the estate of a childhood friend, and he refuses to tell why.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- The Defense Department today announced a new total of 107,965 Korean battle casualties, an increase of 299 over last week's report.
Andrew M. McBurney has been appointed general manager of sales for the Oxford Paper Company and Oliver S. Barrie has been named manager of sales for Oxford Miami Paper Company, a subsidiary.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts yesterday designated May 12 for the sale of issues of new bonds totaling $53,860,000. The obligations are to finance various improvements and will come due from 1952 to 1972.

The Maritime Administration has notified Hoboken that the agency would lease six Government-owned piers to the New Jersey city by Aug. 1 or earlier, it was announced yesterday by Mayor Fred M. DeSapio.

CINCINNATI, April 30 -- A new rubber-like material with marked resistance to wear, heat and weather has been developed and is expected to find use in such articles as auto tire treads, white sidewall tires, wire and cable coverings, it was announced here today at the opening session of three-day meeting of the Division of Rubber Chemistry of the American Chemical Society.

The award of its gold medal to Carl Sandburg by the American Academy of Arts and Letters is eminently fitting. Poet, newspaper man, historian, wandering minstrel, collector of folk songs, spinner of tales for children, his place in American letters is not easily categorized.
DENVER, April 30 -- An often-postponed strike of oil workers swept across the country today. It closed some refineries, curtailed pipeline operations and started motorists lining up for gasoline.

LONDON, April 30 -- Most sections of the Stock Exchange opened a new bookkeeping account in subdued mood today. British Government securities fell about 2s 6d (35 cents). Foreign bonds were erratic with Japanese issues finishing irregularly lower.

Proposals of the Securities and Exchange Commission to charge $50 "registration fees" for brokerage offices and to "levy a $10 head tax" on securities salesmen are "of doubtful constitutional validity," Richard H. Crooks, chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, asserted in Washington yesterday.

If "The Male Animal" seems funnier now than it did twelve years ago, everything else in the world must have been going backward. This is the comedy James Thurber and Elliott Nugent wrote in 1940, managing somehow to make everything confusing and hilarious.

LOS ANGELES, April 30 -- Herman Steiner, of this city, former United States chess champion, took the lead after three rounds of the Hollywood International Invitation tournament today, with a score of 2 1/2 -- 1/2.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., April 30 -- John Foster Dulles, former Republican adviser to the State Department, charged tonight that the nation's military procurement program was falling dangerously behind Russia's because unrealistic Washington leaders were content to be "very patriotic -- on paper."

The prosecution lost an attempt yesterday to limit the amount of evidence introduced in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders, charged with conspiring to advocate and teach the overthrow of the Government of the United States by force and violence.

The rezoning of a large section of lower Manhattan between Canal and Fulton Streets -- an area that includes City Hall, Foley Square, Columbus Park, the Worth Street textile center and part of Chinatown -- was proposed yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

Dr. J. B. De Berenguer Cesar, Consul General of Brazil, yesterday presented to City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses the highest honor of Brazil, the Southern Cross. The presentation was made at a reception and cocktail party at Dr. Cesar's home, 290 Park Avenue, attended by seventy-five persons, including Mayor Impellitteri, who congratulated Mr. Moses.
The election of Winthrop Rockefeller as a member of the New York University Council, governing body of the university, was announced yesterday by George Emlen Roosevelt, president of the council.
MINEOLA, L. I., April 30 -- The Sea Cliff Summer Theatre won its fight against what was termed prohibitive zoning restrictions in a decision handed down in Supreme Court here today.

Displaying many new faces and few of their old habits, the Browns made a striking 1952 debut at the Stadium yesterday by routing Vic Raschi and thrashing the Yankees, 9 -- 4, in the first game of a double-header.

PARIS, April 30 -- Europeans who have for months been preparing displays for the Chicago International Trade Fair were incensed today to learn of the cancellation of the project and the alleged bankruptcy of the organization, which is reported to have taken place without any formal notice.
GLASGOW, April 30 (AP) -- Scotland's team gave a lesson in the British style of soccer to a United States squad tonight by winning the first international game between the two nations, 6--0.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Mme. Henri Bonnet, wife of the French Ambassador, today presented to the Red Cross $11,195, the result of one of the most remarkable balls in the history of the nation's capital. It was held last Saturday night.
Proponents of the scheme to tap the Hudson River as an auxiliary source of the city's water supply attacked yesterday what they said was "the myth about the purity" of the present sources.

Science and advertising came in for considerable discussion yesterday among some segments of the advertising fraternity. The relation of science and cigarette advertising was a subject for comment by Allen L. Brassell, president of the United States Testing Company.

The Bronx branch of Hunter College, which became a four-year coeducational college last September, will celebrate its twentieth anniversary tomorrow with a convocation for students and their parents in the assembly hall of the Manhattan building, Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street. The program will start at 2 P. M.

Dr. William S. Carlson, new president of the State University of New York, called yesterday upon educators, as part of the general team promoting health and welfare, to develop a "purposeful uniformity of educational philosophy." Dr. Carlson, who was installed in his new post on April 1, spoke at a luncheon of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City at the Biltmore Hotel.
Shakespeare's infrequently produced comedy, "Much Ado About Nothing," will be presented this evening at 8 o'clock at the Music Box by Luther Greene, in association with Jerry Tishman.

The May Department Stores Company, which operates a chain, achieved the highest volume of sales in its history with $424,991,000 transacted in the fiscal year ended with January, Morton D. May, president, reported yesterday. Sales for the preceding fiscal year totaled $416,689,000.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Accelerated tax amortization certificates covering 177 new or expanded defense facilities, and involving an investment of $513,060,000, were approved by the Defense Production Administration from April 3 to 10, it was announced today.
Communist and other left-wing organizations will march in their traditional May Day parade today under the watchful eyes of 1,800 police and detectives.

The youth of Germany has no interest in militarism now, Anne O'Hare McCormick, member of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday at the closing lecture of the course for teachers given by THE TIMES in cooperation with the city's Board of Education.

Approval of a reorganization plan which gives immediate control to a new operating group, and which makes $1,000,000 in new funds available, was announced here yesterday by directors of Yellow Transit Freight Lines, Inc., a common-carrier truck line.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Eddie Robinson's home run off 43-year-old Bobo Newsom with two out in the eleventh inning gave a 4-3 victory to the White Sox over the Senators in the second game of a twilight-night double-header after the White Sox had won the opener, 7 -- 3, tonight.

GENEVA, April 30 -- Many of the Arab refugees in and around what was formerly Palestine are eating more and better than settled Arabs among whom they live, the World Health Organization said here toaay.
ALBANY, April 30 -- Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, State Commissioner of Education, today urged immediate planning to meet the problem of overcrowded classrooms and inadequate buildings.

MEXICO CITY, April 30 -- The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions lost its uneasy foothold in Mexico today when four of the nation's eleven labor federations, including the only two affiliated with that anti-Communist organization, merged to form a new Union of Industrial and Farm Workers.

Ola Elizabeth Winslow, author of "Jonathan Edwards," which won the 1940 Pulitzer Prize in Biography, has a new work on Macmillan's list for June 24. It is "Meetinghouse Hill, 1630-1783," discussing the men of Colonial days and the battles they waged over self government.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- Economic Stabilizer Roger L. Putnam said today he sees no need for keeping curbs on consumer installment buying. But, he told the House Banking Committee. Congress should continue the Federal Reserve Board's power to employ the credit curbs because they may be needed in the future.

The new Democratic State Committee, elected at the primary on April 22, will meet today in the Biltmore Hotel to elect eight delegates-at-large and eight alternates-at-large to the Democratic national convention. Each delegate-at-large will have a one-half vote.

PANAMA CITY, Fla., April 30 -- Senator Richard B. Russell's Presidential popularity campaign team toured Florida's "Old South" section today and delivered a series of talks warning voters that Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee was a partner in a left-wing "legislative axis."
Colorful spectacles of the heavens will be depicted in the May-June show, "Weather and the Stars," beginning today in the Hayden Planetarium, Eighty-first Street and Central Park West.

BERLIN, April 30 -- This city girded itself tonight for two rival May Day demonstrations tomorrow. Although hundreds of thousands were expected to take part in rallies three-quarters of a mile apart, Western officials were hopeful only minor clashes would take place.

JACKSON, Miss., April 30 (UP) -- Backers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower seized control of the State Republican convention today and forced the election of a slate of delegates pledged to the general.

The ceremony was brief. Seven-year-old Luise Macomber, with blue eyes and blonde hair shining in the sun, made no speech. Her audience of seven lads beamed. She smiled for the photographers and waved a soda bottle filled with water from Westchester Creek.

Even while the courts are dealing with the grave constitutional issue raised by President Truman's seizure of the steel industry, by Judge Pine's order restoring the mills to their owners, and by the Court of Appeals' decision granting a stay of Judge Pine's order, the nation faces a steel strike that may result in incalculable harm to the defense program.

W. L. Little has been elected president and chief executive officer in all operating matters of Bucyrus-Erie Company, it was announced yesterday. N. R. Knox, president, was elected vice chairman of the board. L. S. Cline and F. C. Weiblen were elected secretary and treasurer, respectively.

PARIS, April 30 -- Delegates negotiating a treaty to create the European Defense Community hope to finish most of their labors Saturday but if a draft is initialed then it will be incomplete in spite of much progress toward a solution of the outstanding problems.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- The Young Women's Christian Association, opening its nineteenth national convention here today with 3,000 delegates on hand, heard Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Rumolo, Philippines Ambassador to the United States and permanent delegate of his country to the United Nations; describe the United Nations' first six years of eforts to maintain world peace and promote international welfare as "only the spade work" for the "world of tomorrow."

A mixed reception of cheers, applause, boos and carefully aimed ripe tomatoes greeted Communists and members of many left-wing groups yesterday as they marched down Eighth Avenue to Union Square in the city's annual May Day parade.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., May 1 -- Temporarily relieved of her duties as a housewife, an Air Force veteran who has logged 1,400 hours as a pilot is back on duty. She is the only woman among 165 World War II "retreads" taking a fifteen-day refresher course at headquarters of the First Air Force.

New sources of revenue to support the city's public schools must be found, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday in discussing the Budget Director's recent cut of $22,000,000 in the Board of Education's operating expense request.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Grain futures generally showed a stronger undertone today with buying on setbacks broader and pressure of long liquidation easier. Uncertainty over labor developments, the Korean situation and optimistic crop reports also checked buying.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 1 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, apparently stung by implications that his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination represented a Southern political maneuver to establish a third party, spoke out sharply today in defense of his record of party regularity.

To emphasize its support of a strong civil rights program, the Democratic State Committee for the first time yesterday named a Negro, Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., as a delegate-at-large to the Democratic National Convention.
Three Russian priests, now teachers and lecturers at Fordham University, were among the 313 students and faculty members who donated blood yesterday in the university's gymnasium.
BERLIN, May 1 -- More than 1,000,000 Berliners participated today in rival May Day demonstrations on two sides of the city.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 1 -- Israeli workers marked May Day with stoppage of work and parades throughout the country.

The steel situation struck another substantial blow yesterday to the stock market. With only a slight expansion in business, the list sagged to the lowest levels since last November, reducing the composite rate further by 1.68 points.

Senator Brien McMahon of Connecticut formally announced yesterday his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President. He thus joined Senators Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, Richard B. Russell of Georgia and Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma, and W. Averell Harriman of New York, Mutual Security Administrator, as avowed seekers of the honor.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Physicists at the opening of the American Physical Society's meeting here this morning were urged to apply atom-splitting techniques to the study of germs in order to learn the mechanics of bacteria and viruses by germ-splitting.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Armed Services Committee of the House of Representatives scheduled today hearings to start next Wednesday on proposed legislation designed to give either the President or Congress emergency power to enjoin strikes in key industries indefinitely where labor disputes persisted.

GENEVA, May 1 (AP) -- Dr. Brock Chisholm, Director of the World Health Organization, said today 1951 was "an encouraging year for the health of the world." The statement was in his annual report prepared for the World Health Assembly here next week.

LOUISVILLE, May 1 -- It was lovely at Churchill Downs this morning. Unfortunately the morning always comes much too early at race tracks. The horse is such a privileged character in the barn area that he probably could sleep late if he so desired. But these gallant chargers insist on getting up with the dawn and filling their lungs with fresh, invigorating air.

Homeless children, many of them babies, are the chief concern of the Sheltering Arms Childrens Service at 122 East Twenty - ninth Street. The service, one of the Greater New York Fund's 423 participating agencies, devotes itself to finding substitute homes for these helpless victims of circumstances.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Any stoppage in the steel industry extending for more than a month will bring drastic ctions by the National Production Authority to curb commercial building, cut back automobile production and to put a general clamp on consumer durable goods production, officials of the defense agency said today.

An overall decline in the number of advertisers using television during the first quarter of this year, as reported by Rorabaugh TV Report. During the quarter such advertisers totaled 6,400, compared with 6,730 in the fourth quarter of 1951. Network advertisers dropped from 198 in the fourth quarter to 188 in the first quarter, spot advertisers from 1,370 to 1,277, and local-retail advertisers from 5,162 to 4,395, according to the study.

Five hundred persons attended a tea yesterday afternoon at St. Luke's Home for Aged Women, 114th Street and Broadway, which is celebrating its 100th anniversary. Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan of the New York Protestant Episcopal Diocese cut the birthday cake, which bore 100 smaller candles and a larger one symbolic of the home's future.
KEYPORT, N. J., May 1 -- Flames and explosions partly destroyed the chemical plant of Nord Co., refiners of coal tar products, here early this morning, causing damage estimated at $200,000.

A cool and pretty summer wardrobe, composed entirely of McKettrick dresses, was presented yesterday to the public on the third floor of Gimbels. A news feature was the large proportion of nylon dresses.

The N. B. C. Television Opera Theatre, which closed its season last night, is beginning to develop a repertoire of its own. For its eighth and final presentation of the 1951-52 period, it repeated Puccini's "Gianni Schicchi," which it had done last year in a notably successful version.

BOSTON, May 1 (AP) -- Duane Pillette threw a five-hitter against the Red Sox and batted in three runs today to give the Browns a 6-1 victory that moved them within a game of the American League's top place.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 1 -- About 2,100 men engaged in the first Marine Corps atomic warfare maneuvers today as the Atomic Energy Commission set off another atomic bomb at its Nevada proving ground, the twenty-eighth bomb exploded by this country.
CLEVELAND, May 1 (AP) -- Emil Rieve was re-elected president today of the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., defeating George Baldanzi 1,223 to 720.

ST. LOUIS, May 1 (AP) -- Successive home runs by Nippy Jones and Connie Ryan in the sixth inning wipe out the Cardinals' lead and sent the Phillies on to a 6-to-3 victory tonight. Robin Roberts kept eight Cardinal hits scattered in earning his third victory of the season.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The dispute in the steel industry is now centered in the constitutional questions growing out of the President's seizure. But it was the vote of the "public members" of the Wage Stabilization Board on wage increases and the union shop that sent the controversy toward seizure and the Supreme Court because, joining with the labor members against those from industry, they created the board majority.

In a grass-carpeted field in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, bordered by 200 lavishly blooming Japanese cherry trees, a pretty blonde Brooklyn high school girl was crowned "Queen of the May" yesterday afternoon. The pageant, with a Maypole and folk dances, is an annual event for the 4,000 girls of Prospect Heights High School, which is near the gardens at Classon Avenue and Union Street.

James F. McHugh's Jam, a 5-year-old son of Impound, scored an easy victory in the International Steeplechase Handicap, the first jumping feature of the horse racing season, at Belmont Park yesterday. Ridden by Earl Phelps, Jam moved competently all the way through the course of about two miles, to beat the Brookmeade Stable's Flaming Comet by eight lengths.

CHICAGO, May 1 (AP) -- Live hogs reached a new high level since Feb. 15 today at $18,35 a hundred pounds at the top. This was a gain of 85 cents for the week to date. Cattle were steady to 50 cents lower and sheep mostly steady. Department of Agriculture reports of Livestock trading here today:
BOSTON, May 1 -- Complete, unofficial returns from Massachusetts' 1,739 election precincts today showed the following results in Tuesday's write-in Presidential preference primary:

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The State Department announced today a new ban on travel by United States citizens to the Soviet Union and all Moscow - controlled Communist countries, unless permission was specificially given by the United States Government.

As balloting began for eighteen directors of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company yesterday a woman stockholder rose to address the annual meeting. "I feel," she said, "that there are too many directors. I should be happy to see some of those nominated today rise and announce their resignation or withdrawal."

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The United States Court of Appeals, again dividing 5 to 4, refused today to attach a wage freeze requested by the steel companies to its order reinstating the Government's seizure of the mills.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 1 (AP) -- Doris Hart and Shirley Fry advanced to the semi-final round of the British hard courts championships today.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- This afternoon in Wrigley Field was only a little less harrowing to Chuck Dressen, manager of the Dodgers, than last night in Sportsman's Park. His pitching was sour and hitting anemic, resulting in a decisive 7-to-2 triumph by the Cubs.

Operations of the Continental Oil Company and its subsidiaries in the initial quarter this year resulted in a net income of $9,386,000 after all charges including $4,000,000 for taxes, according to the consolidated report released today.
BRANFORD. Conn., May 1 (AP) -- Three women perished today in a fire that destroyed a rest home for the elderly, and another died of a heart attack.

A subsidiary of the Metropolitan Distributing Corporation, one of the country's largest truck rental companies, bought the blockfront on the west side of Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive from 105th to 106th Streets for immediate improvement with a building for its own use.

PARIS, May 1 -- Clashes between the police and demonstrating North African workmen in the mining region of northeastern France today produced casualties on both sides in the only violent incidents in the nation's May Day celebration.

" He Hanged Them High, a new work by Homer Croy, will be published May 27 by Duell Sloan Pearce-Little, Brown. Subtitled "An Authentic Account of the Fanatical Judge Who Hanged Eighty-eight Men," the story describes the life and times of Isaac C. Parker, judge of the United States District Court for Western Arkansas, at Fort Smith, in the last part of the last century.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- Navy Secretary Dan A. Kimball said today that a House-imposed $46,000,000,000 limit on military spending next year "can only cause irreparable loss to the Navy and the Government."

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 1 (AP) -- Top-seeded Vic Seixas, the No. 1 player in the United States, gained the semi-final round of the Bermuda international tennis tournament today with a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Sidney Wood of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Senate voted without debate or dissent today to take from the President the authority to appoint a Recorder of Deeds for the District of Columbia and give it to the local Commissioners.

Consolidated net sales of the City Stores Company attained a new high of $219,243,471, including leased departments, for the period covering Feb. 1, 1951 to Feb. 2, 1952. This exceeded the previous year's record volume of $205,703,941 by 6.58 per cent, the annual report of Albert M. Greenfield, board chairman, disclosed yesterday.

Joan Denise Schiadaresis, 4 years old, was strangled with a scarf and then the body was put in a bathtub of water by her mother yesterday in their home, 44-21 Mac-Nish Street, Elmhurst, Queens, according to the police.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 1 -- Arab and Asian delegates appealed directly to the powerful Latin-American bloc today for help in getting the Tunisian case a hearing before the United Nations.
The State of Maryland announced yesterday that it will receive bids May 13 on issues of school bonds totaling $11,032,000. The bonds will come due from 1955 to 1967.

LANSING, Mich., May 1 -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams gave a detailed report today on last week's Jackson Prison riot to an informal joint session of the legislature and made recommendations to prevent a recurrence of trouble in the prison.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- President Truman appealed to Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., tonight to call off the steel strike and asked him and presidents of the six largest steel companies to meet at the White House at 10 A. M. Saturday.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 15 to 28 points net higher than on Wednesday.
A press preview of summer separates preceded the opening of Ohrbach's Sun Shop yesterday.

Nine members of a Norwegian-American singing society were injured, two seriously, at 6:30 o'clock last night when an airplane loading ramp collapsed. The ramp was attached to a Scandinavian Airlines System plane on which the singers were posing for a publicity photograph at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

MUNICH, Germany, May 1 -- Apparently seeking to employ the religious simile to give a message of ultimate hope to the oppressed populace of Poland, the Roman Catholic Primate of that satellite country has issued a pastoral letter, reminding his flock that, although "Hell trembles today and mourns," it should be recalled that Christ led mankind "out of a bottomless abyss."

The pressing need for a fairly immediate solution to the labor difficulties in the steel industry has caused much discussion and various assessments of blame. What has not been seen or heard is serious thought on just what might be done to prevent a recurrence of the present disastrous confusion.

TAIPEI, Formosa, May 1 -- Maj. Gen. William C. Chase, commander of the United States Military Assistance Advisory Group here, declared today that the combat efficiency, morale and physical condition of the Chinese Nationalist Army had improved considerably during the past year.
A marked decline in the urge to fly is indicated by the increasing difficulties the armed services are having in persuading young men to apply for flight training.

THE ice is leaving the Maine lakes with a speed exceeded only by the melting velocity of the same commodity in a glass of "Kennebago Lightning," according to reports from wardens in near, remote and "scattered" sections of the state.

For all of Art Houtteman's earlier superb pitching and the long-range batting of Vic Wertz, who slammed a pair of two-run homers, the Yankees were in excellent position to beat the Tigers last night at the Stadium. Even though they went into the ninth trailing by two runs, Casey Stengel's men had the visitors reeling as Bobby Brown. Bob Cerv and pinch-hitter Johnny Mize rifled solid singles, good for a run.

Three brief paragraphs in this newspaper yesterday told of the retirement from Government service of Dr. Hugh H. Bennett. Three volumes would be insufficient to tell in detail what Dr. Bennett has done during the last half-century for his country and for the world.

Federal sea safety authorities are making a minute search of the entire fleet of city-owned ferry-boats for unsatisfactory life-jackets as the result of official rejection of 800 nonfloating jackets a month ago.

PITTSBURGH, May 1 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., promised tonight that he would reply by noon tomorrow to President Truman's request that he call off the national steel strike.

TOKYO, Friday, May 2 -- Scores of violent street clashes broke out in Tokyo yesterday, bringing death to one Japanese and injuries to about 450 persons, including several Americans, as throngs of May Day demonstrators went on the rampage in one of the most serious riots in Japan's labor history.
Combined dollar volume of major New York City department stores for April was 2 per cent less than for the like month of last year, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Manhattan defeated New York University, 5 -- 2, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. The victory made the Jaspers' Conference mark 3-2 and left the Violets with a 3-3 record.

LONDON, May 1 (Reuters) -The International Wheat Council has reduced Australia's export quota for the current crop year from 2,414,000 metric tons to 1,959,500 tons, it was disclosed tonight. Of this cut of 454,500 tons, 150,000 tons have been allotted as an increase in Canada's export quota, raising it from 6,341,000 to 6,491,000 tons.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that sales by wholesale concerns in the first quarter of 1952 were 11 per cent below a year ago.

Corruption must be replaced by "character and character-building such as rose from homes, schools and the Young Men's Christian Association," the Rev. Charles C. Noble, Dean of Hendrick's Chapel at Syracuse University, declared last night at the centennial dinner of the Brooklyn and Queens Y. M. C. A.

John Cacopardo, 42 years old, was convicted fifteen years ago of second-degree murder in Kings County Court, principally on the testimony of his uncle, Paul Petrillo, who three years later was executed in Pennsylvania as the "evil genius" in an arsenic murder-for-insurance ring.

CINCINNATI, May 1 -- Wide differences of opinion on new areas of action by the League of Women Voters kept delegates to the league's annual convention debating through another late session here today. With little time left before adjournment tomorrow noon. the program remained uncertain.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Senate Labor Committee today approved a bill to modify effects of the Taft-Hartley law on unions in the building trades. Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, ranking Republican on the committee, is a sponsor of the bill.

The forty-five family apartment house at 65 West 192d Street has been sold by Buren Estates, Inc., to Joseph Nayvin and Yermachiel Ben Zeev through Allan S. Feldman Co., brokers. The property is assessed at $160,000 and was sold subject to mortgages of $119,425.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1 -The story of the Wright brothers,as told by Fred Kelly in the book "The Miracle at Kitty Hawk,"published last year, will be brought to the screen by the Stanley Kramer Company. Beyond purchasing the screen rights Mr. Kramer has not yet made any plans for the film, which will be produced as part of his program for Columbia distribution.

A request that Chile modify its April 24 ban on imports previously admitted from this country without a license has not been answered, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York reported yesterday. The association made the request on Monday through the United States Embassy in Santiago, urging exemption on orders placed before April 24, particularly those for which letters of credit have been established.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 1 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois appealed to Oregon Democrats tonight to disregard his name on this state's Presidential primary ballot May 16, but he refused to say he would spurn the Presidential nomination in event of a draft at the national convention in Chicago July 21.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The White House official social program was renewed today with a 5 P. M. diplomatic reception after a four-year lapse occasioned by rebuilding.

The ice cream industry in the metropolitan area put into effect yesterday an industry-wide pension and welfare program financed by thirty-two employing companies and affecting 3,200 employes and 10,000 dependents.
