SAIGON, Indo-China, May 1 -Jean Letourneau, France's new Minister-Resident in Indo-China, returned here today from a week's air tour during which he visited the rulers and top officials of the three Indo-China states of Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 -- A surprise move to restrict lay representation on the administrative boards of every Methodist Church to those persons who "shall be total abstainers from intoxicating liquors" threw the denomination's quadrennial general conference here into a mild uproar today.

A former New York exporter, arrested yesterday in his home at Daytona, Fla., and a freight-forwarding company have been indicted here on a charge of making possible the illegal trans-shipment of machinery bearings behind the Iron Curtain.

The four-story apartment house accommodating twenty-three families at 15-17 Varet Street, Brooklyn, has been resold by the Estate Securities Company, operators, to Sylvia Kleiner. Philip Balsam was the broker and the attorneys were Jacobs, Leibowitz Kahn for the seller and Freeman Hyman for the buyer.

The New York Infirmary filed plans yesterday for a modern ten-story building to replace the old hospital at 1-9 Livingstone Place, 320-24 East Sixteenth Street and 327-29 East Fifteenth Street at an estimated cost of $3,813,400. The new structure will contain 200 beds.

The legality of Columbia University's refusal to bargain collectively with its striking cafeteria employes on the ground that educational institutions are exempt from state labor regulations was upheld yesterday by Justice Bernard Botein of the State Supreme Court.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (UP) -Joe Dobson pitched no-hit ball for 7 1-3 innings in hurling a two-hit, 3-0 victory tonight for the White Sox against the Athletics.

In your editorial concerning the annual bulletin of the F. B. I., in which a decided increase in crime throughout the United States is reported, you imply astonishment that the tide of crime should rise "despite the vigilance and excellent work of the F. B. I. and of many other law-enforcement agencies."

Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, has won another victory in a campaign to obtain controlled construction materials. He announced yesterday that 125,000 pounds of copper wiring had been allotted for traffic relief projects here.

The Chrysler Corporation and its wholly owned United States subsidiaries increased earnings in the first quarter this year 41 per cent to $18,793,677 from $13,316,672 in the corresponding three months last year, despite an increase of 373 per cent in taxes and a decrease of 8 per cent in sales.

Pan American World Airways, another of the eleven trans-atlantic airlines engaging in air coach service between the United States and Europe, sent its first high-density plane from New York to London yesterday when one of its Clippers left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 1:45 P. M.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 1 -- Senator Robert A. Taft opened the final drive of his campaign for his friendly home state's fifty-six delegates today with a special plea to the labor vote in Northern Ohio. The Senator centered his campaign in the industrial areas of Elyria, Medina, and Akron.

Lamb registered another seasonal price increase this week, tagging the already costly loin and shoulder chops beyond the reach of most housewives. Six cents a pound was added to the cost of the chops, bringing the loin to $1.25 a pound and the shoulder to $1.05.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today the election of Commissioner J. Haden Alldredge as its chairman for one year, beginning today. The chairmanship of the I C. C. is rotated among the members, usually for the calendar year.

The Treasury's decision to revamp its non-marketable 2 3/4 per cent "accord" bond of last winter for deficit-financing purposes caused a momentary outburst of bullishness in the Government's longer-term non-bank bonds yesterday, but opinion in the financial district about the new development was generally cool and skeptical.

The Navy's Distinguished Civilian Service medal, highest of its non-military awards, was presented yesterday to three officers of the transport Gen. A. W. Greely for their part in the rescue of the passengers and crew of the freighter Flying Enterprise last December.

To sit down in a restaurant and order a three-minute egg is the act of an improvident man. He might as well ask for a boiled egg, or simply an egg. For some reason, casual egg-eaters feel that specifying the time an egg is to be boiled will give them a certain result.

YUMA, Ariz, May 1 -- Water from the Colorado River was diverted into the new eighty-two-mile Wellton-Mohawk Irrigation Canal system today, to turn back the clock of agriculture 500 years and restore Arizona's "dust bowl" to its pristine fertility.

DENVER, May 1 (AP) -- Forced hoarding of petroleum supplies was ordered today in the face of spreading local gasoline shortages and a continuing deadlock in negotiations aimed at breaking a nation-wide oil strike.

VERPLANCK, N. Y., May 1--The link under the Hudson River in the 2,200-mile pipe line that will carry natural gas from the Texas oil fields to New England consumers this year is rapidly being completed, an inspection here showed today.
Your editorial of April 28 "Kashmir, Hardy Perennial," seems to me to be hardly fair to India.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- President Truman said today the District of Columbia, which is governed by Congress, had more separate agencies than the entire Executive Branch of the Federal Government.

LOUISVILLE, May 1 -- The zoom-zoom-zoom of bass fiddles was heard as musicians went to work in the lobby of at least two Louisville hotels at noon today. Policemen received orders to go on twelve-hour shifts. A race horse arrived from Long Island by airplane.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 1 -- The burned, broken wreckage of the Pan American Stratocruiser that vanished Monday night was found in northern Brazil today. There was no evidence that any of the fifty persons aboard, including nineteen Americans, lived through the crash.

Largely because of the strike that shut down the Bayonne refinery for most of the first quarter of this year net profits of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company for that period fell to $6,749,671, or $1.06 a share, William F. Humphrey, president, told the annual meeting here yesterday.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 1 -- The campaign of Lake Success village officials and civic groups to change the proposed route for the extension of Horace Harding Expressway into Nassau County won the support of County Executive J. Russel Sprague at a conference here today.

After a week's delay brought about by a switch in directors and an overhauling of the script, "The Victim" will be appraised by the critical brigade this evening, starting at 8 o'clock, at the President Theatre.

The U. S. Circuit Court of Appeals, by a vote of 5 to 4, has turned down the request of the steel companies, which had asked that it enjoin Secretary of Commerce Sawyer from changing wages and working conditions pending their appeal to the Supreme Court from the same court's earlier decision to restore the mills to the Government.
TOKYO, Friday, May 2 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 46, on Thursday's operations:

TOKYO, Friday, May 2 -- The Communists turned down today a United Nations proposal for an over-all settlement of the issues still standing in the way of an armistice in Korea, but advanced a counter-proposition of their own, on which future meetings of the full truce delegations were scheduled.

John J. Scanlon, a longshoreman sought since Feb. 7 as one of the men alleged to have savagely beaten two dock workers in a bar, was ordered held without bail yesterday after General Sessions Judge Jacob Gould Schurman was told that witnesses were in "mortal fear" of the man.

Mayor Impellitteri will proclaim today the beginning of a prolonged new campaign for a cleaner New York City. The Sanitation Department promises to make this one of its toughest drives to educate -- and prosecute, if necessary -- the litterer of our streets and sidewalks. The department will attack on every front.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -Government price controllers may suspend ceilings next week on raw cotton, many textile fabrics and numerous types of apparel, including shoes.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Congressional budget-cutting drive came to a halt tonight as the House passed a $724,003,669 appropriation bill for the Agriculture Department for the 1953 fiscal year.

The "protective instinct" of parents can become a definite problem in the role they play in their child's education unless they will recognize, analyze and face this emotional factor intelligently, Dean Millicent C. McIntosh of Barnard College declared last night.

Business reports continue to show a mixture of firm and soft spots, "which in the aggregate add up to a steady volume of trade and a high level of industrial operations," the National City Bank of New York says in its Monthly Letter, published today.

Disregarding all the warnings about the dangers confronting us in this crucial year of the East-West conflict, Congress continues to wield the meat axe on all defense funds to an extent which threatens to precipitate a demobilization even before Western mobilization has been completed.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan and District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Brooklyn announced yesterday that John Mazziotta, a flashily dressed waterfront bookmaker and ex-convict, was being sought in connection with the killing of Arnold Schuster, the salesman who led the police to bank robber William Sutton.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Competition from British and other European machine toolmakers, promoted with United States tax dollars, is damaging the American tool industry, Frederick S. Blackall Jr., president of the National Machine Tool Builders Association, charged today.

Eight television and radio programs and two broadcasting stations were cited yesterday at the twelfth annual presentation of the George Foster Peabody Awards for "outstanding and meritorious accomplishments" in 1951.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- During the week ended April 30 member bank reserves increased $65,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, May 1 -- The decision of the British Labor party executive committee to call on the Conservative Government "to take steps without further delay" to arrange a new four-power conference on Germany reflects the wide-spread dislike of the idea of German rearmament and distrust of the United States policy regarding it.

LOS ANGELES, May 1 -- With a victory over Lionel Joyner of Toronto in thirty moves in the fourth round of the Hollywood international invitation chess tournament, Herman Steiner of this city, former United States champion, maintained a half-point lead in the field of ten today.

VIENNA, May 1 -- The office of the Austrian Chancellor will protest to Washington against the release by the United States High Commissioner's Office of a report on restrictive Austrian trade practices, People's party newspapers reported today.
The National Amateur Athletic Union will conduct an inquiry into the amateur status of one or more of the men named for the 1952 United States Olympic basketball team.

YONKERS, May 1 -- Neola Hanover, a 4-year-old mare, suffered a possible broken back at Yonkers Raceway tonight when she broke gait at the first turn in the second part of the Greyhound Trot and stepped into the sulky wheel of the trotter, Scoot, throwing both horses and drivers to the turf.

WINNIPEG, May 1 -- The problem of conditioning western Canada's huge stocks of damp grain -- the greatest such problem ever to confront a major grain-producing nation -- has been solved, Chief Commissioner George McIvor of the Board of Grain Commissioners reported today.

The young Japanese widow of a television cameraman killed in Korea, who feels "like a queer egg," in her native land, began yesterday a hopeful wait to see whether Congress would allow her to remain in "the country my whole life has been leading up to."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 1 -A past president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, advocated tonight continued support of the United Nations in an address to members of the Connecticut State Federation of Women's Clubs.
TAMPA, Fla., May 1 (UP) -- An Air Force B-29 plunged into the Gulf of Mexico today while practicing low-level gunnery. At least seven of the fourteen men aboard survived.

A fierce flash fire burned three persons critically in a Lower East Side garment loft yesterday and injured twenty-six others. A truck driver, in a courageous rooftop rescue operation, halted a panic in the burning building and probably prevented a major tragedy.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission in an order today authorized the Jersey Central Power and Light Company of Asbury Park, a subsidiary of the General Public Utilities Corporation, to sell all its gas properties and related facilities to the New Jersey Natural Gas Company for a base price of $13,757,385.
Barnard College acquired one block of 119th Street yesterday as its very own.

The non-sectarian College of Medicine, sponsored by Yeshiva University, will be of tremendous help in reducing the shortage of doctors and medical facilities here, Mayor Impellitteri said in an address last night. The Mayor, Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore and others spoke at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in honor of State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein, national chairman of the University $25,000,000 Medical Center campaign.

From ground floor to attic, on every available bit of wall space, color blossomed yesterday throughout the Sirovich Center for Older Persons at 203 Second Avenue. It was the day center's first art show, and Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy called it "an outflowering of special talent"

Asserting that Senator Robert A. Taft or General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower would be the Republican candidate for President, Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, predicted last night that the Democratic nominee would defeat either one of them.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 1 -- When the Universal Postal Congress convenes in Brussels, Belgium, May 14 for its regular legislative session, held every fifth year, it will be confronted with more than 700 proposal for changes in its regulations, the Universal Postal Union said in its annual report to the United Nations released today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 1 -- Nine exiled Argentines protested to the United Nations today that the Peron Government had instituted a "reign of crude terror" to crush political opposition. They asked that a committee of inquiry be sent to Argentina to verify their charges.
Any lingering doubts that America is a country of travelers can be resolved by the "annual statistical survey" of the National Travelers Aid Association, made public yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 1 -- President Getulio D. Vargas broadcast to the nation today details of an elaborate program of social benefits for farm workers, which he said was already underway. Speaking to Brazil's workers for May Day, he promised that rural labor would soon have all the benefits given to labor in the cities under Brazil's advanced social security legislation.

Violence, actual or potential, dominated the Stalinist May Day celebrations in many parts of the world yesterday. Actual violence reached its height in Tokyo, where 20,000 Red rioters injured over 450 people including some Americans, In Berlin 5,000 Communist rowdies invaded the French sector and had to be dispersed by the police, while East German President Wilhelm Pieck threatened the West he would create a Communist German Army.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 1 -- The United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs today began consideration of governmental reports on illicit traffic, which included an apparent mention of Charles (Lucky) Luciano as a suspect in connection with narcotics smuggling in Italy.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, serving an area stretching from Texas to New York, asked the Federal Power Commission today for a $42,000,000 a year increase in its natural gas rates.

MOSCOW, May 1 -- Premier Stalin stood atop Lenin's tomb in Red Square today witnessing the demonstration of the Soviet Union's air and armored strength followed by a parade of 1,000,000 Muscovites celebrating May Day with slogans proclaiming "Stalin Is Peace," "We Are for Peace" and "Peace for the Whole World."
The Board of Education's staff relations plan, designed to improve teacher morale, touched off new verbal fireworks between board members and teacher representatives at yesterday's board meeting.

The National Association of Women Artists will open their sixtieth annual exhibition with a preview this evening in the galleries of the National Academy. Beginning tomorrow the exhibition will be open to the public until May 18. Approximately 300 entries in all media are included in the event.

BAYONNE, N. J., May 1 -- Thirteen-and-a-half tons of lumber, simulating a heavily loaded combat plane, whooshed from the flight deck of the carrier Oriskany here today, shot 150 yards over water and tore a startling geyser from the surface of the Lower Bay as it crashed.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -Frank Campos' single scored Gill Coan with the winning run in the last half of the thirteenth inning tonight to gain a 2-1 victory for the Senators over the Indians.
Net increases in defense borrowing held the decline in business loans from New York banks to $19,000,000 last week.
Volume was down in commodity futures trading yesterday but prices were generally higher. Rubber lost ground again but other markets were either higher or mixed.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Congress was asked today to authorize construction projects for the Army, Navy and Air Force in this country and overseas that would cost $3,027,752,000.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The State Department reported today that the United States Ambassador to Czechoslovakia had finally been allowed to talk with William N. Oatis in a Prague police headquarters and had found the Associated Press correspondent, jailed more than a year ago, in good health.

Amateur radio operators began use of their new 21-megacycle band yesterday morning, but it was believed that it might be several weeks before it would be known how much their transmissions might interfere with television reception on older video receivers.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Permission to carry air mail, parcel post and express at a revised and non-subsidized rate that would reduce present rates by half was asked of the Civil Aeronautics Board today by three independent scheduled air freight carriers.

ALBANY, May 1 -- Nassau and Suffolk Counties led the other sixty in the state in population growth from 1940 to 1950, the State Commerce Department reported today. The Nassau increase was 65.4 percent, while Suffolk's population rose 39.9 per cent.

Controller Lazarus Joseph points out that if he is permitted to spend $775,000 to hire more city accountants and clerks he will collect an additional million dollars. Ask any business-minded business man who has not been stung by the spending mania if this is sensible, percentage-wise. Even a charity racket brings in more than this for the particular charity institution.

BALTIMORE, May 1 (UP) -- Suggested, one of Brookmeade Stable's three Preakness candidates, put in a bid to start in the May 17 renewal of the famous stake by winning today's Old Hilltop Purse by a length as Pimlico began its eighty-second racing season.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today it had passed along to the United Nations a Bank report on a proposal to stimulate private investment in underdeveloped countries.
BERLIN, May 1 -- Wilhelm Pieck. President of East Germany, announced today in his May Day speech that East Germany would have to rearm if West Germany became integrated with Western Europe.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 1 (AP) -- Honorable discharges have been recommended for two of the six officers of Randolph Air Force Base recently charged in court-martial proceedings for refusing to fly.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower took the lead in the Republican race for President today at about the same time that the retiring Democratic President, Harry S. Truman, said the general was as fine a man as ever walked.

The new Narcotics Term of the City Magistrates Courts was opened yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh. He appealed to parents, relatives and friends to take adolescent narcotics user to the new court so that they might be treated with "sympathy and understanding."

WINCHESTER, Va., May 1 -Nina "Honeybear" Warren was crowned Queen Shenandoah today at this area's Apple Blossom Festival. The youngest of the three daughters of Gov. Earl Warren of California reigns over a four-day observance which also celebrates the 200th anniversary of Winchester's founding.

LONDON, May 1 -- Apart from foreign bonds, which were active and erratic, most markets continued quiet today. Prices were inclined to drift lower for lack of support, although there were one or two improvements in later dealings.
MADRID, May 1 (UP) -- Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, Archbishop of Seville, accused Spanish civil authorities today of censoring and curtailing publication of his pastoral letters.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- The Navy told Congress today that Capt. B. C. McCaffree of the aircraft carrier Wasp saw the destroyer-minesweeper Hobson cutting across his bow and tried by "emergency signal" to avoid the diastrous collision.

MONTREAL, May 1 (UP) -- Gordie Howe, right wing of the Detroit Red Wings who led the National Hockey league in scoring for the second year in a row, today was named winner of the Hart Trophy as the most valuable player for the 1951-52 season.

CINCINNATI, May 1 -- Five Presidential candidates and Paul G. Hoffman, appearing for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, joined tonight in a forum discussion of 1952 campaign issues that showed wide agreement among Republicans and Democrats on the necessity of continuing economic aid to friendly countries.

LONDON, May 1 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler declared today that the Conservative Government had averted a perilous economic crisis. He pointed to a slight improvement in March and signs that it might continue.

Radio and television set production in the United States in the quarter of this year dropped more than 40 per cent, compared with the like period last year, the Radio-Television Manufacturers Association reported yesterday. Radio set output decreased 44 per cent and television sets were down 40 per cent.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 1 -- Charges that this island's industrial revolution is taking place at the expense of business and labor in the continental United States were attacked here today.

The twenty-first anniversary of the Empire State Building, largest office structure in the world, was observed yesterday afternoon with a brief "cake-cutting" ceremony on the outdoor terrace of the eighty-sixth floor observatory.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 1 -- The United States delegation wants anybody who is worried to know that the United Nations has not taken over nine towns in California, that it has no intention of doing so and that it never had any plans to do so.

CINCINNATI, May 1 (UP) -- Dick Sisler drove in three runs with three hits and Relief Pitcher Frank Smith choked off the Braves' ninth-inning rally to help the Reds beat Boston, 7 to 6, today before 2,497 fans.

Louis F. Budenz testified at the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders yesterday that Marxism-Leninism was founded on "the violent shattering of governments of bourgeois states," including that of the United States. He testified also that this aim was cloaked in "Aesopian language" in the constitution of the Communist party of the United States.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., May 1 -- A chilling 40-mile an hour gale greeted women of the New Jersey Golf Association today when they opened their season over the hilly No. 1 and 4 nines of the Montclair Golf Club course.

The experimental television programs presented on Wednesday by the Montclair (N. J.) State Teachers College for students in thirteen schools of Montclair and Bloomfield provided an encouraging augury for educational video.

Two new films will arrive in town this morning. "The Pride of St. Louis," Twentieth Century-Fox's dramatization of the career of Dizzy Dean, with Dan Dailey playing the pitcher, is at the Rivoli. Harmon Jones directed and Jules Schermer produced from a screen play by Herman J. Mankiewicz and a story by Guy Trosper.

CAIRO, May 1 -- The Egyptian Foreign Ministry announced tonight that Egypt had not at all accepted the principle of the common defense of the Middle East. Press reports stating that Britain and Egypt had agreed on a common defense formula in connection with an alleged agreement by the British to withdraw their garrison from the Suez Canal Zone, were denied.
The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York yesterday elected George H. Coppers president at its annual meeting at 65 Liberty Street. Mr. Coppers is president of the National Biscuit Company.

The St. Regis roof restaurant was thrown into a mood of mid-summer festivity yesterday noon when Saks Fifth Avenue and Adele Simpson put on a fashion show, concentrating on the designer's collection. Typical of Adele Simpson were not only the delicious airy dresses but the picnic baskets which each guest found at her place at the table.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Senator Frank Carlson, Republican of Kansas, proposed today that Congress try to balance the Federal budget for next year by cutting more than $12,000,000,000 from President Truman's spending estimates. He said Congress should aim for a tax reduction in the 1954 fiscal year.
OMAHA, Neb., May 1 -- Parents are the key in the handicapped children program, an authority from Texas in child special education said today.

Former Police Capt. Joseph C. Workman was granted yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court a certificate of reasonable doubt on his conviction of perjury in the first degree. Justice Charles N. Cohen ordered the defendant released in $15,000 bail pending the outcome of his appeal to the Appellate Division, Second Department.

BUENOS AIRES, May 1 (AP) -- President Juan D. Peron opened Argentina's eighty-sixth Congress today with a declaration that two years of crop failure and the threat of a world-wide economic crisis presented new problems to his Government.

Since "Much Ado About Nothing'' is an old classic, we must be vigitant and treat it with all respect. But it is not much older than one theatregoer feels after sitting through the production that opened at the Music Box last evening.

HIS mother and father were respectable and conventional working-class people, kind to their children and scrupulously honest. The family lived in a pleasant Chicago suburb. But when Gene was only 10 or 11 he began "finagling around," by which he means stealing. In the thirty-five years since then Gene has never stopped "finagling."

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended April 26 totaled 779,402 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 44,305 cars or 6 per cent more than for the preceding week, 45,260 cars or 5.5 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 34,107 cars or 4.6 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- Charles E. Wilson, former Defense Mobilizer, told President Truman he preferred a steel strike to granting the C. I. O. steel workers a package wage increase of 26 cents an hour.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- Senator George D. Aiken accused the Administration today of hiding details of a Government purchase of Egyptian cotton to protect two Cabinet members who knew of "millions of dollars of undue profits" from the transaction.
More Protestant and Roman Catholic children are receiving their elementary school training in schools with church sponsors than at any time in the history of this country.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -Representative Edwin Arthur Hall, Republican of New York, was subjected to sharp criticism by his House colleagues today for suggesting that tipsy members of Congress were "leaking" vital atomic secrets.

The eyes of the nation were on the Missouri Valley in April as the crest of the flood rolled down the mighty river, leaving ruin and desolation in its wake. But April did quite well in these parts, too, even if on a somewhat smaller scale. In case anyone hereabouts hasn't noticed it yet, the Weather Bureau reports that April in New York was "unusually wet and cloudy."

ATHENS, Ga., May 1 (AP) -- Don January shot the first round of the Southern intercollegiate golf tournament today in 67 strokes -- the same as he did in 1950 -- and this year the blazing golf was good enough to put him ahead of the national amateur champion.

The first of May puts us in mind of the hot days not so distant when ice cream will taste better than it does at any other time of year. Perhaps those days were in the mind, too, of the buyers for city stores that have just introduced a new kind of ice cream freezer.

Against a Paris street scene background with ballet dancers scattering nosegays of lily of the valley, Abraham Straus presented a showing of summer fashions yesterday celebrating the opening of the Cotton Shop. Crisp summer suits in white and frosty pastels were the first warm weather designs to make their appearance.

PITTSBURGH, May 1 -- The Giants definitely are on the move and today they caught up with Branch Rickey's team of the future, a feat that took some doing considering the Pirates are generally regarded to be made up of players physically many light years away.

BONN, Germany, May 1 -- The Free Democratic party, the mutinous second power in the Government coalition, listed today the alterations it demanded that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer make in the contractual agreement, before the party could agree to that document.

GENEVA, May 1 -- The Director General of the International Labor Organization, David A. Morse, in his annual report published here today advised the nations to make plans for coping with unemployment when the present armament drive slackened.

GENEVA, May 1 -- The Director General of the International Labor Organization, David A. Morse, in his annual report published here today advised the nations to make plans for coping with unemployment when the present armament drive slackened.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 1 -- Local building construction was stopped today by a strike of masons and laborers. Their walkout added to an uneasy labor situation that had resulted earlier today from a strike by production workers at the Norma-Hoffman Bearings Corporation.
MEXICO CITY, May 1 (AP) -- A small Communist group tagging along after being excluded from Mexico's big, union-organized May Day parade was fired on today by a band of armed men.

The city's financial plight and its need for new revenue sources were emphasized yesterday with the disclosure that the 1951-52 yield of the 3 percent sales tax would in all probability fall about $2,000,000 short of the $205,000,000 estimate made by Controller Lazarus Joseph last February.
A panorama of a Southern home and its gardens is the design of a mural included in the new collection of wallpapers available through decorators at Murals, Inc., 501 Madison Avenue.
Purchases of lead, which was reduced to 18 cents on Tuesday from the ceiling price of 19 cents a pound, have all but stopped in metal markets here in expectation of further cuts.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 2 (AP) -- Favored Vic Seixas of Philadelphia and Billy Talbert of New York, Davis Cup team-mates, stroked their way into the final round of the Bermuda international tennis championships today. They clash for the title tomorrow.

For more than a year now -- ever since the Federal Reserve discontinued "pegging" the price of marketable Government bonds -- the terms of the various issues of Treasury savings bonds have been out of touch with realities. As a consequence sales of new securities in this general category have tended to lag behind redemptions, or "cash-ins."
WILMINGTON, Del., May 2 (AP) -- E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. today reported net income of $50,812,906 for the first three months of 1952 -- nearly $9,000,000 less than for the same period last year.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 2 (AP) -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan said today police had obtained secret, serious information about plans of the Torch Commandos, an organization of war veterans who oppose his Nationalist Government. He urged the people not "to play with" the Commandos.

The National Safety Council, in its May bulletin just released, warns parents that 1,635 youngsters under 5 years old were victims of motor vehicle accidents in 1950, the latest figures available. Some of these children, it was said, were passengers in automobiles involved in accidents.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 2 -- The National Headliners Club announced today eighteen "headliner achievement" medal awards in journalism and associated fields and four medals for valor, to be presented June 7 at the annual Headliners Frolic here. The winners are:

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina and the lawyers who have been plodding for eighteen months through the anti-trust trial of seventeen banking houses will see a Giants-Dodgers baseball game at Ebbets Field on May 28 -- Weather Man, please note.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- The aviation industry is lining up strongly against the prospective mushrooming of television towers across the nation.

Early convertibility of currencies, particularly by such major powers as Britain and France, will be among top subjects to be developed at a meeting of the international Chamber of Commerce directors scheduled in Paris May 8 to 15.

MADISON, Wis., May 2 -- Greater participation by professional engineers in public affairs is urgently needed during these critical times, Glenn B. Warren of Schenectady, N. Y., general manager of the General Electric Company's turbine division, said here tonight.

NEWARK, May 2 -- A sign reading "Last Bar Before Turnpike" was ordered removed from the K. L. Circle Inn on Highways 3 and 35 in Sayreville today by Edward J. Dorton, acting director of the Division of Alcoholic Beverage Control.
The Red Cross announced yesterday that 1,195 pints of blood had been donated on Thursday. The bloodmobiles sent out for important collections as usual did better than the permanent borough centers.
A sea career that began forty-eight years ago in sailing vessels ended last evening with the retirement of Capt. Trygve Martinsen, "Commodore Master" of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company fleet.

PARA, Brazil, May 2 (UP) -- A United States Air Force officer said today the Pan American Airways stratocruiser that crashed in central Brazil Tuesday evidently had exploded in the air, killing all fifty persons aboard.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches got under way yesterday with more than 700 district golfers participating.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 2 (AP) -- Colonial Airlines, Inc., announced today that stockholders have re-elected a management slate of directors and failed to approve the sale of Colonial's assets to National Airlines.

The fishing season officially began in our town when 2,500 youngsters brought their gear down to Hughes Lake to participate in the seventeenth annual fishing contest sponsored by the recreation department.
LOUISVILLE, May 2 -- Will Calumet Farm's Hill Gail run as well as he did in the Derby Trial?

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 2 -- French Army transport planes two days ago dropped seven tons of food and medical supplies to French Union and other friendly military prisoners of war in a Vietminh camp at Thanh Hoa in North Annam, French headquarters announced today. The air drop was made under an arrangement between the French Red Cross and the Vietminh Red Cross.

The first annual report of the Colombo Plan has just been released in London. It certainly seems to justify the faith and imagination of the original planners. Back in January of 1950 representatives from most of the British Commonwealth met in Ceylon to discuss what could be done to improve standards of living in South and Southeast Asia.

The market for lead, which had been almost at a standstill as consuming industries held up purchases in anticipation of another price cut, broke yesterday as major companies reduced the price to 17 cents a pound. On Tuesday the price was cut to 18 cents from 19, the ceiling, which had been maintained since Oct. 3.
SALT LAKE CITY, May 2 (AP) -- -- A flood-spawned lake formed in this city's west side today as residents fled on the greatest mass evacuation of the city's history.

NEW DELHI, India, May 2 -- Communist China's recent offer to sell 100,000 tons of rice to grain-hungry India is considered in India to have political implications. It has not been forgotten that only a few months ago the Peiping Government informed New Delhi that there was no rice to spare.

Heeding an appeal by state and city mediators that they return to their jobs while negotiations continued, Columbia University cafeteria workers ended their eighteen-day walkout last night. They voted to return to their posts at 12:01 A. M. tomorrow.

Many segments of the home furnishings industry either throw up their hands helplessly at poor business or belabor the Government as some kind of monster. But the carpet industry, as hard hit as any home furnishings unit, is coming out fighting mad.
LONDON, May 2 (Reuters) -- The British Royal Family today ordered its first seagoing yacht in fifty-three years. But it will be another couple of years before the vessel is ready for use.

LONDON, May 2 -- The existence of winds blowing at speeds of between 200 and 300 miles an hour in the heavyside layer or F region of the ionosphere 130 miles above the earth has been confirmed by a new radio astronomy technique carried out at Manchester University. The experiments have a direct bearing on meteorology, radio transmission and changes in the earth's magnetic field.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 2 -- Mrs. Effie M. Morrison of Millville, director of the Roosevelt Park Colony, received today the 1952 Cecilia Gaines Holland Award of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs for "outstanding humanitarian service."

TOKYO, Saturday, May 3 -- United Nations and Communist delegates met for twenty-four minutes at Panmunjom this morning. As far as could be learned under the conditions of secrecy, they made no further progress toward an agreement on the Allied proposal for an over-all settlement of the issues still remaining in the way of an armistice in Korea.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The five-judge majority of the Federal Court of Appeals declared today that "there is at least a serious question as to the correctness" of District Judge David A. Pine's ruling that the seizure of the steel industry by President Truman was illegal.
EL PASO, Tex., May 2 (AP) -- Lieut. Verne Goodwin, under a court-martial sentence for refusing to fly, has resigned from the Air Force under a "new policy," Biggs Air Force Base announced tonight.

WEST HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., May 2 -- The body of a 2 1/2-year-old boy was found tonight on a bed in a house on Calico Hill, where the child and his 45-year-old mother, a former inmate of a mental institution, had been guests. The mother was found in near-by underbrush almost three hours later with both wrists slashed.

ST. LOUIS, May 2 (AP) -- Harry (Peanuts) Lowrey's single with one out in the ninth drove in Solly Hemus with the winning run tonight for the Cardinals as Wilmer (Vinegar Bend) Mizell, 21-year-old rookie, hurled a four-hitter for a 3-2 victory over the Phillies.

Not many years ago, there was a big beautiful forest at the end of a street in the Bronx. But the years went on, the forest disapappeared, the neighborhood ran down and a jungle of bedraggled, lonely children, gang wars and hatred grew up.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 2 -- Governor Stevenson, following his first West Coast speech of the 1952 Presidention campaign here last night, was viewed today by Oregon Democratic party leaders and both Democratic and Republican newspapers as highly eligible for a draft at the National Convention.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 2 (Reuters) -- Chile today denounced her 1951 agreement with United States copper companies which fixed how much of the metal can be sold at controlled prices. In effect, Chile reclaimed her original powers to set exports annually, according to usually reliable sources.

American films gained in popularity abroad last year and resulted in substantial increases in revenue from foreign markets, Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, declared yesterday in an annual report and appraisal of the industry's outlook for 1952.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- More than half of the nation's present military forces are in the late teen-age group, Mrs. Francis T. Christy of Brooklyn, chairman of the Defense Services Department of the Young Women's Christian Association, declared today in presenting a report on United Service Organization work to the nineteenth national convention of the association in the Conrad Hilton Hotel.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Election-year hopes of adjourning Congress before the July political conventions appeared today to have been clouded by President Truman's steel seizure order.

One of the largest shows ever staged by the National Association of Women Artists, which draws its membership from all parts of the country, opened last night at the National Academy, 1109 Fifth Avenue, with a preview for the participants and their guests.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 2 -- Continued experimentation in how close to atomic-bomb bursts troops can maneuver with safety was presaged today in statements from two of the principals in yesterday's record proximity exercise at the Atomic Energy Commission's Nevada Proving Ground.

CINCINNATI, May 2 -- The League of Women Voters concluded its five-day session here today with the acceptance of two objectives that had been proposed by its board of directors as the bases for the program of the next two years.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Army's Chief of Staff disclosed today that foreign commitments had drained the United States of all its regular infantry divisions.

THE next few weeks should find the salt water fishing well under way along the New York and New Jersey shore, for the mackerel have made their appearance, pollock are due to show at Montauk almost any day, and the striped bass are along the South Shore.

The appointment of L. J. Campbell as president of Firestone Steel Products Company, a subsidiary of The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, was announced yesterday by Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman of Firestone Tire.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- There was a growing belief in Washington tonight, which President Truman reportedly shares, that Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois would not refuse the Democratic nomination for President if he were drafted by the national convention.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Futures were strong in early trading on the Board of Trade today but the market lacked any great reserve buying force and, with a lull in demand, local pressure again came into play. Prices receded sharply from early tops in all pits, with buyers not inclined to be aggressive.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were barely steady yesterday, closing 5 points higher to 17 points lower.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 2 -- Prof. Elmer Adler, a leading authority in the field of graphic arts in this country, was honored here tonight at a testimonial dinner on the occasion of his retirement from the Princeton University faculty, which he had joined in 1940, and from the curatorship of the Graphic Arts Pavilion of the Princeton Library.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, May 3 (UP) -- Communist and United Nations military police held a "little armistice" conference here Friday to restore harmony in the rival press camps after a series of incidents in which:

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- A spreading walkout of heavy equipment operators threatened today to halt $100,000,000 worth of industrial and municinpal building in the five-county Philadelphia metropolitan area.

Mambo was as gentlemanly as the Continental as far as Sira, Gingi, Wadi and Souja were concerned in the animal nursery at the Bronx Zoo yesterday. He didn't invite them to the polished television wooer's usual fare of champagne and cigarettes but he did offer kisses and hugs.

RANGOON, Burma, April 6 (By Air Mail) -- The Burmese Government is reaching back into traditions of the centuries before British rule in its efforts to build a new national consciousness and a new cultural unity in Burma. The restoration of Buddhism to the vital position it once held in Burmese life is the most prominent aspect of the Government's efforts.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Truman made a bitter attack tonight on "political gangsters" who traduced Federal employes with indiscriminate charges of dishonesty and disloyalty.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 2 -- Jerry Wald has completed arrangements to buy out the interest of his partner, Norman Krasna, in Wald-Krasna Productions, but the company will retain its present corporate identity. Mr. Krasna will receive approximately $500,000 for his share.

PARIS, May 2 -- The French Ministry of National Defense outlined today for the National Assembly how the nation would spend the franc equivalent of $3,628,000,000 -- one-third of the national budget -- to meet commitments to the North Atlantic Treaty forces and to the French Union.
This year's Kentucky Derby will be settled by sundown today, but the mint julep controversy will rage for ever.

May Day this year was strictly Anti-American Day in Communist circles all around the globe. From Tokyo to Moscow all the comrades were lined up to stage orgies of hate directed at the United States. Today the "workers of the world" are supposed to "unite" against us, and apparently only against us.

Today's new film is "The Narrow Margin," an R. K. O. melodrama featuring Charles McGraw Marie Windsor and Jacqueline White, at the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux. Richard Fleischer directed and Stanley Rubin produced from a script by Earl Felton.

The Public Housing Administration announced yesterday the sale by twenty-six local housing authorities of $188,384,000 of short-term loan notes at interest costs ranging from 0.97 per cent to 1.06 per cent.

With that impeccable air of rectitude it assumes on such occasions, the Soviet news agency Tass denounces President Truman's statement that his ultimatum got Soviet troops out of Iran in 1946 and asserts that Soviet troops left that country "in precise accordance with the time fixed by agreement" between the Soviet Union and Iran.

PITTSBURGH, May 2 -- The Giants went back to making the home run their most potent weapon tonight as they flattened Billy Meyer's suddenly revivified Pirates in ten innings, 5 -- 3, before 17,111 sorely disappointed onlookers.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use about the home.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- A Delegation of Jewish leaders called on Secretary of State Dean Acheson today to press for continued United States support for material claims being made against Germany by the Israeli Government and other Jewish victims of nazism.

MADRID, May 2 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco announced today a general amnesty for all types of convicts. Officials estimated that the measure would affect about 10,000 of 30,000 persons who are said to be now in Spanish jails.

Canceling the balance of the musical's pre-New York bookings, Irving Gaumont has decided to bring his production of "Shuffle Along" to the Broadway Theatre next Thursday evening. The attraction was to have remained for another week at the Shubert Theatre in Philadelphia and then gone to Boston's Colonial Theatre for a fortnight's engagement, starting May 12, arriving in these parts around May 29.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- The text of a memorandum issued today in which five judges of the United States Court of Appeals explained why they stayed the effectiveness of United States District Judge David A. Pine's decision holding illegal the seizure of the steel mills follows:

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark discussed the problems of the war in Korea with President Truman this morning and said afterward he would "work hard for an honorable armistice" when he assumed command of the United Nations forces there.

Donald F. Taylor and Joseph J. Schweinfurt have been made general superintendents in charge of automotive production by the Buick division of General Motors Corporation in Flint, Mich. Mr. Taylor also will continue to superintend ordnance production.

TRENTON, May 2 -- The New Jersey Republican organization in a tentative draft of its platform urged the voters today to elect Republican candidates for President and Congress "to clean out waste, corruption and incompetence in the National Administration."

The one-story taxpayer on a plot 120 by 100 feet at 2196-2200 Clarendon Road, Brooklyn, has been purchased by George J. Abrams. The building was constructed about a year ago by the Bregman family for use by the Grand Union Company. Sale was subject to a mortgage of $78,000.
SECAUCUS, N. J., May 2 -- Two men were killed here last night when a truck got out of control on the Hackensack River Bridge on Route 3.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 2 -- The dogwood, now at the height of its beauty, will still be a sight for several hunred visitors expected next Saturday for a tour of ten homes in this historic community. With an early start, those who appreciate the spring countryside and old houses will get their fill on May 10 when the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society of Connecticut holds it open house.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Dr. Stanley K. Hornbeck, former director of the State Department's Office of Far Eastern Affairs, was disclosed today to have entered a formal charge two years ago that the United States Government began to put pressures on Nationalist China on behalf of the Communists in 1945.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The sixth annual conference on elementary education, a group of 100 educators representing seventy organizations, summed up today the current educational trend as "moving from a child-centered school to a school-centered community."

Members of the New York State Society of Professional Engineers believe that private enterprise, rather than the Federal or state Government, should undertake proposed hydroelectric developments of the Niagara River, their president, Charles Molineaux, reported yesterday.

The issue of the Presidential power to seize the steel mills has now gone to the Supreme Court. This issue is, of course, part of a wider issue -- namely, how great the powers of the President are. It has seemed to many of us that those powers have been overextended during the past few years and that the time has come to redefine and limit them.
PARIS, May 2 -- Lord Ismay, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Council, is now engaged in reorganizing the structure of that body into three main subsidiary sections.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 2 -- It is doubtful if Eugene Jackson of Philadelphia would have had much luck at the near-by Garden State Race Track today. Jackson failed to reach the track because of a series of other bad breaks that presaged little good fortune with horse bets.

Vince Martinez, 149 1/2 pounds, Paterson, N. J., registered an impressive technical knockout victory over experienced Tony Pellone, 148, Greenwich Village, in the feature bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

Ralph M. Carson, defense counsel in the investment banking antitrust trial here, cross-examined Harold L. Stuart, Chicago banker, yesterday in an effort to establish "the degree of activity of restrictive character which makes an investment banker a non-conspirator in the opinion of the Government.

Colorful floats and new street-cleaning equipment sparkled in the noonday sun at City Hall Plaza yesterday as Mayor Impellitteri and Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain took part in outdoor ceremonies starting the city's annual spring clean-up campaign.
LONDON, May 2 (AP) -- The International Wheat Council announced here today its approval of Australia's request for a reduction in the wheat quota she is obligated to export for the controlled market.

The Cities Service Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income for the first quarter of this year of $17,115,000 after taxes and all charges, equal to $4.40 a common share. In the corresponding three months of 1951 the net income was $20,017,000, or $5.15 a common share.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Ellis G. Arnall, the Director of Price Stabilization, told Congress today that the steel companies "feel they have the country over a barrel and intend to extort their price increase or wreck the economy."

CHICAGO, May 2 -- For eight innings today Omar (Turk) Lown, 28-year-old right-hander, held the Dodgers hitless and had every one of the 11,339 Northside fans sitting on the edge of their seats rooting for the no-hitter.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Senators heard sworn testimony today that a strategically placed Agriculture Department official gave confidential information to an Egyptian who sold the United States Government some $37,000,000 worth of cotton last year.

The official canvass of the total vote in Illinois sent Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio into the lead in popular votes yesterday in the eight states so far to hold Republican Presidential preference primaries, The Associated Press reports. On the basis of incomplete figures from Illinois, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower had been leading.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 2 -- Senators Estes Kefauver of Tennessee and Richard B. Russell of Georgia crossed paths in a cigar, factory here today, and after five minutes of friendly joshing the Tennessean pocketed a half-dollar given him by the Georgian in a jest about resources.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 2 -- The United States has declared that it is not irrevocably opposed to a United Nations hearing of the dispute between France and Tunisian nationalists.

CAIRO, May 2 -- The Grand Mufti of Egypt, Hassanein Mohammed Makhlouf, came out today against the agitation for women's suffrage. He dealt a heavy blow to the principal suffragette leader Mme. Doria Shafik, head of the Daughters of the Nile organization, who first came to public attention as runner-up in a nationwide beauty contest in Alexandria.
This is to thank you for the service rendered the taxpayers and beauty-lovers of our region. Your April 15 editorial on "Vandalism in Parks" presents a shocking picture indeed.

After she was rescued from a flaming seventh - floor apartment in a three-alarm fire at 214 Riverside Drive, at Ninety-fourth Street, Mrs. Carolyn Taubert, 96 years old, died of a heart attack yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The aurora borealis, or northern lights, appears when immense clouds of gas from the sun have broken through the earth's protective mantle of magnetism, a Harvard University astronomer reported here today at the meeting of the American Physical Society.

George M. Bragalini, a bank official, took over yesterday as Acting Postmaster of New York to fill the vacancy caused by the retirement of Albert Goldman. The appointment of Mr. Bragalini at a salary of $13,770 a year was made on the recommendation of Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, with the sponsorship of Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany. He was sworn in Thursday afternoon.

Events today: Three Choir Festival, Temple Emanu-El, 10:30 A. M.; Ernest Bloch's Sacred Service, Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, 10:30 A. M.; Larry Adler, harmonica player, and Little Symphony Orchestra conducted by Daniel Saidenberg, Town Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Jewish People's Chorus, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.

William Sutton, with another sentence of thirty years to life for bank robbery imposed upon him in Queens County Court during the morning, returned at 3:10 yesterday afternoon to Sing Sing Prison, from which he had escaped on Dec. 12, 1932, after serving barely eighteen months of a thirty-year term.

DETROIT, May 2 -- Frieda B. Hennock, member of the Federal Communications Commission, said here today that the recent decision of the commission assigning 242 television channels for noncommercial educational purposes could result in the revitalization "of our entire educational process and make an invaluable contribution to the vigor of our democratic way of life."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., May 2 (UP) -- Samuel Gold, 52 years old, of New York, was arraigned today on felony charges, the sixth person to be identified of the nine newly indicted by a grand jury investigating gambling at this resort.

Holding that the eighteen members of the Police Department charged with being involved with Harry Gross, the bookmaker, had not been placed in double jeopardy within the meaning of the State Constitution, Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein refused yesterday to grant a temporary injunction to bar their retrial.

Three Rings, with not a drop of moisture anywhere near to make him shy, sped home the winner of the Lucky Draw Handicap at Belmont yesterday. The 7-year-old gelding owned by Mrs. Evelyn L. Hopkins indicated that he is on the way back to major form by beating Abe Levinson's High Bracket half a length in the mile race.

A voluminous indictment of the Peron regime has been submitted to the United Nations by a group of exiles from Argentina. It accuses the Government of crushing civil liberties, jailing and torturing large numbers of the citizens, and otherwise conducting a "reign of crude terror" against its opponents.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- An Air Force spokesman said today that the old Wharton estate at Hammonton, N. J., had been selected for a big air maintenance depot originally scheduled for Lancaster County, Pa.

The Treasury Department is to be congratulated on smashing, at least as far as this country is concerned, one of the two principal rackets by means of which the Chinese Communists seek to obtain dollars to finance their terror at home and their war in Korea. The two rackets are the extortion of money from Chinese abroad and the smuggling of opium, for which Communist China has become the principal source of supply.

" Not uninteresting" might be the words for Leonard Lesley's "The Victim," which was put on at the President last evening. For the sadistic persecution of a strong man by a weak one carries with it a certain terrifying fascination. In the present instance a drunken derelict out of the gutter blames his failure in life on a decent sort of fellow with a conscience.

A plot about 800 by 1,600 feet on Jericho Turnpike in Westbury, L. I., has been sold by Joseph Klein to the Jostan Development Corporation, which plans to build one-family houses in the $14,000 price class. John P. Gering was attorney for the seller and Gelfand Shedler acted for the buyer.

ALBANY, May 2 -- The State Tax Commission cracked down today on a western New York trucking company, filing warrants totaling $29,465 against its assets for its alleged failure to pay the state's weight-distance and diesel motor fuel taxes.

The Commerce and Industy Association of New York announced yesterday that it had asked the Federal Reserve Board to repeal Regulation X. The trade body said it made the request because the 50 per cent limitation on loan value on non-residential property which the credit restrictions impose ultimately would drive private enterprise from the non-residential construction field and would prevent presently unemployed capital and labor from being put to work.
LOUISVILLE, May 2 (AP) -- The first coast-to-coast telecast of the Kentucky Derby tomorrow will be the most expensive half-hour show in television's brief history.

The defense in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders failed yesterday in an attempt to have Eugene V. Dennis, one of the convicted eleven top party leaders, transferred from the Federal penitentiary in Atlanta to New York for consultation.

SEOUL, Korea, May 3 (AP) -- Two United States destroyers slugged it out with Communist shore guns Wednesday in Wonsan harbor in what the Navy said today was the longest such duel of the Korean war. Both destroyers were hit, but damage was slight.
Following is the text of President Truman's address to the National Civil Service League at its seventieth anniversary in Washington last night, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

DETROIT, May 2 -- There is nothing wrong with the automobile sales picture that a hard and astute merchandising job plus the dropping of Government credit restrictions will not cure, E. C. Quinn, vice president of Chrysler Corporation and general manager of the company's Chrysler division, said here yesterday.

LONDON, May 2 -- With a payload of thirty-six passengers, a British Overseas Airways Corporation Comet took off for Johannesburg from London Airport today on the first commercial jet flight in history.

BALTIMORE, May 2 (AP) -- Repetoire, unplaced in three previous starts this year, regained his winning form today when he won Pimlico's Green Spring Valley purse, but had to share attention with a $2,500 "plater" who won the opening race at $274.80 for $2.
The United Nations and United States foreign policy were attacked yesterday in a resolution adopted at the 148th convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs in the Astor Hotel.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 2 (AP) -- Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., the defending titleholder, and Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, her best friend, advanced to the women's final of the British hard-court tennis tournament today.

TRENTON, May 2 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll has commissioned the State Conservation Department to make a study of the Air Force's proposal for a depot at Hammonton before the state gives its endorsement.

The two-story taxpayer building containing three stores and six lofts at 777-81 Avenue of the Americas, near Twenty-sixth Street, was sold by the Equitable Life Assurance Society through Schimmer, Kerner Feder, brokers, to Jack Brause, operator, who resold it to the Jayette Corporation for investment. Robert S. Kline was the broker in the resale.

BOSTON, May 2 (AP) -- Walt Dropo walloped a grand slam homer as the Red Sox set off a nine-run explosion against Ned Garver in the sixth inning today while overwhelming the Browns, 13 -- 6. The triumph enabled the Red Sox to extend their first-place lead over the Browns to two games.

On the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday the No. 4 world sugar contract closed 1 point lower to 3 points higher on volume of 2,400 tons. The domestic contract closed 1 to 3 points lower on 8,650 tons. There was no activity in actual sugar.

BONN, Germany, May 2 -- British refusal to concede anything further to the West German Government in the writing of a contractual agreement and bitter criticism by two of the three parties in the Bonn Government coalition about the "severity" of the proposed agreement have combined to produce a serious and perhaps critical situation.
The Delehanty Institute, alma mater of 50,000 present and former policemen, was involved yesterday in an $11,354 payroll robbery. There was not a policeman in sight at the time.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Maj. Gen. E. C. Lynch, chief of the Defense Department's Manpower Requirements Branch, said today that present plans called for the drafting of about 610,000 men in the year starting July 1.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- The stature of many colleges and university officials will be judged by their efforts to re-establish intercollegiate athletics as "a valuable and honorable educational experience," Dr. John A. Hannah, chairman of the special committee on athletic policy of the American Council on Education, warned today.

LONDON, May 2 -- The stock markets were inactive today and movements were irregular and mostly small. British funds rose about two shillings sixpence (35 cents), but this was in response to week-end leveling of books and toward the close the undertone was less firm.

The Allied Stores Corporation, which operates a chain of seventy-one department, major branch, junior department and specialty stores, reported record sales of $476,692,651 for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31. The gain was 8.4 per cent from the previous year's volume of $439,908,620.

" Plagiarism and Originality," by Alexander Lindey, a member of the New York Bar who is a specialist in the law of literary property, will be published Wednesday by Harper. It is a history of copyright infringement and of important court decisions and deals with plagiarism in all its aspects.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 (AP) -- The Methodist General Conference approved today a proposal to reduce the membership of general boards and agencies of the church. The size of the boards and agencies will be determined later by the conference.

DENVER, May 2 -- The country-wide oil strike forced the Air Force to curtail all its flying except in the Korean war zone today and the Government announced it would limit commercial aviation soon. John F. Floberg, Assistant Navy Secretary, directed that all possible economies in the use of gasoline and oil be made by the Navy.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (UP) -- A mine safety bill authorizing Federal inspectors to close unsafe pits was approved today by a House Labor subcommittee.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 2 -- A bold bid by Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee for support from the "regular" Democratic organization, which is pledged to former Senator Robert J. Bulkley as Ohio's "favorite son" in the Presidential primary next Tuesday, was reported today by The Dayton Daily News.

The Katherine Berkan Judd prize for the greatest advancement made during 1951 toward the discovery of a cure for cancer was awarded posthumously yesterday to Dr. Konrad Dobriner, former chief of the division of steroid metabolism at the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Arthur E. Strudwick of Long Lake, Minn., received Patent No. 2,594,696 this week for an invention appropriate to Derby time -- a device for evaluating horses. It consists of a plate, small enough to be held in the hand, on which are thirteen buttons, each representing a past-performance statistic.

PITTSBURGH, May 2 -- The national steel strike was called off today at President Truman's request, but the United States Steel Corporation said it would require "reasonable assurance" that the workers would not walk out again before it resumed production.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- A television production executive and a former president of an Eastern women's college expressed sharp differences here today at the thirty-fifth annual meeting of the American Council on Education over the possibilities of using commercial television as an educational medium.

The fifteenth annual Three-Choir Festival, conducted by Lazare Saminsky, opened yesterday afternoon at the assembly hall of Temple Emanu-El. The event was under the joint auspices of the International Society for Contemporary Music, United States section, and the Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York.

BONN, Germany, May 2 -- An era of "better understanding," promising "peace and prosperity," was foreseen by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today at the conclusion of a farewell visit to Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (UP) -- Hank Majeski's single to left field scored Gus Zernial from second base as the Philadelphia Athletics out-slugged the Chicago White Sox, 13 to 12, tonight before a crowd of 3,679.

The Communist-ruled nations of Eastern Europe made appreciable industrial gains during the first three months of 1952, but the increased output of key commodities was below the high goals set in the current military - economic preparedness programs, according to a review of official statements from those countries.

TRENTON, May 2 -- A picture of the State Prison at Trenton as an "obsolete, overcrowded firetrap" where hundreds of idle men sit in "dark, medieval-type cells" for twenty hours a day was drawn here today in the investigation into the recent series of prison riots in New Jersey.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., May 2 -- John Motley Morehead, former Minister to Sweden, announced here today that he had made a gift of $1,000,000 in securities to the Morehead Foundation, which sponsors scholarships.

Amid the bustling activity of the Sunnyside yards of the Pennsylvania Railroad in Long Island City, an old passenger coach car is converted into a classroom three days a week by three New York University professors.

ATHENS, May 2 -- Turkish Premier Adnen Menderes and Foreign Minister Fuat Koprulu left for home tonight by sea, having completed a six-day goodwill mission about which nothing more was said officially than that the talks had been held in a "cordial atmosphere."

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended April 29 to 111.2 percent of the 1974-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 3.3 per cent below the average for January, 1951, and 1 per cent below the index for March, 1952 -- the latest available comprehensive index.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Secretary of the Air Force Thomas K. Finletter said today that contemplated cuts in the Air Force's new budget might mean an invitation to air attack by the Soviet Union.
Cletus Keating, an attorney of this city, was elected president of the Maritime Law Association of the United States at the group's fifty-third annual meeting here yesterday.

HOBOKEN, N. J., May 2 -- Service by the East Asiatic Company between Copenhagen and New York was resumed today with the arrival at the Eighth Street pier of the motor vessel Falstria, carrying twenty passengers and a general cargo.
Included in this week's art events are six one-man exhibitions of paintings that show, to varying degrees, accomplishment and promise.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe approved today the payment of an additional $2,572,402 to four groups of bondholders of reorganized Chicago street car companies that have been taken over by the Chicago Transit Authority.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Selective Service turned to the Bible today for what it called the origin of the military draft. In a booklet on the historical background of selective service it quoted the first and second verses of the first chapter of Numbers:

LONDON, May 2. -- Admiral William M. Fechteler, United States chief of naval operations, said on his arrival from Naples today that he would confer with Admiral Sir Rhoderick McGrigor, First Sea Lord, on the differences over the Western Allied command in the Mediterranean.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 2 (UP) -- Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland said today he had not meant to suggest in a Paris statement that the Maryland delegation to the Republican national convention would be for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidential nomination.
May Day re-echoed yesterday in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, when a 30-year-old displaced person who wanted to go to Russia was sent instead to the observation ward of Kings County Hospital.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UP) -- Representative Edwin Arthur Hall, Republican of New York, accused his House colleagues today of "one of the most cowardly attacks * * * in history" and said he might have hit home with his suggestion that tipsy members of Congress were spilling atomic secrets.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 2 -- The United Nations Correspondents Association has appealed to the members of the world organization for help in removing barriers that "seriously affect" the working conditions of newsmen here.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L. I., May 2 -- One of New York State's more notorious summertime traffic bottlenecks is expected to be eliminated May 10 when the new $7,000,000 Atlantic Beach Bridge, connecting the Long Beach area with the mainland of Long Island, is opened to the public.

During the last six months or so there have been complaints over a "soft" market and some business men have become fearful over the uncertainty of conditions in the future. The result is that many are not making plans for even next year, let alone two years hence.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 2 -- President Victor Paz Estenssoro appeared today to be facing a strong and constantly increasing opposition to his comparatively mild political and economic objectives. The labor movement under the direction of the Minister of Mines and Petroleum, Juan Lechin, has called for virtual confiscation of Bolivia's tin mines and complete Government control of all foreign and domestic commerce.

TOKYO, May 2 -- The Government moved today to investigate the causes of the May Day riots, which took two lives and caused injuries to hundreds in Tokyo and throughout Japan. The Japanese press and the public generally attacked the Administration for faulty control of violence and, in the words of the newspaper Mainichi, characterized the first labor holiday since national independence as "a memorable day of shame."

STAMFORD, Conn., May 2 -- State Highway Commissioner G. Albert Hill today made "final" the route through Stamford for the Fairfield County Thruway, which he announced as "preferred" a month ago. The Commissioner revealed his decision through Mayor Thomas F. J. Quigley after three delays.

The favorable turn in the steel situation had a heartening effect on the stock market yesterday. Recoveries of fractions to more than 3 points were chalked up in reflection of the end of the steel strike, wiping out about two-thirds of the losses previously sustained during the week.

The rate of timber growth in five of the six New England states, New York and Pennsylvania may double in the next ten years, Rand Stowell, president of the Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association, said yesterday. He said such growth is probable because Northeastern mills in the last year have adopted scientific conservation as a permanent policy without reservation.
LONDON, May 2 (UP) -- The Comet is designed to travel seven miles high, at speeds up to 500 miles an hour.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 3 (AP) -- Emperor Hirohito formally celebrated Japan's new independence today and called on his people to see that "the previous mistake is not repeated."

Your editorial commenting on the United States national attitude toward the Point Four Program said that "in the long run, a program aimed at providing three square meals a day for people living on the edge of starvation may prove more important than anything else in establishing the conditions of lasting peace."

Saying that in the state and the nation political leaders had been more concerned with maintaining their organizations than with selecting winning candidates, James A. Farley, former National Chairman, called yesterday for "a house cleaning" of the Democratic party.

CLEVELAND, May 2 -- The Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., concluded a turbulent five-day convention today with Emil Rieve firmly entrenched as president of the 400,000-member organization, which has been split in the last three years by a battle between the factions.

Two major manufacturers of men's furnishings presented fall lines yesterday and will send representatives on the road with them on Monday. The lines of Manhattan Shirt Company and B. V. D. Company, Inc., stress styling and color rather than price.
The Marymount College Glee Club, under the direction of Hugh Ross, sang a concert at Town Hall last evening.

LOS ANGELES, May 2 -- A triple tie for first place was brought about today as a result of play in the fifth round of the Hollywood International Invitation chess tournament. Herman Steiner of this city, former United States champion, drew his game with Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., in a Ruy Lopez lasting eighteen moves and lost his sole grip on the lead.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 (UP) -- Union and industry spokesmen said today that the liquor industry faced a general crisis.

At a time when freer intra-European trade is desperately needed to prevent a relapse in the convalescent economy of Europe it is bad news that the European Payments Union is facing a crisis. The E. P. U. was expressly designed to facilitate commerce by making currencies convertible and help cover dollar deficits.

The thirteenth floor penthouse of Ceil Chapman, women's dress designer, at 230 East Seventy-third Street was robbed yesterday of furs and jewelry valued at $19,600 while two well-trained watch-dogs, both Boxers, were chained on a terrace outside a locked door.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Al Rosen's seventh home run, a three-run blast in the seventh inning, was the big blow as Cleveland defeated Washington, 6 -- 2, tonight as Mike Garcia pitched a seven-hitter. Dale Mitchell also homered for the Indians in the second, as Cleveland pounded Julio Moreno and Tom Ferrick for fifteen hits.

MILWAUKEE, May 2 (UP) -- The sixteen-day-old truck strike here forced both Nash automobile plants in Wisconsin to close today, furloughing 6,000 employes. At least 10,000 persons were made idle by the dispute and business was crippled in southeastern Wisconsin.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 2 -- Mayor Thomas F. J. Quigley promised today that this city would continue its efforts to acquire the Cove Island shore property for which the Connecticut Light and Power Company yesterday filed a title deed in the Town Clerk's office.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (UP) -- The Government set up a special three-man panel today to try to settle the month-old Western Union strike and scheduled a meeting for 10 A. M. Wednesday.

PARIS, May 2 -- The French premiere of Alban Berg's opera, "Wozzeck," was given here tonight in the Champs Elysees Theatre with an effect that left an audience of music lovers and connoisseurs from all parts of the world speechless for a moment after the last note had vanished into silence.

The sole purpose of the Atlas Corporation is "to make legitimate profits" for its stockholders, Floyd B. Odlum, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday, adding that there were "too many obstacles" in the way of the considered merger with the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation and the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 24 (By Airmail) -- "Within a scant thirty years the Turkish Republic has laid the agricultural and industrial base for a modern state," United States Ambassador George C. McGhee told a recent meeting of the Turkish-American University Association, adding that in his opinion Turkish cooperation with the Western powers alone had kept the Middle East from falling prey to Russia.
MEXICO CITY, May 2 -- A tentative agreement among the major opposition parties to contest the coming Mexican election with a single candidate and platform appeared today to have broken down.

A 6-year-old Japanese girl whose entry to this country was made possible by a special act of Congress signed by President Truman arrived yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, on a Northwest airliner.
CINCINNATI, May 2 (UP) -- Pitcher Jim Wilson drove in both his team's runs tonight with a single in the second inning as the Braves defeated the Reds, 2 -- 1, before a crowd of 11,050.
