WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- The State Department suggested today that import restrictions imposed by this country might throw trade turned away from American markets into the lap of Stalin.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 3 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 47, as of 6 P. M., Friday (5 A. M., Friday, Eastern daylight time):

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Luther H. Evans, Librarian of Congress, told the second annual Washington pilgrimage of 100 religious leaders of all faiths today that this nation should endorse the United Nations covenant on human rights.

The trend of modern colleges and universities to follow "the principles of factory management and design" was criticized yesterday by Dr. Baker Brownell, Professor of Philosophy at Northwestern University. He declared the present system of higher education "tends to dry up the sources of imagination and in time will suppress the vitality and demand" for liberal education.

Two-hit pitching by Lefty Lopat carried the Yankees to a 4-1 victory over the Tigers yesterday at the Stadium. There was, however, no tension for the 7,540 fans, because George Kell, the second man to face Lopat punched a single to right.

Even though the production of new housing so far this year is almost at last year's level, the building industry is afraid Government controls on building materials and mortgage credit will be increased, and this is a principal deterrent to the development of new communities in this country, according to a survey of the national real estate market conducted by the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

The executive office of the Religious Education Association, which has been in Chicago since 1903, will be transferred here to 545 West 111th Street, at Broadway, on Monday. The association is composed of members of Protestant, Jewish and Roman Catholic faiths who collaborate on methods of introducing religious ideals into education and educational ideals into religion and of keeping alive in the public mind the need and value of a moral and religious sense.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 2 -- The New Jersey Department of Health today ordered five industries and three municipalities that had refused to join the proposed $30,000,000 Raritan Valley trunk sewer program to submit at once their plans for sewage treatment.

After months of court action, Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman approved yesterday a contract between the trustee for the Third Avenue Transit Corporation and Local 100, Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.

A plea that this country accept the plan to trade with Russia and the satellite countries announced at an International Economic Conference in Moscow last month by Mihail Nesterov, president of the Soviet Chamber of Commerce, was made here yesterday by five American union officials who attended the meeting.

Varied divertissements will feature the dinner dance, known as the Carnation Ball, to be held on the night of May 14 in the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of the Youth Consultation Service. Mrs. Gaudin de Gaete and Mrs. Samuel P. Peabody are co-chairmen of the benefit committee, and among their aides are Mrs. R. Thornton Wilson Jr. and Miss Beverly Merrill.
COLORADO SPRINGS -- Better roads, a great deal more water and prices that may be lower than last year's are three good reasons why tourists can expect a happy time in the Rocky Mountains this summer.

TO the general public George Jean Nathan was long known as a sort of junior partner of H. L. Mencken, because of their joint editorship of The Smart Set in the century's teens, and in the Twenties, their brief joint editorship of The American Mercury, published, as the advertisements used to tell us, for the "civilized minority."

Customs agents were searching yesterday for a man who had booked passage on the Queen Mary but had failed to appear for the sailing last Wednesday after his automobile had been seized with $142,000 worth of concealed gold.

A chronic illness, best described as "a hardening of the transportation arteries," has affected this country for years and many "general practitioners" have been trying through small groups and individually to effect a cure. Their scattered efforts, up until recently, however, were producing little improvement in the patient because of the lack of a rallying point where all knowledge and effort could be pooled.

Financial markets gave desultory performances most of last week as traders awaited clarification of the muddled steel wage-price controversy. The brief midweek walkout by the steel workers, following temporary return of the industry to management by court order, and the strike in the petroleum industry induced a sagging tendency in the markets, but prices turned firm toward the week-end on the more optimistic outlook for a settlement in steel.

Increased services to business, and new efforts to promote foreign trade, have been achieved by the New York regional office of the United States Department of Commerce since it moved from Lower Manhattan late last year to new headquarters at 2 West Forty-third Street.

--/ rodern homes in New Canaa ,] IConm, designed by five New Ca-I naan architects, will be opened to the public throughout the day ofI [ly 25, from 11 o'clock in thel morning until 5 o'clock in the lafternoon, for the benefit of the New Canaan Community Nursery I School.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 3 -- Connecticut Democrats whooped it up tonight for Senator Brien McMahon, state senior Senator, who had announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President earlier this week.

LOUISVILLE, May 3 -- George Edward Arcaro, the list-topping Derby jockey, and Benjamin Allyn Jones, the head-of-the-list Derby trainer, combined their talents with those of a 3-year-old colt named Hill Gail to win the seventy-eighth running of Kentucky's big horse race today.

For the competence and thoroughness of its news coverage and for the usual soundness of its editorial opinions I hold THE NEW YORK TIMES in high respect. I am sure, however, that THE TIMES would be the last to claim that its judgment is infallible, and in the light of its recent editorial calling for Presidential veto of the so-called tidelands legislation I believe any such claim would be difficult to sustain.

THERE is no such thing as the American Language any more than there is such a thing as the English Language. There are half a dozen species of each and some of them are more or less identical. I have, for example, just been reading through some editorials in THE NEW YORK TIMES and The London Times.

A program for the improvement of school-district organization in Midwestern states has been initiated by the Midwest Administration Center of the University of Chicago in cooperation with the University of Nebraska. In addition to the two universities, other Midwestern universities, state departments of education and administrators' associations are expected to collaborate in the school-district organization program.

WASHINGTON -- The vast and varied domains of the National Park system are expected to draw a record number of visitors this year. Anticipating an increase of visitors in the millions, Park Service officials here list a series of new attractions and improvements in certain areas but they couple their good news with a discouraging report on the progress being made in expanding the already bulging accommodations.

TOKYO, May 3 -- Japan, officially celebrating today the return of national independence and sovereignty, was warned by Emperor Hirohito that events of the past and the mistakes of totalitarianism and aggression must not be repeated and that faith with foreign powers, both East and West, should be carefully maintained.

THE exemption from the 20 per cent Federal admissions tax having been granted last Nov. 1, the nation's orchestras have been able to put in a full season without this burden. For some, like the York (Pa.) Symphony, it has meant the difference between breaking even and going into the red.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 3 -- Yugoslav authorities are preparing constitutional reform that would transform the existing system of government into the closest approach to the completely monolithic state achieved to date by Communist political theorists.

Five teen-age youths, said to be members of two gangs that have preyed on taxicab drivers and parked motorists in the last few months, were arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court and held in $25,000 bail each by Magistrate Matthew Fagan for appearance in Adolescent Court.

CAIRO, May 3 -- British Ambassador Sir Ralph Stevenson's return to Cairo this week, after decisions were reached in London on what Britain could offer Egypt, seemed like the possible opening scene in the last act of a stormy thirty-year period in Egyptian history.

THERE are times, mighty few of them, when "Forty-Four Gravel Street" contains jottings of fine perception and cutting sensitivity -- but by far the greater portion of the novel reads as though the author had, through some perverse streak, crossed out every other sentence of his MS before pressing it on a publisher.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Truman sat down in the East Room of the White House and played the piano today while an estimated total of 30,000,000 Americans in a television audience watched and listened.

NEW DELHI, May 3 -- The dispute between India and Pakistan over the Princely State of Kashmir, now nearly five years old, is still deadlocked over the conditions for a plebiscite in this strategic northern territory. The third report of Dr. Frank Graham, United Nations mediator, has shown no improvement in the situation, while at the same time events elsewhere in Asia make a settlement more imperative.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 3 -- Connecticut supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower are so elated over the strong showing by the general in this week's state-wide Republican caucuses that they expect to commit all this state's twenty-two national convention delegates to his candidacy.

JUST over medium height and strong and substantial of physique, the author of "Invisible Man" is visible indeed. His face is firm and sensitive and remarkably handsome, a scar and a thin mustache failing to mar it.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Government today ordered a 30 per cent cut in use of civilian aviation gasoline because of the country-wide oil strike. The reduction is to become effective at 3:01 A. M. Eastern daylight time, Tuesday. It will apply both to airlines and to private planes.
LONDON, May 3 (AP) -- Newcastle United defeated Arsenal, 1 -- 0, on a goal by Chilean-born George Robledo to win the Football Association Cup today for the second straight year.

Eighteen policemen accused of having taken gambling graft from Harry Gross, the convicted bookmaker, lost yesterday the second round in their fight to block their departmental retrial, which is scheduled to start tomorrow morning at Brooklyn Police Headquarters.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The House Education and Labor Committee will begin an inquiry into the Wage Stabilization Board next week with something other than a whitewash brush in hand.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 3 -- Columbia gained a 6-1 victory in the second game of an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League twin bill today after Cornell had won the opener, 1 -- 0.
CHICAGO, May 3 -- Toby Atwell, a former Dodger farmhand catcher, struck a mighty blow on behalf of the Cubs and the Giants before 27,194 cheering witnesses at Wrigley Field today.

ITHACA, N. Y., May 3 -- Cornell University's eight-oared crews swept a moonlight regatta with Columbia and Syracuse on Cayuga Lake tonight. The Big Red varsity finished in 10:49.1, three lengths ahead of Columbia and nine lengths ahead of the Orange.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 3 -- Mines and farms of the Ninth Federal Reserve District were being geared for increased production in the defense effort. Traffic and transportation men gathered for the quarterly meeting of the Northwest Shippers Advisory Board were told that crop prospects in Minnesota and the Dakotas ranged from good to excellent.
Columbia won its first outdoor dual track meet in fifteen years yesterday when it crushed Rutgers, 90 -- 49, at Baker Field.

The Lighthouse, New York Association for the Blind, will benefit this year by proceeds of the Belmont Ball, which will take place at the Turf and Field Club at Belmont Park on June 6. Mrs. John A. Morris is chairman of the executive committee.

Convinced that if they are to win a fourth straight flag immediate help is needed, the Yankees yesterday made a deal, aimed principally at bolstering one position -- centerfield. In what amounted to a four-for-one swap, New York got Irv Noren of the Washington Senators.

THERE are tulips and, then again, there are tulips which are best described as "odd." Like all rarities, they can only be used as specimens. Most of them belong in special garden locations and are perhaps less adaped to general use than they are to cutting for indoor decoration. This group includes the Lily-flowered tulips, the Parrots, the Bizarre and Bybloemen varieties.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 3 -- Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., defeated her best friend, Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, today to take the British hard-court tennis title for the second straight year.

The outlook for metallic-filled apparel linings appears extremely favorable for the fall of 1952, distributors of the cloth said last week. Merchandising efforts of Deering, Milliken Co., Inc., with "Milium," the first successful thermostatic lining, have paved the way for wider sales not only for their own fabric but for similar products by other manufacturers.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 3 -- Jouett Shouse's Cinda and the King Ranch's Tilly Rose accounted for the two divisions of the Colonial Handicap at Garden State today.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 3 -- Utah communities, buffeted by a $1,000,000 flood this week and facing severe water damage to homes, industries and farms by mid-May, have learned the folly of over-building along "dry" water-courses in a semi-arid region of scanty rainfall.
BALTIMORE, May 3 -- Listless campaigning has marked the approach of Maryland's primary election Monday.

WHAT will America be like in 1970? Miss Caldwell's apocalypse makes Spengler seem cheerful by comparison. In this novel of fierce prophecy she sees a Communist conspiracy in control in Washington. The courts and the Constitution have been outlawed; family life is directed by the Government; the fifth world war is about to erupt (this one against South America, the rest of the world being subject and in ruins).

THE Kraft Television Theatre this week observes its fifth anniversary on the air and, appropriately enough, the program has been the recipient of congratulations. Words of praise are in order, for in the main the dramatic program has turned in a remarkably competent record of performance on Wednesday evenings over N. B. C.

TWO interesting motor routes not generally known to United States visitors cross the South American continent linking two great capitals, Lima and Buenos Aires, and providing adventure as well as scenic interest.
Blood collections in this area got off to a good start for May with 1,953 pints donated during the first two days toward the quota of 22,500 pints, the Red Cross announced yesterday.

After reading Tyrone Guthrie's "Growing influence of the Ballet" (April 20) I am obliged to conclude that our British cousin is to the world of dance what a McKinley Republican is to the world of politics.

Adolf A. Berle Jr., State Chairman of the Liberal party, expressed confidence yesterday that on Jan. 1, 1954, the Liberal party would "take over the administration of the City of New York and rescue the city from the worst jam it has been in for many years."

THE TIMES is to be congratulated on the fine editorials on the need for keeping the lines of international trade open. Both Italy and Great Britain have protested our restrictions on their imports. Now Belgium has struck back. This should call public attention to the curious inconsistencies in our policy.

ECONOMY is the watchword throughout the movie stuios today, as it has been in varying degree for the last several years, but there are indications that thrift is to be more strongly enforced in the immediate future at Twentieth Century-Fox.

The stock market drifted narrowly and closed firm yesterday in the second dullest session of the year. Gains in selected issues were reflected in the advance of 0.67 in THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average of fifty stocks.

RANGOON, Burma, April 7 -- (By Airmail) -- Subjected to widespread devastation during World War II, her ports, cities, towns and railways smashed by air bombardments, Burma is developing a reconstruction program aimed at restoring her national production to pre-war levels within two years and increasing her gross output by another one-third in the following three years.

Each afternoon since the first warm day of spring motorists driving past a small farm house in a Midwestern rural community have seen a man sitting on the front porch. Many who live in the neighborhood wave to him as they pass, for he has become a familiar sight.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Closing its two-day thirty-fifth annual conference here today, the American Council on Education unanimously commended the work of its special committee on athletic policy and endorsed the committee's recent report which advanced several proposals for clearing up intercollegiate athletic programs.

BECAUSE a postage stamp gets around, and because it may bear a message, it perfectly serves the propagandist's purpose. Keeping this in mind, the Soviets have taken to issuing stamps to further their aims in their current "peace" offensive.

If this country were suddenly plunged into a third World War, the Maritime Administration could bring a ship out of its reserve fleets in less than one-fourth the time that was required to reactivate a vessel for the Korea conflict or for the transportation of economic-aid cargoes to Europe under the Marshall Plan.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 -- Legislation permitting any Methodist Church to transfer its affiliation from one jurisdictional area to another, provided certain requirements are fulfilled, was adopted here today by the Quadrennial General Conference of the denomination.

IN 1587, the year in which this story takes place, it was not unusual for a lad of 16 to play a man's part in the adventurous, dramatic world aboard an Elizabethan man-of-war. John Forrester, young hero of "The King's Beard," sees action of the most swashbuckling and satisfactory sort on board Sir Francis Drake's flagship, the Elizabeth Bonaventure.

LONDON, May 3 -- Prime Minister Churchill told the British people in a radio broadcast tonight that the bill to restore the nationalized iron and steel industry to private ownership had been drafted. He promised that it would be presented to Parliament this year.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 3 -- Princeton's track team defeated Yale by 73 -- 67 in a closely contested dual meet on DeWitt Cuyler Field today to halt Eli domination of this annual event. It was the Tigers' first outdoor track triumph over the Blue since 1941.

MOST appropriate for this particular election year is a retelling of the story of Wendell Willkie. That story becomes a pulsing, full-bodied narrative in the hands of Mary Earhart Dillon, chairman of the Department of Political Science of Queens College.

PORTLAND, Ore. -- Individual railroads have as many personal and private characteristics as different hotels. My wife and I have discovered this after a pilgrimage both ways across the continent by rail, with side trips which made our journey extend into half the states of the nation.

BONN, May 3 -- The strafing of a Berlin-bound French airliner this week by two Soviet Air Force fighters emphasized two aspects of the German problem which the Western world has forgotten since the blockade of Berlin was lifted three years ago this month.

The first concert in New York devoted entirely to Israeli chamber music will be given today at 3 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The program includes works by composers who went to Palestine fifteen years ago and by younger, later arrivals.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The range of the world's fastest bomber, the Air Force B-47 Stratojet, has been increased to more than 4,000 miles.

A warming event took place in Philadelphia a bit back when that city dropped its normal Sunday evening affairs in order to say good-bye to a railroad station. Just before the Pennsylvania System's last train left the Broad Street Station the Philadelphia Orchestra, outward bound on its spring tour, gave a brief concert and then its conductor, Eugene Ormandy, led spectators and passengers in the singing of "Auld Lang Syne."

MOBILE, Ala., May 3 -- Keen contests in three Congressional races will be decided in Alabama's Democratic primary Tuesday. Delegates to the Democratic National Convention will be chosen under harmony conditions. The state will have eight delegates at large and two delegates from each of the nine Congressional districts.

MOTORISTS heading out of the city today will find spring in one of its loveliest phases. Even some of the oaks have started to leaf out, and hickory buds are just breaking. Flower buds are standing up like miniature candles on horse chestnuts.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 3 -- The workers of this island are so union-minded that half belong to labor organizations, yet United States unions have paid little attention to them until lately. Of a total work force of about 700,000, more than 52 per cent are organized.

Student editors and photographers from the city's fifty-four academic and technical high schools, thirty-one vocational schools and a number of parochial high schools will attend a press conference to be held by Grover Whalen, Civil Defense Coordinator of Recruiting and Public Information, tomorrow at 3 P. M. at 500 Park Avenue.

LINCOLN, Mass. -- The museum-wide exhibition, "New England, A Photographic Interpretation," will open here today at the deCordova and Dana Museum with photographs describing many variations of the theme but, regrettably, with only token support from photographers of the region.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The writing, distribution and reading of books are never worth the energy that is put into them from the thermodynamic point of view, physicists asserted today at the end of the meeting of the American Physical Society.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M. -- Freshened by the most extensive winter's precipitation in years, the traditionally arid Southwest is emerging verdantly into its new season with a repertoire of tourist attractions ranging from the oldest Indian ceremonials to the latest marvels of atomic science.

What well may be the final chapter in the long and colorful life of Feltman's, pioneer restaurant and amusement center at Coney Island, will be written on June 25 when the property is put up at auction.

Somehow, one could sense that the Yankees were headed for trouble yesterday in the fifth inning of their struggle with the Tigers at the Stadium. Just after they had edged in front, 2 -- 1, came the worst of a series of blunders that eventually cost the Bombers a 6-3 decision in a contest completed under protest by the home side.

Although the wool textile business has shown signs of recovery, price difficulties at the raw commodity level inject a note of uncertainty into the picture. Prices of raw wool, it was pointed out last week, have fallen below the Government support level.

Brushing aside all remaining obstacles to the unification of Western Europe. General Eisenhower declared after a two-hour conference with Chancellor Adenauer that he and the leading German statesman found themselves in "warm agreement," and that he was convinced that we are on the verge of important developments ushering in a new era of confidence, peace and security.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 23 -- "Nothing that has happened about Trieste could possibly affect the permanent friendship of Yugoslavia for Britain and the United States."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 3 -- Yale split an Eastern Intercollegiate League double-header with Harvard today, winning the second contest, 2 -- 0, after suffering an 11-7 setback. Both were seven-inning games.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of a steel company memorandum filed with the Supreme Court today in connection with the Government's application for a review of the United States district court order enjoining seizure of the steel industry:

THIS time of year is usually a critical and worrisome one for the people who operate the transportation and the hotels that make up this country's resort and travel industry. Ordinarily, things would not have crystallized this early in May and it would still be anyone's guess whether the coming summer season would be a lean or a fat one.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (By Science Service) -- Students wanting to cram for final examinations might try getting themselves hypnotized. While hypnotized, they should gain time and learn much more.

PITTSBURGH, May 3 -- Two of the nation's top steel producers that had balked at reopening mills after the United Steelworkers C. I. O., ended the recent strike put out "resume operations" orders today.

Apple blossoms are pink and white in the orchards, and the bees are working overtime. Violets bloom in the lowlands. Dogwood whitens in the woodland, and along the gray stone walls the windflowers blow, the bloodroot still blooms and jack-in-the-pulpit and Trillium open big, new leaves and prepare exotic blossoms.
FRESNO, Calif., May 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias turned in a men's par 72 today to lead the $5,000, 54-hole Fresno women's open with a two-round total of 152.

CHICAGO -- Michigan, lower and central Wisconsin, Indiana and Illinois, among the Midwest states, expect a big crop of summer vacationists. The operators depend considerably upon visitors from New York, Chicago and other big cities in the East and in the Middle West for much of their patronage.

RICHMOND, Va. -- With reports from the five-state area of the Midsouth already showing an increase in travel this year over the same four-month period in 1951, beach and mountain resort owners throughout Kentucky, North Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia and West Virginia are preparing for another record-setting tourist season this summer.

In the White House yesterday ten men gathered around the long oblong table in the Cabinet Room. Their business was a case officially titled, "In the Matter of the Basic Steel Industry and United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O."

ALTHOUGH documents have not been drawn, there are indications that the Tennessee Williams hit play, "The Rose Tattoo," may be headed for the movies. Last week, the playwright's representatives confirmed the fact that Hal Wallis was definitely interested in doing a film version of the work and that Williams already "had written an outline of a treatment to present to Joseph I. Breen and the Production Code office in Hollywood.

The young skipper of the destroyer-minesweeper Rodman, whose sister ship, the Hobson, was sunk in mid-Atlantic on April 26 after colliding with the aircraft carrier Wasp, brought his vessel to port here yesterday with high praise for his crew's rescue work.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 3 -- The present Bolivian Government is the last bulwark against communism in this country, Vice President Hernan Siles Zuazo declared today. Asserting that the National Revolutionary Movement had not toyed and would not toy with orthodox Marxist doctrines, he said that the present Cabinet sought "only to maintain our own national and international independence -- independence of Moscow, Buenos Aires and Washington."
The police in Los Angeles were astonished to find that the check forger they were looking for was an armless midget. (He wedged the pen between chin and shoulder.)

THE achimenes, an easily grown relative of gloxinia, is a colorful summer-blooming plant for shaded areas. It produces leaf stems up to a foot high. Blossom buds form in the leaf axils to open successively from the lowest to the highest.

JOB expressed a desire that his enemy would write a book. Aneurin Bevan has plenty of enemies and the news that he was writing a book was received by them with agreeable anticipations of a new target to aim at. The target is here all right, for Mr. Bevan's book has very many faults of manner and a good many faults of matter.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The impact of Federal taxes on corporation earnings was pointed out today by a joint report on 1951 earnings prepared by two Government agencies, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Trade Commission.

THE indiscriminate application of topsoil is hardly an effective means of improving soils which are basically poor and unproductive. Besides the labor and expense involved, there is often the likelihood that soil diseases and undesirable weed seeds may be introduced.

ANGLERS are endowed, by tradition if not always by nature, with a greater store of patience than are the followers of other sports, especially of those in which strenuous activity is paramount, and of all the manifold forms of angling, salmon fishing seems to call for the greatest display of this virtue.

The United States military mission to Formosa has completed the first year of its activities, and its commander, General Chase, reports a considerable degree of progress. He is optimistic and encouraged in the face of what have been and still are heavy and complex duties and problems.

LONDON, May 3 -- Paramount Chief Chitimukulu, elderly ruler of the Bemba tribe, the largest in Northern Rhodesia, who came to London to oppose a Central African federation, recalled boyhood memories of Dr. David Livingstone at a meeting here today

NEW HOPE, Pa. -- Next Saturday, rain or shine, some 2,000 persons will gather in this small Delaware River town (pop. 1,066) to enjoy a prowl through nine historic homes here and in the adjacent Bucks County countryside.

Recently I went into a drug store which is a member of a national chain. While standing at the counter to be served, two white ladies walked up on the other side. The clerk, at the time, was serving someone else, but was well aware that I was first in line. When he had finished with the customer that he was serving he turned to those of us waiting at the counter.

PRIMROSES, long a favorite on the West Coast, are now meeting with wider acceptance. For with the advent of new hybrids, their value for gardens here in the East has greatly increased. Another factor which is contributing to their rise in popularity is a greater knowledge of their cultural requirements.

Tempelhof Airdrome, in the American sector of Berlin, handles an average daily traffic of 110 incoming and outgoing flights of three commercial airlines -- one American, one British, one French. Templehof and the other operating airfields in the Western sectors also handle a small number of military courier flights.

Organization or a New York State Harriman-for-President Committee with Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, as chairman, was announced yesterday by Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., chairman of the national Harriman - for - President Committee.

IN a succession of flowering trees that open one after another all spring, crabapples mark a high point. Only a half dozen different kinds of these small trees are needed for bloom throughout May, and perhaps may even start in April.

PLANNING of the program for the five-day convention of the Photographic Society of America, to be held from Aug. 12 to 16 at the Hotel New Yorker, is well under way. Attendance at the sessions is open to nonmembers as well as members on payment of a $5 registration fee for the full convention, $2 for a single day.

Citing reports of a rebirth of nazism and fascism abroad, Rabbi William F. Rosenblum, preaching yesterday morning at Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, expressed concern over a possible resurgence of totalitarianism in these forms and their rise in the United States.

The Fund for Adult Education disclosed yesterday it had found severe handicaps to adult education in lack of suitable materials and programs, of trained leadership and of coordination. Therefore it has decided to concentrate on these three major fronts.

The Calumet Farm's Hill Gail, 11-10 favorite ridden by Eddie Arcaro, won the $124,350 Kentucky Derby, with Sub Fleet second and Blue Man third, yesterday. Parading Lady took the Acorn Stakes at Belmont Park.

THE French dictionary says that a fonctionnaire is "one who performs a public function." The word is French, but its implications are European, and anyone traveling in Europe will soon come to the conclusion that the Continent and all its facilities are run by fonctionnaires.

The main event of Mental Health Week activities arranged by the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene will be the presentation of a television drama over WNBT at 12:15 P. M. today, the official start of the period.

The indictment against college theatre directors for producing no original plays, which John T. Dugan wrote in your section on April 6, is certainly justified. These men are just as worshipful of Broadway successes as is Broadway itself.

LONDON, May 3 (Reuters) -- Newcastle's victory today made it the first club to win the Football Association Cup a second year in succession since Blackburn accomplished the feat sixty-one years ago. The Northerners also gained the honor of being the first team to take the cup four times at Wembley Stadium.

CLEVELAND, May 3 -- Senator Robert A. Taft said today that if he won all of the fifty-six delegates in Tuesday's Ohio Presidential primary he would have 396 delegates pledged to him.. He "expects" to have 254 more before convention time, he added, for a total of 650. It takes 604 convention votes to nominate a Republican candidate for President.

THE Juilliard School of Music could scarcely have chosen a more distinguished opener for the production activities of its newly established department of dance than the recent series of performances by Martha Graham and her company, which sent most of the cognoscenti scurrying up to Claremont Avenue in the rain night after night.

IN Hollywood Clark Gable is known as the "iron man" because he has stayed in the top rank of stars for twenty-one years, while Bing Crosby is known as "lazybones." Yet Gable has only a one-year edge on Crosby in the longevity sweepstakes.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 3 -- The British jet airliner Comet streaked into Johannesburg today with a pay load less than twenty-four hours after it had left London for the 6,724-mile flight. It ushered in the jet age of commercial air travel.

It is the role of Catholic education to learn how to "wage peace," the Rev. Laurence A. McGinley, president of Fordham University, told 600 alumnae and graduating seniors meeting yesterday at the sixth annual alumnae reunion luncheon at Manhattanville College.
Fall orders are running slightly ahead of last year, manufacturers of men's clothing reported last week. With lines out about a month, producers were beginning to note trends for the coming season.
New York is still the "big town."

WHETHER "Of Thee I Sing," the musical satire on politics in an election year, has acquired moss or a halo in two decades is the primary question to be resolved when the revived Pulitzer Prize-winner of 1932 opens at the Ziegfeld in New York tomorrow evening.

HARRISBURG, Pa. -- Recreational travel and vacation business in Pennsylvania, including the vast Pocono Mountain resort area in the northeastern corner of the state, should be the best in many years. A check by the State Department of Commerce indicates that an increase of 15 per cent in volume over last year's highly successful summer is expected.

THERE is no such things as the status quo in the Catskill Mountain vacationland. The mountains themselves do not change perceptibly from one year to the next, but the resort hotels that occupy the four counties -- Delaware, Ulster, Greene and Sullivan -- that comprise the Catskill Preserve, do change noticeably.
A NUMBER of prize contests are offered during the coming months for outstanding pictures in a number of different categories.

WHEN the Asia Institute of New York asked Robert Payne to join a cultural expedition to Iran in the spring of 1949 he did not know much more about that country than the average Occidental who loves to travel and who is interested in the way of life of distant peoples.

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 3 -- Elizabeth Flotilla 306, United States Coast Guard Auxiliary, has formed a new flight squadron to operate with the unit in directing rescue operations. The flotilla is the only one in the East with its own air wing, according to Joseph F. Durkin, commander.

Recognizing, and of course correctly, that an enormous increment of the hundreds of thousands of federally numbered recreational power boats are cabin cruisers, William Edgar John of Milton Point, Rye, is doing just what the American Power Boat Association hoped he would when it named him national vice president for cruisers and chairman of the Cruiser Racing Commission.

THE future looked pretty bleak to 12-year-old Connie Rowley when she and her younger brother Danny followed their two big sisters into their new home, a neglected house in the country. However, fixing up the house, finding a map of an old mine behind a fireplace brick, and generous help from the neighbors made the situation more and more attractive.

Brooklyn College will turn its athletic field into a colorful fair-ground on Friday in celebration of the twenty-second birthday of the college. Five thousand persons are expected to attend the "country fair" that annually marks the college's anniversary as a part of the municipal system of higher education.
CINCINNATI, May 3 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds backed up Frank Hiller's five-hit flinging with a thirteen-hit attack today to defeat the Boston Braves, 8 to 1.

Parading Lady led a procession of fifteen others to the wire in the $20,000 added Acorn Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. The mile fixture for 3-year-old fillies had its twenty-second running and it was a thrilling event, with the crowd of 39,850 being generally pleased with the artistic triumph turned in by Parading Lady and her apprentice rider, Jim Hardinbrook.

MIAMI, May 3 -- Florida voters will go to the polls on Tuesday, with the highlight of the Democratic primary a Presidential popularity contest featuring the candidacies of Senators Estes Kefauver of Tennessee and Richard B. Russell of Georgia.

Points in favor of Paul-Henri Spaak's "Creating a New Europe -- 'It Must Be Done'" ( April 20) should find support with the majority of Europeans. However, division of Europe has been an Anglo-French-American political tenet for years, as witness their recent guarantees of territorial integrity for Poland and other European nations.

Despite its 78-year-old tradition, the Kentucky Derby became a first-time starter over the television waves yesterday when an estimated ten to fifteen million racing fans saw the first live telecast of the race over WCBS-TV.

POETRY must communicate before it is understood. You can communicate with some of the people all the time, you can communicate with all of the people some of the time, but it is vain to hope to communicate with all of the people all of the time.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 -- Despite an overwhelming Democratic lead in California registration, supporters of Senator William F. Knowland have not given up the idea that their candidate for re-election might duplicate Gov. Earl Warren's feat of two years ago and win both major party nominations at the primary election.

The Port Authority's new $9,000,000 tunnel under West 179th Street and the city-state $4,600,000 Highbridge Interchange will be put into service tomorrow to speed traffic on and off the George Washington Bridge.

Television reception near the Port Jefferson, L. I., railroad yards finally has been cleared up. But the job took the combined efforts of thirteen irate citizens, a member of Congress, the Federal Communications Commission, the Long Island Rail Road and the Long Island Lighting Company.

LOUISVILLE, May 3 -- Churchill Downs was a seething madhouse today. It always is on Derby Day. But off on the far side of the track in the barn area it was a lot quieter, although the same air of electric excitement gave warning that this wasn't just another day at the races. This was THE day.

IN 1927, when he was "an amiable old gentleman of 71," Bernard Shaw made the only intentional phonograph recording of his life. It was one of his whimsical acts of generosity, for he made it for the Linguaphone Institute to aid foreign students learn English.

NEARLY half a century has passed since Clifford Beers wrote "A Mind That Found Itself," his autobiographical account of conditions in the mental hospitals of his day. In the years since then much has been done to improve the state of affairs about which Beers wrote.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 3 -- A near clean sweep of the points in the speed events gave Manhattan's I.C.4-A champions a 77-to-63 edge over Army's Heptagonal titleholders today at North Field in the annual dual meet clash between two of the East's leading track and field powers.

TOKYO, May 3 -- Japan regained her national sovereignty and independence this week -- after more than six years of military occupation -- with probably as little pomp and fanfare as ever marked an important turn in modern history.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Supreme Court of the United States forbade the Government today to change the wages and employment conditions in the seized steel industry pending disposal of the case by the bench.

ALL of New England is honeycombed with dirt roads that are ideal for cycling and bring the enthusiast closer to the type of scenery for which the region is noted. For several years we have been cycling on short jaunts in Vermont and New Hampshire.

With the Republican National Convention only nine weeks away, the race for the nomination is moving into the homestretch. During May the Republicans in a dozen or more states will hold primaries or conventions. The close of this month will bring almost to an end the official selection of delegates to Chicago, as in only three or four states is the final choice deferred to June.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. -- The unsophisticated sharpies who inhabit the non-existent Broadway of the columnists have a phrase for the rest of the United States of America that tells more truth than they know, It reads, "It's II Bridgeport," and it is anathema to residents of Bridgeport, Conn.

NEWARK, May 3 -- A fund to aid 3-year-old Michael Goy, who was born without hands, was increased today by $30, a full year's prison pay, contributed by P. James Pellecchia Jr., who is serving a ten-to-fifteen year sentenc for embezzlement of $663,000 from the former Columbus Trust Company.

A "Panel of Americans," the first college panel of its kind in the Nebraska area, has been initiated at the University of Omaha. Made up of one representative each from the Catholic, Negro, Jewish and white Protestant groups, the panel will present for discussion the problems encountered by each of its members and their views on the intolerance problem as it exists today in America.

THE elegant opening last week of the new Beekman Theatre, a movie house of luxurious appointments at Second Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, is but another evidence of two significant things respecting the changing economy and the cultural evolution of the screen.

All-year, gas-operated home air-conditioning offers natural gas suppliers considerable promise of easing the seasonal summer slump in domestic gas consumption. Such was the assertion made last week by John A. Gilbreath, assistant vice president of Servel, Inc., and head of its air-conditioning division.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Diplomatic authorities said today that a meeting of the heads of the United States, British, French and Soviet missions in Germany would be one way of introducing talks on proposed free, all-German election.

ALTHOUGH it is written for an older group of readers, this is, in a sense, an "Understood Betsey" kind of story. Like Betsey, Jill is a motherless city girl who spends a year on the farm with competent country cousins.

FURTHER evidence, if indeed such evidence is needed, that radio has priced itself out of the market is the decision of Chesterfield cigarettes not to renew contracts expiring at the end of this season for the services of Bing Crosby and Bob Hope -- two of the highest budgeted shows in radio.

JERUSALEM is to become the site of large-scale international festivals of music, the dance and the drama, as soon as the "Binyanei Ha'Umah" (The National Convention Center Buildings) are completed. A. Ezer, director of the center, is sure he can keep his first deadline.

TOKYO, Sunday, May 4 -- The official Peiping radio said today that the Chinese and North Korean delegates negotiating for an armistice in Korea had made their "last concession" on the disputed issue of an exchange of war prisoners.

Columbia's lightweight crews swept a four-race regatta on the Harlem River yesterday. The Lion varsity, junior varsity and freshman eights defeated Cornell, while a four-man shell with coxswain overcame the New York Institute for the Blind.

IN city parks for several weeks women with baskets and knives have been assiduously digging dandelions. They are not weeding the lawns as volunteers, but are taking the still edible young greens home to cook. Dandelions, however, are not the only "weeds" to be eaten.

THOSE familiar with the first volume (Vol. VII: Matthew and Luke) of "The Interpreter's Bible," which appeared last fall, realized that this is to be the standard Bible commentary of our time. Sound scholarship, clearly written notes and introductions, together with a well conceived editorial plan, produced a book that deserved the favorable critical approval it received.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 3 -- Wisconsin's 1951 intercollegiate rowing champions today took the wash of the finest Navy eight-oared crew since 1947.

KINGS POINT, L. I., May 3 -- Adelphi's track and field team, with 88 1/2 points, won a seven college meet today. The victors were paced by Joe Martini, who captured the javelin thtrow, the shot put and the discus.

INSIDE a modern, high - ceilinged courtroom of the Court of Special Sessions in lower Manhattan, as night closes in on the big town, some fifty young men and women, between the ages of 17 and 20, white and Negro, are seated. The Chief Justice takes his seat on the bench as a uniformed attendant calls the young people forward. This is Night Probation Court.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 -- Movement of general merchandise remains satisfactory. Gradual improvement during April afforded further correction of inventories among retailers. Supplies of distress goods from factories and wholesalers are not readily available in volume, retailers seeking special promotions say.
ST. LOUIS. May 3 (AP) -- Cloyd Boyer, trying for a comeback at 24, made his season debut as a starting pitcher today by hurling and batting the Cardinals to a 3-0 victory over the Phillies.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 3 -- The 1952 tournament schedule for the Women's Tri-County Golf Association was released today by Mrs. Archie McLave of Hudson River, the secretary. Listed are four one-day eighteen-hole events, together with the eighth championship tourney, to be held Aug. 11-15 at the Apawamis Club.

Sinking of five concrete piers into the bed of the Harlem River for the New York Central Railroad's new $18,500,000 bridge is nearing completion and from now on thousands of interested window-gazing commuters will be able to follow closely the progress of the over-water construction.

THE hero of Alex Gaby's sad little novel -- he is never named -- comes home one night and discovers that his wife has committed suicide. No reason for the mad act suggests itself to him. His wife, of good family and sound mind, six months pregnant, has always seemed happy to him; there was a shine on their lives like that on her copper-colored hair.

ACAPULCO, Mexico -- Centuries ago the magnificent harbor and protected lagoon of Acapulco were put to use as a haven for travelers. As New Spain's main Pacific port, the sun-soaked village served as terminus for the fabulous trade in silver and silk that Spanish galleons carried between Mexico and Manila.

THANKS to the persistence of the Loft Players in Sheridan Square, Tennessee Williams' "Summer and Smoke" is having a second chance. This is a dispensation devoutly to be wished for both the play and the players.

KALIMPONG, India, May 3 -- The Chinese Communist military headquarters in Lhasa has alerted all troops garrisoning the Tibetan capital following an armed clash between Chinese and Tibetans, reports reaching here said today.

THE many-languaged babble of early-season visitors, already filling the streets and piazzas of Rome, is currently being echoed by the lingual calisthenics employed, of necessity, on the sets of two films of international nature now in production in Cinecitta's spacious sound stages.

BRIDGEPORT, W. Va. -- Summer vacationists looking for a week or two of relaxation and quiet at a reasonable price would do well to consider what West Virginia has to offer. Nowhere in the East can be found more majestic scenery with better roads or greater diversity of historic and natural points of interest than in this mountain state.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The State Department's Voice of America has told its listeners across the world that the refusal of three-fourths of the Chinese prisoners-of-war held by the United Nations in Korea to return to their police-state homeland exposes "the fiction of the Chinese volunteer."

TO help prospective vacationists with their summer plans, hundreds of tourist bureaus are now in operation throughout the country, providing free information about accommodations, rates, points of interest and sports possibilities in areas they represent.

BONN, Germany, May 3 -- A leading member of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's own Christian Democratic Union proposed today that "new and extensive" negotiations be held on the contractual agreement establishing West Germany's new status in Europe.
The trustees of the Presbyterian Hospital will honor Charles Proctor Cooper, president of its board of trustees, Thursday night, at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

YOUNG "Spider" Webb found an Indian arrowhead in the field behind his house. Certain that he had located the site of the Indian village which his grandfather talked about, he began a feverish period of digging.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 3 -- Annual elections of school board members will be held Tuesday in most of the sixty-five public school districts of Westchester County. Issues concerning "Communist infiltration," new buildings, merger of districts and expansion of spending powers will be at stake directly or indirectly.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today 133 additional battle casualties in Korea. The new list reported twenty-nine kilted, ninety-nine wounded and five missing in action. The following were listed from New York and New Jersey (None from Connecticut):

GALVESTON, Tex., May 3 (AP) -- Frank Noel, an Associated Press photographer who is taking pictures while a prisoner in Korea, was cited tonight by the National Press Photographers Association at its annual convention.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 3 -- Harvard's varsity crew regained the Compton Cup today by out-rowing Princeton, M. I. T. and Rutgers on the placid waters of Lake Carnegie.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 3 -- Although once again a sovereign state, with no outside limitation on its military or economic activities, Japan appears to be a reluctant dragon in so far as the final stage of its rehabilitation -- application for admission to the United Nations -- is concerned.

At least a dozen artificial kidneys are in spasmodic use in various hospitals. A new one has come out of the Westinghouse engineering laboratories, where it was designed by George W. Jernstedt and Harry H. Barker at the request of the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, Boston. A similar apparatus has been used for several months in the Children's Hospital, Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A proposal for holding Democratic national conventions every two years instead of every four will be put before the executive committee of the Democratic National Committee at its May 15 pre-convention meeting.
PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (UP) -- Left-hander Alex Kellner pitched a three-hitter for his first victory of the season today as the Athletics defeated the White Sox, 7 -- 1, before 4,000 fans.

WENATCHEE, Wash. -- Wenatchee's annual Apple Blossom festival is invariably the signal that the tourist season is well under way in the vast outdoor reaches of the Pacific Northwest. This year the orchards above Lake Chelan were in flower spectacularly from last Thursday through yesterday for the event that always heralds the beginning of the regular influx of motorists and sight-seers.

ALBANY -- New York's 522-mile barge canal, which opened the Empire State to western commerce, is being rediscovered by twentieth-century boating enthusiasts whose crafts range from kayak or canoe to power launches.

DESPITE America's acceptance of motoring as the predominant way of getting around, many travelers consider roads merely a means of going from one place to another. Actually, hundreds of American highways are fascinating tourist goals in themselves.

Robert Lippmeier, 16-year-old Forest Hills High senior, won the one-mile run that was a feature of the fifth interscholastic track and field meet sponsored by Brooklyn College in connection with the P. S. A. L. on the Kingsmen's athletic field yesterday.

THIS summer the attractions of the Far West are expected to persuade an increasing number of motorists with four to six weeks at their disposal to follow the sun. Others with less time will head for recreation areas in the Great Lakes area, Canada and New England's coasts and mountains.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 3 -- Pan American Airways officials and Brazilian authorities were working together today on plans for an expedition overland to the point where a Stratocruiser crashed last Wednesday, carrying fifty persons to death in the Amazon jungle.

When the United States Supreme Court last week held the released-time program in the schools constitutional, it set at rest an issue that had been troubling schoolmen for many years. "Released time" permits schools to let their pupils leave the classroom for a certain period during the school day to attend religious classes of their own choosing.

The word Independence has a special meaning for Mr. and Mrs. Foster L. Dockstader. For the Independence is the liner aboard which they were married at sea last Monday. She docked here at Pier 84, North River, at 9 A. M. yesterday with 700 passengers from Mediterranean ports.

THIS time with Scotland as a setting, Leslie T. White has produced another racy melodrama. The hero is low-born, broad-shouldered Davy Dugald who, page one reveals, has a keen eye for a lass. This harbinger of concupiscence is quickly followed by violence between Davy and his priggish master, Lord Ian Dugald.

WHILE reading this book, I could not help musing on what Freud would have felt about it. During his eventful lifetime, when the methods and doctrines he advocated seemed so revolutionary to his contemporaries, he was well used to tirades against himself and his thought, and I am sure he would have been much amused by this one.

Larry Adler gave his first full-length solo recital in New York yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Since it was the harmonica player's first appearance in this city since his joint program with Paul Draper at the City Center four years ago, it attracted a good number of his admirers.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday May 4 (AP) -- Sabre jet pilots shot down five Communist MIG'S yesterday in sunset battles near Manchuria that gave the United States two new jet aces, the Fifth Air Force said today.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Air Force announced today it had allowed Verne Goodwin, one of fourteen officers who had refused to fly, to resign "under conditions other than honorable."

THE New American Library, publishers of paper-bound books, has launched an interesting project with "New World Writing." Strongly influenced by the example of John Lehmann's "Penguin New Writing," it is a consciously highbrow but firmly eclectic anthology of avant-garde writing.

A man arrested after a street fight yesterday was identified by the police as one of the three gunmen who on Friday held up the Delehanty Institute, 155 East Fifteenth Street, kidnapped two guards and escaped with an $11,354 payroll.

EVER since 1934, when the Pittsburgh Playhouse emerged as the leader of a city-wide little-theatre movement, Pittsburgh has fostered the hope of one day attaining parity with the country's large-scale community theatre centers.

The job of the Supreme Allied Commander in Europe (SACEUR) is to build and direct an international army for the defense of Western Europe, composed of units from member nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. It is a task of vast military, psychological and political complexity and one requiring diplomatic skill as well as military knowledge.

BOSTON, May 3 (UP) -- Ellis Kinder, pitching tightly in the clutches, turned back the Browns today, 5 -- 2, as the Red Sox took the rubber game of the three-game series before a crowd of 12,159 at Fenway Park.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Atomic bomb explosions in Nevada are interfering with the time clock of Dr. W. F. Libby, University of Chicago physicist. His time clock is a method of measuring the age of anything that lived up to 25,000 years ago by the strength of the radioactive carbon contained in the ancient materials.

BONN, Germany, May 3 -- The headquarters of the United States armed forces in Heidelberg announced today it intended to discontinue "certain support activities and services customarily rendered occupation forces by the indigenous economy."
CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) -- Grains ended on a firm tone on the Board of Trade today after spending most of the session hovering around previous closing prices. Soybeans led the moderate advance.

IT is always a pleasure to have a story about Whitey, that intrepid small cowboy who helps Uncle Torwal run the Rattlesnake Ranch. The tales are generally quite simple in construction and it is this very simplicity, added to a realism and an understanding of boys, which makes them so memorable.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The civil rights issue which split the Democratic party in the 1948 Presidential election poses a knotty question, imperative of resolution, for both Democrats and Republicans in the coming campaign.

THE hero of this book of tough adventure in Mexico is amoral, resourceful and hard-boiled -- a man of wry humor and violent temper, nasty in saloons, often surly, always blunt, and as likable a character as ever you will meet.
THE electronic brain, which man can use to compute anything from the thinness of split hairs to the fatness of government budgets, now is challenging its master to a direct battle of wits.
IF the art season opens with a salvo of one-man shows it is apt to conclude, in the spring with a flurry of groups.

TO that miniscule band of hardy travelers fortunate enough to have heard Joan Lowell tell the almost incredible tale of how she and her husband pioneered a road into the heartland of Brazil's Goiaz state, her book about that adventure comes as a disappointment.

The year 1952 promises to be a critical one for the American air transport industry, which is to say the operators and the makers of the planes and engines which since the war have dominated the field. That domination is seriously threatened by the British.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 3 -- Dr. Lewis Webster Jones will be inaugurated as fifteenth president of the 186-year-old Rutgers University at 3 P. M. Thursday in the presence of presidents of sixty-three universities and colleges, 337 representatives of institutions of higher learning and learned societies, alumni, faculty members and the student body.

Holders of United States Savings Bonds who plan to shift their investments into the new, higher-rate issues announced by the Treasury last week should "think twice" before making the switch, in the view of many money market observers who have made a careful study of the actual interest yields.

Combined sales volume of major department stores last week fell an estimated 7 per cent below that of the corresponding week of last year, but the loss was viewed as due largely to an unfavorable statistical comparison. In part of the week last year, volume was inflated with extra buying of big-ticket goods by purchasers anxious to beat the new city 3 per cent sales tax before the May 1 deadline.

Full details of the eleventh and twelfth games of the match between Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires at the Jockey Club in Mexico City arrived yesterday, satisfying the curiosity of local chess devotees as to how Reshevsky happened to lose two games in succession.

THE road between the two great French industrial cities of Lyon and Saint Etienne passes through one dreary mill town after another. It is hard to tell where one leaves off and the other begins. There are coal mines in the near-by hills and foundries and blast furnaces all about.
The current series of atomic tests in Nevada has focused increased attention upon civil defense -- always, in America, the stepchild of preparedness.

IN his first volume of poems, Ernest Kroll displays an extraordinarily rich and mature poetic talent. This is poetry that combines to a remarkable extent imaginative spontaneity and effortless control. And, whether Mr. Kroll is writing a mocking sketch of a Sunday driver or a meditation on the ambiguous rewards of public office, his work bears the impress of a deeply reflective wit.

In the Republican race last week Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the first time nosed ahead of Senator Robert A. Taft in delegate strength. This was the box score at the weekend as compiled by the Associated Press on the basis of bound delegates and those willing to commit themselves:

Generally, interest paid by a taxpayer upon his indebtedness is deductible in the year in which payment is made if he makes his income tax return on the cash receipts and disbursement basis, and in the year of accrual if he makes his return on the accrual basis. This applies also to corporations.

NEW DELHI, India, May 3 -- The Indian Government has appealed to Ceylon to use "magnanimity and statesmanship" in meeting the nonviolent movement in Colombo that is protesting the disfranchisement of more than 200,000 Indian settlers on the island.

ROBERT HILLYER has been studying, teaching and writing poetry for many years. He has received a Pulitzer Prize (1934) for his work and many other honors, among them his recent election to the presidency of the American Poetry Society.

Sunday morning round-table conferences by civil defense officials of eight eastern states are being held bi-weekly over "ham" radio facilities, the New York State Civil Defense Commission announced yesterday.

Although retail sales volume has shown a slight improvement recently, merchants generally are agreed that the best that can be hoped for during the next two to three months is to keep the mild pick-up alive.

HATTERAS, N. C. -- Hard surfacing now is in progress on the last 12.34-mile section of a coastal highway that will give the motoring vacationist comparatively easy access to a fifty-five-mile-long strip of North Carolina's Outer Banks, hitherto one of the state's most isolated regions.

GEN. MATTHEW BUNKER RIDGWAY, a master of hot war, has taken over military control of the greatest "cold war" in history. As Supreme Allied Commander in Europe he takes up the fight in a bigger and more civilized Korea, but the basic problems are the same as those he found when he first came to the battle-torn peninsula in the Christmas season of 1950.

Taking nine first places and three seconds in the twelve-event program, Poly Prep won the seventh annual Ivy Prep School League track and field championship for the seventh consecutive time on their field in Brooklyn yesterday.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 3 (AP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will make at least two or three speeches in the United States before the Republican National Convention opens July 7, one of his chief political backers said today.

The Council on Student Travel released yesterday its 1952 schedule of student and teacher sailings to Europe. Five round trips are contemplated -- two out of New York and three from Montreal -- again using the motorships Nelly and Anna Salen, which last year carried 2,500 persons in student travel.

THE airplane, which has done more to popularize Alaska than Robert W. Service, Jack London and all the sourdoughs of 1898, stands ready this year to fly a record number of vacationists into the Land of the Midnight Sun.

A screen "original" is defined by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences as a story property specifically written for the motion picture and not previously published or reproduced in any other medium. Originals run to two basic types: those the writer thinks too thin or foolish for expansion into novel or play form and those fat and fascinating enough to attract large immediate sums from the producers.

Cotton prices were sharply lower last week, with the major losses occurring in spots and in the nearby futures contracts. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed the week 63 to 157 points below the level of the week before.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (AP) -- A Negro leader said today that most of the candiadtes running for the Presidency "are far below the standards set by President Truman" on the issue of civil rights legislation.
TOKYO, Sunday, May 4 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique 1238, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M. Saturday (5 P. M. Friday, Eastern daylight time):

THE United Nations, an organization composed of capitalist, Communist and a lot of in-between countries, is having considerable trouble these days with the profit motive. It seems that the name, emblem and flag of the U. N. can be a pretty good thing commercially, with a little promotion and merchandising, and the United Nations isn't at all happy about it.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Despite slightly higher prices, attributed to rising operating costs, advance reservations in the resort areas of northern California point to a summer travel season as good as, or even somewhat better than, 1951 in volume of patronage.

The Kremlin has ordered another major step to raise Bulgaria's military-economic potential, and that country's Government has hastened to obey. In frenzied haste an iron and steel combine is to be built near Sofia under a schedule that calls for the first pig iron to be produced by early next spring.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 3 -- The Vietminh headquarters for Cochin China was located and destroyed by French Union and Vietnamese troops in a three-week operation that ended yesterday. The attackers found that the Communist-led force's commander, Le Duan, and his staff had slipped away a week before the French drive began, leaving behind valuable supplies and installations but no defenders.

KAREL CAPEK, one of the most versatile and entertaining Czech writers, had an enviable reputation in Europe. Unfortunately, in this country only a few plays ("R. U. R.," "The Insect Comedy") have gained him an audience -- and a small one at that.

WHEN Canadian television stations go on the air in August, the event will mark an experiment in North American television. It will be the first Government-operated television system on this continent. The Government's Canadian Broadcasting Corporation will open a station at Toronto and another at Montreal, on Channels 9 and 2, respectively.

ATLANTIC CITY -- Predictions of a record-breaking summer vacation season are being made here following the announcement of results of a State survey that credited more than half of New Jersey's 1951 resort revenue to business in this seaside metropolis.

WITHIN the next few weeks vacationists will begin pouring into the mountain-ridged Jasper-Banff-Lake Louise triangle of the Canadian Rockies. Perhaps in greater numbers than ever before, the pleasure travelers will make their way by trail, train or car to the very edges of the thick prehistoric glaciers or icefields that dot the area.

ONE of the milestones in life, when one is 5 or 6 or so, is losing the first tooth. On that crisp Maine morning, when Sal felt a tooth beginning to wiggle she was first horrified -- but her consternation turned to excitement and pride when Mother explained that it was part of growing up.

YONKERS, May 3 -- Making her first start of the season, Floating Dream, 4-year-old bay mare owned by McKinley Kirk and Robert and Harry Vallery of Waverly, Ohio, staged a plucky finish to win the feature race at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
Committee heads to carry out plans for the celebration of Columbia University's 200th anniversary in 1954 were made known yesterday.

TOKYO, May 3 (UP) -- Hard punching was seen in the finals in the Far Eastern Command boxing tournament held tonight at Memorial Hall. Winners will advance to the All-Army tournament at Fort Monmouth, N. J., to take place sometime later this month.

A MAN of wit, taste and talent, Ludwig Bemelmans has earned a grateful public with such titles as "Hotel Splendide," "My War with the United States," "Life Class," "The Donkey Inside" -- books that preserve for us, like half-pints on a narrow, refrigerated shelf, the ever-fresh cream of humor.

LONDON, April 18 (By Air Mail) -- A technique of depositing a transparent film of gold a quarter of a millionth of an inch thick on plate glass has been devised by a group of light technologists at the national physical laboratories here.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., May 3 -- Arthur H. Haaren, 59-year-old lawyer, of 15 Woodbine Avenue, Larchmont, collapsed and died of a heart ailment at 9:10 A. M. today while fishing here at Campfire Club, of which he was a member.
BALTIMORE, May 3 (AP) -- Alerted, a son of Calumet Farm's famous sire Bull Lea, won another bundle of money for Hampton Stable today in the Fifty-first running of the Dixie Handicap.
Paul J. Keeler, for several years marine superintendent of the John W. McGrath Corporation, has been named vice president in charge of operations. He will continue to make New York his headquarters.
CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) -- A five-year-old white female fox terrier got a medal from the American Humane Association yesterday for saving the lives of seven persons.

AMONG recent record releases are three operas which have never been widely popular: Verdi's Simon Boccanegra (Cetra-Soria), Giordano's Andrea Chenier (Urania) and Dvorak's Rusalka (Urania). Each is on three disks.

TAMPA, Fla. -- By far the greatest amount of automobile travel in Florida is north and south; yet an east-west trip will give a tourist a better understanding of the basic qualities and the natural resources which the state possesses.

ASMARA, Eritrea, May 3 (Reuters) -- United Nations Commissioner Anze Matienzo submitted to the Eritrean Representative Assembly today the draft of a new constitution establishing this former Italian colony as an "autonomous unit federated with Ethiopia."

LOS ALAMITOS, Calif., May 3 (UP) -- Gerry Coleman, New York Yankees' second baseman who traded in his diamond uniform for the Marine Corps green, started a tour of military duty here today, but his mind was still on baseball.

JONES BEACH, L. I. -- This biggest of the thirteen state parks in the Long Island chain, famous for its mile upon mile of dazzling white sand beaches, will ring up the curtain at its new Marine Stadium in June. Productions on its extremely stagey stage, perched atop the waters of Zachs Bay, will be handled by Michael Todd.

NEW Jersey shore resorts expect to benefit from public acceptance of the high - speed New Jersey Turnpike this year. Even the highly publicized places like Asbury Park and Atlantic City will be helped by this new highway, but it is the more remote resorts such as Ocean City and Cape May which will show the greatest percentage of increase in visitors.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 3 -- The long week-end that began with Israel's independence day and May Day has been an occasion for much stock-taking among Israelis, both official and private.

MORRISTOWN, N. J. -- Extensive building activity throughout Morris, Sussex and Warren Counties since last summer has included construction of several highway cabin retreats for tourists. In addition, most country hotel owners have completed extensive modernization programs.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- A Washington minister said today President Truman did not tell the truth when he said Calvin Coolidge "just about broke up" the First Congregational Church by attending it while President.

CAIRO, May 3 -- British Ambassador Sir Ralph Stevenson, who has just returned from two weeks of consultations with his Government in London, met Ahmed National El Hilaly Pasha, Egyptian Premier, today and announced later that he had given him a message from Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary.

I disagree with George R. Stewart's explanation in "'Iron-Hewer' or 'Man of Toft'?" (April 20) of the original meaning of the name Kefauver. In my opinion this name is one of the various old-time spellings of a German word meaning vat-maker or vat-hewer, which are, for example:

On the morning of Dec. 22, 1950, Dwight Eisenhower left the U. S. to begin his mission as Commander in Chief of SHAPE. That afternoon Matthew Ridgway became Commander of the U. S. 8th Army, succeeding Lieut. Gen. Walton Walker, who had been killed during the Korean retreat of that winter.

A picture with "State Convention Time" in your issue of April 20 showing a county chairman of the G. O. P. discussing matters with three working men in work clothes is a photographic masterpiece. It depicts the free flow of ideas between the listeners and the talker.

The first photographs taken by a new camera specially designed for studying meteors have clearly indi cated much turbulence in the upper atmosphere, Dr. Fred L. Whipple, Professor of Astronomy at Harvard University, told the National Academy of Sciences last week.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UP) -- Pete Runnels' two-out single in the last half of the ninth inning scored Gil Coan with the winning run today as the Senators scored their second straight victory over the Indians, 7 -- 6.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- There is general agreement that the confused mass of immigration and deportation laws piled up over nearly thirty years needs overhauling and amalgamation into an up-to-date, "streamlined" statute. Even opponents of legislation approved by the House of Representatives last week by a 206-to-68 vote and due for Senate floor consideration next week go along with this slated objective.

A program for developing better citizenship in the nation's elementary and high schools has been prepared by the Commissioners of Education of the Northeastern States (New England, New York and New Jersey). The 105-page report, "Education for Citizenship," was issued last week by the education commissioners.

Twenty-five years ago the science reporter was not welcome in the laboratories of universities. Today he is recognized as an indispensable interpreter of new discoveries. Howard W. Blakeslee, the able science editor of The Associated Press, did much to bring about this change.

MINNEAPOLIS -- Given enough good corn - growing weather -- up to 100 degrees during the day and still hot at night -- Wisconsin and Minnesota resort operators figure on an influx of sweltering Midwesterners to the northern lakes and forests that will make for a record vacation season.

IN spite of the fact that Gov. Adlai Stevenson pulled the carpet out from under two biographers encamped in Springfield, Ill., when he ruled himself out of the Presidential primaries, at least one of the books will be completed and published. Noel F. Busch's "Stevenson of Illinois" will be a June, or pre-convention, publication of Farrar, Straus Young.

A sharp decline in offshore employment in the last few weeks, coupled with the inability of many seamen to qualify for unemployment insurance, has created a situation that is giving concern to the shipping industry. The situation is said to be worse than at any time since the outbreak of the Korean War and observers believe it will continue to deteriorate in the next few months.
Marcel Pesch, in a letter about Pepys in your issue of April 6, states that Pepys "wrote his diary to save time, not for the sake of secrecy."
The "red tape of trade and travel," with its accompanying costly documentation and delays, is under attack by the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

In two sales this week the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, will auction outstanding modern French paintings and fine French eighteenth - century furniture and decorative objects from the estate of the late Benjamin E. Levy.

A FORSYTHIA in bloom or a birch in full leaf may look just right for a certain spot in the garden but these stages are not, generally speaking, the best times in which to move woody plants. No matter how carefully this is done, it is not possible to dig up and transplant a shrub or tree without losing a portion of its root system and disturbing the growth of the rest of the plant.

BONN, Germany, May 3 -- Nearly 3,000,000 Germans are expected to vote tomorrow in the communal elections in the state of Hesse which have taken on an importance far beyond usual district elections of this kind. Instead of local issues, national matters have occupied the campaigners and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has delivered a major address in defense of his policies for Western European integration.

A Brooklyn man, accused of striking a disabled Marine corporal and snatching his wallet, was captured yesterday after fellow patrons at a bar and other pedestrians had chased him for four blocks along sidewalks crowded by disbanding participants in Brooklyn's Loyalty Day parade.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: With apple trees in blossom, it is safe to sow almost all kinds of seed except such warm weather vegetables as lima beans and corn. Make second sowings in short rows of lettuce and radish. Sprinkle vegetable and flower seeds thinly, whether in a row or broadcast, and firm moist soil over them.

THE Philadelphia Civic Grand Opera Company, which has limited means but which operates out of an ambitious and lively point of view, produced Verdi's "Nabucco" some ten days ago. The occasion was of such musical and historic interest that quite a few New York opera buffs hastened to Philadelphia to see and hear the piece.

AUBURN -- The Finger Lake region of central New York is a place of spectacular glens, rolling farmland and deep, pure lakes. It is warm in tradition of the Indian and strong in appeal for the vacationist.
