PITTSBURGH, May 3 -- Sal Maglie, his razor perhaps not as sharp as usual, nevertheless retained a sufficient keenness today to shave the already sadly shorn Pirates and give the Giants the series finale by a score of 3 -- 2.

BOSTON -- Vacations on wheels, the postwar trend that has led families to break their holiday time into short stays at a variety of places, will be catered to with increasing enthusiasm this year in New England. Inquiries in the region even before the ice had gone out of the northern lakes indicated that a busy season was in prospect.

NICARAGUA'S Jefe de la Oficial Filatelica (equivalent to Philatelic Director), Augustin Vanegas P., advises from Managua that President Anatasio Somoza ordered a few weeks ago "a surprise inspection of the stocks" of all of the republic's stamp dealers and that "great quantities of forged stamps were confiscated."

ALTHOUGH trend-spotting too often can be a pretty disappointing pastime, occasionally a trend spotted turns into reality. Such, happily, has been the case with those historical symphonic dramas, a movement for which Paul Green must be given major credit.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., May 3 -- New Mexico will cast its primary vote Tuesday, with most Republican interest centered on the three-cornered race for the United States Senate nomination, in which former Maj. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley is opposed by Wesley Quinn and John Knorr.

TORONTO -- A paved transcontinental highway now under construction in Canada and expected to be ready by 1956 is the major item in a road improvement program on which the Canadian Provinces and the Federal Government are spending about $300,000,000 this year.

A baby girl named Kathy, healthy and intelligent and with delicate features, found a mother and father last week through the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service. In a world where couples seeking babies for adoption far outnumber the supply Kathy had to wait thirteen months because her skin was too dark.

THE advent of the spring and summer, when amateur cameras are worked longer and more productively than at any other time of the year, will see the intensification or the inauguration of club projects in various parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Presidents have resorted to seizure of private property on many occasions and under divers circumstances, and their acts have been challenged frequently, but few of the challenges have produced actual litigation that was carried to a conclusion in the nation's courts.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Supreme Court's order today in the steel case:

BALLET THEATRE, which has stood up well under the grind of four a day at the Warner Theatre, will continue there through Thursday of this week, presenting "Rodeo" and excerpts from "Princess Aurora," alongside the cinema exploits of Errol Flynn.
PARIS, May 3 (AP) -- French port fees are costing the United States $6 for every American officer and more than $2 for every enlisted man landed in France, Washington's partner in Western defense.

YANKEE Gen. Phil Sheridan is famous in the Lone Star State for his blunt assertion that if he owned hell and Texas he would sell the latter and dwell in the former. In this volume of exciting Mexican border tales, John Houghton Allen, a Texas native, is more bitter than Sheridan.

DALLAS, May 3 -- Employment gains, good crop prospects and higher retail sales were reported for the Southwest. In the Eleventh Federal Reserve Bank's monthly business summary on Thursday the bank reported a gradual increase in non-farm employment as a result of growing defense activity and seasonal factors.

Picturesque city gardens and penthouse terraces will be opened to the public on Tuesday afternoon and the afternoon of May 13 for the benefit of the Children's Gardens of the City Gardens Club, the Scholarship for Nature Teachers and Christmas at Kingsbridge Veterans Hospital.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- With highways into the scenic interior of the province improved, and the number of auto courts doubled in the past four years, all phases of British Columbia's travel industry are planning for their biggest year in 1952.
If voluntary hospitals, health and welfare service agencies were to be self-supporting they would have to charge enough to cover costs, which most families cannot afford.
LONDON, May 3 -- "But what was Moscow like?" people ask me, and I never know where to begin.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement made by President Truman at the White House today to representatives of the steel mills and union workers:

Historic and modern homes in Princeton, N. J., will be opened to the public on the afternoon of May 17 for the benefit of the scholarship funds of Mount Holyoke and Radcliffe Colleges. The tour has been arranged under the auspices of alumnae of the two colleges in central New Jersey.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- The draft deferment program for college students may be ended in the next two or three years because of the manpower demands of the armed forces, the American Council on Education was told here today at the closing session of its thirty-fifth annual conference.

Members of the American Association of Cereal Chemists heard Dr. S. S. Jackel tell how bread can be kept fresh for two to five days. All the baker has to do is to add a pinch of an enzyme (alpha-amylase) to the dough while it is being kneaded. There are many amylases. Nearly all break down in hot ovens. Dr. Jackel's special amylase is stable, for which reason it stands up under heat.

ONE evening a month or so ago mothers and dads of beginning youngsters in a Midwestern school, gathering for a parents' meeting, were handed little mimeographed booklets strongly resembling a child's first reader.

DANBURY, Conn., May 3 -- Former State Senator Alice V. Rowland of Ridgefield, an announced supporter of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination, was elected today as a member of the Republican State Central Committee from the Twenty-fourth District.
ALBANY -- Special celebrations and Canadian-United States dollar parity are two factors expected to lure more vacationists to New York State this year than in any past season.

STRENUOUS efforts to change the consumer state of mind are in the cards for the immediate future. Merchandising executives are inclined to worry even when things are going well, in terms of dollar and unit volume.

FRESH fruits in abundance and variety still are many weeks away but there are delectable alternatives to add refreshing piquancy to spring desserts. Unlike the home cook of another generation, who had to make do in March, April and May with the fruits she had canned the year before, today's shopper has a wide choice of canned and frozen products -- peaches, pears, plums and pineapple.

THIRTY - THREE physicians contribute to this unique book with a clinical description of their own diseases. Some of these ills are fatal, some disabling. Others, such asalcoholism, morphinism or mental disorder, are compromising for a doctor and therefore published under pseudonyms.

Reorders were received on summer lines as consumers started early purchasing, resident buying offices reported last week. Fall lines were completed in the wholesale market here and some business was placed. Stores in steel mill areas have requested postponement of shipments and some have canceled orders.

THE story of the evolution of man, says Gerald Heard, is the biggest and most wonderful of all stories. And so it is. It still holds riddles, chief of which at the moment is "why all animals except man have now become so specialized that there seems very little hope of their further advance, very little doubt that they are on the way to extinction."

MORE and more people are visiting Grand Canyon National Park each year. Most of them look at the tremendous gorge, are appropriately impressed and return home to tell their friends they have "seen" it.

Members of two Navy fighter squadrons who left Floyd Bennett Field for Korea a year ago will receive a gala welcome when they return Tuesday morning but, at their request, the ceremony will be a short one. They told planners of the reception that their one desire was to get home.

IT may be that Arturo Toscanini has finally decided to show the youngsters how to go about it. Or it may be mellowness, now that his eighty-fifth birthday has gone. Or, on the other hand, it may be nervous energy. Toscanini is always unpredictable, except when he is on the podium.

OF all the flowers which May brings to the garden, the tulip is one of the most popular and most widely planted. Because of its brilliant color and orderly manner of growth, it is also being used more extensively in public parks and city squares, and to lend a touch of brightness to industrial centers.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind. -- The fabled Wabash River is not particularly fabulous or even picturesque anywhere above Vincennes, where George Rogers Clark crossed it. Conceivably, the sycamores and moonlight celebrated in song could be seen either in New Jersey or Pennsylvania in clear weather.
The five Witty "boys" have formed as good a combination in business as they did in high school and college.

ROME, May 3 -- The provincial and municipal elections to be held in Central and Southern Italy on May 25 afford a good opportunity to test Italian public opinion and ascertain the changes that have occurred in the attitude of the victors toward the Government in the four years since the last general election -- April 19, 1948.

CLEVELAND, May 3 -- With write-in votes ruled out and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower not entered in the Ohio Republican primary Tuesday, interest here is concentrated on the showing of Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, whose bid for Democratic convention delegates is being contested in most areas by the state organization.

Under brilliant skies, in happy contrast to the downpour that marred a Manhattan parade a week before, 60,000 Brooklynites marched yesterday in the borough's fifth annual Loyalty Day parade. Another 150,000 persons lined the route.
MORE than half of all unsuccessful slam contracts are beaten because one of the defenders has a singleton and gets a ruff.

EXCELLENCIES of varied sorts are part of the equipment of great judges. Legal learning and wisdom and a sturdy competence in practical matters are primary requisites for judicial statesmanship. To these may be added what perhaps should be esteemed as adornments rather than essentials in the workaday function of presiding over trials and writing appellate opinions.

EDWARD R. MURROW, news narrator and co-producer of the "See It Now" television program on Channel 2 each Sunday at 6:20 P. M., has many reservations about video's facility to present day-to-day coverage of spot news events.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee reported today that military aid shipments to Europe had been "slower than desirable" but looked for sharp step-ups in the immediate future.

IN the vicinity of New York City, the outdoor planting season usually starts in earnest "on or about" May 10. Garden clubs have taken this date as a timely signal for annual plant sales, by which they raise money to carry out their various projects.

GENEVA, May 3 -- Experience gained over a period of several years in the field of technical assistance to underdeveloped Communist-threatened countries has convinced many Western officials that the United States is getting too little done by trying to do too much.

IT is generally known that the Libera Me, concluding part of Verdi's Requiem Mass, written in commemoration of Manzoni, constituted originally the corresponding section of a requiem in honor of Rossini, to which, as suggested by Verdi in a letter to Ricordi of Nov. 17, 1868, twelve other leading Italian composers contributed.
VACATIONISTS seeking distant places at a reasonable transportation cost will find that the railroads still offer a solid travel bargain.

Every believer in government by law and in fair play will applaud the Supreme Court ruling late yesterday forbidding effectuation of President Truman's threat to raise steel wages Monday morning unless a contract was reached before then by those meeting at the White House.

UNDERLYING all the volumes in the "Made in -- " series runs the basic theme that understanding of the people of any country comes in part from knowing how they live and what they make. That theme is brilliantly stated in Mrs. Ross' "Made in Mexico" which replaces Susan Smith's charming little book of the same title, now out of print.

SOME 50,000 years ago, giant glaciers of the late Ice Age blocked the flow of the Columbia River at what is known today as Big Bend, the site of Grand Coulee Dam in Eastern Washington. The river, backed up to lake depth, eventually spilled over a surrounding hill and cut a new course through the lava-encrusted plateau.

EVERY once in a while a book is born out of such compelling personal experience that the story of the person becomes the epitome of his people. Damon Orlow's "Red Wedding" is like an operatic drama of pre-Soviet peasantry, filled with the songs that rise out of the hearts of an oppressed people.

Manufacturers of large household appliances, as business men, are losing no sleep over the steel situation. Whatever their concern as Americans over the outcome of the controversy, they regarded the siphoning off of steel supplies last week with indifference.

MEXICO CITY, May 3 -- A call to the Government to outlaw the Mexican Communist party and to sever diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union as a consequence of the bloody May Day street fighting in downtown Mexico City was issued today by the Nationalist party.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Expenditure of $16,989,000 for new industrial plant facilities in the Chicago area were announced during April, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. The April figure, up nearly $6,000,000 from the March total, compared with $37,115,000 in April, 1951, and $36,000,000 in the 1950 period.

Harry Schwartz's "Stalin Trains His Olympic Teams" (April 20) was very interesting and informative. I should not venture to challenge any of his statements of fact, but I once knew a good deal about Soviet athletics, and have kept in touch with them to some extent through the numerous Soviet publications to be found in many libraries: those of Boston University and Harvard are the ones I see oftenest.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- The recent collapse of privately supported plans to stage a second United States International Trade Fair in Chicago this year, it was learned today, was due primarily to wariness by trade experts of foreign governments, lack of enthusiam for the project among midwestern business, industrial and merchandising leaders, and the sponsors' empty coffers.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 3 -- Rutgers University's Bureau of Mineral Research thinks it has the answer to a problem threatening the extinction of a relatively small but important industry in New Jersey -- the manufacture of cinder block for home, store and industrial construction.

IN his memoirs, which cover chiefly his service as German Ambassador in Moscow, Tokyo and London. Herbert von Dirksen reveals an episode which alone makes his book worth reading. He relates -- for the first time, I believe -- how Prime Minister Chamberlain of Great Britain some months after the Munich Conference offered Hitler a far-going pact of appeasement which Joachim Ribbentrop, with his Fuehrer's approval, threw into the waste basket.

DETROIT, May 3 -- In a comprehensive statement of views on vital national and international issues, W. Averell Harriman, Director of the Mutual Security Administration, stressed tonight that the nation's domestic and foreign policies were inseparable.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UP) -- A House subcommittee asserted today it had picked up fresh ammunition for its campaign against military waste from an Army exhibit designed to show how much the Army was saving.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- General Eisenhower took the lead in the Associated Press delegate poll for the first time this week. And the opinion is growing here that he will get the Republican nomination in the first two or three ballots unless some new issue or some great blunder changes the trend.

REGINA, Saskatchewan -- Wheat and wilderness -- that is the prairie province of Saskatchewan, heart of Canada's West. Politically, the Forty-ninth Parallel separates Canada's Saskatchewan from the United States' Montana and North Dakota.

Apparently (to judge by C. B. Palmer's "The Consummately Dry Martini." April 6) the authentic dry martini is as yet unknown in New York The recipe calls for two parts gin to be poured in a glass, after which the pouree dashes outdoors (closing the door firmly behind him), whispers "Vermouth" under his breath, then re-enters to serve the drink.

The Armed Services of the United States have recognized the existence and professional equality of women physicians by granting them commissioned officers' rank and status. Is there any valid reason why men nurses who are as well qualified by experience and education as their female counterparts should not be so recognized, especially since a reputed scarcity of nurses for the services exists?

A page of theatrical history, packed with cherished memories, will be re-examined tonight at the Ziegfeld. At 8 o'clock, "Of Thee I Sing," the first musical to win a Pulitzer Prize, that was in 1932, will be restored to the stage. The opening was deferred from May 1.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Negotiations for ending the steel industry's wage dispute broke down at the White House this afternoon with little hope of an early resumption of the parleys.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 4 (UP) -- Supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower claimed today a "big sweep" over Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in Republican precinct meetings across Texas yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 4 (AP) -- The Most Rev. John F. Dearden, Bishop of the Pittsburgh Roman Catholic diocese, issued new marriage regulations yesterday that permit church marriages of Catholics and non-Catholics.

LOUISVILLE, May 4 -- Ben Jones wore a broad-brimmed hat and a broad grin as he suddenly popped up, jack-in-the-box fashion, in the middle of the track just in front of the winner's circle late yesterday afternoon. As if by magic Mrs. Warren Wright appeared on the infield side of the racing strip for the victory ceremonies. Eddie Arcaro's smile stretched from ear to ear as he jogged back on Hill Gail.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 4 -- If there is a truce in Korea, it may take as many as 500 specialists -- including military observers, secretariat workers and service personnel -- to assist the authorities in bringing permanent peace to the country, a United Nations official said today.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Department of Agriculture has made substantial progress during the past year in putting into effect a program to make bureaucrats live together and like it, something that some officials have maintained could never be done.

SALEM, Ore., May 4 -- With a final fortnight of intensive Presidential primary campaigning opening tomorrow in Oregon, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's managers were haunted tonight with fears based on a paradox.
CHICAGO, May 4 -- The grain futures price trend was irregular last week. There were periods of long liquidation which at times found a thin demand.
CLEVELAND, May 4 -- Winding up his Ohio primary campaign here today, Senator Robert A. Taft suggested that the United States should consider breaking off diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.

Every third person in New York has benefited in some way from the services of one or more participating agencies of the Greater New York Fund. Your friends, the men and women in your company, their families and children, 3,000,000 New York ers each year, instead of knocking on a neighbor's door -- your door -- seek help at the doors of the fund's participating agencies.

BEACONSFIELD, England, May 4 -- The one-acre Lilliputian village of Bekonscot is faced with destruction under the Town Planning Act of 1929 because its houses none of them more than a few feet high, were built without obtaining a license from the town authorities of Beaconsfield.
PORTLAND, Me., May 4 (AP) -- A slight, gray-haired Chinese mother of eight talented children said today her selection as American Mother of 1952 would make no difference in her arduous daily routine.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 4 -The Garden City Library opened its doors here this afternoon, eighty-three years after the founding of the community, the last of the state's incorporated villages of at least 5,500 population to establish library facilities.

The employment of chaplains on a full-time basis at New York State prisons has been a prime factor in the rehabilitation of criminals, the Rev. Dr. Luther K. Hannum Jr. said yesterday. He is resident Protestant Chaplain of Sing Sing Prison.

MIAMI, May 4 -- Former Senator Claude Pepper of Florida, a political stalwart of the New Deal and Fair Deal Administrations, endorsed the candidacy of Senator Estes Kefauver for the Democratic Presidential nomination today and two hours later Rudolph Halley, President of the New York City Council, made a public plea in Miami in the Tennessean's behalf.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -The Council of the Federation of American Scientists recommended today that the United States make "a new and clearer statement" on the question of biological warfare.

ST. LOUIS, May 4 (UP) -- Al Brazle's fine relief pitching earned the Cardinals a 4-3 victory over the Braves today, but two brief displays of power gave the Braves a 5-1 victory in the afterpiece. Brazle's performance enabled Gerry Staley to gain his fifth straight victory.

Seventy thousand lives were saved last year by early detection and treatment of cancer, but 215,000 deaths set a new record in the annual toll taken by the disease in this country, the American Cancer Society reported yesterday.
City officials have begun talks with the owners of private bus lines with a view to sale of the municipal bus lines to the private companies.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- Several periods of trading in which there was heavy long liquidation in various Board of Trade futures pits increased activity on the exchange but total grain and soy bean futures purchases were not quite as large as in the preceding week.

When the first city Traffic Commissioner, Lloyd Reid, resigned in mid-June, 1951, we remarked on this page that "he did some good here, but the pity of it is that we did not give him a freer hand and really let him be the boss on traffic." This was a good example, we added, of the truth that no city Commissioner can travel any faster than the Mayor wants him to go.

Distance may lend enchantment, but in springtime there's enough magic for anyone's soul a scant dozen blocks from Times Square at the border of Central Park. This is especially so in the hush and serenity just before the breaking of dawn.

RED BANK, N. J., May 4 -Matawan's beautiful Lake Lefferts probably will disappear in a few days if someone doesn't manage to get that other floodgate closed. The lake's limpid waters are on their way to Raritan Bay and the fish are traveling with them.
Interest in the foreign exchange market last week revolved around the softness of British sterling, firmness of the Canadian dollar and the strength of the Swiss franc.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 4 -- Debates are raging in the press and in Congress on the best way to exploit Brazil's strategic materials without falling prey to foreign "trusts" or imperialisms.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- At least one of the nine Supreme Court justices has said that the President has "exceedingly great" inherent power to deal with a national emergency growing out of a labor dispute.

MEXICO CITY, May 4 -- New evidence accumulated today indicating that the Mexican Government was testing public opinion to assay the reaction stirred up by a strong official campaign against the country's Communists.

The New York City Department of Commerce and the Commerce and Industry Association of New York have played leading roles in the cooperation of business, labor and Government groups that has enabled the city to maintain its pre-eminence in the nation's business, to prevent business from being lured away, and to attract new business.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., May 4 -- Mr. and Mrs. George H. Bostwick's mare Queen's Flight, ridden by Mrs. Bostwick, scored 14 1/2 points to win the working hunter championship at the Rice Farms spring horse show today. The show was a benefit event for the St. Charles Hospital for Crippled Children.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 4 -Four new story properties were announced yesterday for filming by three studios. Paramount led with two purchases, both of which will go before the cameras as soon as the screen plays are completed.

There has been a rather lively discussion for the last three or four weeks as to whether President Truman, instead of resorting to seizure of the steel plants of the nation, should not have used the emergency sections of the TaftHartley Act for dealing with the situation.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -Archie Wilson and Jackie Jensen, making their debut with the Senators after being obtained in a deal with the Yankees, collected nine hits between them today to pace the Senators to a double-header sweep over the Browns, 2 to 1 and 15 to 7. As a result Washington advanced to third place, ahead of St. Louis, .533-.529.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Monday, May 5 -- West Germany's Social Democrats, opposed to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's rearmament policies in the Federal government at Bonn, rolled up an impressive popular victory in yesterday's local elections in the State of Hesse, final returns showed today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 4 (UP) -- A Negro Presbyterian congregaton with cramped quarters and a white Presbyterian parish, the pioneers of which built a church much too large for the present fifty members, solved their problems today.

President Truman needn't be at liberty after the end of his seven-year-run in Washington; he can have his own TV show. His tour of the White House on Saturday afternoon stamped him as a multiple box-office attraction -- guide, historian, humorist and pianist.

PITTSBURGH, May 4 -- Even if there are no more shutdowns in steel and there is no assurance that that will be the case -- the net steel loss because of two shutdowns in the past three weeks will approach two million tons when all the figures are in.

" Christianity is a religion that cares about what happens to people," the Rev. Dr. Albert J. Penner said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, at Fiftysixth Street.

After Dr. Charles W. Ballard retires as dean of Columbia University's College of Pharmacy on July 1, he will set up one room of a farmhouse in Rennselaer County as a laboratory to conduct certain studies with a microscope for which he never found time in forty years of service at the college.
PORT ARTHUR, Tex., May 4 -- L. A. Darnall, Port Acres business man, set an example for political bosses yesterday.

Some good can yet come out of the "Demon Rum." Once it was the inspiration for a concoction called the Tom Collins Mixer. Something made out of lemon flavor, sugar and carbonated water. Canada Dry, originator of the mix to simplify things for bar-keeps and the home, found that its retail sales on the product rose sharply last summer and showed an even more rapid rate of climb last winter.

GENOA, Italy, May 4 -- Seizing the opportunity offered by the presence at the Milan Trade Fair of thousands of influential businessmen from all parts of Europe, this city has focussed public attention on the serious economic consequences bound to follow if the fierce competition between the ports of the North Sea and the Mediterranean are carried to extremes.

There never was any reason for optimism over the possibility of an Anglo-Egyptian agreement on the Sudan in present circumstances. One need not therefore feel too disappointed that Sir Ralph Stevenson, British Ambassador to Cairo, and Sir Robert Howe, Governor of the Sudan, have returned to their respective posts from London without a settlement in their pockets.

MONTREAL, May 4 -- Five hundred prisoners staged a four-hour riot over food conditions at Bordeaux Jail today. They broke windows, set fires in cellblocks and their chapel and smashed cell furnishings before the rioting ended.

Net profit of Ohio Oil Company and subsidiaries for the quarter ended March 31 last amounted to $10,028,527, equal to $1.53 a common share, according to the report released yesterday. This compares with $9,015,064, or $1.37 a share, a year earlier.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- The Ford Foundation has granted the Young Women's Christian Association $98,500 for an international leadership training project, it was announced tonight at the nineteenth national convention of the women's organization.

The last of two evenings of' music by young composers was presented last night by the League of Composers at the Museum of Modern Art. Marga Richter was represented with a short, abstract, five-movement Quintet for Winds. Russell Smith's contribution was six of the Blake "Songs of Innocence," for soprano and piano.

On the eve of their departmental trial today in Brooklyn Police Headquarters, two of the eighteen policemen accused of accepting graft pay-offs from Harry Gross, the bookmaker, yesterday reported themselves as too ill to take the witness stand.

LONDON, May 4 -- An estimated 20,000 overseas buyers -- including the highest post-war attendance yet of Germans and Japanese -and 100,000 British buyers are expected to visit the annual British Industries Fair, which will open here and in Birmingham tomorrow.

DETROIT, May 4 -- The morale of the United States service man at the front in Korea is "unusually high" and his link with home is a strong element in the preservation of this "wholesome attitude," three officers of the National Jewish Welfare Board reported today.

The Yankees, who have been looking so puny in recent games, took on a robust appearance at the Stadium yesterday. They took two games, 8 -- 0 and 3 -- 1, from the White Sox, rose to .500 in the standings and for the first time this season actually resembled pennant contenders made healthy by fine pitching, flawless fielding and opportune hitting.
CHICAGO, May 4 -- It took the Giants some time today to put the surprising Cubs in their proper place, but when the moment arrived the Polo Grounders made an excellent job of it.

The new Beekman-Downtown Hospital, the first general hospital to be constructed in Manhattan in the last twenty years, should be ready for full occupancy late this fall, Howard S. Cullman, president, said in the thirtieth annual report issued yesterday.

PARIS, May 4 -- For the second consecutive month official statistics have shown a declining tendency for prices. The wholesale price index for April was 146.8 based on 1949 as 100 whereas in March it was 149.3; February, 152 and January, 152.5. The present level is equivalent to that of October, 1951.

The American Friends of Anti-Bolshevist Block of Nations, Inc., which operates through underground movements in Iron Curtain countries, recommended yesterday to the United Nations that Soviet Russia be called upon to free subjugated nations or face expulsion from the organization.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -The Department of Agriculture reported today that farmers grossed $8,700,000,000 from marketing during the first four months of this year, a 3 per cent gain over the corresponding period of last year.

A new literary venture, Discovery, a magazine for current writing in the short form, will make its first appearance next January or February. The announcement was made yesterday by John W. Aldridge and Vance Bourjaily, editors of the magazine, who said that it would contain the best writing by the best writers in this country and abroad, whether established or unknown.

BONN, Germany, May 4 -- The turbulent German political situation has had one good result. The clouds of wishful thinking and reckless optimism have been dispersed and the great unanswered questions about Germany are in the open.

In reassigning of dates to take care of the recent three-game Dodger series washed out in New York, the Giants yesterday revealed that for the first time in the history of the Polo Grounds a night game would follow an afternoon encounter on the same date with separate admissions charged for each game.

CINCINNATI, May 4 -- There is no more monopolistic industry in the United States than the newspaper industry and the amount of money necessary to start a newspaper is itself a restraint, Woodruff Randolph of Indianapolis, president of the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., said here today in an address at a dinner marking the union's 100th anniversary.

PARIS, May 4 -- The Hungarian Government is in trouble with the Cominform's Council for Mutual Economic Aid, known as the Molotov Plan, for inadequate production and falsification of statistics that show output achievements not verified by facts.

A syndicate headed by Joshuah Sidney Shultz, attorney, bought two four-story apartment houses on plot 50 by 100 feet at 226-28 East Seventy-sixth Street from Wallace J. Grove through Harold M. Silverman, broker, for cash over mortgages amounting to $91,000. The houses have a total of thirty-two apartments.
LONDON, May 4 -- Following the steady and considerable recovery in the preceding three weeks the stock markets last week have experienced a distinct pause with reactionary tendencies here and there.

HAIFA, Israel, May 4 -- Abba Khoushy, Mayor of Haifa, has a reputation of being more like an American than any other Israeli in public life. Friends here like to compare him to former Mayor Fiorello LaGuardia of New York because he not only has big ideas but he gets things done.

The latest State Department regulator regarding visits by American citizens to the Soviet Union or the countries it controls sets up a uniform procedure for all, extending provisions formerly applicable only to some. With regard to all these nations citizens of this country must now obtain specific permission from the Department before going to them.

A Christian's way of life on earth should be to "live as strangers and pilgrims, as persons who already have their citizenship, hopes and joys in heaven," the Very Rev. James A. Pike, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, declared in a sermon yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period April 26 to May 2 are given in the appended tabulation:

It seems that where cook books are concerned, everybody wants to get into the act. The latest author to join the ranks is Elsie the Cow. With the assistance of Harry Botsford, food chronicler for Esquire, she has compiled her own "Elsie's Cook Book" (Bond Wheelwright, 374 pp., $3).

LAS CRUCES, N. M., May 4 (UP) -- Lieut. Verne Goodwin, who was sentenced to two years in prison for refusing to fly and then allowed to resign from the Air Force, said today it had taken Washington officials only seven hours to free him once they got "all the facts."

LOUISVILLE, May 4 (AP) -- Now that the Calumet Farm's classy Hill Gail has the Kentucky Derby safely stowed away, the big question in this blue grass country today is whether or not he can become the ninth horse to sweep racing's triple crown.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Eight Republicans in the House of Representatives denounced today the International Materials Conference, which regulates the flow of scarce raw materials in free countries, as a "super-cartel" that was "short-changing" the United States in copper.

In connection with the recent Moscow Economic Conference it has been pointed out that the proposed Soviet purchases in the West would be paid for primarily in timber, grain and coal, and that the Soviet exports of these commodities in recent years have been modest relative to the amounts that would be required if the proposals made at Moscow were carried out in full.
TOKYO, Monday, May 4 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique 1,239, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M., Sunday (5 P. M., Saturday, Eastern daylight time):

I have long been puzzled by the failure of many thoughtful people to sense the importance of choosing a President with a lawyer's training. This is especially true at this time, when Mr. Truman's lack of it is responsible for the mistakes that have demonstrated its importance.

LONDON, May 4 -- The Cunard Steamship Company has contracted for eleven new ships to be built during the next five years, it was announced in the company's report and accounts for 1951, issued here today.

CLEVELAND, May 4 -- Senator Robert A. Taft and Harold E. Stassen sat together here last night and appeared to enjoy a series of sketches in which their candidacies for the Presidency drew satirical fire from a group of the Senator's fellow-Ohioans.

Once more the Police Athletic League, better known as the PAL among the 100,000 New York City boys and girls among whom it works, is asking the people of the city to give generously so that it may expand its program of recreation so necessary for the moral and physical welfare of youth.

With more than forty exhibitions, a busy week is beginning here in the art world. Three large exhibitions will open on Wednesday, including work in all mediums from the permanent collection at the Whitney Museum. The others are recent acquisitions and additions to the art lending service collection at the Museum of Modern Art and the annual "Portraits in Review, 1951-52," at Portraits, Inc.

CAIRO, May 4 -- The Egyptian village is close to being the most insanitary place to live of any civilized part of the world and is far below villages studied in India, China and the West Indies, according to statistics gathered by the Rockefeller Foundation in the course of four and a half years of experimental work in five typical Egyptian villages.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Proponents of a constitutional amendment to limit Federal taxes to 25 per cent on incomes, gifts and estates are inching ahead in their drive for a constitutional convention on the issue.

" Peace in Their Time," by Robert H. Ferrell, a study of the United States and the origins of the Kellogg-Briand pact to outlaw war, will be published on May 21 by Yale University Press. It is based on unpublished transcripts from official files.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -Three newspaper men who turned to politics, Senators A. S. Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma, Blair Moody, Democrat of Michigan, and Fred A. Seaton, Republican of Nebraska, had harsh words today for a Presidential order setting up procedures for keeping some news secret.

The fifty-seven-family apartment house at 1083 Longfellow Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Abraham Langsdorf and E. J. Blomenfeld to 1803 Longfellow Avenue, Inc., Frieda Levinson, president. The property is assessed at $115,000, and title to it was insured by the City Title Insurance Company. Alex Goldman was the broker in the sale.

Christians cannot relax until they become "color-blind" to the differences among men of all races, the Rev. Dr. Theodore A. Gill declared yesterday in a sermon at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.
The housewife, the mechanic and the secretary all had one thing in common -- they liked to paint. At least they liked to try; and that, their instructor had told them, was the important thing.

VIENNA, May 4 -- The Austrian Parliamentary committee, appointed two years ago to investigate the role played in the disbursement of Marshall aid by this country's two great banks and its Chamber of Commerce, criticized today the behavior of New York representatives of all three institutions, and, in the case of the Credit Anstalt Bank, the parent institution itself.
Eight new films, including importations from France, Italy and Israel, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

PITTSBURGH, May 4 -- Carl Erskine spun the first shut-out of his major league career today, putting the Dodgers back on the pennant main line with a 6 -- 0 triumph over the Pirates before 19,522 at Forbes Field.

PARIS, May 4 -- The official index indicates that during April the retail prices of a list of goods commonly in household budgets fell about 1 per cent. This degree of stabilization was attributed partly to a seasonal trend and partly to the actions of merchants eager for the success of Premier Antoine Pinay's effort to stabilize prices and balance the budget to prevent further inflation.

Plans for the erection of six-one-family homes were announced in connection with the purchase by Bronxville Crest Homes, Inc., builders, of a plot 204 by 295 feet at the northwest corner of North Road and Fairview Avenue, Eastchester, in Westchester County.
BONN, Germany, May 4 (AP) -About 50,000 German refugees here from all parts of Germany chanted demands today for a share-the-wealth program at home before West Germany takes part in Western defense.
Visitors to the newly decorated White House who admire "that little red and white print material in the hall outside the West Sitting Room" may duplicate that fabric as well as several other designs.
The Stuttgart Kickers of Germany began their eight-game goodwill tour of this country yesterday by halting the German-American Soccer League All-Stars, 4-3, at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.

Unless Actors Equity Association modifies what has been termed onerous conditions, forty-three members of the Stock Managers Association who do not employ stars will suspend operations in the summer or else engage non-union actors.

Three raging woodland fires and a series of smaller brush fires kept men and equipment on the go yesterday in the metropolitan area. In one blaze near Brentwood, L. I., three firemen were seriously injured, three houses were damaged and twenty-five fire-fighting units from a 200-square-mile sector of the island were summoned to bring the flames under control.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower does not believe it economically feasible to match Russia division for division, hitherto secret Senate testimony showed today.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg disclosed today that the Strategic Air Command would be equipped with elusive new long-range fighter-bombers capable of delivering atomic bombs against key targets deep in an enemy's homeland.

One of the best shows on Broadway last night, for twenty minutes at least, proved to be a smoky fire in a sign on the roof of the Capitol Theatre Building that attracted hundreds of spectators and disrupted traffic.

MADRID, May 4 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco has decided to lodge a protest with the Vatican against what he is understood to regard as persistent and unwarranted criticism of the Spanish Government by Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, Archbishop of Seville.

Yesterday afternoon's concert of Israeli chamber music, presented at the main branch of the New York Public Library, was said to be the first such event of its kind given in this city, and most probably the first in the United States.

Striking oil workers agreed yesterday to an Air Force request to release 10,000 gallons of aviation gasoline for military use from a struck Kansas plant, as commercial airlines around the nation searched for ways of meeting a Government order to cut their fuel use by 30 per cent.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 4 -The French forces in Indo-China are watching for indications that the Vietminh Army may stage one more big attack in Tongking before the summer rains in June reduce campaigning to minor proportions until November.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 4 (AP) -Government leaders renewed efforts today to settle Chile's nine-day-old wage strike of 12,500 copper workers which is costing the country about $176,000 a day in lost income.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -- The Philadelphia Nationals defeated the Scots-Americans in their third-round game of the American Soccer League's Lewis Cup competition, 6 to 5, today and took first place in the standing with 6 points. At the end of the first period, the teams were deadlocked, 3 -- 3.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 4 -- Suffolk County Democrats had a new leader today. He is Adrian Mason, World War II veteran, who was elected last night to succeed Joseph V. Kelly, who had been serving since February by authority of the party executive committee.
The Department of Marine and Aviation is engaged in an indecisive battle with some newfangled launching davits for lifeboats on its three newest ferryboats.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The late Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny of France lifted his countrymen's morale by reminding them of victories under Napoleon, says Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther.

TRENTON, May 4 -- Ch. Bang Away of Sirrah Crest, the boxer owned by Dr. and Mrs. R. C. Harris of Santa Ana, Calif., took best in show in the twenty-third annual event of the Trenton Kennel Club today and established a record.

It has often been felt that one of the most efficient methods of selling a variety of merchandise offered by one organization was through the medium of a catalogue. The customer took his time and made up a large list which was then sent to the company to be filled. Clothing, machinery, jewelry, lumber, seed, fertilizer could all be ordered on the same list to be delivered at a minimum cost to the recipient.

Yes, it's Germany again. Writers and readers have to resign themselves to the hard fact that the German question will remain in the forefront of the news for a long time to come. Today all the "inevitables" inherent in the situation since the defeated Reich was split into two Germanys, each under a regime hostile to the other, are coming to a head at the same time.

If the economists who come after Allen M. Sievers carry his interpretation of the ideas of Karl Polanyi much farther, the future may see instruction in most branches of human knowledge lumped under the single heading of economics.
PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (UP) -The Athletics swept both games of a double-header from Detroit today, 10 -- 6 and 6 -- 5, sending the Tigers deeper into the American League cellar.

LONDON, May 4 -- The United States, British and French Governments are nearing agreement on a carefully drafted joint reply to the Soviet Union, which in notes on March 10 and April 9 called for early "unification" of Germany.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 4 -Israel Mining Industries, Government-controlled company for development of mineral resources of Negeb tonight signed a contract with the Societe Belgo Contenantale des Mines et Metaux under which the Belgians will make their patents and production processes for mining of copper available to the Israelis.

BOGOTA, N. J., May 4 -- Four small children and a man died when fire swept a three-story frame residence here at 5:30 A. M. today. The victims were four children of Mr. and Mrs. John Patton -- Claire, 9 years old, Eileen, 6, and Janet and Joyce, 6-month-old twins -- and Bernard Nelson, a friend of the Pattons from Hoboken.

An objection to the city's proposed condemnation of sites for four Manhattan redevelopment housing projects, to be built by private capital with Federal subsidies and municipal tax concessions, was registered yesterday by a group of ten civic, welfare and labor organizations.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The vote-pulling power of Senator Estes Kefauver will receive a major test Tuesday in Florida's Democratic Presidential primary where the Tennessean is pitted against the favored Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia.

The internal dispute between factions of the port's dock union was resumed for another round yesterday when officials of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., issued a report on union local activities in the Brooklyn area.

Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia and Arturito Pomar of Spain played to a draw in twenty-three moves yesterday and tied for the lead in the invitation chess tournament at Hollywood, Calif., with scores of 4 1/2 -- 1 1/2. Gligoric, with the black pieces, played the king's Indian defense, according to reports from the coast.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 4 -- American risk capital is not waiting for United States recognition of the National Revolutionary Movement Government before heeding President Victor Paz Estenssoro's invitation for private exploitation of Bolivia's underground wealth.

The chances of part or total recovery from the most common mental illness -- schizophrenia -have nearly doubled in the last twenty-five years, it was reported yesterday after one of the most comprehensive studies of mental illness ever conducted.

The Welch Chorale and the University Singers joined the Emanu-El Choir last night in the fourth and final concert of the annual Three Choir Festival of Temple Emanu-El. The event took place in the Temple's Isaac M. Wise Hall.

All faiths and races will participate in and all five of the city's boroughs will benefit from the 1952 campaign, now under way, of the Greater New York Fund, 11 West Forty-second Street, on behalf of a city-wide network of 423 hospitals and health and welfare agencies.

TOKYO, Monday, May 5 -- Hopes for peace in Korea dipped again this morning as the Communist radio, following yesterday's thirteen-minute session of the armistice negotiations at Panmunjom, stepped up its hate barrage.

BOSTON, May 4 (UP) -- The Indians staged a five-run uprising in the seventh inning today to take a 9-6 victory over the Red Sox before 32,571 at Fenway Park. The Tribe moved within two games of the league-leading Bostonians.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 4 -- Builders of the new Puerto Rico are so eager to change the face of their island commonwealth that they are appropriating money for the job faster than they can construct.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Following are the texts of statements by Philip Murray, as head of the Steel Workers Union, and by A. B. Homer, president of Bethlehem Steel, on behalf of the steel industry, following collapse of White House negotiations:

Phillips-Jones Corporation will lower its normal profit margin to create a fast-selling line and insure an early and complete sell-out, it was announced yesterday at the company's fall sales meeting in the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.

CINCINNATI, May 4 (UP) -- Airtight relief pitching by Frank Smith in both games helped the Reds win a double-header from the Phils today, 5 to 4 and 8 to 7, to replace the Chicago Cubs in third place in the National League.

Camp Fire Girls from over the country will give a practical demonstration of their skills today at the Statler Hotel, where 1,200 delegates are attending the national triennial conference. They will build a small fire by rubbing two old mortgages together at a luncheon meeting, with Mayor Impelletteri as a witness.

PITTSBURGH, May 4 -- The collapse of steel peace talks left the rank and file of the United Steelworkers, C. I. O., angry and resentful tonight but apparently willing to obey their leaders' directive to stay on the job.

Closely associated with the sportswear market throughout her designing career, Lorraine Budny feels that this branch of fashion most truly reflects the American touch in the field of design. This country leads the world in sportswear, she asserts.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 4 -- The Israeli Cabinet decided today to move the Foreign Ministry from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem as soon as possible, probably this summer. The Foreign Ministry is the last Government agency to have its main offices in Tel Aviv.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 4 (UP) -- A nervous, repentent gunman, who plans to become a missionary, stood in a Topeka church pulpit today and confessed the details of a bank robbery he committed four years ago. Another suspect in the robbery was promptly arrested for questioning.

With the tall steins on their ledges and the stark sailfish opposite the bar, Luchow's restaurant on East Fourteenth Street opened last night a month-long celebration of its seventieth anniversary with a special Sunday dinner.

Top-hatted veterans, some of whom were in the last three wars, marched along Park and Fifth Avenues yesterday to the applause of thousands of strollers who lined a twenty-eight-block route to view the sixty-third annual memorial service parade of the Association of Ex-members of Squadron A, 101st Armored Cavalry.
NEW DELHI, India, May 4 -- A strong difference of opinion has arisen between India and Pakistan during the last few days over a new issue, while an old dispute between them has sharpened.

FRESNO, Calif., May 4 (AP) -Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias won the $5,000 Fresno women's open golf tournament today with a 54-hole total of 226.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said yesterday that he was supporting W. Averell Harriman, director of the Mutual Security Agency, for the Democratic nomination for President because he believed he was better qualified than any other man in America to carry out the duties of the President today.
PORT HURON, Mich., May 5 (UP) -- A seiche, similar to a small tidal wave at sea, swept the shores of southern Lake Huron today, sending three walls of water over the banks.

Hope that the national oil strike would end in a few days was expressed here yesterday by Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior. His optimism was voiced as commercial airlines in the metropolitan area began to curtail their operating schedules, the armed forces cut their use of motor fuel and the Government extended its control over supplies of major petroleum products to forty-three states.

The Department of Sanitation's clean-up drive got under way yesterday with inspectors issuing 211 summonses to persons found littering streets in Manhattan. At the same time, an educational campaign employing special floats and a public address system went into operation in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $1,300,000,000 of 91-day Treasury bills to be dated May 8 and to mature August 7 were opened to the Federal Reserve banks today.

Prices of all Van Heusen staple shirts will remain at spring levels but some reductions have been made in sports shirts, it was announced yesterday at the fall sales convention of Phillips-Jones Corporation at the Savoy Plaza Hotel.
A record number of foreign students is at colleges and universities in the United States, the Institute of International Education, 1 East Sixty-seventh Street, reported yesterday.

The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation began yesterday to pull a 6,600-foot natural gas pipeline across the Narrows of New York Harbor to provide a second means of entry into this area for natural gas brought here from Texas over the company's 1,840-mile system.

New York is still the "big town." It is not on the way to being a ghost town. On the contrary, figures from various official sources confirm that New York business has been growing, not wasting away. These are the conclusions drawn in two articles written by Russell Porter and published in this newspaper Sunday and Monday.

Art Infants Wear Inc., in a purchase for partial occupancy, has acquired the eight-story business building at 441-447 Pearl Street from David Rapoport. The property, on a plot 100 by 101 feet, is assessed at $325 000. The Charles F. Noyes Company was the broker and the attorneys were Aberman Green for the buyer and Sohn Oklum for the seller.

The appointment of Charles H. Silver, vice president of the American Woolen Company and active in the affairs of Tammany Hall, as a member of the Board of Education to succeed the veteran member James Marshall was accepted as certain last night at City Hall.

President Truman has been criticized for his refusal to employ the national emergency dispute provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act in the steel controversy. Actually, in view of the experience with the law in this connection, there is very little reason to believe that the utilization of the eighty-day injunction feature of the law would have averted a steel strike.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A wage bargain in the steel industry seemed a remote possibility today until the Supreme Court decides the fundamental question of the President's seizure powers.

Charlie McAdam and Sky Ship shared the headlines at Belmont Park yesterday. Each of these colts won a section of the Swift Stakes, the historic seven-furlong test that drew so many 3-year-olds it had to be run in two divisions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 5 -- Prof. V. V. Zakusov, Soviet representative on the United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs, today accused United States forces in Japan and Korea of wholesale debauchery and degrading conduct, including addiction to habit-forming narcotics.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 5 -- The Swedish Army is being re-equipped with modern weapons and the firepower of the field artillery is being considerably increased, according to Lieut. Gen. Carl August Ehrensvaerd, Chief of the Army.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- A regional conference of the National Rehabilitation Association was told here today that "medicine's number one problem" was to teach persons afflicted by chronic diseases to live within the limits of their disabilities but to the full extent of their capacities.
Science has a mouse that isn't really a mouse but a gadget with a "super-memory" that might be envied by mice or men if they ever had to find a piece of "electrical cheese" in a maze.

George M. Humphrey, president of the M. A. Hanna Company twenty-three years, was elected board chairman and chief executive officer of the company at the annual directors' meeting yesterday. Joseph H. Thompson, vice president since 1937, was elected president and chief administrative officer.

TRENTON, May 5 -- A proposal that fathers of motherless children give up their jobs and receive state or Federal doles to stay home and keep house was rejected today by the State Board of Child Welfare.

The management of the R. K. O Palace has announced that the theatre will inaugurate on Saturday a summer policy of first-run films accompanied by eight acts of vaudeville on a contnuous performance schedule. No seats will be reserved and the offerings will be presented on a basis of popular prices.
THE sunny week-end brought out the anglers on both trout streams and salt water but the results were not not had been anticipated, despite some excellent catches in a few areas.

SAN JUAN, P. R., May 5 -- Capt. John C. Burn, pilot of the Pan American Airways transport that crashed at sea off San Juan April 11 with the loss of fifty-two lives, told a Civil Aeronautics Administration inquiry board today he did not know the plane had had engine trouble on a flight from New York the previous day.

The first step in a sweeping legal action to liquidate the bail fund of the Civil Rights Congress of New York, whose carefully concealed list of 5,000 contributors has furnished bail for arrested Communist party leaders, has been taken in Supreme Court by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

The shouts of 15,000 crippled, handicapped, orphaned and underprivileged youngsters echoed in Madison Square Garden between 10 A. M. and noon yesterday when they were treated to a special showing of the circus.

Open season on extra pay for flying in the armed services has rolled around again, and the opponents this year seem to be not less vocal than in the past. As one who has been active in many phases of flying for the past forty years but who has no further personal interest in extra pay for flying, my views may be of interest.

HELENA, Mont., May 5 -- A joint offer by two New York companies, Smith, Barney Co., and Blyth Co., Inc., and associates, to buy $21,701,649 in bonds to finance a state bonus for World War II veterans, was accepted today by the State Board of Examiners.
PITTSBURGH, May 5 -- Home runs again were the answers as the Dodgers made it two straight over the Pirates today, 5 -- 1, in a game halted at the end of eight innings by rain.

An all-male jury is to begin deliberations this afternoon in the first degree murder trial of two men accused of the arson death of a New York detective. The defendants, Abraham (Al) Keshner, textile manufacturer, and Jacob Mayron, truckman's helper, have been on trial before the General Sessions jury and Judge Francis L. Valente since April 21.

Andy McGowan's three-run homer in the ninth inning gave Manhattan a 10-8 Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference victory over C. C. N. Y. at Babe Ruth Field in Macombs Dam Park, the Bronx, yesterday. The triumph was the Jaspers' ninth in twelve games and fifth in seven circuit engagements.
Three teen-aged youths, who had snatched a pocketbook containing $17 from a Columbia University student, escaped last night after policemen had fired nine shots while pursuing them.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Federal Reserve Board abandoned today its voluntary credit-restraint program, already crippled by President Truman's recent insistence that state bond issues be excluded from the anti-inflation regulations.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP) -- Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican of Michigan, demanded today in a shouting, gavel-banging session of the House of Representatives that Representative Edwin A. Hall, Republican of New York, be called to the bar to explain his recent remarks about tipsy Congressmen and atomic secrets.

Plans for acquisition by the New York City Omnibus Company of five deficit-ridden city-owned bus lines in Manhattan moved speedily forward yesterday as Controller Lazarus Joseph and bus company officials advanced arrangements looking toward July 1 as the "target date" deadline for the transfer.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 5 -- Sarah Lawrence College, recently under American Legion attack for retaining some faculty members who were suspected of once having favored causes that Communists also had favored, was called a leader in higher education today by Herman T. Stichman, state housing commissioner. He referred to President Harold Taylor as "great," the faculty "outstanding' and the college a "House of Truth."

William H. (Alfalfa Bill) Murray, former Governor of Oklahoma, presented yesterday to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur in the latter's suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel an anti-Communist plaque. The presentation was in recognition of the general's "courageous and continuous fight against communism."
LONDON, May 5 -- With the exception of British Government securities, which improved modestly where changed, most sections of the stock market here appeared weaker today.

CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -- A new spurt of buying interest from the East forced hog prices 50 cents to $1 higher today. The continuation of last week's steep climb placed the market at its highest level since Oct. 24 at $20 a hundred pounds. Cattle were mostly steady except cows which were strong to 25 cents higher. Sheep also were steady generally. Department of Agriculture reports of the day's trading:

ATHENS, Greece, May 5 -- Admiral Robert B. Carney, Commander in Chief of Allied Forces, Southern Europe, arrived in Athens today and had talks with Acting Premier Sophocles Venizelos, George Mavros, Under Secretary for National Defense; Gen. Theodore Grigoropoulos, the Chief of Staff, and his aides; members of the United States Mission to Greece, and military attaches of all the countries of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization represented in Athens.
The Manchester United football team from England arrived here yesterday for a soccer tour which will take it across the United States and into Canada.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 5 -- Declaring the Opposition planned no coup but would act constitutionally, Hamilton Russell, an Opposition member of Parliament, asked Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan today for "assurance that he is not planning a coup d'etat."
MATAWAN, N. J., May 5 -- Lake Lefferts quietly disappeared today, but it will be back -- the owners of waterfront property hope.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP) -- Manly Fleischmann, Defense Production Administrator, told Congress today that the Government's secret stockpile of strategic materials "unfortunately" was only one-third completed.

During the past few years this newspaper has vigorously applauded the furthering of rehabilitation programs for the handicapped by both governmental and voluntary groups. Impressed as we are with the humanitarian values of restoring disabled persons to lives of productivity and independence, we have been equally impressed by the economic returns which accrue.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Ethel Merman, the stage ambassadress to "Lichtenburg," and an audience sparkling with real-life diplomats and high Government officialdom tonight restored diplomatic relations between Washington's historic National Theatre and the "living" drama.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Truman asked Congress today to provide a $1,500,000,000 self-supporting flood-disaster insurance program. He proposed that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation administer the program, which would insure individuals and corporations against damage by floods like those that have ravaged the Missouri River Valley.

The opening of the annual British Industries Fair in London and Birmingham is a moment for stocktaking on the hopeful side. At these remarkable exhibitions Britain is always able to demonstrate the business "know-how," the skills, the artistic qualities and behind them all the generations of financial experience to prove that John Bull is very far from moribund.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Supreme Court refused today to review $6,000 in libel judgments that a Kentuckian had obtained against a labor union and a newspaper for publishing an advertisement charging him with unfairness toward labor.

NEW DELHI, India, May 5 -- Widespread demonstrations against increased prices of food grains came to a climax in the capital today when a crowd estimated by newspapers at more than 4,000 carried protest banners to the inaugural session of the Delhi state first Legislative Assembly.

George Givot has done all right in show business. As the "Greek ambassador of good will," he has made his way in such tough fields as the Broadway musical theatre, vaudeville, the night clubs, the radio and the movies. Last night at Town Hall he tried to storm another citadel which, it must be sadly confessed, refused to yield.

The stock market proved highly apathetic yesterday to the latest turn of events in the domestic economic field. Prices turned slightly firmer in the late trading after drifting to an easier level in the previous hours. Trading was slow, the turnover dropping to the smallest since Oct. 3, 1949.

The crippled aircraft carrier Wasp was making ten knots along the Long Island coast last night, bringing her crew and the sixty-one survivors of the destroyer-minesweeper Hobson to the joyous reunion with families awaiting them here this morning.
Not the state of the nation's financial health but the state of its emotional health occupied the attention of Wall Street leaders and business men yesterday.

The Army's decision last week to bring court-martial charges against Maj. Gen. Robert W. Grow, until recently military attache to Moscow, condemns the man who made the mistake but not the policies that made the mistake possible.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer came to Washington today at the personal request of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur to assume the chairmanship of a citizens committee backing the presidential candidacy of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

MADRID, May 6 -- Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, Archbishop of Seville, has instructed the clergy of his diocese to desist from informing Roman Catholics of the contents of a "pastoral admonition" that he published April 30 accusing the Spanish Government of having violated the "rights of the Church" in Spain.

Francisco de Miranda, Venezuelan patriot and apostle of South American freedom, is the subject of a biography by Joseph F. Thorning, entitled "Miranda: World Citizen." It is published today by the University of Florida Press. The volume describes Miranda's work, in conjunction with Simon Bolivar, in the cause of independence.

" Replace that divot" may become an obsolete phrase in golf terminology within the next decade because of the development of a new type of grass, Dr. Frank Grau, director of the United States Golf Association's Green Section, indicated yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- America's stand on liberty and democracy is being tested throughout the world by the fate of the Negro in America, Mrs. E. Harris Harbison of Princeton, N. J., a member of the national board of the Young Women's Christian Association, said today.

A general 5 to 10 per cent mill-price reduction in wool, wool-synthetic and synthetic carpets will occur in the next few days, store executives predicted yesterday. This, they said, would be the first since last August.

Lack of adequate services and facilities for children needing care away from their homes 'impair the usefulness of the Children's Court and daily take a toll in terms of happiness, normal development and life of the children of this city," Justice Justine Wise Polier of Domestic Relations Court declared last night.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 5 -- This city suffered a tactical setback in an encounter with the Connecticut Light and Power Company here this afternoon, one phase of a battle for possession of a beautiful and historic strip of waterfront property known as Cove Island.

LONDON, May 5 -- Sir Ivone Kirkpatrick, British High Commissioner in Germany, made a hurried flight to London today at the request of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to discuss urgent problems concerning the part West Germany is to play in the future of Europe.

LONDON, May 5 -- The conference to draft a constitution for a Central African federation ended here today with an agreement on an incomplete plan. It will be published shortly as a White Paper to promote public discussion in the hope of reaching final agreement before the end of the year.
" The Shrike" by Joseph Kramm won the 1952 Pulitzer Prize yesterday for the best original American play, and "The Caine Mutiny" by Herman Wouk was judged the best novel by an American author.

Although the United Nations negotiators in Korea may have serious doubts about the matter, the American steamship traveling public has decided that an armistice agreement will be reached. That is how steamship passenger travel officials interpret the tremendous interest of American tourists this year in overseas trips -- an interest that has accounted for unusually heavy passenger lists since January.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's message to Congress today proposing a national system of flood disaster insurance:

PARIS, May 5 -- Prof. Frederic Joliot-Curie, Nobel Prize-winning French Communist physicist, reiterated today his charges that United Nations forces in Korea had engaged in germ warfare and cited a statement by a United States member of Congress to support the Communist version of the technique employed.

Sales of American Viscose Corporation in the first 1952 quarter dropped 26 per cent and reduced earnings to $4,151,000, or 95 cents a share on the common stock, against $6,330,000, or $1.48, in the corresponding 1951 period, Frank H. Reichel, chairman and president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

EASTVIEW, N. Y., May 5 -- Fifteen years of volunteer work by Mrs. Arthur R. Richtmyer Jr. of 37 Lookout Circle, Larchmont, providing musical therapy for patients in Grasslands Hospital here, was lauded this afternoon at a tea given by the hospital for 120 volunteer workers from all parts of Westchester.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Senate voted, 40 to 33, today to send the $6,900,000,000 Mutual Security authorization bill to the Armed Services Committee for further study instead of acting on the measure as reported from the Foreign Relations Committee.

OTTAWA, May 5 -- Finance Minister Douglas Abbott announced today that he would suspend tomorrow all regulations made under the Consumer Credit Act, but he retained the power to reimpose them if necessary.
BASIN HARBOR, Vt., May 5 (AP) -- The outboard motor boat believed used by three University of Vermont students missing on Lake Champlain since yesterday, was found today on the New York shore.

Wings Shirt Company will enter the boys' wear field this fall with a line of dress shirts, sports shirts and pajamas, it was announced yesterday at the showing of the new line, Wings Boyswear, Inc., the division handling the new items, will present the line to the trade this week.
VIENNA, May 5 -- After two years of urging by Marshall Plan authorities, representatives of management and labor met here today for the first time to launch a productivity campaign in Austria.

HOBOKEN, N. J., May 5 -- Irving S. Olds, chairman of the $3,000,000,000 United States Steel Corporation, declared today that President Truman acted "without much regard for the actual facts" in the seizure four weeks ago of the nation's steel plants.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 5 -- The Eastern States Antiques Fair, which, spring and fall, brings together dealers from New England, New York, Pennsylvania and other points and their huge assembled stock in the Westchester County Center here, opened its thirty-fourth edition today for a six-day run.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 5--Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations today received a message from the Norwegian Storting (Parliament) that it had adopted unanimously a resolution requesting the Government of Norway to consider whether practical ways could be found for expanded Norwegian aid to economically underdeveloped countries.
Operations of the National Steel Corporation in the March quarter this year resulted in net earnings of $8,772,466 after all charges, including $11,600,000 for taxes, the report disclosed yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 5 -- The $1,515,000 chemistry building at Rutgers University was dedicated today in the second event of a week-long celebration to be climaxed Thursday afternoon when Dr. Lewis Webster Jones is inducted as the university's fifteenth president.

ROME, May 5 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived in Rome this afternoon for a good-by visit to Italian authorities before he relinquished command of Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, next month. As he stepped off his four-engine United States Air Force plane he received a cordial reception by a small crowd of Italian and United States officials who had gathered at Ciampino airport to welcome him.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The controversy evoked by the President's seizure of the steel industry has demonstrated one constructive fact at least: that the constitutional guarantees of private rights cannot yet be abridged by any public power in this country without due process.
WASHINGTON, May 5--Presi-I dent Truman, welcoming Clarence Lorenzo Simpson as the new Ambassador of Liberia today, con-[ gratulated the envoy on the "excellent reports on Liberia's economic progress.

Parents who do not care about understanding their daughters may find there are persons in the underworld who will do all they can to make their life attractive to the daughters, Dr. Miriam Van Waters, superintendent of the Reformatory for Women, Framingham, Mass., told nearly 1,200 leaders of the Camp Fire Girls yesterday at the Statler Hotel.

A program to stimulate development of adult driver education in all states is a means of reducing the high motor vehicle death and injury toll was outlined yesterday by Dr. Herbert J. Stack, director of the Center for Safety Education, New York University.

Eighteen plainclothes men accused of taking bribes from Harry Gross, the convicted bookmaker, are to have two separate departmental trials. Trial Commissioner James A. Delehanty yesterday ordered the twin proceedings when the men were arraigned before him at Brooklyn Police Headquarters.

BONN, Germany, May 5 -- Although final returns today confirmed the victory yesterday of the Social Democrats in most of the communal elections in the State of Hesse, analyses of the returns indicated that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's position within the Federal Government coalition might have been considerably strengthened.

A plea to end the impasse between the city and the Port of New York Authority that has blocked construction of a third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel was made yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the bi-state agency.

A new group of upholstered furniture, designed with an eye toward architectural peculiarities in rooms as well as the smallness of contemporary living quarters, is now on view at Abraham Straus. A collection of tables and dining-room furniture that might be used with the upholstered pieces is also on view.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The, United States Emergency Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that retailers and wholesalers were entitled to ceiling price relief under the Capehart amendment to the Defense Production Act.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, refused through counsel to testify today at a pre-trial hearing of the $2,000,000 libel-slander-conspiracy suit filed against him by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

Efficiency and economy must be the watchwords of education, Dr. William F. Russell, president of Teachers College, Columbia University, said yesterday at the opening of the annual regional conference of the Cooperative Program in Education Administration.

CANNY Clark Griffith, an old hoss trader from way back, got the better of his most recent deal with George Weiss, the David Harum of the Yankees. The Washington owner gave up Irv Noren for Jackie Jensen, Archie Wilson and Frank Shea. There were two other pawns in the transaction but they never counted anyway and cancel themselves out.
WHITEVILLE, N. C., May 5 -- A new Columbus County Grand Jury today indicted thirteen alleged members of the Ku Klux Klan on charges that they flogged a Whiteville mechanic last Dec. 8.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Joseph D. Nunan Jr. of New York, former Commissioner of Internal Revenue, declined publicly today to answer any questions about his financial affairs even for the period when he was in Government service.
MONTREAL, May 5 -- Official silence blanketed activities today at Bordeaux Jail despite two disturbances by leaders of yesterday's four-hour outbreak of riot and wreckage.

BALTIMORE, Tuesday, May 6 (AP) -- George P. Mahoney, Maryland's Democratic National Committeeman, appeared early today to have clinched nomination for the United States Senate, as Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee easily won the party's Presidential preference primary.

LOS ANGELES, May 5 -- The only winner in the seventh round of the Hollywood International invitation chess tournament today, Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia, took an undisputed lead with a score of 5 1/2 -- 1 1/2. His opponent was Mrs. Sonja Graf Stevenson, Los Angeles, who, on the black side of a Ruy Lopez, drifted into an unfavorable line and resigned after twenty-five moves.
Mrs. Lytle Hull was named vice president of the New York City Center for Music and Drama and Joseph D. McGoldrick was elected treasurer by the board yesterday.
Sketches of those receiving Pulitzer awards and citations follow:
