Trustees for the Waltham Watch Company reported yesterday that the 100-year-old concern appeared to have turned the corner. For 1951 it had a net profit of $11,728 against a 1950 net loss of $430,035. Last year was the first since 1945 which did not show a large loss.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 5 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is setting in motion plans for a full-scale adventure drama dealing with the white roans settlement in South Africa. "Turning Wheels" is the title for the film, to be adapted from the novel of the same name written by Stuart Cloete and published in 1937.

HAVANA, April 30 (By Airmail) -- Recently five huge trucks rolled through the heavily guarded gates of "la Chata," the country home of the deposed President Carlos Prio Socarras, and packers began crating the personal possessions left behind when the former Chief Executive and his family fled following seizure of the Government by Gen. Fulgencio Batista March 10.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- Grain futures displayed more buying initiative today than for a long time. Liquidation by longs, which has been drastic, appeared to have run its course and the markets were more responsive to buying. May wheat started off with a gain of 3 cents and this sparked advance in other wheat deliveries, also in other grains.

A controversy about the kitchen highlighted the third annual Automatic Gas Range Conference held yesterday at the Pierre Hotel. Arranged by the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association, the day-long sessions had for their theme "Tomorrow with the American Family.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, May 5 -- Here in Central Africa men are trying in earnest now to build a British structure above South Africa in the thin but real fear that one day this structure may become the last rampart for British colonists in all this continent

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley went behind the scenes of the secret councils of the Joint Chiefs of Staff today to disclose that Russia's rising military strength will become a serious threat to the security of this country in 1954.
Reports of sharp price declines in Singapore forced rubber 90 to 127 points lower on the Commodity Echange here yesterday in the most violent action of the day. Volume was 1,010 tons.

The Brazilian Government and the Export-Import Bank were urged yesterday to make known what steps had been taken to alleviate the tightness in the Latin-American nation's dollar exchange payments due exporters in this country. This action was requested in a resolution adopted by the International Trade Section of the New York Board of Trade.

A high school boy who had experienced two bombings in Yugoslavia and had seen the effect of many others in post-war Germany was reassured by a civil-defense official yesterday after he had publicly expressed the fear that the use of school corridors as shelters here would lead to "mass murder" in case of an air attack.

The Laetare Medal, awarded annually by the University of Notre Dame to the outstanding United States Roman Catholic layman, was presented yesterday to Thomas E. Murray, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission.

Directors of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., have elected Dr. Paul D. Merica as president, it was announced by Dr. John F. Thompson, chairman of the board and retiring president, following the annual organization meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 5---Gen. Mark W. Clark departed by air here this afternoon for Tokyo to take command of the United Nations forces in the Far East. He declared upon boarding his plane that he would do everything in his power "to bring about an honorable armistice in Korea."
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Truman today nominated Joseph Coy Green, a career diplomatic official, to be United States Minister to Jordan.
Augusta, Ga., announced yesterday that it would receive bids May 20 on an issue of $3,000,000 water revenue bonds dated June 1, 1952, and due Aug. 1 from 1953 to 1972.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Two of the large railroad systems in the Western area and the Northwestern Pacific Railroad Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve an increase of 10 per cent in their passenger fares, both coach and Pullman.

The world premiere of Leonard Bernstein's opera, "Trouble in Tahiti," a revival of Kurt Weill's "Threepenny Opera" in a new adaptation by Marc Blitzstein; the first American performance of Pierre Schaeffer's "Symphonie pour un hommne seul" and the first choreographed performance of Igor Stravinsky's "Les Noces" will be highlights of the Brandeis University Festival of Creative Arts to be held on the University's campus in Waltham, Mass., June 12 through June 15.

Hasis (or Harvey) Bistany, long-time burglar, plug-ugly and friend of William Sutton, was being questioned last night in Providence, R. I., by New York authorities as a "prime suspect" in the murder of Arnold Schuster, whose tip led to the bank robber's capture.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 5 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors today paved the way for proceedings to condemn a 1,000-foot row of thirty-five trees that reportedly constitute a hazard to air traffic at the Westchester County Airport in Purchase.

PARIS, May 5 -- Contending that the French had been left "too much alone" in Indo-China, John Foster Dulles, former adviser to the United States Secretary of State, suggested today that the best defense of that area and other parts of Asia would be a threat of retaliatory action against Communist China or the Soviet Union.

In the broader fields this year's Pulitzer Prizes announced yesterday are not especially surprising. The awards in drama and in fiction followed a popular recognition already bestowed. The history and biography awards had not been perhaps so clearly indicated, and no one can ever say with certainty what were the best poems or what was the best piece of music published or produced during a given year.

PARIS, May 5 -- Designing on youthful bouffant lines that delight the eye by exquisite coloring and fabric, De Givenchy devotes his midsummer collection mainly to evening gowns for the Festival of Twentieth Century Music now opening in Paris.

JERUSALEM, May 5 -- The Government introduced in the Knesset (Parliament) today a bill to give the Jewish Agency for Palestine special status as the principal agency of Jews abroad authorized to work in Israel.

KALIMPONG, India, May 5 -- Following an armed clash last week between Chinese Communist troops and Tibetans in Lhasa, Chinese guards now are patroling the streets of the Tibetan capital, according to reports reaching Kalimpong.

Negotiations are under way for a merger of Foremost Dairies, Inc., of Jacksonville, Fla., with the ACF-Brill Motors Company, Philadelphia manufacturer of motor coaches, buses and internal combustion engines.

A price slash of about 17 1/2 cents a wine gallon on industrial alcohol was made yesterday as a result of a 6imilar price cut made last Friday by Carbide and Carbon Chemical Company. Shifts in supply, demand and distribution were given as basic causes for the drastic cuts.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Clovis D. Walker, under Congressional fire for allegedly giving United States trade secrets to an Egyptian broker, resigned today as director of the Agriculture Department's Cotton Branch.

The money market became tighter in April than had been expected following a protracted period of ease in the last half of March, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York points out in its monthly review of credit and business conditions, isssued for publication today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 5 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, new commander of United Nations forces in Korea, pledged himself today to do everything in his power to bring about an "honorable armistice followed by honorable peace" and five hours later took off on the trip to Tokyo.

Nothing much having changed since 1931, "Of Thee I Sing" is still a hilarious and pertinent musical burlesque. In 1931 George S. Kaufman and Morrie Ryskind appeared to be applying the bastinado to the Republican party; and everyone, including the Pulitzer trustees, was very happy.

PARIS, May 5 -- Eleven European nations, each unable to support alone the staggering costs of a full scale atomic research program, met in Paris today to plan a joint venture that will provide them with one of the most powerful "cosmotrons" in existence for their common use.

Sugar Ray Robinson, middleweight champion of the world, asked 200 members of the business world yesterday to help turn "the wonderful dream" of the St. Charles School and Community Center into a reality.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 5 -- Without dissent, the United Nations' Human Rights Commission voted today to include an article in a future international pact that would recognize the right of all persons to work, and the responsibility of all governments to promote employment.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 5 -- Bolivian authorities yesterday arrested a United States citizen on charges of being involved in the assassination of a National Revolutionary Movement leader a year ago, according to reports received from Santa Cruz today.

Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, told the Western Union Telegraph Company last night that he expected its wage negotiators to attend a meeting in Washington tomorrow with the company's striking employes.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 5 -- Primary campaigns in behalf of Gov. Earl Warren of California and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, aimed at winning for them Oregon's eighteen votes at the Republican National Convention. got under way officially today.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., May 5 -- The vice president of the First Bank and Trust Company, a man prominent in civic affairs and highly trusted by his employers, was arrested here tonight on a charge of embezzling $400,000 of the bank's funds.

Harold L. Stuart, former banker for the Insull interests and subsequent leader in the trade campaign for compulsory sealed public bidding for bond issues, testified in Federal court yesterday as to why he did not try to get an underwriting participation in the Illinois Bell Telephone Company financing of 1935 from Morgan Stanley Co., underwriting manager.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 5 -- A fundamental mechanism that protects the brain's supply of sugar, the only fuel it can use for energy, was described here today. A report on the mechanism was presented at the annual meeting of the American Society for Clinical Investigation by Dr. Lillian Recant of the Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis.

The Living Theatre, Inc., last evening presented a concert of new music at the Cherry Lane Theatre. The program included works by John Cage, Henry Cowell, Alan Hovhaness, Lucille Dlugoszewski and Lou Harrison. Except for the works of Mr. Cage, all the pieces on the program were first performances.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., the city's largest union, announced last night that it was throwing all its resources into a campaign to eliminate "open-shop gangsterism" from the New York dress industry.

A combined showing of boys' apparel lines at the New Yorker Hotel has drawn over 2,000 buyers on the first two days, it was announced yesterday by Leon M. Singer, executive secretary of the Boys Apparel and Accessories Manufacturers Association, sponsors of the event.

CLEVELAND, May 5 -- Fair, warm weather was forecast for tomorrow as Ohio voters prepared to choose fifty-six Republican and sixty-two Democratic delegates to the national conventions in a direct primary election.
LONDON, May 5 -- Queen Elizabeth II took up her residence in Buckingham Palace today for the first time since her accession.

Bloodmobiles in the Red Cross donation program made collections yesterday at the Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue; the Farrand Optical Company, Bronx Boulevard and East 238th Street, and the Downtown Athletic Club, 18 West Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., May 5 -- The Methodist Federation for Social Action was formally requested here today by the Quadrennial General Conference of the church to drop the word "Methodist" from its name and to vacate its headquarters at the church's Fifth Avenue office building in New York.

BONN, Germany, May 5 -- The State Department's suggestion that the three Allied High Commissioners confer in Berlin with Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, Soviet Commander in Chief in Germany, on steps toward all-German elections and unity, has frightened the Federal Government.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 5 -- A search for an escaped four-and-a-half foot rat snake on the campus of Adelphi College went on here today with the school's 900 co-eds and a number of the male students reportedly getting more nervous by the hour.

Interest centers on the shades rather than the bases of a new and ingenious collection of lamps designed by George Nelson, made by the Howard Miller Company and introduced here this week by B. Altman and New Design, 33 East Seventy-fifth Street.
Another plea has been issued by the Better Business Bureau of New York City for newspapers and radio and television stations to refuse reupholstery "bait" ads.

MIAMI, May 5 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, whose candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination has the support of virtually all the leaders of the South's dissident Democrats, said tonight on the eve of the Florida primary that he would not leave the party in a fight over the civil rights issue.

Sugar Ray Robinson, as unpredictable as the weather, yesterday agreed to a match he had been ignoring for a year and had flatly refused only two weeks ago. He decided to fight for the light-heavyweight championship of the world, currently in the possession of Cleveland's Joey Maxim.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday 4 to 37 points net higher than on Friday, with the most pronounced strength in the old May and July positions.

Louis F. Budenz began his second week of testimony in Federal Court here yesterday in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders, charged with conspiring to advocate and teach the overthrow of the Government of the United States by force and violence.
CHICAGO, May 5 (UP) -- Chicago racing fans resigned themselves to a second day of shutdown at Sportsman's Park tonight as "striking" horse owners refused to make entries at the half-mile track.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP) -- A leading atomic scientist said today that this country's nuclear progress had been slowed because officials in charge of the program were "overly cautious" and afraid to risk research failures.

GREAT NECK, L. I., May 5 -- A field of ninety-eight teams took part in the season's first Long Island pro-amateur tournament of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association today at the Fresh Meadow Country Club. However, less than a fourth returned cards, attesting to the difficulty of the 6,700-yard course that had been lengthened since last year.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP) -- Three ex-Yankees. Spec Shea, Archie Wilson and Jackie Jensen, pitched and batted the Senators to a 13-to-1 conquest of the Browns tonight. Ned Garver, St. Louis' twenty-game winner last year, was blasted from the box for the third straight time.

BOSTON, May 5 (UP) -- Bob Avila, belting his first home run of the season, started a three-run assault in the tenth inning today as the Indians beat the Red Sox, 4 -- 2, to sweep a two-game series before 8,523 Fenway Park fans.

GREENVILLE, Del., May --I Benjamin M. May. retired general! manager of the rayon departmentI of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., was found dead today in the garage of his home near here. The state police said he apparent-I ]y had shot hhnself in the chest] -ith a shotgun that was foundI near his body. His age was 67.

The annual luncheon and fashion show arranged by officers and managers of the New York Women's Bible Society will be held on Thursday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre for the benefit of the organization. Miss Margery P. Stoddard is chairman of the benefit committee, and among her aides is Mrs. Joseph W. Dorland.
I read with keen interest the article "Europeans See a Paradox in U. S. Trade Restrictions" by Michael L. Hoffman, published April 27.
CINCINNATI, May 5 (AP) -- Umpire Scotty Robb, who was fined for pushing Manager Eddie Stanky of the St. Louis Cardinals during a game here on April 22, resigned today.

The Government cut of 30 per cent in civilian aviation-gas consumption and the intensifying shortage of gasoline in Midwest areas focuses attention on the strike of 90,000 gas and oil workers which began on April 30. California, whose refineries produce most of the vital aviation oil required for Korea, has been exempted from the stoppage up to now and the walkout affects New York only to a slight degree so far.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Seven witnesses told Congress today that both Newbold Morris and J. Howard McGrath, former Attorney General, knew that Mr. Morris connection with surplus oil tanker deals was being looked into by the Justice Department before he was appointed a special Assistant Attorney General to clean up corruption in the Government.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 6 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique 1.240, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M.. Monday (5 P. M., Sunday, Eastern daylight time):

A showing of fashions in various shades of the tawny tone of the liqueur Benedictine was presented last night at the Paris Theatre by Julius Wile Sons Co., importers. The showing provided preview glimpses of winter fashions as well as day and evening summer designs.

The Wisconsin Electric Power Company borrowed $12,500,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of first mortgage bonds due in 1982. The obligations were sold at competitive bidding to a syndicate headed by Glore, Forgan Co. and associates at a bid of 101.1599 for interest of 3 1/4 per cent.

GENEVA, May 5 -- The Fifth World Health Assembly opened here today in an atmosphere of quiet enthusiasm for the progress that has been made in a short time by an international attack on disease, dirt and premature death afflicting hundreds of millions of people in many parts of the world.

Underwriting syndicates headed by Blair, Rollins Co., will make public offering today of $8,000,000 of debentures and preferred stock of Southern Union Gas Company concurrent with the company's offer, without underwriting, of 166,706 shares of new common stock to the company's stockholders.

As the Western Powers consult in London on their reply to the latest Soviet note on Germany events continue to move in a direction indicating that the struggle for that country, on which depend both the unification of Europe and the whole Western defense plan, is entering into a critical phase.

The enforcement division of the regional Wage Stabilization Board scored yesterday its first victory in its action against thirteen local ship-repair concerns accused of having raised wages illegally and of having made false statements to the board.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 6 -- As the armistice negotiations at Panmunjom continued in a deadlock today. Gen. James A. Van Fleet. Eighth Army Commander, accused the Communists of not wanting a cease-fire in Korea.

A Broadway prospect for early next season is a dramatization of a short story entitled "Maria Concepcion," by Katherine Anne Porter, considered one of the foremost stylists among contemporary American writers.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., May 5 -- The Westchester P. G. A. inaugurated the area's tournament season with pro-amateur best-ball play at the Leewood Golf Club today. Sixty-six teams formed the field, and three at 65 shared top laurels, requiring a match of cards to determine prize winners.

Representatives of 71,000 General Electric workers broke off negotiations with the company yesterday and called an "emergency meeting" of their conference committee for May 14 to consider a strike. The meeting will be held at the Belmont Plaza Hotel in this city.

BONN, Germany, May 5 -- Expressing his lack of enthusiasm in complying with a request by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, Dr. Theodor Heuss, West German President, accepted today the third stanza of the Deutschlandlied as the official anthem of West Germany.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- The Polo Grounds Express was still moving through the West at top speed today as Leo Durocher's Giants, though held to four hits by southpaw Paul Minner, rolled back the Cubs, 3 to 2, on two healthy shots. A Wes Westrum home run accounted for the first two New York runs, a triple by Bobby Thomson drove in the third.

LONDON, May 5 -- Despite four days of conversations here between Admiral William M. Fechteler, United States Chief of Naval Operations, and British defense officials headed by Field Marshal Viscount Alexander, Minister of Defense, the United States and Britain were reported tonight still deadlocked over the question of the Allied naval command in the Mediterranean.
Johnny Cesario, 148 pounds, of Hartford, Conn., outpointed Carmine Fiore, 145, of Brooklyn, in an eight-round bout at St. Nicholas arena last night.
SAN JUAN, P. R., May 5 -- Puerto Rico, once a land of disease and early death, is healthier today than ever before.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 5 -- "Hitler and Mussolini did the same thing in Germany and Italy as Truman has done in the United States," Thomas E. Millsop, president of Weirton Steel Company, told the Coal Convention of the American Mining Congress here today, while discussing President Truman's recent seizure of steel mills.

Unfair attacks on the public schools may lead to their destruction and the consequent loss of the freedoms associated with the American heritage, Rabbi Judah Goldin, dean of the Teachers Institute of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, declared yesterday.

PARIS, May 3 -- The Soviet Union appears to be making a concerted effort to accelerate production of the key raw materials required for the manufacture of atomic weapons by stepping up the output of Czechoslovakia's uranium mines through extensive use of forced labor.

Robert Geis, bass-baritone, appeared in recital at Town Hall last evening. A native of Indiana, he received his training at the Juilliard School, where he studied for five years with the late Anna Maria Schoen-Renee.

Now it is May, and a good time for the poets. It is a month when some of them are garlanding their verses with the flowers and ferns of the spring, while others, with imagination following more practical lines, are glancing ahead for matter suitable for June publication, with payment in July.
New leaders took over in all three districts as the second week of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches were concluded yesterday.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 6 -- Talk of "inherent powers" of a President should put the American people on guard these days, Gov. Earl Warren of California cautioned here today as he campaigned for Oregon's eighteen delegates to the Republican National Convention.

THERE was an undercurrent of uneasiness and expectancy in the hotel headquarters of the Cleveland Indians yesterday. It was almost as though the Tribe couldn't wait for that second shoe to fall. General Manager Hank Greenberg and Manager Al Lopez had been in constant conference in Boston and they disappeared soon after reaching New York.

Events tonight: "Acres of Sky," opera by Arthur Kreutz, first New York performance, Brander Matthews Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30 o'clock; Kathie Reid, soprano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Third Street Music School Settlement Concert, 8:30; Cantata Singers, Church of the Heavenly Rest, 8:30; Chamber Music Program, Mannes Music School, 8:30; Diana Denise, soprano, and Victor Powell, organist, Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, 8:30; Maria Rey, pianist, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30.

TRENTON, May 6 -- New Jersey Democratic leaders, in a tentative draft of their 1952 campaign platform, charged the state Republican administration today with falling to clean up crime and corruption in Atlantic and Bergen Counties.
The State of New York borrowed $62,720,000 in the public market yesterday on housing bonds maturing serially from 1954 to 2002 at an interest cost of 1.8278 per cent.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- A dispatch from the Far East Command of the Army to headquarters here says that "ammunition is plentiful," but is rationed "to save money and maintain ammunition reserve."

Dr. Jules H. Manes' letter regarding compulsory automobile insurance say: that this is the only safeguard for the innocent driver, passenger or pedestrian. And that "the vital problem remains the protection of life and limb."

James W. Carpenter, president of the Long Island Association, announced yesterday the appointment of a Long Island Rail Road reorganization committee. It will study operation of the road under a trusteeship and the plans of the Long Island Transit Authority.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6 -- An associate dean of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology was charged today in East Cambridge District Court with "disturbing the peace" when he arrived to plead for leniency for seventeen students facing similar charges.

Fourteen Red Cross chapters in six upstate counties have joined the Regional Blood Program and will be visited by bloodmobile units from the city, Dr. William M. Markel, director and administrator of the program, announced yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, May 6 -- Judge George A. Welsh ruled in United States District Court here today that the Federal law requiring gamblers to buy a $50 tax stamp was unconstitutional.
Horace Mann School scored 48 points to win the third annual Van Cortlandt pentagonal track and field championships held Monday and yesterday at the Van Cortlandt Park Stadium.

Henderson Supplee Jr., executive vice president, was elected president of the Atlantic Refining Company by the board of directors following the annual stockholders' meeting yesterday in Philadelphia. The stockholders approved a split of two-and-a-half for one in the common stock, after which the directors voted to increase the dividend rate.

The Indians, who bagged only one victory in eleven tries here last year, made off with a highly encouraging bit of plunder last night in their first 1952 raid on the stronghold of the world champion Yankees.
DALLAS, Tex., May 6 (UP) -- Eisenhower Republicans and anti-Administration Democrats apparently won control of a majority of county political conventions in Texas today.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- Choppy markets were the rule on the Board of Trade today, with weather developments now being closely watched for a clue to future price developments. Western Canada had rain relief in parts of Alberta and Saskatchewan, but dust storms were reported in Manitoba and large sections of Saskatchewan and Alberta have had no rain. Increasing anxiety now prevails in regard to the American Northwest, where there was little rain.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, declared today that the big grain warehousing firm Cargill, Inc., had charged the Government $37,000 for work it never had done.

ALBANY, May 6 -- An upstate delegate to the Democratic National Convention broke with his leaders today and announced endorsement of Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee for the Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Protesting witnesses opposed a proposal today that American Power and Light Company directors name the first board of directors for Washington Water Power Company. Joining in the opposition were minority stockholders and Idaho and Washington state and community representatives.

PARIS, May 6 -- Paintings from United States collections by European artists, which have been little seen in Europe but are well known by reputation and by reproduction, formed the basis for the exhibition opened here today in the Museum of Modern Art as part of the festival of "Twentieth Century Masterpieces."

SCARSDALE, N. Y., May 6 -- Fifteen hundred Scarsdale residents, at a meeting that set a record for such annual gatherings and overflowed from the gymnasium to other rooms in the high school here, strongly supported its Board of Education in a three-year-old controversy over charges of Communist infiltration into the local school system.
Students of the Fashion Academy, 812 Fifth Avenue, modeled yesterday clothing they had designed and made from Brand Oppenheimer fabrics. The style show was held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

In the course of his farewell tour of the North Atlantic Treaty nations General Eisenhower has issued in Rome a series of statements which summarize some of the fundamental convictions he has acquired as Supreme Allied Commander, and which might be regarded as the gist of his farewell message to Europe. That message is, in effect: Unite or perish.

TUNIS, Tunisia, May 6 (AP) -- In a surprise move, the French released former Premier Mohammed Chenik and three of his nationalist Ministers from house arrest today. Observers linked the action with the current visit here of the head of the United States State Department's Middle East division.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J. May 6 (AP) -- United States Attorney Grover C. Richman asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation today to aid Perth Amboy officials in their investigation of the $400,000 embezzlement charged to William C. Horley, vice president of the First Bank and Trust Company.

ST. LOUIS, May 6 -- Eddie Stanky's first passage at arms with his former team-mates resulted in a triumph for the new Cardinal skipper tonight as the Redbirds sent the Giants sprawling, 9 -- 4, in the opener of a three-game series.

The flowers of the province of Dalecarlia in Sweden will bloom in New York for the next ten days on fabrics and ceramics in an exhibit that opens today at Bonniers. The designs have been created by members of the Jobs family, who live in Leksand in Dalecarlia.

Realizing that a revival must be kneaded with super quality these days to recapture its original glory, Blevins Davis and Robert Breen are doing everything within their power to surpass former presentations of "Porgy and Bess." How well they have succeeded should be apparent when the famous Negro folk musical opens on Sept. 3 at the Metropolitan Opera House for a limited run through Oct. 12.

As one of his last acts before leaving the Board of Education after seventeen years of service to it, James Marshall, senior member from Manhattan, announced yesterday a staff relations plan to improve the working conditions of the board's 5,100 civil service employes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6 -- The United Nations Postal Administration released today a photograph of the design selected for the first United Nations commemorative stamp. The five-cent blue design will be issued in honor of the signing of the United Nations Charter in San Francisco in 1945 and will be released on United Nations Day, October 24.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 6 -- A brief flare-up over civil rights proposals occurred tonight as New Jersey delegates to the Democratic National Convention met here with five potential candidates for President or their representatives and then decided to defer making any choice among them for another month at least.

Senora Rosa de Gonzalez Videla, wife of President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla of Chile, arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday from Santiago to receive the first world award of the American Mothers Committee at a luncheon Friday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 6 -- City College and Hofstra split a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference double-header today. The Flying Dutchmen won the opener, 4 -- 1, scoring twice in the third inning without a hit. City took the nightcap, 4 -- 0, as Neal Deoul held Hofstra to four hits.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 6 -- The Knesset (Parliament) tonight adopted a resolution calling upon the Israeli Government not to resume talks with the West German Government for reparations "until a clear and binding offer is received from the Bonn Government concerning the amounts and the schedule of payments." The vote was 50 to 340.

A defense contention that thirteen local ship-repair concerns had an agreement to increase their pay rates before the Government's wage freeze order of Jan. 25, 1951, remained unshaken yesterday after almost five hours of questioning.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -The Government has approved more than $1,000,000,000 worth of new electric power projects in the last five weeks in an effort to end power shortages, a review showed today.
TOKYO, May 6 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,241, for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Tuesday (5 P. M. Monday, Eastern daylight time):
PITTSBURGH, May 6 (AP) -- Robin Roberts hurled a two hitter tonight as the Phillies snapped a four game losing streak in beating the last place Pirates, 6 -- 0.
There was a wordless moment in the lounge of the Naval Receiving Station in Brooklyn yesterday when the first survivors of the Hobson arrived to meet their families.

Individuality, a quality encouraged in American design today, distinguished household objects as well as clothing in Early America, judging from a collection of pictures now on view at Altman's. The paintings, part of the group that makes up the Index of American Design, were lent by the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

Britain's highest judicial authority, the Privy Council, will have an opportunity in the near future to rectify some highly unfortunate decisions made in the courts of Hong Kong. The Supreme Court of the colony has authorized an appeal by Maj. Gen. Claire Chennault from its orders transferring title to some forty planes owned by him to the Chinese Communists.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 -- A major revision of the social creed of the Methodist Church was approved overwhelmingly here today at the closing business session of the denomination's Quadrennial General Conference.
Evidence that many enterprising persons do not believe a depression is due soon can be gleaned from a survey of new business incorporations by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

A device to save as much as 1,000,000 tons a year of cast iron in this country was described yesterday by Arthur Croft, a British engineer who is one of its inventors, in an interview at the Biltmore Hotel. Mr. Croft is chairman and managing director of Crofts (Engineers), Ltd., Bradford, Yorkshire, England.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Officials of the Office of Price Stabilization looked today to the United States Supreme Court to upset a lower court decision which they said would "make a mess" of the agency's retail price regulations.

" Lights Out," the N. B. C. program that has the unenviable assignment of trying to compete with Lucille Ball, fell on its supernatural this week (9 P. M. Monday). It tried to put mind over matter and found itself only holding a jar of chlorophyll tablets.

TAIPEI, Formosa, May 6 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek declared in an interview here today that the Chinese Nationalist Government would recognize the Communist redistribution of land in the mainland of China under the principle of "land to the tiller."

LONDON, May 6 -- With their collective eye on the woman shopper, British manufacturers are exhibiting an unusually large collection of home furnishings, time, labor and fatigue-saving office equipment as well as jewelry and consumer goods at the British Industries Fair.
Abraham Keshner, the garment manufacturer who paid for the arson scheme that caused three, deaths in a five-alarm fire on Eighteenth Street last fall, was convicted yesterday of first-degree murder.

BELGRADE Yugoslavia, May 6 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, announced today that an office of President of the Yugoslav Republic, endowed with wide executive powers, would be created under the proposed constitutional reform, one of the aims of which is to eliminate the last vestiges of dualism in the executive branch of the Government.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- One of the questions on which General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will be expected to recite when he gets home next month is that old Republican bugaboo: what are you going to do about the tariff?

Greater emphasis on the importance of having private business participation in Point Four assistance program for underdeveloped countries was urged yesterday at a meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York in the Roosevelt Hotel. A panel of five executives in the international selling field addressed the meeting, which was held in collaboration with the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

Syndicate managers bidding on new issues of corporate and local government bonds worked with sharp pencils yesterday. The sharpest pricing of the day was in the sale of Philadelphia's $7,700,000 of refunding bonds where the bid of a National City Bank syndicate won out by 55/1000 of 1 per cent.
LONDON, May 6 -- Strength of British Government securities provided the main feature of the stock markets today. Prices rose steadily and closed at their best, up to ten shillings ($1.40) higher.

The new American Ambassador to Italy, Ellsworth Bunker, who presents his credentials to the Rome Government today, is a newcomer on the European scene and in the diplomatic service. He is a notable exception to a rule President Truman seems to have adopted as his Administration draws to a close.
The New York State Federation of Music Clubs will hold a three-day convention at the Henry Hudson Hotel beginning tomorrow, with Mrs. A. Stuart Carpenter of Salamanca, presiding.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted a $1,010,900,000 cut today in President Truman's $7,900,000,000 foreign aid bill, directing that the full amount of the reduction be made in military assistance and defense support for Europe.

Failure of one of the two engines of the freight transport plane of U. S. Airlines that on April 5 plunged into Jamaica, Queens, killing its crew of two and three persons on the ground may have caused the crash, it was indicated yesterday as the Civil Aeronautics Board opened its hearing into the accident.

OTTAWA, May 6 -- To give additional incentive to the search for radioactive ores the Canadian Government-owned Eldorado Mining and Refining Company will purchase uranium in ores and concentrates at a minimum price up to March 31, 1962, it was announced today.

PARIS, May 6 -- What must have been one of the most brilliant occasions that the Paris Opera, the scene of many a brilliant occasion, has witnessed in this century was the first appearance in Europe of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, with Charles Munch conducting, which took place in that famous theatre this evening.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6 -- On its twentieth vote during today's meeting, the United Nations Commission on Human Rights adopted an article covering conditions of work for inclusion as an article in the covenant on economic and social rights it is drafting.
The Chamber of Commerce of the United States, in its annual meeting last week, went on record as favoring the idea of a constitutional amendment limiting the taxing power of Congress.

CLEVELAND, Wednesday, May 7 -- A heavy Ohio primary vote was indicated last night as Senator Robert A. Taft, who hopes to sweep all fifty-six Republican delegates to the national convention, took commanding lead over Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, in early returns.

The development of contemporary Danish design in silver over almost half a century can be traced in an exhibit now on view at Georg Jensen. "Nine Modern Artists in the Jensen Silver Tradition" is the title of the show, and the pieces included in it date from 1904 to 1952.

BONN, Germany, May 6 -- The general treaty between West Germany and the United States, Britain and France, which forms the basis for the political position of the West German Republic in the future, aims at the creation of a "free and united Germany" and a peace settlement between this country and its former enemies that is to be the basis of a permanent peace.

In symphony orchestras percussion men often have little to do except keep endless track of their colleagues to come in on time for a few entrances. But last night at the Museum of Modern Art three percussionists and a tympanist came into their own. They were the star performers at a percussion concert presented by the museum's Junior Council.
In Western Europe Eisenhower is building a European army for defense against the fanatic Bolshevik threat. Here we are in the midst of a vast program.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- The House of Representatives voted today to overturn the court-martial conviction of a young officer who, according to the Navy, was made the "scapegoat" for the blunder of a famed naval hero in the War of 1812.
The automobile market is passing out of a period of "pull" into a phase of "push" selling, Harry J. Klingler, vice president of the General Motors Corporation, said last night.

This is not the time to relax Regulation W and other credit restrictions imposed by the Government, Dr. Sumner H. Slichter, Harvard economist, warned last night. Defense expenditures are on the upgrade, he asserted, but a year hence they will be leveling off and at that time credit relaxation would be in order.

ALBUQUERQUE, May 6 (AP) -- Patrick J. Hurley, seeking the Republican party's nomination for his third try at the United States Senate, moved into the lead tonight in a three-cornered fight for the nomination on early scattered returns from the New Mexico primary election.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -Arizona asked the Federal District Court today to rule that it had the right to bar Indians on reservations from a state public welfare program.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 6 (AP) -- Four delegate candidates favoring Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia took an early lead tonight in Alabama districts as this state selected an unpledged delegation to the Democratic National Convention.

With a shocking display of contempt for public opinion Mayor Impellitteri has dropped James Marshall from the Board of Education and replaced him with Charles H. Silver, Tammany Democrat and a generous donor to party campaign funds. The Mayor has scorned advice and appeal from civic bodies that he reappoint Mr. Marshall.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- William McArthur, an Agriculture Department official, said today that some of the wheat this country had exchanged for long-staple cotton from Egypt had been diverted into the world market by Egyptian traders at big potential profits.

Questioning since Monday night has failed to elicit an admission from Hasis (Harvey) Bistany that he was in Brooklyn on March 8 when Arnold Schuster was shot and killed. The young clothing salesman was slain three weeks after his recognition of Willie Sutton in a subway train had brought about the bank robber's capture.

Suzanne Gosse and Alex Manson took off a couple of hours the other morning to talk about a favorite subject, the Maison Glass. The fiftieth birthday of that delicacy shop at 15 East Forty-seventh Street was the reason for reminiscing.

It took two deck officers of the sunken destroyer - minesweeper Hobson to reveal yesterday that two enlisted men sounded alarms on their own so that their buddies -- many sleeping in bunks below -- might try to escape from the fatal crash with the carrier Wasp, twenty times the Hobson's size.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- The Ford Motor Company attacked the Government's controls program today as "unfair" and urged a change.

Leaders of the planned parenthood movement in New York state heard a prediction yesterday of a possible major change in the attitude of the Roman Catholic Church, historic foe of contraceptive birth control.

The carrier Wasp stood in from the open sea in a gray dawn yesterday and was moored in Gravesend Bay off Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn. She brought home sixty-one survivors and two dead men from the crew of the destroyer - minesweeper Hobson, which sank in a collision with the Wasp on April 26 during night maneuvers, 725 miles northwest of the Azores.

BONN, Germany, May 6 -- The West German Bundestag opened debate today on the proposed law for the equalization of World War II burdens. Debate is expected to last until the middle of the month and when the measure is approved, as most observers expect it to be, albeit with many amendments, it may become the basis for a vast redistribution of wealth.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Judge James P. McGranery, whom President Truman has nominated to be Attorney General, expressed the opinion today that the President should not seize private property without Congressional authorization "if Congress is in session and circumstances permit."
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, proposed today to extend from eight to twelve years the maximum bonding period for whisky.

Recognition of the role of the practical nurse in health, along with registered nurses and doctors, is growing satisfactorily, officers of the Practical Nurses of New York, Inc., reported yesterday at the annual convention at the New Yorker Hotel.
A Brooklyn saloon keeper and a Dodgers' ticket seller were arrested yesterday on charges of speculating in Dodgers' tickets.

The western world is going through "a psychiatric revolution" that has been bringing about changes in medicine, education and even welfare, Dr. Ernst Kris, psychoanalyst, said last night. He spoke at the Freud lecture on "Psychoanalysis and the Study of Creative Imagination," under the auspices of the New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.

Today a new chief will preside over the United States Steel Corporation, the world's largest producer of steel. Upon retirement of 65-year-old Irving Sands Olds as chairman of the board of directors, Benjamin F. Fairless was elected to succeed him and was named chief executive officer of the giant industrial concern.

The trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders was interrupted yesterday to permit the defense to make a flying trip to Atlanta to consult a top Communist party executive imprisoned there. There will be no court session today, but the trial will continue tomorrow.
Two museum exhibitions open to the public today -- recent acquisitions at the Museum of Modern Art and a selection from the permanent collections at the Whitney.

" High priests of mass production who cry wares and not a way of life" may be adding to the frustrations of man rather than helping him, W. Howard Chase, public relations director of General Foods Corporation, told the Triennial Conference of Camp Fire Girls, Inc., yesterday.
Twenty-two more veterans who pleaded guilty to defrauding the Veterans Administration's education and training program received suspended sentences yesterday from Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan.

We read your "veto" editorial of April 25 with some surprise. No public issue of our time has received less intelligent attention from the press than the "Tidelands" controversy. The federal oil bonanza created by the Supreme Court at the expense of the traditional rights of California, Louisiana and Texas seems to have completely seduced popular opinion and the press too, for the time being.
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 6 (AP) -- The University of Kentucky announced today it would "make such reforms" as were needed in its athletic program to avoid future scandal.

Mayor Impellitteri yesterday made his predicted appointment of Charles H. Silver, vice president of the American Woolen Company, to a seven-year term on the Board of Education and touched off a storm of protest by education and political groups.

ST. LOUIS, May 6 (AP) -- International officers of the C. I. O. Brewery Workers Union, who were advised to "grab the first train out of town," announced late today they would withdraw pickets from the Anheuser-Busch brewery here.

Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires, in Central America for the last lap of their eighteen-game chess match, started the fourteenth test of the series, according to a report received yesterday from San Salvador.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 6 (AP) -- Archer Daniels Midland Company, one of the nation's top three soybean processors, said today it plans to halt most of its soybean operations because of a "price squeeze" brought on by the Office of Price Stabilization.

MIAMI, Wednesday, May 7 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia appeared early this morning, with two-thirds of Florida's precincts counted, to have established a trend that would carry him to victory over Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee in the state's Presidential preference primary.

BOSTON, May 6 (UP) -- Clyde Vollmer smashed two homers that accounted for five runs tonight to set the pace for a scoring spree as the Red Sox beat the White Sox, 11 -- 2, before 16,256 Fenway Park fans in the opening of a three-game series.

A foster mother who has aided the Department of Welfare by providing a home for twenty underprivileged children during the last fifteen years received a citation yesterday from Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy, head of the department.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Charles E. Wilson, former Director of Defense Mobilization, recommended today that the Wage Stabilization Board be shorn of authority to handle labor-manage ment disputes and its composition changed to a board of all public members, instead of the present make-up of six public, six business and six labor members.
LONDON, May 6 (AP) -- British Laborites apparently made impressive gains today in early balloting of week-long, nation-wide municipal elections.

DETROIT, May 6 -- Intensified planning and promotion to increase sales on credit was recommended today at the nineteenth annual conference of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. The meeting will continue through Thursday.
L. A. Watkins has been appointed general sales manager of Ditto, Inc.

Simple shapes and muted colors reveal the skill of Frances Simches and James Crumrine in a joint collection of serviceable ceramic pieces opening today at Greenwich House Gallery, 16 Jones Street. The exhibit continues daily through May 14 from 10 A. M. to 9 P. M.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Carbine Williams," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama with James Stewart, Jean Hagen and Wendell Corey, is at the Capitol. Richard Thorpe directed the Armand Deutsch production, which has a screen play by Art Cohn, from his own story. Carl Benton, Paul Stewart, Otto Hulett and Rhys Williams are among the supporting cast.

PARIS, May 6 -- Jean Desses' collection, which appeared yesterday morning, stresses several fashion points: stoles for daytime and evening, pleats in skirts and bodices, shirred folds over the midriff and hips suggesting a corselette, mounting necklines, and a full-skirted, fluid silhouette.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The Supreme Court has refused to review, and thereby has left in force, a lower court decision which the major movie distributors fear may set a precedent that will cost them many millions.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Conrado Marrero limited the Tigers to six hits as the Senators defeated Detroit, 5 -- 2, tonight. Washington's fifth straight victory was achieved at the expense of Art Houtteman, who suffered his third loss.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- Miss Ruth Rifkin, 40 years old, a public stenographer, refused to say today whether she gave Communist agents information about the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration when she was a secretary for the now dead agency.

The New York State Masonic Grand Lodge began its 171st annual convention yesterday in Masonic Temple, 71 West Twenty-third Street. Two thousand delegates from all parts of the state attended the sessions, which will run through tomorrow.

The five-story corner building containing two stores and twenty-four apartments at 34-04 Thirty-fourth Avenue in Astoria, Queens, has been sold by Leo Winogron to a customer of Citadel Realty, broker in the transaction. Sale was for cash above a first mortgage of $45,000.
LONDON, May 6 -- The Labor opposition to Prime Minister Churchill's Government is expected to oppose the rearmament of Germany now when the matter comes before Parliament next week.

ALBANY, May 6 -- The State Commerce Department, which is dedicated, among many other duties, to publicizing New York's virtues as a vacation paradise, stood accused today of hijacking a New Hampshire river and passing it off as a local asset.

Two national strikes hampered the homecoming yesterday of the pilots and ground crews of four Naval Air Reserve squadrons from the aircraft carrier Antietam, which returned to San Francisco on Friday after five months in Korean waters.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Senate-House conferees reached agreement today on two bills to increase veterans' benefit payments by about $214,000,000 a year to meet cost-of-living rises.

The Appellate Division reserved decision yesterday on the action of Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein in refusing to halt the retrial of eighteen policemen on departmental charges of accepting graft from the bookmaker, Harry Gross.

What distinguishes a scientist from other men is his use of and devotion to the scientific method. The scientist probes nature, experimenting, observing, verifying and verifying again. When he conceives an hypothesis it is only for working purposes. If his experiments and observations confirm the hypothesis he continues using it; if they disprove the hypothesis he rejects it.

TOKYO, May 6 -- Communist China issued a bitter denunciation against the new sovereignty of Japan today in a broadcast special statement over the Peiping radio by Chou En-lai, the Minister for Foreign Affairs. He described the Tokyo leaders as "lackeys" of the United States Government and made the open charge that the Japanese Government is planning to invade the Chinese mainland in an attempt to revive Japan's imperialist rule over Asia.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Truman declared tonight that this country was being led down the alley that Soviet Premier Joseph Stalin wanted it to follow by the tendency of Congress to hamstring Government programs by cutting appropriations.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and final prices for active months were 10 to 32 points net lower than on Monday.

CINCINNATI, May 6 -- A balk by Billy Loes in the ninth inning sent tonight's game with the Reds into overtime, but the Dodgers pulled out a 5-4 victory in the tenth on a triple by Andy Pafko and a scoring fly by Carl Furillo off Ken Raffensberger. Coupled with the Giants' defeat at St. Louis, the triumph put the Brooks back in first place by a half game.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The United States Court of Claims ruled today that a Navy enlisted man who served as an Army officer in World War I is entitled to retirement pay based on his Army rank.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6 -- The Iranian Government was challenged this afternoon in the session of the United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs to explain a discrepancy of 330 tons of raw opium that it asserted was credited to it in error by the Permanent Central Opium Board.

Top procurement officials of the three armed services and other Federal agencies joined yesterday in the first large-scale effort here to qualify small business men as suppliers to the Army, Navy and Air Force.

Holders of common stock of the Northwest Bancorporation are being offered rights to subscribe at $50 a share for 103,185 shares of new 4.2 per cent convertible preferred stock of $50 par value at the rate of one new share for each fifteen shares of common held, it was announced yesterday. The offering is being underwritten by a group headed by the First Boston Corporation and Blyth Co., Inc.

Veteran theatregoers may recall Edward Knoblock's "My Lady's Dress," which sketched dramatically the social history of a modern gown. Lots of water has gone over the dam since that play was presented. Through union organization and at much personal sacrifice the dressmakers have won respite from long hours, meager wages and untoward working conditions.

Janie goes her cheerful way every morning up and down subway stairs to a job in a handbag factory. She's as good a worker as the girl next to her at the power machine, and her pay check buys the same.

PARIS, May 6 -- A formula for the guarantee to be given by members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to the projected European Defense Community was approved today by the permanent representatives of the North Atlantic Council.

Doctors and nurses at Beth Israel Hospital find the art of painting and scupture a valuable aid to the art of healing. Several of the staff held forth yesterday on this theme in the hospital solarium overlooking Stuyvesant Park, where Beth Israel's third annual art exhibit opened to the public for a week.

Joey Maxim of Cleveland, who will defend his world light heavyweight title against Sugar Ray Robinson, middleweight champion, in Yankee Stadium on Monday night, June 23, came to an agreement with the challenger yesterday on the division of the purse. Each will receive 30 per cent of the net receipts which, with television and radio fees, may exceed $750,000.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- Western Union officials reversed their stand today and agreed to attend Government-sponsored meetings with the Commercial Telegraphers Union, A. F. L., tomorrow in an effort to end the thirty-three-day strike of 30,000 clerks, messengers and telegraphers for a wage increase.

Fifty-seven girls, all seniors at public high schools in this city, received a thorough briefing on life in the Women's Army Corps yesterday when, as "WAC's for a day," they made a tour of installations at First Army headquarters on Governors Island.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The Gulf Stream, one of the great highways of the sea, may have two predominant courses, one for summer and the other for winter, a group of Navy researchers reported today.

BALTIMORE, May 6 (AP) -- Christiana Stable's Andre, a 3-year-old son of Pavot, won the Mount Washington Purse at Pimlico today, while After Bim, 4-5 favorite with the crowd of 10,055, finished fourth.

The board of directors of Brown Bigelow, advertising agency, authorized the issuance of $7,500,000 in refunding debenture bonds at a meeting yesterday in St. Paul. The entire issue was purchased immediately by four life insurance companies.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Senate and House conferees agreed today on the terms of a bill to give the coastal states title to submerged lands off their shores and thus to overrule Supreme Court decisions holding that the Federal Government had paramount rights over the oil-rich belt beneath the waters bordering California, Texas and Louisiana.

MOSCOW, May 6 -- George F. Kennan, the United States' outstanding specialist on Soviet affairs, arrived at Unukovo Airdrome here this afternoon to assume his post as United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

Fire in a rubber works at 159 Duane Street caused injuries to ten firemen yesterday, cast an odorous black smoke over the downtown civic center and business district and tied up traffic along West Broadway and Hudson Street.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, May 7 (Reuters) -Australia's second nation-wide port stoppage in five weeks will leave 100 ships idle today.

BONN, Germany, May 6 -- The growing restiveness of the West German industrialists under a variety of embargoes against trade with the Eastern nations erupted in the Bundestag today, with a motion, adopted by a show of hands, calling on the Federal Government to appeal to the occupation authorities for fuller freedom to conduct such trade.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (UP) -- Rookie Clint Courtney and Marty Marion hit their first American League home runs tonight as the Browns snapped a five-game losing streak with a 5-1 victory over the Athletics before 7,381 fans.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 6 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation at the annual meeting today authorized an increase of 1,500,000 shares in common capital stock without par value to 12,594,662 shares.

The Park Association of New York City, at its annual meeting yesterday, announced it was seeking improvements for the part of Flushing Meadow Park near the Queens Botanical Gardens on the old World's Fair site.

Despite lack of special news, the stock market managed to make progress yesterday. While awaiting a decision in the steel situation and hoping for settlement of the oil strike, traders re-entered the market on a limited and highly selective basis.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 7 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme United Nations Commander in Korea, announced today that the Communists had rejected a final "package proposal" for solution of the remaining issues in the Korean armistice negotiations.

The city was urged in a report published yesterday to consolidate the administration of all its retirement and pension systems into a single agency. The existing New York City Employes Retirement System was proposed as this overall body.

HUNTING, fishing and allied activities are entering the lists in intercollegiate competition these days, and next week-end will find teams from ten American and Canadian colleges competing in a Woodsmen's Week-end at Middlebury College in Vermont.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 6 -- President Gabrill Gonzalez Videla is seeking a return to work by the striking copper miners while the Government negotiates with the Anaconda company for better wages and working conditions and with Washington for a better price to solve Chile's dollar deficit and the copper company's difficulties in meeting salary increases.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Army today conceded the existence of a multi-million-dollar Korean black market in stolen American property, but said that strong remedial steps were being taken.

GENEVA, May 6 -- In timber, formerly one of the two or three most important items of trade between East and West Europe, Western Europe is now virtually independent of supplies from Russian or Russian-dominated territory.

IN Prague in February, 1948, the vultures were gathering. The small free nation of Czechoslovakia, which had barely survived seven years of prostration beneath the Nazi tyranny, was about to fall for the second time in only ten years. The Communists were scurrying about in various governmental departments like rats in an old house.

The nation's universities generally are doing an inadequate job of preparing public school administrators, speakers said yesterday at the annual regional conference of the Cooperative Program in Educational Administration, held at Teachers College, Columbia University.
CHICAGO, May 6 -- A program to prevent war and promote peace was offered here tonight by Dr. O. Frederick Nolde, director of the Commission of the Churches on International Affairs.

Automobile liability and property damage insurance rates will rise throughout the country starting within thirty days. The average rise for private automobiles will be about 20 per cent, with this city, where the charges now are the highest in the nation, slated for an increase up to 30 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Personal liability insurance for all motor vehicle drivers, whether or not they own a car, as a measure to reduce highway accident hazards, was urged here today at the opening of the fourth Highway Transportation Congress.

Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today issues of bonds totaling $67,500,000. Included are debentures of an Eastern telephone company, convertible debentures of a Western oil company and mortgage bonds of a Western public utility.

Tammany Hall is arranging a $50-a-plate fund-raising dinner in honor of the New York County Democratic delegation to the party's National Convention, with Mayor Impellitteri scheduled to be invited, it was learned yesterday. Plans for the dinner, to be held at the Hotel Commodore on June 10, were approved at a conference of Tammany leaders with county leader Carmine G. DeSapio.

Three new taxes estimated to yield $19,500,000 to help finance the city's prospective 1952-53 budget of $1,469,265,102 were passed by the City Council yesterday and rushed to the Board of Estimate. The prospect was that the three imposts would be enacted into law by May 15.
MEXICO CITY, May 6 -- Mexico, with a rapidly expanding population of more than 25,000,000, is about to pilck her national heroine of the year: the mothre with the greatest number of living children.

The first-quarter report of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, issued to stockholders yesterday, showed that net sales increased 5 per cent to $280,844,765 from the $267,071,395 for the initial three months last year. Earnings, however, declined under the pressure of higher operating costs.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Opposition to a grant of permanent authority to Seatrain Lines, Inc., to transport freight in box cars aboard vessels between Edgewater, N. J., and Savannah, Ga., was voiced by railroads today in a hearing before Examiner J. Edgar Snider of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

LONDON, May 6 -- The movement of cattle except by official permission was brought to a standstill throughout England and Wales last midnight in a desperate effort to check the spread of hoof and mouth disease. This is the first time since 1937 that such a wide area has been placed under such a control order. About half of Scotland also is affected.

Crumbling prices in Singapore and London sent crude rubber lower here yesterday on the Commodity Exchange, which saw the heaviest volume of trading since the reopening of business on March 3 and the lowest prices since July, 1950.

Research at the New York Hospital-Cornell University Medical College into the crippling disease of muscular dystrophy has reached the stage that made Dr. Ade T. Milhorat, director of the project, exclaim yesterday:
CHICAGO, May 6 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports of today's livestock trading here:

Bernard Berenson, art critic and scholar, had to take to the hills of Italy in 1941, at the age of 76, to avoid the advancing Fascists and Nazis. While in hiding, he kept a diary in which he recorded his wartime experiences and his philosophic and humanistic meditations.
In "Topics of The Times" for April 29 not only is the name of William A. Fairburn misprinted as "Fairbanks" but the great contribution of Mr. Fairburn to the public welfare is not stated.

Many young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons are aiding in plans for the block party for the benefit of the House of the Holy Comforter on May 23 in East Seventy-first Street between Park and Madison Avenues.
CHICAGO, May 6 (AP) -- Johnny Klippstein tamed the Braves with a blazing three-hitter as the Cubs jolted Vern Bickford for a three-hit, two-run fifth inning and a 2-0 victory today.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, May 7 (AP) -- Allied planes dealt a crippling blow to the main north-south railway line in Communist Korea Tuesday with a saturation bombing of the vital Sunchon-Pyongyang link.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- The restaurant business, fourth largest industry in the country, is meeting rising labor costs and the stiff competition provided by the American housewife with increased mechanization and improved efficiency.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., May 6 -- New plans for development of a hospital on the Albany Post Road midway between Tarrytown and Ossining to take the place of outmoded hospitals of these villages were outlined today. A total of $2,900,000 is believed to be available toward the $3,900,000 estimated cost.

A decision to throw open to the highest bidder the purchase of five city-owned Manhattan bus lines now operating at a $350,000-a-year deficit was made yesterday by Controller Lazarus Joseph, chairman of the Board of Estimate's special committee on buses.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6 -- First Avenue from Forty-second Street to Forty-eighth Street may be renamed United Nations Plaza by New York authorities.

Abba Khoushy, Mayor of Haifa, Israel, arrived here by plane yesterday from Lydda, for a five-week tour of the United States in behalf of the $500,000,000 State of Israel independent bond issue. He also will attend the United States Conference of Mayors opening May 15, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

About 1,000 stockholders of the Radio Corporation of America, one of the world's largest producers in the radio, television and communications fields, were informed yesterday that 1952 profits were lower because of higher operating expenses and a sharp decline in the sale of television sets.

The Wage Stabilization Board called on 90,000 striking oil workers yesterday to end at once the week-old walkout that had cut off a third of the country's petroleum supply. Strike leaders promised to consider the back-to-work plea, but censured the board for its action.

LONDON, May 6 -- The United States, British and French Governments are considering a sharp protest to the Soviet Union for its neglect to reply to their joint notes of March 13 regarding the long standing impasse on an Austrian treaty, diplomatic circles here say.

CAIRO, May 6 -- Premier Ahmed Naguib El Hilaly Pasha, addressing the diplomatic corps, his Cabinet and high Egyptian officials today at an official reception at Zafahran Palace on the sixteenth anniversary of King Farouk's accession to the throne, made it abundantly evident that Egypt was determined to see Egypt and the Sudan united under a common crown.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Gamblers who quit their activities after the occupational wagering tax became effective last Nov. 1 are still liable for the purchase of the $50 tax stamp.

A film recording of the televised tour of the White House conducted last Saturday by President Truman will be presented over Channel 2 on Sunday at 1 P. M. The original "live" presentation, running for forty-eight minutes, was carried by three networks.

Many young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons are aiding in plans for the block party for the benefit of the House of the Holy Comforter on May 23 in East Seventy-first Street between Park and Madison Avenues.
CHICAGO, May 6 (AP) -- Johnny Klippstein tamed the Braves with a blazing three-hitter as the Cubs jolted Vern Bickford for a three-hit, two-run fifth inning and a 2-0 victory today.

PARIS, May 6 -- In explaining his defense budget to the Finance Committee of the National Assembly today, Rene Pleven, Minister of Defense, said the equipment of the twelve divisions that France proposed to form this year could be completed only if France received from the United States 170,000,000,000 francs or nearly $485,000,000 in "off shore" orders.

CHICAGO, May 6 (AP) -- Headed by Metropolitan New York with eight berths and Philadelphia and Illinois with seven each, a list of 104 qualifying places for the National Professional Golfers' Association tourney at Louisville, Ky., June 18-24, was revealed today.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Gamblers who quit their activities after the occupational wagering tax became effective last Nov. 1 are still liable for the purchase of the $50 tax stamp.

A film recording of the televised tour of the White House conducted last Saturday by President Truman will be presented over Channel 2 on Sunday at 1 P. M. The original "live" presentation, running for forty-eight minutes, was carried by three networks.

ROME, May 6 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower took off by plane for Paris this afternoon after a one-day goodby visit to Rome. He left behind the distinct impression that he was a stanch advocate of a European federation and that if elected President of the United States an effort to urge or force the European nations into closer political and economic cooperation would be a basis of his foreign policy.

PARIS, May 7 -- A major step in the new United States defense aid program, an agreement with France to allot to her $200,000,000 for military supplies, has been virtually completed after long negotiation here.
SCHOHARIE, N. Y., May 7 -- Senator Estes Kefauver declared tonight that his strong showing in the Florida and Ohio primaries "practically assured" him of the Democratic Presidential nomination.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 7 -- Paramount Pictures will release during the eighteen-month period beginning in July a program of features "without precedent in scope and investment" for the company, Barney Balaban, president, said today.

MEDFORD, Mass., May 7 -- Dr. Robert E. Lincoln, developer of a system of treatment by which he claimed to be able to eliminate cancer and other diseases from the human body, resigned today from the Massachusetts Medical Society.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 7 -- With each side applying splitting tactics against the other, the Government suspended the rules of Parliament today to enable the House of Assembly to sit all night to finish an acrimonious debate on the second reading of the bill to create a "high court of Parliament.

Why should the Republican National Convention nominate an individual for the Presidency of the United States who was picked by our Democratic President, in fact his very first choice, for the Democratic nomination for that office?

Competition between private bus companies for a franchise covering the five Manhattan lines now operated by the city was assured yesterday when Lester T. Doyle, Federal trustee for the Third Avenue Transit System, filed an application with the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Federal Reserve Board suspended controls on installment credit purchasing today but recommended that Congress continue its authority to reinvoke the curbs should circumstances warrant.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 7 -- Adequate engineering control constitutes the most important phase of prevention of occupational disease caused by inhaling harmful dust, R. Emmet Doherty, dust control engineer of the Anthracite Institute, Wilkes Barre, Pa., told the American Mining Congress today.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 7 -Cambodian claims for a revision in the Cambodian Kingdom's relationships with the French were spotlighted anew yesterday by a student demonstration in the Cambodian capital of Phompenh.

CHICAGO, May 7 (AP) -- Hog prices resumed their climb today after leveling slightly yesterday. While the top of $20.15 a hundred pounds was down a dime from the extreme paid ill the previous session, it was up a nickel over Tuesday's load lot top. Most sales of hogs, cattle and sheep were steady to 25 cents higher. Department of Agriculture reports on the day's sales:

A Federal proposal for Washington mediation on a labor dispute in one of the country's most important military aircraft jet engine plants evoked charges last night from the General Electric Company that Federal mediators were prejudiced in favor of labor demands for the union shop and wage increases.
TOKYO, Thursday, May 8 (AP) -Eighth Army tactical summary 52, for Wednesday:

The Republican State Committee, elected at the primary on April 22, yesterday elected six delegates-at-large, headed by Governor Dewey, to the Republican National Convention to be held in Chicago, beginning July 7. Though uninstructed, they are known to favor General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the nomination for President.

Senators Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, and Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, went into the lead yesterday in the nationwide contests for delegates to the national conventions and each issued a claim of victory for the Presidential nomination.

As in most of the previous performances of Arthur Mendel and his Cantata Singers, an effort was made last night to approximate conditions of Bach's own time. A relatively small chorus was used, the orchestra was of chamber size, and the acoustics those of a church itself.

Members of the women's auxiliary of St. Luke's Hospital have arranged a luncheon and fashion show for May 14 in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre in behalf of the work of the organization. Guests have been requested to bring packages of useful and decorative articles suitable for resale later at Everybody's Thrift Shop, 922 Third Avenue, for the benefit of the charitable enterprises of the auxiliary.

That was Jockey Sam Boulmetis' six-word summing up of the way that S. P. Steckler's 2-year-old colt, Fort Salonga, won the seventy-sixth running of the Juvenile Stakes in Belmont Park's Widener chute yesterday. Fort Salonga, the 17-to-10 favorite, led all the way in a five-furlong sprint that was marred by a spill shortly after the start.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 7 -- The "sobering fact" that many students go through college without acquiring a zest for reading books was decried today at a symposium at Rutgers University. The conference was held in connection with the inauguration tomorrow of Dr. Lewis Webster Jones as president of the university.

BOSTON, May 7 -- Dr. Paul H. Magnuson, chairman of President Truman's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation, said tonight that the medical school of the future "might concentrate largely on preventive medicine."

GENEVA, May 7 -- A new plan to mobilize the world's food resources for the relief of regions stricken by sudden famine has been prepared by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations for submission to governments.

A ruptured diaphragm in the fuel feed valve of the left engine of the U. S. Airlines air freighter that crashed in Jamaica, Queens, on April 5, killing its crew of two and three persons on the ground, probably caused the accident.
DENVER, Colo., May 7 -- The 90,000 striking oil workers rejected tonight a Government plea to return to work. The refusal was expected to put the dispute up to President Truman.

The stock market did well again yesterday in the face of domestic economic troubles. The railroads and oils continued to sustain prices and brought about an increase in the composite rate of 0.86 point. It was the consensus in Wall Street that a new base of operations had been established -- this in spite of the upsetting picture in the steel and oil industries resulting from disputes between management and labor.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 7 -- Foreign Minister Ole Bjoern Kraft submitted to the Danish Parliament today a bill to establish a permanent Scandinavian parliamentary council.
The saga of an amazing voyage of exploration and adventure by four men on a twenty-nine-foot ketch was unfolded here yesterday by the versatile skipper of the craft.

Three political appointees and personal friends of former Mayor William O'Dwyer were named yesterday by Harry Gross, the convicted bookmaker, as recipients of his gambling pay-offs and election contributions.
BERLIN, May 7 (AP) -- East Germany's Communist rulers announced tonight that they were forming an army to defend the Soviet zone "against aggression."

Although the dimensions of the reversal are not yet clear, or even decided probably, public ownership of passenger transit in New York City has begun receding, ending a long trip in the other direction.
GENEVA, May 7 -- India needs and will continue to seek means of applying scientific population control to her teeming population, an Indian spokesman told the Fifth World Health Assembly here today.
