STAMFORD, Conn., May 7 -- Construction of a major power station in this area was justified before the State Public Utilities Commission at a hearing here today by Dr. Alexander Graham Christie of the Engineering faculty of Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore on the ground that in the event of another world war Connecticut would be "pretty badly crowded."
TOKYO, May 7 (UP) -- Following is the text of Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's statement today on the Korean truce negotiations:

THE mackerel seem to be paying the way for the New Jersey party boat skippers, and with large catches being brought in by the boats from Shark River, Manasquan River and Barnegat, there appears to be no lack of angling customers.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Truman today named Henry H. Fowler, head of the National Production Authority, to assume the additional job as Defense Production Administrator, and indicated he soon would centralize all production responsibilities under one man.

Hopes for lower food prices dimmed yesterday when the Dun Bradstreet wholesale food price index showed increases for the second week in a row. On April 22, the index had dropped to the lowest average of 1952. The average on Tuesday, May 6, was up three cents above the level of a week earlier to $6.36, although it was 11.4 per cent below the level of a year ago which was $7.18.

Netting only two runs from the twelve hits they collected off Mike Garcia, while the opposition was pounding Vic Raschi and two successors much more productively, the Yankees bowed to the Indians for the second straight day before 12,644 spectators at the Stadium yesterday.

JERUSALEM, May 7-- A symposium on desert research, sponsored by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, opened here tonight with fifty scientists from twelve countries on hand.

Efficiency and honesty mark the administration of the school system in the typical American community, Dr. John K. Norton, director of the division of administration and guidance at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday.

TAIPEI, Formosa, May 7 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, United States Commander in Chief in the Pacific, watched a reinforced Chinese Nationalist battalion and three squadrons of Nationalist planes stage a combined military exercise today on the Formosa coast southwest of Taipei.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 7 --- The police and fire chiefs of Hackensack top a list of nine men who face departmental trials as a result of the twenty-one-month Bergen County gambling and crime investigation, which ended today with the dismissal of the special grand jury.

ALBANY, Ore, May 7 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California declared today that retention of the Democratic party in power would mean its "complete absolution" and condonement by the American people of the Truman Administration's "complacent" attitude toward official misconduct and inefficiency and financial irresponsibility of government.

Dr. Leopold Figl, Chancellor of Austria, is scheduled to arrive Sunday morning at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, for a sixteen-day visit at the invitation of the United States Government. Dr. and Frau Figl will be the guests of President Truman during their four-day visit to Washington.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Like its sister resort state of California, Florida in recent years has had a large and permanent infusion of citizens who differ substantially in background and viewpoint from the native stock. Just as immigrants from the Middle West have overcome in numbers the early settlers of Southern California, so immigrants from all parts of the United States have erased the old regional markings of Southern Florida.

Dr. J. R. Sterling and others have purchased the one-story taxpayer at 88-12 to 88-20 Queens Boulevard in Elmhurst, Queens, from Julius Mintz, operator. Thomas G. Sarris was the broker and title was insured by the Inter- County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee today heard in executive session two witnesses who opposed the appointment of Judge James P. McGranery to be Attorney General. As a result of their testimony, the committee decided to summon additional witnesses, who will be heard tomorrow, and obtain the records in two court cases in which Judge McGranery was involved.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 7 -Captain Eddie McHugh belted two triples and a pair of singles in five trips to the plate to pace Yale to a 9-4 baseball triumph over Columbia today.

PARIS, May 6 -- Jacques Fath, whose collection was shown here yesterday, quickly dispelled the rumor that he was ill. He used two means: Showing a lovely mid-season line, and, then, by stating: "People are announcing that I am dead or dying; it is not true.

MOORESTOWN, N. J., May 7 -Milton Conroy Barber, general manager of the Underwood Corporation of Burlington, N. J., shot and killed himself late this afternoon in the den of his home at 501 Irving Court, according to the authorities.

A thirty-hour work stoppage, which spread to 981 American Airlines maintenance employes here and in Philadelphia but failed to block flights, ended last night when the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., announced a company agreement to reinstate an inspector to a post from which he had been downgraded and to give him back pay.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson accused the Soviet Union today of committing an "international crime" in repeatedly charging the United Nations with using germ warfare in Korea. He then questioned the wisdom of holding talks with a Government whose intentions appeared so hostile.

LONDON, May 7 (Reuters) -- Britain will increase her newsprint imports from Scandinavia by about 10 per cent in the second half of this year, it was believed here today. The price will be something below the 70 ($196) a long ton paid in the first half.

CHICAGO, May 7 (AP) -- Sportsman's Park remained strike-bound by horse owners for the third successive day today and the Illinois Racing Board charged that "all conscientious efforts have not been made" to settle the matter.

CHICAGO, May 7 (AP) -- Chuck Davey, scoring four knockdowns, easily defeated Chico Vejar tonight in their ten-round welterweight battle in Chicago Stadium. Davey, who is undefeated, received a unanimous decision.
MADISON, N. J., May 7 -- Speedy action by a priest and two altar boys in shepherding 200 children out of a blazing Roman Catholic church this morning saved many of them from death or injury.

LONDON, May 7 -- British Government securities again provided the only firm section of the stock markets here today and they too faltered in the afternoon. Leading industrial shares continued to drift quietly lower and most other industrial groups also tended to weaken, although losses were mostly small.

The Appellate Division unanimously refused yesterday to grant a stay in the disciplinary proceedings against eighteen members of the Police Department charged with accepting graft from Harry Gross, bookmaker.

LONDON, May 7 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden refused demands from the Labor Opposition today that the rearmament of West Germany and its integration with the West be delayed until after a four-power conference to explore the possibility of free elections and the unification of that partitioned country.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- An action for treble damages has been instituted by the Department of Justice in behalf of the Office of Price Stabilization against the Max Ein Minerals Corporation of 25 Broad Street, New York City, the O. P. S. announced today.

BALTIMORE, May 7 (AP) -- Walter A. Edgar's Jack the Great toyed with four rivals in the featured Towson Purse at Pimlico today to lead from start to finish of the three-quarter mile dash. With Nick Shuk aboard, the homebred colt won by three and a half lengths.

Today's new film is "Scaramouche," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's Technicolor version of the Rafael Sabatini adventure, with Stewart Granger, Eleanor Parker, Janet Leigh and Mel Ferrer, at Radio City Music Hall. Carey Wilson produced and George Sidney directed. Henry Wilcoxon, Nina Foch, Richard Anderson and Robert Coote are among the featured participants.

The trade fight among securities underwriters over the merits of negotiated underwriting and public sealed bidding is itself a reflection of the play of competition, Judge Harold R. Medina observed yesterday at the anti-trust investment banking trial in progress in Federal Court here.

The schools motion picture committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

VANCOUVER, B. C., May 7 (Canadian Press) -- The Consultative Committee on Doukhobors warned today that violence might break out afresh in southwestern British Columbia unless reforms in the Doukhobor colonies were undertaken immediately.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 7 -- Six thousand five hundred ship workers at the New York Shipbuilding Company's plant here went to work half an hour late today as a "show of strength" in a wage dispute.
One of the avowed aims of the Welfare and Health Council's annual hobby show for older persons is to awaken public interest in the creative potentialites of citizens who have passed 60.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- A compromise bill to create sixteen new Federal judgeships was approved today by a House Judiciary subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The boss contractor on the much-criticized American air base job in North Africa first agreed "in general" today with an accusation that Congressional investigators of the job were "headline hunting" to promote Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas for President. Then he withdrew the whole statement and apologized.

The right of the Bureau of Smoke Control to prosecute waterfront smoke violators was upheld yesterday by Magistrate Louis A. Pagnucco in a test case that had been in the Magistrates' Courts for thirteen months.

William Patrick O'Brien resigned as Police Commissioner on Sept. 25, 1950, the day that the then Acting Mayor Impellitteri had earlier implied he would dismiss him if he failed to quit. Mr. O'Brien had been Commissioner since March 1, 1949, an appointee of former Mayor William O'Dwyer.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Progressively worse traffic congestion and increased highway hazards throughout the country as a result of the lag of street and road construction far behind needs were forecast today at the fourth Highway Transportation Congress meeting here.

" Acres of Sky", described as a ballad opera, had its first New York performance at Columbia's Brander Matthews Theatre last night, and even if it was a halting, flawed product, it was a brave effort at the creation of something distinctive in the way of American lyric theatre.

" Tibetan Sky Lines," by Robert B. Ekvall, an account of several years spent in that country, will be published by Farrar, Straus Young tomorrow. Mr. Ekvall, who is a missionary on horseback, poet and anthropologist, describes his experiences in Tibet and his nomad friends.

Parts for the Republic F-84 Thunderjets being flown by pilots of the member nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will be manufactured by Finmeccanica, an Italian concern, under terms of a contract signed yesterday by American and Italian officials.

BONN, Germany, May 7 -- The Soviet Union is the chief beneficiary in Germany of the dispute within the Bonn Government parties over the contractual agreement on the one hand and, on the other, the differences among the Western Allies over the best way to answer the second Soviet note urging German reunification.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- The international executive board of the United Steel Workers of America, C. I. O., instructed Philip Murray today to hold out for all the wage increases and other benefits recommended by the Wage Stabilization Board.
The stringent Government quotas on imported cheeses have brought protests from several foreign countries and are working to the disadvantage of American consumers.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed quiet yesterday, with active months 6 to 19 points net higher than on Tuesday.

MIAMI, Fla., May 7 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia emerged today as the winner by more than 53,000 votes in his bid for Florida's Presidential popularity support, but his opponent Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, nevertheless was credited with an impressive showing.
Sally was four and frightened. It was her first day in nursery school and there was so much noise. Sally was unaccustomed to sound. Her parents were both deaf mutes.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, showed the House a shopping basket filled with drug store items today to back his claim that "the consumer gets a rooking under so-called Fair Trade Laws."
CHELSEA, Mass., May 7. (UP) -- Five terrific explosions, apparently set off when an acetylene torch ignited jet plane fuel fumes, wrecked and sank an 818-ton tanker at her dock today.

In a deal in which the contract of sale was signed and title taken in one day, two five-story apartment houses at 348-50 Lenox Avenue were bought by the Estate Securities Company, operators. The buildings occupy a plot 50 by 100 feet and contain three stores and twenty apartments.
The 32,000-ton carrier Wasp, which sank the 1,600-ton destroyer Hobson in mid-Atlantic during night maneuvers on April 26, finished unloading in Gravesend Bay before darkness last night.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -The Senate ignored the protests of Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, and voted today to take up an immigration bill introduced by Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada.

William O. Douglas, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, asked last night that this country eradicate racial prejudice and show itself as a land of equality, equal opportunity and freedom and justice to thwart communism in Asia.

A teen-age delegate to the 1952 triennial conference of the Camp Fire Girls in the Statler Hotel recommended yesterday "that adults on the council take a survey to find out why they are afraid of more participation by girls on the program."
Following is the way the Republican and Democratic line-ups for the Presidential nominating conventions stood last night for leading candidates:

PORTLAND, Ore., May 7 -- Although profits have risen recently in department and similar stores, the average merchant still faces the task of overcoming present consumer sales resistance and indifference. Such was the comment today of George Hansen, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, at the Pacific Southwest Retailers' Clinic.

HOBOKEN, N. J., May 7 -- Plans for a $22,000,000 program to rehabilitate this city's piers between First and Fourth Streets, replacing the present obsolete and rundown structures with three superpiers, each 650 feet long and 345 feet wide, were outlined today by Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, and Walter P. Hedden, the authority's director of port development.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -- The steel industry recommended today that it be allowed to sell steel to manufacturers of civilian goods without allotment tickets. The proposal -- which would become effective in October -- was made to the National Production Authority by an industry advisory committee.

Samuel Reshevsky of New York won the fourteenth game and drew the fifteenth to clinch his chess match with Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires last night. According to reports from San Salvador, the former United States champion now has a total score of 9 1/2 to 5 12, which assures him of the victory regardless of the outcome of the remaining three games of their series still to be contested.
LONDON, May 7 (AP) -- The Labor party forged ahead today in Scotland and continued to score gains elsewhere in the second day of nation-wide municipal elections that last through Saturday.

PARIS, May 7 -- Madeleine de Rauch showed her collection yesterday -- a small one concentrating on summer country club fashions. There were many middy styles in blouses, bodices and jackets. All were moderately curved at the waist.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, one of the country's richest labor groups, has decided to use its own funds to finance a $7,500,000 mortgage for a cooperative housing development under union sponsorship on the lower East Side.

Eighteen years having elapsed since a new O'Casey play was done in this town, a patron of the arts instinctively rises to attention when a new bill is announced. Some actors who admire the most invisible of our dramatists have put on three O'Casey one-act plays at Yugoslav-American Hall, 405 West Forty-first Street, where they opened last evening.

Much of the burden resulting from the need to re-evaluate advertising programs in the face of rising costs will have to be borne by agency research departments, according to Neil Du Bois, director of research development at Geyer, Newell Ganger, Inc.

The questioning of Hasis (Harvey) Bistany in Providence, R. I., has failed to uncover any information that would contribute to the solution of the murder of Arnold L. Schuster, District Attorney Miles F. McDonald reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 7 (AP) -- Will Harridge, president of the American League, today hired Douglas W. (Scotty) Robb, who quit his National League umpiring job two days ago after being disciplined and fined by the senior circuit's boss, Warren Giles.

Hugo E. Rogers, $10,000-a-year special counsel to the Traffic Department, has sent a letter to Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan suggesting a way of ending bottlenecks under the West Side (Miller) Highway -- a matter that comes within the general purview of Mr. Rogers' technical superior, Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.

Citing the steel crisis as an example of the "startling" influence of special interests on Capitol Hill, George Meany, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Labor, charged last night that Congress had done nothing to meet the major problems confronting the nation.

New lessons in the art of war -- learned in two recent maneuvers -- are being analyzed and studied by the Army and Air Force and will result eventually in tactical and technical changes of considerable importance.

BONN, Germany, May 7 -- An official spokesman said today that the West German Government was willing to make a concrete offer to Israel in response to a vote by the Israeli Parliament yesterday that negotiations for the $1,000,000,000 reparations sought by Israel remain suspended until such an offer was made.
Paul G. Hoffman,, former Economic Cooperation Administrator, said last night he believed this country could bring about a change in Soviet policy from one of conquest to one of live-and-let-live.

After I left Berlin, where I attended the Third Annual Congress of the International Federation of Free Journalists, I read your story about that congress. I refer to your Sunday, April 27, edition. Your correspondent wrote:

PITTSBURGH, May 7 (AP) -Southpaw Howie Pollet scattered five hits tonight as he pitched the Pirates to a 5 -- 1 victory over the Phillies to snap a six-game losing streak for the last-place Bucs. The Phils helped the Pirate cause by committing five errors.
The Fordham baseball team defeated Manhattan, 7 -- 4, on Fordham Field yesterday in a non-Conference game. The victory was the Rams' eighth in twelve starts.

LOS ANGELES, May 7 -- Administering the first defeat to Herman Steiner, former United States champion, in the eighth round today, Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia continued to hold first place in the Hollywood International Invitation chess tournament with a score of 6 12 -- 1 1/2.

The Federal Administration's opposition to the so-called Long Range Bill, currently the subject of hearings in Washington before the House Merchant Marine Committee, continued to highlight the testtimony of Government representatives yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Two Senators branded as groundless today fears that Federal claims to submerged off-shore lands might jeopardize city ownership of waterfront facilities.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Announced United States battle casualties in Korea reached 108,172 today, an increase of 207 since last week.

The Franklin National Bank, largest independent commercial bank on Long Island, will merge with the Bank of Farmingdale at the close of business on Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Arthur T. Roth and Robert Simon, presidents of the respective institutions.

After she finally decided her jewels really were missing, Mrs. Edna Chappell called the police yesterday to report the theft of two necklaces and a pin insured for $29,575. Mrs. Chappell, the widow of Delos Cahppell, theatrical producer, who died in 1945, lives at 1 West Seventy-second Street.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- Directors of Carson Pirie Scott Co. elevated Bruce MacLeish to be chairman of the board yesterday and appointed John T. Pirie Jr. to succeed him as president. They also designated the chairman as the principal policy-making officer of the company and the president as the principal executive officer.

Rubber in Singapore plunged yesterday to its lowest price in two years, showing a 20 per cent loss in a month, and the price sagged again on the Commodity Exchange here. September delivery, the first on the board, dropped 45 points and closed at 30.15 cents after going as low as 29.8 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Truman declared today that forced repatriation of prisoners in Korea would be "repugnant" to the free world and he described the latest United Nations armistice proposals as a "just and real opportunity" to end the Korean conflict.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Roger L. Putnam, Director of Economic Stabilization, disputed in an interview today the accuracy of statements made by his former chief, Charles E. Wilson, yesterday before a Congressional committee investigating the Wage Stabilization Board.

LONDON, May 7 -- No. 10 Downing Street announced tonight that Prime Minister Winston Churchill had decided on a redistribution of duties among the members of his Cabinet. This does not involve a major Government shake-up or any change of policy.

TOKYO, Thursday, May 8 -United Nations and Communist delegates met for eighteen minutes today at Panmunjom. The only development in the negotiations for a truce in Korea was a violent denunciation by North Korean Lieut. Gen. Nam Il of the Allied attempt to reach an over-all settlement.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 7 -New experimentation aimed at enlarging the nation's repertoire of atomic weapons was hinted today as Atomic Energy Commission scientists, detonating the fifth nuclear "device" of the current test series, abruptly shifted their test techniques.

PIERRE, S. D., May 7 -- Members of the Missouri Basin Inter-Agency Committee lashed out today at critics of the Pick-Sloan plan for harnessing the Missouri River and presented figures to show that April's record flood would have been prevented by dams now under construction on the upper reaches of the river.

The Oxford Theatre and a two-story taxpayer at 2246-80 Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, have been purchased by Irving Maidman operator, from Albert A. Beregh. The property, assessed at $235,000, fronts 167 feet on Jerome Avenue.

CLEVELAND, May 7 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, upsetting the plans of Ohio's Democratic leaders to keep this state's delegation uncommitted, captured twenty-seven of the fifty-four convention votes at stake in yesterday's Presidential primary.

The latest moves of France in Tunisia indicate that far from proving more conciliatory and generous, the French are clamping the lid down still harder on the Tunisian nationalists. Yesterday's news of the release of former Premier Chenik and three other Cabinet Ministers is now followed by word that they must refrain from political activity and stay away from Tunis and Carthage.

First-quarter operations of the Phelps Dodge Corporation produced a consolidated net income of $9,819.205 or $1.93 a share before and $9,286,609 or $1.83 a share after deduction for depletion of mines, the report disclosed yesterday.

Joey Maxim of Cleveland, world light heavyweight champion, and Ray Robinson of New York, middleweight titleholder, signed an official contract to fight for Maxim's crown at the Yankee Stadium on Monday night, June 23, at the New York State Athletic Commission office yesterday. Each boxer is to receive 30 per cent of the net receipts.

" Shuffle Along," the 1952 edition of the successful all-Negro musical comedy of the early Twenties, opens tonight at 8 o'clock at the Broadway Theatre. Irving Gaumont produced it in association with Grace Rosenfield.

Former Representative Ellsworth B. Buck was re-elected chairman of the Richmond County Republican organization last nigh at the annual meeting of the County Committee at Public School 14 in Stapleton. The former president of the city Board of Education was elected a delegate to the Republican National Convention on April 22 by the margin of twenty-two votes over former Assemblyman S. Robert Molinari.

WIESBADEN, Germany, May 7 (UP) -- United States air units inI [Europe and Africa, including fighter planes based along the Iron Cur-: itain, have reduced combat training to a minimum to conserve gasoline: supplies reduced by the oil strike,' ,an Air Force spokesman said toidly.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Western Union officials and leaders of the striking Commercial Telegraphers Union met here today for the first time in weeks. After an all-day session, there was an official "no comment." A Federal conciliator announced the parties had agreed to resume talks tomorrow morning.
YORKTOWN, Va., May 7 -- A $9,000,000 toll bridge to speed traffic between Washington, D. C., and the South Atlantic seaboard was opened here today after dedicatory services.

A 5 to 10 per cent drop in butter sales is expected here when selling of colored margarine becomes legal in New York July 1. Large producers are confident, however, that present sales levels will be regained within a few weeks after the first flurry of interest in the new product subsides.

THERE is an open trunk near the door of the Yankee Stadium dressing room. It usually is crammed to overflowing with baseball bats. But yesterday it was half empty. Phil Rizzuto, attired in nothing more than an oversize sweatshirt, peered inside.
CALCUTTA, India, May 7 -- Life in this sprawling city came to a complete standstill today as the result of a general strike.

In New Brunswick this afternoon Dr. Lewis Webster Jones will be inaugurated as the fifteenth president of Rutgers University. The institution, which began with the granting of a charter by Holland in 1766, has come a long way in rendering service to state and nation.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Truman was "ecstatic" today over the gift of first prints of songs by Franz Schubert, autographed by the master, and said he would have his daughter Margaret sing them for him.

AS the assistant editor of the "Columbia Lippincott Gazetteer of the World" may I be permitted to amplify the statement of Leon E. Seltzer, editor of the Gazetteer, which appeared in THE TIMES of April 26 regarding the aid that the Soviet unwittingly gave the compilers of this great reference book.
Frank J. O'Brien Jr. has been elected a vice president of Metal and Thermit Corporation, it was announced yesterday. It was also announced that Charles R. Hervey has been made assistant controller.

A record $1,500,000 in contributions was reported last night at the annual dinner of the real estate and builders' division of the United Jewish Appeal at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. About 350 industry leaders attended the dinner, part of the division's drive for $2,350,000 this year.

PARIS, May 7 -- French authorities in Tunisia today transferred the exiled nationalist leader, Habib Bourguiba, from confinement in a southern desert camp to the tiny island of Galite In the Mediterranean, thirty miles off the north coast.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A Mutual Security bill authorizing $6,901,100,000 for building military and economic strength throughout the free world in the 1953 fiscal year was approved today by the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

Wage Stabilization Board Chairman Nathan P. Feinsinger has told the House Labor Committee that a rash of serious strikes and "industrial chaos" may result if the board is stripped of the power to handle industrial disputes. We believe he is in error.

Summer fashions from David Crystal, Inc, were presented yesterday by Saks Fifth Avenue at a luncheon-fashion show in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Fashion suggestions for hot weather included town suits, casual dresses and gay separates for the country and beach.

LONDON, May 7 -- The status of Britain's Negro community of about 60,000 has been the subject of a "preliminary statement" to members of the Anthropological Institute by Dr. Ruth Landes, formerly of Columbia University, who is studying the problem here as Fulbright research scholar.

The Museum of Modern Art yesterday increased its Lending Service, for the rental and sale of modern art to its members, by the addition of twenty-nine new paintings and nine graphic works by nine artists not heretofore represented.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill for enforcement of mandatory Federal safety standards in the country's disaster-ridden coal mines.

Our New York City Board of Education will not seem the same without James Marshall. This distinguished son of the lawyer Louis Marshall took his seat on the board Feb. 27, 1935, by appointment of Mayor La Guardia. "My attitude always has been on the liberal side regarding public matters," he remarked soon afterward in setting his course.

Bondholders of the Chicago Alton Railroad Company filed a $45,000,000 damage suit yesterday in Federal Court against the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, charging the B. O. with mismanagement during the period it controlled the Chicago railroad.

CLEVELAND, May 7 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was not on the ballot in yesterday's Ohio primary but two candidates who spoke of supporting him were snowed under in the home state avalanche for Senator Robert A. Taft.

Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. presented to the Costa Rican Mission of the Franciscan Friars yesterday a gold chalice inscribed in the memory of Charles S. Hand, who was Manhattan Commissioner of Borough Works until his death two months ago.
YONKERS, May 7 -- Henry Clukey drove the first triple of the Yonkers Raceway season tonight, scoring with two trotters and a pacer in the second, third and seventh races before 16,383 fans.

The Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Md., borrowed $8,700,000 yesterday on bonds duel from 1953 to 1992 and callable in 1967 at an interest cost of 2.79771 per cent. The bonds were sold at sealed public bidding to a syndicate headed by Glore, Forgan Co. and Blyth Co at a bid of 100 for 4s, 3s, 2 1/2s and 2 3/4s.

A line of spun-dyed staple fiber with interesting possibilities has been developed by Courtalds, Ltd., the largest English producer of viscose rayon, it was announced last night by Harold Ashton, head of Courtald's Arrow Mill, Rochdale, England.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Nathan P. Feinsinger, chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board, testified today that serious strikes might occur if jurisdiction over labor disputes were taken from the board and no adequate substitute was provided promptly.

Store policies and procedures necessary for adequate human relations with the consumer, public and employe were discussed yesterday at the fourth annual conference on human relations in retailing. The session, under the auspices of the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, was held at the Town Hall Club.

Many stores will begin selling television sets, refrigerators, washing machines, furniture, carpets and other home furnishings for "nothing down," with longer, periods to pay, now that the Government has relaxed its restrictions on installment sales.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., May 7 (AP) -- Governor Dewey told a Protestant Episcopal convention today that "if freedom of religion is going to survive in this world, it will survive only if the present floodtide of communism begins to ebb."

ST. LOUIS, May 7 -- Sal Maglie, who has been shaving them pretty close the past few years, had a close shave himself tonight as the Giants slipped over a 3-1 triumph on the Cardinals, but, for the first time this season, the Barber was not around for the finish.
BOSTON, May 7 (UP) -- With Clyde Vollmer hitting at a .555 clip, the Red Sox continued to set the pace in the American League today by beating Chicago, 7 -- 2, before 3,721 Fenway Park fans.
Two fixers of basketball games pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to conspiring to bribe a New York University athlete in January, 1950.
New York accorded its traditional honors yesterday to Abba Khoushy, Mayor of Haifa, Israel's industrial city and chief seaport, with ceremonies at City Hall, before a crowd of 5,000 persons.

Painting an encouraging picture as to sales and earnings of the Pepsi-Cola Company, Alfred N. Steele, president, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Wilmington that their equity in the company had increased from $22,300,000 to $26,800,000.

Emmet J. McCormack, vice president and treasurer of Moore-McCormack Lines, was sworn in yesterday morning as honorary deputy commissioner of the city's Department of Commerce. The oath was administered by Commissioner of Commerce Walter T. Shirley in the department's offices at 500 Fifth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement today on the Korean armistice negotiations:

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -Rear Admiral Walter S. De Lany has been named to succeed Vice Admiral Oscar C. Badger as Commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier and the Atlantic Reserve Fleet, the Navy announced today.

The American Petroleum Institute announced yesterday that because it has been impossible to obtain complete information on refinery activity, due to the strike at "several refineries," it has decided to forego the release of its regular weekly operation report on industry operations.

Martin B. Friedman and Stanley Eisner has sold the three-story apartment house accommodating thirty-one families at 140-144 Broadway in Passaic, N. J., to the Vineyard Haven Corporation, represented by Philip Riskin, attorney. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

Pensions paid to retired employes of public utility companies in New York State may be added to other operating expenses as a base for rates, according to a new policy announced yesterday by the State Public Service Commission.

Sonoco Products Company, manufacturers of cones and paper carriers for the textile trade, is offering to its common stockholders rights to subscribe for 150,000 new shares of common stock at $16.50 a share.

JACKFIELD, England, May 7 -An earthquake in slow motion has hit this pottery-making village in the west of England on the banks of the Severn River. Shropshire County Council officials are pessimistic about halting the peril, which has already destroyed six houses.
An intensive public relations program was urged on the chemical industry yesterday, to bring about a better understanding of its work by the general public.

James J. Moran, the 50-year-old former First Deputy Fire Commissioner to whom Harry Gross, bookmaker, reportedly gave political contributions, is in Green Haven Prison near Beacon, N. Y. The ex-official's sentence was twelve and one-half to twenty-five years for extortion and conspiracy.
JOHNSTOWN, Pa., May 7 (AP) -- The stockholders of the Pennsylvania Coal and Coke Company have approved a plan to double the capital stock.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -- A Government panel recommended today that various Government agencies speed up their purchases of textiles in an effort to relieve unemployment in the industry.

New issues of corporate bonds totaling $77,239,000 were placed on the market yesterday by underwriting syndicates. Most of the borrowing is for the purpose of refunding railroad debt. The flotations include, however, new issues of public utility bonds and debentures being sold to finance capital improvements.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, May 8 (AP) -- Allied air power blasted the crippled North Korean rail system again yesterday in the stepped-up campaign to choke off Communist armies from Manchurian supplies.

A rabbinical school president warned yesterday that any union between church and state, no matter how remote, would ultimately bring about the persecution of non-conforming religious minorities. He declared that even state recognition of all religions discriminated against its non-theistic citizens.

Denim in many guises has been a favorite of designers this year for spring and summer attire. It has been embellished with beading and braid in sophisticated evening designs, treated to be used in raincoats, tailored for town suits and worked in a wealth of sportswear.

A property in the Gracie Square section of Yorkville that had been in the same ownership for three generations passed to new control with the sale by Frederick and Christopher Arfmann of the five buildings at the northwest corner of York Avenue and Nintieth Street to Antiquities, Inc., an affiliate of French Co., art dealers and interior decorators.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 7 -- William C. Horley's familiarity with record machines and his reputation for conscientiousness as vice president of the First Bank and Trust Company of Perth Amboy made it possible for him to embezzle $456,000 from that institution during the last five years without being detected, Prosecutor Alex Eber of Middlesex County said today.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 7 (AP) -Bolivia's paralyzed tin-mining industry was told yesterday that the Government would proceed to nationalize it "at all costs."
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -The Senators scored their sixth straight victory tonight by defeating the Tigers, 6 -- 2, as Sid Hudson pitched a five-hitter.

A protest against increased efforts to restrict imports in the interest of domestic producers, particularly in the case of recently imposed quotas for cheese imports, was voted yesterday by the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at a meeting in the Statler Hotel.
Saudi Arabia is seeking changes in her fifty-fifty profit-sharing agreement with the Arabian-American Oil Company (Aramco), the world's largest producer of crude oil.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 7 -- The outer layer (cortex) of the all-important adrenal glands, situated astride each kidney, "still holds a most important secret that has not yet been revealed," Prof. Edward C. Kendall, Princeton University chemist, said here today.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- Possibility of rains in the dry Northwest restricted buying of grains today, and there was enough profit-taking by longs to cause a moderate price recession. The promise of general relief for dry conditions in the spring wheat country is not too definite, but traders were inclined to be cautious.
CHICAGO, May 7 -- E. L. Gibson of Park Ridge sued the principal and coaches of Maine Township High School today for the right of his son, James, to decide what sport he will play.

MONTREAL, May 7 -- The joint industrial strength of Canada and the United States is the main reason Premier Joseph Stalin of Russia is not declaring war on the rest of the world, John Jay Hopkins, international industrialist, told Canadian manufacturers here today.

PARIS, May 7 -- France's highest military title, that of Marshal of France, will be conferred on two of the soldiers who led French armies back from the disintegration of 1940 to major roles in the liberation -- Gen. Alphonse-Pierre Juin and the late Gen. Jacques-Philippe Leclerc.
CINCINNATI, May 7 -- The Dodgers headed for home tonight in first place after edging the Reds, 5 -- 4, at Crosley Field for the second straight time to run their winning streak to four games.

Mature women who have cared for the ordinary illnesses in a family possess "an incomparable background" that prepares them for training as practical nurses, Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, told a convention session of Practical Nurses of New York at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 30, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP) -Alex Kellner of the Athletics and Earl Harrist of the Browns waged a tight mound duel tonight as the A's beat the Browns, 1 -- 0. Kellner allowed five hits and Harrist four.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -New Mexico and Arizona officials today urged Senate restoration of an $18,000,000 cut made by the House of Representatives in the amount President Truman budgeted to aid the Navajo and Hopi Indians.

LONDON, May 7 -- The British Government had been fully consulted before Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway issued his statement that the United Nations Command had made its final proposal for a truce in Korea, a Foreign Office spokesman said here today. He added that the Government was in complete accord with the views expressed.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 7 (AP) -- Don McNeill and Frank Guernsey, both of New York, entered the semi-final round of the Coral Beach invitation tennis tournament today after close matches.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- By unanimous vote, the Senate Elections subcommittee today ordered a resumption of public hearings on a resolution seeking the expulsion from the Senate of Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 6 -- Australia is counting on a patch of country in the "outback" to become one of her main sources of uranium ore, putting the country on the map as one of the world's five big producers of atomic materials.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP) -Alex Kellner of the Athletics and Earl Harrist of the Browns waged a tight mound duel tonight as the A's beat the Browns, 1 -- 0. Kellner allowed five hits and Harrist four.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -New Mexico and Arizona officials today urged Senate restoration of an $18,000,000 cut made by the House of Representatives in the amount President Truman budgeted to aid the Navajo and Hopi Indians.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 35 to 64 points net higher than on Wednesday, with the most pronounced strength in old May and July contracts.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 8 -- Education must produce responsible citizens and not "dangerously skilled barbarians," Dr. Lewis Webster Jones declared today at a ceremony marking his installation as the fifteenth president of Rutgers University.

Eleven buildings occupying the entire blockfront on the east side of Second Avenue from Seventieth to Seventy-first Streets have been purchased by a syndicate of realty investors represented by Geller Saslow, attorneys, it was announced yesterday.

Dick Eichhorn, sophomore right-hander, posted his fifth victory without a defeat as St. John's downed Hofstra, 7 -- 4, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday. The victory put the Redmen into a first-place tie at 5 -- 2 with Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended May 3, 1952, totaled 744,592 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 34,810 cars, or 4.5 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 58,745, or 7.3 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 596, or 0.1 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.
LOS ANGELES, May 8 (AP) -- "The world carryover of cotton as of Aug. 1 will be increased by 1,800,000 bales to 13,000,000," according to Frank R. Ahlgren, editor of The Memphis Commercial Appeal.

To offset reports that although supporting General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republication nomination for President he hoped for a deadlock that might bring him the nomination, Governor Dewey reiterated yesterday that he was not a candidate and asked the New York delegates to the Republican National Convention not to vote for him at any stage of the proceedings.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -- The House gave final approval today to two compromise bills to increase compensation and pensions of disabled veterans by $202,000,000 a year.
PARIS, May 8 -- Alix Maguy is showing a small advanced collection of winter suits and coats to a selected number of customers.

DENIS W. BROGAN, Professor of Political Science at Cambridge University, is an erudite and versatile Scot whose delight it is to display his fabulous learning elaborately dressed in the most fashionable literary language. The prose in which Professor Brogan presents his academically journalistic books bears no resemblance to the professorial jargon of many of his colleagues.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Enactment of laws throughout the country to rid the roads of reckless and incompetent drivers was urged today at the closing session of the Fourth Highway Transportation Congress here. Fatalities and injuries resulting from preventable accidents were described as "appalling and ghastly," with economic losses mounting into billions of dollars.
WHITEVILLE, N. C., May 8 -- Three admitted former members of the Ku Klux Klan turned state witnesses today in the flogging case of Woodrow Johnson, 40 years old, an auto mechanic here.
ROME, May 8 (UP) -- The Italian Government today charged the Yugoslav Minister to Austria with making a speech in Vienna containing "vulgar and offensive" remarks about Italy.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- During the week ended May 7, member bank reserves increased $94,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LOS ANGELES, May 8 -- Svetozar Gligoric of Belgrade was declared the winner of the Hollywood international invitation chess ters' tournament after taking the additional point he needed from Lionel Joyner of Toronto in the final round today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 8 -- Gen. Ciro Cardoso, the War Minister, has issued a warning to all officers that the presence of Communists in the Brazilian Army has been positively established and that officers must "maintain the most rigorous vigilance so that any surprise action may be avoided no matter from where it may come."

The development of two new electronic devices, one of which which will be used to keep secret the speed of the superliner United States, was described yesterday in simultaneous announcements from Newport News, Va., and Kings Point, N. Y.

For his New York debut piano recital last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, Roman Stecura played Beethoven's Sonata in D, Op. 10, No. 1, Mussorgsky's "Pictures From an Exhibition," pieces by Debussy and Hindemith and Schumann's Symphonic Etudes.
ST. LOUIS, May 8 -- Behind Dave Koslo's slick four-hit pitching, the Giants today closed their first Western trip of the year by beating Gerald Staley and the Cardinals, 3 to 0, in the series finale.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- President Truman insisted today that there was a grave marker at Tombstone, Ariz., bearing the inscription:

Confirming the preliminary findings that led the National Collegiate Athletic Association to vote overwhelmingly last January in favor of another year of controlled football telecasts in 1952, the National Opinion Research Center of the University of Chicago has come out with a true bill of particulars in the case of college football against video.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 8 -- In its annual report prepared for submission to the United Nations and released today, the Food and Agriculture Organization characterizes the 1950-51 period as "the year in which we made the biggest strides forward."

With household pets holding the limelight for the last few days during the annual "Be Kind to Animals Week," continued kindness and loving care for canine friends is encouraged with the release yesterday of an illustrated booklet, "The Dog as a City Pet."

Masons of New York state elected Ward B. Arbury as Grand Master yesterday, the final day of the three-day annual state convention, held in Masonic Temple, 71 West Twenty-third Street. Mr. Arbury, a Buffalo attorney, succeeds Richard A. Rowland of Schenectady.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 8 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, the United States No. 1 ranking player, and Gustavo Palafox of Mexico today advanced to the semi-final round of the men's singles in the Coral Beach tennis tournament.

Buying continues heavy at the openings of the early fall lines of the members of the Guild of Better Shoes Manufacturers, Inc., producers said yesterday. The showings, which opened last month at guild headquarters in the Shelburne Hotel and at the private showrooms of the companies, will continue through next week.
ST. LOUIS, May 8 (AP) -- Bill Bangert, St. Louis athlete who had been considered hopelessly blind, is gradually regaining his vision through a new and experimental treatment, doctors disclosed today.
The sharp rise on Wednesday in the price of the new Chicago and Western Indiana Railroad bonds came in for discussion at the investment banking antitrust trial in Federal Court here yesterday.

Because of the city's increased heatlh and welfare needs and mounting prices, the 423 member agencies of the Greater New York Fund will need a 1952 operating budget of $202,000,000, Earl B. Schwulst, fund president, predicted yesterday.

Marking the sixth decline in seven weeks, loans to business by New York banks dropped $19,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday. The reduction, largely the result of seasonal influences, brought the decrease in business loans this year to $340,000,000, against a rise of $408,000,000 in the similar period in 1951.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A hitherto unrevealed episode of the Constitutional litigation over the steel industry seizure came to light today. This was that Federal Judge David A. Pine requested a Government stipulation that steel wages would not be raised pending a decision and Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, requested the Justice Department to make the stipulation, but it was never done.

American hens lay nearly half the eggs produced in the world, it was pointed out at the Ninth World Poultry Congress in France last summer. Lately they have been bettering their own records, and consumers will find ample supplies of eggs again this week-end at prices well below those of a year ago.

MEXICO CITY, May 8 -- Tommy Bolt of Durham, N. C., paced the field in the first round of the $15,000 Pan-American open championship today, building up a four-stroke lead with a 64 over the new Mexico Golf Club course.

Dr. Harry N. Wright, retiring president of City College, received yesterday afternoon a scroll from the student body of the School of Business and Civic Administration at the college's Charter Day Convocations.

PARIS, May 8 -- Bikini swim suits on horizontal lines, transparent beach frocks over one-piece suits, picturesque terry cloth garments are a part of the cotton and linen collection offered by Jacques Heim.

HEWLETT, L. I., May 8 -- A Texas golfer, Don Cherry of Wichita Falls, found the wind-blown seaside Seawane Harbor Golf Club course no enigma today as he spun around with a 2 under par 70 to win the qualifying medal in the William D. Richardson Memorial Tournament.

As a native New Yorker, an enrolled Republican and member of La Guardia's last Cabinet, I would like to speak up in defense of the appointment of Charles H. Silver as a member of the Board of Education. He is a particular type of business man that the board badly needs. He will give it some "new blood" and bring to it a deeper interest in public school education and environment.

George F. Kennan has brought to his new post in Moscow as United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union one of the finest minds in our diplomatic service, a wealth of experience and knowledge in Soviet affairs, and a sincere determination to work for the cause of peace. Having served in our Moscow embassy for several extended periods since 1933, he knows the technical problems he will face as Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- In a move designed to save the Defense Department billions of dollars a year, the House of Representative passed by a standing vote of 228 to 48 today a resolution directing the three armed services to use a single catalogue for the millions of items they buy. The measure now goes to the Senate.

The Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday the cigarette, automobile use and liquor license taxes enacted last Tuesday by the City Council. Mayor Impellitteri is scheduled to sign the new tax laws immediately after a statutory public hearing to be held in his office at City Hall at 9:30 A. M. next Thursday.
PARIS, May 8 -- Machinery for planning an international laboratory for cooperative nuclear research was completed at a meeting of scientists of eleven nations which closed here today.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Home building, breaking, moving and rebuilding, modern style, was demonstrated today by the Pressed Steel Car Company at its Hegewisch plant here today. It took a dozen workmen and a few pieces of standard trucking equipment an hour and twenty minutes to accomplish the process with a five-room-and-bath movable plywood house called "The Unishelter."

August W. Flath and William T. Whalen, accused as bribe takers in yesterday's police trial testimony by Harry Gross, the Brooklyn gambler, were the right and left arms of Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien who also was accused by Gross.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to legalize provisions of state "fair trade" laws that were invalidated last year by the Federal Supreme Court.

LOUISVILLE, May 8 (UP) -- Hill Gail's chances of running in the $75,000 added Preakness Stakes on May 17 appeared "pretty good" to Trainer Ben Jones today after the Kentucky Derby winner had galloped at Churchill Downs with no sign of a limp.

The three-month feud between Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, Brooklyn dock boss, and Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, that has sporadically threatened to erupt into open violence was renewed yesterday with a cross-fire of accusations and threats.

Described as a professional diamond smuggler by Federal authorities, Charles Travitsky, a 49-year-old jeweler, of 1421 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx, was held in $25,000 bail for a hearing on June 10 when he was arraigned yesterday afternoon before United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein in Brooklyn.

BAYONNE, N. J., May 8 -- Repairs to the shattered bow of the 32,000-ton carrier Wasp were started today at the Navy Yard Annex here, several hours after the battered fighting craft was warped into the huge drydock.

Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, declared yesterday in a letter to the Joint Committee Against Communism that he would not prevent Howard Fast, the author, from speaking at the college on May 16.

There will be ample funds for home financing in 1952 but there is little likelihood of any widespread relaxation of mortgage money rates, speakers declared yesterday at the eighth annual mortgage conference of the Long Island Real Estate Board at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City.

TOKYO, Friday, May 9 -- Lieut. Gen. Nam Il, senior Communist delegate at the negotiations in Panmunjom for an armistice in the Korean war, denounced at yesterday's meeting the "screening process" by which prisoners were permitted to express their desire either to return home after a cease-fire or remain in democratic territory.

H. R. (Bob) Reeve of the Bayside Tennis Club, the defending champion, eliminated R. H. Berger of the Crescent A. C., recent winner of the veterans' championship, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 9, at the Columbia University Club yesterday as play began in the singles title tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 8 -- General of the Amy Dwight D. Eisenhower told an audience of 2,000 Copenhagen University students assembled in the inner courtyard of Christiansborg Palace tonight that the choice at this juncture was one between freedom and dictatorship.

The lifting of controls on consumer credits gave the stock market a momentary excuse to advance yesterday but other basic factors held back any furtherance of the rally and late selling diminished early gains.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 8 -- The Soviet Union told United Nations disarmament delegates today that agreement on atomic control would be impossible until the United States gave up its proposal for international ownership of atomic facilities.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Congressional staff of tax experts predicted today that Federal deficits in the 1952 and 1953 fiscal years would fall $5,200,000,000 short of President Truman's January budget estimates.

LONDON, May 8 -- The first experiment of Britain's Conservative Government in unscrambling the socialism of the past six years of the Labor Government may cost the taxpayers an initial payment of about 20,000,000 ($56,000,000).

General Eisenhower has now joined President Truman and other top-ranking political and military leaders in urging Congress to authorize the full $7,900,000,000 mutual security program providing for aid to our allies and to refrain from wrecking it through crippling cuts.

Harry Gross, the convicted gambler, lost his reticence with a bang once he decided to talk in public. The result is wholesale name-dropping which confirms and enlarges previous installments of his shocking story as conveyed second-hand to the public by District Attorney Miles F. McDonald, by the Brooklyn Grand Jury and in Judge-Rifkind's report after a departmental trial last December.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- On the theory that what a child learns at home during his first few years vitally affects his later adjustment to school and life, education authorities and parent group leaders here are at work on a program of instruction for parents of pre-school youngsters.

BEERSHEBA, Israel, May 8 -- Israeli farmers began harvesting today the best crop in the memory of the oldest settlers on a quarter of a million acres in the northern Negeb. The Israelis are harvesting about half of this area for the first time and under a new plan combining cooperative and capitalistic elements.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Sales of the International Harvester Company in the first six months of the 1952 fiscal year, ended April 30, are estimated at $648,202,000, the largest for that period in any year and the second largest six months in the company's history, John L. McCaffrey, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting today.

Frank Nawrocki, business agent for Local 808 of the International Longshoremen's Association. A. F. L., was found guilty of first degree perjury by an all-male blue-ribbon jury last night in Kings County Court. He has been on trial since Monday in connection with an incident growing out of the Brooklyn waterfront strike in the Fall of last year.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 8 -- The Illinois Democratic convention adopted a cautiously worded resolution today pledging the support of the state party's sixty national convention delegates to Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson if he should seek the Presidential nomination.

MOSCOW, Friday, May 9 -- Premier Stalin expressed today the hope that Germany would at the earliest moment achieve unity, independence and democracy, with the withdrawal of all armed force from her territory and the signature of a treaty of German peace. Mr. Stalin made his statement in a message of greeting to Premier Grotewohl of the least German...

The first day of the cross-examination of Louis F. Budenz at the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders started yesterday with polite legal arguments between counsel, but ended with the lawyers snarling at each other and charging unfair tactics.

A special sale will be held today to mark the first anniversary tomorrow of the opening of the Spence-Chapin Corner Shop at 974 Lexington Avenue under the auspices of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service. Throughout next week "open house" will be held at the shop. Within the last two months the organization has expanded its enterprise into the adjoining shop.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The election of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as President would give business men a bigger voice in the conduct of Government affairs than they have had in the last twenty years, Paul G. Hoffman said today.
The Department of Sanitation toured the Times Square and Grand Central areas yesterday with two floats and a mobile public address system, bringing clean-up messages to thousands of New Yorkers.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -- President Truman's "watchdog committee" on information security gave its approval today to the "secret" classification stamped on a study of world oil cartels by the Federal Trade Commission.

Amid a clamor and din raised by about 100 persons who shouted and screamed their angry opposition to the project, the Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday a map change that will pave the way for the construction of the proposed $12,500,000 Morningside-Manhattanville housing development near Columbia University.

A mechanic and an inspector, neither of whom held a Civil Aeronautics Administration license to work on aircraft engines, assembled, installed and checked the part of the engine that failed in the U. S. Airlines plane that crashed in Jamaica, Queens, on April 5, killing the crew of two and three persons on the ground.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- General Dodd was born in Angola, Ind., on Oct. 5, 1899. He went to school in Tallahassee, Fla., and later was graduated from West Point in June, 1923. His first assignments were with the Sixth Field Artillery at Camp Meade and Fort Hoyle in Maryland.

Further evidence that New York City is one of the nation's top production centers is contained in an analysis of current potentials for nineteen basic industries made by Sales Management magazine. The city is the leading producer in five of these industries and near the top in fourteen others, the study reveals.

TOKYO, Friday, May 9 -- Communist prisoners on Koje Island, off the South Korean coast, have seized the camp commandant, Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd, and are holding him prisoner, Eighth Army headquarters announced this morning. The Communists ignored a demand for the release of the 52-year-old West Point graduate but, according to headquarters, passed out a note written in his own hand stating that he was unharmed.

GENEVA, May 8 -- Some monetary technicians have discovered the clue to Europe's most intractable problem of international trade and payments next to the dollar problem itself -- the persistent Belgian surplus in settlements with the rest of western Europe through the European Payments Union.
Alan Valentine, president of the Committee for Free Asia, asserted yesterday that American economic aid to other nations, especially in Asia, had often been nullified by excessive population.

PARIS, May 8 -- A warning that indiscriminate use of public funds for international loans and grants to underdeveloped countries might dry up the flow of private risk capital was sounded here today by a commission of the International Chamber of Commerce.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 8 -- The United States, which exercises the unified command of United Nations forces in Korea, does not believe that the Communists will now launch a major offensive. However, if one should develop, the United States is ready to take what are described as "practical measures" to stop it while waiting for a special session of the General Assembly to reach a decision.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Noting the anniversary today of the defeat of Germany in World War II, President Truman condemned Congressional slashing of defense and foreign aid programs as actions that played into Russia's hands at a time of grave crisis.

The Beatrice Foods Company achieved a new high record in sales during the fiscal year ended on Feb. 29, the total of $228,661,163 being 11.4 per cent above the $205,257,498 volume for the preceding fiscal year, William G. Karnes, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

Jam, owned by James F. McHugh and ridden by Earl Phelps, went according to plan and expectations to win the Charles L. Appleton Memorial Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday. Established the even-money favorite by the crowd of 20,906, the 5-year-old son of Impound made the figures stand up by scoring a three-length victory over F. Ambrose Clark's Lone Fisherman.

Pope Piux XII has honored twenty-one members of the priesthood in the New York Archdiocese with higher rank, Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday. Msgr. James J. Lynch, director of New York Catholic Charities, was elevated to Prothonotary Apostolic.
BALTIMORE, May 8 (AP) -- Mrs. C. O. Schweitzer's Radical capped a day of upsets at Pimlico today by winning the Francis Scott Key purse over Penocc and The Pincher.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A conference committee from the Senate and the House of Representatives agreed today on a compromise bill to increase the pay of the armed forces by 4 per cent and allowances by 14 per cent. The leaders hoped the bill could be passed in time for it to become effective for May paychecks.

A new twist in sales meetings was introduced yesterday when Sol Tobias, general sales manager of Wayne Liquor Corporation, distributor of all Kinsey and Continental brands, arranged for a customer to "tell off" the salesmen. The retailer chosen to do the job -- a Jamaica tavern owner -- said that not enough emphasis was being put on the "back label."

Jackie Goldsmith, one-time basketball star at Long Island University, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to bribery charges that may result in a maximum prison term of ten years and fines amounting to $20,000.
PARIS, May 8 -- The mode for separates is exploited with no little charm by Lafaurie in garden frocks of crisp denim in cornflower blue, sun yellow or grass green.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 8 (AP) -- Ed (Porky) Oliver of Lemont, Ill., got away to a fast start in the Greenbrier Open Golf Tournament today by shooting to within one stroke of the course record of 60.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- A final Department of Agriculture survey today put the 1951 cotton crop at 15,130,000 bales, with a record farm value of $3,304,315,000 for the lint and cottonseed combined.

TOKYO, Friday, May 9 -- Successive waves of Allied fighter-bombers made the greatest aerial strike of the Korean war in a dawn-to-dusk blow yesterday that wiped out the ancient city of Suan, near the North Korean capital of Pyongyang.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -- Admiral E. L. Cochrane, United States Maritime Administrator, testified today that during the last eighteen months the United States had sailed "the greatest merchant marine of any period in history short of actual war."

When John Golden sets out to accomplish something, he generally does. The splendid notices that greeted "The Male Animal" -- there wasn't a dissenting note in the lot -- galvanized not only him but a number of other showmen to do everything in their power to obtain the privilege of moving the Elliott Nugent-James Thurber comedy to a Broadway house at the conclusion of its fortnight stand at the City Center.
BOSTON, May 8 (UP) -- Saul Rogovin shook off a case of firstinning jitters today and pitched the White Sox to a 4-2 victory over the Red Sox to end Chicago's six-game losing streak.

LONDON, May 8 -- United States and British leaders in industry and labor who have worked together in the Anglo-American Council on Productivity since July, 1948, agreed at its last joint meeting today that there is a need for successor organizations on both sides of the Atlantic.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- President Truman said today that he had no present intention of publicly endorsing any aspirant for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Oliver La Farge, president of the Association of American Indian Affairs, told the opening meeting of the Institute on American Indian Assimilation tonight that it was as useless to take a position against assimilation as against gravity.

Rent increases for 94,841 of the 3,000,000 tenants living in controlled housing were approved in the first three months of this year, Joseph D. McGolrick, State Rent Administrator, reported yesterday. In most instances tenants consented to the increases to get either two-year leases or additional services.
The American Can Company is undertaking today public financing intended to raise more than $25,300,000 through the sale of new common stock to the company's stockholders.

KALIMPONG, India, May 8 -- Dr. K. I. Singh, Nepalese rebel leader who fled to Tibet with a small armed force when his brief revolt in Katmandu was defeated earlier this year, was reported here today to be formulating plans for "liberation" of the strategic Himalayan kingdom under Communist auspices.
LONDON, Friday, May 9 -- Britain's Labor party won a resounding victory in nation wide local government elections yesterday, according to virtually complete results reported early today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 8 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has no fear that television will push motion-picture theatres out of business, Dore Schary, studio operations chief, asserted today in outlining to an audience of 100 leading exhibitors a long-range program of eighty-three productions to be made at a cost of $120,000,000 between now and 1954.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Defense officials eyed the nation's copper stockpile today as Chile canceled her agreement to ship copper here. A prolonged withdrawal of Chilean supplies, it was explained, would be a serious blow to defense production because Chile furnishes the bulk of our copper imports and supplies of the metal are tight.

A plan for "comprehensive medicine" centering around the patient and integrating specialized practices for his benefit is opening up a new era in medical care, Dr. Lester J. Evans said yesterday at charter day ceremonies of the New York Hospital.

TAIPEI, Formosa, May 8 -- As the Korean armistice talks reached a new stage of tenseness, Admiral Arthur W. Radford, United States Commander in Chief Pacific, reaffirmed his conviction here today that the United States Navy had the capacity to impose an effective blockade of Communist China.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -- The Defense Production Administration refused today to recommend $401,600,000 in loans on five steel expansion projects because "defense funds should not be used where expansion can be obtained by other means."
Investment bankers expect to see their way clear by June 3 to make a definite proposal for the purchase of $330,000,000 of revenue bonds to finance the projected Ohio Turnpike.

Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, retired, in the course of opening headquarters yesterday at the Chatham Hotel for the National Citizens Committee for Taft, which he heads, said some kind words about Generals of the Army Douglas MacArthur and Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Production of primary aluminum in March for the second month this year exceeded the average monthly production of 1943, peak year of wartime needs, according to figures released yesterday by the Aluminum Association. According to Donald M. White, secretary of the association, the production for the first quarter of 1952, at 452,667,474 pounds, exceeded the 1951 quarter by 12.8 per cent.

BERLIN, May 8 -- Otto Grotewohl, Premier of the East German Government, warned today that a new "Korea" might result in Germany if the Bonn Government formed a military alliance with the North Atlantic Treaty powers.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended May 3, fell 2 per cent below sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The American Bible Society at its 136th annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, paid tribute to two of its oldest members.

The nine - story and penthouse apartment building at 146-52 West Fifty-fifth Street has been sold by Hardwick Stires to an investing client of Joseph S. Gershman, attorney. Cyrille Carreau, Inc., was the broker and Thomas Stokes was attorney for the seller.

The narcotics evil in this city is growing worse, both in the quantity of smuggled heroin and increased addiction among teen-agers, Raymond M. Hilliard, executive director of the Welfare and Health Council, asserted yesterday. He charged the existence of "a scandalous movement to soft-pedal the spread of narcotics use among teen-agers."

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP) -- Outfielder Willard Marshall tripled with the bases loaded and singled across a fourth run to lead the Braves to a 6-4 victory over the Cubs today before a chilled crowd of 2,046. Chicago's defeat enabled the idle Reds to climb into a third place tie with the Cubs.

THE NEW YORK TIMES on April 8 carried a perceptive editorial on the suspension of the German-Israeli talks at The Hague. I must dissent, however, from your view that "the Germans argue with some merit that their ability to pay these claims must be considered in the light of other obligations imposed upon them, including the demands of their other foreign creditors and their contribution to Western defense."

WITH reasonable cooperation from the weather this week-end should provide the first really interesting period of the season for the fly fishermen. Reports from the Catskills, lower Adirondacks, Connecticut and eastern Pennsylvania indicate that most of the streams are in excellent condition as to water levels and temperature.

Four talented women sculptors gave a spirited public performance yesterday of their abilities, and their models, four clergymen, an admirable demonstration of endurance. The sitting lasted three hours.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- After four days of hearings the Senate Judiciary Committee agreed today to vote at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow on the nomination of Judge James P. McGranery of Pennsylvania as attorney General.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- President Truman celebrated his sixty-eighth birthday today with brimming goodwill and avowed youthfulness. He told his news conference that his life has been as happy and full as any man's of this age.

PARIS, May 5 -- As a corollary to the establishment of a "national" Catholic church in Czechosioakia, the Prague Communist regime has created a network of forced labor camps for priests, monks and nuns who refuse to knuckle under and have scorned the schismatic clerical establishment, remaining loyal to the Roman hierarchy.

Two more high-ranking police officials were identified yesterday by Harry Gross as among the more than 100 policemen to whom he contributed bookmaking graft between 1942 and 1950. The two were the highest line officers of the Police Department.

Mount Sinai Hospital issued its ninety-ninth annual report yesterday showing that $6,375,000 was spent in 1951 to treat 73,386 persons and maintain one of the largest non-university medical research and education programs in the country.

LONDON, May 8 -- Most prices drifted downward in idle conditions on the stock markets here today. The only market that offered real resistance was that for South African gold shares, which continued to improve on a more optimistic interpretation of the political situation there.

Although trial and travail for the original version of the all-Negro musical, "Shuffle Along," eventually resulted in triumph, a parallel set of vicissitudes has not had the same magic charm for the current edition. Presented at the Broadway Theatre last night before a host of friends and well-wishers, this "Shuffle Along" is full of warm-hearted, earnest, ingratiating performers.

BONN, Germany, May 8 -- Renegotiation of the contractual agreement between the Western Powers and Western Grmany was suggested today by Erich Ollenhauer, acting leader of the powerful Socialist party.

In knowing that I comes before e except after c and other letters have their rules in specific instances, the girls in our town can do better than the boys by 20 to 12. At least that's the conclusion one is forced to make after attending the final round of the spelling bee held in the high school auditorium to select a representative to the national contest beginning next week in Washington.

BERLIN, May 8 (UP) -- The Western Allies asked the Soviet commander in Germany today to approve a four-power investigation by Berlin's Air Safety Center of "material damage" inflicted on an Air France DC-4 by Soviet fighters.

Efforts by some domestic manufacturers to obtain legislation that would restrict imports were roundly condemned yesterday by speakers at the fourth international advertising convention of the Export Advertising Association in the Plaza Hotel.
Cabinets for television sets are included in new collections of glass furniture pieces now on the market.

Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee announced yesterday his intention of seeking delegate strength in New York State over the head of the Democratic State organization, the leadership of which is sponsoring W. Averell Harriman for the Democratic Presidential nomination, which the Senator also wants.
During the past several years the New York Stock Exchange has become an increasingly important factor in the new issue market, according to The Exchange, the institution's magazine.

The United Nations Covenant on Human Rights should certainly be defended from the attack made upon it in your letter columns recently by Russell J. Clinchy, whose letter was really an adaptation of a portion of his pamphlet published in February by the Foundation for Economic Education.
CHICAGO, May 8 -- A live baby was born every 10.7 seconds in the nation's hospitals last year, the Council on Medical Education and Hospitals, American Medical Association, reported today.
HARTFORD, Conn., May 8 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio disagreed today with the position taken by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower on reductions in foreign aid funds.

The controversy over Tunisia in the last few weeks has largely missed the point. In the argument on whether the Tunisian protest should be heard in the Security Council it has been assumed that the French must have a bad case if they wanted to deny a hearing, and the merits of the French policies in Tunisia have been forgotten, ignored or distorted.

TENAFLY, N. J., May 8 -- For the second week in a row, there was a tie for gross honors in a Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament. Playing over the Knickerbocker Country Club course today, Charlotte DeCozen of Montclair and Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches had identical scores of 40, 42 -- 82.

BALBOA, C. Z., May 8 -- Today was ladies' day in the armed forces of the Canal Zone. A realistic exercise in disaster control followed the simulated explosion of an atomic bomb aboard a tuna boat in Miraflores Locks near the Pacific terminal of the Panama Canal.
