PARIS, May 8 -- A draft treaty to create a European Defense Community with a common integrated defense force under the North Atlantic Treaty command will be initialed here tomorrow by experts representing France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

When Manly Fleischmann leaves his post as head of the Defense Production Administration May 31, following his resignation last Wednesday, he will leave behind him a record of solid accomplishment. Since August, 1950, he has played a key role in directing the massive effort by which this nation has reshaped its production apparatus from one primarily directed toward peacetime production to its present state of substantial military output accompanied by sizable, but less, civilian production.

With the coming of the season for baseball, program awards and spring fever, somebody usually gets around to worrying about the standards of radio and television. This year there is a movement afoot in the House of Representatives to put broadcasting under the microscope and decide where it has erred.

Murder Case Prisoner Released on Plea by Prosecutor Albert Tassiello, 36 - year - old prisoner who had been tried on three different occasions for first degree murder in connection with a hold-up in 1945, was released yesterday in General Sessions. Judge Jonah J. Goldstein freed the prisoner on the motion of Assistant District Attorney Alexander Herman.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -- A Government investigator testified today at a hearing of the Senate Agriculture Committee that the Commodity Credit Corporation allowed a grain concern to make between $500,000 and $1,000,000 on Government wheat purchases by buying procedures a private milling executive called "ridiculous."

Several factors point to a marked improvement in the wool-textile industry, according to Ames Stevens, who was elected president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers yesterday at the annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Export-Import Bank of Washington is giving close attention to Brazil's critical dollar exchange problems, but has not received any application from Brazil for help in overcoming the slowdown in the transfer of dollar payments on commercial obligations, it was learned here yesterday.

The season's eighth and last Composers' Forum was held last evening at McMillin Theatre, Columbia University. The event was sponsored by the Jean Tennyson Foundation, in cooperation with the New York Public Library and Columbia University, with assistance from the Alice M. Ditson Fund.

Renegotiation of Government defense contracts should be based entirely on the merits in each case and should not be governed by a set formula, John T. Koehler, chairman of the Renegotiation Board, declared yesterday. Efficiency resulting in Government savings or unusual contributions to the defense effort should be rewarded by higher profits, he said.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 8 -- The sounds of Presidential aspirants' voices on the Oregon political front rose in volume today.
The Army's newly developed atomic gun can hit its target under any weather conditions and give ground troops the kind of "devastating" close support that never before has been available in warfare.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The nations of the world are building ships at a furious pace but American shipbuilding for private owners is lagging far behind, the National Federation of American Shipping, Inc., reported today.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 8 (AP) -- Jockey Sammy Boulmetis completed a triple when he piloted Mrs. D. W. Hickey's Buzzing Bee to a head victory over Garden State's fast racing strip today.
Texture interest prevailed in summer fashions shown at Martin's in Brooklyn yesterday.

PELHAM, N. Y., May 8 -- On a match of cards with two rivals who also shot 89, Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester County Club won the low gross award in today's Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament at the Pelham Country Club. The other parties to the three-way deadlock were Mrs. Donald O'Brien of Winged Foot and Mrs. Donald F. Aldrich of Whippoorwill.

RANGOON, Burma, May 8 (AP) -- The Government said today the Burmese Army had wiped out the supreme headquarters of the Stalinist rebels in Burma's northern jungles. The surprise attack brought to a climax a four-year campaign that, an official announcement said, had reduced the Soviet-inspired Red force by two-thirds.
How to eat your meat and keep a part of your dollar, too, is the daily dilemma of the home cook appetites.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 8 -- Political preferences of the 350 Sarah Lawrence College students are the same as the average of 9,000 college graduates throughout the nation, Harold Taylor, president, told the Sarah Lawrence board of trustees this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -Following is the text of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's views on money needs of the foreing aid program, as expressed in a letter to Senator Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee:
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 8 -- William C. Horley, a vice president who has admitted embezzling $456,000 from the First Bank and Trust Company of Perth Amboy, collapsed late last night.

Alex Rose, state vice chairman of the Liberal party, charged last night that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, in their contest for the Republican nomination for President. were fighting for the right to deliver this country to the forces of reaction. He said neither could win.
Four children, two of them Mohawk Indians, received from Mayor Impellitteri at City Hall yesterday certificates of merit for excellence as members of Brooklyn settlement houses.

Shouting City College students stood or danced in front of cars and buses for more than two hours yesterday afternoon in a demonstration that halted traffic along Convent Avenue from 138th to 140th Streets.

Now that he has seen them all, A1 Lopez, the popular pilot of the Indians, is convinced that the Yankees are the best among Cleveland's seven rivals in the American league. He said so before yesterday's finale at the Stadium and repeated it even after the Indians had blasted the New Yorkers, 12 -- 5, for a sweep of the three-game series.

PARIS, May 8 -- Igor Stravinsky enjoyed a triumph of literally epochal significance tonight when the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Pierre Monteux conducting, performed his "Sacre du Printemps" before a wildly cheering audience in the Champs-Elysees Theatre, and history reversed itself.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- The Government agreed today to pay $8,500,000 to settle claims of six times that amount growing out of its World War II seizure of the trucking industry in the Midwest.

New York State "is backward" in its small loan laws, David D. Lichtenstein, executive vice president of the American Investment Company of Illinois, declared here yesterday at the spring meeting of the New York State Consumer Finance Association.
A union expelled from the Congress of Industrial Organizations for refusing to pay a sister union $4,000 in a "raiding" dispute is trying to get back into the C. I. O., it was learned yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 8 -- A "new approach" in a search for the "basic causes" of the increasing burden of mental disease was called for today by Brig. Gen. James Stevens Simmons, dean of the Harvard School of Public Health.
Marshall Houck has been made general sales manager of the American Safety Razor Company of Brooklyn.

The Federal Reserve Board has announced that it is suspending controls over installment buying. These controls, which have been administered under the board's Regulation W, represented the first actual move made by the Government in its effort to deal with the post-Korea inflation. By readying them in advance the Reserve Board was able to put them into effect Sept. 8, 1950, the day President Truman signed the Defense Production Act.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower told Congress today that the $1,000,000,000 cut in the Mutual Security authorization bill would be "heavily and seriously felt" and that a much greater reduction would require a drastic revision of existing European defense plans.

ATHENS, May 8 -- Five civilians and four policemen were injured, one seriously, in a demonstration today for the union of the British-held island of Cyprus with Greece. The demonstrations were at first forbidden by the Government but the ban was lifted under pressure from the Archbishop of Athens after police officials had said they could keep order.

Taking advantage of the removal of installment buying curbs by the Federal Reserve Board Wednesday, merchants throughout the country began yesterday to advertise "no down payments" for automobiles, television and radio sets and large household appliances like refrigerators and washing machines.

THE signing of Scotty Robb by the American League was a startling move. Up to a couple of days ago Scotty was an umpire in the National League. But he resigned in obvious protest at his public spanking by Warren Giles, the league president. His career seemed ended because no one dreamed that the American League would make goo-goo eyes in his direction and then embrace him.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Washington and Detroit played a 4-4 tie today in a contest suspended at the end of eleven innings to permit the Tigers to catch a train.
CAMP COOKE, Calif., May 8 (AP) -- Illinois' Forty-fourth Division today put on a gigantic military show for its Governor, who called it "the most memorable day of my life."

In recent years the Port of New York has been the object of more self-searching, analysis and criticism than in any similar period in many decades. Yet there has been no large-scale diversion of trade to other sea gateways, and rival ports need not assume that they are listening to the death rattle of a moribund competitor.

Proper application of "the scientific method in human relations" would bring about "a world of peace and contentment," it was asserted last night by Dr. Fred J. Emmerich, president of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation. He made the statement at a dinner of the American Institute of Chemists in the Commodore Hotel, at which he received the society's gold medal.

John Foster Dulles, former foreign policy adviser to the Department of State and author of the Japanese peace treaty, returned yesterday from Paris, where he conferred twice with General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and made a foreign policy speech.

ALBANY, May 8 -- A seldom used power to enforce collection of the state's tax on Diesel motor fuel was invoked today when the State Tax Commission suspended the license of a retail dealer near Buffalo.

President Truman said yesterday that the oil strike had not reached the point where he felt it necessary to consider an eighty-day injunction under the national emergency provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act.

Five new films will have local premieres today. "The Sniper," a psychological drama produced by Stanley Kramer for Columbia release, featuring Adolphe Menjou and Arthur Eranz, opens at the Criterion. Harry Brown wrote the screen play from a story by Edna and Edward Anhalt, who also served as associate producers. Edward Dmytryk directed.
People who live near airports haven't heard anything yet, experts warned here yesterday at a meeting of the Acoustical Society of America at the Statler Hotel.
TOKYO, Friday, May 9 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 53, for Thursday:

There are now in this city seven functioning headquarters of candidates for the Presidency. Three are for adherents of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, two for Senator Robert A. Taft, one for Senator Estes Kefauver and one for W. Averell Harriman, Director of Mutual Security.
PHILADELPHIA, May 8 (UP) -- Jim Rivera, returning to action after being benched for light hitting, smashed a homer in the ninth inning today to beat the Athletics for the Browns, 9 -- 8.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Active buying of wheat developed today on the Board of Trade, with substantial gains also registered by the coarse grains, rye and soybeans. Absorption of wheat and oats was based largely on the drought in the Northwest and western Canada, and apprehension that the Korean truce negotiations may be near the breaking-off point, because of the stubborn attitude of the Communists ever the exchange of prisoners.

The City of Buffalo, N. Y., borrowed yesterday $7,628,000 on bonds maturing serially from 1963 to 1981. The issue was purchased at sealed bidding by a syndicate headed by Chase National Bank at a bid of 100,0995 for interest of 1 1/2 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at yields ranging from 1.40 per cent to 1.90 per cent.

Witty Brothers, manufacturers and retailers of men's clothing, moving from 1400 Broadway, ground floor and basement in 1384 Broadway at W 38th St through Harris, Newmark Co, agents -- Joseph F. Bernstein, broker.

The third annual concert in memory of the distinguished American pianist and teacher, Olga Samaroff, was presented at Town Hall last night under the auspices of the Olga Samaroff Foundation. There was interesting music by capable musicians, and presumably the foundation, which seeks to help young musicians and to further the cause of the late Olga Samaroff's beloved art in this country, gained funds for its good works.

News came from London the other day that the University of Manchester is building a radio mirror 265 feet in diameter, the largest of its kind in the world. Nothing will be seen with this instrument, but much will be heard -- more than can be heard with Manchester's older 220-foot mirror. It seems that the sun and about a hundred invisible stars so far discovered are hissing at us.

TRENTON, May 8 -- The Republican State Convention adopted a campaign platform today after sharp debate over its foreign policy plank, which critics said was virtually an endorsement of "Truman-Acheson" policies.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 8 -- Housewives, white-collar workers, professional men and laborers of this community expressed indignation here this afternoon at a plan under which the average tax rate would be reduced by approximately two mills or, on existing properties, by about 4.5 per cent.

Rubber, which had been under severe pressure for two days, steadied yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Commission-house short-covering met speculative short-selling and the trade houses were inactive. The result was a close 15 to 35 points higher on volume of 1,280 tons.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said tonight he had offered to find for the Senate Elections subcommittee the "key witness" it needed for hearings starting Monday on the Senator's activities.

Furniture merchants are spurning place and show in the race being run constantly for the consumer dollar, and are out to win. The National Retail Furniture Association has just asked its more than 8,000 member stores throughout the country to get rid of their stocks as quickly as possible.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 9 (UP) -- The Government said today that information regarding prices and amounts of its copper sales in the world market will be withheld from the public for the time being.

LONDON, May 9 (Reuters) -- Representatives of forty-six countries, meeting here to discuss renewal of the International Wheat Agreement under which most of the world's exportable wheat is sold, are reported to have reached a deadlock on quantities and prices.

A 20-year-old youth who was able to leave an orphanage at Eddington, Pa., three years ago, when an executive of a magazine sales concern gave him a job selling magazines on commission, appeared yesterday in Mid-Manhattan court as complainant against his employer.

Once again generous New Yorkers are being asked to give of their means to the United Jewish Appeal to make possible another vast life-saving program of aid. Already justly proud of its record of constructive philanthropy, this agency must now provide relief, emigration assistance and other help to 1,000,000 distressed Jews in twenty countries.

Sammy Giuliani, Stamford, Conn., middleweight, marked his twentieth birthday last night at the St. Nicholas Arena by scoring a technical knockout over Johnny Williams of Montgomery, Ala. After flooring his foe for 9, Giuliani, 155 pounds, had Williams, 145 1/2, reeling from a two-fisted attack as the bell ended the fifth round.

I would like to comment on your editorial "Yugoslavia and Italy." First, a correction. Premier De Gasperi comes from the Province of Trento (German: Trient) and not from the region of Trieste. Secondly, I would like to ask why the 1946 peace treaty should be considered to be badly constructed because it gave Yugoslavia all the mountain territory overlooking the Venetian plain.

A $250,000 suit against the United States Government was filed in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday by Mrs. Alice Friedman as the result of the death of her husband, William S. Friedman, when a United States Air Force plane crashed into Long Island Sound on June 15, 1951.

BURLINGTON, Vt., May 9 -- Dr. Carl W. Borgmann, 47 years old, dean of faculties at the University of Nebraska, was named today as president of the University of Vermont. He will succeed Dr. William S. Carlson, who became president of the State University of New York April 1.
NEWARK, May 9 -- Three theatre employes were arrested here today for showing the documentary movie "Latuko."

VIENNA, May 9 -- What was described by the Prague radio as the "biggest military parade that Czechoslovakia has ever known" took place in Prague today. It was apparently intended to demonstrate how greatly Czechoslovakia had increased her armed strength with the Soviet Union's aid and how little truth existed in the recent Yugoslav contention that President Klement Gottwald was turning out to be another Tito.

Members of the alumnae associations of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart and of the Sacred Heart Academies in Greenwich and Noroton, Conn., and at 1 East Ninety-first Street, have arranged a tea dance for May 15 in the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of their philanthropic work.

Dr. Harold Lenz, Dean of Students at Queens College, who has stirred controversy over his outspoken political beliefs, has been relieved as dean, effective Sept. 1, and reassigned to a teaching position in the German Department of the college.

Paul B. Jones, a rookie policeman who was attached to District Attorney Miles F. McDonald's special rackets squad, was sentenced yesterday in Kings County Court by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz to a term of two and a half to five years in Sing Sing Prison.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina said yesterday that he probably would grant a Government motion to expand the complaint in the banking trial to include a charge that underwriting syndicate agreements are themselves illegal even if unrelated to other conspiracy.

James A. Moran, former First Deputy Fire Commissioner, lost a legal round yesterday in his battle for freedom when Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr. denied his application for a certificate of reasonable doubt and admission to bail.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Indian assimilation cannot be "hot-house forced," Darcy McNickle, project director of the National Congress of American Indians, told the Institute on American Indian Assimilation today.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 9 (AP) -- The Commerce Department's business advisory council gave Secretary Sawyer its advice today on price and wage controls: get rid of them.

The New York Telephone Company's net income for the first quarter this year declined about 3 per cent, or $463,756, to $13,953,265 from $14,417,021 in the initial three months last year, despite the nearly $12,100,000 gain in operating revenues.
SALEM, Ore., May 9 -- The Truman Administration drew a double attack from Republican Presidential aspirants today in the Oregon primary campaign. The state will vote next Friday.
The Public Service Commission authorized yesterday the fifth increase in passenger fares on the Long Island Rail Road since 1947.

PARIS, May 9 -- A gay midseason collection was shown by Carven yesterday morning. This designer who is known for her fashions that are young in spirit, devoted much attention to flower themes this season.

The lobby of "D" Building in the Veterans Administration Hospital, 130 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, became a gallery yesterday for about sixty patients there who have taken to the brush. The third annual art exhibit by hospitalized veterans, the show was attended by a number of the artists, their friends and families.
HAVANA, May 9 -- The National Bank of Cuba put into circulation today an issue of $5,000.000 in fractional currency to substitute for American coins which will be withdrawn from circulation.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, reported today that Harry Gross, New York bookmaker, filed no Federal income tax returns for 1949 or 1950 or for years prior to 1946.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP) -- Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, today introduced a resolution to set up a ten-member commission to study and streamline Senate rules.

Four new films will arrive at first-run theatres over the weekend. Today's offerings are headed by "The Wild North," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer outdoor adventure in Ansco color, with Stewart Granger, Wendell Corey and Cyd Charisse, at Loew's State.

CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- Striking thoroughbred owners, who shut down Sportsman's Park this week, today rejected a purse distribution offer by officials of Lincoln Fields which is scheduled to open a thirty-day meeting at Hawthorne Park Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Irked by the failure or refusal of Federal officials and others to testify on strike control legislation, a member of the House Armed Services Committee suggested today that the committee subpoena Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, and Philip B. Perlman, acting Attorney General, if they continued a "sitdown strike" against the hearings.

A nine-acre portion of the former Pierre DeLalio farm opposite the Grumman Aircraft Company plant on the Hicksville-Massapequa Road in Bethpage, L. I., has been sold by George V. Spohrer to Bethpage Industrial Builders, Inc., for improvement with one-story factory buildings on two-acre plots.
SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, May 10 (AP) -- Allied fighter-bombers yesterday carried their relentless rail-busting offensive almost to the Manchurian border, shrugging off a Red jet attempt to interfere.
The fatal stabbing of a 15-year-old high school girl by her 30-year-old married suitor threw mid-afternoon crowds at Thirty-fourth Street and Seventh Avenue into a ferment yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Ammunition supplies in Korea although rationed, are adequate for current operations. Frank Pace, Secretary of the Army, reported today. He warned, however, that there was no assurance the situation would continue.

Although I am certainly not a supporter of Senator Taft, I must agree strongly in principle with the letter of E. A. Kracke printed in your column recently. Mr. Kracke states, quite correctly, that you have appealed for support of General Eisenhower for President before he has made his views known, telling the voters in effect to nominate him first and let him express his opinions on matters of current interest and controversy later.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 10 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,245, covering Friday's activities:

The impressive fight made by Senator Estes Kefauver in the recent Presidential popularity primary in Florida has convinced him that the South is swinging away from its traditional sectionalism and merging with the national democratic attitude, former Senator Claude Pepper of Florida said yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 9 -- A parent who becomes unduly disturbed when his child reaches a certain age may be unconsciously reliving the loss of his own parent which occurred when he was that age, Dr. Josephine Hilgard, Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at Stanford University, declared today.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday put off until late June a hearing to determine whether the licenses of' the International Boxing Club should be revoked or suspended for alleged acts detrimental to boxing in this state.

" I HAVE really a bump of reverence and love to worship heroes," young George du Maurier, first in a notable family of professional romantics, wrote a friend ninety years ago this summer, "but think, on the whole, that I do not care to mix with them."

Samuel Reshevsky of New York, winner of his match for the championship of the non-Communistic world with Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires, increased his margin yesterday by winning the sixteenth of the series, according to a report from San Salvador.

District Attorney Miles F. McDonald defended his office and the Kings County rackets grand jury yesterday for their failure to take punitive action against the high police officials named by Harry Gross as recipients of his bookmaking graft.

The decision by the Government to flatten out the defense program brings a "steadier plateau" into view, materially lessening inflationary pressures and adding to the stability of the economy, L. M. Cassidy, chairman of the board of the Johns-Manville Corporation, said at the annual meeting yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The nomination of Federal Judge James P. McGranery of Pennsylvania to be Attorney General was approved today by the Senate Judiciary Committee. The vote was 8 to 4.
NEWARK, May 9 (AP) -- A joint $9,000,000 suit to collect damages suffered in the South Amboy munitions explosion was filed today against the Federal Government by more than 8,000 claimants.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9 -- The police of this city today consented to the withdrawal of a complaint charging Prof. Frederick G. Fassett Jr., associate dean of students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, with "disturbing the peace" last Monday night during a student demonstration at Radcliffe College.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The McCarran Bill, designed to revise and codify the immigration and naturalization laws, appeared tonight to face one of the Senate's hardest and longest fights in years, unless it was returned to committee for reconsideration and hearings that also would cover a rival measure.

One of the turf's famous mile races, the Withers, will have its seventy-seventh running in Belmont Park today. Ten 3-year-olds are entered in the $25,000 added test. If all go, the race will be worth $22,250 to the winner.

Ruling that Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman had acted as both judge and prosecutor and thus denied the defendants a fair trial, the United States Court of Appeals yesterday reversed the convictions and sent back for retrial the case of two men charged with fraudulently collecting money through the mails for cancer victims.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 9 (AP) The General Electric Company says it will divide its military electronics work into two operating units -- one at Syracuse and the other at Utica and New Hartford -- because of expanding business.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- An invention to protect ships, buildings and their occupants from radioactive poisons, war gases and heat waves was patented this week. It employs a series of umbrella-like screens of water that are pumped up from a deep and uncontaminated source and are charged with electricity.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set May 22 as the date for a hearing on the bond and common-stock financing proposal of the Northern States Power Company of Minneapolis.

CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- The Washington-Detroit game yesterday, called after eleven innings with the score tied, 4 -- 4, to permit the Tigers to catch a train, is not a suspended game and must be replayed entirely. Will Harridge, American League president, said today.

PARIS, May 9 -- The draft treaty to create a European Defense Community with a combined force administered by a "supranational" authority was initialed here today by experts representing France, Italy, West Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

PARIS, May 9 -- What purported to be a report of Admiral William F. Fechteler, United States Chief of Naval Operations, contending that war with the Soviet Union was inevitable before 1960 and that Europe might be overrun in three days, was published today by Le Monde, a leading Paris newspaper.
RICHMOND, Va., May 9 (AP) -- The Southern Conference couldn't agree today on whether it should permit member football teams to play games before the formal opening of their autumn terms.

PARIS, May 9 -- A joint statement issued today by the United States Embassy and the Mutual Security Agency seemed to take issue with Rene Pleven, the French Defense Minister, regarding additional United States aid to the French defense program.
A man who apparently went berserk at a New York University block party early today was shot and killed by a university special officer trying to maintain order.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Staff experts of the Armed Services Committee of the House of Representatives calculated today the exact pay and allowances for members of the armed forces as they would be authorized by the compromise pay increase bill agreed on yesterday by conferees from the Senate and the House.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today last year's tobacco crop was worth $1,190,920,000 which was $142,417,000 above the 1950 yield.

In the best traditions of the Hatfields and the McCoys, Joseph P. Ryan and Anthony Anastasia yesterday laid down their "shootin' irons," bringing to an apparent end the long-smoldering feud that threatened to result in open warfare on this port's docks.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Government issued an order today to operators of bulk gasoline plants, terminals and large filling stations in thirty-two Eastern and Central states and the District of Columbia to reserve supplies of motor gasoline for possible allocation to maintain essential transportation.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Following is a communique issued by the United States, Britain and Italy, together with a memorandum of understanding among the three powers reached at London today concerning the administration of Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste:

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 9 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, top-ranked tennis star from Philadelphia, advanced to the final round of the men's singles and doubles and the mixed doubles of the Coral Beach invitation tournament today.
DETROIT, May 9 (UP) -- The White Sox pushed across three runs in the sixteenth inning today to defeat the Tigers, 8 to 5, in a 4-hour 27-minute game that saw 34 players in action.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 9 -- A controversial Pieta, or figure of the Virgin Mary mourning over the dead Christ, reputed to be the work of Michelangelo and carrying a million-dollar price tag, has been impounded here by the United States Treasury Department.

George Abbott has been offered the directorial assignment for "Only Human," the comedy by Harry Garson and Edward Beloin dealing with the complications that arise when an American movie star, on vacation in Italy, decides to make a picture with an eccentric Italian director.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- Two bills raising benefit payments to veterans by $202,000,000 a year were passed today by the Senate. The measures now go to the White House.

ST. LOUIS, May 9 (AP) -- The Reds, scoreless for six innings, broke out with seven runs in the seventh tonight against Wilmer (Vinegar Ben) Mizell and defeated the Cardinals, 8 to 3, to move into undisputed third place in the National League race.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The United States, Britain and France prodded the Soviet Union today for a reply to the three-power request of March 13 for the adoption of an abbreviated treaty for Austria. A State Department official on making the announcement charged that the Soviet role in the Austria negotiations had been a "classic study of Soviet obstructionism and procrastination."

BUFFALO, May 9 -- Counsel for Carl G. LoDolce, accused of the murder of his superior officer, Maj. William V. Holohan, behind enemy lines in Italy in 1944, charged today that the Army was making confidential documents available to the Italian government but denying them to his client.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee was told today that Jack L. Cowart, recently convicted of accepting money illegally from a private concern while employed in the Production and Marketing Administration, collected some hidden fees through Alex Campbell, former high Justice Department official.

EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Korea, Saturday, May 10 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet threatened last night to use force "at an early date" if Communist prisoners of war holding Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd as a hostage did not release the general.

LONDON, May 9 -- The National Committee of the Amalgamated Engineering Union, Britain's third largest, unanimously voted today a resolution expressing concern at Britain's present rearmament burden and calling for a peace pact among the five great powers -- The United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China.

BONN, Germany, May 9 -- This will be a week-end of decision for West Germany. Tomorrow Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, his Cabinet and the Parliamentary leaders of the three parties of the coalition Government begin three days of meetings in which they will decide whether the Government can accept the contractual agreement with the United States, Britain and France.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved an increase of 6 per cent in all transcontinental motor carrier rates.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast this year's winter wheat crop at 986,468,000 bushels, the third largest of record. This estimate is 39,623,000 bushels more than the 946,845,000 bushels forecast a month ago.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- The grain list had a reactionary trend on the Board of Trade today, yesterday's upturn being halted by free profit-taking, while there was a disposition by wheat traders to even up over the Government's May crop report scheduled for announcement after the close.
Five of the recently opened art exhibitions in New York galleries provide highly diverse interest.
With only two matches remaining in the Women's Metropolitan interclub team contests, no district leader has a clear-cut margin after play yesterday.
Fireman Edmund J. Knoblich pleaded guilty yesterday at a departmental hearing on charges of shaking down a Bronx merchant while serving as aide to former Deputy Chief Nathan Perlman.
Engineers put away their slide rules for a while yesterday and lifted the curtain for a peek at a few of their new products.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 9 -- France told the Soviet Union today that the Western powers were strong enough now to prevent any new "military promenades" and could not be split politically by Moscow.

PARIS, May 9 -- Return to a regime of classic freedom in international trade -- with free convertability of currencies, lowering of tariff barriers and suppression of import and export quotas -- was advocated today by commissions of he International Chamber of Commerce here.

Now that the better weather is here, at least until the next raw day, the season is one for the week-end. As the theory runs, it is invigorating to get into the country for a few days, to kick clods of the good, rich earth or to wander along yet uncrowded beaches, gathering shells, health, repose and high-test oxygen.

LONDON, May 9 -- Without yielding anything to Italian aspirations of sovereignty over Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste, Britain and the United States announced here today that an agreement had been reached to give Italy a larger share in the Zone A civil administration.

The discovery that mother's milk contains a factor mostly absent in cow's milk, together with studies indicating that this newly found human milk factor may endow breast-fed infants with a higher resistance to certain virus diseases, including polio, was reported yesterday by a team of scientists of the University of Pennsylvania.
The stock market fell into a vacuum yesterday with price changes narrow and volume at its second lowest for a full day since October, 1949.
BALTIMORE, May 9 (UP) -- High Ground Stable's Comte de Grasse and Maine Chance Farm's Jet A Dandy were withdrawn today from the Preakness Stakes on May 17. Both were supplemental nominees.

Hot dogs and corn-on-the-cob vied with pizza pie and German weiners yesterday for the attention of visitor to Brooklyn College's big city style "country fair." International attractions were mixed with native American treats as the college turned its athletic field into a gala carnival site in celebration of its twenty-second birthday.

PARIS, May 9 -- The announcement by the Communist weekly newspaper Action that it will cease publication with the number issued today marks a new decline in the activities of the Communist press in France.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 9 (AP) -- Ed (Porky) Oliver ate lunch while most of the other Greenbrier Open golfers played during the worst of a rain storm, then finished in the sun to hold his lead in the second round todady.
LONDON, May 9 -- The stock markets remained inactive today. Only South African gold shares were able to establish a better tone.

OSLO, Norway, May 9 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower expressed delight today at the news that the European six-power defense treaty draft had been initialed. At a press conference here he said inclusion among the signatories of West Germany "on a self-respecting basis" was especially encouraging for Western unity and security.

The Richfield Oil Corporation reported yesterday in its quarterly statement covering the first three months of this year a net income of $5,689,359 after all deductions, compared with $6,938,987 earned in the corresponding quarter a year ago.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The National Trust for Historic Preservation, chartered three years ago by Congress, opened to the public today Woodlawn Plantation, the first historic monument for which the trust has assumed responsibility.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 9 -- Two gunners competing in the forty-third annual Amateur Championships of America trapshoot at Travers Island today scored perfect 100's in the preliminary event that opened the meet. They continued their flawless work with seventy-five more hits in three subsequent shoot-offs.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- An Air Force crew, flying near the top of the world, has discovered a supply cache left by Rear Admiral Robert E. Peary during his polar expeditions in the early Nineteen Hundreds.
LONDON, May 9 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force called off squadron training at home and abroad today because of the oil strike in the United States. Jet fighter units were excepted.

Confidence of United States exporters in doing business with Chile was shaken yesterday with news that the South American country's April 24 stoppage of non-licensed imports payable in dollars will include prior orders covered by confirmed letters of credit. Exemption of these orders had been confidently expected here.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Average primary market prices rose 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index, 111.3 per cent of 1947-49 average, was 3.2 per cent below the average for January, 1951, and 0.9 per cent below the level of the latest comprehensive index -- March, 1952.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 10 -- Communist delegates discussing an armistice in the Korean war at Panmunjom charged today that the United Nations Command planned a "massacre" to rescue Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd, captured and held hostage by North Korean prisoners on Koje Island, off the south coast of Korea.

KEARNY, N. J., May 9 -- The Manchester United team, English League champion, opened its North American tour by gaining a 4-0 victory over a combination of talent from two of the strongest clubs in the American Soccer League -- the Kearny Scots and the Newark Portuguese -- at the High School Stadium tonight.

MEXICO CITY, May 9 -- After a record-shattering 64, Tommy Bolt of Durham, N. C., fired a 4-over-par 76 in the second round of the $15,000 Pan-American Open golf championship today and had to share the halfway lead at 140 with Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, May 10 -- An American general held captive for three days by tough North Korean prisoners of war on Koje Island has asked the Eighth Army not to attempt his rescue by force until full Communist demands are made known.

A 45-year-old woman was the first patient to be discharged officially by Sea View Hospital as a result of having undergone treatment with the new anti-tuberculosis drugs, it was learned yesterday. She left the municipal institution on Staten Island a week ago.

Events today Raoul Laparra Memorial Concert, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; All-Gershwin Concert, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; New York Mandolin Symphony, Town Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Dante Alighieri Music Festival, Smith Auditorium, Manhattan College, 8:30 P. M.; City College Symphony Orchestra and Chorus, Great Hall, City College, 8:30 P. M.; New York University Glee Club, University Heights Symphony Orchestra, Gould Memorial Library, 8:30 P. M.

WHITEVILLE, N. C., May 9 -- Closing arguments began this afternoon in the trial of five men accused in the Ku Klux Klan flogging of Woodrow Johnson, Whiteville mechanic, with indications the jury would get the case around noon tomorrow.
LOUISVILLE, May 9 (AP) -- Hill Gail, the Kentucky Derby winner was declared out of the Preakness today because of an ankle condition.

The Jewish Labor Committee's new headquarters, the Atran Center for Jewish Culture, a five-story building at 25 East Seventy-eighth Street, was formally opened last night before leading labor officials.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 9 -- The Connecticut Light and Power Company completed today before the State Public Utilities Commission the presentation of its technical case for the building of a great new generating station in this city. Hearings are to be resumed July 8, when the City of Stamford will present witnesses opposed to the project.

Charles H. Silver, vice president of the American Woolen Company, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri as a member of the Board of Education to succeed James Marshall. The ceremony was held in the Board of Estimate chamber at City Hall in the presence of an audience of 350 persons, many of them prominent in the city's business, financial, civic and political circles.

Steve Dillon added nearly nine feet to his own meet record in the hammer throw, then placed second to Columbia's Albert Thompson in the discus yesterday at Baker Field, as Manhattan's favored defenders got a jump on six rivals in the nineteenth annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate track and field championships.

Justice Eugene L. Brisach of the Supreme Court ordered arbitration yesterday in the $3,000,000 suit brought against the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Elias Simadiris, a banquet waiter who alleged the hotel had withheld that sum in tips over a period or six years from him and 100 other waiters.
Only one book is published today. It is "Study of the Bible in the Middle Ages," by Beryl Smalley, which the Philosophical Library is issuing at $7.50.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, today praised seven boy and girl school safety-patrol members who risked their lives to save classmates from possible death.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Administration's chief military and foreign policy spokesmen told the Senate Armed Services Committee today they would not accept responsibility for any substantial cut in the $7,900,000,000 requested for the Mutual Security Program in the 1953 fiscal year beginning July 1.

With all of the official proclamations issued during the year in honor of anniversaries and fund drives for the large number of worthy causes which we are glad to support each year, it is entirely fitting that there be an official tribute to an industry in which we take pride.

A line drive from the bat of Billy Goodman rammed against Johnny Sain's right knee in the second inning of yesterday's Stadium clash between the Yankees and Red Sox. Sprays of ethyl chloride and between-inning ice packs enabled the right-hander to continue until the pain forced him out at the start of the eighth.

A single organization of all retail merchants, covering the dry goods, grocery and other fields, was recommended last night at the annual dinner of Long Island University's department of retailing. The proposal was made by Max Hess Jr., Allentown, Pa., retailer, who said such a move would strengthen the position of retailers. He also predicted a record increase in retail sales in the last quarter of the year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 9 -- Alvin Manuel, Hollywood literary agent, is organizing a motion-picture producing company in London with financial backing by a syndicate of British investors composed of members with interests in the movies and in unrelated businesses.

With something like $3,000,000,000 to spend this year in the New York area, the armed forces are devoting next week to showing the small business man that it is neither necessary for him to make a trip to Washington nor to hire a "five per center" to secure either prime contracts or subcontracts.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 9 -- The United Nations' Narcotics Commission ended its seventh session tonight after refusing a final Soviet attempt to reply once again to charges that Chinese Communists and North Koreans had smuggled heroin into Japan.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP) -- A rise in retail food price ceilings was reported imminent today, and Ellis Arnall, Director of Price Stabilization, warned that living costs might show a "marked increase" unless Congress tightened the controls law.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 9 -- Large-scale unemployment has appeared in the principal cities and industrial area of Yugoslavia for the first time since the war.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., May 9 -- Young people today are optimistic about the future despite the doubts, fears and problems that beset the free world and, moreover, they are willing to accept their individual responsibilities in helping to solve the problems, a panel of high school students agreed today at the weekly youth forum of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Rubber, plastics and synthetic rubber, with a common meeting ground in chemistry, "are growing closer and closer together economically and technically to a point where it is impossible to pull them apart," it was asserted here by John P. Coe, vice president and general manager of the Naugatuck chemical division of the United States Rubber Company.

ROME, May 9 -- Premier Alcide De Gasperi personally announced to a couple of hundred Italian and foreign newspaper men this afternoon the successful conclusion of the London negotiations for giving Italy a larger share in the administration of Zone A, the United States-British zone, of the Free Territory of Trieste.

CHICAGO, May 9 (UP) -- The National Association of Real Estate Boards charged today that what it called the "political public housing" program advocated by President Truman takes "a long step towards communism."
The apartment house at 908 Kelly Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by Peter I. Feinberg, operator, through Morice Haymes, brokers. Charles Rubman, attorney, acted for the buyer.

The sixteen-story apartment house for ninety-three families on plot 93 by 100 feet at 710 West End Avenue, near Ninety-fourth Street, has been sold for cash by the Carmenia Corporation, H. Axelrod, president, to Knepper Levin, operators.

Paul G. and Gertrude Haass have sold the four-story apartment house accommodating forty-seven families at 325 Marine Avenue, Brooklyn, to Max Zamore, Charles Metz and Isidor Wollan. The property, on a plot 115 by 122 feet, is assessed at $151,000.
" Uncle" Moe retired yesterday. And 500 fifth and sixth graders, parents and teachers cheered as they never had cheered before. Public School 64 in the Bronx was saying good-by to an old friend.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use about the home.

The appointment of J. Paul Austin and Alexander Makinsky as vice presidents of the Coca-Cola Export Corporation has been announced. Mr. Austin, formerly assistant to the president, was named vice president, was named vice president and assistant to the president, with headquarters here. Mr. Makinsky of Paris, was named vice president in charge of Continental Europe -- with headquarters in Paris.
BERLIN, Saturday, May 10 -- This city seemed today to be due for a new spell of "blockade jitters."

Many Italian-Americans, when they wish to dine magnificently in the Italian style, journey up Route 32 to Newburgh and the restaurant of Umberto Lacagnino. The attraction is not the decor of this simple roadside establishment, but rather the superb cooking of Umberto.

BAYONNE, N. J., May 9 -- The senior surviving officer of the destroyer-minesweeper Hobson told a Navy board of inquiry today that his skipper changed course suddenly from right rudder to left rudder a few minutes before the Hobson was struck and sunk by the aircraft carrier Wasp.
COLUMBIA, Mo., May 9 (AP) -- The University of Missouri presented six medals of honor for distinguished service in journalism at a special Journalism Week convocation this afternoon.

Today, seventeen months after the close of the Midcentury White House Conference on Children and Youth, held in early December, 1950, activity and interest stimulated by the gathering are still growing, Leonard W. Mayo said yesterday.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 9 -- A New York National Guard trophy to be awarded annually to the outstanding West Point cadet company in summer field training exercises was presented today to the United States Military Academy and the corps of cadets.

The question of foreign domination of the policies of the Communist party of the United States arose yesterday during the cross-examination of Louis F. Budenz at the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders.

Sugar futures traders paid little attention to developments in the spot market yesterday. After the close on Thursday 3,000 tons of Philippines due at the end of May sold at 6.2 cents a pound, duty free. Yesterday a cargo of Cuban for shipment in the latter half of June went to New Orleans on a 5.75-cent basis.
Charles W. Wood has been made vice president and general manager of the Aimcee Wholesale Corporation.

CAIRO, May 9 -- The Rockefeller Foundation, now finishing four and one-half years of painstaking study of the health problems of the Egyptian peasant, has found what its representatives regard as most encouraging signs of a revolt by the peasants against their heritage of disease and early death.

ACCORDING to the Ducks Unlimited survey of the Canadian breeding grounds, surface water conditions are excellent in all three provinces of the great "duck factory" and the continuation of normal weather should insure another excellent nesting and rearing season.

The thirtieth anniversary of the Hymn Society of America will be celebrated next week-end by Protestants and Roman Catholics. A compilation of more than thirty hymns composed in this country has been arranged for use in the programs that will be held.

Most commuters say they couldn't even afford to be living in the suburbs if they weren't working in the city. It's a way of saying that there are more jobs, better jobs and greater opportunities for advancement wherever business is most con centrated.

HEWLETT, L. I., May 9 -- Don Cherry of Wichita Falls, Tex., who has found the dunes of the windswept Seawane Harbor course to his liking, gained the semi-finals of the Long Island Golf Association's William D. Richardson Memorial Tourney today with another spurt of sub-par golf.
Travel clothes that double for many occasions and can be packed with never a wrinkle were presented by Oppenheim Collins last night at the Ambassador Hotel.

ATHENS, May 9 -- Greek and Turkish land and naval forces will come under the command of Admiral Robert B. Carney without an intermediary. The admiral, North Atlantic Treaty commander for Southern Europe, announced his regional command this afternoon as he boarded a plane that would take him back to his headquarters in Naples after a three-day visit in Athens, Crete and Salonika.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 9 -- The power of prayer was credited here today with settling a strike of 1,000 employes in a ball-bearing manufacturing plant after two weeks of effort by Federal and state mediators.
LONDON, May 9 (AP) -- Laborites said tonight they had dealt the Conservatives their worst local election defeat since World War II.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., investment banking concern, before the Interstate Commerce Commission today opposed an application of Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company for exemption from an I.C.C. rule that requires competitive bidding for the sale of railroad securities.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department said today harvesting of early potatoes should be of considerable volume by the end of the month.

The woods were so full of birdwatchers you couldn't have spotted an ostrich in red suspenders at Central Park yesterday. Sixty bird fanciers from P. S. 612, of 113 East Eighty-seventh Street, bent on an errand of mercy, entered the park at exactly 1 P. M.

The draft treaty creating a European army, known as the European Defense Community, was initialed yesterday in Paris. The formal agreement marked the end of a period of negotiation which lagged and stalled because the negotiators were always of two minds. They were afraid to go forward and afraid to hold back.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (AP) -- Bobby Shantz, the Athletics' five-foot six-inch southpaw, pitched a six-hit, 9-3 triumph over the Senators tonight while gaining his fourth victory of the year and first over the Senators since 1949. The Philadelphia triumph snapped a six-game Washington winning streak and was marked by Gus Zermal's second home run of the season that highlighted a four-run fifth inning against Bob Porter-field.

JERSEY CITY, May 9 -- With a Congressional investigation of the Port of New York Authority scheduled to start next Wednesday morning in Washington, auditors representing this municipality will begin a study of the Port Authority's financial records on Monday morning, it was announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (AP) -- A process that does away with the crucible in melting metal was described here today by research engineers of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. In the new technique, a lump of metal is suspended in space by an electromagnetic field while electric currents are shot through the lump, melting it.

A Senate Labor subcommittee majority has filed for Government publication its report on an investigation of labor-management relations in five Southern textile mills. The document will prove a highly controversial one, for it deals largely with charges of "union busting" in the South, and it has already evoked a vigorous dissent from Senators Taft and Nixon.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The following table, based on figures supplied by the House Armed Services Committee, shows the present rates of pay and allowances for members of the armed forces (naval personnel in parenthesis) compared with the rates authorized in the pending compromise pay increase bill. The figures are based on an average length of service for indicated grade:
Since this is election time for many women's organizations, those assuming new responsibilities will have special interest in a recently published book:

Institutional advertising of a public service nature, the fastest-growing classification in the business is the most efficient builder of good-will, Samuel C. Gale, vice president in charge of advertising for General Mills, Inc., said yesterday.

OTTAWA, May 9 (AP) -- C. E. S. Smith, Canadian Director of Immigration, said today that Dr. W. E. B. DuBois, United States Negro author and teacher, and his wife had been sent back to the United States from Toronto for refusing to undergo an examination.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Recognition of the need to expand and strengthen the contract tool and die industry hand in hand with the development of the machine tool industry is now clearly established in the defense program, it was said today by Franz Stone, deputy administrator of the National Production Administration.

OTTAWA, May 9 -- Concern over the uncertainties of rubber production, consumption and price has led the International Rubber Study Group to establish a special committee to consider what measures are necessary and practicable to prevent burdensome surpluses or serious shortages.

Scores of travelers, Europe-bound from Canada, are shuttling from Halifax to New York by ship because they are unable to obtain visas permitting them to travel through this country to reach their ships here, it became known yesterday.

GENEVA, May 9 -- The growing interest in Congress and in influential private groups in the potentialities of United States procurement in Europe as a technique of accomplishing the purposes of the Mutual Security Program is up against a tough and purely American problem. The American Army does not like buying things abroad.
Your editorial of May 3 entitled "Sub Judice" and relating to national emergency disputes prompts me to submit the following for the consideration of "the court of public opinion."

Recreating the days of speakeasies, flaming youth and easy money, the senior class at Hunter College, led by Jeanne Kilpatrick, won top honors for its interpretation of the "Roaring Twenties" yesterday at the college's thirty-sixth annual inter-class song competition, Sing.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Against the background of a beautiful spring day, the Andrew W. Mellon Memorial Fountain was dedicated and presented to the nation this afternoon.
OSLO, Norway, May 9 (AP) -- General Eisenhower tonight reaffirmed his intention "not to campaign for the Presidential nomination."

The two-story garden apartments known as Colfax Manor Gardens at Roselle and Colfax Avenues in Roselle Park, N. J., have been sold by Lieb Schwartz to Mayflower Estates. The property, on a five-acre tract, contains 192 apartments.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 9 (AP) -- Premier Wilopo today pledged his five-week-old Government to a rigidly independent foreign policy and indicated he would seek to water down military pledges the previous Indonesian Government made to the United States in return for aid under the Mutual Security Act.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 9 -- The United Nations Commission to investigate conditions for free elections in Germany reported today that it had not been able to carry out its task. It explained that the authorities in Eastern Germany had not even answered its letters but said that the Commission would stand by in Geneva to await developments.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., May 9 (AP) -- This resort and industrial city of 90,000 dismissed more than 600 of its hourly paid workers today under a state law prohibiting strikes by public employes.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 9 (AP) -- Premier Wilopo today pledged his five-week-old Government to a rigidly independent foreign policy and indicated he would seek to water down military pledges the previous Indonesian Government made to the United States in return for aid under the Mutual Security Act.
