It explained that the authorities in Eastern Germany had not even answered its letters but said that the Commission would stand by in Geneva to await developments.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., May 9 (AP) -- This resort and industrial city of 90,000 dismissed more than 600 of its hourly paid workers today under a state law prohibiting strikes by public employes.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- President Truman and Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Ambassador of the Philippines, installed a new herd of mahogany water buffaloes in the lobby of the White House executive offices today.

The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations is now coming up with three plans -- or three variations of the same plan -- to organize food resources and surpluses in such a way that famine can be effectively fought. What is proposed is the regulation and financing of storage of food products so that supplies can be moved quickly to deficit areas.

RIGHT from the start Ray Robinson expressed a profound disinterest in a match with Joey Maxim for the light heavyweight championship. When George Gainford, his manager of record, stoutly declared that Sugar Ray would fight Pal Joey, the middleweight king remarked "Let George do it."
ST. LOUIS, May 10 (AP) -- Del Rice drove in three runs and Cliff Chambers pitched steadily tonight as the Cardinals broke a three-game losing streak, beating the Reds and Ewell Blackwell, 5 to 3.

The discussion of what should or should not be cut from the proposed appropriation of $7,900,000,000 for foreign aid makes it necessary to return to an appraisal of the whole "mutual security" plan and program. This is not, or should not be, a mere pork-barrel proposal from which given items or fixed percentages can be trimmed at will and at political convenience.

A program of music by the late Raoul Laparra was presented yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. M. Laparra, born in 1876, was a pupil of Massenet and Faure, and won a Prix de Rome in 1903. He was killed during the second World War in a bombing of strategic points in Paris.

THE current season on Broadway is a much more important season than most of us have realized, but the reasons are not surface reasons. There has been a lack of new writing for the theatre. In some ways this is good, since it forces (a) a re-examination of current values and (b) a digging into the recent past.
CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- Bob Hush hurled a four-hitter and Ransom Jackson belted his fifth homer today as the Cubs defeated the floundering Pirates, 3 -- 1.

SEATTLE, May 10 (AP) -- Betsy Rawls of Austin, Tex., chopped five strokes off woman's par with a 70 today and pulled even with Babe Didrikson Zaharias in the quest for the women's Weathervane golf championship.
ON National Hospital Day, which is tomorrow, a million women in red will be helping to keep the nation's hospitals in the black.
SALT LAW CITY, Utah, May 10 -- Senator Kefauver gave a forty-minute keynote address in which he took cognizance of flood conditions in Utah that had delayed the arrival of some convention delegates.

Sociologists have proved that scientists and artists respond unwittingly to the aspirations and the reasoning of the world in which they live. It is no accident that Italian artists of the fifteenth century painted many madonnas and saints, or that Louis XV danced the minuet and not the waltz.

A forecast of increased efficiency in machines through the use of extremely high temperatures was made last week by Dr. Paul Schwarzkopf, president of the American Electro Metal Corporation of Yonkers.

PARIS, May 10 -- During the recess of the National Assembly Premier Antoine Pinay has completed all preliminaries of the three-fold program he proposed as bulwarks of his campaign for the defense of the franc.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 10 -- Sam Snead went through the rain and mud on his home course in 5 under par today to gain a 3-stroke lead with 18 holes to play in the Greenbrier Open.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., May 10 -- The Hill School took two of the three athletic contests with its traditional rival, Lawrenceville, before an alumni week-end crowd today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 10 -- Striking Chilean copper miners, employes of subsidiaries of Anaconda Copper of the United States, agreed tonight to return to work Tuesday. About 10,000 men of the Chuquicamata and Potrerillos workings had been out for two weeks on pay-rise demands.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 10 -- The congregation of the First Presbyterian Church voted this week to start preparations for a new edifice, a project that has been in mind for nearly ten years.

Jacob Blaustein, president of the American Jewish Committee, called on the American people and American organizations last night to encourage and activate democratic forces within Germany to counteract "German reaction, chauvinism and racialism."

HOUSTON, Text., May 10 (AP) -- A nation-wide strike in the oil industry is something everybody could feel. But how much one feels it, whether one will, and how -- that is something that hinges on too many questions. But it depends mostly on one question. How long the strike ?

The seventy-fifth anniversary of the Ethical Culture Schools was celebrated last week in a testimonial dinner given to Herbert A. Wolff, former president of the New York Society for Ethical Culture. The anniversary also marked the launching of the Fieldston-Ethical Fund for the maintenance of their extensive scholarship program.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (UP) -- Jackie Jensen singled to left field after a two-out ninth inning muff of a pop-fly by Ferris Fain filled the bases today to give the Senators a 3-1 victory over the Athletics.

PARIS, May 10 -- The report attributed to Admiral William M. Fechteler, United States Chief of Naval Operations, but repudiated by him after the publication of extracts from it in the Paris newspaper Le Monde yesterday, was conspicuously reproduced and commented on in most of the French press today.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -Mr. McGrath added an unusual touch tonight to the dinner after the skit lampooning his relations with President Truman.
Three Columbia crews that hadn't won a race all season came through handsomely on the Harlem River yesterday.

Evidence assembled in the fatal shooting of a New York University night student who went berserk at a Student Union Week block party in Washington Place early yesterday will be presented to a grand jury.

HAD you been in Haiti the Saturday before Easter you would have seen, along the roads that wind up into the mountains, women in kerchiefs of shrill color and men in bright sequins and satins, their dark faces powdered and rouged, forming into processions propelled by a swaying, prancing, lilting step, with an occasional individual moving somnambulantly in zombie-trance.

NO "rule" of bridge playing is more thoroughly learned by the average player than this one: dummy's trumps are best used for ruffing; declarer's trumps should be hoarded and used for ruffing only when necessary.

WILD plants serve a definite purpose in the conservation of soil and water. Their roots keep the soil from washing away and, by completing their life cycle, they build up the earth and make it more productive.

Prices steady and activity limited -- that was the story in security markets last week as traders continued to pursue a cautious course. Major commodity markets, however, exhibited strength during most of the week.

MAY is a month of great activity in the garden. Two of the most important jobs to be done in both flower and vegetables plots are thinning and transplanting. These chores take time, but they are essential to the full development of seed-grown plants.

A broad eight-week survey course designed to acquaint American students with the peoples and problems of the Near East will begin June 23 at the University of Michigan. The special program in Near Eastern studies is to survey the area's history, ancient and modern, its geography, cultural and political development, economic conditions, languages and laws.

BONN, Germany, May 10 -- The United States is about to start broadcasting to the Soviet people in Russian from a powerful transmitter in Munich. The first broadcast, as part of a program of the Voice of America, is expected to take place later this month, probably the night of May 22.

BY virtue of many assets -- brilliant and secure recording, idiomatic performance, rhythmic drive, aristocracy of style -- the performance by Artur Rubinstein of six Chopin Polonaises, the Fantasy-Polonaise and the Andante Spianato and Polonaise can head any current round-up of piano disks.

Asparagus, once planted, sends up spears for cutting spring after spring. Roots set out this year will yield a small harvest next May, a larger one the second year and thereafter may be cut as fast as the fresh new shoots appear during May and June.

NEW YORK STATE'S automobile owners are to be made aware this year of the need for guarding highway safety in more ways than one. The big reminder will come soon, and where it hurts most -- in the pocketbook.
TONOPAH, Nev., May 10 (AP) -Nevada Republicans elected a presidential nominating slate today, giving a strong advantage to Senator Robert A. Taft over General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 10 -- The visit yesterday by Jean Letourneau, French Minister Resident in Indo-China, to Pnompenh resulted in no formal attempt to settle specific details of the French-Cambodian differences, a spokesman for M. Letourneau said here today.

BAYONNE, N. J., May 10 -- A 27-year-old lieutenant placed the blame today on the skipper of the destroyer-minesweeper Hobson for sinking his ship on April 26 in a mid-Atlantic collision with the aircraft carrier Wasp.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 10 -- Some parents, through misunderstanding of psychoanalytic theory, are misapplying the knowledge they have acquired in the bringing up of their children, Dr. Mary O'Neil Hawkins, New York psychoanalyst, declared today.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 10 -- First of the sizable summer racing yachts made their appearance today on Long Island Sound in the annual tune-up regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

A BOX of flowering plants on a porch or window sill is always pleasant to look at. To have such a vista from spring to early fall is indeed a luxury, but not an expensive one. We made certain of having it when we planned our home, and geraniums helped us carry out the desired scheme.

THE first half of this picture book is really more fun than the latter part, for it begins with a wonderful confusion of dirt and disorder on a run-down, broken-down farm. Such characters as a cobwebby cat, a slammacky slummocky sheep, a fusty rusty cow will, I suspect, interest the unregenerate mud-pie set more than will the very clean pig which literally falls into this topsy-turvy world.

The powers of the Presidency, not precisely defined in the Constitution, have been the subject of furious debate from the beginnings of the American Republic. Through the years, as the cartoons here illustrate, the broad use of Presidential authority has usually generated fierce opposition.
TO the rail fan spring means it is time to get out and ride the high iron, explore railroad shops and lovingly inspect locomotives, Diesel or steam, the latter preferred.

Two direct efforts to intimidate principal figures in the departmental trials of eighteen policemen on graft charges came to light yesterday when Assistant Corporation Counsel Victor J. Herwitz reported a telephone threat to his home on the heels of a Friday night beating of Jack Gross, younger brother of Harry Gross, former bookmaker.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L. I., May 10 -Under a sky that rolled away the clouds for a smiling sun just as motorists hoped traffic woes might be floated away, the six-lane $7,000,000 Atlantic Beach bridge over Reynolds Channel from here to Lawrence was formally opened today.

JOE DiMAGGIO, shy and serious, never known to talk much during the thirteen years he played center field for the New York Yankees, is now conducting a televised chit-chat program (Channel 11) for baseball fans before and after games at Yankee Stadium.

FOR today's airminded children, this book presents a rocket's-eye view of the earth: its sea and land masses, its ocean and air currents, its relationship to other bodies of the universe. Closer views of the continents and their inhabitants (both human and animal) are provided by over 300 full-color paintings by Cornelius DeWitt.

STRIKES and prospective strikes in steel, oil, railroads, aluminum, coal, communications and other basic industries have set the country off on a frantic new search for ways to keep labor-management conflict from undermining the national safety.

THE advance of spring finds tulips and lilacs competing for top billing today and for the rest of this week. In many sections they began to unfold almost ten days ago and so those which have just made their entrance will round out this distinctive annual performance.

Among the sparks of hopefulness that sometimes pierce the grayness of the world scene is the report by the Institute of International Education that more than 30,000 young men and women from dozens of countries the world over are now studying, working and playing alongside their American counterparts in universities and colleges across our nation.

BONN, May 10 -- Until the last few weeks the United States and Western policy toward Germany moved steadily, almost placidly, along a broad white autobahn leading to happy valleys of security and snug cities of industrial and economic cooperation.

As the first contribution toward a ten-year $40,000,000 development program to strengthen Emory University and broaden its influence in higher education, the General Education Board has made a grant of $7,000,000 to Emory for endowment in support of graduate work.

NO small-boat enthusiast, whether foldboater or canoeist, should miss taking a trip on the Delaware River, which offers enough variety in boating pleasure to fit almost any kind of taste. For it includes slow water as well as long stretches of fast water and provides a view of some of the most beautiful scenery in the East.

HOLLYWOOD. The early history of the movies in New York, from about 1895 through 1925, will be told in "Two Reels and a Crank," a forthcoming book from Doubleday written by Phil Koury, who spent six years in the Hollywood publicity mill after writing about the industry from afar for The Kansas City Star and only last February returned to Kansas City, Mo., to practice law.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Leaders of 50,000 or more Czechoslovak exiles in the United States and Europe have patched up a quarrel that split them into two rival camps more than a year ago.

HOLLYWOOD has of recent years been accused of turning out rubber stamp beauties, all from the same mold. There may be some truth to this rumor. But the synonym for a durable and genuine spark-striking celebrity is still Marlene Dietrich, who made her first Hollywood picture twenty-one years ago and is to be seen soon in "Rancho Notorious," her first Hollywood film in three years.

YORKTOWN, Va. -- Motorists southbound on U. S. 17 will find a substantial reduction in travel time when they use the George P. Coleman Memorial Bridge, crossing the York River, which opened last week. The modern double-swing-span structure, said to be the largest of its type in the world, crosses the river between Yorktown and Gloucester.

NO one in his right senses, you would think, would deliberately choose the humble mouth organ as vehicle for a serious career in music. The violin, the 'cello, the piano -- these are the instruments that hold the way to virtuoso glory.

SET in the wilderness of the Smoky Mountains, "Brave Interval" again promotes Miss Yates' idealistic faith in human nature. In her simple, persuasive prose, she brings together five people who have chosen an eight-day pack trip through this primitive country as a means of escape from their personal problems.

THE one man who did more than any other to free South America from Spain the wiry, almost delicate, beautifully educated aristocrat, Simon Bolivar -- was as great a lover as fighter. In Victor von Hagen's words, "He made love as the Russians operated their military commissary: he lived off the country and one could follow his loves by a map of his campaigns."

French furniture, the second and final half of the collection of Count Philippe de La Rochefoucauld, and paintings, silver, rugs and other decorative accessories will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday in one of three sales at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

Meeting at Teachers College, Columbia University, for their annual regional conference last week, members of the Cooperative Program in Educational Administration reported the results of two years of research and field work carried out by five research teams of professors and school superintendents.
New York's savings banks are inclined to shun common stock investments in favor of preferred issues, under present conditions.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -- Columbia University's baseball team remained in the running for the Eastern Intercollegiate League southern division championship today by beating Pennsylvania in both ends of a double-header, 3 -- 1 and 4 -- 1.
With reference to George R. Stewart's explanation that the name "Eisenhower" means "hewer of iron," in his article, "'Iron-Hewer' or 'Man of Toft'?" (April 20):

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Sunday, May 11 -- Communist prisoners of war released Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd last night from their prison compound on Koje Island where they had held him hostage since Wednesday.

TOKYO, Sunday, May 11 -- The Chinese Communists' Peiping radio charged today that Washington had ordered the United Nations armistice delegation at Panmunjom to conduct a "sitdown strike'' to draw out the eleven-month-old negotiations for a Korean truce.

LAST December a strange story was brought back from the Himalaya Mountains. A party of explorers told of a creature seen there, known as the Abominable Snowman. He was part beast and part savage, his body hairy but his face bald, and he had an insatiable appetite for yaks and Humans.

LONDON -- Kings and queens in medieval England used to float down the rivers for pleasure in the royal barge. Coal and iron magnates in the Industrial Revolution made their empires with the help of a new canal system which carried their goods and linked the mines with the works.

BERLIN, May 10 -- The French conceded today that their military courier plane, which was the subject of yesterday's complaint by Soviet authorities, had "briefly" left the air corridor leading to Berlin from Frankfurt.

In a step-up of efforts to enforce the city's anti-smoke law on the waterfront, smoke control inspectors will take to harbor waters to apprehend vessels emitting excessive smoke -- if the bureau can obtain the use of a launch, Director William G. Christy said yesterday.

The battle for and against increased limitation of foreign goods entering this country will enter a decisive stage this week when House Banking Committee hearings begin on several measures for restriction of imports.

Six fire companies from lower Manhattan were called upon last night to help Staten Island firemen extinguish a spectacular brush fire in the town of Kreischerville, S. I. The police said that the fire was the biggest of its kind in twenty years.
Construction of a large extension to the Odd Fellows Home for Aged Persons in the Bronx has just been halted for lack of funds, it was announced yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 10 -- Best in show in the twenty-fifth annual event of the Spring-field Kennel Club today went to a white standard poodle. Champion Blakeen Bali Ha'i, owned by the Puttencove Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. George Putnam of Manchester, Mass., and shown by Bob Gorman.

THE vine crops -- cucumbers, melons, squashes and gourds -- often become a nuisance in the garden because of their delight in running over wide areas of ground. Since the natural habit of cucurbits is to clamber over other plants, some kind of support is worth while, particularly for cucumbers, gourds and some of the melons.

For decades the New York Athletic Club has been holding its annual July yacht race to Block Island. This year the thirty-ninth annual event for power cruisers will be a humdinger. Vincent P. Cronin of Mount Vernon, who was installed by Commodore Eugene J. Hynes as race chairman, has surpassed all early promises and phophesies.
From Izvestia, as reported in the Current Digest of the Soviet Press, we learn that Soviet scientists have taken up the problem of the origin of the planets as a matter of ideological importance.

When John P. (Jack) Cunningham, fresh out of Harvard, came to New York in 1920 looking for a job in an advertising agency, he had two large manila envelopes. One contained samples of drawings he had done for the Lampoon and the other copies of poems and articles he had done for the Advocate --both University publications.
WHILE television schedules for the summer months will offer a diversity of subject-matter it looks as though a goodly portion of summer viewing will be offered on film.
Harry Gross, 34-year-old convicted bookmaker, last week told a story of New York City police graft on an astonishing scale, which he summed up in four words:

Armed Forces Week will begin today with sermons and a recital of the Department of Defense's "Armed Forces Prayer" in many churches. The week will end Saturday with "open house" at military and naval units and a parade on Fifth Avenue.

BASIC exposure data for photographing a total eclipse of the moon, a phenomenon that will be visible in the eastern part of the United States on Jan. 29, 1953, were supplied last week by Peter A. Leavens of Pavelle Color, Inc., in the course of an illustrated talk on sky spectacle photography at the May meeting of the New York Technical Section, Photographic Society of America.

ROY LOCKWOOD, who directed a British-made adventure in 1939 titled "Mutiny on the Elsinore," is moving ahead with plans for a repeat performance on the high seas to be called "The Return of the Sea Witch."

SCIENCE editor of The London News Chronicle, Ritchie Calder is one of the best of the present generation of British science writers. In this book he tells the story of Lord Rutherford (father of atomic physics as Einstein is of modern physics itself); Sir Alexander Fleming (penicillin); Sir Robert Watson-Watt (radar); Lord Boyd-Orr (nutrition research); and Sir Frederick Gowland Hopkins (vitamins).
LONDON, May 10 (AP) -- Dr. John Thoburn Williamson, Canadian geologist who keeps diamonds worth fortunes in a row of pickle jars, is offering some of his gems for sale in London.
LOS ANGELES -- Well, as they say on television, those three London buses have crossed the continent. And everybody concerned pronounces the expedition a smashing success.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 10 -- The Yugoslavs publicized today their rejection of the London agreement associating Italy more closely in the administration of Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste, which is controlled by British-American armed forces. The rejection came as no surprise and conformed to the position taken by the Yugoslav Government when the London conference convened last month.

THIS handsome volume, companion to Mrs. Coolidge's "Greek Myths," deals with the legend of the Trojan War as told in "The Iliad," "The Odyssey," and other accounts of the famous conflict. Beginning with the meeting of Paris and Helen. the story tells in sequence the familiar episodes leaclihg to the wax and to the wanderings of the Greek heroes on their way home from the long siege of Troy.

Bright signal pennants and flags will fly proudly from the masts and rigging of American ships in all the ports of the country on National Maritime Day, May 22, as the American merchant marine takes the nation's salute for its contribution to security and peace.

A CURIOUS little book will be published in England this week: a reminiscence of Premier Stalin by his expatriate nephew, Budu Svanidze, called "My Uncle Joe." When the manuscript turned up in Paris last winter, literary agents who saw it were skeptical at first.

" STUDIO ONE" came to grips last week with Robert Louis Stevenson's "Treasure Island" but the results leaned much more to the yo-ho-ho and a bottle of rum than to very effective drams. In fact, the TV version was so surprisingly pedestrian and heavy-handed that youngsters who stayed up to see it can be forgiven if their loyalty to Gene Autry and Space Cadet remained unshaken.

CAIRO, May 10 -- Egyptian economists are beginning to tell the public that the severity of an economic slump that is appearing here is a result of the bare subsistence existence of the mass of the population, which has no purchasing power.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 10 -- Harvard's track team scored its second consecutive triumph in its fifty-sixth meeting with Yale today by 83 -- 57. It was the final meet for Jaakko Mikkola, who retires after sixteen years as the Crimson head coach.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives refrained from cutting Administration requests for military aid to the Far East because of growing concern over French Indo-China, members said today.

WITH gardens in town and country looking their prettiest, tours to outstanding properties are at the height of their popularity among flower lovers. This week gardens in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Connecticut will be opened to the public by special arrangement.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 10 -- A diplomatic conference on maritime law ended here today in agreement on three conventions embodying uniform legal rules on collision and arrest.

BONN, Germany, May 10 -- Federal Germany must assume certain obligations, burdens and restrictions under the treaty system linking it with the West, John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, told the German people today, but these drawbacks would be more than balanced by the peace and liberty that would result from integration in the European community.

A master development plan to make the American side of Niagara Falls a more beautiful and interesting place to visit was made public here last week by Joseph Davis, president of the Niagara Frontier State Park Commission, and Robert Moses, chairman of the State Council of Parks.
Tomorrow a historic legal battle -- the Constitutional battle over steel seizure -- will be joined in the United States Supreme Court.

BOSTON, May 10 -- East, west, north and south the Giants are still bowling them over. Today they moved into the Hub to topple Tommy Holmes' Braves. Jim Hearn's strong armed hurling marked the 4-2 victory. They extended their latest winning streak to three in a row.

IF we go by rarity value, easily the most important theatrical event here since I last wrote has been the production at the Old Vic of James Forsyth's play, "The Other Heart," which gives a dramatic account of the wasted life and lamentable death of Francois Villon in medieval Paris.

RADIO in Israel, like all Gaul, is divided into three parts. Kol Israel, the "Voice of Israel," is a national service provided by the Government of Israel. Galei Tzahal, the "Waves of the Army," serves as an official Israel Defense Army operation.

WHEN the late Dwight Morrow was preparing to run for the United States Senate, he somewhat anxiously asked his Amherst friend, Calvin Coolidge, what kind of speeches a "Wall Street candidate" like himself ought to make.
Discussions growing out of the steel seizure are beclouding the basic issue, which is how labor disputes are to be settled in industries where strikes create national emergencies.
Remarking that he had only three months to live because of cancer, an armed thug invaded Roosevelt Hospital at 11 A. M. yesterday, terrorized six employes, and escaped with more than $2,000 in cash.

The excellent article, "Four Great Lacks in Mental Health" (May 4) by Oren Root, the competent and inspiring president of the National Association for Mental Health, deserves the widest dissemination, especially among high Government officials.

THE training of canine thespians for the movies, grown to become possibly Hollywood's biggest behind-the-scenes operation, today is led by the husky but gentle son of one of the Early West's most colorful figures.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 10 -- Walter Ostrom, of Orangeburg, N. Y., led a field of 168 today to take the 200-target singles in the second session of the three-day amateur trapshooting championships at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island traps.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, challenged the Senate Elections subcommittee today to produce evidence of any wrongdoing in his $10,000 book deal with the now-defunct Lustron Housing Corporation of Columbus, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -Jesting members of the Gridiron Club put words in the mouths of Presidential hopefuls and lampooned top political figures and issues at the club's spring dinner at the Hotel Statler tonight.

AJUGA is an easily grown, undemanding perennial that is best used in places where grass will not thrive. Also known as bugle, carpet bugle or bugle-weed, its green or bronze foliage will cover and beautify previously barren and difficult sites. Blossoms appear in May or June.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 10 -- The Point Four technical assistance program now getting under way is the smallest part of American aid to Israel, but is tackling what some observers consider Israel's most fundamental economic problem. This is the lack of technical skills, especially among the mass of new immigrants from Arab lands.

A NEW ocean liner service that will permit United States tourists in the Canadian Maritime Provinces to cap their vacations with a one-and a half to two-day sea trip from Halifax, N. S., to New York has been established by the Italian Line and the Home Lines.

IT is nearly a century since Edward FitzGerald's translation of the "Rubaiyat" of Omar Khayyam made its unnoticed appearance in England. It was destined to become a classic of English poetry and to provide an extraordinary European fame for the twelfth-century Iranian author.

IN hot, dry situations where other plants will burn in the midsummer sun, the annual rudbeckias, or coneflowers, will bloom unscathed. They are reliable over a long period, starting in early summer and continuing through the days of killing frosts.
Revenue-seeking legislators will hear a poser Tuesday morning in the form of a bipartisan bill which, if passed, would reduce Federal income.

THIS strangely absorbing first novel by a native of Texas, and with Texas flavor in the title, is about a conflict outside the realm of six-guns and oil money. It is no Western, and the Texas setting -- except for a scene in which a small boy sees a sick bull that has been blinded by vultures so hungry they couldn't wait -- has little real importance in the over-all narrative pattern.

Taking four of the six events, Wagner of Staten Island gained the team title yesterday in the first annual metropolitan college girls track and field meet at Macombs Dam Park, the Bronx. The competition was held under the auspices of the Metropolitan A. U.

A woman employe of a Manhattan millinery concern has been accused of conspiring with her employer to underpay Puerto Rican milliners working for the Jaeton Novelty Company, 38 West Thirty-ninth Street.
WEST POINT, N Y., May 10 -- Army and Brown split an Eastern Intercollegiate double-header at Doubleday Field today, the cadets taking the opener, 4 -- 1, before losing, 5 -- 3.

BECAUSE of rich color and pleasing fragrance, heliotropes have long been favorites with gardeners. The true heliotrope is treated as an annual in this part of the country. The hardy perennial known as garden heliotrope is an entirely different kind of plant, comes from another family, and its correct name is valerian.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Canadian Government, in a note to the United States State Department has agreed to this country's proposal that the high-water problem on Lake Ontario be referred to an international joint commission for study.
BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Real Delight added to her standing as queen of the 3-year-old fillies today by winning the $25,000 added Black-Eyed Susan Stakes at Pimlico.

BERLIN. SOMETIME soon, if events go as devoutly hoped by Konrad Adenauer, the Chancellor of the Federal Republic of West Germany, he will move woodenly onto the speaker's rostrum in the Bundestag and in his dry, flat voice present "Meine Damen und Herren" of that body with a series of treaties which represent the life work of this strange old civil servant turned statesman.

PRESENTED with the problem of creating an uncluttered contemporary look in an old brownstone house in New York City's East Seventies, industrial designer L. Garth Huxtable came up with several solutions, some of which are pictured here. Confining the actual furniture to designs that are completely modern in concept, he managed to achieve an integrated look without either eliminating or tampering with such old-fashioned architectural details as the ornate moldings, carved fireplaces and paneled walls.

THE United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization announced recently that a world reporting service for plant pests and diseases will be put into operation this year. The FAO will act as an international clearing house for the collection and dissemination of information on the various horticultural plagues.

Bewitched by Federal decontrol measures, bothered by the general business decline and bewildered by the high cost of operations, industry is revising downward its earlier calculations of prospective earnings. This is particularly applicable to the capital goods industries, where an attitude of caution is replacing the optimism engendered by demand and production in the last eighteen months.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 10 -- In what must be considered the major racing victory in the East so far this season, Navy's sweep-swingers defeated Pennsylvania and Harvard in the Adams Cup Regatta on the Charles today. The triumph was a relatively easy one, the Middies winning from the Quakers by two lengths.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Seizure of the steel industry by President Truman, which has touched off the sharpest constitutional controversy in recent years, was attacked and defended in briefs filed with the United States Supreme Court today.

BOSTON, May 10 -- Three state political conventions in New England next week are expected to add at least seventeen delegates to the list for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and two for Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in the Republican Presidential nomination race.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- President Truman's concept of Presidential powers wil stand trial figuratively before the Supreme Court on Monday. But the President believes he has won his battle against Big Steel.

In a review and appraisal of the recent legislative session published yesterday, George H. Hallett Jr., secretary of the Citizens Union, credited the legislature with several major accomplishments and charged it with several notable failures.

A protest against any 25 per cent increase in the wholesale rates and charges for natural gas -- sought by the Transcontinental Gas Pipeline Corporation, which supplies local gas companies -- was registered last week with the Federal Power Commission in Washington by Mayor Impellitteri.

Cousins of the rose make our world a wondrous place to see and smell, just now, though the roses themselves are waiting for June. That, of course, is because the rose family is one of botany's biggest. It includes low-growing plants, shrubs and trees ranging from the little cinquefoil known as false strawberry to the towering bird cherry tree.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 10 (AP) -- Senators Richard B. Russell of Georgia and Estes Kefauver of Tennessee both gained new supporters in the twenty-two-vote Alabama delegation to the Democratic National Convention today in a poll of the men elected in last Tuesday's party primary.

The United States is willing to share its know-how for the production of plasticized textiles and chemical finishes as well as supply basic textile material to foreign producers, it was pointed out last week. The chemical division of B. F. Goodrich Company was instrumental in establishing a new vinyl plant in Japan which begin production this month at Kambara, near Tokyo.

Two members of Hunter College's class of '78 had an opportunity to see the changes that had taken place at their alma mater since their graduation seventy-four years ago with the showing of a film. "695 Park Avenue" to 300 alumnae at a reunion yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UP) -- Members of the House Veterans Committee predicted today the group would end its disputes and agree on an $800,600,000-a-year GI Bill of Rights for veterans of the Korean war.
LONDON, May 10 -- A wave of wage rise demands by union members since last March, when he submitted his budget, is causing R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, considerable concern.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 10 (AP) -- Princeton's Bill Ragland fired a thirty-six-hole 149 to capture medalist honors for the second year in a row, but a Virginia quartet marched off with the Eastern intercollegiate golf team championship today.

LANDSCAPES of England and France; yachting and racing scenes; witty and exact impressions of pomp and circumstance in the British Army; some still-life and figure pieces -- such is the range of subject matter in Paul Maze's 128 oils, pastels and water-colors at Wildensteins.

ALONG New York City's streets and avenues these days, horse-drawn wagons piled high with flowers in pots and evergreens in tubs are patronized by city-bound gardeners. A geranium for the window sill, pots of ivy for the terrace -- the load of springtime color and fragrance is almost irresistible.
Armageddon, flying the blue-and-white-blocked silks of Harry F. Guggenheim's Cain Hoy Stable, won the seventy-seventh running of the Withers Stakes for 3-year-olds at Belmont Park yesterday.
CLEVELAND, May 10 (AP) -- Southpaw Tommy Byrne, who makes a habit of stopping Cleveland winning streaks, snapped the Indians five-game skein today by pitching the Browns to a 6-4 victory.

WASHINGTON -- This capital city and tourist goal has a brand new $5,832,000 package of concentrated sight-seeing to offer the traveling public -- the new White House. The home of the Chief Executive, which was closed down late in 1948 to be rebuilt completely, was opened to the public on April 22 and sight-seers are now permitted to inspect it between 10 A. M and noon, Tuesday through Saturday.

AN editor and contributor to the multi-volume "Interpreter's Bible," currently being published, Walter R. Bowie yet finds time to continue his writing of Bible stories for young readers. The present volume dealing with the Old Testament is a companion to Dr. Bowie's previous one on the New Testament.

LONDON, May 10 -- After six months in office, Prime Minister Churchill's Conservative Government is not popular with the people of Britain. Mr. Churchill never expected that it would be at the beginning. He said himself that it would take three years to test his Government's policies and that in the interim he would not shrink from any measures, no matter how unpalatable politically, if in his view the welfare of the country required them.
The Federal Reserve Board freed a Tartar last week.

THIS morning in millions of homes throughout the land the lady of the house will enjoy the luxury of breakfast in bed, followed by a day of what passes for leisure among adults who live with children.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, May 10 -- At the height of the Missouri River flood last month, President Truman said he was going to give his idea for Federal flood insurance a "kick" in Congress. This week he sent up to the Congress a proposal for a $1,500,000,000 flood insurance program.

Sometimes nowadays episodes take on such a fantastic character as to be almost unbelievable. A brigadier general of the United States Army has just been released by Communist prisoners of war, whose camp he commanded, after being kidnapped and held hostage for three days.
Rabbi Jacob Polish, in a sermon honoring mothers yesterday morning at the Hebrew Tabernacle, 605 West 161st Street, emphasized the influence women could use to prevent war and "wanton killing."

GREENWICH, Conn., May 10 -Nearly five hundred persons today toured ten eighteenth and nineteenth century homes spread over Greenwich's forty-eight square miles of countryside. They were participating in the semi-annual meeting and tour of the Antiquarians and Landmarks Society, Inc., of Connecticut, for which the Greenwich Historical Society served as host.

CHARLES CALLAN TANSILL has written several bocks of very high quality, including a diplomatic history of World War I which, despite its tendentious character, is a useful and well-documented account of an important period.
TRENTON, May 10 -- Fourteen New Jersey municipalities, headed by Atlantic City, will hold regular or special elections on Tuesday to select their top administrative officials.

IT has long been a matter of injured pride to Scandinavians that many American tourists visualize Europe as little more than Paris, the Riviera, the Alps and Piccadilly Circus. Students at the universities in Norway, Denmark and Sweden finally decided that measures were overdue to establish better communication between young Americans and young Scandinavians.

DANBURY, Conn., May 10 -- Danbury's school teachers have won a major step in their fight for salary increases of $400 a year but the possibility that they may face a court test to determine the validity of their contract loomed large today.
BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) -- A group of road engineers advanced the first solid evidence today for a theory they long had preached about the way big loads break up highways.
KINGS POINT, L. I., May 10 -- Adelphi College won the Kings Point invitational track and field meet for small colleges today with 56 3-5 points.
FRESNO, Calif., May 10 (AP) -- Running under a broiling sun in a temperature that reached 86 degrees. Aldo Scandurra of New York today won the marathon at the twenty-sixth annual West Coast Relays.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 10 -- Spartan Valor, rated by many horsemen as the finest New Jersey-bred horse since Exterminator, took another victorious stride toward the 1952 handicap championship today by winning Garden State's Valley Forge Handicap with a brilliant record-breaking performance under 130 pounds.

IN 1860 students at Oberlin College, voting in the first mock political convention ever held on a campus, nominated Abe Lincoln for President. Since then the whole student body at Oberlin has tried to guess the Republican nominee every four years -- and has been right almost half the time. The last winner they picked was Herbert Hoover in 1928; in 1948 their man was Arthur Vandenberg.

AMERICAN airlines, which have been watching with equanimity so far while the British develop jet commercial service, may get a chance soon to see what they can do against direct competition from jets in their own backyard.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 10 -- A fight for survival by Senator Harley M. Kilgore and Walter F. Hallanan, Republican national committeeman, will be decided Tuesday in the climax of a bitter primary campaign.

MORE than 63,000,000 Americans will be traveling in cars during this summer vacation period, and if 1952 follows the pattern of recent years a lot of them will be killed and injured in accidents involving automobiles that are mechanically unsafe.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 10 -- Cornell's track team took nine first places and tied for another today in beating Princeton, 74 to 65, at Palmer Stadium. Four meet records were established.

GLeN COVE, I,. L, May 1.0-- Three estates on Long Island's North Shore, famed 'for beautiful lawns and gardens,.ill be opened to the public Thursday afternoon from ! to 6 o'cloek to aid the scholarship fund of Wellesley College. This -nnual Wellesley-inNassau garden pilgrm-ge is spoasored by Wellesley al,mre as their contribution to the college's scholarship fun

Prices in the domestic cotton market were somewhat firmer last week. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 26 to 63 points from a week ago. The best gains were recorded by the near-by deliveries. For the previous week, the market had registered net losses of 63 to 157 points, with the sharpest declines in the near-by positions.

LONDON, May 10 -- For the first time since World War II, the maximum price of newsprint produced in Britain will be reduced by just over $8, starting May 19, the Ministry of Materials announced today.
TOKYO, Sunday, May 11 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,246, for Saturday operations:

WOODBURY, L. I., May 10 -Defying competition from glittering super-markets of near-by villages, J. Irving Baylis still operates a general store off Syosset Road in much the same setting that prevailed when he and his brother, Arthur, opened it sixty-five years ago.

UNLIKE Martin Greenberg's other anthologies, this one does not pretend to any unifying scheme, and he has given us no statement of his aims. We must assume that his aim was simply to give his readers pleasure; and so far as this reader is concerned, he has marked up three hits, one near miss and one bad miss.

SIMCOE, Ont., May 10 (Canadian Press) -- A mysterious land boom in this Southwestern Ontario district is linked with iron ore deposits reported underlying ten square miles between Simcoe and Port Ryerse on Lake Erie.

ANOTHER summer theatre season is on the horizon and once again operators on the straw hat trail are immersed in their planning. It is a feverish period of lining up scripts, signing contracts, rushing hither and yon, chasing one detail after another.

UNTIL some inspired genius comes along with a totally new concept of opera (perhaps even entailing so radical a notion as creating new works in terms of contemporary esthetics), the position of the opera ballet is going to be difficult. Occasionally, however, some intrepid spirit barges into the field, ignoring the perils, and comes up with something not unlike victory.
The course of the market for prime-risk securities will bear close watching because the financial community is now going through an experience for which there is no ready parallel.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 10 (AP) -- The first two serious crashes of the season sent two race car drivers to the hospital today and damaged their cars so badly that they have slight chance of running in the 500-mile race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway on May 30.

New York marine insurance underwriters have named J. W. O. Von Herbulis, vice president of Waterman Steamship Company, to serve a two-year term as a member of the Board of Commissioners of Pilots, in New York.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 10 -- The James Forrestal Research Center will be dedicated here next Saturday as a "living memorial" to the late Secretary of Defense.

SOME folks in turn - of - the-century Tangier, Ill., thought that Charley Hinckley -- Good Old Charley -- was too kind-hearted. He carried other people's burdens and paid the price for other people's mistakes. His career was encumbered by moral and financial responsibility for his wastrel brother George.

THERE was a time when the diversity of cultures and religions in the world presented no problem -- beyond that of a challenge to the missionary zeal of one group or another. Now that the progress of science has brought us to the familiar "one world/no world" antithesis, and the world is bifurcated by the Communist movement, we are forced to ask, as does this book, a fundamental question.

ON SATURDAY, the Hudson River Day Line will start its daily and Sunday roundtrip cruises to Indian Point, Bear Mountain, West Point, Newburgh and Poughkeepsie. One of the line's three steamers will leave Pier 81 at the foot of West Forty-second Street, every morning at 9:30 (D. S. T.) with stops at 125th Street and Yonkers.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 10 (UP) -- Tornadoes struck Arkansas today and high winds caused two deaths in Tennessee as a violent storm front raked the South from Texas to the Atlantic seaboard. At least twenty persons were injured in the storms.

WASHINGTON officials gave recognition last week to a fact business men have known for some time: Consumers are reluctant to buy and need inducements. Acting under mounting pressure from retailers, the Federal Reserve Board suspended controls on installment credit purchases.

THE author of the controversial novel, "The Widow," has chosen to tell whatever story there is in her current offering through the device of having three women -- half-sister, mistress, wife -- describe a lost and "devil-ridden" young man as each knew him.

IN his first new novel in more than two years, Henry Green tells simply and wonderfully a tale of middle-aged dalliance set against the London of 1949. A highly skilled and wittily penetrating comedy of manners, it will be called, the author notes slyly, "decadent but it is not.

WITHIN the past fortnight two of the liveliest productions of the season have opened for business, and they both came out of the archives. "The Male Animal," by James Thurber and Elliott Nugent, comes out of the 1940 files; and "Of Thee I Sing," by George and Ira Gershwin, George Kaufman and Morrie Ryskind, comes from 1931.
TOKYO, May 10 (AP) -- General Ridgway issued tonight this message to United Nations troops in the Far East on the eve of his departure for Europe:

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Break or cut off dead flowers on hyacinth and daffodils, and on the tulips when bloom fades. Do not touch foliage until it turns yellow; in about a month or six weeks it will pull out easily. Tulips and hyacinths may need to be lifted every three years; spring and fall feeding maintains others.

IF bread is the staff of life, then bread with butter is a gold-headed cane, somebody once remarked. But bread is far from being the only thing that butter makes better. It enhances asparagus, green corn and other fresh vegetables to such a degree that butter consumption actually increases as warm weather brings these delicacies into market stalls.

IN 1946 Emperor Hirohito of Japan gave a reception for George D. Stoddard, the distinguished educator who is now president of the University of Illinois, and who had gone to Tokyo as head of an advisory educational mission. Without warning or consultation with any of his advisers, Japanese or American, the Son of Heaven asked Mr. Stoddard to recommend a tutor for his eldest son, the Crown Prince Akihito.

VIOLETS, one of the traditional harbingers of spring, are blooming in woods and fields now, and so are their garden counterparts (named varieties). It is perfectly possible and, in fact, not difficult to transplant them at this time.

CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- All grains except rye dipped gently on the Board of Trade today. There wasn't any selling pressure on the market, but the splendid outlook for new crop grains discouraged speculative buying.

IN Bohemia's Halls, where every man is reputedly a king, the young George du Maurier was from the first an heir apparent. This handsome and talented young artist, grandfather of the modern best-selling Daphne du Maurier, produced in the Eighteen Nineties a remarkable pair of bohemian romances, "Trilby" and "Peter Ibbetson."

THE turbulent and often perplexing course of French music during a perplexing half-century is epitomized in two recent releases. They are the Symphony in G Minor and Bacchus et Ariane Ballet Suite of Albert Roussel (both on a disk from Urania) and three works of Georges Auric and Pierre Gradwohl, brought out by Renaissance Records.
BOSTON, May 10 (AP) -- LaSalle of Philadelphia whipped eight other crews today to retain its varsity championship of the Dad Vail regatta -- the smaller rowing colleges Little Poughkeepsie classic.

RYE, N. Y., May 10 -- Mariano Durante of 23-22 Tilden Avenue, Brooklyn, head of the Unity Paper Stock Company, 159 South Street, New York, was killed at 5 A. M. today when he was struck by an automobile and crushed beneath his son's parked car, which had stalled on the Hutchinson River Parkway near Ridge Street here.

" THE better the staff, the better the child care." That is the keynote of this honest book, prepared by the director of Youth House, New York City's detention home for the temporary care of delinquent boys. Based on training courses given for child-care workers, "Children in Trouble" sets forth the program, organizational steps and staff work necessary to make "a healthy institutional atmosphere for the rehabilitation of damaged children."

The New York State Thruway Authority expects to open the new toll express road on a revenue basis from Batavia to Utica by the fall of next year, Bertram D. Tallamy, chairman of the Authority, said here last week at a luncheon meeting of the Municipal Forum at the Lawyers Club.

TOKYO, May 10 -- United Nations forces in the Far East got their third commander this week when Gen. Mark Wayne Clark stepped from a plane at Tokyo's Haneda Airport to take over the functions first fulfilled by General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, then by Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, who is now to lead Allied troops in Europe.

BAY SHORE, L. I., May 10 -Dr. George S. King has been too busy to keep tab on the number of babies he helped bring into the world in the fifty years he has been a practitioner here. He plans a "round-up party," however, at the South Bay Golf Club on June 14, the anniversary of his coming to Bay Shore, to which all "his babies" are invited.

In regard to the recent discussion in THE NEW YORK TIMES about the American consumption of newsprint and its influence on world prices, I should like to reply particularly to the letter of Cranston Williams of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
" Assignment to the United States" might well be the phrase which characterizes the latest accomplishment of an individual who has roamed the seven seas -- in an industrial and financial manner.

SAN JUAN, P. R., May 10 -Every day is moving day on this overcrowded little island but humanity really will be in motion between now and August when 20,000 Puerto Ricans will fly to the continental United States for seasonal farm work.

TRENTON, May 10 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll signed today five bills designed to guarantee monetary compensation up to $5,000 each for most innocent victims of automobile accidents in New Jersey, whether or not the driver at fault carries liability insurance or is financially responsible.

THE subtitle of this book -- "The War in Korea" -- is somewhat misleading. Captain Karig and his associates have written the story of the war in Korea through the end of 1950 as fought by the Navy and, to a lesser extent, the Marine Corps.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Congressional motto "You invent it, we'll tax it" got a swift workout today following an announcement that a scientist had discovered how to transform sugar cane waste into something that looks, smells and tastes like tobacco.

YOUR readers may be interested in a new project -- or, more accurately, the revival of an old project -- by the Eastman School of Music of the University of Rochester, for the recording of works by American composers.

ALBANY, May 10 -- The number of children in New York State requiring foster care declined 17 per cent in the twelve years from 1940 through 1951, but the total public and private cost of the program doubled over the same period, the State Social Welfare Department reported today.

The Yankees touched new heights at the Stadium yesterday when they crushed the Red Sox, 18 to 3, before 30,769 fans. Casey Stengel's champions surpassed anything they had been able to achieve previously this season in hits and runs for a game and for an inning, while sending Lou Boudreau's candidates for the American League pennant to depths that have not been plumbed by a Red Sox team in recent years.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 10 -- Michigan's Democratic state convention, pledging forty Presidential votes to Gov. G. Mennen Williams as its "favorite son," fractioned four of its national convention votes among twelve delegates at large today to accommodate the minority and labor groups demanding representation.

Austin Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, said last night that Newark Airport, closed as a result of three fatal air crashes, was expected to reopen for full flying operations on Nov. 1. Mr. Tobin explained that the reopening hinged on the completion of a new $10,000,000 instrument-flight runway scheduled for that date.

After three decades of uncertainty in the Federal taxation of stock dividends the only case in which there is absolute certainty as to non-taxability of such transactions is where the issuing corporation has but one class of stock outstanding and the stock dividend is paid in the same class of stock.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Once again Congress and President Truman are approaching a collision on a long-standing issue that mixes oil, politics and states' rights, producing, much heat, propaganda and confusion.

THE espalier fruit tree is ideal for the small garden. It is ornamental and, at the same time, yields a rewarding amount of fruit. It is developed by grafting dwarf rootstock to the root of a selected variety. Popular varieties, such as Delicious apple and Bartlett pear, are available in espalier form.

At the spring meeting of the American Chemical Society's Division of Rubber Chemistry, Dr. H. Leverne Williams of Polymer Corporation, Ltd., Sarnia, Canada, told of a new rubber which for some purposes is better than GR-S, by which cryptic term the present general-purpose synthetic is known.

Vice Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, chairman of the Maritime Administration, told members of Congress last week that the Truman Administration was strongly opposed to any extension of construction subsidies and tax deferment benefits to unsubsidized shipping operators.

ON a bright, hot Saturday morning in 1602 -- the date was May 15 -- a doughty English captain named Bartholomew Gosnold was taking his logy little ship southwestward along the shores of Norumbega (as New England then was called) with a company of gentleman adventurers and prospective settlers when he saw, between him and the open sea, "a mighty headland."

Six thousand Chinese students and recent graduates of American universities, stranded in this country, face a bleak outlook. The overwhelming majority are unwilling to go back and fall into the hands of the Communist Government.

Mayor Impellitteri, in a ceremony at City Hall tomorrow, will proclaim Civil Defense "Alert America" week here, beginning on Tuesday. The occasion, to be marked by an exhibit at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, will bid for the enlistment of additional thousands of defense volunteers.

The Port Authority has authorized the expenditure of $230,000 for a cargo terminal and fumigation building at Port Newark. The appropriation was made at yesterday's monthly meeting of the bi-state agency.

LONDON, May 10 -- Dr. Leopold Figl, Chancellor of Austria who has been here on a state visit for three days, emphasized today that the Allied Council in Vienna was the only four-power organ left where tile Western powers and the Soviet Union met on a day-to-day working basis.

About four hundred hydrocarbons will produce cancers. Four years ago Drs. B. S. Oppenheimer, Enid T. Oppenheimer and Arthur Purdy Stout reported that cancers (sarcomas) could also be produced in albino rats by embedding a bit of transparent plastic package-wrapper under the skin of the belly or by wrapping it around a kidney.

THIS first week of the cultural exposition called "Masterpieces of the Twentieth Century," given in this city under the auspices of the Congress for Cultural Freedom, has proved a stimulating and exciting occasion.

DENNIS, Mass., May 10 -- The discovery of a broken adze and a rusty iron spike buried in the earth of a dry gully here today were reported as possible proof that Vikings discovered America 500 years before Columbus.

Paced by its swift sprinters, Manhattan romped off with team honors in the Metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday. Capturing six titles and scoring in all but one of the sixteen events, George Eastment's Jaspers rolled up 85 1/2 points to outdistance their rivals for the third straight year.
Ford Motor's First won the featured West Point, Class A pace, over a route of one mile at the Yonkers Raceway last night. The event attracted seven entrants. with Ford Motor's First the favorite.

Dr. J. G. Davidson, president of Carbide and Carbon Chemicals Company, declared yesterday that production of chemicals from coal by hydrogenation "is now a reality." His views were based on successful operation of the $11,000,000 coal-hydrogenation chemicals plant of the company at Institute, W. Va.

MAYBE you haven't noticed, but the most striking of the recent films, looking back over a period of a fortnight, up until press time of last week, have been pictures set in locations of absolute authenticity and deriving a lot of their flavor from the character of their locales.
MADISON, May 10 (AP) -- Wisconsin's crew, rowing smoothly and deep in slightly choppy water, swept to a five-length victory over Massachusetts Institute of Technology on Lake Monona today.

What is said to be the first successful use in this country of a heart-lung machine on a human patient was reported at last week's meeting of the American Association for Thoracic Surgery. The machine ("dispersion oxygenator" is its technical name) was developed at the Fels Research Institute for the Study of Human Development, Antioch College.

Announcement is expected soon of an offer for public sale by the United States Government of E. Leitz, Inc., a New York company which distributes the Leica camera in this country and manufactures optical instruments and accessories, it was learned yesterday.

DURING April, and on the first Friday evening in May, a quiet, section, of Riverside Drive occasionally resounded to music that is not normally associated with a quiet section of Riverside Drive. The sounds came from the apartment of Rosalyn Tureck, who sponsored four musical evenings of modern -- very modern -- music, much of it played from manuscript by a distinguished group of musicians.

Your article "Waters on the Rampage" in the editorial columns of THE TIMES for April 20 suggests that the problems of flood control belong to the category of those that may be studied by "operations research."

THE author of placid novels of the Breckland district of Norfolk, Michael Home, has an affectionate following in England where he has been read with grateful pleasure over the last quarter of a century. "The Brackenford Story" is much broader in scope than his other tales of village life in the flat East Anglia County.

SAN FRANCISCO'S Veterans' War Memorial Building, in which the United Nations Charter was signed on June 26,945, will illustrate the 5-cents blue stamp -- the world organization's first piece of commemorative postal paper -- to be issued on Oct. 24, United Nations Day.

DEEP affection for his home town, New York City, is the pervading theme in Dr. D. J. Ruzicka's one-man retrospective show at the Camera Club, 121 West Sixty-eighth Street, where it can be seen through May 15.

HONOLULU -- Probably the only commemorative event honoring a king held annually on American soil will highlight the late spring and summer program in Hawaii. It is the annual Kamehameha Day observance honoring the memory of Hawaii's first monarch. Kamehameha I. Although the traditional date is June 11 (Kamehameha's actual birth date is unknown), the program this year has been expanded into a four-day affair from June 8 to 11.

The country-wide oil strike, which has reduced the nation's gasoline and fuel supply by 35 per cent, extended its impact yesterday when the United States and Great Britain joined in a worldwide appeal to restrict the consumption of aviation gasoline.

Ellsworth B. Buck, former Representative from the Sixteenth Congressional District, announced last night that he would resign May 19 as chairman of the Republican County Committee in Staten Island and as chairman of the county executive committee.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A greater freedom for the American' Indian in the handling of his own affairs was recommended today by the Association on American Indian Affairs at the end of a three-day conference on Indian Assimilation.

" In Malaya the Front Is Everywhere" (May 4) by Hugh Carleton Greene, former head of the British Information Services in Malaya, goes some way in supplying a much-needed antidote against widespread publicity which would have us believe that the only thing wrong in Malaya today is Communist banditry, without which the situation would be idyllic.

ANOTHER book about Henry Ford? Why not? Most of those who tried to "interpret" him made him more of a riddle. In this sparkling book, Garet Garrett, a verbal alchemist who puts glamour into the dismal science of economics, describes "in terms of its darling practitioner * * * what we have left behind."

THE small bulbs of spring follow each other in quick succession and, suddenly, are finished with bloom for the year. There are, however, two minor bulbs that flower in May just about the time that tulips and iris start to bloom.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Senators Lister Hill and John J. Sparkman of Alabama today announced their support of Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The trustees of North Shore Hospital, a voluntary 150-bed institution being built on Lakeville Road in Great Neck, L. I., have adopted an unusual method of selecting departmental heads of the medical staff, it was announced yesterday by Edward E. James, director.

The liquor industry is facing more trouble today than at any time since the repeal of prohibition. Thomas J. Donovan, new executive vice president of Licensed Bever- age Industries, Inc., and top policy maker for the organization, was the authority for that statement last week. !

TOKYO, May 10 -- In his last press conference as Commander of United States forces in the Far East, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, who will leave Monday to take over as Supreme Commandder of Allied Powers in Europe, bitterly denounced the Communists today on the ground that they had used the Panmunjom armistice talks as an excuse to spread deliberate lies.

AS a trial in technique, William Faulkner's "As I Lay Dying" followed its plot across country like a fictional game of dominoes in which each chapter-long monologue matched and extended the one preceding it. It was a perilous journey.

IT has long been known that Puccini wrote a mass for his graduation thesis at the Musical Institute of Lucca when he was turning 19. In the seventy-four years that have gone by, however, little thought has been given to that student piece.

METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER will attempt this summer to prove to Shakespearean scholars that Hollywood moviemakers can handle Elizaethan dramaturgy with the integrity and commercial success of their British opposites as exemplied by Laurence Olivier's "Henry" and "Hamlet."

AT Army posts throughout the country, a war "baby" -- the Women's Army Corps -- born five months after Pearl Harbor, celebrates its tenth birthday this week. Over the years the WAC has become a full partner of the United States Army, its members serving on an equal basis with men in all parts of the country and in the European and Far East commands.

The first patient has been officially discharged from Sea View Hospital after having been treated for tuberculosis with the newly discovered drugs. This may well be a landmark in the history of medicine and human welfare.

IT is this driving compulsion to read that enables the reader to overcome obstacles that might prevent his reading with intelligent delight. He will not submit tamely to the handicap of poor eyesight; if neither time nor place to read permits, he will create both, drawing on everything that he has learned or experienced in interpreting the printed page.

HEWLETT, L. I., May 10 -- Frank Strafaci scored a one-sided victory in the final at the Seawane Harbor Club today to win the William D. Richardson Memorial golf tournament.

SIMON PEELTOWER, hero-narrator of this musky melodrama built against a backdrop of India's great Sepoy Rebellion of 1857-58, is easily the busiest hunter of the season. In addition to hunting tigers, he trails treason, he seeks money and love, he searches for self and God.
LONDON, May 10 -- All those with special knowledge of the Soviet Union are familiar with the two inevitable questions -- "Will there be war?" and "What will happen on the death of Stalin?
PORTLAND, Ore., May 10 -General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today was considered the favorite to win Oregon's Presidential preferential primary election next Friday.

Six years ago, Morris High School in the Bronx, the borough's oldest and at one time the city's largest secondary school, was in danger of being closed. It seemed to Dr. Jacob Bernstein, who became principal at that time, that he had been appointed to preside over the school's demise.

SOUTHERN readers will delight in the honest-to-goodness rendering of homely speech and familiar ways in Worth Tuttle Hedden's new novel. Some people not born and bred in our briar patch may just possibly be more grudging.

Two for the price of one was President Walter F. O'Malley's good-will gesture to Flatbush fans last night at Ebbets Field. However, the head man of the Dodgers had in mind two games, not defeats, when he listed a twilight-night double-header with the Phillies.

DETROIT, May 10 (AP) -- Bill Kennedy, relief pitcher discarded by the Browns, rescued the White Sox for the second straight day to give Joe Dobson his fourth victory, a 6 -- 3 decision over the Tigers today.

TRENTON -- Impressed by the tremendous success of the New Jersey Turnpike in attracting traffic and toll money, New Jersey highway officials are reassessing their entire roadbuilding program with a view to using tolls to pay for more highway construction.

HONG KONG, May 10 -- The Chinese Communists have not stood still during the past nine months of lull in Korea. Their mobilization movement has included a military build-up featured by expansion of the armed forces, training of new troop and officer cadres, and a modernization program based on more Soviet-supplied materiel.

This is the first of two articles on the housing situation in the New York area. The end of non-subsidized housing construction by New York City and the tightening of Federal limitations on subsidized public housing are making it increasingly difficult to find family-sized apartments that rent for less than $100 a month in new buildings, particularly in Manhattan.

With these two statements, one by the retiring U. N. Commander in Korea, the other by the head of the Communist truce delegation at Panmunjom, the Korean truce talks last week arrived at their most critical juncture to date. The two sides had narrowed the truce talks down to a single issue -- prisoner repatriation.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, who has parlayed a national reputation for exposing gambling and other crimes into one of the more remarkable stakes of United States political history, was confronted this week by a strange situation.

IN June of 1783, when Spain's empire in America appeared more solid than ever, there arrived in Philadelphia a young Venezuelan. His father had come from the Canary Islands, and the young man wore the uniform of an officer of the Spanish Army.
