UNITED NATIONS, N Y., May 10 -- At the instigation of President Theodore Roosevelt, representatives of many nations assembled in Shanghai in 1909 to discuss the possibility of establishing international controls over traffic in narcotics.

PARIS, May 10 -- For the first time a foreign dance troupe gave a complete performance on the great stage of the Paris Opera, when the New York City Ballet, with a company of sixty-five performers under the direction of George Balanchine, made its first appearance tonight in the Paris festival of "Twentieth Century Masterpieces."

PRINCETON, N. J., May 10 -- Rising from three successive defeats, Princeton won the Carnegie Cup today as Cornell suffered its first setback of the season, finishing in third place behind Yale. The Tiger victory, gained by three-quarters of a length in 9:08, came as the climax of three tremendously exciting heavyweight rowing races at a mile and three-quarters that had the thousands on the university bank of Carnegie Lake cheering madly.
EASTON, Md., May 10 -- Works by twelve American artists and five sculptors will be featured at an exhibition opening here on May 18 at the Eastern Shore Art Center, a non-profit organization.

School systems in the New York City area are taking steps to keep experienced and qualified teachers in the classroom, despite inflation and an increasing number of high-paying defense jobs, according to a survey made public last week by the Metropolitan School Study Council, a research affiliate of Teachers College, Columbia University.

A television program in color covering surgical procedures and a variety of clinical subjects will be a feature of the 146th annual five-day convention of the Medical Society of the State of New York, opening tomorrow in the Statler Hotel.

IN 1851, Lieut. William Lewis Herndon of the United States Navy received official orders to make a journey from Peru down the intricate system of rivers leading into the Amazon and on to its mouth. Herndon's orders told him to report on the "present conditions of the valley, with regard to navigability of its streams but also its capacities for cultivation and the character and extent of its undeveloped resources."
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- President Truman's views on his Constitutional powers in the steel seizure reminded steel industry attorneys of James I, Charles I, James II and George III.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., May 10 (AP) -- Lillian Miskavich, a 19-year-old sophomore in the Indiana University School of Music, is to receive the most valuable prize ever given to a student here.

PANAMA, May 10 -- Panama votes tomorrow for a President and other officials with the prospect for a relatively quiet election. Perhaps the largest vote in the history of the country is expected because of the intensity of the campaign and the unusual interest of women, who are balloting for the second time.

WELLS, Nev., May 10 (AP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, appeared today to be the first choice for Nevada's ten-vote delegation to the Democratic National Convention. The delegation, however, apparently will not be pledged to any candidate.

THESE are tense times for prisons. Wardens pace their offices. Commissioners argue hotly with budget directors. Prison chefs decide to put more meat in the stew. Parole board members schedule special meetings. Orders go out constantly over intercom speakers in numberless guard towers.
WHITEVILLE, N. C., May 10 (UP) -- Three former Ku Klux Klansmen were convicted tonight of conspiring to flog a mechanic during a wave of terrorism here and received two-year jail sentences.

EACH season the coastal fishing is marked by boating accidents which too often claim a heavy and unnecessary toll of lives. As a result of the Pelican disaster last year public pressure for the creation of regulations that would insure greater safety had been put on the officials responsible for the rules. Another off-shore fishing season is about to begin and no definite action has been taken.

A free pig roast will mark the opening of the annual Brooklyn Week for the Blind tomorrow in Loeser's department store, Fulton and Bond Streets, Brooklyn. Twenty pigs, mounted on spits, will be roasted and then sliced and served to persons present.

The powerful salvage vessel Curb strained restlessly at her moorings in the Staten Island yard of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation yesterday waiting for a call that would send her racing to sea to tow some floundering vessel to safely or to heave a stranded ship from a beach or bar.

The eighth Popular Price Shoe Show of America, sponsored by the New England Shoe and Leather Association and the National Association of Shoe Chain Stores, will open today at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels with the largest number of exhibitors in its history, it was announced yesterday by Edward Atkins and Maxwell Field, co-managers of the show. The fall and winter footwear display will continue through Thursday.

CAIRO, May 10 -- Britain has proposed to Egypt the British evacuation of the Suez Canal Zone base, with British experts in a civilian status remaining to keep the base prepared for immediate re-occupation by the Western Allies in case of war, but has refused to recognize Farouk as King of the Sudan until after the Sudanese people have been consulted, the Cairo newspaper A1 Ahram reported today.

PARIS, May 10 -- The Cominform has admitted officially that the Bulgarian Communist party has been penetrated by "avowed enemies" of the regime, some of whom have managed to work their way into "responsible posts."

FOR his seventieth birthday, George Jean Nathan received a splendid present: a sort of chrestomathy, a selection of his writings, titled "The World of George Jean Nathan." Though no one was talking about Michelangelo, it seemed the right time to make our visit.

THE hero who dies too soon is sometimes less tragic than the one who lives too long. Witness, for example, the melancholy history of Charles Edward Stuart, better known as Bonnie Prince Charlie, "The Young Pretender." To quote testimony from Vaughan Wilkins' new historical novel: "He was the bravest, gentlest and most honorable soldier in Europe."

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, May 10 (AP) -- Utah Democrats selected tonight twenty delegates to the national convention and, in close balloting, elected Milton Weilenmann, Salt Lake City Hospital Administrator, as state chairman.

City College, in a report issued yesterday, claimed unqualified success for the intensive business training courses given at its midtown center, 430 West Fiftieth Street, during the last five years. At the same time announcement was made that this summer the center would provide similar intensive courses in retailing for college graduates with the opportunity to work -- and be paid for it -- in some of New York's biggest retail establishments.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 10 -Connecticut Republicans have been unable to agree on a nominee for the United States Senate to oppose Senator William Benton and a state convention struggle over the nomination seems unavoidable.

UPTON, L. I., May 10 -- The general public got its first look today at a giant atomic accelerator, the Cosmotron, as 1,500 students and other guests participated in the Brookhaven National Laboratory's third annual visitor's day.

A PURPLE haze may be seen here and there among wood-lots in late April or early May. When glimpsed from the windows of a train or automobile, it is hard to identify the soft mass of color as the paulownia or empress tree in bloom.

The stock market drifted listlessly and closed mixed yesterday in the dullest and narrowest session in more than two and one-half years. With the steel and oil labor controversies remaining unsettled, traders continued to move cautiously.

LILACS, long the most popular of our flowering shrubs, are now in full bloom in New York City and environs. Farther north, it may be a month before lilacs open, for they are hardy anywhere in the Northern States from Maine to Oregon and Washington and in all Canada except the eoldest parts of Manitoba and Saskatchewan.

NEW DELHI, India, May 10 -- Chakravarti Rajagopalachari, chief Minister of the state of Madras, declared open political war yesterday on the Communist party, which has captured sixty-two of the 375 seats in the state legislative assembly and is attempting to overthrow the Congress party ministry through coalitions with other opposition groups.

WHETHER they are fantasy or everyday stories, all Miss Baker's books have a disarming make-believe quality about them. Even the everyday stories are romantic to the point of improbability, but they are also well-written, warm and humorous.

SCIENCE fiction is as old as the myth of Daedalus. Among its practitioners were Cyrano de Bergerac, who voyaged to the Moon long before Verne did, and Casanova of the scabrous memoirs, who also anticipated Verne by journeying to the earth's interior.

When director Joshua Logan began casting "Wish You Were Here," musical based on Arthur Kober's "Having Wonderful Time," he decided to seek out young people who might not have had years of Broadway experience, but who would look right at Camp Karefree, a summer spot in the Catskills, where "Wish You Were Here" is set.
The Korean truce negotiations came to another seeming impasse last week as the Communists rejected the United Nations' "final" truce offer.

New developments in the techniques and machine equipment of modern printing, and also the art of printing by hand press, will be described on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. by Ernst Reichl, book designer, in a lecture at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
Seven years ago last Thursday THE NEW YORK TIMES carried this headline:

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 10 (AP) -- Business warned Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, today that a Government-granted pay increase to steel workers could start an inflationary new round of wage increases and strike problems.

MADRID, May 10 -- Despite the strong criticisms that Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, the fiery Archbishop of Seville and former Primate of Spain, has been leveling at the Franco regime in the last few months, relations between church and state authorities in Spain are closer and better than in any country in Europe, including Italy.

MEXICO CITY, May 10 -- Temperamental Tommy Bolt of Durham, N. C., and Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago, a man without nerves on a golf course, remained tied for the lead in the $15,000 Pan-American Open golf championship today. Both carded 70's, two under par for the hazardous Mexico Golf Club layout.

SCIENCE fiction is as old as the myth of Daedalus. Among its practitioners were Cyrano de Bergerac, who voyaged to the Moon long before Verne did, and Casanova of the scabrous memoirs, who also anticipated Verne by journeying to the earth's interior.

When director Joshua Logan began casting "Wish You Were Here," musical based on Arthur Kober's "Having Wonderful Time," he decided to seek out young people who might not have had years of Broadway experience, but who would look right at Camp Karefree, a summer spot in the Catskills, where "Wish You Were Here" is set.
The Korean truce negotiations came to another seeming impasse last week as the Communists rejected the United Nations' "final" truce offer.

ATHENS, May 10 -- Acting Premier Sophocles Venizelos expressed reiterated approval today of a speech last night by Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, now on a visit here, in which the Deputy Supreme Commander, Allied Forces, Europe, recommended a reduction in the numerical strength of the Greek Army.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11 -- "One Little Boy," the recently published book written by Dorothy Baruch dealing with the problem of a maladjusted child, will be produced independently by Alex Gottlieb in the fall. Brandon de Wilde, who achieved fame on the stage in "The Member of the Wedding," will play the boy.
The oil strike forced new cuts in aviation schedules here and abroad yesterday, but no gasoline shortage marred the day for Sunday drivers.
Under no circumstances will Austria sign a separate treaty with the Western powers, Dr. Leopold Figl, Chancellor of Austria, said upon his arrival here yesterday.

The United Press story in THE TIMES of May 3 relates "Selective Service turned to the Bible today for what it termed the origin of the military draft," citing the Book of Numbers. If this is to be construed as giving divine sanction to the drafting of men to be soldiers they are on uncertain ground.
(Catastrophe: [Gr. katastrophe, to turn up and down * * *] 1. The final event in a drama, romance, etc. * * * denouement * * * -- Webster's New International Dictionary.)

CAIRO, May 11 -- All indications tonight were that the Egyptian Government would give an essentially negative answer to the British proposals for settlement of the Anglo-Egyptian dispute brought from London by Sir Ralph Stevenson, Britain's Ambassador, ten days ago. Egypt's reply may be made tomorrow.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- Pit trade in grain and soy bean futures fell off moderately last week compared with the preceding week, but was considerably larger than a year ago. Wheat assumed its normal leadership on the Board of Trade, but the activity in the big pit was only slightly larger than the trade in soy beans.

MADRID, May 11 -- Ecclesia, a weekly magazine that reflects the views of Spain's Roman Catholic hierarchy, accused two Catholic publications in the United States today of having "incurred real doctrinal errors contrary to papal encyclicals" in recent editorials discussing the Protestant situation in Spain.

ROME, May 11 -- With provincial and municipal elections in central and southern Italy two weeks away, the situation still was extremely uncertain today in three of the principal cities where voting will take place.

The following account by Stanford L. Zalberg, an International News Service correspondent who reached Koje Island on a fishing boat Saturday, was pooled by the Army for all American news services. He was the only correspondent to reach the prison island while Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd still was a captive of the Communist prisoners.

ALAPAHA, Ga., May 11 (UP) -- A new tornado striking more than eight hours behind other twisters and windstorms that killed four persons in the South roared through this little town today, injuring three persons and splintering buildings.

A police captain and a sergeant whose retirements on pension become effective on Friday unless a verdict is returned against them by that date are expected to take the stand in their own defense today at the resumption of the departmental trial of five plain-clothes men accused of accepting bookmaking graft from Harry Gross.

NEWARK, May 11 -- Officials of Essex and Union County communities near Newark Airport joined today in protesting the Port Authority's newly announced plan to reopen the airport to general use by Nov. 1, declaring that they opposed the reopening unless precautions were taken meanwhile to prevent the recurrence of air disasters such s those that took 119 lives last winter.

There is nothing in the rules governing the umpire, his rights, duties and responsibilities to indicate that Lou Boudreau's protest of yesterday's game between the Red Sox and Yankees at the Stadium will be upheld by Will Harridge, president of the American League.

The membership of the Richmond County Republican Committee, as well as rank-and-file members of the party, expressed surprise and regret yesterday over the announcement on Saturday night by former Representative Ellsworth B. Buck that he was resigning as county leader of the party.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- About an hour after noon tomorrow John W. Davis, eminent corporation attorney, is scheduled to rise in the Supreme Court to tell the nine justices why the steel industry believes its seizure under President Truman's orders is illegal and unconstitutional.
CHICAGO, May 11 (UP) -- Striking horse owners reached a last-minute settlement with officials of Lincoln Fields tonight, assuring opening of the track's meeting on schedule tomorrow.
TOKYO, Monday, May 12 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,247, covering Sunday's activities:

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- A special five-man Senate subcommittee including two former newspaper men will try to determine whether Government "censorship" is interfering with the free flow of legitimate news.

The old disagreement between governmental agencies on shipping subsidies moved into a new phase yesterday when Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer declared that he intended to abide by a contract between the Government and the United States Lines for construction of the new superliner United States.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A critic of the Administration's foreign trade and tariff policies charged today that Secretary of State Dean Acheson was not "facing the facts" when he recently upheld British and Italian protests against United States import restrictions.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 -- The ten-week-long strike on the Pacific Greyhound system which had halted bus service in seven Western states, was settled early today.

A growing tendency of Government restriction of the free gathering of legitimate news, in democratic countries as well as in totalitarian nations, was reported yesterday by the International Press Institute.

The five-story apartment house for seventy-two families at 685 East 140th Street, the Bronx, was sold by Abraham Langsdorf to a syndicate represented by the Investors Funding Corporation of New York, Jerome Dansker, president. It is on a plot 150 by 91 feet and was sold through Stanley Russell of Farber-Wittman, Inc., brokers.

CHICAGO, May 11 (UP) -- Pittsburgh swamped the Cubs, 11 to 2, on fourteen hits to divide a double-header today before 14,845 fans. Southpaw Paul Minner hurled Chicago to a five-hit, 8-to-2 victory in the first game.

Lamb is less of a luxury than it has been in some time. All cuts are cheaper than they were last fall, the local office of the Extension Food Marketing Program reports. They also are considerably cheaper than a year ago, as the Department of Markets recently pointed out to week-end shoppers.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 11 (UP) -- Brig. Gen. Bonner Fellers said tonight that General of the Army Douglas MacArthur had made his truce talk proposal last year because an intercepted message had indicated Communist forces in Korea could not hold out much longer.

A combined team representing four metropolitan clubs in the American Soccer League defeated the Paterson Dovers of the National League, 7 to 2, at Triboro Stadium on Randall's Island yesterday. This was a test match preliminary to the international game with Manchester United on the same ground next Sunday.

Most of us are familiar with the customs barriers of Europe. Every traveler on the Continent is indeed qualified to express himself vehemently on the conduct of inspection officers and the general foolishness of examining personal baggage. Our own customs officers, no matter how polite and considerate they may often be, are in duty bound to make things difficult for the returning traveler.

PITTSBURGH, May 11 -- The steel ingot rate regained 31 points to 81 per cent of capacity last week from the week before. The revised rate for the previous week was set at 50 per cent of capacity. These low rates were the result of strikes in the industry.

The twenty-fifth annual service for Knights Templar of twenty-six commanderies in the metropolitan district was conducted yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The sermon was by the Rev. E. Robert Chable, Grand Prelate of the Grand Commandery of the State of New York,

A chronology of events since Nov. 27, 1951, when the United Steelworkers and the steel industry opened negotiations on a new contract, shows, up to this point, the history of the controversy, passing through three more or less distinct stages. At the first stage public debate was confined largely to the merits of the union's wage demands themselves.

The many museum and gallery exhibitions this week include work by two important European artists -- sculpture by Henri Laurens at Curt Valentin's, opening today, and the showing tomorrow of a collection of Kandinsky paintings at Knoedler's (assembled by the Boston Institute of Contemporary Art), which are of especial interest.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 11 -- A report tending to explode popular myths about life in hot climates was read by Prof. W. S. S. Ladell of the Climate Physiological Research unit near Lagos in Nigeria before the United Nations Economic, Social and Cultural Organization's symposium on desert research in Jerusalem and has stirred widespread interest among Israelis.

SEATTLE, Wash., May 11 -- A blinding white flash at 1:26 o'clock this morning transformed the skies over Seattle into daytime brightness and was accompanied by a series of explosions that shook buildings and routed mystified residents over a wide area.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- A Government examiner today found ten manufacturers of metal building lath guilty of price-fixing and recommended that they be ordered to halt such practices.

People who "take themselves too seriously" and give themselves too much "credit" for their accomplishments were chided yesterday by the Rev. Charles J. McManus at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Father McManus, who is a member of the cathedral clergy, said that both types erred in overlooking their dependence on God.

The Phillies scored one unearned run at Ebbets Field yesterday but the Dodgers scored two of the same variety and the second one, in the tenth inning, gave them a 4-3 victory and moved them within one game of the idle first-place Giants.

BONN, Germany, May 11 -- One person was killed and two were injured today in fighting between the police and a Communist-led mob of at least 30,000 in Essen. It was the largest of three demonstrations organized by the Communists against the contractual agreement now being completed between the Western powers and the Federal Government and against West Germany's participation in European defense.

The perennial suspicions of American intentions to defend Europe in Europe must be accepted as an inevitable feature of the contemporary scene. Ever since the cold war began it has been necessary to fight against "third forces," neutralism, pacifism, Bevanism, fellow-traveling and unadulterated communism.

An appeal to 17,000 corporations for contributions to help overcome a "serious financial crisis" in the country's seventy - nine medical schools, in which it costs $7,000 more than tuition fees to train each doctor, is being mailed out today by the National Fund for Medical Education, 475 5th Ave.

The Very Rev. Dr. James A. Pike, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, declared in a sermon yesterday that an individual could "act right, without repression or frustration," only if he gave his first love to God.
ST. LOUIS, May 11 (UP) -- Harry Perkowski scattered eight Cardinal hits today to give the Reds an 8 to 5 victory.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 11 -- Under pressure of the rearmament program, world production in 1951 was the largest in history, yet the rate of increase in total production over that of 1950 was greater than the increase in military goods, statisticians of the United Nations disclosed today.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 11 (AP) -- Don Gehrmann of Wisconsin showed that his famous finishing kick was just as good in a straightaway race today when he won the fifth running of the boardwalk mile in a record for the event of 4:05.3.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Monday, May 12 -- Every effort was made yesterday by top-ranking military authorities in Korea to conceal the circumstances surrounding the seizure and release of Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd by Communist prisoners of war in a prison compound on Koje Island.

In the present crisis at home and abroad it is important to bear in mind that civilized men only in comparatively minor numbers have lived under free institutions. Historically considered, these institutions are on trial.

MANHASSET, L. I., May 11 -- Mr. and Mrs. James C. McGusty's chestnut gelding Darby Davis, ridden by Mrs. George H. Bostwick, won the hunter title at the annual Oaks Hunt horse show, feature of the North Shore spring festival on the Jock Whitney estate today.

As a result of the Mother's Day celebration yesterday, telephone operators across the country had a busy time of it. The large volume of calls brought delays of one to six hours in completing connections.

Summer camps already have mailed to the coming season's campers and their parents one or more sets of mimeographed greetings and instructions, which are being read not once but many times by parents and young campers-to-be alike.

General Ridgway left Tokyo this morning after more than a year of service as our top commander in the Far East. He had a hard job to do and he has done a good job. He takes on his new assignment with a record of substantial achievement in which his fellow-countrymen take pride.

The Third Avenue bridge across the Harlem River will be closed for repairs later this year when the Willis Avenue span is reopened to traffic, Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works, said yesterday in his annual report for 1951.

BIRDIE TEBBETTS is as intelligent and as articulate a man as you'll find in the major leagues. His frankness sometimes becomes painful, particularly when his barbed words puncture much too tender hides. Since he always gives an honest opinion, however, he was asked what he thought of the deal which brought Noren from Washington to the Yankees in order to fill the unfilled centerfield position.

The executive branch of the American Jewish Committee called yesterday on the three major religious faiths for a unified condemnation of racial and religious bigotry in the current Presidential primaries and the fall Presidential campaign, as the executive group ended its two-day semi-annual meeting at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Congressional interest in a proposed billion-dollar, four - year United States aid program for India appeared to be mounting this weekend as a result of the zeal and persuasive manner of a young Indian visitor.

HONG KONG, May 11 -- Karl L. Rankin, United States Minister to Nationalist China, declared today he was "very much more optimistic" about Formosa than when he took up his post there twenty-one months ago.

MEXICO CITY, May 11 -- With machine-like precision, Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago shot a sub-par 69 today to win the first Pan-American open golf championship on the new Mexico Golf Club course. Mangrum's 279 was nine strokes under par for the 72 holes, good enough for a six-stroke edge over Tommy Bolt of Durham, N. C., and $2,600 prize money.

Workers pushed ahead all day yesterday on the job of installing a new bow on the damaged aircraft carrier Wasp in drydock at the Bayonne Annex of the New York Naval Shipyard, in hope of restoring the 32,000-ton carrier to the fleet in record time.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 11 -- A new radar unit that is said to aid aerial navigators and to warn of bad weather or obstacles as far as 200 miles ahead of a plane is being produced here for the Navy and Air Force by the Radio Corporation of America.
Convalescent care for children 2 to 5 years old represented one of the heaviest demands on the services of the Children's Aid Society last year.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 11 (AP) -- Sam Snead remained sharp in the cold and rain today to shoot his fourth straight sub-par round and win his second consecutive Greenbrier open.
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., May 11 -- The Army Signal Corps announced today the development of a greatly advanced combat camera that is capable of taking ten pictures in as little as five seconds.
Rained out of their final double header in Boston the Giants arrived in New York last night elated over their most successful road tours in years.

Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, retired, national chairman of Citizens for Taft, announced yesterday formation of a city area branch, with Archibald B. Roosevelt, son of the late President Theodore Roosevelt, as chairman and Mrs. Paul R. Milton as co-chairman.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 11 -- Delegates to the eighteenth biennal convention of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C. I. O., meeting here this week, are expected to suspend for two years the rule compelling union officers to retire at the age of 65.

Prof. John Kenneth Galbraith has written a book that is a sitting duck for the misquoter. "American Capitalism"* already has been described as a defense of monopolies. It can as truly be called an appeal to the Government to help farm laborers and white collar workers to organize.

The trait of "greatness" is indicated in those persons who see good in others, do something for them or express gratitude for what others have done, Bishop Hampton T. Medford of the Twelfth Episcopal District of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church of Washington, declared in a general conference session of the denomination in Brooklyn yesterday morning.

PARIS, May 11 -- First estimates of exports for April showed today that they amounted to 67,000,000,000 francs. That figure about corresponds with the monthly average for the first quarter of the year, indicating a tendency toward stagnation.

BELLINGHAM, Wash., May 11 (AP) -- The trim Dragon Class craft Skiddo, skippered by W. L. (Bill) Horton of Wilmington, Calif., made a perfect double swing around Bellingham Bay today to win the Olympic trials.

BONN, Germany, May 11 -- Federal Germany is bound to carry out most of the economic reforms introduced into Germany by the conquerors of 1945 and to continue to make restitution to the victims of Hitler's regime under one of the key conventions of the contractual agreement.

The men's clothing industry operated at 77 per cent of capacity in the first quarter of 1952, compared with 98 per cent a year ago, according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. The figures are based on information supplied by the Bureau of Census.

Classic simplicity is the theme of the fashions offered today by Patterns of The Times. The big feature of these designs from Advance Pattern is that they make up into formals as well as street dresses.

The proof is in the pudding in the exhibition of children's art now in the Young People's Gallery of the Museum of Modern Art, for the paintings, collages, mobiles and sculptures that fill the room demonstrate that the museum's teaching techniques can result in personal, original and increasingly competent work.

The news that increases of up to 30 per cent in automobile liability insurance rates are in the offing for residents of New York City will certainly cause widespread anger and resentment. Granted that certain parts of this city have extraordinarily high loss records, the fact remains that the basis for determining automobile insurance rates is unrealistic and unjust.

A new comedy by Moss Hart, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, has been scheduled for production on Broadway this fall. Mr. Hart has delivered the script to Joseph M. Hyman and Bernard Hart, brother of the author, who will be the co-producers.

A patrolman and a detective who paid for their heroism with their lives and another patrolman who survived a revolver battle with a thug were cited yesterday for the police medal of honor, the highest award in the department.
PANAMA, May 11 -- Voting in Panama's national election today got off to a slow start and the polls were kept open beyond the scheduled 5 P. M. closing time in this city.
PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- The bulk of some 3,000 delegates to the convention of the United Steelworkers, C. I. O., are expected to register here tomorrow.
LOS ANGELES, May 11 (AP) -- Louise Brough upset Maureen Connolly of San Diego, the national champion, to win the women's singles title in the Southern California tennis tournament today.

MEXICO CITY, May 11 -- For the first time in 182 years Mexico's National Lottery has made a mistake. It was discovered today that in last Friday's drawing for a prize of 1,000,000 pesos (about $116,000), 2,000 numbers were left out of the basket from which the winner was plucked.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 11 -- The ground search for the wreck of the Pan American airliner that carried fifty persons to death when it crashed twelve days ago in the Amazon jungle has become a sort of circus for publicity hunters while search parties have only begun the trek toward the scene of the disaster.
The election of Alfred E. Daff, vice president and director of world sales of Universal Pictures Company, Inc., as a director has been announced by N. J. Blumberg, president.

AKRON, Ohio, May 11 -- Participation by the United States Government in an international commodity agreement or "cartel arrangement" in rubber would force this country further along the road to socialism and a lower standard of living, John L. Collyer, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company, declared here today.

CLEVELAND, May 11 (UP) -- Bob Lemon pitched a masterful two-hitter to beat the Browns 1 to 0, in the first game of a double-header today and then big Mike Garcia scattered eight hits to win the nightcap, 3 to 1, as the Indians took a two-game lead in the American League race.

LONDON, May 11 -- In his broadcast just over a week ago Prime Minister Winston Churchill said "if our present progress continues and is not upset by world misfortunes we ought before the end of the year to be paying our way."
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- It may be at least a year before any noncommercial, educational television stations are in operation. One of the big drawbacks is lack of income from commercial programs.
Bertrand Russell's fame for his frankness on such subjects as morals and sex led last night to his running afoul, by proxy, of the United States Customs.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has announced a school of television technique for politicians. According to the network, candidates who are afraid that they might offend will be taught how to talk, walk, sit down and get up in front of the cameras.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 11 -- Official French sources here emphatically deny that Jean Letourneau, French minister resident for the Associated States of Indo-China, has engaged in any effort to initiate peace negotiations with the Communist-led Vietminh.

TOKYO, Monday, May 12 (AP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, soldier diplomat and Pentagon troubleshooter, gave up General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's old job today to take over General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's command for the Allied powers in Europe.

LAKE GENEVA, Wis., May 11 (UP) -- An astronomer at the Yerkes Observatory said today that the phenomenon apparently was a "fireball" -- a big meteor heavy enough to penetrate into the earth's lower atmosphere. The expert, Prof. Gerard Kuiper, said, however, that he was inclined to doubt that the object had exploded at anything like 2,000 feet over Seattle, as reported.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The E. J. Lavino Company is involved in one of the great constitutional questions of our time, and no one is more surprised and displeased than the Lavino people.

The Canadian dollar last week suffered its sharpest setback since the upward movement began several months ago when it crossed parity with the American dollar for the first time since 1939. In the interval, it had risen to a premium of 2 3/16 cent, established on April 4.

Frank J. LaMorte and James Wilson of the host organization, the Staten Island Harriers, finished one-two in the metropolitan senior 10,000-meter championship walk at Clove Lake Park, S. I., yesterday. John R. Sterner of the Pioneer Club was second across the finish line, but was disqualified for illegal walking.

Parkchester in the Bronx, Stuyvesant Town in Manhattan, Clinton Hill in Brooklyn and some of the Sunnyside, Woodside and Astoria apartments in Queens are outstanding examples of how insurance companies have invested in real estate developments, providing homes for thousands of middle-income families.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Top American military leaders believe it is "quite likely" that the Kremlin has not yet decided whether all-out war with the West was inevitable, the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives said today.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 11 -- People who are chronically bored, or overcheerful or overgrave are frequently warding off deeper feelings of depression, rage and anxiety, Dr. Ralph R. Greenson, psychoanalyst, declared today.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Bureau of Agricultural Economics made an optimistic forecast today for business men who have been worrying in recent months because of a persistent lull in consumer buying.

DENNIS, Mass., May 11 -- New evidence dating their find in the last century today took the wind out of the sails of a party of amateur archaeologists who yesterday had dug up tools and timbers that they had hoped were of a ship cradle built on Cape Cod by Vikings about 1,000 years ago.

NEW DELHI, India, May 11 -- The lines of the battle between the Indian National Congress, which is the Administration party headed by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, the Communists and the Rightist Opposition are being drawn at party meetings being held in preparation for the opening Tuesday of India's first generally elected Parliament.

It may surprise many pleasant after-dinner conversationalists who never tire of expounding on the theme that advertising agencies do nothing but dream up tooth paste slogans that some members of the advertising fraternity follow current events religiously. They even relate them to their copy. Geyer, Newell and Ganger, Inc., is such a branch of advertising.

DETROIT, May 11 (UP) -- George Lerchen's eighth - inning single scored Johnny Lipon from second base to give Detroit a 2-1 victory over Chicago in the second game after the White Sox had won the opener, 6 -- 5.

SEATTLE, May 11 (AP) -- Betsy Rawls of Austin, Tex., fired a 69 -- six under women's par -- to win the Seattle link of the Weathervane open golf tournament today and take a nine-stroke lead over the field in the cross-country event.
BALTIMORE, May 11 (AP) -- The horses are even flying to Pimlico now that Hill Gall won't be in their way.

A program of songs unusual in its enterprise and musical worth was assembled by Richard Weagly for his Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon. The highlight was the first American performance of Andre Jolivet's "Suit Liturgique," a work scored for 'cello, harp, oboe and tenor.
PHOENIX, Ariz., May 11 (UP) -- The head of the Mexican Government petroleum industry made a plea today for help by United States contractors in exploring Mexico's oil reserves.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 11 -- The same Vienna opera company that gave nine days ago at the international exposition of "Masterpieces of the Twentieth Century" in Paris so authoritative and atmospheric a performance of Alban Berg's ultra-modern "Wozzeck" has been giving this week in Brussels a cycle of operas by Mozart.
Five new films, including a pair of imports from England, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

MOSCOW, May 11 -- The Soviet Press, led by Pravda and Izvestia today warned in editorials that if the West German Government signed the Contractual Agreement with the Western powers, the step might "submerge Germany in the malestrom of a new war."

DARIEN, Conn., May 10 -- Despite showery weather, several hundred persons attended the formal opening of the new $238,000 wing of the Holmes School here this afternoon and inspected the four classrooms and the combination library and dining room that constitute the addi tion. It is expected to be occupied this week.

The judicial process moves slowly, but in the public interest, in the city's fight on the smoke and soot nuisance. City Magistrate Louis A. Pagnucco, disposing of a waterfront violation case that had received a dozen court adjournments since mid-September, has upheld present smoke law and its delegation of power to the Bureau of Smoke Control.
The sanctity of the home and the dignity of motherhood were hailed yesterday in New York pulpits as prime bulwarks of democracy.

LONDON, May 11 -- A week of local elections, concluded yesterday with small rural and urban contests, showed that the Labor party had whittled Conservative and independent majorities in county councils almost everywhere.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Missouri Pacific Railroad Company declared today that gross irregularities figured in last year's voting on a reorganization plan for the big Mopac system.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP) -- The second game of a twin-bill between the Athletics and the Senators was rained out after two innings today. The Senators won the opener, 5 to 2, as the result of a Philadelphia fielding lapse.

AMSTERDAM, May 11 -- After a period during which the stock market seemed to have touched bottom, some demand developed last week for several leading shares including selected industrials, shipping and Indonesian issues.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, front runners for the Republican Presidential nomination, clash this week in two primaries and five party conventions from the Atlantic seaboard to Hawaii in which eighty-eight delegates to the national convention are at stake.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 11 -- Marshal Tito announced today that the Yugoslav Government would take appropriate measures to defend itself against the London agreement associating Italy more closely in the administration of Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste, which is controlled by British-American armed forces.
ELMIRA, N. Y., May 11 (AP) -- Representative Edwin Arthur Hall said today that it was about time that Representative W. Sterling Cole gave "somebody else a chance to get on the gravy train."

A report by Dr. Harry N. Wright on his eleven years as president of City College was made public yesterday by Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education. Dr. Wright will retire Sept. 1.

BUENOS AIRES, May 11 -- The crew of the world's largest factory whaler, the Juan Peron, 23,000 gross tons, continued their five-month vigil over minnows in a slip in Puerto Nuevo today as the nation's Appelate Court confirmed an embargo against the vessel's use because of irregular exchange dealings by her owners.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 11 -- Exploitation or "tapping" of the exceptional child's potential freedom and sources of ability and the lightening of pressure on the negative was the general theme of the fifth annual Conference on Mental Hygiene and Problems of Exceptional Children sponsored by the School of Education at Syracuse University.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 11 -- Dick Baldwin, a 15-year-old left-hander from Danbury, Conn., topped a field of 140 today as the forty-third annual invitation amateur trap-shooting championships of America came to a close at Travers Island.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, May 11 -- It is raining in the Congo, rain that falls in measureless melancholy, but this nevertheless is one of the brightest spots in many an African mile.

Persons who try to duplicate the darkened conditions of a motion picture theatre in their living rooms for watching a television set may cause eyestrain to the viewers, according to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

TOKYO, Monday, May 12 -- The Communist delegation negotiating at Panmunjom for an armistice in Korea has warned the United Nations Command against the use of violence among the war prisoners who captured, then released, Brig. Gen Francis T. Dodd, former commander of the internment camps on Koje Island, off the Korean south coast, the official Peiping radio said today.

Ignoring the program-making convention. Constantine Stronghilos in his Town Hall piano recital last night started off with the moderns and ended with the romantics. Music by Wallingford Riegger and Mr. Stronghilos occupied most of the fore-part of the program.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- The Army reported today that 4,400 combat-fit men have been transferred from desk jobs to field duty since the beginning of Congressional attacks on the "Army chair" corps. Lieut. Gen. A. C. McAuliffe, head of Army personnel, said an experiment in replacing able-bodied soldiers with civilians and WACs had proved successful and soon would be expanded.

As a Bolivian citizen I have followed with natural interest your news and comments on the recent events in Bolivia. I must confess I cannot understand why disparaging terms are invariably used to qualify the ideas and aims of the political party led by Victor Paz Estenssoro.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- Prospects of one of the largest winter wheat crops ever garnered in this country curbed buying of wheat last week, but in spite of this situation quite a respectable recovery was made from the recent low spots.

Austria desperately desires peace, but not at the price of a division of the country. This was the gist of Chancellor Figl's statement on his arrival yesterday for an official visit to the United States. He declared that his Government has no intention of concluding a separate peace with the Western Powers because this would mean the permanent splitting up of the capital and the country.

Betty will soon hear wedding bells, but she will not see her bridal gown. Her sight was lost through an accident. Only after a teacher on the staff of one of New York's voluntary services for the blind told Betty that she, too, was sightless could Betty be persuaded to attend the agency's workshop.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 11 -- The words "rob" and "larceny", the former on literature mailed by supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and the latter in a statement issued by backers of Senator Robert A. Taft, confronted voters of Oregon today, five days before Friday's primary election.

It was very cool for May yesterday and the unseasonably chill weather and the intermittent rainfall spoiled Sunday for a lot of New Yorkers. There was little strolling in the parks, and for the most part automobile excursions to the country were canceled.

Amid the sounding of gongs and the staccato blasts of thousands of firecrackers, the Eng Suey Sun Association of New York dedicated its new headquarters at 5 Mott Street yesterday afternoon and played host to the opening session of the group's second national convention. The organization is composed of 4,000 Chinese in the United States, all members of the Eng family, and is devoted to the maintenance of close family ties and mutual aid.

BONN, Germany, May 11 -- Historians from the United States and European countries, including Britain, France, Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Italy, Greece and Norway, will join German historians tomorrow in Brunswick for a ten-day conference.

" Revolution in China," by Charles Patrick Fitzgerald, an explanation of the revolution in its context of Chinese civilization and tradition, will be published by Frederick A. Praeger on June 20. The author, now teaching at the Australian National University at Canberra, lived in China for fifteen years.

On the eve of Alert America Week, to be proclaimed by Mayor Impellitteri at City Hall today, Arthur W. Wallander, retiring Civil Defense Director, declared that a lone plane, stringing a dozen of the latest type of small atom bombs from the Battery to the Bronx, could "almost completely destroy the entire city of New York in a single attack."

From time to time we have supported plans in Congress to separate airmail payments for both the domestic and international certified air carriers from subsidies to support such of these operations as still require them. Last year the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, under the chairmanship of Senator Johnson, held lengthy hearings on this subject which resulted in Senate Bill 436 which passed the Senate and went to the House.
The new main pavilion of Beth-El Hospital in Brooklyn, at Linden Boulevard and Rockaway Parkway, was dedicated yesterday at a brief ceremony attended by 250 persons.

EDGEWATER, N. J., May 11 -- The children of this little elongated borough, which hugs the west shore of the Hudson River opposite upper Manhattan, have a severe shock in store for them beginning Thursday night, when the town fathers will re-impose an old curfew law. It seems that many of the youngsters have been getting out of control of late and that vandalism is on the rise.

LOS ANGELES, May 11 -- Dr. Linus Pauling, head of the Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at the California Institute of Technology, disclosed today that the State Department had refused to issue a passport to him to visit Great Britain.

BONN, Germany, May 11 -- Germans have been absorbed for three and a half weeks in the sensational trial in Munich of Philip Auerbach, former chief of the Restitutions Office for the state of Bavaria, who has been indicted on many counts of fraud in paying false claims on funds allotted for Jewish victims of Nazism.

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., May 11 -- Scoring his fourteenth best of show. Ch. Dah-Lyn Kai Jin of Caversham, owned and shown by Jack Royce of Brookline, Mass., triumphed in the annual Windham County Kennel Club event of nearly 600 dogs under the judging of Mrs. William Constable today.

The United States Customs office denied yesterday that it had held up for censorship a tape-recorded interview with Bertrand Russell, British philosopher and Nobel Prize winner noted for his frankness on such subjects as morals and sex.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 -- Nine major film companies and a leading theatre circuit corporation were charged with violations of the Sherman Anti-trust Act in a $4,500,000 treble damages suit filed today in the United States District Court in Los Angeles by the former owners of the Vogue Theatre in Hollywood.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 12 (AP) -- Paul Harney, 22-year-old star from Holy Cross, upset the defending champion, Linc Roden of Yale, 1 up, today, to capture the Eastern intercollegiate golf title.
BALTIMORE, May 12 (AP) -- Max Kahlbaum, an astute German immigrant, and his horse Jampol put themselves right up among the top Preakness figures today by winning the $10,000 Preakness Prep.

BAYONNE, N. J., May 12 -- With his ship broken apart and sinking fast after a night Atlantic collision with the carrier Wasp, the skipper of the destroyer-minesweeper Hobson cryptically told an inquiring seaman: "Somebody didn't change course."

Sugar trading was slow yesterday. The No. 4 world contract on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange closed 2 points lower to 2 points higher on 1,650 tons. In the domestic market a cargo of Cuban, due tomorrow, was offered at a basis of 5.65 cents a pound.

Application of special Federal regulations to the toiletries industry, notably the extension of Food and Drug Administration rules to cosmetic products containing new ingredients, was criticized yesterday as unreasonable.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Senate investigators developed today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, had been assessed almost $4,000 more in Federal taxes when the Bureau of Internal Revenue refused to allow him to report a $10,000 fee received in 1948 as income for 1949.

The Berkshire Music Center at Tanglewood has been a germinal influence in the country's musical life, and one of its fruitful results was evidenced last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, when the Concert Choir, led by Margaret Hillis, gave a program of rare musical excellence.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Truman requested Congress again today to grant voting rights to hundreds of thousands of service men who could not qualify under state laws. He explained that most states with inadequate voting laws would not convene their legislatures this year.

Operations of Eversharp, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on Feb. 29, resulted in a consolidated gross income of $17,597,284, of which $16,604,960 represented net sales and the balance of $992,324 derived from other income. In the preceding fiscal year, consolidated gross income was $20,024,872, including $19,688,071 net sales and $336,801 of other income.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 12 -- The Connecticut Medical Examining Board today found Dr. Donald F. Gibson of Redding guilty on three of six charges of unprofessional conduct and recommended to the State Health Department that his license to practice medicine and surgery in Connecticut be revoked.

The sovereign state of New Hampshire announced yesterday that it was about to take measures to stop other states from pilfering New Hampshire's noblest scenery. Deacon Ralph H. Morse of the New Hampshire Planning and Development Commission burned the long distance lines out of Concord yesterday spreading the word.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 12 -- Thomas S. Lamont of New York, vice president of J. P. Morgan Company, was elected today to the seven-man corporation of Harvard University.

Now that a mental health program is in full swing, it is the proper time to think when and how to start mental health. We have learned from preventive medicine how to preserve the health of populations by starting to treat a child even before he is born, and many contagious diseases which took a high toll from youth are almost eliminated, such as smallpox, diphtheria, etc.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Government has taken new steps to gear up its normal war on insects and at the same time provide a skeleton defense organization against use of bugs in biological warfare.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 13 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, new United Nations commander in Korea, denounced last night as "unadulterated blackmail" the demands made by Communist war prisoners on Koje Island before they released the kidnapped camp commander, Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd.
PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -- The United Steelworkers of America, C.I.O., charged today that the Taft-Hartley Act had been a major factor in precipitating the steel labor crisis.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Deputy Attorney General A. Devitt Vanech, the second ranking official in the Department of Justice, failed to pass at least three bar examinations before he was admitted to practice, a House Judiciary subcommittee disclosed today.

LOS ANGELES, May 12 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia opened a three-day campaign tour of California today with a dig at Senator Estes Kefauver, his rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, for being "just a little left of the middle of the road."

In an election that offered no surprises, Richard M. Crooks, a partner of Thomson McKinnon, was chosen yesterday to succeed himself as chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Crooks, who lives in Summit, N. J., is 46 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- In an election-year Congressional session already noted for breaking records in conducting investigations, the House of Representatives voted by voice today to start three more.

Some of the 50,000 tenants in Manhattan and the Bronx who have been getting bills from their landlords for submetered electricity were puzzled yesterday about whom to pay for this month's electricity.

The price of lead was cut again yesterday, this time by 2 cents to 15 cents a pound, 4 cents below the ceiling level. The reduction was put in effect by the same large custom smelter which on April 29 cut the price to 18 cents and a few days afterward to 17 cents.

LONDON, May 12 -- The campaign by the Labor Opposition to frustrate attempts by the Conservative Government to restore part of the nationalized industries to private hands gained strength today among the unions of the Trades Union Congress, which is the backbone of the Labor party's strength in the country.

Virgil Peterson, Chicago lawyer and former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has written a history of Chicago crime and politics that will be published June 9 by Atlantic-Little, Brown. Mr. Peterson traces the origin and growth of organized crime in Chicago from the time the first political machine was formed shortly after the great fire in 1871.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- A fast moving rye market featured grain trading today, buying of this cereal being a belated reflection of the Government's bullish May crop forecast of less than 18,000,000 bushels, the smallest of recent years.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -The American Farm Bureau Federation called today for outright removal of price and wage controls. Spokesmen for other farm groups urged Congress to vote for suspending or lifting price ceilings on specific agricultural commodities.

PARIS, May 11 -- A question of newspaper ethics has arisen as a result of the publication by Le Monde of a document purporting to be a report by Admiral William M. Fechteler, and giving a pessimistic view of the defense of Western Europe.

HENRY GREEN is a baffling writer. Each of his novels presents a problem to prospective readers. Is it really as slight and trivial as it seems or is there more here than meets the eye? Many perceptive literary intellectuals on both sides of the Atlantic admire Mr. Green so fervently that one is tempted to feel humble in this ambiguous novelist's presence and to read into his works more significance than seems to be there.

LONDON, May 12 -- The United States, Britain and France were understood today to have reached substantive agreement on a four-point reply to the Soviet Government's notes of March 10 and April 9 calling for the unification of Germany under an all-German Government.

PARIS, May 12 -- Viscount Alexander, Britain's Minister of Defense, gave today what French officials described as convincing and satisfying assurances of Britain's willingness to associate her land, air and naval forces closely with those of the proposed European Defense Community.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 12 (AP) -- Dick Chapman of Pinehurst, N. C.. the defending champion, and Billy Maxwell, the United States amateur king from Odessa, Tex. head a record field of forty-one Americans entered in the British amateur golf championship.

ON this date a year ago the Giants were in seventh place with eleven games won and fifteen lost. Today they are leading the National League with fifteen won and only five lost, no longer the discouraged and frustrated fumblers they were at this time last season. They move with assurance and confidence as they return to the Polo Grounds tonight for a long stay at home after a rousing ten-for-eleven road trip.

In "The Taming of the Shrew," Biondello, Lucentio's servant, tells of a servant who gathered parsley to stuff a rabbit. Today's home cook may have other uses for this most common of herbs. She will do well to employ them frequently now, for though parsley is available the year round, May marks the beginning of the season when supplies, coming from near by, are most abundant.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Truman was reported today to be ready to invoke the Taft-Hartley Act's strike-stopping court injunction provisions unless the oil strike is settled soon.

Mayor Impellitteri proclaimed the opening of Hospital Week yesterday in a City Hall ceremony attended by Commissioner of Hospitals Marcus D. Kogel and Dr. Henry N. Pratt, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association.

Navy's undefeated varsity crew was seeded first yesterday for the heavyweight sprint regatta of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges. The races will be held Saturday on Carnegie Lake, Princeton, with the qualifying heats starting at 8:45 in the morning and the finals at 4 in the afternoon.
St. John's University took undisputed possession of first place in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference by defeating Brooklyn College, 4 to 0, at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Sir Gladwyn Jebb, permanent United Kingdom Representative to the United Nations, told 450 luncheon guests of the Economic Club of Chicago today that ejection of the Communist bloc from the world organization would reduce its membership to nations of the North American Treaty Alliance, the Pacific Pact countries and the states of Latin America.

MUNSAN, Korea, Tuesday, May 13 -- The Communists charged today that Allied planes strafed the enemy armistice delegation yesterday, killing one of its staff members. They also voiced further bitter charges against the Allied United Nations treatment of prisoners of war.

A scale model of the controversial playground designed for the United Nations site by Isamu Noguchi and rejected by Park Commissioner Robert Moses will go on display this morning at headquarters of Creative Playthings, 867 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Mrs. Toy Len Goon, the laundress whose struggle to bring up eight children as useful citizens won her the title of American Mother of 1952, was congratulated at the White House today by Mrs. Truman.

Prospects for Congressional approval at this session of a satisfactory mine-safety measure appear to be excellent. The Senate has adopted a safety bill and a House Labor subcommittee has sent to the full committee a proposal of its own. Both bills give the Federal Government power to close unsafe mines until dangerous conditions have been corrected, but they differ in detail.
THE local fishing was only half successful over the weekend, and many of those who planned a full two days headed for home after hearing the Sunday morning weather report.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Since a majority of the Supreme Court has the power to dispose of any case before it by a general or specific ruling on the issue presented by the lawyers on either side, or to state another issue and leave the main point undecided, it is the most futile kind of crystal-gazing to try to foresee exactly what the court will do about the Presidential seizure of the steel companies.

Although they have until midnight tomorrow to cut down to the legal limit of twenty-five players, the Yankees, who were four over, yesterday optioned two men and were arranging for the disposal of another. That left them with only one player to be lopped off the roster.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 12 -- More "well-qualified women running for higher political offices" were called for here today by Mrs. Hiram Cole Houghton, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, as the organization, representing more than 11,0000,000 women in the world, opened its sixty-first annual convention.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Defense Department declared tonight that the agreement reached by Brig. Gen. Charles F. Colson with Communist leaders in the Koje Island prison camp off Korea gave several erroneous impressions.
SHEFFIELD, England, May 12 (AP) -- There's hardly a speck of dust on new British motor cars bound for New Zealand these days.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 2 -- Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C. I. O., demanded today that defense procurement responsibilities be taken out of the hands of the military.

Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires drew in the seventeenth test of their eighteen-game chess match yesterday, according to a report from San Salvador. Thirty-seven moves were recorded.

PARIS, May 12 -- A new outburst of clandestine bombings and clashes between the police and nationalists in the French protectorate of Tunisia prompted French authorities there today to tighten the curfew in Tunis and the suburban area.

WILMINGTON, N. C., May 12 -- The Federal Government began a major attack on recent Ku Klux Klan terrorism in the Carolinas today when it brought eleven former Klan members into court here on a two-count indictment charging kidnapping and conspiracy.
Many are the prospective girl graduates now faced with the problem -- and a pleasant one at that -- of selecting dresses to wear for approaching commencement exercises.

MADRID, May 12 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco has dropped from the National Council of the Falange party Col. Luis Serrano de Pablo, a Spanish Civil War hero of the Nationalist forces, who caused a considerable stir in the Spanish political world last winter with his criticism of the Government's policy.

A major demonstration of the problems and progress of civil defense, on the local, state and national levels, had its official preview last night at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue. Earlier in the day, at City Hall, Mayor Impellitteri had proclaimed Alert America Week, preliminary to the public opening of the defense exhibition at 10 A. M. today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 12 -- The Yugoslav Government is scheduled to announce soon the measures it will take in retaliation against the decision of the British and United States Governments to give to Italy greater control over the civil administration of Zone A of Free Territory of Trieste.
Dr. Harry N. Wright has been president of City College through a difficult period, but a time in which the college has been of tremendous usefulness to youth, to the community and to the nation.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Tuesday, May 13 -- Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd, former prison camp commander, revealed last night how he had acted as middleman in the barter deal for his life between Communist prisoners of war and Allied troops surrounding the prison compound in which he was held hostage on Koje Island.
COOS BAY, Ore., May 12 -- "Too much secrecy in Government" was blamed today by Gov. Earl Warren of California for many of the scandals in Federal agencies during the Truman Administration.

I read in THE TIMES of May 9 the story of how the U. N. air force "wiped out the ancient city of Suan" in an all-day raid that was initiated by dumping 12,000 gallons of flaming gasoline on the town and its inhabitants.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The United States has assured Britain that this country still adheres to the "basic principle" of lowering international trade barriers and believes import duties should be increased only in cases of "genuinely serious injury."
LEONIA, N. J., May 12 -- A highly developed sense of civic responsibility on the part of Leonia's citizens has created what is described as a new type of Youth Museum in this community of 7,500.

ANGOLA, La., May 12 (AP) -- Twenty-five leaders of a four-day sitdown and hunger strike were in solitary confinement at the State Penitentiary here tonight after the strike had been broken by a gas attack on the dining hall of Camp H.

The stock market had considerable difficulty yesterday in charting a definite course. On balance prices drifted to an easier level in the slowest trading since October, 1949. Price changes in the main were within a fractional range and the ratio between the stocks to advance or decline proved meager.

LONDON, May 12 -- Virtually all sections of the London stock market were quietly dull today. Most British Government securities finished around five shillings (70 cents) cheaper, while losses in the industrials were around one shilling. Electrical equipment issues were among the few that resisted the trend.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- Admiral William M. Fechteler said today that a Paris newspaper report that he believed the Soviet Union could overrun Western Europe in three days was "completely fantastic."
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- By a 6-3 vote, the Supreme Court today set aside the contempt of court conviction of James Singleton of Philadelphia.

Judge Harold R. Medina indicated in Federal Court here yesterday that he was satisfied with the stand taken by Government counsel in the anti-trust investment banking case in connection with the Government's recent motion to include, by amendment to the complaint, the charge that all syndicate price-fixing was illegal, even if not otherwise related to conspiracy.

Despite the fact that the Civil Aeronautics Board has refused to permit Seaboard and Western Airlines to fly scheduled freight services across the Atlantic, along with its competitive Transocean Air Lines, Seaboard, celebrating its fifth anniversary of irregular freight flying yesterday, showed that it is doing very well.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Administration argument in the steel seizure hearing that the President had inherent or basic powers that justified such action in emergencies brought one sharp comment from Justice Douglas that the argument seemed to be there was "no apparent need for Congress."

Six trans-Atlantic liners, carrying almost 4,500 passengers, will arrive here between 8 A. M. and 11 A. M. today, creating the most serious examination and clearance problem of the year for the understaffed Customs, Immigration and United States Public Health Services.
BERLIN, May 12 -- Walter Ulbricht, Deputy Premier of East Germany, made today what appeared to be a threat of new pressure on West Berlin if West Germany joined the European Defense Community.

CASPER, Wyo., May 12 (AP) -- Wyoming's Republican convention gave-Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio at least six national convention delegates today against two for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower. Twelve delegates were elected, with four saying they were uncommitted for any Presidential aspirant.

The five-member Board of Health, at its regular monthly meeting yesterday, voted to double the $10 permit fee paid annually by each of 22,000 local restaurants. The new $20 fee becomes effective July 1.

Although operating revenues of W. R. Grace Co. and all its majority-owned subsidiaries other than Grace Staff Corporation and Grace National Bank of New York, in 1951 were 32 per cent above the level of the previous year, taxes reduced net profit by 19 per cent.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 12 (UP) -- Rocky Marciano, heavy-weight star from Brockton, Mass., knocked out Bernie Reynolds of Fairfield, Conn., in two minutes 21 seconds of the third round tonight before 4,528 fans at the Rhode Island Auditorium in a scheduled ten-round bout.

HOUSTON, Texas, May 12 -- The contention that the nation is and has been in a sound prosperity is the greatest hoax ever perpetrated on the American people, the executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men said here today.
BOSTON, May 12 (AP) -- Reorganization of the Waltham Watch Company was completed today before Chief Judge George C. Sweeney in Federal court.

CORINTH, Greece, May 6 -- Archaeological disclosures likely to increase considerably man's knowledge of ancient Greek culture and customs are the unexpectedly early fruit of American field operations now in progress at the eastern end of the Corinth Canal. Here in classic times stood a sanctuary of Poseidon (Neptune to the Romans), a theatre and a stadium.

LONDON, May 12 -- British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden expressed regret in the House of Commons today that Marshal Tito had attached the British-American agreement giving Italy greater administrative responsibility in Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste.

Louis F. Budenz began his third week on the witness stand yesterday at the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders, undergoing sharp questioning on his definitions of Marxism-Leninism and "Aesopian" language.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Revision of the social security laws so that nearly all retired persons receiving old age and survivors insurance would have their benefits increased by 12 1/2 per cent, or at least $5 a month, was proposed in a bill introduced today in the House of Representatives by Representative Robert L. Doughton, Democrat of North Carolina.

HONOLULU, May 12 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway and his family were due to take off from Hickam Field here tonight on the next stage of their flight from Tokyo to his new assignment as Supreme Commander, Allied Powers in Europe, after a day passed resting in Hawaii.
LONDON, May 12 (Reuters) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said today that Britain has made no commitment to join any United States blockade of Communist China if the Korean truce talks fail.

Frank Costello's contention that he was legally justified in refusing to answer questions by the Senate Crime Investigating Committee fourteen months ago was sharply questioned yesterday by three judges of the United States Court of Appeals, who reserved decision on Costello's appeal from a contempt-of-the-Senate conviction.
ROME, May 12 -- A thousand liters (1,056 quarts) of Italian wine has been sent by the Pontifical Relief Commission to flood victims in the United States.
CAIRO, May 11 -- The Prosecutor General presented his indictment today against those accused of having been principally responsible for the great riots here Jan. 26.

After reading in the International Air Edition for April 21 the article "Four Bills Calling for New Taxes," by Paul Crowell, I searched the "Spanish scene," where imposts are a fine art, and came up with a source which brings tremendous revenue to the Franco treasury. It is a tax on razor blades which amounts to 1.35 pesetas per box of ten blades, plus a stamp tax of 10 centavos.

Given to the Greater New York Fund, your dollar is a miraculous thing. It is endowed with powers you yourself do not have, it speaks languages you cannot speak; lifts burdens you cannot touch with your fingers; saves lives with which you cannot directly deal. Your dollar knows no politics, no color or creed.
Thomas Weitemeyer, art gallery, in 954 Madison Ave; Louis H. Green, advertising, David Lipman, George H. Wiley, in 735 Lexington Ave -- Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc, brokers.
PARIS, May 12 (AP) -- Eric Johnston, spokesman for the Hollywood movie industry, said today that "France is the most restricted film market in the world outside of the Iron Curtain countries."

Another change in the ever-shifting agency scene took place yesterday with the announcement by Thomas L. L. Ryan, president of Pedlar Ryan, that he will retire on Oct 1. At that time one of his chief accounts, Camay Toilet Soap (a Procter Gamble Company product) will move to Benton Bowles, Inc.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- The Senate approved an amendment to the Taft-Hartley Act today to make bargaining regulations "more convenient" for building trades workers and the construction industry.

A motorcycle patrolman was chased and knocked from his vehicle in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon by a motorist who had shouted, after getting a traffic ticket: "This is the last summons you will ever serve."

The Broadway engagement of "Shuffle Along," the 1952 edition of the successful all-Negro musical comedy of the early Twenties, has suspended for two weeks. The show, featuring Flournoy Miller, Noble Sissle, Eubie Blake, Delores Martin, Napleon Reed, Hamtree Harrington, Earl Sydnor, Avon Long and Thelma Carpenter, opened last Thursday at the Broadway Theatre, under the auspices of Irving Gaumont, and continued through Saturday.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 12 (AP) -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan told a questioner in Parliament today that the 200,000-member war veterans' group, Torch Commando, was a subversive organization that contemplated "lawlessness and the overthrow of authority by means of force."

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 12 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today captured all eight Rhode Island delegates to the Republican National Convention in the face of a State Republican Central Committee proposal to send a "harmony" slate to the convention, which opens in Chicago July 7.

The newest model of the compact, portable machine for collecting and processing human blood, developed at Harvard University last year, was demonstrated yesterday at the opening of the annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York at the Statler Hotel.

The four-day departmental trial in Brooklyn Borough Hall of five plainclothes men charged with taking bookmaking graft from Harry Gross ended yesterday afternoon. Trial Commissioner James A. Delehanty promised an overnight decision in the case of Lieut. Thomas J. Evans, one of the defendants, whose retirement becomes effective at midnight.

WITH THE TWENTY-FIFTH DIVISION, in Korea, May 12 -- The United States Army's new protective vests, made of twelve layers of tough nylon, have proved to be lifesavers in Korea, the chief of a test team said today.

H. Robert Reeve of the New York Athletic Club, the defending titleholder, yesterday gained the semi-final round of the national squash tennis championship by beating Louis Krauthoff of the host organization, 15 -- 9, 15 -- 6, at the Columbia University Club.

BONN, Germany, May 12 -- A new problem was added to the many facing Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and the Federal Government today when Christian Fette, chairman of the West German Trade Union Federation, threatened the application of "all union measures" to defeat the factory constitution law now being prepared by the Bundestag (Parliament).

Proposal to reduce the authorized shares of senior preference stock in the American Investment Company of Illinois and to increase par value were approved yesterday by shareholders at the annual meeting. There are now 160,000 shares of $50 par value stock authorized.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Earl J. McGrath, United States Education Commissioner, told a conference of leaders of the General Education Movement today that hope of future peace lay in the spread of this system.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., May 12 -- Clarence Doser of Scarsdale, who led the metropolitan district qualifiers for the national Professional Golfers Association championship two years ago, did so again today in the trials held at the Vernon Hills Country Club.

Apropos the Administration's argument before the Federal District Court that the President is vested with "implied powers" by the Constitution, it is of interest to recall that Alexander Hamilton, then a leader of the conservative and quite reactionary Federalist party, 150 years ago claimed that the Constitution gave implied powers to the President.

WEST POINT, Pa., May 12 -- The greatest economy must be exercised in using blood because the supply, unlike the ever increasing demand, is not inexhaustible, Dr. Douglas M. Surgenor of Harvard University warned here today.

American achievements of the last 150 years are but a prologue to the future, Edward T. McCormick, president of the New York Curb Exchange, told an audience yesterday at the University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa. He was made an honorary member of Beta Gamma Sigma at a joint convocation of the fraternity and the School of Commerce and Business Administration of the university.
Cotton future prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 4 to 15 points net lower than on Friday after a rather dull day.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- In the hearing of arguments today, Chief Justice Vinson and Justices Jackson, Douglas, Burton and Frankfurter cut in with questions that at times appeared to put Mr. Perlman on the defensive. He appealed to them at one point to "let me finish."

Appointment of Dean Carpenter, a vice president and a director of Hilton Hotels International, Inc., as special European representative for the Hilton Hotels Corporation, was announced yesterday by Conrad N. Hilton, president.

BONN, Germany, May 12 -- The terms under which responsible West German politicians would agree to the holding of elections in East Germany as a first step toward the reunification of Germany now include the abolition of the military units in the People's Police and the freeing of 40,500 political prisoners held in East Germany.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- The Air Force disclosed today that it would need at least $5,000,000,000 to build extra bases for an expanded air arm of 143 wings.
