For the first time since its establishment in 1812, the New York City Mission Society last night named a group of women to serve on its board of directors. Elected at the organization's annual meeting at Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street, the new board includes twenty-four men and an equal number of women.

The formation of a student committee to fight the removal of Dr. Harold Lenz as dean of students at Queens College was authorized yesterday by the college's student council. More than 350 students attended the council's meeting in Ira Remsen Hall on the Flushing Campus to protest the removal.

Benjamin F. Fairless, president and chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, has been selected to receive the John Fritz Medal, often called "the highest award in engineering," it was announced last night. The certificate will cite Mr. Fairless as a "champion of the American free enterprise system for notable industrial achievement in the production of steel."
The State of Massachusetts borrowed $53,860,000 in the public market yesterday on issues of bonds maturing serially over twenty years at an interest cost of 1.52968 per cent.
We are sadly disappointed in the explanation advanced by supposed experts for the blinding flash which occurred over Seattle the other night.
LONDON, May 12 (AP) -- The forty-six countries seeking to shape a new International Wheat Pact today tossed the price question to a special committee after kicking it around for three weeks.

" Hylan's a Folly," a term applied now and then to a group of twelve piers built on Staten Island in the Nineteen Twenties, is no longer a fitting appellation. For the first time, except for war years, the entire group of piers is on the verge of full occupancy.

MONTREAL, May 12 (Canadian Press) -National Breweries, Ltd., became Dow Brewery, Ltd., by vote of shareholders today at a special general meeting. Wilfrid Gagnon, chairman of the board and president, told the stockholders definite advantage would be gained because the new name is the same as that of the company's principal product.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 12 -- The Johannesburg City Council has agreed to the Nationalist Government's plan to move 58,000 natives (Negroes) from the so-called "black spots" in Johannesburg's western suburbs to new, exclusively native, townships to be established farther out of the city.

Buying was heavy yesterday at the Popular Price Shoe Show of America at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels. Registration, more than 2,900 for the two days, was well over a year ago and established a record for early attendance.

MANILA, May 12 -- The Philippine Senate unanimously ratified the mutual defense treaty with the United States today after a four-day debate marked by Opposition claims that it gave insufficient guarantees against possible future aggression by Japan.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Tuesday, May 13 -- Appeasement as a means of operating Communist prisoner of war camps on Koje Island seemed to have been proved a complete failure by the statements made yesterday by Allied authorities involved in the release of Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd from a Communist compound in which he was held as hostage from last Wednesday to Saturday.

The Parents League of New York will form a young players' orchestra for boys and girls between the ages of 8 and 14, it was announced yesterday at the group's annual luncheon meeting. The meeting was held at the Women's City Club, Hotel Sulgrave, Park Avenue at Sixty-seventh Street.

New York City should abandon further thought of the Hudson River as its major future source of water supply and rely on upland sources, principally the Delaware River and its tributaries, Dominick F. Paduano, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, told Mayor Impellitteri yesterday.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 13 -- The Communists served notice yesterday on the United Nations Command that they meant to continue the daily meetings of the delegations at Panmunjom, but would "never" accept Allied conditions for an armistice in the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- The Department of Defense told Congress today that it opposed development of civil jet airliners at present because such a move might interfere with military aircraft production.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that if Congress cut the Mutual Security Program more than $1,000,000,000 under the $7,900,000,000 asked by President Truman there would be far-reaching results "both in discouraging our friends and in encouraging those potentially hostile to us."

BRUNSWICK, Germany, May 12 -- United States and German historians in the presence of historians of several other countries of Western Europe started today a ten-day intensive review of United States and German history textbooks with an eye to eliminating errors of fact and emphasis that have grown out of national viewpoints.

Unusual shapes and glazes distinguish the two new groups of ceramic objects on exhibit at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street. The ceramics were made by Fred Farr, an instructor at the Brooklyn Museum School, and Frans Wildenhain, who teaches at the School for American Craftsmen in Rochester.

The problem of what to do with 347 of 580 bus operators and dispatchers now on the Board of Transportation's payroll loomed yesterday as a possible complication in the city's efforts to sell its five deficit-ridden bus lines in Manhattan to a private operator.
The chips are down in Germany and the decisive phase of the struggle for Europe has started.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 13 (AP) -Eighth Army tactical summary 55, for Monday's action:

CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 12 -- Backers of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio forecast tonight a clean sweep for their candidate at tomorrow's Republican Presidential popularity contest in West Virginia and in the election of eighteen delegates to the G. O. P. national convention.
NEW ORLEANS, May 12 -Senator Paul Douglas, Illinois Democrat, indicated today he was undecided whether he would accept the Presidential nomination of his party if it were offered.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 12 -- In spite of new scientific developments to combat mental illness, psychiatrists should remember that technology cannot replace the relationship between the doctor and the patient, Dr. Leo H. Bartemeier, president of the American Psychiatric Association, declared here today.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A major political battle is now developing over the seating of outstanding Taft and Eisenhower delegations from seven Southern States at the Republican National Convention in Chicago July 7.

Sales of leading mail order and chain stores for April showed an aggregate increase of 13.2 per cent over volume of the month last year according to a compilation of figures for forty-two companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 12 -- A new global survey of social conditions was issued by the United Nations today. The report underscored the critical needs of underdeveloped countries for more food and housing and better health and education.

Three films have been added to the attractions arriving this week, thus bringing the total to eight. On Thursday "The Outcasts of Poker Flat," Twentieth Century-Fox's adaptation of the Bret Harte story, with Anne Baxter, Dale Robertson, Miriam Hopkins and Cameron Mitchell, will arrive at the Mayfair.

James A. Wechsler, editor of The New York Post, will speak at City College on "The Newspaper of Today and Tomorrow" at 8:30 P. M. today. The talk, first of two sessions in the fourth annual John H. Finley series of public lectures on "The Newspaper and Society," will be held in the faculty room of the Main Building, Convent Avenue and 139th Street.

Congress gets so much abuse from all sides when the time comes to work out appropriations, grants and loans for foreign countries that it would be unfair to withhold praise when it is due. So far as India is concerned both houses and many individual Congressmen are showing a proper awareness of the problems involved and of the role that the United States can play.
GENEVA, May 12 -- A young housing expert from Tucson, Ariz., has worked out a principle whereby "homes in the place of hovels" could be provided for the teeming millions of Asia.

Roger N. Baldwin, former director of the American Civil Liberties Union, said last night that the steps taken by the Federal Government to combat the Communist menace had contributed to raising the national temperature of intolerance.

BOSTON, May 12 -- The Federal Government, through "a general pattern of favoritism to the South," has contribute to the serious slump in New England's textile industry, the New England Governor's Committee on Textiles reported today.

A veteran destroyer and amphibious-craft officer who saw action in the Pacific and European theatres in the last war will direct the small-boat patrol that enforces the Federal anti-pollution laws in the Port of New York and its approaches.
A world that only artists could dream up when they let themselves go took shape yesterday in the Astor Hotel via gallons of paint, vast stretches of mural surface and glittering metallics.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A plea to uphold President Truman's seizure of the steel industry on the basis of unspecified emergency powers in the Constitution ran into a barrage of questions and substantial doubt in the Supreme Court of the United States today.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 21 -Vietminh propaganda is attempting to capitalize on a current wave of rumors and speculations regarding the possibility of peace negotiations in the Indo-China war. Competent observers, however, doubt that the Vietminh regime and its backers -- Peiping and Moscow -- really are planning a genuine peace effort.

The month of May is still not behaving like her own sweet self. On Sunday she acted as if she were April. Cold and unfriendly showers fell intermittently through the day. Yesterday May borrowed a leaf from March's book.

Henry G. Beaumont of Los Angeles, president of the Institute of Real Estate Management, will be guest of honor and speaker at a dinner sponsored by the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York on Thursday at the Brass Rail Restaurant, 521 Fifth Avenue.

The month of May is still not behaving like her own sweet self. On Sunday she acted as if she were April. Cold and unfriendly showers fell intermittently through the day. Yesterday May borrowed a leaf from March's book.

Henry G. Beaumont of Los Angeles, president of the Institute of Real Estate Management, will be guest of honor and speaker at a dinner sponsored by the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York on Thursday at the Brass Rail Restaurant, 521 Fifth Avenue.

John Foster Dulles, Republican expert on foreign affairs, recommended here last night that the free people of the world "invent ways to defend the entire frontier of freedom," preferably through the creation of an effective striking power, soundly financed, "openly organized and clearly defined."

LONDON, May 12 -- The American State Department's action in refusing a passport to Prof. Linus Pauling of the California Institute of Technology, thus preventing him from attending scientific gatherings here this month, has drawn criticism from leading British scientists.

Keeping clear of trouble, Mrs. Henry Obre's Coup-de-Vite won the Belmont National Maiden Hurdle Stakes yesterday. The fifth running of the event served as the feature on the program at Belmont Park, and was witnessed by a crowd of 19,400.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, predicted today that United States airlines would turn to using British planes on international routes unless the United States Government subsidized construction of American jet-powered transports.

Donors in the metropolitan area contributed 861 pints of blood to the American Red Cross on Monday, officials of the agency reported yesterday. The contributions were headed by the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, whose employes gave 378 pints, and the Naval Supply Corps School, Bayonne, N. J., with 158 pints.

The rites of May were celebrated yesterday by nearly 3,000 school girls under a cold and clouded sky. Breezes blew sharply over the Sheep Meadow in Central Park where the annual frolic was held, giving the dancers still more reason for showing their exuberance.

Except in rubber, of which 1,280 tons was exchanged, volume ebbed in commodity trading in New York futures markets yesterday. On the Commodity Exchange news from both Singapore and London sent rubber prices up 65 to 100 points. Hides also showed strength after recent weakness and climbed 30 to 40 points on sixty-five sales.

LONDON, May 13 -- The United States, British and French Governments proposed to the Soviet Union today that an impartial commission should immediately determine whether there existed in East Germany and in West Germany the conditions necessary for holding free elections.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 -- The United States Government won a legal skirmish today in its effort to retain control of the $68,000,000 American President Lines, which the R. Stanley Dollar interests, pioneer shipping operators, have sought to reclaim
The Public Service Commission's grant of an additional cent on each single-fare ticket and of increases on other tickets for the Long Island Rail Road will be effective today.

The family unit, basic to our democracy, is often in trouble in these days of world unrest and tension. One of the most important aspects of work done by the Greater New York Fund service agencies is in the field of counseling to families and individuals.

BONN, Germany, May 13 --- The West German Government has prepared a draft for an anti-trust law that despite the original inherent unwillingness of its framers to make it so, may prove to be a model for Europe, according to Allied experts. Some German industrialists wryly concede they are of the same opinion.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 13 --A fantastic encounter between the pilot and radio operator and a four-foot green mamba, a deadly African snake, at the moment of takeoff from Dar es Salaam, Tangyanika, East Africa, recently was described at Durban today by Alan Hannaford Rice, the radio operator.
Elizabeth Arden's summer collection of ready-to-wear fashions, starring white for day and evening, were presented at a luncheon yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

ST. LOUIS, May 13 (AP) -- A three-run fourth inning, highlighted by a triple to center field by Pitcher Bobby Shantz, gave the Athletics all the runs they needed tonight to defeat the Browns, 5 -- 1. Shantz, tossing a five-hitter, allowed only one safety after the third inning.

The Museum of Modern Art opens today the fourth in its series of new talent exhibitions. Four artists are represented -- Philip Elliott, director the Albright Art School in Buffalo, and Gorman Powers, formerly of Chicago and now residing at Croton Falls, N. Y., both painters; Walter Rogalski of Glen Cove, L. I., represented by engravings, and Carol Summers of New York, who is showing woodcuts, mostly in color.
The American Export Lines announced joyfully yesterday that the liner Constitution had lost a passenger on the last trip.

The oil industry must spend an additional $8,000,000,000 between now and the end of next year if the expansion program of the Petroleum Administration for Defense is to be carried out, S. A. Swensrud, president of the Gulf Oil Corporation, said yesterday.

LONG BEACH, Calif., May 13 (UP) -- Two planes collided 15,000 feet in the air today and plunged into the ocean off the coast of California. Of the fourteen persons in them, six were rescued and one body was recovered.
BALTIMORE, May 13, (UP) -The pre-race favorite, Sub Fleet, went through his last extended workout today in preparation for Saturday's Preakness.

As the warm weather approaches, homemakers may want to refurbish the decor of their "outdoor living rooms.' Advice on painting outdoor furnitur and fiber rugs, as well as the exterior of the house, which may form a backdrop to the terrace or garden, has been included in some recent bulletins.

Exporters affected by Chile's April 24 suspension of its non-licensed import system were still left with uncertainties yesterday on the South American country's belated reply to successive trade requests for exemption of orders placed prior to the sudden suspension.

The Museum of Modern Art, which has achieved so enviable a record in art education for children, now is bringing its resources to television in a new program presented at 12:30 P. M. Sundays over WNBT. The program is called "Through the Enchanted Gate" and, once the rough edges are smoothed out, it should be an excellent addition to children's viewing fare.

BAYONNE, N. J., May 13 -- The 32,000-ton carrier Wasp started a last-minute left turn of her own just before the abrupt left turn by the destroyer-minesweeper Hobson that wound up in a collision that sank the smaller vessel April 26 with the loss of 176 men.
The city put a friendly arm about the shoulders of its oldest business and industrial concerns yesterday and publicly acknowledged their contribution to its progress.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Spokesman for more than twenty organizations urged Congress today to allow personal income tax deductions for payments to private retirement funds.

New offerings of corporate-debt securities totaling $110,300,000 will be offered to investors today by underwriting syndicates. The new issues will raise funds to increase working capital and to finance capital outlays of two industrial companies and will help finance the purchase of new Diesel locomotives for an Eastern railroad.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 14 -- The Communists today redoubled their charges of war atrocities against United Nations troops fighting in Korea. The Peiping radio said this morning that United States planes and artillery dropped poison gas projectiles over Chinese and North Korean lines five times last month, once within five miles of the Kaesong headquarters of the Communist truce delegation.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, May 14 (AP) -- The United States Fifth Air Force today credited its Sabre jet pilots with destroying five Soviet-built jets -- one without firing a shot -- in six dogfights Tuesday between Pyongyang and the Manchurian border.
PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- The threat of a new steel strike was raised today by the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O.

THERE was an item in the papers the other day that Adolph Rupp, University of Kentucky basketball coach, had withdrawn from a Texas coaching clinic "to avoid further discussion of the issue in Texas." It's nice to know that Adolph finally has had a pang of conscience.

CLEVELAND, May 13 -- Manager Casey Stengel tonight experimented with Mickey Mantle as a third-base replacement for Dr. Robert Brown, but the move became just another incident as the Yankees bowed, 10 -- 6, because the Indians said it with home runs against Lefty Bill Miller and Joe Ostrowski and plastered Bob Kuzava with five of their fifteen hits.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Dr. Leopold Figl, Chancellor of Austria, left a White House conference "happy" at assurances he said had been given him that the United States would do all it could to conclude a treaty for Austria.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 13 -Bing Crosby, who now is on the "Road to Bali" for Paramount, has mapped out another comedy excursion, which, of course, is also meant for those other good companions of the "Road" series, Bob Hope and Dorothy Lamour.

Thomas Contino, 34-year-old taxi driver of 85 Bay Forty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, who the police said knocked a motorcycle patrolman from his vehicle after receiving a traffic ticket, gave himself up yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- The United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., charged today that most of the nation's newspapers and news magazines had been guilty of "unprecedented displays of bias, misrepresentation, withholding of the truth and reliance on demagogery and prejudice" in their handling of the steel wage dispute.
The causes, consequences and cures of inflation will be discussed by eighty-five citizens at the second American Assembly at Arden House, near Harriman, N. Y., from Sunday through Thursday.

Under certain conditions, the anti-trust trial against seventeen investment banking firms which began in November, 1950, might continue another two years, according to a revised timetable set up yesterday in Federal Court here.

ALTHOUGH there may be a few miniature icebergs floating on some of the far northern lakes, the ice is now officially "out" in Maine, and those who have been waiting for the signal to leave for Aroostook County waters can take off without delay.
CLEVELAND, May 15 (UP) -- Ellis Arnall, Director of Price Stabilization, said here today that his office was about to increase margins for super markets and chain groceries.

Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, declared yesterday that even if the most extraordinary results were achieved with the new anti-TB drugs being tested by the city at Sea View Hospital on Staten Island, "a score of years would have to pass before one would dare halt the construction of tuberculosis facilities.
The statistics on vessel construction in United States shipyards were virtually unchanged last month. Only one new ship, a tanker of 24,600 deadweight tons, was added.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Lack of commercial transport roads in underdeveloped countries is hampering industrial progress in the United States, delegates were told today at the opening session of the International Road Federation's meeting here.

John Foster Dulles is providing us with much food for thought these days. He is arguing, with customary profundity and earnestness, that the "frontier of freedom" around the Communist bloc can only be defended by creating the ability to strike an aggressor "where it hurts." This is a variation, or at least an extension, of the present policy of containment.

The sighs of relief that may be heard as one passes the offices of the Quartermaster Corps in the Pentagon are probably those of procurement officers who have just finished a gigantic task. The 100,000,000-pound military wool-reserve program has about been completed, and all contracts authorized under Public Law 843 passed in 1950, have been awarded or will be awarded by July 1, according to the Department of Defense.
The lead changed hands for the third time in the New Jersey district of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's inter-club matches yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- A new element was injected into the grain market situation today with the report of one of the most widespread locust plagues in history in Africa and the Middle East. [Story on Page 1.]

Having scored with "The Male Animal," a sturdy comedy of 1940, the New York City Theatre Company, of which George Schaefer is the artistic director, hopes to obtain equally felicitous results with its second comedy revival of the spring season, "Tovarich."

ATLANTIC CITY, May 13 -- Psychiatrists and social psychologists, if they use "the greatest tact and restraint," can help political leaders and other persons in situations of crisis, Dr. Joost A. M. Meerloo, official adviser to the Netherlands Government during World War II, declared here today.
A period when "hard-sell advertising" will be a necessity lies ahead, Marion Harper Jr., president of McCann-Erickson, Inc., advertising agency, warned yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- Walter S. Franklin, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, reported at today's annual meeting of stockholders that the higher freight rates would increase the carrier's earnings this year if business conditions continued good.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Thirteen Senators, ten of whom have actively denounced and fought filibusters in the Senate, were accused in effect today of preparing to stage one themselves unless the pending McCarran bill to revise the immigration and naturalization laws was returned to committee for hearings to include the rival measure the thirteen sponsor.
TOKYO, Wednesday, May 14 (AP) --United Nations Command communique 1,248, for Monday's operations:

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The United States, Britain and France, through their embassies at Moscow, delivered identical notes to the Soviet Union today in reply to a Saviet note of April 9 concerning Germany. The text of the United States note follows:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 13 -- Veljko Vlahovic, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, handed an aide memoire to United States Ambassador George V. Allen and British Charge d'Affaires A. Duncan Wilson today rejecting the London decisions associating Italy more closely in the British-American administration of Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste as a violation of the Italian peace treaty.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx last night praised "the great courage" of Mayor Impellitteri in ignoring the pressure of interested citizen groups and appointing Charles Silver, "a man of his own choice," to the Board of Education.

OTTAWA, May 13 -- Continuing a movement for the better design of articles of every day life, the industrial design section of the Canadian National Gallery opened here today a selected display of furniture, electric fixtures, toys and textiles by British designers.

BATON ROUGE, La., May 13 (UP) -- Robert F. Kennon, a back-country judge who gave the powerful Long family its worst defeat in a Louisiana election, was sworn in as the state's fifty-first Governor today.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Government counsel argued in the United States Supreme Court today that the President's seizure of the steel industry was justified and must be upheld because "we are at war."
BERLIN, May 13 -- Soviet authorities tightened today their restrictions on Allied military highway patrols between Berlin and West Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson flashed a red light on Acting Attorney General Philip. B. Perlman during Supreme Court hearings on the steel seizure issue today, but the Government counsel talked forty minutes more.

Two burglary suspects were arrested yesterday in the Riverdale section of the Bronx after a chase in which a radio car patrolman fired six shots while at the wheel. During the pursuit, the suspects' car plunged twenty feet down an embankment and struck a tree.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The famed bust of Lincoln modeled from life by Leonard Volk and rescued from a junk shop by Harry Hershfield, the cartoonist, was given to the nation today.

Operations of the Bachmann Uxbridge Worsted Corporation so far this year have been at a relatively high level, Harold J. Walter, president and treasurer, told the annual meeting yesterday, April 30 backlog, he said, was about $13,300,000, with about $5,000,000 in Government orders.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 -- Repudiation of the agreement under which Gen. Francis P. Dodd was released from captivity by Communist prisoners of war on Koje Island "conceivably could have a very great effect" on Korean truce negotiations, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway said here today.

One morning 158 years ago a group of Columbia College students in knee breeches, jerkins and tri-cornered hats were ferried from the ferry stairs at the foot of Manhattan to level a hill on the southwest side of Governors Island to make a breastworks.

The London agreement does not solve the international problem of Trieste but it provides Rome and Belgrade with useful ammunition for domestic purposes. Premier De Gasperi makes the best of the concessions granted to Italy by the United States and Great Britain in order to gain support for the Government parties in the municipal elections to be held May 25.

LONDON, May 13 -- The end of the bookkeeping account on the Stock Exchange today was characteristic by widespread falls. British funds closed at their lowest with losses ranging up to 12s 6d ($1.75). In the foreign market both Japanese and German bonds recovered part of their early losses.

A resolution condemning the practice of "ghost surgery" and approving a measure depriving any physician or surgeon engaging in it of insurance against malpractice was adopted yesterday by the House of Delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 13 -Frank Rosenblum, secretary-treasurer of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C. I. O., charged today that a growing retail monopoly was threatening wages and working standards in the clothing industry.

QUEBEC, May 13 (Canadian Press) -- Rising newsprint and postage costs are causing an increase in daily newspaper prices throughout Canada and the United States. This was indicated at the nineteenth annual convention of the Canadian Circulation Managers Association that closed today.
The nation's biggest banking consolidation in recent years was scheduled yesterday when plans to merge the Manufacturers Trust Company and the New York Trust Company were announced.

The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad is ready to move for representation on the board of directors of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, William White, president of the Lackawanna, told stockholders at their meeting yesterday. He said that the Lackawanna held 330,000 shares of Nickel Plate common stock and that an application would be made to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to have this holding represented.

The "Economic Survey of Europe in 1951," just released by the Research and Planning Division of the Economic Commission for Europe, invites a look-back at recent international currency policies. In two respects, at least, the general currency devaluation of 1949, led by the United Kingdom, represented an advance over the manner in which such adjustments were made, let us say, in the Thirties.

Despite stiffer competition than they ever faced before, newspapers can be "the champ" among all advertising media this year, as they were in 1951, according to Harold S. Barnes, director of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 13 -- Bob Carmen and J. Nibs Segal of the host organization fashioned a 31, 35 -- 66 to capture the best-ball phase of the opening tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Elmwood Country Club today. Forty-nine pairs participated.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Two rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination agreed on one thing today -- that any candidate running on their party's record for the last twenty years could defeat any man who had to defend the course the majority of the Republican party had followed during that period.

A 15 per cent across-the-board wage increase for unlicensed sea-going personnel was sought yesterday by the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., as a contractual wage review began between the union and the Committee for the Companies and Agents -- Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, representing forty-two ship operators.

Is the Western Hemisphere going to see another Prensa case? The slow strangulation and expropriation of the great Buenos Aires newspaper by General Peron shocked the whole free world. There has been nothing in the history of journalism comparable to the world-wide struggle on behalf of La Prensa in the name of freedom of the press.

PARIS, May 13 -- Just how much the disciplined apparatus of French communism has been strained by Moscow's new policy of advocating a national German army is something no one can gauge. Nevertheless, there have been enough muted grumbles among assorted party members and fellow travelers to indicate that some sort of fracture has taken place.

A fifth public offering of bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will be made in the United States today. It consists of $50,000,000 of 3 3/8 per cent bonds due in 1975 and priced at 98 1/2 to yield 3.47 per cent to maturity.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 13 -- The United Nations Disarmament Commission today ruled out official distribution of Communist documents charging the United States with starting germ warfare in Korea and China.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- W. Averell Harriman, the rich underdog of the Presidential race, tried to get his campaign off the ground today in a major speech before the National Press Club, and, while it cannot be said that he soared, it can probably be said that at least he got aloft.

PARIS, May 13 (UP) -- The New York City Ballet tonight banned forever from its programs and publicity the name of Marc Chagall, French surrealist painter, who charged with ballet costumes worn by the company were "outrageous caricatures" of those he designed.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- George W. Armstrong Jr., an industry member of the Wage Stabilization Board, urged Congress today to outlaw industry-wide bargaining and abolish the board's powers in labor disputes.

BOSTON, May 13 (AP) -- After three previous failures Vern Bickford, the Braves' ace right-hander, gained his first 1952 triumph by keeping nine hits scattered tonight as the Tribesmen opened their home night-game schedule season with a 3-1 victory over the Pirates.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 13 (AP) -- P. L. Kelly's Sea Grass scored an upset in the Risley Purse at Garden State Park today, winning by a half-length over Kenilworth Farm's Thee and Me. Almost a length back in third place was Palatine Stable's Chicle II.

LANSING, Mich., May 13 (UP) -- Another outbreak of violence at Southern Michigan Prison "seems inevitable" unless conditions that caused the bloody riot last month were eliminated, a fact-finding committee warned today.

LANSING, Mich., May 13 -- Michigan smiled indulgently today at the suggestion that it had stooped to pilfering picture postcard scenes from New Hampshire. Robert J. Furlong, executive secretary of the Michigan Tourist Council, said that he had found New Hampshire's apprehension surprising.

The stock market held to a noncommittal course yesterday in another session of restricted trading. Selected gains during the morning were canceled to a considerable extent in the afternoon, leaving the composite rate higher by only 0.11 point.

THERE were only six families in the little Irish village of Caherlo. Each family lived in a whitewashed house with a thatched roof. There were silver birches along the road and plantain trees around the houses. The fields were as green as only fields can be in Ireland. Even the bog was beautiful. But life in Caherlo was no rural idyl.

LONDON, May 13 -- About seventy American honorary knights appeared today in Debrett's Peerage a chronicle of the British Empire's nobility first printed in the year George Washington whipped the Redcoats.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- John G. Byler, vice president of W. T. Grant Company, was elected chairman of the board of the American Retail Federation at its annual meeting here today. Mr. Byler succeeds Edwin I. Marks of R. H. Macy Co., New York.

Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today more than $41,000,000 of new common and convertible preferred stock of industrial and public utility companies. Substantially all the funds raised by the financing will go to finance expansion or increase general corporate funds for the support of a sustained increase in business volume. The offerings are as follows:

Eddie Stanky, on his first official visit to these parts since he became manager of the Cardinals, was asked yesterday at Ebbets Field what it was about his club that has pleased him most. "It's the pitching," he said. "I like my pitching." That was just before the Redbirds engaged the Dodgers, with Joe Presko pitted against Preacher Roe.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, May 14 (UP) -- The Eighth Army has failed to explain what it meant by last Friday's statement that General Dodd was the only United Nations soldier who had been held prisoner by the Red prisoners.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Wednesday, May 14 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio scored an easy and expected victory over Harold E. Stassen, former Minnesota Governor, in West Virginia's Republican Presidential preferential primary yesterday.

" Passion for Life," a French film written and directed by Jean-Paul Le Chanois and now being distributed nationally by Brandon Films, Inc., was honored yesterday by the motion - picture committees of twelve national organizations and the Motion Picture Association of America in a reception at the Harvard Club, 27 West Forty-fourth Street.
LONDON, May 13 (Reuters) -The Warwickshire-Sussex County cricket match at Hove ended tonight in a tie -- cricket's rarest result. The counties were level when the last batsman was out.

Larry Jansen encountered more difficulty than usual in subduing the Reds last night, but the Giants, reveling in the unaccustomed luxury of leading the league at this early date, rallied nobly to the support of their crack right-hander with a concentrated attack that piled up the wherewithal for a 7-4 victory in just two innings.
LONDON, Wednesday, May 14 (Reuters) -- The Western powers' reply to the Soviet Union on German unity evoked detailed editorial comment in today's British press.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Strong, unexpected opposition to human rights provisions of the proposed Puerto Rican Constitution arose today in the House of Representatives. Action on a resolution of approval, which must be enacted before the instrument can take effect, was consequently postponed until Thursday.

GENEVA, May 13 -- A proposal for a definitive solution of Austria's long-standing refugee problem has been put forward by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees for consideration by Austrian, United States and international authorities.

Newbold Morris, who recently was dropped as special assistant to the Attorney General to help clean up corruption in the Government, was appointed yesterday special assistant to the president of Actors' Equity and Chorus Equity Associations.

The Association of Casualty and Surety Companies elected Manning W. Heard, vice president of the Hartford Accident and Indemnty Company, as president of the association yesterday. George D. Mead, president of the Glen Falls Group of Insurance Companies, was elected vice president of the association.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Wednesday, May 14 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet, Commander of the United States Eighth Army, yesterday named Brig. Gen. Haydon L. Boatner new commander for the prison camp at Koje Island off the south coast of Korea.

After a lively one-hour debate the Association of the Bar of the City of New York voted last night to oppose the proposed Bricker amendment to the Constitution limiting present treaty - making powers and the President's authority to make executive agreements in the international field.

BONN, Germany, May 13 -- John J. McCloy, the United States High Commissioner, announced today a drastic cut in the personnel of his office. Included are the four state commissioners of the United States occupation zone, who are due to leave by June 13, and the seventy remaining local resident officers, whose assignments will end June 5.

QUEBEC, May 13 (AP) -- The free enterprise system desperately needs a free press and a free press has equal need of advertising revenue if it is to remain free, James N. Shryock of Chicago, executive vice president and managing director of the Audit Bureau of Circulation, told the circulation managers.

ROME, May 13 -- A new kind of war is raging in the Middle East, where international action is being taken to combat what threatens to develop into the worst plague of desert locusts seen in a hundred years, Rome headquarters of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization announced today. The plague of locusts, it said, "is threatening the entire food supply of agricultural countries from Africa through Asia Minor to Asia."

Storytellers of the New York Public Library had a special group of tales to relate last night at their forty-second annual symposium in the Fifth Avenue building at Forty-second Street. The stories chosen for the periodic review of the spellbinders' art were to honor Mrs. Frances Clarke Sayers, superintendent of the library's Department of Work with Children, whose retirement was announced at the symposium.

A feeling of optimism prevailed at the Popular Price Shoe Show of America yesterday as more manufacturers of women's shoes reported that they were booked solid through September. This was the first indication of major improvement in the shoe industry in more than a year.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A busy two weeks was announced today for Mrs. Truman prior to her usual vacation visit at her home in Independence, Missouri, starting early in June.

Spirited bidding marked the purchase yesterday of parcels in the Bronx at the second day of a series of auctions by the city of real estate acquired through "in rem" foreclosures of tax liens. The sale was held in the Council Chamber of City Hall under the direction of William M. Ellard, director of real estate of the Board of Estimate.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Plans have been made to resume drilling for oil on property of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad in the Northwest, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the board of directors, said today at the annual stockholders meeting.

I read with interest the four articles on South Africa by William S. White which you published recently. I pay tribute to their excellence and have no wish to criticize them in detail. What does seem to emerge from them, however, is a spirit and feeling of hopelessness for the racial future of South Africa.
The State of Maryland borrowed yesterday $11,032,000 on school construction and assistance certificates of indebtedness due from 1955 to 1967 at an interest cost of 1.4147 per cent.

Louis F. Budenz admitted yesterday that he had used "Aesopian" language to call for the overthrow of the Government of the United States by force and violence when he issued a public statement announcing that he had joined the Communist party in 1935.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Senate Banking Committee voted today to abolish the present Wage Stabilization Board and replace it with an all-public panel stripped of any power to recommend wage dispute settlements. The vote was 7 to 3.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- New York spokesmen appealed today to the Senate Appropriations Committee for money to complete or undertake five projects within the state. They involve both flood control and waterway improvement projects.

Scribe's is one of several steak houses around Third Avenue and Forty-fifth Street favored by the journalists of that neighborhood. Its cookery is what might be called the succulent-sirloin type -- straight American with the accent on good, simply prepared beef.

Warning that a concentrated atomic attack was "now capable of blotting out an entire city?" Arthur W. Wallander, Civil Defense Director, called for additional volunteers yesterday "to guide the public in a pattern of survival."

Sidney H. Bingham, chairman of the Board of Transportation, asserted yesterday that unless measures were taken to speed traffic both above and below ground, the "full development" of the city would be inhibited and residents would be "encouraged to leave it for less congested areas."

The percentage of sports shirt production to total shirt output reached 70 per cent during March, the highest ratio ever attained in the industry, the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers said yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, May 13 -- A letter of protest is being circulated for signatures among leaders of the American colony in Mexico City in defense of United States Ambassador William O'Dwyer. The protest is addressed to the editor of The Reader's Digest and was inspired by an article by Fulton Oursler in this month's issue of the magazine.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries, in the first three months this year, had net earnings of $16,346,318 after all charges, including $12,653,396 for taxes, Dr. John F. Thompson, board chairman, reported yesterday.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., May 13 -- The greatest commercial vessel built in an American shipyard, the United States, is ready to begin her career as this country's first superliner.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Declaring that the Wage Stabilization Board was of the "unanimous opinion" that the present oil industry wage disputes "should and can be settled through collective bargaining," Nathan P. Feinsinger, chairman of the board, began a series of conferences today with labor and industry spokesmem.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 13 -- Overriding objections of a small minority, the General Federation of Women's Clubs voted today to take religious groups into its membership for the first time in its sixty-one-year history. The action, long a subject of heated debate within the federation, was taken at the second day's business session of the annual convention.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan yesterday accepted as the truth Harry Gross' sworn story that he had paid graft to policemen for permission to operate his numerous gambling places between 1942 and 1950.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Carl G. Strandlund testified under oath today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, set the $10,000 price that the Lustron Corporation, at the time heavily in debt to the Federal Government, paid him for an article on housing in 1948.

The need for some clarification of the Robinson-Patman Act in provisions requiring equal treatment of business customers on discounts, promotion allowances and other pricing arrangements was demonstrated yesterday in a debate on whether the theory and philosophy underlying that law are in the best interests of industry, trade and the public.

Citations of merit for contributions to treatment of the mentally ill were awarded last night by the Association for the Improvement Mental Hospitals to a magazine, two writers, a psychiatrist and a public officer.

Col. Sidney H. Bingham, chairman of the Board of Transportation, revealed yesterday that "all the engineering details" of a rubber conveyor-belt system carrying ten-seat cars to replace the present antiquated, inconvenient shuttle between Times Square and Grand Central Station are under careful scrutiny by the city and private industry.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (UP) -- Lefty Curt Simmons allowed only two hits and struck out twelve as he pitched the Phillies to a 6-0 victory over the Cubs tonight for his second triumph in three starts after eighteen months of military service.
Members of the Republican Committee of One Hundred voted by more than two to one yesterday in favor of the candidacy of Senator Robert A. Taft for President.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -A complaint against two trade associations and their members, charging they are attempting to monopolize the sale and distribution of surgical materials, has been filed by the Federal Trade Commission.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 13 (AP) -Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan touched off another vehement dispute in this racially tense country today by demanding control of three British protectorates.

In one of its first acts after regaining sovereignty the Japanese Government has decided to apply for membership in the United Nations. The decision must still be approved by the Japanese Parliament, but there is no reason to expect opposition from that quarter, and a formal Japanese application may be expected at United Nations headquarters in the near future.
Prices of cotton futures declined 13 to 21 points yesterday after having held steady in trading on the New York Cotton Exchange earlier in the day.

I was somewhat surprised and puzzled by the statement of Jerome Alexander in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES concerning William Fairburn in which he stated that a misstatement by Dr. Felix Adler "that the Diamond Match Company had foisted 'phossy jaw' on the industry" was later restated by Dr. Alice Hamilton in her book on industrial poisons.

BOSTON, May 13 -- The American Woolen Advisory Council of the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., voted unanimously today to recommend adoption of a new two-year contract between the union and the American Woolen Company.

This year the privately financed Central Reference Library of the New York Public Library faces an operating deficit for the fourth time in its 103year-old history. The Library's annual drive for contributions now stands at a little over $300,000, not including endowment funds. The goal is $400,000.

Because of the inadequacy of salaries there probably will be a national shortage of 2,000 clergymen in the Protestant Episcopal Church within the next few years, Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan warned members of the l70th annual convention of the Diocese of New York here yesterday.

The new immigration and naturalization bill on which the Senate began debate yesterday represents the first thorough revision of our immigration statutes in a generation. It is an understatement to say that a complete overhaul of this body of law is badly needed.

BONN, Germany, May 13 -- A number of German reservations to the contractual agreement that will establish West Germany's new status as a member of the West European community must be referred to the three Allied Governments.
I should like to comment on a letter from Laurence S. Carroll, Red Circle Freight Lines, Inc., published in THE TIMES April 22, in reply to my letter which appeared in your columns on April 10.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio today told thirteen women supporting him for the Republican Presidential nomination that "no Cabinet officer I may appoint will tolerate communism for one minute in his department."

TRENTON, May 13 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll said today he would withhold his endorsement of the proposed reopening of Newark Airport to commercial flights until he was convinced that every possible safety measure had been taken.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley was the guest speaker today at Hadassah's silver jubilee luncheon in the Chicago Convention Building and International Amphitheatre. Hadassah is the women's Zionist organization of America.

NEW DELHI, India, May 13 -- Following formal installation this morning of Dr. Rajendra Prasad as India's first President elected under the Republican Constitution he reappointed Jawaharlal Nehru as Prime Minister. A new Cabinet was announced in the evening.

PARIS, May 13 -- Thousands of art lovers jammed the Petit Palais on the Champs Elysees today for the opening of a notable exhibition of Italian medieval art arranged by agreement between the French and Italian Governments.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 13 -- The Hebrew University-Hadassah Medical School awarded degrees of Doctor of Medicine today to its first sixty-two graduates.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 13 -- Eight police and fire officials of this city, charged by Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler with having accepted gifts, were found not guilty today by Harold V. Reilly, City Manager, who had conducted departmental hearings all day yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 13 -- Edward L. Bernays, New York counsel on public relations, said here today he had found "widespread criticism and disapproval" of the American press on the part of both its readers and its publishers.
NEW HAVEN, May 13 -- A wild free-for-all resulted today when 1,000 or more Yale students took sides in a fight between two ice cream sellers battling over a choice site near the campus.

CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Minnie Minoso drove across four runs, two of them with a 415-foot homer, as the White Sox and Lefty Billy Pierce handed the Red Sox their fifth straight loss, 5 -- 0, before 38,861 fans tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Fifteen Ohio Valley power companies have proposed formation of a power combination to supply electric energy to a proposed billion-dollar atomic plant.

As Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday that city-state conferences on a long-range solution of the city's financial ills would begin Friday, the City Council received measures calling for three-year extensions of taxes yielding $222,650,000 a year.

The possibility of further serious consideration of the Hudson River as a future reservoir of New York City's drinking water was virtually ended yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri when he referred to the Board of Water Supply a recommendation that the river be studied as a supply source.

The Harriman - for - President headquarters at the Lombardy Hotel, 111 East Fifty-sixth Street, will open formally tomorrow afternoon. There will be a reception at 5 P. M. for W. Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security and New York's favorite son candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The eighteenth and final game of the chess match between Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires at San Salvador was won by Najdorf in forty-three moves, according to a Central American report yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 13 (AP) -- The Rochester Transit Corporation discharged about 1,100 striking bus and underground trolley operators today. The company said the strike was "illegal" and that it had a right under the Taft-Hartley Act to discharge the men.

DETROIT, May 13 (AP) -- Two wild throws by Tiger infielders broke up a pitchers' duel tonight and enabled the Senators to gain their ninth victory in ten games, 4 to 3. Conrad Marrero allowed only five hits to beat Detroit for the second time this season.

An employer has the right to discharge a union employe who, in the performance of his duties, refuses to cross the picket line of another union at a customer's plant, the United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday in a two-to-one decision.

Mayor Joseph Altman and three of the four commissioners who served with him as head of Atlantic City's municipal government were returned to office by substantial margins yesterday despite a nonpartisan campaign against them based on disclosures of a year-long series of investigations.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -The Air Force today took the "classified" label off its two new all-jet heavy bombers, the YB-52 and the YB-60.

Popularity and its place in the lives of youngsters was discussed before an audience in the Dobbs Ferry (N. Y.) High School last night at a community meeting under the auspices of the Hudson River committees of the Mental Hygiene Association of Westchester.

PARCHMAN, Miss., May 13 (UP) -- A trusty guard on a mule broke up an escape attempt at the State Penitentiary here today, killing one prisoner and wounding another in an exchange of gunfire. A third prisoner, who got away, was recaptured five miles away.

WILMINGTON, N. C., May 13 -- The Federal Government won an important victory here today against the Ku Klux Klan when Judge Don Gilliam in United States District Court found ten of eleven former members of the hooded order guilty of kidnapping and conspiracy. He acquitted the eleventh defendant.
Felix A. Meyer, formerly divisional merchandise manager for The White House Stores, Houston, Tex., has been appointed sales manager of Artcraft Hosiery Mills.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee tentatively cut $400,000,000 more today from the Mutual Security authorization bill, which the Foreign Relations Committee already had slashed $1,000,000,000 under the Administration's $7,900,000,000 request.

A report by the Anti-Defamation League on racial and religious prejudice in the United States last year will be published May 22 by Doubleday under the title "The Troublemakers." Written by Arnold Forster and Benjamin Epstein, the volume traces the course of bigotry in America, describing its organization in a vicious network and its direction by professional rabble-rousers, with a report on "the results of the malicious and nefarious campaigns."

PRINEVILLE, Ore., May 13 -Gov. Sherman Adams of New Hampshire, campaigning in Oregon for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, paid tribute here today to a rival candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, Gov. Earl Warren of California.
ATHENS, May 13 -- Greek military expenditures will be reduced by 10 per cent without cutting the numerical strength of the armed forces, according to an authoritative announcement today.

Former Representative Vito Marcantonio, state chairman of the American Labor party, declared last night at a party rally in Madison Square Garden that 1952 would mark the disintegration of the Democratic party "as we know it."
LUXEMBOURG, May 13 -- By 47 votes to 4, the Chamber of Deputies of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg ratified today the Schuman plan for pooling the coal and steel resources of six European countries.

With many a creaking sigh the old house settled itself for the night. High in his room, the guest heard the settling noises of the inhabitants and, finally, of the house itself, adjusting its beams after another day of man's heavy steps on stair and floor.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 14 -- A city ordinance that would have required that fresh milk sold in Mount Vernon bear a date was invalidated today by Supreme Court Justice Elbert T. Gallagher. The Justice granted a motion by Mount Vernon milk dealers for a declaratory judgment invalidating the Mount Vernon ordinance, which was adopted in January.

DENVER, May 14 -- A coordinating committee of the nation's twenty-two striking oil unions today "reluctantly approved settlement" of the union-industry wage dispute on the basis of a 15-cent-an-hour limit on wage increases, as set earlier in the day by the Wage Stabilization Board in Washington.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) -- The Government announced today that its drive against the potato black market had resulted in court action against nine more dealers accused of selling at above-ceiling prices.

NEWARK, May 14 -- Officials of the National Newark and Essex Banking Company and the Bloomfield Bank and Trust Company today announced a plan to merge the institutions. The plan has been approved by the boards of directors of both banks and will be submitted for action by stockholders at meetings in June.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- The Truman Administration, through Vice President Alben W. Barkley and Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin, gave unqualified support today to the United Steelworkers of America, C.I.O., in its fight to win wage increases, a union shop and other benefits recommended by the Wage Stabilization Board.

Two new films will arrive at first run theatres today. "Outcast of the Islands," a British made adaptation of the Joseph Conrad work, produced and directed by Carol Reed from a script by William Fairchild, is at both the Astor and Fine Arts Theatres. Trevor Howard, Sir Ralph Richardson.

ST. LOUIS, May 14 (AP) -- The Browns, who had gone without an earned run in three successive defeats, collected sixteen hits off four Philadelphia pitchers to beat the Athletics, 12 -- 7, tonight. A six-run splurge in the fourth inning put the Browns ahead and they stayed in front as Satchel Paige starred in relief.
The first ceremonies in observance of Manhattan College's centenary year were held at the college yesterday afternoon, when a special academic convocation honored Cardinal Spellman.

Ultra-feminine fashions, in fragile colors, brought summer into the Empire Room at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday when Russek's presented a luncheon fashion show. Palest pinks, mauves, blues, yellows and white were shown for all hours of the day.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 14 -- The South African Government has sent a new oral reply to an invitation to participate in United Nations talks concerning its disputed jurisdiction over the neighboring territory of South-West Africa.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 14 -- The Women's Long Island Golf Association opened its 1952 season today over the Piping Rock course, with sixty-two contestants in the field which included several former champions returning to action.
Arnold Constable's presentation of summer fashions yesterday at a luncheon in the Cotillion Room at the Pierre Hotel placed emphasis on fresh American-looking fashions by American designers.

Cadet Richard A. Gunst received the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation's trophy yesterday as Fordham University's outstanding military graduate at the Demonstration Day of the university's Reserve Officer's Training Corps.

CLEVELAND, May 14 -- On rain-soaked Municipal Stadium tonight, before a gathering of 26,028, Johnny Sain and Rapid Robert Feller renewed a pitching rivalry that had its beginning in the 1948 world series between the Braves and Indians, and Hank Bauer saw to it that Sain won again.

ROME, May 14 -- Hostile demonstrations by Communist-led dock workers against the United States Army Logistical Command gave rise today to turbulent scenes in Leghorn and caused United States Army personnel there to be alerted.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- Philip Murray told the United Steelworkers convention today that Clarence B. Randall, president of the Inland Steel Company, had retreated at the White House from his radio charge of a "corrupt political deal" between President Truman and Mr. Murray, who is president of the steel union and the C. I. O.

NEWARK, May 14 -- The City Commission today unanimously approved a resolution urging Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to initiate a study of possible sites in other parts of the state for the relocation of Newark Airport.

The economic position of Britain will improve "automatically" this year, in the opinion of Hugh Gaitskell, former Laborite Chancellor of the Exchequer, who arrived in this country yesterday for a brief speaking tour.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Truman not only is planning to attend the Democratic National Convention and make a speech, an intimate acquaintance said tonight, but also intends to go as a delegate from his home state of Missouri.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 14 -- The text of the Yugoslav aide memoire to the British and United States Governments, which was released today in Belgrade, said that the London decisions, giving the Italian Government an increased share in the civil administration in the British-American Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste paved the way for the zone's union with Italy.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., May 14 -- Vermont Democrats today chose a ten-member delegation to cast six votes at the National Convention in Chicago in a relatively harmonious session that lasted less than two hours.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The seizure of the steel industry by President Truman without specific authority of law, and the fact that this may oblige the Supreme Court in these critical times to make a narrower definition of executive power than it would by free choice, arise from the same reason.

BAYONNE, N. J., May 14 -- Seconds were "crucial," and a ten-degree error in sighting might have meant 170 yards in those last few minutes before the carrier Wasp rammed and sank the destroyer-minesweeper Hobson on April 26, the Wasp's deck officer on duty that night testified here today.

LONDON, May 14 -- The United Kingdom's atomic weapon will be tested at the Monte Bello Islands off the northwest coast of Australia in a joint operation involving Britain's three fighting services and the Ministry of Supply as well as the Australian Government and Australia's three fighting services, the Prime Minister's office announced today.

ATHENS, May 14 -- A United States Embassy spokesman said today that the "confusion" occasioned by Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery's speech here Friday night in which the deputy commander of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces implied that Greece, beset by financial difficulties, should reduce her armed forces' numerical strength was "mitigated" by his subsequent statement at the airfield Sunday before his departure for Turkey.

Despite the threats emanating from Moscow and East Berlin the three Western Powers -- the United States, Britain and France -- have served notice on the Kremlin that they are determined to proceed with the formation of a European Defense Community including Germany, and that they will not be deflected from supporting such a project as the true path to European unification and peace.

LONDON, May 14 -- Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today that "there is as yet no divergence of view" between the United States and British Governments over the much discussed command arrangement in the Mediterranean.

PARIS, May 14 (UP) -- American delegates to the International Chamber of Commerce Council meeting here agreed with European business men today that East-West trade cannot be shut off until other outlets are found for Western-produced goods.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., May 14 -- Princeton's golfers carried off top honors for the second year in a row in the Metropolitan Golf Association's intercollegiate championship today at the St. Andrews Golf Club.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., May 14 (AP) -- T. M. Girdler, chairman of Republic Steel Corporation, said today that "events of the past six months emphasize the necessity for prompt Congressional action on the underlying problem of labor monopoly."

Fifteen artists, composers and authors were named yesterday as the recipients of $1,000 grants, awarded annually by the National Institute of Arts and Letters to non-members, both in recognition of the work of established artists and as encouragement to younger artists of ability.

A turning point in the rayon and acetate textile market has been reached, according to Royal Little, president of Textron, Inc., who spoke yesterday at a meeting of the Synthetic Organic Chemical Manufacturers Association of the United States in the Commodore Hotel.

New issues of railroad and public utility bonds totaling $27,325,000 will be offered to investors today by investment banking syndicates. The bankers acquired the securities at public sealed bidding transactions yesterday and Tuesday. The offerings are as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP) -- Russ Meyer dodged the hard luck that had beset him in four previous defeats to win his first game of the season today. The right-hander hurled the Phillies to a 9-2 decision over the Cubs.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Dr. Leopold Figl, Chancellor of Austria, assured the United States today that the Austrian people would never stop fighting for liberty and independence until they achieved it.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., May 14 -- The Rev. William C. Kernan, a leader in the three-year fight against "Communist infiltration" in the Scarsdale public schools, is leaving the Protestant Episcopal Church to become a Roman Catholic, and has been suspended from further service as a priest.

Twenty-five trucks of advanced design ranging from frozen food refrigerated units to a "hospital on wheels" were shown at a preview yesterday at East Side Chevrolet Corporation, Sixty-first Street and First Avenue.

LOS ANGELES, May 14 (AP) -- Lauro Salas, an overstuffed featherweight from Monterrey, Mexico, pulled the upset of the year tonight when he wrested the world lightweight championship from Jimmy Carter of New York in fifteen bristling rounds at the Olympic Auditorium.
DETROIT, May 14 (AP) -- Vic Wertz blasted a tie-breaking home run in the eighth inning today to give the last-place Tigers a 3-2 victory over the Senators before a slim gathering of 2,886.

BERLIN, Thursday, May 15 -- The East German Government lashed out last night at the latest note of the Western powers to Moscow concerning German unification. The Allies were accused of seeking to partition Germany "forever" so as to incorporate the Western zones into the Atlantic alliance.

ANOTHER two weeks should find the weakfish providing plenty of activity on Peconic Bay, and although the big "tide-runners" of the old days are no longer plentiful, the angler with light tackle can find real sport on the small fish.
Samuel Reshevsky, who finished his touring chess match with Miguel Najdorf of Buenos Aires in San Salvador with an 11-7 triumph, returned yesterday by plane via New Orleans.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 -- The Matson Liner Lurline canceled her sailing for Honolulu today after a union jurisdictional dispute had delayed her scheduled departure for forty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Truman asserted tonight this country was winning the cold war but expressed fear of defeat if Congress finally approved the cuts now being made in the defense and foreign aid programs.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 14 -- The United Nations Human Rights Commission today rejected a Soviet proposal that its Russian sponsors insisted would prevent governments from "criminal misuse" of science for the development of atomic bombs and germ warfare.

A controversy has developed between Local 802 of the musicians' union and John Golden, who has taken over the control of "The Male Animal" from the City Center, where the James Thurber-Elliott Nugent comedy closed a two-week run Sunday night, that may affect tonight's scheduled resumption of the play under Mr. Golden's sponsorship at the Music Box.

TUNIS, Tunisia, May 14 -- French Mobile Guards took up positions today outside the summer palace of Sidi Mohammed el Amin Pasha, the Bey of Tunis, and a new crisis seemed to be building up in this turbulent North African protectorate.

The cross-examination of Harold L. Stuart, Chicago banker, by defense counsel in the investment banking anti-trust suit came to an end here yesterday with the witness declaring that he had no knowledge of the defendant bankers being in a conspiracy involving historically "frozen" syndicate commitments and an agreement not to compete against each other for the management of under-writings.

BERLIN, May 14 -- Soviet authorities allowed a United States military highway patrol to leave Berlin this evening and proceed toward West Germany, thus apparently bringing to an end the stoppage of such vehicles that began last Thursday.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, who has the East's top-ranking 2-year-old colt in Native Dancer, also has a 2-year-old filly of high quality. That was made clear to all hands at Belmont Park yesterday when the Vanderbilt-bred Home-Made, with Oliver Erie Guerin in the saddle, won the filly division of the National Stallion Stakes.

Thomas Kling, confederate of William Sutton, the bank robber, had an unprofitable day yesterday in General Sessions before Judge Jonah J. Goldstein. He appeared there for sentencing on his plea of guilty to a charge of illegal possession of a firearm when he was arrested last Feb. 20 in a rooming house at 308 East Eighteenth Street.
Except for rubber and cocoa, which rose, commodity futures on the New York markets were lower or mixed yesterday. Volume was generally light.
The house of delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York approved a resolution yesterday making a loyalty oath to the United States a requirement for membership.

The Cerro de Pasco Corporation reported yesterday for the first quarter of this year a consolidated net income of $3,087,931, or $2.49 each on the 1,238,271 capital shares outstanding. This compares with $2,537,904 in the similar quarter last year, or $2.15 each on the 1,178,984 shares then outstanding. Gross sales were $16,173,180 compared with $10,848,250.

LONDON, May 14 (Reuters) -- A modest, bespectacled Briton who turned down an offer of $42,000 a year to work in the United States on atomic research will direct Britain's first atomic weapon tests this year.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Top stabilization officials pleaded the cause of continued wage, price and rent controls before the American Retail Federation convention here today.

TOKYO, Thursday, May 15 -- United Nations investigators yesterday traveled to Kaesong, headquarters of the Chinese and North Korean truce delegation, after the enemy charged that Allied planes had dropped parachute flares near the city and Allied guns had lobbed in 20-mm. shells.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Officials of Jersey City came to Congress today with vociferous complaints against the Port of New York Authority but received little sympathy.

PARIS, May 14 -- Paul Cezanne's painting, "Apples and Biscuits," sold for 33,000,000 francs ($94,281) today in France's biggest twentieth-century art auction. The fabulous collection of Gabriel Cognacq, valued at $1,200,000, was sold to the highest bidders at the Charpentier Gallery. More than 4,000 persons jammed the gallery for the sale.

HONG KONG, May 14 -- Warehouses in this British commercial center are bulging with unsold goods in the midst of a continuing depression that has caused considerable concern about Hong Kong's economic future.

The number of television receivers in operation throughout the United States may exceed the number of homes with electricity by 1960. This was the forecast made last night by Dr. W. R. G. Baker, a vice president of the General Electric Company and general manager of its electronics division.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) -- The Defense Department today announced a new total of 108,413 American battle casualties in Korea, an increase of 241 over last week's report.

THE fragility of the thoroughbred probably never was better demonstrated than this year. It was a handsome crop of juveniles that advanced to the sophomore class on New Year's Day, a group so impressive that at least one of them, it seemed, would achieve the rare equine designation of "great." But Windy City disappointed in California and went to the sidelines.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended May 7:

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that officials here were "fully aware" of the new Soviet threats against West Berlin, and commented everyone should understand that the United States intended to protect its position there.

PARIS, May 14 -- France's favorable balance with the European Payments Union in April gave no great satisfaction here today for two reasons. First, the reversal of the trend for one month made only a small dent in the aggregate French deficit to the union amounting to $442,400,000, which still remains a problem.

Buying has been so good at the Popular Price Shoe Show of America in the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels that several companies, their production sold up months ahead, removed their displays yesterday, a day before the show was to close. These exhibitors said they were leaving because the orders had overloaded their production schedules through early fall.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier again yesterday, due to weakness in the old July contract. Final prices were 6 to 52 points net lower than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The Government told sausage makers today they could resume mixing horsemeat with their product beginning Monday. The Office of Price Stabilization stipulated that the processors must mark clearly their product as containing horsemeat.

PARIS, May 14 -- News agency dispatches from Tunisia asserting Ithat the French had placed the Bey of Tunis under military guard drew a denial--admittedly based ,on a brief, undetailed dispatch by ithe official French news agency-- !from a Foreign Office spokesman tonight
MELBOURNE, Australia, May 14 -- Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies left Sydney today for London.

Directed by a Police Department helicopter hovering overhead, a policeman waded out into the East River off Randalls Island late yesterday afternoon and recovered the body of a 9-year-old schoolboy who had jumped into the river on a dare.

A collaborative exhibition by scientists and artists opened yesterday at the New York Academy of Science, 2 East Sixty-third Street, for the benefit of the Music Research Foundation. The exhibition, which attracted. 200 visitors, will also be open between 4 and 9 P. M. today at $5 admission.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Standards for the great bulk of the nation's bread, under consideration by the Food and Drug Administration since 1941, were issued today. They cover the five leading kinds of bread -- white, enriched, milk, raisin and whole wheat.

NORMAN, Okla., May 14 (AP) -- The University of Oklahoma will remain in the Big Seven Conference and comply fully with the new conference rules governing athletic recruitment, the Board of Regents voted today.

The Greater New York Fund should either expand its operations, or use its entire collections to aid the nonsectarian, nonfederated social agencies, Stanley M. Isaacs declared yesterday in his president's report to the annual meeting of United Neighborhood Houses.

In an attempt to head off misleading advertising for freezer-food sales in the New York area, the Better Business Bureau of New York City, Inc., released a series of recommendations yesterday to cover advertising and selling of food freezers.

Your paper quoted Gerhard Eisler, on April 26, as asserting that 170,000 German youth had been recruited in the French Foreign Legion, and that 40,000 of them had died in Vietnam. This represents a typical example of Communist propaganda. As such it would not deserve any reply, but it might have created the impression among your readers that the French are fighting communism in Vietnam mainly with German soldiers.
The tragedy of errors on Koje Island during the last week once again emphasizes the nature of our enemy.

BONN, Germany, May 14 -- The Soviet Union having offered the Germans the carrot of unity and neutrality now is using the whip of force to demonstrate the West German and Allied helplessness in Berlin and vulnerability elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Wage Stabilization Board in effect told 90,000 striking oil workers today that it would not approve wage rate increases of more than 15 cents an hour, unless unusual circumstances were shown. It was a tactical move the board hoped would speed a settlement of the strike.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 14 -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas said today that the United States could not hope to stop revolutions in the Middle East and Asia with guns and money.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 14 -- Herman (Stumpy) Orman, Atlantic City political figure, was found guilty today in United States District Court on four counts of contempt of Congress. He faces a possible four-year prison term and a $20,000 fine.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) -- Twenty-one Coast Guardsmen were decorated for heroism today in the rescue of seventy men from two vessels wrecked by a heavy storm at sea Feb. 18-19.
I read with interest the thoughtful letter of Edward Spector which you printed on April 28.

BALTIMORE, May 14 (AP) -- Pimlico expects twelve starters for the $75,000 added Preakness Stakes with Dixiana Stable's Sub Fleet listed as the probable favorite to duplicate the 1943 victory of his sire, Count Fleet.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- A special Senate subcommittee was named today to investigate the effect of President Truman's controversial security order on Government news.

The motorship Panama Maru, newest and fastest vessel in the Japanese merchant fleet, was welcomed officially into New York Harbor yesterday afternoon, after completing her maiden voyage from Yokohama, Japan, in twenty-four days, two hours.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 14 -- Two Southern political leaders here to describe "America's Destiny" to the General Federation of Women's Clubs' annual convention agreed on the destiny, but were somewhat divided on the leadership.
