With output curtailed twice because of the steel wage dispute, production of raw steel by domestic mills in April declined 1,421,191 net tons from the record high achieved in the preceding month.
The 1952 medal of the American Cancer Society for "important contributions to the control of cancer" was presented to Mrs. Edward F. Hutton at a luncheon at the Plaza Hotel yesterday.

Maurice Schwartz, founder and for thirty years star of the Yiddish Art Theatre, will appear tonight at the Booth Theatre in an English-language presentation of "Conscience," a one - character drama. The Messrs. Shubert, by arrangement with Joseph Kipness and Jack Small, are sponsors of the production. The opening-night curtain is scheduled to rise at 8 o'clock.
CRANSTON, R. I., May 14 -- A 41-year-old convict tonight gave authorities the names of two men he said took part in the $1,219,000 Brink's, Inc., robbery.

HONG KONG, May 14 -- A preliminary meeting for the convocation of a so-called Asian and Pacific Peace Conference is scheduled to be held in China on May 28, the Communists' Peiping radio said tonight.

One of the more difficult tasks in the job placement field has been that of encouraging personnel officers to consider handicapped people for responsible positions. Since the war, more and more handicapped people have entered the job market and have proved themselves to be competent, conscientious, skilled and careful workers no matter what job they undertook.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The Government cut its price for crude natural rubber more than 20 per cent today while industry officials were urging Congress to turn the synthetic program over quickly to private enterprise.

MIAMI, Fla., May 14 (AP) -- The president of the Southern Baptist Convention warned political candidates today that Baptists did not want any man in the White House who favored sending missions to the Vatican.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- President Truman once protested to the Federal Reserve Board, both by telephone and letter, against reports the board was going to remove fixed pegs from Government security prices.

The Greater New York Fund, in its first campaign luncheon since its 1952 drive began May 1, reported yesterday that it had received $2,685,752 in contributions. This is $183,000 more than the same sources donated last year.

Perriette, the perennial sparrow, has done it again. The fat old bird, one of the ornithological wonders of the Bronx, has returned to the same fire escape for the ninth year and started another family. It was a toss-up whether Perriette would make it again. She didn't return until March 18 -- in other years she generally pulled a Capistrano by

MOSCOW, May 14 -- Diplomatic quarters suggested tonight that a meeting of the new United States Ambassador, George F. Kennan, with Generalissimo Stalin in the relatively near future is not beyond the realm of possibility.

Dr. Paul B. Magnuson, chairman of the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation, declared last night that there had been too much "private empire-building in the past by the providers of medical care in this country." The nation, he said, can no longer "tolerate" this.

Proposals for zoning revisions designed to prevent overbuilding, help avoid additional traffic and transit congestion in connection with future building and expedite large-scale housing developments were brought out yesterday by the City Planning Commission for public hearings at 10 A. M. on May 28.

GEORGE ORWELL'S "Homage to Catalonia"* is a milestone in the violent education of modern man. It is the bluntly honest story of his adventures in Spain's Civil War, where he was allied, somewhat to his own surprise, with the freebooting Anarchists against the totalitarian Communists.

BOSTON, May 14 (AP) -- Shortstop George Strickland juggled Pete Whisenant's bases-loaded grounder just long enough to permit Jack Daniels to register the winning run with two out in the tenth inning today as the Braves downed the last-place Pirates, 4 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Carl G. Strandlund told Senate investigators today that he was "scared some" after paying $10,000 to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, for an article on housing purchased by the Lustron Corporation for use in advertising.

A banking syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and Mitchum, Tully Co. will place on the market today $13,425,000 of new common stock of Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation, a financing transaction to help the company finance an expansion program requiring outlays of more than $20,000,000 this year.

TRENTON, May 14 -- The state investigation of waterfront rackets in Hudson County, begun nearly a year ago, has resulted in the indictment of sixty-four persons. Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons announced today. The charges involved murder, grand larceny, conspiracy and false swearing.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee voted 7 to 6 today to kill a proposal cutting an extra $400,000,000 from the $6,900,000,000 Mutual Security authorization recommended by the Foreign Relations Committee. President Truman has asked for $7,900,000,000.

Because of the importance of Latin America in supplying raw materials essential to this country's economy and defense program, Government relations with our southern neighbors should be consolidated in a single agency, Hugh A. Davies, director general of Latin American operations for the International Harvester Company, said yesterday.
TOKYO, Thursday, May 15 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,249, covering Tuesday's operations:

TOKYO, Thursday, May 15 (UP) -- The Communists today accused the United Nations of using atomic bombs in Korea. The charge was among a long list of accusations made at the day's truce session in Panmunjom.

TOKYO, Thursday, May 15 -- The New United Nations commander, Gen. Mark W. Clark, today promised an early conclusion of the investigation into the incident on Koje Island where Communist prisoners kidnapped the camp commander, Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd, and held him captive for seventy-eight hours while bargaining for concessions from headquarters.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., May 14 -- John Saunders of Mamaroneck, chairman of the Americanism Committee of the Westchester County American Legion, announced here tonight he had been informed that the House Committee on Un-American Activities would "soon" begin an investigation of the Legion's charges of subversive influences at Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, N. Y.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 14 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio today added fourteen West Virginia delegates, and a possible fifteenth, to his strength at the Republican National Convention, but apparently failed to win the complete sweep his backers confidently had predicted.
TOKYO, Thursday, May 15 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark today announced that the agreement between Brig. Gen. Charles F. Colson and Communist prisoners of war on Koje Island "has no validity whatsoever."
Mayor Impellitteri was criticized yesterday for "a great dis-service" in "throwing the latest round in the Cannonsville-Hudson River water supply fight to the Board of Water Supply."
Sal Maglie rolled up his sixth mound triumph of the season yesterday at the Polo Grounds and, all things considered, the Barber of Niagara Falls could not have had it easier.

LONDON, May 14 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden challenged the Labor Opposition today to accept the present plans for the rearmament of West Germany and its integration with the West as a free and sovereign power or take the responsibility for wrecking all existing plans for the defense of Europe against Soviet aggression.

Is it not time to tell the truth and use plain language about the so-called "bacteriological warfare" in Korea? The truth is that it is staged, in all its details, by certain agencies well known to the world from the Katyn, the Mindszenty, the Vogeler and a long list of other affairs. By now we must be familiar with these methods; we recognize the fingerprints and the masterminds; we know the picklocks of the burglars.

Dr. C. J. MacKenzie, chairman of Canada's Atomic Energy Control Board, said yesterday that peacetime applications of atomic energy waited not only on cheaper methods of producing fissile materials but on finding profitable industrial uses for them.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 14 (AP) -- Sammy Boulmetis combined his riding talents with the Savoy Stable and its trainer, Thomas Bonham, to score a double at Garden State Park today.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 14 (UP) -- President Victor Paz Estenssoro today ordered a nine-man technical commission to prepare to take over Bolivia's tin mines.

PARIS, May 14 -- The French Cabinet discussed today the publication here last week of a purported report of Admiral William M. Fechteler, United States Chief of Naval Operations, questioning the defensibility of Western Europe. The Government is expected to make a statement on the subject in the National Assembly, Gen. Pierre Billotte having asked Premier Antoine Pinay to clarify Washington's policy.

More than 600 Mayors and other municipal officials representing 250 American and twenty-seven foreign cities arrived in New York yesterday for today's opening sessions of the twentieth annual meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 14 -- Hofstra blew a 9-to-0 lead into a 15-to-13 loss to Brooklyn College in a Metropolitan Conference game today.
BUENOS AIRES, May 14 -- The Argentine Army is being thrown into the nation's greatest battle -- that of needed production in time of crisis -- Gen. Franklin Lucero, Army Minister, announced today.

What will become of the program of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization if all the member nations start slashing their military budgets and paring down their commitments to joint defense? An announcement that Greece is about to reduce her military expenditures by 10 per cent follows closely on the decision of the Foreign Affairs Committees in the Senate and House to cut approximately $1,000,000,000 from the appropriations for foreign aid under the Mutual Security Act.

Resumption on Monday of a steamship service for the transport of truck trailers between New York and Albany was announced yesterday by Hans J. Hvite, president of the American Overseas Chartering Corporation.

Pressure groups with axes to grind are gradually "eviscerating" education, James Marshall, former Manhattan member of the Board of Education, declared last night at the Annual dinner of the Public Education Association. These groups, he asserted, are reducing education "to a negative state in which it will offend no one."

Next week for the first time in more than a decade canned hams from Germany will begin to appear in stores in this country. This afternoon at a ham and champagne party at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, food editors will have a chance to sample this new arrival and to meet Robert Drews, managing director of Fleischwaren Export, the organization of seventy-one principal Germany meat packers that is sending the product here.

Describing them as "members of the greatest naval fighting unit in the United States," Borough President John Cashmore welcomed home yesterday seventy-five Navy officers and enlisted men on the steps of Brooklyn Borough Hall. As members of Fighter Squadrons 831 and 837, the men had returned last week to the United States Naval Training Station, Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, after combat action in Korea.
H. Newton Whittelsey, Inc., has been commissioned to draw up plans that will enable the Government to convert two types of merchant ships for military use in an emergency.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 14 -- Dr. Y. N. Dadoo, president of the South African Indian Congress and prime mover in a campaign to develop mass disobedience to "unjust laws" against non-whites, has received a letter from the Government ordering him under the Suppression of Communism Act to resign from the Indian Congress within thirty days.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, a Democratic Presidential aspirant, told a press conference here today that he was opposed to the compulsory aspects of the bill to create a Federal Fair Employment Practices Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A new education and readjustment program for veterans of the Korean war and others serving in the armed forces after June 26, 1950, was unanimously approved today by the House Committee on Veterans Affairs.

A new novel, "The Old Man and the Sea," by Ernest Hemingway, will be published Sept. 8 by Sribners, a year and a day after publication of "Across the River and Into the Trees." The book is described as being shorter than the usual novel, but "longer than what has come to be called the long story."
CHICAGO, May 14 -- Grain futures had a choppy course on the Board of Trade today, with lots of evening-up transactions in the May deliveries, and many cross-currents in deferred futures.
The City of Houston, Tex., borrowed $13,155,000 yesterday in the public market on bonds due from 1953 to 1982 at an interest cost of 2.19 per cent.
The lawlessness and filth in Central Park have reached unbelievable proportions. For years almost daily I have taken walks in the park and have watched it decline from a beautiful place to a sewer.

Beth Israel Hospital started construction yesterday of its new six-story out-patient clinic on East Seventeenth Street, between Second and First Avenue. The new clinic, to be called the Charles H. Silver Clinic in honor of the hospital's president, will be completed next spring and will be able to take care of 100,000 visits annually.
A "night into day look" was a feature of the summer fashions designed by Brigance and shown at Jay Thorpe yesterday.

YONKERS, May 14 -- My Horse, a 5-year-old brown stallion, tonight paced the fastest mile in Yonkers Raceway's three years' of racing, winning the $5,040 Port Chester Pace in 2:02 before 18,323, and cutting 2/5 of a second off the former standard set by Good Time last Oct. 19.

A number of variations on the chair frame theme have been composed by Norman Fox McGregor and Peter Schladermundt and included in their designs for the New World collection of contemporary furniture made by Valley, Inc. The 150 pieces in the new group will be available after May 23 through decorators in the Valley showrooms at 428 West Fourteenth Street and will be on view in stores here by the middle of next month.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The nation's present steel crisis is a direct outgrowth of the "fumbling" approach to the problem of mobilization made by this nation in the months immediately following Korea, Bernard M. Baruch, adviser to Presidents, told the Industrial College of the Armed Forces in a speech here today.

PARIS, May 14 -- Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, asserted today that the signing of the contractual agreement between the three Western Allies and West Germany need not bring to an end the possibility of an understanding with the Soviet Union on German unification.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today the State Department strongly opposed legislation pending in Congress to place a tariff of 3 cents a pound on imported tuna fish.

Louis F. Budenz completed his twelfth day on the witness stand at the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders yesterday, but his testimony was overshadowed by a discussion of the Russian Revolution.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 14 -- Strong feelings of sudden hate toward a person may be aroused because that person reminds us of a part of ourselves that we unconsciously hate, Dr. Henry P. Laughlin, Washington psychiatrist, declared today at the annual convention of the American Psychiatric Association.

PEARL RIVER, N. Y., May 14 -- Twenty-four hundred members of the International Chemical Workers Union, A. F. L., went on strike tonight at the plant of the Lederle Laboratories Division of the American Cyanamid Company. The plant is said to be the largest pharmaceutical laboratory of its kind in the world.

New York dress manufacturers are experiencing an upsurge in business and production in the market is estimated to be running well in excess of 10 per cent ahead of a year ago. A survey among leading manufacturers yesterday indicated that deliveries on summer dresses were a week to ten days behind schedule.

A report on "The Government's Wasted Manpower," made public yesterday by the National Civil Service League, 120 East Twenty-ninth Street, documents charges that millions of dollars are wasted in Federal personnel operations through "red tape, duplication of effort and paper shuffling."

Dave Sisler pitched a three-hit shut-out for Princeton to defeat Columbia, 2 -- 0, and jolt the Lions' hopes for the Southern Division Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League championship on Baker Field yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Traffic troubles of Helsinki, capital of Finland, were described today as similar to those of Manhattan.
HOBOKEN, May 14 -- Jasper Dibble, a Long Island real estate broker, arrived home in America today, having fulfilled a life-long ambition.

New York City is happy to play host this week to the United States Conference of Mayors. It is the seventh time in the twenty-year history of the organization that the Mayors have met here. The attendance is described as the largest ever, with close to six hundred city officials expected, along with two hundred wives and relatives.

LONDON, May 14 -- The stock markets continued dull today. Prices in most sections rallied after a poor start and generally closed steady although some of them seemed to be hesitating again in late business, particularly British funds. German bonds and oil shares were firm all day.

Events tonight: Gerald Cassen, bass-baritone, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M., Beatrice Lind, folksongs, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Program of French chamber music, French Institute, 22 East Sixtieth Street, 8:45; Mannes Choral Group, Mannes Music School, 8:30; Community Chamber Ensemble and Concert Choir, Taft Youth and Adult Center, Sheridan Avenue and 172d Street, 8:30; Brooklyn String Orchestra, First Unitarian Church, Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, 8:00.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Government today offered for sale all of the capital stock of E. Leitz, Inc., a New York company that was taken over from German owners on Aug. 24, 1942, and had been owned and operated by the United States since that time.
FRANKFORT, Germany, May 14 (AP) -- A West German music critic praised today the Boston Symphony Orchestra for its concert here last night under the direction of Pierre Monteux.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder announced today that subscription books probably will be open for the rest of the month on the Treasury's new offer of an unlimited amount of bonds bearing 2 3/4 per cent interest and maturing in 1980.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Senate leaders indicated concern today that the bitter opposition to the pending McCarran bill to revise the immigration and naturalization laws might prevent an early July Congressional adjournment for the conventions and campaigns unless the 302-page measure either was returned to committee for further hearings or was shunted aside to make way for other business that was piling up.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 14 -- Elia Kazan, stage and screen director, warned here today that a combination of fear and secrecy presently gripping American life has apparently centered on the film industry and worked to its detriment.

Mrs. Robert P. Patterson, widow of the former Secretary of War, assailed isolationism last night in an address at the annual memorial services of the 306th Infantry Association in the Seventy-seventh Division Clubhouse, 28 East Thirty-ninth Street.

The sale of John David, Inc., men's clothing chain, to Col. Ralph E. Ladue, its president, for $2,375,000 in cash, was announced yesterday by Walter Hoving, president of the Hoving Corporation. The latter company is also the owner of Bonwit Teller, Inc.

CHICAGO, May 14 (AP) -- The sagging Red Sox suffered their sixth straight defeat today as the White Sox jolted Bill Henry, rookie southpaw, for a six-run sixth inning, capped by winner Saul Rogovin's homer, for a 6-3 victory.

As a result of testimony given last week by Harry Gross, at least twenty policemen who hitherto had not been accused of taking his graft will be subjected to official charges at the next departmental trial of plainclothes men who allegedly accepted the bookmaker's pay-offs.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 14 -- Net income of $4,182,184 for the first quarter of 1952, an increase of more than 23 per cent over that of the last quarter of 1951, was reported today by the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company in its quarterly report.

Brooklyn's batting guns, which had boomed so loudly the day before, were spiked by Gerry Staley yesterday. The St. Louis right-hander, now the proud possessor of six victories against a single defeat, held the Dodgers to six hits in pitching the Cardinals to a 5-1 triumph at Ebbets Field.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 14 (AP) -- Johnny Longden today pulled up to within one victory of hitting the 4,000 mark for winning mounts, but failed to attain the coveted milestone in his career.

In its last scene, Jacques Deval's "Tovarich," put on at the City Center last evening, begins to show its age. Prince Mikail Alexandrovitch Ouratieff gives a Soviet commissar four billion of the late Czar's francs. In 1952 it is less likely that large sums of money remain to the Czar's account than it was in 1936 when this comedy was new.

MOSCOW, May 14 -- In the opinion of some diplomats here the note delivered to the Soviet Foreign Office last night by the United States, Britain and France sharply widened the split between the East and the West on the German question.

At a dinner tonight honoring Dr. Samuel Schulman the Jewish Publication Society of America does honor to itself. This grand old man of American Judaism, now in his eighty-ninth year, is one of the great scholars, orators and thinkers of his time; and his beneficial influence on the integration of Jewish cultural and religious life into the framework of American civilization will be felt by generations yet to come.

Caution continued yesterday to dominate trading on the stock market. After moving over a mixed course the greater part of the session, prices sagged near the close to leave the composite rate lower by 0.42 point.

Along the cobblestone road that had sparked and sighed to the grind of Hitler's tanks making their way to Vienna fourteen years before, another procession recently rolled upon the capital. Austrians paused for a moment at their tasks to watch the great bell on the open truck move leisurely by.
ON BOARD THE UNITED STATES, At Sea, May 14 -- The American merchant marine is on the verge of winning Atlantic speed laurels for the first time in this century.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 14 -- Two conflicting decisions by the United States District Court in Los Angeles have tended to deepen the confusion over the issue as to whether a movie company has the right to tie-in the showing of movies on television with commercial advertising without the consent of the performers involved.
VIENNA, May 14 -- A "free church in a free society" was set as the goal for the Austrian Roman Catholic Church in a statement issued by the Catholic Day Preparatory Committee, which met at Mariazell.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- American corporations paid out 6 per cent more in cash dividends during the first three months of 1952 than in the comparable period last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

You are to be commended for the editorial in which you gave support to a single catalogue for the armed forces, and I am glad to hear that the Congress is presently considering legislation to put this into effect.

Prices must come down before the public will buy the large amount of goods now being produced, Q. Forrest Walker, economist for R. H. Macy Co., told delegates to the second annual convention of the National Society for Business Budgeting yesterday in the Belmant Plaza Hotel.

The 1952 Bancroft Prizes for "the best works in American History" were awarded last night by Columbia University to Merlo J. Pusey, for his biography "Charles Evans Hughes," and to C. Vann Woodward, for a history entitled "Origins of the New South, 1877-1913."

WASHINGTON, May I5 -- Every election imposes fundamental restrictions on the Government in the field of foreign policy, but the current campaign need not develop into a holding operation alone. It can also be a period of constructive review, and if it is wisely handled by both major parties it can provide the basis for a new beginning by the time the next President is inaugurated in January.

In 1933 a group of American labor leaders headed by B. Charney Vladeck set to work in a one-room office "to aid the victims of Nazi and totalitarian persecution." Since that time the Jewish Labor Committee, as this organization was called, has been in the forefront of groups establishing "new frontiers against racial and religious discrimination," furthering an understanding of the workings of democratic institutions, giving aid and comfort to displaced persons and orphans.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The railroads' passenger train service, operated at a loss since 1946, sank still deeper into the red last year, official figures disclosed today. But net operating income from freight service reached a new peak, absorbing the passenger service losses.
Flower-fresh prints in classic summer sheers were shown for the travel wardrobe at Stern's yesterday in collaboration with Grace Lines and the Silk and Rayon Print Institute.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 15 -- The stage has been set for recovery of the cotton textile industry and there are definite signs of renewed buying interest among the industry's customers, Charles C. Hertwig, president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute, asserted here today.

LONDON, May 15 -- Britain's economy cannot stand further pay rises unless there is an increase in productivity, R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told a meeting of representatives of workers and management today. He called upon both sides of industry to appoint a joint committee to try to devise a formula for wage scales based on productivity rather than the cost of living.

The Chinese Communists' radio has broadcast a call for delegates from all Asiatic and Pacific nations to hold a "peace" conference in China, beginning May 28 next. The subjects for discussion are to include such matters as the "revival of Japanese militarism" and "the menace of atomic, chemical and bacteriological warfare in the Far East."

BERLIN, May 15 -- Soviet authorities seemed to be playing a cat and mouse game today with Allied military highway patrols on the autobahn linking Berlin with West Germany. At least that is the way the United States and British military police viewed the situation.

BOSTON, May 15 -- Indications are that business will continue in balance "at a high level without inflation," bankers were told here today. Woodlief Thomas, economic adviser to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, a speaker at the annual conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks warned however that, in view of the Government deficit, the "balance" could easily be upset and inflationary pressures renewed.
SEOUL, Friday, May 16 (AP) -- Allied warplanes smashed a big vehicle repair center in northwest Korea yesterday and shredded the Communists' patchwork rail system with high explosives.

The New York State Bureau of Motor Vehicles has decided to slow down the persistently reckless driver by making it twice as difficult for him to get on the road. Hereafter, serious or repeated violations of certain traffic laws will result in mandatory suspension of license for twelve months instead of six.

Unusual color combinations and whimsical details keynoted the Italian - designed casual clothes shown to the press yesterday by Gimbels. Original imports and copies may be purchased although the price tags vary accordingly. The fashions will be available to the public Monday in the third floor Sportswear and Specialty Corner.

Legislation intended to extend the displaced persons program should recognize that Federal financial responsibility for such immigrants ought not to end with their arrival at a port of entry but should continue until the D. P. has reached his final destination, it was declared yesterday by the National Travelers Aid Association.

Plans for a new branch at 531 West Fourteenth Street for the Greenwich Savings Bank, which has its main offices at Broadway and Thirty-sixth Street, have been filed with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The cost is estimated at $370,000. Halsey, McCormack Helmer, Inc., are the architects.

General Clark's vigorous and sweeping repudiation of the "agreement" that Generals Colson and Dodd reached with Communist prisoners on Koje Island is the only possible course of action to take in the present confused circumstances. Agreements with kidnappers have no standing, and kidnapping indeed seems to be the right word, for there is more than a touch of the juvenile on our side of this sorry affair.

GENEVA, May 15 -- Delegates to the fifth United Nations World Health Assembly heard an optimistic report from a medical authority and a pessimistic report from an equally eminent economist today on the economic consequences of better world health.

Harold L. Stuart, the Chicago banker who made and lost a fortune as underwriter for the Insull utility empire, said in Federal court here yesterday that he had no "friends" from 1932 to 1935 and that in his period of need only one man -- a person he said he scarcely knew -- came to his assistance. Mr. Stuart is a Government witness in the anti-trust trial of seventeen investment banking houses.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- A $1,413,820,000 deficiency appropriation bill, most of it for Korean war costs, was sent to the House today by its Appropriations Committee. The total is $61,600,000 less than President Truman had requested.

DETROIT, May 15 (AP) -- Virgil Trucks of the Tigers hurled the season's first no-hit no-run game in the major leagues today and did it mostly with control. Just when it looked as if Trucks might have to go into extra innings against Washington, Vic Wertz blasted a two-out home run in the last of the ninth inning to beat the Senators, 1--0.

Business executives who keep driving themselves "like an engine working at top capacity" may in reality be demonstrating their unconscious longing to relax and take it easy, according to a report presented yesterday at the annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York at the Statler Hotel.

Plans for erecting an office building at the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street were announced yesterday by Green Seizer, attorneys for David Green, who has purchased the property from Octave Blake and others. The sale was the first involving the holding since 1901.

Federal, state and city governments must help subsidize the rehabilitation of muscular dystrophy victims, doctors declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Muscular Dystrophy Associations of America in the Sherry Netherland Hotel.

LOS ANGELES, May 15 -- The student government at the University of California at Los Angeles has withdrawn recognition from the campus chapters of three national musical sororities because of alleged discrimination against Negroes in the national membership policies.
Franklin W. Camman will retire this afternoon as supervisor of Tower A in Pennsylvania Station. He has been pulling switches in the Pennsylvania Station ever since it was built in 1910.
The testimony of Louis F. Budenz at the trial of the sixteen secondary Communist party leaders appeared to be drawing to a close yesterday, his thirteenth day in the witness chair.

The McCarran Act is at present under reconsideration by Congress and the public. Called to carry the weight of the world through the most serious spiritual and material struggle in history, will we keep in mind that we must not forgo the men of brain, character, creative thinking who, if we will let them, will flock to us from all parts of the globe to help us meet the challenge?

HOUSTON, Tex., May 15 -- Victor C. Eggerding, general credit manager of the Gaylord Container Corporation of St. Louis, was installed as president of the National Association of Credit Men as the group closed its fifty-sixth annual credit congress here today. Mr Eggerding succeeds Lorne D. Duncan of New York City.

The withdrawal from service yesterday of an additional forty-six vessels raised to 375 the number of Government-owned ships ordered returned to reserve fleet anchorages, the National Shipping Authority announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15 --- The Senate Elections subcommittee quickly explored and as quickly exploded today a charge by a witness that "innuendo and foul play" were being used at its hearings to kill the character and political career of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

Open warfare between the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor in the textile industry seemed a certainty yesterday when it was disclosed that George Baldanzi, an unseated vice president in the C. I. O. group, had switched his allegiance to the A. F. L.

Since Maurice Schwartz is more dedicated to acting than most actor, his need of audiences is probably abnormal. He is a thorough professional in a classical European style. He has deep-sunk eyes, a fretted brow, the tortured, melancholy mask of a professional thespian, a bushy lock of hair tossed carelessly to the right side of his head and a deep, resonant voice.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Government liberalized restrictions today on the use of steel and other materials both for home and commercial construction effective July 1. The orders, issued by the National Production Authority, have been in preparation for some weeks and would have been issued earlier but for the uncertainties introduced by the steel strike.

Manufacturers should put "a large chunk" of their advertising appropriations into the hands of capable advertising departments of retail stores which would write and place the ads. This was suggested yesterday by Miss Bernice Fitz-Gibbon, advertising director of Gimbels, New York, at a luncheon of the Women's Advertising Club of Milwaukee in the Blatz Auditorium in that city.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 15 -- Varied weather greeted the contestants as the forty-second annual Walter J. Travis Memorial golf tournament started today over the Garden City Golf Club course. With a field of more than 150 players trying for the sixteen places in the championship light a three-way tie resulted for the qualifying medal.

Market value of listed stocks on the New York Stock Exchange dropped $5,251,076,182 in April, the institution reported yesterday. Average price of a listed share dropped $2.25 from $42.78 at the end of March to $40.53 on April 30. The latter figure was the lowest since June 30, 1951, when it was $38.73.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 15 (UP) -- Johnny Longden rode his 4,000th winner on a recognized American track today after two days of having the record elude him.

Two editorials appear in interesting juxtaposition in your paper of May 10. The first, "Honoring King Cotton," records with pride that 90 per cent of America's cotton textiles are distributed through New York City; the second, on the "Senate Textile Report," implies regret that the Textile Workers Union (C. I. O.) captured so few members in its million-dollar "Operation Dixie."

CAIRO, May 15 -- The Egyptian Foreign Office issued a communique today assuring the Sudanese that Egypt was sincere in her efforts to grant them self-government. The declaration was an indication of the considerable difficulties Egypt was having in defining exactly her position on the Sudanese problem.

A class of eighty-two nurses was graduated from St. Luke's Hospital School of nursing at commencement exercises held yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Miss Ruth K. Moser, director of nursing, presented the class and Edwin S. S. Sunderland, president of the hospital, conferred the diploma.

LONDON, May 15 -- Prime Minister Churchill assured Commons today there never had been any document of the kind alleged to be a secret report by Admiral William M. Fechteler, United States Chief of Naval Operations, which recently was published in the Paris newspaper Le Monde.

Asserting the Congress had lost effective control of annual Federal expenditures, Senator Harry F. Byrd declared last night that it would be extremely difficult ever again to balance the Federal budget.

A delegation of banking investment and Government leaders from all over the country and local officials will attend the formal dedication today of the new cigarette plant of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., in Louisville, Ky. The 116,000-square-foot plant, which is part of the $10,000,000 expansion program of Philip Morris in Louisville, will be able to produce more than 100,000,000 cigarettes a day on a single shift.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- A hybrid sort of plane that combines the outstanding characteristics of the helicopter and fixed-wing aircraft may be the short-haul air transport of the future, the eighth annual forum of the American Helicopter Society was told here today.

ROME, May 15 -- Palmiro Togliatti, Italian Communist leader, said today that the Roman Catholic church had nothing to fear from communism. He made the assertion in response to questions addressed to him by members of the Foreign Press Association.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 15 -- A five-under-par 67 by Sam Snead carried the Professional Golfers Association chairman into the lead as the Palm Beach round-robin tourney opened at the Wykagyl Country Club today.

Two Army corporals reacted quickly to an emergency last night when they subdued a passenger who, the police said, suddenly went berserk and attacked the driver of a Boston-bound bus while the vehicle was traveling up Tenth Avenue between Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets. There were twenty-eight passengers in the bus.

ALBANY, May 15 -- The State Commerce Department asked 2,600 metal-working firms in the state today for an estimate of open time available on critical machine tools in July, August and September. The survey is intended to help fill the continuing demand of defense contractors for machine hours open on specific types of precision tools.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 15 -- Petroleum has become Brazil's most controversial issue of the moment. Should foreign capital be allowed to help develop it or would that involve the risk of mortgaging national interests to "foreign trusts?"

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 15 -The people of this Lehigh Valley steel town heard fourteen trombones chanting tonight high in the Victorian gothic steeple of the Packer Memorial Chapel of Lehigh University. They knew what it meant. Another Bach Festival had begun.

PITTSBURGH, May 15 (AP) -- Pittsburgh Plate and Libby-Owens-Ford Glass Companies signed a union contract today that granted immediate wage rises ranging from 8 to 16 cents an hour to 18,000 employes in seven states.

The threat of renewed unrest along the local waterfront was manifest again yesterday just six days after Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., announced an accord ending his three-month feud with Anthony Anastasia, Brooklyn dock boss.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 15 -The District Court of Appeals in Los Angeles today denied without comment the writ of mandamus sought by the Screen Writers Guild in a dispute with R. K. O. Radio Pictures over screen credits for Paul Jarrico as a co-author of the film. "The Las Vegas Story."

ATLANTIC CITY, May 15 -- It is "a hoary false concept" that psychoneurotics do not make good soldiers, Col. Donald B. Peterson of the Army Medical Corps, consultant in psychiatry to the Far East Command, declared today.

Pittsfield, Mass., borrowed $4,300,000 yesterday in the public market on an issue of school building bonds maturing from 1953 to 1972. The bonds were bought by a syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.0555 for interest of 1.60 per cent.

A suit of armor over which student shave differed on the score of original ownership is now on loan by the Metropolitan Museum of Art to the Louvre, and in exchange the Metropolitan Museum has received from the Paris museum one of its treasured suits of armor for exhibition.

TOKYO, Friday, May 16 -- The new commander on Koje Island, Brig. Gen. Haydon L. Boatner, indicated yesterday there would be tighter discipline hereafter in the barbed wire stockades where the hard core of Communists had ruled over almost 80,000 prisoners of war.

LANSING, Mich., May 15 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, addressing the Michigan Legislature in joint session tonight, charged influential Democrats with an attempt to coerce the Republican party into nominating General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidency.
A picturesque stone millhouse on the east bank of the Bronx River that once provided much of the grist for eighteenth century snuff boxes will soon be savoring of food.

The Stuttgart Kickers continued their unbeaten play in this country by turning back an all-star combination of the German-Hungarians, national champions, and the Eintracht Sport Club, 2 -- 1, last night at Eintracht Oval in Astoria, Queens.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, warned the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., today that government seizure of industrial plants could become "the doom and the end of free collective bargaining and a free economy" in this country.

HEADQUARTERS, United States Fifth Air Force, in Korea, Friday, May 16 -- Col. Walker M. Mahurin of Fort Wayne, Ind., one of America's greatest aces of World War II, was shot down Tuesday while bombing enemy rail lines at Kunu, main traffic center fifty miles north of the North Korean capital of Pyongyang, in his F-86 Sabre jet.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 15 -- A peace offering designed to placate commuters who were inconvenienced last Thursday morning was made by 170 grade pupils this morning at the Nassau Boulevard and Stewart Manor stations of the Long Island Rail Road.

The rose motif suggested to enhance the bride's trousseau keynotes a collection of ensembles for the home which will be shown in a series of settings at Macy's on Monday. China bed, bath and table linens, all using some form of the rose design, will be shown in appropriate displays.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 15 -The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania joined the State of New Jersey today in opposing an application by the City of New York for the right to draw more water from the Delaware River.

A mandatory death sentence was imposed yesterday in General Sessions on Abraham Keshner, 42-year-old garment manufacturer who had been convicted of first-degree murder in an arson plot that took three lives last Sept. 10.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, and closing prices were 15 to 30 points net higher than on Wednesday.

In a letter to THE TIMES Cyril F. Dos Passos asks: "Why should the Republican National Convention nominate an individual for the Presidency of the United States who was picked by our Democratic President, in fact his very first choice, for the Democratic nomination for that office?"

TOKYO, Friday, May 16 -- The Communist delegation to the Korean armistice talks at Panmunjom charged today that the United Nations had rearmed Chinese and North Korean war prisoners held on Koje Island, off the south coast, with the intention of turning them over as "cannon fodder" to the Nationalist Chinese regime and to the South Korean Republic.

BAYONNE, N. J., May 15 -Damage and repairs to the 32,000-ton carrier Wasp are costing the Navy more than $1,000,000, Rear Admiral Roy T. Cowdrey, commander of the New York Naval Shipyard, told a Navy court of inquiry here today.

Any attempts by mass-buying retailers to jeopardize trade practices governing existing buyer-seller relations would weaken the dress industry's price structure when the competition for the consumer's dress dollar is keen, Louis Rubin, executive chairman of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group, Inc., said yesterday at the annual meeting at the Governor Clinton Hotel.

A memorial library honoring Floyd Taylor, newspaper man and director of the American Press Institute until his death last August, will be established at Columbia University with a fund contributed by journalists over the country.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 15 -- Delegates of eighteen member nations of the Social Commission of the United Nations Economic and Social Council today gave unanimous approval to twelve recommendations by the Department of Social Affairs on the needs of children deprived of normal home life.

A German 88-millimeter shell fragment snuffed the light from his eyes but it couldn't touch the flame of adventure that marks the character of David Ferguson, former Canadian Third Division infantryman, who outlined yesterday his plans for a five-month bicycle tour of Europe.
Vice President Alben Barkley pledged himself last night to "fight for the principles of the New Deal and the Fair Deal to my dying day, whether or not I am ever again a candidate for public office."
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The House quietly voted today to reduce the taxes of the members of Congress, the move being one that could save thousands of dollars for some.

This is a restless time for those who work fifty weeks for the privilege of not working two. It is a between-vacations-season time, and as such it clearly is not the best part of the year, no matter how fine the weather.

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Kangaroo," a Twentieth Century-Fox adventure in Technicolor, filmed on location in Australia, with Maureen O'Hara, Peter Lawford, Finlay Currie and Chips Rafferty, is at the Roxy.

Ruth Painter Randall, wife of James G. Randall whose multi-volume biography, "Lincoln the President," is still in the process of completion, has trained over to Little, Brown her manuscript of a study of Mary Lincoln. Based on new material, Mrs. Randall presents the relationship between Mrs. Lincoln and the President, explores the question of Mrs. Lincoln s insanity and analyzes the Anne Rutledge legend.

It was strawberry festival time yesterday at Public School 33, 281 Ninth Avenue. Shortcake, iced tea and pink punch were served in the gymnasium; sixth - graders entertained in the auditorium with dances and songs; speeches were made. The occasion was as relaxed and friendly as any in a town of 5,000.

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 15 -- A special Mayor's Committee of Union and Essex Counties, organized last year to study "the airport problem" today adopted a resolution urging Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to call a special session of the Legislature "to immediately correct the situation which calls for reopening of the Newark Airport by the Port of New York Authority."

ON BOARD THE UNITED STATES, AT SEA, May 15 -- Full-power speed trials for the new superliner United States were postponed tonight after a full day of tests in windy weather 120 miles off the Virginia Capes.

The National Association of Manufacturers predicted yesterday there would be plentiful supplies and no inflationary price rises in six general categories of consumer goods this year. It described the situation as even more favorable to the consumer than at this time last year.

PARIS, May 15 -- At the same time that the foreign ministers of the three Western powers meet to complete the accord to give West Germany a new status, the foreign ministers or their deputies representing the six European nations will try in Paris next week to complete the treaty to create the European Defense Community with a single defense force.
The Columbian Carbon Company, in its March quarter report issued yesterday by C. E. Kayser, president, showed net earnings of $1,130,995.
THE fishing for this week-end, with weather conditions unsettled, can only come under the heading of a "calculated risk" for both the fresh and salt water anglers.

The provisions of a new City Council bill proposing to revamp the administrative set-up for the city's war against smoke were announced yesterday by Council Majority Leader Joseph T. Sharkey, Brooklyn Democrat, author of the measure.

Despite a net loss of 844 members reported at the annual opening session of the New York District Conference of the Methodist Church yesterday afternoon at St. Mark's Church, 49 Edgecombe Avenue, the district superintendents announced that "there are hopeful signs of a growing interest in the church and religion."
PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (UP) -Robin Roberts scored his sixth straight victory with a five-hit effort tonight that gave the Phillies a 5-1 triumph over the Reds before 14,752 fans.

LONDON, May 15 -- The stock markets were dull and quiet today. British Government securities drifted lower throughout the day and the industrial section had a quiet session with prices presenting an irregular appearance at the close.

W. Averell Harriman, New York's candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, declared yesterday that the policies and principles of Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman, carried forward by the Democratic party, would be the principal issues of the coming campaign.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Efforts by Senator Ernest W. McFarland of Arizona, Majority Leader, to obtain agreement for a test vote on the ocntroversial McCarran bill to revise the immigration and naturalization laws failed today.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- During the week ended May 14, member bank reserves decreased $81,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Grover B. revealed speed in capturing the Hampden at Belmont Park yesterday. The mile and a sixteenth event for 3-year- olds packed considerable class, and Grover B., who is owned by T. P. Morgan, proved the best as he covered the distance in the excellent time of 1:43. The record for the course is 1:42 1-5.

PARIS, May 15 -- United States delegates took a firm stand against resuming East-West trade during discussions with European delegates to the seventy-seventh session of the Council of the International Chamber of Commerce, which closed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- House investigators said today they had "strong evidence" that the Justice Department had tried to "intimidate" Ernest Branham, an anti-trust division attorney and key witness in their inquiry into the law enforcement agency.

PARIS, May 15 -- Newspaper editors from throughout the free world heard demands today from press analysts for the publication of more and better background information to make day-to-day news developments in a complex world intelligible to their readers.

Brentano's has leased space on the concourse of the R. C. A. Building at 30 Rockefeller Plaza for a branch store for the sale of books, periodicals, greeting cards, prints and stationery. There also will be a rental library.
LONDON, May 15 (Reuters) -The annual report of the West India Committee, to be presented May 28, condemns Britain for neglect of passenger shipping in the West Indies.

LONDON, May 15 -- Donald Wolfit, noted actor, called today for a public inquiry into the conduct and administration of the Old Vic, which he described as "this monstrous pretense of a national theatre." He charged that public money was being poured out to keep it alive.

A site suitable for a gasoline service station near the Aqueduct Race Track in Ozone Park attracted the greatest interest yesterday in the auction by the city of seventy-five parcels of Queens realty for a total of $212,480. The site, offered is three parcels, is north of the Sunrise Highway and fronts on North Conduit Avenue and Cohancy and Bridgeton Streets.

If one should yearn to spend some enchanted evening in the Fiji, Cook or Tongan Islands, American or Western Samoa or New Zealand, a ticket thither can now be bought in any United Air Lines office. W. R. Ireland, United's traffic vice president, announced yesterday conclusion of a general sales agency agreement with New Zealand National Airways Corporation, which serves the storied lands.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of an address by President Truman, with interpolations as delivered, at the sixth annual honor awards program of the Department of Agriculture:

TUNIS, Tunisia, May 15 -- The Bey of Tunis, bowing to French readiness for a crackdown if necessary, appealed to his people tonight to help end a months-long campaign of violence led by nationalist extremists.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 15 -- Leaders of the Asian-Arab bloc believe now that they are within three to six votes of being able to win approval of a call for a special session of the United Nations General Assembly on the Tunisian case.

Weather, which thus far has been about the only element capable of slowing the Giants, got in the path of Leo Durocher's redhot National League champions again yesterday when early morning rains, threat of more and wet grounds caused the postponement of the opener of the three-game series with the Cubs at the Polo Grounds.
DENVER, May 15 (UP) -- Nationwide bargaining between striking oil unions and companies produced two settlements involving 1,700 workers today, but the over-all walkout did not end.

VIENNA, May 15 -- Joseph Joham, managing director of Austria's biggest nationalized bank, the Creditanstalt, denied today that under its auspices he had established for his own profit private concerns in Washington, Switzerland or England, as was charged this week by Dr. Alfred Migsch, Austrian Socialist and former Minister.
Fashions for round the clock were presented by Jo Hughes, Inc., 10 East Fifty-sixth Street, at luncheon at the St. Regis Hotel yesterday.
The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that it had revised its program to curtail week-end service on nine bus routes and one trolley line in Brooklyn, beginning tomorrow.

A new step in parent education has been taken by the Association for the Help of Retarded Children with the formation of special courses for mothers of mentally retarded pre-school children, it was announced yesterday. The first session of a nine-week course was conducted last Saturday in offices at 853 Broadway.

TRENTON, May 15 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, a frequent critic of the Port of New York Authority, defended it today after a Democratic Representative from Jersey City sought action to abolish the interstate agency.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 15 -Twenty-two of the country's major corporations have become corporation associates of Princeton University's James Forrestal Research Center in a program designed to further basic scientific research.

An extra session of batting practice yesterday failed to snap the Dodgers out of their hitting slump, but last night still was a joyful occasion in Flatbush as Billy Loes, one of the neighbors' children, shut out the Pirates, 2 -- 0, in his major league debut as a starting pitcher.

Mayors and other top officials representing 250 of the largest American cities, meeting here for the twentieth annual United States Conference of Mayors, were welcomed to New York yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri at City Hall after a noontime parade up lower Broadway.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended May 10 totaled 719,793 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 24,799 cars or 3.3 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 88.334 cars or 10.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 8,004 cars or 1.1 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., May 15 -- Dawn Duncan, 10 years old, of Drydon Road, rested easier today. She can keep Tobey, a week-old fawn, and her father, Lieut. Comdr. Robert J. Duncan, assistant Public Relations Officer for the Third Naval District, is not going to jail.

DALLAS, Tex., May 15 (AP) -- Gordon McLendon, president of the Liberty Broadcasting System, which grew to more than 400 stations through the broadcast of major league baseball, said today that it was suspending operation.

While much has been made in the past of "so-called crime along the waterfront," the integrity of the United States Customs Service has never been questioned once during that time, Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs for the Port of New York, told the graduating class of the Customs School yesterday.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 15 (AP) -- Attorneys tonight took a sick bed deposition from a Rochester detective about a statement he allegedly took from Carl G. LoDolce.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 15 (UP) -- The Pennsylvania Workmen's Compensation Board ruled today that Eddie Waitkus, first baseman of the Philadelphia Phillies, was not entitled to $3,500 compensation for a gunshot injury inflicted by a girl baseball fan.
ACCRA, Gold Coast, May 15 -- The black man's brave new world is slowly rising here on the backs of those who once were his white masters and now do his bidding -- the British Civil Service men.
Gradual dispersal in recent years of its milk processing operations to outlying centers has resulted in the sale by the Sheffield Farms Company of its big plant on Manhattan's West Side.

The steady march of the Puerto Rican people toward complete self-government under American guidance is a fact, not a theory. Last year the insular Government called a constitutional convention, and the Constitution which it drew up was approved by the people of Puerto Rico in a referendum two months ago.

LOS ANGELES, May 15 -- Dr. Albert Einstein, the mathematical wizard, took time out from investigating the mysteries of the universe a few days ago to help a 15-year-old Los Angeles girl 3,000 miles away with her plane geometry course.

The increasing rates that must be paid for insurance against hospital and surgical expenses are the result, in part, of abuses of the plans by patients who demand unnecessary treatment, a Blue Cross officer said here yesterday. Too many patients have been moved by "health propaganda" to seek treatment, it was said.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 15 -- Byron Nelson, the gentleman rancher from Texas, sat in the locker room at Wygakyl this morning enjoying himself. The one-time Mechanical Man of golf is making one of his rare tournament appearances in the Palm Beach round-robin for the benefit of New Rochelle Hospital, and he had all the reactions of an ancient fire horse instinctively responding to the alarm.

New techniques that are expected to bring about important money savings in metals production were announced yesterday by Maj. Gen. William N. Porter, president of the Chemical Construction Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Department-store sales in the United States during the week ended May 10 were 6 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Figures from the board's weekly report on sales by districts follow in terms of percentage changes from like periods of 1951:

Four more policemen were dismissed from the force yesterday for taking graft from Harry Gross, the convicted bookmaker, and for lying about their dealings with him. They had denied knowing him or accepting his bribes.

Borrowings for business and industrial purposes in the New York area decreased for the fourth consecutive week during the period ended on Wednesday. Seasonal repayments of loans, concentrated in commodities, foods and tobaccos largely accounted for a reduction of $22,000,000 which brought the outstanding total down to $7,571,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The national school lunch program, which has grown steadily each year since its start in the early New Deal days as a means of using farm surpluses, is in a crisis.

An eight-point program to "improve public safeguards and reduce noise" at the three major metropolitan airports was adopted yesterday by the civilian aviation industry. The an nouncement was made by Capt. E. V. Rickenbacker, chairman of the National Air Transport Coordinating Committee, who recommended the immediate reopening of Newark Airport.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- The Senate Banking Committee today unanimously approved the appointment of Henry H. Fowler as head of the Defense Production Administration. Senate confirmation was recommended after the group heard a report from D. P. A. Administrator, Manly Fleischmann, in closed session on pending negotiations with Chile for a new agreement to supply copper to the United States.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, May 15 -- In this important steel-producing city of the Ruhr, as well as in Brunswick, a machinery and truck manufacturing center, and in Cologne, the commercial hub of the Rhineland, at least 250,000 workers quietly but effectively quit today for an afternoon of demonstrations. Public transportation halted in each city.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 15 -- Mrs. Clarence D. Wright, legislative chairman of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, today called attempts to table resolutions at the annual convention here "subterfuges" of special-interest groups.

LOS ANGELES, May 15 (UP) -- Lauro Salas, newly crowned world lightweight champion, said today he was ready to give the former titleholder, Jimmy Carter, a chance to regain the crown he lost last night, but the question was where.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., May 15 -- Jess Larson, General Services and Defense Materials Procurement Administrator, voiced assurance today that there would enough aluminum to take care of the nation's needs for the foreseeable future.

Mayor Impellitteri signed yesterday three local laws imposing new city taxes expected to yield a total of $19,500,000 to help balance his record 1952-53 budget of $1,469,275,101. The Mayor reserved decision at the end of a seventy-five-minute public hearing in his office at City Hall, but ten minutes later signed the measures.
The prevalent notion that news commentators would not do well before television's cameras is in the process of being disproved, albeit for the moment under circumstances somewhat short of ideal.

Stockholders of the Central Maine Power Company approved yesterday at their annual meeting in Augusta, Me., an increase in authorized common stock from 2,500,000 shares of $10 par value to 3,250,000 shares. They also authorized an increase in preferred shares from 300,000 to 330,000 shares of $100 par value.

An imaginative collection of fashions designed and executed by students of the Parsons School of Design was presented yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. The event was held for 200 students who will graduate this month after completing the three-year course.

LONDON, May 15 -- The Government published today a new plan for British radio and television that within a few years might end the British Broadcasting Corporation's monopoly while assuring its continued predominance as a national institution.
Gerald Cassen, South African bass-baritone, who has appeared widely in opera and recitals in Europe and his native country, gave his first local recital at Town Hall last evening.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 15 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley became for a few minutes today the favorite son Presidential candidate of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C. I. O.

GUAM, May 15 (AP) -- Native constabulary men led by a Chicagoan captured two naked Japanese yesterday in their eagle's nest hideout on Saipan in the western Pacific. They had lived there since American troops captured the island eight years ago.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -The Navy announced today that the keel will be laid next month for the Nautilus, the nation's first atomic-powered submarine.
CHICAGO, May 15 (UP) -- Ray Scarborough snapped a six-game Red Sox losing streak today by shutting out the White Sox on four hits, 1 to 0, before 3,440 fans.

MADRID, May 15 -- Lincoln MacVeagh, the United States Ambassador, said today that negotiations with the Spanish Government for a bilateral agreement on economic and military collaboration were proceeding in a "friendly and understanding atmosphere."
TOKYO, Friday, May 16 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,250, covering Wednesday's activities:
Robert W. Dowling was elected president of the National Urban League yesterday at the organization's annual board meeting in the Commodore Hotel.

The outstanding choices for this week - end's food shoppers are broilers and fryers. The City Department of Markets reports that for the second successive week the cost of the birds has dropped two cents. The current city-wide average is 41 cents a pound and in several chains and independent stores the price is as low as 29 to 35 cents a pound.
LONDON, May 15 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Mrs. Eisenhower arrived here by air today on a two-day farewell visit to the British Government.

UNITED NATION, N. Y., May 15 -- It is only too apparent to United Nations delegates that the weird events connected with the revolt of the prisoners of war on Koje Island have played into the hands of the Communists, and have weakened support for the position taken by the United States, as the agent of the United Nations, in the armistice talks.

ONE of the most ambitious and, in certain respects, one of the most impressive novels of the current publishing season is Worth Tuttle Hedden's oddly titled "Love Is a Wound." Love, as it is experienced by three major characters of this intense and painful book, is a trial and a tribulation, an obsession and an agonizing emotional torture.

Dick Eichhorn, unbeaten sophomore right-hander, yielded only four hits in pitching St. John's University to a 7-3 Metropolitan Collegiate Conference victory over City College yesterday at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, Queens.

Everyone hopes that the French know what they are doing in North Africa and that they do intend to meet the nationalists half way. What one keeps asking one's self these days, in all friendliness but with considerable anxiety, is when this process is going to take form.
The stock market continued into lower ground yesterday although prices managed a partial recovery after losses ranging to a point and slightly more.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -Congress completed action today on a bill giving members of the armed forces a "cost of living" pay increase of 4 per cent plus a 14 per cent increase in food and quarters allowances. The bill went to the White House for signing.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 15 -- With General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Estes Kefauver strong favorites to win the Presidential preference contests at the Oregon primary election tomorrow, candidates on both Republican and Democratic tickets made their final appeals to voters today and sat back to await the verdict.

Without benefit of "flyovers" -military and naval planes whizzing overhead -- the Armed Forces Day parade down Fifth Avenue tomorrow afternoon will be the major feature of a broad demonstration throughout the metropolitan area of what the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps and Coast Guard can do.

Three large art exhibitions here by groups contain a number of pictures among which the gallery visitor is bound to find several, if not many, favorites and, perhaps, a few occasions for indifference or hostility.

Success in the first year's operation of an unusual project to maintain family health has encouraged the Community Service Society to expand the plan so that next year there are expected to be nearly 1,000 persons under observation.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Strong opinion that Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois eventually will be drafted as the Democratic Presidential nominee despite his reluctance to run was expressed today as top-ranking Democratic officials met to recommend Gov. Paul A. Dever of Massachusetts as keynoter and House Speaker Sam Rayburn of Texas as permanent chairman of their Chicago nominating convention to begin July 21.

The epidemic of spring campus "riots" spread to Columbia College early this morning when a noisy crowd of undergraduates, estimated at 1,000, besieged three Barnard College dormitories in a "panty" raid by the light of torches and fireworks.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Members of both Houses of Congress demanded today that the Department of Defense provide the legislators with a full report on the circumstances of the Koje lsland Communist prisoner incidents.

" New Faces of 1952," representing the fourth revue in the series introduced by Leonard Sillman, will be disclosed at 8 o'clock tonight at the Royale. Its predecessors were identified as the editions of 1934, 1936 and 1943.

Bernard M. Baruch, '89, declared yesterday that "like many others I have seen a victim of intolerance and criticism; I feel a great debt of gratitude to City College for affording me the opportunity for depth and serenity."
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- A House committee today postponed until next week a decision on what to do about bills exempting organized baseball from anti-trust laws.
ALBANY, May 15 -- The State Board of Law Examiners today announced the names of 418 persons who passed the State Bar examination held March 6 and 7. The test was taken by 1,179 law students.

Boxing returns to Madison Square Garden tonight when Billy Graham, 29-year-old East Sider, meeting Rocky Castellani, 25-year-old Luzerne, Pa. scrapper, in the principal bout of ten rounds. The contest brings together two of the nation's foremost boxers, with Graham, who lost a disputed title decision to Kid Gavilan, the world welterweight ruler, last August, taking a crack at middle-weight competition.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The House of Representatives demonstrated its disposition to override President Truman's prospective veto of the hotly disputed offshore oil bill today by approving the final draft of the measure, 247 to 89.

PEARL RIVER, N. Y., May 15 -- A helicopter and a small plane flew over the heads of frustrated pickets today to carry food and beds to a score of scientists and about 400 other workers held by a strike inside the world's largest pharmaceutical plant in Rockland County.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Federal Trade Commission in a 3-to-1 decision today ordered the Book-of-the-Month Club, Inc., to stop using the word "free" in its advertising and promotional literature without giving a fuller explanation of the limitations the club placed upon the word.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Grain futures lacked aggressive buying support today, and while there was fair absorption early in the session, with a strong tone, buyers backed away from moderate offerings and reactionary price trends developed.

CLEVELAND, Miss., May 15 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina urged today that "the white people of the Southern states" function as a minority bloc to repel what he described as the "antagonisms" of the Truman Administration and the political pressures exerted by big-city minority groups through patronage alliances.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- A witness told Senate investigators today that a United Nations economist recently was dismissed after he had refused to answer when asked by a grand jury if he was a member of a spy ring.
A strike by 500 driver-salesmen of the Krug Baking Company halted deliveries yesterday of bread and cake to an estimated 300,000 families in the metropolitan area.

KALIMPONG, India, May 15 -The Chinese Communists now ruling Tibet have set up a new system of quasi-religious administration in the formerly autonomous theocratic Himalayan state, according to reports from Lhasa, the Tibetan capital.

ALBANY, May 15 -- Construction work on another section of the Major Deegan Expressway will get under way soon, Bertram D. Tallamy, State Superintendent of Public Works, announced today as nine bids for the project were opened here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 15 -- A series of provisions calling on governments to promise adequate living standards, improved health conditions and compulsory primary schooling, was approved today by the United Nations Human Rights Commission for inclusion in a projected universal treaty on basic rights.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Truman asserted today that the Democratic platform this year would be patterned on the platforms going back to 1932, when the New Deal was born, and vowed he would campaign as hard for the Democratic nominee as he would for himself.

In the language of Broadway, our friends and neighbors in Jersey City seem to have laid an egg in asking Congress to rescind the 1921 Congressional approval of the bi-state compact setting up the Port of New York Authority. Representative Celler, chairman of a House subcommittee, indicated that Mayor Kenny had sent his complaints to the wrong address.
PARIS, May 15 (AP) -- The French Foreign Office denied today that France had made any moves to restrict the freedom of the Bey or any member of his family. An Associated Press correspondent in

PITTSBURGH, May 15 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles called tonight for a new United States foreign policy keyed to a firm warning to the Communists that any further aggression will be met by "retaliatory punishing power so severe that the aggression would not pay."

BALTIMORE, May 15 (AP) -- The entry box for the seventy-sixth Preakness Stakes was opened this morning, two days before the running of the $75,000 added Maryland classic, and six of the ten horses expected to make up the field were entered officially.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 15 (AP) -- G. F. Strickland's Devilkin coasted home a six-length winner of the Downington Purse at Garden State today, having no trouble beating her eight 3-year-old rivals in the six-furlong sprint.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Truman defended the Administration's agricultural policy today as an economic "crusade" and gave assurances he would repeat his 1948 intensive stumping tour in support of a candidate who would stand behind the program.

ST. GEORGES, Del., May 15 -Four seaman were believed to have perished today when a tank ship carrying 640,000 gallons of high octane gasoline exploded in flames after she was in collision with a freighter in the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal, three miles west of here.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 15 -- Col. Milos Stamatovic, head of the Yugoslav military administration in Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste, issued today three decrees establishing closer ties between his zone and Yugoslavia in retaliation against the London decisions that gave the Italian Government control over the civil administration of Zone A, the United States-British zone.

PARIS, May 15 -- Andre Francois-Poncet, 64-year-old French historian, diplomat and author who currently is serving as the French High Commissioner in Germany, today was elected to the tradition laden French Academy -- seat of the Forty Immortals."

Dealings in actual cocoa over-shadowed futures market trading yesterday. Brazil sold 11,750 bags to importers and manufacturers in this country and 6,100 bags to other markets, mostly for October-November shipments and all but 250 bags from the new crop.
Leaders of Reform Judaism paid tribute to Dr. Samuel Schulman, 88-year-old rabbi emeritus of Temple Emanu-El, at a dinner last night in the Delmonico Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent during the week ended May 13, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index, 111.6 per cent of the 1947-49 average, was 0.3 per cent below the level of the latest available comprehensive index -- that for April -- and 3 per cent lower than the average for January, 1951, the month during which the General Ceiling Price Regulation became effective.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, today proposed a constitutional amendment to limit non-military Government spending to 5 per cent of the national income and to levy special taxes to pay off the national debt.

Your editorial "Chennault's Planes" called attention to a subject of world significance. I talked to General Chennault when he was in Washington a month ago concerning these airplanes, impounded at Hong Kong for over two years and under litigation before the Privy Council in London.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 17 -- Peiping warned the United Nations today against "retaliation" or disciplinary action upon the prisoners of war who captured their camp commander, Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd, on Koje Island, off the Korean south coast, last week and held him captive for seventy-eight hours.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- More than 100 small manufacturers benefited to the extent of $16,000,000 in prime contracts and subcontracts as a result of industry assistance clinics held last January over the country under the auspices of the National Production Authority and the Munitions Board.

Marking the latest in a long series of obstacles, officials of Long Island University made two announcements yesterday adversely affecting 300 students attending classes at the university's Oyster Bay Division and the Hicksville (L. I.) Evening Annex.

The Government of Puerto Rico announced yesterday that it would offer on May 27 an issue of public improvement bonds totaling $6,400,000. Dated July 1, 1952, the bonds will come due serially on July 1 from 1953 to 1972.

ROME, May 16 -- The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano today urged Catholic voters to rally round the Christian Democratic party in the provincial and municipal elections that are to take place in central and southern Italy on the twenty-fifth of this month.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said tonight that President Truman almost gave up going to banquets last year because a confused waiter had served him bowl of chicken broth intended for a White House aide with an ulcer.
ST. LOUIS, May 16 (AP) -- Bob Nieman supplied the power while Earl Harrist and Satchel Paige held the Red Sox to two hits in ten innings to give the Browns a 2-to-1 triumph tonight.

Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer signed two orders yesterday directing the city to show cause next Thursday why the $5 and $10 use taxes on automobiles and trucks should not be declared unconstitutional and a temporary injunction be issued.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A bill designed to prevent the abuses revealed by the tax scandals investigation was introduced in the House of Representatives today.
SALT LAKE CITY, May 16 (UP) -- Northern Utah, still recovering from the worst flood in the state's history, was buffeted today by strong winds. Gusts were as fierce as 100 miles an hour.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 16 (AP) -- Johanna Mankiewicz, the 15-year-old high school girl who took her troublesome geometry problem to Dr. Albert Einstein, drew a rebuke today from her school authorities.

BERLIN, May 16 -- Any possibility that the Soviet stoppage of United States and British military highway patrols on the autobahn linking Berlin with West Germany could be attributable to technical reasons was dispelled today when the Soviet Union charged that such "armed patrols" were illegal.

The market for underwriting new issues of corporate securities is showing signs of strain but no great slowdown in the pace of recent marketing is imminent. The backlog of public financing transactions seems likely to keep much of Wall Street's undewriting capital under earmarks until well along in June.
