HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 16 -- Jane Wyman will be starred in "Broadway Revisited," to be produced by Henry Blanke for Warner Bros. The story still in the process of being transferred into screen play form, will deal in a romantic vein with the professional and personal life experiences of a movie star who returns to the Broadway stage.

Unanimous votes in both houses of Congress on Thursday will give the members of the armed forces a "cost of living" pay increase of 4 per cent plus a 14 per cent increase in food and quarters allowances. This seems not unduly generous, in view of the kind of work many members of the armed forces have to do.

BONN, Germany, May 16 -- Worried by trade-union tactics of hit-and-run strikes, in which industries in two more West German cities were brought to a halt today, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of the Federal Government said tonight he regarded the strikes as a "dangerous disturbance of the domestic order."

BAYONNE, N. J., May 16 -- Two veteran destroyer skippers told a Navy court of inquiry here today that the ship-handling of Lieut. Comdr. William J. Tierney, missing skipper of the U. S. S. Hobson, just before its collision with the aircraft carrier Wasp was "reasonable" under the circumstances.

The action of the Medical Society of the State of New York in approving a resolution making a loyalty oath to the United States a requirement for membership brings up once more a question that goes to the heart of the citizen's relation to his country. How does a democracy insure the good faith and devotion of the people?

The Police Department placed on trial in absentia yesterday a missing lieutenant who failed to heed a Staten Island corruption inquiry subpoena on April 22 and put in his retirement application the same day. Dismissal would nullify the retirement application before it could take effect at midnight next Thursday, in the department's view.

Your editorial on the Chennault (?) planes lacks the balance and sobriety so characteristic of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Without the record no one can pass an opinion of any weight upon what seems to be a novel question. On the point of the bona fides, it is important to consider the large value, estimated to be many millions, which would seem to be beyond the means of a professional soldier.

It was a shock to the Giants yesterday to lose a 3-2 decision to the Cubs, but Leo Durocher's National League champions finished a long afternoon's exercise reeling as the hustling Chicagoans went on to trounce them again, 6 -- 4, in the second game of a doubleheader that attracted 11,350 customers to the Polo Grounds.

BURBANK, Calif., May 16 -- A fire that started on a reproduction of a New York street raged for three hours here today and destroyed a huge motion picture sound stage and several acres of outdoor film sets at the Warner Brothers studio.
The following is a round-up of bits of advice, culled from various sources which may be of use to homemakers:

PORTLAND, Ore., Saturday, May 17 -- Oregon Republicans went to the polls under warm, sunny skies and gave a thumping endorsement to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower yesterday in the Presidential preferential primary election.
AN ANTI-COMMUNIST PRISON CAMP, in Korea, May 16 (AP) -- The United Nations Command is demonstrating a great degree of faith in Communist prisoners of war who declare themselves anti-Communists.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -Irving Kaplan of New York, a United Nations employe who is under discharge notice, refused to tell Senate investigtaors today whether he is now or ever was a member of the Communist party or a Soviet spy.

A plea for Federal tax reductions and better control of Government expenditures was made yesterday by Hamilton Merrill, president of Manning, Maxwell Moore, Inc., Stratford, Conn., industrial firm. He addressed members of the National Society for Business Budgeting at their annual conference in the Belmont Plaza Hotel.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 16 -- The whole program for United States aid in the economic development of Brazil has been stalled over the question of a United States investor's right to withdraw his earnings from Brazil.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 16 -- Arne Sunde, who has represented Norway in the United Nations since 1948, said this morning in a farewell statement that the refusal of the Security Council last month to place the Tunisian question on its agenda was the most disappointing United Nations development he had known.

LONDON, May 16 -- Week-end influences and Chancellor Richard Austen Butler's renewed warning of the danger of inflation restricted business still further in the stock markets today. British funds continued to fall but leading industrials generally held firm.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Strength in May deliveries of wheat and corn was a feature of the grain futures trade today. On the other hand, there was pressure on May oats because of deliveries. Deferred deliveries of wheat, corn and rye were firm on more general commission buying, and in the case of corn the sensational upturn in hog prices of the last two days encouraged buying.

Shareholders of Bankers Securities Corporation will vote on May 26 on a proposal to take it out of the investment company field and put it into merchandising and real estate. Albert M. Greenfield, chairman of the board, said that the decision was made by the board because the concern has concentrated most of its investments in those lines.

The immunity from motor fuel taxes and other state levies enjoyed by contractors working on Atomic Energy Commission projects was protested yesterday by Charles F. Conlon of Chicago, executive secretary of the National Association of Tax Administrators.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 16 -R. W. (Bobby) Knowles, Walker Cup player from the Palmetto G. C. in Aiken, S. C., and Johnny Humm of Rockville, the defender, shared honors in the opening rounds of match play in the forty-second annual Walter J. Travis Memorial invitation golf tournament at the Garden City G. C. today.

PARIS, May 16 -- Ernest Ansermet has just completed his program of Swiss and French music by the Orchestre de la Suisse Romande, held this evening under the auspices of the Congress for Cultural Freedom at the Champs Elysees Theatre.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- An international economic conference to survey developments since 1945 and formulate a program to deal with major economic problems of the free countries of the world was recommended today by Hugh Gaitskell, former Chancellor of the Exchequer in Britain's Labor Government.

New Yorkers who favor Americana may be particularly interested in some new wallpaper panels, now available through decorators at Katzenbach Warren, 575 Madison Avenue. The eight panels, which cover nearly twenty-seven feet, display a panorama of the Hudson River as it might have looked almost 100 years ago.

For years sales executives have been endeavoring to attract promising young men into the selling field. Their chief problem has been to offset the unfavorable impressions created by comedians, authors of such plays as "Death of a Salesman" and unsuccessful, over-exuberant and in some cases deceitful practitioners of the profession.

JONES BEACH, L. I., May 16 -- This famous public beach will open for its twenty-third bathing season next Saturday, May 24 -by which time, park officials hope, the weather gods will be willing to admit that summer soon will be coming in.
Except for coffee and cottonseed oil, trading volume was generally small in New York commodity futures markets yesterday.
" In the House and Out," by Samuel Yellen, is the only book published today. It is a selection of Mr. Yellen's poems. Issued by Indiana University Press, the volume sells for $2.75.

BOSTON, May 16 -- A Brookline, Mass. couple and their three sons were named the "Jewish Family of the Year" tonight at the Sabbath Observance dinner of the National Convention of the United Synagogues of America.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 17 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 59, for Friday:
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A general increase in social security insurance benefits, effective Sept. 1, was approved by the House Ways and Means Committee today by a near-unanimous voice vote.

Traffic congestion that threatens to strangle downtown urban areas and the allocation to municipalities of revenue sources sufficient to meet their responsibilities were listed yesterday as two of the most urgent problems facing American cities.
The most decorated hero of the Korean fighting, who once refused rotation back home, apparently became faint of heart at the prospect of a press conference yesterday.

At its Paris meeting last Thursday the International Press Institute performed a signal service for journalists of the free world by spotlighting the problem of reporting on the Soviet Union. As the speakers at the forum there indicated, the heavy censorship of the Soviet Government and other restrictions on the few foreign correspondents permitted in Moscow make their task most difficult.
Your editorial of April 28 "Kashmir, Hardy Perennial" and the letter of M. S. Rajan of May 2 do not answer all the political and legal questions raised in the dispute.

PEARL RIVER, N. Y., May 16 -- The two-day-old strike at the American Cyanamid Company's Lederle Laboratories here took an unusual turn tonight when representatives of management and the union interrupted their negotiations in the plant to eat a dinner including food flown in earlier for strikebound workers.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 (AP) -Gran Hamner singled with the bases loaded in the tenth inning tonight to give the Phillies a 3-2 triumph over the Reds. Ken Heintzelman helped his own cause along in the final frame by bunting and making first on a fielder's choice.

Max Grossberg, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the one-story taxpayer containing four stores at 39-01 to 39-15 Woodside Avenue, Queens, from Hugh Bek. The property, with a 150-foot frontage, was sold for cash above mortgages of $56,000.

The Associated Press tabulation of Presidential nomination delegates switched W. Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, back into the lead in known and avowed delegate strength for the Democratic Presidential nomination yesterday.

Suggestions for the treatment of two areas in the house, the bedroom and an apartment terrace, are included in the annual exhibition of students' work on view at two art schools in this city. At the Parsons School of Design, 136 East Fifty-seventh Street, several treatments for bedrooms are depicted in sketches, and at the Traphagen School of Fashion, 1680 Broadway, the actual setting of a terrace is on display.

Boys will be boys, and sometimes they are college students. But when they turn into mobs, as they have done recently at Yale, Harvard and Columbia, they can only be classed as delinquents. From time out of mind college students have periodically opened their safety valves in such muscular ways as froshsoph battles on a muddy football field.

BALTIMORE, May 16 -- At the Pimlico Race Track, where the wooden stands creak with (a) age and (b) tradition, the Preakness Stakes will be run for the seventy-sixth time on the morrow. It's the second contest in the Big-Three series for 3-year-olds; the first was the Kentucky Derby on May 3 and the third will be the Belmont Stakes on June 7.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., May 16 -- The 52,000-ton liner United States returned to her birthplace shipyard on the James River late this afternoon after successful builder trials at sea.

GUATEMALA, May 16 -- The Government of President Jacobo Arbenz has proposed an agrarian reform law that would nationalize virtually all privately owned uncultivated and share-cropped land in Guatemala for redistribution among the landless peasant masses of the country.

The new management of the Glenn L. Martin Company authorized an offering of new common stock to the company's stockholders yesterday at the rate of nine new shares for each ten shares held. The new stock is to be priced at $6 a share.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Commissioner Richard B. McEntire, vice chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that while there have been a great number of "unscruplous salesmen" of Canadian stocks, the ranks are slowly dwindling.

Girls in Barnard College dormitories awoke yesterday to find a stern reprimand from Dean Millicent C. McIntosh for their part in encouraging 1,000 Columbia lingerie raiders the night before. Educators elsewhere acted to stem the rash of "spring fever" campus outbreaks.

On a tour of housing developments and welfare centers in Inwood, Harlem and the lower East Side and in a speech to Young Democrats in the financial district, W. Averell Harriman yesterday repeatedly spoke out against all forms of discrimination and prejudice.

NEW DELHI, India, May 16 -- President Rajendra Prasad, in his inaugural address to India's new Parliament, today took the United Nations sharply to task for banning a discussion of the Tunisian question.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 16 -- Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C. I. O., dedicated his union today to an intensified program of organizing and political action.

LOS ANGELES, May 16 (AP) -Denis Johannson of Finland ran off with the feature 1,500-meter race in the Los Angeles Coliseum relays tonight, leaving an all-star field of Olympic candidates fifteen yards behind at the finish.

Getting adequate services for children in any city, regardless of size, depends on vigilance by the community and action by enlightened citizens, Charlotte Carr, executive director of the Citizens Committee of Children of New York City, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- President Truman declared tonight that the United States was much stronger now than a year ago and that the chances of a third world war "are just that much less."
CHICAGO, May 16 (AP) -- The Government's champion of small business today accused the Army and Navy of "dragging their feet" in giving defense work to small companies.

The Virginia Electric and Power Company reported yesterday net income of $4,291,074, equal to 71 cents a share on 4,946,392 common shares, for the first four months this year. In the corresponding period last year the net was $3,585,619, or 65 cents a share on 4,496,718 shares then outstanding.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to order a reduction in Railway Express Agency rates whenever wages of agency employes fell 1 cent an hour.

BONN, Germany, May 16 -- John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, is being pressed by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and other West German Government political leaders to remain in Germany until after the ratification of the treaty system that will integrate the Federal Republic into Western Europe.

In October, 1950, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower announced the completion of plans for a long-term undertaking which he called "the most important step I have taken as president of Columbia University." The project was christened the American Assembly, and it may best be described, perhaps, as a new and imaginative application to outstanding public questions of one of the most cherished of American institutions -- the "town meeting."
Sharp criticism of Canada's "moose pasture" stock salesmen and praise for Canada's tax laws were combined yesterday by Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange.
MADRID, May 16 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco announced today to the Spanish Cortes that he had decided to conclude bilateral economic and military agreements with the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- Spokesmen for the meat industry urged Congress today to abolish "unworkable" price controls and let the housewife do the "stabilizing" by fighting it out with her butcher.

A safety device to reduce fatalities or injuries by airplanes to persons on the ground has been produced by Charles Adler Jr., the inventor whose many devices are used in the commercial and military air services.

Howard Fast, the author, told an audience of 150 Hunter College students yesterday that President Truman and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt were among those who had praised his books before his name became linked with communism.

BOSTON, May 16 -- Congress has lost control over Federal spending, it was asserted here today. Roswell Magill, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, pointed out that in the President's budget of $85.4 billion for fiscal 1953, only about $29 billion is clearly subject to annual Congressional review.

The Port of New York rang to the clatter of baggage escalators and the blare of taxicab horns from 8 A. M. to 10 P. M., yesterday as 6,168 ocean travelers boarded thirteen Europe and Caribbean-bound liners.

The City of New York received $972,262 and returned 297 parcels of real estate to the tax rolls during its five-day auction sale of tax lien foreclosures. Yesterday's bidding resulted in the sale of eighty-five Staten Island properties for $115,075, which was about 25 per cent above the upset prices.

ROME, May 16 -- The measures taken by Premier-Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia to tighten his hold on Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste were branded as "illegal" by the Italian foreign ministry today.
DETROIT, May 16 -- Irv Noren supplied the power and Allie Reynolds the pitching at Briggs Stadium today as the Yankees tamed Red Rolfe's Tigers, 3 -- 2, before a chilled gathering of 6,209.

Prof. Theodore Goodman was better known to the students, faculty and alumni of City College than to the world in general. And this was true precisely because of his devotion to the college, his own alma mater, where he taught writing courses for thirty years, and where he was a living legend.

A slight trend to the higher side was exhibited yesterday by the stock market, but the effort bogged down in slack trading. Price changes among the major units were confined to fractions, only a few issues showing changes of a point or more.

Earnings of the Creole Petroleum Corporation in the first quarter of this year approximated $56,500,000, or $2.18 each on the 25,865,310 shares outstanding, A. T. Proudfit, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday. This compared with $48,000,000, or $1.86 a share, in the similar period of 1951.
When Truman Capote, author of the recent "The Grass Harp," took his typewriter to Italy last month, he promised to pound out at least two new plays.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- In an angry denunciation of Communist charges that the United Nations had used poison gas and germ warfare in Korea, Secretary of Defense Robert A. Lovett warned today that if the charges masked a Communist plan to use the dread weapons "they'll just wish they'd never been born."

Readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES who have followed Herbert Matthews' very interesting articles on Venezuela recently are aware of the existence of a military dictatorship there. They may not know the military junta now governing Venezuela has recently issued a call for war unto death against the leaders of the country's majority party, the Accion Democratica.

DETROIT, May 16 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, speaking today in this center of industrial unionism, urged American labor to reject special privilege at the expense of the general public and to resist political pressure aimed at "the exploitation of industry."

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today forty-five additional battle casualties in Korea. The new list reported ten killed, thirty-four wounded and one missing. The following were listed from New York (none from Connecticut or New Jersey):

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP -- The airplane crash at Elizabeth, N. J., on Feb. 11 in which 33 persons died was blamed by the civil aeronautics board today on the reversal in flight of one propeller and the subsequent feathering of another.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Air Force today postponed plans for the civilian Ground Observer Corps to maintain an around-the-clock watch on the skies for unidentified planes.

LONDON, May 16 -- Peace in the world rests on spiritual and economic as well as military strength. General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower said today before leaving London. Of these factors he placed the spiritual first.
Five art exhibitions here demonstrate that almost any subject, even the absence of a "realistic" subject, is sufficient grist for the modern artist's mill.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 16 -- Members of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, closing their annual convention today, passed a resolution reaffirming their belief in the United Nations, acting in the face of an anti-United Nations campaign by outside interests.
Somewhere in New York today is a young robber who hopes his victim is feeling all right and who has promised to return the loot from an apartment he ransacked in the Bronx yesterday.

BOSTON, May 16 (UP) --JumpingI on starter Wilmer (Vinegar Bend)t 1Vfizell for five runs in the second/ 4 inning, the Braves went on to deifeat the Cardinals, 8--3, behind the seven-hit pitching of Warren Spahn tonight.
Inwood, the 1951 Metropolitan and Long Island district winner, was dethroned by a half-point as the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team matches were concluded yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., charged today that the Secretary of Commerce, Charles Sawyer, who is technically in charge of the steel mills seized by the Government, had displayed "an almost unthinkable degree of bias" against the steel union.

The Public Service Commission authorized the New York Central Railroad yesterday to increase its basic commutation fares by 25 per cent. Officials of the railroad announced that the increase, which will apply to 40,000 commuters in this area, would become effective next week.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- A National Production Authority official today resisted, the Ford Motor Company's proposal to redistribute scarce metal, saying it probably would put the Kaiser-Frazer and Crosley companies out of business.

DENVER, May 16 (UP) -- The nation-wide oil strike appeared to be breaking up tonight, but slowly. Agreements were near or had been signed that would permit the immediate return of more than one-fifth of the 90,000 striking oil workers to their jobs.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 16 -- Six cantatas formed the fare at today's sessions of the annual festival of the Bach Choir of Bethlehem. Three were sung in the late afternoon and three in the evening. Both sessions drew audiences that overflowed the 1,100 capacity of Lehigh University's Packer Chapel.

The 164th annual General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. will be held at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, starting Thursday and ending May 28. This will be the first time this assembly has met here in fifty years.

Plans for converting the milk processing plant of the Sheffield Farms Company on the West Side into one of the largest television centers in the East were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of the property by the Columbia Broadcasting System from Webb Knapp, Inc.

BONN, Germany, May 16 -- The weary West German Bundestag adopted today a complicated but drastic equalization of burdens law after two weeks of steady debate and a final flurry of promises by the Government to increase the cash outlays to take care of the immediate needs of the refugees.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. "The Lion and the Horse," a Warner Brothers Western drama filmed in the new Warnercolor and starring Steve Cochran, is at the Palace. Louis King directed and Bryan Foy produced from a screen play by Crane Wilbur.

Pan American Airways said last night at Idlewild Airport that it would cancel four regular flights to London and three to Paris next week in compliance with Petroleum Administration Defense order number six.
Lloyd R. Leaver, vice president in charge of the industrial rubber division of Thermoid Company, has been elected a director of the company, according to Fred Shluter, president.

LONDON, May 16 (AP) -- Sweden's favored defending champions and highly rated Italian and Danish tennis teams assumed 2 -- 0 leads today in second-round play of the European Zone Davis Cup eliminations.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 16 -- Thirteen Arab and Asian countries charged today that the Bey of Tunis' appeal for an end to violence in Tunisia had been made under duress.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 16 -- Cotton textile manufacturers face a loss of 25 per cent in shipments abroad this year, according to John Quirk, vice president of the National Foreign Trade Council, speaking at the second day sessions of the annual meeting of the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute.

Bernard M. Baruch, a Manhattanite for seventy-one years, is still an "unreconstructed Confederate." The affable elder statesman, who came here from Camden, S. C., in 1881, when he was 11 years old, accepted with "a deep sense of pride" the first annual award of the American Veterans Committee, presented yesterday by the Simon Baruch Chapter No. 42, of 283 Rivington Street, for his contributions to Americanism.

This is the day on which we have the welcome opportunity to pay our special tribute to the men and women of the Army, the Navy, the Air Force and the Marine Corps. We are happy to entertain those from the Services who are in New York. We are proud of them and proud to have them with us.

Two dock workers, held as material witnesses in the case of John Scanlon, who has been indicted with another longshoreman in the beating of two men with a baseball bat and club, were enmeshed in further legal difficulties after visits to the grand jury yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- Delegates to the Americans for Democratic Action convention split wide open tonight in their opening sessions on the question of endorsing a Presidential candidate.

As the chef who did the most in 1951 to interest "young American men" in the culinary profession, Paul F. Muellet of Seattle has just received the annual Debands Award of DeBragga Spitler, Inc. Although the rules of the contest mention only men, Mr. Muellet firmly believes that women have an equally important place in the restaurant or hotel kitchen.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The State Department said today that it had held several conversations with the French Government recently to emphasize "the need for reforms in Tunisia."

When John Foster Dulles left the Government after ratification of his principal accomplishments -- the Japanese peace treaty and the Pacific security pacts -- he announced that he would devote himself to an exposition of a bipartisan foreign policy in which he expects the Republican party to assume leadership and which he considers necessary to save this nation from mortal danger.
Louis F. Budenz completed his testimony yesterday in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders. He had been on the witness stand fourteen days.
LOS ANGELES, May 16 (UP) -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins disclosed today that the ground forces soon may be employing guided missiles against large enemy troop concentrations on a wide front.

Declaring that "We are suffering today from moral awkwardness," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman of Christ Church (Methodist), Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, in an address last night called for "stressing great causes." He spoke at a session of the New York Conference of the Methodist Church at St. Mark's Church, 49 Edgecombe Avenue.
NEW ROCHELLE. N. Y., May 16 -- Sam Snead continued as the pace-setter in the Palm Beach round-robin golf tourney today at the Wykagyl Country Club with two more sub-par rounds.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The House of Representatives passed a bill today to give the Marine Corps a greater hand in the countray's defense, including membership on the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The vote was 253 to 30.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -Investigating Senators learned today that about a dozen Federal employes helped Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, to prepare the article on housing that he sold to the Lustron Corporation for $10,000 in 1948.

LONDON, May 16 -- The House of Commons paid its annual lip service today to women's claim for equal pay for doing the same job as men in government service. It passed without a division a non-committal resolution calling upon the Government to announce an early and definite date for its enactment.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A price increase of $10 a ton for newsprint won the approval of the Canadian Government today despite a protest from United States Price Stabilizer Ellis Arnall here that the increase was "shocking and alarming."

Oscar Albin Olson, 68 years old, a compositor who had been employed by THE NEW YORK TIMES forty-eight years, was injured fatally at 1 A. M. yesterday, when struck by a city-owned bus at Thirty-seventh Street and Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn.
PARIS, May 16 (AP) -- Germans head the list of foreign exhibitors at the forty-eighth annual Paris trade fair, which opens tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, filed a brief in the Senate today asserting that Congressional committees had legal power to force newspaper reporters to disclose confidential news sources.

Don't look now, but an excellent light revue has come to town. "New Faces of 1952," which opened at the Royale last evening, includes some new talent as well as new faces, and it has been expertly staged by John Murray Anderson.

Amendment to the Standard Gas and Electric Company's proposal made on Feb. 8 to allocate securities in exchange for Standard's prior preference stocks has been agreed to conditionally by representatives of Standard Power and Light Corporation and committees representing holders of common stock and certain classes of preferred, with the approval of the Public Utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

THE signs all point to a big fishing week-end, with the first Fishermen's Special leaving the city for Peconic Bay and Montauk, a Coney Island fishing derby scheduled for Steeplechase Pier, and the rowboat and party boat fleets certain of finding fish in the bay and off-shore -- if the weather holds fair.

The Chemical Construction Corporation, a subsidiary of American Cyanamid Company, has granted to Chemetals Corporation an exclusive license in the United States, Canada, Mexico and the United Kingdom, and preferential rights elsewhere, in connection with a process for producing copper scrap, brass scrap and blister copper.

A net income of $7,173,000, equal to $1.66 a common share, was reported yesterday for the first quarter this year by Pure Oil Company and its subsidiaries, almost equaling the $7,213,000, or $1.67 a common share, earned in the initial three months last year.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. must grant licenses to make and sell nylon under existing patents, but not on a royalty-free basis as suggested by the United States Government, Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan held yesterday.

THERE are almost as many Indias as there are writers about India. There is the India of Vincent Sheean and the India of Louis Bromfield, the India of Rumer Godden and the India of Katherine Mayo, the India of G. A. Henty and the India of Louis Fischer, the India of Jawaharlal Nehru and the India of Winston Churchill.
OTTAWA, Ont., May 16 -- The Canadian Government has informed the Newsprint Association of Canada that there must be no increase within the Dominion.

GENEVA, May 16 -- Hugh S. Gibson, United States diplomat, has been nominated as director of the Provisional International Committee for Migration from Europe, subject to confirmation by the committee meeting in Washington next month.

PARIS, May 16 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Chief of Staff of Supreme Allied Headquarters, rejected completely today the theory of the basic indefensibility of Western Europe advanced in the repudiated so-called Fechteler report but he conceded that the West now lacked the forces to withstand a Soviet attack.

GENEVA, May 17 -- European governments and business circles are watching with much concern the struggle between the British trade unions and the Conservative Government over the wage levels in Britain. It has been widely accepted that one of Britain's greatest assets in the post-war struggle for solvency has been the remarkable restraint shown by the British trade unions in pressing for higher money wages.

BUFFALO, May 16 -- The Italian Government cannot extradite Carl G. LoDolce and try him for the "cloak-and-dagger" murder of Maj. William V. Holohan because Italy and the United States were still at war when the alleged crime was committed. Mr. LoDolce's attorney declared today in Federal District Court.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- This week's issue of The Official gazette, in which new patents are announced, brings bad news for crows. They may expect their meals to be constantly interrupted by a modern scarecrow equipped with an electric horn, and they run the risk of death from the slugs of a new repeating magazine slingshot.

Billy Graham had to rally to gain a draw with Rocky Castellani of Luzerne, Pa., in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The East Side welterweight earned the deadlock by outscoring his foe in a bristling last round that thrilled the crowd of 5,394 fans.

A play-by-play report of the Gaelic football world's championship game being played tomorrow in Dublin, Ireland, will be broadcast by recording over WMGM beginning at approximately 5 o'clock tomorrow afternoon. The competing teams are New York Selected and Cork.

A sixty - family garden - type apartment house at 2336 Wallace Avenue and 2315 Barnes Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Leo Bercow and Walter Berger, operators, to Peter Doelger, Inc. The apartments were built in 1950 by Farber-Wittman, Inc., and sold in November, 1951, to the sellers.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -- State troopers were assigned to maintain order at the $200,000,000 Levittown housing project today after some 400 stone-throwing pickets besieged the development in defiance of a Bucks County court order.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -Elmer E. Walker labor member of the Wage Stabilization Board, testified today that a "vile and slanderous campaign" against the board actually was an attempt to destroy trade unionism.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 16 -- The question of official status and a charter for the Zionist Organization remained unresolved as the Zionist General Council, which is the supreme instrument of movement between Zionist congresses, wound up a week-long conference in Jerusalem at midnight yesterday and adjourned until November.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 16 -A blue standard in his first American show, Frenches Blue Marvel, owned by Louise Branch of Pawling, N. Y., took best of breed today in the specialty of the Poodle Club of America on the grounds of the Garden City Hotel.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday 5 to 21 points net higheh than on Thursday, with old July leading the advance.

Ending a week of ceremonies, Armed Forces Day will be celebrated today with "open house" at military establishments in this area and a parade of 20,000 persons down Fifth Avenue from Ninety-fifth to Sixty-seventh Streets.

PARIS, May 16 -- The United States has strongly urged France to speed implementation of the program of home-rule reforms for her North African protectorate of Tunisia or face the prospect of a loss of United States support if nationalist claims for a United Nations hearing are to be raised again.

BOSTON, Saturday, May 17 (AP) -- The Navy said early today that its radio station at Winter Harbor, Me., had reported that "what was thought to be a submarine had been sited 500 yards off the coast" but that weather had defeated efforts to check.

Black marketeers who are taking advantage of the potato shortage in New York are being tracked down by the Office of Price Stabilization. More than thirty large dealers are now under investigation and early indictments are expected.

Dr. Cornelius P. Rhoads, director of Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Disease, reported yesterday on recent observations, described by him as "particularly exciting," in which a definite pre-cancerous condition had "spontaneously reversed itself" to normal. He addressed the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York at the Statler Hotel.

The four-story dwelling containing ten rooms on lot 18.9 by 100 feet at 218 East Thirtieth Street has been sold by Olive Clandorf and Alvin Perlmutter to Fred H. Hill, operator, for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $11,500. The house is vacant and will be altered into a store and six apartments.

Duke Snider's timely hitting and Clem Labine's excellent relief pitching brought the Dodgers a 6-4 victory over the Pirates yesterday at Ebbets Field. And, in the wake of developments at the Polo Grounds, the Brooks gained a dead heat for first place with the Giants.

ALBANY, May 16 -- An April increase of 11.4 per cent in the number of unemployment insurance claimants in New York City was reported today by Edward Corsi. State Industrial Commissioner. He said, however, that, despite the increase, mid-April figures for the city and the state were at their lowest post-war levels except for 1951.

The embattled Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., moved swiftly yesterday to hem in dissidents in its ranks who seek to follow George Baldanzi, a former vice president of the union, into the American Federation of Labor's United Textile Workers Union.

A special school for young narcotics users will be opened next September on North Brother Island, it was announced yesterday at a reception marking the fifth anniversary of the city's "600" schools for socially maladjusted pupils.

With 500 parents and pupils watching, the Board of Education dedicated yesterday the new Public School 249, Caton Avenue and Rugby Road in Brooklyn. Opened last September, the school was built at a cost of $1,500,000 and can accommodate 1,150 elementary pupils.
YONKERS, May 16 -- Pronto Don, the Hayes Fair Acres trotter, gained his seventeenth consecutive victory tonight before 25,866 Yonkers Raceway fans by winning the $10,000 Mount Vernon Trot.

The fifty-ninth running of the $30,000 added Metropolitan Handicap will top today's program at Belmont Park, with twelve thoroughbreds scheduled to parade postward for the mile test. The likely favorite is George D. Widener's Battlefield, who will be making his second start this year.
HOUSTON, Tex., May 16 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley declared tonight that the nation must arm itself militarily and industrially for peace.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Newark Airport is a safe airport, Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle said today, and added inferentially that it should be reopened. The opinion was concurred in by Charles F. Horne, Civil Aeronautics Administrator.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- Congress today put up to President Truman the issue of state versus Federal control of oil-rich lands beneath the marginal seas.

Our feathered fellow-citizens, the pigeons, are a peculiarly urban lot. You almost never see them out in the country. You see them almost anywhere in London, Venice or New York. But in each city they have their chosen places of resort: in London, the vicinity of that funny little statue of Queen Anne near St. Paul's; in Venice, the Piazza San Marco, and, in New York, Bryant Park.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 16 -- The United Nations received today the final account of the global welfare program undertaken by the International Refugee Organization to find homes for thousands of war-displaced persons.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 16 -- Petit mal, or minor epilepsy, and epilepsy were interpreted today as seen in the treatment of seven persons as the way in which they fought against "an explosive reaction'' inside themselves which endangered their lives or the lives of those living with them.

CLEVELAND, May 16 (UP) -Two former Yankees, Frank Shea and Jackie Jensen, continued to make Manager Bucky Harris of the Senators look like a trading genius tonight as they teamed up to beat the league-leading Indians, 2 -- 0.

Traditionally, the blind weave baskets or become beggars, but a handsome sightless man from Turkey, here as a guest of the United States, is convinced that anyone can do almost anything in spite of anything.

EARLY this month, Dr. William S. Carlson, new president of the State University of New York, called for development of an educational philosophy that would "give everyone an opportunity to seek out the contribution that he and he alone can make," one that would "encourage the thinker, the creative artist, the research scientist and the leader in political affairs."

To most psychologists the interpretation of handwriting is little better than fortune-telling. At last week's conference of graphologists, which was held in New York City (it was the second of its kind), psychologists to whom handwriting is a revelation of personality traits made it plain that graphology is to be taken as seriously as IQ and inkblot tests.

English eighteenth-century furniture and English decorations from the Fifth Avenue residence of Mrs. Harrison Williams will be auctioned at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, on Thursday and Friday afternoons.

GREELEY, Colo., May 17 (UP) -- Rocky Mountain Conference officials voted unanimously today to abolish spring football practice and to end the football season on the Saturday following Thanksgiving Day, which in effect placed a ban on bowl games.

Women of society and debui tantes of this and recent seasons 'are active in plans for the block party for the benefit of the House of the Hefty Comforter Friday night in East Seventy-first Street between Park and Madison Ave'Hues.

IN the vicinity of New York City the lilacs have passed their prime. But a little farther north two of the outstanding collections of this favorite shrub will be at their best this week-end and throughout the week. It's "Lilac Sunday" at the Arnold Arboretum outside Boston, Mass., while "Lilac Time" in Highland Park, Rochester, begins this morning and continues until Saturday night.
The excellent letter of Albert V. Baez on flood research published in THE TIMES of May 11 prompts me to develop the subject on more definite lines.
MILWAUKEE, May 17 (UP) -- Russ Kemppel of Akron, Ohio, rolling in his first American Bowling Congress tournament, took over tenth place in all-events tonight with a 1,924 score.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., May 17 -Thomas Jefferson High School of Elizabeth, N. J., retained its laurels and Milton Campbell, national interscholastic champion from Plainfield High was the top scorer with 14 points at the sixth annual Englewood Memorial track and field meet today at the Winton White Stadium.

IT is often said there is a resistance to chamber music in the United States. Recent reports, though, indicate either that the notion is erroneous or that the situation is rapidly changing. The city of Akron, Ohio, is a case in point. It found there was no resistance to chamber music when admission fees were lifted.

Entries for the Morris and Essex Kennel Club show, largest in America, closed with 2,862 dogs, the highest total since the event's post-war revival in 1946. The show will be next Saturday on the Giralda Farms estate of Mr. and Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge in Madison, N. J.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Cut new lawns as soon as they are more than two inches high. Old lawns need to be mowed once a week, maintaining them at one and one-half to two inches high. Use hand clippers or an edging machine to trim grass along paths, flower borders and around specimen plants to complete grooming of the lawn each time it has been mowed.

ALL the drama soothsayers of the town agree that "The Male Animal" is an immensely funny comedy. Some of us are also under the impression that it is funnier now than in 1940 when James Thurber and Elliott Nugent first exposed it to the risibilities of the public.

PARIS, May 17 -- Several suggestions for intensifying European cooperation and, notably, the association of Britain in Europe's defense, were included in resolutions adopted today by the Council of Europe's General Affairs Committee, meeting to prepare the session of the Consultative Assembly which will open at Strasbourg in another week.

TO New Yorkers the Arkansas Ozarks are undiscovered territory, a region known primarily through comicstrip jokes, Bob Burns and Lum and Abner. But I am here to suggest that a summer visit to the Ozarks, with headquarters at Eureka Springs and side trips into the fascinating countryside, would make a really new and different vacation for Easterners.

A THREE - MONTH vacation on Uncle Jim's ranch in Colorado seemed to Barbara Dufrayne and her brother Scott the ideal way to spend a summer. Barbara, however, found that earning her share of the trip's expenses was harder than she had expected.

The importance of maintaining a high volume of foreign trade as the outlet for expanded production and a bulwark against recession after defense spending ends will be emphasized in the annual observations of World Trade Week beginning here tomorrow.

Yacht clubs may open. They can have their going-into-commission days and their cocktail parties. They can raise their colors and burgees for the season. They can start their launch service, realign their moorings. Members can even start wearing white uniforms.

Financial and Business Editor Stock prices made little headway last week as financial markets continued under the domination of the steel and oil disputes. The abandonment of some controls and relaxation of others reflected the Washington official attitude that business evidently needed a stimulant.

EPHRATA, Wash., May 17 -- A great sagebrush desert of central Washington, destined to blossom into "a modern Garden of Eden," is about to receive its first irrigation water from Lake Roosevelt, behind Grand Coulee Dam on the main stem of the Columbia River.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., May 17 (UP) -- A thousand firefighters smothered the last of a $1,000,000 oil fire with chemicals today after battling the flames for seventeen hours to save the city from a fate akin to that of Texas City in 1947.

BIRMINGHAM, May 17 (AP) -Alf Holmberg, the Stockholm Limited now based at the University of Tennessee, ran through a drizzling rain today to set Southeastern Conference records in the mile and two-mile races.
PRESIDENT TRUMAN, when asked recently to summarize his behavior in the Presidency, replied by citing what he described as the epitaph of one Jack Williams of Tombstone, Ariz.: "He done his damndest."

Problems that hinder youths in adjusting to their surroundings start at an early age, according to a survey made by Dr. H. H. Remmers, Professor of Education at Purdue University, and Dr. R. H. Bauernfeind of Carleton College, Northfield, Minn. The survey recommends that personal-guidance programs should therefore start in the lower elementary school grades.

Aggressive leadership, backed by adequate armed forces and supported by a united and informed public, is need now, Gen. Lemuel C. public, is needed now, Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd, Marine Corps commandant, said last night. He addressed members of the Military Order of World Wars at an Armed Forces Day dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

INQUIRIES the Prince Edward Island Travel Bureau started earlier than usual this spring and in April showed an increase of 1,000 over April of last year. The bureau has enlarged its branch office at Aulac, N. B., where, among new features there will be a revolving art exhibition of island paintings by island artists.

A lounge and a group of conference rooms on the second floor of the new building of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, rising on First Avenue facing United Nations headquarters, will provide a meeting place for organizations interested with the Carnegie agency and the United Nations in work for world peace.

OF all the great French novelists of the last century, none stands in need of a reappraisal in English-speaking countries more than Zola. His name was once anathema. His devoted, though none too skilled translator, Vizetelly, went into debt and into prison for having published him in England: yet he had presented Zola as a French Puritan and "L'Assommoir" as the greatest temperance tract ever written.
CHICAGO, May 17 -- Today's livestock prices reported by the Department of Agriculture follow:

CHICAGO, May 17 (AP) -- Grains advanced toward the close of trading on the Board of Trade today after holding most of the session around previous closing levels. Trading picked up on the late advance.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 17 -- Programs of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund will reach youngsters in seventy-two countries and territories, according to a new tabulation released today.
Memorial Day will open the summer excursion-boat season. A fleet of eight excursion boats and six sightseeing craft will provide one-day short range cruises for countless New Yorkers.

ALTHOUGH only a fraction of its uses have been developed, it is predicted that bamboo will become one of the nation's most valuable crops when grown in sufficient quantity. Already rated high in importance, it is expected to fulfill yet undiscovered uses.

AT this point Roberto Rossellini may be termed industrious since the noted director has two pictures awaiting release ("St. Francis" and "Europe 1951") and currently he is putting the finishing touches on "Where Is Freedom?", his first attempt at directing comedy with Toto, Italy's top funny man, in the leading role.

WAY back in the Furious Forties, several million Europe-bound voyagers were given free literature by their benevolent travel agency, the armed forces, when they were halfway out in the Atlantic Ocean.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 17 -- Throughout the world the graph of industrial production, which shot steeply upward in 1950, continued to ascend during 1951, although at a more moderate angle during the second half of the year, United Nations experts show in a survey on recent changes in production, released today.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., May 17 -- With Charles (Chuck) Heppenstall stopping a ninth-inning rally, Lawrenceville turned back The Hill School, 8 -- 6, today in the fifty-third baseball meeting between the two traditional rivals.

The two and a half million people in West Berlin man the Eastern outpost of the Western world. On all sides they are surrounded by the hostile forces of Communism. Only the most tenuous ties -- a single road, an air corridor -- connect them with the outside.

OTTAWA, May 17 -- The dispute developing over the price of Canadian newsprint to United States customers -- the price was increased $10 a ton yesterday -- is regarded here as likely to be only one example of the irritations and inconveniences that will quickly develop in the relations between the two countries unless a stable exchange situation can be reached.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 17 -- The United States ranks well toward the bottom of the list of countries that have taken steps to ease the high cost of raising families.

PANSIES are cheerful plants -- so cheerful that most people are disappointed when their flowers grow smaller or plants turn yellow in the hot days of early summer. In May the large, velvety blossoms are like faces, full of expression.

THE flowers and upper leaves of the herb sweet woodruff, steeped in chilled champagne or Rhine wine, make the fragrant May wine that is traditional this month. The flowers are also delightful additions to small bouquets and have several other uses, as well.

FIFTY years ago Tuesday the Cuban national flag was raised in Havana amid scenes of wild enthusiasm. It was the formal birth of the Cuban Republic. Tomas Estrada Palma, one of the heroes of the wars of independence, became the first President.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 17 -- The Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis foresees an upswing in Minnesota resort business this year if actual occupancy follows the pattern established by early reservations. Unlike last year, facilities at American plan resorts are being spoken for early.

THOSE magnificent tall bearded iris with their iridescent, orchidlike blossoms, which are now in full bloom in so many gardens, are one of the best investments a gardener can make. They are not difficult to grow and they respond generously to any little extra care that is given them.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- When a housewife orders five pounds of new potatoes and is told by the grocer that there are no new potatoes, or old ones either, in his bins, "annoyed" is a mild word to describe her reaction.
BERLIN, May 17 -- The concern over the possibility of a new Berlin blockade seems on the surface to be less in this city than in Washington.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 17 (AP) -- LaSalle College today won the fortieth annual Middle Atlantic Track and Field Association championships, scoring 62 points and crowning five individual champions. Lafayette College, the defender, was second with 42 1/2.

FOR this volume of folk-history Harold Preece gathered the stories of fifteen old-timers who lived through the early days in Texas and neighboring areas. All fifteen of his tale-tellers were alive at the time he got their stories, but he says quite frankly that he did the "actual writing of these tales" apparently from notes rather than from recordings.
The St. John's University track team defeated Fordham, 71 -- 69, in a dual meet at Red Hook Stadium, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Greater activity than expected took place in the wholesale market here last week as many buyers placed orders, resident buying offices reported. Stocks were low in stores, resulting in many requests for replacements. Promotional merchandise was well received and buyers began placing fall orders in many departments.

Under clear and sunny skies 2,400 Norwegian-Americans marched yesterday through Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, the fourth largest Norwegian population center in the world. They marked the 138th anniversary of the adoption of the Norwegian Constitution.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 17 -The city board of finance this afternoon fixed a tax rate for 1952-53 that is $4 a thousand lower than that of last year, but tax bills may well be higher because assessed valuations rose an average of 26 per cent in the same period.
The legal controversy over steel seizure is now in the hands of the Supreme Court and the labor-management dispute is suspended in mid-air. This is the situation.

Magistrate Anna Moskowitz Kross recommended yesterday formation of a joint committee of the women's bar associations of the city to make a more intensive study of family problems in the courts of different jurisdictions, to develop new procedures aimed at solution of the problems.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 17 -- The structure of the current United States program of aid to Israel has been radically revised by agreements reached in Washington between the Israeli Minister of Industry, Dov Joseph, and the Mutual Security Agency and the Technical Cooperation Administration.

Because of the paucity of dollars abroad, most Governments are reluctant to release the funds needed for advertising and marketing programs necessary for foreign goods to compete successfully in the markets of this country. Nevertheless, many foreign concerns are entering trade channels here with a "fighting chance" for success due chiefly to the ingenuity of American representatives, distributors, public relations concerns and advertising generally.

The responsibilities of religious leaders in an age of crisis were emphasized yesterday morning at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, by the Rev. Dr. Julian Morgenstern, president-emeritus of Hebrew Union College, Cincinnati.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad -Known as the Land of the Humming Bird before Columbus discovered and renamed it on his third voyage, Trinidad is perhaps best known today as the land of calypso, and that strangest of musical media, the steel band.

DETROIT, May 17 (UP) -- Two girls and a boy speeding home to keep their promises of "being in early" were killed shortly before midnight in an automobile collision that also killed a young couple in another car. Three others were injured critically.
It took the Giants the better part of three hours at the Polo Grounds yesterday to convince Phil Cavarretta's cantankerous Cubs that they already had accomplished sufficient mischief for one visit.
Twenty-seven business executives from newspapers in seventeen states will meet at Columbia University tomorrow for a one-week management and costs seminar to be given by the American Press Institute.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 17 -- With a clear sky and a fine fourteen-knot breeze from south-south-west, twenty-eight of the summer sailing craft appeared today for the pre-championship racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

TWO of the newly opened one-man shows of work by famous artists may well be added to the number of recent exhibitions which have seemed to afford compass points amid the confusions of the modern art world. One of these is the retrospective exhibition of sculpture by Henri Lauresn, at the Curt Valentin Gallery; the other is the exhibition of paintings by Kandinsky at the Knoedler Galleries.
POKER bridge is an opprobrious term to most bridge players. Some think that bluffing and trickery are unethical in bridge, others only that it spoils the game.

The Young Women's Christian Association, disturbed by "growing restrictions" on freedom of expression in America, has joined the National Council of Jewish Women in a nation-wide campaign to "revive the climate of opinion for the free exchange of ideas."

The New York Conference of the Methodist Church, meeting at St. Mark's Church, 49 Edgecombe Avenue, adopted yesterday recommendations of its commission on social education and action, which included a condemnation of loyalty oaths.

EVEN a banker, if he tangles with films, has to submit sooner or later to the glamour treatment. James Lawrie has not had -- and certainly has not sought -- much publicity since he became managing director of the National Film Finance Corporation; there were little kudos in being the man who doled out state-aid to keep British film production this side of the grave.
Kermit Tracy, Columbia's pitching ace for the last three years, hurled a two-hitter against Army yesterday as the Lions won, 4 -- 0, at Baker Field.

SHOULD tomatoes be grown on stakes? I have heard this question argued pro and con by home gardeners for the past thirty-five years. Actually, the lore and legend surrounding the raising of tomatoes would fill more than one large instructive and, perhaps, amusing volume.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The difference between what is news and what is truth was never better illustrated than by the headlines and happenings of this week in the fields of United States foreign policy and politics.

IN Dijon, France, a Swiss resident of undetermined nationality was arrested recently by agents of the French customs for non-observance of frontier formalities and violation of French exchange control laws. His arrest followed an examination of the hub caps of the large American car in which he crossed the Swiss frontier at La Cure at an early hour in the morning.

POPULAR in the best sense of the word, this book does not pretend to do what a book cannot do -- namely, cure people by way of the printed page. But it does present an interesting, sound, abundantly illustrated survey of psychiatry for lay readers in their own language.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 17 -- J. G. N. Strauss, the Opposition leader, announced last night that when the bill setting up a High Court of Parliament had passed through both Houses, he would "take it back to the courts."

As the date nears for the promised Government decision on the Defense Production Administration's proposal for augmenting the nation's aluminum supply there is a feeling in industrial circles that only part of the program will be adopted. The decision is expected this week.

BONN, Germany, May 16 -- The Social Democratic party, second largest in the Federal Republic, formally rejected today the contractual agreement that would establish West Germany's new status in Europe and demanded new negotiations between the Western powers and West Germany based on "genuine equality."

During this past week we have celebrated Armed Forces Day. We have observed the tenth anniversary of the WAC. We have discussed the level of our military appropriation and both our President and the Secretary of State have just urged eloquently that it should not be reduced at this time. We have moved toward the signing of further compacts in Europe. We have lost a jet ace in Korea. We have seen friends

IF radio and television broadcasters are not completely without common sense and self-respect, they will take the offensive against the absurd attempt of the House of Representatives to decide what should be the moral standards of broadcasting.

A strong all-star eleven picked from the four Metropolitan American League professional clubs will provide the opposition for the touring Manchester United soccer team of England this afternoon at Randalls Island. The game will start at 3:30 o'clock, after a preliminary between Mount Kisco and Sada in the Metropolitan Challenge Cup semi-final.

IT has often been a source of amazement to the writer to see the amount of technical genius expended to produce excellent recordings with the use of high fidelity audio equipment and then to see this effort completely thwarted by improper playback methods.

In your May 4 layout of Soviet news photographs entitled "What's Wrong With These Pictures" your caption on "Women's Rights" stated: "The [Soviet] caption calls this group of architects who helped plan Moscow's metro 'renowned women of the Soviet land.'

Dr. Mordecai Johnson, president of Howard University, declared yesterday that the "skillful use of scholarship money is one of the most effective ways of building up any group of people" and spreading democracy. He spoke at a luncheon of a group known as the Hands Across the Sea Annual Scholarship Awards, Inc., which provides scholarships for students of the Virgin Islands.

DURING the past fifteen or twenty years an incalculable number of people have written genial little memoirs about their relatives, but unlike most of the devotees of this form of belles lettres Ruth McKenney is very good at it. She has incorporated her sister into the American Legend (pretty girl division), and it is fine to have a new book containing the best Eileen stories.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 17 -The Bach Choir brought the first week-end of its forty-fifth Bach Festival to a close this afternoon with its major effort, the B Minor Mass. It proved a worthy climax, for the 181 singers gave the work a fine vibrant performance.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (UP) -- The National Boxing Association announced today an international tournament to produce an interim featherweight champion while Sandy Saddler is in the service.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 17 -- Sam Snead retained the lead at the end of the fourth round in the Palm Beach round-robin golf tournament at the Wykagyl Country Club today despite a record-breaking effort on the part of Cary Middlecoff.

BEFORE the end of this year Broadway may be hearing from an organization called The Theatre Circle. This is not, as its name might lead you to suspect, another of those groups dedicated to productions in-the-round.

CAIRO, May 17 -- Some sort of Oriental magic has transformed the Anglo-Egyptian problem. The original issue, from the standpoint of the Western powers, was to induce Egypt to enter an arrangement for the defense of the Middle East and to maintain the British-occupied Suez Canal base as the jointly held keystone of that defense system.

BOSTON, May 17 -- A complete revision of savings bank thinking in the light of present conditions, particularly taxation and higher interest rates, was called for today by Robert M. Catharine, new president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 17 (UP) -- Jouett Shoue's Cinda showed more courage than speed today as she led all the way under Charlie Burr to win the first running of the $26,250 Betsy Ross Stakes by a neck at Garden State Park.

BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, May 17 -- The two-day conference on migratory workers at Bowling Green State University closed today. Many of the sixty delegates from interested organizations in the state approved suggestions for a Governor's commission and county committees to watch the welfare of 9,000 migrants who harvest Ohio's fruits and vegetables each summer and fall.

NEW DELHI, India, May 17 -In a conciliatory note to the Government of Ceylon today India suggested that the two countries "agree to differ" on the question of Indians' status on the island and try to reach a solution on a basis that would not intensify the controversy.

To help meet the heavy demands for blood and plasma, several thousand civil defense workers and city employes will make mass donations to the joint Red Cross-Armed Forces blood program at the State Building, 80 Centre Street, beginning tomorrow The contributions will continu through Friday.
GUATEMALA, May 17 -- Both sides in Guatemala's burgeoning struggle over the Government's proposed agrarian reform bill have begun to talk of civil war.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Connie Rings' entry of Conversion and Joystick ran one-two in the $25,000 Golden State Breeders' Handicap today, but the fireworks at Hollywood Park came when a 52-to-1 shot named Tonga upset such aristocrats of the filly ranks as Princess Lygia and A Gleam in the $20,000 Sea Breeze Stakes.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 17 -- A four-run rally in the ninth inning gained a 5-to-4 victory for Colgate over Princeton today at University Field. Dave Sisler suffered the loss after relieving Ray Chirurgi in the final inning.

LONDON, May 17 -- Britain's major post-war effort to import large numbers of Italian coal miners to overcome the critical manpower shortage in the nationalized industry has ended in failure because of the opposition of British miners to foreign labor.

MOTORISTS headed from the West Coast to northern Canada and Alaska this summer will be able to save 400 miles of tough driving on their way to the beginning of the Alaska Highway at Dawson Creek, B. C.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 17 (UP) -- Ten of the nation's top economic land financial experts predicted today that the country faced an "indefinite period of long-term inflationary threats."

SIERRA MADRE, Calif. -- One of the nation's most unusual tourist attractions is a single plant that attracts sightseers by the tens of thousands to this town every year. It is a sixty-year-old wisteria vine which makes unchallenged claim to being the world's largest.

IT would be hard to find two people less suited to spend their lives together than Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle. Their brand of love was a tortured and fretful affection which made it impossible for them to be happy together or apart.
CLEVELAND, May 17 -- The Indians gave Pitcher Bob Lemon more runs today than in all six of his previous starts this season by blasting three Washington pitchers for sixteen hits and a 9-2 victory.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 17 -The James Forrestal Research Center, combining secret defense projects with long-range studies for the peace benefits of mankind, was dedicated in moderate sunshine here today on 850 acres of flat and flowering land.

LONDON, May 17 -- resolution calling on the Government to announce an early and definite date to put into effect the principle of equal pay for equal work for women in the public services was carried without a division in the House of Commons this week.

Assessments for extensive sewer improvements, tough quite common in the wide-open spaces of Queens and Staten Island, have become nearly unknown in the city's more populous, built-up areas. But property owners in the high-income section of Manhattan along Central Park West from Seventy-second Street to Eighty-fifth Street have just learned that "It can happen here."
With reference to Peter Kihss' "Man Against the Locust" (April 6) and the ensuing discussion in your letter columns of the edibility of those insects:

The Jackson Memorial Laboratory of Bar Harbor, Me., is a charitable, non-profit research institution which supplies inbred mice of pure strain to cancer researchers everywhere. At present it has 150,000 mice, 1,500 rabbits and many guinea pigs, hamsters and other animals.

THE summer vacationist will have his first opportunity this year to see a new attraction in an old and lovely setting -- Ten Commandments Mountain (formerly Burger Mountain), which was dedicated last September. It is located at Fields of the Wood, N. C., eighteen miles west of Murphy, in the southwestern corner of the state near Lake Hiwassee, and on the very edge of a superb vacationland, Nantahala National Forest.

LOS ANGELES -- Motorists visiting California's southern capital this summer will find their parking headaches ameliorated by what is said to be the world's largest underground garage, newly completed in the heart of the city.

A LARGE percentage of the 60,000,000 drivers in this country could benefit from instruction in car operation, according to findings by the Center for Safety Education of New York University. A program to develop driving education for adults has been formulated by the Center under the direction of Dr. Herbert J. Stack, director.

TEN years ago Serge Koussevitzky created the Koussevitzky Music Foundation, which had as its broad purpose the encouragement of the growth of musical culture. On June 1, 1942, the first meeting of the foundation's board took place, and the first of a series of compositions was commissioned.

Without any thought of discrediting the performance of Berlioz's Requiem given a few weeks ago in Carnegie Hall by the National Orchestral Association, it seems important to correct a misstatement made by a member of your staff.

THE end of the Revolutionary War finds Munro Dunbar, late of Marion's Brigade, ripe for change. Back home in South Carolina, he discovers that he has been tricked out of his farm and that his childhood sweetheart doesn't really love him after all.

BUSINESS is getting better. There are signs in plenty that momentum is picking up, along with the thermometer. The biggest single reason ascribed for this good news is the fact that controls are coming off. Regulation W, curbing consumer credit, is on the scrap heap, and Regulation X, limiting credit for residential construction, is next on the list.

TROY, N. Y., May 17 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, said tonight that "endless friction and trouble" were in store for the Western nations until they adapted themselves to the growing spirit of nationalism in oil-producing countries of the Middle East.
A new style of construction has been furthered by an architect whose original ambition was to be a professional football player.

The recent action of the Department of State in making all American passports invalid for visits behind the Iron Curtain is but one aspect of a problem which has been growing in seriousness over recent months.

FROM such major figures as Varina Davis and General Grant, Shirley Seifert moves in her latest fictionized biography to a comparatively unknown lady who was prominent in her day -- the brilliant and beautiful Elizabeth Moss.

APPEALING as an old building often is, it's quite a feat to make one the central figure of a story. Virginia Lee Burton did it with signal success in "The Little House" and, if Mrs. Payne's "The Stable That Stayed" hasn't quite the poetic scope of Miss Burton's book, it is, nevertheless, an unusual, imaginative story.

The nation's growing military strength was displayed impressively yesterday in this country and other parts of the world as the Army, Navy and Air Force joined in parades and demon strations celebrating the third annual Armed Forces Day.

THE future of Newark Airport as a commercial air terminal now seems assured. Two announcements last week by the Port of New York Authority leave no doubt as to what the bi-state agency and the commercial airlines plan to do with the big field.

Two New York boys were killed yesterday in freakish accidents. In Rego Park, Queens, a 4-year-old was crushed when a large cardboard carton in which he was playing was run over by the cab of a trailer truck. In the second accident a 7-year-old was killed when an abandoned refrigerator fell on him as he played in a vacant lot in Staten Island.

LONDON, May 17 -- The Conservatives have found that the task of unscrambling even the small part of the nationalized industries they propose to restore to private ownership is a task more difficult financially than it is politically.

AFTER the spring abundance of flowering shrubs comes a rapid decrease as the year advances. The gardener often turns to the well-known rose of sharon (Hibiscus syriacus) to fill the need for mid-summer bloom, or the bush honey-suckles for their early and brilliant fruits.

To meet housing needs of American colleges and universities Congress has authorized a loan program of $300,000,000. Of this amount, $40,000,000 was released a year ago to build dormitories and faculty housing. An additional $20,000,000 has been released for 1953, making the total available $60,000,000.

THE first dozen pages of this book contain all that Winifred Holt left of her autobiography. From that point on her husband, Rufus Graves Mather, and her sister, Edith Holt Bloodgood, have attempted to create a living picture of one of the world's most dynamic women philanthropists by sorting and piecing together excerpts from Winifred's voluminous notes and letters.

If Stalin were smart he'd send you a five-pound can of caviar in appreciation of your publishing that swell photo of the Moscow subway station ("What's Wrong With These Pictures?". May 4). As one who struggles twice a day through that rat's nest of tangled tubes known as the Times Square Station, my man-in-the street reaction is, "Those Communists have got something, after all." * * *

In connection with Oren Root's excellent article, "Four Great Lacks in Mental Health" (May 4) is there not a very important lesson also on the side of prevention of mental ills to be deduced from the facts he recites?

Bryant College (Providence, R. I.) has added a course in "Good Citizenship" to its curriculum. This college, which has for the past eighty-nine years devoted itself exclusively to the education of students for the business world, has added the new course because "the compelling events in our political life demand more active participation in community life by business and business men."

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- President Truman made it amply clear tonight that he would veto the much-contested offshore oil bill, which is now awaiting his action. He said it constituted "robbery in broad daylight -- and on a colossal scale."
Should the lights on Hunter College's Bronx campus start blinking tomorrow, the caretakers would know that Mrs. Pete, a prominent member of the college community, has finally found a new home.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 17 -In a series of slow methodical operations French forces and troops from Vietnam, one of the Associated States of Indo-China, are continuing their efforts to clean Vietminh troops from the Tonkin delta. Activities are concentrated in the southern part of the delta.

The most far-reaching development to hit Publishers' Row in a long time was announced last week with the formation of a new publishing company to be known as Ballantine Books. Ordinarily, publishers can come and go and not many people are the wiser.

COMMEMORATING last Tuesdays inauguration of the House of American Tourists in Tel-Aviv, Israel's postal administration issued a 220-pruta dark blue and gray stamp illustrating the structure. In the background is an outline of Manhattan's skyscrapers.

SENATOR William Benton of Connecticut, one of the first to attend the C. B. S. network's school for Congressmen in Washington, reports that the course in TV showmanship provided an "instructive hour."

BEFORE the Russians, before the coming of Captain Vancouver and the English, before the purchase from the Czar by Secretary of State Seward, Indians roamed wild and free through Alaska, which is an Indian word meaning "the Great Land."

With the approach of the vacation season, the luggage industry is expecting its most active period. While large orders are usually placed in March and April in order to have goods on hand for late May and June selling, during the last few years there has been a tendency to procrastinate, manufacturers said.

NINE - YEAR - OLD Ronnie lived in a one-room mountain cabin in northern California with a woman he called Aunt Sal. He felt that one tart-spoken old woman and a boy, not really related, were not much of a family.

WHEN German Arciniegas came into the room he held himself quite erect; he appeared taller than he was. As he sat down with a certain clerical neatness, he smiled; it was a friendly smile, direct and winning.

Government bonded warehouses now contain more whisky than the public would be willing to buy in some years at current prices and the monthly production of liquor continues to be greater than total national consumption. These two factors add up to only one thing. More liquor prices will drop.
PARAMUS, N. J., May 17 -- A 363-bed county hospital unit, its nine stories rising like a sky-scraper out of these acres of flat farmland, will be dedicated June 7.
In a little known Bronx garment 'factory" men and women, victims of tuberculosis and heart disease, are earning their living in a novel program of industrial convalescence.

The experience gained in driving a car is often a hazard for the man who turns to motorboating, Rear Admiral Louis B. Olson, commander of the Coast Guard's Eastern Area and Third Coast Guard District, declared last week at the annual "Operation Safety" held at the Coast Guard moorings, Pier Nine, East Rivet.

ST. LOUIS, May 17 (AP) -- Three rookies -- Jim Rivera, Bob Nieman and Clint Courtney -- supplied three ninth-inning hits to give the Browns a 2-1 triumph today, spoiling a seemingly winning mound performance by southpaw Mel Parnell of the Red Sox.

MADRAS. VENKATASWAMI REDDI, whom we interviewed in the Indian equivalent of a "bread line" at a dusty village about 100 miles from here, said that he sometimes saw the color of about 100 rupees, or $20, in cash during a year's time. A "good" year, that is.

BERLIN, May 16 -- Western officials breathed a sigh of relief today as all six scheduled Allied highway patrols along the autobahn between Berlin and West Germany were allowed to pass Soviet check points.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 17 --- There is no more prospect of ending the Korean war than there was two years ago, Senator Harry F. Byrd declared here today. One tragic mistake after another has been made in the conduct of "the police action." he said, and the direct cost of it is $8,000,000,000 to $10,000,000,000 a year.

FOR longer than three centuries, from 1490 to 1815, princes of the house formed by Eugene Franz von Thurn and Taxis, or Francois de Tassis (1450-1517), operated a postal service in the Low Countries (the modern Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg) with royal consent.
