WASHINGTON, May 17 (UP) -Senate leaders, on an embarassing spot, said today they would try to limit the "living allowance" tax cut voted quietly by the House for all Members of Congress.

CHICAGO, May 17 (UP) -- Dean Cavy and Happy Carrier, stable-mates from the Louisville stable of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Veeneman, finished one, two in the $11,800 Joliet Stakes today but Jockey Johnny Adams stole the show on the muddy Lincoln Fields track by winning the last five events.

IN the highly seasoned opinion of Dr. Serge Urling of Wenatchee, Wash., a grizzled monolith of 67 with a tarnished brass mustache and a spectacularly cratered nose, the two most beautiful sights in the world are a prospective mother and a carnival train on a curve.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 17 -Any doubt as to the class of the heavyweight crews turned out by Rusty Callow at Navy this season was erased this afternoon when the middies captured all three races in the seventh annual Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges sprint championships.

The long waited turn in the rayon textile market has been reached. Weavers and knitters of fabrics have reduced their yarn inventories to less than normal quantities and must come into the market soon to meet their fall fabric requirements.

Yachtsmen are rushing to complete the tail end of the fitting-out season. These are fast-moving days at every club and boat yard. Skippers of cruisers further inshore on the railways are huffing and puffing because some slowpoke nearer the launching water is dragging his feet and slowing down with his paint or varnish brush.

HAVANA -- The current celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of Cuba's independence has given impetus to the island's incipient summer season during which the republic will be visited by many American tourists.
These are the statistics on New York City policemen directly affected by the scandals that were touched off by the arrest of Harry Gross, Brooklyn gambler, a year ago last September:

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 17 -- Ch. Braeval Biscuit, a splendid cream-colored miniature poodle who has been knocking at the door right along, achieved a best-in-show triumph today. It was the for the importation since he was acquired by the Seafren Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Saunders Meade and was gained in the event of the Ladies Kennel Association of America.

Combined dollar volume of major New York City department stores was estimated last week as 6 per cent below volume for the like week of last year. However, the trend was considered normal in consideration of the greater degree of inflation a year ago.

Members of Congress interested in the merchant marine are discussing the possibility of ordering a second superliner to serve as a running mate for the new United States, which had her first sea trials last week.

The need for more funds and personnel for research on the prevention and cure of muscular dystrophy was stressed by speakers yesterday at a medical conference on the disease. They felt that hopes were justified that some day a treatment and cure might be found.

COLLEGE campuses everywhere are getting the once-over these spring week-ends. But it's not only prospective students with their anxious parents who are wandering through the grounds of Swarthmore College, Swarthmore, Pa.

KHARTUM, the Sudan May 17 (AP) -- The Sudan's Legislative Assembly was adjourned indefinitely today amid signs that it would be replaced by a more representative Parliament and with a greater measure of self-government promised by Britain.

THE Congressional Directory says there are 435 members of the House of Representatives, but Representative Edwin A. Hall believes he has discovered an unlisted 436th -- a fellow called John Barleycorn.

ALBANY, May 17 -- A former bank robber who was the state's key witness in one of New York City's most sensational robbery trials may lose parole credit for the fourteen years he spent in county jails to escape gangland reprisals, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein has ruled.

The Federal Government's wartime deficits were linked with its program of heavy post-war spending as major causes of inflation yesterday by the American Assembly as it prepared to open a five-day discussion of the nation's leading domestic problem.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., May 17 -A 17-year-old Greek orphan, who worked without pay for two years in a Maine lumber camp to defray the cost of his passage to this country, was being held today in the Hudson County Parental Home, Bayonne, while immigration authorities investigated his story.

THERE were some nostalgic reminiscences from old-timers when a concert version of Bizet's Pearl Fishers was given in this city last season. The opera has not been in the repertoire since the Metropolitan season of 1916-17, when Caruso was around to sport the tenor lead.

WHEN, six years ago, a young woman presented herself to Dr. Hinton D. Jonez, a country doctor practicing near Tacoma, Wash., and told the typical tale of woe of the multiple sclerotic, he knew little about the disease. Nor did most other practicing physicians.
The tanker Fort Mercer, which broke in two in one of last winter's severe storms on the North Atlantic, will return to the sea again as a larger and stronger ship.

The New York Public Library's free art lectures will wind up the spring series on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. when Simon Lissim, head of the institution's Art Education Project, will speak on "Art for All" in the Fifth Avenue and Fortysecond Street building.
AUGUSTA, Ga. -- Thousands of motorists have been converging on Clarks Hill Dam, twenty miles north of here, as this new project, largest of its kind southeast of Tennessee, approaches completion.
Following is the text of President Truman's address last night in Washington to the national convention banquet of Americans for Democratic Action, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
A twenty-pound tigress crouched in fright before hundreds of admirers yesterday afternoon as she began a caged life in the Lion House of the Central Park Zoo.
A total of 378 student nurses will be graduated within the next month from the five schools of nursing of the Department of Hospitals.

VIVALDI'S star being in the ascendant, a number of companies has been issuing recordings of his concertos. Many of them have been rather poorly identified, but now Vox has come forward with a magnificent set that not only helps place many of the other concertos, but reveals they have been quarried from a single gold mine -- the set of twelve concertos known as L'Estro Armonico (The Harmonic Whim), Op. 3.

WEST WARWICK, R. I., May 17 -- An ex-convict night club operator was slain by shotgun blasts today, and late tonight the police said his killing had led them close to solution of the long-unsolved $1,219,000 Brink's robbery of 1950.

One thing about the catbird: he insists that this is a good world in which to be alive, but he does so with a sense of proportion. He doesn't just go around singing, "Goody, goody gumdrop, listen to my happy song!" He looks before he sings, and he rasps out a few snarls just to see who is edgy enough to jump, and he laughs raucously, and then he sings.

Americans, directing workmen with picks and shovels, have invaded the territory of Poseidon on the Isthmus of Corinth and, according to last week's dispatch from THE TIMES correspondent, have turned up some interesting relics of the old "earth shaker.

The dancing clatter of wooden shoes on the paved stone plaza of St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church In-the-Bouwerie yesterday drew hundreds of Lower East Side neighbors to see the church's old Dutch traditions celebrated in its annual Tulip Festival.

SO I am to cry, with Alexander Pope: "dear, damned distracting town, farewell"? Over two centuries ago, when Pope wrote that valedictory message to London, the place was already damned. For its size, no doubt its distractions were more potent, if less diverse, than those with which modern London bedevils a writer's concentration.

THERE'S no getting away from it -- muskmelons are difficult to grow. Large, well-netted, sweet and flavorful melons produced year after year are evidence of gardening ability. In fact, a gardener may be judged by the melons he raises.

The United States Secret Service for the last several weeks has quietly been investigating reports that agents of Communist China with unlimited funds have been trying to buy black-market gold here to be smuggled into Hong Kong, it was learned yesterday.

PICTURES of children by Suzy Harris, a young photographer with a remarkably keen understanding of the child's world, are on display through Thursday in Parents' Magazine Photographic Gallery, 52 Vanderbilt Avenue. She has recorded her subjects absorbed in their tasks, in relaxed attitudes, moodily gazing into space, never posed.

CONTINUING his studies, the author of "Hold Your Tongue!" and other books in the field of literary law here offers a rich treatise on plagiarism, mainly in its legal aspects. He probes other matters, too, such as the debt all artists owe to the great corpus of their art, the line between research and theft.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The removal of Lowell B. Mason, Federal Trade Commissioner whose barbed criticisms of what he has termed the "stuffy" Federal agency have been quoted widely throughout the country, was demanded today by the National Federation of Independent Business.

WITH THE UNITED STATES NINTH CORPS, in Korea, May 17 (AP) -- The United States Army is carrrying out front line tests to determine how efficiently combat troops can operate when faced with the threat of an atomic attack.
ABILENE, Kan., May 17 -- This mid-Kansas community is getting all spruced up for the biggest celebration in its history.

PARIS, May 17 -- In half of the departments of Metropolitan France and a large number of the overseas departments, separate electoral colleges will name tomorrow the senators to represent them in the advisory council of the Republic, which, in the Fourth Republic, has replaced the formerly powerful French Senate.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP) -Two of Pennsylvania's top Democrats are hard at work today trying to convince members of the seventy-vote National Convention delegation that they should support the Presidential candidacy of Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee.

A few mice and 150 members of Youth for Eisenhower will hold a block party Wednesday night at the group's courtyard headquarters in the Marguery Hotel, Park Avenue between Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets. If it rains, the festivities will be deferred to Thursday.
LEONIA, N. J., May 17 -- At the age of 77 Dr. Frances Bartlett Tyson has abandoned her only unrealized ambition -- to resign as physician in the public school system.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 17 (AP) -- The Indonesian Cabinet announced today it would accept technical and economic aid under the United States Mutual Security program, but not military assistance.

High school students learn good citizenship more effectively by practical experience, using their schools and communities as civics "laboratories," than by formal study and other strictly academic methods.

The Bey of Tunis is a mild-mannered Arab prince named Sidi Mohammed el Amin Pasha. In theory the Bey is the absolute ruler of the French North African protectorate of Tunisia. In practice the ruler is the French Resident General who controls the French resident army. But the Bey has great prestige among the Arabs.

BUENOS AIRES, May 17 -- Bolivia's new President, Dr. Victor Paz Estenssoro, scored a partial victory over the more radical elements of his Government this week when he announced the composition of a committee to study procedures and conditions under which the nation's large tin producers are to be nationalized.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -With relaxed credit controls, durable goods manufacturers and retailers began a strong effort this week to move heavy inventories of consumer items of this kind. It is too early to report on response, but every sort of promotion is being used.

SOME interesting intimations of the thinking that is being done these days by the people who instigate and fashion the product of Hollywood may be had from a casual comparison of the "Scaramouche" just released and the "Scaramouche" made by Rex Ingrain back in 1923.
DETROIT, May 17 (AP) -- There has been a continued upward swing in new car sales, but how much of the increase is due to removal of credit restrictions still is not clear.

I READ with interest Howard Taubman's review of the Little Orchestra Society's presentation of Bizet's "Pearl Fishers," but I do not think such a work should receive a stage revival when there are so many recent operas that have not yet been heard in New York. To name a few:
ALBANY, May 17 -- The bulk of New York State's income tax revenue comes from 19 per cent of the higher income tax payers, a study by the State Tax Commission disclosed today.

All seeded performers advanced in the opening rounds of the twentieth annual Eastern Interscholastic tennis championships for private schools yesterday. Forty-one matches, singles and doubles, were contested at the Horace Mann and Riverdale School courts.

LOS ANGELES -- The most notable local development in the travel picture in many years is crystallizing with the approaching completion of the $25,000,000 Statler Hotel. Its 1,275 rooms and 2,500 beds will almost double Los Angeles' downtown first-class hotel accommodations.

THE shrub with the fancy name of Harlequin Glorybower is a hardy member of the same family as the greenhouse clerodendron. Its name is suggested by the striking contrast of blue berries and prominent red calyxes at fruiting time in fall.

TOKYO, Sunday, May 18 -- Vice Admiral Charles Turner Joy, senior United Nations delegate negotiating at Panmunjom for an armistice in Korea, called on the Communists yesterday to drop their propaganda campaign against the Allied command and make a sincere move for achievement of a truce.

DURING the summer months four ship lines maintain frequent cruise service along the Inland Passage between Seattle, Wash., and Vancouver, B. C., the southern terminals of the scenic coastal route, and ports in Alaska.

I read with much interest Gertrude Samuels' "Inner View of the Probation Problem" (May 4). It gave a clear picture of the functions of the probation workers in the Court of Special Sessions of the City of New York, and will, I am sure, be helpful in educating the public as to the methods and values of probation in all our courts.

IT is all but impossible to come away from the Carroll-for-President headquarters in Cleveland and not feel that you have been in the camp of the winner. A campaign staff naturally gives off a glow of excitement about its hero, and even a candidate who doesn't have a prayer of winning can find a coterie of followers who will at least simulate a passion for him and a belief in his destiny.

BALTIMORE, May 17 -- Blue Man, the up-and-at-'em colt owned by Arthur W. Abbott of Rye, N. Y., made one of his on-the-outside runs from last place to win the seventy-sixth running of the Preakness Stakes at old Pimlico today.

CROSS from France into Italy along the Mediterranean and you are in Liguria, the long mountainous crescent stretching 180 miles on either side of the great city of Genoa at the middle of the curve, the throbbing center of Ligurian life.
The following are the Republican and Democratic line-ups for the Presidential nominating conventions as they stood last night:
TRENTON, May 17 -- A Heaton Underhill, State Director of Fish and Game, has expressed regret that people continued to pick up "lost" baby deer and take them home as pets for their children.

THOUGH Julia Gwynn had not received at Gwynn Place in thirty-five years, her influence reached almost everyone in Tateboro. The mill hands wondered why the owner took no more interest in their plight. Hallie Ashland lived in self-imposed invalidism, hoping always that Julia would call.

LAST week's announcement by the Army Signal Corps at Fort Monmouth describing a combat camera that uses 70mm film marks the first practical achievement in a decade of experiment with the film width. Its principal advantage is that, although yielding the comparatively large picture size of 2 1/4x3 1/4 inches, the new camera has design and performance features characteristic of the 35mm minature camera.

The "monetary reform" carried out in Bulgaria last week provided the finest example yet of how a Stalinist state robs its people, reducing large numbers of them to paupers with a single blow. Without any previous warning, the Bulgarian Government suddenly announced a new currency based on the Soviet ruble.

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 17 -State Senator Kenneth C. Hand said today he would ask Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll next week to call a special session of the Legislature to have the state take over nearby Newark Airport and prevent its reopening for commercial flying.

THE chief German correspondent for THE TIMES tries in this book to impart to his countrymen the political and military information which will give them a feeling of urgency about The North Atlantic Treaty Organization's (NATO's) mission of checking Russian aggression.

MODESTO, Calif., May 17 (AP) -Ollie Matson -- the University of San Francisco's All-America football star and one-man track team -- stamped himself a top contender for a berth on the United States Olympic squad when he won the 440-yard dash at the California Relays tonight in 46.9 seconds.

SHAKESPEARE'S Sonnets are by general agreement the supreme sonnet sequence in English literature. The truth is, though, that the Sonnets are not always easy to understand, and the general reader finds little help in the commentators.
As the life span continues to increase because of advances in science and medicine, the problem of the aged in the community becomes increasingly acute.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., May 17 -- A youth leadership training course started by the St. Albans Chamber of Commerce is serving as the pattern for a nationwide project by the National Junior Chamber of Commerce.
The Pennsylvania Railroad has started a search for the passengers of the Pennsylvania Special, which opened de luxe, express, extra-fare service between Jersey City and Chicago fifty years ago.

WITH her folksy, chatty style, Jane Abbott writes once again of the problems of small-town life, of the prejudice and hypocrisy, as well as the tolerance and understanding. Middle-aged Deborah Brent comes back to the New England village of her birth, though she knows she is a target for town gossips.

IT often happens that a writer, revealing a secure gift in one sphere, moves ambitiously to another. Unfortunately, he seldom reveals the same certainty of gift. Is this statement an admission of prejudice, an involuntary confession that man begrudges his fellow-men their versatility?

Moving with unexpected speed at the finish, C. V. Whitney's Mameluke won the $30,000 added Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. With Georgie Porch in the saddle the 4-year-old Mahmoud colt surprised the greater part of the crowd of 39,889 by overtaking George D. Widener's Battlefield in the last sixteenth and going on to win the mile fixture by a half length in 1:36 2/5, under 112 pounds.

Since Harry Gross, convicted Brooklyn bookmaker, started nearly two years ago to tell his fantastic story of corruption and graft at all levels of the Police Department, that city agency has undergone radical reorganization.

THE George Orwell who went to Spain in late 1936 was a man who could analyze his feelings when he shot for the first time at a human being and yet take careful aim, who could calmly examine the risks he was running without pretending not to be afraid, who could set down his exact emotions on receiving what seemed to be a mortal wound.

LONDON, May 17 -- Speaking at a Conservative rally at Aberdeen today, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden expressed confidence that the European Defense Community agreement would be signed within ten days.

Many business men are not happy over the present status of "fair trade." Everybody is confused on its operation in the legal twilight of the moment and S. Klein is upsetting apple carts right and left.

THE desire to possess two square feet of fresh clean earth is strongest in the spring. It is most evident in the tired, slightly sunburned faces in the subway, bus or train of a Sunday evening; faces nodding quietly over a tightly clutched and slowly wilting bunch of flowers.

SHRUB OAK, N. Y., May 17--Voters in a sprawling area of northern Westchester and southern Putnam will vote at the schoolhouse here July 1 on a proposal for construction of a $1,650,000 junior and senior high school---one of the largest projects of its kind in these counties since the war.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Miss Gertrude S. Carraway, former city editor of The New Bern (N. C.) Sun-Journal, and long-time chronicler of the history of that colonial capital, announced today her candidacy for the post of president general of the Daughters of the American Revolution.

THE heroine of this tale of Lesbian love is a lonely 19-year-old, who has been brought up, more or less as an orphan, in a semi-religious "home." At the novel's opening, Therese Belivet has been working for two years in New York, trying to save $1,500 for membership in the stage designer's union.

PEARL RIVER, N. Y., May 17 -- Nobody -- including 500,000 animals used for experimental purposes -- appeared to be in any hurry today to end a strike here by 2,400 employes of the American Cynamid Company's Lederle Laboratories.

Borough President John Cashmore disclosed yesterday that a group of Coast and Geodetic Survey employes had joined with his engineering staff in making an official record of the physical layout of Brooklyn.

Cotton prices last week turned firm after losing ground earlier in the period. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed off 1 to 40 points from the previous week. The sharpest losses were recorded in the near-by July delivery, while the near-by May contract, trading in which expired on Tuesday, went off the board at a level 14 points above the previous week's close.

SAVANNAH, Ga., May 17 (AP) -- The Savannah Morning News printed part of its issue today on paper made from sugar cane waste. Only a limited quantity was available and full results could not be gauged from the test. The pressmen expressed belief, however, that the paper was satisfactory for newspaper use.

ACCORDING to reports from several parts of the country, politicians eventually will campaign on the promise of a "boat for every family," and sports and conservation groups insist that this boat will be vital if the assorted Federal and state agencies and private power interests are permitted to build all the dams they now have in project.

Gross operating revenues and net income of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation for the twelve months ended April 30, last, increased 22 per cent and 10 per cent, respectively, above the levels for the year earlier.

MONTPELIER, Vt., May 17 -General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower captured today all twelve Vermont delegates to the Republican National Convention. The state convention, meeting here, broke tradition in electing a pledged delegation and departed further from custom by instructing the delegation to stand pledged to General Eisenhower until "the remote possibility" arose that he would want to release his delegates.

THE iris world is humming. As the American Iris Society meets today in St. Louis and a regional group convenes in the Pacific Northwest, less ardent fans look forward to seeing this favorite flower blooming in local gardens.
TOKYO, Sunday, May 18 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,253, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Sunday (5 P. M., Saturday, Eastern daylight time):

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands. AFTER some hurried last-minute negotiations with conductors and artists, the final progra has been assembled for the Holland Festival, which will run this year from June 4 to July 4. It will feature four Dutch orchestras, the Netherlands Opera, the New York City Ballet Company and smaller ensembles.

FRANKFURT, Germany, May 17 (UP) -- United States forces on the ramparts of Europe paraded their fighting punch today. From isolated Berlin to the North Sea and the Mediterranean, the United States Army, Navy and Air Force joined in celebrating their inter-service unity.

WASHINGTON, May l7 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin served notice from the outset that there would be "no holds barred" in his campaign against what he charged was Communist infiltration of the State Department.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor has issued a 117-page, two-part report showing that women's work as wage earners has been for the last sixty-four years mainly for the support of themselves and their dependents.

AS Joe Williams might phrase it: And whatever became of Branch Rickey? It's an intriguing question because Rickey is now the resident genius of the Pittsburgh Pirates, the helpless, hopeless Corsairs are currently the worst team in either league. Has Rickey lost his magic touch? Has he finally encountered failure after more than a quarter of a century of fantastic success?

Multicolored spring blossoms, flowering potted plants, corsages and boutonnieres will be sold by debutantes of this and forthcoming seasons at the twentieth annual Flower Mart for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association to be held throughout Tuesday on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

FROM all that can be gathered at long distance, the New York City Ballet has had a great success in Paris. Press reports say that it was received with enthusiasm at its premiere last Sunday, when it gave the first complete performance of ballets ever to be given on the stage of the Opera by a foreign company.
Many persons afflicted with bursitis, arthritis, sinusitis and several other disorders have World War II to thank for alleviation of their suffering.

As the father of a schizophrenic child of pre-school age, I was gratified that THE TIMES Magazine gave space to Oren Root's "Four Great Lacks in Mental Health" (May 4). One point was not sufficiently emphasized -- namely, that mental illness such as schizophrenia does not merely affect some disembodied figment we call "the mind," but is a disease in the true sense of the word, with corollary effects on the entire body.

SALT LAKE CITY -- Long known as a do-nothing commonwealth in so far as official efforts to bag the wily tourist have been concerned, Utah this season has established a State Tourist and Road Information Office that is already seeking to attract more wayfaring strangers to the Beehive State and undertaking the difficult task of persuading tourists to tarry a while.

A BALANCE of continuous bloom is sometimes difficult to maintain as well as to work out in the small garden. This is particularly true when perennials are the backbone of the planting. If too much space is given to spring-blooming kinds, there will be a dearth in summer, or vice versa.

SAMUEL Goldwyn is heading down the homestretch with "Hans Christian Andersen" and in the process of shooting the lavish Technicolor fantasy, which went before the camera last Jan. 21, he has written into the contemporary history of Hollywood a spectacular episode in free spending while the rest of the industry, for the most part, is off on a new penny-pinching spree. Swimming against the Hollywood current is, however, an old Goldwyn custom.

ANDOVER, Mass., May 17 -- The Andover track team led a field of fifteen preparatory schools in the annual New England interscholastic track meet today. The Blue scored eighty-one points for a margin of sixty tallies over second-place Exeter.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 17 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower appeared on the basis of incomplete returns tonight to have captured the entire Oregon delegation of eighteen members to the Republican National Convention while also winning the Presidential popularity contest in his party's state primary yesterday.

On May 8 (Korean time) Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd captured by Communist prisoners on Koje Island. Here are excerpts from a report to Washington by Gen. Mark W. Clark, U. N. Commander in Korea, or the negotiations for General Dodd's release:

YONKERS, May 17 -- Dudley Hanover tonight added another $4,500 check to the Hayes Fair Acres Farm of Duquoin, Ill., by coming out of a break at the start of the $10,000 Stamford Pace to defeat Good Time in a brisk 2:03 1/5 before 22,339 at Yonkers Raceway.

BONN, Germany, May 17 -- Experts in the West German Federal Government have worked out in general terms a program for restitutions to Israel which, provided Chancellor Konrad Adenauer approves it, they hope will satisfy the Israeli Government and make possible a renewal of the negotiations that were broken off at The Hague in April.

IN the summer of 1948 many an eyebrow was raised in Times Square's cynicthronged precincts, as well as in the loftier reaches of the academic world, at the news that the city would have a public high school to train boys and girls for careers behind the footlights.
NORMAN, Okla., May 17 (AP) -Kansas' Jayhawks had the manpower today to capture the Big Seven Conference outdoor track and field championship in a meet held in steady rain and on waterlogged cinders.

IN Cat Track Hollow, a mountain land of twisty valleys and sky meadows, life is lived as it was a hundred years ago. Granny Hits, who braved the perils of progress and took a steam ride to Washington when her valley was threatened, is the matriarch of the Hollow, and as such she quilts and listens while the nine brides tell their love stories.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 17 -- Princeton and Army, national co-champions of college lacrosse in 1951, battled to an 11-11 tie in two overtime periods on University Field today.

THE delicate grace of bloom, the sheer size and color of the Japanese iris (Iris kaempferi) amply repay the gardener for his efforts to grow this beauty. It also fills the gap in the blooming schedule between the more common bearded iris of late May and the spuria iris of mid-July.

WHEN young Dave Brant arrived at The Port of Missing Men, a huge run-down estate in Connecticut which he had unexpectedly inherited from an elderly cousin, he walked right into a tangled web. He found there another unknown cousin, 14-year-old Serena, and his old friend Steve Larrup, the amateur detective who first appeared in "The Sunken Forest."

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP) -Six Philadelphia locals of the Textile Workers, C.I.O., representing some 9,000-members, voted today to quit the Congress of Industrial Organizations and join the rival United Textile Workers of the American Federation of Labor.
The World Assembly for Moral Re-Armament will be held on Mackinac Island, Mich., May 29 to June 10, it was announced yesterday at Moral Re-Armament headquarters, 640 Fifth Avenue.

HARTFORD, May 17 -- Connecticut Republicans have begun preliminary work on the selection of this state's twenty-two delegates to the Republican National Convention July 7. Virtually all of the delegates are expected to favor the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for President.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 17 -- "Service to others is impossible without education and achievement," Charles F. McCahill, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, told 451 graduates of the Rochester Institute of Technology today.

THIS, Walter Macken's fourth novel in four years, marks the steady rise of a vigorous new talent m Anglo-Irish fiction. His "Rain on the Wind," published here last year, was a very good novel. "The Bogman," a fresh, free-flowing, affirmative story of life in a small Irish village of six families, is an even better one.

Long before the Pirates got their first hit off Ben Wade, the Dodgers had a dozen runs yesterday at Ebbets Field. No club, let alone this youth-conscious, experimental group that Billy Meyer has under his wing, can spot a rival so many points and entertain a reasonable hope for survival, and so another Pittsburgh defeat was inevitable.

A BOOK about the Soviets is nowadays expected to be a passionate denunciation of, or a just as passionate apology for, that which is the Soviet Union, for or of the Soviet Union. Raymond A. Bauer seems to be free of animus or adoration.

A new department to give direct service to teachers and public schools is being organized at Wesleyan University. The new division will concentrate on reading, citizenship, current events and social studies. It will pro vide scholarships for teachers, offer in-service training, support research in primary and secondary education, and publish educational magazines, papers and books.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 17 -- Five New York department stores were told here today that if they wanted industrial peace they would have to accept as a pattern an agreement made recently between Bloomingdale's and District 65 of the Distributive, Processing and Office Workers Union, independent.

PEARL HARBOR, May 17 (AP) -- Seaman Bruce S. Hopping, wealthy son of a New Jersey lumber family, was sentenced to a bad conduct discharge from the United States Navy yesterday after he had been convicted of criticizing naval discipline.

Virginia's Colonial Williamsburg has just begun celebrating its "Prelude to Independence," an annual event which begins in mid-May and continues to July 4, with George Mason's Virginia Bill of Rights as the chief exhibit in a collection that draws its sources from a dozen countries. Visually the exhibition will remind Americans that the aspiration for freedom, and human rights incorporated into basic law, has a long genealogy tracing back to the springs of our culture.

The United States Conference of Mayors, representing the Mayors and other officials of the nation's largest cities, closed its twentieth annual meeting here yesterday by urging Congress to vote larger sums for civilian defense and urban highways.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP) -The Reds, behind the seven-hit pitching of Frank Hiller and timely hitting by Hank Edwards and Grady Hatton, broke a four-game losing streak today by defeating the Phillies, 7 to 3. The defeat snapped a four-game Philadelphia winning streak.
In Jorge Joveyn's "Robot's Gambit" (May 4) the name of the inventor of "The Turk." "the most famous game-playing automaton in history," appears as Wolfgang von Kempelen. This is a German translation.

TWO fairly large group shows of modern American painting and sculpture, one at the Betty Parsons Gallery and one at Kootz, contain some arresting things but they really raise more questions about the avant garde than they provide clear-cut answer.
BEING stranded in Europe without enough money for passage home to the United States is not uncommon among young American tourists, whose enthusiasm for travel is often matched by their improvidence.
MEDIA, Pa., May 17 -- Mrs. Simon T. Patterson's McGinty Moore, an 8-year-old bay gelding, today won the Gloucester Fox Hunter's Plate at the Rose Tree Fox Hunting Club's ninety-third spring meeting.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Senator Robert A. Taft's basic strategy still is to regard the Republican Presidential race as a sprint, to be won in a hurry, and not an endurance match testing his staying power against that of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

LIKE many travel stories this is information thinly disguised as fiction. The Cabitor children who explored Washington in "Adventure on the Potomac" now investigate the T. V. A. with their father, a Congressman from Connecticut.

WRITTEN by a Southerner from Georgia, this first novel, whose language is Tennessee-Georgia dialect expertly wrought into a clipped, elliptic and blunt style, introduce its author as a writer of power. There is in Flannery O'Connor a fierceness of literary gesture, an angriness of observation, a facility for catching, as an animal eye in a wilderness, cunningly and at one sharp glance, the shape and detail and animal intention of enemy and foe.

TOKYO, May 17 -- The troubled camps of Koje Island, off the south coast of Korea, where the United Nations has interned some eighty thousand angry and determined Communist prisoners of the Korean war, got a new commander this week as Allied leaders sought to get to the bottom of the circumstances and the policies which for the third time this year had brewed an explosive incident inside the barbed-wire stockades.

KEEL is the name and, from all indications, it suits him. Equipped with a whopping baritone, a good-natured grin and a towering frame, Howard Keel has sauntered steadily through seven films, spanning "Annie Get Your Gun" and "Lovely to look At."

DENVER, May 17 (UP) -- The issue of wage reopening provisions and strikers' disappointment" at a pay-increase ceiling of 15 cents an hour delayed a general settlement of the country-wide oil strike today.

PARIS, May 17 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson is expected to come to Europe next week to further a United States policy looking to the closer union of Western Europe based upon a French-German partnership sustained by the cooperation, but not the full participation, of Britain.

After a hesitating start, Wall Street is beginning to tell its story on film. The first picture, not notably successful, was "The Nation's Market Place," made for the New York Stock Exchange in 1930. The next was "Money at Work," made by the March of Time in 1946 for the Stock Exchange and played about the country until the celluloid fell to pieces.

KINGS POINT, L. I., May 17 -Alfred's squad retained the New York State College Track and Field Association championship in the third annual twelve team meet held at the United States Merchant Marine Academy today.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The forces of Senator Robert A. Taft took the first round this week in the most spirited primary contest in the history of the District of Columbia. In meetings of eleven of the District's forty-three precincts Taft-backed delegates triumphed in ten, beating the backers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, who took the remaining one.

It is the story of how the Washington Heights-Riverside District Health Committee of upper West Side New York has, in the impersonal and highly complex atmosphere of a big city, developed a community-wide interest in, and responsibility for, its own health.

BOSTON, May 17 (UP) -- The Cardinals held off a late-inning surge and defeated the Braves, 5-4, today to cling to sixth place in the National League.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -The Defense Department identified today ninety-seven more battle casualties in Korea. The new list reported fourteen killed, eighty-one wounded and two injured. The following were listed from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons are serving on the junior committee for the buffet dinner dance of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church on the night of June 5 in the auditorium and Park Avenue terrace of the church, Park Avenue at Fiftieth Street.

It was a hearth-breaking homecoming yesterday for 26-year-old Mrs. Brenda Holt, English wife of T/Sgt. Julian S. Holt, 28, of Lake Park, Fla. When she arrived at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from London, she was told her husband had been killed Friday night in an automobile accident at Columbus, Ohio.

RICHMOND, Ind., May 17 -- A National Committee on Religion and Rural Life was formally incorporated here today to raise funds for the support of groups and individuals who seek to "foster spiritual and cultural values in rural living."

Pravda's two New York correspondents have blossomed out as stock market experts and have given their readers what is said to be an infallible Marxist formula for guessing when the market will go up or down. But a New York Stock Exchange official predicts that anybody who follows that formula will go bankrupt very quickly.

IN this primer of the budget-making process -- its complexities, shortcomings and attendant frustrations for economy-minded legislators -- Senator Paul Douglas of Illinois seeks to awaken the people and Congress to what he calls "the desperate need for economy."

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UP) -Dr. John R. Steelman, Presidential Assistant, called representatives of the railroads and Big Three Brotherhoods to the White House today and handed a package proposal to them for settling their three-year-old wage contract dispute.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -Joseph C. Harsch, news commentator, and stations WCAU (with WCAU-TV) of Philadelphia and WEEI of Boston won citations tonight at the presentation of the annual Alfred I. du Pont Foundation awards.
Armed Forces Day was celebrated throughout the nation yesterday as another critical summer approached in the dangerous era of half-war-half-peace in which we live.

IT had been raining since 5 o'clock in the morning. By noon acres of lowland along the Hudson River Valley were flooded over. Undaunted by the driving downpour, a group of youth hostelers got off a train at Poughkeepsie, N. Y., and started cycling to Hyde Park.

THE people of the past invented tales to explain the patterns on the moon, the shapes of the constellations and the paths of the stars. The stories in this volume, collected and retold from source books and folklore journals, reflect that ancient wonder at the night scenes in the sky.

TOKYO, Sunday, May 18 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations commander, moved an American airborne force yesterday to Koje Island, off the south coast of Korea, where rebellious Communist war prisoners captured the camp commander, Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd, ten days ago and bargained for seventy-eight hours before he was released.

TELEVISION is suffering from a dearth of original plays and writers do not seem to be inclined to do anything about it, according to Robert Montgomery, producer and host of an hour-long dramatic show presented over Channel 4 on Mondays at 9:30 P. M.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 17 (AP) -Freddy Agabashian of Albany, Calif., won the pole position for the 500-mile Memorial Day race today with a record - smashing 138.01 miles an hour by the Cummins Diesel Special.

Wilfrid Pelletier conducted the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra in a concert yesterday afternoon at the Belasco Theatre. The program consisted of Brahms' "Academic Festival" Overture, Faure's "Pelleas et Melisande" Suite, a tone poem, "The Silver Lake," by Elinor Remick Warren, and Tchaikovsky's "Caprice Italien."

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 17 -Playing steady golf on the back nine, R. W. (Bobby) Knowles, Walker Cup player from the Palmetto G. C. of Aiken. S. C., defeated Henry Kowal of Dutchess County, 1 up, in the final match of the forty-second annual Walter J. Travis Memorial golf tournament at the Garden City G. C. today.

New Yorkers streamed by the thousand toward the waterfront yesterday to make Armed Forces Day inspections of seven Navy ships, including the battleship Missouri, a submarine and an aircraft carrier. They had come into port at "full dress ship" for the occasion.

HARMON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., May 17 -- Torments of urban life are gradually overtaking New York commuters who thought they could live the simple -- and cheap -country life in rural areas of Northern Westchester. Now they are on the verge of losing free parking privileges at the railroad station here.

AMERICA, as you know, is a great place for anniversaries, and there is hardly a week in the year that some Mayor or Governor doesn't dedicate to a worthy cause or a cause that would like to be thought worthy.

Hugh Carleton Greene's "In Malaya the Front Is Everywhere" (May 4) will do much to help us here in America realize that the bandit trouble in Malaya is far from the "popular uprising" certain propaganda would have us believe.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The President is now playing "It" in a new guessing game: What Democrat will he support, directly or indirectly, for the party Presidential nomination? He is enjoying this game as much, apparently, as the one he ended on March 29 by announcing that he would not accept renomination. And he is being equally mysterious.
ELIZABETH, N. J., May 17 -- The Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart was $17,000 richer today but very much perplexed about where the windfall originated.

THESE twenty short stories, mainly of the mid-T'ang and Sung periods (eighth to twelfth centuries), are diverse enough in circumstances and characters to entertain a wide circle of American readers. It is as though a rich assortment of Chinese dishes, old-style banquet variety, had been packaged and distributed through the pigeonholes of the Automat.

Next Tuesday is the twenty-fifth anniversary of the historic airplane flight of Charles A. Lindbergh from the suburbs of New York to the suburbs of Paris. He was the first man to fly alone across the Atlantic from the mainland of North America to the mainland of Europe without an intermediate stop.

A second place finish in the last event enabled Cardinal Hayes to retain its team title yesterday in the thirty-sixth annual track and field championships of the Athletic Association of Private Schools at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium.

NO member of the large family of iris, and, in my opinion, almost no other perrennial gives more rewards for less effort than the Siberian iris. These tall, slender plants with their butterflylike flowers that come in white, blue, purple and magenta, grow well in almost any well-drained soil.

Dr. Mordecai M. Kaplan, Professor of Philosophies at the Jewish Theological Seminary, proposed last night the convening of a "Jewish world council" to formulate a new covenant on international Jewish unity.

THE native habitat of dahlias, which is the mountains of Mexico, offers a clue to their needs -- well-drained soil with plenty of humus and settled weather conditions. A cold, wet spell after planting can cause severe stunting and even loss of plants.

A strawberry barrel is an old-fashioned method of growing this popular fruit. There is much to be said in its favor, not only because it saves space but also because the three dozen plants which can be accommodated yield a decent crop for two persons.
OAKLAND, Calif., May 18 -California crews won all three races from Washington today on the Oakland estuary, the first sweep for the Bears in the history of the regatta.
LONDON, May 17 -- Sweden, defending champion, moved into the third round of the European zone Davis Cup tennis eliminations today along with Italy and Denmark.

A second place finish in the last event enabled Cardinal Hayes to retain its team title yesterday in the thirty-sixth annual track and field championships of the Athletic Association of Private Schools at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium.

THE first-round Eisenhower campaign literature must by now be nearly all in. Soon the General is due to begin speaking for himself. It's about time, for the biographies are beginning to repeat themselves. However, in "Man From Abilene" Kevin McCann, president of Defiance College, Ohio, does an unaffected and workmanlike job in pulling together the Eisenhower biographical facts and the Eisenhower ideas.

ROME, May 17 -- Clemente Cardinal Micara, Vicar of Rome, urged the faithful today to pray for victory for the anti-Communist forces in the provincial and municipal elections that will be held in central and southern Italy one week from tomorrow.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, May 17 -- The Western World's position in Africa south of the Sahara is in urgent need of strengthening. If war should be forced by the Soviet Union, this vast continental area, with all its indispensable minerals from uranium on down, might well be lost to the free side through passive resistance among the 200,000,000 Negroes or even through rebellions.

IN the Pacific Northwest today, wide fields of rainbow-colored iris are being visited by delegates to the spring regional meeting of the American Iris Society. The two states of Oregon and Washington contain the greater part of the nation's commercial bearded iris plantings, and both make yearly contributions of new and worthy varieties of this magnificent perennial.

HONG KONG, May 17 -- While the top leadership of the Chinese Communist party remains basically the same, with the reins of power still held by the men of Yenan, the Communist capital in wartime days, and by the civil war generals, some key changes have been taking plane in the party's middle and lower ranks.

MID-MAY brings the great tidal wave of the spring migration of billions of birds to nesting grounds that reach from our Gulf marshes to the northernmost Arctic shore. Some weeks later the tragedies of the wilderness reach their highest intensity. Countless immature birds, fish and other animals then face the perils of hungry fang and talon, and the diseases and accidents that weed out the less fit.

In Nutrition Reviews, Dr. Henry C. Sherman of Columbia University surveys the conclusions reached by research scientists who have studied the human need for calcium for over half a century. Up to about thirty years ago experimental evidence indicated that a daily allowance of 0.67 grams of calcium for a body weight of 70 kilos (154 lbs.) was about right.

Blue Man, favorite at $5.20, won the seventy-sixth running of the Preakness at Pimlico yesterday. Jampol was second, three and one-half lengths behind the victor, and One Count third. At Belmont, Mameluke raced to a surprising triumph over Battlefield in the Metropolitan Handicap for a $41.60 mutuel pay-off.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UP) -Suspension of price ceilings on raw cotton, textiles and whisky shaped up today as the next major move in the Administration's race to get rid of unnecessary controls before Congress does the job itself.

It's about time, for the biographies are beginning to repeat themselves. However, in "Man From Abilene" Kevin McCann, president of Defiance College, Ohio, does an unaffected and workmanlike job in pulling together the Eisenhower biographical facts and the Eisenhower ideas.

ROME, May 17 -- Clemente Cardinal Micara, Vicar of Rome, urged the faithful today to pray for victory for the anti-Communist forces in the provincial and municipal elections that will be held in central and southern Italy one week from tomorrow.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, May 17 -- The Western World's position in Africa south of the Sahara is in urgent need of strengthening. If war should be forced by the Soviet Union, this vast continental area, with all its indispensable minerals from uranium on down, might well be lost to the free side through passive resistance among the 200,000,000 Negroes or even through rebellions.

A trial to determine whether disciplinary action should be taken against former District Attorney Herman Methfessel of Staten Island and his former first assistant, Irving Rivkin, as a result of their arrest of a witness for the State Crime Commission last September will start at 10 A. M. today in Room 118, Brooklyn Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Two big retail groups asked Congress today for specific application of the Capehart pricing provision to their trade. At the same time they denied Price Stabilizer Ellis Arnall's statement that such a move would bring marked price increases.

CAIRO, May 18 -- Ahmed Hussein, chief of the Egyptian Socialist party, whose features are Communistic, Nationalist and Fascist, and five associates charged as chief instigators and organizers of the Cairo riots Jan. 26 went on trial for their lives today.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- With promise of the largest attendance in its history, the National Association of Building Owners and Managers opened its forty-fifth annual convention here today. City property investors and their agents from all parts of the country and from Canada will discuss building management problems arising from a changing urban economy.

SOUTH SALEM, N. Y., May 18 -- With sunlight bursting forth to defeat rainclouds as the hour of worship approached, the Presbyterian Church of South Salem began today the celebration of its 200th anniversary. Its 11 A. M. service was attended by 130 members of its congregation, including seven direct descendants of the Rev. Solomon Mead, who founded the church and was its pastor for forty-eight years.

Greater emphasis will be placed on an "annual improvement factor" or an "increased productivity factor" in labor-management negotiations during the next eight months, according to Austin M. Fisher, a partner in the management consulting firm of Fisher, Rudge Neblett.
Three new films, including an importation from England, are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

A program to improve day camps that would involve the cooperative effort of parents, educators, social agency workers, city officials and private camp operators was outlined this week end by Dr. Leona Baumgartner, assistant commissioner of the city Health Department.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 18 -- An experiment started four years ago to help the United Nations Secretariat become better acquainted with the United States and its people has proved a success.

More than 150 .public schools in all boroughs will benefit from the] $3,000,000. modernization fundI voted by' .he Board of Estimate I April:21, Charles J. Bensley, chair-[ man of the Board of' Education committee on'buildings and sites said yesterday.

It can be reported with authority this morning that television has not entirely corrupted the younger generation. Despite the influence of death rays and other instruments of violence that are so popular on juvenile shows along the video channels, kids still are impressed by the kind of entertainment that appealed to an earlier generation.
CHICAGO, May 18 (UP) -- The White Sox and Senators split a double-header today, Chicago taking the second game, 6 to 4, after Lou Sleater had won his first start for Washington, 2 to 1.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- The Government announced today it had approved $337,000,000 more of civilian construction.

The shapes of the outrigger and the surfboard, two means of marine transportation in the Pacific, appear in the new "Pacifica" furniture collection, made by Brown-Saltman of Southgate, Calif., and now on view at Gimbels.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- A hitherto unpublished letter by Mary Todd Lincoln, widow of President Lincoln, in which she tried to discredit assertions of her husband's reported early love affair with Ann Rutledge, was made available for publication today by Williard L. King, a Chicago attorney.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., May 18 (UP) -The Atomic Energy Commission announced a device known as the "swimming-pool" reactor today, suggesting new strides in the highly secret development of a nuclear-powered airplane.

At its last meeting the International Congress of Astronautics considered the problem of building an artificial satellite which would revolve around the earth at a distance of 300 to 500 miles. The astronauts need a filling station if ever they are to kick themselves by rocket to the moon.

HOBOKEN, May 18 -- The shakedown cruise of the Coast Guard Cutter Courier, the seagoing radio broadcasting station of the Voice of America, was a complete success, her captain announced as the cutter put into the shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company here this morning.

The Jewish People's Philharmonic Chorus presented its twenty-ninth annual concert Saturday evening, in Town Hall, with Leo Kopf conducting. A highlight of the performance was a new oratorio by Dmitri Shostakovich, "Song of the Forests." The work was sung in Yiddish translation by N. Buchwald.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 18 -- Sam Snead stayed even with par on the fifth and final round of the Palm Beach round-robin golf tournament today and that enabled the West Virginian to stave off another bold challenge by Cary Middlecoff and win.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Aug. 1 was set today as the target late to start a second payment to American World War II prisoners for treatment they received while in enemy prison camps.
