And that is why some 3,000 to 4,000 fans who wended their way through sunshine to Coogan's Bluff between the hours of 11 A. M. and 2 P. M. ran into locked gates.

ON May 25, 1951, a scared young outfielder, who had just passed his twentieth birthday, reported to the Giants from their Minneapolis farm team. Not even a full year has passed since that historic date. That's when Willie Mays became a Giant.

A year ago this week the first meeting of the American Assembly convened at Arden House, in Harriman, N. Y., to discuss the problem of United States-Western European relations. Today the Second Assembly meets to explore another mayor problem, the Problem of Inflation -- Its Causes, Consequences and Cures.

The old adage "Man does not live by bread alone" is taken literally by the Continental Baking Company. Raymond K. Stritzinger, chairman of the board, has informed The Advertising Council that his company will actively participate in next fall's Get Out and Vote campaign, sponsored by the council and The American Heritage Foundation.

GENEVA, May 18 -- Western leaders who concern themselves with world economic trends are worried about the lack of any clear signs of improvement in production and in the availability of what are commonly thought of as the necessaries of life in the non-Communist underdeveloped areas.

TOKYO, Monday, May 19 -- Vice Admiral Charles Turner Joy, senior United Nations delegate, accused Lieut. Gen. Nam II, chief Communist negotiator, today of "out-and-out lying" at the conferences on an armistice in Korea.
BATAVIA, N. Y., May 18 (AP) -The Batavia Downs grandstand seated churchgoers today as Roman Catholic and Episcopal Bishops conducted services opening Genesee County's sesquicentennial celebration.

Greatly encouraged by the election of solid blocks of delegates in Oregon and Vermont, supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower claimed yesterday a probable first-ballot strength of 524 votes for him at the Republican National Convention.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, disclosed today that the Senate Armed Services Committee would question Gen. Matthew B. Ridgaway this week, probably Wednesday, on the kidnapping of an American general in the Koje Island prison.

BONN, Germany, May 18 -- The operation of a thoroughly representative form of government from county to national level is the most important achievement of United States policy in Germany, according to United States High Commissioner John J. McCloy.

PARIS, Monday, May 19 -- Returns for 129 Senatorial seats of a total of 157 to be filled in elections yesterday for the French Council of the Republic gave indications of strong support for Premier Antoine Pinay's efforts to defend the franc.

Africa has been something of a "Dark Continent" in United States foreign policy. William S. White, THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent who has just completed a two months' trip to Africa, reminded us of this fact in his concluding dispatch on Sunday. The remedy, however, is not easy.

The eighth annual spring book drive of the American Merchant Marine Library Association will open today and continue through Saturday. A sail-rigged and fully equipped lifeboat from the tanker Esso New York will be "moored" in front of the entrance of the Esso Building, 22 West Fifty-second Street, to act as a depository for book donations in the week.

BAYONNE, N. J., May 18 -- The drydock in which the 32,000-ton aircraft carrier Wasp has undergone a record repair job since May 8 for fitting of a new bow section was flooded today to a depth of twenty-eight feet.

AMSTERDAM, May 18 -- Trade with Argentina has developed so disproportionately in favor of Holland that the Government took measures last week to avoid being left with huge peso balances because of large orders for railroad and electrotechnical material and equipment concluded last year.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Fifty-nine more delegates will be named to the Republican National Convention this week but there is little prospect that the selections will greatly alter the nip-and-tuck race for the Presidential nomination.

BERLIN, May 18 -- The East German Government is engaged in a drive against alleged spies and saboteurs so intense that Western officials believe it presages stricter internal policing and tightening of border controls between East and West Germany.

Those who condone the extraordinary, if not extralegal, handling of the steel dispute by President Truman minimize the effectiveness of the Taft-Hartley Act to meet the emergency. They may have forgotten that if it is ineffective that is largely the fault of the Administration itself.

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it opposed, as contrary to democratic liberties, any ban or regulation against the employment of a teacher solely because of his views or associations, such as communist or fascist.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, announced today that the average total of those covered by state unemployment insurance laws reached a new high of 34,800,000 in 1951, with a peak of 35,600,000 in December. The 1951 average was 2,000,000 greater than that of 1950, he said.

Possibly because taxes and governmental economy give promise of becoming the major issues of the political campaign that lies ahead, books on those subjects are popping up every other day or so. Of the five now on this desk, three are worth reading.
Ceremonies dedicating the relocated entrance of the Presbyterian Church of the Covenant, 310 East Forty-second Street, were conducted yesterday morning by the pastor, the Rev. Raymond H. Rosche.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- The American Psychological Association announce tonight that because of the Internal Security (McCarran) Act it had abandoned plans to invite the 1954 International Congress of Psychology to meet in New York.
More or less preoccupied with "The Emporium" since 1948, Thornton Wilder yesterday assured a stage chronicler that the script would be completed in time for a fall production.

GREENSBORO, N. C., May 18 (AP) -- The Southern ranks of the United Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., grew thinner today as thousands of North Carolina members voted to switch affiliation to the American Federation of Labor.
The American Theatre Wing last night gave its fifth annual award recital at Town Hall. The event was sponsored by the music faculty of the Wing's professional training program.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (UP) -- Cardinal ace Gerry Staley gained his seventh victory of the season today with a 4-3 decision over the Phillies, but needed relief in the ninth inning and a brilliant catch by Tommy Glaviano to save it.

In a concrete effort to expand its interdenominational character and to promote the spirit of Christian unity, New York's famed Riverside Church will affiliate in the fall with the New York City Congregational Church Association.

The two-story factory building at 1180 Longwood Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Kate Jarvis to an investing client of Joseph Howard Katz, lawyer. Samuel Rubin, attorney, acted for the seller, and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
Sweeping reorganization and modernization of the city's civil service system were urged yesterday in four reports submitted to the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey.

New York City has 221,956 employes, or about one person on the municipal payroll to every thirty-six persons living in this city of roughly 8,000,000 population. More people work for the city government in New York than live in the whole city of Syracuse, the fourth largest city of the state.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 18 -- The Brazilian Government has settled one acute economic problem by guaranteeing a minimum price to cotton producers and offering to buy their whole crop if necessary. It thereby has plunged itself into a new problem -- selling the cotton on a world market where Brazil's prices are considered too high.

That General Eisenhower should have come out ahead in the Oregon primary could not really have been called surprising. His supporters certainly did not expect that he would be defeated. What is important, however, is the margin of his victory. As in some previous contests he polled a considerable larger vote than even the more optimistic of his campaigners had expected.

A crossroads shopping center representing an investment of about $17,000,000 and containing parking space for 8,000 to 10,000 automobiles is planned for a 100-acre tract in Bergen County, N. J., six miles west of the George Washington Bridge on Route 4.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Election-year pressures may force a much greater liberalization of the Social Security program than was contemplated by sponsors of a bill introduced last week for a general increase in old age and survivors insurance benefits.

Inadequate vision tests used in New York State schools fail to detect many of the visual defects that retard a fifth of the pupils in their studies, Dr. Harold M. Fisher, chairman of the board of directors of the New York State Optometric Association, charged yesterday.

An insurance broker, an accountant and a real estate man delivered sermons yesterday at the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity, Central Park West at Seventy-sixth Street, as the Rev. Dr. Benjamin B. Hersey, minister, joined other parishioners in observing Layman's Sunday.
What could be pleasanter than to take a three-month swing through France, visiting produce markets in the city, farms in the country, and both as the guest of the French Government?

DALLAS, May 18 (AP) -- Charles Comiskey 2d, son of the president of the White Sox, said today he was negotiating for the purchase of a major league baseball club and that he had the financial backing of a Dallas oil man.
The State Department has denied a passport to the Rev. Dr. J. Henry Carpenter, prominent Brooklyn churchman and civic leader, to visit Japan
DENVER, May 18 (UP) -- Scattered settlements were signed by striking oil workers across the country today in action that may signal the beginning of the end of the country-wide oil strike.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Flashing lights on a big map of the United States illustrate how life starts -- and stops -- in this country.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Installation of new Federal Civil Service tax officials for Illinois at a ceremony in Chicago Tuesday morning will mark the first step in the implementation of the Bureau of Internal Revenue's field service reorganization.

NO well qualified observer of the present international crisis, with hot war in Korea, Indo-China, Burma and Malaya and cold war everywhere else, can be an optimist today. There are too many cracks in the ramparts of civilization, too many frightful possibilities which may be probabilities. One exceedingly well qualified observer is Drew Middleton, chief correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES in Germany and author of "The Defense of Western Europe."*
CHICAGO, May 18 -- All grain futures, except oats, showed a fairly strong undertone last week, but advances in wheat, corn and rye encountered free selling.

NEWARK, May 18 -- Joseph Stacher of South Orange, known as Doc Rosen during the bootlegging era, will take steps immediately to recover $340,486 paid to the Federal Government last week as additional income taxes for the years from 1933 to 1941, according to his counsel, Samuel I. Kessler of this city.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 18 -- Any slim possibility that Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio might have at least one of Oregon's eighteen votes at the Republican National Convention disappeared today as the count of ballots cast at the state's primary election of last Friday neared completion.

There is something in the mere act of writing for chorus that seems to arouse the slumbering platitudes in even the great composers. Karol Rathaus' new "Diapason," for chorus, baritone solo and orchestra, which received its premiere on Saturday evening by the Queens College Choral Society, Choir and Orchestra conducted by John Castellini, is a case in point.

TOKYO, Monday, May 19 -- Brig. Gen. Haydon L. Boatner, the new commander of the prisoner-of-war camp on Koje Island, off the south coast of Korea, revealed yesterday that he had conferred briefly with the Chinese leader of Compound 76, where the former camp commander, Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd, had been held captive by Communist prisoners.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, May 18 -- Immediately after the signing of the treaties that are to ally Western Germany with the Western powers, negotiations will be resumed, it is expected, among the member nations of the Schuman plan for pooling Western Europe's steel and coal resources, to put the plan into effect beginning next year.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 18 -- The Presidium of the Yugoslav National Assembly has promulgated what is believed to be the first law ever voted in a Communist state to permit citizens to sue government agencies for trying to enforce regulations that violate statutory law.
ST. LOUIS, May 18 -- The Yankees came back today from the humiliation of being beaten by a couple of their castoffs to split a double-header with the Browns before 17,385 at Sportsman's Park.

An attack on "official and public apathy" that has permitted hundreds of children in need of shelter to go unsheltered and has left unfulfilled many of the needs of New York's delinquent and dependent children was made yesterday by the New York County Lawyers Association.

A Police sergeant, who ignored an order to appear as a witness at the recent departmental trial of five policemen convicted of having protected the bookmaking empire of Harry Gross, the gambler, has resigned from the force.

Gottfried Von Cramm, an international tennis player for many years, won the all-important singles match yesterday to send West Germany into the third round of the Davis Cup competition in the European zone.
The recent letter from a retired Air Force general concerning flight pay mentioned many points which I feel need clarification by way of further discussion.

Preaching yesterday morning at St. Mark's Methodist Church, 49 Edgecombe Avenue, where in the afternoon the New York Methodist Conference ended a four-day session, Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the New York Methodist Area challenged Christian churches to end racial discrimination.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 18 -- The steadily expanding Vietnamese national army has been a main factor in the big over-all increase during the last year in the total of regular army troops on the French-Indo-Chinese side of the war in Indo-China.

MIAMI, Fla., May 18 -- An investigator for the United States Civil Aeronautics Administration and a Brazilian Air Force major were reported today being held as hostages near the scene of the crash of a Pan American World Airways plane in the jungles of northeastern Brazil on April 29.

BOSTON, May 18 -- The Boston police laid aside tonight what first appeared to be a new lead in the solution of the million-dollar Brink robbery, despite the insistence of Attorney General William E. Powers of Rhode Island that they did not seem "too interested" in solving the case.

PARKS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., May 18 -- Lieut. Gen. Robert W. Harper, chief of the Air Training Command, said here yesterday that, to "eliminate misunderstanding," Air Force reservists must henceforth be willing to fly before called to active duty.

LONDON, May 18 -- The conspicuous recovery of West Germany has raised hopes of Germany's pre-war creditors that representatives of the Federal Republic will come forward with a reasonable plan for settlement when the international German debt conference that began Feb. 28 resumes here tomorrow after a six-week recess.

With piercing, brave blasts of wind shrien and drum thunder, 200 kilted bagpipe bandsmen proved Saturday night to the British Army's senior pipe major that New York Scots and Irish still could play the music of Bonnie Prince Charlie and Brian Boru.

The Atlantic Refining Company, which has financed the broadcast of leading college football games in the East, South and Middle West for the last sixteen years, is withdrawing from future sponsorship. In place of the college football radio program the company, it was said, is planning a "major" program of telecasts of professional football.

The Muscular Dystrophy Associations of America, Inc., closed its second annual nationwide medical conference yesterday by announcing the establishment of at least ten postgraduate fellowships for research men to find the cause and cure of the deadly ailment.

CLEVELAND, May 18 (UP) -- Bobby Shantz of the Athletics blanked the Indians on three hits, 2 to 0, in the first game today and then Mike Garcia of Cleveland came back to hurl a nine-hit 6 to 0 shutout.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The market value of this country's output, known technically as "gross national product," was running at an annual rate of $339,500,000,000 in the first three months of this year, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce announced today.

PITTSBURGH, May 18 -- The steel rate snapped back to pre- strike levels last week when the industry was able to produce steel at 100.5 per cent of capacity -- up 18.5 points from the revised rate of 82 in the week before. It was expected that the rate this week would be equal to or slightly higher.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 18 -- Warner Brothers, apparently on the verge of going all-out for color, will film twenty-seven of its next thirty-three productions in color, Jack L. Warner, vice president in charge of production, has announced.

I can agree 100 per cent with the sentiments expressed in your editorial "Shuttle Trouble." In the midst of a great city like New York the idea of a makeshift transportation unit, thirty-three years old and established originally on a temporary basis, seems absurd.

In addressing the first general assembly of the International Press Institute in Paris last week the French Foreign Minister made a statement that has received less attention than it deserves. "As long as there is no ratification (of the contractual agreement with Germany and the treaty for the European army) there is no fait accompli," he said, "and the Russians will have an opportunity to make unification proposals."

HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 18 -- Federal mismanagement of fiscal problems, in peace as well as wartime, and extravagant public spending were blamed today by Lewis W. Douglas, former Ambassador to Great Britain, as long-range causes of present inflationary pressures.
TOKYO, Monday, May 19 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique, 1,254, for Sunday's operations:

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, suggested today that the Government, specifically the Secretaries of Commerce and Labor, encourage the formation of industrial councils -- composed of labor, management, and the public -- to improve industrial relations.

The five-story building containing twelve apartments and two stores and occupying a plot 27 by 75 feet at 1353 Park Avenue, corner of 1O2d Street, was sold by the estate of Jonas Weil to Michael Wildorf, operator, who resold it to the Rosbar Realty Corporation, Morris Nadel, president.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 18 -- When Dr. Louis J. Finkelstein, chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, confers the honorary degree of Doctor of Hebrew Letters on Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion next Sunday, he will propose the establishment in Jerusalem of an academy made up of distinguished scholars and men of affairs and devoted to the great problems of civilization.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 18 (UP) -- The Southeastern Conference executive committee today ordered a "complete and thorough" investigation of alleged irregularities in University of Kentucky athletics.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- Angry backers of the controversial offshore oil bill said today they had an even chance of overriding President Truman's threatened veto of the measure, but Administration forces predicted they would be defeated.

DETROIT, May 18 (AP) -- Vern Stephens, starting at shortstop for the first time since 1950, smashed a three-run homer, scored twice and accepted nine chances flawlessly to spark the Red Sex to a 7-4 victory over the last-place Tigers today.

Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., and subsidiaries operated at record dollar volume level and made the largest shipments in the company's history, according to the report for the six months ended March 31, last, released yesterday by Ward M. Canaday, president.

Manchester United, England's Soccer League champion, yesterday made the first New York appearance of its twelve-game tour and again proved it would take a mighty good American team to stop one from overseas. Matched with a selected eleven from the four metropolitan clubs in the American League, the British booted their way to a 5-to-1 triumph.

PARIS, May 14 -- One reason that little news reaches the Western world from the huge Soviet Ukraine is that Moscow's police and military authorities have rather effectively squashed all organized resistance movements there opposing the Stalinist regime.

" A united Presbyterian Church is again possible within our lifetime," the Rev. Dr. Harrison Ray Anderson, retiring Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., said yesterday as he hailed the great gains -- 267,000 new members -- made in the last five years.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., May 18 (UP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway threw off his military cares today and became just another family man interested mainly in showing his wife and 3-year-old son New Mexico's tourist spots, including the Santo Domingo Indian pueblo.

GUATEMALA May 18 -- Perhaps the most common comment now heard among the rich estate owners of Guatemala on the heels of the Government's publication of its proposed agrarian reform law is that "this is the beginning of the end for us as a class."

Dr. Linus Pauling is one of this country's outstanding chemists. His contributions have been basic to much of the progress made by chemistry during the past several decades. He is now, however, in a curious predicament.

ROME, May 18 -- One of the renowned and picturesque Florentine landmarks is in danger of disappearing. It became known today that the quaint old Ponte Vecchio and its superstructure of goldsmiths' and antiquaries' shops is in danger of collapsing.

The Ritz Brothers, who have been purveying their own special brand of organized confusion in the cabarets and variety houses for a good many years, made their television debut Saturday night over N. B. C. and rather handily walked off with late season honors in video comedy.

Those who favor the currently popular decorating style that makes use of Oriental objects may be interested in some of the new reproductions of Chinese and Japanese water-color paintings included in the extensive collection of Altman's new Print Gallery, which opens today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Americans for Democratic Action deferred today until after the major party conventions endorsement of any Presidential candidate after a debate in which many delegates expressed from the floor the hope that Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois could be drafted as the Democratic standard-bearer.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 18 -- The 3-year-old cream-colored miniature poodle, Ch. Braeval Biscuit, completed what for him was a perfect week-end today. He added best in show of the Long Island Kennel Club to the one he had taken yesterday at the Ladies Kennel Association competition in Garden City.

YONKERS, May 18 -- Leaving his closest pursuer two-thirds of a mile behind, Victor Dyrgall of the Millrose Athletic Association today captured the Amateur Athletic Union's national marathon title. His decisive victory automatically gave the 33-year-old New Yorker the No. 1 berth on the three-man United States marathon team for the Olympics.

Bronze busts of Susan B. Anthony, crusader for women's rights, and Thomas Paine, pamphleteer of the American Revolutionary period, were unveiled yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of the Gould Memorial Library on New York University's Bronx campus, 181st Street and University Avenue.
Those pretty June brides of many a long year ago are now beginning to make remarks about the imminent arrival of the wedding anniversary. Thus far the remarks have been casual.
Mrs. Anna Mary Vetter, 42-year-old mother of four children who was sentenced four years ago for burning one child's hand on a gas stove, was held without bail yesterday for stabbing her husband.

Persons who criticize Department of Welfare workers should remember that in this and other cities welfare workers have been "killed, shot, knifed and beaten," Raymond M. Hilliard, former Welfare Commissioner in New York and now director of the Welfare Council, said yesterday.
Daria Karanowicz-Hordinsky, the pianist, made her appearance in a Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon. A native of the Ukraine, she studied in Vienna and has given concerts extensively in Europe.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 18 -- An "on-the-job" strike against six of New York's leading department stores beginning tomorrow was approved here today at the closing session of the fifth biennial convention of District 65, Distributors, Processing and Office Workers of America, independent.

ROME, May 18 -- The center parties, headed by the Christian Democrats, were thought today to have strengthened their position compared with both the left wing and right wing for the provincial and municipal elections in central and southern Italy next Sunday.

PARIS, May 18 -- Premier Antoine Pinay in all probability on Tuesday or Wednesday will submit to the French National Assembly his detailed project for the Government bond issue that will be opened for subscription on May 26.
LONDON, May 18 -- Nothing seems to have gone right for the stock markets last week.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 18 -- In the last preparatory race before the Long Island Sound class championships start next Saturday, thirty-two summer sailing craft were out in a wing-spread today from the Larchmont Yacht Club.
Cool summer fashion, especially adaptable to the many new sheer fabrics available now, are brought to you today by Patterns of The Times.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission will release for public showing on Tuesday a film made last spring at Eniwetok, the Pacific island proving ground where the A. E. C. tests its most powerful atomic weapons.

The foreign exchange market ran along parallel lines with stocks last week, although normally neither are on a comparable level. In foreign remittances it was reasoned that so far as British sterling and the Canadian dollar were concerned each had reached relative stability at this time and present interest lies only in completing routine requirements. In stocks domestic political factors were cited as the explanation of the slowdown.

New York art exhibitions this week comprise a mixture of large groups and one-man shows. Important in the former category are the retrospective paintings at the Museum of Non-Objective Art, which aim to show the development of taste during the twentieth century.

Scientific distribution and production control have taken the gamble out of New York's billion-dollar women's coat and suit industry. Manufacturers here utilize modern methods of control, selling, advertising, and direct-mail follow-up to the extent that they can predict within 5 per cent the dollar volume for any given season.
With so much world interest in the peaceful development of the Republic of Indonesia, your editorial of April 25, "Case of the Moluccas," deserves our comment.

We feel that New Yorkers generally will approve of the orders that have just gone out from Police Headquarters to all commands directing that "special attention" be given to the highway-safety campaign which the police will conduct this summer. Very sensibly, the police are directing, much of their effort toward cutting down the number of accidents involving children.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau is likely to be charged with a $150, 000,000 bad guess on whisky tax collections this year barring a sudden spurt in drinking next month.

A sort of minor millennium arrived at Ebbets Field yesterday when Preacher Roe made half the Dodgers' meager total of four hits as the Brooks breezed to a 7-2 victory over the Cubs and moved into the National League lead, half a game ahead of the idle Giants.

LONDON, May 16 -- The age of Stonehenge, the finest megalithic monument in Britain, has been determined by Prof. W. F. Libby of the University of Chicago to whom a small piece of burnt wood taken from the site on Salisbury Plain was sent.

Working With Roosevelt," by Samuel I. Rosenman, will be published on May 27 by Harper. Former Justice Rosenman, who edited "The Public Papers and Addresses of Franklin D. Roosevelt," a series of thirteen volumes, tells the story behind the speeches, the circumstances under which they were written, the work and action that preceded and followed them and of the men who helped to shape them into words, ideas and policies.

The American Jewish Congress and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, in a joint report issued yesterday, assailed Federal, state and municipal governments for failure last year to take "forthright action" to eliminate discrimination and segregation and to stop illegal attacks against minority groups.

A plea to Roman Catholics here to extend brotherly love and understanding to the Puerto Ricans coming into this city and "give them the opportunity to be accepted by us as our brothers in Christ" was made yesterday by the Rev. Joseph P. Fitzpatrick of the Society of Jesus, instructor in sociology at the Fordham University Graduate School.

PARIS, May 19 -- Tableaux vivants of no mean order took place tonight in the Champs Elysees Theatre, crowded to the gunwales, when Igor Stravinsky and Jean Cocteau held forth together in a gala performance of "Oedipus Rex," of which the poet and the composer are joint authors.

Plans for the conversion of the three-story two-family dwelling at 14 Fiske Place, Brooklyn, into small apartments were disclosed in connection with the announcement of the purchase of the property by Mary Guckian from George Gunderson.

The Department of Sanitation began a new phase of its cleanup drive yesterday. The agency ordered 1,253 building owners and superintendents to replace worn-out refuse receptacles with leak-proof cans.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- A Senate committee heard testimony today that the Postmaster General would become the nation's biggest political power under President Truman's plan to put the nation's postmasters on a strict civil service basis.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 19 -- With summer just around the corner, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is heading into one of the most ambitious hot-weather production programs in its history and will put seventeen pictures before the cameras during the next ten weeks.

The Board of Estimate yesterday denied the application of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for permission to raise the rents of 8,755 families living in Stuyvesant Town, the company's vast middle-income housing project on the East Side. The board's action was taken at a special meeting by a vote of 15 to 1.
BOSTON, May 19 -- The battle between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations for dominance in the textile industry increased in bitterness today.

A winged hitchhiker, a chirping swallow that decided to come down to New York from New England along the sea lanes rather than by the customary air corridor, took a brief look at the Chelsea waterfront yesterday morning and then took off for points unknown.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- While his mates were in Kansas City for an exhibition game against the Yankee farm club Blues, Vic Raschi came on here today in a happy mood, having turned in his first full-time pitching job of the campaign.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, in the first release of quarterly figures, reported yesterday the largest backlog in its history on March 31. The total of $1,576,485,000, counting firm orders and contracts in negotiation, increased 178 per cent from $567,059,000 at the end of March 1951.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A minority report of the Senate Judiciary Committee, made public today, questioned the "integrity, ability and veracity" of Federal Judge James P. McGranery and declared him "unfit for the high trust and responsibility of the office of Attorney General."

The threat of a "book-of-rules" strike action against six of the city's major department stores remained in the talking stage yesterday, with neither the union nor the stores reporting any unusual action.
The following book, of interest to parents, was published recently:

With the Eastern sprint championships, dominated so convincingly by Navy last Saturday, out of the way, rowing enthusiasts turned their attention yesterday to the intercollegiate regatta to be held on Lake Onondaga at Syracuse June 21 and the Olympic trials to be staged on Lake Quinsigamond, Worcester, Mass., July 3, 4 and 5.
Today 1,500 persons are in the air over the Atlantic flying in planes between the United States and Europe. Twenty-five years ago today there was only one.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway arrived here tonight to "change his hat" from that of former United Nations Commander in the Far East to that of the Supreme Allied Commander in Europe of the North Atlantic Treaty nations. He is succeeding General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in Europe.

For the first time in eighty years security trading hours in New York are to be changed. The New York Curb Exchange, commencing June 2, will extend the closing hour, Monday through Friday, to 3:30 Eastern daylight savings time.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Senate refused today by a 44-to-28 vote to send back to the Judiciary Committee its own bill to revise the immigration and naturalization laws for direct contest with a much more liberal rival measure.

PEARL RIVER, N. Y., May 19 -- After a fourteen-hour conference between officers of Local 143 of the International Chemical Workers Union, A. F. L., and officials of the Lederle Laboratories division, American Cyanamid Company, an agreement was reached this morning on an 8-cent-an-hour across-the-board wage increase and a two-year contract with a reopening wage clause in one year and another in eighteen months.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- C. L. Austin, president of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, asserted today that the Government's stabilization program was a "double standard" bent on stimulating wages while it squeezed profits.

All the "patching up" of individual members of families that specialized agencies may accomplish is apt to have little social usefulness if the family as a unit fails to perform the basic functions that society demands of it, Bradley Buell asserted yesterday.

BONN, Germany, May 19 -- The chairman and deputy chairman of the West German committee negotiating for restitutions to Israel and Jews of the world have resigned. They charged that the Federal Government was unwilling to make good on its promise to make restitution to Israel.

Tony Mottram put Britain in the quarter-finals of the European Zone Davis Cup competition yesterday when he defeated Josip Pallada of Yugoslavia, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2, in the fifth and deciding match at Belgrade. Britain thus qualified to meet Italy in the quarter-finals.

Rain in the third inning delayed last night's game between the Dodgers and Cubs at Ebbets Field for forty minutes. At that stage it was a scoreless duel between Billy Loes and Turk Lown. In the seventh, when Plate Umpire Jocko Conian no longer could stand the dampness, he called a second halt.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 19 (AP) -- William M. Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today the price of Government securities should be fixed by a free and orderly market and not by Government dictation.

YONKERS, May 19 (AP) -- Henry Thomas drove one of the best races of the Grand Circuit meet at Yonkers Raceway tonight as he sent Jimmy Highland to a length victory over Danny Direct in the Cortlandt Pace.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, May 19 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower told the cadets at the Royal Netherlands Military Academy today that he had once taken a United States Army cook's course to round out his training in leadership.

Fifty cents will gain one admittance to the Metropolitan Opera House next fall when "Porgy and Bess," the George Gershwin-Du Bose and Dorothy Heyward musical is revived there under the auspices of Blevins Davis and Robert Breen.

With more than $6,500,000,000 being spent annually for advertising it is important that something be known about the persons who decide where and how this vast sum should be spent. Results of a recent survey among advertising agency executives by Business Week, throws some light on the subject.

At a special meeting of the 300 women residents of Barnard College yesterday, Dean Millicent C. McIntosh deplored the part that Barnard girls played in the raid by 1,000 Columbia students in the early hours of last Friday.
By action in Congress, the Marine Corps now is on the way to obtaining its own voice in the highest strategic councils of the nation.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 19 -- To retain the friendship of the free Asiatic nations our country needs as allies we should learn to understand and respect their virtues in the same way that we ask them to respect ours, Governor Dewey said here last night.
SAIGON, Indo-China, May 19 -- Casualties of the Communist-led Vietminh forces in Indo-China for the six months ended May 1 were estimated at almost 79,000 in official French figures released today.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., May 19 -- Jack Mallon, pro for the Cold Spring Country Club, teamed with Amateurs Marty Schecter and Ted Hymes to tie for the weekly honors in the Long Island P. G. A. amateur-pro tournament today with nine-under-par 63s.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The cost of a "modest but adequate" level of living for a city family of four at prices of October, 1951, ranged from $3,812 a year in New Orleans to $4,454 in Washington, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The figure for New York was $4,083.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- The House of Representatives passed today and sent to the White House a bill to extend through 1954 the basic authority for Government subsidy payments to farmers for soil conservation.

PARIS, May 19 -- Complete but unofficial returns today on yesterday's Senatorial elections confirmed the success of Premier Antoine Pinay's Independents at the expense of the Gaullists, but did not give evidence of any decisive shift toward the Left or Right.

Harvard University has decided to vote against the management of the second largest electric power and light company in the United States, the American Gas and Electric Company, on the controversial question of cumulative voting.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The State Department charged today that the technique of "the Big Lie" had been put to work against Secretary of State Dean Acheson, in a recent magazine article receiving "wide distribution."

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department revealed today that it had overhauled its crop storage policy in an effort to prevent recurrences of recently disclosed shortages in private warehouses.

The linen rental business has grown into a $300,000,000 industry with more than 1,200 companies, according to John Isaacs, president of the Linen Supply Association of America. The industry, however, he said, has a larger potential which can be realized with additional promotion and advertising.

At 4 P. M. yesterday 150 small fry tumbled out of Forest Neighborhood House, on Forest Avenue between Home and 166th Streets, in the Morrisania district in the Bronx, to start the annual spring clean-up on the block.

The offshore oil bill, nullifying three Supreme Court decisions which held that the Federal Government has paramount rights over the lands beneath the marginal seas, has now passed both houses of Congress. The President has vetoed similar legislation once before, and we hope and expect that he will do as much again.

To alert the communities of New York State to the rise in delinquency and provide help for them in combatting the increase, the New York State Youth Commission will undertake a thorough study on delinquency, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Senator Herman Welker, Republican of Idaho, said today that President Truman had told "a complete and utter falsehood" when he had listed him among Republican Senators who jeered at Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, for his views on foreign policy.

With its facilities expanded, the aluminum industry can sell all the metal it can produce and perhaps more, I. W. Wilson, president of the Aluminum Company of America, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.
Kenawna County, W. Va., designated July 15 yesterday as the date of sale for an issue of $9,950,000 of school building bonds dated June 1, 1952, and due June 1, 1953 to 1972.

LONDON, May 19 -- Britain informed the Chinese Communist Government today that British concerns, finding it no longer possible to do business in Red China under present circumstances, intended to wind up their affairs and leave.

The United Press reported from Washington the other day that the capital is girding itself for the newest battle in its sixty-year war with the starling, or sturnis vulgaris. According to the news agency's story residents feel they have found the solution to the problem of what to do with the starling in a resin-like item called "No-Roost."

The annual spring drive of the American Merchant Marine Library Association opened yesterday with ceremonies at a fully equipped lifeboat from the tanker Esso New York on display in front of the Esso Building, 22 West Fifty-second Street.
LONDON, May 19 -- Queen Elizabeth sent to the House of Commons today a message asking it to make financial provision for the royal family through a revised Civil List of payments.
BALTIMORE, May 19 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft today described President Truman's definition of bipartisan policy as "he'll make the policy and the Republicans will shut up about it."

MUNSAN, Korea, Tuesday, May 20 (AP) -- The Communist truce delegation unleashed another attack today on the United Nations, and the chief Allied delegate called it the most "vicious, degrading propaganda" in nearly one year of armistice negotiations.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved special charges for reserving seats on the named reserve-seat coach trains operated into the Southeast and between New York and Chicago and Boston and New York.

Promising additional recreational and vocational centers for the city's elderly residents, Mayor Impellitteri officially opened yesterday afternoon the new East Harlem Day Center, 310 East 109th Street.
J. Waties Waring, former Federal judge in South Carolina, last night urged Negroes to use their votes to help break down racial intolerance and discrimination.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- The House of Representatives moved swiftly today to crack down onon illegal operators who were "flooding" the mails with obscene literature and defrauding business concerns with a fake advertising racket.

Women who long have been active in the work of the Association for the Relief of Respectable Aged Indigent Females will assist at the annual bazaar for the benefit of the organization to be held this afternoon and early evening at the headquarters of the home maintained by the association at 891 Amsterdam Avenue.

Silver brooches, leather-bound reproductions of a charter signed in 1920 and an illuminated scroll also made by handicapped members of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled were presented yesterday to persons who helped found the rehabilitation center and to others who assist in its activities.

An optimistic picture of inter-American trade was presented here yesterday by Jose Rafael Llovera Paez, president of Flota Mercante Grancolombiana, one of the largest and most successful South American shipping concerns. Senor Llovera Paez described the expansion plans of his company and the prospects of increased commerce among the United States, Venezuela, Colombia and Ecuador.
Steps were taken yesterday to advance two important mergers in the airline field.

BOSTON, May 19 -- W. Averell Harriman, carrying forward his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, will make a plea for support here tomorrow to the leaders of 8,500,000 members of the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Clifford Odets, playwright, told the House Un-American Activities Committee under oath today that he had joined the Communist party in the latter part of 1934 at a time when he was "living on 10 cents a day."

In his letter published in THE TIMES on May 12 Carlos Salamanca [former chairman of the Bolivian Delegation to the U. N.] poses the question of why "disparaging terms are invariably used to qualify the ideas and aims" of the M. N. R. party which has just taken control of the Government of Bolivia through the process of revolution.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 19 -- With emphasis on such problems as education, narcotics, physical fitness and civil defense, the National Congress of Parents and Teachers opened its fifty-sixth convention today.

" Matador," a second novel by Barnaby Conrad, will be published by Houghton Mifflin on June 26. It is a story about a famous matador on his last day in the bull ring. The author, during the war, served as consul in Sevilla, Spain, and studied bullfighting under Sidney Franklin and Juan Belmonte, appearing in the ring himself in 1945.

BAYONNE, N. J., May 19 -- Back on active duty, the fully repaired carrier Wasp rode out of drydock here on the morning tide today and steamed six miles to an anchorage in Gravesend Bay. There she began loading ammunition for her next assignment.

The head of the world's largest operating electric and gas utility, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., asserted yesterday that President Truman's seizure of the steel industry "points up dramatically how far the Government has worked its way into the conduct of private business affairs."

Large groups of air raid wardens and auxiliary police and firemen were the first blood donors on hand yesterday as Arthur W. Wallander, Civil Defense Director, officially opened a week-long campaign of blood donations at the State Building, 80 Centre Street.
CHICAGO, May 19 -- Sigma Delta Chi, national journalism fraternity, at its annual banquet here tonight presented its 1952 awards for distinguished service last year in the field of journalism.

Four new trans-Atlantic liners will enter service this year, and at least nine ships will be diverted from other runs to the New York-Europe route this summer. However, there still will not be enough passenger shipping to handle the demand for accommodations.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 19 -- Brazilian authorities rushed paratroopers today to the Amazon jungle area where a United States Civil Aeronautics Authority official and a Brazilian major were reported being held as hostages by a group of adventurers near the scene of the Pan American Airways crash in which fifty persons were killed April 29.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, May 20 (AP) -- Despite a heavy overcast that limited aerial activity, the Fifth Air Force reported fighter-bombers cut Communist rail lines at forty-seven places by dusk yesterday.

Gilbert G. Southwick has been elected chairman of the board, president and treasurer of Childhood Interests, Inc., Roselle Park, N. J., educational toy concern. He succeeds Harry E. Miller, founder, who died April 10.

Hitex gave an exhibition of high octane running through the stretch in the six-furlong race that featured the program at Belmont Park yesterday. The 3-year-old owned by Mrs. B. F. Whitaker sped to a four-length victory over C. H. Johannsen Jr's Heap Big Chief, covering the distance in 1:11. Dave Gorman rode the winner.

Plans are being advanced for the Strawhat Party, the annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation, to be given on the night of June 4 in the St. Regis Roof. Members of the benefit committee, including Mrs. David Du Vivier and Countess Robert de Veyrac, have been holding meetings in the Barberry Room of the Berkshire to complete arrangements.

PARIS, May 19 -- The Paris newspaper Le Monde, which published on May 9 a pessimistic report on the defense of Europe that it attributed to Admiral William M. Fechteler, the United States Chief of Naval Operations, admitted today that the document did not bear Admiral Fechteler's name but bore that of his office.

A constitutional amendment to limit the powers of the President is a very definite prospect if the Supreme Court should uphold Mr. Truman's seizure of the steel industry, it was declared yesterday by Senator Wallace F. Bennett, Republican of Utah.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Defense Department said today that Senator Alexander Wiley and his bride were flown to Europe on an Air Force plane last week because his trip was "in the national interest."

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, accused big business today of backing a drive that would "literally cut the heart out" of the law setting minimum wages on Government contracts.

John Wanamaker celebrated the recent redecorating of its third-floor fashion shop with a style show there yesterday afternoon that offered an attractive assortment of prices and sizes. There were summer fashions in misses', juniors' and women's sizes.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 19 -- The Westchester County Council of Social Agencies and an independent citizens committee met here tonight and approved the proposal to establish in Westchester a voluntary, non-sectarian placement agency with child adoption as its major service.

The Wage Stabilization Board's trial of thirteen local ship-repair concerns, charged with illegally raising wages after the 1951 freeze order and of submitting false statements to the board, was resumed yesterday after a five-day recess. The three-man enforcement commission trying the case reserved decision on a defense motion for dismissal on the ground that the Government had failed to prove its contention.
I write to applaud the letter of Cyril F. dos Passos in the May 8 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES. To me, and I believe to most thoughtful people who read it, its reasoning is sound.

BONN, Germany, Tuesday, May 20 -- The contractual agreement, the longest step toward German equality and the incorporation of Federal Germany in Western Europe, will be signed in Bonn Monday, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The concept that regeneration of a severed spinal cord does not occur in higher animals, long printed as a truism in medical texts, has been refuted on the basis of ample animal experimentation, Dr. W. F. Windle said today in a lecture at the National Institutes of Health.

NEWARK, May 19 -- Although banned for commercial showing in New York State by the State Board of Education, "Latuko," a film of life in an African tribe, may be shown in New Jersey, it was decided today by Superior Court Judge Walter L. Freund.

Buying, while not exceptionally heavy, was reported good yesterday at the sixth annual New York Stationery Show at the New Yorker Hotel. Three hundred companies are represented at the exhibti, more than in any previous year.

It may be a little premature, but it seems safe after Sunday's elections in France to say that Antoine Pinay has performed the miracle. When his rather-right-wing Government started on its shaky course two months ago there were few who gave it hopes for success.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Evening up of May contracts was responsible for the major part of the trade in grain futures today, and the market generally had an orderly process of winding up such operations. The open interest in wheat and soybeans is still large, and erratic price moves are to be expected tomorrow and Wednesday, as the 1952 May deliveries will expire, so far as future trades are concerned, at the close on Wednesday.

Central Vermont Public Service Company borrowed $1,500,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of first mortgage bonds due in 1982. At the same time the company awarded an underwriting contract covering an offering of 108,900 shares of common stock to the company's stockholders.

Although the cotton futures market recovered a bit yesterday on news that the Office of Price Stabilization had decided to remove ceilings on the raw product and most textiles, the consensus in the trade was that the action by the control authorities was only a gesture.
BERLIN, May 16 -- The announced intention of East Germany to rearm if West Germany contributes to a European army has forced the Western Allies to review their entire military policy in Berlin.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, introduced legislation today to ban still photographs or radio or television broadcasts of Senate committee hearings.

A driver brought to Traffic Court for passing a light found himself charged yesterday with driving without a license after he allegedly admitted paying $25 for his permit. He was also the center of an investigation by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office.

" High Treason," a British-made suspense drama, which arrives at the Fifty-second Street Trans-Lux, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Roy Boulting directed and collaborated on the story and screen play with Frank Harvey. Liam Redmond, Mary Morris, Andre Morell and Kenneth Griffith are among the principals in the J. Arthur Rank presentation, which is being released here by Pacemaker-Mayer-Kingsley.

Carl (Bobo) Olson, 163 1/2-pound Hawaiian, made an impressive New York debut last night by scoring a technical knockout over Walter Cartier. 163 1/2, New York at 1:01 of the fifth round in Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn.
Futures on the Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday and closed 28 to 49 points net higher than on last Friday.

HONG KONG, May 19 -- John Keswick, head of Jardine, Matheson Co., oldest and one of the biggest British trading companies in the Far East, declared here today that long established British concerns had come to the conclusion their branches in China "were not suited to present conditions in that country."

NORTH WILDWOOD, N. J., May 19 -- A 27-year-old mental patient who had a "terrific urge to kill" wounded three persons here today as the climax of a shooting spree. Two of his victims were hospitalized.

DETROIT, May 19 (AP) -- More than $15,000,000 worth of new rolling stock has been ordered by the Grand Trunk Western Railroad, a subsidiary of the Canadian National Railways, Donald Gordon, chairman of the board, said today.

DETROIT, May 19 (AP) -- Manager Lou Boudreau's "oldtimers" gave the Red Sox a 3-2 victory over the Tigers today. The triumph, credited to Bill Henry, a rookie, lifted the Bosox into a virtual second place tie with the Senators.

SPIRIT LAKE, Wash., May 19 (AP) -- An Episcopal clergyman met ski patrolmen bringing his dead son down from the heights of Mt. St. Helens today and read the last rites of the church over the youth's broken body.

The Board of Higher Education announced last night that Dr. Willilam J. Fordrung, suspended from the Hunter College faculty last June for teaching sex hygiene "in a sensational and unwholesome manner," had been relieved from teaching duties and assigned to a school medical office.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The State Department was represented today as having been "aware" of Britain's increasing business difficulties in Communist China and officials appeared not surprised at the decision announced in London.
Three persons were injured seriously last night and traffic on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive was tied up for an hour as a result of a head-on collision between two autos.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 19 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council will open a twelve-week meeting here tomorrow. Forty-six items are on the agenda for the session, which will be devoted mainly to economic problems, including examination of the recent United Nations survey of the world economic situation.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- The Western Union Telegraph Company was reported today to have offered a wage increase to 30,000 striking American Federation of Labor union workers provided the Government approved an increase in telegraph rates.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- An expanded program of raw material stockpiling to help stabilize the economies of other free nations was suggested today by W. Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security and candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said today that undue restrictions were curbing the healthy growth of international trade.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 19 -- Total sales of industrial supplies and machinery on a national basis reached a record in 1951, but increased sales efficiency will be necessary to equal or exceed that peak during the next year.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Office of Price Stabilization suspended price controls today on raw cotton and a wide variety of cotton, wool and synthetic textiles, effective tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson said today that President Truman could not "pressure" the Senate into sustaining his threatened veto of the offshore oil lands bill.
United States Attorney Myles J. Lane yesterday termed Alger Hiss' motion for a new trial based on newly discovered evidence as "frivolous" and "sheer speculation."

That large plantation owned by the Trujillo family, which is better known as the Dominican Republic, is changing its managers. Of course, it remains the property of the head of the family, Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo, who has run it without any real interruption and without any argument since 1930.

FOR an unashamed admirer of Byron Nelson, it was a delight to encounter the Mechanical Man once more last week-end. There are flecks of gray at his temples but he looks unchanged. He still stands 6 feet 1 inch and is a hard-packed 192 pounds. If there is any change, it is an inward serenity. Lord Byron finally has found complete relaxation.

Portions of the American Medical Association's annual convention in Chicago will be televised over the National Broadcasting Company network on Tuesday, June 10, from 9:30 to 10 P. M. and Wednesday, June 11, from 10 to 10:30 P. M.

Branch Rickey's extraordinary creation of young and old Pirates, who seem to be groping their way around the National League in a sort of "transom," came mighty close to putting everyone to sleep at the Polo Grounds yesterday, including 4,461 spectators.

The British decision to close out the commercial investment in Communist China is more "realistic" than some of the political wishful thinking has been. This is another "de facto" recognition, a recognition that business as usual will not be forthcoming with the Communist regime.
In New York the Bureau's regional office reported that the $4,083 living cost here for a family of four was figured without any provision for savings.

The tiny single-celled alga called Euglena, which has been nothing but a laboratory curiosity for 278 years, may provide the answers for important new nutritional questions about the use of B-12, the anti-anemia vitamin, Dr. William J. Robbins, director of the New York Botanical Garden, reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- With eventual merger as their goal, representatives of more than 1,600,000 Baptists and almost 2,000,000 Disciples of Christ opened simultaneous five-day annual conventions here tonight.
Supreme Court Justice Samuel S. Di Falco ruled yesterday that picketing by a union seeking to organize employes of a company was not illegal. He refused to grant an injunction barring such picketing.

MUNSAN, Korea, May 19 -- Maj. Gen. William K. Harrison Jr., who will face grim Lieut. Gen. Nam Il of the North Korean forces in the tent at Panmunjom where the armistice talks are held, seems more like a tolerant school principal than a former cavalry officer.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Government issued a price order today that would mean, it said, an increase of one to two cents a can in many stores for nine of the most popular canned vegetables, fruits and juices.
In several executive changes at R. H. Macy Co., Inc., voted by directors here yesterday, Wheelock H. Bingham was elected president of Macy's New York, effective Aug. 1.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 20 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations Commander, announced yesterday the appointment of Maj. Gen. William K. Harrison Jr., a cavalryman, to succeed Vice Admiral Charles Turner Joy as head of the Allied delegation negotiating with the Communists for an armistice in Korea.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Production jobs in factories declined by about 410,000 in the year to mid-April, the Bureau of Labor Statistics estimated today. The mid-April total was 12,700,000.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The executive committee of the Democratic National Committee said today that charges of waste and extravagance lodged against Frank E. McKinney, the national committee's chairman, had been examined and found to be "without merit."
Two of the city's oldest communities opened exhibitions yesterday of their youngest residents' art.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The House of Representatives surprisingly rejected today a bill designed to add 12 1/2 per cent, or at least $5 monthly, to the benefits paid some 4,500,000 old-age and survivor beneficiaries under the Social Security program.
The American Geographical Society, a large research organization with a specialized library of 150,000 publications and 220,000 maps and atlasses, will celebrate its 100th anniversary Thursday.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 19 -- Leaders of a cross-section of American life expressed disagreement today as towether the nation would face inflation or recession before the end of this year.
CHICAGO, May 19 (UP) -- Johnny Adams ran his string of consecutive victories to seven today at the Lincoln Fields - at - Hawthorne meet.
The State Department passport division declared yesterday that it had denied a passport to the Rev. Dr. J. Henry Carpenter of Brooklyn because of his "political activities.''
Entries closed yesterday for the United States open golf championship and officials announced a record list of 1,700 names.
Airlines here and abroad continued yesterday to cancel additional flights, despite major advances in settling the twenty-day country-wide oil strike.

Subsidiaries of the Omnibus Corporation enjoyed a 3 per cent increase in first quarter passenger traffic, compared with a decline of 4.68 per cent in other large cities, the New York corporation reported yesterday.
When the chief of the Nutrition Clinic of the City Department of Health writes a book for laymen on this nation's most serious nutritional problem, we have a headliner in food news.

LONDON, May 19 -- The dispute over the principle of the closed shop has flared up again in the county of Durham where the County Council, controlled by the Labor party, has renewed a policy of discrimination against teachers in the county's schools who do not belong to trade unions.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 20 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique 1255, for Monday's operations.

ANYONE who goes woodchuck shooting with a man who is convinced that he can bowl over these varmints at ranges of from 300 to 400 yards deserves what he gets, and although our experience was productive of only two chucks, there were other compensations -- in retrospect.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Down with appeasement and trimming, said the President to the Americans for Democratic Action Saturday night. Down with the dinosaur-dominated Republicans. Down with Congress for certifying state ownership of the lands under the marginal seas -- "robbery in broad daylight on a colossal scale."
TOKYO, May 19 (AP) -- Vice Admiral Joseph J. Clark will relieve Vice Admiral Robert P. Briscoe as commander of the Seventh Fleet tomorrow in ceremonies aboard the fleet flagship, the battleship Iowa.

Mary Todd Lincoln never did like Billy Herndon. Billy Herndon never did like Mary Todd Lincoln. To Mrs. Lincoln it must have seemed that Herndon invented the Ann Rutledge story of Lincoln's first and greatest love in order to hurt the woman Lincoln married. It doesn't really seem that way to us now.
LONDON, May 19 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill said today United States air bases would remain in eastern England "so long as they are needed in the general interests of world peace and security."

LONDON, May 13 -- The United Whalers' factory ship Balena is being refitted at Newcastle after her return from a four-month expedition to the Antarctic, where two of her catcher vessels were equipped experimentally with a new type of whaling gun and electric harpoons.
Former Chief Inspector August W. Flath is scheduled to appear today before the special Staten Island grand jury investigating police and other official corruption on the island.

A program of rehabilitation for the Navajo tribes will become inoperative unless the United States Senate rescinds drastic cuts made in funds by the House of Representatives, the Association on American Indian Affairs asserted yesterday.

Your recent article dealing with the semi-annual report of the F. B. I. on national crime statistics does not mention the number of narcotics cases for 1951 which is given in this bureau's report. The total is 13,030, and it is more than 50 per cent larger than that of the previous year. The trend for the last six years is as follows:

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 20 (AP) -- Yoshiro Shirai, a skilled counter-puncher with a rapier left, last night brought Japan its first world boxing title, wresting the flyweight crown from aging Dado Marino of Honolulu.

The city opened bids yesterday from three private operating companies for five city-owned Manhattan bus lines that are incurring an annual loss of about $340,000. A quick preliminary analysis of the offers by observers was that the proposal of the New York City Omnibus Company put forward the most "hard cash" and therefore was likely to be the one selected.

Members of the American Management Association attending a three-day insurance conference at the Statler Hotel were told by experts in the field yesterday that there was scarcely a business risk that could not be covered by an insurance policy.

GENEVA, May 19 (AP) -- The World Health Organization withdrew from the controversial problem of birth control today after delegates from several strongly Roman Catholic countries had warned that action in this field would endanger existence of the organization.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The nation's railroads accepted tonight a proposal of Dr. John R. Steelman, the Assistant to the President, for settling their three-year dispute with three major operating unions -- the engineers, firemen and conductors.
The advertising agency field was startled yesterday when it was revealed that H. W. Newell, executive vice president of Geyer, Newell Ganger, would leave that organization June 2.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 19 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin, Republican of Massachusetts, House minority leader, charged here today that a "never-ending parade of phony emergencies" had been proclaimed to gain more power for the Executive Branch o fthe Government.

PANAMA, May 19 -- Roberto F. Chiari, candidate of the Civil Alliance, against Col. Jose A. Remon, supported by the Pattriotic Coalition in the Presidential elections May 11, charged that the elections were a "dangerous burlesque of democratic principles" in a statement to the press today.

Shunting minority groups into segregated residential areas is a time-proved way of breeding slums that are costly to the public generally, speakers declared yesterday at a meeting arranged by the New York State Committee on Discrimination in Housing and the National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing.

An early-morning fire in a Williamsburg, Brooklyn, rooming house yesterday caused the death of a 63-year-old woman. Four other persons were injured, one critically, when they jumped from second-story windows.
LONDON, May 19 -- Apart from some sharp declines in foreign issues, business generally was quiet in the London stock markets today with price movements aimless and narrow.

BERLIN, May 19 -- The three Western commandants of this city handed to Dr. Ernst Reuter, Mayor of West Berlin, today a three-power declaration stating that the status of Allied rule in Berlin would be unchanged by the signing of the contractual agreement in Bonn. The agreement will end Western Germany's status as an occupied state.

HARTFORD, May 19 -- Connecticut Democrats, meeting in statewide local caucuses and primaries, selected tonight 1,100 delegates to attend the Democratic state convention in Hartford on June 13 and 14. The state convention will elect Connecticut's twenty-two national convention delegates, who will have sixteen votes at the convention.
The state of the world in 1920 occupied the attention of the judge, the jury and counsel yesterday at the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders in the United States District Court here.

Barring last-minute snags, next week promises to initiate a period of great decisions in Europe which will determine whether that old continent is capable of creating a new order assuring the survival of Western civilization on it, or whether it must continue to wallow in suicidal strife, which has already delivered its eastern half into the hands of a new conqueror from the East and threatens the western half with the same fate.

NEWARK, May 19 -- Boyce Motor Lines, Inc., was fined $8,000 by Federal Judge Thomas Meaney today on six counts of transporting flammable chemicals in violation of Interstate Commerce Commission regulations. One of the counts was in connection with the explosion and fire in the Holland Tunnel on May 13, 1949.

New York at night sparkles like a fairyland. There are millions of lights and each represents a window. Behind one of the windows are a group of teenage boys, concocting plans for stealing a car. Another light in the distance marks the despair of a husband and wife.
PARIS, May 19 (AP) -- Twenty-eight Cleveland business men were the luncheon guests today of the Paris Trade Fair -- the sixth fair they have visited on their European business study tour.

NEWARK, May 19 -- Boyce Motor Lines, Inc., was fined $8,000 by Federal Judge Thomas Meaney today on six counts of transporting flammable chemicals in violation of Interstate Commerce Commission regulations. One of the counts was in connection with the explosion and fire in the Holland Tunnel on May 13, 1949.

New York at night sparkles like a fairyland. There are millions of lights and each represents a window. Behind one of the windows are a group of teenage boys, concocting plans for stealing a car. Another light in the distance marks the despair of a husband and wife.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., May 19 -- The Westchester P. G. A. opened its season today with the largest field in years, seventy-seven teams competing in a pro-amateur best-ball tournament over the Vernon Hill Country Club course.

JERSEY CITY, May 19 (AP) -- Long - smoldering resentment of Jersey City longshoremen over the hiring of New Yorkers here boiled over today in a walkout at Claremont Terminal, hampering operations at the Army installation.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 20 -- A high level review was ordered yesterday by Gen. Mark W. Clark, United Nations commander, of the incident in which rebellious Communist war prisoners on Koje Island, off the south coast of Korea, kidnapped their camp commander, Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd, and held him as a hostage for seventy-eight hours.

HARTVILLE, Ohio, May 19 (UP) -- Undaunted by the loss of one eye in a baseball accident, Bobby Slaybaugh planned today to leave for Omaha to start a comeback he hopes will land him another chance in the major leagues.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Following is the 150-140 vote by which the House failed to pass a bill increasing Social Security benefits. Although the bill received a majority of the votes cast, it needed two-thirds for passage:

BOSTON, May 19 -- The Boston police threw cold water tonight on the story of a Rhode Island prisoner about the $1,219,000 Brink robbery by saying they had established that he had been in Tampa, Fla., from November, 1949, to March 8, 1950. The robbery occurred in Boston, Jan. 17, 1950.

ST. LOUIS, May 20 (AP) -- Connie Marrero pitched a four-hitter tonight as the Senators gained their fourth-straight triumph over the Browns, 2 -- 0. It was Marrero's fourth triumph against no defeats this year.

As one of the Japanese war veterans to be rearmed and incorporated into the million-man standing army suggested by Edward H. Dodd in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 7, I should like to make a few comments. First, I should like to make it clear that the majority of the Japanese people are prepared to accept responsibility for defending their land from totalitarian aggression.

PARIS, May 20 -- The foreign ministers of six European countries, or their deputies, met all day today and will meet all day tomorrow in the hope of completing by Tuesday what may be called the last lap in the formal integration of West Germany with the Atlantic community.

A substantial increase in magnesium castings for the aircraft industry was predicted yesterday as the result of the transfer to the Navy's Bureau of Ships and Docks of the Eclipse-Pioneer foundry at Teterboro, N. J. Ralph D. Ferguson, manager of the foundry, said the transfer "gives the green light to an extensive program of machine tool replacement and expansion through the Navy's facilities program."

BONN, Germany, May 20 -- The West German Government was making strong efforts today to assure the world of its intentions to carry out its promise to pay restitutions to Israel and Jewish organizations and at the same time to ward off the possibility that the international conference on Germany's external debts in London would break down.

BONN, Germany, May 20 -- As more than 300,000 workers in the four key cities of Frankfurt, Bielefield, Bochum and Reutlingen left their jobs for the afternoon tying up public transportation for several hours, the West German Employers Association threatened to sue the trade unions for damages.
Micol Fontana, one of the leading members of the Italian couture, has come to this country to go into partnership with an American manufacturer. The new company is under the name of Tafel-Fontana.

TORONTO, May 20 (Canadian Press) -- Austin S. Iglehart, president of General Foods in the United States, today advised Canadians not to laugh off the "growing pains" caused by an expanding economy but to profit from mistakes made by United States business.

Grace Spofford, who has been director of the Music School of the Henry Street Settlement for the last seventeen years, was honored last night at Town Hall when a clock was presented to her on behalf of the faculty and flowers on behalf of the school's adult council and the parents of the students.

LONDON, May 20 (AP) -- Don Cockell, British light-heavyweight champion, survived two early knockdowns tonight to outpoint the Italian champion, Renato Tontini, in a close ten-round non-title battle. Each man weighed 177 pounds.

LONDON, May 20 -- Concessions announced by Chancellor R. A. Butler in taxation of business earnings had little immediate effect on the stock markets today with the exception of rubber and tin shares, which showed some rise in prices.
THE doctor was very postive in his diagnosis. He had checked the patient thoroughly and scoffed at the idea that a sacroiliac conditian was the cause of the trouble.
PARIS, May 20 -- A noble experiment was undertaken tonight at the "Twentieth Century Masterpieces" concert given in the Champs Elysees Theatre with some unexpected results.
PARIS, May 20 (AP) -- All American favorites advanced into the second round easily as play opened today in the French international tennis championships at Roland Garros Stadium.

BOSTON, May 20 -- The executive council of the Massachusetts Medical Society was disclosed today to have accepted the resignation of Dr. Robert E. Lincoln of Medford, Mass., developer of a system of medical treatment for various diseases.

A measure designed to freeze rents in Stuyvesant Town, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's East Side housing for middle-income families, at the present level of $17 a room a month was approved yesterday by the City Council in a turbulent session.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Truman has signed a bill giving members of the armed forces a 4 per cent cost-of-living pay increase plus a 14 per cent increase in food and rental allowances.

ZEIST, the Netherlands, May 20 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower acclaimed today the Vatican's fight against communism as he addressed an international conference of chaplains of the Atlantic Pact nations.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 20 -- Prompted by a statement in Parliament by a member of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist Cabinet that it was "disgraceful" for an American to publish "such cartoons in South Africa," the United States Consulate General in Johannesburg has made a routine check on Bob Connolly, a well known cartoonist on the Rand Daily Mail.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Dr. Allen V. Astin, Government scientist and weapons expert, was nominated by President Truman today as director of the National Bureau of Standards. Dr. Astin has been acting chief of the bureau since last October, shortly after the resignation of Dr. Edward U. Condon.
In a letter to the editor published by THE NEW YORK TIMES on May 13 Abdul Majeed Abbass, delegate of Iraq to the United Nations, declared, in particular:
BERLIN, May 20 -- All East Berlin newspapers reported today the discovery of United States military maps allegedly based on recent aerial photographs of East Germany.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, May 20 (AP) -- The Amsterdam Stock Exchange stopped all operations today in protest against a court decision nullifying the purchase of Jewish-owned securities during the Nazi occupation of Holland.

NEWARK, May 20 -- The criminal action against the motion picture theatre manager and the two projectionists who participated in the showing of "Latuko," a film of life in an African tribe, will be pressed, George V. Astley, assistant corporation counsel here, announced today.

HOUSTON, May 20 -- The formation of a nation-wide anti-subversive movement designed to promote better citizenship was announced here today by the president general of the National Society of the Sons of the American Revolution.
CHICAGO, May 20 (UP) -- Johnny Adams completed a top-flight riding feat today when he won witch five of his six mounts to bring his victory total to twelve in three days at Lincoln Fields.
Dr. Adolph Jacoby, director of the Health Department's Bureau of Social Hygiene, will retire May 31 after thirty-six years of service in the city's war against venereal disease.
