LONDON, May 20 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly of San Digo, Calif., America's top contender for Wimbledon tennis honors, arrived by plane tonight and won her first set -- over British reporters.

Despite a drop in net profits after taxes of $1,465,200 for the first quarter compared with the record high of $2,450,000 in 1951, William J. Hogan, vice president and treasurer, told the annual meeting of American Airlines stockholders yesterday in Wilmington, Del., that prospects for the rest of the year were not to discouraging, barring the extension of gasoline rationing due to the oil strike.

Harrison Williams. one of the nation's multi-millionaires, voted his $2,570,400 investment in the common stock of the American Gas and Electric Company by proxy yesterday in favor of cumulative voting for directors. Mr. Williams, long an advocate of complete control over corporate situations, was opposed by Harvard University.

MANILA, May 20 -- President Elpidio Quirino has summoned Provincial Governors and Mayors of chartered cities to meet here tomorrow for a discussion of the tense world situation. The move caused a mixed reaction in the Philippine Congress, which is scheduled to adjourn its 100-day session Thursday.

The start of central buying activities here for a new chain of complete department stores for medium-size and rapidly growing cities was announced yesterday by Fedway Stores, division of Federated Department Stores, Inc. The parent organization operates a national string of large-city stores, including Abraham Straus and Bloomingdale Brothers, William Filene's Sons Company, Boston, and F. R. Lazarus Co., Columbus, Ohio.
BRISTOL, Tenn.-Va., May 20 -- It will be Ron Necciai Night tomorrow night as Bristol baseball fans honor the 19-year-old right-hander who is re-writing strikeout records.

In taking over the presidency of the National Urban League Robert W. Dowling has accepted an opportunity for great service to his fellow-Americans. The League is the nation's oldest interracial service agency. It is principally concerned with achieving equal economic opportunity for Negroes in all fields of endeavor.

I served as a juror in the Municipal Court for two weeks and if called again I shall again serve because it is my duty, but I feel I have been unnecessarily abused and so do many of those with whom I served. We feel that perhaps as many as nine of every, ten cases should not have been brought to court.

HARTFORD, May 20 -- John Foster Dulles, Republican foreign affairs expert, assailed President Truman tonight for making "highly partisan use of our bipartisan foreign policy" in a speech last Saturday night in Washington when, Mr. Dulles said, the President "spread fears" about the future of American foreign policy.

" Blind Date," with Arlene Francis as mistress of ceremonies, is expected to return to the air over Channel 4 on Saturday, June 7, from 9 to 9:30 P. M., serving as one of the summer replacements for "Your Show of Shows." The Block Drug Company will be the sponsor. The 9:30 to 10:30 time segment will be filled during the summer by "Saturday Night Dance Party."

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 20 -- Another anti-French student demonstration in the West Cambodian city of Battambang yesterday emphasized the continuance of agitation in certain Combodian quarters against the present French-Cambodian relationships.

Debate in the City Council yesterday as it adopted the $1,469,265,102 budget for 1952-53, largest in the city's history, brought a dramatic challenge from the floor by City Council President Rudolph Halley to the Councilmen to "go on record as to whether they are for Costello or not." The members did not take up the challenge.

BONN, Germany, May 20 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has raised anew the key question of the political independence of a united Germany during this last phase of the negotiations between West Germany and the three Western powers on a contractual agreement to establish the Federal Republic as a partner in Western Europe.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Senate confirmed today by a vote of 52 to 18 the nomination of Federal Judge James P. McGranery of Pennsylvania as Attorney General.
Central Vermont Public Service Corporation's financing through two securities issues totaling $2,835,000 will begin today.
Following is the text of President Truman's address yesterday at the Sesquicentennial Convocation at the United States Military Academy in West Point as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CHICAGO, May 20 -- The first joint session in history of the American Baptist Convention and the International Convention of Disciples of Christ was held tonight in Chicago's Convention Building and International Amphitheatre.

New York City Housing Authority borrowed $6,560,000 yesterday in the public market on a temporary loan note date June 23 and due Dec. 22. The short-term issue was awarded to the Hanover Bank and Trust Company at an interest bid of 0.95 per cent, with a premium of $59.

NEW DELHI, India, May 20 -- India today announced the appointment of N. Raghavan, one of her most trusted diplomats, as ambassador to Communist China. He replaces Sardar K. M. Panikkar, who became a controversial figure during his tenure in Peiping.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 20 (AP) -- Jess Linthicum, a 5-year-old chestnut horse from the barn of Gee M. Cohen, found the sloppy going to his liking in the feature race at Garden State Park today.

The annual return of World Trade Week reminds us that New York City has attained its position as the commercial capital of the world largely by reason of its pre-eminence as a port for foreign trade. World trade offers a channel through which may flow mutual understanding among the nations of the earth.

BOSTON, May 20 -- The American Federation of Labor served notice today that organized labor would walk out of the wage control program again if Congress ousted labor and management from direct representation in the Wage Stabilization Board and substituted a board made up exclusively of public members.

The Commander, a sixteen-story apartment hotel on plot 80 by 100 feet at 238-44 West Seventy-third Street has been sold by the Commander Operation Corporation, Minnie Smith, president, to Commander Associates, Inc., headed by Adolph Bordiga and Dr. Louis Sunshine.
Manhattan College's Block "M" award dinner will be held this evening in the college cafeteria where ninety-six athletes in seven sports will receive awards.

WEST POINT, May 20 -- President Truman, acting as Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces of the United States, ordered a general amnesty today for all cadets of the United States Military Academy who were under sentence of extra marching duty.

Not content with increasing subscription audiences outside of New York, as it has been doing successfully for past season, the Council of the Living Theatre hopes to implement its efforts in revitalizing the stage by having representative managements send out six first-class tcuring attractions.

The League of Women Voters of the City of New York voted yesterday to make the public aware of the recommendations of the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey in personnel administration, finance and budget procedure.
LONDON, May 20 -- The Soviet radio and newspapers tonight accused the United States of building Nazi-style extermination camps in Arizona and Oklahoma.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today it was dismissing "under honorable conditions" and without court-martial twelve Reserve officers who refused to fly.

The appointment of Miss Amy Hostler, a leader in the field of early childhood education, as the first president of the Mills College of Education was announced yesterday by Mrs. Jarvis Maximov, chairman of the college board of trustees.
CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- Authorities pushed tonight an investigation into the death of a Connecticut salesman who body was found early today in a gutter in Chicago's northwest section.

A criminal trail starting in Washington Heights and extending possibly to Sydney, Australia, was uncovered yesterday when the police announced the arrest of eight men in a gem theft plot that had begun through a chance meeting at a hotel bar.

Frozen Danish brook trout, which many experts rate superior to the domestic, is about to enter the period of peak supply. The open season for catching the fish in hatcheries in Denmark began May 1, and the first of regular weekly shipments is crossing the Atlantic now.

PARIS, Wednesday, May 21 -- By vote of 324 to 206 the French National Assembly last night approved Premier Antoine Pinay's government loan, with its capital value attached to gold, as a means by which it is proposed to balance the budget and restore a normal economy.

The property at 38-44 Washington Avenue, southwest corner of Flushing Avenue, Brooklyn, consisting of four store and loft buildings, has been sold by William Ulmer, Inc., to an investing customer of R. M. Dinsmore Co., brokers in the transaction. The parcel, about 60 by 82 feet, is assessed at $67,000.

Harry and Elsie Seiffert have terminated an ownership of eighteen years in the sale of the Old Heidelberg Hotel at Seneca Drive and Pine Acres Boulevard, Brightwaters, L. I., to William and Elizabeth Ooms. Title insurance was furnished by the Security Title and Guaranty Company.

Evidence that a pay agreement between thirteen local ship repair concerns and the Marine Trades Council, A. F. L., pre-dated the Government's wage freeze was presented yesterday as the companies opened their joint defense before a three-man regional enforcement commission.

The administrative policy of the New York City Center of Music and Drama, under fire because of the dismissal last winter of Laszlo Halasz and recent resignations from the board of directors, was vigorously defended yesterday by Newbold Morris, chairman of the civic center's board.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The Government said today an increase of at least 4 per cent may be authorized in manufacturers' ceilings for popular-priced table china used in most American homes.

RENO, Nev., May 20 -- A stockholders' protective committee today accused the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation of hopeless mismanagement and suggested that "it get out of the automobile industry altogether.''

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Seventeen national leaders in the public health field were appointed by the United States Public Health Service today as a consultant committee to a two-year study on the amount and kind of nursing service required to meet minimum public health needs.

TRENTON, May 20 -- The wardens of Trenton State Prison, Rahway Prison Farm and four reformatories in New Jersey testified here today before Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's special investigating committee that they were handicapped by a serious shortage of qualified guards.
Three top members of the city administration expressed divergent views last night on how the city government should be reorganized to handle city business.

LONDON, May 20 -- Herbert Morrison, speaking for the opposition in the House today, expressed regret at the decision of British business interests to withdraw from Communist China but agreed that under present conditions there was no alternative.
Two rookies who weren't wanted -- Hec Rodriguez of the White Sox and Clint Courtney of the Browns -- are giving American League veterans a lesson in the fine art of fielding.

Quiet Step of the Apheim Stable was the easy winner of the $10,000 added Assault Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Under a precise ride by Teddy Atkinson, the son of Some Chance came along strong in the stretch to win the mile event by three lengths.

The new long-range towboat Russell No. 14 will make a trial run around Manhattan Island today preparatory to entering the Russell Towing Line's harbor and offshore service tomorrow morning. The test run will start from the East River and Thirty-fourth Street at 10:30 A. M. and stop briefly at Pier 1, North River, for public inspection.

The B. F. Goodrich Company had consolidated net sales of $138,248,530 in the first three months this year, a decline of 12.4 per cent from the $157,728,418 volume for the corresponding period a year ago, John L. Collyer, board chairman and president, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Air Force pilots and ground communicators will eliminate "miles per hour" and "statute miles" from their vocabulary and convert to "knots" and "nautical miles" on July 1.

The three-block area bounded by West Forty-sixth Street, Ninth and Tenth Avenues and West Forty-ninth Street is well chosen for a slum-clearance low-rent public housing project. The State Housing Commissioner, Herman T. Stichman, announced approval of this 11.8-acre site yesterday, along with a $21,825,000 state loan.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 20 (AP) -- A convicted bookmaker testified today that he paid Mayor Joseph Srholez of Little Ferry $25 a week for every telephone operated in the borough by a bookie phone-renting syndicate.

Directors of the Eastman Kodak Company at their annual organizational meeting yesterday elected Albert K. Chapman as president to succeed Thomas J. Hargrave, who became board chairman. Donald McMaster, vice president, was named to the additional office of general manager.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is looking for some way to put the Government's $750,000,000 synthetic rubber industry in private hands, Harry A. MacDonald, administrator of the agency, told a group of Chicago bankers and others at a lunch given today by Peter I. Bukowski in the Lake Shore Club.

Five years' experience with the Health Insurance Plan, summarized here yesterday at the fifth annual meeting of the board of directors, indicates that comprehensive medical care can be provided at a price the average man can afford to pay by using physicians in group practice, officers of the plan declared.
Commodity futures prices moved generally downward yesterday. Volume was low except in cottonseed oil.

Surrogate George Frankenthaler has ruled, it became known yesterday, that City College rather than the Board of Higher Education is entitled to a bequest under the will of Al Jolson, who died on Oct. 23, 1950.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, who won country-wide attention as chairman of last year's televised Senate Crime Committee hearings, declared his opposition today to a proposed Senate ban on radio, television and still cameras.
BALTIMORE, 20 (UP) -- The May Maryland Racing Commission today threatened to cancel Pimlico's racing dates unless track-officials presented some "improvement and rebuilding plans."

The apathy of the Government and the State Department with regard to the construction and maintenance of a strong merchant marine was sharply criticized yesterday by Theodore Brent, president of the Mississippi Steamship Company.

The Aluminum Company of Canada, Ltd., principal unit in the Aluminium Limited group, will make a public offering in this country today of $90,000,000 of 3 7/8 per cent sinking-fund debentures to finance part of its expansion program.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 20 -- Members of the American Assembly worked today on specific suggestions for cutting down Federal spending, which they agreed was the one biggest inflationary factor. They decided that military and other public outlays could be reduced substantially without impairing national security.

In an effort to increase the popularity and sales of wine, Fromm Sichel, Inc., which owns Paul Masson Vineyards in California, will standardize production next fall. The company proposes to simplify selection of wine by limiting production to only one type of each wine and to maintain consistent quality by blending.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Members of Congress were assured today that this country would make no major commitment for aluminum supplies from Canada without first consulting with appropriate Congressional committees.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, recommended today that, because of political tensions, Congress refrain from passing a comprehensive bill dealing with national emergency labor disputes.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Halsey, Stuart Co., Chicago investment banking concern, asked today that Congress require Securities and Exchange Commission registration and regulation of the private placement of corporate securities.

An exciting hint of the luxurious furs to be worn this fall was offered yesterday by Joseph Bernham in his new salon at 16 East Fifty-second Street. Limited to twenty-six pieces, the designs relied on styling and the beauty of the furs rather than on the tricky or novel.
The influence of plant forms on design through the centuries is shown in a diversified collection of textiles and objects that go on display today at the New York Botanical Garden.

In 1929, just before the great depression, a major league baseball club owner needed $140,000 a year for players, coaches and a manager. The total outlay for sixteen major league clubs that year was approximately $3,765,000.
Charles M. White, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, sharply attacked yesterday the Government's methods in dealing with industry.

BAYONNE, N. J., May 20 -- A "trick of his subconscious mind" may have caused the destroyer-minesweeper Hobson's skipper to order a sudden left turn -- when he really wanted to turn right -- just before the April 26 collision with the aircraft carrier Wasp, Capt. Burnham C. McCaffree of the Wasp suggested here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20 -- A militant male majority today pushed through measures to protect the equality of women -- over the protests of three of the four women members of the United Nations Human Rights Commission.

THE New Jersey anglers had no time to mourn the lost mackerel schools, for while cruising around in search of these fish they ran into large schools of bluefish, some of them scaling just short of seven pounds.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Trade interest centered largely in the May deliveries of grain today. Pit operations were generally on the choppy order but mostly the market held within narrow ranges, the process of closing out the May contracts being orderly.

Former Chief Inspector August W. Flath, who was named recently by Harry Gross as one of scores of policemen to whom he paid book-making graft, testified for four hours yesterday before the special Staten Island grand jury that is inquiring into gambling and official corruption in Richmond County.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 20 -- Brazilian authorities announced today that the sitlation at the jungle clearing where a party of Brazilian civilians had been holding a United States official and a Brazilian major as hostages to force official aid in withdrawal of the whole group had been "restored to normal."

Gambling is the principal cause of employe thievery, John J. Jackson, assistant general attorney of the Fideltity and Deposit Company of Baltimore, said yesterday at the insurance meeting of the American Management Association at the Statler Hotel. Extravagant living, family difficulties and inadequate salaries, he said, follow gambling in that order as causes of dishonesty.

A new lease was taken on life yesterday by the stock market and, in reversing the downward trend of recent sessions, prices scored the best recovery in two weeks. Some wide gains in the chemicals, which recently were under pressure, inspired a sufficient amount of buying in representative groups to lift the composite rate 0.85 point.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Although resistance has developed among some tenants to further increases in office and store rentals, peak in prices charged for commercial space throughout the country has not been reached, the National Association of Building Owners and Managers was told today.

The first real, honest-to-goodness thunderstorm of the season is a pretty fine thing. There have been thunder and lightning in the early spring -- indeed, a thunderclap was heard this year in the midst of a snow flurry -- but no one paid much attention to those preliminary mutterings.

Two cargo ships of United States registry collided early today in the Atlantic Ocean off Block Island, the Coast Guard here reported. Early reports said that neither vessel was in immediate danger, and that a Coast Guard cutter was standing by.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, May 21 (AP) -- United States Sabrejet pilots reported that they shot four Communist MIG-15's from the skies yesterday -- the first anniversary of the crowning of the first United States Air Force's jet ace.
Some time within the next thirty days a $500,000 building will be opened on the Bowery at Third Street where any alcoholic with a sincere desire for rehabilitation may go to be "dried out."

GUATEMALA, May 20 -- Officers of the National Association of Agriculturists conferred with President Jacobo Arbenz last night and offered an agrarian reform bill that they insist meets the present needs for agrarian reform and at the same time respects private property.

DETROIT, May 20 (AP) -- The new Hudson light automobile will weigh about 2,800 pounds, will have an engine developing more than 100 horsepower and will sell l in the low-price field. A.E. Barit, president of the Hudson Motor Car Company, informed stockholders today.

LONDON, May 20 (Reuters) -- Middlesex's cricket team took the lead in the county championship race today with a victory over Northamptonshire in the extra half hour of play which may be claimed to get a result.

DETROIT, May 20 (AP) -- Eugene (Silent) Hairston, 22 - year - old fighter, is rated a slight favorite over Jake La Motta, aging Bronx Bull, in their ten-round middleweight bout at Olympia Stadium tomorrow night.
ALBANY, May 20 -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Problems of the Aging, praised newspapers today for "pioneering in effective use of older workers."

UPTON, L. I., May 20 -- The first billion-volt atomic bullets ever made by man were generated today by the giant cosmotron, most powerful machine ever built to force the nucleus of the atom to yield its cosmic secrets.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 21-- Vice Admiral Charles Turner Joy, senior United Nations delegate negotiating at Panmunjom for a Korean armistice, accused the Communists today of "crass hypocrisy in their stand on the exchange of war prisoners.

The patience of union executives and their resourcefulness are no doubt strained to the utmost from time to time. The same goes for employers, or indeed for any of us trying to carry on in this frenetic world. But application of an "on-the-job" strike technique to six local department stores by District 65, Distributive, Processing and Office Workers of America, seems scarcely the best or wisest approach to union's objective.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 20 (UP) -- An atomic weapon mounted on a 300-foot tower strung with a maze of wires failed to explode in a scheduled test involving 2,000 soldies today, and surprise scientists did not know what went wrong.

WEST POINT, May 20 -- President Truman served notice on the Soviet Union today that the democracies were winning their fight against aggression. He said that United Nations intervention in Korea had brought "tremendous gains toward a world of law and order."

Fifty-four colleges have nominated 714 individual athletes for the seventy-sixth annual Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships, a final check on entries showed yesterday. The varsity classic, major spiked-shoe attraction of the Olympic year in the East, will be staged in Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island on May 30-31.
LONDON, May 20 -- A political struggle between the Conservative Government and the Labor party opposition over denationalization will open tomorrow in the House of Commons.
TOKYO, Wednesday, May 21 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 63, for Tuesday's operations:

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department said today it had filed $7,819,717 in claims against 131 warehouse men in connection with shortages of Government-owned commodities during the last five years.

Adept at coining words and phrases that sell, the advertising business also has surrounded itself with a colorful workaday language that is Greek to the uninitiated. Examples are such words as "Chinese White," "Chisel Point," "Telop" and "Whatman."

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 21 -- Armed United States troops marched into the prisoner-of-war compound at Pusan, Korea, yesterday and in a struggle with Communist captives killed one prisoner and injured eighty-five. One guard was slightly injured.

A Presbyterian meeting here was told yesterday by Representative Brooks Hays, Democrat of Arkansas, that the United States must guard against a "spiritual isolationism" in which it would seek to impose its self-will in international councils.

MADRID, May 20 -- Conversations began today between John J. McCarthy, vice president of the Motion Picture Association of America, and Spanish Government officials to find a way of implementing the United States-Spanish film agreement signed last January.

The weather dealt the deadlocked Giants and Dodgers another foul blow yesterday. An all-day downpour washed out both the scheduled night game between the Giants and Cardinals at the Polo Grounds and the afternoon contest between the Dodgers and Reds at Ebbets Field.

PARIS, May 20 -- When Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway assumes command of the North Atlantic Treaty forces at the end of this month, he will be faced with political problems of mounting intensity in the Mediterranean area, a geographical entity considered to be of paramount importance in European defense.

In his speech commemorating the 150th birthday of West Point, President Truman again summarized the foreign and military policies of the United States in a world confronted with the subversion, aggression and world-conquering amibitions of the Soviet dictators.

Calling the United Jewish Appeal a "potent force for freedom," Governor Dewey accepted yesterday the post of honorary chairman of the appeal's leadership mobilization, which recruits volunteers to help raise funds.

Jewelry and furs worth $11,200 and $900 in cash were stolen yesterday afternoon from the fourteenth floor three-room suite of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Korn in the Croydon Hotel, 12 East Eighty-sixth Street, the police reported.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 20 -- The Connecticut Republican platform drafting committee announced today its proposed 1952 state platform. It includes recommendations for increased state expenditures that would lead to a tax increase next year.

LONDON, May 20 -- Mrs. Eirene White, the champion of liberalized divorce laws, pleaded before a Royal Commission on Marriage and Divorce today for a better deal for some husbands separated from their wives.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -- The House of Representatives approved and sent to the Senate today an emergency appropriation of $55,000,000 to repair flood control projects damaged in the recent Missouri and Mississippi River floods.

The second volue om David Riesman's explorations into the minds of Americans, which he began with "The Lonely Crowd," is published today by Yale University Press. Written in colaboration with Nathan Glazer, "Faces in the Crowd" probes the lives of some of those who make up the lonely crowd, showing how they respond to political, social and personal issues.
CHICAGO, May 20 -- Johnny Sain's six-hit pitching turned back the White Sox, 4 -- 3, tonight before a crowd of 33,294.

Young family members should be taught to work together at household tasks rather than do complete jobs independently, Dr. Dorothy Lee, associate Professor of the Department of Anthropology at Vassar College, recommended last night.

Marion B. Folsom, chairman of the Committee for Economic Development and treasurer of the Eastman Kodak Company, announced yesterday the election of seven new members of the board of trustees of the committee.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 20 (AP) -- Dr. W. Allison Davis, Professor of Education at the University of Chicago, declared tonight that the schools of the United States were turning out principally Students "with crippled minds, trained only in memorization or blind, unreasoning rote-learning."

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 20 -- A move that would have threatened the position of the Rev. William Howard Melish in the Brooklyn church from which his father was ousted was turned aside here today at the eighty-fifth annual eonvention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The Apostolic Delegate to the United States announced tonight the appointment of two new Roman Catholic Bishops.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The House Un-American Activtiies Committee today asked Clifford Odets, the playwright, to explain associations with Communist-front organizations after 1935, when, he said, he had quit the Communist party.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Following is the 52-to-18 vote by which the Senate today confirmed the appointment of Federal Judge James P. McGranery of Philadelphia to be Attorney General:

A special meeting of stockholders of the St. Joseph Lead Company, the nation's largest individual producer of lead, has been called for June 16, to act on an amendment of the certificate of incorporation which would permit the extension of its activities to the petroleum and natural gas fields.

A "thank you" was formally extended yesterday to the ships and crews that sought to help the Isbrandtsen cargo liner Flying Enterprise in the fruitless struggle of Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen and his ship against the devastating effect of last winter's terrific North Atlantic storm.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Canadian Government advised the United States today that it considered the $10 a ton increase in newsprint proposed by Canadian exporters to be a legitimate price rise.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Gov. Allan Shivers of Texas predicted today that the Texas delegation to the Democratic National Convention would be uninstructed, although he personally favored the nomination of Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia for President.

A low-rent public housing project within a few blocks of Times Square was authorized yesterday when State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman approved the application of the New York City Housing Authority for a $21,825,000 state loan.

On May 20, 1946, the rescue ship Marine Flasher arrived in New York with 800 displaced persons, the vanguard of a total of 325,000 who were to find a haven in this country in the succeeding six years. Among the first arrivals was Murray Fenster, a frail 19-year-old orphan whose will to live had triumphed over the calculated cruelties of the Dachau and Auschewitz concentration camps.

" The Girl in White," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama starring June Allyson, Arthur Kennedy and Gary Merrill and based on the book, "Bowery to Bellevue," by Emily Dunning Barringer, has been scheduled to open at Loew's State on Friday, May 30. Armand Deutsch produced and John Sturges directed from a screen play by Irmgard Von Cube and Allen Vincent and an adaptation by Miss Von Cube and Philip Stevenson.

Directors of Food Fair Stores, Inc., have voted to increase the authorized indebtedness from $12,000,000 to $25,000,000 and to increase the authorized common shares to 5,000,000 from 2,500,000, Samuel Friedland, chairman, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, reported "considerable improvement" today in the production of airplanes for the military forces, but added that it was "not good enough."

Gay, inexpensive sun fashions were previewed by the press yesterday at Hearn's. Designed for the beach, the country or weekends sunning at home, the clothes will be presented to the public in a fashion show Saturday at 2 P. M. on the second floor.

The prosecution met two setbacks in the trial of the sixteen secondary Communist party leaders yesterday when Judge Edward J. Dimock in the United States District Court excluded two documents offered as evidence by the Government.

Timed for the casual type of dining that many homemakers practice in the summer is the arrival at Altman's of coordinated tableware called Raymor modern. The group is composed of ceramic dinnerware designed by Ben Seibel, glassware, black metal stands to support some of the serving dishes and table mats.
Franklin H. Wolf will join the New York buying office of Butler Brothers, Chicago, on June 2 as buyer of men's furnishings and sport clothing.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and on active months closed 7 to 19 points lower than on Monday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 20 -- Further attacks on the Government were heard today at the meeting of the National Executive Committee of the South African Trades and Labor Council, which says it represents 88,000 members.

The ability of television to enable millions of persons to share in a stimulating association with an active and original mind was vividly affirmed last Sunday afternoon in the National Broadcasting Company's half-hour interview with Bertrand Russell.

LANGHORNE, Pa., May 20 -- Because no centralized agency exists with over-all responsibility for services to mentally retarded children, facilities that would help them develop their abilities are "scattered, scanty and poorly coordinated," Miss Katharine G. Ecob said today.

The steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral were banked with blossoms yesterday as the flower mart held each year by the Outdoor Cleanliness Association opened on schedule in spite of the downpour. The committees and their aides, protected by umbrellas and raincoats, reported an unexpected number of sales.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Wage Stabilization Board declined today to make a recommendation on the issue of multiplant bargaining involving the Borg-Warner Corporation and the United Auto Workers, C. I. O.

HONG KONG, May 20 -- The decision of British concerns to close down their branches in Communist China and walk away from an investment stake estimated at $800,000,000 still left some important questions unanswered in business circles here today. These include:...

VIENNA, May 20 -- The Austrian Cabinet and Parliament unanimously objected today to the refusal of Walter J. Donnelly, United States High Commissioner, at last Friday's Allied Council meeting to approve an Austrian law for an amnesty for former Austrian Nazis repatriated as prisoners of war since 1949.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20 -- By a vote of 14 to 3, with no abstentions, members of the United Nations Economic and Social Council demonstrated today their lack of agreement with a bitter attack launched by the Soviet bloc against the United States.

LISBON, Portugal, May 20 (AP) -- Ruy Luis Gomes, a disqualified Leftist candidate in last year's Presidential election, went on trial today with three colleagues on charges of subversive propaganda activities.

LONDON, May 20 -- Abdul Fattah Amr Pasha, Egyptian Ambassador, gave Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, the Cairo Government's oral reply today to informal British proposals on ways out of the deadlock over the Sudan. Although a solution still appeared remote, British sources were pleased that the Egyptian Government appeared interested in keeping the diplomatic ball in play.

Aggregate short interest in stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange on May 15 stood at the lowest level since mid-August, 1950. The figure was 1,844,576 shares, down from 1,907,952 shares on April 15 and comparing with 1,744,353 shares on Aug. 15, 1950.

The author and publisher of a critical article on Secretary of State Dean Acheson, which was branded untrue by the State Department, asked last night for an opportunity to prove their statements in public.

Except for sales by a small percentage of retailers selling cigarettes at cut-rate or as loss leaders, sales after midnight Saturday will call for one-cent additional per package to cover the new city tax which goes into effect this weekend, trade sources said yesterday.

Morton Baum, tax attorney who is prominent in civic affairs, was designated yesterday by the Republican local organization to run for the State Senate from the Nineteenth Senatorial District, which takes in most of the West Side of Manhattan. He will run against Francis J. Mahoney, the Democratic incumbent.

GUATEMALA, May 19 -- An endless discussion goes on here among foreign observers and Guatemalans alike over whether Communists, or at least Communist ideologies, are determining the actions and the political trends of President Jacobo Arbenz's Government.
ROME, May 20 -- The growing tenseness between Italy and Yugoslavia was reflected in a sharply worded note that the Italian Minister in Belgrade delivered to the Yugoslav Government this morning.

Raymond M. Foley, Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency Administrator, reported yesterday that of 230 new projects being planned under the Housing Act of 1949, 42 per cent were for interracial occupancy on the voluntary decision of local authorities.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Three major railroad unions put off again today their answer to a White House proposal for settling their three-year dispute with the nation's railroads. They indicated they might have an answer tomorrow, and it was far from certain that they would accept.

Agrarian reform has long been overdue in Guatemala as in many Latin-American countries. It is a recognized feature of our times that in promoting social justice there should be a relatively fair distribution of the land. Vast holdings, or latifundia as they are called in Europe and Latin America, are now generally considered a social evil.
LONDON, May 20 (AP) -- The American challengers in the British women's golf championship next month will lose at least one Curtis Cup player in the first round.

The committee investigating Senator Benton's charge that his colleague Mr. McCarthy is unfit to hold office as a Senator has been hearing testimony recently on the Lustron case. The former president of the now defunct corporation, which manufactured prefabricated housing, has stated that Mr. McCarthy asked and received $10,000 from Lustron in 1948 for an article that formed part of a pamphlet used by the company for advertising purposes.

The Aluminum Company of America will unveil at its plant in Cleveland today a 15,000-ton forge press made in Germany during World War II and recently leased from the United States Air Force. The giant press, constructed by the Schloemann Company of Duesseldorf for use in Germany's wartime light alloy industry, will make it possible for Alcoa to produce large aluminum and magnesium forgings for aircraft faster and more economically than before, the company said.
In his letter appearing in your issue of May 11 Oliver La Farge weakens his case for aid to the Navajo Indians by repetitive overstatement.
NEW CITY, N. Y., May 20 -- The body found in a swamp off Route 9W last Sunday was identified here today as that of Sydney Selwyn of Brooklyn, a well-to-do business man who disappeared Feb. 27.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -- Ellis Arnall, Price Stabilizer, said tonight there were "widespread" signs that prices were rising again and urged Congress to pass a strong controls law to replace the expiring Defense Production Act.
TRENTON, May 20 -- A new system of revoking licenses of New Jersey motorists who repeatedly commit traffic violations was announced tonight by Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons.

The increasing size of television screens may induce eye strain, the television committee of the New York State Optometric Association reported yesterday at the close of the organization's three-day annual convention.

Mrs. Eleanor H. Nave, a children's librarian who, through more than three decades, has been a source of comfort and help to thousands of youngsters, is retiring from her New York Public Library post at the end of this month.

LONDON, May 21 -- In the first round of the battle to restore the property of a nationalized industry to private ownership Prime Minister Churchill's Conservative Government won a political victory in the House of Commons tonight on its proposal to return trucking to private hands.

The earnings of the Sinclair Oil Corporation for the 'second quarter of this year will be augmented by a substantial non-recurring profit which should offset any decline in operating net income resulting from the strike, P. C. Spencer, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday.
You're lucky. You're healthy. Your eyes see, your legs work, and your arms do, too. But there is a man whose eyes can't see, whose legs don't work or his arms, maybe.

LONDON, May 21 -- Prices fell fairly widely throughout the stock markets here today under the lead of British Government securities. British funds opened slightly lower on consideration of the nation's trade returns for April and weakened later on rumors of an early further increase in the bank rate.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21 -- A new United Nations treaty was brought into operation today under which willing governments would put aside all import duties on books, newspapers, educational films, newsreels and art objects as well as on scientific instruments for laboratories and a long list of other materials used by schools or libraries.

DETROIT, May 21 (AP) -- Jake LaMotta, the aging Bronx warrior bent on a comeback, made his late-round bull rushes pay off tonight to win a unanimous ten-round decision over young Gene (Silent) Hairston before an estimated crowd of 10,000 at Olympia Stadium.

LONDON, May 21 (AP) -- A record field of thirty-nine 3-year-olds appeared likely today to start in the 173d running of the Epsom Derby next Wednesday, with Silnet, a French horse, favored to win the greatest of all British racing classics.

Events today: Composers' Concert, Carl Fischer Building, 5 P. M.; Women's Choral Ensemble of the New York Association for the Blind, The Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, 8:15; Langston Hughes, poet. Margaret Bonds, pianist, and Daniel Andrews, baritone, "An Evening of Music and Poetry in Negro Life," Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, 8:15.

The date of sale of $10,722,000 of state-guaranteed bonds of ten Massachusetts housing authorities has been changed from June 3 to May 28. The borrowings will be: Everett, $3,082,000; Somerville, $2,258,000; Cambridge, $1,568,000; North Adams, $909,000; Haverhill, $809,000; Boston, $839,000; Beverly, $466,000; Athel, $406,000; North Attleboro, $245,000; Agaway, $140,000.
THE increasing interest in light-tackle fsihing became more apparent than ever during the past few days, resulting from a brief discussion of "cotton thread" fishing in one of last week's columns.

After a study of racial and religious bigotry in the United States covering the last eighteen months, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith said yesterday that Americans "find themselves accepting hysterical unproved denunciations with less and less repugnance."

DETROIT, May 21 (AP) -- Virgil Trucks, nervously intent on pitching his second straight no-hit game, ran his hitless string to fifteen and two-thirds innings for the Tigers today. Then Billy Hitchcock of the Athletics spoiled it with a one-out single in the seventh inning.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, May 21 -- The Egyptian Foreign Minister, Abdel Khalik Hassouna Pasha, said in this Egyptian summer capital today that Egypt had not presented counter-proposals to the British Government in regard to settlement of the Sudan question.

Your "Topics of The Times" on starlings betrays, I regret to note, the prejudice of ignorance, or perhaps I should say the ignorance of prejudice. Starlings may be pests in cities -- although in my opinion the people that plaster Corinthian capitals and other such curvaceous "decorations" on the exterior of new buildings deserve a fate even worse than starlings.

SAN SALVADOR, May 21 -- With good crops and coffee prices still booming, El Salvador, the smallest of the Central American republics, is enjoying the kind of economic prosperity and political stability that Washington would like to see throughout this region.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (AP) -- Robin Roberts gained his seventh victory as the Phillies turned back the Pirates, 7 -- 3, at Shibe Park tonight. Roberts hasn't lost a decision since the Phillies' 1952 opener.

To stimulate greater interest in apple products such as canned sauce and slices, bottled juice and cider, the Processed Apples Institute was luncheon host yesterday at the Park Lane Hotel to a group of food editors and radio and television commentators.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 -- Cary Grant and Deborah Kerr will have the co-starring roles in M-G-M's "Dream Wife," a fable of a man who visions an ideal mate in his dreams and then falls in love with a woman of a vastly different sort.

DAYTON, Ohio, May 21 (AP) -- Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. White got married twenty-five years ago after they had saved a modest amount. They decided they would live frugally and save something for their old age.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Copper importers today were authorized to pay higher prices for the metal and to reflect 80 per cent of increased costs in their selling prices to domestic users.

Refrigerator manufacturers are beginning to look less like pall bearers. Yesterday General Electric reported that the recent reduction in factory refrigerator inventories will eliminate the necessity for a previously announced shutdown of the Erie, Pa. refrigerator plant for the week beginning June 9. W. A. Timmerman, general manager of the household refrigerator department, said the plant will run at 50 per cent of capacity during the week.

What to do about women is a question that hasn't troubled most national advertisers for years. They know that women play an important part in the "buy side" of the market for thousands of household items. Consequently, advertisers have wooed them extensively in connection with dual - purchase items ranging from carpets to cars.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended May 14:
American Airlines, after a month's intensive campaign, gave details yesterday of results of its efforts to promote the regular shipment of apparel by air freight.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- During the current litigation over the President's seizure of the steel industry the argument was stressed that, if he found the Taft-Hartley Act an imperfect instrument to keep steel production going, he could have used other statutory authority for his action instead of proceeding without citing any and thereby precipitating a critical issue of constitutionality upon the Supreme Court.
LONDON, May 21 (AP) -- Britain's film industry faces quick collapse unless, it gets continued Government aid, a report to the industry said today.
Another box lunch fashion show was presented at Saks-Thirty-fourth Street yesterday, when vacation clothes were featured.

The New Symphony Orchestra of New York, under the direction of Maurice Bonney, made its appearance last evening at the auditorium of the Central High School of Needle Trades. The all-Beethoven program, commemorating the 125th anniversary of the composer's death, which occurred in March, 1827, listed the "Egmont" Overture, the Rondino in E flat for Eight Wind Instruments, and the Ninth Symphony.

PARIS, May 21 -- There are increasing signs that the French Government, under pressure from at home and abroad to reach a settlement with the Arab nationalists in the strategic North African protectorate of Tunisia, is considering an offer of new concessions on home rule as a conciliatory move.
BELGRADE. Yugoslavia, May 21 -- Italian-Yugoslav relations have fallen to the acrimonious level of the relations between the West and Eastern European Governments.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 21 -- Dave Sisler blanked Pennsylvania with a masterful two-hitter and Princeton collected six hits to register a 2-0 victory today on University Field in the Eastern Baseball League's final for both teams.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Following is the 51-to-27 vote by which the Senate defeated today a more liberal substitute for the immigration and naturalization bill of Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada:

BERLIN, Thursday, May 22 -- The imminent signature of a contractual agreement between West Germany and the Western Allies will bring Germany "to the brink of civil war and of a new third world war," Otto Grotewohl, East German Premier said last night.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Govs. Thomas E. Dewey of New York and Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey joined four former governors today in defense of the Port of New York Authority against attacks by Jersey City officials.

The Giants and Cardinals, with Eddie Stanky making his formal bow at the Polo Grounds as skipper of the Redbirds, spent a long day and night under the lee of Coogan's Bluff yesterday without either party enhancing its prospects.

The railroad issues kept the stock market on the upgrade yesterday. Extending Tuesday's gains, the list managed a further rise of 0.47 point, although the steels continued to lag and mixed changes occurred in many of the main trading units.
DENVER, May 21 (AP) -- Three weeks after it began, the nation's oil strike was "slowly but surely approaching settlement," in the words of a union spokesman, but the rate of progress today was slow.

LOS ANGELES, May 21 -- A report of a big plane's crash sent ambulances, fire trucks and stretcher bearers into rugged mountain country above the San Fernando Valley today, but it all turned out to be an optical illusion.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (UP) -- Three professional football teams today signed television agreements blacking out all 1952 home games -- a move the Government charged violates the anti-trust laws.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 21 --Two unions were enjoined here today from continuing "coercive" picketing of the Metropolis Country Club of Greenburgh. Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis issued the injunction on a plea by the club that its employes were not seeking unionization and that the purpose of the picketing was to intimidate the club into leading the employes into unions.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The curtain was pulled aside for a brief preview today of the part the farm program will play in the 1952 political campaign as the Senate Agriculture Committee questioned Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, regarding the conduct of his department.

Reduction of trade barriers among the free nations and recognition of the damaging effects of those already imposed or being sought against imports in this country was urged yesterday as essential in winning the economic struggle with communism.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 21 -- The United States and its European Allies have embarked upon "an age of inflation," which they must accept and attempt to hold within limits as part of the price for the cold war against communism, the American Assembly was told today.

A program to enroll "senior citizens" over 60 years old in New York's civil defense organization was started yesterday when ninety-six men and women members of Welfare Department day centers for the aged were inducted as civil defense volunteers.

Early expansion of imports by Belgium of materials and equipment from the United States was indicated yesterday with announcement of a $50,000,000 loan to that kingdom through the Export-Import Bank of Washington. The credit with thirty-two commercial banks throughout the United States providing $45,000,000 of the total, involved the largest number of commercial banks participating in any Export-Import Bank loan.

The city's Bureau of Smoke Control won a major legal victory yesterday when the Appellate Division ruled that the bureau had the power to go into the Magistrates' Courts and get summonses issued directly against violators of the anti-smoke ordinances.
CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Truman lashed out at Congress again tonight for cutting funds for Administration programs, and denounced the American Medical Association for what he termed influencing the House to defeat the Social Security bill on Monday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 21 (UP) -- President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla announced the settlement of the three-week-old impasse between the United States and Chile over the price of copper in his annual message to Congress today. In a last minute addition to his annual message, President Gonzalez said: "The United States has agreed to modify its price control for sales of the metal.
An 18-year-old German boy who feared induction into the Polish Army arrived in the United States yesterday, a stowaway aboard a Pan American World Airways plane.

TRENTON, May 21 -- Among several new laws signed by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today was one requiring a railroad to erect signs to warn train engineers approaching temporary run-around tracks at reconstruction sites.

Most of the current trends in textile printing are represented in the new collection of fabric designs introduced here by Isabel Scott, 17 East Fifty-third Street, and available from that showroom through decorators.

MUNSAN, Korea, Thursday, May 22 -- Vice Admiral Charles Turner Joy, in his farewell statement as chief Allied truce delegate, told the Reds today "there is nothing left to negotiate -- the decision is in your hands."

NEW DELHI, India -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared in the Council of States, or upper house of Parliament today that it was a matter of "deep regret" to him that the truce negotiations in Korea should have become deadlocked on the single issue of the exchange of prisoners.

The steel industry expects its ingot production to continue at, or very close to, full capacity through the third quarter of the year, but looks for a moderate drop in the operating rate in the last three months.
George M. Weiss, Yankee general manager, conferred with Frank Lane of the Sox before the struggle, but if anything developed it was top secret.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- Some members of Congress demanded today that the United States take "retaliatory action" against Canada through the Trade Agreements Program because of an "outrageous" $10-a-ton price increase in Canadian newsprint.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 21 (AP) -- The State Supreme Court today refused to grant a petition by the Eisenhower faction of the Texas Republican party to nullify six walkout county conventions held by Taft forces.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 21 -- Michael Orecchio, former chief of detectives of Bergen County, was sentenced to two to three years in State Prison today on three counts of misconduct for failure to suppress gambling in the county.

In refusing to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company the rent rises to which it is entitled in Stuyvesant Town the Board of Estimate and the City Council fail to honor the city's contract. They act politically: there is one landlord and there are about 25,000 residents, many of whom are voters.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 21 (AP) -- A floppy eared, bug-eyed jackass is fast supplanting the familiar figure of Uncle Sam in Iran as the symbol of the United States.

A doctors' committee agreed yesterday to "go along" with State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman's pioneer plan for full-scale medical centers in state-aided housing projects, after hearing him pledge that the private physician would control each center through medical organizations.

BONN, Germany, May 21 -- The Western Allies are not going to wait for the West German Government to break up the Central Coal Sales Agency, the big coal dispensing cartel, but are issuing a regulation to be published soon that will have the same effect.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The three-year-old railroad labor dispute came to an end at the White House tonight.

An underwriting syndicate headed by White, Weld Co., will place on the market today $18,000,000 of 31/4 per cent sinking fund debentures of National Fuel Gas Company, a holding company directing the distribution of both natural and mixed gas in western Pennsylvania, western New York, eastern Ohio and part of Ontario, Canada.
PARIS, May 21 (AP) -- Premier Antoine Pinay pinned the Medaille Militaire on General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today, then kissed him farewell in the name of France.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., May 21 (AP) -- The head of F. W. Woolworth Company called today for "sober consideration" on the question of how much of a tax burden "our economy can shoulder without faltering or breaking down." A. L. Cornwell, president and chairman of the board, spoke at the annual meeting of Woolworth stockholders.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A majority of fifty leading political writers polled by Newsweek magazine believes that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will be selected as the Republican Presidential candidate and Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois as the Democratic standard bearer.

Brazil's draft indebtedness rose $17,900,000 last month to a new high of $160,600,000, according to the monthly report on Latin American export credit, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For Latin American countries other than Brazil the report showed aggregate draft payments rose only 0.4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Truman paid a tribute today to the men who guard him. At a dedication of a bronze tablet honoring Pvt. Leslie Coffelt of the White House police, who was killed during the attempted assassination of the President Nov. 1, 1950, Mr. Truman said:

The Anaconda Copper Mining Company, and subsidiaries, world's leading producer of copper and largest fabricator of copper products, had a net income in the first quarter this year of $11,050,014, compared with $12,166,605 earned in the initial three months last year, according to preliminary figures reported yesterday.

Herve Bazin's second novel to be published in this country has been scheduled by Prentice-Hall for June 2 issuance under the title "Head Against the Wall." It is a story about a man's revolt against his reactionary family and social institutions.

A friendly, cooperative relationship between home and school is an important factor in the discipline of children, Dr. Roma Gans, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared last night. Dr. Gans discussed discipline in relation to the home, the school and to personal relationships before the Parent-Teacher Association of the West Side Branch of the Bentley School, 48 West Eighty-sixth Street.
GENEVA, May 21 -- Some progress, although United States officials think not enough, is being made in Western Europe toward a more strenuous form of competition among business enterprises.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 21 -- Rehearsals will begin tomorrow for "The Singing Girl," first of the operettas to be presented in the County Center by the Shubert interests of New York. The musical, scheduled to open June 3, is a new vehicle that will receive a week's tryout here and be taken to Broadway in the autumn, the Shuberts said.

GLEN COVE, L. I., May 21 -- The Roman Catholic Order of the Sisters of St. John the Baptist of 3304 Waterbury Avenue, the Bronx, has offered to purchase, for an undisclosed sum, the fifty- seven-room mansion on East Island that was the home of the late J. P. Morgan, it was learned here today.

LONDON, May 21 (Reuters) -- A couple of flashing centuries by the opening batsmen, Eric Bedser and David Fletcher, today gave Surrey a formidable score in the first day of its league match against Essex.
PARIS, May 21 (AP) -- Top-seeded Frank Sedgman of Australia led the way into the third round of the French international tennis championships today, but he had strong American company.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson will leave for Europe soon, perhaps tomorrow, to sign two agreements bringing West Germany into the Western community and to discuss that and other important issues with the British and French Foreign Ministers.

LONDON, May 21 -- For the third time in ten days questions criticizing the use of napalm bombs or jellied gasoline by United Nations forces in Korea were asked in the House of Commous today. Nigel Birch, Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Defense, replied that the bombs were being used against military targets and he thought with much greater care now than last winter.

Ferdinand Smith, a Communist and former maritime labor leader who left the United States voluntarily last August after having been ordered deported, returned yesterday as an airline passenger on his way from the West Indies to London.

Prime Minister Nehru was not being helpful yesterday in vaguely and uselessly suggesting that both sides take "one big step" in the Korean truce negotiations to solve the prisoner exchange dispute. He added the perfectly obvious point that a successful conclusion of the talks would "give a tremendous feeling of relief to common people all over the world."

Now that the Defense Department has issued an order calling for the drafting of 610,000 men beginning July 1 the youths of our country who fall into the 19-26-year-old age category and have yet to don khaki, blue or olive drab find themselves in the precarious position of having but a few short weeks left in which to enjoy the comparative bliss of civilian life.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, accused two Government agencies today of "using foreign aid funds to manipulate American markets to the great detriment of our farmers."

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (UP) -- The return title bout between Heavyweight Champion Jersey Joe Walcott and Ezzard Charles on June 5 will be televised and broadcast throughout the nation, but Philadelphia and a seventy-five mile surrounding area will be blacked out.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- President Truman nominated three high military officers to new posts today.
Here's how the Dodgers scored their fifteen runs against the Reds in the first inning at Ebbets Field last night:
Frieda Hempel's dog Brownie died of old age yesterday.

ALBANY, May 21 (AP) -- Two separate wage strikes by bus drivers today gave 2,000 school pupils an unexpected holiday and left thousands of commuters stranded in the suburban East Greenbush-Nassau area here.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Senate, by a vote of 51 to 27, rejected today a substitute for the controversial McCarran bill, which is designed to overhaul and codify the hundreds of immigration, deportation and naturalization laws that have piled up through generations.

The article on spelling bees in your May 9 issue under "Topics of The Times" was most interesting and timely, particularly the sentence in the last paragraph which reads "there is no real expert when it comes to spelling."

ASBURY PARK, N. J., May 21 -- A resolution condemning the activities of the "American Medical Association and the organized medical profession for seeking by misinterpretation and misdirection to destroy legislation for national health insurance" was adopted at the seventy-fourth annual convention of the New Jersey Federation of Labor, A. F. L., here today.

Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the Department of Trusteeship for the United Nations, received in absentia yesterday the first City College Human Relations Award at the college's 105th Charter Day ceremonies. Dr. Bunche was confined to his home with a spinal ailment.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest public utility enterprise, made known yesterday plans to raise more than $58,000,000 through the sale of debentures and common stock within the next month.

W. F. Williamson, formerly executive vice president of the National Coffee Association, has been elected president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, it was announced yesterday at the annual board meeting of the hosiery group.

Supreme Court Justice Ernest E, L. Hammer reserved decision yesterday on a petition of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for a court order requiring the Board of Estimate to approve a rent increase of $7.87 a room a month for its Stuyvesant Town development.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 14 to 20 points net lower than on Tuesday, when there also was a drop.

Party politics would be less corrupt if more citizens voted and participated in local political activities, a panel of high school students agreed yesterday on a New York Times Youth Forum at the Bishop Loughlin High School in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway reported here today that there had been a "significant" build-up of the Soviet Union's Far Eastern military strength behind the heavily augmented Chinese and North Korean Communist forces battling the United Nations.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 21 (UP) -- Emil Rieve, president of the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., today suspended thirty-five officials of eleven union locals in Rhode Island and Massachusetts in an attempt to halt a bolt to the American Federation of Labor.
CHICAGO, May 21 -- Churchgoers in the United States were urged tonight to combat with all their power the "spreading growth" of isolationism within this country.

If the hard-pressed members of the United States Senate would only take time to familiarize themselves with the details of Mr. McCarran's massive anti-immigration bill it is difficult to believe that they would accept it in its present form, or even in the slightly better version that has already swept through the House.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Army Chief of Staff, said today the United States had scheduled ammunition deliveries to sustain "violent combat in Korea, if it recurs." In a letter to the Senate Preparedness subcommittee, he amplified recent testimony before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee that disclosed that some types of ammunition had been rationed on the Korean firing line.

CLEVELAND, May 21 (AP) -- Early Wynn and Mike Garcia proved too much for the Red Sox tonight and the Indians won the opener of their two-game series, 5 -- 1. Wynn, credited with his fifth victory, was rescued by Garcia in the eighth.

PARIS, May 21 -- A breakdown in the time table for the integration of West Germany into the Western defense system came when the foreign ministers of six European nations failed to reach the agreement they had planned for today on a treaty to create a European Defense Community with a single force.

JERSEY CITY, May 21 -- Long lines of trucks rumbled defiantly along the Pulaski Skyway today. They rumbled past the Jersey City police who for fifteen years have barred them from the use of the roadway. And there didn't seem to be a thing that the police could do about it.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Bern Hetlelid of Brooklyn, a deckhand on the F. L. Hayes, testified today that the tanker answered at least one of the warning blasts from the whistle of the Barbara Lykes, a freighter, just before they were in a crash last Thursday.

LOU BOUDREAU announced in Florida last March that he intended to start his veterans and switch to a rookie line-up only if his experienced hired hands indicated that they were incapable of winning a pennant. Then he'd sink or swim with the youngsters. But Lou became so enamored with his bobby soxers that he reversed the procedure.

BONN, Germany, May 21 -- Prof. Franz Boehm of Frankfurt University decided today temporarily to withhold his resignation as head of the West German delegation negotiating restitutions to Israel after Chancellor Konrad Adenauer had promised him that the Federal Government would present a concrete offer to transmit to the Israeli delegation before June 19.

ALBANY, May 21 -- The creation of the "Safe Drivers of America," an organization aimed at reducing highway accidents, lowering automobile insurance rates and "driving the careless motorists from the roads," was announced today by Clifford J. Fletcher, former Motor Vehicle Commissioner, and six other state officials.

The Department of Health reported yesterday that it was carrying out experiments to determine the effectiveness of the new anti-tuberculosis drugs in reducing the danger infection from afflicted of persons who are not hospitalized.

Belmont Park's Widener chute has its knockers, but at the moment the three owners of the Harborvale Stable undoubtedly are of the opinion that it's the finest racing strip in the land -- even though hardly anyone besides the jockeys knows what's happening when the horses are in another county up at the start.

The courtyard of the Marguery Hotel was transformed last night into a combined country fair and political rallying ground with the help of 4,000 boosters for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower. The event was staged by the New York Chapter of Youth for Eisenhower to help finance its activities.

TOKYO, Thursday, May 22 -- Communist armistice delegates of Panmunjom yesterday lodged a strong official protest against the suppression by United States infantrymen of a sitdown strike by enemy prisoners at Pusan Tuesday in which the captives, who had been serving as hospital attendants, impeded the treatment of prisoner patients.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption for the period March 30 to May 3 averaged 33,898 bales for each working day. This compared with an average 39,936 bales for the corresponding period a year ago, and with 36,827 for the March period this year.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- Lillian Hellman, stage and screen writer, refused to say today whether she ever had belonged to the Communist party because her testimony "would hurt innocent people in order to save myself."

WOODSTOCK, Conn., May 21 -- Standing in a flowering apple orchard atop a 700-foot hill in the northeast corner of Connecticut is a small one-room red brick schoolhouse that the residents of this secluded Windham County community believe is the oldest of its kind in the country.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Final prices for the expiring May deliveries of wheat and soybeans were much higher today. May corn sold off to the lowest price in several weeks and May oats were pressed down to a new low on the crop.
Prices in the commodity futures markets were mixed yesterday. Hides and coffee rose. Tin, sugar and wool edged lower. Rubber, cocoa and vegetable oils were irregular.

MANILA, May 21 -- The Philippine Senate began today the discussion of ratification of the Japanese peace treaty by consideration of a resolution declaring the state of war with Japan at an end and asking that the Philippines conduct her own negotiations with Japan to obtain a more favorable settlement than the treaty offers.
An "amateur" burglar, apparently unskilled in the refinements of his craft, took jewelry valued at $24,750 from a fourteenth-floor suite of the Plaza Hotel, it was reported yesterday by the police.

LONDON, May 21 -- Prime Minister Churchill assured Emrys Hughes, a pacifist member of the Labor Opposition in Parliament, today that there was little wild life on the Monte Bello Islands in Australia, where Britain plans to conduct tests of atomic weapons.

Your summary report in the May 11 Review of the Week on "New Deadlock -- Over Truce in Korea" forcibly reveals the magnitude of the one remaining obstacle to a truce. In this instance it is a step toward solution to know that no opening is to be found by continuing on the present path.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Television cut sharply into the advance sales of tickets for football games, the New York Giants said today in an answer to the Government's anti-trust suit against the National Football League and its teams.
Printed fabrics in motifs associated with the cooler aspects of summer may help to give a fresh look indoors in the warm weather.

Johnny Bratton, Chicago welterweight, and Del Flanagan, St. Paul scrapper, yesterday completed training for their main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. Both are in fine physical condition.
A proposed local law that would fine parents $25 for vandalism by their children against city property came under heavy fire yesterday at a City Council committee hearing.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 21 -- "There will be a need for civil defense until the basic differences between the United States and the Soviet Union are solved," delegates to the fifty-sixth annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers were told here today.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 21 -- The Sons of the American Revolution, by a resolution adopted today reaffirmed its stand against this country's joining any form of world government, Atlantic Union or "other federal union of super-government."
A short movie that soon will be seen by theatregoers all across the country was shown yesterday for a group of business, industrial and theatrical leaders.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee approved by a voice vote today an extension of the Defense Production Act certain to meet with the powerful opposition of organized labor.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., May 21 -- A warning that national unity may be endangered and religious intolerance encouraged if religion is introduced into the public schools was sounded here tonight by Dr. Hollis L. Caswell, dean of Teachers College, Columbia University.
The accepted designation for the principal regions of the Orient is, as Harold Isaacs pointed out in his recent letter to THE TIMES, confused and contradictory.

The British production team of Herbert Wilcox and Anna Neagle will produce a series of Technicolor films for world distribution by Republic Pictures, it was announced yesterday by the producers and Herbert J. Yates, president of Republic Pictures Corporation, at a luncheon held at the "21" Club.

As Federal and city authorities intensified their drives against black marketeers in potatoes, purchasing agencies for municipal and private institutions reported yesterday that they were in danger of running out of the precious spuds.

Two men, one of whom was formerly an armored car guard, were arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and charged with the $100,000 armed robbery on March 7 of the Quonset Point Naval Station Credit Union in Rhode Island.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 21 -- The retirement of Dr. Peter Debye, professor of chemistry at Cornell University and Nobel Prize winner, was announced today by Deane W. Malott, president of the university.

PARIS, May 21 -- The Belgians have taken a strong stand in favor of a settlement in cash of their surplus credit in the European Payments Union. They assume, according to those in the negotiation, that the United States should provide the dollars for such a payment; and they contend that they will be unable to fulfill their rearmament commitment to the North Atlantic Council unless they recover the dollars due them from the union.

HARTFORD, May 21 -- Turmoil broke out among Connecticut Republicans today as Gov. John Davis Lodge sought, for undisclosed reasons, to oust William H. Brennan of Stamford, Fairfield County party leader, as National Committeeman and to prevent him from being named as a delegate at large to the Republican National Convention.

The Dodgers set six modern major league records in the process of scoring fifteen times in the first inning against the Reds last night. From this sizzling take-off, the Brooks rocketed to a 19-1 triumph that boosted them into undisputed possession of first place.
TOKYO, Thursday, May 22 (AP) -- Eighth Army tactical summary 64, for Wednesday's activities:

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that United States aid to friendly governments could be reduced if those countries were enabled to sell more of their goods to this country.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21 -- In a minority report supplementing that submitted to the United Nations Trusteeship Council by the Advisory Council on Somaliland, Victoria D. Carpio of the Philippines expressed vigorous criticism of Italian administration in that trust territory.
TOKYO, Thursday, May 22 -- Uneasy quiet rested today over the United Nations stockades in South Korea where Communist prisoners of the Korean war had staged a series of riots.

NEWARK, May 21 -- The Newark judge who refused to ban the film "Latuko," dealing with life in an African tribe, "does not venture forth from his ivory tower frequently enough to come into contact with today's law enforcement problems," according to Public Safety Director John B. Keenan of Newark.
The proposed merger of the Manufacturers Trust Company and the New York Trust Company, announced last week, has been canceled for the lack of "enthusiastic support" of New York Trust stockholders.
BOSTON, May 21 -- The International Jewelry Workers Union, A. F. L., which has been under fire for allegedly tolerating racketeers within its ranks, pledged itself today to oust "corrupt elements."

Traveling aboard a baggage car especially rigged to accommodate their iron lungs, two young polio victoms, both ardent baseball fans, left Grand Central Terminal at 11:30 o'clock last night for Buffalo, where they will undergo respirator rehabilitation treatment at the Chronic Disease and Research Institute.

A comment made Sunday by Governor Dewey on the state's responsibilty to children was pointed out by Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy yesterday as a springboard for Day Care Council members in continuing their efforts to obtain state aid for the centers.

ST. LOUIS, May 21 (AP) -- Sid Hudson walked Bobby Young with the bases loaded in the last of the tenth inning tonight to give the Browns a 2-1 victory over the Senators. The triumph, credited to Satchel Paige, relief pitcher, broke a string of four consecutive losses to Washington by the St. Louis club.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21 -- Over vehement protests from the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and Poland, admission of Spain to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization was approved today by the Economic and Social Council, 12 votes to 5, with one abstention, Libya and Nepal were endorsed by acclamation.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 21 -- A $20,000,000 former luxury liner, designed for round-the-world cruises, was accepted by the Navy today as a military transport. In ceremonies at the New York Shipbuilding Company yards here, the U. S. N. S. Barrett was formally accepted by the Navy for use as a troopship.
TRENTON, May 21 -- Investigators of New Jersey's prisons and state institution officials agreed today the parole system needed revision to eliminate inequities.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- Brig. Gen. Harold L. Maddux said today that the Air Force was "alarmed" by the growing opposition of community groups to the construction of urgently needed air bases.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 21 -- The United States Embassy still was trying tonight to get definite news of the whereabouts and the condition of Scott Magness, the United States Civil Aeronautics Authority official who reportedly has been held in the Amazon jungle as a hostage since Sunday.
