Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations, applauded last night the extension of human rights and democracy by United Jewish Appeal agencies.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- W. Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, belabored Congress today for considering a cut of $1,000,000,000 in foreign aid and for showing a "strange intolerance" when other countries thought and acted differently from what we did.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark, N. J., applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to market $40,000,000 worth of debenture bonds due June 1, 1972, to be offered for public sale at competitive bidding.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The House of Representatives began debate today on a $6,901,100,000 Mutual Security authorization with chances of preventing further heavy cuts enhanced by a split between supporters of the chief contenders for the Republican Presidential nomination.

John Garfield, stage and screen actor noted for his portrayal of tough characters, died of a heart ailment in the apartment of a friend, Miss Iris Whitney, at 3 Gramercy Park yesterday morning. He was 39 years old.

STRASBOURG, France, May 21 -- Strenuous efforts to rescue the plans for European unity and for the European Defense Community will be made at a foreign ministers' meeting starting tomorrow and at the succeeding short session of the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 -- The Matson Navigation Company's liner Lurline, kept at her pier here since May 12 by a union controversy, now is scheduled to depart for Los Angeles tomorrow afternoon to pick up a full load of passengers for Honolulu.

The General Assembly, supreme governing body of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., will open its 164th annual meeting this morning in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, the first such gathering to be held in this city for half a century.

WE who must live all our lives under the dark shadow of our century's permanent crisis can approach an understanding of it only if we recognize two momentous and horrid truths. One is about the nature of the conflict now being waged between the beleaguered and disunited forces of civilization and the hosts of darkness; the other is about the nature of men themselves.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- The Defense Department today announced a new total of 108,707 American battle casualties in Korea, an increase of 294 over last week's report.

THOMPSONVILLE, Conn., May 21 -- Rather than have all the $70,000 in the local's treasury fall into the hands of the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., the 2,500 textile workers who made up the membership of Local 2188 but who seceded from the parent organization last week, have donated $58,000 for the construction of a hospital here and also have contributed another $1,000 for the maintenance of an ambulance.

TIEL, the Netherlands, May 21 -- The largest inland navigation lock in the world and a new stretch of canal linking the heavy river traffic of inland Europe with the North Sea -- a new mouth for the Rhine River -- were opened here today by Queen Juliana.
PITTSBURGH, May 21 (AP) -- Three civic groups in near-by McKeesport today called a portion of Milton Berle's coast-to-coast television program "monumental bad taste."
The editorial in THE TIMES of May 19 on the passport case of Dr. Pauling concludes: "In fact, the whole passport situation needs looking into."

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Out of patience with the run paucity that has beset him since the season started, Allie Reynolds went into production on his own today at Comiskey Park. He coupled solid pitching and timely batting to help the Yankees score a 5-1 victory over the White Sox before 7,841 fans.

Thomas F. Reilly, a civil engineer who was a lieutenant commander in the Navy in World War II, was appointed Commissioner of Borough Works yesterday by Borough President Cornelius Hall of Richmond. The post pays $10,000 a year.

SEOUL, Thursday, May 22 (AP) -- Allied tank guns of the Fortieth Division and other units went into action along twenty miles of the central Korean front Wednesday in one of the heaviest sustained tank firings of the year.

The trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders was interrupted for more than an hour and a half yesterday when Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock and counsel for both sides held a closed session in the judge's chambers in the United States Court House in Foley Square.

The observance of National Maritime Day, which gives the American merchant marine its annual brief moment in the spotlight, opened here last night. Today, in ceremonies in the nation, the fleet's economic and security importance will be emphasized.

TIEL, the Netherlands, May 1 -- Seventeen years in construction the new waterway will bring Amsterdam much closer to the Rhine River ports of Germany, France and Switzerland, making it their nearest approach and giving Amsterdam a new advantage in its age-old rivalry with Rotterdam and Antwerp for the coveted river traffic.

Scoring fifteen runs in the first inning, the Brooklyn Dodgers set six modern major league records while crushing the Cincinnati Reds, 19 -- 1, at Ebbets Field last night. The Dodgers sent twenty-one batters to the plate in that inning and scored twelve of their runs after two were out.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21 -- The Vatican's representative in the United States praised the "untiring efforts" of the United Nations today and said the world turned to the organization with "ardent hope."

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 21 -- A small piece of chromium found at the scene of a hit-run auto accident that on Sunday cost the life of John R. Gamble, 50 years old, of 1000 Sheridan Avenue, led today to the arrest of a suspect after painstaking work by five detectives.
The United States Curtis Cup team of women golfers left yesterday aboard the Cunard liner Britannic for the international matches with the British players, June 6 and 7 at Muirfield, Scotland.

BONN, Germany, Thursday, May 22 -- The basic principles for the division of West Germany's defense contribution were virtually settled by the Federal Government and the Allied High Commission last night and with the elimination of this final barrier to a contractual agreement the long and involved negotiations establishing the Federal Republic as a partner in Western Europe neared their end.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 21 (UP) -- Woodruff Randolph of this city ran for his fifth term as president of the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., today in the union's regular biennial election. Mr. Randolph was opposed by C. G. Sparkman of Detroit, whom he defeated in the last election two years ago by 7,500 votes.

Posses whooped and hollered through dense woods and in deep old Indian shelters on and around Limekiln Mountain yesterday from dawn to late afternoon, calling in vain for Ramsey Conklin, last of the Ramapo Mountaineers.
BOSTON, Mass., May 21 -- The American Federation of Labor decided today to concentrate much of its political energy in the next two months on primary fights against three incumbent senators.

TRIESTE, May 21 -- The campaign for the municipal elections, which will take place in the city of Trieste and five other municipalities composing Zone A of the Trieste Free Territory at the same time as the provincial and municipal elections in Central and Southern Italy, is drawing toward a climactic close on Friday.

ALBANY, May 21 (AP) -- The State University of New York has bought a mansion here for $68,000 as a home for its president. Dr. William S. Carlson, who took office April 1, is expected to move into the house about Aug. 1.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Federal District Judge James P. McGranery, who was confirmed yesterday as Attorney General, said after a visit to President Truman today that he would not have given up his life tenure in the judiciary if he had not believed he could clean up corruption in Government.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- A 28-year-old first grade teacher received congratulations today from President Truman for her selection as "Teacher of the Year."
KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Thursday, May 22 (UP) -- Sixty Communist inmates of Compound 76 defied ,jeered and menaced United States guards in the presence of Allied news men.

George Ross, theatrical publicist, is planning to turn Broadway producer next season with a "thriller" tentatively labeled "The Perfectionist." Written by Reginald Denham and Conrad Sutton Smith, it is based on a short story by Margaret St. Clair that was published in the O'Brien Collection of "Best Detective Stories."

Terms for the largest single financing in American corporate history were set yesterday by the directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The giant communications concern intends to issue $500,000,000 of 3 1/2% per cent convertible debentures, maturing in twelve years. The new financing was authorized by stockholders of the company at their annual meeting on April 16.

Despite the warnings of all our top political and military leaders, including President Truman and General Eisenhower, Congress continues to treat all defense fund bills, both our own military budget and foreign military and economic aid requests, with a sovereign disregard for the realities of the present perilous situation.
Miss Hellman made public here yesterday a letter she had sent on Monday to Mr. Wood. In it the author declared:

The Division of Language, Literature and the Arts at Queens College, representing a third of the entire faculty, adopted a series of five resolutions yesterday condemning the action of Dr. John J. Theobald, college president, in reassigning Dr. Harold Lenz from his position as Dean of Students to a teaching position in the German Department.

" About Face," a Warner Brothers musical comedy in Technicolor, featuring Gordon MacRae, Eddie Bracken, Dick Wesson, Virginia Gibson, Phyllis Kirk and Aileen Stanley Jr., is today's new film arrival at the Warner Theatre. Roy Del Ruth directed and William Jacobs produced from a script written by Peter Milne and the stage play, "Brother Rat," by John Monks Jr. and Fred F. Finklehoffe.

I saw recently a striking cartoon entitle "When a fellow needs a friend." In it was depicted a policeman standing alone, apparently bewildered by the baiting, the ridicule and the condemnation of the crowd at his back.
THE NEW YORK TIMES in its May 5 issue gave a brief account of the mass meeting of the "American Friends of Anti-Bolshevist Bloc of Nations, Inc." The rally took place at Manhattan Center on May 4.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- In a stepped-up drive against violators of its regulations, the National Production Authority filed charges today against the Weinstein Lumber Company of 139 Elizabeth Avenue, Union, N. J. The company is charged with illegal use of aluminum through 1951.

Aggregate resources of community trusts in the United States, Canada and Hawaii rose from $102,005,711 to $110,091,128 during 1951, according to a study by the New York Community Trust released yesterday.

Reflecting repayments by textile and textile factoring interests, business loans from New York banks declined $27,000,000 last week, registering the fifth successive weekly decrease. The reduction, according to data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, brought the decrease in commercial loans since the start of this year to $389,000,000 against an increase of $411,000,000 in the similar period last year.

The Veterans Administration has interrupted subsistence payments to 874 veterans studying at the Robert Louis Stevenson School, 246 West Eightieth Street, a private preparatory institution, because the State Department of Education has withdrawn approached of the school, it was announced yesterday.
ALBANY, May 22 -- An attempt by a New York City motorist to have the city's anti-horn ordinance declared unconstitutional was unanimously rejected by the Court of Appeals today.

A Greenwich Village landmark has passed to new control as the result of the sale stock controlling the studio building at 51 West Tenth Street to S. Tarlow and Julius Vinik. The transaction was negotiated by William Alfred White, broker, with Abraham M. Weinberg and Caesar Nobiletti acting as attorneys for the buyers.

THE current Churchillian Restoration is the right moment for Robert Lewis Taylor to bring out his impudently informing "Winston Churchill: An Informal Study of Greatness.''* It is a time that calls for Aristophanic rather than Aeschylean drama. We can be grateful that Mr. Taylor has not produced one more stuffy and sonorous Appraisal of the Man and His Work.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22 -Vigorous opposition to corruption and racketeering in labor was voiced today by Alex Bail of New York, president of the Playthings, Jewelry and Novelty Workers International Union, C. I. O.

Lifting of Regulation W doesn't mean that dealers can simply transfer responsibility for their consumer credit to the banks, Mort Farr, president of the National Appliance and Radio-TV Dealers Association, warned yesterday.

Not all of us have been to sea. Those of us who have know, and others can guess, at how slowly the hours below deck pass before the turn on watch comes, or at the lonely vigil the radioman must pass. "God help the lads at sea on a night like this," the old timers say as the wind whips about the house and the trees creak in the rain.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 22 -- Addressing Nationalists gathered in Capetown City Hall last night to celebrate his seventy-eighth birthday, Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan said South Africa was passing through a "crisis graver and bigger than any in our history of crises."
Brooklyn's scoring merry-go-round slowed down from its record-breaking clip of the night before but still spun fast enough yesterday to carry the Dodgers to an 8-7 victory over the Reds.
CLEVELAND, May 22 (AP) -Maurice McDermott pitched and batted the Red Sox to a 3 -- 2 victory over the Indians before 5,394 fans today, gaining an even break in the two-game series for Boston.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Mink Traders Association, Inc., and its members, all of New York, were charged today by a Federal Trade Commission hearing examiner with restraint-of-trade practices and were ordered to halt them.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 17 totaled 754,373 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 34,580 cars or 4.8 per cent more than for the preceding week, 55,102 cars or 6.8 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 11,060 cars or 1.5 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Thirteen-year-old Jimmy Carrick of Pittsburgh, who solicited 8,000 pints of blood for the American Red Cross, was welcomed to the city yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri as the winner of the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce "Kid of the Year." Award.
The Seaboard Air Line borrowed $15,000,000 in the public market yesterday on serial equipment trust obligations maturing over fifteen years at an interest cost of 3 per cent.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., May 22 -- All New Jersey candidates for Congress will be asked to sign a pledge before election to vote for repeal of the Taft-Hartley Law if they are elected. A resolution adopted here today at the closing session of the seventy-fourth annual convention of the New Jersey Federation of Labor provides for this.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 22 -- Gen. Alcides Etchegoyen has defeated Gen. Newton Estillac Leal, the former war minister, in one of the most bitterly contested elections ever held for the presidency of the Military Club.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Senate passed with a voice vote tonight the long-controverted McCarran bill to overhaul and codify the immigration, naturalization and deportation laws that have piled up piecemeal through generations.

Fresh and summery-looking designs are included in two collections of wallpapers. One group is at Sigfrid K. Lonegren, Inc., 515 Madison Avenue, the other at F. Schumacher Co., 60 West Fortieth Street. Both collections are available through decorators.

Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it was cutting out the two extra sections to its seven weekly tourist flights between New York and Europe as a result of the gasoline shortage. The line also said its seven weekly regular-fare flights would be cut to two for the same reason. The cuts become effective immediately, a spokesman for the line said.

In addressing the members of Congress yesterday General Ridgway gave a statesmanlike report of his period of service in the Far East. His manner was above reproach -- one is inclined to say, beyond praise. He knew what he was talking about and talked about it plainly.

" Report From Formosa," by H. Maclear Bate, will be published June 9 by Dutton. The book presents a combination of the author's observations, a history of the island and a study of the part the island has played, and still plays, in world politics.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 22 -- Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium, first president of the United Nations General Assembly, has agreed to devote part of his time to promote the work of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund on a voluntary basis.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A Republican majority of the House of Representatives tentatively cut another $615,300,000 from an already trimmed Mutual Security authorization bill today after beating off repeated Democratic attempts to postpone the voting until tomorrow.

Racing among the 12-meter yachts will be revived on Long Island Sound when a group of them head the week-end regattas there and engage in several distance events, including the New York Yacht Club cruise.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) -Navy Secretary Dan A. Kimball said today the United States should have at least four 60,000ton aircraft carriers under construction "right now" to offset the "capability of the Communist aggressors."

The membership of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals committed its board of managers yesterday to study the advisability of a court test of the controversial Metcalf-Hatch law, which provides for state-licensed research using stray dogs, before it becomes effective on July 1.

The engineers', firemen's and conductors' brotherhoods have "reluctantly" accepted White House proposals for settling their three-year-old dispute with the carriers, and the railroads, which were seized by the Government when a strike was threatened twenty-two months ago, will soon be released from token custody and restored to their owners.

Five workmen employed on the Pennsylvania Railroad's Pier 77, at West Thirty-seventh Street, were booked last night at the West Thirtieth Street station on charges of grand larceny in the theft of six .22 caliber automatic pistols from packing cases on the pier some time between 2 A. M. and 4:30 A. M. yesterday.

Girl Scouts of Greater New York land children who paint in the centers of the Police Athletic League joined the ranks of about 300 adult sidewalk showmen at yesterday's opening of the semi-annual Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 2 points lower to 10 points higher than on Wednesday.

BOSTON, May 22 -- The American Federation of Labor decided today to send a delegation to Puerto Rico to discover why its Puerto Rican affiliate was "out of step" with the island's people. The investigation may result in suspension of the Puerto Rican group's officers and reorganization of its internal machinery.
SIOUX FALLS, S. D., May 22 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, today promised a 15 per cent reduction of taxes within a year if he was nominated and elected President.

The impact of unsettled world conditions on the personalities of young people today has made the task of successful vocational counseling "increasingly difficult," Dr. Helen R. Smith, director of the Vocational Advisory Service, declared yesterday.

A new kind of map is needed to bring home to Americans the changes in national relationships resulting from air transport, John Foster Dulles, former Republican foreign-policy adviser to President Truman, told the American Geographical Society yesterday.

The Standard Warehouse Corporation has leased the Castle Ice Cream Company plant at 663 Midland Avenue in Saddle River Township, N. J., from the United States Realty Company and plans to occupy the property about Aug. 1. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

BOSTON, May 22 (UP) -- Pitchers Bob Rush of the Cubs and Warren Spahn of the Braves alternated in a pair of excellent hurling performances today, each winning a shutout in a double-header. The Cubs took the first game, 3 -- 0, and the Braves captured the second, 5 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Presidential Clarifying Authority, a White House agency that is often overworked, resisted all pleas today to reconcile several mystifying comments on the implied powers of the Executive that Mr. Truman made at his press conference. Apparently the time finally arrived, as many expected it would, when the requirements of the task exceeded the ingenuity of the Authority or the explanation would reveal what is still a secret plan.
The Public Housing Administration will accept bids on June 4 on an issue of short-term notes totaling $69,013,000. Funds derived from the note offering will be used by twelve housing agencies.

THE angler can run the gamut this week-end, provided he does not insist upon largemouth bass, marlin or tuna, for trout fishing conditions are reported to be excellent, and the salt water offers a real variety.

STRASBOURG, France, May 22 -- In a four-hour meeting today the Foreign Ministers Committee of the Council of Europe was unable to agree on a proposal by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, for the integration of the European defense and other specialized communities into the organization of the Council of Europe.

The appointment of Lloyd R. Leaver as a director of the Thermoid Company, Trenton, N. J., was announced yesterday by Fred Schluter, president. Mr. Leaver is vice president in charge of Thormoid's industrial rubber division.

The announcement by the Red Cross this week that only 381 pints of blood were collected on Monday indicates that the warm-weather slumps in blood donations are upon us again. Every year these periodic letdowns in contributions to the Red Cross blood program cause untold hardship to our service men here and abroad.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -Texas Eastern Gas Transmission Corporation, supported by present and prospective customers, asked the Federal Power Commission today to permit it to allocate its excess natural gas among applicants for improved service.

Directors of A. G. Spalding Bros., Inc., athletic goods manufacturers, elected as president yesterday William T. Brown, who will be chief executive officer. He succeeds Charles F. Robbins, president since 1933, who was elevated to chairman of the board of directors.

PARIS, May 22 -- Indications from the Soviet Union hint that Moscow is becoming somewhat worried about the political loyalty of the great belt of non-Slavic Moslem peoples stretching across the southern part of the U. S. S. R. all the way from the Black Sea into the heart of Communist-dominated China.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Organized baseball is capable of running its own business and needs no Governmental regulatory agency to police it nor any legislation by Congress to modify or set aside any of the rules under which it operates, a House Judiciary subcommittee concluded today.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Public recognition of the value of probations in the treatment of juvenile and adult criminal offenders is imperative to the successful reduction of crime, Irving Ben Cooper, Chief Justice of the Court of Special Sessions of New York City, told the opening session of the forty-fifth annual conference of the National Probation and Parole Association here tonight.

Call it old-fashioned if you like, but we believe that when a child destroys or damages property the parent ought to make good if he is financially able. A bill that would establish this principle to a modest extent in connection with vandalism against public property in New York City is now under consideration in the City Council.

St. John's University took first place in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference from Manhattan College by defeating the Jaspers, 5 -- 1, at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday, in a contest featured by a bases-loaded triple-play by the Redmen.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) -Joseph W. Childs, a labor member of the Wage Stabilization Board, charged today that Representatives Richard B. Vail, Republican of Illinois, used "dirty insinuations" to "smear" him and two other board members as being pro-Communist.
WASHINGTON. May 22 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended May 17 were unchanged from a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- President Truman repeatedly asserted today that he had inherent Constitutional powers, including seizure, and neither the Judiciary nor Congress could deprive him of them. Yet he said he would return the steel mills to their owners if the Supreme Court decided his seizure of the industry was illegal.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway today called the Communists' insistent propaganda charging the United Nations forces in Korea with having used gas and germ warfare "a monumental warning to the American people."

A pictorial history of the city is being prepared by Columbia University for publication in October, 1953, as one of its public service projects in connection with its bicentennial celebration in 1954. Entitled "The Columbia Pictorial History of New York," the book will be edited by Dr. John A. Kouwenhoven, Professor of English at Barnard College, Columbia University.
MOSCOW, May 22 -- If you want to telephone the Kremlin the number to call is Center 6-7571.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- During the week ended May 21, member bank reserves increased $174,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, Friday, May 23 (UP) -- The Western Union Telegraph Company wage dispute that led to a seven-week nation-wide strike was reported early today to have been settled.

One has to lose a thing to realize its worth, the old saying goes. So it would seem with the humble potato. Now that the spud scarcity is really pinching, a hue and cry is being raised in many sectors of the food front.

BONN, Germany, May 22 -- The three Western Allied High Commissioners and Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, completed nine months of negotiation on a contractual agreement tonight and with the exception of three relatively minor points this document is now ready for signature by the Western Big Three foreign ministers and the Chancellor.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 22 -Leaders in several fields of American life announced today their finding, after five days of secluded deliberations, that the current decline in consumer spending was only a lull in a continuing inflation that threatened the stability of the national economy and the security of the entire Western world.

On his present visit to this country Foreign Minister Sharett of Israel has appealed to world opinion for moral pressure on Germany to discharge its debt of recompense for the crimes committed by the Hitler regime against the Jews. This appeal will undoubtedly find a sympathetic response.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -A United States official said tonight that the Soviet Union's protest to Iran against United States military aid evidently was designed to intimidate the Iranian Government.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- President Truman today authorized the removal of 22,000 tons of copper from the nation's stockpile of strategic materials. The metal will be used to make up the deficit in the projected supply of copper which has been caused by the strike of copper workers in Chile and the embargo of shipments of copper from that country because of price differences.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- A House Judiciary subcommittee recommended today that Congress declare the President had no inherent power under the Constitution to seize private property.

Starting Monday, June 2, the city intends to place on sale the $5 and $10 nuisance automobile tax stamps that must be affixed by Monday, June 16, to all motor vehicles registered in the five boroughs. City Treasurer Spencer C. Young will get stamp No. 1.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 22 -Leading United States specialists on Soviet economy gathered at Arden House here tonight for the opening tomorrow of the first extended conference on Soviet economic problems ever held in this country.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, in a defense of shipping subsidies, declared tonight that it was possible our Government had given free as much to European shipping and shipbuilding in four years as it had spent on our own shipbuilding in sixteen years.

Capt. Isidore Schwal, whose retirement was approved last Monday by the Police Pension Board, was called back to active duty yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan. Then he was suspended and ordered to trial next Monday on charges of having, while a lieutenant, conspired to permit Harry Gross to operate as the city's master bookmaker.
School children joined yesterday in a drive to keep Central Park from being defaced by vandals.
LONDON, May 22 (AP) -- The United States Navy sped bottled oxygen to a transport ship 800 miles out in the Atlantic tonight and saved the life of a two pound, five ounce baby.

Dr. Eleanor Hudson Grady, Dean of Faculty at Hunter College, announced her retirement yesterday, effective next February. Dr Grady, who has been associated with the college since 1915, will be on a leave of absence during the fall semester.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Atlas Powder Company of Wilmington, Del., announced here today the filing of a petition in the United States Court of Appeals at Philadelphia asking a review of the Federal order that eliminated from the standard bread loaf the polyoxyethylene monsterate type of softeners.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) -The Federal Reserve System's Board of Governors said today its 6,800 member banks had $50,200,000,000 outstanding in loans at the end of March.
Government and labor unions drew sharp criticism yesterday at the concluding session of the American Iron and Steel Institute's annual meeting here.

MUNSAN, Korea, May 22 -Seven hours after Vice Admiral Charles Turner Joy had delivered his last speech at the Korean armistice talks, he made another farewell address to the Allied truce delegates and staff officers at the United Nations base camp in which he had lived for ten and a half months.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., May 22 -- Mrs. Saul Weinsier of the Fresh Meadow Club played sparkling golf over the windswept Wheatley Hills Golf Club layout today to take the first gross prize with 40, 40 -- 80 in the initial one-day tournament of the Women's Cross-County Golf Association.

ALBANY, May 22 -- Chairman Benjamin F. Feinberg of the Public Service Commission announced today he has protested to the Federal Power Commission against a 37 per cent increase in the wholesale rate of natural gas proposed by the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 22 -- A divot from the famed golf course at St. Andrews, with a golf ball and tee attached, was being flown to Reno, Nev., today, a gift to the Rotary Club there.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- John A. Dawson, an investment broker from this city, was nominated late this afternoon for the presidency of the American Baptist Convention. His formal election tomorrow as the head of more than 1,600,000 Baptists is regarded as a virtual certainty.
LONDON, May 22 -- The fall in security prices gathered fresh momentum today. Selling of British funds increased and prices fell abruptly, in some cases as much as 1 7s and 6d ($3.85).

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 22 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's address to Congress today was warmly welcomed by most United Nations delegates. They contrasted his insistence upon the role of the United Nations in the defense of South Korea with the fact that General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, his predecessor as United Nations Commander, in his speech to Congress a year ago did not mention the United Nations.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, May 22 -- Egypt stands to gain more than any country in the world from the American delegation's efforts at the meeting in Rome of the International Cotton Advisory Board now under way to stabilize world cotton prices. This is the opinion voiced by commercial interests here which sell internationally Egypt's principal resource -- cotton.

Navy divers recovered from the bottom of the Pawtuxet River yesterday $30,000 of the $100,000 taken in the Quonset Point, R. I., naval air station robbery as a 25year-old former private detective seized here in connection with the robbery was held in $25,000 bail pending his removal to Rhode Island.

Directors of the Aspinook Corporation yesterday adopted a plan of recapitalization which also involves partial liquidation for distribution of excess capital arising from the sale of the corporation's Hampton, Apponaug and Union Bleachery Divisions.
One method of handling "open floor" room plans is exhibited in both of the Hotpoint Houses of the Fifties, which open today.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 22 -- The National Society of the Sons of the American Revolution ended the business sessions of the sixty-second annual congress of here today by naming Ray O. Edwards Jr. of Jacksonville, Fla., Deputy Chief of Public Works during World War II, as its new president general.
The reports of Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's comments to Congress and the press about the Korean prisoner-of-war situation still left the somber history of Koje obscure and incomprehensible yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (UP) -American industry must re-examine its compulsory retirement policies "or unions will do it for them." Albert J. Abrams, director of the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Problems of the Aging said today.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP) -- Bob Porterfield's pitching and home runs by Eddie Yost and Mickey Vernon helped the Senators beat the Browns, 4 to 2, tonight. The victory put second-place Washington within two games of the league-leading Indians.

Further headway was made yesterday by the stock market, again under the leadership of the railroad issues. Interest spread to several other sections aside from the carriers, notably the metals. The copper stocks were helped materially by the Government's authorization for higher prices on products made from foreign copper.

The Rev. Dr. Hermann Nelson Morse, the soft spoken and scholarly general secretary of the Board of National Missions, received the rare honor here yesterday of being elected Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. by acclamation at the church's 164th General Assembly in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street.
Five thousand of the city's 40,000 licensed retail alcoholic beverage sellers organized yesterday to fight imposition late next month of the city's 25 per cent tax on state liquor licenses.
Vegetable oils and hides increased in price on the New York commodities futures markets. Coffee and sugar declined. Wool tops, cocoa and rubber showed mixed results for the day.

Most home furnishings are slowly emerging from the doldrums, but furniture has turned the corner at a really satisfactory pace, Harry Fish, president of American Furniture Associates, said yesterday. Stores are in the market for furniture for the first time in eight months, he said.

A new type of inexpensive loudspeaker that equals or surpasses the performance of sound-reproducing apparatus costing many times as much was demonstrated here yesterday by two acoustical experts of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

NEW DELHI, India, May 22 -Communist propaganda on alleged United States germ warfare in Korea and mistreatment of prisoners on Koje Island has apparently excited little interest in India, despite the fulminations of the local Communist press.

PARIS, May 22 (AP) -- Five of America's top tennis stars -- including Tony Trabert, who is on leave from the United States Navy -scored victories today in the French international championship before some 10,000 spectators at Roland Garros Stadium.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) -Consumer prices almost equaled their record high mark last month, but the rise was not sufficiently sharp to keep 1,000,000 auto workers from losing part of a new wage increase, the Government disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Senate Agriculture Committee's hearing today on the operations and management of the Department of Agriculture opened on a discordant note and held that pitch throughout a turbulent day.
City College honored its athletes and guest, Pincus Sober, chairman of the United States Olympic Track and Field Committee, before 400 alumni and guests at the main gym last night.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, May 23 (AP) -- Allied warplanes yesterday smashed the third Red supply base in two months, leaving in flaming ruin the huge storage center near the North Korean capital of Pyongyang.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 22 -- The world Communist propaganda campaign alleging United Nations use of germ warfare and the mistreatment of war prisoners by the United Nations in Korea has done little to advance the Communist cause in Southeast Asia.

For the first time since the latter part of January, beefsteaks are higher at retail. Pork prices are up for the third successive week and lamb costs again have increased, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

GREAT NECK, L. I., May 22 -Long Island won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches for the second straight year when the Creek defeated New Jersey and Westchester rivals over the Fresh Meadow Country Club course today.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 22 (UP) -Premier Mohammed Mossadegh insisted today that he was determined to quit after the hearings early next month by the International Court of Justice on the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company dispute with Iran.

IT'S odd how one train of thought inevitably leads to another. There was nothing involved about the original proposition offered in this space yesterday to the effect that Lou Boudreau had abandoned his experiment of using only rookies on his Red Sox because he needed the know-how of the old-timers in order to make a fight of it.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -Doris Ann Hall, 13 years old, of Hudson, N. C., today correctly spelled "farraginous," "vignette" and thirty-seven other hard ones to win the twenty-fifth annual National Spelling Bee.

Shubert Alley savants, whose knowledge of matters theatrical enables them to predict events, had no hesitancy yesterday in identifying the Morosco's next attraction, "The Deep Blue Sea," which will mark the return of Margaret Sullavan to the Broadway stage after much too long an absence.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 22 -Supporters of William H. Brennan of Stamford, Republican national committeeman from Connecticut, started a counter-attack today against efforts by Gov. John Davis Lodge to oust him as a committeeman and to keep him from being named a delegate at large to the Republican National Convention.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Johnny Hopp, infielder-outfielder of the Yankees, today received his unconditional release as the champions recalled Bill Miller, left-handed rookie pitcher from the Kansas City Blues.

JERSEY CITY, May 22 -- Asking that a legislative hearing be held on Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons' plan to institute a point system in penalizing traffic law violators. T. James Tumulty, former Assemblyman and now secretary to Mayor John V. Kenny of this city, today declared the Attorney General's plan "smacks of a police state mentality."

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Owners and agents of leading commercial buildings throughout the country were told today that they might look forward with confidence to future revival and stability of property values in the central business districts of metropolitan areas.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22 -- R. K. O. Radio Pictures has added a new property titled "Murder" to its immediate production schedule and has named Jean Simmons for the feminine lead. The story falls into the mystery-melodrama category and was written by Chester Erskine.

GENEVA, May 22 -- The Fifth World Health Assembly closed here today after approving a budget of $8,485,000 for the United Nations World Health Organization's activities during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1953.
TOKYO, Friday, May 23 (AP) -United Nations Command communique 1,257, for the twenty-four hours to 6 A. M., Thursday, Korea time.

Among measures essential for solving the European Payments Union credit tie-up is restoration of "minimum flexibility" to member countries' pegged currencies as an offset to the inflation represented in accumulated credits in fixed-rate soft currencies, a top Belgian banking official declared yesterday.
LONDON, Friday, May 23 (AP) -Following is the Soviet broadcast of the text of the Russian note to Iran protesting against Iran's acceptance of United States military aid:

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., May 22 -- Mrs. Philip Conway of Siwanoy carded 42, 41 -- 83 to win gross honors by 4 strokes in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association at Innis Arden today.

The New York City Unit of the American Women's Voluntary Services will be the beneficiary of a canasta tournament to be held Tuesday night in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria, with a feature of the entertainment being an auction of original cartoons that have been donated for the occasion by well-known artists.

Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., announced in its quarterly statement issued to stockholders yesterday that it had a net profit of $6,808,933 for the three months ended with April. This was slightly larger than the estimate announced at the annual meeting last month.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- President Truman asserted in his news conference today that he had already started working to get the Democratic Presidential nominee elected. He reiterated that he would support any candidate chosen by the convention.
Six more fellowships for study and observation abroad by American newspaper men and women were announced yesterday by the Reid Foundation after the annual meeting of its board of directors.

Say what one will about the shortcomings of Ed Sullivan as a master of ceremonies, the columnist certainly deserves credit for recognizing the need for trying new things on his Sunday night program, "Toast of the Town," over C. B. S. television.

MOSCOW, May 22 -- The Soviet Union charged today that United States aid to Iran violated the Soviet-Iranian Treaty of 1921 and was not compatible with the maintenance of good neighborly relations between the Soviet Union and Iran.

Ben Touster, recently elected president of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, arrived here yesterday on the French liner Liberte after completing a six-week study of the problem of Jewish refugees and displaced persons in Europe.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Friday, May 23 (AP) -- Communist inmates retained control within the seventeen barbed wire enclosures of this big prisoner-of-war camp today, but were weakening under a firm show of force by battle-tried United States troops.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Canada released an additional $41,000,000 to the World Bank today to be lent to member nations at the bank's will.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 22 -- Mayor Joseph Srholez of Little Ferry, on trial in County Court here on charges of misconduct in office, today denied that he had accepted $200 a week as protection money for two years for use by "sitting bookies" of eight telephones in the community.

Eight potato retailers have been cited for over-ceiling sales by the Office of Price Stabilization, which also struck yesterday at price abuses in the advertising and selling of freezer-meat combinations.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (UP) -Curt Simmons pitched his second successive shut-out and registered his third victory of the season against one defeat as the Phillies downed the Pirates, 6 to 0, today before 3,065 fans.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (UP) --Woodruff Randolph, seeking a fifth two-year term as president of the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., held a slight edge today over C. G. Sparkman of Detroit.

ROME, May 22 -- The Feast of Ascension, celebrated today as a national holiday, gave all political parties an opportunity to push their campaigns for Sunday's provincial and municipal elections in central and southern Italy. Approximately 100 rallies, large and small were held in Rome.

BEDMINSTER, N. J., May 22 -State Senator Malcolm S. Forbes of Somerset County announced today that he would be a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor at the party primary next April. He said the "nubbin" of his campaign would be increased state aid for education, and he revealed that he had a "team" of one lawyer, two statisticians and one tax expert working now on ways the state could finance the aid.

YONKERS, May 22 -- After relinquishing the lead just past the half-mile mark, Direct Rhythm closed fast tonight to capture the second United States Harness Writers Pace in 2:03 flat before 22,096 Yonkers Raceway fans. Driven by Del Miller, the 4-year-old son of Billy Direct defeated The Black Prince by a length and Floating Dream by two.

BOSTON, May 22 -- Massachusetts physicians were warned today against continued or excessive use of chloromycetin, a new drug, on the possibility that it might destroy blood elements and even cause death.

The most natural and down-to-earth way the ordinary citizen has of informing friends and relatives overseas how Americans really live, think and act is through writing letters. Every year more than 200,000,000 letters flow outward from this country, and it is inevitable that these letters play an important part in shaping the concept of the United States that is held abroad.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Cutting down the high death toll in the "perinatal" period, just before and after a baby's birth, was the principal theme at today's opening session of a three-day meeting of the American Academy of Pediatrics.

BERLIN, May 22 -- Bishop Otto Dibelius, head of the German Protestant Church, today urged that Germany unity talks be held and by implication chided the Western powers for having delayed such conferences.

Twenty-five thousand Roy Scouts of Greater-New York are ready for the presentation of their fourth Scout-O-Rama, a fifteen-act panorama in eighty-two scenes depicting every phase of the Scouting movement. Special emphasis will be on the Scouts' two cardinal principles -- character-building and citizenship training.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, said today he proposes to get to the bottom of a proposal for a long-term contract for purchase of Canadian aluminum.

LONDON, May 22 -- The Government's plan to permit commercial television, competing with the British Broadcasting Corporation, stirred the House of Lords today to lively objections to airborne advertising as it is practiced in the United States.

RALEIGH, N. C., May 22 -- The North Carolina Democratic convention endorsed the candidacy of Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia for the Democratic Presidential nomination today but declined to instruct delegates having thirty-two votes specifically to support Senator Russell or any other candidate at the national convention in July.

TOKYO, Friday, May 23 -- The Communist delegates, in a surprise move, agreed today to a recess in the negotiations for an armistice in Korea, after a fortnight of sessions at Panmunjom had made no progress toward breaking a deadlock over an exchange of war prisoners.

The police come up yesterday with a new version of the manner in which Stanley Simcoe, Brooklyn salesman, came into possession of $15,000 worth of jewelry he said had been purchased for $3,400 from an Australian "mystery woman."
CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) -- Today's livestock prices reported by the Department of Agriculture follow:

Johnny Bratton, former National Boxing Association welterweight champion, is favored over Del Flanagan of St. Paul in the principal bout of ten rounds tonight at Madison Square Garden, but Flanagan is determined to carry the fight to the ex-titleholder.

FORT WORTH, May 22 (UP) -Ray Gafford, host pro for the national open at the Dallas Northwood Club next month, and North Texas State's Joe Conrad clipped two strokes off par today to share the eighteen-hole lead in the $20,000 Colonial national invitation golf tournament.

A tiny 34-year-old woman spent fifteen minutes in the role of a bank robber yesterday -- part of the time trying vainly to escape with the $400 she had obtained at the point of a toy pistol. Captured, the young mother apologized, and explained that she had wanted the money for medical expenses.

OTTAWA, May 22 (AP) -- Canada made it easier yesterday for the United States to extradite operators of stock frauds originating in this country. The House of Commons approved a resolution adopting an amendment to the Extradition Treaty between Canada and the United States.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Continued dry weather in the western Canadian spring wheat area was a bullish factor in wheat today, and traders also were impressed by the manner in which the May delivery acted yesterday, closing at the highest price in many weeks.

A taxpayer site 105 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of 159th Street and Northern Boulevard in Flushing, Queens, has been purchased by Myron C. Simon and Arthur I. Kraft from Joseph Angelone. L. J. Phillips Co. were the brokers.

A new credit reporting arrangement will be established in the fur industry to reduce the incidence of failures, it was announced last night by J. S. Silberman, retiring president of the American Fur Merchants Association.

WASHINGTOI, May 22 (AP) -The managing editor of The New York Compass, Tom O'Connor, refused today to tell the House UnAmerican Activities Committee whether he ever had been a Communist. He said he was not one now.

NEW DELHI, India, May 22 -Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru launched a frontal attack against the Communist party today and described its activities as "counterrevolutionary and completely out of date."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 22 -- The economic development of the Middle East is proceeding slowly, the United Nations reported today in a regional survey that blamed the lack of technical skills, inadequate health standards, unfavorable land policies and unequal distribution of income.

Presiding Bishop Henry Knox Sherrill of the Protestant Episcopal Church announced yesterday his appointment of Francis B. Sayre as his personal representative to the Episcopal Church in Japan, and to the Most Rev. Dr. Michael Hinsuke Yashiro, its presiding bishop.

William Wyer, trustee of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road, dropped strong hints yesterday that he would seek to abandon service on three outlying branches in eastern Suffolk County that are particularly unprofitable.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 21 (UP) -- Game little Ruth Lily, given a hard ride by Gordon Glisson, scored a nose victory today in the $10,000 Westchester Handicap at Hollywood Park.

MANILA, Friday, May 23 -- Engrossed in partisan politics and localized disputes, the Philippine Congress adjourned last midnight without Senate ratification of the Japanese peace treaty and without approving President Elpidio Quirino's $250,000,000 budget for 1953.

The attractions of New York as a vacation center as well as "a convention city" will be stressed in a campaign to draw visitors from the 30,000,000 persons who live within several hundred miles of here.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 -Karl P. Billner, a Philadelphia engineer and inventor, said today that the Soviet Government recently awarded the Stalin Medal for 1951 to a Russian, Osip Abramovitch Gerschberg, for a construction process that Mr. Billner developed and turned over to the Russians in 1944 under Lend-Lease.

William S. Webb, deputy State Tax Commissioner, told 100 business men and civic leaders yesterday that $405,957 had been raised in Brooklyn for the Greater New York Fund since the drive began April 28. Mr. Webb, executive vice chairman for the Brooklyn drive, made the report at a luncheon in the St. George Hotel.

The Government of Yugoslavia has offered as a gift the granite needed to build a monument here to the 6,000,000 European Jews killed by the Nazis. The American Memorial to Six Million Jews of Europe, Inc., announced the offer yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 22 -- The Czechoslovak Government has refused to give the details of its charges against two Israeli citizens under arrest in Prague and has refused to allow Israeli representatives there to see the detained men, the Israeli Foreign Ministry announced today.

Television station WATV in Newark will move its transmitter and antenna to the top of the Empire State Building under authorization granted yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission. Its studios will remain in Newark.
ALBANY, May 21 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft has picked up six additional probable delegate-votes in New York, on the basis of an Associated Press poll.
Following is the text of an address by Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway yesterday before a joint session of Congress as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Navy Gun was right on the target in the Corinthian Steeplechase Handicap, the historic field event that occupied the feature spot on the program at Belmont Park yesterday. The 7-year-old son of Battleship was rated ably by Pat Smithwick to close strong and score by more than two lengths in the contest of about two miles.

After six months of delay the Board of Estimate finally approved unanimously yesterday the request of Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley for the purchase and installation of 13,000 more parking meters to cost $975,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22 -- Motion picture studios have begun a new and widespread investigation of the loyalty of more than 200 Hollywood personalities whose names appear on a list, sent to the studios by the national headquarters of the American Legion, of persons suspected of Communist associations or activities.

Patronage of American shipping, not as charity or as patriotism but as a means of obtaining the best possible service, was urged upon American business men yesterday by Vice Admiral E. L. Cochrane, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board.

Plans for financing the Ohio Turnpike Commission's proposed 241-mile toll highway with a $330,000,000 issue of revenue bonds bearing interest of 3 1/4 per cent, were outlined here yesterday to prospective underwriters by representatives of the Ohio commission and its financial and legal advisers.

Four large slum-clearance projects for Manhattan, aggregating more than $85,000,000 in cost, were approved unanimously by the Board of Estimate yesterday for construction under Title I of the National Housing Act. Three of the projects will be cooperative and one standard rental, all for middle-incomes.

Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, president of the Protestant Council of the City of New York and pastor of Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, said yesterday "I don't believe I've ever seen American morals at quite so low an ebb."

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 22 -Officials of Nassau County's overcrowded community hospitals, facing the necessity for at least $10,000,000 with of expansion projects this fiscal year, have united in a last-ditch bid for allocation of Federal funds under the Hill-Burton Act.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson left by plane for Europe tonight, hopeful of bringing back within a week two agreements binding a nearly sovereign West Germany into the defense system of the free world.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 22 -- The United Nations Disarmament Commission is preparing a report that in essence concedes failure to make any progress thus far, but promises to keep on trying.

Ben E. Tate of Cincinnati, national treasurer of Senator Robert A. Taft's campaign committee, said yesterday that the Senator now had the support of 474 delegates to the Republican National Convention.

The Board of Estimate approved unanimously yesterday an $8,500,000 contract for the city's purchase of the Rockaway Beach branch of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road for inclusion in the municipal transit system.

After more than a year of negotiations the veil of secrecy about the "contractual agreement" with Germany is being lifted. Promptly strong opposition is registered by the majority of the German political parties. If the treaty will be signed at all, it will be because, as Drew Middleton reports, the Germans "realize they cannot get anything better for the present."

Directors of the Southern Pacific Company declared yesterday a regular quarterly dividend of $1.50 a share on the capital stock and called a special meeting of stockholders for Aug. 5 to act upon a proposal to double the number of authorized shares to provide for a split of the shares on a two-for-one basis.

The hustle and bustle, color and confusion of New York's East Side, the serene beauty of a Shelley poem and the grim realities of a homework assignment apparently are what inspirations are made of. And tonight and tomorrow night the fruits of these inspiration -- three original musical compositions -- will be presented at the semi-annual concert of the High School of Music and Art, 135th Street and Convent Avenue.

Mrs. S. T. Patterson's Gift of Gold, winner of the Carolina Cup and the Virginia Gold Cup this season, today will carry top weight of 168 pounds as he attempts to repeat his victory of last year in the Connecticut Cup at the annual Adjacent Hunts meeting at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club, Purchase.
Adolph L. Gross has resigned as president of Hudson Radio and Television Corporation and disposed of his interest to David H. Ormont.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- All quota restrictions on the export of Government-produced general purpose (GR-S) synthetic rubber were lifted by the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce today. It was the first time since the fall of 1950 that shipments of the synthetic abroad have not been under strict quota regulation.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The State Department said today that the Soviet Union's protest to Iran against acceptance of United States military aid was another attempt to "intimidate" the Teheran Government.

It is a long and painful struggle to attain stardom as an operatic soprano but the neighbors should not have to share the pain, Magistrate Abner C. Surpless ruled yesterday in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 24 -- Colonel Dodd received the notification of his punishment today without comment. Just released from a hospital in Korea after treatment for a stomach disorder, he told correspondents: "I have nothing to say -- for the moment they are in the driver's seat."

YONKERS, May 23 -- Disqualification of Pronto Don, 1951 harness horse of the year, elevated the 75-to-1 shot Peter Abbey to first place in the $10,000 New Rochelle one-mile trot before a crowd of 27,162 at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
William E. Smith Jr. has been promoted to sales manager of the Bert Clark real estate agency in Fair Lawn, N.J.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- The Senate approved today the nomination of Vice Admiral C Turner Joy, former chief negotiator in the Korean truce talks, to be superintendent of the United States Naval Academy. Action was by a routine voice vote but Senator John C. Stennis of Mississippi said the admiral's distinguished service deserved a "word of appreciation."

The Park Avenue Synagogue last evening presented the first performance of "Arvit L'Shabbat," the Friday Evening Service No. 2 of Frederick Jacobi. The work was performed by Cantor David J. Putterman and the synagogue choir, under the direction of Max Helfman, with Isidor Geller at the organ.

Colony Wine and Spirits, on Madison Avenue since 1933, opens today at No. 809 in a French provincial setting of teakwood shelves and paneling. Oscar Fabres has painted lively scenes over the shelves; at the rear are depicted champagne festivities with the emblem: "Optima Dona Deorum."

BONN, Germany, May 23 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France arrived here today for two days of conferences and Monday's signing of the contractual agreement with Western Germany. Secretary of State Dean Acheson, on his arrival, described this agreement as "a great contribution to the security and peace of the world."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 23 -- Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations, and Mrs. Austin gave a farewell reception at the Hotel Plaza today for Francis B. Sayre and Porter McKeever, who are leaving the delegation to return to private life.

Several weeks ago THE TIMES carried a fairly lengthy story from Washington in regard to the plans of a group of members of the House of Representatives from urban districts to attempt to reduce agricultural appropriations. As I recall, this plan was in part motivated by the opposition to the House program on economic controls which farm-district members have evidenced.

CHICAGO, May 23 (UP) -- Tony Skoronski brought in three winners today at the Lincoln Fields-at-Hawthorne meeting and Johnny Adams continued his consistent riding by piloting two winners, including Best Doings in the featured Espino Gold Purse.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., May 23 -- Dr. David cleared out right after luncheon this afternoon as Yale Drama School Players got into costume for a dress rehearsal of an outdoor show depicting the half century that the good doctor has run the Gaylord Sanatorium here.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- Cyrus S. Ching, Director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, indicated today that he believed the Wage Stabilization Board had acted improperly in attempting to mediate the steel dispute after it had recommended a settlement.

LONDON, May 23 -- Before an audience that included some of the most famous mathematicians and physicists in the country, the Astronomer Royal, Sir Harold Spencer Jones, gave what amounted to official approval to a new theory of creation for all universal matter at a meeting of the Royal Institution tonight.
How hearing aids and new eyeglasses helped interest aged persons in club activities and adult education was reported yesterday at a conference of leaders of programs for men and women over 60.

WASHINGTON. May 23 -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, denied today that because of the high political connections of Jack Cowart he had been tender in handling a charge that Cowart, a former Department of Agriculture employe, had attempted to "shake down" a Texas warehouse company.
William J. Grede's letter on settling labor disputes, which you printed on May 15, strikes me as provocative in some parts and rather frustrating in others.

Events today: Greater New York Chapter of the American Musicological Society meeting, Room 213, Public Library, 4 P. M.; Russian Orthodox Cathedral Choir, Town Hall, 8:30; International Society for Contemporary Music, United States section, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30; concert and art exhibition, High School of Music and Art, 7:45; jazz concert, Central Plaza, 111 Second Avenue, 8:30.

Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock reserved decision yesterday on a defense motion to strike out all testimony given by Louis F. Budenz at the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders in Federal Court here.

A site in Bayside, Queens, has been purchased by the Clarruth Realty Corporation of Elmont for improvement with a two-story apartment house. The property forms an "L" around the Masonic Temple, which occupies a plot 100 by 150 feet at the northeast corner of Bell Boulevard and Thirty-sixth Avenue, and comprises the remainder of the block also bound by Corporal Stone Street and Thirty-fifth Avenue.

BOSTON, May 23 -- Angered by a sudden upsurge of racketeer-infested unions in New York and other large cities, the American Federation of Labor has set up a special committee to force a house cleaning in its affiliated unions.
LANCASTER, Pa., May 23 (AP) -- The Hamilton Watch Company disclosed plans today to import cheaper seventeen-jewel watches in 1953 to increase profits and improve its competitive position.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Text of a letter by Frank Pace Jr., Secretary of the Army, to Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia and chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, reporting on the difficulties with Communist prisoners on Koje Island follows:

SPOKANE, Wash., May 23 -- A charge that the forces of Senator Robert A. Taft were planning to bolt the Republican state convention here tomorrow, hold a rump session and elect a slate of twenty-four Taft-pledged delegates to the national convention was made tonight by strategists in the Presidential campaign of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

CHICAGO, May 23 (UP) -- Shortstop Johnny Lipon batted in five runs and Southpaw Teddy Gray allowed only seven hits tonight to spark the Tigers to a 9-to-2 triumph over the White Sox before 16,524 fans at Comiskey Park.

In the wake of a walkout Wednesday evening by members of a teamsters' union that closed three wholesale cake and pastry baking establishments, seven additional wholesale bakery employers belonging to the same management association shut up shop yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Danny Kaye of Beverly Hills, Calif., entered a new field of art this week. He and Edward Dukoff of North Hollywood got design patent No. 166,807 for a blowout toy. A blowout unrolls when inflated and has at the end a feather suitable for tickling noses and a device for delivering a mild Bronx cheer.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, May 24 -- Allied warplanes struck the greatest air blow of the Korean war Thursday and yesterday, turning a huge enemy supply and arsenal complex into what one pilot called "a little hell."

Flint, Mich., announced yesterday the sale of $3,500,000 of water-revenue bonds due from 1953 to 1983 to Halsey, Stuart a Co., Inc., and associates at a bid of 100.002 for 3s, 2s, 2 1/4s and 2 1/2s, an interest cost of 2.4179 per cent. Reoffering was made at prices to yield from 1.1 per cent to 2.5 cent.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 24 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,259, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M., Saturday:

Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced yesterday that he had opened a state-wide investigation into allegations that a number of doctors, drug companies and drugstores were operating illegal profit-sharing prescription combines.

The four-story building accommodating eight families at 140 Amboy Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Celia Rothberg to Abraham and Rose Roseman. Title was insured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 23 -- More than 700 Princeton University students crowded into Alexander Hall today to pay tribute at the final lecture of Dr. Walter Phelps Hall, one of the most beloved teachers of his time.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, May 23 -- A special revolution of the kind that has usually meant considerable blood-letting in Central America is occurring peacefully in Honduras. Everyone here is agreeably surprised that it should be so and the explanation seems to lie in the fact that the country had a dictator who knew when to give up.

ROME, May 23 -- The campaign in the provincial and municipal elections in central and southern Italy on Sunday came to an end at midnight tonight. Tomorrow public meetings and manifestations of all kinds are forbidden by law.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 23 -- The Russians have succeeded in having circulated among members of the United Nations more Communist charges that United States is using germ warfare in Korea and China.

BRAINERD, Minn., May 23 -- A wriggling carpet of black-and-yellow caterpillars spread across a million acres of Minnesota northwoods today, covering houses and stripping trees and bushes. Residents of the area east of here donned high boots and in several places automobiles skidded on the roads in the worst caterpillar invasion in the state's history.

Bottlenecks both to defense and to a proper flow of goods for the civilian economy were outlined before last week's Highway Transportation Congress by Albert Bradley, chairman of the National Highway Users Conference and executive vice president of General Motors.

DETROIT, May 23 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will make a major address in Detroit on June 14, Arthur E. Summerfield, Republican national committeeman from Michigan, announced today. The general will speak earlier the same day at City Hall.
Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, dashed cold water yesterday on the story of Mrs. Anne Myers, who said she held up a bank teller to get $400 for medical treatment.

BERLIN, May 23 -- The tempo of events seemed to be increasing hourly here today as the East German Government reorganized to meet purported dangers from the West and Soviet authorities announced the closing of two more highway links between East and West Germany.

TAHLEQUAH, Okla., May 23 (UP) -- Lightning set a shack on fire in the midst of a violent thunder and hail storm here today and nine Cherokee Indian children were burned to death in this village at the end of the storied Indian "trail of tears."

The Soviet press and radio have broken out in a new frenzy of anti-American accusations these last few days. We are, they say, doing all kinds of horrible things: preparing the North Pole as an anti-Soviet attack base, building concentration camps in Oklahoma and Arizona which will be the Maideneks and Oswiecims of the future, and secretly mapping Eastern Germany.

ST. LOUIS, May 23 (AP) -- Extra-base hitting, including Al Rosen's ninth home run of the season, backed up Mike Garcia's four-hit pitching as the Indians scored a 6-to-3 victory over the Browns tonight. Ned Garver, the Brownies' ace of last year, suffered his fourth setback.

Vocational training students at the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, First Avenue and Twenty-third Street, pushed back the parallel bars and training stair-steps in their functional therapy gymnasium yesterday and entertained their friends at a gay and colorful carnival.

EUGENE, Ore., May 23 (AP) -- Sim Iness of Southern California hurled the discus 183 feet 5 1/2 inches -- 4 feet 6 inches beyond the recognized United States college record -- at the Pacific Coast Conference track meet today.

CHICAGO. May 23 -- Grain futures had a strong tone on the Board of Trade in early session operations today, but upturns were brought to a halt by free selling, part of which was profit taking. Support was poor after short covering.

PITTSBURGH, May 23 (UP) -- Gus Bell and Johnny Merson slammed back-to-back doubles in the thirteenth inning tonight as the Pirates gained a 6-5 victory over the Cubs. The Pirate triumph broke an eight-game losing streak.

The stock market took a breathing spell yesterday but only after extending gains to new highs since last mid-April. The railroad and petroleum issues showed considerable strength for a good portion of the day but then faltered later on, while the steels and motors continued to present a ragged appearance.
CINCINNATI, May 23 (AP) -- The Reds today traded Outfielder Johnny Wyrostek and pitcher Kent Peterson to the Phillies for pitcher Bubba Church.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, May 17 (Delayed by Censor) (AP) -- South Korean sources said today four Republic of Korea (R. O. K.) guards and three North Korean Communist prisoners were killed and fifty-seven Reds were wounded in a riot April 10. [The Eighth Army confirmed the information today, May 24.]

Charges that Arnold Schuster, the slain Brooklyn salesman, had tried in vain to get police protection after having identified William F. Sutton, the bank robber, were made yesterday at the office of Corporation Counsel Denis M. Hurley.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 23 -- A reform of the system for fixing prices so as to stimulate competition and implement the new economic policy has been decided upon by the Ministry of Industry and will be announced by the Government soon.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- The Chicago Board of Trade will look into the question of extending trading hours, Carl Bostrom, president, said today.

The Stuttgart Kickers of West Germany scored their sixth victory in succession in this country by beating the Brooklyn Sport Club of the German-American Soccer League, 5 -- 4, at Metropolitan Oval, Maspeth, Queens, last night.

WASHINGTON, May. 23 (UP) -- Representative Reva Beck Bosone said today that she accepted $630 in "voluntary" campaign contributions from two of her four employes in 1950, but that she did not believe she had "violated the spirit of the law."

With 874 veterans barred from attendance at the Robert Louis Stevenson School at 246 West Eightieth Street because the State Board of Education has found the curriculum "below standards," the principal, Dr. Annette T. Rubinstein, who also is vice chairman of the American Labor party, obtained yesterday a show-cause order to which the Veterans Administration must reply before Federal Judge Edward A. Conger on Tuesday at 10 A. M.
Mr. A may have tuberculosis. He may pass it on to Mr. B, who may give it to Mr. C. Tuberculosis is communicable; it spreads from person to person.

Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the New York Methodist area, speaking at yesterday morning's session of the annual meeting of the New York East Methodist Conference at Hanson Place Central Methodist Church, St. Felix Street, Brooklyn, denounced "self - appointed guardians of this country who are casting aspersions upon our church, upon the curriculums of our schools, upon our church leaders and upon our church agencies."

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Western Union Telegraph Company and the Commercial Telegraphers Union, A.F.L., reached a conditional agreement this morning that may provide an end to the union's fifty-one-day strike against the company.

YONKERS, May 23 -- Philipse Manor Hall, 270-year-old Dutch Colonial landmark on busy Manor House Square in the heart of this city, was rededicated this afternoon. The ceremony was occasioned by a refurbishing made possible by the gift of Franco Scalamandre of Long Island City, a specialist in fabrics, who has provided draperies that are appropriate to each period of the Manor House's construction.

DOVER, Ohio, May 23 (UP) -- A natural gas explosion shattered windows and crumbled plaster in a new $750,000 wing of Union Hospital here today, but only two persons were injured. Patients had not been moved into the wing.
PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- Robert A. Evans, captain-elect of the University of Pennsylvania's 1952 football team, and Edward Bell, star end, were elected today to the Sphinx Senior Society.

Today's new film is "Models, Inc.," an independently produced drama released by Mutual Production Corporation and starring Howard Duff, Coleen Gray, John Howard and Marjorie Reynolds, at the Palace. Reginald Le Borg directed and Hal E. Chester produced the Jack Dietz, presentation from a script written by Harold Essex and Paul Yawitz and a story and adaptation by Alyce Canfield.

Dollar sales volume of major New York department stores this week again ran below that for the corresponding week of last year by an estimated 8 per cent. Cold and rainy weather through part of the week was an adverse factor.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 23 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower paid a farewell visit today to the headquarters of the international troops of his Central Command. In a brief ceremony in the courtyard of the historic royal palace in Fontainebleau the Supreme Allied Commander told the units drawn up before him:

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered railroads today to reduce unloading charges on fresh fruits and vegetables at pier stations in lower Manhattan. The same order applies to charges at Philadelphia.

It is regrettable when the forces that bind powerful groups together in fighting the world-wide Communist conspiracy develop schisms that may affect their common objective. That is why current differences between the American Federation of Labor and the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions are of great significance.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Office of Price Stabilization is making every effort to protect the public from price-gouging during the potato shortage, Ellis G. Arnall, head of the agency, said today.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 23 -- A total bus strike that has plagued this industrial center for twenty-four days will end tomorrow on the basis of truce terms agreed to here today.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The nation's railroads were handed back to their owners today, on orders of President Truman, twenty-one months after they were taken over by the Army to avert a paralyzing strike in a dispute over wages and working rules.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 23 (AP) -- Defense production by General Motors Corporation amounts to about 20 per cent of the total volume of its various divisions, stockholders were told at the annual meeting today.

BUENOS AIRES, May 23 -- After the personal intervention of President Juan D. Peron, Minister of the Interior Angel Borlenghi last night ordered the release from jial of approximately 100 Roman Catholic teen-age youths who had been picked up by the police last Tuesday evening for demonstrating at the premiere of a film they considered immoral.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) Following is the vote by which the House today passed and sent to the Senate the $6,174,600,000 foreign aid bill:
A second former member of the District Attorney's staff in Staten Island was accused yesterday of having been a visitor in a house on the island that was used for gambling.
Prices of cotton futures dipped 16 to 25 points yesterday in moderate volume of business on the New York Cotton Exchange.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 23 (AP) -- Samuel P. Steckler's Decapolis copped a day of long-shot winners at Garden State Park before 16,073 fans today when he captured the featured Chambersburg Purse to pay $33.20 for $2 as the rank outsider.
YONKERS, May 23 -- Sixty-five teams a record for the event, took part in the Westchester Professional Golfers Association "pro-lady" tourney at the Hudson River Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Dr. Joseph W. Weinberg, the "Scientist X" accused by the House Un-American Activities Committee of having given atomic secrets to Russia, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of having lied when he denied he had been a member of the Communist Party.

A collection of seating pieces designed with the characteristically Danish regard for both good proportion and comfort has just arrived at We Moderns, 227 East Sixty-seventh Street. Imported by John Stuart from Copenhagen, they were designed by Ole Wanscher, a well-known interior architect of that city.

JONES BEACH, L. I., May 23 -- With the promise of fair weather and temperatures well up in the 70's, authorities here were ready tonight for the first rush of sun and water bathers tomorrow when the resort will usher in its twenty-third warm weather season.
