LONDON, May 23 -- The British Ambassador in Madrid, Sir John Balfour, has informed the Spanish Government that Britain considers the 1945 agreement for international control of Tangier still in effect.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 23 -- J. Russel Sprague, who has been County Executive of Nassau County since 1938, announced today at a meeting of Republican leaders of the county in the old Court House here that he would not be a candidate for re-election.

Public housing bonds are gradually disappearing from the secondary market for tax-exempt obligations, it was observed here yesterday. The Blue List's advertised offerings of $247,375,000 of local government obligations carries only $4,467,000 of the housing bonds.

Hitler's looting of the Austrian economy was "inadvertently sanctioned" at Potsdam -- where President Truman, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin met in 1945 -- and the decisions there had enabled the Russians to continue the process, Dr. Leopold Figl, Chancellor of Austria, declared here yesterday.

Bernon T. Woodle Jr. has sold the four four-story apartment houses at 1, 3 and 5 Minetta Lane and 17 Minetta Street to Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, in a transaction negotiated by J. Clarence Davies, Inc., as broker. The buildings, at the southeast corner of the two

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 23 -- The pressures of world rearmament have caused Britain, France and Belgium to change -- and sometimes curtail -- plans for the economic development of their African territories, the United Nations reported today in a new economic survey.

CLEVELAND, May 23 -- Medical research is as important as industrial research, and American business leaders should apply the same active interest to both as a practical investment, A. W. Robertson of Pittsburgh, chairman of the board of the American Heart Association, said here tonight.

In its ten years the James Foundation of New York, Inc., has distributed $12,019,800 in gifts to charitable, religious and educational institutions, the trustees reported yesterday. Established under the will of Arthur Curtiss James, capitalist, who died in 1941, the foundation, at the end of 1951, had assets valued at $31,275,901.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 24 -- The United Nations Command rejected yesterday Communist charges that its planes three times this month bombed prison camps in North Korea where captured Allied soldiers are interned.

About $2,000,000 will be spent this year by the Mississippi River Fuel Corporation to increase its capacity to 450,000,000 cubic feet daily from 400,000,000, William G. Marbury, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting in St. Louis.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Army disciplined today the two general officers held responsible for the recent Koje Island prisoner-of-war incidents by stripping them of their stars and demoting them to colonels. A third general was reprimanded.

The issues raised by the conduct of Communist prisoners-of-war in Korea and by inept United States control of these prisoners continued yesterday to obscure and confuse the larger issue of peace or war in Korea
The Woman's Press Club of New York City will hold an international-relations program today at the Statler Hotel. Officers will be installed for the 1952-54 term.

Two men were arrested yesterday for allegedly operating a gambling wire room in the rear of a fruit-and-vegetable store in Elmhurst, Queens, as a result of a raid led by Supervising Assistant Chief Inspector James R. Kennedy of the Police Commissioner's confidential squad.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 23 (UP) -- The Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., today voted to tie up West Coast shipping over the week-end and served notice on the Pacific Maritime Association a full coast-wide strike would be called Monday if shipowners refused to negotiate a new contract with the union.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A delay of a couple of seconds has cost the Glidden Company, Cleveland paint manufacturer, $19,000.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- The American Baptist Convention and the International Convention of Disciples of Christ, together representing more than 3,600,000 churchgoers, ended a simultaneous five-day annual meeting here tonight.
John Golden, chairman of the theatre industry's fund-raising drive for the Actors' Fund of America, announced yesterday that its goat of $100,000 had been attained.

An old galley slave whose memories cling to the days when New York's newspapers clustered about Park Row has taken note of the fact that Brooklyn Bridge was opened officially on May 24, sixty-nine years ago -- a day which happened to be Queen Victoria's birthday.

Two books dealing with ancient civilizations are scheduled for publication a month apart. On Tuesday, Library Publishers will issue "Secret Cities of Old South America: Atlantis Unveiled," by Harold T. Wilkins. Based on more than ten years' research, Mr. Wilkins' book contends that the lost continents of Atlantis, Mu and Pan are to be founds, not in the depths of the ocean, but in the West Indies and in Central and South America.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company plans to replace its eleven-story building on East Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Streets and Madison and Fourth Avenues with a thirteen-story office structure to cost $23,200,000. Charles G. Taylor, president of the

Atherton Pettingell, president of Dorland, Inc., his key executives and the agency's clients will join Wesley Associates, Inc., June 1, it was learned yesterday. On that day Wesley will move from its present quarters at 347 Madison Avenue to Dorland's office at 247 Park Avenue.
I read with interest your excellent editorial on the recent actions of the passport division of the State Department.

Two hundred young musicians received diplomas and degrees at yesterday's commencement exercises of the Juilliard School of Music. The ceremonies, conducted by William Schuman, president, and Mark Schubart, dean, marked the end of the school's forty-seventh academic year.

WATERTOWN, S. D., May 23 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, intimated strongly today that if he was elected President, General of the Army Douglas MacArthur would play an important part in foreign policy. To reporters covering his South Dakota campaign tour he said:

President Truman hailed the leaders of the Boy Scouts of America yesterday for good citizenship in promoting a non-partisan campaign to encourage all citizens to register and vote in the forthcoming elections.

PARIS, May 23 -- The shrill world-wide Communist propaganda campaign against the tightening bonds of Western defense erupted tonight into violent demonstrations and clashes with police in three areas of Paris as French authorities launched a legal counterattack.

Likelihood of any critical supply problems in primary steel exports in event of a resumed steel strike were called remote by trade sources yesterday. Slackened demand overseas and in intensified dollar shortages abroad were cited as factors making for less severe restriction of available supply in event of a renewed production stoppage.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused to act today on hundreds of requests for the suspension of the new scale of class rates on railroad freights, and the new uniform freight classification which go into effect on May 30.

Individuals and business organizations subject to the automobile use tax must pay up not later than June 16 and affix to the windshields of their cars by that date the prescribed $5 or $10 stamps serving as evidence of payment, City Treasurer Spencer C. Young, said yesterday.

Johnny Bratton gained the decision over Del Flanagan of St. Paul in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The Chicago welterweight, who once had some recognition as the champion of his division, had an easy time against Flanagan, and the only wonder was that the decision was a split one.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- More flexible visiting hours for parents have proved helpful in preventing emotional problems for children in hospitals, Dr. Dane G. Prugh, associate psychologist of the Children's Medical Center, Harvard Medical School, told the American Academy of Pediatrics today.

It is certainly to be hoped that action soon will be taken on the suggestion made the other day by Bernard F. Gimbel, chairman of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, and Thomas D'Arcy Brophy, president of the American Heritage Foundation, for the formation of a citizens' committee to plan for the celebration of New York City's 300th birthday next year.

VIENNA, May 23 -- The Austrian People's party has received the choice of forcing through an investigation of the handling of Marshall Plan funds by Austria's biggest bank, the nationalized Creditanstalt, or having further Marshall Plan aid for this country cut off this year.

GENEVA, N. Y., May 23 -- Prof. M. T. Munn, Chief of the Division of Seed Investigation at the New York State Agricultural Experiment Station will retire Aug. 1 after forty years of research work. He is 65.

An edict forbidding ministers to officiate at the remarriage of a divorced person until one year after the divorce was rescinded here yesterday by the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. The church now requires only satisfaction that there is "penitence for past sin and failure."

KOJE, May 23 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Haydon L. Boatner, prison camp commandant, continued today arrangements to split the Communist prisoner-of-war population of this riot-torn United Nations camp into smaller groups.
GREEN BAY Wis., May 23 (AP) -- An intensive study to find means of improved less - than - carload service on the nation's railroads was recommended here yesterday.

STRASBOURG, France, May 23 -- The text of the treaty for a European Defense Community, sub ject to approval by higher authorities, was completed today by the foreign ministers of the six countries to be represented in the army.

Directors of A. D. Juilliard Co., Inc., elevated Burnet Valentine, vice president, to president yesterday to succeed Robert Westaway, who has retired after more than 50 years with the textile company. Mr. Valentine joined Juilliard in 1941, prior to which he had been with the Pepperell Manufacturing Company twelve years as merchandise manager.

The 1952 Pulitzer Traveling Scholarships for study abroad have been awarded by the faculty of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism to the Rev. John B. Bremner, William C. Kreger and Emerson E. Chapin, students at the school.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 23 -- The New Jersey State Bar Association took steps today to deny membership to any attorney who is a member of the Communist party or who advocates the overthrow of the United States Government by force or violence.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Truman, who is awaiting a Supreme Court decision on use of Presidential powers in the steel case, engaged Congress today in a battle over his executive powers on treaties and agreements.

In a surprise move yesterday, two of three alleged basketball fixers, who are scheduled to go on trial in General Sessions on Tuesday, were remanded to City Prison after Assistant District Attorney Vincent A. G. O'Connor expressed fear that his prospective witnesses were being intimidated.
The three-story building containing six apartments at 458 Eighth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Violet F. Neebe to Mary A. Newkamp. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured title.

Lowered from the burning roof of a five-story building at 120 East 102d Street, a fireman yesterday morning caught hold of a young woman who had been trapped in her top-floor apartment. Fastened to a rope, the fireman, carrying the rescued woman, was then lowered to the courtyard.

Senate passage of the McCarran anti-immigration bill means now that hope of defeating this monstrous piece of legislation lies in a Presidential veto. We trust that the veto will be forth-coming and that enough Congressmen will have read the measure prior to that time to insure that the veto will be sustained.

UTICA, N. Y., May 23 (AP) -- Preliminary outline of a plan to consolidate the Utica Knitting Company and the J. T. Flagg Knitting Company has been approved "in principle" by officials of both concerns, stockholders of the Utica company were told today.
VIENNA, May 23 (AP) -- The Czechoslovak Government broadcast orders today for drastic cuts in the use of electricity in plants, shops and homes throughout the Communist nation.

BOSTON, May 23 (UP) -- Eddie Sue, Fred W. Hooper's brown filly, established herself as a strong contender for next week's Bay State Kindergarten Stakes as she loafed to an easy victory over seven other 2-year-olds today in the Colonial Purse at Suffolk Downs.

BATON ROUGE, La., May 23 (AP) -- Gov. Robert Kennon said today a majority of Louisiana's twenty-four-member delegation to the Democratic National Convention favored the Presidential candidacy of Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia.

Charles Virion, a machinist who was born in France and became a naturalized American, will scrub up with special care this evening after work on his electronic gadget for the armed services at the W. L. Maxon Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The Department of Defense today identified eighty-three additional battle casualties in a new Korea list (No. 570) that reported twenty killed, filly-nine wounded, two missing and two injured. The following casualties were reported from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

Indignation over the shortage and high price of potatoes manifested itself yesterday in the declaration of boycotts by two restaurant associations and a purchasing agency supplying twenty-five hospitals and other institutions in the city.

AFTER a solid week spent contemplating the private woes of fictional characters and the public catastrophes that oppress mankind it seemed high time for a change of literary diet. Something more relaxing seemed indicated, and what could be more suitable than a novel about the eternal triangle, that mainstay of story-tellers for the last 3,000 years?

One of the interesting aspects of the transfer of Gen. Matthew Ridgway from Asia to Europe is that it is also a transfer from service in a universal to a regional security system. In Korea he was the commander of the United Nations forces; in France he will he the commander of the army of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

PARIS, May 23 -- The French Cabinet decided late tonight to attach conditions to the signature by the French of the treaty to create a European army and the contractual agreement with West Germany. The conditions would be part of the two treaties submitted to the French Parliament.
PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- Behind the neat pitching of Ben Wade and the home-run hitting of Roy Campanella, the Dodgers rolled to their seventh straight triumph tonight before 30,323 Shibe Park fans.

The Rev. Dr. Andrew Drummond Harcus, general secretary of the Free Church Federal Council in Britain, who is one of fourteen British clergymen scheduled to preach in the United States this summer in an annual interchange of preachers, will preach at 5 P. M. tomorrow at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street.

COLOMBO, Ceylon. May 23 -- Ceylon, the smallest dominion in the British Commonwealth, begins tomorrow her crucial week-long general elections, her first since she became independent in 1948, with the Conservative Government party seeking to hold power for another five years against a spirited campaign by Leftists and others.

A crowd estimated by the police at 10,000 persons lined the streets yesterday afternoon outside the Riverside Memorial Chapel at Amsterdam Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street during a funeral service for John Garfield, the actor, who died on Wednesday of a heart attack at the age of 39.
The sixty-nine-family apartment house at 2819 Morris Avenue, has been purchased by Geisinger Rau, operators, from Anna Seigel. The property is assessed at $215,000.
A freakish automobile accident at Broadway and Wall Street caused injuries to three persons and a traffic tie-up about 2 P. M. yesterday.

Two 18-year-old theft suspects, one on parole from a reformatory, were arrested early yesterday after an automobile chase through Brooklyn streets. The police charged the youths were responsible for thirty robberies in Brooklyn and Queens, and said they had admitted ten burglaries and thefts of property from automobiles.

After a turbulent session the Philippine Congress has just adjourned without taking action on the proposed budget for 1953 or making provision for the essential counterpart funds for further economic aid and progress. The Philippine Senate, also, refused to ratify the San Francisco peace treaty and took no action on a substitute proposal that would have authorized a bilateral treaty with Japan.
]Viol Co. will retire as a member firm of the New York Stock 'Exchange on May 29.

Davey Williams, successor to Ed Stanky at second base for the Giants, started three 4, 6, 3 double plays against the Braves at the Polo Grounds last night. Each helped Sal Maglie achieve a 5-3 victory, his eighth straight this season. Of course, a five-run attack against Max Surkont in the fourth counted heavily, too.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to homemakers.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- Assistant Atttorney General H. Graham Morison urged a Senate Small Business subcommittee today to launch an investigation of the nation's economic make-up.
PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- Plans for several $100-a-plate Republican "unity" dinners in Pennsylvania on June 19 were announced today by the party's finance committee.

Ford C. Frick, commissioner of baseball, said yesterday that the qualified recognition by a House Judiciary subcommittee of the necessity for a reserve clause "confirms the convictions of all baseball people."

Justice Bernard Lloyd Shientag of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court collapsed yesterday evening of a heart attack in his apartment at 737 Park Avenue and died at 7:30, before a physian could reach his side. His age was 65.

A House Judiciary subcommittee, after hearings that began last July, has brought in its finding about legislation concerning baseball. It has decided that baseball's controversial problems can be decided "by the rule of reason" and that there is no occasion for Congress "to enact a special rule of reason" for the game.

DENVER, May 23 (AP) -- Oil union officers recommended the strike of a large California refinery today, just as the Government announced that restrictions on automotive gasoline, kerosene and fuel oil had been ended and those o naviation gasoline would be relaxed next week.

The Ingersoll-Rand Company, manufacturer of air and gas compressors, rock drills, oil and gas engines, pumps, condensers, air conditioning and refrigeration machinery, had a net profit in the first quarter this year of $4,914,555 after taxes and all charges.

Textile finishers and dyers were urged yesterday to join an industry-wide effort to improve the quality of fabrics. The finishers and dyers have a responsibility to the consumer, it was pointed out, that goes beyond the instructions of fabric manufacturers and distributors buying their service.

The Women's Meeting of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., held an all-day service yesterday at Riverside Church, dedicated to its missions. More than 2,500 attended, many from other cities, and late arrivals had to be turned away.

DETROIT, May 23 (AP) -- This week's automotive production was estimated today by Ward's Automotive Reports at 118,438 cars and trucks. The figure represented a drop of 1,501 units from last week's production. The loss was attributed to labor troubles which affected Chrysler Corporation, Briggs Manufacturing Company and Ford Motor Company's Mercury division.

The thirty-sixth running of the $50,000 added Coaching Club American Oaks will be staged at Belmont Park today, with the Calumet Farm's Real Delight a probable 1-2 favorite. The Bull Lea filly has won five of her last six starts, including the Kentucky Oaks and Black-Eyed Susan Stakes.
FLORENCE, Italy, May 23 -- The city of Florence made public amends today for the hanging and burning of a Dominican monk whose defiance threatened a schism in the Roman Catholic Church 454 years ago.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., May 23 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California, opening his final drive to capture his home state's seventy votes in the Republican national convention, took pains today to deny the existence of any sort of horse-trading deal with any other candidate.

ALTHOUGH the majority of the zealous anglers are moving north at this season, a small but equally enthusiastic group always heads south, for the tarpon begin showing in great numbers in the rivers and "passes" along the Florida coast.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway expressed confidence today that the North Atlantic Treaty defense force, of which he is about to take command, would "frustrate" Communist designs in Europe as the United Nations forces have in Korea.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 23 (AP) -- The Greentree Stable's Guillotine has received top weight of 126 pounds for the $10,000-added six-furlong Wilmington Handicap, the inaugural feature when Delaware Park opens its thirty-three-day meeting Thursday.

Lumber production for the week ended May 17 was 25.4 per cent below the comparable week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by regional associations. Shipments were down 12.3 per cent and orders 20.7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Average primary market prices rose 0.4 per cent over the week ended May 20, 1952, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index, 112 per cent of the 1947-49 average, was 2.6 per cent below the average for January, 1951, and 0.1 per cent above the level of the latest comprehensive index -- April, 1952.
TRIESTE, May 23 -- The four-cornered election fight in Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste ended officially tonight in a blaze of oratory.

ROME, May 23 -- Relations between Italy and Yugoslavia became appreciably more tense today when the Italian Government requested Yugoslavia to withdraw her military attache in Rome, Lieut. Col. Rudi Kodric. The Italian Government previously had recalled its military attache in Belgrade, as was announced in the Yugoslav capital yesterday.

AVERILL PARK, N. Y., May 23 -- The vice chairman of the Republican State Committee, Jane H. Todd, warned today that bitter pre-conventionu strife between the backers of Senator Robert A. Taft and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower would injure the party's chances in the November election.

The current debate in the House of Commons on the inflationary character of the new wage demands of British labor sounds like an echo of the discussion held this week at the American Assembly. The conference at Arden House ended with a report which pointed up the grave dangers to the American economy and the stability of the Western World of the inflationary pressures created by the abnormal international situation.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 23 -- An electric gremlin -- static electricity -- is causing trouble in the new synthetic "wonder clothes," a chemist said tonight.

MOBILE, Ala., May 23 -- Baldwin County potato shipping centers are so jammed with trucks waiting for Irish potatoes that Sheriff Taylor Wilkins and his men were called out today to clear the vehicles off the streets. Baldwin has a good crop and apparently potato dealers from all over the nation are on hand.
HACKENSACK, N. J., May 23 -- Mayor Joseph Srholez of Little Ferry was acquitted tonight of charges of misconduct in office for allegedly having failed to suppress bookmaking in his community.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 23 -- Superior Court Judge Ralph J. Smalley ruled here today that Vincent Higgins of South Amboy could not serve on both the South Amboy Board of Education and the City Council.

NEWARK, May 23 -- The Federal grand jury have indicted today two companies and three individuals for conspiracy to defraud the Government in negotating a $473,000 Federal Housing Admininstration loan for home building from the County Trust Company of Tarrytown, N. Y.
WANTAGH, L. I., May 23 -- This village, which has been fighting for four years to get a bank, is going to get not one but two banks -- and it doesn't like it at all.

Jack Hurley, manager of Harry (Kid) Matthews, Seattle light heavyweight, will confer with President Jim Norris and Director Harry Markson of the International Boxing Club on Monday or Tuesday regarding a match between Matthews and Rocky Marciano.

PARIS, May 23 -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati and Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables Fla., were among the winning players today in the French tennis championships, which have attracted most of the world's leading amateurs to Roland Garros Stadium.
TRENTON, May 23 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, opposed to price-fixing in principle, announced approval today of a legislative measure restoring minimum price control for cigarettes in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- An authorization of $6,174,600,000 for the Mutual Security Program in the fiscal year 1953 was voted 245 to 110 by the House of Representatives and sent to the Senate today. Passage came after a coalition of Republicans and runaway Democrats had trimmed $1,725,400,000 from the amount requested by the President.

The donation of 1,047 pints of blood yesterday raised the total collected in the Red Cross local regional blood program to 18,996 pints in the first twenty-three days of this month. The quota for May is 22,500 pints.

Despite a general slump in liquor sales, rum producers expect their business to pick up in the next few months. Over-all liquor sales have been unusually bad, both in bars and package stores, since the last tax increase in November pushed up prices, but the rum people believe they can still achieve normal summer business levels.

The American Council for Judaism, in a letter to President Truman yesterday, urged him to do everything in his power to prevent enactment of the McCarran-Walter immigration bill. The President was asked instead to encourage the adoption of "some such liberal immigration policy as that formulated in the Humphrey-Lehman bill."

LONDON, May 23 -- Heavy selling of British Government securities continued to depress prices in the stock markets today. However, pressure relaxed in the afternoon and losses of British funds were smaller than yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- The Government predicted today that a record $32,000,000,000 would be spent for new construction this year. This would top outlays in 1951 by about $1,000,000,000.

Of a lot of Philippines sugar reported originally at 75,000 tons, unsold and due here in June, only 20,000 to 30,000 tons remained yesterday. But spot market prices have been affected to the extent of a 15-point reduction in two days.

FORT WORTH, May 23 (AP) -- Rain caused postponement of the second round of the $20,000 Colonial national invitation golf tournament today and tournament officials expected another postponement tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 23 --Considerable concern is being expressed here over the prospect that the United States will be more than $1,000,000 in default on its contribution to the United Nations budget for 1952.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., May 23 (AP) -- Six hundred former city employes voted tonight to go back to work without the wage increase they were seeking in a labor dispute that has tied up garbage collections and other city services for sixteen days.
Governor Dewey, holding that socialized medicine "has wrecked the standard of medical care in every country where it has been tried," declared yesterday that it is a high road to totalitarianism."

Your correspondent's recent comments on Moscow propaganda may be supplemented by anyone with a good short-wave radio. I listened in stark astonishment the other evening over 31.31 meters to the Prague-Moscow relay. I barged into an eloquent address, ostensibly from a United States prisoner, who inveighed against our capitalist invasion of peaceful North Korea.

PITTSBURGH, May 23 (AP) -- The East Pittsburgh plant of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation will be closed for the next four days -- three days by order of the union and the fourth by order of the company. The 17,000 employes will be affected.

The maritime Industry's plea for a "more reasonable" approach in smoke-control matters was supported yesterday by Rear Admiral William S. Maxwell, deputy director of the city's Bureau of Smoke Control, who called present regulations "too stringent" for ships and tugboats.
LONDON, May 23 (Reuters) -- Middlesex added to its lead in the English County cricket championship today.
CINCINNATI, May 23 (UP) -- Wally Post and Roy McMillan tagged Harry Brecheen for home runs tonight to give Ken Raffensberger and the Reds a 2-1 victory over the Cardinals before 12,235 fans.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 23 -- Unites States Customs authorities are hindering research on the Soviet Union by detaining for long periods vital Soviet periodicals, students of the Soviet economy said today during informal conversation at Arden House here.

Four of last year's group winners, including the English setter that went on to best in show, are among the 2,851 dogs entered in today's Morris and Essex Kennel Club competition at Giralda Farms in Madison, N. J. The event is the largest dog show in America.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Senate passed by the voice vote of about a half dozen of its ninety-six members today a bill to increase the authority for Government assistance to housing by $1,395,000,000, mostly in critical defense areas.
NORWALK, Conn., May 23 -- The bookies start young in this suburban community, the State Police found out today.

The forty-first semi-annual outdoor art show is now in session on the walls, railings and streets surrounding Washington Square Park. Several hundred exhibitors are showing their work this year, many of them for the first time, competing for valuable prizes and for the recognition that all artists would like to get.
With summer week-ends and vacations ahead, the indispensable man - tailored shirt again steps ahead as a versatile packable item for women of all ages.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A globe-girdling House investigating subcommittee reported today that unification of the military forces was still so lacking in the supply services that logistical support had suffered and surpluses and waste were piling up.
Inland shipyards launched 138 boats and barges in the first three months of this year, the American Waterways Operators reported yesterday

PURCHASE, N. Y., May 23 -- After numerous engineering, political and fiscal obstacles had been hurdled in two years of discussion, contracts for construction of the first large hangar for commercial and private planes at the Westchester County Airport were near signature today.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Truman approved today with "great reluctance" two bills that will add approximately $400,000,000 a year to the cost of pensions and allowances for more than 3,000,000 disabled veterans and their dependents.

BOSTON, May 23 (UP) -- Northeastern's Sal Mazzocca, defending champion in the broad jump, starred in the sixty-fifth New England college track championship trials today with a leap of 23 feet 8 inches to equal the Massachusetts Institute of Technology field record.
ROME, May 19 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, is scheduled to dedicate on June 6 the copy of the Princeton Index of Christian Art that he himself made available to the Vatican.

After overhanging financial markets a fortnight, disagreement between labor and management appears to be nearing a solution. Both financial circles and the general public, as a result, have assumed a more optimistic view, and stock prices developed a firmer tone during the week, scoring the best advance in two months.

IN his fourth volume of poetry, "From Time to Time." John Ciardi displays his striking and original talent exercised upon a diversity of themes. Although many of his poems are quite explicit studies of a limited number of recurring subjects -- death, the father, birth -- one is always aware of the particularity and immediacy of the experiences that inspired these poems.

WASHINGTON -- Those who enjoy stepping back into the historic past will find an authentic gem in old Gunston Hall, home of George Mason, author of the Bill of Rights. This plantation house on the Potomac River has reopened after being closed for almost a year for restoration to the period in which it was built, 1755 to 1758.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway has advised Senators that the United Nations forces have the military power in the Far East to end the Korean war, but that "political" decisions would have to precede any effort to do so.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -- Representative John W. McCormack, the House Democratic leader, said today the American Medical Association had put on "the greatest exhibition of pressure" he had ever seen in the recent House fight over increasing Social Security benefits.

The recent article on the role of Stalin and on his likely successor, written by Sir David Kelly, until a few months ago British Ambassador to Moscow, is one of the keenest analyses of such matters which has appeared anywhere. Sir David's conclusion that it is unlikely that any dramatic change

NEWARK, May 24 -- Edward T. Dickinson of Washington, vice chairman of the National Security Resources Board, will speak Tuesday at the annual "Vineland Day" sponsored by the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs at the Vineland Training School, an institution for retarded children.

MOST National League batters wish that Sal Maglie had been wearing a catcher's mask that day many years ago when he was behind the plate, catching other fellow's pitches. But he wasn't wearing a mask, and a foul tip smashed him in the mouth.
DEVON, Pa., May 24 -- Margaret C. McGinn tonight retired the J. W. Waring Memorial Challenge Trophy for the best child rider at the Devon Horse Show.

ANY child who has longed for a pet, "something little and alive," will know how excited Ellen was at the prospect of a kitten. Father maintained that an apartment was no place for a pet, but Ellen promised faithfully to take care of Smokey herself.

MUNICH, Germany, May 24 -- Bavaria's Minister of Justice, Dr. Josef Mueller, has the choice of resignation or dismissal from office for having refused to testify how much money he had received from a rabbi accused of fraud, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Air Force has reversed itself and assured the Senate that it favors development of civilian jet airliners now.

BONN, Germany, Sunday, May 25 -- The foreign ministers of the United States. Britain and France labored until early this morning to find a formula that would satisfy France's demand for a guarantee against a German walkout from the European Defense Community.

LINDEN, N. J., May 24 (AP) -- A small group of men gathered one morning in 1883 in a little office at Bayonne, N. J. An oak roll-top desk stood in the corner. A gas burning lamp stuck out from one wall. The men drew their chairs up to a plain table and opened the first annual stockholders' meeting of the Standard Oil Company at the company's refinery in this waterfront city.

NOT every gardener can do each chore at the right time. Most do what is first at hand in the few spare hours available during a busy week. However, a sense of timing does speed the job, as well as make it easier and more effective.

IF epicures save their big burgundies and well-made clarets for winter festivities, then it follows that they turn in warm weather, when eating becomes more casual, to what they call the "small wines."

MADISON, N. J., May 24 -- An imported wire-haired foxterrier rose to the top in America's largest dog show today and the hopes of a beautiful Doberman pinscher to add its highest honors to those he took at Westminster fell into the soggy green grass of Giralda Farms.

IF the popular interest and favor manifested toward such films as "King Solomon's' Mines," "The River" and, recently, "The African Queen" are any sort of criteria, then the. picture that Carol Reed has made from Joseph Conrad's "Outcast Of The Islands" should be a winner, indeed.
IN his "Dictionary of Gastronomy" (Farrar, Straus, 1949) Andre Simon, president of the Wine and Food Society of London, cautions against spoiling the taste of strawberries by washing them.

THE use of your valuable space is asked to say a few words about the gifted John Garfield, star of the American stage and screen, and his untimely death last week, so stunning to all of his admirers and friends.
FORT WORTH, May 24 -- Ray Gafford, Dallas professional, took an undisputed lead in the $20,000 Colonial golf tournament today as he came in with a one-under-par 69 for a 36-hole, total of 137.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 24 -- With its finest performance of the season, Army's lacrosse team trounced Navy, 15 -4, in the twenty-fifth game of the traditional rivalry on The Plains today.

UNUSUAL activity in the photographic publishing field is reflected in the issues of new works in several categories. Most of these deal with technical matters. One exception is the record of a two-year photographic adventure that served as a honeymoon for a photographer and his wife, a picture magazine researcher.

ONE afternoon in Williamsport, Pa., many years ago, Carl Stotz sat dejectedly on the sidelines during a sandlot baseball game, his glove clutched in a grimy fist. The bigger boys had chosen up sides for a game and Stotz, being a little fellow, had been by-passed. What plunged him into even greater despair was that this was happening all the time.

BOSTON, Mass., May 24 -- Organized labor, long accustomed to advertising its political likes and hates in neon lights, is unusually modest about how much it hopes to accomplish in the crucial election campaign this fall.

Your layout, "Bad Birds -- Or Benefactors" (May 18) left out one which is badly misunderstood, I believe, and undergoes serious persecution on that account. It is the cormorant, which many inland sports fishermen accuse of eating game fish. It is not protected by Federal law, and on its migrations through the Midwest is destroyed in great numbers.

BLUE is the spark that enliv ens any garden color scheme. It can be used for contrast or harmony, or for its own value alone. Yet it is the rarest hue on the floral color wheel. In a search for blue flowers to replace perennial delphiniums, which, in my West Virginia garden behave like annuals, I discovered the value of anchusas.

JACK L. WARNER might well have been speaking for the entire motion picture industry when he remarked that "we believe our future has never been rosier, both literally and figuratively'' in announcing the other day that Warner Brothers would use color photography on twenty-seven of its next thirty-three productions.

IN writing about nothingness, the author unfortunately suggests having nothing to write about. The nothing he chooses is Berlin, 1947. A nobody named Paul Stein visits Berlin on a routine Army P. R. O. job.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 24 (AP) -- Two managers and one former player were fined and suspended today by Henry S. Baynard, Florida International League president.

LONDON, Sunday, May 25 (AP) -- The new Soviet note, broadcast by Moscow radio early today, replied to American, British and French notes of May 13. The Allies said at that time they were willing to join in talks on unifying Germany if the Soviet Union first agreed to free all-German elections.

The growth of New York State's government in recent years is mirrored on a reduced scale in the evolution of the State Department of Commerce which, in a sense, had its beginning in 1929 as the Bureau of State Publicity in the Conservation Department.

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 24 -- Although ordered recently by the Board of Fire Commissioners to ignore alarms on the New Jersey State Turnpike here, Fire Chief Patrick F. Keelan said today that firemen had doused three fires starting in hay used by landscapers on the embankments along the toll road.

Delegates to the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. adopted yesterday a church benevolence budget for 1953 of $19,086,000, an increase of $136,000 over last year. At the same time, they heard that $6,625,418 had been pledged to the $12,000,000 building funds campaign begun March 2.

BEN GRAUER, the institutional voice of the National Broadcasting Company, has become a new kind of symbol in television. For twenty-two years his voice has been to the N. B. C. radio network what Leo the Lion is to M.-G.-M, but now the major portion of his television appearances take place on specialized programs having nothing to do with selling soap or deodorants.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 24 -- Princeton's varsity track team took twelve first places and swept three events to overwhelm Pennsylvania, 96 -- 44, in the rain at Palmer Stadium today.
A policy ring that in the last ten days had done business of more than $2,500 a day was broken up yesterday afternoon by a raid on a renovated tenement apartment in East Harlem, the police announced.

MOSCOW, May 24 -- Pravda and other Moscow newspapers asserted today that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was campaigning for the Republican Presidential nomination as a kind of Democratic trojan horse, who would throw off his wraps after the election and reveal that he was really a Democrat.

BUENOS AIRES, May 24 (UP) -- Roman Catholic prelates today joined in a campaign against alleged immorality in stage and movie shows. Riots in Buenos Aires connected with the campaign were attributed to United States Catholic missionaries by the Government.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, May 24 (AP) -- Emily Rebecca Rozelle, 5 days old, whose premature birth at sea sped a United States Navy ship off her course in the Atlantic, was rushed in an oxygen tent to Southampton General Hospital today when the United States transport Washington docked here.

JERSEY CITY, May 24 -- Two men were found guilty today of the murder of Brother Salesius Klein, head of the Roman Catholic order of the Brothers of the Poor of St. Francis. The jury, which deliberated three hours and forty minutes, recommended that the men be sentenced to life imprisonment at hard labor.

THE striking and expensively clad young woman entered the library, shook hands formally and proceeded to solve the mystery of the trayful of round lumps on the Capehart. "Have a popcorn ball," Jennifer Jones offered.

PARIS, May 24 -- Current history has devised events in such a fashion that when Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway arrives in France next Tuesday he will be faced immediately with some of the most urgent and vital problems involved in his new task as Supreme Allied Commander, Europe.

Female sex hormones may be a possible key to the mystery of why women under 50 are far less susceptible than men to hardening of the coronary arteries. The role of the sex and adrenal hormones was the subject of one of several scientific reports delivered at Cleveland, Ohio, last week at the annual meeting of the Council for High Blood Pressure Research of the American Heart Association.

Six education students at Hunter College who received certificates this week in recognition of the volunteer work they have done in community centers and other social agencies in the city are more enthusiastic, however, about the insight their experience has given them into problems they may meet when they are teaching.

Led by Claire Sullivan, who scored 26 points, Our Lady of Wisdom Academy of Ozone Park, Queens, registered 70 markers to take the team trophy in the high school division of the women's development track and field day at Triboro Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.

AS the title indicates, the theme of "Big Family of Peoples" is the essential oneness, the interrelationship, of all mankind. Beginning with a hypothetical prehistoric family, Miss Eberle shows how families intermarried, became tribes, developed into races and nations, and yet kept right on mixing with other peoples.

THE first days of the Masterpieces of the Twentieth Century Exposition held in this city have seen a plethora of significant music, and many more events than one observer, even if he could divide himself, could possibly attend.

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 4 -- The Union County Park Commission will make refunds to 228 members of the Galloping Hill Golf Club, holders of season tickets for the course in near-by Kenilworth, W. Richmond Tracy, engineer and secretary of the commission, said today.

Northwood Preparatory School of Lake Placid, rowing in competition for the first time, captured first place yesterday in a special race on the Harlem River. The New York Institute for the Education of the Blind was second, followed by the Columbia University spares.

SIX photographers in quest of truth present their findings, each in his own way, in the first of a serise of exhibitions which opened last week in the Auditorium Gallery of the Museum of Modern Art. The show will continue through Aug. 17.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., May 24 -- Henry (Hank) Braun and Ed Mathews of the Ridgewood (N. Y.) Country Club set the pace today in the first half of the seventy- two-hole handicap member-guest tournament at the Rockville Country Club, posting a 134 to establish a seven-stroke lead over Jerry Burns and Tom Foley of North Hills.

SO far as I know, this beginner's manual of instruction in field archeology by Kathleen Kenyon, lecturer at the London University Institute of Archeology, is the first of its kind. The deficiency, of course, has not been widely deplored, for the art of digging up the past is not a popular pursuit.

Jewelry stores are selling more than they are buying, with the result that inventories are slowly but steadily dropping at the retail level, trade sources reported last week. While business has been poor at retail and even slower on the manufacturing level, the clearing of stocks is tone reason producers predicted a normal season in the fall.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations called today for a "total war against poverty and social injustice" throughout the world as a companion measure to military preparations against Soviet aggression.

After extensive hearings, the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs agreed last week on a new G. I. Bill which provides educational opportunities for the service men who are now beginning to return to civilian life. The measure is expected to go onto the floor of the House for debate soon, possibly this week.

GENEVA -- The Swiss Federal Railways are celebrating their fiftieth anniversary this year. It is more than 100 years since the Swiss began edging railways up to their mountains and nearly seventy-five since they began seriously to punch tunnels through them.

IT is a pity! For once the board of the Metropolitan Opera thought big and acted with reasonable expedition. With its immediate goal virtually achieved the project blew up in its face. And now there must be a fresh start.
HOUSTON, Tex., May 24 -- The president of a rice mill here announced today that he and a group of Cubans were cooperating in a large scale cattle and rice producing venture in Cuba.

EUGENE, Ore., May 24 (AP) -- Long-armed Sim Iness failed today in his attempt to crack the world discus record, but he and his Southern California teammates won the annual Pacific Coast Conference track title.

The week that dawns over Europe today is destined to produce a series of events which, if brought to their final fruition, might make this one of the most important weeks in the history of the Old Continent. For during this week there are scheduled to be signed a number of diplomatic instru

Anyone with working knowledge of the game can manage a big-league ball club provided he knows (a) how to handle men and (b) knows when to remove a pitcher. There are other requisites but these two, baseball people agree, are most important. It follows, then, that Leo Durocher must be a good manager.

IN a recent message Luis Munoz Marin, Governor of Puerto Rico, spoke of "the fervor of our aspirations." This phrase rings in the mind when one surveys the art scene in Puerto Rico and illuminates the two aspects of that scene which seem to me the most interesting: the architecture of Henry Klumb and the graphic arts which are used as a tool of community education.

WITHIN a month visitors and residents of Miami Beach are going to find it a lot easier to make arrangements for rail travel. Both the Seaboard and Florida East Coast railroads plan to open branch offices on the Beach, thus saving clients the expense and time of getting across Biscayne Bay and through Miami traffic to the lines' central offices.

"Our republic is destined to pay a very heavy price today for what has become known as McCarthyism' both in university and community life," declared Rabbi Louis I. Newman in his sermon yesterday morning at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 24 -- In its spring offensive to check summer mosquito attacks, the Union County Mosquito Extermination Commission has loosed vast quantities of DDT dust and oil over breeding places of the pest, George E. Powers, superintendent of the commission, announced today.

YONKERS, May 24 -- Dr. Stanton led the best of the nation's pacers in the $10,000 Bronx Pace tonight with a tremendous stretch drive to pay $109.30 for $2. A crowd of 27,657, present for the final night of the Yonkers Raceway meeting, was surprised at the result.

Billy the Kid, the legend-surrounded bad man of the Southwest who has been dead for more than eighty years, put in an appearance last week at Public School 4, at Pitt and Rivington Streets on the East Side. But it was a brief return for poor Billy -- once again a young sheriff's bullet found its mark and Billy will be seen no more, at least not until graduation time next month.

PURCHASE, N. Y., May 24 -- Gift of Gold, Mrs. Simon T. Patterson's 11-year-old gelding, today gained his third postand-rail success in as many starts this season. Competing in the Connecticut Cup at the annual Adjacent Hunts meeting, the 1951 timber champion romped home five lengths before Walter W. Wickes' Big Bones.

One sweltering day last July Vice Admiral Charles Turner Joy faced a group of Communist officers across a green, baize-covered table in a tent at Kaesong. He said: "The good faith which you bring to these talks will directly determine the success or failure of our negotiations."

HARTFORD, May 24 -- William H. Brennan of Stamford, Republican National Committeeman whose purge has been ordered by Gov. John Davis Lodge, charged today that the Governor had "so little concern for the welfare of the Republican party" in Connecticut that he had threatened to split it wide open on the eve of the state convention, which opens here Monday.
A four-year experiment to improve basic planning for higher education through increased faculty participation is being launched by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching.

With large-scale building projects being held up all over the country -- and especially in California, Oklahoma and Texas -- by a shortage of mortgage money, efforts are being made to tap the investible resources of pension funds.

IT hardly seems possible, but this book about modern women is on their side. When an astute business concern buys or merges other companies possessing well-known and respected names it usually seeks to retain those names. It is good business to capitalize on the character and reputation of all the concerns involved even though the resulting combined name may be a bit cumbersome.
Why do not stones and stars fall apart? What is it that holds every atom in the universe together? The question is one that physicists have been trying to answer for decades.

TUBEROUS-ROOTED begonias are one of the showiest flowering plants in a partly shaded location. Tubers may be planted outdoors when all danger of frost has passed. This is the timetable, whether tubers themselves are planted directly in the open ground or sprouted ones, started indoors in March or April, are transplanted outdoors.
The metropolitan harness racing scene shifts to Roosevelt Raceway on Long Island tomorrow, with the first four weeks of the 108-night stand devoted to the Grand Circuit phase of the sport.

AVERILL PARK, N. Y., May 24 --Senator Irving M. Ives declared tonight that the Republican party faced "the mightiest challenge since the crisis of slavery" in its efforts to defeat a Democratic opposition characterized by "irresponsible absolutism and incompetent leadership."

A TURNSPIT dog, as everyone in the Massachusetts Bay Colony must have known, was a bit of canine machinery designed to do kitchen service. Spit ran in the wheel that turned the spit that held the meat over the fire for dinner, and only 8-year-old Abiah understood that he was also, really, a dog.

PARIS, May 24 -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati was eliminated from the French tennis championships today as Richard Savitt, Gardnar Mulloy, Budge Patty, Hamilton Richardson and Irvin Dorfman reached the round of sixteen. Tiny Felicisimo Ampon of the Philippines defeated Trabert as a crowd of 7,500 applauded the cleverness and skill of the victor in Roland Carros Stadium on this warm, sunny day.

SHAKESPEARE, that dependable source of screen material which supplied the co-winner of the major award in the Cannes Film Festival -- Orson Welles' "Othello"--will be tapped again. The news is that Renato Castellani, director of "Due Soldi Di Speranza" ("Two Pennies Worth of Hope") which shared the top prize with "Othello," currently is{ preparing a movie version of the Bard's "Romeo and Juliet."

INDIANAPOLIS, May 24 -- A break in rainy weather sent a steady stream of drivers out today for 500-mile auto race qualifications that broke speed records at the Indianapolis Speedway for the third time in eight days.

With the summer vacationer in mind who is planning a tourist flight to Europe or air travel in this country, we gathered together the principal elements of a wardrobe which would come within the baggage allotment of the air companies: that is, forty-four pounds for the tourist flight to Europe and forty for domestic travel. Each costume on this page has been weighed.

AFTER lunch at a midtown Manhattan hotel, we took the elevator up to the hotel room. There was the usual business of sitting down and getting comfortable in the rough - textured, over - stuffed chairs.

A two-year study of Egyptian views on international organization and possible amendment of the United Nations Charter will be undertaken as a joint venture of the Egyptian Society of International Law and the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, of New York.

OFFICIAL spokesmen for the United Nations last week took up their pens to explain carefully to the American Association for the United Nations that the design of the U. N.'s forthcoming "United Nations Day" commemorative 5-cent blue stamp does not contain pro-Russian propaganda.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- One of the last almost untouched big-game hunting areas on the continent, and one of the remotest and most expensive in which to operate, has been opened in the Stikine River region of northern British Columbia.

A procession of 1,000 Sunday school children from churches of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York marched around the grounds of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon at the annual service for the presentation of missionary offerings.

LAST summer, when Robert Whtiehead took on the complex responsibility for presenting the American National Theatre and Academy's second play series, he dedicated himself to putting on five productions that would be thoroughly expressive of the American idiom.

The declining trend of business in the last several months is continuing, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reports in its monthly survey, released for publication today.

The Secretary of the Army has acted wisely in ordering the prompt demotion of the two officers most closely associated with the recent prisoner-kidnapping fiasco on Koje Island. He is equally wise in giving immediate publicity to his action and in permitting his letter to Senator Russell to be published.

CHICAGO, May 24 (UP) -- Andy B. W., a lightly campaigned bay colt, raced over a sloppy track with ease today to win the $11,600 Edward J. Fleming Memorial Handicap by three lengths at the Lincoln Fields-at-Hawthorne meeting.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 24 (AP) -- Forty persons, including six whites, were injured by police clubs as trade unionists fought to protect Solomon Sachs, whom the Government had ordered into retirement from his union duties.

SINCE the obvious ham and eggs operas have been recorded not once but several times, the record makers are beginning to cast about for rarities. The gratified record collector may accordingly hear works which are seldom or never done on the operatic stage.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -An unusual action this week strengthened a belief in Congress that House Speaker Sam Rayburn of Texas may become a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The Pacific Northwest, whose potential as a source of electric power is one of the greatest in the country, is fast becoming one of the largest public power districts to be developed under Federal ownership.

Two of Europe's outstanding soccer teams will meet on even terms in this country when the Manchester United eleven, English champions, line up against the Stuttgart Kickers of Western Germany in an international clash today at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.

Selections from two operas that have not been performed by the Metropolitan Opera since 1916 will be heard in the noon to 2 P. M. recorded concert on Wednesday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
SOUTH RIVER, N. J., May 24 -- Jesse Selover, borough historian, has started a one-man campaign to preserve and perpetuate many of the area's historical landmarks.

WHEN Easley Blackwood, the Indianapolis insurance man, devised a new slam-bidding method back in 1933, his object was a very simple and unambitious one. He wanted only to save himself and his regular partners in neighborhood bridge games from reaching hopeless slams and losing tricks to two opposing aces.

NEW PALTZ, N. Y., May 24 -- Governor Dewey declared today that the nation's prospective teachers were "the most important people in the country" because of their responsibility to educate American youth for world leadership.

The loss of the double-decked Strato-cruiser in the heart of Brazil nearly a month ago has emphasized the wild and untraversable terrain over which the big planes regularly fly.

Admiral Alan G. Kirk, former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, contrasted the youth of Russia and the unregimented American boy yesterday at a luncheon of the national council of the Boy Scouts of America.

BALTIMORE, May 24 -- The Maryland delegation of twenty-four to the Republican National Convention is uninstructed, except for a "favorite son" vote on the first ballot for Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin, a serious candidate for the Vice Presidential nomination.

LONDON, Sunday, May 25 -Russia charged in a new note to the Western Allies today that the West German peace contract is "actually an open military alliance" between the Big Three Western powers and the Bonn Federal Republic.

CHICAGO, May 24 (UP) -- Wheat, soybeans and rye maintained a firm tone on the Board of Trade today while corn and oats were inclined to lag, at times dipping below previous closing prices. Trade was light.

British European Airways announced yesterday that it was "doing its utmost" to accommodate everyone who had booked passage on its planes flying throughout Europe and the British Isles despite the curtailment of schedules caused by the strike of American oil refinery workers.

TOKYO, Sunday, May 25 (UP) -- Soviet-built MIG-15 jet planes defeated United States jets for the first time in the Korean war in a series of air battles last week, the Fifth Air Force disclosed yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 24 (UP) -- A strike by the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., tied up West Coast shipping today.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -- A Republican Congressman, who used to work with the wartime Truman Senate Investigating Committee, said today President Truman was "out of character" when he complained about strong curbs on military spending.

THE month of roses is just a week away. Tomorrow, the All-America Roses for 1953 make their local debut at the Channel Gardens, Rockefeller Center, Fifth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street. The two winners are Chrysler Imperial, a crimson hybrid tea, and Ma Perkins, a floribunda described as coral shell pink.

DALLAS, May 24 -- Heavy rains over a good portion of Texas during the week eased the drought and improved crop outlooks. The rains came as the north Texas onion harvest began to get under way and likely will increase production. Early season prices are $3 and $4, compared with $2 last year.

PARIS, May 24 -- Antoine de Recy, one-armed Resistance hero and a former Deputy in the National Assembly, confessed today that he had stolen 100,000,000 francs (about $290,000) worth of bonds. He had denied it during the first fifteen days of his trial.

Your recent articles on developments in Africa were of particular interest to us of the Institute; and we want, in the first instance, to thank you for their publication, which is so completely in conformity with the high standards of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Your articles will, we hope, be only an opener in the important process of our enlightenment as to "Dark Africa."

One of the two known perfect copies of the first edition of Lincoln's First Inaugural Address, made in 1861, will be auctioned at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, in an afternoon and evening sale on Tuesday. The other perfect copy is in the Library of Congress.

EVERY day, these days, the jungle appears in our newspapers. The vision of it springs at us from those three and four line reports that tell of the fighting in Southeast Asia, of the unending, half-forgotten wars: "* * * Army units made a five-day forced march to reach the Communist camp in the dense jungle country * * *."

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 24 -- In the South as well as in the North, the fierce battle between supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio for the Republican nomination is generating bitter feelings and inflicting wounds that may not heal before November.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Despite Monday's refusal by the House of Representatives to pass such a bill, it appears likely that Congress will act this session to increase insurance benefits under the Social Security system.

THE battle for commercially sponsored television in Great Britain is over and nobody is sure who has won. On the whole, having a regard for the deeply entrenched position of B. B. C., with its quarter-century-old monopoly, it is a modest victory for advocates of competition by private enterprise.

THE oriental poppies that are just starting to bloom really make gorgeous cut flowers. Pink and white kinds and many of the new varieties with their delicate colorings are particularly desirable. But for cutting to be worth while, special care is needed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., May 24 -- Although President Truman is not a candidate for renomination and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower has no place on the California ballot and cannot legally receive a single write-in vote, the names Truman and Eisenhower are influencing this state's primary campaign with only ten days to go.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 24 -Army and Navy battled to an even break today in the two major events of their annual spring sports fiesta, which attracted President Truman and thousands of visitors to the Naval Academy. At Lawrence Field, where the President threw out two balls, one left-handed, one right-handed. Navy's baseball team rallied with two runs in the seventh inning to defeat the Army nine, 3 -- 1.

HELEN GAHAGAN, who was known to theatrical audiences for her acting and her beauty before she left the Broadway stage in 1936, returns Wednesday night in the revival of "First Lady" at the New York City Center.

TED SHAWN has announced the schedule for the eleventh annual festival at Jacob's Pillow, near Lee, Mass. The season will run for ten weeks this summer, beginning June 27, and will consist of fifty performances.

Instead of the thrilling chase that might last a whole

The Brooklyn Chapter of the Amereican Red Cross urged residents yesterday to commemorate Memorial Day in advance by giving blood this week. In making the plea the chapter noted "a severe diminishment of donors" in recent weeks.

In an earlier book, Becky and her dog, Tatters, learned to adjust themselves to life in the apartment house that Becky's mother managed. Now, in the same house, Becky earns money by caring for pets whose owners are temporarily out of town.

With the potato shortage due to continue another three to six weeks, restaurant and hotel proprietors took careful inventory of their dwindling supplies yesterday and looked to substitutes to tide them over the current famine. Others resorted to boycott rather than pay premium prices or accept bottom-of-the-bin quality.

Robert Patrick Kirby has been bartender in the Roxy Bowling Alleys at Fiftieth Street and Seventh Avenue for more than a year. As a result, he has grown rather blase about the crash of a bowling all against the ten pins -- indifferent as to whether the ball rolls in the gutter or sends the pins spinning for a strike.
Anticipated reconstruction and improvements to the heavily traveled Manhattan Bridge "may cost millions of dollars," Budget Director Abraham D. Beame has informed the Board of Estimate in a report.

Critical appraisals of the extent and purposes of United States aid to Latin America and several sharp references to the Peron regime in Argentina enlivened yesterday's luncheon of the Pan American Women's Association at the Town Hall Club.

"YOU will shortly receive your copy of "To Fu,' the biography of the great eighth - century Chinese poet, which we shall publish on May 28." begins a letter from the Harvard University Press. "The text of the book is interlarded with 374 of Tu Tu's poems translation made by the author, William Hung, a Chinese scholar."

The United States could "commit no greater folly than to let the restless and discontented people of the earth believe that only communism is interested in their problems," Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, told the Religious Newswriters Association last night.

A committee representing former world and Olympic sports champions as well as other outstanding athletes from Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Esthonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Rumania and Yugoslavia announced last week that a petition had been sent to Lausanne requesting that they be permitted to participate in the 1952 Olympic games at Helsinki as group of exiles.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 24 -Support of a $25,000,000 bond issue for state institutions, a highway program including equalization of road-user payments and development of education in the state were called for today in a platform adopted here by the Young Republicans of New Jersey.

VIENNA, May 24 -- About 200,000 Roman Catholics will gather in Vienna in September for Austria's first Catholic Day since the end of World War II to consider a policy for their church that would break with all tradition.

The free-market value of gold and the privilege of tax-exempt interest are about to be elevated to key positions in the inflation-wracked French economy as incentives for getting the nation's savings out of sterile hoards and back to work in the form of capital investment.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 24 -- Nassau Public Works Commissioner John C. Guibert warned today that traffic volume on county roads was presenting serious congestion problems with no immediate promise of relief.
PITTSBURGH, May 24 (UP) -- Fine relief pitching by Dutch Leonard in the seventh inning and Johnny Klippstein in the ninth gave the Cubs a 7-5 victory over the last place Pirates today.

KIPLING sang of the Himalayas but South Dakotans would maintain stoutly that he had in mind their own Black Hills which were right where they are now when the site of the Himalayas was sea-level swampland.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 24 -- Martin Rosensweig of New York and Katharine Daly of Gladstone, N. J., won blue ribbons in the feature events of the fourteenth annual Rock Spring Horse Show this afternoon. The show, which closes tomorrow at the West Orange Riding Club, was marked by Carolyn Storck's triple in the morning.

ANYONE harboring the notion that the wife of a newspaper publisher, when accompanying her husband to a foreign land, dutifully tags behind at impressive receptions, functions and interviews is obviously not acquainted with Willie Snow Ethridge.

FOLKS in Seattle the other day had a scare. A meteor burst into what the press described as a "blinding white flash" at 1:26 A. M. and "was accompanied by a series of explosions that shook buildings and routed mystified residents over a wide area."

DOVER, Del., May 24 (AP) -- Delaware Democrats elected today six delegates to the national convention, five unpledged and uninstructed and one, Senator J. Allen Frear Jr., openly supporting Vice President Albert W. Barkley for the Presidential nomination.

A COMMON complaint among today's architects is that, because they cannot control the decorating of the interiors, the esthetic content of a house is often damaged, sometimes even completely lost. It is, therefore, always interesting to see how an architect handles a home of his own. Pictured here is a fieldstone and brick house built in the New Canaan area of Connecticut by architect Marcel Breuer and intended for his own use.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Illinois non-farm employment rose slightly in March compared with the February total, a gain of only 0.5 per cent, while the 3,282,100 worker total rose 11,000 over the March figure last year, the state reported.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 24 -- Garment workers tried to prevent the police from arresting Solomon Sachs, general secretary of the Garment Workers Union when, in defiance of a Government order under the anti-Communist law, he addressed 10,000 persons today outside the City Hall of Johannesburg.

DEVON, Pa., May 24 -- The Bryn Mawr Hospital will benefit from the proceeds of the Devon Horse Show and Country Fair, which opened here today with the Devon pony and juniors' horse show and the Horse Show Ball, which took place tonight at the Merion Cricket Club, Haverford. The event will continue throughout next week.
THERE is a very sick man in academic America today, and he is dying of an incurable disease. I call it "Ridiculitis." The Yale Record calls it "humor."

THE winds of change have blown gently but effectively through the main galleries of the Museum of Non-objective Painting. The rarefied atmosphere of upper ether which had so long prevailed has given way for the occasion to an atmosphere in which the visitor may breathe easily.

Beginning this week, about 6,000 retail food stores in the metropolitan area will cut price of frozen food 10 to 15 per cent on volume sales. The term "volume sales" covers consumer orders of $25 or more in lots usually ordered by retailers. These might range from six units up to a full case, depending on the item.

HONG KONG, May 24 -- Unable for prestige reasons to concede that more than half of the Communist prisoners of war in Korea refuse to be repatriated, Chinese Communists and North Koreans have launched an intensive, cleverly organized propaganda campaign
Twenty-five thousand Scouts of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, took part yesterday in the opening sessions of their annual Scout-O-Rama at Madison Square Garden.

CINCINNATI, May 24 (UP) -- Andy Seminick hit two home runs in successive innings, the second with the bases loaded, and drove in six runs with three hits today as the Reds routed the Cardinals, 11 -- 5, in a rain-soaked game.

ASSUMING that the musical stage is designed for entertainment, the seventeen young people of "New Faces of 1952" have made a contribution to the season. They have put together a cheerful evening of good-humored material and given New York one of the pleasantest events of the year.

BOSTON, May 24. -- A survey of the New England political battlefields on which the forces of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower have scored triumphs since March indicates that his Presidential candidacy has left its mark on state level conceptions of both Republican strategy and leadership.
For several years Henri Corbiere has been asking the world's celebrities how they started to climb the road that leads to Parnassus. Recently he got around to the scientists.

ONE could, without too much exertion, get considerable fun out of "Alcohol, Culture and Society." Here are extracts from pompous pronouncements of grubby-minded social scientists, nasty-minded psychoanalysts and a pedantic Teuton who attributed alcoholic addiction to "incompletely repressed homosexuality."

WHEN the City of New York decided recently to impose nuisance taxes on cigarettes, automobile use and liquor licenses, thereby assuring itself of about $19.5 million a year and the enduring ill will of a large part of the citizenry, it broke no new ground in the field of fiscal policy.

BOSTON, May 24 (UP) -- J. L. Friedman's Orco gained revenge for defeats in his last two starts and snapped Royal Marvel's unbeaten Suffolk Downs victory streak today when the gelding scored a two-length triumph over Eddie Siravo's bay colt in the $5,370 Constitution Handicap.

The setting up of Girl Scouting for American children in Germany and Austria involved the adaptation of the program to the realities of army life, but it also involved the adaptation of the United States Army to the Girl Scout way of doing things, Miss Janet Tobitt reports.

Cotton prices turned easier last week after showing early strength. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 2 to down 17 points compared with net declines of 1 to 40 points in the previous week. The only net gain was recorded in the July delivery.

OFTEN the critic is asked to write about what are called the "trends" in contemporary writing. The request is natural enough. With a good deal of reading and a little application one can usually discover a "trend" or two somewhere; but, having described the "trends," the critic is soon dogged by doubt.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 24 -- A young student nurse is to take a leave of absence next month to serve as community ambassador to Westbury's "adopted" village of Correggio in northern Italy.

SOVIET distortions of the ills suffered by American Negro citizens are among the most difficult to meet of all the Big Lies circulated by Russia for the purpose of winning the colored races of Asia to its side. Lies about American germ warfare in Korea make us angry, but reports that the newspapers of India have headlined the racist bombings in Miami must strike home, for we know that they happened.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 24 -- Several hundred thousand Ceylonese, men mostly in colorful sarongs and women in Indian type saris, went quietly to the polls, drenched in a heavy monsoon rain today, to choose the government of this strategic tropical island for the next five years.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -- The State Department served notice today that it would continue to bar Americans from traveling abroad if they were Communists or fellow travelers or the trips were not in the nation's "best interests."
LONDON, May 24 -- Britain's hope for recovery from her latest economic crisis is being threatened by a new round of demands for higher wages.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 24 -- Prof. Raphael Lemkin, who has spent the last decade fighting for international action against genocide, warned today that his work and the United Nations treaty that grew out of it were in danger of destruction by the United Nations itself.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 24 -Championship yacht racing on Long Island Sound opened today with a noisy and unexpected reception.

RAINY week-ends in April and May are restful but hardly contribute to a gardener's peace of mind, particularly his hobby is practiced only over the week-ends. Even in the best of years seed sowing and planting are barely completed before maintenance must begin.

MANY United States sportsmen who ordinarily look forward with enthusiasm to an annual trip to Canada for big game hunting are prospecting for areas in this country that might provide equal opportunities, for the recent regulation by the Department of Agriculture may prevent the transportation of big game animals across the border.

All wholesale departments here were active last week as more seasonable weather hit the area, resident buying offices reported. Heavy reorders were received and promotional goods were in demand. The conservative buying policies that stores observed earlier in the season has placed them in an open-to-buy position.

OF the three novelist-winners of the Nobel Prize for Literature living in America today one occupies a position of enormous influence, another of great prestige. The work of William Faulkner is studied by critics, analyzed and discussed, and drawn upon for nutriment by a horde of young writers. He is even, with the republication

The controversial question of whether or not the United States Government should now negotiate a long-term supply contract for Canadian aluminum will be explored tomorrow in Washington by a key Congressional group, the Joint Committee on Defense Production.

LONDON (as this pleasant memoir reminds us) has always been the cultural magnet of an empire, attracting to herself men of letters not only from the British Isles but even from abroad. It is not surprising, therefore, to find that Frank Swinnerton's roster of the literary great of England who were born or lived in London reads almost like an index to English literature.

LIMA, Peru, May 24 -- Peru today celebrated the addition of three United States-built destroyers to her Navy with a full dress review of destroyers, frigates and submarines by President Manuel A. Odria at the port of Ancon, twenty-five miles north of Lima.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -- The United States Weather Bureau has inaugurated a new service to make life easier for airline pilots and flying more comfortable for the passengers.

A LITTLE attention given house plants this month and throughout the summer will do much to make them more attractive and healthy for indoor decoration next winter. All house plants, except those with hairy leaves, will benefit by spending the summer months outdoors in the shade of a tree or on the north side of the house.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., May 24 -- More than 5,000 former patients and friends came to Gaylord Farm Sanatorium today, the fiftieth anniversary of this institution, to return the love they had received from Dr. David R. Lyman, founder and superintendent.
