FLORENCE, S. C., May 24 -- Thomas L. Hamilton, Grand Dragon of the Associated Carolinas Klan, was arrested here today on North Carolina charges that he was a conspirator in two Klu Klux Klan flogging cases. He will be arraigned there Monday.

Nine Brooklyn College students were honored last week for achievement in student activities. They received the college's top awards for student leadership at a presentation ceremony Wednesday in the faculty lounge. Those honored were:

LEGEND, folklore and mystery have ovarlaid Colorado's history at all times, enhancing the melodrama, but never was this more true than in the territorial days of the Eighteen Seventies. That was the period when prospectors were pushing over the continental divide into the land of the Utes, defacing the majestic beauty of the San Juan and Sawatch ranges.

The trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders ends its second month this week with every indication that it will last as long as the trial of the top leaders of the party -- nine weary months.

ST. THOMAS, V. I., May 24 -- The appointment of Dr. Roy A. Anduze as Commissioner of Health for the Virgin Islands and as chief municipal physician for the municipality of St. Thomas and St. John has been announced by Gov. Morris F. de Castro.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 24 -- Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., broadened his margin today over a rival who his seeking to keep him from a fifth term in office.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 24 -- Senior Harry Brightman hurled a no-hit, no-run game today as Princeton snapped Fordham's eight-game winning streak, 5 -- 0, before 300 spectators who watched in a steady drizzle at University Field today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -Billy Loes, the wonder boy from Astoria, L. I., pitched the Dodgers to their eighth straight triumph tonight when he shut out the Phils on five hits as the Brooks won, 5 -- 0, before 15,894 Shibe Park fans and retained the National League lead.

Six American employes of the United Nations who were investigated as security risks were notified recently that their contracts had been terminated effective June 15 and June 30 on the ground that their services were no longer required.

The spate of invective and abuse which for ten and a half months has characterized the Communist "negotiations" at the Korean ceasefire talks was stilled temporarily last week as the deadlocked discussions were recessed for three days.

Thank you for Herbert Mitgang's article, "Warren Wins -- in Oberlin" (May 11). Perhaps this is the place to lodge my opinion that the educational purpose of the convention should have been more clearly indicated.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 24 -- William Reichard of Bethlehem, Pa., was elected today supreme tall cedar of the Supreme Forest of Tall Cedars of Lebanon at the final business session of the Masonic organization's golden anniversary conclave here.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 24 (AP) -- Alerted, a tried and true performer from Hampton Stable won the $20,000 added Thomas J. Healey Handicap before a crowd of 31,931 racing fans at Garden State Park today.

The task of training an adequate crew for the superliner United States, largest commercial ship ever built in this country and designed to be the fastest and most modern passenger vessel afloat, has been under way for a month and is expected to continue until the liner enters trans-Atlantic service in July.

A NUMBER of exhibitions, most of which offer paintings and sculpture by artists who are relatiyely unfamiliar to New York, opened last week. It would be foolish to proclaim them major events, but minor work, aside from its moments of spasmodic vitality, has another and quite special interest.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 24 -President Truman evened up the score of his service academy visits today by paying a formal visit to the United States Naval Academy here five days after he had paid a similar call on the Military Academy at West Point.

AT least three of the eight points in the new program adopted last week by the National Air Transport Coordinating Committee for commercial airline operations at the big New York metropolitan area airports might well have been put into use a long time ago.

For the first time in fifty years the top posts in the United States Steel Corporation are occupied by one individual. And, oddly enough, with all the talk about the steel labor-management dispute, the biggest steel company in the world is being operated by a coal miner's son.

I READ with interest Mr. Robert Montgomery's remarks in last Sunday's TIMES about the difficulties he has been experiencing in getting writers to submit their original plays for sale to his one-hour TV dramatic program.

THE coast of Maine is spattered with islands -- hundreds of them -- large islands that you can drive on, like Orr's and Bailey's, Deer Isle, Sebascodegan and Mount Desert, little dots of islands, just large enough for a flock of sea gulls to alight on.

TIME was when almost everybody was an amateur weather forecaster -- there simply weren't enough experts to go around. Today the subject is so complicated that only a meteorologist knows anything (worth knowing) about weather.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 24 -- For a while early this month Saigon became almost convinced that some kind of contact was being made between French and Vietminh forces aimed at effecting a peaceful settlement in the Indo-China war. The peace talk reports became so widespread and their

LOTS of women have to wash sheets and carry trays and cope with silent husbands, indifferent children, or single loneliness. The three stories in this book by the author of "The Pink House" and "Woman at the Window" show three such women, properly middle-aged, who suddenly see their lives as nothing.
MAHLER has not been doing so well as Bruckner on long-play. All of the latter's symphonies except the Ninth have been recorded, whereas only Nos. 1, 2 and 4 of Mahler's have been in the catalogues.

LIKE America's only contribution to the creative arts -- jazz music -- Louis Binstock came up the river from New Orleans to Chicago. In New Orleans, he had been a leading rabbi in the reform wing of Judaism; in Chicago, he became leader of Temple Sholom, on Lake Michigan, where his congregation is now the largest in American Jewry, and where many of other faiths go to hear him speak and lecture and teach.

IT is spring in Belgrade, which is good news in a city where coal, wood and electricity are outrageously expensive (one ton of coal costs about $23, which is more than the minimum monthly wage of a skilled worker), and the streets are filled with strollers fleeing their overcrowded apartments at the first signs of clement weather.

ROME, May 24 -- More than 10,000,000 persons of both sexes are eligible to vote tomorrow and Monday to elect new provincial councils in thirteen of Italy's ninety-one provinces and new municipal administrations in 2,422 of the slightly more than 7,800 municipalities.
ST. LOUIS, May 24 (UP) -- Larry Doby and Luke Easter hit home runs to lead the Indians to a 5-3 victory over the Browns today.

One of the hack horses that await sightseers at the Plaza ran away in Central Park yesterday afternoon with its aged driver and a couple of customers. The horse slammed into an automobile on Cross Drive near Seventy-second Street, the carriage was overturned, and the driver was injured seriously.

PRESTWICK, Scotland, May 24 (UP) -- The defending champion Dick Chapman of Pinehurst, N. C., shot a practice round of 68 today to establish himself as a firm favorite to-retain his British amateur golf championship in the tournament beginning Monday.

PLANTING, in a general sense, is not confined to spring and fall, but may go on throughout the summer. There may be sound reasons for sowing seed in summer, such as the need for succession crops or rounding out the flower display.

Major department stores last week had an aggregate dollar sales volume decline estimated at 8 per cent below volume for the comparable week of last year. Chilly and rainy weather through much of the week was partly responsible for the decline, but there appeared also to be at least a temporary easing of the mild pick-up dating from early April.

WOODSTOCK, Conn., May 24 -- A campaign to save the 204-year-old little red brick schoolhouse on Wabbaquasset Hill here drew the endorsement today of President Truman and a $1,000 check from a woman resident of Bronxville, N. Y.

BUSINESS is incompatible with culture and must be eliminated. This is the conclusion reached by Elijah Jordan, former Professor of Philosophy at Butler University. He finds business to be without intelligence, without morals, and corrupting to everything it touches. It is without intelligence, for it knows and cares nothing of the broad consequences of its actions.

The New York City Housing Authority has been asked by a group of Bronx residents to undertake a slum clearance and low-rent public housing development in the Claremont Parkway-Washington Avenue area of the Bronx. A petition filed with the authority contended that this section had the highest juvenile delinquency and tuberculosis and infant mortality rates in the Bronx.

Early next month, 36-year-old George A. Jackson of Riverhead, L. I., will say good-by to the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation at Thirty-fourth Street and First Avenue. His wife, Marie, and 11-year-old daughter, Barbara, will be with him as he heads for home to take up a new life and a new vocation.

TOKYO, Sunday, May 25 -- The official Peiping radio charged this morning that the United Nations "refused to negotiate" in the conference at Panmunjom for an armistice in Korea in order to gain time for a scheme to retain Chinese and North Korean war prisoners as "cannon fodder."

LOVERS of Sophocles, classical Greek and the notion of seeing the national theatre of another nation in action can begin preparing to celebrate a fortnight's holiday come November. For, after more than a year's negotiations, arrangements have finally been concluded whereby the American National Theatre and Academy will sponsor Guthrie McClintic's presentation of the Greek National Theatre, starring the eminent Katina Paxinou and her husband Alexis Minotis.

STARTING with their June releases, Victor will package its long-play records in a slightly different type of envelope. It will resemble the one generally in use up to now, but there will be a stiff backbone, about an eighth of an inch in width, on which are printed the composer, title of the disk, and the artist involved.

FOR the first time, a strong and honest novel has been derived from the rich materials of New Orleans jazz, the gaudy sinks of the late (but not very late) Storyville restricted district, and the teeming life of the city's Negro tenements, bars and honky-tonks.

QUEEN MARY, Britain's living link between the gaslit era and the atomic age, will be 85 tomorrow. With her rolled umbrella and her high toques, designed to please herself rather than to conform to a changing fashion, she has become a symbol of the continuity of the British royal house.

Capturing nine first places in fifteen events, Manhattan College's trackmen easily defeated Penn State at Van Cortlandt Stadium yesterday, 84 to 56. Pacing the victors was Lindy Remigino, who won the 100-yard dash in 0:10.0 and the 220-yard dash in 0:21.7.

EXETER, May 24 -- Phillips Andover Academy won its ninth straight spring track meet from Exeter Academy this afternoon before a large and enthusiastic Alumni Day crowd. The meet went to Andover, 68 --58, but it wasn't until the very final event, the broad jump, was reported that the outcome was sure.

A NOVEL and reportedly successful plan developed in Guayas Province of Ecuador for speeding road projects is being studied by highway organizations in this country who are looking for ideas to help solve bottlenecks created by lack of needed traffic arteries.

Many up-and-coming areas of the country -- notably the South -have been trying for years with varying success to lure industry. Last week a new note was added to the "move-to-our-business-paradise" chorus.

ALTHOUGH television of the colored variety has not been newsworthy of recent date, because of a Government ban on the production of color sets, the Radio Corporation of America and the National Broadcasting Company have not exactly been idle in that department.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 24 -- E. G. Bailey, New York industrialist and inventor, will be among six men who will receive Distinguished Service Awards at the June 6 commencement exercises at Ohio State University, Dr. Howard L. Bevis, university president, announced today.

IN this novel, Miss Mitchell employs a hackneyed device of plot, of which even the movies are tiring. In San Luis Rey fashion a random group of people meet violent death together. Was there a reason? What are their stories?

BERLIN, May 24 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the West German Republic, assured the citizens of West Berlin today that his Government and the Western powers would back them up no matter what tactics were used against the city by the Soviet Union and East Germany.

THE realities of Soviet life and the capacity of the Russian mind (once considered a fairly serviceable organ) to accept these grotesque realities with reasonable complacency have been explored quite successfully by Arthur Koestler and practically no one else.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 24 -- The New Jersey Savings and Loan League urged the Veterans Administration today to raise the interest rates on G. I. home loans to bring them more in accord with present economic conditions.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 24 (AP) -Sparked by Bob Jones and Jack Goldberg, Tufts made a successful defense of its New England intercollegiate track and field championship today on M. I. T.'s Briggs Field.

LINCOLN, N. M. -- William H. Bonney, otherwise Billy the Kid, who was southern New Mexico's No. 1 badman back in the Eighteen Seventies, bids fair to become -- in spirit at least -- one of the state's most popular tourist attractions in the Nineteen Fifties.

BOSTON, May 24 -- Cornell University's crew broke the course record for a mile and three-quarters upstream on the Charles River today to beat the Harvard eight by a foot and a half. Boston University was a distant third. Cornell's time was 8:45.6 against Harvard's 8:45.7. B. U. was clocked in 9:21.6.

A merchandising campaign featuring low prices will be launched next month by independent department stores throughout the country in an effort to overcome consumer resistance, reduce large inventories and reverse the recent sluggish sales trend in the retail field.

IN Britain Mr. Churchill suffers (though with aplomb) from a popular reaction against the American idolatry of him. And this book will have its detractors there among precisely the people who share Mr. Taylor's view of the old warrior but who shudder and stomp away from the altar at which Mr. Tayor kneels.

AMERICAN mothers, most of whom feel secure only when they own a substantial list of tried and proven baby sitters, quite naturally hesitate to take young children into the bobby sox-less world of Europe. A child can be taken by the hand through the Vatican or up the Jungfrau, out what does he do at night in Paris?

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Moshe Sharett, Israel's foreign minister, said here tonight that the serious shortage of hard currency in Israel had forced the nation to adopt "makeshift methods" of economic existence. He declared that the shortage of funds was jeopardizing the full development of Israel's agricultural and industrial potential, particularly the "epoch-making discoveries of mineral wealth."

DURING the Revolution, Frances Slocum, the small daughter of a Quaker family living in Pennsylvania's Wyoming Valley, was abducted by the Delaware Indians. She grew to womanhood among them, married a Miami and, when opportunity offered, declined to leave her Indian family to return to her relatives.

PARIS, May 24 -- The French Cabinet has asked its Foreign Minister, Robert Schuman, to try to persuade Secretary of State Dean Acheson and British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to go as far as they can toward providing for the European army treaty the United States and British guarantees urged by the French National Assembly.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 24 -- This city's transit system, shut down since May 1 by a strike of 900 operators and mechanics, resumed operation at 4 A. M. today.

The first Englishman is said to have set foot on China in 1620, the year that better-remembered Englishmen and Englishwomen set foot on New England. Thus the British business concerns which last week announced that

AS FAR as I am concerned, it all began thirty-two years ago. That was when I started to garden on seven acres, more or less, of fairly good Connecticut meadow land. During this span I dabbled in all sorts of plants -- flower, vegetable and fruit.

BOSTON, May 24 -- The Yankees faced a two-pronged jinx here today with the inevitable result. They lost a ball game to the Red Sox, 5 to 2, before 30,694 fans, and left the scene still looking for their first triumph of the season here.

In the dark of night on Christmas Eve, 1950, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway boarded a plane in Washington for a fateful mission. From a desk job in the Pentagon he was bound for Korea and the command of the Eighth Army, then reeling under the weight of a Communist offensive.

After reading, in a recent Sunday TIMES, Olin Dowries' excellent arguments about the impossibility of separation of the music and "the language in which it was conceived and created" without destroying or at least lowering the artistic unity as a whole, it seems to me that the basic issue involved is being lost sight of.

DALLAS, May 24 (UP) -- Roy Cullen, Houston oil man who probably is the Republican party's most liberal contributor in Texas, appealed to Senator Taft tonight to keep his followers from precipitating a "national scandal" at the party's state convention.

MANY vegetable gardeners are now harvesting early crops like radishes and scallions. If good, high quality vegetables are to be had throughout the entire growing season, it is important to continue planting operations.
An assertion that steel is wasted in this country by excessive usage in the construction of heavy machinery was made last week by Fritz Fischer, designer and head of the company of that name.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) -- John B. Kelly Jr., former Diamond Sculls champion representing the Navy Olympic squad of Philadelphia, won two sculling events on the Schuylkill River today, sprinting to victory in the quarter-mile dash and taking the Farragut Cup championship singles.

Because they contain both choruses and solos, Bach's cantatas have proved difficult to record. Sometimes the solos have sounded well, but choruses have not been picked up very clearly; or else microphones adjusted for choral masses, have not been too kind to soloists.
Bank stockholders refused to take "yes" for an answer last week.

To begin a second decade of competition among medical students the Schering Corporation announces a series of cash prizes for papers to be submitted on "Steroid Hormones in Geriatrics," "Topical Uses of Antihistamines" and "Chemotherapy of the Eye."

Hilda J. Couch of The Jersey Journal, Jersey City, was installed yesterday as president of the Woman's Press Club of New York. Other officers inducted included Eleanor Pedersen, first vice president; the Rev. Glenn Argoe, recording secretary, and Florence E. Stieler, registrar. Jessie B. Chamberlin. Mrs. Thomas H. McClintock, Grace Harden, Dorothy Hopkins and Jean Hortense Norris became directors.

The textile industry has emerged from the morass of price control. In the last eleven years the industry has spent more than six years under one type of pricing regulation or another, it was pointed out last week, and during extended periods under such control the unwritten law of supply and demand prevailed rather than any duly inscribed code of the pricing bureaus.

In Washington last Friday nine railroad executives who had been running the rails for the United States Army took off their uniforms and put on mufti. After twenty-one months under Government seizure, the rails were restored to private ownership. In the other big industry under seizure -- steel --company executives continue in their unwanted role as "managers" working for the Government.

CHICAGO, May 24 (UP) -- A Professor of Law, Frank W. Remington of the University of Wisconsin, urged today that states agree on whether adultery was a felony, a misdemeanor or no crime at all and eliminate other "inconsistencies" in law. He told the National Probation and Parole Association that crimes should be reclassified so as to measure their seriousness with the penalties imposed.

LIKE housekeepers, certain American critics and teachers have a passion for making lists and, in particular, lists of great books. But such catalogues overlook one important consideration: great books alone do not make a literature.

THE New Year is the great holiday in Japan. Tremendous preparations are made beforehand, houses cleaned, bills paid, all the hanging threads of the previous year carefully gathered in and tied. Special food is prepared, so that for the first three days at least of the new year there need be no cooking in the house.

Of the $409,105 bet on the $63,200 Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park yesterday, more than $237,000 rode with Calumet Farm's remarkable 3-year-old filly, Real Delight. It was a money-in-the-bank ride.

TRIESTE, May 24 -- The fourteen political parties of Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste, which fought an intensive political battle for three weeks, faithfully observed today the twenty-four-hour truce imposed by the Italian electoral system. Balloting will begin tomorrow morning in about 325 polling stations in the city of Trieste and five other municipalities that compose Zone A.

A pioneer psychological study to investigate the use of alcohol by individuals of high school age in Nassau County will be undertaken by Hofstra College at Hempstead, L. I., Dr. Matthew N. Chappell of the college faculty said yesterday.
The National Production Authority of the Department of Commerce was requested last week to assist the shipbuilding industry in its tanker-strengthening program by increasing steel allowances.

JUST two weeks ago at the Atlantic City convention of the American Psychoanalytic Society, Dr. Mary O'Neil Hawkins, a psychoanalyst, and Dr. Benjamin Spock, of baby book fame, had some words to say about parents who try too hard to apply what they think they know about psychoanalytic theory to the rearing of children.
TRENTON, May 24 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today neared the end of his task of approving or rejecting more than 400 measures passed by the 1952 Legislature.

IT is the clash of ideas rather than of personalities that vitalizes this first novel by a British newspaper man. The author, who has worked for Lord Rothermere and Lord Kemsley, explores the meaning of press freedom in the context of modern England.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Scientific studies into how woman's role as wife and mother is affected by full-time paid work will be undertaken at Harvard and Yale Universities this fall under two fellowships awarded today by the American Association of University Women.

MORE than any other American writer, Yugoslav-born Louis Adamic was responsible for destroying Mikhailovich and propelling public opinion toward Tito during World War II. We have here the book which he had almost completed when he was found shot dead under sensationally mysterious circumstances in his New Jersey farmhouse early last September.

Although specifically directed to problems of airport improvement and development, the recent report by Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle and his associates on the President's Airport Commission has called attention to the need for increased research on reducing the hazards of the human as well as the mechanical elements in flying.

THE Ritz-Carlton Hotel in New York is dead and gone. At one time in its swanky career, it had three employes to every room. Throughout this land, the Statler hotels, which average slightly less than one employe per room, are flourishing like the green bay tree.

Winning all but one of the seven field events, New York University defeated Fordham, 74 to 66, at Baker Field yesterday. The dual meet was held on the Columbia track because N. Y. U.'s Ohio Field was being prepared for graduation exercises.

PARIS, May 24 -- Sharp exchanges and an undercurrent of opposition during this week's debate on the Government loan in the National Assembly showed that Premier Antoine Pinay's plans for French recovery have inspired much less confidence in Paris and in upper political levels than they have among the public of the provinces.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild has pledged to turn over $100,000 to the Metropolitan Opera Association for the 1952-53 season. The money will be applied to the new production of Stravinsky's "The Rake's progress" and the revival of Verdi's "La Forza del Destino."

TORONTO, May 24 (UP) -- Epigram, a bay colt claimed last year for $2,500, galloped through the mud and rain at Woodbine Park to win the ninety-third Queen's Plate today by a length for the Three V's Stable of Toronto.

HERBICIDES are rapidly replacing much of the back-breaking work of hand weeding and cutting brush. Since the introduction of 2, 4-D in 1945 for control of broadleaved weeds in lawns, each year has seen an extension in the use of chemicals in horticulture.

IBIZA, Balearic Islands -- "For bright lights and the fast life, no one in his right mind would come to Ibiza," a fellow American told me between sips of his cognac and soda. "But for relaxation, beauty and economy you'd have to look a long way for a better place."
BRYN MAWR, Pa., May 24 -- Science scholarships of $1,000 each were awarded today by Bryn Mawr College to three 17-year-old high school seniors who have enrolled for the September session.
Sixteen prominent French business men will arrive in New York on June 1 and 2 to begin a several-week tour of this country's industries.

BARCELONA, Sprin, May 24 -- In similar oral notes delivered to the Spanish Foreign Office earlier this week, the Governments of the United States, Britain and France accepted in principle Spain's request for changes in the administration of the international zone of Tangier.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -Striking employes of the Western Union Telegraph Company began voting today on whether to accept settlement terms tentatively agreed upon by their union negotiators. The vote covers 30,000 members of the Commercial Telegraphers Union, A. F. L.

JUST before the turn of the century Moisei Iakovlevich Ostrogorski, a famous Russian political scientist, attended a Democratic nominating convention in Chicago to gather material for his monumental work on political parties in a democracy.

GUIDED tours at the United Nations headquarters on the East River are now being planned and it is hoped that the full program of tours will be in operation coincident with the opening of the United Nations General Assembly, scheduled for September.

The strike now coming to an end after closing for more than three weeks a large part of the country's oil installations has emphasized further the importance of petroleum in the industrial and civilian economy and the necessity of continuing the flow of oil to the millions of consumers dependent upon it for heat and power.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -Senator Spessard L. Holland, Democrat of Florida, said tonight that President Truman has used "abuse and invective instead of argument" against a bill to restore ownership of oil-rich submerged coastal lands to the states.

May I express my interest and appreciation in your publication of James Bennett's "Why Fear and Hate Shadow Our Prisons" (May 11). Mr. Bennett described the symptoms rather than explained the causes of the current dilemma of the modern prison and while such a traditional treatment is always enlightening it leaves too many questions unanswered.

EVERY rental librarian is familiar with the inevitable Hokinsonesque customer who wants "a mystery novel about really nice people." It's a little hard to persuade her that a cast of potential murder-suspects must, to some degree, be lacking in charm; and she's apt to be impervious to the understanding pity with which a Margaret Millar can impart sympathy to the most superficially unlikable characters.

Those of us who live in large urban areas expect public library service somewhere in the neighborhood. Therefore, it must come as a distinct surprise to find that some 30,000,000 citizens in the United States, largely in rural and sparsely settled areas, are without any library service whatsoever.

AMERICANS traveling, or planning to travel, in Great Britain may be pleased by the deep legislative consideration and thought devoted by Parliament to the comfort and convenience of tourists. Much of a recent session of the Commons was given over to a rather one-sided debate on the variable regulations controlling the sale and serving of alcoholic beverages throughout the United Kingdom.

A FORMER pilot of the towboat Coal Queen, Richard Bissell knows the Monongahela, the bustling and grimy Monongahela, which flows northward through West Virginia's industrial heartland to join the Allegheny at Pittsburgh. The valley of the Monongahela is a land of chemical plants and coke plants, of glassworks and steel mills -- and of coal.

LANCASTER, Pa. -- With summer at hand, the call of the sight-seeing bus guide is once more abroad in the land -- this land and any other where there are roads and buses and fuel. Guided bus tours may be corny but they can be good, and with enough discrimination between the worthwhile and the spurious elements of the guide's spiel, a tourist can find out a lot about a place comfortably and quickly.

MORE encouraging trends continue to mark the over-all business picture, suggesting that inventory readjustment in many lines will be well advanced by the end of the first half of the year. Confidence is growing that fall trade should be good, with leading merchants inclined to the view that sales losses in recent months will be wiped out by gains in the fall period. Wholesale market activity has increased.

LONDON, May 24 -- Robert A. Menzies, Australian Prime Minister, arrived today for a fortnight's visit to discuss economic, political and strategic matters of common interest with British Government officials.

WASHINGTON. WITH politics providing the principal entertainment on some 18,000,000 television sets during the next few months, high-ranking politicos in Washington are seizing the opportunity to give their personalities a winning touch when they are projected out over the airways. The opportunity is being provided without cost by the local staff of CBS -- TV.

MINERAL WELLS, Tex., May 24 -- The pro-Taft Texas Republican "Old Guard," beaten by backers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in a series of precinct and county conventions across the state, pinned their hopes today on prospective action of the Republican State Executive Committee to give Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio an overwhelming majority of the state's thirty-eight votes to the Republican National Convention in Chicago.

BOISE, Idaho, May 24 (UP) -More than 250 convicts brandished knives and set fire to equipment today in a riot at the Idaho State Penitentiary, but finally surrendered meekly after club-swinging guards and officers moved in on them behind a tear-gas barrage.

The Giants, on the strength of a three-run homer by Hank Thompson in the first inning, defeated the Braves again yesterday, 5 -- 4. In Boston, the Yankees dropped a 5-2 decision to the Red Sox. Unbeaten Billy Loes gained his fifth victory and extended the Dodgers' winning streak to eight games by blanking the Phils, 5 -- 0, last night in Philadelphia.

Ten Harriman for President clubs have been organized in colleges throughout the state to support W. Averell Harriman for the Democratic nomination for President, Manhattan Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr., state chairman of the Harriman for President Committee, announced yesterday.
Two young men from Wichita, Kan., who said they had come here to pursue the study of yoga, ran poor seconds to three New York detectives in the practice of the art.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -- The Senate Internal Security Committee today made public a 1945 Army Intelligence report, formerly secret, warning that the Chinese Communists were real Marxists "sponsored and guided by Moscow."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 24 -- This city took steps to speed up its slum clearance program this week when the City Commission introduced an ordinance creating a committee to work with a rehabilitation supervisor in ridding the downtown area of buildings beyond repair.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., May 24 (AP) -- Schenectady's Mont Pleasant High School track team took unofficial first honors today in the twelfth annual interscholastic sports carnival.
A NEW YORK TIMES correspondent, a long-time observer of the German scene, last week cabled this picture of the mood in Western Germany in May, 1945, and in May, 1952:

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 24 -- All Vietnamese men between the ages of 20 and 28, with educations of grade school level and up, were made subject to active military duty as second lieutenants or sub-officers in a Vietnamese Government decree published here today.

"If there is such a picture, it is one of indescribable mel ancholy * * *" Such is the picture John Pudney foresees in his "Plea for Old London" (May 18), a rebuilt London of "near-Corbusier working class flats' standing on sooty lawns with concrete curbs."

A plan which authorizes changes in the structure of the Graduate School and also modifies policy requirements for graduate degrees has been approved by the University of Kentucky. The reorganization includes plans for the immediate enlargement of the graduate faculty on the basis of high professional attainment.

BOSTON, May 24 -- Billy Martin, New York Yankees' second baseman, and Jim Piersall, young Boston Red Sox infielder, had a fist fight under the stands at Fenway Park this afternoon. The battle took place in the runway leading from the Sox dugout to the dressing rooms about an hour before game-time.

MOST gardeners are inclined to think of the greenhouse as a strictly winter hobby. Actually, the greenhouse is an ideal place to grow certain cut flowers and vegetables throughout the summer, and also tropical plants, which reach a much higher degree of perfection under glass.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The House of Representatives "struck at the heart of the whole Mutual Security Program" when it slashed funds for defense-supporting activities of the Western European countries by $615,300,000, W. John Kenney, deputy director of the Mutual Security Administration, told reporters today.

CUERNAVACA, Mexico -- Having completed an extensive system of highways throughout the republic, the Mexican Government is now embarked on a program of making its roads not only passable but safe. The newest link in the system is an improvement on the heavily traveled Mexico City-Cuernavaca road, to be completed in July.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Soil still moist from the rainy days is in fine shape for cultivating and edging. Loosening the soil surface with a scuffle hoe or cultivator uproots weeds before they call establish themselves and crowd out seedlings. Edging along the front of flower and shrub borders is easier after a rain. If it is done right, once is enough for the year.

KERNVILLE, Calif. -- This celebrated Gold Rush town, famed in song and story as "Whisky Flat," and familiar under scores of other aliases to uncounted Western film fans, will be visible to tourists for the last time in the months just ahead.

Paintings by seventeen living Americans have been purchased by the American Academy of Arts and Letters for free distribution to museums in this country and Canada. The pictures, purchased from the Childe Hassam Fund, which the academy has administered since 1936, will be on exhibition at the Academy Gallery, 633 West 155th Street.

AFTER reading Bess Furman's article about the tours of the reconstructed White House in THE NEW YORK TIMES and after taking the standard tour, I can report that it took only a few minutes more to see the place than it did to read about it.

SPOKANE, Wash., May 24 -The Republican State Convention ended late tonight after tumultuous sessions in which twenty supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and four backers of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio were elected as the state's delegation to the G. O. P. National Convention.

THE United States Section and the parent body of the International Society for Contemporary Music are back in each other's good graces. For the first time since 1948 an American composer will be officially represented in the annual I. S. C. M. festival.

Contributions by corporations, unless they constitute business expenses, are not deductible for income tax purposes in excess of 5 per cent of the donor's net income, computed before the contribution is deducted.
The freighter Lualaba, of 10.848 deadweight tons, will dock here today under a new name and flying the house flag of her new owners, the Belgian Line.

FORTY two million homemakers are spending fifty two million dollars a year on food. This must be of benefit to someone but certainly not to the family budget. Ida Bailey Allen, an authority on nutrition, tackles this problem, in her latest book, "Solving the High Cost of Eating."

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Sunday, May 25 (AP) -- Communist prisoners, shouting, singing and waving defiant banners and Red flags from behind barbed-wire stockades, gave an unruly greeting to British and Canadian troops on their arrival here today.

I HAD hoped the season would not come to a close without some over-all review of the Choral Masterwork Series presented this year by Robert Shaw and his associates. Since nothing of this nature has appeared in your columns (or elsewhere in the daily press, to my knowledge) I am prompted to voice my regret over this omission.

Every skipper who navigates anything at all, from a bobbing washtub up to an ocean-crossing super liner, pays homage to Nathaniel Bowditch. He is the patron saint of navigators, and especially the learned and erudite yachtsmen of the United States Power Squadrons who study the advanced realms of astronomy and other mysteries, and who use Bowditch's famous ."New American Practical Navigator," first published in 1802, with reverent awe.
A man suspected of staging four hold-ups in four hours was shot and killed in Harlem last night during a chase in which a woman bystander was wounded and a policeman knifed.

GIFTED Thail Cummings, a successful Broadway actress, unwillingly falls in love with Phil Tanner, a suburban M. D. Tanner is unsuitably married to immature, scatterbrained Angie, pitifully attached to him because of her weak-kneed dependence.

General satisfaction with the United States-Chile copper pact announced last week was expressed in the domestic copper trade because it eliminates the threat of a grave shortage of the metal here in June. But several authorities voiced apprehension over price problems which may result from the agreement.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 24 -- Business activity in the district last month held about even with that of April, 1951, but building permits for the first four months of this year are off about two and one-half million dollars from last year, the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis reported.

EARLY last year, Dr. Gordon Seagrave, famed American "Burma Surgeon," was sentenced to six years imprisonment for allegedly giving aid and comfort to Burmese Red guerrillas. He was freed by the Burmese court of appeals after serving seven months in a Rangoon jail.
GLOBAL television with pictures jumping merrily between New York and Europe seems to be stirring up quite a to-do on both sides of the Atlantic.

A 20 per cent surcharge on cargoes to Casablanca will be applied by steamship lines of the North Atlantic Mediterranean Freight Conference after Aug. 1. Members said the charge was necessary to offset expenses incurred by idle waiting periods and enforced expensive night work in the North African port.

BONN, May 24 -- On Monday morning at 10 o'clock German time, in the big white concrete box of a building that serves the Federal Republic of Germany as the seat of its legislature, the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain and France and the German Republic will sign a series of documents revolutionizing the state of Europe.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 24 (UP) -- Joseph W. Weinberg, "Scientist X," insisted today that he was innocent of charges that he had slipped atomic secrets to Soviet agents. He said he would enter an innocence plea to Federal charges that he lied to the House Un-American Activities Committee.

INEVITABLE limitations on space kept me from being more specific on the point to which Father de Jaegher takes exception. As his quotations show, he did try to see General Marshall. But it seemed to me, on reading his account of the incident, that he was inexplicably slow in approaching the general and rather easily turned aside.

In the last Saturday market until October, stock prices drifted narrowly on the Stock Exchange yesterday and closed mixed, with trading dull. Activity in a few low-price utility issues helped expand the day's volume to 300,000 shares, compared with 270,000 a week earlier, when the turnover was the smallest in three years.

Norman Armour has been elected a director of American and Foreign Power Company, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Armour has served in many important posts in the diplomatic service of the United States. He has been United States Ambassador to Chile,

Firm orders for transport aircraft placed within the last ten days indicate a belief that Great Britain, with turbine driven transports in actual service, may not be so far ahead in this important market as the bare facts indicate. In order of importance the developments have been:

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The difficult, frustrating, often bitter relations between the United States and the Soviet Union from the date of Washington's recognition of Moscow in 1933 to the outbreak of war in 1939 is set down in monumental detail in a new volume of documents, most of them never before published, released tonight by the State Department.

The East's most important track and field test of the Olympic year, the seventy-sixth annual championships of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A., will bring the spiked-shoe select of fifty-four colleges to Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island on Friday and Saturday.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- Another addition has been made to Florida's state park system with the recent formal opening of Little Talbot Island State Park in the Jacksonville area. The park, an ocean-front playground just north of Fort George, borders on the Buccaneer Trail, the toll highway completed about two years ago which links Fort George with Fernandina Beach up at the Georgia border.

OUR lives yield so readily the pressures of the world about us, we are not likely to assume that personalities unfold independently of the environment. By experience we know that society decisively influences the character of individuals. Yet the nature of those influences has largely escaped the attention of social scientists; if we understand those forces at all, it is largely through the insight of novelists.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- C. N. Sayen, president of the Airline Pilots Association, announced today that an independent investigation by his group had shown that "aircraft component malfunctions" and not Newark Airport were responsible for the three crashes in near-by Elizabeth.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., May 24 -- William C. Spear of Southport, Conn., capped a thrilling duel with Fred G. Wacker Jr. of Lake Forest, Ill., this afternoon to win the 100-mile event of the fourth annual Bridgehampton road races before a crowd estimated at more than 35,000.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The United States Government will reject the Soviet Union's latest proposal for an immediate Big Four meeting on the unification of Germany, a responsible official said today. The Soviet note containing this proposal was broadcast by Radio Moscow early this morning and a summary of it was sent to the State Department later today by United States Ambassador George F. Kennan.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- Dr. Neil A. Dayton, an executive of the American Association on Mental Deficiency, told the annual conference of the Northeast Region of the National Association for Retarded Children that more state aid was needed for the younger retarded child to keep him out of serious trouble when he became older.

One of the joys of television is how educational the thing is. Were it not for the home screen and all its magnificent twenty inches, thousands of persons would have missed on Saturday night the heady stimulus of learning about stock car racing and girls' baseball.

The Living Theatre is an organization dedicated to the presentation of what it considers "new and exciting" stage works. Not long ago it offered "Dr. Faustus Lights the Lights," a Gertrude Stein play that ranks among the most unintelligible and unnecessary theatre offerings of all time.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- A strip of film taken by the Japanese during World War II has solved the 10-year-old mystery of what happened to the United States destroyer Edsall. A Japanese cruiser sank her off Java.

The annual report of Correction Commissioner Albert Williams released today cites the completion of a survey of the penitentiary and workhouse divisions on Rikers Island as a milestone in the development of a sound correctional program for the city.
PRESTWICK, Scotland, May 25 (AP) -- The week-long match play for the British amateur golf championship gets under way tomorrow with Frank Stranahan labeled the "man to beat."
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 25 (UP) -- Scientists fired an atomic device in the Nevada desert today with a burning blast described as the most spectacular yet seen by Las Vegas residents.

For even the most city-bound culinarian, spring brings to mind herbs fresh from the garden. Fortunately, a few stores offer a variety of these aromatic seasoning greens, though mostly from hothouses. And since they are grown under glass, they may be had from time to time throughout the year.

ATHENS, May 18 -- More than 2,000 years ago this city, once the undisputed center of civilization but now just a European capital, enacted a law designed to curb a perennial menace -- dictatorship. At the time that scholars say it was adopted there was a danger of a barbaric invasion, a fear that democracy would be suppressed. That was in 336 B. C.

An alert radio car patrolman on a lone tour of the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn late Saturday night arrested three paroled prisoners at pistol point. Their parked automobile yielded a loaded .38-calibre revolver, a .25-calibre Colt automatic containing one cartridge, ammunition for both weapons, and a blackjack.

The basements of several Bronx apartment buildings were flooded early yesterday by a twelve-foot break in a twenty-inch water main below the surface of Grand Concourse at 174th Street. The break also cut heat in the six-story house at 1725 Morris Avenue.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, May 25 -- Aly Maher Pasha, chief of the Cabinet preceding the present one and commonly known as the great compromiser, has made a radical suggestion for a solution of Egypt's most pressing problem.
CINCINNATI, May 25 (UP) -- Two pitchers and an umpire were injured as the Cardinals won the first game of a double-header from the Reds, 7 -- 6, today. Rain forced postponement of the second game.

With the signing today of the treaty giving virtual independence to West Germany the second phase of the struggle for Europe begins. No seasoned observer of the war-shadowed stage on which we live and act, each playing his infinitesimal part in the great drama, doubts that the solemn scene in Bonn this morning is the curtain raiser on a new and climactic act.

The American Academy and National Institute of Arts and Letters will hold their joint annual ceremonial at 3 P. M. on Wednesday at the academy, 632 West 156th Street. They will induct new members, award honors for distinguished achievements in the arts and present the institute's annual arts and letters grants of $1,000 each to fifteen creative artists in painting, sculpture, music and literature.

PARIS, May 25 -- Two new elements have just appeared in the development of the price-reduction policy followed by French Premier Antoine Pinay. Speaking last Friday to a meeting of business men, the Government leader for the first time referred to an eventual relaxation of credit controls.
Trips into town on father's day off may become less infrequent if reduced fares and free rides for children can be the deciding inducement.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Grain trade volume increased quite sharply last week, but pit operations were well below the total of the same 1951 week. Oats took the lead in total pit purchases of grain for the week at 54,565,000 bushels which was 5,000,000 more than was traded in the wheat pit.

In the autumn of 1946 the late Fiorello La Guardia urged the statesmen of the world at Lake Success to form an organization to alleviate the plight of children suffering from the aftermath of the second World War. Since then the U. N. International Children's Emergency Fund, financed by voluntary contributions of member states, has spelled milk and food, clothes and shoes, health and shelter to nearly sixty million children in many lands.
SPOKANE, Wash., May 25 -- A "no-gloating" policy was laid down today by Eisenhower leaders after a one-sided victory over the Taft forces at the Republican State Convention here yesterday.

During the winter months of a year ago, two years ago, it was very good to think of living in the country. In a small apartment room it was pleasant to pore over those catalogues which list desirable farms, exceptional half acres or just ranch houses in the suburbs.

As the face of Europe begins to change today, it is worthwhile to reflect again on the permanent factors with which we all have to deal. It is these factors that determine what each country, including our own, is trying to do.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, took issue with Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, today whether a newspaper reporter had the right to refuse to disclose his confidential sources of information.

PARIS, May 25 (AP) -- The French police arrested today Andre Stil, chief editor of the Communist daily newspaper L'Humanite. He was taken into custody at his home near Paris in proceedings ordered by the Ministry of Justice against those judged responsible for organizing demonstrations against Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, the new Supreme Allied Commander in Europe.
Charles happily travels eighty miles every morning to his job at Goodwill Industries workshop. He has not walked in fourteen years. Not so long ago Charles felt lost in a busy world.
PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (AP) -- Gov. John S. Fine emerged today with tighter control of the as yet uncommitted seventy-vote Republican National Convention delegation from Pennsylvania.

The twelve - story apartment house on plot 100 by 90 feet at 405 Park Avenue, northeast corner of Fifty-fourth Street, has been purchased by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, trustee for the Astor Estate, from clients of Robert Steefel of Stroock Stroock Lavan, attorneys.

Are there not city and state laws governing the handling of food in restaurants? I am beginning to doubt it, in view of what I have seen, not in sidewalk stands (which I do not patronize) but in reputable chain and single restaurants, some of them on Fifth Avenue, midtown.
ST. LOUIS, May 25 (UP) -- The league-leading Indians salvaged a split in today's "Dizzy Dean Day" double-header with the Browns at Sportsman's Park.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- The American Bar Association said today that it had opened a vigorous campaign to "eliminate" attorneys who "cooperate" with the underworld and help criminals to evade the law.
Heavy rain yesterday caused a revision of plans for various memorial services and the postponement of some programs until next Sunday.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 -- Officials of the American President Lines reluctantly postponed again today the sailing hour of the President Wilson until 3 P. M. tomorrow.

FORT WORTH, May 25 (AP) -- Ben Hogan put on one of the blazing finishes for which he is famous today to win the $20,000 Colonial national invitation golf tournament with a 3-under-par 67 on the final eighteen holes for a seventy-two-hole total of 279.

Virginia Electric and Power Company is offering to the holders of its common stock rights to subscribe at $21.75 a share for 494,642 shares of new common stock at the rate of one share for each ten held. The offer, which carries the privilege of secondary subscription subject to allotment, expires on June 9.

In this last week before General Eisenhower's return from Europe three state conventions of the Republican party will meet. In Georgia and Texas there is a question of the validity of the claims of Taft and Eisenhower representatives. In Connecticut, although the popular sentiment has already been expressed in favor of Eisenhower, the issue is confused by local personalities and contests.

KOJE ISLAND, Monday, May 26 (Reuters) -- Fanatical Communists grabbed political control of the 80,000 prisoners on this island during a "bloody month" of rioting last year, prison authorities disclosed today.

MIAMI, May 25 (UP) -- Two southern Democratic Presidential aspirants face an important contest Tuesday when 650,000 Florida Democrats will elect the state's twenty-four delegates to the national nominating convention.

DUNELLEN, N. J., May 25 -- Mrs. Leonard Smit's imported wire-haired fox terrier, Ch. Wyretex Wyns Traveller, from Ho-hokus, N. J., who had been best in show yesterday at Morris and Essex, glittered once again today.
LONDON, May 25 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Soviet note of May 24 to the United States on German unification as broadcast by the Moscow radio:

A traveler in Formosa might see, with a single flick of his one good eye, (1) a porter bouncing along with bundles at either end of a bearer-pole, (2) a sullen water buffalo -- the original feather-bedder -- pulling a fifth of the load he could drag if he wished, (3) a combination of rickshaw and bicycle known as a pedi-cab * * * and (7) a jet plane.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 25 Katherine Daly of Gladstone, N. J., and Janice Weitz of New York dominated the Rock Spring horse show today as the two-day event came to a close at the West Orange Riding Club.

WEST POINT, May 25 -- Maj. Gen. Frederick A. Irving, Superintendent of the United States Military Academy, announced today that Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, would deliver the graduation address in the academy's Field House June 3.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- A Republican member of the House of Representatives Judiciary Committee predicted today that the group would approve "veto-proof" legislation tomorrow challenging President Truman's right to seize private property such as the steel industry.
LONDON, May 25 -- The severe break in prices of gilt-edge securities in the last few days has had a demoralizing effect on the stock markets generally.

PARIS, May 25 -- The French Government tonight authorized its Foreign Minister, Robert Schuman, to sign the twin treaties just completed to integrate West Germany in the Western defense system -- the contractual agreement with the Bonn regime and the treaty to create a single European defense force.

NEW DELHI, India, May 25 (Reuters) -- Extremist Hindu political leaders called tonight for a general strike of all Hindus here tomorrow in protest against an attempted marriage between a Hindu girl and a young Moslem.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- The United Jewish Appeal -- the largest voluntary fund-raising agency in the country -- closed its two-day national cash mobilization conference here today as announcement was made that $39,000,000 had been raised in the first five months of this year to meet Jewish needs throughout the world, notably in Israel.

Airplane pilots were warned yesterday by the Civil Aeronautics Administration not to use amphetamine or its derivatives, especially in high dosages employed for reducing weight. Derivatives of the drug such as benzedrine and dexedrine are used principally to stimulate the central nervous system and, in obesity, to control the weight.

Abrogation of Regulation X, the Federal curb on home-purchasing credit, was urged yesterday by State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman, to lift the building industry out of its present uncertainty.

LONDON, May 25 -- The chief purpose of the new Soviet note to the Western Towers on Germany was seen here today as another attempt to delay the ratification of the Bonn agreements. The chief question here as in Washington is how effective it will be in adding to French anxieties and German hesitations.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 25 (UP) -- A second United States Air Force helicopter is on the way to help evacuate an American and fifteen Brazilians from the scene of a jungle air crash, a United States military spokesman said today.

PITTSBURGH, May 25 (UP) -- Dee Fondy, who had singled three times previously, hit his third home run of the season with one on and two out in the ninth inning today to gain a 5-4 victory for the Cubs over the Pirates in a game delayed by rain for an hour and 22 minutes in the third inning.
CHICAGO, May 25 -- The Weather and the closing of May contracts accounted for some widely contrasting developments in the grain market last week.

Raymond M. Hilliard, executive director of the Welfare and Health Council, noting the continued flow of heroin into this city, has urged Congress to enact legislation for more efficient and more effective Federal control of the narcotics traffic.

It is the view of the Child Study Association that the proposed local law that would fine parents $25 for vandalism against city property by children under the age of 16 years is an unsound approach to the problem, both socially and legally.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- Newspaper publishers and representatives of Federal agencies will appear before a House newsprint subcommittee tomorrow to discuss the effects of another Canadian price increase on newsprint.

JERUSALEM, May 25 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion today received the honorary degree of Doctor of Hebrew Letters from Dr. Louis I. Finkelstein, chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, at a ceremony held on the grounds of the Hebrew University in the Terra Santa Convent.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- A special fact-finding committee recommended today that the Government give preferential contract treatment to New England shoe manufacturers to help reduce unemployment in the industry.
Though the art season is waning and summer is nearing, several events of note nevertheless appear among this week's new attractions.
CHICAGO, May 25 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson called tonight for a re-examination of this nation's "total welfare picture" to answer the question, "Where are we going?"
WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- The Senate Small Business Committee said today that Government red tape and procurement officers had turned the defense production pooling program into a failure.

Tchaikovsky's Op. 41, his setting of the Liturgy of St. John Chrysostom, was sung on Saturday night at Town Hall by the seventeen men and twenty-one women of the Russian Orthodox Cathedral Choir of 59 East Second Street.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Two of the largest grocery chains in the country were charged today by the Federal Trade Commission with knowingly receiving price discriminations from suppliers in violation of the Clayton Anti-Trust Act.

Despite the teeming rain, 5,874 hardy souls stood in the open stands of Triborough Stadium yesterday to watch the soccer match between the Stuttgart Kickers of Germany and Manchester United of England. The British titleholders won, 5 -- 2.

Believers in Christ who give way to fears are indulging in a "vice" that is the "universal enemy of the virtue of fortitude," the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan declared at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. He is a vice chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York.

HONG KONG, May 25 -- Three prominent Chinese educators, each of whom embraced Mac Tse-tung's New Democracy and praised it in its early stages, were reported today to have run afoul of the uncompromising "ideological remolding" campaign that has accompanied the over-all shift to the left in the Peiping Government's policies.

The Fund for Adult Education has elected Paul H. Helms chairman of its board and Charles H. Percy, vice chairman. The fund, an independent organization established a year ago by the Ford Foundation, engages in research and the development of programs of liberal education for adults. It has offices in this city, Pasadena, Calif., and Chicago.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Monday, May 26 -- Tough Communist leaders in this big stockade are forging a crudely equipped army to beat back any attempt by United Nations forces to impose control over 80,000 North Korean and Chinese prisoners of war.

The Rev. Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, president of Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday that with the "culmination of the greatest Christian century" man is now facing "a crisis of peril and opportunity" that will determine the future of the Christian Church.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- Jess Larson, administrator of the Defense Materials Procurement Agency, said today that the nation's program to stimulate production of essential minerals had made "substantial progress."

Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway will be the guest today of the United Nations, whose forces he commanded in Korea, and will receive the United Nations Korean service medal at the world organization's headquarters. A similar medal is available for his predecessor, General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- Bobby Shantz of the Athletics became the first American League pitcher to win seven games this season as he beat the Senators, 2 -- 1, in the opening game of a double-header today, but the Senators won the second contest, 1 -- 0, on Lefty Lou Sleater's seven-hitter and Pete Runnels' ninth-inning single.

Deferred from Thursday night, "The Rehearsal," a museum piece stemming from the Restoration era, will be put on in modern guise at 8 o'clock this evening at the intimate President Theatre, 247 West Forty-eighth Street.

SUBJECT to the generalization that all generalizations have their exceptions it is reasonably safe to say that a novel about an issue is rarely as successful as a novel about particular people. Particular fictional people are often confronted with issues and novels about issues have to be dramatized in terms of people. But it is the inspiration, the author's motivation, which makes the difference.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Earl J. McGrath, Federal Education Commissioner, warned today that "hundreds of thousands" of migrant children "present a growing problem of illiteracy." Mr. McGrath's comment came at the end of a five-day conference on the problems of educating children of migrant farm workers who move across the country harvesting the crops as they reached seasonal peaks.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 25 -- The taxi driver volunteered that "the general" would be back from the United States soon and he seemed surprised that anyone would ask whether he was pleased or not.

PARIS, May 25 -- William H. Draper Jr., special United States representative in Europe, said in a statement today that if the Senate concurred in the House of Representatives' cut in appropriations for economic assistance to Europe, the implications would be serious "for the future security of the United States."

WILMINGTON, Del., Monday, May 26 (UP) -- A 10,441-ton oil tanker and a tugboat towing an oil barge collided and burst into flames on the lower Delaware River during a rainstorm last night and fire was still sweeping one vessel early today.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Stanley Andrews, Point Four director, said today that Government spending to assist backward countries abroad would taper off from the record-breaking $227,000,000 Congress had been asked to provide this year.

The International Society for Contemporary Music, United States Section, presented its third concert of the season Saturday evening in the McMillin Theatre, Columbia University. The program included the first performance of a Suite for Piano by Edward Steuermann, and string quartets by Roger Sessions and Ben Weber.

Your recent editorial regarding Japan's entry into the United Nations and the question of membership as a whole was, it seemed to me, rather misleading. This is one of the basic problems before the U. N., and it is of great importance for Americans to understand the facts and the issues involved because of the dominating influence we wield in the U. N.

SINGAPORE, May 25 (Reuters) -- The Singapore Moslem Advisory Board today decided to ask the Singapore Government to withdraw from sale or distribution all May 19 copies of the American magazine Newsweek, which published a "portrait" of the prophet Mohammed.

British sterling sold down to $2.79 1/16, last Friday, under the weight of oil company offerings and liquidation of stale long accounts. This was the lowest since mid-March, which ironically witnessed the first stages of an upward movement inspired by a British budget of tax benefits, relaxation of controls and trading in forwards that subsequently carried it to $2.81 3/8, highest since devaluation in 1949.

About 20,000,000 men in this country smoke cigars, according to the research department of Benton Bowles. But only 5,000,000 of that number are inveterate cigar puffers, who smoke at least one a day. This group accounts for 86 per cent of total national sales.

Charges for parking in the seventy-eight state parks will rise today from 25 to 35 cents and at Jones Beach the fee will be increased from 50 to 60 cents. The decision to raise the rates followed weeks of discussion by members of the State Council of Parks.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- Marv Grissom, a 34-year-old right-hander with a rookie status, hurled a three-hitter and faced only thirty batters today to guide the White Sox to a 1-0 victory over the Tigers after Joe Dobson had blanked Detroit on five hits, 3 to 0, in the opener of the double-header.

BONN, Germany, May 25 -- The United States, Britain, France and Federal Germany today settled all outstanding issues in the contractual agreement and this agreement, restoring the German nation to equality and independence in Europe, is ready for signature tomorrow.
Eleven new films, including imports from Italy and England, will arrive this week in first-run theatres. The programs follow:

BARCELONA, Spain, May 25 -- Preparations were completed today for the thirty-fifth international eucharistic conference of the Roman Catholic Church which will be instituted Tuesday by Frederico Cardinal Tedeschini, the Papal Legate.
TOKYO, Monday, May 26 (AP) -- United Nations Command headquarters communique 1261 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6:00 A. M. today (5 P. M. Sunday Eastern daylight time):

Rain having washed out the Giants-Braves game at the Polo Grounds and the Dodgers-Phils contest at Philadelphia yesterday, the two local rivals will train their big guns on each other for the next three days.

Last week the second American Assembly met in the monastic seclusion of its home, Arden House, high in the Ramapo hills overlooking Tuxedo Park, N. Y. That medieval mansion house, built by the late E. H. Harriman early in the present century, is now a part of the campus of Columbia University.

Thirty-two floors above the Battery, with anemometers spinning in the background and the taller spires of Wall Street shrouded in mist, a little gadget called a tipping bucket did its stuff 142 times yesterday in the process of recording the heaviest rainfall ever to douse the city on a May 25 -- 1.42 inches.

HARTFORD, May 25 -- Connecticut Republicans open their two-day state convention here tomorrow in the grip of a party civil war between Gov. John Davis Lodge and William H. Brennan of Stamford, national committeeman. The Governor announced today that he was supporting James C. Shannon of Bridgeport, former Governor, for National Committeeman against Mr. Brennan.

TOKYO, Monday, May 26 -- The official Peiping radio said today that the United Nations delegates would be called to account when the conferences for an armistice in Korea resumed at Panmunjom tomorrow for the newly revealed riot on Koje Island in April in which three war prisoners were killed and fifty-seven injured.

Music is supposed to have charms to soothe the savage beast, but what will it do for normal persons? To find the answer, the music department of Teachers College, Columbia University, will start next fall a year's study to determine the effect of music on the individual and group behavior of normal children.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 25 (AP) -- A small town publisher who supports General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination is Minnesota's new National Committeeman, after an upset victory over a strong backer of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

Jewelry estimated to be worth $23,800 was stolen from the penthouse apartment of Louis Abrams, president of the New York division of the Emerson Radio Corporation at 230 Central Park South, the police reported last night.

Carl Sandburg's newest work, "Always the Young Strangers," has been scheduled for publication by Harcourt, Brace on Jan. 6, his seventy-fifth birthday. Mr. Sandburg, who has won the Pulitzer Prize for both history and poetry, tells the story of his life in the small town where he was born, of his family and of his friends there.

AMSTERDAM, May 25 -- Last week has been the most spectacular in the Amsterdam Stock Exhange's three centuries of history. As of last Tuesday the Stock Exchange board has refused to make up quotations so that in practice the exchange has been closed.

STRASBOURG, France, May 25 -- Representatives of the Consultative Assembly of the Council of here Europe were gathering here today for what were sure to become turbulent discussions of all aspects of the accord between the Western occuption powers and Western Germany and of the European Defense Community treaty.

More than any other factor, Mr. John Q. Public is responsible for checking inflation in the last year, Dr. Arthur F. Burns, director of research of the National Bureau of Economic Research, Inc., declares in the bureau's annual report issued today.

Reporting 1,716 fewer persons on public assistance rolls in April than in March, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy told Mayor Impellitteri yesterday that the decline occurred in all except one category -- aid to the disabled.
Establishment of a defense program against enemy biological warfare in agriculture was announced yesterday by Lieut. Gen. C. R. Huebner, director of the New York State Civil Defense Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Eighty-second Congress now has just six weeks before the political conventions to complete a program that it has hardly begun in nearly five months of its second session. It must soon go into a spectacular sprint if even the bare essentials of the job are to be achieved by that time.

The old saw, "New York is a great place to visit, but I wouldn't want to live there," was reversed thirty-four years ago by Miss Rebecca B. Rankin, whose retirement on June 30 as head of the New York Public Library's municipal reference branch in the Municipal Building was announced yesterday.

TRIESTE, Monday, May 26 -- Eighty-three per cent of the registered voters of Trieste and as many as 98 per cent of the registered voters in the small towns of Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste voted today in the municipal elections in which the coalition led by Italian Premier Alcide de Gasperi's Christian Democrats sought to maintain itself in power against the combined attacks of the neo-Fascists and the Cominform Communists.

RAPID CITY, S. D., May 25 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio shared a speakers' table with Mrs. Estes Kefauver today and struck out at those who said he could not win the Republican Presidential nomination.
DETROIT, May 25 -- William J. Grede of Milwaukee, head of the National Association of Manufacturers, was elected national president of the Young Men's Christian Association here today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 25 -- Betsy Drake, following in the footsteps of her husband, Cary Grant, has signed a contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and will be co-starred in "The Desperate Search."

A new program of courses in theory and practice of education has been made possible next fall at Barnard College by a grant of $30,000 by the New York Fund for Children, Inc. This was announced yesterday by Dean Millicent C. McIntosh.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature twelve months, amount to within $57,843,056,276. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 25 -- The Window of the Four Chaplains was unveiled today in the Post Chapel at the United States Military Academy. The window memorializes four Army chaplains who sacrificed their lives in the sinking of the troopship Dorchester off Greenland on Feb. 3, 1943.

KOJE ISLAND, May 25 -- In an effort to avert further violence and bloodshed in prisoner-of-war compounds, two representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross conferred today with the ranking Communist prisoner of the 80,000 on this island.

BERLIN, May 25 -- The growing misgivings in West Berlin that the fulfillment of Bonn's treaty with the West will perpetuate this city's isolation have been reflected in the last two days in the press here.

LYNBROOK, L. I., May 25 -- William J. (Big Bill) Duffy notorious figure of the Prohibition Era who in the Nineteen Thirties was the American manager of Primo Carnera, Italian heavyweight champion of the world, died at 1 o'clock this morning in the home of his daughter, Mrs. Winifred Jackson, at 85 Blossom Heath here. He was 69 years old.
WASHINGTON, Monday, May 26 (AP) -- Striking workers of the Western Union Telegraph Company ratified a new wage settlement yesterday and the fifty-two day old strike ended at 12:01 A. M. today.

PITTSBURGH, May 25 -- Steel production last week was up 1/2 point to 101.5 per cent of capacity from a revised rate of 101 per cent of a week ago. So far the industry has not been plagued with outlaw strikes. The longer it takes before the Supreme Court rules on the steel case the more labor unrest is to be expected.

Place mats are pretty as well as practical on bare dining tables in the summer. The variety of new designs available, coupled with the relative low cost of many of the mats, might tempt the homemaker to invest in more than one set for quick changes in the table's decor.

BONN, Germany, May 25 -- The latest Soviet proposals on German reunification have failed to break the Western Allied-German front on integration of the Federal Republic in the North Atlantic Community.

The announcement that the Muscular Dystrophy Association, organized only a year and a half ago, has established at least ten post-graduate fellowships for research aimed at discovering the cause and cure of progressive muscular dystrophy is indeed heartening. Research specialists at several well-equipped medical centers, such as the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical College, are feverishly performing complex experiments in metabolism, nutrition and blood chemistry which require training that these new technicians will acquire.

The Waysol Realty Corporation bought for investment the six-story apartment house for forty-six families on plot 75 by 95 feet at 390 Hooper Street, Brooklyn, from the estate of Morris Walzer and insured title wtih the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The people of New York City, long harassed by the soot and smoke nuisance, can take much satisfaction in the steady flow of court decisions in their favor, the latest of which upholds the Bureau of Smoke Control against the Consolidated Edison Company in the Appellate Division.

LONDON, May 25 -- When the Duke of Windsor reached France after his abdication from the British throne in 1936, he said "I always thought I could get away with a morganatic marriage," according to Lord Beaverbrook, prominent British publisher.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 25 -- The governing United National party barely held an edge over the Leftists and other opposition groups as complete returns from nearly one-fourth of Ceylon's parliamentary constituencies were announced today in the island's first general elections since independence.

A fresh chapter will be started today in the story of Harry Gross and the police-protected $20,000,000-a-year gambling business that he used to run. Principals in a new Police Department trial are to meet at Brooklyn Headquarters to set the time and place for the third disciplinary proceedings against policemen charged with taking Gross' graft.

Two young women treated for extensive tuberculosis of the lungs with the new anti-TB drugs were sent home yesterday from Sea View Hospital, the symptoms of their disease arrested. They had received doses of the isopropyl derivative of isonicotinic acid hydrazide, which is known under the trade name of Marsilid.

BAY SHORE, L. I., May 25 -- A heavy southeast wind that blew steadily at about 25 miles an hour and reached twice that in gusts forced the postponement of the first race of the United States Olympic Star class final elimination series today.

In speaking to the Senate Armed Services Committee General Ridgway did a good job in emphasizing the large political implications in the Korean stalemate. He pointed out that it was not possible to reach a basic settlement at this time unless there were very high-level policy decisions.
ALBUQUERQUE, May 25 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee in effect proposed a United Nations ultimatum to the Communists in Korea today.

A warning of the threat of communism in the United States was voiced last night by Archbishop Gregory, refugee head of the Ukranian Orthodox Church, who said, "If you don't wake up, clean out the Reds from your churches, schools and labor unions, and unite with other free countries to put an end to the danger that menaces all free nations America may be next."

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Backers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower looked today to the week ahead, in which eighty-six delegates to the Republican National Convention will be chosen, to close in on Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in the race for the Presidential nomination.
The Senate Appropriations Committee is being asked this week to use the crystal ball of prophecy to determine when the danger of war with the Soviet Union will be at its maximum.
