A major shake-up in the leadership of the Canadian division of the United Textile Workers International Union, A. F. L., will take place in Montreal today in a move to drive alleged Communists from power.
The Arab victims of the war in Palestine should be helped in resettlement by American Jews, Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said yesterday.

With the inevitable downfall of the Communist empire and the restoration of human freedom to enslaved peoples, a new era will dawn for mankind, Edward M. O'Connor of the Displaced Persons Commission told 700 persons yesterday at Town Hall at the observance of the thirty-fourth anniversary of Armenian Independence Day.

The E. R. Wolfe syndicate, of which Patrick S. Naughton is the treasurer, bought the five-story apartment house for ten families on lot 37 by 110 feet at 874 Longwood Avenue, the Bronx, for altering into furnished rooms.

Columbia College has selected two of its seniors and an alumnus as recipients of the 1952 Kellett Fellowships, worth $4,000 each for two years of graduate study in England. The winners, chosen for their "exceptional proficiency" in the humanities, are Robert C. Pinckert, Elliott Zuckerman and Joseph A. Rothschild. All three are 21 years old.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 25 -- The Cambridge police have been asked by the Committee on Freedom of Information of the American Society of Newspaper Editors to explain their treatment of staff members of The Harvard Crimson who were covering a riot the night of May 15 in Harvard Square.

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 25 -- The election of a trustee and the promotion of nine faculty members at Vassar College were announced today by Mrs. Morris Hadley, chairman of the board, and Sarah Gibson Blanding, president.

Because belts are becoming so important in the fashion picture, Patterns of The Times offers today two simple classic fashions that are perfect foils for the new belt styles, which, as one person in the trade puts it, "are selling our dresses."

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A group of Republican Representatives charged today that this country had been "shortchanged" to the extent of 214,000 tons of copper annually by the International Materials Conference and that the international agency had worked a "cruel injustice" upon workers in the automotive field.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The United States Government has made minor changes in its position on the treaties integrating Western Germany in Europe's defense to meet French demands for an assurance that West Germany would not withdraw from the European Army after entering it.

Your editorial on the anniversary of "World Trade Week," calling attention to the importance of New York City as a port, reminds me of the fact that just a few years ago on the occasion of a previous anniversary of the same event I attended a luncheon at which an address was made by Henry A. Wallace, who was at that time Secretary of Commerce.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 25 -- By 1970 the Soviet Union may reach at least twice its present levels of production and military-economic strength, papers presented this week-end at the Conference on Soviet Economic Growth at Arden House here indicated.

Queen Mary, who is 85 years old today, is a misty figure to Americans. Her daughter-in-law, Queen Elizabeth, is well known in the United States, where her charming personality won all hearts on several visits. Her granddaughter, the reigning Queen Elizabeth II, is a vivid image in all our minds.

MINERAL WELLS, Tex., May 25 -- Backers of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio asserted today their absolute control of Republican State Convention machinery and said that they did not propose to recognize a majority of delegates won by backers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

GENEVA, May 25 -- In meeting the strains of changes in the world economy during the last quarter of 1951 and early 1952, Western Europe for the first time since World War II showed faint signs of functioning as a community with a balancing mechanism linking its various national economies.

BOSTON, May 25 -- That Mickey Mantle will be on the sidelines when the Yankees return to the Bronx in a night game against the Senators Tuesday was indicated today as rain forced postponement of the second contest in the series with the Red Sox.

ROME, Monday, May 26 -- With the opening of the polls at 6 o'clock yesterday morning the bitter battle that the Christian Democrats and their allies have been fighting for the last few weeks against a powerful Communist-Socialist coalition and a threatening Monarchist-neo-Fascist coalition to retain or gain control of local administrations in more than one-third of Italy entered its decisive stage.

PARIS, May 25 -- Jaroslav Drobny of Egypt, the defending champion; Frank Sedgman and Kenneth McGregor of Australia, holders of the American and Australian crowns, and Budge Patty of Los Angeles, winner here in 1950, reached the quarter-finals of the French national tennis championship today.

Racial discrimination in the United States has become "a great international issue" and is handicapping our Government abroad, Dr. Channing H. Tobias, a delegate from this country to the Sixth United Nations General Assembly in Paris, said yesterday in an address to the 164th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. Dr. Tobias spoke at an afternoon session at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, where the assembly is being held.
It is a moot point whether New Yorkers are the worst drivers in the country, but there is no disputing the insurance record that they are the "most expensive."

Discontinuance of the cut rate fare of 15 cents for a combined ride on city subways and the municipal and private surface lines is being considered by the Board of Transportation. If the bargain rate is dropped, such a combination ride will cost 20 cents.

With the waters of the Hudson racing under her planks and the rain washing her decks, the excursion boat John A. Meseck put in at Bear Mountain yesterday with Hunter College students and their escorts, 1,400 strong, and one very dry spot aboard -- the craft's bar.

The rise of secularism can be directly attributed to the fact that religion has ceased to make sense for most persons of the twentieth century, the Rev. Donald Harrington, minister of the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-Fifth Street, said yesterday in a sermon.
BALTIMORE, May 25 (AP) -- George Rhoden won the 300-yard dash and anchored his Morgan State team-mates to victory in the 880-yard relay today in a Morgan State-sponsored special track and field meet.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 25 -- Tension is rising throughout the South African trade union movement after yesterday's clashes between the police and garment workers, most of them women, whose peaceful protest meeting on the Johannesburg City Hall steps became disorderly after the police rushed the platform to arrest Solomon Sachs, general secretary of the garment workers.

The fall underwear lines of Robert Reis Co. have extended the use of Perma-sized shrinkage control, it is announced by Arthur Reis Jr., president. Included in the group are Reis Scandals, additional athletic shirts and "T" shirts and part-wool union suits.

Roosevelt Raceway, the track which started something of a harness racing craze in the metropolitan area, will, weather permitting, launch its thirteenth season tonight. The standard-breds -- and the mutuel machines -- will be in action at the Westbury (L. I.) course for a 108-night session that winds up on Sept. 27.

PRESTWICK, Scotland, May 26 (AP) -- Dick Chapman of Pinehurst, N. C., the defending champion, and the United States amateur king, Billy Maxwell, scored one-sided victories today to lead a strong American charge into the third round of the British amateur golf championship.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The sale of The Cincinnati Enquirer to The Cincinnati Times-Star was opposed as a violation of the Federal anti-trust statutes and not in the interests of independence and freedom of the press, in a brief filed in the United States District Court today by Millard E. Tydings, former United States Senator from Maryland.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday that its striking employes had returned to work everywhere except in Oakland, Calif., where 300 members of the Commercial Telegraphers Union, A. F. L., held out against settlement terms accepted by all the other workers.

THE long succession of war memoirs by generals and admirals seems almost over. But the flood of books by associates of Franklin D. Roosevelt shows no signs of reaching its end. The newest and one of the longest is published today, "Working With Roosevelt"* by Samuel I. Rosenman. Of all the men who worked with Roosevelt probably only two did so on a more intimate basis than Judge Rosenman, and they are dead.

Judge Harold R. Medina said yesterday that there was "no assurance" that he would require defendants in the anti-trust investment banking suit to present a defense after the Government rests its case.

BARCELONA, Spain, May 26 -- On his arrival here tonight Cardinal Spellman expressed the hope that the United States oil strike would not prevent hundreds of American pilgrims from participating in the thirty-fifth international eucharistic congress opening tomorrow.

If a perspective is to be maintained some of the French attitudes toward defense commitments in Europe should be viewed in the light of French commitments in East Asia. If the French are now able to reach a satisfactory working basis in the West this fact may reflect, in part, a gradually improving situation in the East.

It is a "shocking thing to discover how little of the earth's surface is served by a free press." Harry Martin, president of the American Newspaper Guild and a vice president of the new International Federation of Journalists, declared yesterday.

LONDON, May 26 -- British government securities and some foreign bonds finished almost unchanged today after a short-lived rally boosted prices sharply during the morning. Other sections of the stock market were generally quiet.

Once in a while 200 or 150 or 100 years roll around for some anniversary of note and the nation sits up and takes notice -- in varying degrees, to be sure. Collectors of stamps and people in promotion work probably view the incidence of these occasions differently from other folk.

As the Office of Price Stabilization here prepared new criminal actions against retailers for defying ceiling prices for potatoes, the City Department of Markets urged housewives to curtail their buying and serving of the scarce potato to help whip the black market.

MOSCOW, May 26 -- Pravda warned the Western powers again today that the German people would seek "their own paths" toward the unification of their country unless the Big Four immediately undertook the task of resolving the German question.

Colonial Airlines is on the auction block. Because opposition stockholders narrowly defeated a proposal to sell to National Airlines and also a proposal by Eastern Air Lines to buy Colonial, Branch T. Dykes, Colonial's president, announced to stockholders yesterday that he had written to all lines that make contact with Colonial's system soliciting sealed bids for the property.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Capital Transit Company of Washington had a constitutional right to install radio broadcasting in its street cars and buses.

United Artists will release forty-two feature films, of which sixteen are in Color, between July 1 and the end of 1953, it was announced yesterday by Arthur B. Krim, president of the distributing company. Of the forty-two productions, which cost $30,000,000, seven have been completed, twenty-six will go into production before the end of the year and the remaining nine will go before the cameras early next year, he said.
PARIS, May 26 (AP) -- French Government bonds went on sale just like postage stamps today as Premier Antoine Pinay's 700,000,000,000 franc $2,000,000,000 loan was launched.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 26 -- Pro-Truman delegations from twenty-seven counties were frozen out of the Texas Democratic Convention tonight, insuring a pro-Truman bolt from the state convention tomorrow and two Texas delegations at the Democratic National Convention.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Pending the arrival of the Canadian note on the assignment of Canadian troops to Koje, the State Department withheld comment on the statement by Mr. Pearson in the House of Commons at Ottawa this afternoon.
CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) -- John D. Small, chairman of the Munitions Board, told Congress today that United States plane production, particularly jets, still was lagging "far behind" Russian output although the program was "pretty well off the ground."

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- There is much more than election year politics to the drive in Congress to cut the national defense-foreign aid budget below a mark that enlightened and nonpartisan experts hold to be the peril point. The extra intensity of politics in a Presidential election year is a powerful force.

THOSE who want some early Atlantic salmon fishing but find the Canadian rivers too distant and perhaps too expensive, can spend a few days on the Narraguagus and the Dennys in Eastern Maine, for bright fish are now moving up both these rivers.
WASHINGTON, May 26 UP) -- The House Judiciary Committee today tabled, in effect killing, a bill to abolish the Port of New York Authority.
PATERSON, N. J., May 26 -- A Criminal District Court judge here today ordered a man to pay 5 cents a week toward the support of his indigent mother.

BAY SHORE, L. L, May 26 -- The United States Olympic trials for Star Class yachts started on Great South Bay today. After a day's postponement, the weather wasn't much better for sailing, but at least the skippers had a calmer sea. The wind, while not as strong, still was a bit on the fluky side.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 26 -- Hiland G. Batcheller, chairman of Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation Pittsburgh, warned today that continued decay of the moral climate in America will lead to the decline of the country's material property.
Deposits in the nation's 529 Mutual Savings banks increased $117,000,000 in April to reach a record high of $21,435,000,000.

Lockheed engineers have worked their slide rules and come forth with the assertion they have found "the most valuable eighty inches in the world." It is the eighty inches they have added to the length of the cabin in their new Super-Constellations. It makes possible installation of eight more standard or ten more tourist seats.

A threat of a port-wide strike by members of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., was sent late yesterday to Joseph P. Ryan, union president, by union officers protesting against allegedly "high-handed methods" used by State Crime Commission investigators on two Brooklyn piers earlier in the day.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 26 -- Vittorio Gassman, a film star in Italy before coming here a few months ago, has been assigned to a second picture under his new contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer even before he has completed his initial assignment for the studio in "Sombrero," which won't go into production until next month.

TRENTON, May 26 -- Convictions of four men for conspiracy to extort $25,000 from three New York milk concerns were sustained today by the New Jersey Supreme Court. Two of the convicted men are former Newark officials.

The Columbia Pictorial History of New York, which Columbia University plans to have ready for publication in October, 1953, will be a welcome introduction to the university's 1954 bicentennial celebration. Prof. John A. Kouwenhoven will prepare the volume, to contain 500 to 600 pages and more than 1,000 illustrations.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 27 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,262, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (5 P. M. Monday, Eastern daylight time):

The recent rash of firecrackers around town, particularly in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, can be laid at the door of an unwarranted and unwanted court decision permitting not only the manufacture but the sale of firecrackers in candy stores, and taking their control out of the hands of the Police Department.

A giant milling machine, stopped at the last minute from shipment to Russian-occupied Poland, has been put to work making wings for F-84 Thunderjet fighter planes at the new plant of Servel, Inc., at Evansville, Ind.

A new year-round trailership service between Albany and New York was formally opened here yesterday with ceremonies at West Twenty-ninth Street. The run will be handled by two converted L. S. T.'s (Landing Ship, Tanks), each capable of carrying fifty thirty-two-foot truck trailers.
Austrian Chancellor Leopold Figl described his country last night as "a passionate supporter of the idea of a United Europe, which in turn will lead to permanent world peace."

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- A proposed amendment to the Constitution to deny specifically to the President any power to seize private property except under processes proscribed by law was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada and chairman of the Judiciary Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett of Israel indicated here today that he would "help smooth over the difficulties" that had developed between the campaigns in behalf of the United Jewish Appeal and the $500,000,000 State of Israel bond issue in this country.
Arthur King of Toronto last night won a unanimous ten-round decision over Paddy De Marco, the No. 1 lightweight contender, in Brooklyn's Eastern Parkway arena.

The Good Government Award for 1951-52 of the Young Men's Board of Trade of New York was presented yesterday to Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley. He was cited in general for outstanding accomplishment in easing traffic congestion and in particular for "initiative and contribution, beyond ordinary responsibilities to improve municipal government."
Milwaukee announced yesterday that it will take bids on June 10 on issues of bonds totaling $6,000,000. Dated July 1, 1952, the bonds will come due July 1, 1953 to 1962.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 26 -- The National Iranian Oil Company, which took over the British plant in Iran, has concluded a contract for the sale of 3,000,000 tons of oil yearly for five years with a United States concern, officials announced today.

The prosecution rested its case yesterday against former District Attorney Herman Methfessel of Staten Island and Irving Rivkin, his former assistant, who have been on trial in Brooklyn Supreme Court on charges of abuse of official power and unprofessional conduct.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 26 -- C. Francis Cocke, president of the American Bankers Association, urged bankers today to avoid having too large a percentage of their loans guaranteed by Federal agencies if they would continue to be bankers and not "Government clerks."

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- An employer's insistence on a "management functions clause" that reserved to management sole control over certain conditions of employment was not a refusal to bargain, the Supreme Court ruled today in a 6-to-3 decision.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 26 -- Staving off a rush by Sampson Hanover in the closing strides, Thomas B. Scott, T. B. Carlock's 6-year-old pacer, captured the $5,700 Inaugural, the feature on the opening card of Roosevelt Raceway's thirteenth season of night harness racing.
Twenty per cent of all drivers cause 80 per cent of all auto accidents. There is therefore a growing demand for some form of rate reduction for the safe drivers.

THE Congressional subcommittee investigating baseball acted wisely in deciding to do not a thing about organized ball or its reserve clause. This was at least a left-handed tribute to the game and a remarkable demonstration of Congressional restraint. It's truly wonderful in this day and age when anyone, particularly a legislator, decides to mind his own business.

MONTREAL, May 26 -- The United Textile Workers of America, A. F. L., carried through today its program to rid its Canadian division of alleged Communist-line leadership. It suspended the division's entire staff of twelve.

BONN, Germany, May 26 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France and the Chancellor of West Germany signed today the treaties restoring West Germany to equal partnership in the community of free Europe.

AURORA, N. Y., May 26 -- Mrs. Ralph Bunche tonight delivered the speech prepared by her husband for delivery at the eighty-fourth commencement exercise at Wells College here. The Director of Trusteeship for the United Nations is confined to his home in Jamaica, Queens, with a spinal ailment.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Truman asserted today that he might investigate to see whether the Corrupt Practices Act could be invoked against private power companies that, he said, were spending millions of dollars in a "vicious" propaganda campaign against public power.
JOHANNESBURGH, South Africa, May 26 -- The police and garment workers clashed again today as 150 demonstrators gathered outside the Johannesburg police headquarters.

BONN, Germany, May 26 -- The Allied High Commission for Germany announced today plans for "immediate" derequisitioning of Petersberg, mountain-top hotel overlooking the Rhine River near Bonn, which has served as headquarters for the last two and a half years.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 26 -- James G. Smyth, who was ousted as Collector of Internal Revenue here last year, was indicted by a Federal grand jury late today for the third time. The charges in this seven-count true bill were essentially the same as those in one returned on April 15, that he had defrauded the Government of penalties on his own income tax.

An employe's confidence in the free enterprise system will be as good as his experience with the individual employer, Dennis V. Ward, overseas employe relations advisor of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, said yesterday. He held that it was not an employer's responsibility to attempt to influence directly the political or social beliefs of his workers.

KOJE, Korea, May 26 -- Brig. Gen. Haydon L. Boatner, commandant of the prisoner of war compounds here authorized United Nations soldiers today to beat unruly Communist prisoners, but only when absolutely necessary. At the same time he told troops that there must be no killing of prisoners.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- Two seamen were dead and eight missing today in the third tanker collision within eleven days in the approaches to this port. The crashes were in the Delaware River and the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal.
BOSTON, May 26 -- The Yankees slipped quietly out of town tonight still seeking their first victory over the Red Sox at Fenway Park after dropping a two-game series and their fourth in a row here.

SURBITON, England, May 26 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly, 17-year-old American tennis champion, breezed through her first match on English grass courts today. She defeated Jean Petchell, 19-year-old Nottingham salesgirl, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1, in the first round of the Surrey championships.

BERLIN, Tuesday, May 27 -- Reacting a few hours after yesterday's signature of the contractual agreement between the Allies and West Germany and the issuance of a Western declaration on Berlin, the East German Government ordered "strict measures" to close the East-West German border to "subversives."

Piped steam, the lifestream of New York's billion-dollar garment industry, has flooded the State Supreme Court with a controversy in which Justice Kenneth O'Brien made two findings yesterday, which were diametrically opposite to a decision earlier this month by Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber in a similar case.

STRASBOURG, France, May 26 -- Francois de Menthon of France, a leading European federalist, today was elected President of the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe, succeeding Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium who resigned to take a more active part in pressing for political union among the European countries of the West.
The police came by land, sea and air to help rescue two youngsters who seemed to be floundering on a raft in the Hudson River off Seventy-second Street yesterday afternoon.
The Police Department heaved a sigh of relief last night.

Joseph Yursi has sold the altered house at 110 Lafayette Street, Brooklyn, to Mr. and Mrs. Morris Deutch in a transaction negotiated by Paul A. Bogossian Son as brokers. Formerly occupied as a one-family dwelling, the building was remodeled about a year ago into eight suites of two and one-half rooms each.

A nationwide investment banking syndicate headed by Stone Webster Securities Corporation and White, Weld Co. will offer to investors today $17,375,000 of new preferred and common stock of Tennessee Gas Transmission Company. The preferred shares, which have a par value of $100 and a cumulative dividend of 5.25 per cent, are priced at $100 per share.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 26 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council adopted today by eleven votes to none, with six abstentions, a draft convention on the political rights of women. It will be submitted to the General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $1,300,000,000 of 91- day Treasury bills to be dated May 29 and to mature Aug. 28 were opened to the Federal Reserve Banks today.

JACKSON, Miss., May 26 (UP) -- The Mississippi Supreme Court ruled today that a "lily white" faction of the State Republican party which supported General of the Army Dwight Eisenhower is the official G. O. P. representative in Mississippi.
Prices stiffened yesterday on the stock market but the force behind the rally proved insufficient to change materially the basic structure.

History was written in large letters in Bonn yesterday when the Western Powers signed a "peace contract" with the Federal Republic of Germany which not only restores the former enemy country to nearly full sovereignty but also makes it a new and equal partner in the fight for peace and freedom.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- A former major in the Women's Army Corps carried to a Senate Armed Services subcommittee today her protest against being discharged from the reserves because she had a baby.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 27 (AP) -- Behind a wall of secrecy as impenetrable as those guarding Princeton's atomic research projects, the Princeton University athletic department has set an "electronic brain" to work on football.

The home laundress who struggles with washing grimy clothes may take some comfort in the fact that her problems, considerably magnified, bedevil 800 persons, most of them men, who attended the annual convention here last week of the Linen Supply Association of America.

BOSTON, May 26 -- Isoniazid, the latest drug used in the fight against tuberculosis, does not appear to be superior to previous treatments and may be inferior, it was reported tonight at the forty-eighth annual meeting of the National Tuberculosis Association.

JERSEY CITY, May 26 -- Purcell's dramatic opera, "King Arthur," which was first performed in 1691, was presented here tonight by the Jersey City Choral Society, conducted by Judson Rand, at the New Jersey State Teachers College.

Bill Bangert, a husky 6-foot 5-inch young man from Missouri who has made a name for himself putting the shot, is in New York to try out for the United States Olympic team. Last night he showed what he could do in a field other than athletics -- he gave a recital at Town Hall.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 26 -- A bouquet of carnations that ticked like a time bomb forced the cancellation of the Brussels premiere of the Communist-inspired, anti-United States play, "Colonel Foster Will Plead Guilty."

LOS ANGELES, May 26 -- Mr. Harriman, making his first visit to California as a Presidential candidate, basked today in the warmth of a cordial welcome from the same group of old guard Truman Democrats who last week turned a cold shoulder on his rival, Senator Estes Kefauver.

Primarily, I should like to commend you on your excellent, impartial coverage of the transfer of Dr. Harold Lenz from his position as dean of students at Queens College. As a member of the student body at Queens I should also like to express my views on the subject.
Broadway's busiest and, perhaps, fastest writer these days easily could be John van Druten.

The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York was attacked last night as an insidious forerunner of socialized medicine in the address by the retiring president of the New York County Medical Society, Dr. Arthur M. Master. He was succeeded by Dr. Gervais W. McAuliffe, president-elect of the society, who was elected a year ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 26 -- Chancellor Figl spent an hour this morning inspecting the headquarters and facilities of the United Nations as a guest of Secretary General Trygve Lie. He expressed regret that his homeland was not yet represented in what he called "the center of the world."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 26 (AP) -- Police Chief Patrick Ready asked to explain reports that the police had interfered with newspaper coverage of the May 15 clash with Harvard students, said he was satisfied that his men believed conditions "called for police activity."

On sales of $306,698,324 Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., had a net profit of $12,627,140 after taxes land all charges in its fiscal year ended with March, the annual report of Alfred E. Lyon, board chairman, and O. Parker McComas, president, showed yesterday.

Twenty high school teachers from eight states, including six from New York and New Jersey, have received one-year fellowships from the John Hay Whitney foundation, it was announced yesterday. The program is designed to improve high school teaching in the humanities.

Twelve hundred information specialists from the United States, Canada and many foreign countries, members of the Special Libraries Association, opened their forty-third annual convention here yesterday.

Two apartment houses at 212 and 214 West 133d Street, containing twenty-two suites, have been purchased by Seymour M. Tannenbaum, operator, from the Mowil Realty Corporation. Baer Gallin were attorneys for the seller.

Alarm over the danger that a "vigilante state" might be developing in this country was expressed yesterday by a panel of ten educators, business leaders and labor consultants participating in the American Round Table.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 26 -- In the face of repeated Communist threats of violence the French Government will hays on hand tomorrow more than 4,000 uniformed -- and an undisclosed number of plainclothes police -- to protect Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, who is due to arrive at Orly Airport.

ALBANY, May 26 -- The State Thruway Authority today invited manufacturers of toll registration and tabulation equipment to submit proposals for a collection system on the Cross-State Express Way to the state agency on or before July 25.

Garden furniture and ornaments of the traditional kind, fancifully scrolled in iron or sculptured in stone, still remain in high favor with many country' householders and city folk with terrace or backyard.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., May 26 -- Most of the sixty-five teams had completed play in the Long Island Professional Golfers Association one-day tournament when Nathan Zausmer and Pete Burke of Cold Springs came in with a net 63, seven under par, to tie for first place at the Huntington Crescent Club today.

The English-Speaking Union of the United States conferred annual awards on eight journalists and broadcasters yesterday for promoting better understanding in 1951 between the United States and the Commonwealth nations. Three special awards also were made.

Judge Harold Medina, who presided over the trial here of the eleven top Communists, is the subject of a biography by Hawthorne Daniel. The book, which traces the jurist's life from childhood through the trial, is based on information obtained from the judge and Mrs. Medina and from private files.
Five thousand owner-drivers of taxicabs asked public support yesterday for the measure designed to increase cab fares 27 per cent, which is scheduled for action by the City Council this afternoon.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., May 26 -- Missouri Democrats named President Truman as a delegate at large with one-half vote to the party's Presidential convention today and selected an old-time Kansas City friend as his alternate.
One person favored and no one opposed the proposed demolition of the Third Avenue elevated line between the City Hall station and Chatham Square at a Board of Transportation hearing yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, May 26 -- Armed police patroled the streets of India's capitol tonight and public meetings or parades were banned for fifteen days following riots in protest against a proposed mixed-religion marriage.

A union charge that the Welfare Department was being operated inefficiently with overworked and underpaid investigators unable to handle cases properly was denied yesterday by Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy as a "cheap and scurrilous attack."

PARIS, May 26 -- Benjamin Britten's opera, "Billy Budd," with libretto by E. M. Forster and Eric Crozier after the story by Herman Melville, was performed tonight for the first time in France by the Covent Garden Opera Company and Orchestra in the Champs-Elysees Theatre, the composer conducting.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 26 (AP) -- Chet Miller, 49-year-old dean of Indianapolis Motor Speedway racers, cracked the ten-mile record for the track today in final time trials for the 500-mile Memorial Day race.
In connection with your editorial of April 25 and later correspondence concerning it, here are the documents as to fact.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 26 -- Control of the state-owned railway system of Vietnam was formally transferred today from French hands to the Vietnamese Government. Involved in the transfer was about 1,500 miles of railroad about half of which either has been destroyed or is in the hands of the Communist-led Vietminh regime.

The former director of the Columbia University department of public information, Robert Harron, will return to the university soon after July 1 as director of public relations a newly created administrative position.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Supreme Court today unanimously decided that motion pictures were entitled to the constitutional guarantees of free speech and a free press. In doing so, the court reversed the New York State Court of Appeals, which had banned the showing of the controversial picture, "The Miracle," on the ground that it was "sacrilegious."
A show-cause order was obtained yesterday in Supreme Court in an effort to enjoin the city from collecting its 25 per cent levy on liquor licenses.

Consumer acceptance of self- service and the super market is a "clear signal" for department store merchants to re-evaluate their ideas of actual consumer requirements if they wish to continue business at a reasonable profit, the president of one of the world's largest retailing organizations declared yesterday.
GENEVA, May 25 -- In the modern welfare state, Western European version, the breadwinner no longer has to bear the main financial burden of housing the family.

LOS ANGELES, May 26 -- Richard Rober, stage and screen actor, died early today at Santa Monica Hospital of injuries received when his convertible automobile plunged over a seventy-five-foot embankment. His age was 46.

A dense blanket of fog that rolled into the harbor shortly after 6 P. M. Sunday and settled over local waters and airports until mid- afternoon yesterday delayed by as much as twenty-four hours the docking of a score of inbound ships and caused airports to suspend operations for several hours.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 27 -- The Communist delegation at Panmunjom discussing an armistice in Korea made a scarcely veiled threat today of renewed military action in the now almost static war unless United Nations yielded to demands for repatriation of all prisoners by force if necessary.

PARIS, May 26 -- France will ask for assurances of United States material and diplomatic support in Indo-China and North Africa in addition to the military guarantees already agreed on after the signing of the European Defense Community Treaty in Paris tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Interstate Commission Commission approved today the merger of the Central Barge Company into the Mississippi Valley Barge Line Line Company.

A rally with stage artists and musicians of the First Army Band participating opened a four-day blood drive yesterday for employes of the Arma Corporation at 254 Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn. The company hopes to break its own national record for industry donations of 1,004 pints set last fall.

The American Federation of Labor has decided to notify one of its biggest affiliates, the International Association of Machinists, that it faces possible expulsion unless it stops asking the National Labor Relations Board to rule on jurisdictional disputes between the machinists and other A. F. L. unions.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 26 -- Republicans set two records at Ohio's May 6 primary elections, according to the official count announced today by Ted W. Brown, Secretary of State.

There probably will be two new departmental trials of policemen charged with taking bookmaking graft from Harry Gross. This likelihood resulted yesterday from the inability of principals in the case to set an actual starting date for the trial of fourteen plainclothes men, which was originally to have started during the morning.

Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock ruled yesterday that the prosecution in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders had not established a prima-facie case of conspiracy against the defendants prior to 1945.

HARTFORD, May 26 -- In a move to restore party harmony on the eve of tomorrow's Republican State Convention, William H. Brennan of Stamford said today that he would not consent to a fight being carried to the floor for rentention of his post as National Committeeman.
Sales and earnings of Claude Neon, Inc., last year were the highest in its history, and current orders are in excess of $45,000,000, the annual report told stockholders yesterday.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, May 26 -- Political interest in Egypt is centered on the arrival tomorrow of a Sudanese delegation for talks that may settle the question of Cairo's desire for a common Egyptian-Sudanese crown linking the two countries.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 26 -- General Ridgway said today that the armed forces defending South Korea had developed on the battlefield, "in a manner unparalleled in history, a mutual respect, a mutual understanding and a mutual confidence which indeed bid well for the future of the United Nations and of the free world."
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Following are excerpts from the concurring opinion of Justice Felix Frankfurter, seconded by Justices Robert H. Jackson and Harold H. Burton:
CHICAGO, May 26 (UP) -- Assisted by brilliant support in the field, Bob Rush pitched his second straight shut-out in the Cub's 3-0 victory over the Cardinals before 7,128 today.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today upheld the right of the Government to bar price discrimination by manufacturers.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today approved a merger of Braniff Airways, Inc., and Mid-Continent Airlines, Inc.
BONN, Germany, May 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of an official summary of the West German peace contract signed with the United States, Britain and France:

INDIANAPOLIS, May 26 (UP) -- Frank M. McHale resigned today as chairman of the Credentials Committee of the Democratic National Convention after his own Indiana party organization had removed him as a member of the National Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Senate managers of the Mutual Security authorization bill began an uphill fight today to prevent further heavy slashes in the $6,900,000,000 fund recommended by the Foreign Relations Committee.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) -- Defense Production Administrator Manly Fleischmann said today that the United States should build up its aluminum stockpile "without delay."

En route from Piqua, now grown to 17,447, Kankakee with its 25,856 souls, to Dobbs Ferry (pop. 6,268), Miss Rebecca B. Rankin has stopped off in New York City (8,000,000) for thirty-four years. What started out as a vacation visit became a career as head of the New York Public Library's municipal reference branch, guardian of the city's archives, expert on New York City, and the answer-woman to the world's questions about the city.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Truman declared tonight that the recent action of the House of Representatives in cutting the defense program by more than $5,000,000,000 "may require us to demobilize a substantial part of our armed forces."
GENEVA, May 26 -- It was confirmed here today that Adrian pelt of the Netherlands is to succeed Vladimir Moderow of Poland as director of the European Office of the United Nations.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois today said he would make "no comment" on reports that he would endorse for the Democratic Presidential nomination at a dinner here Wednesday night, W. Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- A new "giant" roams the field of American philanthropy -- the corporation. Corporations gave $239,000,000 in 1948 and an equal amount in 1950 and are giving even more this year, F. Emerson Andrews, one of the nation's leading research authorities in the welfare field, reported today.
A move to revise the Lord's Prayer in the interest of "accuracy" and better understanding was set in motion yesterday by the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A.

Business must continue to expose the practices of those who provide "ammunition" for the enemies of our way of life, according to Victor H. Nyborg, president of the Association of Better Business Bureaus, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) -- The House Rules Committee cleared the way today for house debate on a new G. I. Bill of Rights for veterans of Korea but banned any possible move to reinstate the so-called "52-20 Club."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 26 -- Hollywood reacted with joy and surprise today to the decision of the Supreme Court in the case of "The Miracle."

OTTAWA, May 26 -- The Canadian Government has sent a note to Washington asking that, in the future, Canadian forces abroad should remain under Canadian command and control, and that the brigade in Korea should not be broken up for miscellaneous duties.

The American Federation of Labor has usually met charges of racketeering within its affiliates with the argument that the ninety-two chartered national and international unions have autonomous fights which may not be invaded by the parent organization. The Federation's Executive Council, which governs between conventions, has now decided to name a special committee to force a clean-up of racketeering elements inside some affiliated unions.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) -- Federal Judge Walter Bastian rejected today Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's request for a tape recording of preliminary hearings on his $2,000,000 libel-slander suit against Senator William Benton of Connecticut.

MINERAL WELLS, Tex., May 26 -- The Texas Republican State Executive Committee, dominated by "Old Guard" supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, unseated today enough delegates favorable to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to give Taft forces a dominating majority in the state convention that will name thirty-eight delegates tomorrow to the Chicago nominating convention.

ZURICH, May 26 -- From the advance of Interhandel common stock in Zurich since April 1 the conclusion is inescapable that Swiss investors are now more confident than ever that the fight to obtain release by the United States Alien Property Custodian of the General Aniline and Film Corporation will ultimately end in favor of Interhandel stockholders.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Eisenhower homecoming is beginning to take on some of the aspects of a Cecil B. DeMille mob scene. The general will be here Sunday, and by the time he star his pilgrimage to Abilene on the following Tuesday, he is likely to be involved in something entirely new in the history of pre-convention Presidential campaigns.

Bobby Thomson and Whitey Lockman, Giant stalwarts who room together on the road, teamed up last night to give Leo Durocher's champions a nerve-tingling 4-to-2 triumph over the Dodgers at the Polo Grounds.
The Columbia Lippincott Gazetteer of the World describes Flatbush, which was officially founded 300 years ago today, in rather restrained terms:

HOLLYWOOD, May 26 -- The American Legion, which has precipitated a large-scale loyalty investigation within the major motion picture studios by presenting to them a list of more than 200 names of Hollywood persons suspected of Communist activities, has not yet completed its own evaluation of the evidence against these persons.

LONDON, May 26 -- The Boston Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Charles Munch, made its first and only appearance in Britain tonight with a concert of French and American works at Royal Festival Hall here. The audience gave a great ovation to the orchestra, especially for Honegger's Fifth Symphony.
LONDON, May 26 -- Dowager Queen Mother Mary spent her eighty-fifth birthday quietly at home today receiving calls from the immediate members of her family.
Parents of 6-to-12-year-olds might be interested in calling their attention to the following book, published recently:

ROME, Tuesday, May 27 -- The alliance of the center parties headed by the Christian Democrats won the election in Rome and thus made certain that the city of the Popes would continue to be administered by parties friendly to the Vatican.
The pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Cross me some of the neighbors at lunch yesterday to tell them about parish needs for money to refurbish the church.

Trading in lead futures was resumed yesterday on the Commodity Exchange after a ten-month suspension. Prices were 5 to 6 cents a pound below those of July 27, 1951, when all outstanding contracts were settled at 19.2 cents.
PARIS, May 26 -- Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables added another notable conquest to his many for 1952 today in the French tennis championship.

TRIESTE, May 26 -- The Italian coalition led by Premier Alcide De Gasperi's Christian Democrats retained political control of the city of Trieste in yesterday's municipal elections in Zone A of the Free Territory despite heavy losses to Independents and neo-Fascists.

As Mayor Impellitteri declined comment yesterday on reports that discontinuance of the combination 15-cent subway-bus fare was under consideration, Controller Lazarus Joseph called into his office the three bidders for the five city-owned Manhattan bus lines and asked them to "improve" their offers.

TORONTO, May 26 -- The Metropolitan Opera tonight paid its first visit to Toronto since 1901, and if you want an idea of how long ago that was operatically speaking, Enrico Caruso had not yet joined the company. Brought here by the city's ambitious Rotary Club, the Metropolitan made friends for itself, the art it represents and the city and nation whence it comes.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were quiet yesterday with the closing 17 to 21 points net higher than on Friday.
ST. LOUIS, May 26 (UP) -- Billy Pierce gained two victories tonight as the White Sox whipped the, Browns, 6 -- 2, after winning a game suspended since April 20, 10 -- 5.

DEVON, Pa., May 26 -- Entries from Mrs. Josephin A. DeSegura's Pin Oak Stables at Bellaire, Tex., gained three successive blue ribbons tonight at the fifty-sixth annual Devon horse show and country fair.

Both ordinary Americans and those of our fellow-citizens who are in high policy-making positions will do well to ponder the conclusions which follow from the scholarly papers presented at the Conference on Soviet Economic Growth at Arden House tiffs past week-end.

Meetings are already being held in the clubhouse of the New York Junior League, 130 East Eightieth Street, to formulate plans for the second annual Mardi Gras in behalf of the organization's welfare fund, which will take place next Feb. 17 in the main ballroom of the Astor.

PITTSBURGH, May 26 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner belted his fourth home run of the season and his second in two days in the first inning with two aboard tonight to help the Pirates to a 6-to-3 victory over the Reds.

Last week we gave our ideas on substitutes for potatoes. Today several restaurants and hotels volunteer details on what they are doing to meet the scarcity situation. Because the shortage of spuds is likely to continue for at least three weeks, the alternatives they suggest may be of considerable help to home cooks.
LONDON, May 26 (AP) -- The Church of England called today for a tightening of British divorce laws.
The metropolitan retail market, which includes New York City and adjacent counties, not only is the largest in the nation, but is first by a wider margin than has been realized.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 26 -- The inhabitants of Israel's Village of the Blind, near Gedera, are shown off so often that they have become indifferent to visitors. But today, in words of Dr. Nissim Hagel, blind director of the village, they welcomed Helen Keller "not as a guest but as a sister."

Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway called on General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, his predecessor as United Nations commander in Korea, yesterday and discussed the Far Eastern situation before he left from La Guardia Airport for Paris to assume supreme command of North Atlantic Treaty Organization's military forces.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Following is the Supreme Court opinion deciding the case of "The Miracle":

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Sid Hudson held the Athletics to nine hits and batted across two runs today as the Senators defeated Philadelphia, 5 -- 3, on a thirteen-hit barrage against Sam Zoldak and Johnny Kucab.
As the present New York police trials continue there will arise a clamor from some quarters again this year, as there did last summer, to petition the recall of Ambassador O'Dwyer from Mexico.

While two women were busy playing cards on one floor of a Brooklyn duplex apartment on Sunday evening, burglars were busy on the other floor removing $16,500 worth of jewelry and furs. The women said that they did not hear the burglars because the television set was making too much noise.

Getting away fast, Mrs. B. F. Whitaker's Hitex streaked to a half-length triumph at Belmont Park yesterday. Eddie Arcaro figured the 3-year-old could stay in front of the others all through the six-furlong test for 3-year-olds and Eddie figured correctly as he led the eight others home in the excellent time of 1:10 over the sloppy track.

MIAMI, May 26 -- Florida's twenty-four-vote delegation to the Democratic National Convention will be chosen tomorrow in a primary election in which Senators Richard B. Russell of Georgia and Estes Kefauver of Tennessee are vying for support of their candidacies for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The four - story apartment house accommodating twenty families at 30-69 Thirty-fourth Street, Astoria. Queens, has been purchased by Andrew Koi from David Neuwirth. Sale was subject to a first mortgage of $36,000.

Dinah Shore and the National Broadcasting Company are in the process of negotiating a long-term contract that would grant her exclusive television services to the network. It was reported yesterday that all terms of the proposed contract have been agreed upon except one, which is of prime importance to the outcome of the negotiations.

Several hundred of the 12,000 tenants in the Parkchester housing development in the Bronx have decided against paying a recent increase of 6 per cent, scheduled for voluntary imposition on Oct. 1 by their landlord, Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

Fabric has contributed much of the interest to the 1952 crop of beach fashions. Such newcomers to this field as organdy, cotton velveteen and pinwale corduroy are all brining their bit of news to the scene. Even candlewick in a refined version of that old favorite formerly associated only with bedspreads is now being widely used.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 26 (AP) -- The furniture business is looking up again, an industry spokesman said today. For the first time this year -- in the month of April -- orders booked showed an increase over the same month a year ago.

ROME, May 26 -- The Sacred Congregation of the Holy Office, by a decree dated May 20 and published today, placed on the Vatican's index of forbidden books all the works of Alberto Pincherle, better known by his pen name as Alberto Moravia.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, May 27 (AP) -- Allied fighter-bombers, unmolested by Communist jets, struck yesterday at the enemy's main railroad supply line in northwest Korea.

Dick Shea, Army miler, is not a candidate for an Olympic berth, Coach Carl Crowell of West Point said yesterday during the track writers' luncheon at Leone's. Shea, however, will participate in the I. C. 4-A track and field games at Randalls Island Friday and Saturday.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Weather developments over the week-end were favorable, with better conditions for harvesting in the Southwest and with local showers in the Northwest partially alleviating dry spring wheat conditions. As a result there was moderate selling pressure.

Gas appliance manufacturers are giving oil burner producers and other competitors increasingly formidable competition in the battle for the home heating market, the American Gas Association reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's extemporaneous remarks to the Electric Consumers Conference here today:

The Senate committee which is considering the Puerto Rican Constitution should before this have reported it out favorably, as the House committee did. This is the sort of opposition or obstruction to efforts at democracy in Latin America which so puzzles and disturbs our neighbors to the south.

Operations of the New York Central Railroad Company and all leased lines in the first four months of 1952 resulted in a net income of $239,635, according to the report released yesterday. This compares with a net loss of $7,789,727 for the four months ended April 30, 1951.

" No one could stand it unless you were their mother," some harrowed theatregoer exclaimed during the interval at "The Rehearsal," which opened at the President last evening. Although she was ungrammatical, she was speaking under duress.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 26 -- Members of Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., voted tonight to strike to enforce wage demands on shipowners. Harry Lundeberg, secretary-treasurer of the union, announced that picket lines would be set up in major West Coast ports immediately.

BOSTON, May 27 (UP) -- Rookie Harry Byrd won his first major league victory tonight as the Athletics broke up a tight game with three runs in the ninth inning to beat the Red Sox, 7 to 3, before 13,839 Fenway Park fans.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 -- Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Ford Foundation, received the "business statesman of the year" award today from the National Sales Executives in convention here.

PITTSBURGH, May 27 (AP) -- Walkouts and furloughs resulting from Westinghouse Electric Corporation's defense against "wildcat strikes" made more than 19,000 production workers idle in three plants today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 27 (UP) -- A divided Alabama delegation to the Democratic National Convention refused today to pledge its twenty-two votes to either Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia or Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee for the Presidential nomination.

Directors of the Parker Pen Company yesterday elected Bruce M. Jeffris as president to succeed Kenneth Parker, who becomes chairman of the board. Mr. Jeffris is the third person to hold the presidency in the company's history.
A full week of receptions and exercises for 230 Barnard College seniors will precede the conferring of Bachelor of Arts degrees on June 5.

A new novel by Manes Sperber, author of "The Burned Bramble" will be published tomorrow by Doubleday. Translated from the German by Constantine Fitzgibbon, "The Abyss" is the second book in a projected trilogy about the failure of communism in Western Europe.

Rent increases ranging up to 15 per cent, which were granted in the last year to more than 100 hotels by State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick, have been questioned under a decision by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer. His findings became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Senate rejected by a vote of 35 to 27 today an attempt to slash a second $1,000,000,000 from the Mutual Security program. But the same group of adherents to Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio and Presidential aspirant, who sponsored the proposal were preparing a second assault tomorrow that would cut the authorization by $500,000,000.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission has stepped up its schedule for producing atomic weapons and has added the "things" tested at its Nevada proving ground to its arsenal. The information was given to the Senate Appropriations Committee in secret sessions on new funds for the atomic program.

Sable and chinchilla were recommended for "steady duty" at the fall and winter fur fashion show presented yesterday by Ritter Brothers at a luncheon in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel. It was noted that these furs were now grown in America and therefore not as expensive as in the past.

HARTFORD, May 27 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower closed the New England phase of his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination today With an apparent sweep of Connecticut's twenty-two delegates.

Liberal party leaders have temporarily omitted Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., a Democrat, from their slate of Congressional candidates in Manhattan as a deliberate gesture to signify publicly that a chill has settled over their relations with him since 1950.

The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. voiced a "vigorous protest" yesterday against the "persecution" of Protestant minorities in Colombia, South America, and called upon the Vatican and the Colombian Government to take "immediate" steps to remedy the situation.

A sample not only of the interiors he designs, but of the clothes he suggests for wear in them were displayed yesterday at the open house in James L. G. Mitton's new apartment, 118 East Thirty-sixth Street. Decorated in "modern Regence," style, the apartment, one floor of a brownstone house, will also serve as his office.

The annual moonlight cruise on the Hudson River for the benefit of the George Junior Republic will be held on June 27 aboard the S. S. Peter Stuyvesant. The event has been arranged, as in previous seasons, under the auspices of the Foreign Commerce Club of New York.

Thousands of the best examples of Italy's post-war arts, crafts and industries -- from a provolone cheese to an Alfa-Romeo sports automobile -- will go on view, and sale, to New Yorkers, at Grand Central Palace today.
The Oklahoma Turnpike Authority has designated next Monday for the sale of $7,000,000 of term revenue bonds dated Aug. 1, 1950, and due Aug. 1, 1990.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 27 -- The United Nations Human Rights Commission approved today measures aimed at legally protecting the "right to life" and safeguarding all persons from torture or the kind of criminal medical experimentation that had been practiced in Nazi concentration camps.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- Two Congress of Industrial Organizations members of the Wage Stabilization Board denied today what they called "insinuation" by Representative Richard B. Vail, Republican of Illinois, that they had consorted with Communists.

NEW ORLEANS, May 27 (UP) -- Federal District Judge Herbert Christenberry ruled today that The Times-Picayune Publishing Company, owners of The Times-Picayune and New Orleans States, had violated the Sherman Anti-trust Act, by enforcing combination-rate contracts with advertisers.
LONDON, May 27 -- The economic consequences of Western Germany's membership in the European Defense Community has been causing considerable concern to the British Treasury and Ministry of Defense.

Plans for the immediate construction by Macy's, San Francisco, of a suburban store to cost $6,000,000 in the new Hillsdale shopping center on the San Francisco peninsula were announced yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president of R. H Macy Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- The American Automobile Association reported today that Massachusetts, Philadelphia and Jackson, Miss., had won the top awards in the 1951 national pedestrian protection contest. They were judged to have done more than any other states or cities toward reducing the hazards of foot travel.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Wednesday, May 28 (AP) -- Gen. Mark W. Clark sent his Deputy Chief of Staff to Koje Island today to confer with the new commander of the stormy Allied prisoner of war camp and with spokesmen for the defiant Red prisoners who still control their own compounds.

BRIELLE, N. J., May 27 -- The dawn patrol, possibly to celebrate their release by weather, turned out in force this morning from Manasquan Inlet to Long Branch, but although the long squidding rods snapped plugs and jigs from scores of beaches, jetties and breakwaters, the bluefish and stripers were not too cooperative.

TORONTO, May 27 -- The rigid functioning of the United States Internal Security Act, known as the McCarran Act, has led the board of the Toronto Symphony Orchestra to dismiss six musicians, has stirred differences of opinion within the board on a matter of principle and has involved the Canadian Embassy in Washington in discussions with the State Department.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 27 -- The South African Trades and Labor Council, which has 88,000 members in sixty-seven affiliated unions, sent messages yesterday to world trade union organizations, including those in the United States, asking for aid in defending the South African trade unions.

Reports that the city may discontinue the "bargain" combination 15-cent transfer ride between subways and surface bus lines are encouraging only to the extent that they indicate a limited awakening to fiscal realities. But even a $15,000,000 reduction of a prospective $54,000,000 deficit in transit for the fiscal year beginning July 1 could hardly be acclaimed as a bold, courageous attack on the grave budget problems of the city.

ALTHOUGH James Grover Thurber has been identified with The New Yorker magazine and New York City for twenty-seven years, a large slice of his heart still belongs to Columbus, Ohio. This he has made plain in his new book, "The Thurber Album,"* an affectionate tribute to the friends of his youth and the dear, dead days beyond recall.

Being left out of a clique may destroy a child's idea of school and impair his future, a 12-year-old boy said yesterday during a New York Times Youth Forum discussion on "What Makes Children Get Along Together ?"
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Taft and Eisenhower forces really got down to brass knuckles today in their pre-convention maneuvers for the Republican Presidential nomination.
TRENTON, May 27 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll vetoed a controversial bingo referendum bill today.
LONDON, May 27 (AP) -- Silnet, French-owned and bred colt, held firm as the 15-to-2 favorite tonight to win the 173d running of the English Derby over the mile-and-a-half Epsom Downs track tomorrow.

William W. Wallace has been named general manager of the international division of Servel, Inc. The division handles export sales and distribution of household refrigerators, water heaters and air- conditioners, Mr. Wallace has been with the company since 1935.

Like lanes of foam in the wake of a ship, two large questions follow the signing of the interlocking treaties tying the German Federal Republic to the West. The first concerns the attitude of the signatory nations: Will they support the Governments that have concluded the agreements?

CHICAGO, May 27 -- Dr. R. C. Newton, vice president of Swit Co. in charge of research, voiced a warning today that public misunderstanding regarding chemicals in food must be corrected by the food industry itself.

Walter Hoving, president of Bonwit Teller, Inc., and a veteran fighter against the 3 per cent city sales tax, decided yesterday that it would be futile for him to appear personally in opposition to the proposed three-year extension of the tax.

The following is the way the Republican and Democratic line-ups for the Presidential nominating conventions stood last night for leading candidates, including Connecticut and Kentucky results, but omitting those in Florida and Texas: ...

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- An informal but continuing lobby to help fight public power's battle with private utilities was started today with White House blessing. Several labor, farm, electric, cooperative and public power organizations, closing a two-day conference, agreed to set up an Electric Consumers Conference Committee in Washington.

Don Mueller and Willie Mays gathered the Dodgers with homers and Sal (The Barber) Maglie gave them a fancy 3-0 brush-off last night before 28,089 fans at Ebbets Field. Maglie's ninth straight victory and his club's sixth in a row raised New York's lead in the National League race to a game and a half.

Net income of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company for the first four months of 1952 was $7,197,276, it was announced yesterday. This was 80 per cent more than the $4,003,854 cleared in the four months ended on April 30, 1951.

PARIS, May 27 -- Frank Sedgman and Kenneth McGregor of Australia turned in a pair of scintillating performances today that created a big stir at Roland Garros Stadium and advanced them to the semi-finals of French tennis championships.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 -American-flag, dry cargo shipping, except for essential military cargoes, headed toward a standstill in the West Coast today as deck stands of the American Federation Labor turned a temporary work stoppage into a membership-endorsed, full-fledged strike.

BERLIN, May 27 -- The Soviet Union and the East German Government began today to build two walls -- one around West Berlin and the other between East and West Germany. The East German Government decreed a prohibited zone three miles deep along its 600-mile border with West Germany. It also sliced Berlin's telephone system in two and cut most of the city's telephone lines to West Germany.

BONN, Germany, May 27 -- The East German People's Police occ upied the western part of the village of Offleben dead on the frontier last night as part of the nerve war now directed against West Germany and West Berlin under the guise of sealing off East Germany from infiltration by so-called capitalist "spies and saboteurs."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 27 -- Official governmental reports to the United Nations on the origin of opium seized in various parts of the world during 1951 were invoked today by the United States to refute a denial by the Chinese Communist Government of United States allegations that it officially sponsored both the production of opium and an expanding illicit traffic in that narcotic.

Doesn't it strike you as terribly wasteful to cover only 15 per cent of the land with buildings, leaving 85 per cent vacant, in the proposed state housing project at Ninth Avenue and Forty-sixth Street, Manhattan?

LONDON, May 27 -- The industrial and not the military exploitation of nuclear energy is the keynote of the British atomic effort, according to the first official report on the subject published today by the Government.

The Western Electric Company has announced the election as vice presidents, effective next Monday, of Reese F. Clifford of Montclair, N. J., and Arthur B. Goetze of Cleveland. Mr. Clifford succeeds David Levinger, who will retire this summer, and Mr. Goetze, who is operating vice president of the Ohio Bell Telephone Company, will be vice president and works manager at Kearny, N J., succeeding Mr. Clifford.

Herman W. Steinkraus, chairman and president of the Bridgeport Brass Company, told the adjourned annual meeting on Monday that conditions of the security market had not improved since the April 28 meeting was held. As a result, the session adjourned without shareholders taking action on the proposed issuance of 125,732 shares of a new cumulative convertible preferred stock.

A 73-year-old woman was pinned for more than twenty minutes yesterday beneath a city-owned bus that struck her at the busy intersection of Broadway and Halsey Street, in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

Dr. Ordway Tead, Chairman of the Board of Higher Education, made public yesterday a letter from Dr. John J. Theobald, president of Queens College, denying that outside pressure had dictated the removal of Dr. Harold Lenz as dean of students.

OSAKA, Japan, Wednesday, May 28 (AP) -- A United States Army captain who was wounded in the April 10 riot of Red war prisoners on Koje Island said today he was ordered into a seething compound against his own judgment by Brig. Gen. Francis T. Dodd.

TRENTON, May 17 -- The Rev. Robert M. Kelley, 29 years old, director of a children's camp, rode a perilous three miles down the rain-swollen Delaware River today in an open boat before he was rescued by city firemen.

Joseph J. Cusmano, 47-year-old suspended deputy collector of internal revenue, was indicted yesterday by the special Brooklyn Federal Grand Jury on two charges of taking money illegally from taxpayers.

The seven-story industrial building at 525-31 West Fifty-second Street through to 512-18 West Fifty-third Street has been sold by the Interborough News Company to Charles B. and Robert Benenson. It is under long-term lease to Triangle Publications, Inc., owner and publisher of The Philadelphia Equirer and other publications. The sale, lease and financing involved in the t ransaction amounted to about $4,000,000.

PARIS, May 27 -- Following is a summary of the principal provisions of the Treaty Establishing the European Defense Community, as it is officialy called, which was signed in Paris today. (Points covered in the annexes have been placed in this summary under the titles in the body of the treaty to which they pertain.)

CHICAGO, May 27 -- A number of the country's social work leaders took a firm stand today on one of the most important issues facing the welfare field -- whether or not the names of those receiving public assistance and the amounts received should be open to the public.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Some Government agencies, particularly the Atomic Energy Commission and the Salary Stabilization Board, are exercised about a provision in the Defense Production Bill that would exempt professional engineers, architects and accountants from salary controls.

Mrs. Anne Meyers, 34-year-old mother who turned bank robber last Thursday, was indicted by a New York County grand jury yesterday on charges of robbery and grand larceny in the first degree, assault in the second degree and violation of the Sullivan Law as a misdemeanor.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A harsh and unexpected controversy over a proposed new method of tuition payments threatened today to delay Congressional consideration of an education and readjustment bill for veterans of the Korean conflict and others serving in the armed forces after June 26, 1950.
Although two plays are opening at 8 o'clock tonight -- "First Lady" at the City Center and "Sunday Breakfast" at the Coronet -- only the former will be reviewed in tomorrow's paper.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and closing prices were 8 points higher to 2 points lower than on Monday.

Industrial Distributors, Ltd., handler of 95 per cent of the world's industrial diamonds, is releasing crushed bort (diamond fragments) for industrial use in grinding super-hard metals for precision instruments and diamonds for use in drills as fast as they are mined and processed, L. H. Metzger, president of Super-Cut, Inc., Chicago, producer of diamond wheels, said yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A patron, the dictionary says, is "one who protects, fosters, countenances or supports some person or thing; a protector or benefactor; as, a patron of sculpture." For ages the fact was incontrovertible -- and extremely frightening -- that the patron was a prime mover in arranging for most creators to create.

PARIS, May 27 -- The foreign ministers of eight Western countries and representatives of seven others signed today in the famous Clock Room of the French Foreign Office a series of documents to create and guarantee a single unified European defense force and through it to bind Western Germany with the Atlantic defense system and with a gradually uniting Western Europe.

PARIS, May 27 -- When the European Defense Community is finally established upon the ratification of the historic treaty signed here today, Western Germany will not be permitted to manufacture atomic, bacteriological and chemical weapons or magnetic mines.
In their first meeting with the Senators since the May 3 deal that brought Irv Noren to New York in exchange for Jackie Jensen, Archie Wilson and Frank Shea, the Yankees took the honors.
HAMMOND, Ind., May 27 -- Stockholders of Standard Oil Company (Indiana) voted today to increase authorized capital stock from 20,000,000 to 40,000,00 shares at their delayed annual meeting.

Lack of "management succession" as a factor inducing bank mergers is an indication of indifference or neglect of responsibility by the merged bank's board of directors, New York's Banking Superintendent warned last night.

Your issue of May 22 carried an article by Jack Raymond on the liquidation of the Ruhr coal cartel. Since I have been in close touch with this problem, I would like to comment on the report of your correspondent, because it seems to me that he overlooks some of the essential facts.
PITTSBURGH, May 27 (AP) -- Ed Pellagrini hit his first home run of the season in the top of the fourteenth inning to give the Reds a 5-4 victory over the Pirates today.

Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City was questioned for three hours yesterday by the State Crime Commission concerning his meeting in a New York hotel on March 14 with Anthony Strollo, alias Tony Bender. District Attorney Frank Hogan, who disclosed the meeting, had characterized Strollo as "a notorious underworld character whose gangster influence extends over northern New Jersey and lower Manhattan."

BAY SHORE, L. I., May 27 -- Another first and a second place today gave Jack Price's Comanche of the Biscayne Bay, Fla., fleet a commanding lead in the elimination series to select the Star boat crew to represent the United States in the Sailing Olympics at Helsinki, Finland, this summer. The double-header today enabled the fleet to catch up on the schedule, which was disrupted by Sunday's postponement.

The bill to raise taxi fares 27, per cent was passed yesterday by the City Council amid demands by two Councilmen that the entire taxicab industry in the city be investigated. The vote was 21 to 1, with one not voting.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- James Patrick McGranery was sworn in as Attorney General today after a vigorous defense of the Department of Justice by Solicitor General Philip B. Perlman. Mr. Perlman denounced "character assassins" among critics of the department and demanded that the "defamers be driven back into their holes."

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 27 (AP) -- Texas Democrats exploded today into two fighting factions, one electing national convention delegates promising to support the national party's Presidential nominee, the other, refusing.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 27 -- The United States proposed today to the Economic and Social Council that the United Nations take the lead in a long-range program to supply technical aid to countries on water-control projects to avoid costly errors and the waste of natural resources.

Burton Turkus, the erstwhile Assistant District Attorney of Kings County, can't seem to forget Murder, Inc. Although he has been in private practice for some years, he has found time to write a book on his experiences in prosecuting the Brooklyn hoodlums and now is carrying on with a television program on the same theme.
" Fearless Fosdick," a film program based on the cartoon characters created by Al Capp, will make its debut over Channel 4 on Sunday at 4 P. M. The roles will be filled by marionettes.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The Senate agreed today to give top priority, in its debate on extension of economic controls, to a move to cut off wage-price control authority on June 30.

BERLIN, May 27 -- East German youths already have begun training in marksmanship and glider flying to prepare themselves for service in a proposed East German Army, it was announced tonight in a report carried by ADN, the official East German news agency.
PARIS, May 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of the three-power declaration issued in Paris today by the United States, Britain and France:

" I thought I was in heaven," one teen-age girl giggled as she came out of the small-size planetarium yesterday at the Brooklyn Children's Museum. "It was so dark and there were so many stars," she explained while squinting her eyes at the bright sunlight in the corridor.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- Thomas J. Lynch, general counsel of the Treasury said today that present law required the Internal Revenue Bureau to permit unrepaid loans to political parties to be written off as bad debts on income tax returns.
PRESTWICK, Scotland, May 27 (AP) -- America's favored trio -- Dick Chapman, Billy Maxwell and Frank Stranahan -- surged ahead today in their bids for the British amateur golf championship.

TORONTO, May 27 (Canadian Press) -- Henry Borden, president of Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., said today at the company's annual meeting that demand for its public utility services in Brazil continues unabated.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Restrictions on the use of the country's three key metals -- copper, aluminum and steel for civilian products -- have been eased for the next quarter, officials of the National Production Authority announced today.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 27 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, who parachuted into France eight years ago in the war against Nazi aggression, returned here today to take command of the growing Allied armies now defending Europe against the threat of Communist aggression.

The Traffic Summons Bureau of the Magistrate's Courts came up with its second multiple parking violator in less than eighteen hours yesterday when a Bay City, Mich., driver was arrested in midtown on charges of ignoring thirty-one summonses.

TORONTO, May 27 (Canadian Press) -- Sherritt Gordon Mines, Ltd., has arranged with a group of financial institutions for financing the program under which it is opening a nickel-cobalt-copper property at Lynn Lake, in northern Manitoba, and building a nickel refinery near Edmonton.
A discussion of freedom of speech and of the press interrupted testimony yesterday at the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders in United States District Court.
