The Electrolux Corporation, one of the leading manufacturers of vacuum cleaners, is planning to go into national advertising within a few months for the first time in its twenty-seven-year history, it was announced yesterday. Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., is the agency.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Senator John J. Williams, whose exposures of income tax scandals have started Congressional investigations, told the Senate today that the records of the late Scarface Al Capone and associates who have carried his criminal syndicate forward showed that the Treasury dealt more kindly with gamblers and racketeers than with average taxpayers.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman approved yesterday the sale of the Yonkers Railroad Company by the bankrupt Third Avenue Transportation Corporation to the Westchester Citizens Transportation Committee for $50,000.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, told Senators today that diversion of combat planes to Korea had brought "danger of a numerical shortage in the Air Force at the present time."

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The House of Representatives today approved a two-year $1,276,200,000 road - building program. Final action on the measure, however, was deferred until tomorrow because of the possibility of a roll-call vote on cutting out funds for the Rama Road in Nicaragua.

Throughout the United States most markets will be closed on Friday, which is Memorial Day, and the following Saturday. The exceptions will be a few livestock markets, which will reopen on Saturday. Principal Canadian and European markets will be open on Friday but all except the Winnipeg Grain Market will be closed on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Following is the vote by which the Senate defeated 35 to 27 today the motion by eleven Republicans to cut an additional billion dollars from the $6,900,000,000 foreign aid bill:
CHICAGO, May 27 (UP) -- The Cardinals hammered sixteen hits to outslug the Cubs, 8 to 5, before 8,173 fans today.

Enough results have come in from Sunday's communal elections in Italy to show that fascism is back as a national political force of importance. This was feared and expected, but it is always discouraging to see one's fears realized.

THIS is an Olympic year and all the important pre-Olympic track meets except one will be held on the Pacific Coast. The exception is the seventy-sixth annual championship of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America (I. C. 4-A. to you), which will take place Friday and Saturday at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.

Earlier this month the Switzerland Cheese Association, in a nine-page statement to the Banking and Currency Committee of the House of Representatives, explained why it opposed the renewal of Government restrictions on cheese imports.

DEVON, Pa., May 27 -- Defiance II entry of Richard V. N. Gambrill of Vernon Manor, Peapack, N. J., picked up where it had left off twelve years ago by winning today's revival of the Devon horse show's colorful coaching marathon.
A group of 400 executives from many corporate fields opened yesterday at the Astor Hotel a two-day "briefing session" on the training and development of management personnel.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 27 -- Housewives in the metropolitan area will be able to serve Long Island strawberries to their families early next month. Growers estimate that the crop will be ready for picking about June 6.
LONDON, May 27 (AP) -- The Moscow radio broadcast tonight this North Korean communique:

LONDON, May 27 -- Interest in the stock markets was centered today in the foreign bond market. German bonds fell sharply on the belief that in the international conference sitting in London the Germans are trying to scale down pre-war debts.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Congress was asked today to set up a joint House-Senate committee to look for ways to increase production of paper for newspapers and magazines.

MIAMI, Wednesday, May 28 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia held a steady 18-to-6 lead early this morning over Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee in their primary contest for Florida's twenty-four votes at the Democratic National Convention.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Census Bureau today estimated, on the basis of a sample survey, that more married women were working in 1951 than at the peak of World War II. This was attributed to a steady post-war upswing in the number of women working and to a sharp increase in recent years in the married population.

Herman Methfessel, former District Attorney of Richmond County, who had been on disciplinary trial in Brooklyn Supreme Court for having arrested a woman who testified against him last September before the State Crime Commission, rested his case yesterday in unusual fashion.
Flatbush -- or, by its old Dutch name, Vlacte-Bos (the wooded plain) -- was 300 years old yesterday, and its youth marked the anniversary.

Detectives were faced yesterday with the third Central Park South jewel burglary in a fortnight as Mr. and Mrs. Harry Anderson reported the theft of $25,000 in gems and furs from their tenth-floor apartment in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South.

Restrictions on aviation gasoline imposed by the Petroleum Administration for Defense as a result of the strike of American oil refinery workers is costing the international airlines and the European tourist business millions of dollars a week, it was learned yesterday.

RYE, N. Y., May 27 -- The New York women's intercity golf team of seven players won the Griscom Cup again as they defeated Philadelphia, 11 -- 10, and Boston, 14 1/2 -- 6 1/2, for a total of 25 1/2 points over the difficult West Course of the Westchester Country Club today.

ALBANY, May 27 -- A New York exhibitor's license to show "The Miracle," the controversial Italian motion picture, was reinstated today in the wake of the United States Supreme Court's decision that the state could not ban a film because it was considered "sacrilegious."

HEAQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, May 27 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet, commander of the Eighth Army, conferred today with South Korean President Syngman Rhee about the bitter feud between the President and the Republic's National Assembly.

Combat Boots of the Putnam Stable conquered five others in the mile-and-a-furlong Attention Classified Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Established the favorite by the crowd of 19,825, the 4-year-old son of Our Boots went competently under the guidance of Hedley Woodhouse to score by more than three lengths in 1:50 1/5.
BOSTON, May 27 -- A new concept of the manner in which tuberculosis infection spreads within the lungs was presented for the first time in this country today.

PARIS, May 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of the statement today by Secretary of State Dean Acheson on the occasion of the signing of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization European Defense Community protocol:
Retailers were told yesterday that the proposed amendment to limit Federal income taxation to 25 per cent of net income would result in increased excise and nuisance taxes harmful to retailing.
SINGAPORE, May 27 (AP) -- America's badminton team swept to a 3 -- 1 lead over India tonight in the opening day's play of the Thomas Cup interzone final.

Domestic sugar on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange held firm yesterday, despite continued pressure of cargoes soon to arrive from the Philippines. One consignment of 4,000 tons, due on June 2, was sold at 6.1 cents a pound. Another, due this week, is reported still unsold.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- Henry J. Sandusky, Town President of Cicero, Ill., and Theodore H. Wesolowski, the suburb's Fire Marshal, were dismissed today as defendants on charges growing out of the race rioting in Cicero last July. The trial, now in its second week, continued against five other defendants.

Fourteen hundred employes of Stern Brothers department store will receive wage increases of 7 1/2 cents an hour and other benefits under the terms of an agreement signed yesterday between the store and District 65 of the Distributive, Processing and Office Workers of America, unaffiliated.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 11 reported the plight of 6,000 Chinese university students and graduates cut off in this country from their homes in China. But the report did not contain reference to the most saddening fact of all. It is a measure of our times that these young men and women have become a stake in the "cold war."

MINERAL WELLS, Tax., May 27 -- Texas Republicans split into two conventions today and nominated rival slates of thirty-eight delegates to contest for recognition before the Chicago nominating convention.

In a civil anti-rust complaint filed yesterday by the Government in Federal Court, McKesson Robbins, Inc., was charged with conspiring to fix minimum wholesale and retail selling prices for its branded line of drugs, pharmaceuticals, cosmetics and toilet preparations.
PARIS, May 27 -- Following are the ratifications required for the treaties and protocols signed in Bonn yesterday and in Paris today:

Budget - conscious housewives who have been doing without new electrical household appliances because of high prices, heard good news yesterday from the Frigidaire division of the General Motors Corporation. Frigidaire cut store prices as much as $45 on refrigerators, electric ranges, an electric dehumidifier and an automatic electric clothes washer.

Dr. Leopold Figl, Austrian Chancellor, left with his wife for Paris last night from the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens. During his stay here, Dr. Figl had lunch with President Truman and conversations with top-ranking Cabinet members and Congressional leaders.
Dr. David Dodds Henry, 46 years old, president of Wayne University in Detroit, has been named executive vice chancellor of New York University.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -Clayton Fritchey, director of the office of public information of the Defense Department, was appointed an administrative assistant to President Truman today. The salary is $15,000 a year.
TOKYO, Wednesday, May 28 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,263, for Tuesday's operations:

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- Justice Robert H. Jackson of the Supreme Court has stayed the execution of Joseph Louis Paonessa, pending disposition of an appeal from his conviction for the murder of Robert Leonard, 14 years old, son of a Poughkeepsie, N. Y. widow. Paonessa had been sentenced to die in the Sing Sing Prison electric chair next week.

This week, this year, tercentenary comes to Flatbush of Brooklyn. The town traces its official history back to the patents of Stuyvesant himself, although the signature of the white man was being stamped on the settling Flatbush earth a full eighteen years before the founding proclamation of 1652.

Greenwich Villagers have scored their first major victory in resisting "improvements" to the heart of their community -- Washington Square -- when the Board of Estimate, it was learned yesterday, quietly shelved a project to run two new one-way roads through the park.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- United States diplomats appeared neither surprised nor dismayed today by the new border restrictions imposed by the Communist East German Government.
LOUISVILLE, May 27 -- Kentucky's State Democratic State Convention named Vice President Alben W. Barkley today as its choice for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

PUSAN, Korea, Wednesday, May 28 (AP) -- The South Korean National Assembly voted 96 -- 3 today to lift martial law from this provisional capital. It was a rebuke to President Rhee and possibly was aimed to test his powers with the South Korean Army.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., May 27 -- Operations research, an applied science that was developed for the Armed Forces during World War II out of the pioneering of scientists in business, came of age today when the first learned society in the field, the Operations Research Society of America, held its first scientific meeting at Arden House here.

NEWARK, May 27 -- The retail price of cigarettes will not be increased as a result of the new cigarette minimum price act adopted last week by the Legislature, Monroe A. Lewis, executive director of the Tobacco Distributors Association of New Jersey, said today.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 27 -- John L. Collyer, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company, Akron, Ohio, charged today that the United States "is now participating in inter-Governmental commodity cartels that have never been submitted to Congress for ratification."

LONDON, May 27 -- Britain must educate more scientists if the nation is to pay its way and discharge its obligations as a great power, according to the annual report of the government's Advisory Council on Scientific Policy published today.

One of the nation's largest operating electric and gas utilities, the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago, will raise $300,000,000 in new capital in the next three years to finance its contemplated expansion program, Charles Y. Freeman, chairman of the utility, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting in Chicago.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 28 -- The Communist delegates in the Korean armistice negotiations in Panmunjom today renewed a threat of fresh, full-scale war on the Peninsula unless the United Nations abandoned its principle that no prisoner of war would be sent back after an armistice against his will.

Government counsel in the investment banking anti-trust trial yesterday resumed questioning Harold L. Stuart, head of the non-defendant banking house of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and a witness for the Government. The redirect examination was undertaken by Kenry V. Stebbins, special assistant to the attorney general, after cross-examination of the Chicago banker was ended by William D. Whitney and Graham Claytor, defense lawyers.

The rival branches of American labor joined yesterday in an appeal to rival anti-Communist unions in Italy to "enter into a compact of friendship to work together for the common good of the Italian trade union movement."
After five years as president of the National Federation of American Shipping, 63-year-old Frazer A. Bailey attempted to retire yesterday, but the board of directors declined to accept.

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Walk East on Beacon," a Louis de Rochemont production presented by Columbia and featuring George Murphy, Finlay Currie, Virginia Gilmore, Karel Stepanek and Louisa Horton, is at the Victoria.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- The Transamerica Corporation, West Coast banking combine, announced today it had asked the United States Circuit Court of Appeals at Philadelphia to throw out a Federal Reserve Board order severing it from most of its banks.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 -- A jury of eight women and four men was chosen today to decide the innocence or guilt of James Smyth, ousted former Collector of Internal Revenue for Northern California.

BARCELONA, Spain, May 27 -- Federico Cardinal Tedeschini inaugurated today in the name of Pope Pius XII, whose Legate the Cardinal is here, the thirty-fifth International Eucharistic Congress of the Roman Catholic Church, in an impressive ceremony in Barcelona Cathedral.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 -- Plans for five weeks of spadework for W. Averell Harriman among Democratic National Convention delegates already elected in Pacific Northwest states were disclosed today as the Mutual Security Director, a Presidential aspirant, campaigned in northern California.

United States Attorney Myles J. Lane lumped the potato black marketeers yesterday with bookmakers, bootleggers and other racketeers and said they would get the same treatment, including investigation of their income-tax returns.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente signed an order yesterday granting permission for the exhumation from Woodlawn Cemetery of the purported remains of Allan T. Norton, writer and newspaperman, who disappeared from his home in Middletown Township, N. J., on Jan. 3, 1945.

As progress in defense strengthens Western Europe's sense of security, renewed development of economic strength can be expected to follow that will increase the need for more imports from the United States the Export Managers Club was told yesterday at a meeting in the Statler Hotel.

ROME, May 27 -- The latest returns tonight showed the Center parties headed by the Christian Democrats, running ahead of their Left-Wing and Right-Wing rivals in the provincial and municipal elections that took place in Central and Southern Italy last Sunday and Monday, but the Center parties lost heavily in the popular vote compared with the general election of 1948.

An organizing drive in nonunion dress factories in this city has "broken the back" of the garment racket, Charles S. Zimmerman, vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., told 3,000 dressmakers at a Manhattan Center rally last night.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Applications for accelerated tax amortization certificates on some 20,000 projects involving an estimated investment of $30,479,596,000 had been filed with the Defense Production Administration up to the beginning of this month, that agency announced today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 27 -- Motion-picture theatre owners in Southern California now are complaining that they are in a less advantageous position to do business with the producing-distributing companies than in the old days of block booking, forced selling and the fixing of zoning and clearances in connection with the distribution of films.
Representatives of automobile insurance stock companies met yesterday with agents and brokers and agreed on the draft of a "demerit" plan that would penalize poor drivers as much as 20 per cent.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A White House function "to focus attention on volunteers who give hospitality to members of the armed forces" was announced today by Mrs. James M. Helm, social secretary.
ALBANY, N. Y., May 27 (AP) -- The one stockholder in the West Shore Railroad Company voted today in favor of merging with the New York Central Railroad Company. The stockholder? The New York Central.
LONDON, May 27 -- The Conservative Government took further action today to restore competition in Britain and give private enterprise a bigger share in public services.

New issues of $90,000,000 of mortgage bonds, sinking fund debentures and cumulative preferred stock will be offered to investors today by underwriting syndicates. The offerings represent new financing for two industrial companies and a Texas public utility enterprise.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Calvin Rawlings, Democratic National Committeeman for Utah, was named chairman today of the National Committee's subcommittee on credentials at the party's national convention, replacing Frank M. McHale, who recently was defeated for re-election as National Committeeman from Indiana.

STRASBOURG, France, May 27 -- The uncertainties and contradictions of United States foreign policy came under fire today during a debate in the Council of Europe's Consultative Assembly on the annual report submitted to it by the Marshall Plan organization.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- Grain futures markets were nervous with choppy fluctuations within a moderate price range today. Buyers showed no great disposition to follow rallies, but on the other hand there appeared to be more confident absorption on the small recessions in wheat and also in coarse grains.

A loose bolt on a locomotive's axle housing (journal box) made a bid yesterday for the place now held in legend by a horseshoe nail. For want of a nail, it will be recalled, the shoe was lost, as were the horse, the rider, the battle and, ultimately, somebody's kingdom.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- House Republican farm leaders urged their party today to adopt a "strong" 1952 farm plank calling for farm modernization, more grass-roots control and price supports that would assure a "sound and prosperous agriculture."

Dr. William M. Markel, director of the Red Cross blood donor program, appealed yesterday to men and women to make special Memorial Day donations before Friday because all blood centers will be closed Friday and Saturday in observance of the holiday.

The stock market followed the course of least resistance yesterday and, as a result, drifted into irregularly lower ground. The trend was not all one way, for isolated strength was exhibited by main units in several divisions.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, May 27 -- The Mayor of Guayaquil, Ecuador's second city was hiding from police today with the city Government virtually paralyzed. His deputy was running City Hall but under imminent threat of arrest as a warrant also was issued for him.

In an application to reduce his bail from $20,000 to $5,000, William Perl, former Columbia University physics instructor indicted for perjury in the atom spy ring investigation, declared yesterday that he was a loyal American who had never engaged in espionage.

The concerted effort now being made on Congress to allow personal income tax deductions for payments to private retirement funds is one more in an ominous stream of exemptions reducing the tax base. Each such reduction has the reciprocal effect of increasing the tax rates that must be applied obtain a given amount of tax revenue.

The corporate name of Cone Export Commission Co., Inc., one of the oldest textile selling houses in the Worth Street market, will be changed to Cone Mills, Inc., effective Monday, it was announced yesterday.
CLEVELAND, May 27 (UP) -- The Tigers, hitless for five innings, exploded with a six-run rally in the sixth tonight, including a three-run homer by Vic Wertz, and went on to beat the Indians, 6 to 4.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 27 -- Janet Rodger, 20-year-old junior at Hofstra College, who lives at 86-80 102d Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, will go to France this summer on an all-expense-paid vacation she won in an essay contest conducted by the Alliance Francais de New York, a French-American cultural group.

BONN, Germany, May 27 -- A strike of newspaper printers throughout West Germany and West Berlin began at noon today in the midst of one of the most exciting chapters in German history. It is scheduled to last for two days and a complete newspaper blackout will be prevented only by "emergency" papers that editorial workers and other unskilled printers were trying to prepare tonight.

A six-story building at 45-18 Court Square, Long Island City, Queens, formerly occupied by the Tax Department of Queens County and now used as a factory, has been sold by the Henrietta and Stuard Hirschmann Foundation to the Matmor Realty Corporation. The C. Grant Keck Organization was the broker in the sale.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- Two Republicans of the House of Representative asked for a Congressional investigation today to show that Charles A. Lindbergh was "unjustly" condemned as a "disloyal citizen" by the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP) -- A tenth-inning triple by Del Ennis and a fly ball by Willie Jones gained a 5-4 victory for the Phillies in the second game of a twilight-night twin bill tonight after the Braves had won the twelve-inning opener, 4 -- 2.

In deciding the "Miracle" case, the nine justices of the Supreme Court, so widely divergent in their political, economic and social thinking, united in the view that the Constitutional guarantees of free speech and free conscience must be preserved.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 27 -- Reversing the expected leftist trend, the conservative United National Party, headed by Prime Minister Dudley Senanayake, was virtually assured of a majority in the Ceylon Parliament for the next five years when votes from nearly half of this strategic island's constituencies were announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Testimony of a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent that all agents of Soviet-bloc governments in the United Nations and in their embassies and consulates in the United States were engaged in espionage and propaganda against the United States was made public today by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Following is the 43-34 roll-call vote by which the Senate today defeated a proposal by Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana to reduce defense support funds for Europe by $500,000,000:...

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The bitterness of the Taft-Eisenhower contests over the credentials of Southern delegates, and the fact that the number at stake may determine whether the Senator or the General will be nominated for President at the Republican National Convention, has brought to many minds a comparable situation at the party gathering forty years ago.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday but the market was steady and closing prices were unchanged to 17 points higher on the day.

UNION CITY, N. J., May 28 -The Stuttgart Kickers of Germany ended their eight-game tour of this country by playing a 2-2 tie with a picked team representing the Newark, Elizabeth and Hoboken clubs in the New Jersey Division of the German American Soccer League at Roosevelt Stadium tonight.
Two armed fur thieves were caught as they fled from an $11,000 robbery yesterday after they had failed to silence their victims by threatening them with "the same as Arnold Schuster got."

Laszlo Halasz, musical director whose long career with the New York City Opera Company ended With his abrupt dismissal last Dec. 21, won a $15,324 Supreme Court verdict yesterday, which he promptly saluted as a vindication of his professional conduct.

The Hebrew Free Loan Society, 108 Second Avenue, celebrated its sixtieth birthday yesterday by producing facts and figures to back up its faith in borrowers whom banks consider bad risks. Joseph Durst, president of the society, reported at a board meeting that of the $40,000,000 borrowed during the last sixty years by 725,000 housewives, students, unemployed and others needing $5 to $500, only one-tenth of 1 per cent had not been repaid.

Wall Street leaders predicted yesterday that enactment of the proposed local law to double the tax on gross incomes of financial businesses would drive many of them out of New York with irreparable damage to the city's economy and prestige.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Canada asked the United States today for assurances that Canadian troops in Korea would not be split away from their own commands, except under military necessity, without prior approval from Ottawa.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Robert L. L. McCormick, research director of the Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report, asserted today that the Veterans Administration had 11,898 more employes than it needed and could save $44,201,000 a year by letting them go.

The National Jewish Hospital at Denver, a nonsectarian institution devoted to the care of needy tuberculosis patients, celebrated its fifty-third anniversary last night. A $100-a-plate dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel brought in $125,000 for maintenance of the center.

" THE ABYSS,"* by Manes Sperber, is a novel of disenchanted hope in a world of romantic despair. It is the story of Doino Faber, "proud Dion," a rebel without a party, islanded among the outcasts of his own damnation, hating the communism he has belatedly renounced, despised by the democracy he would tardily defend, searching today for a new faith among those he yesterday betrayed.

A banking syndicate headed by W. C. Langley Co. will offer today 100,000 shares of new $100 par value 5 per cent dividend preferred stock of the Long Island Lighting Company. Issuance of the stock was authorized yesterday by the Public Service Commission.

NEWARK, May 28 -- The police today held Mrs. Anne De Nike, 36 years old, a friend of the victim's family, as a material witness in the strangling of Mary Louise Wargo, 4. The child's shoeless but otherwise clothed body, wrapped in a pillowcase and sheet, was found last night in a vacant lot about a third of a mile from her home, 246 Van Buren Street.

LONDON, May 28 -- Most prices held fairly steady in the stock markets here today despite restriction of business with approach of the Whitsuntide Holiday. The foreign bond market was an exception. German and Japanese issues continued to fluctuate widely in accordance with latest reports on debt settlement prospects.

The largest class in its history fifty-three men, was graduated yesterday from the General Theological Seminary of New York, 175 Ninth Avenue, the oldest Protestant Episcopal seminary in the country and the only one operated by the governing body of the church.

MIAMI, May 28 -- Senator Richard B. Russell's candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination moved another step forward today as almost complete returns from yesterday's primary election gave the Georgia legislator a 19-to-5 victory over Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee in their contest for Florida's twenty-four votes at the Democratic National Convention.

Anyone interested in Latin America will be watching events in Ecuador the rest of this week with a mixture of hope and trepidation. The country is due to hold Presidential elections on Sunday, and if New York-born President Galo Plaza has his way they will be fair and free elections.

A thirty-day workhouse term and $2,200 in fines were imposed yesterday on William E. O'Neil, a trucking operator of New Haven, Conn., on his guilty plea to eightyfive traffic law violations dating to 1948.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -At least 4,000 persons on the Federal payroll are behind in the Federal income tax payments -- and House investigators are threatening to crack down on them.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Government sued the General Motors Corporation for $405,000 today for buying an assembly plant site near Wilmington, Del., from the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad for $135,000 less than the railroad paid for it.
Gold plaques in memory of George Polk, who died in Greece in 1948 while engaged in news coverage there, were awarded yesterday for journalistic achievement.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Sales by manufacturers increased slightly during April, the Department of Commerce reported today.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 28 -- The recent heavy flow of United States military aid to Indo-China was emphasized here today by a ceremony that marked the arrival the 150th shipload of United States military supplies to reach an Indo-Chinese port.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 28 -- Leon Fleischer, 24-year-old pianist, who lives at 851 West 177th Street, was the winner of the first prize of $3,000 in the final tests of the Queen Elisabeth of Belgium International Musical Competition held here this evening in the Great Concert Hall of the Palais des Beaux Arts.
Baker-Raulang Co, manufacturer of trucks and materials, handling equipment, store for offices and showroom in 137 Varick St -- Cushman Wakefield, Inc, brokers.

FORT WORTH. Tex., May 28 (UP) -- A $3,500,000 B-36 superbomber exploded into a gigantic ball of fire as it landed today at Carswell Air Force Base. Seven members of the crew were killed and the other ten were injured, none seriously.

LONDON, May 28 -- Parliament learned with satisfaction today that Field Marshal Earl Alexander, Minister of Defense, plans an early visit to Gen. Mark W. Clark in Tokyo and an inspection of the battlefront in Korea to give the British people a first-hand account of what is happening in that Far Eastern trouble center.

Active programs of adult education can spread knowledge and relieve public tensions, Robert F. Moore, new president of the New York Adult Education Council, said last night in out-lining a program recommended for institutions in this city.

Mr. Taft will presumably have from thirty to thirty-four votes from Texas on the first ballot of the Republican convention in Chicago. This will not be because the Texans who voted in the Republican precinct and county conventions wanted it that way. There is no doubt whatever that they wanted a delegation overwhelmingly pledged to General Eisenhower.
Let me first express my deep appreciation of your moderate, intelligent and sober editorial "Vandalism and Parents" on May 23. It states the problem and the proposed attempt to meet it with fairness.

The recent announcement that Amy Hostler has been named as the first president of the Mills College of Education was good news. No newcomer to the field of teacher education, her name has long been associated with the growth of the nursery school and kindergarten movement in this country.

New Yorkers will pay homage to the dead of all American wars today and tomorrow with parades, memorial services and oratory, in which pleas for peace will be coupled with prayers for sufficient might to dispel growing world tensions.

The new table was fashioned of white wrought-iron and it was obvious that the days of the old pickled-pine curio cabinet in the northeast corner of the dinette were numbered. "It won't go," said the lady of the house firmly, meaning not that it must stay but that it didn't match the new wrought-iron table and hence must depart.

Pressure on sugar prices eased again yesterday. The spot market recovered, with buyers offering more than 6.1 cents a pound in the South -- possibly because of threatened labor trouble -- and futures markets followed suit. On the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange the No. 6 domestic sugar contract closed 3 to 5 points higher on 7,000 tons.

More than 2,500 stockholders packed the giant boiler shop of the Bayway refinery of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) for their annual meeting yesterday. They went to Linden, N. J., to hear their management's account of stewardship, to elect fifteen directors and to vote down a suggestion for cumulative voting.

BERLIN, May 28 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, followed the old airlift route into this city today on a visit obviously intended to underline the Western powers' avowed determination to stay in Berlin.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 28 -- Brazil will receive 25,000 Japanese families in five years if an agreement just concluded between Brazil and Japan is implemented.

Nearly all non-residential buildings constructed in the future, as well as many large department stores and factories now in existtence throughout the city, would be required to provide off-street loading berths for trucks under two zoning amendments approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Constitution adopted by a 4-to-1 vote of the people of Puerto Rico last March to make their island a Commonwealth was approved by the House of Representatives today, but with reservations.
Baltimore County, Md., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on June 12 on $11,500,000 of bonds dated June 1,1952 and due June 1, 1955 to 1992.

BARCELONA, Spain, May 28 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York accused the Soviet Union today of being the primary cause of what he termed the present-day moral deterioration of the civilized world and deplored the need for intensive defense efforts to cope with the threats of Soviet aggression because the lack of security was forcing men away from spiritual values and ideals.
Nathaniel Kleitman's recent letter calls for a reply from me.

Agnes Moorehead, one of the distinguished performers of the First Drama Quartet in Shaw's "Don Juan in Hell," which completed recently a successful run at the Plymouth Theatre, will play the important role of Jezebel in the fall production of "Jezebel's Husband."
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -The House of Representatives approved a Federal road building bill today that would authorize the spending of $1,276,200,000 on United States and Latin American highways.
CHICAGO, May 28 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Plans are being made at tea and luncheon meetings for the annual tea dance in behalf of the Judson Health Center to be held on Nov. 20 at the Plaza under the auspices of the Women's Committee of the Center.
WASHINGTON. May 28 (AP) -- The Governors of Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware today urged Congressional approval of a multi-million-dollar plan to develop the Philadelphia-Camden port.

ALBANY, May 28 -- Stockholders of the New York Central Railroad Company approved today a proposal under which seven small wholly owned subsidiary lines will be merged with the parent road. At their annual meeting at the Ten Eyck Hotel they voted 5,104,114 to 23,075 for the proposal.

LONDON, May 28 -- The signing of the agreement bringing a rearmed West Germany into the Western defense complex has increased Clement Attlee's difficulties in holding the left wing of his Labor party in line with a bipartisan foreign policy.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Following are excerpts from the statement by Bernard M. Baruch today before the Senate Preparedness subcommittee:

INDIANAPOLIS, May 28 (UP) -- Kid Gavilan, the welterweight champion, scored a technical knockout victory in the sixth round over Fitzie Pruden in the Coliseum tonight. Cuts over the left eye prevented the Canadian battler from continuing in the non-title bout slated for ten rounds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 28 -- Charles Vidor, the director, has quietly latched onto the screen rights to the new novel, "SPQR," which is making its way up the best-seller list. The romantic adventure story is set in Rome in 1948 and was written by Paul Hyde Bonner.

KRESSON, N. J., May 28 -- The father of five children was burned to death early this morning when fire swept through his bungalow home here. His wife is in critical condition in Burlington County Hospital at near-by Mount Holly.
Since tomorrow is a holiday, this department presents its regular weekly round-up of food prices today.

DEVON, Pa., May 28 -- Oregon Duke, an aged chestnut gelding from the stable of Harry D. Ryan, Uniontown, Pa., gained a leg on the Brian Boru Challenge Trophy by winning the handy hunter contest tonight at the fifty-sixth annual Devon Horse Show.

BAY SHORE, L. I., May 28 -- The battle for series honors in the United States Olympic Star boat eliminations, which concludes tomorrow in Great South Bay, has narrowed down to two boats, with Jack Price's Comanche of the Biscayne Bay (Fla.) fleet leading George Schoonmaker's Dingo of the Nassau American fleet by 2 points.

With the German "peace contract" and the European Defense Community treaty signed and sealed but still to be ratified, world attention again turns to Washington, which must provide the decisive margin of both military power and financial aid to make the historic enterprise envisaged in these compacts a living reality in the face of Soviet efforts to frustrate it.

LONDON, May 28 -- The Foreign Office released today the text of a note to the Chinese Government, delivered yesterday by the British Charge d'Affaires in Peiping, rejecting allegations of British persecutions of Chinese in Hong Kong. The note said that the Chinese Government's public statement on May 10 of deportations, massacres and sabotage was based on "irresponsible calumnies."

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Bernard M. Baruch told Congress today that the United States was losing the arms race with the Soviet Union by stretching out the defense build-up over a longer period than had been planned originally.

LONDON, May 28 -- The General Council of the Trades Union Congress referred to its economic committee today the appeal by Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler to the unions to exercise restraint in their wage demands.

The rapidly expanding Japanese merchant marine will introduce two fast new freighters to the Orient-New York trade within the next few weeks, including one twin-screw freighter ranking with the fastest cargo vessels in the world.

" The obvious dangers of bureaucratic control" are worth risking for Government sponsorship of the arts, Aaron Copland, the composer, told a large audience of distinguished art leaders yesterday at a joint ceremonial of the American Academy and the National Institute of Arts and Letters.

BONN, Germany, May 28 -- The three Western powers and the Federal Government embarked today on two vital programs. The West listed possible counter-measures against the German Communists' restrictions on Berlin and pressure on West Germany and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer began the toughest political task he has yet faced, that of selling integration with the West to the German people.

BARRING a radical change in weather, or in wind, surfcasters willing to make a 75-mile drive for good fishing can head for Seaside Heights and be almost certain of coming home with plenty of big bluefish and possibly a few striped bass.

A young woman who is something of an unofficial psychologist as well as a good shorthand taker and typist was named "Miss Best Adjusted Secretary" yesterday. Doris Dean of Pittsfield, Mass., an attractive 22-year-old secretary to a doctor, was accorded the honor at a meeting in the Weylin Hotel in advance of National Secretaries Week, which begins Monday.
WINNIPEG, May 28 (Canadian Press) -- Canada likely will enter the new crop year beginning Aug. 1 with the biggest wheat carry-over since the war, grain officials said today.

MOSCOW, May 28 -- The Soviet press declared today that the people of both East and West Germany had the fullest Russian sympathy in their struggle against the Bonn treaty, which Pravda declared could be maintained only "by the bayonets of the American military clique."

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Senate passed a $6,720,860,000 Mutual Security authorization by a vote of 64 to 10 tonight and sent the measure to conference with the House of Representatives to adjust differences in the two bills. The companion measure in the House was chopped down to $6,174,000,000 before passage last week.

CLEVELAND, May 28 (UP) -- The heads of three railroad brotherhoods accused President Truman today of "ignorance" and "partisanship'' in reaching the recent settlement of their long-standing dispute with carriers.

PARIS, Thursday, May 29 -- Jacques Duclos, active leader of the French Communist party and member of France's Parliament, was arrested last night as thousands of Paris police smashed a Communist demonstration. The Reds' outburst was described by Minister of Interior Charles Brune as an assault "on the security of the state."
VILLEFRANCHE, France, May 28 -- The powerful United States Sixth Fleet -- the Atlantic Allies' trump card in the Mediterranean -- has a new commander.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, said tonight that all restrictions on the use of aviation gasoline would be lifted next Tuesday.

Continuance of the Federal wage-price control authority under present conditions is likely to do more harm than good, according to the Guaranty Trust Company of New York. Commenting on the outlook in its monthly Survey, to be issued today, the bank asserts that at the moment the balance of economic forces is deflationary.

Brutus Hamilton, coach of the University of California track team, after having withdrawn his squad from the I. C. -4-A meet at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, tomorrow and Saturday, changed his mind and nominated three men to compete in the championships.

PARIS, May 28 -- Richard Savitt was beaten by Eric Sturgess of South Africa in the French tennis championships today after standing at match point in the fourth set and collapsed from exhaustion and cramps at the end of the three-hour struggle. The score was 6 -- 2, 6 -- 8, 4 -- 6, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

The Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries, which operate a chain of 71 stores including Stern Brothers (97 per cent owned) and Gertz in Jamaica and Flushing, Queens, reported yesterday for the three months ended on April 30 net sales totaling $105,732,514, compared with $98,670,160 transacted in the corresponding period last year, an increase of 7.2 per cent.

TRENTON, May 28 -- Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons expressed belief today that Coast Guard security cards issued to pier workers could help keep undesirables off the New Jersey-New York waterfront.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- William McC. Martin Jr., chairman of the board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, told the Bankers Club of Chicago tonight that the Government should avoid deficit financing. Tax increases should be accompanied by "prudent trimming of Federal spending, he said.

Productio n of engine pre-heating equipment to start diesel or gasoline engines under the severest Arctic conditions quicker than hitherto possible was announced yesterday by the Stewart-Warner Corporation.

Imagination in design knows no age limits, judging from the large and varied collection of objects executed by child and adult students of the Greenwich House Pottery and now on view at the annual exhibition of students' work at the Pottery, 16 Jones Street.

One of the defendants in the forthcoming departmental trial of fourteen policemen accused of taking bookmaking bribes from Harry Gross has agreed to postpone the effective date of his scheduled retirement pending a verdict in his case.

PARIS, May 28 -- The French Government brought unusual pressure on Secretary of State Dean Acheson today for further United States aid to France in Indo-China and North Africa. In another session tomorrow the French will make an urgent plea for a United States commitment to a new program of defense contracts for French industry, which the Minister of Defense proposes should amount to $500,000,000.

MINEOLA, May 28 -- County Judge J. Ormonde Ritchie of Suffolk ruled today that the forty-mile-an-hour speed limit fixed by the Long Island State Park Commission for the parkways under its jurisdiction was void and unenforceable because of a technical defect in the statute giving the commission traffic control powers.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Striking dock workers, in a surprise move today, paralyzed loading and unloading operations of at least five ships, some of them ocean carriers, at Chicago ports and several barges along the canal waterway.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 28 -- Admiral Lynde D. McCormick, Supreme Allied Commander in the Atlantic, warned here today that while the Allies' anti-submarine developments in general were keeping pace with the advances in submarine warfare, nevertheless the numbers of air and surface forces available to the Allies for anti-submarine operations were "dangerously low."

If someone came to you and asked for help, you'd give him a dime or a quarter -- perhaps a dollar -- almost without thinking. Yet a penny or two invested in each of New York's voluntary comnity services, once a year, can do more real good for many more persons than larger gifts given haphazardly.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., May 28 -- On a 200-acre site, where the Kitchawanc Indians once buried their dead and where the colonists mounted a cannon to drive off a British sloop in the Revolutionary War, boys and girls from Westchester public schools are combining education and the fun of camp life.

Vincent Sheean's first novel since the publication in 1947 of "A Certain Rich Man" has been scheduled by Random House for Monday. "Rage of Soul" deals with the wife of a State Department official, who after the death of their small son, goes to India partly on a quest for a philosophy of living.

ROME, May 28 -- The center parties triumphed by 463,000 votes, out of a total of more than 7,300,000, over the left-wing parties in this week's provincial elections in central and southern Italy, according to the final results officially announced today. The right-wing parties ran third, 783,000 votes behind the left and 1,246,000 behind the center.

Revealing light on housing conditions in countries of Western Europe, and the reasons for them, appears in a new survey by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe. That these countries have housing shortages to a significant extent has been well known, but what has been less appreciated has been the role of Government policy in both creating and alleviating such shortages.
New furniture and accessories are included in the large collection of furnishings, suitable for summer living, on view in the Tropic Shop, 381 Fifth Avenue.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 28 -- With upward of twenty ships now tied up in West Coast ports by a strike of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., shipowners faced potential problems today in other union quarters.
TOKYO, Thursday, May 29 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,264, for Wednesday's activities:

The oft-delayed alternate-side- of-the-street parking plan on the upper West Side will go into effect next week. Following a three-day warning period, motorists parked illegally will be subject to $15 fines instead of the usual $4 fee for overtime parking. The ban will be in effect from 8 A. M. to 1 P. M.

A thirty-five-acre tract on Newbridge Avenue, south of Old Country Road, in Westbury, L. I., has been sold by Andrew Miller to Herbert Sadkin, builder, who plans to improve it with a group of one-family dwellings. Trylon Realty was the broker.

Aggregate market value of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $655,690,682 and the average market price gained 61 cents between March 31 and April 30, the Exchange reported yesterday. The average price was the highest since last Aug. 31, when it was $99.23.

Tahitian King, the speedster owned by Ben F. Whitaker, registered the third victory of his three-race career yesterday. The son of Polynesian streaked to success in the colt division of the National Stallion Stakes, to the satisfaction of most of the 18,432 fans, who established him the double-riveted favorite, at 35 cents to a dollar.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- Internal Revenue Commissioner John B. Dunlap today denied Senator John J. Williams' charge that notorious racketeers had been getting tax breaks.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- Pvt., Don Newcombe, Negro right-handed pitching ace of the Dodgers, has been found physically fit and must remain in the Army.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission accused two business directory publishers today of using a deceptive sales plan to get advertisements for their publications. It named:

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning, "Lovely to Look At," a MetroGoldwyn-Mayer musical in Technicolor, with Kathryn Grayson, Red Skelton, Howard Keel, Ann Miller and Marge and Gower Champion, is the attraction at the Radio City Music Hall.

A new Biedermeier chest is part of a collection just introduced by Barclay Square, 227 East Fifty-sixth Street. The pieces were adapted by John B. Wisner from originals from Vienna. Rich warm color and a simple beauty of proportion characterize the pieces.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- A proposed amendment to the Constitution forbidding a President to seize private property, except under specific laws passed by Congress, won unanimous approval today by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- With Secretary of State Dean Acheson due back from Europe Friday morning, the United States, Britain and France will get under way promptly here on the joint preparation of a reply to the Soviet Union's latest note on German unification.

As secretary general of the Communist party of France and head of its parliamentary group, Jacques Duclos, who was arrested last night by French police, is the leader of his party there and an important figure in the world Communist movement.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina and forty lawyers involved in a seemingly endless anti-trust trial went to Ebbets Field in Brooklyn yesterday on a self-decreed change of venue for relief from their legalistic chores.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Army completed plans today for an official welcome, including a seventeen-gun salute, for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower at National Airport about 4 P. M. Sunday upon his arrival from Paris.

STRASBOURG, France, May 28 -- Anthony Nutting, the British Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, today defended before the Council of Europe's Assembly the proposals of his chief, Anthony Eden, for combining the European Defense Community and other groups with the Council in such a way that Britain and other non-participating countries might associate themselves with those communities without becoming active members.

A latecomer at the monthly meeting of the Export Advertising Association yesterday in the Shelton Hotel almost backed out and left in the belief that he had entered the wrong dining room. Among the tables were two men with microphones, interviewing the diners as they do on certain radio and television shows. This had never been done before at Export Advertising meetings.

The stock market made some limited progress yesterday but proved unable to maintain early gains when late selling in the amusement section developed softness. The movie stocks were hit fairly hard after Loews reduced its dividend, after a similar action on Tuesday by United Paramount Theatres.

ROME. May 28 (UP) -- Two American priests believed today they might have discovered the Long-lost site of the Roman oircus where Nero raced his chariots and where early Christians were tossed to the lions.

I am writing in reply to a letter which was written to you on May 10 by Zoltan Pfeiffer, a member of the Hungarian National Council's Executive Committee and which appeared in the May 23 issue of your newspaper under the title "Background of General Farkas."

Sluggish curls of black smoke, squirming out of the business offices of the Nash Engineering Company, Inc., on the twenty- fourth floor of the Graybar Building, on Lexington Avenue between Forty-third and Forty-fifth Streets, provided an unusual spectacle for 3,000 spectators last evening while fire crews fought a small blaze of undetermined origin in the engineering company's quarters.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- The Senate elections subcommittee, which has been investigating charges by Senator William Benton. Democrat of Connecticut, against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, received today Mr. McCarthy's demand for a counter-investigation of Mr. Benton.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Paul E. Fitzpatrick, New York State Democratic chairman, said after a White House visit today that W. Averell Harriman was running for the Presidency only and not for the vice Presidency or the Senate.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- Leaders in the House of Representatives agreed today to call up a new G. I. Bill of Rights for Korean veterans for debate Monday under rules barring amendments and requiring a two-thirds majority for passage.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 28 -- By the end of 1952, retail trade, which was "the villain" of the nation's economic picture last year, "may well adopt the hero's role for 1953 by providing a firm and insensitive bulwark against a major recession.
After several comparatively slow years, open-market realty deals in Manhattan again appear to be on the upward trend.

A retired general of the Air Force turned space cadet yesterday. In the midst of a serious plea for better weapons, faster and cheaper, at the dedication in San Diego of Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation's big, new engineering development center, Convair's president, Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, U. S. A. F. (Ret.), said "the wedding of the airplane and the guided missile" is in sight.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 28 -- With none of the frightening urgencies that have prompted political upheavals in other parts of the world, the newest and perhaps the happiest republic on earth -- and one of the smallest -- was born three weeks ago in the Maldive Islands, a cluster of 12,000 tiny palmclad sandspits that break the blue monotony of the Indian Ocean 400 miles southwest of Ceylon.

The Roman Catholic population in the United States, including Alaska and Hawaii, reached a total of 29,407,520 as of Jan. 1, statistics published in the annual Official Catholic Directory by P. J. Kenedy Sons revealed yesterday. This represents an increase of 772,642 over the calendar year 1950.

The question whether studying about the Russian Revolution of 1917 was an exercise in history or a guide for revolution in the United States was explored yesterday at the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders in the United States District Court here.

CHICAGO, May 28 (AP) -- Harry (The Cat) Brecheen one-time nemesis of the Cubs, failed for the third time to finish against the Bruins, who thumped the Cardinals by 7 -- 2 today to take the rubber game of a three-contest', series.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The National Guard Association came out in opposition today to the new armed forces reserve bill, which it had endorsed during its passage through the House of Representatives in October.

JERUSALEM, May 28 -- An overhead conveyor belt or cable car system will be built 3,000 feet out into the sea from the Israeli coast in the region of Ascalon within the next twelve months to load phosphates and potash for export directly into ocean-going freighters, Minister of Transport David Zvi Pinkas said today.

Paul P. Brennan and Paul A. Fino, the members of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, presented detailed replies yesterday to the criticisms of the commission contained in two reports made public May 18 by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey.

ONE year ago yesterday a scared kid of 20 made his first major league hit. Willie Mays hammered a majestic blast over the Polo Grounds roof against Warren Spahn. It was typical of Willie the Wonder that his flair for the spectacular should evince itself so early in his career. But that career ended temporarily at Ebbets Field yesterday.
PUSAN, Korea, May 28 -- From the floor of the South Korean National Assembly came strong out-bursts today against the regime of President Syngman Rhee.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Grain futures showed a flash of strength today in the early trade, helped in part by a strong turn in soybeans and also influenced by less favorable weather news. But rallies were still hard to hold and there was a sharp recession in all grain pits from the early tops.
PITTSBURGH, May 28 (AP) -- Ken Raffensberger gained his sixth triumph against three setbacks tonight as he pitched the Reds to a 5-2 triumph over the last-place Pirates.

LONDON, May 28 -- Condemnation of the policies of Dr. Daniel F. Malan's South African Government was expressed in separate statements issued today by the general council of the Trades Union Congress, speaking for 8,200,000 members of Britain's unions and by the National Executive Committee of the Labor party.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 28 -- The Western Powers proposed today that the United States, the Soviet Union and Communist China cut their armed forces to a maximum of 1,500,000 men each. Britain and France, under a three-power paper put before the United Nations Disarmament Commission, would set ceilings for their armed forces at between 700,000 and 800,000 men.

A pilot project to rehabilitate the more than 10,000 mutilated children in Greece was announced yesterday by Dr. Michael P. Goutos, secretary general of the Greek Ministry of Social Welfare, at the Foster Parents Plan for War Children, Inc., 55 West Forty-second Street.
KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Thursday, May 29 (AP) -- A staff officer said Wednesday that at least 457 war prisoners had escaped from this island prison but that "no one really knows" how many have got away.

PARIS, May 28 -- West Germany soon will submit a concrete proposal for the settlement of' claims totalling $1,500,000,000 submitted by Israel and private Jewish agencies on behalf of Jewish victims of Nazi persecution and property seizures.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- President Truman declared today that the Soviet Union cried for peace but caused war wherever possible, and he denied that the United States had used germ warfare or otherwise had violated the Geneva Convention for the treatment of war prisoners in Korea.

On Jim Hearn's four-hit pitching and the distance clouting of Davey Williams, Don Mueller and Whitey Lockman. the Giants yesterday romped to a 6-2 triumph over the Dodgers at Ebbets Field before 15.835 paying spectators and 6,500 Knothole Gang partisans.

The city was urged yesterday to "go forward without delay to install a complete classification and pay plan" to cover all of its 222,000 employes. The proposal would set up a new classification division at once in the Civil Service Commission under a qualified administrator.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Increases in ceiling prices for groceries, effective Monday, were authorized by the Office of Price Stabilization today. Ellis Arnall, price stabilizer, estimated that the increases would add $100,000,000 to $150,000,000 annually to consumers' food bills.

The board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association at its annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House elected two new directors to membership in the association, re-elected thirteen directors upon expiration of their present terms and re-elected sitting officers of the association for another year.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Three young scientists at the National Institutes of Health of the United States Public Health Service reported today the identification and partial purification of a "clearing factor" capable of removing abnormal fat molecules from the blood stream.
" Italy Today," a sixteen-day exhibition of Italian arts, crafts, and industrial products, was opened yesterday at Grand Central Palace before it was quite ready for public inspection.
SINGAPORE, May 28 (UP) -- The United States qualified to challenge Malaya for the Thomas Cup tonight by beating India in the interzone badminton final by five matches to four.

Not quite halfway through its 1952 campaign, the Greater New York Fund announced yesterday that contributions and pledges had reached $4,023,000, which is considerably more than it had had up to this stage in any previous drive.

BINGHAMTON, May 28 -- An earthbound electronic contraption that will teach future Air Force priors in complete safety and at relatively low cost to fly speed-of-sound jet bombers at 40,000 or more feet was shown here today.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, May 28 -- Ecuador's waning Presidential electoral campaign is in a state of high nervous tension and considerable confusion of thought. Guayaquil and Quito are very different areas of political thinking but in Guayaquil at least there is general apprehension of a military coup either before the elections Sunday or just after the elections if the results prove unsatisfactory to military leaders.

A system of working permits to regulate the employment of children under 16 years old, some arrangement to provide part time jobs for working mothers and more efficiency in enforcing laws that require factory owners to provide nurseries for infants of women employes are among the aims for Chilean workers outlined yesterday by Senorita Felisa Gonzalez, chief of the section on women, children and industrial homework of Chile's National Department of Labor.

The American Management Association at the Astor Hotel yesterday concluded a two-day briefing session on how to choose and develop executives. Spiced by vigorous question and answer periods, speeches to the 400 management men present covered everything from group training to final rating and selection of employes for promotion.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 28 -- The Yugoslav Government has received almost 1,252,600 tons of industrial raw materials and an unspecified tonnage of pharmaceutical raw materials and chemicals valued at $5,500,000 since the spring of 1951 under grants-in-aid made by the United States, British and French Governments.

The present economic health of the nation's department store business was depicted yesterday as alarmingly poor. In the annual "Harvard Report" presented at the thirty-second annual convention of the Controllers' Congress, Malcolm P. McNair, Lincoln Filene Professor of Retailing at the Harvard Graduate School of Business, recited statistics showing that department store profits in 1951 suffered more severely than those of almost any other business.

The American Management Association at the Astor Hotel yesterday concluded a two-day briefing session on how to choose and develop executives. Spiced by vigorous question and answer periods, speeches to the 400 management men present covered everything from group training to final rating and selection of employes for promotion.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 28 -- The Yugoslav Government has received almost 1,252,600 tons of industrial raw materials and an unspecified tonnage of pharmaceutical raw materials and chemicals valued at $5,500,000 since the spring of 1951 under grants-in-aid made by the United States, British and French Governments.

The present economic health of the nation's department store business was depicted yesterday as alarmingly poor. In the annual "Harvard Report" presented at the thirty-second annual convention of the Controllers' Congress, Malcolm P. McNair, Lincoln Filene Professor of Retailing at the Harvard Graduate School of Business, recited statistics showing that department store profits in 1951 suffered more severely than those of almost any other business.

The shift from Wall Street to Main Street in the ownership of American industry was illustrated yesterday by a survey of the shareholder list of the National Securities and Research Corporation, a mutual fund with assets of more than $93,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- The Defense Department today announced a new total of 108,977 United States battle casualties in Korea, an increase of 270 over last week's report.

The Pentagon's continuing attempt this week to persuade the Senate to reverse reductions and limitations made by the House of Representatives in the 1953 military appropriations bill focuses, in the case of the Navy, around the big aircraft carrier.

The International Typographical Union, which has celebrated its one hundredth anniversary this month, is deserving of the eminence it occupies in the forefront of democratic labor organizations because of its long history of achievement, which has been in the interest of all wage-earners and not only on behalf of its own members.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- Former United States Senator Joseph R. Grundy, 89-year-old founder of the conservative political bloc bearing his name, accepted today appointment to the Southeastern Pennsylvania Citizens Committee for Robert A. Taft.

TORONTO, May 28 (UP) -- There are signs that the United States wants to see Canada only as "a hewer of wood and drawer of water," Hugh Crombie, president of the Canadian Manufacturers Association, said today.
EPSOM DOWNS, England, May 28 (AP) -- The Aga Khan's Tulyar, suspected of being strictly a mudlark, pounded over a pavement-like track today to win the 173d English Derby from an international field.

ST. LOUIS, May 28 (AP) -- Satchel Paige performed his relief role in fine style tonight to protect Bobby Cain's fourth victory of the year as the Browns broke a four-game losing streak by defeating the White Sox, 3 -- 1.
Ellis L. Spray, vice president in charge of manufacturing of the W. L. Maxson Corporation, has been named a director.
OTTAWA, May 27 (Canadian press) -- Canada's exports reached new high mark in April rising 50,000,000 to $350,600,000, mainly because of a big increase in Sales to the dollar-short United Kingdom.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended May 21:

Dr. Douglas Southall Freeman, historian and former editor, urged newspaper men and radio writers here last night to occupy their time and talents in more worthwhile writing than was normally demanded in earning their daily bread.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 28 -- Vast hydro-electric, irrigation and canalization developments now under way in the Soviet Union, China and the "People's Democracies" will reclaim scores of millions of acres for cultivation within the next ten years, Georgi P. Arkadyev of the Soviet delegation informed the Economic and Social Council today.

The sudden and untimely death of Justice Bernard L. Shientag marked the passing of a distinguished jurist, a great citizen and a gracious, scholarly gentleman. A man of unusual cultural attainments, Justice Shientag wielded a brilliant pen. He was a skilled literary craftsman, with a gift for the vital word and the illuminating phrase.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Taft steamroller worked efficiently in the Texas convention this week, but it still is not clear who got run over.

A gala showing of fashions from Italy's top couture was given last night for the benefit of the New York City Committee of the American Cancer Society at the Italy Today fair at Grand Central Palace. The fashions will be shown daily through June 12.

CHICAGO, May 28 (UP) -- W. Averell Harriman, Democratic Presidential aspirant, received the glowing praise of Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson tonight and then proceeded to attack those who would "cripple" the Administration's foreign aid program.

The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. warned its 2,500,000 members yesterday against a "blinding fear of subversive forces" that threatens to "tear down the whole structure of freedom and equality in America."

TOKYO, Thursday, May 29 -- United Nations delegates negotiating at Panmunjom for an armistice in Korea disclosed yesterday the full list of questions asked of war prisoners in the South Korean camps to determine how many wished to return after a truce to their former Communist allegiance.

PARIS, Thursday, May 29 (UP) -- The French Government planned to ask the National Assembly to lift Duclos's parliamentary immunity. Police would not disclose the charges against the Communist leader until the Assembly acts on the request, which probably will be submitted today, but informed sources said he would be charged with carrying concealed weapons.

PRESTWICK, Scotland, May 28 (UP) -- Frank Stranahan, Dick Chapman and Billy Maxwell -- Amemca's big three in the fight for the British amateur championship -- led seven United States golfers into the fifth round today.

PRESTWICK, Scotland, May 28 (UP) -- Frank Stranahan, Dick Chapman and Billy Maxwell -- Amemca's big three in the fight for the British amateur championship -- led seven United States golfers into the fifth round today.

The hospitality of New York Presbyterians was demonstrated yesterday at the closing session off the church's general assembly when Mrs. Lillie B. Harris, an elderly, gray-haired Negro delegate from Augusta, Ga., told the churchmen she had eaten most of her meals in lonely solitude because "you aren't ready to accept me as a sister in Christ."

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee refused today to restore $174,000,000 in atomic energy funds trimmed by the House of Representatives but promised to review the atomic budget when President Truman requested funds for his new atomic expansion program.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A special "task force" to investigate the possibilities of relaxing building restrictions so that apartment houses can be constructed in greater numbers will be named by the National Production Authority, officials told a construction industry advisory committee here today.

DES MOINES, May 28 -- Iowa Democrats abruptly adjourned their state convention today on a voice vote, leaving behind the unfinished business of expressing a choice on the party's Presidential nominee.

A painting that had been lost for three centuries has been bought by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It is "The Musicians" by the Italian painter, Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio. Theodore Rousseau Jr., Metropolitan curator of paintings, said it was one of the most important single additions to the museum's collections in recent years.
DETROIT, May 28 (UP) -- South-paw Ted Gray fired a brilliant four-hitter tonight to give the tail-end Tigers a 6-2 victory over the league-leading Indians before 38,662 fans.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture today discontinued "indefinitely" its procurement of extra long-staple Egyptian cotton. The action came at the request of the Munitions Board.
There were extra rations for man and beast yesterday at the Bronx shelter of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, Park Avenue and 173d Street.

Details of the screening methods employed in the case of prisoners of war in Korea have again been made available to the Communists and also, fortunately, to the world at large. It is quite apparent that the United Nations is making every effort to ascertain the wishes of the individuals involved and at the same time actually bringing pressure, in doubtful cases, to sway prisoners toward instead of away from repatriation.

ROGERSVILLE, Tenn., May 29 (AP) -- The Federal Government's suit against the George L. Berry estate has been settled in Chancery Court here with the payment of $337,423 in back taxes and penalties, Ferdinand Powell, Assistant United States District Attorney of Knoxville, disclosed today.

A film depicting some of the various steps taken by fine craftsmen in the restoration of antiques has been made available, without charge, to schools, colleges, organizations and groups by the studios of Ernest LoNano, 235 East Forty-second Street.

The sudden crackdown on the French Communists may prove to be a development of prime importance in Western Europe, but we must not harbor any illusions about what can be accomplished. The Communists again showed expert training and discipline in the rioting on Wednesday and they still have far and away the best organized political party in France.

PARIS, May 29 -- There is every indication that Moscow has ordered its fifth column apparatus to take a tougher line and adopt more active methods in an effort to combat the resurgent strength of the democratic powers on a world-wide basis.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 29 (Reuters) -- The High Court of Parliament bill, introduced by the Nationalist Government last month to curb the powers of the Supreme Court, was finally approved by the House of Assembly tonight.

ROME, May 29 -- The Italian police late last night arrested by error a member of the Yugoslav Legation in Rome whom they had mistaken for a spy. He was released shortly afterward and today the Foreign Ministry formally tendered its regrets.
Seven students and one graduate of Hunter College have won the annual creative writing citations, the English department announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended May 24 rose 4 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Figures from the Board's weekly report on sales by districts follow in terms of percentage changes from like periods of 1951:

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 29 -- Firmly rebuffing the blandishments of the Marxist parties, tropical Ceylon's electorate has given the conservative United National party headed by Prime Minister Dudley Senanayake a heavier representation in the 101-member island Parliament than it gained in the last elections in 1947.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 -- Campaign leaders for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio clashed tonight on the air waves in a bid for California votes, although neither is on the state's primary ballot next Tuesday and write-in votes are illegal.

STANTON, Del., May 29 (AP) -- Succeeding where he had failed just a year ago, F. Ambrose Clark's Tea-Maker romped to a three-length triumph in the $10,000 added Wilmington Handicap today as Delaware Park ushered in its thirty-three-day meeting.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Those who are in charge of the physical arrangements for the July conventions of the Republican and Democratic parties are faced with a difficulty growing out of the modern developments in electronics that was unknown to their predecessors.

ROME, May 29 -- The Central Electoral Office published an official comparison today between the votes cast for the various parties in Sicily in last year's regional elections and this year's municipal elections.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- There are now 2,560 physicians who are displaced persons, refugees from the Nazis or the Russians, working in this country, it was reported today by Dr. Alex M. Burgess, chairman of the National Committee for Resettlement of Foreign Physicians.

The Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice has undergone a change of mind about two issues involved in the current trial of seventeen investmet banking houses, courtroom colloquy indicated yesterday. From statements made by Victor H. Kramer, chief Government counsel, it was understood that the Government would not insist on requiring the defendants to function either as financial advisers to issuers or as purchasers of securities as demanded in the original prayer of relief.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Senate rejected by a vote of 52 to 18 today a proposal to permit price and wage controls to expire June 30.
MEXICO CITY, May 29 (AP) -- A "grass roots" movement to weaken the board of directors of Rotary International was quelled today at the final meeting of the Rotary convention.

The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company announced yester that the official trials of the new superliner United States had again been postponed to permit further adjustment of her power plant. The run from the Virginia port had been scheduled for next week.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that its credit curbs had helped cut installment buying by $752,000,000 in the twenty months they were in effect.

George Carpenter, secretary of the District Council, Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, was designated last night for the Liberal party nomination for State Senator from the Fifth Senatorial District. Mr. Carpenter lives at 187-22 Jordan Avenue, St. Albans, Queens.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's letter to Vice President Alben W. Barkley concerning legislation to extend economic controls. It was sent to Mr. Barkley in his capacity as President of the Senate:
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's message vetoing the bill to give to the states clear title to oil-bearing lands that lie beyond their shores:

ITHACA, N. Y., May 29 -- Cornell University tonight suspended for a year twenty-five students who seized a university radio station last night and broadcast fake reports that European cities had been bombed. A faculty committee on student conduct announced the suspensions after interviewing the students, who included sophomores, juniors and seniors. Their names were not disclosed.
A plea for top management to become sales-minded as well as production and operations minded was made yesterday by W. L. Stensgaard, president of the Point of Purchase Advertising Institute.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson will report to the nation by radio and television Monday night on his week-long trip to Europe, the State Department announced today.
PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- The Giants, setting out on a fifteen-game road tour, got off to a woeful start today.

In 1944 the victorious Allied armies invading Germany liberated thousands of inmates of concentration camps who were for the most part Jews. They were found more dead than alive because of the starvation and other torturous maltreatment to which they had been subjected.
