Gas generators, cans of cyclon gas crystals, incinerator furnaces and other instruments for mass murder were discovered by the Allied troops in these unspeakable camps.

Six Battalion Chiefs of the Fire Department were promoted to Deputy Chief at brief swearing-in ceremonies yesterday afternoon in the office of Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet in his office at Fire Headquarters in the Municipal Building.
TOKYO, Friday, May 30 (AP) -- Eighth Arm tactical summary 72, for Thursday:
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- All the top men in the Justice Department have handed in their resignations, but that does not necessarily mean they will be leaving soon.

JERSEY CITY, May 29 -- Hudson County Judge James A. Coolahan today sentenced two men to life imprisonment at hard labor for the Nov. 8 mugging-slaying of 71-year-old Brother Salesius Klein, world head of the Roman Catholic Order of the Brothers of the Poor of St. Francis.

AFTER six successive weekends of bad weather, anglens seem to be absorbing the philosophy of dice manipulators, that there is magic in the number "seven," and with fishing improving almost daily, the holiday week-end should see both fresh and salt water areas receiving the heaviest pressure of the season.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 29 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio won firm control of the Alabama Republican delegation to the Chicago convention today after a warm floor fight with supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Since "Sunday Breakfast," produced by ANTA at the Coronet, is apprentice work by two authors new to Broadway, no one will be surprised to discover a certain breathless desperation in the writing. Emery Rubio and Miriam Balf have not mastered the craft of playwriting yet.

PARIS, May 29 -- Jacques Duclos, rotund 55-year-old acting chief of the Communist party in France, was sent handcuffed today to Fresnes Prison, charged with an attempt against the security of the state following yesterday's wave of violent Communist-inspired riots throughout France.

The first of three test cases brought by the Bureau of Smoke Control against the Consolidated Edison Company because of dense smoke being emitted at its plants went to trial yesterday in a special part of the Municipal Term Court.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 115 Korean war casualties. Of the total, 17 are dead, 86 wounded, 7 missing and 5 injured in battle zone accidents. The following were listed from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 29 (AP) -- Carmen Basilio's upset victory over Chuck Davey of East Lansing, Mich., was voided tonight by a deputy commissioner of the State Athletic Commission, who said the ultimate outcome rested with Chairman Bob Christenberry.

W. Walter Williams, chairman of National Citizens for Eisenhower, denounced yesterday as "shameful" the action on Monday of the Texas Republican State Executive Committee in unseating those delegates to the Republican National Convention favorable to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

While finding that the Griffenhagen classification and pay plan report for New York City civil service employes "contains many serious deficiencies," a Formal Hearings Board declares that information is now in hand to build a "sound, progressive and integrated" career and salary program.
NEWARK, May 29 -- The Newark police reported tonight that a woman neighbor had confessed strangling 4-year-old Mary Louise Wargo last Tuesday in a fit of rage because the child was making noise.

BOSTON, May 29 (AP) -- Lefty Maury McDermott faced only twenty-seven Washington batters tonight while achieving a one-hit pitching performance for a 1-0 Red Sox victory. Mel Hoderlein ruined McDermott's no-hit hopes in the fourth inning with a single before being wiped out in a double play.

Every financial and commodity market in the United States will be closed today and tomorrow. Livestock reports, however, will be issued on both days. The Winnipeg grain market will be open on both days but other British and Canadian markets will be open today and closed tomorrow.

The mobility of aircraft carriers and their capability for the launching of planes that can carry atomic bombs more than 700 miles inland from an enemy's seacoast are two characteristic that the Navy is stressing to Congress this week.

The general counsel and the chief investigator for the State Crime Commission told yesterday of their dealings with Mrs. Anna B. Wentworth prior to the day last September when the Staten Island housewife testified before the commission.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, largest chain grocery organization, operating 4,583 retail-food stores in the United States and Canada, had the largest sales in its history in the fiscal year ended with February.

The Board of Estimate postponed yesterday until 10:30 A. M. Tuesday a scheduled public hearing of the offers of three private bus companies to take over and operate the city's five bus lines in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee called on the Department of Justice today to take "prompt and vigorous action" on the surplus tanker deals that have involved Newbold Morris of New York, ousted corruption investigator of the Administration; former Representative Joseph E. Casey, Democrat of Massachusetts, and others.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, May 29 -- A North Korean officer held as a prisoner of war on this island was killed and another prisoner was wounded in an accidental volley fired from a guard tower today, a few hours after British and American troops had driven into the same Communist compound with a tear gas barrage and broken up a demonstration of defiance.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended May 24 totaled 761,647 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 7,274 cars or 1 per cent more than for the preceding week, 50,152 cars or 6.2 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 19,279 cars or 2.5 fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce today continued to report signs of a slight pick-up in business in April.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission suspended four proposed increases in wholesale natural gas rates today, which would have totaled more than $50,000,000 a year.

We remember today the dead of all our wars, but more particularly those for whom our grief is freshest -- those of the Second World War and those of the present fighting in Korea. These war dead passed from life at the moment of their greatest strength, in everything except the last deed unfulfilled.
TOKYO, May 29 (AP) -- United Nations officers in a position to know said today a Communist force of just under 1,000,000 men was capable of mounting a spring offensive in Korea without warning.
LONDON, May 29 -- Business dwindled further today in advance of the Whitsun holiday week-end but prices mostly held firm.

DEVON, Pa., May 29 -- Kor-vee, chestnut gelding owned by W. J. Brewster of Southern Pines, N. C., and Escapade, a chestnut mare belonging to Templeton Smith of Pittsburgh, won championships at the fifty-sixth annual Devon horse show today.
MOSES LAKE, Wash., May 29 -- Three rockets were fired into the darkness last night just before midnight from a homesite on a 120-acre farm tract three miles north of this town.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 29 (AP) Miss Helene Frances Kidd, 19 years old, a Baltimore College girl, is the new toast of the Navy. She is the "Color Girl" for June Week at the Naval Academy, a celebration that begins Saturday and ends next Friday with the graduation of 783 midshipmen.

The Supreme Court's opinion deciding that there is nothing unconstitutional about regaling passengers in buses with radio commercials and the recordings of Johnnie Ray may be sound law but it could lead to an awful lot of ulcers.

Among the recently opened art exhibitions is a memorial show at the Willard Gallery of paintings from 1933 to 1948 by a tragic artist, Donald Forbes. In an introduction to the catalogue, Christopher Lazare comments that the story of the artist's life reads like an inverted Horatio Alger story.

The famous old Suburban Handicap, which dates back to 1884 at Sheepshead Bay, is to have its sixty-sixth running today at Belmont Park. It's a $50,000-added race over the mile-and-a-quarter course. It has drawn a field of ten.

Graduates of the Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart were urged at the institution's 111th annual commencement yesterday to oppose trends toward materialism and secularism. The exercises were held in Benziger Hall on the campus at Convent Avenue and 133d Street.

The only book published today is "Water: A Study of Its Properties, Its Constitution, Its Circulation on the Earth and Its Utilization by Man," by Sir Cyril S. Fox. It is published by the Philosophical Library and sells for $8.75.

Grocery manufacturers denied yesterday that higher ceilings on certain groceries will result in price increases to consumers. It was represented in Washington on Wednesday that the nation's food budget would go up about $100, 000,000 as a result of the raised O. P. S. ceilings.

John Christopher De Venuta, whose accomplice testimony last March convicted William Sutton and Thomas Kling of a Queens bank robbery, was himself sentenced yesterday, but sentence is to be stayed so long as he remains on good behavior in the future.
Preparations for the week-end dominated commodity futures markets yesterday. Only in cottonseed oil was volume at an important level.
It paid many motorists in Brooklyn to contribute a pint of blood yesterday. They were able to "flout" the law and were not obliged to notify their offices of their absence.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 29 -- At commencement ceremonies today Sarah Lawrence College conferred Master and Bachelor of Arts degrees on seventy-three young women and headl criticisms of the recent attacks by the American Legion on the scope of the college's "academic freedom."
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The International Materials Conference today freed zinc from any further allocations controls.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 29 -- Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, former women's metropolitan champion, and Leslie Daggett, former Columbia golfer, captured the low gross prize in the Metropolitan Association mixed foursome tourney today.

Four veterans who admitted submitting false claims to the Veterans Administration for tuition to a beauty school they never attended were sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan to thirty to sixty days in jail.
DETROIT, May 29 (AP) -- The nation's auto makers will build 150,000 more cars in the current second quarter than governmental quotas of 1,050,000 call for, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

BOB CHRISTENBERRY, the boxing commissioner, recently penned a blistering attack on the mobsters who exert a disproportionate and undue influence on the Manly Art of Self-Defense. Since he named names and pulled no punches, it was a scathing indictment of at least one unholy fragment of the fisticuff industry. But the crusading commissioner -- may his shadow never grow less -- has arrived on the scene one generation too late.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 29 (AP) -- Military officers of twelve countries tonight said farewell to the man who organized them into the nerve center of the biggest peacetime defense buildup in European history.

A survey by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics indicated yesterday that the weekly earnings of most office workers in this city had gone up twice as fast as the cost of living in the last four years.

MOSCOW, May 29 -- Pravda declared today that the German people now must "take its destiny into its own hands" and achieve a just peace treaty answering its national aspirations regardless of the policy and program of the Western powers.
ST. LOUIS, May 29 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt of Durham, N. C., and Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago took the eighteen-hole lead in the $15,000 Western open golf tournament today with two-under-par 68's.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- President Truman said today that he and a group of historians were studying plans which would prevent the disorderly scattering of historical Presidential papers after a Chief Executive left office.
Prices of cotton futures rose 22 to 38 points net on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, led by the strength in July and October.
ROME, May 29 (AP) -- King Baudouin of Belgium and Princess Margherita di Savoia-Aosta of Italy were heading tonight for a meeting in Italy that may lead to a royal wedding.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 29 -- Barring some unexpected development in the Korean situation, the 1952 session of the United Nations General Assembly, which is scheduled to open here on Sept. 16, will be postponed until Oct. 14.
PUSAN, Korea, Friday, May 30 (UP) -- President Syngman Rhee today ignored United Nations demands for the lifting of martial law and the release of nine National Assemblymen arrested on his orders.

DETROIT, May 29 (UP) -- Harry Simpson drove home five runs with a grand-slam homer and three singles and Al Rosen chased home four team-mates with two doubles and a single today as the league-leading Indians routed the Tigers, 11 -- 4.

The country, determined to preserve the freedom and security for which its heroic dead made the supreme sacrifice, began yesterday the remembrance of the dead of all wars at Memorial Day exercises. Virtually every community will honor its deceased veterans today.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Following is the vote by which the Senate today rejected, 52 to 18, a proposal to end wage-price controls June 30 -- offered as an amendment to a bill to extend the controls to next March 1.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 29 (AP) -- A spokesman for Grotte Schuur Hospital confirmed today that a 65-year-old colored man suffering from tuberculosis had been taken from the hospital and abandoned on the cape mountainside Tuesday night. A colored person in South African usage is one of mixed race.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 29 -- The West will refuse to permit the participation of Communist China in the United Nations debate on the new western proposals for drastic reduction of the armed forces of the militarily mighty powers.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., May 29 -- Henry Herschel Brickell, prominent editor and literary critic and former Latin America expert for the State Department, ended his life by carbon monoxide today in a locked garage at Acorn Cottage, his home here.

NEVER was an age so self-conscious as this one; never before have so many men taken thought about their bodies, their minds and their souls, their political organizations and social habits, their past and future. One of the most intellectually provocative varieties of this self-analysis, as thousands of readers of Arnold Toynbee's "A Study of History" discovered, is the search for a predictable pattern in history.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Dry weather conditions in the Northwest, disconcerting political developments abroad, both in Korea and in Berlin, and lessened selling pressure combined to make for a stronger tone in the grain markets today. A further upturn in soybeans also helped the grain list.

PRESTWICK, Scotland, May 29 (AP) -- A retired Highland army major, who was critically injured six months ago, today eliminated the defending champion, Dick Chapman, and the United States amateur king, Billy Maxwell, from the British amateur golf championship in a pair of resounding upsets.

With teachers as the recognized supervisors of a major part of the daily activities of young persons, some frank comments on them made recently by teen-agers may be of interest to parents. More than 3,000 suggestions were given by 430 senior high school boys and girls in Solvay, N. Y., when they were asked to complete the statement, "If I were a teacher I would -- ."

STRASBOURG, France, May 29 -- Calling for speed and audacity, Paul-Henri Speak of Belgium today drew applause from both opponents and adherents when he pleaded with the Council of Europe's Assembly to make a European federal union at once in order to save democratic Germany from being drawn, like Czechoslovakia, into the Soviet orbit.

Two groups of American economists -- one at the University of Minnesota, one at Arden, N. Y. -- have recently offered it as their virtually unanimous opinion that, while there may be temporary deviations in the trend from time to time, the outlook for the intermediate term is for continuing inflation.

A stop-gap measure to ease traffic snarls along the congested West Side waterfront between Fifty-seventh and Forty-third Streets will go into effect Wednesday at 8 A. M. when the southbound lanes under the Miller Highway are restricted to pier-bound vehicles.

Corporation Counsel Denis M. Hurley set June 24 yesterday as a hearing date in a claim for $300,000 damages filed on behalf of Miss Margaret Mary Moore. Miss Moore contends that her eye became cancerous while she was held in prison for forty-two days as a witness in the case of William F. Sutton, convicted bank robber.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The White House imposed today a close check on stabilization policy decisions taken in connection with the defense production program.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., May 29 (AP) -- The World Assembly for Moral Re-Armament opened here tonight. More than 1,500 delegates from forty countries are expected during the thirteen-day conference.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- There are still two groups of Communists presumably at work within the Federal Government, Elizabeth Bentley, a former Communist underground agent, told the Senate Internal Security subcommittee this morning.

Unfavorable weather conditions have slowed the sale of popular priced summer dresses in the New York market, and preparations for June have been limited by the dearth of new orders. Manufacturers analyzing the summer season business predicted yesterday that there would be a tight market for dresses if June brought an extended spell of warm weather.

BERLIN, May 29 -- The West Berlin police tonight broke up a demonstration of an estimated total of 6,000 persons against the signature of the Contractual Agreement in Bonn Monday. Roughly 280, whom the West Berlin police believed to be East Berlin Communists, were arrested as they tried to storm into the United States sector.

Detecting a musical in "Ninotchka," Michael Todd is trying to clear the path for its stage production. Melchior Lengyel, author of the original screen story, which was converted into a commercial and artistic film success some years back with Greta Garbo in it, is inclined to agree with Mr. Todd, it was said yesterday by Dr. Edmond Pauker, Mr. Lengyel's agent.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- President Truman indicated today that during his contemplated "whistle-stop" campaign after the Democratic national convention he would call to account the Senators and Representatives responsible for heavy slashes in his $7,900,000,000 Mutual Security Program.

PITTSBURGH, May 29 (UP) -- After nine straight defeats at the hands of left-handers, the Pirates turned on Harry Perkowski today and brought back a 4-to-2 victory over Cincinnati before only 1,070 fans, third smallest turnout in modern history at Forbes Field.

PARIS, May 29 -- The United States found itself shut out of the men's singles in the French national tennis championships today with the defeat of Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., by Jaroslav Drobny.
Expansion of facilities of the Ohio Oil Company this year will require more money than last year's outlay of $38,117,000, J. C. Donnell 2d. president, told the annual meeting yesterday.

Manhattan College, paced by its swift sprinters, is an overwhelming favorite to capture team honors in the seventy-sixth annual Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships, which get under way today at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island with trials in twelve of the sixteen title events.

There are numerous signs that many people have either forgotten or have never understood the mainsprings of private competitive systems such as ours. Max Danish's letter, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 24, is one more evidence of this.
LONDON, May 29 -- The Soviet Embassy announced today that Georgi N. Zarubin, who had been Soviet Ambassador to Britain for the last five years had been recalled to Moscow to assume new duties.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- During the week ended May 28, member bank reserves decreased $460,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- The helmsman of the 10,441-ton tanker Michael told a three-member Coast Guard Board of Inquiry today that the captain and the pilot ran for the lifeboats immediately after she was in collision Saturday night with another tanker, the 987-ton A. C. Dodge.
TRENTON, May 29 -- Clarification of parole rules for young prisoners ended today a twenty-four hour sitdown in a conference room by a State Prison inmates' greivance committee.

Vic Raschi, the Yankee right-hander who seldom loses to the Athletics, twirled a 3-2 victory over Jimmy Dykes' club yesterday at the Stadium. Last beaten by the A's on Aug. 13, 1950, Raschi now owns a 23-and-2 career-long record against the Philadelphians, whom he has downed nine times in a row, including three this season.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) -- Ellis Arnall, head of the Office of Price Stabilization, today listed about eighty commodities ranging from steel to cosmetics for which higher ceiling prices have been requested.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Acting Air Force Chief of Staff, said today Russia had twice as many combat planes as the United States and the growing Soviet air power posed "the most ominous threat this country has ever known."

TOKYO, Friday, May 30 -- North Korean Lieut. Gen. Nam II, senior Communist delegate, lodged a protest today at the Korean truce negotiations at Panmunjom against the accidental killing of one prisoner and the wounding of another at the Koje Island prison camp.

LONDON, May 29 -- Although vast areas of the Middle East are still overrun by swarms of the desert locust, the mature insects have probably penetrated as far as they can, according to daily reports reaching the world anti-locust research center here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 29 -- The United Nations program of technical assistance for underdeveloped countries, which has been gradually gathering momentum, is now fully under way. Secretary General Trygve Lie reported to the United Nations Economic and Social Council today, in fact, that most of the requests for aid now being received were based on the recommendations of experts previously sent out by the United Nations.
" Italy Today," the exhibition of Italian goods at Grand Central Palace, made progress slowly yesterday in getting its products displayed.

General Electric Company has "virtually halted" production of television sets, officials of the receiver division in Syracuse reported yesterday. The near-shut-down involves a lay-off for about a week of 1,100 of the division's 1,900 employes, they said.

There was a slight uplift in Flatbush spirit yesterday when the Dodgers beat the Braves, 7 -- 3, for the sixth time this year without a loss and the Phillies obliged by halting the league-leading Giants, thus reducing the Brooklyn deficit to a game and a half.
ALBANY, May 29 -- The Court of Appeals rejected today an attempt by graded New York City Civil Service employes to claim pay at the prevailing rate in a locality for the same work.

Four new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. "Lydia Bailey," a Twientieth Century-Fox technical adaptation of the Kenneth Roberts novel, with Anne Francis, Dale Robertson, Charles Korvin and William Marshall in the leads, is at the Roxy.

In an extort to end the present armament race that is raising the specter of new war the Western Towers have submitted to the United Nations Disarmament Commission a further proposal setting for the first time definite ceilings on the armed forces of all nations. Under this proposal the United States, Soviet Russia and China would each be permitted to maintain a maximum of 1,500,000 men under arms;

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 -- If confidence could win a race, all of the thirty-three entries would cross the finish line in one big huddle at the thirty-sixth annual 500-mile motor classic here tomorrow. Each driver had a four-leaf clover in his mind's eye today and a stockpile of hope that only defeat can scatter.

LONDON, May 29 -- The General Council of the Trades Union Congress acted today to try to stem the swing of the rank and file of its member unions toward support of Leftist Laborite Aneurin Bevan's opposition to rearmament. The Council reminded its affiliated unions that the official policy of the Trades Union Congress still was to support the rearmament program adopted by the Labor Government when it was in office.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 -- Shipowners sat tight today on their demands for at least a year's contract with the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., as the price of resuming negotiations, while hints came from the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, unaffiliated, that the dockmen might cross the sailors' picket lines during the present coastwise strike.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) -- Secretary of Interior Oscar L. Chapman and Jess Larson, the government's procurement chief, called today for an "aggressive exploration program" to find new supplies of critical minerals in the United States.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 29 -- Mrs. Joseph Nesbitt of the Westchester C. C. overcame a bad start to win low gross honors in a one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association with 46, 38-84 over the Wykagyl C. C. course today.

Truck owner's charged in Supreme Court yesterday that the city had exceeded its constitutional taxing powers in imposing the $5 and $10 tax on motor vehicles because the levy was a burden on interstate commerce.
NEPTUNE, N. J., May 29 -- Mrs. Thomas McDarby of Plainfield scored a 40, 38 -- 78 today to win the Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament at the Jumping Brook Country Club.

Two midtown payroll robberies yesterday netted lone thieves $5,900. In one, the loot, $1,400, was recovered and the alleged thief arrested. In each case, the victim was a woman bookkeeper who had just obtained the money from a bank and was returning to her office.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley placed himself in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination today. Mr. Barkley, who will be 75 years old in November, said that although not an active candidate he would accept the nomination if chosen at the party convention in Chicago.

Domestic and international airlines worked at top speed yesterday to restore canceled flights and return to normal operations, restrictions on aviation fuel having been removed, effective next Tuesday. Some of the lines went back to normal schedules yesterday and others reported they hoped to be at the usual level in time to handle the Memorial Day rush.
Dr. Gilbert E. Doan will become manager of the metallurgical branch of the research department of Koppers Company on Aug. 1.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 29 -- Twelve principal women's organizations in Lebanon today opened a direct attack on gambling.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 29 -- There was no smoke but plenty of fire as a tobacco rebellion flared today in the Economic and Social Council chamber.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm prices rose 1 per cent between mid-April and mid-May.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee voted 6 to 3 today to keep the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in business as the Government's chief lending agency. But it decided to write a number of reforms in the law setting up the agency.

LONDON, May 29 (Reuters) -- British Actors' Equity told the British Broadcasting Corporation today to keep television cameras out of the theatres when there is a paying audience present, because actors can't play simultaneously "to the bloke in the gallery and the Mac before the screen."

BARCELONA, Spain, May 29 -- Catholic workers and employers today prayed for an end of social strife in the world during a mass demonstration of faith held in one of the main squares of this city as part of celebrations of the thirty-fifth International Eucharistic Congress.
Department stores were advised yesterday that they must be willing to take "calculated risks" to lower overhead and increase net profit in a year when this branch of retailing "is very sick indeed."

MAYS LANDING, N. J., May 29 -- Herman {"Stumpy") Orman, alleged Atlantic City gambling kingpin, was indicted today on charges of giving false information in applying for a pistol permit by the special state grand jury investigating official corruption in Atlantic City.

A tract of fourteen acres on Hill Street and Cottage Row in the Town of Oyster Bay, Glen Cove, L. I., has been sold by the Commuters Housing Corporation to the Glen Cove Holding Corporation. The parcel, assessed at $38,350, was sold subject to a purchase money mortgage of $12,500. Lewis Fredericks were the brokers and title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

A petition by the Citizens Union to void the appointment of Robert J. Crews to the recently created $9,000-a-year lifetime post of deputy commissioner of records of City Court was denied by State Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr. Mr. Crews is the brother of John R. Crews, Kings County Republican leader.

Thirty-two boys and girls will pile into their chartered bus at noon today and head back south to Wetumpka, Ala., where the 5,000 inhabitants will shortly be hearing their impressions of New York. They will be mixed.

BAY SHORE, L. I., May 29 -- A convincing victory in the final race of the series today gave Jack Price's Comanche of the Biscayne Bay, Fla., Fleet the championship in the Olympic Star yacht trials held in Great South Bay this week. Price and his crew, John Reide, both of Miami, will represent this country at Helsinki in the Star sailing Olympics late in July.

About 200 refrigeration contractors and service men greeted with enthusiasm yesterday an announcement by Councilman Jack Kranis, Brooklyn Democrat, that he was withdrawing two of four bills dealing with licensing and regulating refrigeration and air-conditioning equipment.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) -- The State Department said today that Linus Pauling, a California scientist who was twice denied permission to travel overseas, has filed his third application for a passport.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 29 -- The Saigon Government today prohibited the export of rice from Vietnam for an indefinite period and ordered the lifting of the four-year blockade against rice, and other products of the trans-Bassac region of South Vietnam.

PARIS, May 29 -- The French Government indicated to Secretary of State Dean Acheson today that unless the future of French defense industries were assured by a definite promise of further United States financial aid, it would be difficult for the French to agree to the development of the defense industries in West Germany now planned by the Western powers.

One thousand former citizen-soldiers, members of the American Legion posts of the Metropolitan and New York Life Insurance Companies, took part in a parade and noon-hour service in Madison Square Park yesterday in memory of their comrades who died in the World Wars and on the Korean battlefields.

The Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York and its affiliated agencies will begin on July 2 a summer camp program that will provide free or part-free vacations for nearly 5,000 city children. Free vacations will be given to more than 1,200 children selected by the free camp department of the New York Catholic Charities.

The country cousins can teach the city slickers something, it was proved once again at the first Achievement Night of the Queens Home Bureau, held Wednesday night. The organization is the first unit in this city of the New York State College of Home Economics Extension Service, originally formed to help farm women. Manhattan and the Bronx may soon have similar home bureaus.

RICHMOND, Va., May 29 (A--Z Reynolds Metals Company announced today it has named its rnewest aluminum reduction plant, ]under construction in Arkansas, in honor of the late Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War. Mr. Patterson, general counsel and director of the company, was killed in a plane crash at lq]liTbeth, N. J.

QUITO, Ecuador, May 29 -- President Galo Plaza Lasso said today that he expects peaceful elections on Sunday and is convinced Ecuador's armed forces will accept the virdict whatever it may be and support the constitution. Virtually all other sources are much less optimistic than the President about the military's willingness to accept a result that they disapprove.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- President Truman vetoed the offshore lands bill today on grounds that it constituted "a free gift of immensely valuable resources * * * to the states which happen to be located nearest to them."
ATHENS, May 29 (Reuters) -- Greek women got the franchise today, ending a battle waged sporadically for twenty years.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, May 30 (AP) -- Furious Red artillery fire yesterday for the second straight day raked the Korean front, where powerful Communist forces of troops and tanks are in position to strike.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Defense Department officials struck back at the National Guard Association today, denying charges of intending to "Federalize" the Guard and expressing "astonishment" that its leaders had withdrawn their support for the Armed Forces Reserve Act.
Repayments by the textile and apparel trades were the major influence in a seasonal decline of business borrowings from New York banks which cut commercial loans $36,000,000 last week.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Friday, May 30 -- Four North Korean prisoners of war were killed and three were wounded today in renewed rioting on Koje Island off southeast Korea. The riot was the second in twenty-four hours involving prisoners of war and interned civilians.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 27 quotes from an address by Dr. Arthur M. Master, retiring president of the Medical Society of the County of New York, in which he expresses his personal disapproval of prepaid group practice of medicine.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 29 -- Farley Granger, on loan from Samuel Goldwyn Productions, will report to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer on June 7 to play the wealthy big-town boy who falls in love with Jane Powell in "Small Town Girl."
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- A last-minute revised offer resulted today in the postponement until Tuesday of final action on the sale of The Cincinnati Enquirer.

The Eastman Kodak Company, largest manufacturer of photographic equipment and supplies in the world, will permit all stores selling its products to set the prices they charge their customers. Eastman Kodak notified its dealers throughout the country yesterday that it has terminated all "fair trade" contracts in the forty-five states having "fair trade" laws.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- President Truman called on Congress today to approve a $4,200,000,000 expansion of the atomic program, which is now well on the way of developing atomic artillery and other atomic weapons that can be used tactically on the battlefield.

Too many cookbooks lack an honest reason for being, and too many are written by what a friend of ours calls the "typewriter cooks." An appetizing exception is a spiral-bound volume, "Charleston Receipts" (Walker Evans Cogswell, 308 pp., $2.50).

We are delighted to see Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh handing down severe fines and even workhouse terms to traffic law violators who have proved themselves flagrant outlaws. But law-abiding citizens must wonder how the persistent violators get away with it unscathed for years before the law catches up with them.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Industrial production during May dropped to the lowest point since last July and well under the average for last year, the Federal Reserve Board estimated today. The Board said a preliminary survey indicates the production index for May will be 214 per cent of the 1935-39 average.

NASHVILLE, May 29 (UP) -- Tennessee Democrats, in a rapid-fire, fifty-two-minute convention, pledged the state's twenty-eight national convention votes today to Senator Estes Kefauver in his bid for the Presidential nomination.

The stock market staged a typical pre-holiday performance yesterday. Price alterations in only a few instances varied from the fractional range, with the composite rate raised 0.14 point, although a few more issues declined than advanced.

VIENNA, May 30 -- An announcement today by the Rumanian official press agency that Vice Premiers Vasile Luca and Teohari Georgescu had been expelled from the Central Committee of the Rumanian Communist party indicated that Rumania, like Czechoslovakia, was to have a purge with a show trial to follow.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 30 (AP) -- The Army's finest track and field athletes and college and club stars today began a two-day meet serving as another warm-up for the United States Olympic trials. The athletic carnival will determine both the All-Army and Pacific Amateur Athletic Union championships.
BERLIN, May 30 (UP) -- The texts of two United States notes delivered today to Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, Soviet Control Commissioner:

PRINCETON, N. J., May 30 -- At least a half dozen of Princeton University's thirty-seven retired professors are continuing their contributions to education and leading lives hardly less active than when they were reporting for daily classes.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- Civil aviation is opposing a proposed switch-over July 1 from statute measurements to nautical miles and knots.
CLEVELAND, May 30 (UP) -- Minnie Minoso, sidelined with injuries for twelve days, crashed back into the White Sox line-up with three home runs today to help beat the Indians, 7 -- 2 and 3 -- 1.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., May 30 -- Six Communist members of the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations struck a discordant note here today at a memorial service for Franklin D. Roosevelt by walking out over a reference to Soviet Russia as a major threat to world peace.
Two young City College students were assured early yesterday morning that it took more than a college education to drive a bus. It takes experience, said the police.
SIOUX FALLS, S. D., May 30 (UP) -- Col. Joseph J. Foss, who shot down twenty-six Japanese planes and won the Medal of Honor in World War II, will be released tomorrow from the Air Force.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- A bill designed to prevent a drop in Government support prices for wheat, corn and cotton was approved unanimously today by a Senate agricultural subcommittee.

In the opinion of United States Government officials, Ana Pauker's reign as Communist boss of Rumania is now over and Gen. Emil Bodnaras, Minister of Defense, is now the Kremlin's No. 1 factotum in that country.

As a result of the urgent and increasing need for new tanker tonnage, not only for commercial use but also as a national defense measure, the Federal Maritime Administration has approved in principle proposals by United States companies to build large, high-speed tankers once they have transferred equivalent old tonnage to foreign flag and registry, under strict supervision.

LONDON, May 30 -- British commonwealth and North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries were accused of "dragging their feet" on defense and letting Britain bear an unfair share of the burden, in a discussion on rearmament in the House of Commons today.

QUITO, Ecuador, May 30 -- An agreement for United States aid in the agricultural development of Ecuador under the Point Four program was signed here this afternoon. The United States Ambassador, Paul C. Daniels and the Ecuadorean Foreign Minister, Dr. Neftali Ponce paved the way yesterday with an exchange of notes.

ROME, May 30 -- A simple but impressive Memorial Day ceremony was held this morning at the cemetery of Nettuno in honor of about 8,000 American war dead buried there. Most of them fell in the landing at Nettuno and near-by Anzio on Jan. 22, 1944.
TORONTO, May 30 -- One of the world's biggest trading posts, the Canadian International Trade Fair, will open its doors for the fifth time on Monday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has set June 6 for oral argument of stockholders on the reorganization plan filed by Arkansas Natural Gas Corporation. The plan provides for the creation of two new companies, namely, the Arkansas Louisiana Gas Company and the Arkansas Fuel Oil Company.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 30 -- Northern Pacific Railway will henceforth enter into agreements with oil operators in the Williston Basin on a joint-operating instead of a royalty basis. The new policy was announced this week by Leroy H. Hines, the company's new vice president for oil development.

ST. LOUIS, May 30 (AP) -- The Tigers broke a 5-5 tie in the twelfth inning of the second game with two bases-loaded singles for an 8-5 victory today after the Browns captured the opener of the twin bill, 3 to 2, in the ninth with a double by Joe Demaestri.
RYE, N. Y., May 30 -- Fifty-six sailing craft were out on Long Island Sound today in the regatta of the American Yacht Club, the second of the Association championship series.

DETROIT, May 30 (AP) -- Sickle's Image, Clarence Hartwick's 4-year-old sprinter, kept her head in a day of upsets and records at Detroit race track today and won the $7,500 F. M. Alger Memorial feature.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -- The fastest 500-mile auto race in the history of the Indianapolis Speedway was won through an accident today.
LONDON, May 30 -- The customary balancing of books before the Whitsun Holiday week-end did not prevent the stock exchange from recording a further long list of falls today.

BONN, Germany, May 30 (Reuters) -- A German civilian decoration, borrowed from Prussia in 1918 but later banned by Hitler, was revived today, exactly 110 years after its foundation by King Friedrich Wilhelm IV of Prussia.

Roland La Starza, Bronx heavyweight, scored a decisive victory over Dan Bucceroni of Philadelphia in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. Dropping his foe five times in all, La Starza punched his way to a decision by unanimous vote over the fighter who had out-pointed him last December.
ELIZABETH CITY, N. C., May 30 -- This coastal city stages its annual Albemarle Potato Festival tomorrow but the potatoes had to be "imported" under armed guard.
SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, May 31 (AP) -- Two Russian-made jet fighters were shot down over North Korea early today by United States Sabre jets.
The 17,600-ton Barrett, the Navy's first fully air-conditioned troop transport, will arrive here at 9 A. M. today to join the Atlantic Fleet of the Military Sea Transportation Service.

WINDSOR, Ont., May 30 (Canadian Press) -- An eighty-two-hour truce arranged today between Ford of Canada and striking office workers will result in a reopening of the Ford plant, closed since May 23, company officials said.

PARIS, May 30 -- A majority of French workers today ignored a Communist-inspired call for strikes and demonstrations in protest against the arrest and indictment yesterday of Jacques Duclos, leader of French Reds, for an attempt against the internal security of the state.
A number of new lamps designed for specific purposes are now available

Officials of the International Bank for Reconstruction have announced that Canada has consented to the use of all of its original capital subscription to that institution. The Dominion's quota was $65 million. Of this, however, only $24 million had been made available up to this time. Speaking for the I. B. R., Eugene R. Black, its president, finds the Dominion's action a highly significant step.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday explained that action on the voiding of the Chuck Davey-Carmen Basilio fight in Syracuse Thursday night would be taken when the official score cards of that bout arrive here.

CHICAGO, May 30 (UP) -- Backing superb two-hit pitching of Bob Rush with a fifteen-hit spree, the Cubs swept a doubleheader from the Reds by winning the nightcap, 11 to 0, today. The Cubs took the opener, 7 to 6.
The last phase of the transcontinental Weathervane golf tournament will be staged today at the Scarsdale Golf Club, Hartsdale, N. Y. and tomorrow at the Deepdale Golf Club, Great Neck, L. I.

A proposed two-year contract negotiated with the help of Daniel Kornblum, city Director of Labor Relations, was ratified yesterday afternoon by several hundred members of Local 21,381 of the Funeral Directors, Embalmers and Undertakers Union, A. F. L., ending the threat of a strike set for this morning.

" Young Man With Ideas," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer comedy with Glenn Ford, Ruth Roman, Denise Darcel and Nina Foch, has been scheduled to have its local premiere at the Globe on Friday. The offering was produced by Gottfried Reinhardt and William H. Wright and directed by Mitchell Leisen from a screen play by Arthur Sheekman.

ROCQUENCOURT, May 30 (AP) -- General Eisenhower is to take off at 2 P. M. (9 A. M. Eastern daylight time) tomorrow for Washington. Upon his arrival there at 4 P. M., Sunday, he will get a seventeen-gun military welcome and the glad hand of political backers seeking to get him nominated as the Republican party's Presidential choice.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 31 - Sporadic rioting broke out last night in four large Japanese cities and smaller communities throughout the country on the anniversary of the attack two years ago on United States soldiers celebrating Memorial Day in the Imperial Palace plaza here -- a date set aside annually for special observance by the Japanese-Communist party.
FRANKFURT, Germany, May 30 -- "This is 1939 and if the Americans persist and the German treaties are ratified it will be 1940." This is the propaganda line the Russians are pushing in Europe.

The Italian elections last Sunday were blanketed by thunderously momentous events elsewhere. The vote was significant as an indication of the strength of the Government that has ruled for the past four years, but while the ballots were being counted the head of that Government, Premier Alcide De Gasperi, was in Paris signing the revolutionary document which puts Italian and German troops into a common army with the French and Benelux forces.

Two last-gasp rallies failed and the Yankees fell twice before the Athletics yesterday at the Stadium. Bowing, 2 -- 1, to Bobby Shantz in fourteen innings, and by 4 -- 2 to Bob Hooper and Carl Scheib in the afterpiece, Casey Stengel's club dropped into the second division.

After participating in the most momentous and most successful international conferences since the end of the war Secretary Acheson returned to Washington yesterday to receive the thanks of President Truman, in which the great majority of Americans, irrespective of party, will join.

Albert D. Lasker, advertising pioneer and chairman of the United States Shipping Board after World War I, died at 8 A. M. yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, at the age of 72. His home was at 29 Beekman Place.

I could wish that your editorial writer had shown greater familiarity with your newspaper's excellent series on the middle-income housing shortage. He might then have been more sympathetic toward the tenants of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's Stuyvesant Town.

BONN, Germany, May 30 -- The Federal Cabinet approved today the conventions on West German sovereignty signed Monday by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and the Western Big Three foreign ministers. The Cabinet then sent the texts of the conventions to the Bundesrat or upper house of Parliament for study.

A 31-year-old Queens patrolman was accidentally shot with his own revolver in the right side of his face yesterday by his brother-in-law when the relative tried to help him put on his uniform. The bullet lodged in the policeman's left jaw and he was taken to St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, where his condition was listed as fair.

PARIS, May 30 -- Virgil Thomson's "Four Saints in Three Acts," with libretto by Gertrude Stein, was presented for the first time in Paris this evening in the Champs-Elysees Theatre as the final operatic offering of the International Exposition of "Masterpieces of the Twentieth Century," given under the auspices of the Conference for Cultural Freedom, which comes to an end this week.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 30 -- A Cardinal and four Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church will take part in the forty-second annual convention of the Catholic Press Association, to be held here at Notre Dame University June 18 to 20.

PRESTWICK, Scotland, May 30 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, bidding for his third title, and Harvie Ward of Tarboro, N. C., registered double-barrel triumphs today to produce the third straight all-American final in the British amateur golf championship.

QUITO, Ecuador, May 30 -- While the government was taking measures to insure that the Presidential elections of Sunday be peaceful, an organization of retired military men warned the Ecuadorian people today that the Army "cannot remain indifferent" if the Conservative party candidate wins.
DEVON, Pa., May 30 -- Six champions were named and twelve trophies awarded during morning, afternoon and evening programs at the fifty-sixth annual Devon horse show today.
BOSTON, May 30 (UP) -- The Red Sox split a double-header with Washington today, losing the first game, 5 -- 2, and winning the nightcap, 5 -- 3.

BARCELONA, Spain, May 30 -- Pierre Cardinal Gerlier, Archbishop of Lyon, today called for greater social justice and more determined efforts by governments and peoples as basic prerequisites for the establishment of permanent peace in the world.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in May was the smallest for any month since August, 1949 and the dullest for a corresponding month since May of that year.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 31 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,266 for Friday's operations:

May I congratulate your staff on the editorial "Dominican Dynasty" which appeared in THE TIMES of May 20. I think that with the exception of two basic historical errors that editorial renders a good service to my country and to the free world.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 30 (AP) -- The Central Bank of Chile announced tonight that copper shipments to the United States, which had been suspended because of a price dispute, will be resumed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 30 -- Charles Laughton will bring his visit in England to a halt sooner than he had expected, having signed with Columbia to join Rita Hayworth in "Salome, the Dance of the Seven Veils," slated to go before the Technicolor cameras on June 17, with William Dieterle directing.

New public offerings of bonds in May amounted to $1,022,147,000, the second largest volume for any month since 1926, and was exceeded only by the $1,051,520,000 in April. Stock offerings were the largest for a May since 1946.
Five persons were injured at 3:30 P. M. yesterday in Brooklyn when an ambulance, taking a 3-year-old to a hospital, collided with an auto and turned upside down.
KANSAS CITY, Kan., May 30 (UP) -- A change in travel plans was announced today to give General Eisenhower a night's rest here before he went on to his Abilene homecoming June 4.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Uniform railroad rates on all classified freight traffic east of the Rocky Mountains became effective today.

Two Brooklyn youths were arrested early yesterday morning on charges of having held up two automobiles and a tavern in their home borough. Both longshoremen with police records, they are William A. Sorenson, 21 years old, of 472 Forty-first Street, and Howard C. Lotito, 19, of 899 Fourth Avenue.

A message for Whitsunday from the presidents of the World Council of Churches will be read from many Protestant pulpits tomorrow when the Christian Pentecost will be celebrated. It commemorates the creation of the Christian Church in Jerusalem fifty days after Easter.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 -- Gov. Oren E. Long of Hawaii today asked the Matson Navigation Company and the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., to clear two ships for transport of essential food and drugs to Hawaii during the current sailors' strike.

ST. LOUIS, May 30 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago blew an opportunity to match his first round two-under-par 68, but managed to gain undisputed leadership in the forty-ninth Western Open Golf tournament today with a 138 total for thirty-six holes.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 31 -- The Communist armistice delegates at Panmunjom dropped a hint yesterday of further riots in store among rebellious prisoners in the United Nations stockades in South Korea.

New York City and the nation have lost one of their great citizens in the death of Albert Lasker. His biography is like a Horatio Alger story, but it is much more than that. A cub reporter at the age of 15, he rose to be the head of one of America's greatest advertising firms.

In Paris the other day we saw a horrifying sight -- the activation of the propaganda lie. The riots in the streets of the French capital were not really a protest against the arrival of General Ridgway to assume the supreme command of the North Atlantic Treaty forces; that was only a pretext for organized demonstrations of Soviet anger at the signing of the treaties liberating West Germany and setting up a European army.
CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- An anti-trust prosecutor, Willis L. Hotchkiss, said today the Government would decide "shortly" on new procedures in a suit seeking to break up the du Pont industrial empire.

PUSAN, Korea, Saturday, May 31 (AP) -- Home Minister Lee Bum Suk said yesterday that eleven persons had been arrested for conspiring to assassinate President Syngman Rhee and other South Korean leaders.

STRASBOURG, France, May 30 -- After adopting the proposals of Anthony Eden, Britain's Foreign Secretary, for associating the European Defense Community and other groups with the Council of Europe, the Consultative Assembly tonight passed a compromise resolution that urged the six European Governments involved to entrust either to the Schuman Plan Assembly or the Council of Europe the task of drafting the statute for a supranational authority for Europe.
Brooklyn and Queens honored their war dead yesterday with parades and memorial services in which tribute was paid to the American soldier for his fight for freedom.
As a pleasant reminder of the culinary possibilities of rum, the distiller of a Jamaica rum recently held a Caribbean garden party in the Manahattan home of food writer Poppy Cannon.

PLANS are now completed for the tenth United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament, a club team competition, scheduled to be held this year Aug. 26 to 28 inclusive, with tournament headquarters at New London, Conn., and it is expected that at least thirty teams will compete.
The following is a round-up of items useful to those who spend many of the summer days eating and living in the out-of-doors:

J. C. Berkwit Co., dealers in marine and contractors' equipment, reports that it was the high bidder for forty-six locomotives originally built for Russia under lend-lease and placed on sale by the Property Disposal Branch of the United States Army, Schenectady General Depot.

BERLIN, May 30 (AP) -- East German Communist leaders, in a new outburst of threats, called tonight for "extreme national resistance" and sabotage through labor strikes, against the West German-Allied contractual agreement. German civil wah was mentioned as a possibility.

LONDON, May 30 -- Acting on behalf of the public school teachers who are solidly against the principle of the closed shop in their profession, the National Union of Teachers handed in today the resignations of three-fourths of the teachers in the public school system of Durham County.

Advancing all its candidates into today's semi-finals and finals with nary a casualty, Manhattan College's favored squad yesterday took a firm grip on team honors in the seventy-sixth annual Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championship.

SUDBURY, Ont., May 30 -- Plans for increasing production at the four major steel mills in Canada will make the nation practically self sufficient, according to D. S. Holbrook, executive vice president of the Algoma Steel Corporation of Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

TORONTO, May 30 (AP) -- Prices made little headway today toward the stock market's close after moderate mid-afternoon support bolstered selected base metal issues. Industrials, golds and western oils showed little trend.

WEST HILLS, L. I., May 30 -- Enshrinement of Walt Whitman's birthplace, the object of three organized campaigns in the last thirty years, will be accomplished when the 142-year-old farmhouse is officially opened at dedication ceremonies tomorrow at 2 P. M.
St. John's University clinched the Metropolitan Baseball Conference championship yesterday by defeating Wagner College, 3 -- 0, in the final league game at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, Queens.
A new method of packing garments has been instituted by Max Udell Sons Co, Inc., manufacturer of Gramercy Park Clothes, it was announced yesterday.

ITHACA, N. Y., May 30 (AP) -- Twenty-five students at Cornell University, suspended for their part in a broadcast of fake war bulletins, will seek reinstatement through a student-faculty committee, The Cornell Sun, campus newspaper reported tonight.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 30 -- The soup pots were boiling again today in the huge plant of the Campbell Soup Company, which had been made idle for seventeen days by a strike of 5,000 members of the Packinghouse Workers, C. I. O.

Bonds called for payment in May before maturity totaled $44,123,000, compared with $17,036,000 a month earlier. Last month's volume was strengthened by payments totaling $21,500,000 of foreign issues, which accounted for approximately 49 per cent of the month's payments.

Trieste must not remain a no man's land to be contended for or divided by Italy and Yugoslavia. Trieste in an essential part of Middle Europe, its traditional and natural port. Only the implementation of the status of the Trieste area as a free territory will do justice to thin basic fact, will guarantee equal liberties and prosperity to the people of the territory and remove the present tensions in and around the area.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 30 (Reuters) -- The International Council for Christian Leadership said today that materialism and communism, brought about by the "failure and faltering" of Christendom, were responsible for the world crisis.
PHILADELPHIA, May 30 -- The Giants were again skidding in the wrong direction today when they finally righted themselves in time to head West still in possession of first place.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 30 (UP) -- Max Hooper's pinch hit past short in the last of the eleventh scored Bruce Frazier from first and gave Illinois a 5-4 victory over Ohio University today in the first of a best two-out-of-three N.C.A.A. district play-off.

Arbitration as a principle for adjusting disputes, whether industrial or commercial, is making steady advances. Several years ago the most contentious group of unions in the American Federation of Labor, those engaged in building and construction, set up, in conjunction with employers, machinery to settle disputes among themselves and made arbitration the final step.
EPSOM DOWNS, England, May 30 (AP) -- Capt. A. M. Keith's English-bred Frieze, a 100 to 7 shot, today won the 174th running of the rich Oaks by three lengths.

On record sales of $521,311,426, the American Stores Company and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $5,054,268 in the fiscal year ended on March 29, according to the annual report issued yesterday. The company operates one of the country's larger chains of service grocery stores and self-service markets.

The appropriate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade state, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

BERLIN, May 30 -- The High Commissioners of the United States, Britain and France asked the Soviet Union today to cancel the "series of obstructive measures" in Germany imposed in recent days by Soviet and East German authorities.

The chances are favorable that the important directorial assignment for Robert Nathan's new play. "Jezebel's Husband," will fall to Sherman Marks, a newcomer who never has been represented in the New York legitimate theatre.

PARIS, May 30 -- Frank Sedgman of Australia and Jaroslav Drobny, self-exiled Czech now from Egypt, reached the title round of the French tennis championship today and Doris Hart and Shirley Fry qualified for an all-American women's final.

KATONAH, N. Y., May 30 -- Henry A. Wallace, former Vice President, came from his farm seven miles from here today to take part in Katonah's Memorial Day ceremonies at a World War monument and make a plea for complete national unity regardless of "very great differences of opinion'' concerning the war in Korea and other international affairs.

" Man to Man," an attack on the income-tax laws by Bernard N. Ward, is published today by Caxton Printers of Caldwell, Idaho. The book, based on the author's thirty years' experience as a certified public accountant, describes what he terms inequities as well as waste, confusion and expense in enforcing the income-tax laws.

Many dwellings marked for demolition under the city's slum clearance program could be made decently habitable and thus help relieve the housing shortage, Charles C. Platt, architect and former president of the Municipal Art Society, said yesterday.

Gil Hodges hit a home run in each game, got five hits altogether and drove in eight runs to lead the Dodgers to a double victory over the Boston Braves, 5 -- 4 and 11 -- 2, before 30,703 of the delighted Flat-bush faithful at Ebbets Field yesterday.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., May 30 (AP) -- Ernie Seubert, 23-year-old Brooklyn insurance clerk, outpedaled seventy-nine cyclists today to capture the ninth running of the fifty-mile tour of Somerville, America's premiere bicycle racing competition.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 30 -- Virgil Sherrill and his guest, Richard Harris of Apawamis, scored 29, 33 -- 62, eight strokes under par with the help of a full handicap allowance, to win the qualifying medal of the Meadow Brook's invitation four-ball golf tournament today.

Arthur H. Vandenberg Jr., returning from a five-day visit to Paris, said here yesterday that he would be a sort of political secretary to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower upon the latter's return to this country on Sunday.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- In the face of the threat of Russian imperialism the "underprivileged" of the free world, at home and abroad, must have tangible and continuing evidence of this country's spiritual and moral dedication to the cause of serving mankind, Nelson A. Rockefeller, president of the American International Association for Economic and Social Development, declared here today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 30 -- The Natal Provincial Council (the State Parliament) will make the first move on Monday to secede from the Union of South Africa if the Government attempts to enforce a bill to segregate and restrict the franchise of colored or half-caste persons in Cape Province.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 30 (AP) -Palatine Stable's Woodchuck took the measure of Harborvale Stable's Dark Peter and eight other 3-year-olds by winning the $20,000 added Camden Handicap before a crowd of 40,196 at Garden State Park.

PRESTWICK Scotland, May 30 (UP) -- Charles (Chick) Evans, the 61-year-old Chicago golfer who twice won the United States amateur championship, was confined to bed tonight with a blood clot on his brain and without any memory of his fourth-round defeat Wednesday in the British amateur championship.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 30 -- On assuming today the supreme command of the Allied powers in Europe, General Matthew B. Ridgway found himself plunged immediately into a dispute among top Allied strategists as to how to command the Mediterranean and how to link it with the defense of the Middle East.

Undistributed new corporate securities in the hands of underwriters are estimated at more than $100,000,000. As for the tax exempt-interest bonds of local government, the unsold float approximates $250,000,000.
SEATTLE, Wash., May 30 -- The second "fireball" in three weeks flashed across the sky today and exploded in a shower of sparks.

LOS ANGELES, May 30 (AP) -- A museum to house the hundreds of historical souvenirs collected by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower during his long career is out of the planning stage, Welton Becket, supervisory architect of the project, announced last night, It is to be built in Abilene, Kan., the general's home town, and he will be present for the corner-stone-laying June 4, Mr. Becket said.
GENEVA, May 30 -- For the first time since mid-1950 a serious movement to establish a number of European currencies on a basis of full convertibility is afoot.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP) -- The Government estimated today that 750,000 Americans would travel abroad this year and would spend more than $1,000,000,000 to see the world.
An armed robber killed a bakery owner and wounded a baker in a hold-up at 2:30 A. M. yesterday at the Tasty Talk Baking Company, 1723 Amsterdam Avenue, at 145th Street, and then escaped with $110.

The old and the new constantly are colliding with each other. City streets -- perhaps new in surface, but old in dimensions -- and the latest products of Detroit assembly lines come together, and the result here as in many other cities is something that has to be seen to be appreciated.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 30 (AP) -- Admiral Drake scored an upset victory in the $50,000 Argonaut Handicap at Hollywood Park today, with the favored Miche second and Moonrush third. The time for the mile and one-sixteenth was 1:42.

LONDON, May 30 -- The administration of the prisoner of war camps in Korea was assailed by Opposition speakers today in the House of Commons. Replying, Minister of State Selwyn Lloyd repudiated an attack on the United States conduct of the Korean campaign that he said had been implicit in the remarks of Tom Driberg, Laborite.
Drivers and guards on armored cars in this area were set to strike next week against four major companies that haul 75 per cent of bank and payroll shipments.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 30 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith of New Jersey said here today that while the ultimate hope of a United States of Europe might not be immediately within the realm of possibility, we should keep that hope and vision in mind.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., May 30 -In weather not fit for man or beast and with waves and rollers big enough to rock a Queen Mary, a fleet of a dozen fragile little speed boats started in the sixth annual John E. Fite Memorial forty-three-mile marathon today.

It was a normal Memorial Day evening yesterday on the Central Park Mall. The Naumburg Orchestra started its annual series of four concerts. The weather was clear, though with a touch of chill. Trees were well in leaf and people were lying beneath them, listening to the music, which was spread to a far distance through an amplifying system.

NEWARK, May 30 -- Mrs. Anna Nancy De Nike, 36 years old, of 294 Van Buren Street, pleaded innocent today to a charge of murder in the strangulation of 4-year-old Mary Louise Wargo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Wargo of 245 Van Buren St.

Melancholy Taps, murmured prayers and the quiet-shattering volleys of rifle squads mingled yesterday in Memorial Day exercises from Arlington Cemetery to the graves of American dead in far-off Pacific atolls and remote Australia.

CLEVELAND, May 30 -- The Republican and Democratic parties were denounced as "rotten to the core" by Samuel H. Friedman of New York today as the Socialist party opened its twenty-eighth national convention here.

I have been reading in the Pacific Stars and Stripes accounts of the so-called "panty craze," or "panty raids." It angered me quite a little. What kind of young men are growing up in our country -- the leading nation of the world, standing for democracy, civilization and refinement ?

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Comdr. Ivan Monk of the Navy's Bureau of Ships obtained Patent No. 2,597,890 this week for a rotary engine powered by atmospheric energy. It will run indefinitely without fuel, he says, and will operate amusement and advertising devices, toys, clocks and other small machinery.

Memorial Day traffic moved fairly smoothly yesterday on city and suburban streets and highways. There were occasional tie-ups, especially along the New Jersey shore and in sections of Rockland County, N. Y., but the motorist stream flowed effortlessly on the whole.

TENAFLY, N. J., May 30 -- A last minute entry, Alex X. McGhee and his guest, Fred Schambch, club champion at White Beeches, won the medal of the third annual J. Elmer Westervelt Memorial member-guest golf tourney at the Knickerbocker Country Club today with a 2-under-par 70.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, said today he had instructed the staff of the Senate Elections Subcommittee to investigate the source of an anti-Eisenhower sheet that apparently had received wide distribution.

STANTON, Del., May 30 (AP) -- Duplicating the 1944 success of his sire, Pavot, and giving owner William Goadby Loew his second straight triumph in the race, Centime today sped to a surprise victory in the $10,000 added, five-furlong Christiana Stakes at Delaware Park before a crowd estimated at 20,000.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 30 -- Chester Bowles, United States Ambassador to India and former Governor of Connecticut, is showing continued interest in the Democratic nomination for Governor in 1954, party leaders are saying.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 30 (UP) -Nine prisoners, including two killers, overpowered a guard at knife point and sawed their way to freedom tonight at Ohio Penitentiary.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 30 (UP) -- The Army today disclosed plans for holding the most realistic atomic maneuver in United States military history involving the use of tank-supported ground troops.

RALEIGH, N. C., May 30 -- North Carolina Democrats will choose their nominee for governor tomorrow in a state primary that has some political overtones continuing the factional bitterness that marked the defeat of Senator Frank P. Graham in 1950.

The National Economic Council of the Philippines has submitted a stimulating and provocative report on the need for revisions in the basic provisions of the Philippine Trade Act of 1946. Under that Act free trade between the United States and the Philippines will come to an end in July, 1954, and thereafter United States duties on Philippine goods will be progressively levied.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and his California campaign manager today disavowed publicly any connection with a Republican group that is fighting a bitter battle to keep Gov. Earl Warren from winning the backing of the state's seventy national convention delegates in next Tuesday's primary.

WASHINGTON, May 30 - Backers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today invited Republican leaders and delegates to meet the general and question him in "give-or-take sessions" to get his views before the party's national convention opened July 7 in Chicago.

TRENTON, May 30 -- The Inmate Grievance Committee at the State Prison engaged today in another sitdown in a prisoners' conference room because demands for changes in recreational and other privileges had not been fulfilled.
EPHRATA, Wash., May 30 (UP) -- The United States today held open house at one of the greatest irrigation projects in history.

LONDON, May 30 -- A total of 170,000,000 Deutsche marks [about $40,000,000] annually proposed by the West German delegation to settle Germany's pre-war foreign debts is unsatisfactory, the Creditors Committee reported today to the Steering Committee of the International German Debt Conference here.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP) -- Sixty-seven former members of the House of Representatives and the Senate are drawing $222,964 a year from the six-year-old Congressional pension system.

LONDON, May 30 -- About 200 United States citizens in London attended a Memorial Day service this noon at St. Margaret's, the parish church of Westminster. Ambassador Walter S. Gifford, who was present, then led the group across the lawn to Westminster Abbey where he laid flowers on the grave of Britain's Unknown Soldier.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP) -- Sixty-seven former members of the House of Representatives and the Senate are drawing $222,964 a year from the six-year-old Congressional pension system.
Sgt. Philip H. Ekartd came down from his home in Irvington-on-Hudson yesterday to play the fife in the Memorial Day parade, something he has done in all the parades but two since 1892.

This afternoon, as on every Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday afternoon for the last two years, the young patients in Lenox Hill Hospital's pediatric division will enjoy several hours of quiet play with some of the latest toys produced by American manufacturers.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 30 (AP) -- Illinois, the defending champion, flashed its expected balance and power today to walk off with sixteen qualifying berths on the opening day of the fifty-second Western Conference track and field championships.

WASHINGTON, May 30 - Secretary of State Dean Acheson returned today from a week-long series of meetings and ceremonies in Europe aimed at binding West Germany to the Atlantic defense system and promptly received President Truman's praise for a "great contribution to the peace of the world."

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The "anti-gravy train" amendment adopted by Congress last October appeared today to have halted the practice of wooing highly profitable Government business with entertainment and gifts.

Greentree Stable's One Hitter, who is perhaps best known for the two decisions he hung on Noor in 1950, hung it on the opposition in the sixty-sixth running of the Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

A good example of what can be done on the health front by cooperative effort is afforded in the case of the malaria-control program which has been initiated for Formosa. In the course of about four years, and with the expenditure of not much more than two million dollars, it is hoped that the disease can be wiped out on the island.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, May 30 -- The killing of four North Korean prisoners and the wounding of three others today resulted from a brazen attempt by the captives to pass secret messages among the compounds on this prison island.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 30 -- The United States Ambassador, Avra M. Warren, left today by air for consultations in Washington. He will join talks being held with Chester Bowles, the Ambassador to India, and report on the threatening crises in Pakistan's foreign policy, her internal politics and her economics.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 30 -- Contributions of the Cleveland Health Museum to community betterment were outlined today at the convention of the American Association of Museums.
The work volume turned out by longshoremen here is steadily increasing, employers reported yesterday.

The Kennedy-Van Saun manufacturing and Engineering Corporation of New York and Danville, Pa., announced yesterday that a record shipment of cement mill machinery had been virtually completed for delivery in Trieste and Catania, Italy.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 30 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, chose a Memorial Day program to make his first major statement on foreign affairs today as a crowd estimated by the police at about 1,500 gathered at the city's war memorial.
Some interesting facts pertaining to salary ranges in the advertising and sales fields are contained in the June issues of two trade publications.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 30 -A detachment of Laotian paratroopers was rushed yesterday to Sam Neua in northeastern Laos, one of the states of French Indo-China, to check a foray by insurgent Vietminh troops into the state from northern Annam.

PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP) -- A ninth inning three-run pinch-hit homer by Joe Garagiola gave the Pirates a 4-3 victory over the Cardinals in the second game of a twin bill today after the Cards had topped the cellar dwellers, 3-2, in the first game.

The House Committee on Post Office and Civil Service has reported favorably on a bill that would revise the existing law requiring that vessels arriving from foreign countries discharge all mail carried at the first port of entry.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 (AP) -- The order of the finish in the Indianapolis Motor Speedway 500-mile race today:

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 30 -- On a cool spring morning, with the flags of the fourteen North Atlantic Treaty nations flying in the background, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower formally handed over the supreme command of the Allied Forces in Europe today to Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway.

RONNE AUL will give a solo recital at the Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street, this afternoon at 3. His program will consist of "Welcoming Jester" (Vivaldi), "Proteus"" (Debussy), "Moth" (percussion), "Street Musician" (Albeniz, "F. P. F. F. P." (Scriabin), "The Possible Hunter" (Johnson), "Caller of the Wind" (McLean), "Warrior" (Bach), "Movement Dance" (Raphling), "Runner Upon This Place" (Stravinsky), "Man With Flower" (Schubert), "At the Recital" (Landau).
CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) -- Olympic hopefuls have a jammed calendar for the next six weeks, with ten tryouts scheduled in June and six trials booked the first week of July.
DALLAS, May 31 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, United States open golf champion, carded a par 71 today for the nation to match.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, today urged the Senate Armed Services Committee to disapprove an Air Force request to add 700 acres of the "best farm land in New Jersey" to the McGuire Air Base near Fort Dix.

Alkaptonuria is a strange, rare disease in which the urine turns dark on exposure to the air. The reason is that the urine contains homogentisic acid, which is chemically related to the familiar photographic developer hydroquinone. The urine of a person who has alkaptonuria is a pretty good photographic developer.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., May 31 -- Cornelius Shields' International Aileen, Warner Willcox's boat Twister, Theodore Reyling's Flying Cloud, Howard McMichael's 210 Kangaroo and Seth Corwin's 110 Wow were the winners today in the Y. R. A. regatta conducted by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

TEANECK, N. J., May 31 -- An appeal to Bergen County Democrats to wipe out "intolerable conditions" in county law enforcement was issued tonight by Archibald S. Alexander of Bernardsville, former Under-Secretary of the Army and Democratic nominee for the United States Senate.

DESPITE the rapid mechanization of farming, the appealing symbols of the farming life remain. In recent years, especially where the cities impinge on the farmlands, some new kinds of farmers are emerging.
