MOSCOW, May 31 (AP) -- The biggest question mark in sports here today is not how well Soviet athletes will do in the Olympic games, but whether or not they will participate.

IS it useful for the Metropolitan Opera to tour? The question is not entirely rhetorical even when one has seen the touching eagerness with which the people of Canada have welcomed the company in the past week at Toronto and Montreal after an absence of decades.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- President Truman's whistle-stop campaign is well under way. True, it is a tour on a treadmill, for he is making his pre-convention off-the- cuff speeches in Washington this spring. But he is raising issues while the Presidential aspirants of both parties wrangle among themselves.

THE second annual international film festival in West Berlin is scheduled for June 12 to 25, and at this writing seventeen countries including the United States have accepted invitations to put their best pictures forward.

WHEN the Harper family moves from New York City to the country, 10-year-old Timmy is certain that he will shed the fears and uncertainties which have plagued him in town. He learns, however, that the country holds terrors as well as pleasures of its own.

IN the latest installment of the Parrish family chronicle. Tippy has just turned 18. She and Lieut. Ken Prescott are dreaming of the day when he will come home from Korea and plans for marriage are uppermost in Tippy's thoughts.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's arrival home from Paris tomorrow will be televised nationally by three major networks.

IF one judges a group show by its strongest items, then the current display at Grand Central Moderns deserves a visit. The theme is "New York," but so loosely interpreted that anything goes -- from an abstraction by George Morrison that suggests departure through tunnels and over bridges to such identifiable landmarks as Howard Cook's somewhat tediously stylized skyscrapers.

ONE of the results of the study of astronomical science is to put our appreciation of things we see in the sky into something like a proper perspective. First, man discovered to his surprise that the sun is far greater in both mass and controlling influence than the earth, and that the moon, so popular a figure of the poets and romanticists, is no more than a rather insignificant near-by ball of rock.

VENICE -- The tourist calendar at Venice this year is full almost to the point of sleeplessness. At best, Venetians and their visiting hordes seem to look upon sleep as a pleasurable indulgence only after a hearty midday meal and in the weary hours before morning.

A new twelve-week summer course on Eastern Europe at New York University will include guest lectures by Adolf A. Berle Jr., former Assistant Secretary of State, Grigore Gafencu, former Minister of Foreign Affairs in Rumania, and Bogdon Radista, former press secretary to Marshal Tito.

YOU can tell Louis Lochner, who reviewed "Moscow, Tokyo, London: Twenty Years of German Foreign Policy," that the Soviet Army found the papers of Herbert von Dirksen on his estate at Groditzberg and they were published by the Soviet Ministry of Foreign Affairs as Volume 2 of "Documents and Materials Relating to the Eve of the Second World War."

I CANNOT help beginning this review with a personal recollection. In November, 1944, being a Soviet officer, I made an attempt to get a transfer to the Polish Corps. Before the war I had never been outside Russia, and when the Red Army entered Poland I fell in love with that small, heroic and completely charming country.

IT is rather ironic that Richard Rodgers, who has written so many of the great show tunes of our time, should also have collaborated on the show which made such tunes all but obsolete. When the curtain rang up on "Oklahoma'' it rang down on the old-style musical comedy, a vehicle that was usually short on book, but long on good tunes.

Two golden crowns, studded with 500 diamonds and other jewels and insured for $100,000, were reported stolen yesterday morning from an altar painting in the Roman Catholic Votive Shrine of Regina Pacis at Twelfth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, Brooklyn.

IN "The Alexandrians" Georgia-born Charles Mills has produced a novel of the South big in scope and distinguished in quality. In time it covers a century, from the founding of a town called Alexandria in 1839 to the centennial celebration in 1939, and it traces the threads of American history.

ST. LOUIS, May 31 (AP) -- Westwood Country Club's stubborn par 70 finally caught up with Lloyd Mangrum today, but he stayed even for 54 holes with a 210 to retain his lead in the forty-ninth Western open golf tournament.

MOZART'S final opera, "La Clemenza di Tito," will be the major work to be mounted this summer at Tanglewood by the opera department of the Berkshire Music Center. Boris Goldovsky, who will be in charge, believes the production will be the opera's first complete presentation in America.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 31 (UP) -- The Devil's red and blue silks of Calumet Farm flashed one, two today as A Gleam and Two Lea finished first and second in the $28,950 Milady Handicap at Hollywood Park.

TOKYO, May 31 -- The showdown between the Japanese Government and the Communist party, now largely underground, came closer today on the heels of the sporadic rioting yesterday in four large cities. These riots are now declared to have been inspired by Communist leadership and dissident Korean elements.

ONE of the most effective and least expensive methods of increasing wildlife population is provision of suitable cover through planting and habitat restoration. Artificial restocking often overloads a given area with far more wildlife than it can possibly support, with consequent damage both to the area and to the wildlife; but artificial restoration or improvement of the land creates a basis for permanently greater wildlife production.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 31 -- Swarms of "foundlings" are back this week-end to help celebrate the 150th commencement of the United States Military Academy which ousted them. They will receive the same parades, honors and salutes as graduates, because the "foundlings'' are loyal West Pointers, too, and their alma mater values them highly.

Eastman Kodak Company, the American Fair Trade Council and the Legislature of the State of Louisiana last week contributed new chapters to the continuing fair trade dispute. Kodak, the largest manufacturer of photographic equipment and supplies in the world, unexpectedly ended on Thursday all fair trade price agreements with stores in forty-five states.

FOUR new titles in the Everyday Adventure Stories uphold the standard set by the first of this social science series published last fall. These informative stories, adapted to the reading needs of the elementary school child, are designed to develop the child's understanding of everyday problems of human relationships and of different phases of American life.

Jack Tuero of New York, top-seeded entrant, and Sid Schwartz, second-seeded player from Brooklyn, triumphed as play in the twelfth Inter-American invitation tennis singles tournament began yesterday on the courts of the Hispano T. C., Whitestone, Queens.

CHORE OF THE WEEK: Now that both soil and nights are warmer, all summer-flowering bulbs may be planted outdoors. Dahlias, tuberous begonia, cannas are set out where they are to flower, and successive plantings made of gladiolus. Peruvian daffodil and fairy lilies bloom promptly, usually within a month. Caladium and calla lilies give color in the shade.
Back at his favorite cavalry post, Cain Hoy Stable's one-eyed colt, Armageddon, yesterday scored his third stakes triumph.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 31 -- Two Jordanian civil servants, including Munir Rifai, a relative of former Premier Samir Rifai, were reliably reported today to have been arrested in Amman, together with other Government employes and citizens, on the charge of having deliberately spread rumors that King Talal would abdicate and that the Jordan Government was seeking peace with Israel.
AUGUSTA, Me., May 31 (AP) -- Gov. Frederick G. Payne called tonight for a grand jury investigation of testimony about "graft" in connection with the Maine Liquor Commission.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 31 -- Pan-Arabism and the parliamentary state are rapidly losing prestige in this part of the Arab world. Those who keep a close watch on public opinion report a steady, unmistakable change in attitude, as indicated by press comment, public declarations and conversation, toward both institutions, which have been closely linked in the history of the Arab community of nations since the first World War.

Rained out yesterday, the Yankees and Indians are listed for a single game at the Stadium today, with Ed Lopat and Bob Lemon set to pitch. Both clubs, beaten twice on their home grounds on Memorial Day, were anxious to start anew yesterday but the weather frustrated them.

THE story of the English Warner children, who first appeared in "The Cruise of the Maiden Castle" is continued in "Crazy Castle" and, as ever was in series, the characterizations are as simple as ABC. Here we have Alan, the photographer; Joan, the horsewoman; Chris. the raiser of caterpillars and a mention of Jeremy Red, 4 years old. who "could not be expected to show any enthusiasm."
An age-old dream case its shadow across the pages of history last week as the treaty providing for a European army was signed in Paris.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The bitterest public battle to date between backers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft simmered here tonight awaiting the general's return to Washington.

EQUIPPED with shears, pastepot and an insatiable and boundless curiosity, George Stimpson has capped off a lifetime of scrapbook-keeping with a series of fascinating and informative miscellanies. In close succession over the last few years he has published "Information Roundup,"

Dr. Olin J. Eggen, assistant astronomer in the University of California's Lick Observatory, has just returned from an astronomical expedition to the Commonwealth Observatory, in Canberra, Australia, with news about a famous nova or exploding star, Eta Carina.

Unless the Congress acts by June 9 to set aside President Truman's three newest reorganization plans all postmasters, custom officers and United States marshals will henceforth be selected on the basis of merit and worth rather than by political appointment. Thus, after sixty-nine years, the civil service system planned in the Pendleton Act of 1883 will be consummated.

TOKYO, May 31 -- Indications of dissension among the nations allied in the Korean war -- some troubles probably of scant importance and others with explosive potentialities -- came out into the open this week while the Communists did their best to help the differences along.

THE influence of current architectural trends on furniture design becomes steadily more apparent. Combined living-dining areas, smaller rooms and fewer of them, large glass areas, open floor plans: these are characteristic of contemporary housing and these are among the factors which have most decidedly influenced modern furniture design.

ATLANTA, May 31 -- The Georgia Republican faction recognized by the national party organization held its state convention today and formally ratified a slate of national convention delegates with fourteen out of seventeen votes reportedly favorable to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

It was a late spring night in 1928 and the arena in Philadelphia was packed. The spectators were watching a contest which would decide who was the nation's amateur heavyweight wrestling champion and the man eligible to represent the United States in the Olympic games of that year.

THE office of the American Ambassador in Moscow is a severely functional room, twenty-five feet long and twenty feet wide, and considerably less impressive than that of a Deputy Price Administrator in Washington or the quarters of a bustling brigadier general in the Pentagon.

It is the custom in our home to lay aside the Magazine section of the Sunday TIMES on the end table in our living room so that the contents may be read at leisure during the week. But so malevolent was the expression on the face of the Communist P. O. W. adorning your May 18 cover that the Magazine section did not occupy its usual prominent spot this time.
Among Presidential candidates I favor Russell for the Democratic nomination.

The barrier across Germany erected last week by the Russians is not as solid as the Great Wall of China nor as formidable as the old Maginot Line. It resembles rather the Roman Times which once crossed Germany from the North Sea to the Danube and was intended to stop the unwanted visits of the Germans in peace as well as their incursions in time of war.

More than 2,000 leaders of the nation's $23,000,000,000 electric power and light industry are scheduled to gather in Cleveland tomorrow for the twentieth annual convention of the Edison Electric Institute. The convention will continue through Wednesday.

LONDON, May 31 -- Bill Nankeville, 26-year-old British miler, reeled off a spectacular 3:49 clocking in the 1,500-meter international invitation run, highlight of today's British track and field games at White City Stadium.
To celebrate its seventy-fifth anniversary, the American Library Association has launched a campaign for popular education on the theme "The Heritage of the U. S. A. in Times of Crisis."

IT is possible this morning to report that the Theatre Guild and Gabriel Pascal, having won the race for the rights to produce a musical version of Shaw's "Pygmalion," are now making additional progress. Unless plans become badly unhinged somewhere along the way, it appears likely that Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe will be the team to do the musicalizing.

BEDRICH SMETANA is a famous composer whose works, paradoxically, are little known. "The Moldau" and the "Bartered Bride" Overture are no farther away than music by Muzak; and the E Minor Quartet ("From my Life") is almost as overworked as Tchaikovsky's Andante Cantabile.

GEORGE McMILLAN, in his review of "Shiloh," states that "the conscript armies proved * * * their inexperience at war: the men in gray paused to eat and loot when they should have pressed their advantage.''

For nearly five months Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has been a candidate by proxy. For the next five weeks he is going to be thrust for the first time into the political arena with his rival, Senator Robert A. Taft.

WHETHER it is a pool or a puddle, any body of water inevitably draws more attention to itself than any other feature of the landscape. Even a small pool in a small garden may fascinate an adult as much as the puddle does a child.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Lindsay C. Warren, Controller General of the United States, again has protested against the refusal by Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, to review the contract between the Government and the United States Lines for the new superliner United States.

BEFORE the heat of summer and vacation plans take the edge off growers' enthusiasm, garden groups are giving members a chance to show off their prized blooms. Schedules for competitive exhibits cover almost any kind of plant that might be in flower now.
ROME, May 31 -- It was a triumphant but uneasy Christian Democratic party that emerged from this week's provincial and municipal elections.
AFTER telling us that mutton and lamb are the best possible meats to roast, the estimable Escoffier in his great cookbook lists the cuts suitable for that culinary method -- leg, saddle, etc.

WEST HILLS, L. I., May 31 -- Three hundred persons wandered among peonies, purple iris clumps and under spreading maple trees this afternoon to await their turn to enter the farmhouse where Walt Whitman was born 133 years ago on May 31.

MOSCOW, May 31 (UP) -- The Don and the Volga, two of Russia's great rivers, were linked today through a newly completed canal that forms a part of an immense waterway that eventually will extend from the Baltic to the Black Sea.

ATHENS, May 31 -- A merger of two Government coalition parties -- the Progressives under Premier Nicholas Plastiras and the Liberals under Deputy Premier (at present acting Premier) Sophocles Venizelos -- will take place before Oct. 15, when Parliament, which recessed last night, is scheduled to reconvene.
PONTIAC, Mich., May 31 (AP) -- The eleven Moore orphans bravely kept back the tears today as four of them left to live with foster parents in a distant city.
Rain, fog and overcast skies kept most New Yorkers home on the second day of the long holiday week-end yesterday, but elsewhere in the country good weather lured crowds to the highways and beaches.

KOJE ISLAND, May 31 -- The Communist prisoners of war here buried one of their dead today in a ceremony calculated to exploit to the full the propaganda benefits, but firm insistence by camp authorities on proper procedures caused the plan to misfire.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A prediction that women would soon rise more rapidly in politics than they have since they won the privilege to vote, as a result of assuming financial responsibility, was made today by Mrs. Gilford Mayes, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee in charge of women's activities.

WITH all the attention focused on television, the radio art has been forced to take a back seat and apparently this trend is to become even more pronounced. The big stars of radio are a drug on the market and substantial cuts in the night-time advertising rates, perhaps as high as 50 per cent, are likely before fall.

The Textile Workers of America, C. I. O., plagued by a secession movement, by employers seeking to lower wage scales because of a "depressed" industry condition and by unemployment in some areas, is prepared for additional trouble tomorrow, with 18,000 members ready to strike at four major carpet manufacturing plants and several smaller ones.

KINGS PARK, L. I., May 31 -- The twenty-fifth annual Summer Day Fair for the benefit of St. Johnland, a home for children and elderly persons in this community, will be held on June 26 on the grounds of the institution. It will be an all-day event with booths, food tables, handiwork, games, pony rides for the children and refreshment stands.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board said today that American Federation of Labor unions squared off against each other in fifty-two bargaining elections during the first quarter of this year. Once there were three A. F. L. affiliates on the same ballot.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Dr. Earl J. McGrath, Federal Commissioner of Education, stepped into a heated controversy today over a new G. I. Bill of Rights for Korean war veterans with a letter defending a proposed system of tuition payments for the education of men who served in Korea.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 (AP) -- The $33,000,000 Greater Pittsburgh Airport, world's second largest commercial field, was dedicated today in ceremonies marking the opening of this steel city's fourth annual Welcome Week celebration.

AS Hollywood set about the filming of its third "Prisoner of Zenda" the other day, an air of sentimental nostalgia was given the proceedings by the presence of a white-haired actor who could look upon the perennial story as something of a favorite child.

THE pursuit of culture requires certain margins of physical security and comfort; but the extension of the margins does not guarantee the further development of cultural values. It may lead to a pre- occupation with the margins and obsession with the creature comforts.

NOW that the Government has lifted controls on installment selling, the American family is hypothetically free once again to plunge recklessly on television sets, automobiles, furniture, washing machines, jewelry -- these being our favorite flings under the blessings of a financial miracle called consumer credit.

A NEW contract bridge method is slow to gain a foothold. No one but Ely Culbertson, with his genius for publicity, has managed to change the bidding habits of a nation overnight; and though Mr. Culbertson turned the trick a few times, take all his efforts and you will find that the bridge-playing public has sent him more rejection slips than outright acceptances.

THAT shadowy figure, the Central European ex-Communist, has already become one of the harrowing symbols of this age. Perhaps when the serious political novelists get done with him as a symbol, they may turn him over in the flesh to the thriller-writers, since his life involves as many cloak-and-dagger exploits as that of the old-fashioned international spy.

JERSEY CITY, May 31 -- A Keansburg, N. J., tavern owner, who had been beaten, bound and gagged, staggered into Hudson Boulevard Police Headquarters here early today and reported he had been kidnapped and robbed of $500 by three young men.

Is it not ridiculous that the peoples of the world arbitrarily translate into their own languages, mutilate or completely change geographical names? We do not translate names of individual persons. Why should this be done with names and titles of countries and cities?

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 31 -- The This strategic island dominion and British naval base of Ceylon, commanding the tropical seaways from the Antipodes and Singapore to India, will continue to cooperate with the Western Powers and the British Commonwealth, Prime Minister Dudley Senanayake declared in an interview today.

Barnard College has received a $75,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation of New York, it was announced last week by Dean Millicent C. McIntosh. The fund, which will be available at the rate of $15,000 a year for five years, will make possible the start next fall of a new program in American Civilization.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 31 -- Cadet Richard T. Shea of Portsmouth, Va., acclaimed as the finest distance runner in the history of the military academy, was signally honored at the traditional athletic review today held in conjunction with June Week ceremonies on the Plain.

EVERYONE admired Tom Owen's Uncle Steve, first mate on the tugboat Bessie, so it was surprising to find that he had an enemy. It was even more surprising when the Bessie crashed into another boat because of a short circuit -- and Uncle Steve's knife was found beside the cut wire.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 31 -- Baccalaureate and advanced degrees will be awarded to 1,850 graduates of eleven colleges and divisions of Rutgers University at the 186th anniversary commencement exercises at the Rutgers Stadium on Saturday.

EVERYTHING to be said about roses may already have been said, but many people even make special pilgrimages to see them in June. There are any number of places where roses bloom en masse this month in and around New York City.

BEAUMONT, Tex., May 31 -- Spindletop, the fabulous oil field that rocketed petroleum production into the realm of big business and paved the way for profitable mining of sulphur along the Texas Gulf Coast, is now yielding the pale yellow element so vital to the nation's industries.

There was a time not so long ago when the regatta badge wearers thought they needed the Atlantic or Pacific Ocean or at least Lake Michigan to find elbow room enough for a race meet. But sizes of speed craft have come down. Now the daredeviltry can be fitted into little rivers, small lagoons, even mud ponds.

SOME American tourists abroad would rather die than come home empty-handed. Europe to them is a vast, roofless department store, with liqueurs sold at the French counter, tweeds at the English, and Borsalino hats at the Italian.

A grim picture of the current Albanian economic situation is painted in Albania's new five-year plan for 1950-55 broadcast by the Tirana radio. Detailed data published in the plan make this document a major departure for the Albanian regime, which hitherto has been the most secretive of Soviet satellites.

During 1950 the twenty-five accidents of the nation's scheduled airlines accounted for the loss of 172 lives. Nine hundred thirteen other persons lost their lives in the 4,531 accidents occurring to nonscheduled commercial and private planes.

The newly elected editor of the Hunter College student newspaper, The Hunter Arrow, is Maureen O'Neill of 1900 Hennessy Place, the Bronx, an upper junior at the college. During the three years she has been on the newspaper's staff, Miss O'Neill has served as news editor and copy editor.

BONN, Germany, May 31 -- Western Germany recently extended a feeler to Israel on a program for "initial restitutions" in the delivery of goods valued at 300,000,000 Deutsche marks ($71,430,000), but Israeli representatives quickly rejected it.

BALTIMORE -- An experiment here to demonstrate, at least by implication, that artists are better fitted than conventional salon juries to judge pictorial exhibitions resulted in little that was conclusive, but much that was helpful as to standards, and raised serious questions as to the feasibility of the new method.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) -- The American Farm Bureau Federation today renewed its charge that the Farm Policy Review of Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, was conducted for purely political purposes.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. -- There is a notion spawned by Western movies that Coloradans are mainly hard-riding cowboys chasing horse thieves or otherwise leading dangerous lives at home on the range.

Opposition to the enactment of the McCarran Immigration bill was expressed yesterday by Rabbi Simon Noveck from the pulpit of the Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East Eighty-seventh Street. He indicated preference for the Humphrey-Lehman bill.

Webster's definition of schizophrenia, appended to the letter from the father of a schizophrenic pre-school child in THE TIMES Magazine of May 18, is incomplete. It omits the very point which your correspondent was attempting to make -- that schizophrenia, particularly childhood schizophrenia, may be something different from a phenomenon "characterized by loss of contact with the environment and by disintegration of the personality."

TOKYO, May 31 -- The South Korean Assembly's fight with President Syngman Rhee, which has broken out again, is the result, the President's critics say, of his determination to prevent the Assembly from picking a new President in the next three weeks.

In a schoolhouse converted from five store buildings on Deer Park Avenue in North Babylon, L. I., five Hunter College graduates began their teaching careers last February without benefit of desks, blackboards or other classroom equipment.

The stock market, in the final sessions of the month, moved in the narrow pattern which it has followed for some time. Traders were disappointed when the Supreme Court failed on Monday to hand down its decision on the steel seizure case.

LONDON, May 31 -- The Duke of Windsor slipped quietly into London this week to visit his aging mother, Queen Mary, and found himself right in the middle of a fresh controversy regarding his abdication from the British throne in 1936.
CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) -- Today's livestock prices reported by the Department of Agriculture follows:
CLEVELAND, May 31 -- Conscription was opposed and a world-wide "peace" income tax was advocated in platform planks adopted by the Socialist party's national convention here today.

Twenty years ago school and college leaders undertook a challenging educational experiment known as the "Eight-Year Study." Financed by a $1,000,000 grant from the General Education Board, the study was designed to see whether the nation's colleges could relax their admission requirements and accept students from high schools who did not have the traditional pre-college course of studies.

Gilbert Verney's new yawl, Sea Lion, built in Germany the past winter and making her first racing start yesterday, won the Storm Trysail Club's race of 175 miles out around Block Island. Sea Lion is sixty-seven feet long and enrolled in the New York Yacht Club, but for the contest the yacht was entered in the name of the Nantucket Yacht Club.
TOKYO, Sunday, June 1 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,267, for Saturday's operations:

PARIS, May 31 -- Gardnar Mulloy of Miami and Richard Savitt of Orange, N. J., qualified with Australia's Frank Sedgman and Kenneth McGregor for the final of the French championship tennis doubles today.

WHEN Edgar Faure was Premier of France for a brief time last winter, it was often forgotten that he was also Edgar Sanday, author of non-best selling detective stories. His latest is titled, "Monsieur Langois nest pas toujours Egal a Luimeme," or "Mr. Langois Is Not Always Up to Snuff."

There are about a hundred million galaxies --- colossal swirls of stars. How were they created? Even before the war Fred Hoyle, Hermann Bondi and Thomas Gold, three bold, bright young mathematicians of Cambridge University, decided that the original star-stuff was still lying around in the black spaces of the universe and that new galaxies were being formed.

A SEAMAN sees cities differently. He arrives at the waterfront, not at an airport, bus terminal or railroad station. He approaches his destination freshly across a bay, not tortuously through suburbs, used-car lots or slums.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 31 -- Virgil Sherrill and Richard Harris of Apawamis, the medalists, led the way into the semi-final round of the Meadow Brook Club's annual four-ball invitation golf tournament with a pair of victories today.

For months the world looked to the latter part of May in expectation of a critical turning point in the East-West struggle. At that time the West was scheduled to take a momentous step bringing sovereign rearmed Germans into the Western coalition against communism -- something the Kremlin has set itself to prevent ever since the end of World War II.

ROME, May 31 -- The Vatican's Sacred Congregation of the Holy Office placed all works of Andre Gide, French novelist, on the index of forbidden books by a decree dated May 24 and published today. Last Monday, the congregation announced that all works of Alberto Moravia, Italian neo-realist novelist, similarly had been placed on the index.

Under the direction of the New York State Department of Education, a number of "community ambassadors" are to be sent abroad this summer as part of an experiment in promoting international understanding.

The first commercial production of full-fashioned hosiery on long section 66-gauge knitting machines will be included in the fall lines of Gotham Hosiery Co.. Inc., it was announced yesterday by Roy E. Tilles, president.

SINCE the inhabitants of the world of the stage tend to be non-conformists, it is not surprising that the theatre officially ends its season toward the middle of the year. Yesterday marked the termination of Actors Equity run-of-the-play contracts and the new season of 1952-53 begins today, although it will not reach full momentum until some six months from now.

Many buyers are expected in the wholesale market here this week due to the numerous group meetings scheduled and a desire for early delivery of fall goods because stocks are low, resident buying offices reported. All activity in the markets will be on fall items for the next few months.

BERLIN, May 31 (UP) -- Following is the text of a note from Gen. Thomas T. Handy, commander in chief European Command, to Gen. Vassily A. Chuikov, commander in chief, group of Soviet occupation forces in Germany:

BERKELEY, Calif., May 31 (AP) -- Lieut. Warren Druetzler of the Far East Command, expected to be a member of the United States Olympic team this summer, today won the 1,500-meter race that highlighted the All-Army track and field championship.
Saigon was intelligently sensitive in greeting with ceremony the arrival of the 150th ship bearing United States aid. This is a practical demonstration that our help is really going forward.

ROSELLE, N. J., May 31 -- Expanding a drive against juvenile delinquency, Judge Libby E. Sacher of the Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court of Union County has appointed three referees to hear complaints against boys and girls up to the age of 18 in Roselle.

THE big question before the airlines and the airplane manufacturers of this country is not whether or how to build jet airliners, but how to finance their production. Recently a suggestion was put forth by Donald Nyrop, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, that the effort be more or less underwritten by the Federal Government.
HARTSDALE, N. Y., May 31 -- Betsy Rawls of Austin, Texas, maintained her lead in the $17,000 Weathervane open golf tournament as the transcontinental competition entered into its final stages today.

HUNTINGDON VALLEY, Pa., May 31 -- Champion Aristo von Marienlust, smooth dachshund, owned by Mrs. Lancaster Andrews of Westbury, L. I., was selected as the best in show today at the Huntingdon Valley Kennel Club fixture on the George W. Elkins estate.

PARIS, May 31 -- The French Government struck today at the central command structure of the nation's massive Communist network in raids by hundreds of police on the national and provincial offices of the Communist party and its satellite organizations.

Charley Grimm, a two-time previous major-league manager, yesterday was named pilot of the Boston Braves after Tommy Holmes had been dropped. The latter replaced Billy Southworth in mid-season last year and brought his club home in fourth place.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 31 -- A campaign against Costa Rican Jews has developed since the Jewish New Year holidays last September. Pushed by a group calling itself the Junta Patriotica, the campaign has been marked by virulent newspaper propaganda paid for by the junta, by anti-Jewish slogans painted on walls and by a few acts of violence.

HAVING been in the show business practically all of my life, I have been keenly aware of the fact that glory is so transient. And from my earliest days I have fought to get whatever recognition I could in everything I did -- and as the years have gone by, I have also fought a little for the other fellow.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, May 31 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet, Commander of United Nations Ground Forces in Korea, declared today he did not think the Communists would open an offensive. He pointed out that although the enemy's strength had been increased considerably during recent months so had that of the United Nations.

MORE than four hundred enthusiastic iris growers gathered at the recent annual convention of the American Iris Society in St. Louis. Most of the visitors were there mainly to see what was new in the way of tall bearded iris.
JUNE starts with abundant greenery, which is clean and pleasant looking. The gardener, nevertheless, must be on the lookout for trouble well before the month ends.

ON the island of Amapala, south of Honduras, beautiful, quiet and fertile, life was unbearable. The island was full of insects. Seven-year-old Geraldina lived here m a hut with her two young brothers and parents. All suffered from the fever -- malaria and Geraldina's father said that the island was cursed.

The American Fund For Israel Institutions, which supports or maintains fifty-one of Israel's outstanding cultural, educational and social institutions, will close its annual drive for $1,934,000 with the staging of two major events on the evenings of next Saturday and June 15.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The trend is definitely toward decontrol of the economy, but the Government is far from surrendering its claim on prices, wages and allocation of materials. The decontrolling, in fact, has tended to assure renewal of the Government's controls authority.

RALEIGH, N. C., May 31 (AP) -- With more than one-half of the precincts reported, former Senator William B. Umstead led former Justice Hubert Olive of Lexington tonight by more than 15,000 votes in North Carolina's Democratic primary for Governor, which is tantamount to election.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 (AP) -- Indiana's thirty-two-member delegation to the Republican National Convention will be chosen June 6-7 and will probably predominantly favor Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio for the Presidential nomination.

IN 1900 when the present head of the Brown family was born, he was widely acclaimed by the press as "the world's richest baby." We have long known about the Browns of Providence, but we have not known very much.

NEWARK, May 31 -- The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company was authorized by the New Jersey Public Utilities Commission today to increase the intervals between trains in nonrush hours and on Saturdays and Sundays.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 31 -- The Polish American Congress urged this country tonight to sever diplomatic relations with Soviet Russia and her satellite nations, and also called on the United States Senate to repudiate "the infamous and unjust agreements of Yalta and Teheran."

TOKYO, Sunday, June 1 -- The Communists charged the United Nations Command yesterday with an attempt to extend the war in Korea through mistreatment of Chinese and North Korean war prisoners on Koje Island and in mainland stockades.

FEDERAL Germany, entering upon an independent career in Europe, is beset by problems that appear more complex and stubborn than those facing any other European power. The central fact of contemporary German society is that Germany is divided. Reunification of the nation is desired by nine out of ten Germans.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) -- The Treasury's top rackets foe said today that his agents had collected $115,000,000 in unpaid taxes and penalties from racketeers in the past ten months and expected to recover another $45,000,000 by July 31.

A BANNER boating season is again in the offing for both the summer sailor and spectator. Yachting events will be held every week-end through mid-September on Long Island Sound and a number of top speedboat events will take place within a short journey of the city.

VALHALLA, N. Y., May 31 -- A granite monument to the memory of Federal Judge Murray Hulbert of New York, who died in April, 1950, was dedicated at his grave in Gate of Heaven cemetery here this morning by the Grand Lodge of Elks, of which he was Grand Exalted Ruler in 1928 and 1929. Fifty relatives, friends and former judicial, fraternal and political associates attended.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) -- Although the Eighty-third Congress doesn't convene for eight months, the petroleum industry already is flexing its muscles for a new battle against higher taxes.

VIENNA, May 31 -- The "people's democracies" of Eastern Europe have been ordered by Moscow to take draconic measures to increase production of heavy industry, particularly of those industries necessary for armament. More and more Russian experts are being sent to the East bloc satellites to supervise execution of this order.

WESTON, Mass., May 31 (AP) -- Nancy Vadner and Betty King each scored two goals for Philadelphia's No. 1 team today as that favored team defeated the Boston No. 1 forces, 7 -- 4, for its fourth straight victory in the women's national lacrosse tournament at Nickerson Field.

STANTON, Del., May 31 (AP) -- Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' Yildiz, unable to win since he captured Hialeah's Flamingo Stakes early last year, withstood a hard drive at Delaware Park today to earn a photo-finish triumph in the $10,000 added Brandywine Handicap.

High school boys outranked their girl colleagues more than 2 to 1 in the seventh annual contest of the National Honor Society for Scholarships, Awards and Certificates of Merit, conducted by the National Association of Secondary School Principals.

The efficient manufacturer of uniforms henceforth will receive more Army business. This decision, made last week by the New York Quartermaster Procurement Agency, subject to ratification by Washington, was greeted with applause by the men's clothing industry.

Banking's response to the appeal of The Greater New York Fund represents one of the most effective public relations policies that the banks have adopted, according to Henry C. Alexander, president of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc.

With great histrionic reaction I read in last Sunday's TIMES Mr. Schrank's reply to Robert Montgomery's comments on TV scripting. As a newcomer to show business via TV, I'm one of the "new generation" just conceived by this meteoric industry, a member of that vast group of possibilities who have little claim to any theatrical background but who hope some day to be able to express their ideas in this medium.

BOSTON, May 31 -- Marv Grissom pitched a five-hitter today as the White Sox defeated the Red Sox, 7 -- 3, before 10,562 fans at Fenway Park. Grissom, formerly with the Tigers and a 20 -game winner with Seattle of the Pacific Coast League, struck out eight as he notched his second victory against three losses.

DALLAS, May 31 -- Improvement in the Southwest was indicated in the Eleventh Federal Reserve Bank's monthly business summary. Rains in April and May broke the drouth in much of Texas, improving the outlook for farm production.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 31 -- The forty-second anniversary of the formation of the Union of South Africa was celebrated today in the midst of the most bitter racial crisis in its history.

These are the two opposing points of view on an issue which, in terms of money, is the biggest issue before Congress. The issue is United States spending for national security. It embraces national defense and foreign aid -- which together account for 70 per cent of the President's $85 billion budget for the coming year.

The State Department's foreign information organization came under attack from two quarters yesterday. Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, called in Washington for a reappraisal of the program and a change in its tone, while Mrs. Marion K. Sanders, Chief of the Department's Publication Branch, announced her resignation in protest against a new reorganization plan.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Sunday, June 1 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Haydon L. Boatner, commander of the prison camp here, cracked down today on the North Korean officer responsible for last Thursday's demonstration by prisoners in Compound 66.

TENAFLY, N. J., May 31 -- The medalist team of Alex McGhee and Fred Schambach of White Beeches, the defending champions, Harry Payne and Les Daggett of Rockland, and two other strong combinations moved into the semi-finals of the third annual J. Elmer Westervelt Memorial member-guest tournament at the Knickerbocker Country Club today.

WE have become so aware of the presence, the loud, insistent presence of a number of forms of communication. sometimes called sub-arts, that do not require any real reading, that we may well begin to think of Americans as reading less and less while they grow younger and younger.
Had it not been for the Uniformed Firemen's Association, an inconsequential one-alarm fire in the apartment of a retired fruit peddler at 1:51 P. M. yesterday would have gone unnoticed by the public.

After five years of testing, the University of Michigan has opened a new graduate program in journalism. It will offer two years of specialized study followed by a year's internship on selected newspapers. The program has been organized on both the domestic and international levels and includes preparation for foreign correspondence as well as for domestic newspaper administration.

LONDON, May 31 -- The National Coal Board and the Italian Embassy are negotiating on how much compensation is due the 800 Italian miners who have been rejected as co-workers by the British coal miners.

THIRTEEN years ago a black- haired, brown-eyed girl of 22, fresh from the graduating class of Vanderbilt University in Nashville, Tenn., arrived in New York with her heart set on being an actress. No acting opportunity blossomed, so she became a radio singer, catching public attention relatively fast without having to walk over dead bodies.

Late ordering of all-wool tropical worsted suits by retailers will cause them to lose sales this summer, according to the Wool Bureau, The stores under-estimated the demand and bought in small quantities and now that activity has improved it is too late for the mills to supply the cloth and the manufacturers to make the suits, the bureau explained.

Forty-two of the nation's top lacrosse players will start training at West Point tomorrow in preparation for the eleventh annual North-South All-Star game to be played Friday night at the Polo Grounds. Proceeds of the contest will go to the Damon Runyon Cancer Fund.

The Moore-McCormack Lines has announced its most ambitious cruise program since its South America passenger service was established in 1938 -- a series of five thirty-eight-day summer cruises through the Caribbean and the South Atlantic to Buenos Aires.

The truce tents at Panmunjom lie roughly on a line which divides the northern and southern halves of the Korean peninsula. Last week, as United Nations delegates went through another series of futile truce sessions at Panmunjom in an effort to resolve the last remaining issue in dispute -- the conflict over forced versus voluntary repatriation of prisoners -- they found themselves under increasing and ominous pressure from both sides of that line.

WINNERS in the 1952 Scholastic - Ansco Photography Awards for high school students were announced last week by Scholastic Magazines. The 132 award-winning prints will go on display Tuesday in the gallery and windows of the East River Savings Bank, 41 Rockefeller Plaza, where they will be on view through June 30.

Only a few days ago, the Life Insurance Association of America was told that new electronic devices capable of revolutionizing the nation's business and industrial operations would be available in a reasonably short space of time.

LAMBARENE, French Equatorial Africa, May 10 -- The hospital founded a quarter of a century ago by Dr. Albert Schweitzer on the Ogowe River, a few hundred yards from this small post in the heart of the Gabon hinterland, remains an institution unique in Africa.

A new type of reversal photographic paper was described last week at the twenty-sixth annual meeting of the Blue Print and Allied Industries at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., by Frederic A. Tompkins, assistant superintendent of the paper-manufacturing plant of the Eastman Kodak Company.

THIS sensitive, pleasant chronicle of English class-consciousness at bay lacks the romantic tenderness which would make a pretty calendar of a social revolution. Gently but firmly, Marghanita Laski reduces some fine old social taboos to absurdity while she tells her story of young love among the caste complexes.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, called today for a reappraisal of the United States foreign information service and the abandonment of "the superior, almost patronizing tones of a rich and moral uncle addressing poor relatives."

Combined sales volume of major department stores last week came up against their first statistical comparison with the heavy sales gains recorded during last year's "price war." As a result, combined volume for the latest week was about 21 per cent below that for the corresponding week of 1951.

The Navy's newest, fastest and only fully air-conditioned transport, the 17,600-ton Barrett, docked at 10:05 A. M. yesterday after her shakedown cruise. She will join the Atlantic fleet of the Military Sea Transportation Service in two weeks.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 31 -- Schoolrooms are shutting down for the summer in South Jersey, and swimming suits are being dragged out of attic trunks, fishing poles resurrected from the cellars. But there is one schoolyard near Camden for which many of its vacationing pupils will long -- the Clinton Street School in suburban Oaklyn.

About 100 copies of a small book will be delivered by the printer to Barnard College on Thursday. This achievement coincides with the graduation of the class of 1952. The paper-bound volume is entitled "Barnard Poetry 1952," and carries an emblem, a tiny delicate head which, it is hoped, will be on more books and thus establish a Barnard tradition.

THE lash of a figurative whip provokes two extremes of humor. For the whipped-up kind, screamy-meemie and listen-to-this-it-will-killya stuff, tune in on any TV channel. For the whipped - down, mouse-in-the-corner, deceptively unobtrusive variety, consider the master of the meditative phrase and the sneak attack of understatement.

ABILENE, Kan., May 31 -- The Eisenhower - for - President headquarters in Washington has asked that housing reservations be made here for 107 delegates and alternates to the Republican National Convention for the Kansas-Eisenhower Day celebration on Wednesday.

INDIGNATION and fear was apparent in the reaction last week of many of Hollywood's more prominent citizens in the wake of the public disclosure that a new loyalty investigation was under way in the major studios in what amounted to a last desperate effort by the policy makers of the motion-picture industry to ward off a full-dress showdown with the American Legion on the issue of communism in Hollywood.

MOSCOW, May 31 -- For the second time within about six weeks, great mass meetings are being held throughout the Soviet Union expressing public indignation and anger at the United States conduct of the Korean war.

SURBITON, England, May 31 -- Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., won the Surrey grass courts tennis championship today by defeating Mrs. Patricia Canning Todd of La Jolla, Calif., 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4. It was a sweet victory for 17-year-old Maureen, who had been beat-ten twice by Mrs. Todd.

The peace treaty signed last week by Western Germany and the Allied Big Three, while it still faces an uncertain course toward final ratification, can become a potent force in further long-term development of Germany's revitalized foreign trade.

MATTHEW LEWIS wrote "The Monk," a sensational Gothic novel or tale of terror, at the age of 19, when he was employed in the British Embassy at The Hague. It was the summer of 1794. The book published the following year and rapidly achieved a vide audience.

THE examination of the modern university from the insights of Christian theology, principally inaugurated by the work of Arnold Nash and Sir Walter Moberly, is here extended to a wider audience by George Buttrick, pastor of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York City.

Manhattan College, whose keyed-up representatives held close to form in an upset-studded meet, scored a smashing victory in the seventy-sixth annual Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. outdoor track and field championships at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday.

RETAILING, particularly department store merchandising, came in for extensive self-analysis last week. Much of the discussion centered on the poor 1951 results, but the conclusions reached have their bearing on retail operations this year and probably for some time to come.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- There are three things in relation to the current potato shortage on which the Department of Agriculture has decided opinions. These are:

In his Chicago address last Friday Nelson A. Rockefeller presented a cogent argument for American aid to foreign countries and spelled out some of the chief criteria we must use in giving such help. If for no other reason, he pointed out, this country's growing dependence on imported raw materials makes it essential for us to be concerned with socio-economic problems abroad and to help prevent Communist conquest of the sources of these materials.

The independent liberal arts college is in serious financial trouble. Fifty per cent of these institutions are operating on a deficit. Many are on the verge of bankruptcy. Large numbers are beginning to curtail existing academic services.

The first Conrad Rostan Wrzos Scholarship, which will enable a graduate of Columbia University's School of Journalism to spend at least six weeks in Brazil to study that nation's press, has been awarded by the school to William Seamans of Mount Vernon, N. Y.

BARCELONA, Spain, May 31 -- The Roman Catholic Church's thirty-fifth International Eucharistic Congress reached a climax today when 80,000 persons prayed in unison as 813 deacons from ten nations were ordained as priests by four Archbishops and seventeen Bishops in a brilliantly impressive ceremony in the Barcelona Sport Stadium.

RADIO reports from the 1940 Democratic convention indicated that a conservative might be nominated Vice President. Listening at the White House, Franklin Roosevelt picked up a pencil and wrote out a message declining the nomination for President. He handed the draft to Judge Samuel I. Rosenman, asking him to polish it so it could be delivered to the convention if Henry Wallace were not chosen as running mate.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 (UP) -- The Indianapolis Speedway split its largest purse in history tonight -- $230,100 -- as the pay-off for the thirty-sixth annual 500-mile Memorial Day auto race.

The island of Jamaica, B. W. I., heretofore noted for its rum, sugar and attractions as a resort, will soon be benefiting from the most recent feather in its cap -- the distinction of holding one of the world's largest reserves of bauxite, the raw material of aluminum.

HARTFORD, May 31 -- The break between Gov. John Davis Lodge and William H. Brennan of Stamford, Republican National Committeeman who was ousted this week on the Governor's orders, may cause continued dissension among Connecticut Republicans in the next two years.

JERSEY JOE WALCOTT and Ezzard Charles will fight for the heavyweight championship of the world in Philadelphia's vast Municipal Stadium on Thursday night. It's a match of such boundless attractiveness that it has provoked polite yawns from one end of the country to the other. No one seems to give a hoot.

EMPORIA, Kan., May 31 (UP) -- W. Averell Harriman, candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said today that he left the Republican party twenty-four years ago because he was convinced G. O. P. leaders "were" unable to face the facts of life in the twentieth century."
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 31 (UP) -- The new Bolivian Government appointed a ten-man commission today to prepare the nationalization of the country's large tin mining companies.

The ambulance service for premature babies, set up by the city in 1948, has resulted in a substantial decrease in the mortality of prematures, the Hospital Council of Greater New York reported last week.

ANYONE who likes to observe exact anniversaries and turning points in history would do well to stand by for two minutes on June 4, 1952, at 10:24 A. M., zone "Yoke" (Greenwich plus 12) time. It will be 3:24 P. M. (standard) in San Francisco, and 7:24 P. M. (daylight) in New York. Exactly ten years earlier, to a minute, occurred the crisis in the Battle of Midway, and in the Pacific war.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 31 -- A. C. and A. W. Jackson's Bernard Hanover from Oxford, Mass., with George Phalen driving, rushed forward in the stretch to capture the Williston Class A Pace by a length at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

IT looks as if Existentialism is here to stay. A few years back the general public was curious about it as a new and sensational fad from Paris, while our professional philosophers chose to look upon it with a disdainful eye as a bizarre bit of French finery, full of rhetorical glitter and color but a solution to practically nothing.

Organized labor is battling against a new invasion by organized crime. The invasion has not attained anything like the dimensions it reached in the mid-Thirties -- when Louis (Lepke) Buchalter was a more respected figure in many union offices than William Green -- but top union leaders want to make sure that it never does.

ST. LOUIS, May 31 -- Their National League lead whittled down to a scant half length by their loss of two out of three games to the Phillies, the Giants arrived in the West today with Leo Durocher hopeful that the worst part of this tour has been hurdled.

THE relative merits of garage, shed and outdoor parking will be examined along with other topics at the annual summer meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers, opening today at Atlantic City and continuing through Friday.

ROME, May 31 -- The Christian Democratic party in a long statement summarizing the results of this week's provincial and municipal elections acknowledged that it had lost votes compared with the last general election in 1948, but said it had strengthened its control of provincial and municipal councils.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 31 (AP) -- Illinois, the defending champion, came through in the final event, the pole vault, today to nip a determined Michigan bid, 67 3-5 points to 65 1-10, in the fifty-second Western Conference track and field championships.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., May 31 -- The Hutchinson Farms' gray gelding, Peg's Pride, scored 13 1/2 points to win the jumper championship and the J. T. Bragg Memorial Challenge Trophy during the fifth annual Brookville horse show at the J. T. Bragg stables today.
SAIGON, Indo-China, May 31 -- Prospects are fading that the insurgent Vietminh forces will launch a "rice battle" offensive against the Tonkin Delta.

SPIDERLILIES have won acclaim in our garden by producing spectacular beauty quickly and with little effort. Amazing success rewarded our initial trial with these summer- flowering bulbs, and it seems strange that they are not seen more often.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Senator Ernest W. McFarland, the majority leader, said today he would ask the Senate to put its legislative machinery into high gear for the next thirty days. With other Congressional leaders, he has these twin goals:

QUITO, Ecuador, May 31 -- Ecuador's armed forces gave a public pledge of fidelity to the Constitution and "any democratic and legally constituted Government" in a statement published throughout the nation today on the eve of the hotly contested Presidenial ejections.

THE message contained in this slim volume seems to be that, for the city dweller -- the man who has spent his adult life learning to contend with the vagaries of restaurant captains rather than with, say, beetles -- Nature is not everything Rousseau and Thoreau made it out to be.

A FORMER state parole officer assigned to New York's lower East Side. Fred Berson makes the job sound like one of high adventure. The anecdotal account of his experience reads like a succession of capsule melodramas, replete with pistol-play, tough hoodlums, loose women and parole officers who perform in current private-eye fashion.
CANTON, N. Y., May 31 (AP) -- A former Ogdensburg police chief and a slot machine distributor were sentenced today to one year in jail and fined $500 each for conspiracy in a slot machine racket.

WASHINGTON -- A unique experiment to aid the motorist who gets confused in an unfamiliar city is under way here, directed by District of Columbia traffic officials. And they think it may be a good idea for other municipalities.

The maiden voyage of the superliner United States will be of special interest not only to the shipping industry and the traveling public, but also to philatelists, says George M. Bragalini, Acting Postmaster.

New York will play host to several thousand buyers this month. Starting tomorrow and continuing for the next four weeks, women's apparel manufacturers here will show their latest creations in coats, suits, dresses and sportswear to merchandise men and women from all parts of the country coming to view the initial openings for the fall of 1952.

Twenty-seven awards for heroism, two of them posthumous, will be made to members of the Police Department at commencement exercises for 503 probationary patrolmen at noon tomorrow on the steps of City Hall. Mayor Impellitteri will present the awards, which are for acts of bravery in 1951.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 31 -- Although in agreement on most of the candidates for the top Westchester offices in the next seven months, county Republican leaders were uncertain today on choices for District Attorney, County Judge and one Assemblyman.

We seldom remember in April how tall the grass at the roadside and in the meadows will be by June. Or that daisies will frost the fence row and buttercups gild the meadow. We forget, most of us, that chokecherries are now in bloom with their sharp-tanged flowers, and that June is other things than roses.

Along with the Cuban shortness of memory which Herbert L. Matthews mentions in "'Republic With No Citizens'" (May 18), there is another facet of the Cuban temperament which also needs to be noted: the undercurrent of buoyant Cuban laughter.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) -- The Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report tonight hailed the House of Representatives Expenditures Committee's decision to speed hearings on remaining Hoover Reorganization bills.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue holds that since a change in the membership of a partnership results in a new partnership, the transfer of interests in partnership securities effects a change of ownership therein, thus incurring the transfer tax in respect of the partnership holdings of securities.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 31 -- A wild throw with two out in the bottom of the fifteenth inning enabled Army to beat Fordham, 3 -- 2, in their traditional June Week tussle at Doubleday Field today.

Although the trans-Atlantic passenger piers here resounded to the tread of increasing numbers of outbound tourists last week, steamship booking agents noted with satisfaction that fairly solid bookings in April and May and reservations for August had apparently erased the limits of the traditional tourist season.

WITH his last three Co-Columbia disks, Robert Casadesus has identified himself with Ravel, phonographically speaking, as did Backhaus with Brahms, Schnabel with Beethoven. Those three disks contain all of Ravel's piano music, including the four-hand Ma Mere I'Oye and Habanera which Casadesus plays with his wife, Gaby.
After six years of incompatibility, liquor enforcement agencies of the Federal Government and the State of New York have agreed to bury the hatchet.

A baccalaureate service in St. Paul's Chapel this afternoon will open Columbia University's 198th commencement week. The ceremony will be the first in a series of formal and informal exercises preceding the graduation of 7,000 students on Thursday.
A return to first place in the National League race was the big objective of the Dodgers as they entrained for Chicago at 6 o'clock yesterday evening on the first leg of their second western tour.

BONN, May 31 -- The Russians are the most xenophobic of peoples and of all aliens they dislike and distrust the Germans the most. Consequently the decision of the Political Bureau in Moscow to clasp East Germans to the breast of Mother Russia and shout "Tovarich" probably has aroused more secret doubts among Russians than any Government action of the post-war years.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- With General Eisenhower coming out of the Army and Willie Mays of the New York Giants going into the Army, it would be less than accurate to suggest that this fun-loving, politics-crazy town was thinking very much about the great issues of foreign policy.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 31 -- The most prosperous meeting in the 11-year-old history of Garden State came to a close today with the finale headed by the richest 3-year-old race in New Jersey. Winner of the $36,700 Jersey Stakes was the second choice, Isidor Bieber's King Jolie, who triumphed over Starmount Stable's Primate by a neck.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 31 -- Twice rained out, the Navy and Columbia baseball teams went at it today and, after five innings in the Eastern League contest still were without a decision. The game was called because of rain with the score tied at 1 -- 1.

PARIS, May 31 -- The French Communist party is trying to summon its militant cadres to outright attacks on American installations and by implication appears to be encouraging attacks on American citizens themselves. This is the first time the party's strong-arm squads have been called out on so frankly violent an anti-American basis.

DEVON, Pa., May 31 -- Thoroughbreds from Mrs. Josephine A. De Segura's Pin Oak Stables at Bellaire, Tex., carted off the major share of championships and trophies as the fifty-sixth annual Devon Horse Show came to an end tonight.

NARCISSA WHITMAN, wife of a medical missionary to the Indians, was the first white woman to reach Oregon in the late Eighteen Thirties. At 28 she had been living contentedly with her family in Amity, N. Y., when Marcus Whitman -- and love -- appeared on the scene.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- If the Eighty-second Congress does not get as bad a lacing at the hands of President Truman this summer as did the Eightieth during the campaign of 1948 it will be for reasons of politics, not because of its glowing achievements.

MOSCOW, May 31 -- The Soviet press this week has reached one of its periodic peaks of indignation against the Western powers and particularly the United States, as a result of the signing of the Bonn contract and the Paris agreements on the European Defense Community.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., May 31 -- Boxers from the Fifth Army took the team title as ten champions were crowned in the finals of the All-Army tournament tonight. The winners triumphed in the featherweight, lightweight, welterweight and the light-heavyweight divisions.

PUSAN, Korea, May 31 -- The South Korean police arrested a twelfth member of the National Assembly today as President Syngman Rhee tightened military control over the country in defiance of pleas from the Assembly and the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, said tonight that Southern Democrats must present their own candidate for the Presidency if the party platform endorses a "nefarious" civil rights program.

PARIS, May 31 -- The most significant index to the relative strength of the Communists and their antagonists in this week's demonstrations in Paris and other French cities is the fact that the roly-poly ex-pastry cook, Jacques Duclos, the French Communist party's acting leader and principal parliamentary polemicist, has been led off to jail in handcuffs, charged with an attempt against the internal security of the state.

A series of classes for expectant mothers, given by the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, will begin this week at fifteen locations in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens, Marian G. Randall, executive director of the organization, announced last week.

A NOVELIST who possesses high literary talent combined with a sharp plot-mind is often faced with a very nearly insoluble problem: Should he say what he wants to say about the world and its people in the form of a straight novel, which may reach anywhere from a million readers to none, or in the guise of a detective story, which has a limited but none the less guaranteed minimum public.
PHILADELPHIA, May 31 -- (AP) -- Ezzard Charles rules a 12-to-5 favorite to upset the tradition of the ring Thursday night by becoming the first former heavyweight champion to win back the title.
SINCE dancers are known to be adventurous by nature, it will probably surprise nobody to find Bambi Linn and Rod Alexander dancing in the Persian Room of the Plaza.

IT is always pleasant when a favored member of the family is honored in public. One may then, without immodesty, bask in -- even join in -- the laudatory remarks. And one may have, too, the satisfaction of saying, "I knew it all the time."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 31 -- Navy's undefeated crew rowed to a four-length victory over an outclassed Boston University eight today on the mile-and-three-quarters Severn River course.
CINCINNATI, May 31 (AP) -- Tommy Holmes, one of baseball's finest gentlemen, had nothing but praise for the Boston Braves management which fired him as manager today.

WHEN the Mayflowers are blooming in the woods, expect a brisk, peremptory questionnaire from Variety's Abel Green, who is in a hurry and wants to get off to Europe fast. Every year he requires the town's drama critics to select the best actors in about a million categories, it seems, and to answer some pertinent questions about current show business.

THERE is a good deal that is new, and a great deal that is incredibly old and vieux jeu, in the present musical manifestations of this city. There was the night that they performed Stravinsky's "Oedipus Rex," with the composer in the conductor's chair, and with Jean Cocteau, in flowery attire and insinuating graciousness, reciting the French text.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) -- A baby-sitter who saved her seven charges from fire, a boy who saved a girl from an alligator, and another boy who promoted a three-point civil defense program were chosen today for United States Government medals.

CARL SANDBURG seems a tall man though he isn't; and approaching 75, he seems a young man. He is a bony, fine-looking fellow, with flattened-down, white, symmetrical hair (that can get quite disheveled), enigmatic eyes, a bold nose and mouth.

CHARLESTON, W. Va. -- More and more motorists are becoming aware of the excellent highways and historic attractions of West Virginia. The state is not large and many of its points of interests are only a short drive from the eastern metropolitan centers.
ADAMO DIDUR PROGRAM: Arias from Ernani, Der Freischuetz, The Barber of Seville, etc. (Eterna). Reissue of Didur's acoustical recordings, technically poor by today's standards but musically polished.
IN "Bright Procession" the author of "The Townsman," "The Angry Wife" and "The Long Love," tells of a man groping for the true interpretation of his soul.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) -- The Voice of America announced today it was opening a Chicago office to get private Midwest organizations to play a more active role in the Government's "campaign of truth."
The Treasury's new type savings bond -- the Series H -- which is intended to combine current interest income with the Series E bond's 3 per cent yield to maturity, will go on sale tomorrow.

SPANISH troops lined eight University of Havana medical school freshmen against a wall on Nov. 27, 1871, and shot them to death. When tried -- with companions who were exonerated -- they had pleaded innocence of desecrating the grave of a Cuban "Volunteer" captain who had supported the Spanish overloads.
In the quiet streets of lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon the police needed only ten minutes to recover an ambulance reported missing by the Beekman Downtown Hospital.

PRESTWICK, Scotland, May 31 -- Harvie Ward, an easy-swinging North Carolinian who was spurned by United States Walker Cup selectors a year ago, thwarted Frank Stranahan's bid for a third British amateur golf championship today when he trounced the Toledo, Ohio, spark plug heir, 6 and 5, in their all-American final.

BERLIN, Sunday, June 1 -- The Russian-inspired drive of the German Communists to seal off West Berlin and stifle the influence of a free community on the totalitarian state now being organized in East Germany moved inexorably toward a climax today.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio begins the final phase of his campaign next week confident he will win the Republican Presidential nomination if he can hold his own in June.

A PROFESSOR of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, Lyman Bryson is also director of that excellent, literate weekly radio program, "Invitation to Learning" -- a program based upon the novel concept that not all Americans are mental bubblegum chewers.

ANOTHER two weeks and the big-league summer music season will be beginning. Most of the major cities will have their usual outdoor concerts. In this city the Goldman Band will begin the Guggenheim Memorial Concerts in Central Park on June 18 and five days later Dimitri Mitropoulos will launch the series at Lewisohn Stadium.
ST. PAUL, Minn., May 31 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Oscar L. Chapman warned today that any attempt by the Democratic party to weaken the civil rights plank in its platform would mean trouble.

Period furniture, a selection of less expensive pieces in French and English styles and decorations from the estate of Fanny W. Le-Roy of New York will be auctioned on Thursday and Friday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

FEW dailies in America have a more picturesque circulation realm than the Spokane Spokesman-Review. It is distributed by newsboys in communities scattered across 350 rugged miles, from the Cascade Range to the irrigated Montana valleys east of the Continental Divide.

As was to be expected, the new anti-tuberculosis drugs, originally called "isonicotinic acid hydrazides," but now lumped together under the general term "isoniazid," were thoroughly discussed at last week's annual meeting of the National Tuberculosis Association, held in Boston, Mass. Medical opinion on isoniazid is still divided.

There was simplicity and dignity in the ceremony in which General Ridgway assumed his new and difficult post in Europe. He is obviously aware of its grave responsibilities. He is called upon for the most conspicuous qualities of leadership at a time and in a situation that is critical and delicate.

TEN days ago the Family Service Association of America published a 124-page booklet. "The Adolescent and His World," which, although primarily intended for professional workers with young people, may very well interest the group of parents who are, as the saying goes, "psychoanalytically oriented."

ROANOKE, Va., May 31 (AP) -- Virginia Republicans named a new state chairman tonight and elected four delegates at large to the national convention, three of them supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and the fourth uncommitted.

NOW that "New Faces of 1952" has collected its share of critical kudos and is attracting the customers in droves to the Royale, it should be noted, that the smash musical seems headed for the movies. Last week Leonard Sillman, producer of the revue, divulged that "we are not considering offers from the major companies but intend to do it ourselves."

Two new versions of the Bible or parts of the Bible are now under way and their publication has been timed to coincide in the fall with the 500th anniversary of the printing of the Gutenberg Bible in Europe.

That political convulsions of the gravest kind are now taking place in Rumania seems clear. Ana Pauker has been dropped from the Politburo and given a place only in the subordinate Orgburo. Teohari Georgescu and Vasile Luca have also been dropped from the Politburo, the former being assigned to some unknown lesser job and the latter being handed over for party trial on charges of "opportunism" and "conciliatory attitudes."

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., May 31 -- Backers of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower filed rival victory forecasts today for Tuesday's South Dakota Republican primary in which an estimated 110,000 to 125,000 voters will pick fourteen delegates on a winner-take-all basis.

THE American Geographical Society is celebrating its centenary this year. Dr. J. K. Wright, a well-known historian and geographer, has commemorated the occasion by writing the society's history and tracing the more recent evolution of geography.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 31 -- President Getulio Vargas laid the cornerstone today of a steel mill to be built in the Minas Geraes state by a corporation of mixed capital in which the state has an interest and including a German steel company.

TRENTON, May 31 -- New Jersey's thirty-eight delegates and thirty-eight alternates to the Republican National Convention have been invited to meet both General Eisenhower and Senator Taft in New York on June 12. Notice of the invitations has been sent to the delegates and alternates by John Dickerson, chairman of the Republican State Committee.

PROBABLY no two big-game hunters will ever reach complete agreement as to what constitutes the "No. 1 Trophy," and in recent years the competition for outstanding trophies has been based on "size" rather than rarity, but a New York sportsman has just taken what is, unquestionably, the most unusual trophy of the past fifty years, a glacier bear.

In his scholarly article on the Presidential acceptability of Charles A. Carroll ("Portrait of the Perfect Candidate," May 18), Robert Bendiner overlooked the clincher: the name of Carroll has double R's and double L's.

In the May 18 TIMES Magazine, I noticed with Gilbert Millstein's article, "Carnie Biz -- Bigger Than Ever," photos of the Great Lester in action. One picture of the Buzz Saw Illusion had the notation above it, "For a small extra fee, magician will show crowd how saw really won't slice a girl in half."

PRINCETON, N. J., May 31 -- Employment opportunities for members of Princeton University's graduating class have reached a new high, it was reported today by Gordon G. Sikes, director of the university's placement bureau.

When General Eisenhower steps from his plane in Washington today he will be, for the second time, returning from Europe after a conspicuous triumph. On this occasion, however, he represents something of a dual personality. There are almost two General Eisenhowers.

EAST NORWICH, L. I., May 31 -- Mrs. Orin T. Leach of Laurel Hollow, Cold Spring Harbor, is chairman of the committee for the Holiday House Ball to be held for the benefit of North Shore Holiday House of Huntington on June 7 at the former residence of ex-Gov. Nathan L. Miller on Mill River Road, here.

SANTA FE, N. M., May 31 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio scored a 7-to-3 victory tonight over supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in a sharp battle for ten contested seats on New Mexico's fourteen-member delegation to the national convention.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 31 -- President Getulio Vargas laid the cornerstone today of a steel mill to be built in the Minas Geraes state by a corporation of mixed capital in which the state has an interest and including a German steel company.

EAST NORWICH, L. I., May 31 -- Mrs. Orin T. Leach of Laurel Hollow, Cold Spring Harbor, is chairman of the committee for the Holiday House Ball to be held for the benefit of North Shore Holiday House of Huntington on June 7 at the former residence of ex-Gov. Nathan L. Miller on Mill River Road, here.

SANTA FE, N. M., May 31 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio scored a 7-to-3 victory tonight over supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in a sharp battle for ten contested seats on New Mexico's fourteen-member delegation to the national convention.
