ALTHOUGH summer resorts on the lakes and mountains of New England are opening for the season, winter sports fans in the East can still find good skiing at Notch in New Hampshire. In the past few weeks thousands of skiers have been making the two-hour climb up 6,288-foot Mount Washington near by to Tuckerman's Ravine, the natural amphitheatre above the timberline.

The revenue bond base for financing the nation's growing network of toll express highways and motor-age bridges stands to be increased substantially this week by the flotation of $330,000,000 of bonds to finance Ohio's projected 241-mile expressway.

HONG KONG, May 31 -- The Peiping Government's "Five Anti" movement, which has involved a double-barreled political and economic assault on the Chinese urban middle class, is drawing to a close after three months of frenetic mass "confessions," accusations and financial levies.

THE American Book Publishers Council is not opposing a recent House resolution calling for an investigation of "certain phases of current literature'' on the theory that Congress has a right to investigate anything it wants, even publishers.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 (AP) -- Southpaw Joe Muir, who balked at being sent to the minors, won his second game of the year today as the Pirates beat the Phillies by 5 -- 3 in the first game of a three-game series.

One of the nation's most prolific ship buyers -- he has purchased seventy-five over the last five years -- has now gone in for railroads. He has just about completed the purchase of forty-six locomotives and tenders although he doesn't own a single inch of track-age.

THERE was trouble in Paradise the year that Janet Brownlee, a young New Yorker, arrived there to teach. In the Florida mining town, everything, including the school, was company-owned and talk of consolidation threatened to do away with the only contact the townspeople had with the world beyond the phosphate flats.

Opening night here was the most frightening thing I ever went through. The State Fair Auditorium here has more than 4,000 seats, and Alex [Miss Channing's husband] says the last row is exactly a football field away from the stage. I looked out opening night and told myself it was impossible for one human being to reach another a block away.

" THERE'S just two kinds of people, folks and trash," Uncle Wick tells Shelby. The Olmsteads are folks, the Cloptons are trash, but off-hand there does not seem to be much difference between the way Shelby Olmstead catches her Yankee husband, Stewart, and the way Jewel Clopton catches Shelby's brother, Wyatt.

" IM renting a place for the summer. Can I have a garden without too much work or expense?" The answer to this frequently asked question is "yes." Anyone can have a one-season garden, whether it be at the seashore, in the mountains or some place in between.

Gogol, who died in 1852, and whose centenary is being celebrated in many parts of the world, is certainly one of the most remarkable figures in Russian literature. In his work we can trace the gradual shift from the local color of romanticism to a national naturalism and subsequently to a realism with critical social undertones.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 31 -- The United Nations' annual month of Malik begins tomorrow. There are no reliable forecasts for the political weather.

A HISTORICAL romance souped up on the dry bones of the French Revolution. "Caroline Cherie" may be praised or critically cow-hided, according to the individual point of view. It all depends on which side of the fence the reader may be in relation to the current controversy over the naturalistic school of literature.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 1 -- To dispel "some misunderstanding abroad of the content of American independence, it seems necessary to make it as plain as possible that political independence is one thing, and independence in the realm of culture and spirit is entirely another."

LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 1 (UP) -- One thousand soldiers climbed from their sheltering holes after scientists exploded an atomic device 7,000 yards away today and advanced immediately toward the seared target area.

Following is the text of a speech on foreign policy delivered by Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, over the National Broadcasting Company network from Washington yesterday, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

We have been reading so much of late that is bad about some of the members of the Police Department that we feel it only fair to tell the public of a wonderful deed performed by the department on Thursday night, May 22.

A new ceramic tile, which is available in a series of textures from dead mat to high sheen, has been introduced by Kerama-Tiles. The collection is distinguished by a group of tiles that have a dull, rough finish. The process was developed by Carter Winter, who, with a group of other designers, has contributed a variety of interesting patterns.

The Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation has formed a new division to take over the manufacturing and related operations of the nitrogen and organic sections of the Solvay Process division and the sales of the products involved now handled by the Barrett and Solvay Sales divisions.

Only just returned a week ago from Arden House, where he had been privileged to watch the second American Assembly in action, this writer found -- and reported -- that the experience had left him with a definite sense of exhiliration.

Bad weather in several areas appears "mercifully" to have cut down the holiday week-end death toll on the highways. Even so, the fatalities are in the hundreds. Thus attention is again called to the need for remedial measures.

BALTIMORE, June 1 -- Maryland's $44,000,000 Chesapeake Bay Bridge, to be opened about mid-summer, stands to span more than a body of water. It is expected to bring the Eastern Shore and the Western Shores of the state, as the opposite sides of the Bay area are known, into closer unity of thought and habit, and to work other important social and economic changes -- all in time, of course.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, June 1 -- In a quick postscript to the removal and segregation today of a Communist leader from a prisoner-of-war compound on this island for conduct described as arrogant and insulting, Allied officials ordered the 80,000 captives on Koje to stop mass singing during the night.

PITTSBURGH, June 1 (UP) -- Ninth-inning home runs by Pete Castiglione and Ralph Kiner took a double-header victory right out of the hands of the Phils today as the Pirates roared back to win the nightcap, 2 -- 1, after dropping the opener, 5 -- 1, before 15,529 fans.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 1 -- A teeming rain hampered but did not halt Long Island's first benefit outboard speed boat regatta today on Dosoris Pond adjoining the Morgan estate. Three of the scheduled six races were completed and he enthusiasts decided to duplicate the regatta next Sunday with the proceeds again going to the Glen Cove Community Chest.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 1 -- Cadet Harry L. Van Trees Jr. of Kansas City, highest ranking student in this year's graduating class at the United States Military Academy, received nine of the twenty-three military and academic awards presented to members of the class at ceremonies here today.

Henry Laskau of the Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A. outclassed twenty-six rivals yesterday in capturing the National A. A. U. 10,000-meter walking title for the sixth straight year and, as he was in 1948, will be the No. 1 United States representative in this event at the Olympics.

The Rev. Michael Deacy of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral, in a Pentecost sermon yesterday, termed the struggle between communism and Christianity another phase of "the age-old conflict between the evil spirit and the Holy Ghost."

CHICAGO, June 1 -- The shadow of the impending winter wheat movement is over the futures market and, while there is some concern over dry weather conditions in the Northwest and western Canada, buyers probably will not have a great deal of confidence until the first run starts to market.

MANCHESTER, N. H., June 1 (AP) -- The finance chairman of New Hampshire's Eisenhower for President Committee offered to raise money tonight to have Republican National Convention delegates visit Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio as well as General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Obesity, Dr. F. Eugenia Whitehead reminded us the other day, is the nation's number one public health problem. The best way to solve it, she went on to say, is not to become overweight in the first place.
ST. LOUIS, June 1 -- The Polo Grounds Express, which swept through the West like a scourge only a month ago, almost wrecked itself running up a siding today.
The Rev. Dr. John Heuss, rectoreleet of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street, preached a Whitsunday sermon yesterday morning.

" Plants, Man and Life," a study by Edgar Anderson, Professor of Botany at Washington University, will be issued on Thursday by Little Brown. Mr. Anderson traces the history of weeds and cultivated plants, showing man's effect upon plants rather than the effects of plants upon man.
Max Bloom, Bronx chairman of the Liberal party, announced yesterday the following designations or nominations for Representativess in Congress, State Senators and Assemblymen in Bronx County:

BARCELONA, Spain, June 1 -- In a message addressed to the thirty-fifth International Eucharistic Congress Pope Pius XII today called upon the Roman Catholic world to intensify prayers "for true peace."

CHICAGO, June 1 -- The Dodgers regained first place in the National League race today. Before the second largest National League crowd of the year, 40,389, the Brooks nosed out the Cubs, 3 -- 2 at Wrigley Field. A fine relief performance by Joe Black helped.

Along with many thousands of long-suffering car owners I read with considerable dismay your excellent article of May 26 on the proposed increases in automobile - insurance rates. No doubt the insurance companies have valid reasons for seeking such large rate increases at this time.

LONDON, June 1 -- The problem of how clothes moths kept alive before there were any human beings on earth with clothes for them to fed on has been solved by a group of Government biolo gists here, according to an official report. This document on pest infestation was published last week.
RALEIGH, N. C., June 1 (AP) -- Former Senator William B. Umstead won the Democratic nomination for governor in yesterday's primary. The nomination is tantamount to election.

ROME, June 1 -- Pietro Nenni, Left-Wing Socialist leader, speaking in Milan today, said his party was willing to re-enter the Cabinet provided Premier Alcide De Gasperi fulfilled certain conditions, one of which was that Italy quit the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

QUITO, Ecuador, June 1 -- As Ecuadorians voted today to choose his successor, President Galo Plaza Lasso broadcast an appeal to the nation for the sake of democracy not to rebel against the result, whatever it might be.

CINCINNATI, June 1 (UP) -- Charlie Grimm took over as Braves manager today with the vow that "I'll try to win and win quickly." His team dropped the first game of a double-header to the Reds, 1 -- 0, but blasted eighteen hits in the nightcap to win, 9 -- 4, and snap a five-game losing streak.

During its fifty-six-performance run on Broadway in the late fall of 1949, Marc Blitzstein's "Regina" won many ardent admirers. A number of those enthusiasts, including eight members of the original cast, saw to it that the opera had a second chance last night by presenting it in concert form at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A.

HONG KONG, June 1 -- The third stage of the "land reform," involving the expropriation and redistribution of landlords' property, has been completed in large parts of southwest and northwest China, according to recent Chinese Communist dispatches.
MILWAUKEE, June 1 (AP) -- Three Detroit keglers hung up as many new scoring records for the current American Bowling Congress tournament today, one of the men registering two of the marks.
With the coming of June summer group exhibitions begin to make their appearance in the art galleries.
PARIS, June 1 -- Jaroslav Drobny retained the French tennis championship today and Doris Hart of Miami, Fla., wrested the women's title from Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio.

The $5 and S. $10 stickers showing payment of the city auto use tax go on sale today at the offices of City Collector Alexander E. Frontera in the five boroughs. Individuals and business concerns subject to the tax have through Monday, June 16, to purchase the required stamps, which must be affixed to the windshields of their motor vehicles.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 1 (AP) -- The Minnesota Democratic-Farmer Labor party unanimously endorsed today a 34-year-old Minneapolis attorney and close friend of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat, for the nomination for Governor in the September primary.

The problem of supplying the free world with mica -- essential in a host of defense and industrial uses -- apparently has been solved, it was learned last week. Attempts to produce mica, the only nonmetallic mineral classed during the war as strategic, in commercial sheets by synthetic means have won considerable success.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- The United States this year holds one of the poorest trade balances on record in world meat markets because of high imports and low exports, trade specialists at the Chicago Stock Yards reported today.
Arthur W. Wallander, city civil defense director, reminded New Yorkers yesterday that the air raid sirens were sounded at noon daily merely to insure that they were in working order.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- W. D. Matthews, Canadian Minister to the United States, said today the St. Lawrence Seaway would take from four and a half to five years to complete after it was begun possibly in "the spring of 1953."
Yesterday's rain forced a change in the scheduling of two important golf events in the metropolitan area.

Andrew G. Clauson Jr., president of the Board of Education, announced yesterday that the board had approved a list of nineteen school building projects for inclusion in the 1953 capital budget. The structures, estimated to cost $59,765,000 for building and equipment, would provide for 26,450 pupils.

" I'll die if I don't start to design soon!" These words were spoken by Anne Fogarty as she left Times Hall after seeing the Fashions of The Times production five years ago. Her good fairy must have overheard her make the remark, for within a few weeks she was employed in her first position as assistant designer.

If only because so many quiz shows have disintegrated into arch and disingenuous sessions in which the guests strive to be terribly bright, it is always rewarding to return to the old standby, "Twenty Questions." The program is as good as ever and real fun to tune in.

ABILENE, Kan., June 1 -- This was not the quietest Sunday in Abilene's history. Everywhere townspeople seem to be doing something as the mid-Kansas community of 6,000 prepared to welcome a native son everyone here seems to know as General Ike.
Excellent job prospects for the 3,000 graduates of the day sessions of City College, Hunter College, Brooklyn College and Queens College were reported yesterday by the Board of Higher Education.
The Port of New York in 1951 handled 32,482,000 tons of seaborne foreign trade of all categories, a gain over the total in 1950, but its share of the national volume declined.

The American Yarn and Processing Company and the Efird Mills, Inc., have consolidated under the name of American Efird Mills, it was announced over the weekend. The merger brings together two companies making a wide range of combed and carded cotton yarns and fine worsted, synthetic and blended yarns, with a combined total of about 152,000 spindles.

The Yankees, who were to have engaged the Indians at the Stadium yesterday, were rained out for the second straight afternoon and now Dan Topping and Del Webb, co-owners of the Bombers, know how Horace Stoneham of the Giants feels. For the first time since Sept. 30, 1950, the Yankees lost a Sunday date at home because of he weather.

BERLIN, June 1 -- East Germany technically closed its doors yesterday to outsiders, but the new travel regulations announced a day after the Contractual Agreement giving West Germany virtual sovereignty was signed in Bonn, have been only partly applied.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- The Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report predicted today that "tremendous pressures" would be brought to bear against twenty-nine reorganization plans pending before Congress.

The Long Island Transit Authority is certifying today to Governor Dewey and other state and local officials that the public interest requires that the authority have power to acquire all or part of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road.

A two-family dwelling on lot 24 by 100 feet at 1824 East Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Dr. Arthur Rubovitz to Sidney S. and Eleanor Block in a deal negotiated by the Harry M. Lewis Company, brokers, who also arranged mortgage financing with the Fulton Service Corporation.

One of the largest free sample promotions ever undertaken in the housewares industry is being conducted by Ekco Products Company, Chicago manufacturing firm. Samples of Ovenex tin bakeware are being sent to nearly 25,000 retail and department store buyers, according to John Brooks, vice president in charge of houseware sales.

Mr. and Mrs. George Home of 961 Todt Hill Road, Dongan Hills, S. I., became the proud foster parents of three nestling robins last week. Things are going fine now. But the Hornes are worrying about the fall: What and how do you teach a fledgling about migration?

Wall Street once again is preparing for its annual visitation of professors of business and economics and of prize college students who intend to teach those subjects. This year, under the sponsorship of the Joint Committee on education, there are to be ten of the former and thirty of the latter.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Congress is showing signs of determination to dispose of its 1952 legislative program in a whirlwind finish during the five weeks between now and the July political conventions.

PANAMA, June 1 -- Col. Jose Antonio Remon received in a brief ceremony today his credentials as President-elect of Panama from the hands of Ernesto de la Guardia Jr., chairman of the National Election Board. Colonel Remon will take office Oct. 1 for a four-year term.
PIERRE, S. D., June 1 -- General of the Army Douglas McArthur took sides today in the sharply contested primary campaign here in a telegram urging support for Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- The Senate Preparedness subcommittee said today that Russia got as much firepower, if not more, from a 500-man infantry battalion as the United States got from one of its 800-man battalions:

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- The Government program for a 50 per cent increase in newsprint production passed the three-quarter mark today with approval of a $30,000,000 newsprint project at Millinocket, Me.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A doctor reported a new development in anesthetics today. The system may make it possible for surgeons simply to serve their patients a "cocktail" before an operation.

CLEVELAND, June 1 -- Plans for one of the most comprehensive undertakings in the history of the $23,000,000,000 electric power and light industry were reported here today by executives of the nation's privately-owned power companies.

Referring to your headline in THE TIMES of Sunday, May 25, "textbook Censors Alarm Educators," in this contest between freedom of speech and of the press, on the one hand, and subversive propaganda on the other, is there not a middle ground ?

More than 7,000 ordinary golfers have done what the best golf pros couldn't do in the 1948, 1950 and 1951 United States Open tournaments -- "they beat Ben Hogan," The Associated Press reported yesterday.

PUSAN, Korea, Monday, June 2 (AP) -- The Government of the Republic of Korea today appeared ready to close down the National Assembly if the legislative body refused to support President Syngman Rhee.

Indifference to our religious heritage menaces Christianity in this country, the Rev. Dr. Albert J. Penner warned yesterday in his sermon at the Broadway Tabernacle Church, Congregationalist, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.

TOKYO, Monday, June 2 -- United Nations delegates at Panmunjom dared the Communists yesterday to accept a rescreening of war prisoners held in South Korean stockades, under impartial control or with Chinese and North Korean participation.

ZURICH, June 1 -- The Swiss Federal Council a few days ago recommended that Parliament should sanction the prolongation of Switzerland's membership in the European Payments Union for another two years from July 1, 1952.

Groton School at Groton, Mass., one of the country's most socially exclusive boys' preparatory schools, has completed arrangements for the admission of a Negro student for the first time since the school's founding sixty-eight years ago.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 1 -- An appeal to President Truman to veto the McCarran immigration bill was adopted today by the Polish-American Congress as it closed its third national convention here today. The group endorsed the rival Celler bill, although urging amendment to allow entry of 7,000 former Polish soldiers now in Great Britain and the remaining Polish displaced persons in Germany.

BERLIN, June 1 -- Without warning or announced reason, the Russians have shifted gears in Berlin. But they have not, as was expected, gone from second into high. They have gone from second back to first and the offensive against Berlin's communications has become a defensive against the spirit of freedom emanating from the Western half of this city.

Prices of cotton futures scored gains of 44 to 82 points last week. The best gain on the New York Cotton Exchange was registered by the near-by July delivery. In the preceding week prices ended mixed, with net changes ranging between an advance of 2 points and a decline of 17.

You nave been most generous in allowing space for the discussion of the proposal to fine parents for the vandalism of children. Henry Epstein's contribution in your issue of May 29 evidences how little need there is for this ill-considered amendment. As he admits, both the Domestic Relations Court Act and the Penal Law now permit the fining of parents who neglect properly to control their children.
Those who have wearied of looking at complicated road maps over the week-end might be interested in some simpler versions of cartography, displayed in a new collection of maps at Altman's.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower returned home today and received a noisy eighteen - gun salute -- seventeen from the United States and one extra political blast from his chief Republican rival for the Presidency, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

Thousands of holiday week-enders splashed and slithered homeward last night over water-logged streets and highways. Not only was it the fourth consecutive rainy Sunday in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area, but it also produced the second heaviest one-day rainfall of an exceedingly wet spring -- 1.33 inches.
TOKYO, Monday, June 2 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,268, for Sunday's operations:

TOMMY HOLMES is as nice a guy as ever managed a big league ball club. But he had to pay the penalty for the failures of others in accordance with baseball's oldest unwritten law: in time of trouble fire the manager. So the Boston Braves eased Tommy out of office and replaced him with Charlie Grimm, who also is a nice guy but slightly crazy.

AMSTERDAM, June 1 -- The Amsterdam stock market -- following a week's "strike" during which the exchange was closed --reopened last Wednesday following an exchange of letters between Pieter Lieftinck, Finance Minister, and the board.

The Elder Dempster Lines. Ltd., announced here yesterday that it was reopening its cargo service between the United States and the Belgian Congo this month for the first time in a decade. Although the company has been operating regular services between this country and West Africa since the close of World War II, calls in the Congo never were resumed.

As parishioners prayed yesterday for the recovery of two jewelled crowns stolen Friday night from the Roman Catholic Votive Shrine of Regina Pacis, Twelfth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, the police were seeking a green sedan that had been reported parked near the church about the time of the robbery.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., June 1 -- A new method of gathering more accurate facts about wind speed and direction, which may be used to forecast which way radioactive materials will scatter, has been developed by the Army Signal Corps, the Army announced today.

As every motorist, and indeed every mother, knows, this is the season for tarring the road. A month or two back, highway officials came around, studied the ruts and holes made by the winter and then went away, sadly shaking their heads.

Lawmakers and business men will find a treasury of provocative ideas in "Business Fluctuations" * by Robert A. Gordon of the University of California. It ties down the theories of Lord Keynes and applies them to the economy of today.

The Federal Government now holds 35 to 40 per cent of the savings of Americans. Governmental units are increasing their share of the national wealth, while the average private citizen's share has dropped. One-sixth of the nation's personal income is paid out in Federal and other governmental pay checks, interest and welfare payments.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 1 -- Israel's Communist party concluded its biennial congress today with resolutions condemning Zionism, calling for the return of Arab refugees and the expulsion of "American imperialists" and demanding that the state abandon all territories not assigned to it by the United Nations partition resolution of 1947.

Dr. John Dewey, the philosopher from whose teachings has grown the school of progressive education and "learning by doing," died of pneumonia in his home, 1158 Fifth Avenue, at 7 o'clock last night. He was 92 years old.

PARIS, June 1 -- The long Whitsuntide week-end produced a temporary lull today in the current struggle between the Government and France's powerful Communist party, but Communist-dominated unions warned that the undeclared truce would end Wednesday.

The forward-looking spirit of the United Nations has now come to rest in a velvety haven at 20 East Forty-sixth Street where the plush Hollywood decor of an abandoned restaurant may well surprise strangers to this town.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio called today for a United States foreign policy backed by unbeatable air power and aimed at protecting the "security, the peace and the solvency of America."

As part of the city's accident- reduction program, the Department of Traffic has started to install newly designed signs to improve observance of control regulations, Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley announced yesterday.

Pound sterling was hit hard again last week. British needs to cover oil payments here brought out offerings considerably in excess of the market's ability to absorb, resulting in a break to $2.78 3/16, a new low. Thursday's final was $2.78 5/8, a loss of 1 1/16, cents from the previous week.
Three new films, including an importation from Russia, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

JAMESTOWN, R I., June 1 (AP) -- Raymond E. Leonard, 39 years old, of 285 South Central Avenue, Hartsdale, N. Y., a Brown University alumnus, who had been participating in reunion activities with classmates here, was killed and a companion seriously injured early this morning when their sports car turned over on a twisting road at the southerly end of this island community.

In testimony last week before a subcommittee of the Senate Armed Services Committee representatives of the National Guard Association made a surprising switch in their position on the bill to establish an organized, available and effective Federal military reserve force. This bill was adopted by the House last October. It is now before the Senate.

The Senate has rejected, 52 -- 18, a proposal which would have permitted price-wage controls to expire June 30. Most economists agree that, though they are comparatively inactive at the moment, the forces making for inflation are still present. Therefore it would seem desirable, other things being equal, that the machinery for price-wage controls be continued for the time being under a directive that they be administered flexibly and intelligently.

Some educators are undoubtedly concerned, as Benjamin Fine reports in THE TIMES of May 25, about what he terms a "censorship" of school and college textbooks. But other educators are welcoming the aid of alert and informed citizens who are increasingly aware of a prevailing left-wing philosophy in teaching materials used by their children.
PARIS, June 1 -- The launching last Monday of the new French Government's 3.5 per cent loan, linked to the fluctuations of gold on the Paris free market has resulted in two developments.

The excessive May rains that continued into the first day of this month caused serious concern yesterday to fruit and vegetable growers in this state and neighboring New Jersey. Most agricultural experts refused, however, to estimate the extent of the damage to crops, although the overabundance of rain has disrupted farming schedules in the two states.
Trial of a sea-salvage claim involving unusual circumstances will open in Federal Court this morning before Judge J. Skelly Wright, a visiting jurist from Louisiana.

NEW DELHI, India, June 1 -- With Chinese Communist troops gradually spreading along India's northeast frontier, the Central Government is devoting urgent attention to fortifying the border regions by improving communications and bringing about closer contact between the hill tribes and the administration.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 1 -- Constant rains that have battered down breezes, together with individual club events, have placed a damper on the association championship events this season out on Long Island Sound.

A Nobel Prize winner and a Pulitzer Prize winner are among the twelve men and women born in Brooklyn or associated with the borough who have been chosen to receive the annual "Youth Oscar" awards of Youth United, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Ted Gray held Washington to six hits and captured his fifth decision for Detroit, 6 -- 3, in the second game of a double-header today after the Senators won the opener, 4 -- 3.

The primary task of the church today is to find persons who will be "full-time ambassadors of Christ," the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers asserted yesterday in his sermon at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Sixty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The race between Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower held the center of interest today as Republicans prepared to select 124 delegates this week, virtually completing the roll of the National Convention.

Twenty-six couples, ranging in age from a chipper 67 to a spry 90, who somehow never got around to a formal observance of their fifty or more years of married life, were the guests yesterday afternoon of the Grand Street Boys Association's sixteenth annual golden wedding party.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 (UP) -- Gov. Earl Warren counted today on a sizeable victory in his home state primary Tuesday to boom his stock as a compromise Republican Presidential candidate.

SAIGON, Indo-China, June 1 -- The forthcoming visit to Washington of Jean Letourneau, French Resident Minister for the Associated States of Indo-China, is expected here to produce a thoroughgoing re-axamination of the Indo-China situation, particularly with regard to perspectives for the future.
ROME, June 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of Pope Pius XII's message today to the Eucharistic Congress in Barcelona, Spain, in the English translation supplied by the Vatican press office:

Candidates for bachelors' degrees at Columbia University were advised yesterday to trust in God absolutely and to seek His help through prayer whenever they find themselves incapable of surmounting life's crises

The first of the ten-game series between Samuel Reshevsky of this city and Svetozar Gligoric of Belgrade at the Manhattan Chess Club was adjourned after forty-two moves yesterday, with Reshevsky claiming a favorable position. Play will continue this morning.

LONDON, June 1 -- Although a modest rally developed in the gilt-edge securities last week and no change was made in the bank rate, the stock markets and the City generally remain uneasy and nervous over the failure of the pound sterling to recover from its recent weakness.

ALAN VILLIERS, the sea-going Australian who wrote nine books about his maritime adventures, has recently taken to writing books about the oceans themselves and the saltwater adventures of others. Three years ago his lively history, "The Coral Sea," was published. Today his new one is with us, "Monsoon Seas: The Story of the Indian Ocean."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has Humphrey Bogart, winner of Academy Award laurels for his acting in "The African Queen," for the starring role in "Battle Circus," a drama about the Army Medical Corps Surgical Unit 66 behind the front lines in Korea.

A move to have the small community of Richmond Town at Staten Island's center declared a national monument has been made by Park Commissioner Robert Moses. Representatives of the National Park Service already have inspected the site and a decision from Washington is awaited.
WESTON, Mass., June 1 (AP) -- The All-United States team overwhelmed the United States Reserves, 12 -- 2, in the final of the women's national lacrosse championship today at Nickerson Field.

Five weeks before the scheduled departure of the American team for Helsinki, the United States Olympic Committee still lacks $490,000 of the $650,000 needed to send a full complement of 332 athletes and accompanying officials to the 1952 games.

LOS ANGELES, June 1 (UP) -- The Manchester United soccer team, champion of the English League, scored a hard-fought 2-to-0 victory over the fiery Atlas Club of Guadalajara, Mexico, before 17,000 fans today in a game highlighted by a near riot and several fist fights.

ST. LOUIS, June 1 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum, setting a new competitive course record with a blistering 64 on the final round, today won his first Western Open golf championship. He had a 72-hole total of 274, six under par.

The General Electric Company yesterday reported that retail sales of major appliances are improving. Clarence H. Linder, general manager of the major appliance division, said that unit retail sales during May were up about 24 per cent from April and about 25 per cent higher than in May, 1951.

BELLEVILLE, N. J., June 1 -- Moved from the Harlem River to the Passaic, its original site, for the first time since 1901, the New York Rowing Association's regatta was held on schedule today with the New York Athletic Club capturing the bulk of the honors. The Winged Footers took ten of the fourteen events, one a row-over, and easily dominated the competition.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 1 -- Ceylon's controversial policy on rubber, which has permitted the shipment of nearly 15,000 long tons of this strategic commodity to Communist China since last October over protests from the United States, will be re-examined by the new Government elected by an overwhelming majority last week. This was disclosed by Prime Minister Dudley Senanayake.

The State University Maritime College at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, oldest maritime school in the United States, will hold its ninety-sixth graduation exercises in the college armory at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow. Ninety-seven white-uniformed cadets will be graduated at that time as the first class to complete the college's four-year baccalaureate program.
A strike pattern as irregular as a hooked rug developed yesterday at big carpet and rug factories in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

Warning of a continuing attempt by Communists to infiltrate all phases of American life, United States Attorney Myles J. Lane told a National Guard regiment yesterday at a communion breakfast that spies had given Soviet Russia some of our top secrets, including a project for a platform 3,000 miles in space.
A persistent clerk in a midtown hotel turned detective after he had been held up yesterday afternoon and brought about the arrest of one of a pair who, he said, had robbed him.

BOSTON, June 1 (AP) -- Ellis Kinder, Red Sox right-hander, gained his eighteenth straight triumph over the White Sox-today, 3 -- 2. Fred Hatfield's first home run of the season helped Kinder win the game that was played in a steady drizzle.

The mass retail distribution methods of the United States, in contrast to the small French family-operated retail store, will be studied by heads of French Chambers of Commerce. Eleven arrived here yesterday by air for a month's visit arranged by the Mutual Security Agency. Three more, including Jacques Fougerolle, president of the Paris Chamber of Commerce, are scheduled to arrive tomorrow on the Ile de France.

The New York Public Library's neighborhood branches in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island, and reference divisions at Central Building, Fifth Avenue and Forty- second Street, go on summer schedule today. The schedule will be observed through Sept. 30.

PITTSBURGH, June 1 -- Despite the Memorial Day holiday the steel industry last week was able to advance its operating rate to 102.5 per cent of rated capacity -- up one point from the week before. This is one of the highest operating rates for many months.
Refusing to loosen their grip on "The Magic Bed-Knob," Leland Hayward and Joshua Logan expect to get a dramatization of Mary Norton's book for children on the stage one of these days.

The six-story apartment house for twenty families on plot 50 by 100 feet at 1430-32 Third Avenue, corner of Eighty-first Street, in the Yorkville section of Manhattan, has been sold by the 235 East Fifty-sixth Street Corporation to Leonard Equities, Inc., for investment.
PUSAN, Monday, June 2 (Reuters) -- The Syngman Rhee Government yesterday accused its allies of "interfering with internal affairs" and threatened to oust all United Nations agencies.

BARCELONA, Spain, June 1 -- The International Catholic Migration Commission, at the end of its general conference here this week, appealed to "Governments with resources and territories to liberalize their immigration legislation" to permit the resettlement of surplus populations, refugees and exiles.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- The Midwest's newest and largest psychoosomatic and psychiatric institute, opened just a year, is helping to break down the resistance that exists against accepting the relationship between physical and mental ills.
BUENOS AIRES, June 1 -- One of the last remaining sources of information on activities and proposals of President Juan Peron's opposition will no longer be available to the Argentine public.

The most noteworthy feature of business reports for May was the improvement in some of the depressed consumers' goods items at the mill level, according to the monthly letter of the National City Bank of New York for June, issued today.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- The Government reported today that 1,101,000 unemployed workers applied for jobless benefits in May -- a 1952 monthly low due to a seasonal increase in outdoor work.
Bobby Dykes, 153 3/4 pounds, Miami, won a unanimous ten-round decision over Joe Miceli, 148 1/2, New York, last night, at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn.

Violence flared again yesterday in the twelve-week-old strike of 1,800 employes at the Sunshine Biscuit Company's plant in Long Island City, Queens. Nine men were arrested on charges of malicious mischief and third-degree assault after windows and windshields of two independently driven trucks were broken near the Manhattan end of the Queens-Midtown tunnel.

NEWARK, June 2 -- Kings Super Markets, which operate twenty stores in North Jersey, filed suit in Superior Court in Trenton today to upset the new law giving the state the power to fix the price of cigarettes. A state order, setting a minimum retail price of $2.02 a carton and 21 cents a pack, went into effect today.
With the heaviest travel season since the war unfolding, Custom House officials have sent into their special training school on Stone Street a record peacetime class of inspector candidates.

Two of the largest member agencies participating in CARE, the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, have withdrawn their sponsorship on the ground that CARE no longer supplies the person-to-person relief for which it was organized and that the general relief work in which it is now engaged could be handled "more efficiently" through regular channels.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $1,300,000,000 of 91-day Treasury bills to be dated June 5 and to mature Sept. 4 were opened to the Federal Reserve Banks today.

Trading on the New York Curb Exchange, for the first time in sixty-five years, yesterday continued until 3:30 P. M. The Midwest, Detroit and Pittsburgh Stock Exchanges also continued for the extra half-hour.

Opera Futures, the workshop that presented Benjamin Britten's "Rape of Lucretia" at the end of its first session, last night presented the same composer's "Albert Herring" as the culminating work of its second session. It was the comic opera's first presentation in New York.

BERLIN, Tuesday, June 3 -- In an obvious retaliation for Soviet measures against Allied highway patrols between Berlin and the West, British troops sealed off today the Soviet radio station in West Berlin.

The increasing frequency with which domestic concerns are seeking restrictions on imported products was called "alarming" yesterday for the large number of persons in this city deriving income and employment from foreign commerce.

Public Service Company of Indiana, Inc., reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on April 30, a net income of $8,943,287, equal to $2.29 a share on 3,578,655 common shares outstanding. In the similar period ended with April, last year, net income was $8,350,357, or $2.48 each, on 2,918,587 common shares then outstanding.
Reduced sales and earnings for the quarterly and annual periods ended on April 26 were reported yesterday by R. H. Macy Co., Inc.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Tuesday, June 3 -- The accidental firing by an Allied soldier of a heavy machine gun near a prison stockade on this island killed one North Korean captive and wounded another this morning.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- The combination of favorable weather news, bearish crop reports and big receipts accumulated over the long holiday period was too much for the bulls and prices for all grains receded sharply. Support was poor at the start because of the heavy late short covering last Thursday and there was heavy pressure, especially in wheat, through the session.
PARIS, June 2 -- French national doubles tennis champions successfully defended their titles in all divisions today as the tournament came to an end at Roland Garros Stadium.

Mrs. Anna Wentworth repeated yesterday the accusation she had made before the State Crime Commission last September that she had seen former District Attorney Herman Methfessel of Richmond County in a gambling house while he held public office.

Two more Canadian newsprint producers, including International Paper Company, announced they would increase the price of newsprint $10 a ton on June 15. International and the Mersey Paper Company of Nova Scotia informed customers of the rise by telegram during the holiday week-end, but many publishers did not receive the news until yesterday.

A 1952 Horatio Alger plaque was presented yesterday to Charles F. Kettering by the Horatio Alger Awards Committee Colleges Association at the association office at 30 Rockefeller Plaza. Mr. Kettering, who is research consultant to the General Motors Corporation, was honored for his work in enhancing "the American tradition of overcoming obstacles to achieve success."

Combined dollar sales volume of the twelve major New York City department stores for May was 5.5 per cent below that for May last year, according to the study made public yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The showing continued the unbroken string of monthly volume declines this year in comparison with the first five months of last year, a period affected partly by abnormal buying and generally by inflation.

Dire financial difficulties face many manufacturers of branded jewelry unless Congress enacts a "fair trade" law, Leo Weisfield, president of Weisfield's, a West Coast jewelry chain, said in an interview yesterday.

QUITO, Ecuador, June 2 -- Twice deposed in the past as President of Ecuador, Dr. Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra appeared tonight to have won election for the third time by an astonishing margin over his nearest rival, Dr. Ruperto Alarcon Falconi, the conservative candidate.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The United States granted today formal diplomatic recognition to the Bolivian Government that seized control April 11 after a bloody revolution.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, June 3 -- Further details of the 30,000,000 [$84,000,000] barter agreement negotiated in Peiping between Red China's International Trade-Promotion Committee and three unofficial Japanese visitors were made public today.

Quite an array of favorites paraded home at Belmont Park yesterday and leading the delegation was the Charfran Stable's 3-year-old Blenomar. Piloted by Eddie Arcaro, the Blenheim II colt led L. W. Jennings' Eolus to the wire by a length, with the same margin separating A. L. Aste's Homely Duke from the runner-up.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 2 -- With Nicholas Schenck, president, and Charles Moskowitz, vice president and treasurer, here from New York, a series of top-level policy meetings got under way this morning at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer with Dore Schary, vice president in charge of production, and other studio executives.

The steel situation was right back again yesterday as a problem for the stock market. After the Supreme Court ruled the Government seizure of the steel industry illegal, prices rallied. When a strike call went out from the union leaders shortly thereafter the share list promptly sagged. These two major shifts in the steel situation left the market in a highly ragged state.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the Supreme Court majority opinion voiding President Truman's seizure of the steel industry; digests of the five concurring opinions, and the conclusion of the dissenting opinion:
TOKYO, Tuesday, June 3 -- Maj. Gen. William K. Harrison Jr., senior United Nations truce delegate, told the Communists today: "The entire future of the armistice negotiations is now up to your side."
ABILENE, Kan., June 2 (UP) -- This little Midwestern town neared a frenzy of excitement today as it prepared to welcome a famous son.

The idea that youngsters who are failing in school could do better "if they would just try" gets no support at all from the findings of an unpublished research study just completed by Emmy Drake Jenkins, a student at the School of Social Work, Adelphi College, Garden City, L. I., as part of her work for a master's degree.

BONN, Germany, June 2 -- The West German debate on ratification of the European Defense Community treaty and the sovereignty convention, signed last week, opened today. Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of the Social Democratic party, raised the specter that the Bonn Government policies would lead to the complete militarization of East Germany.

Looking curiously but kindly at the paleface from the city was Hezekiah Cobb, confirmed countryman and unterrified fox hunter in the region where George Washington used in the same sporting pursuit a horse that (as he put it) "could go along."
BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 2 -- The National Assembly proclaimed Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej as new Premier of Rumania today to succeed Dr. Petru Groza, who was named President of the republic.

Harold Holden has been elected president and director of Eastern Corp., succeeding Clyde B. Morgan, who resigned last July to become president of Rayonier, Inc. Ira D. Wallach, who continues as executive vice president of Eastern, has been chief executive officer since Mr. Morgan's resignation.

The current stoppage in the steel industry as a result of the Supreme Court's decision, marks the third time since early April that the nation's basic producers have felt the loss of production. Some 950,000 tons of the vital metal were lost in April, 1,350,000 tons in May and now a daily loss of approximately 270,000 tons.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 -- Harry D. Lemmon, the pilot aboard the tanker Michael when she was in collision with the tanker A. C. Dodge in the Delaware River on the night of May 25, denied today that he ran from the bridge to a lifeboat after the crash.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Truman urged the Senate today to approve two agreements putting West Germany on a footing of equality among nations and binding an enemy of World War II to the free world's defense alliance.

A would-be bank robber who escaped although three armed guards were near by was foiled yesterday in an attempt to hold up the Irving Trust Company at 100 East Forty-second Street by an alert 27-year-old teller, described by his superiors in the bank as a "guy with real guts."

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 2 -- Delegates favorable to the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower outnumbered backers of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio by a 21-to-4 margin today as the Missouri State Republican Convention completed the formalities of naming a twenty-six-member group to the Chicago nominating convention.

John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner for Germany, expressed confidence here yesterday that the agreements signed in Bonn and Paris last week, designed to give sovereignty to West Germany and bring the republic into a European army, would be ratified despite an all-out drive by the Soviet Union to block the move.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 2 -- A continued high level of business for the balance of the year in the plumbing and heating industry was predicted here today by business leaders attending the seventieth annual convention of the National Association of Master Plumbers.

United States District Judge David A. Pine, in ruling on April 29 that President Truman's seizure of the steel-making industry was an illegal act, refuted in vigorous language the Government's contention that the President's power of seizure was inherent in law and the Constitution.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Two of the four Supreme Court justices appointed by President Truman and four appointees of the late President Roosevelt joined today in holding the steel seizure unconstitutional.

JOHANNESBURG, June 2 -- The African National Congress, representing African natives, and the South African Indian Congress have set June 26 as the date for starting a mass campaign to defy "unjust laws." These include "Europeans [whites only]" notices on the railways, laws restricting movement by the natives, curfew regulations and the restrictions against entering white queues in public buildings.

LONDON, June 2 (UP) -- Don Gehrmann of Wisconsin, America's top mile runner, bettered the British record for the 1,000-yard event today as he won two races in the conclusion of the two-day British track games at White City Stadium.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP) -- Connie Marrero of the Senators scattered nine hits tonight to post his fifth victory of the season, beating the Tigers, 5 to 2.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP) -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins testified today that the Army had less than half the anti-aircraft units needed to defend this country and overseas bases from Russian attacks.
CINCINNATI, June 2 (AP) -- Max Surkont struck out eleven Cincinnati batters tonight and yielded only four hits as Charlie Grimm's Braves took the rubber game of a three-game series, 4 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The President announced in advance of the Supreme Court's decision on the legality of his seizure of the steel industry that he would abide by its finding; therefore, once more the irresistible force and the immovable object created by the language of the Constitution will not collide.

The smiling soldiers in the pay line at the finance window at Governors Island were doubly enriched as the increase in pay and dependents' allowances, provided by the new Armed Forces Pay Bill, went into effect yesterday.

Mayor Impellitteri and Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan led 2,500 persons at noon yesterday in honoring twenty-seven policemen and welcoming to the Police Department 503 probationary patrolmen. Both officials, as they addressed the new members in City Hall's sunlit plaza, offered words of warning.
Irving Silver has sold the two-family house at 114-20 109th Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, to Joseph J. Widmer and Gustave Haltiner. Title was insured by the Guaranteed Title and Mortgage Company.

WEST POINT, June 2 -- The 523 members of the graduating class of the United States Military Academy paraded with the Corps of Cadets on the historic Plain for the last time today. Tomorrow, they will receive their diplomas and commissions as second lieutenants in the Army or Air Force at the academy's 150th graduation exercises.

A taste of things to come was served on a platter yesterday as thirty-seven waiters and four waitresses, wearing their restaurant uniforms instead of the traditional academic caps and gowns, were graduated from the first waiters' class of the State University's Institute of Applied Arts and Sciences in Brooklyn.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., June 2 (AP) -- A nuclear physicist who helped create the atom bomb apologized for the Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombings to a Japanese delegation at the World Assembly of Moral Rearmament today.

The Moore-McCormack Lines has both the funds and the design for two new 25,000-ton liners for its service to South America, but is unable to go ahead with construction plans because of the inability of the Federal Maritime Administration to negotiate a firm contract, Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of the company, declared yesterday.

BOSTON, June 2 -- Lieut. Col. Robert Ellis Key of London, England, and Boston, former British officer, was named today as president of The Mother Church, The First Church of Christ, Scientist, in Boston.

Neighborhood retailers and small department stores are demonstrating a willingness to buy early for fall, exhibitors at the back-to-school and fall showing of the Metropolitan Juvenile Style Mart, Inc., reported yesterday. The pattern of fall buying has returned to normal, they noted, now that excess inventories built up after the start of the Korean war have been worked off.

LONDON, June 2 (UP) -- Mass Observation, a British public-opinion poll, disclosed today that 200 persons questioned knew more about the late President Roosevelt than they did about British celebrities.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today struck down a motion picture censor ordinance by which the City of Marshall, Tex., disapproved the showing of the film "Pinky."

The steel case has given rise to a Supreme Court decision far more important than the immediate production or non-production of steel. We have, in the opinion delivered by Justice Black yesterday and sustained by five other justices, a redefinition of the powers of the President.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 71 additional battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 16 killed, 54 wounded and 1 missing. The following casualties were listed for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

NEWARK, June 2 -- A public hearing on a plan to regulate the marketing of milk produced for sale in north Jersey and southern New York got under way here today at the Robert Treat Hotel. The sessions are being held by the United States Department of Agriculture and are expected to last at least two weeks.

A new book by Constance and Harmon Helmericks, authors of two volumes about life in Alaska, will be published by Little, Brown tomorrow. Entitled "The Flight of the Arctic Tern," the book describes the authors' travels in their Cessna 140, the "Arctic Tern" of the title, over thousands of miles of uncharted Northland.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 2 -- Bachelor of Arts degrees were presented this afternoon to 192 young women at the forty-fifth commencement of the College of New Rochelle. Fifteen hundred persons attended the ceremonies, held on the lawn.

Samuel Reshevsky took the lead yesterday in his ten-game match with Svetozar Gligoric of Belgrade at the Manhattan Chess Club, when the Yugoslav, without play, resigned the first test of the series, unfinished Sunday night, after having sealed his forty-second move.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 2 -- Charges that Communist China is using slave laborers will be made before a special United Nations committee that has been ordered to make an inquiry into forced labor practices in all parts of the world.

Not satisfied with only two adopted children, Senator Fred A. Seaton, Republican of Nebraska, and his wife, Gladys, arrived from Germany yesterday with two more they had taken to their hearts in a displaced persons orphanage in Bavaria.
The Hotels Statler Company has received approval from the National Production Authority to proceed with the construction of a 700-room hotel in Dallas, Texas, and a 450-room hotel in Hartford, Conn.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The treason conviction of California-born Tomoya Kawakita was upheld by the Supreme Court today in a 4-to-3 decision.

It was no surprise to learn that Col. Jose Antonio Remon has been elected President of Panama for a term beginning Oct. 1. North Americans can be wondering who their next President is going to be, but Panamanians ceased wondering the day "Chichi" Remon threw his hat into the ring.

TRENTON, June 2 (AP) -- A list of judicial appointments he will submit to the State Senate on Monday was announced tonight by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll. The Legislature will sit that day in continued veto session and the Senate will have to be called in special session at the same time to consider the appointments.

A hearing into Government complaints against thirteen local ship repair concerns for alleged over-the-ceiling wage rates was adjourned indefinitely yesterday afternoon after an all-day session that featured a barrage of motions by opposing counsel.

Bibb lettuce from New Jersey has just appeared on the wholesale market for the first time this spring. The shipment of the loose-leaf green, distinctive in taste and unusually tender, was quickly snapped up by buyers for hotels and restaurants.

A rise of twelve to fifteen points in the city's basic real estate tax rate of $3.08, already the highest in history, was forecast unofficially yesterday when the final valuations of taxable real estate and special franchises were set at $19,425,499,087 for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 2 -- Llanoria, Magnus Konow's six-meter yacht, today clinched the best-of-seven series to determine the United States representative in this class in the 1952 Olympics at Helsinki. Llanoria gained a 2-1 lead over Goose, Seawanhaka-Corinthian Club syndicate rival, during the week-end, and took both races today for a 4-1 margin.

George C. Johnson, president of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, has sent letters to all members of the House and Senate urging that Congress pass legislation to abolish Regulation X and the companion regulations imposed by the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration which restrict home mortgage credit.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 3 to 18 points net lower yesterday than on last Friday. The tone was barely steady.

PUSAN, Korea, Tuesday, June 3 (UP) -- President Syngman Rhee promised Gen. Mark W. Clark yesterday that he would not order South Korean troops out of the front lines to support his clash with the National Assembly.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 -- The largest primary vote in California's history tomorrow was forecast by Frank M. Jordan, Secretary of State, as the Presidential preferential campaign of unusual bitterness and heavy financial outlay came to an end tonight.
MADISON, N. J., June 2 -- A record group of 143 candidates received degrees today at Drew University's eighty-fifth commencement.

A forty-two-bed ward to enable doctors to accelerate their clinical research studies on new forms of chemicals and viruses in the treatment of cancer has been opened at James Ewing Hospital. The city-owned institution at Sixty-eighth Street between First and York Avenues is affiliated with Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases.

MOSCOW, June 2 -- Pravda reported today that the Central Committee of the Ukrainian Communist party had been subjected to very sharp criticism by a number of high party and state officials of the Ukraine and noted that two important regional party officials had been released from their posts.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- President Truman said today that industrial accidents last year took 16,000 lives, disabled 2,000,000 workers and cost almost $5,000,000,000. He called it a "shocking national tragedy."

THE NEW YORK TIMES for May 21 carried a letter from John E. Kelly of Washington replying to a previous letter from Oliver La Farge dealing with the problems facing the Navajo. In taking issue with Mr. La Farge, Mr. Kelly set forward a number of arguments which are themselves open to question.

Alexander P. de Seversky, aeronautical engineer, endorsed yesterday the charges made Sunday by Senator Robert A. Taft that the Truman Administration had allowed the country's air power to deteriorate.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., June 2 -- Production of Thunderjet fighter planes at the Republic Aviation Corporation plant was slowed today by an unauthorized "sick strike" of a group of members of the International Association of Machinists.

President Millicent C. McIntosh received the class gift of the graduating seniors at Class Night ceremonies yesterday on behalf of Barnard College. The gift, the "Class of 1952 Fund," is $500. It will be available for students to borrow.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower has asked to be placed on the Army's retired list without pay, starting tomorrow. This request, which the Army said today had been approved by Secretary of Defense Robert A. Lovett, will release the general from the Army's regulations against political campaigning.
ST. LOUIS, June 2 -- The Giants' fortunes dipped to a new low tonight when Sal Maglie the Magnificent failed Leo Durocher's faltering champions.
PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (UP) -- Home runs by Eddie Joost and Gus Zernial carried the Athletics to a 2 -- 1 victory over the Browns tonight as Ned Garver suffered his sixth loss in eight decisions.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Census Bureau announced today final figures on the 1950 census -- a total population of 154,233,000 for the United States as of April 1 of that year.
The elevation of Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej to the Premiership apparently represents the final step in the complete and open monopolization of power in Rumania by the Workers (Communists) party.

A group of delegates from various French chambers of commerce is scheduled to visit the United Nations building at 3 P. M. today. The group, which arrived Sunday for a month's visit arranged by the Mutual Security Agency of the United States, will study trade methods in this country.
LOS ANGELES, June 2 -- In a fiery speech today, Governor Warren denounced the "phantom" Republican slate opposing him as a corrupt menace to democratic processes.

Thousands of New Yorkers hung up their raincoats and went back to work in ironically brilliant Monday sunshine yesterday after a Memorial Day week-end blighted by foul weather. In New Jersey's Passaic River Valley 173 families were forced from their homes when rain-swollen rivers overflowed their banks as an aftermath of the storm.

Thousands of postal workers in the metropolitan area failed to receive their paychecks yesterday because of a Congressional dispute over an appropriations bill. They were among an estimated 400,000 postal employes throughout the country similarly affected.

Navy and California, both unbeaten and both seeking the honor to be this country's eight-oared representative in the Olympic Games at Helsinki this summer, will be in adjoining lanes in the golden jubilee regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association on Syracuse's Onondaga Lake, June 21.
Ten pounds of pure heroin with a retail value of $960,000 were confiscated yesterday in an uptown apartment by narcotics agents, who accused two young mothers of selling and possessing the narcotic.

ALBANY, June 2 -- The date for transferring the State Institute of Applied Arts and Sciences in Brooklyn from its present status to that of a community college has been postponed from July 1 to April 1, 1953, Dr. William S. Carlson, president of the State University, announced today.

The Manhattan Cerebral Palsy Recreation Center, said to be the first of its kind designed to aid children afflicted with cerebral palsy, was dedicated formally yesterday at 55 West Sixty-Eighth Street.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 2 (AP) -- "It is high time that education and business got together," Frank Abrams, chairman of the board of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, said today.

HELMSTEDT, Germany, June 2 -- The strength of the military units of the East German People's Police is to be doubled to approximately 110,000 men by the end of this year, according to one Allied estimate.

THERE are thirteen short stories in Geoffrey Household's "Tales of Adventurers" laid in eleven settings. And about every locale Mr. Household writes with an intimate authority that is marvelously convincing. Few modern authors have seen so much of the world or have steeped themselves more deeply in the local culture and special atmosphere of so many places.

The Police, Traffic and Sanitation Departments agreed yesterday to begin, on June 16, the enforcement of the new alternate-side-of-the-street parking rules on the upper West Side to enable sanitation crews to clean streets with high-speed motorized equipment.

John Lautner, a former official of the Communist party, began his third week of testimony yesterday in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders in the United States District Court on Foley Square.

Business and the country in general is surfeited with special weeks set aside out of allegedly pure sentiment to honor individuals and institutions. Yesterday at a luncheon at the Vanderbilt Hotel came the first details of a special week to be observed as frankly, unashamedly and aggressively commercial.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Supreme Court denied today to James J. Moran, former Water Commissioner of New York and close friend of former Mayor William O'Dwyer, a review of his perjury conviction. This leaves standing the sentence of five years imprisonment and $2,000 fine imposed upon Moran on May 11, 1951.

DOC BLANCHARD was the terror of the gridiron during his playing days at West Point. The Doc splintered rival lines with his irresistible bursts down the middle. He was a teeth-rattling tackler and blocker. Still remembered with a shudder is the block he threw in the Yankee Stadium on John (Tree) Adams of Notre Dame. The Doc almost cut him in half.

JACKSON, Miss., June 2 (UP) -- Backers of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower walked out of the convention of Mississippi's state-recognized Republican party here today when it refused to pledge national convention delegates to the general.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., which operates a chain of twenty-five department stores, including Bloomingdale's and Abraham Straus and their branch units, increased its sales for the thirteen and fifty-two weeks ended on May 3 over the corresponding periods last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Fred Lazarus Jr., president.

PITTSBURGH, June 2 -- The steel industry got its mills back today, but they were producing no steel. Six hundred thousand members of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., quit work as soon as they learned that the Supreme Court had ruled against Government seizure of the steel plants.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- With steel workers walking out of mills all over the country in the wake of the decision of the United States Supreme Court today nullifying the President's seizure of the industry, the next move was held to be up to Mr. Truman.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- President Truman today nominated Lieut. Gen. Lauris Norstad, Commander in Chief of U. S. Air Forces in Europe, for promotion to four-star general.
Two networks rejected yesterday a request for free air time by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican Presidential candidate.

The city of Boston, Mass., borrowed $5,000,000 yesterday in the public market by the sale of notes due Nov. 17 at 1.03 per cent interest with a premium of $52. The purchase bid was made by J. P. Morgan Co., Inc.

Maternity care has gradually undergone many significant changes, with increasing numbers of mothers demanding a more active part in their own care, according to the Maternity Center Association's five-year report, released yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (UP) -- The University of Pennsylvania revealed a nine-game major college football schedule for 1953 today which contained only one Ivy League team but which heralded a closing of the oft-rumored rift involving it and other members of the Ivy group.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today that a $25,000 award won by a Utah musician in a Pan-American symphony composition contest was subject to Federal income tax.
Two Italian scientists arrived here ysterday to complete studies which they hope will enable them to combat the effects of droughts and floods in their homeland.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 2 -- The discovery of an unrespectable number of embezzlements in a fairly concentrated area has awakened bankers all over the country to the need for establishing adequate internal audits and for making them effective, not only for the large banks, but also for the small ones where the job is more difficult.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Supreme Court of the United States ruled, 6 to 3, today that President Truman's seizure of the steel industry to avert a strike violated the Constitution by usurping the legislative powers reserved to Congress.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 2 (AP) -- Prime Minister Dudley Senanyake, whose anti-Communist United National party will have sixty-six votes in the new 101-member Parliament, announced today a Cabinet, dominated by young men. Eight of the fourteen Cabinet choices are in their forties.

Two university professors stand out as having infused philosophy with new life and a new relevance to this scientific age. They are William James and John Dewey. Both were pragmatists, but of the two John Dewey exerted the greater influence on American philosophy. Pragmatism is older than either James or Dewey.

This is the time of year when transit problems habitually become troublesome, or perhaps we should say more troublesome. In the spring of 1950 Mayor O'Dwyer had his "fact-finding board." In early June, 1951, Mayor Impellitteri appointed a "special transit committee," which worked out a transition to the forty-hour week for city transit employes.

The Bell System National Committee of Award announced yesterday that three employes of the Bell Telephone Company of Nevada had won the Vail Medal, the telephone industry's highest award for public service, for rescuing a fourth employe from a snow slide.

Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, dean of Barnard College, will assume the new title of president of Barnard College on July 1 under the terms of a new agreement between the trustees of Columbia University, the parent institution, and the women's undergraduate college.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 2 -- Belgium, Canada and the United Kingdom submitted virtually parallel views today on corrective measures need to restore equilibrium to international commerce as the Economic and Social Council opened debate on its major agenda item, the recent world economic report.

Fred Haas of New Orleans, firing 69, 64 -- 133 at St. Louis, set a sizzling pace for the nation's golfers yesterday as nearly 1,400 amateurs and pros in twenty-six districts sought to qualify for 121 berths in the United States Open Championship at Dallas June 12-14.
TOKYO, June 3 (AP) -- United Nations Command Headquarters communique 1,269, for Monday:

OTTAWA, June 2 (AP) -- Combines Commissioner T. D. MacDonald has reported to the Government the alleged existence of combines in Canada's rubber industry. Nineteen rubber companies, including all the leading manufacturers, are involved, as well as the Rubber Association of Canada, the industry's spokesman.
The strike of the Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., against major carpet mills in the East was only partly successful yesterday, with only 11,000 members instead of 18,000 participating.
Favorite fashions for summer wear in the city are practical but pretty, dark cottons.

A 4-hit shutout was Allie Reynolds' contribution toward the decline and fall of the Indians yesterday at the Stadium. The 2-0 whitewashing job by the ace of the Yankees, coupled with the victory of the Red Sox at Boston, pushed the Cleveland club out of first place, the Bosox taking over the lead by four percentage points.
The handsome grainings of polished mahogany, combined with some unusually veined marble give a rich appearance to the pieces included in a new collection of furniture now on view at Lord Taylor.
CLEVELAND, June 2 -- The attack by President Truman against the nation's private electric power and light industry last week was termed today "pure hokum." This comment was made

The Park Association of New York City will conduct on Friday a "Know Your City Parks" tour for members and others. Participants will assemble at 10:30 A. M. at the Arsenal, Sixty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue, after which there will be a walk to near-by points of interest in Central Park, including the Zoo, the Wollman Memorial and the new carrousel.

Thirteen-year-old John Arzoomanian, who took $66 from the till of his father's grocery store in the Bronx to finance his second try at getting into the Korean war, returned home yesterday after having been picked up by the police in Fairbanks, Va.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's message to the Senate today urging prompt ratification of documents on relations with West Germany:
CLEVELAND, June 2 (AP) -- The president of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen praised today the decision that President Truman could not legally seize the steel industry.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 2 (UP) -- Ezzard Charles' weight became the big question today when he scaled 196 3/4 pounds, the same as Champion Jersey Joe Walcott, at their preliminary weigh-in for Thursday night's heavyweight title fight at Philadelphia.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 2 -- Rhode Island Democrats held a state convention tonight to select twenty unpledged delegates to the national convention that starts July 21 in Chicago. The deputation will have a total of twelve votes.

In your issue of March 27 H. White, Public Information Officer in the Cyprus administration, gives information on the educational system in Cyprus. May 1, as headmaster of the oldest and biggest school of secondary education in Cyprus and as an ex-member of the Council of Education of the Cyprus Government, be allowed in reply to state the following:

The twelve-story thirteen-family apartment house at 927 Fifth Avenue has been sold by David H. Knott to a group of the tenants under a plan of cooperative ownership. On a plot about 60 by 125 feet at the southeast corner of Seventh-fourth Street, the property has an assessed valuation of $600,000, of which $350,000 represents land value.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Congress generally hailed today the Supreme Court's 6-3 decision holding President Truman's seizure of the steel industry unconstitutional.

BALTIMORE, June 2 (AP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, exuding confidence in his own campaign for President, today said Republican squalling over foreign policy could wind up in destruction of the G. O. P. as a party.

PIETERMARITZBURG, South Africa, June 2 (AP) -- Pro-British Natal warned Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist Government today to abide by the Constitution or face a break-up of the Union and "destruction of the white civilization in our land."

Congress heard much testimony last week about the crisis in the air, our "lag" in production of planes, but paid little attention to a more serious weakness, the failure of military flying to attract sufficient highly qualified applicants.

From the vantage point of solid, enlightened Republicanism here in the Berkshires it is clear that Taft is right -- unfortunately -- in asserting that the present factional row in the party is not one between personalities. It is purely an "organizational" fight.
ROME, June 2 -- The greatest military parade seen in Italy since the end of World War II took place in Rome today to celebrate the sixth anniversary of the proclamation of the Italian Republic.
TRENTON, June 2 -- State penal authorities indicated tonight that their "patient policy" toward the sit-down of a state prisoners' grievance council was near its end.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP) -- -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge, the Eisenhower campaign manager, disputed today Senator Robert A. Taft's charge that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower is a "me, too," Republican Presidential candidate.
Murray Baron, New York County chairman of the Liberal party, announced yesterday the following party designations for Representatives, State Senators and Assemblymen in New York County:

NEW DELHI, India, June 2 -- The events leading to the postponement of the civil marriage between a Hindu Brahmin girl and a Moslem youth that led to serious rioting last week were detailed to the House of the People (lower house of Parliament) today by Dr. K. N. Katju, Home Minister.
A light turnout of grumbling automobile owners marked the first day's sale yesterday of the new $5 and $10 automobile use tax stickers that must be affixed to car windshields by June 16.

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., June 2 -- The political camps of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower traded their last bitter words in South Dakota's Republican Presidential primary campaign as voters prepared to cast ballots tomorrow that are expected to have a major influence on the party's nominating convention next month.

BOSTON, June 2 (AP) -- Don Lenhardt's grand-slam tenth inning homer aggravated the already heavy woes of an ex-teammate, Ken Holcombe, today as the Red Sox took the rubber contest of a three-game series with the White Sox, 6--2.
