In a day of light trading, futures commodities prices yesterday tended generally downward. Lead, in which nine contracts were traded on the Commodity Exchange, presented the only consistently brighter picture, rising 15 to 30 points.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- When Chin Poy, an old acquaintance and former employe, walked into the Hoboken laundry of On Lee a year or so ago, the laundry proprietor had no idea that Chin Poy was "wired for sound." But he was. In fact Chin Poy, called by the Federal Government "an undercover agent" and denounced by On Lee as a "stool pigeon" for the Bureau of Narcotics, was electrically equipped.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh gave final warning yesterday to 100 multiple-parking violators, each of whom had ignored ten or more tickets. He advised them to appear in court in the next forty-eight hours or "face straight jail sentences."

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Billy Loes, the wonder boy from Astoria, L. I., lost his magic at Wrigley Field today and retired at the end of four innings charged with his second defeat of the season, the Cubs routing the Dodgers, 6 -- 1.
A first grade fireman attached to a Bronx hook and ladder company pleaded guilty yesterday at a departmental trial to soliciting funds illegally from fashionable shops in East Fifty-seventh Street.

PARIS, June 2 -- Premier Antoine Pinay summoned today a group of Cabinet Ministers to organize plans for countering a wave of "sit-in" strikes, scheduled Wednesday by Red unionists as a protest against recent severe anti-Communist measures.
Martin O. Kahn has been appointed merchandise counselor in charge of misses', women's and junior budget, moderate and better dresses at Macy's New York.

Varied diversions have been planned for the annual street carnival for the children of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church throughout Saturday at Rutherford Place and East Sixteenth Street. The event will be held in the Parish House of the church, 207 East Sixteenth Street, in case of rain.

The television committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which regulates the number of college football games that may be televised each year, announced its new plan yesterday for the 1952 season.

THE holiday week-end was a disappointment to many anglers, due to the unsettled weather, but some excellent bluefish and striped bass catches were reported during the period prior to the weather, with a 51-pound striper going to a Block Island fisherman.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Justice Department told the Senate Commerce Committee today that housewives "would be up in arms" if they understood fully a price regulation bill now pending in Congress.

IRONWOOD, Mich., June 2 (UP) -- Five iron ore miners were trapped 2,800 feet below the earth's surface tonight by a cave-in and 100 fellow workers called off a scheduled strike in an attempt to save them.
GENEVA, June 2 -- The industrial countries of Western Europe are beginning to benefit from the lower costs of raw materials.
The Theatre Guild has taken an option on a new play by Nelisse Child called "The Happy Ending." If the principal feminine role can be cast in time, the play will be done on Broadway this season.

SAN FRANCISCO, Wednesday, June 4 -- Gov. Earl Warren, after a slow start, appeared on the basis of a state-wide trend in the tabulation of primary election ballots early today to be headed for the Republican National Convention in Chicago next month with California's seventy delegates committed to his Presidential candidacy.
CHICAGO, June 3 -- The weather and the Cubs cooled off almost simultaneously today, a pair of fortuitous circumstances the Giants promptly turned to good account.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Satchel Paige's third straight single, with two out in the seventeenth inning, scored Joe DeMaestri from second base with the run that lifted the Browns to a 3 -- 2 victory over Washington tonight.

A producer of seeds and several banks in the metropolitan area paid Federal Post Office employes in their localities yesterday as a Congressional dispute over an appropriations bill continued to hold up the distribution of the Government pay checks, which were due on Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A subcommittee of the House of Representatives assigned to investigate the moral level of television and radio programs ascertained today that the necklines of television actresses were higher since the industry adopted a code of ethics.

Youths who want to earn vacation money by working in grocery stores and delicatessens found a friend yesterday in Magistrate J. Irwin Shapiro. The point was a bit technical, but it boils down to the fact that, in the opinion of the former chief assistant District Attorney of Queens, storekeepers who sell beer for home consumption may hire youngsters less than 18 years old without violating the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Law.
Volume picked up and sugar futures prices were higher yesterday as the market for actual sugar made what amounted to a 10-point recovery from a temporary low.

Simplicity of line, emphasized by a restrained use of decoration, distinguishes the latest additions to the directional series of furniture designed by Paul McCobb. The pieces, which may be coordinated with upholstered furniture introduced earlier in the year, are available through decorators at the Directional Modern Showrooms, 201 East Fifty-seventh Street.

DES MOINES, June 3 (AP) -- The total vote for Governor in yesterday's primary election rose well over the 400,000 mark as unofficial tabulations ended late today with only one of Iowa's 2,479 precincts unreported.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, Pa., June 3 (AP) -- Mrs. George Busch Jr. of Essex County today took the lead in the New Jersey State Women's Golf Association thirty-six-hole championship tournament for the Mrs. T. S. B. Nielsen Memorial Trophy with a 72, eighteen-hole low net at the Shawnee Inn and Country Club course.
ABILENE, Kan., June 3 -- Abilene residents completed today hectic last-minute preparations for welcoming the home town boy who made good and an estimated 50,000 of his admirers were there.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President and Mrs. Truman gave their annual garden party for wounded, sick and disabled service men and women today and shook hands with 1,351 of them and their attendants.

Maj. Gen. Courtney Whitney, aide and adviser to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, declared yesterday that General MacArthur was not violating any Army regulations in speaking out on political questions while continuing to draw his full military pay.
SAIGON, Indo-China, June 3 -- In a surprise move, Nguyen Van Tam, the Minister of the Interior, took over today as Premier of Vietnam from Tran Van Huu.

The conditions in the Central Canadian Arctic that foster the breeding of insects will be studied this summer by a professor of biology at City College. Dr. Alexander B. Klots, former president of the New York Entomological Society, will depart Saturday to lead a research party into that remote section for the Canadian Government.

General Eisenhower bade farewell yesterday to the Army, to which he has given thirty-seven years of devoted service. As he did so, he summarized again at a press conference his basic philosophy and some of the outstanding issues that have confronted him as Supreme Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty forces in Europe.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 3 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council opened its eleventh session today and decided to begin work Friday on the examination of Italy's administration of the African territory of Somaliland.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UP) -- The Senate voted today to spend $1,381,000,000 over the next two years to improve the nation's highways and earmarked more than one billion dollars of it as Federal aid to the states.

Further evidence that the reconstituted Advertising Research Foundation, Inc., means business was presented yesterday with the publication by that organization of the first issue of a newsletter that will be put out intermittently. The foundation was started in an effort to fill the need for sound techniques in advertising research. Its basic objective is the betterment of the entire advertising industry by building a solid basis for all advertising.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 3 (UP) -- The Rumanian Communist party announced today that it had reprimanded Mme. Ana Pauker for rightist deviations. She was dropped last week from the Politburo and the Secretariat of the party's Central Committee.

Exit the salesman. Enter the distribution expert. That was the stage direction offered yesterday by J. Sidney Johnson of the National Biscuit Company in a talk at a luncheon of the Sales Executives Club at the Hotel Roosevelt. There have been "revolutionary changes" in retailing, he said, and consumers now accept more than one brand of specific items.

NEW DELHI, India, June 3 -- A fully packed House of the People (the lower house of Parliament) today heard with great attention but amid running interruptions from Communist members a highly documented speech in which the charge was made that Soviet grand strategy included the capture of India.

Two more Canadian newsprint mills have joined more than a dozen others in announcing a $10-a-ton price increase effective June 15, it was made known here yesterday. They are the Bowater Newfoundland Pulp and Paper Mills and the Donnacona Paper Company, Ltd., Quebec.

PITTSBURGH, June 3 -- By trouncing the Pirates for the sixth straight time this season without a loss, the Dodgers tonight retained their one-game first-place lead over the Giants, with the advantage all in the lost column.
STANTON, Del., June 3 (AP) -Alan T. Clarke's homebred Senator Joe, the 4-5 favorite, took the Bethany Purse at Delaware Park today before a crowd of 11,000.

The prediction that new easing of restrictions on voluntary relief services in Korea would bring increased aid from Americans to the troubled people of that country was voiced yesterday by Msgr. George Carroll, Maryknoll missionary and representative in Korea of War Relief Services, National Catholic Welfare Conference.

The taxpayer building at 2196-2200 Clarendon Road. Brooklyn, occupied by the Grand Union Company as a supermarket, has been resold by George J. Abrams to David Ziegler of the Ziegler Desk Company. George J. Abrams was attorney for the seller and Harry Krauss acted for the buyer.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Congressional conferees on the Mutual Security Program "split the difference" between the House and Senate bills and agreed today on an authorization of $6,447,730,750 for the 1953 fiscal year. The amount was $1,452,270,000 under President Truman's $7,900,000,000 request.

Sidney Wood, former Wimbledon champion, met with unexpected opposition before eliminating Andrew Stern, New York City, in the second round of the Inter-American tennis singles tournament yesterday on the Hispano Tennis Club courts in Whitestone, Queens.

The April and May net profits of Paramount Pictures Corporation appear to have run "a little ahead" of the corresponding 1951 figures, Barney Balaban, president, told the annual meeting yesterday. June figures, he said, would be difficult to compare, because a year ago many blocked currencies were unfrozen.

A new recommendation to open Newark Airport to commercial airlines on a limited basis was made yesterday by the National Air Transport Coordinating Committee. It took the form of a letter to the Port of New York Authority, the bi-state agency that closed the airport on Feb. 11, after three crashes causing 119 deaths in near-by Elizabeth.
BUENOS AIRES, June 3 (UP) -- A shake-up in the Argentine Government's economic departments was announced today on the eve of the second inauguration of President Juan D. Peron.

Supreme Court Justice James B. M. McNally, in a test suit brought by a retired school teacher, ruled yesterday that cost-of-living bonuses were part of salaries and must be included in computing pensions. The decision affects every school teacher and eventually may affect every employe of the city.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, June 3 -- General Matthew B. Ridgway, newly installed Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, made his first official visit today to President Vincent Auriol of France at the latter's official residence, the Elysee Palace in Paris.

Judge Harold R. Medina characterized as "fantastic" yesterday certain evidence adduced by the Government in the investment banking anti-trust trial to support a charge that the seventeen defendants conspired to prevent compulsory competitive bidding for securities.

The stock market's attitude to the new switch in the steel situation, which found all operations in the industry closed down, was contradictory in many respects. A highly mixed closing, with little choice between the number of issues to advance or decline, produced a loss of 0.03 point in the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES index.

Commencement week at the College of Mt. St. Vincent, Riverdale, came to an end yesterday when 120 women graduates received bachelor degrees from the Most Rev. Joseph P. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, who presided in the absence of Cardinal Spellman, president of the college.

As the school year draws to a close it becomes apparent that a number of things have been going on since last fall which the pupil never thought to mention. These are not bad things, but nice things -- evidences of achievement, of considerable mental activity and research.
Tampa Electric Company sold yesterday to banking syndicates at public bidding an issue of S5,000,000 of $100 par value preferred stock and $2,268,000 of new com!mon stock.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Two pamphlets, "The Child With Epilepsy" and "The Child Who Is Hard Of Hearing" were issued today by the Children's Bureau, Federal Security Agency, to inform the general public on two special fields in which progress had been made in recent years.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Department store sales by Federal Reserve Districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, and percentage comparisons with a year ago, for the latest week, are as follows. The figures, ordinarily published on Sundays, were delayed because of the Memorial Day holiday.

According to well-established tradition, the Ralph Marano collection of fall furs created for Russeks Design Studio deals largely with mink. In a few instances, however, Mr. Marano departs long enough from mink to lavish his distinctive treatments on such skins as Somali leopard, Argentine nutria, glistening black broadtail and a fabulous wrap of snow white ermine.

NEWTOWN, Conn., June 3 -- Construction of a 1,400-foot dam and a hydrolectric power plant on the Housatonic River at a point near U. S. Route 6 at the Newtown-Southbury town line is planned by Electric Power, Inc., a subsidiary of the Connecticut Light and Power Company, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A group of ten Republican Governors, in a statement issued today, accused backers of Senator Robert A. Taft of keeping the Republican party in the South "small, weak and ineffective" and of putting it in the control of a small clique.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 3 -- Samuel Faile, Assemblyman of Westchester County's Fifth District for the last four years and former Deputy Corporation Counsel of White Plains for twenty-five years, was chosen today by Republican county leaders as their candidate for District Attorney.

TRENTON, June 3 -- The nine-member Inmate Council at the state prison ended its five-day sitdown strike in a prison conference room at 3:30 P. M. today. The members left the small room voluntarily and prison authorities said no force was required.

PARIS, June 3 -- A proposal to elect Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, as president of the European Marshall Plan council this week, is being ardently pressed by the French. This probably would mean that R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, would replace Mr. Eden in the council most of the time, the issues dealt with being economic and financial.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 3 -- The Yugoslav Government was reported today considering the possibility of establishing a free foreign-exchange market as a means of expanding foreign trade. The fundamental question whether the existence of such a market would be compatible with Marxism and the prevailing Yugoslav economic program has not yet been settled.

New York City high school girls triumphed over their masculine competitors in the New York State Chamber of Commerce's annual student essay contest by winning eighty-six out of 133 prizes awarded yesterday at 65 Liberty Street.

A method for doing dried beans in a pressure saucepan that reduces cooking time to a mere fraction of what has been considered necessary in that utensil is one outstanding result of research now being undertaken by the United States Department of Agriculture's Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics.

BOSTON, June 3 (UP) -- Mike Garcia held the Red Sox to their first Fenway Park shut-out in two years tonight as the Indians scored a 6-0 victory and regained first place in the American League after dropping to second place, back of Boston, yesterday.

Sales of war-built merchant ships to foreign nations or nationals, under the terms of the Ship Sales Act of 1946, have brought in $30,000,000 in interest charges alone, the Maritime Administration asserted yesterday.

RYE, N. Y., June 3 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of the Century Country Club managed under trying playing conditions at the Apawamis Club today to win the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day contest for Class A players with a gross round of 42, 38 -- 80.

THE value of the striped bass as a sports fish, far in excess of its worth on the fish market scales, is now being recognized as far south as Washington, and a bill has been introduced in the House that would limit the taking of the striper to "hook and line."

Nevil Shute, author of "The Legacy" and "Round the Bend," moved his family from England to Australia two years ago. His love for his new country is expressed in his latest work of fiction, "The Far Country," that Morrow will publish Sept. 3.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 3 -- The member organizations of the Motion Picture Industry Council, a public relations agency supported by management and employe unions and talent guilds, now are considering a proposal for the establishment within the council framework of a special committee to function as a clearing house on information for studio workers who may be charged with Communist association or sympathies.

Tickets weren't being sold yesterday to "Of Thee I Sing," starring Jack Carson and Paul Hartman, for next week at the Ziegfeld. As a matter of fact, the sale for performances after this week had stopped on Monday. Which means that the initial Broadway revival of the George S. Kaufman-Morrie Ryskind-George and Ira Gershwin show -- the first musical to receive the Pulitzer Prize -- is on its way out Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Senate was told today that a man named Jacob (or Jack) Udell, with mail addresses in New York City, Miami Beach and Frankford, Del., had collected $451,559.30 from the Government through "devious methods" after a charge against him of evading $792,094 in income taxes had been withheld from prosecution.

Final valuations of taxable real estate and special franchises in New York City for the fiscal year to begin July 1 are $19,425,499,087, an increase of about $650,000,000 over the present year. Tax-exempt property is also rising, and reaches in the coming year about $6,780,000,000, so that New York is better than a $26,000,000,000 city.

Speculation earlier this week that Ana Pauker, Stalinist boss in Rumania, had fallen from power is confirmed by news of her reprimand for "rightist deviations" and by the linkage of her condemnation with that of Vasile Luca and Teohari Georgescu, the two Politburo members expelled last week.
A man who knows door-to-door selling like the palm of his hand told retail store owners yesterday that they should be grateful to house-to-house canvassers instead of constantly attacking them.

The Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway Company notified the Public Service Commission yesterday of its intention to discontinue all passenger service on its three lines as of July 7. The road said it could no longer compete with city-owned and "subsidized" bus lines and laid its plight also to the greatly expanded use of automobiles.
Department stores were advised yesterday not to underestimate the competition of supermarkets in selling children's apparel.

" Diplomatic Courier," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama starring Tyrone Power, Patricia Neal and Stephen McNally, will have its local premiere on Friday, June 13, at the Roxy, it was announced by the film company. Henry Hathaway directed and Casey Robinson produced from his own screen play.

CLEVELAND, June 3 -- The extent of future public power expansion is limited only by the "desires and ambitions" of public power advocates and the tax-paying capability of the citizens of the nation, Earle J. Machold, president of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, said today at the annual convention of the Edison Electric Institute.

The Ben Axelrod Supply Company has leased the new one-story building at 58-87 Fifty-fifth Street, Maspeth, Queens, from J. F. . F. J. Clarke and will use it for the distribution of roofing materials, shingles and building sidings. The Kalmon Dolgin Company was the broker.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UP) -- The Western Union Telegraph Company said today that the "heat" put on organized gambling by Congress and law enforcement agents had halted illegal use of telegraph facilities by bookmakers for the time being.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 3 -- Now that the men's clothing industry has reduced its stocks through cuts in production, the outlook for the fall is very good, according to Morton J. Baum, president of the Rochester Clothiers Exchange. He spoke here today to the International Association of Clothing Designers.
PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP) -- Homers by Hank Majeski and Al Clark were the payoff blows tonight as the Athletics gained a 3-to-1 decision over the Tigers. The victory stretched the A's streak to four.

ST. LOUIS, June 3 (AP) -- Jim Wilson hurled the Braves to a 3-2 victory over the Cardinals tonight. He yielded a single on his first pitch and then tossed hitless ball until the eighth inning, when he gave the only other blow he allowed and both St. Louis runs.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Mainly favorable weather in all sections emphasizes the excellent outlook for all crops, and the "June scenery" is responsible for much selling of grains. Today the wheat market was heavy, with rallies on short profit-taking and commission buying failing to hold.
The police yesterday crashed through a door marked Esta Novelty Company, Manufacturers of Hand Embroidery, Fagotting and Crochet Beading, and accused its occupants of making only one product -- book.

An indication was given yesterday that John P. Crane, ousted fireman and former president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, will be a prosecution witness in the General Sessions trial of Gerard W. Purcell, who is accused of misappropriating more than $200,000 from the organization.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UP) -- A record 52,000,000 cars, trucks and buses traveled the highways last year, burning up a record 38,300,000,000 gallons of gasoline and diesel oil, the Public Roads Bureau reported today.

WASHLNGTON, June 3---Helen Gahagan Douglas, former mplber of CongTess now appearing on the stage in "First Lady" in New York, made a hurried trip here today to plead that better living conditions for migratory farm -orkers be made a 'vital" issue. in the political campaigru

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 3 -- United States warned the United Nations Human Rights Commission today against adopting a series of provisions that would "throttle" the guarantees of free speech and freedom of the press now laid down in the planned universal covenant on civil and political rights.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A move to write new emergency powers for the President into the Defense Production Bill took hold in the Senate today, but Republicans announced that they would fight it.

PUSAN, Korea, Wednesday, June 4 (UP) -- President Syngman Rhee called off plans for the dissolution of the Korean National Assembly today after receiving a firm note from President Truman urging him not to take any "irrevocable" steps until United States Ambassador John J. Muccio arrives for consultations.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Wednesday, June 4 -- Tank-led United States soldiers charged into three defiant North Korean prisoner compounds today, smashed down and burned Communist flags and signs and brought out the disobedient leaders of one compound without firing a shot.
Buyer response to the fall lines opened this week indicates a gain for major lines of women's and children's apparel, a survey of New York's wholesale market showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- A Senate Rules Subcommittee announced today it would run parallel investigations of Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, each on complaint of the other.
Vice President Alben W. Barkley laid the cornerstone of the six-story outpatient clinic of Beth Israel Hospital yesterday on East Seventeenth Street between First and Second Avenues.
Lay-offs resulting from the national steel strike increased yesterday, and there were indications that unemployment would rise even more sharply if the strike lasted through this week.
QUITO, Ecuador, June 3 -- Dr. Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra, after five years of exile, has been elected President of Ecuador for the third time and by a crushing margin over his nearest competitor.

President Truman reminds us that last year industrial accidents took 16,000 lives, disabled 2,000,000 workers and cost almost five billion dollars. By themselves these figures cannot bring home to us the individual tragedies they represent. As the President told the Annual Conference on Industrial Safety, the statistics disclose a "shocking national tragedy."

PLEASANTVILLE, N. J., June 3 (UP) -- Despite his exceptional weight, Challenger Ezzard Charles was impressive today as he finished training for his heavyweight title fight with Champion Jersey Joe Walcott at Philadelphia Thursday night.

James La Sala, 56-year-old Queens carpenter who was recently named Foster Father of the Year by the Children's Aid Society, was honored yesterday for having served as foster father to seventeen boys and girls in twenty-one years.
LONDON, June 3 -- Last week's downward trend on the stock markets was continued today when the Stock Exchange opened after the three-day Whitsun holiday.

There ought to be a law against any club winning a thirteen-inning ball game the way the Yankees won from the White Sox, 4 -- 3, in the game that started at the Stadium at 8:30 last night and ended twenty-seven minutes after midnight.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Truman has intervened in South Korea's new Government crisis for fear that the bitter dispute may throw new roadblocks in the path of the Korean truce. Diplomatic sources said Mr. Truman took the unusual step of sending a personal note to Korean President Syngman Rhee expressing "shock" at Dr. Rhee's feud with the South Korean National Assembly.

Arise of the Addison Stable took over in the stretch and went on to score a decisive triumph in the Eight Thirty Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The 6-year-old son of He Did gave weight to the five others in the one-mile test, yet was installed the favorite at a little mere than 2 to 1 by the crowd of 20,446.

GREAT NECK, L. I., June 3 -- Betsy Rawls of Austin, Tex., who has been playing professional golf for fourteen months, today won the Weathervane open tournament with a record score of 590 for the 144-hole competition.

For the nineteenth successive year net sales of General Foods Corporation surpassed those of any previous reporting period, Clarence Francis, chairman, said yesterday in the report for the fiscal year ended with March. The record net sales of $632,544,531, compared with $589,223,204 the year before.

BALTIMORE, June 3 -- Maryland's delegation of eighteen to the Democratic National Convention was elected today and instructed to vote for Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, but only on the first ballot.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 4 -- The official Peiping radio called on the United Nations today to make new concessions on the crucial issue of an exchange of war prisoners as the price of an armistice in the Korean war. It also praised the "heroic and just" rebellion of the captives in the South Korean stockades.

Your lead editorial of May 29 points out that whether the "historic enterprise" envisaged in the German "peace contract" and the European Defense Community becomes "a living reality" depends upon the United States. The enforcement of both these treaties is now widely regarded as essential to the success of our bipartisan foreign policy toward Europe and an important contribution to our prospects of peace.
CHICAGO, June 3 -- Four scientists were accidentally "overexposed" to atomic radiation yesterday while conducting an experiment at the Argonne National Laboratory.

Ninety-seven cadets received degrees and licenses as third officers in the merchant marine yesterday at the ninety-sixth graduation excises at the State University Maritime College at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx.

John McKim Minton, defense attorney, asked Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey yesterday to quash two perjury indictments against William W. Remington, former Government economist, and to order a hearing into alleged improprieties - in the grand jury that returned the first indictment.

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Wednesday, June 4 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft were locked in a close race early today for fourteen crucial delegates in South Dakota's Republican primary, the country's last test between the two prominent rivals before the National Convention in Chicago July 7.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, with gains of 20 to 38 points net. The upturn was led by strength in the old July contract.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Charges of entering into an unlawful agreement to deprive competitors from sources of supply in Czechoslovakia were made by the Federal Trade Commission today against fifteen American importers of Czechoslovakian glass.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower apparently is going to be "a natural" on television. His appearance yesterday morning at the press conference in the Pentagon was virtually a model illustration of how to act in front of the cameras. He let television take care of itself and was just himself.

Three-year extensions of taxes estimated to produce an annual total of $225,650,000 for the city's treasury were voted yesterday by the City Council. The imposts included the highly controversial 3 per cent retail sales tax estimated to yield $208,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- As part of its drive against violators of its priority and allocations regulations, the National Production Authority moved today against the Sterling Faucet Company of Morgantown, W. Va., for alleged misuse of 600,000 pounds of copper.

America must never trade its "principles for expediency," even if that means opposing our allies, William O. Douglas, associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, declared last night in a commencement address here.

VIENNA, June 3 -- In return for permitting an examination of the books of the Swiss subsidiary of the Creditanstalt, her big nationalized bank, Austria received today a grant of $11,000,000 in Marshall Plan aid that had been withheld pending consent for the examination.

The American Civil Liberties Union criticized yesterday the recently adopted television program code as being "stultifying and illegal censorship." It asked the Federal Communications Commission for a hearing to determine whether the code contravenes the Federal Communications Act.

The New York Hotel Trades Council, agent for ten American Federation of Labor unions in the hotel industry here, has purchased for cash the four-story building at 522 West Forty-second Street from Webb Knapp, Inc., who acquired the property about a year ago from he New York Kindergarten Association and the Mills School.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 3 (UP) -- The revolutionary government imposed a monopoly on mineral exports today, decreeing that only the state might sell Bolivia's tin and other valuable ores to foreign purchasers.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Kathleen Winsor, author of "Forever Amber," wrote for her own amusement, and thus she is entitled to refund of $26.358 in taxes paid on the sale of motion picture rights of her book, the United States Court of Claims announced today.

The name of a former Republican party official was added yesterday to that of former District Attorney Herman Methfessel of Richmond County, a Democrat, as among the persons who allegedly frequented a house on Staten Island used for gambling.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 3 -- Immediately after Nationalist Prime Minister Daniel F. lVZs/an announced today that Governor General Ernest G. Jansen had signed the High Court of Parliament Bill, which enables the Government through the parliamentary majority to override the Appeal Court in' constitutional cases, Jacobus Strauss, opposition leader, warned that the validity of the bill would be tested in the courts "almost immediately."

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 3 -- J. Russel Sprague, Nassau County executive since the present county charter went into effect fifteen years ago, gave a farewell address at a meeting of the Republican County Committee here tonight and named A. Holly Patterson of Hempstead as Republican candidate for his post in the November election.

Residents of Greenwich Village have not only defeated a plan to run two one-way roads through Washington Square Park; they have evolved a plan of their own for park traffic that has earned the unofficial approval of Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr.
HELSINKI, Finland, June 3 (AP) -- Russia today announced she would participate in the summer Olympics here, ending months of speculation on whether the Soviet would send teams to the games.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Chief Judge Bolitha J. Laws of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia deferred action again today on the sale of The Cincinnati Enquirer after the Portsmouth Steel Corporation had submitted an offer of $7,600,000, to be paid in cash within thirty days.

BONN, Germany, June 3 -- The night before the signing, last Monday, of the conventions giving West Germany virtual sovereignty, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was host at a state dinner at Schaumburg palace, his official residence.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 3 -- Dr. Marcus Nadler, economist at the Graduate School of Business Administration, New York University, said here today that the principal problems confronting the nation were to maintain the integrity of the dollar and prevent sharp fluctuations in business activity.

Robert Moses made a bitter attack yesterday on a county judge who ruled that the forty-mile-an-hour speed limit on the Long Island parkways was void, and coupled the denunciation with an announcement that the technical defect in the law had been remedied.

A former basketball star at St. John's University in Brooklyn was held in $1,000 bail yesterday on a charge of criminally receiving furs valued at $2,000 that were alleged to be part of $23,000 worth of mink furs stolen from the Reckler Lamazor Fur Company, 333 Seventh Avenue, last April 16.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 3 (AP) -- An investment syndicate today offered to buy $326,000,000 of bonds which would be issued to finance building of an Ohio Turnpike -- the largest revenue bond issue ever attempted.
Columbia College will honor its 198th graduating class this morning at the annual Class Day exercises in Van Am Quadrangle on the campus.

Research engineers of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation are beginning tests on specially designed equipment in the company's laboratories. From the results obtained They hope to produce "the smoothest ride of all time."

BERLIN, June 3 -- About twelve hours after British troops had isolated the Soviet radio building in West Berlin, which houses the Berlin radio, Sergei Dengin, Berlin representative of the Soviet Control Commission, asked today for an appointment with Maj. Gen. C. F. C. Coleman, British Commandant.

United States recognition of the Paz Estenssoro Government of Bolivia was, if anything, overdue. However, the problem of the recognition of a revolutionary Government in Latin America is always a delicate and complicated affair. In theory, it is supposed to have become almost cut and dried and to have no political or moral significance.
Alumnae of Barnard College surpassed their goal for 1951-52 by contributing $54,153, the annual Alumnae Reunion held yesterday at Barnard was told. Their goal was $50,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 3 -- Senator John Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Small Business, said today that his committee would "shortly be in a position to recommend to the Senate Finance Committe definite proposals for easing the tax burden of small business men."

INDIANAPOLIS, June 3 -- The recent United States Supreme Court decision voiding a New York State ban on the Italian film "The Miracle" is approved in the current issue of The Indiana Catholic and Record, official newspaper of the Archdiocese of Indianapolis.

CINCINNATI, June 3 (AP) -- Wally Post, usually weak-hitting outfielder, knocked in two runs for the Reds with a single and his second homer tonight as Cincinnati scored a 2-1 victory over the Phillies and Robin Roberts. Frank Smith, who took over when Starter Ewell Blackwell's shoulder tightened on him in the fourth, allowed only one hit to gain credit for his second triumph.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UP) -- The Committee for Economic Development recommended today an extension of price-wage controls only until Dec. 31 and a "vigorous" policy of selective decontrol in the next six months.

The first public offering of shares of a new open-end investment company organized to invest in enterprises exploiting Canada's natural resources will be made today by Frank L. Valenta Co., Inc. The new fund is Natural Resources of Canada Fund, Inc.

IN the early autumn of 1936 Jason Lysander Bent left the little town in Illinois which had been his home for twenty-two years to seek his fortune in New York City. Like thousands of other young men and women Jason felt that only in the shadow of Manhattan's towers could he realize his best potentialities and become a writer, perhaps as good a writer as Tom Wolfe.

BONN, Germany, June, 3 -- The Mutual Security Agency's special mission here disclosed today that it had taken provisional action against eighty-seven West German concerns because of "improper trade" with companies in the Soviet orbit.

Eight Manhattan executives, founders of the Outboard Commuters Club, made a test run in two swift outboard motorboats yesterday from New Rochelle, down Long Island Sound to the East River Boat Basin at Twenty-third Street.
Herbert Lane has been appointed buyer of women's and misses footwear in the upstairs store of Saks-34th Street.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 3 -- Warning that another great war might mean the complete destruction of the nations involved, Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, asserted today that the fundamental purpose of this country's foreign policy was to establish a world in which peace would be assured.

Since Mrs. Donald J. Kramer has taken up the cudgels in THE TIMES of May 22 regarding spelling, brought up by your "Topics of The Times" column of May 9, which had chiefly to do with spelling bees, I'd like to contribute a few of my views.
Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock reserved decision yesterday on a defense motion for a mistrial in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders in the United States District Court here.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 3 -- The Shuberts presented a new operetta, "The Singing Girl," here tonight before 2,000 persons in the County Center. The show, first of twelve scheduled for that many weeks, is a new type of suburban venture for the Shuberts and a new use for the county-owned building.
PITTSBURGH, June 3 -- Industry-union negotiations to seek an end to the national steel strike are likely to begin by Friday, authoritative sources reported here today.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 3 -- The nation's banks today were urged to look into the possibilities of establishing school savings programs, which would permit students to buy shares in a banking corporation and to serve as book-keepers, tellers and supply clerks.

Paraplegics, ailing infants and a group of aged and infirm patients were carried, led or wheeled to safety in Christ Hospital in Jersey City yesterday afternoon after a fuel tank explosion in a hospital courtyard had filled their wards with thick greasy smoke.

The British quality worsted and woolen mills are due for a good season and will increase their exports to this country. But producers of common-grade cloth are in for tough sledding as their markets gradually dwindle, Fred and Spencer Witty, vice presidents of Witty Brothers, manufacturer and retailer of men's clothing, said in an interview yesterday.

In a ceremony rich in reverent symbolism, the Rev. Dr. John Heuss was formally instituted yesterday as thirteenth rector of historic Trinity church. Located in the heart of the financial district at Broadway and Wall Street, Trinity is the oldest Protestant Episcopal parish in the city.

MOSCOW, June 3 -- The newspaper Red Star reported today that the great new Gorki hydroelectric development on the upper Volga was nearing completion and would be next on the program of major Soviet construction projects to be finished.

PRINCETON, N. J. June 3 -- Dr. John A. MacKay, president of Princeton Theological Seminary, conferred 128 degrees today, largest number in the seminary's history, at its 140th commencement exercises in the Princeton University Chapel.

The Appellate Division heard conflicting arguments yesterday as to whether it should interpret literally a clumsily worded law or be guided by the legislative sponsors' statement of what they really had meant the law to say.
KATMANDU, Nepal, June 3 -- Bad weather has beaten a Swiss attempt to climb Mount Everest -- the world's highest peak -- and a British team trying to scale neighboring Cho Oyu.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 3 -- Statements by France, Sweden and the Philippines in the Economic and Social Council's debate today on the world economic situation showed an emergence of unified opinion among Western delegates as to the nature of current problems and possible remedies.

It is splendid news that New York City and the Port of New York Authority have at last reached an agreement that permits the Authority to proceed at once to construct a third tube for the Lincoln Tunnel under the Hudson River. This is a real achievement. No one questioned the need of this traffic relief.
TOKYO, Wednesday, June 4 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,270, for twenty-fours hours ended 6 A. M. Wednesday (5 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern daylight time):

PARIS, June 3 -- Premier Antoine Pinay once more herded a wavering majority into line in the French National Assembly tonight to pass a law providing for a sliding scale of minimum wages increasing automatically with the cost of living.

The Navy enlistment quota for the area between New York City and Springfield, Mass., has been increased from 1,070 in May to 1,534 in June and will go up again in July, the Navy recruiting office at 346 Broadway announced yesterday.

There's an old American saying, "I like the rooster because of his crow -- and because he has spurs to back it up with." For years teachers, recreation workers and park attendants have pleaded with young people to take care of public property; the results are all too evident.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Dr. Paul B. Magnuson expressed the belief today after a visit to the White House that it would be possible to work out a national health insurance plan that would be acceptable to the politicians, the American people and American doctors.
The delivery of payroll cash and bank deposits, running into the "millions," was halted yesterday by a strike of 600 drivers and guards for four armored car companies.

A few minutes after Mayor Impellitteri denied last night that juvenile delinquency was "rampant" in this city, a leading clergyman declared that "hordes of young barbarians are swarming our streets," making New York physically unsafe to live in.

The building at 113 Broad Street, Elizabeth, N. J., formerly occupied as a branch of the Union County Trust Company, has been purchased for investment by the S. M. A. Realty Corporation of Jersey City. The new owners plan to alter the structure for occupancy by retail store.

PARIS, June 3 -- France braced tonight to meet the threat of nation-wide strikes called for tomorrow by the Communist unions and the Government warned its own hundreds of thousands of employes that they would face disciplinary action if they followed the Red appeal for a walkout.

The Composers Group of New York City last evening presented it@ fifth annual concert at Carnegie L Recital Hall. Composers whose reworks were performed were Robert I E. Allen, Richard Cumming, Arnold Freed, Elizabeth Gyring and Irving Mopper. Artists participating in the concert were Mr. Allen, .Mr. Cumming, ]Vfr. Freed, the Kohon String Quartet, Doris Doree, so- prano; Toby Falleder, soprano; Marjorie Capo, soprano, and Stuart Fastofsk. y, violinist.

Whether or not exporters are permitted to take, or do take, permissible percentage mark-ups on their sales, they must file a report of their practices with the export-import branch of the Office of Price Stabilization in Washington, traders were reminded yesterday by Gene Herz, New York O. P. S. regional price executive.

GENEVA, June 3 -- After a six-week on-the-spot survey of the situation in Korea, J. Donald Kingsley, United Nations Agent General for Korean Reconstruction, has decided to base all his planning on the assumption that there will be no armistice in the Korean war in the foreseeable future.

Foster homes have been found for 263 children since the establishment in 1949 of the Department of Welfare's Division of Foster Home Care, Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy announced yesterday in a tribute to the foster parents who have made possible the division's accomplishments to date.

No immediate additional service will be available on the Long Island Rail Road for residents of Suffolk County who use the Greenport division, according to testimony given yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission at 233 Broadway.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 3 -- Nationalist China attacked today the Western powers' latest proposal for reduction of armed forces. It warned that this proposal would hamper the Chinese people in their "struggle for freedom" against the Chinese Communist regime.

Profits of food manufacturers have not reflected the increase in food prices since the Korean outbreak in mid-1950, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., said yesterday.
Enforcement of the Federal anti-pollution laws in New York Harbor and its approaches, a Navy function since 1888, is to be turned over to the Army Corps of Engineers.

A class of eighty-nine was graduated yesterday by the Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing at its fifty-eighth commencement exercises. The ceremony was held on the garden slope adjoining the Anna C. Maxwell Hall, the student nurses' residence at 179 Fort Washington Avenue, and was followed by a reception for families land friends of the graduates.
A "realistic compromise" that will permit a start of construction of the $90,000,000 third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel was reached yesterday between the city and the Port of New York Authority.

ALBANY, June 3 -- Governor Dewey today invited New York's ninety-six delegates to the Republican National Convention and their alternates to "a get-acquainted meeting" with General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in New York City on June 11.

In a balanced position and with forces even, Samuel Reshevsky and Svetozar Gligoric yesterday agreed to a draw in the second game of their match at the Manhattan Chess Club after the fortysecond move, sealed by the Yugoslav expert, at adjournment on Monday night, had been disclosed.
I have read with great interest your fine and searching editorial of May 30 on the puzzling problem of "Schizophrenia in Prices."

KANSAS CITY, Kan., June 3 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower (retired), an unfamiliar figure in a gray double-breasted suit and a summer straw hat, arrived in his home state of Kansas tonight to open his personal campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination.
LONDON, June 3 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, Atlantic pact deputy to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, confided to a British radio audience tonight that "I love Ike."
SEROWE, Bechuanaland, June 3 (Reuters) -- The police arrested thirty-eight Africans in a surprise raid today in this British South African tribal capital of the Bamangwato tribesmen.

LONDON, June 3 (UP) -- The University of Pennsylvania's 150-pound crew will defend the Thames Challege Cup in the 1952 Royal Henley regatta in a bid to win the tropy for the United States for the fifth straight year.
More stringent requirements governing the installation of flue-fed incinerators in apartment houses have been included in amendments to the regulations of the Smoke Control Bureau.

PATERSON, June 3 -- Frank Chickory of Aldecress fashioned a one-over-par 71 at the North Jersey Country Club today to top a field of fifty-four in the low gross phase of the one-day tournament of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

DETROIT, June 3 (AP) -- The pennant-contending Red Sox and the last-place Tigers traded nine players today in a deal that jolted the baseball world. The transaction, one of the biggest in the American League in years, sent Third Baseman George Kell and Outfielder Hoot Evers to the Red Sox.

A report to the Board of Estimate by its special bus committee yesterday found that of the three proposals made by private firms to acquire the city's five deficit-ridden Manhattan bus lines "the best is the proposal of the New York City Omnibus Corporation."
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower took off his five stars today to close a 37-year career as an Army officer and answer what he said was another "call to duty."

When local politicians wake up to the fact that the welfare of 2,000,000 children can provide a political issue "far livelier than the old 5-cent fare," the boys and girls of New York City may get more of the services they urgently require, Judge Jerome N. Frank of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals said last night.

BERLIN, June 4 -- A United States military policeman was slightly injured today when a patrol jeep came under fire at the West Berlin city line. A United States protest said the shots had been fired by an East German policeman and demanded that he be severely punished.

TWO gentle and mild-mannered men will do battle for the heavyweight championship of the world in Philadelphia's vast Municipal Stadium tonight. Jersey Joe Walcott, the venerable titleholder, will face Ezzard Charles, no spring chicken himself, in a bout that would be undistinguished were it not for the fact that sportdom's most cherished prize is at stake.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Forty-four Government agencies are engaged in some form of lending to individuals and corporations. C. Francis Cocke, president of the American Bankers Association, said today in deploring Government intrusion in the banking field.
Six persons; including two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, were injured yesterday afternoon in a head-on collision involving five cars on the elevated West Side Highway.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 4 -- Rutgers University will confer thirteen honorary degrees at its 186th anniversary commencement exercises on Saturday, Dr. Lewis W. Jones, president, announced today.

Most commodity futures markets were strong yesterday, closing higher or mixed. World sugar on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange was an exception. From Cuba there were reports that the single selling agency had marketed 16,000 tons at 4.25 cents a pound and had turned down a bid for 100,000 tons at 4 cents.

A group of property owners and representatives of civic and trade organizations from the Kings Highway district of Brooklyn tried hard yesterday before the City Planning Commissin to block a requested zone change that they argued would make an "eyesore" of the site for a library planned for their area.

WASHINGTON June 4 -- President Truman asked Congress today for supplemental appropriations for the Defense Department aggregating $3,463,555,440 for the 1953 fiscal year, beginning July 1. Nearly $3,000,000,000 of the total is for hundreds of bases and other military installations at home and abroad.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Continued absenteeism prevented action by the House of Representatives today on an appropriation bill to release funds for payment of overdue wages of thousands of postal and other Federal workers.

Spokesmen for the steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America have accepted the invitation of Acting Defense Production Administrator John R. Steelman to meet him at the White House today. The meeting can be the starting point for settling the steel strike which began on Monday when the Supreme Court held that president Truman lacked authority to seize the steel mills, causing their immediate restoration to their owners.
A Broadway fall prospect is a new script called "The Happy Ant Hill," described as "a character comedy with a European background," written by Franz Spencer.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 4 -- A thirteen-hit assault by Rutgers downed Princeton, 7 to 2, as the Scarlet extended its winning streak to five games on University Field today.
The Bronx Democratic Executive Committee yesterday designated Representative Christopher C. McGrath as the Democratic candidate for Surrogate of Bronx County.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 4 -- A three-day convention of the International Federation of Newspaper Publishers and Editors opened today with Johan van de Kieft of the Netherlands as chairman. Participating are eighteen affiliated associations from fifteen countries, which consume 80 per cent of the world's newsprint.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Those citizens, headed by the young intellectual radicals of the Thirties, who found so much wrong with the public institutions of the United States that some turned Communist or fellow-traveler and nearly all espoused fundamental changes by direct or indirect methods might ponder the most recent demonstration of the strength and equity of those institutions.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
Following is the text of the address by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower at Abilene, Kan., last evening as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
I have read with interest the remarkable editorial in your issue of May 27 with respect to the probable duplication here of the productivity of Soviet Russia in 1970.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- An Air Force court martial rejected today a defense plea for dismissal of charges of improper conduct against Col. David G. Sippel, who formerly served at Air Force headquarters here.

MEXICO CITY, June 4 -- In another of a series of measures designed to insure peaceful elections, President Miguel Aleman ordered the Army today to undertake a country-wide search for hidden arms, while the Defense Ministry called on the people to surrender illegally held weapons.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 4 -- The Ohio Turnpike Commission went into the Ohio Supreme Court today for a speedier determination of constitutionality of the Ohio Turnpike Law after a prearranged refusal by its secretary-treasurer to sign $326,000,000 of revenue bonds to finance the 241-mile toll road across northern Ohio.
LONDON, June 4 -- The opening of a new bookkeeping account today brought with it a cessation of the recent bout of selling of foreign bonds and a steadier tone to the stock markets generally.

Although most synthetic fabrics are easily washable, many of the garments made from such materials are difficult to launder, Mrs. Natalie Barry, supervisor of the General Electric Home Laundry Institute, said yesterday at a meeting of newspaper and magazine representatives.

Twelve charitable institutions were named among the legatees in the will of Mrs. May Gordon, filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court. Mrs. Gordon, a resident of 299 Park Avenue, died last Sunday. Her estate was estimated at more than $250,000.

SHAWNEE - ON - DELAWARE, Pa., June 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Charles Davitt, Glen Ridge, and Mrs. James Dorment, Montclair, shared honors today in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association 36-hole championship tournament at the Shawnee Inn and Country Club.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 4 -- The new so-called "wonder drug" treatment of tuberculosis through isonicotinic acid derivatives is still in the experimental stage and is not ready to be used clinically on patients, the head of the Trudeau Laboratory declared today.

The Government of Premier Antoine Pinay of France has brought "hope and confidence" to French business men, Jacques Fougerolle, president of the Paris Chamber of Commerce, declared yesterday at a luncheon in his honor at the Essex House.

New issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling $11,300,000 were placed on the market yesterday by underwriting syndicates. The offerings included preferred and common stock of the Tampa Electric Company and equipment trust certificates of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.

LONDON, Thursday, June 5 (Reuters) -- Two leading British newspapers asked today just how General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower would cut United States Federal spending if elected President and how such an economy program would affect United States aid to Europe.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 4 -- Robert C. Downie, retiring president of the Pennsylvania Bankers Association, warned today that if the nation's independent banking system did not provide the services the public wanted, then the people would turn to the Government for them.

I Retail merchants appear indif-I ferent to customer preference for more night openings of department and specialty stores, according to a survey conducted by students ofi New York University's School of Retailing. A report on the survey was made yesterday at a luncheon given in honor of the Class of '52 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
HELSINKI, Finland, June 4 -- The Soviet military delegation stayed away today from the first Army Day parade held in Finland since 1939.

In a plea for strong United States support of Israel, Representative Jacob K. Javits of New York said yesterday that Israel's military effectiveness "makes it the hard core of Near East resistance, as Turkey does not consider itself a Near East power."

Guaranty Trust Company of New York voted yesterday to raise the quarterly dividend on the bank's capital stock for the quarter ending June 30, 1952, to $3.50 a share. The dividend is payable on July 15. In previous quarters the bank paid $3. At the year end an extra dividend of $2 also was declared, making total declarations in 1951 of $14.

Dr. de Sola Pool writes about the desire of many of his friends and himself to erect a memorial to the Jewish victims of Nazi persecution. He states that the majority of these were Jews which may be. He also reminds us that the City of New York has given an imposing site on Riverside Drive for the proposed memorial.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today that he would ask a Federal court to make Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, reveal the names of persons who might contribute to Mr. Benton's defense of a $2,000,000 suit filed by Mr. McCarthy.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 4 -- A silent -- but for the beat of muffled drums -- procession of men and women and of war veterans of the Torch Commando marched through Capetown's main street today in protest against the High Court of Parliament Act, which was promulgated today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 4 -- Mediocre crop prospects and low reserves are again compelling the Government to import wheat for Yugoslavia, once one of the graneries of Europe.

Hiland G. Batcheller, chairman of the board of the Allegheny-Ludlum Steel Corporation, said last night that America's greatest strength arose from our freedom of thought and action. He addressed the ninety-third commencement of the Cooper Union in the Great Hall, Eigth Street at Fourth Avenue.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 4 -- Dr. Lewis W. Jones, president of Rutgers University, conferred baccalaureate degrees today on 276 graduates of the New Jersey College for Women at the thirty-first annual commencement exercises. Dean Margaret T. Corwin of the college presented the graduates.
The various efforts made from time to time in recent years to subdue city noises, especially the motor horn, have been failures.

Is the Board of Transportation or the Transport Workers Union managing New York City's transit system? This question, which recurs from time to time, arises anew in the reading of a report by a committee of city officials, headed by Controller Joseph and including as a member Chairman Bingham of the Board of Transportation.

GENEVA, June 4 -- The non-Communist labor organizations of the world have oversubscribed a special fund established by the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions to aid in organizing workers in areas long dominated by Communist-controlled union organizations.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- John J. Muccio, United States Ambassador to Korea, has been instructed to make the strongest representations against what officials here regard as disregard of the South Korean Constitution by President Rhee.

George Ball, formerly of El Paso, Tex., now a resident of New York City and a teacher at Browning School for Boys, was one of the second-round winners in the Inter-American invitation tennis tournament at the Hispano Tennis Club in Whitestone, Queens, yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4 -- The festive June Week activities at the United States Naval Academy neared their climax today with announcement of the names of the honor men in the graduating class and the presentation of academic prizes.

CLEVELAND, June 4 -- The continued trend toward "socialization" of the electric power and light industry in the United States has reached the point where 27 per cent of private power plants are affected by Federal power operations, John E. Corette, vice president of the Montana Power Company, said today at the closing session of the annual convention of the Edison Electric Institute.
Ninety-four men and fifteen women were graduated as doctors from New York Medical College yesterday in exercises at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.

PARIS June 4 -- The Belgians have proposed to use the United States offshore purchase policy as one means of liquidating their excessive credit to the European Payments Union but they apparently have found no support for this idea among United States officials.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP) -- Daniel D. Sullivan, director of the Miami Crime Commission, charged today that Western Union proposed new tariff restrictions to relieve itself of responsibility in banning its facilities to operators of handbooks.

BONN, Germany, June 4 -- The pressure by the Russians and East Germans on the Federal Republic and West Berlin has increased support for Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's policy of arming West Germany and integrating that nation in the Western community.

When they go away they leave lists. When they go away for even a day or two they leave lists everywhere. The milkman will find his list upon the porch and the laundryman will find his buried somewhere between the sheets and towels. Everywhere are lists.

NEWARK, June 4 -- Additional testimony in support of the proposal to bring northern New Jersey milk producers under joint Federal supervision with lower New York State producers was offered at the hearing today before an examiner of the United States Department of Agriculture.

Official signals got crossed yesterday and a plan to ease congestion near the big West Side piers went more awry than the traffic. Various city officials were supposed to meet to start a program of traffic relief along the busy waterfront. They all arrived, but could not find one another. The result was that the confusion remained as bad as ever, if not worse.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 4 -- Bobby Jacobson of Hollywood won the nineteenth annual William Rice Hochster Memorial golf tournament with 74, 73 -- 147 over the Quaker Ridge Country Club course today.

CINCINNATI, June 4 (UP) -- Three singles, a walk and Willard Marshall's run-scoring fly enabled the Reds to score two runs in the eighth inning tonight and defeat the Phillies, 10 -- 8, in a game in which both teams enjoyed seven-run innings.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 4 -- In the Economic and Social Council's debate on world economic problems, Dr. Isador Lubin, United States spokesman, submitted today an appraisal marked by confidence and measured optimism, which contrasted with the dubious tone of preceding speakers.

Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Science Degrees were awarded yesterday afternoon to sixty-seven young women graduates of Notre Dame College, on Grymes Hill, S.I., at the annual commencement exercises held on the campus.

The railroad issues took the stock market into higher territory yesterday. Although strength among the carriers was confined to a few units, the composite rate managed to climb 1.82 points to register the widest advance since May 2. The gain was considered purely of a technical nature and not attributable to news developments.

In its first change of ownership since its erection in 1926 by the late Sam Minskoff, the twenty-five-story Hotel Navarro at 112 Central Park Souht has been sold by the builder's estate to Navarro Ascociates, a syndicate consisting of Mannie Alt, Solomon Goldberg and Jerome Goldberg.

Author Harold Isaacs and Arthur Upham Pope of the Asia Institute are on solid ground in objecting to the use of the term "Far East" in reference to East Asia. They are wrong, however, in trying to make "Middle East" and "Western Asia" synonymous. They are not the same thing.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee postponed decisions indefinitely today on fifteen measures introduced in the heat of adverse Congressional reaction to the Government's seizure of the steel industry. The measures seek to impeach President Truman, to censure him, or to take from him by law powers claimed as being "inherent."
COMPTON, Calif., June 4 (AP) -- Big Jim Fuchs of the New York Athletic Club equaled his own American mark in the shot-put tonight with a throw of 58 feet 51/2 inches.

ALBANY, June 4 -- An Albany attorney told the Court of Appeals today that the special grand jury investigating gambling and corruption in Saratoga County had been selected with "the deliberate designed inclusion of those of a certain political persuasion."

Premier Antoine Pinay has done it again. In the Parliament and in the streets the mild-looking, quiet-voiced little man who heads the French Government is moving resolutely and successfully to restore the authority of France. On Tuesday he put through the National Assembly another of the controversial measures his predecessors tried in vain to enact into law.

PARIS, June 4 -- The overwhelming majority of French workmen demonstrated unmistakably today that Jacques Duclos, acting Secretary General of the French Communist party, would have to get out of jail as best he could by his own means.

A former paperhanger who is determined to be a history professor was graduated last night cumlaude from Long Island University, along with a 48-year-old Queens woman who is a volunteer tutor of the blind, and a young man who was unable, because of cerebral palsy, to take class notes or written examinations.

The radio speech made by Senator Taft on June 1 expounding his foreign policy is a strange brew of contradictions and inconsistencies. He has undertaken the nearly impossible task of rationalizing his voting record since 1939.

Countess Mara, Inc., manufacturer of neckties, bought the two-and-a-half-story building on lot 18 by 100 feet at 716 Fifth Avenue, near Fifty-sixth Street, from the Hanover Bank and Christian Zabriskie, executors of the estate of Frances Zabriskie.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Jimmy Carrick of Pittsburgh, 13-year-old "Kid of the Year," asked President Truman today to contribute blood for the troops in Korea, but the President said he was too old.

NEW DELHI, India, June 4 -- Referring sharply to the manner of the "foreign" administration in the centuries-old Portuguese and French settlements on India's two coasts, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared in Parliament today that these small detached territories "must inevitably" be joined to the Indian Union.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The possibility that the Mutual Security Program might become an issue in the selection of a Republican Presidential candidate was increased today when General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was invited to give his views on the drastically cut authorization to the Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives.

MANCHESTER, England, June 4 (UP) -- Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., former Wimbledon champion, gained the semi-final round of the northern England lawn tennis tournament today with a 6-4, 6-2 victory over Britain's Susan Partridge.

ABILENE, Kan., June 4 -- Like his invasion of Europe eight years ago, General Eisenhower's political invasion of the Middle West turned out this afternoon to be an amphibious operation. An hour before the general was scheduled to make his main address of the day it rained as if would never it stop.

More than 1,000 department store infants' wear merchandise managers and buyers warned yesterday that supermarkets may capture a large proportion of the substantial retail sales in their products this year. Ralph K. Guinzburg, president of the I. B. Kleinert Rubber Company, who sounded the warning, said estimates placed 1952 retail dollar volume in infants' wear between $2,800,000,000 and $8,000,000,000.

BONN, Germany, June 4 -- West Germany probably is better able than any other Western nation to increase its defense contribution and even enjoy a modest increase in its living standard, according to an official report of the Office of the United States High Commissioner.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 14 -- France proposed today that the United Nations dust off an international pact on news gathering -- shelved three years ago -- and asked member states to sign one section that pledged governments to help correct "false or distorted" news reports.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., June 4 -- If the Port of New York Authority expects to start construction on a $90,000,000 third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel between mid-Manhattan and this city, it should work out with the municipalities on this side of the Hudson River the problems faced by those communities that will comprise the "door-step" of the tuunel, Mayor Charles F. Krause Jr. said here today.

PUSAN, Thursday, June 5 (UP) -- A Government spokesman today indicated the South Korean political crisis might be settled within a few days by a compromise giving President Syngman Rhee his demands for direct popular election of the President and the creation of a two-house legislature.

PARIS, June 4 -- The new Government gold-backed loan is going so well that the State Printing Works has temporarily run short of 50,000 ($150) and 100,000 ($300) franc bonds, the Council of Ministers was told today.

CHICAGO, June 4 (UP) -- Johnny Saxton, a welterweight, remained undefeated in twenty-nine professional bouts by pounding out a unanimous decision tonight over Luther Rawlings, a lightweight, in the Chicago Stadium.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 4 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson, Cherry Valley, and Mrs. Thomas R. Rudel of The Creek Club combined to clip one stroke from par with 35, 35 -- 70 to take the first-day lead in the Women's Long Island Golf Association 36-hole four-ball tournament at the Creek Club today.

PITTSBURGH, June 4 -- A dozen timely hits, including home runs by Jackie Robinson and Duke Snider, enabled the Dodgers to beat the Pirates tonight, 7 -- 4, and move two full games ahead of the second-place Giants, who now have lost three more than the Brooks.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 4 -- One of the country's leading liquor executives went on record here today with the statement that the ten leading brands of whisky would not cut prices in the "foreseeable future."

New York unions appealed yesterday for Supreme Court review of a recent decision of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals giving an employer the right to discharge a worker who refused to cross the picket line of another union at another plant.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP) -- Temperance groups urged Congress today to tune out that fellow in the television commercials who took a long sip of beer, smacked his lips and told how good it tasted.

The city joined state efforts yesterday to find a peace formula in the strike by 600 armored car drivers and guards, who transport "millions" daily between banks and business concerns for four armored car companies.
Billy Cox, the Dodgers' third baseman, submitted his painfully injured left arm to X-ray examination yesterday and was told to rest it a while longer.

We had a good dinner the other night at the newly reopened Maisonette, 151 East Forty-ninth Street, and an equally good talk with the proprietor, who is also the chef. Such a combination of functions in one person may recommend a restaurant, for it implies that the boss is attentive both to food and service.

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., June 4 -- The tally in South Dakota's important Republican primary test between Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was so close tonight that talk arose of a recount that could delay an official verdict for some time.

Renew of the King Ranch exhibited her fast-closing qualities to the fullest in taking the Top Flight Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The 5-year-old daughter of Blue Larkspur, regarded as just about out of the mile and a sixteenth event as far as the mutuel board was concerned, surprised a crowd of 21,100 by earning the victory by three-quarters of a length under a good ride by William Boland.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday, and closed 3 to 67 points net higher, led by a strong covering movement in old July.
The State of California borrowed $50,000,000 yesterday in the public market on an issue of school-aid bonds maturing serially from 1954 to 1978 at an interest cost of 1.8678 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, this afternoon filed with the Federal Communications Commission a complaint asking that the Columbia Broadcasting System be forced to give him as much time as it has provided for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.
LONDON, June 4 -- Britain protested today to President Syngman Rhee over his purge of hostile members of the South Korean Assembly and continuation of martial law in Pusan.
The substructure stage of the port's most novel steamship pier is nearing completion at Grassy Point, N. Y., and the first section will be floated down the Hudson River early in July.

ST. LOUIS, June 4 (AP) -- Cloyd Boyer, a sore-armed pitcher most of 1951, pitched his second 1952 shut-out tonight as the Cardinals took advantage of wildness by two Boston pitchers to breeze to a 6-0 victory, breaking the Braves' three-game winning streak. The 24-year-old Boyer allowed only four hits.

The steel industry will urge the Government at a White House meeting today to keep hands off the steel wage dispute and allow the parties to try to settle the strike issues through collective bargaining.

Trailing by 1 point as the final event started, Boys High took second place in the 1,200-yard relay to gain 4 points and win the forty-eighth Annual Public Schools Athletic League track and field championship yesterday at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island. The Brooklyn schoolboys coached by Sid Elstein scored a total of 28 points to retain the laurels they won in 1949, before the championships were suspended because of the coaches' strike.

Very little steel is being produced -- no more than 10 per cent of the industry's capacity -- but steel output during May was rather good, despite a strike-caused curtailment early in the month. May production is estimated at 8,566,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings.

Army trucks became parade floats, a 40-by-80-foot field hospital tent was the Big Top and WACS turned up as hula dancers and tattooed ladies on Governors Island yesterday. Military police, rigidly awesome in Times Square, cavorted as white rabbits, donkeys and clowns.

The nation's gasoline stocks and light and heavy fuel oil supplies are in good supply, according to a report yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. This is the first weekly report on refinery operations since April 30, when 90,000 refinery workers went on strike. Most are now back at work.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 -- With more than forty ships tied up on the West Coast by a strike of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., officials of major American-flag lines met today to discuss the situation but announced no policy decision.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- In the arena that always will be associated in boxing history with the passing of a great champion, Jersey Joe Walcott will defend his world heavyweight title tomorrow night against the ex-champion, Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati.

The new anti-tuberculosis drugs, used experimentally up to now on hundreds of volunteer patients in hospitals all over the country, were released yesterday by the United States Food and Drug Administration "for use under close medical supervision."
BOSTON, June 4 (AP) -- Eugene Holman, president of Standard Oil Company (N. J.), said today the element of independence in the industry is impaired by Government price fixing.
BONN, Germany, June 4 -- Should the 16-year-old daughter of war criminal Albert Speer be permitted to go to the United States under the State Department exchange program?

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Trade in grain futures on the Board of Trade was overshadowed today by the display of speculative fireworks in the soybean market, where limit advances in all deliveries reflected a wave of short covering and professional buying that swept aside all selling opposition.
