HOBOKEN' N. J., June 4 -- Arriving on the Holland-America Line's flagship Nieuw Amsterdam, which docked today with 1,107 passengers from Rotterdam and Channel ports, Robert J. Corkery, coordinator for Europe of the United States Displaced Persons Commission, reported that a scheduled six-month job of bringing 54,000 German nationals to this country had been completed within four months.

RALEIGH, N. C., June 4 -- Three guards and seven civilian foremen of prison workshops were released unharmed tonight after they had been held as hostages by 150 prisoners at North Carolina Central prison here for five hours and forty minutes.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Thursday, June 5 (AP) -- United States infantrymen supported by tanks marched into a compound of 3,340 Communist civilian prisoners today and threw up a double barbed-wire fence cutting the enclosure in two.

SAYREVILLE, N. J., June 4 -- With his father, brother and a brother-in-law among clergymen officiating, the Rev. George Robert Buttrick was ordained into the Presbyterian ministry and installed as pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of this borough tonight.

Vol. XXVI, No. 1 of the Bawl Street Journal, an eight-page, full-size newspaper lampooning business, finance and government, is off the press and will go on sale tomorrow morning at Broad and Wall Streets. The publication, under the editorship of John A. Straley, is published annually on the occasion of the Bond Club's annual field day at Scarborough, N. Y. at sells for $1 a copy.
LONDON, June 4 -- Four new peers, five baronets and sixty knights appeared on the Birthday Honors List published today -- the first titles bestowed in the reign of Queen Elizabeth II.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 4 -- Authorities at Rutgers University protested today the detention yesterday of nine German labor union leaders attending the Rutgers-State Federation of Labor Summer School. The union leaders were questioned for half an hour by the police for taking photographs in a Negro slum area.

Ownership of two apartment house projects in Forest Hills, Queens, has been conveyed through the sale of the common stock of the Loumas Building Corporation to a client of Dreyer Traub, attorneys, in a transaction negotiated by Pearce, Mayer Greer as brokers. The properties are the Benson Gardens at 65-30 and 65-40 108th Street and the Supernal Gardens at 65-35 and 65-39 108th Street.

PARIS, June 4 -- A Berlin dispatch to Agence France-Presse, Frence News Agency, quoted Premier Stalin as having said to Polish journalists that the Oder-Neisse or existing Eastern frontier of East Germany was a secondary issue, but could be discussed with a Germany that was unified and neutral

EL CENTRO, Calif., June 4 -- The perennial issue of the use of Mexican workers by Southwestern farmers because of an asserted shortage of domestic labor came to a head again today as the National Farm Labor Union, A. F. L., called a strike at the height of the Imperial Valley's $8,000,000 melon[ harvest.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A bipartisan group will ask Congress tomorrow to pledge this country to such help to India in her five-year investment plan as would be "consistent with the financial capability of the United States."

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (AP) -- Bobby Shantz chalked up his ninth victory of the year tonight as he pitched the Athletics to a 4-to-3 triumph over the Tigers. A fourth-inning homer by Eddie Joost with one on was the clincher as the A's ran their winning streak to five straight.

J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., unveiled its new sales offices yesterday at the northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-first Street. The company, which is one of the largest textile manufacturers in the world, has consolidated fabric sales of four separately located offices here under one roof to create the largest textile selling house in the world.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 -- California's potent bloc of seventy votes will be available to Gov. Earl Warren at the Republican National Convention next month and its sixty-eight Democratic votes will bolster the Presidential ambitions of Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee.

An advertisement announcing the largest security offering to date this year -- the $326,000,000 bond issue to finance the construction of the Ohio Turnpike -- will break today in forty-seven newspapers and business and financial publications throughout the country.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard reserved decision yesterday on a defense plea for a new trial -- or at least a hearing by himself of experts and other witnesses -- on alleged "frauds" that might have led to the perjury conviction of Alger Hiss, former State Department official.

Terence Hearn, 39 years old, of 383 Tenth Avenue, a seaman who contracted malaria after being bitten by a mosquito in African waters, won a $25,000 settlement in Supreme Court yesterday after the case had been before Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan and a jury for a week.

MONTREAL, June 4 (UP) -- Hundreds of potato-hungry Americans crossed to Canadian border towns today and bought up all the potatoes they could carry home. Most of the potatoes came from the United States in the first place.

WASHINGTON, June, 4 (UP) -- Supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican Presidential nomination cheered his first political speech at Abilene, Kan., today but backers of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio called on him to be more specific.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 -- A new movement is under way within the ranks of the Screen Writers Guild for the organization to discontinue its breach of contract action against Howard Hughes and R. K. O. Radio Pictures, which refused to give screen credit on a film to Paul Jarrico after he refused to tell the House Un-American Activities Committee whether or not he was a Communist.

Pounding Joe Dobson for thirteen hits, including a two-run homer by Yogi Berra, the Yankees yesterday maintained their mastery over the White Sox and moved into third place in the tight American League pennant race.

BOSTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Red Sox drew a quick dividend today from the new talent obtained in yesterday's five-for-four trade with Detroit as they regained the American League's top rung by ousting the Indians with a 13-11 victory over Cleveland.

KALIMPONG, India, June 4 -- Chang Ching-wu, head of Communist China's civil and military headquarters in Lhasa, called a meeting of the working-class population of the city last week to pacify the growing bitterness against the Chinese representatives stationed in Lhasa. He also appealed for "working-class consciousness."

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Another bitter fight over the Truman Administration's efforts to whittle away the political patronage of members of Congress is developing in the Senate, with a showdown due within the next few weeks.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 5 -- United Nations armistice delegates at Panmunjom yesterday sought information from the Communists on more than 900 Allied prisoners captured by the Chinese and North Koreans in the Korean war but not included on the roster of captives be exchanged after a truce.

Ecuador has set an example of democratic electoral procedure of which the whole inter-American community can be proud. The outcome of the Presidential elections of last Sunday, which Dr. Velasco Ibarra won by a large margin, was astonishing. He actually was given an even smaller chance than Harry Truman in 1948, but he also fooled the pundits and (let it be confessed) the newspaper men.

For a brief hour yesterday the little town of Abilene was more important than Washington or London, Paris or Moscow. A soldier and a statesman had come home. Millions of his countrymen waited eagerly to hear the first words he would speak as an active candidate for his party's nomination for the great office of the Presidency What they heard must have been deeply reassuring.

HONG KONG, June 4 Four Jesuit priests -- three Americans and one Frenchman -- have arrived here from Communist China after having been jailed in various prisons there for ten months. Their story was told today in a statement issued by the Catholic Welfare Center, which said Msgr. Eugene E. Fahy, one of the Americans, had passed almost three months of this time with his feet shackled to iron bars of a prison cell.

A photographer was taking pictures at Hillside Hospital recently. As is customary at hospitals for the mentally ill, he started to pose patients with their faces turned from the camera, protecting them from the supposed "stigma" of mental illness.

As a result of a double-barreled intervention by President Truman and the British Government, President Rhee of the Republic of (South) Korea appears to be reconsidering the arbitrary and unconstitutional policy he has pursued in his feud with the Assembly.

CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- A Federal Court jury convicted the police chief of suburban Cicero and two policemen tonight of denying a Chicago Negro his civil rights. A riot broke out last July when a mob kept the Negro and his family from moving into the all-white suburb.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 4 -- The most decorated soldier of the Korean fighting was free today even though he could not pay his fine on a traffic charge.
BRUSSELS, June 4 (AP) -- A four-man Australian delegation led the way into the quarter-final round of the Belgium international tennis championships today
ABILENE, Kan., June 4 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's homecoming today was a little like William Jennings Bryan's old invasions of the Bible Belt, during the Chautauqua circuit days.

MEDFORD, Mass., June 4 -- Some Boston Yankees, who like to boast of the cultural advantages of their city's environs, have gone through life without ever setting foot on the campus of Tufts College, a purposely modest but venerable institution that is observing its centennial this year.

REPORTS from several northern rivers indicate that early runs of Atlantic salmon are making an appearance. This week will find many of the more impatient anglers heading for favorite rivers in Quebec, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia and Newfoundland.

A roster of former major college basketball stars, gamblers and notorious underworld characters was read off yesterday as selection of a jury began in the General Sessions trial of two alleged basketball fixers.

Taft strategists had originally regarded South Dakota as "safe" territory. Two months ago the Taft manager for the state thought his slate of Republican convention delegates would be "elected handily, especially if the Senator comes into the state." Mr. Taft did go into the state, stumping it to the farthermost corner for five days just before the primary and expressing views that its isolationist and rural voters most wanted to hear.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 4 -- Herman Barron, professional at the Fenway Golf Club of White Plains, N. Y., who was the Western Open champion ten years ago, set the pace in the Metropolitan District's qualifying trials for the United States Open championship with 139 at the Montclair Golf Club today.

KOJE, Korea, June 4 -- United States infantrymen, moving behind Patton tanks with fixed bayonets and faces masked against the tear gas barrages, today ripped down the last Communist flag over this island prison and burned the last insulting banner that the Reds had strung along the barbed wire.

Lew Hahn, president emeritus of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, was honored yesterday at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel marking his retirement from business. About 100 executives in the department store and allied fields paid tribute to him for his "outstanding contributions to retailing during the last thirty-four years."

Sales of the new automobile use tax stickers at the Municipal Building totaled 18,055 yesterday, according to figures made public by the City Collector's office. For the first time the total reflected a substantial number of mail orders.

Sharp, brilliant colors skillfully combined or used with neutral tones provide excitement in an extensive collection of textiles introduced by the Herman Miller Company and available through the decorating department of Bloomingdale's. An architect, Alexander Girard, planned and designed the group, which includes woven, fabrics in weights suitable for both upholstery and draperies, a sampling of loose, translucent casement cloths, and four printed designs with variations.

Mrs. Anna Wentworth spent an uncomfortable day on the stand yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court at the disciplinary trial of former District Attorney Herman Methfessel of Richmond County and Irving Rivkin, his former assistant.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A proposal to set up legal machinery for Government seizure of a struck industry was put before the Senate today as labor and management in the strike-bound steel industry accepted a White House invitation to meet tomorrow for a resumption of peace talks.

SAIGON, Indo-China, June 4 -- Nguyen Van Tam, Vietnam's new Premier was reported today to be trying to form a small Cabinet that would include only five other Ministers besides himself. Mr. Van Tam was said to be planning to be his own Minister of the Interior, the post he held in the former Government and which carries with it control of the national police and the supervision of regional governors.

QUITO, Ecuador, June 4 -- Faced with the election results, Dr. Ruperto Alarcon Falconi apparently abandoned hope today of contesting Dr. Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra's right to the presidency. He issued a statement denying that he had ever intended to impugn the honesty of the supreme electoral tribunal and said he had only meant that the first figures published might be inaccurate.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 4 (AP) -- A new threat to Iran's already shaky economic and financial structure loomed today in the slowly but steadily increasing unemployment reported from industrial areas throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today accused a big group of tomato processors of combining to boycott and destroy a cooperative of tomato growers in Ohio, Michigan and Indiana. A hearing was set for July 10 in Los Angeles, with Examiner Everett F. Haycraft presiding.

WASHINGTON, June 4 Senator Estes Kefauver was jubilant today over his primary victories in the South Dakota and California Presidential primaries. He said that the seventy-six delegates he gained in those two states assured him almost 300 "definitely committed" votes at the Chicago national convention opening July 21.
Operating results of Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., for April and May improved over the similar period last year, F. J. Andre, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

ABILENE, Kan., June 4 (UP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower would not talk about a "moral victory" today when shown reports from South Dakota's Presidential primary in which Senator Robert A. Taft held a slender lead.

The New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects yesterday elected as its new president Hugh Ferriss, internationally known consultant, to succeed Francis Keally. Mr. Ferriss served as consultant to the United Nations Headquarters Planning Staff and at present is consultant for planning the Inter-American Center in Miami, Fla.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended May 28:

Columbia College graduates were urged by their dean yesterday to remember that their education had been made possible by the free expression of ideas and that it was their responsibility, as educated men, to protect that freedom.

A certified public accountant, his daughter and his son-in-law have been charged with operating a fraudulent income tax scheme that could have cost the Government $1,787,000, United States Attorney Myles J. Lane announced yesterday.

A major effort to increase the nation's tactical air strength and fundamental revisions in the Air Force system of supporting ground troops are urged in the final report of Project Vista, now under study in Washington.

John J. Lenney, who is 81 years old, will receive a Doctor of Philosophy degree from Columbia University today. Unlike his 6,847 classmates he will see nothing too unusual in the situation, because "learning is my occupation."

PARIS, June 4 -- The first observance in Paris of the establishment of the Koussevitzky Music Foundation took place this afternoon at the American Embassy. The theatre was packed for the musical program and motion picture, "Tanglewood on Parade," held for a distinguished audience.

Tie-Bar, Inc, store in 1474 Broadway; Armigene Johnson, Walter E. Jacobson. John B. Dawson, in 179 Madison Ave; Durette Lingerie, Inc, through Williams Co, in 176 Madison Ave -- Charles F. Noyes Co, broker.

The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, Samuel Antek conducting, will play its first outdoor concert Sunday afternoon, June 15, at the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus C. Studer Jr., 25 Prospect Avenue Montclair.

BOMBAY, June 4 (Reuters) -- India exported to the United States goods worth $296,500,000 in 1951 and imported goods worth $464,300,000, thus having a trade deficit of $167,800,000 with America, official figures showed today.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP) -- James V. Bennett, director of the Federal Prisons Bureau, declared today that many unnecessary "cruelties and indignities" are heaped on prisoners in non-Federal prisons and jails.

ABILENE, Kan., June 4 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower declared today that the American way of life was threatened by Communist dictatorships abroad and by policies at home that promoted disunity, inflation, excessive taxation and over-centralization of power in the Federal Government.

The Committee for the Armed Forces of the Welfare and Health Council of New York asked the aid yesterday of taxi drivers in steering young service men on leave in this city to "wholesome" lodgings for the night.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 4 -- The events that led up to the Jordan Government decision to depose King Talal as reported by diplomatic sources were as follows:

POBLET, Spain, June 4 -- The mortal remains of thirteen kings and queens who ruled Aragon and Catalonia in the Middle Ages were brought for interment to the monastery of Poblet today from the cathedral of Tarragona where they had been preserved for more than a century.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- A spokesman for the American Federation of Labor has asked the Wage Stabilization Board to approve an 11 per cent pay rise for all workers on the basis of productivity gains in the last two years.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, candidate for the Republican nomination for President, will hold a press conference at 11 o'clock Saturday morning in the East Ballroom of the Commodore Hotel.

BUENOS AIRES, June 4 -- With his wife Eva by his side, Juan Domingo Peron took the oath of office this afternoon to succeed himself as President of Argentina for another six-year term. A few minutes later he swore in his twenty-one-man Cabinet which contains seven men comparatively new to the Argentine political limelight.

The Carrier Corporation, pioneer in air-conditioning, had a net profit of $3,900,079 in the twelve months ended with April, equal to $4.26 a common share, according to the report issued yesterday. In the twelve months to April 30, 1951, the net was $4,470,360, or $4.90 a common share.
Summer styles, ranging from high-fashion cottons for daytime to silk organza after-five dresses, were a feature of the style show in B. Altman's misses' dress department Tuesday.

Gerard W. Purcell, former fireman and official of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, was accused in the Court of General Sessions yesterday of misappropriating more than $200,000 in association funds while he was the "sole boss" of its fund-raising activities from 1948 through 1950.

Six thousand families in the Flatbush and Canarsie sections of Brooklyn were deprived of electric current for a brief period last night when a severe thunderstorm swept over the metropolitan area. A Consolidated Edison Company spokesman said that lightning apparently struck a pole carrying feeder lines to the two affected areas at 9:16 P. M.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The books and records of business concerns are open to examination by the Office of Price Stabilization, that agency announced today. The claim to authority for examining records, O. P. S. enforcement officials said, has been established through a ruling by Federal Judge John Knight of the United States District Court for the Western New York District.
The following is the way the Republican and Democratic lineups for the Presidential nominating conventions stood last night for leading candidates, excluding Republican results in South Dakota.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 3 -- An agreement redrawing the line of demarcation between Israel and Jordan was reached several weeks ago by Israeli and Jordanian members of the mixed armistice commission but was rejected by the Jordanian Government, it was authoritatively learned today.

Mark Schorer and the executors of the estate of Sinclair Lewis have signed a contract with McGraw-Hill for a biography of the late novelist. The executors have agreed to make available to Mr. Schorer all of Mr. Lewis' papers that they control.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that there was complete solidarity of view among the United States, Britain and France on their determination to maintain their position in Berlin.

The Buckeye Mariner, fifth of thirty-five new-type ships under construction by the Government, will be launched at noon tomorrow at the yards of the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, Chester, Pa.
Arguments, study outlines, excerpts and books, but little evidence were presented yesterday at the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders in United States District Court.

Six thousand families in the Flatbush and Canarsie sections of Brooklyn were deprived of electric current for a brief period last night when a severe thunderstorm swept over the metropolitan area. A Consolidated Edison Company spokesman said that lightning apparently struck a pole carrying feeder lines to the two affected areas at 9:16 P. M.

The Buckeye Mariner, fifth of thirty-five new-type ships under construction by the Government, will be launched at noon tomorrow at the yards of the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, Chester, Pa.
Arguments, study outlines, excerpts and books, but little evidence were presented yesterday at the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders in United States District Court.

First-quarter sales of the National Department Stores Corporation were down 2 1/2 per cent from the similar period ended in April last year, Harry H. Schwartz, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

One of those things that many a fire engine "fan" has often speculated on happened in Brooklyn yesterday. The rear section of a Fire Department hook and ladder truck went out of control and scraped three parked vehicles -- two commercial trucks and a taxicab.

Mayor Impellitteri turned down yesterday an invitation to attend the Tammany dinner for the New York County delegation to the Democratic National Convention, thereby blocking all efforts to end his feud with Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany.
PARIS, June 5 -- In a statement that he called a warning to the nation, Gen. Charles de Gaulle attacked tonight both the Bonn convention and the European Defense Community treaty.
Beginning July 1 the 15-cent combined ride on city subways and municipal or private surface lines will be eliminated, and those using such connecting facilities will have to pay 20 cents.
Following is the transcript of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's televised press conference held yesterday at Abilene, Kan., as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

A woman who had confessed killing her husband, after his death had been listed as an apparent suicide by gas, was acquitted of first-degree murder yesterday by a Queens County Court jury on instructions of Judge John F. Scileppi.

The future of free trade unionism is a subject of absorbing interest in a world where some Governments tend to encroach on the right of individuals to associate freely for purposes of self-organization in pursuit of their legitimate economic interests. Where dictatorship prevails trade unions cannot exist.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 5 -- Capt. Guy K. Troy of St. Petersburg, Fla., held a narrow lead today after three events in the United States modern pentathlon championship.

Appealing for a stepped-up program of carrier construction, Secretary of the Navy Dan A. Kimball declared last night that "we don't need to look forward to war if we are prepared properly to meet aggression.

Patrick J. Linehan, a classics-quoting tavern owner, moved in Supreme Court yesterday to have set aside the new liquor license surtax on the ground that it was unconstitutional. Mr. Linehan, whose Linehan-Leary Corporation owns a tavern at 237 West 105th Street, says "we pay occupancy taxes, gross receipt taxes and every other of the taxes which the ingenuity of man exercising dominion over man has conceived."

Fruit stalls are taking on a summer look; today the numerous offerings include cherries and cantaloupes from California, watermelon from Florida and blueberries from the Carolinas. Strawberries are particularly plentiful, although there is a great range in both quality and price.

The American Nationality Press, representing 106 foreign language newspapers in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania, will give a luncheon today for W. Averell Harriman, candidate for the Democratic nomination for President. The luncheon will be held at the Pierre Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street.
The futures market on the Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and prices eased 20 to 35 points.

Although no one yet seems to have discovered a method of making a silk purse out of a sow's ear, quite a few persons have been able to convert an old coat into a living-room rug, judging from Miss Rebecca Andrews' report on her expanding hooked-rug business, which she described in an interview here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP) -- The Tigers clubbed their way to a 12-2 victory over the Athletics tonight in a game marked by home runs by Jerry Priddy and Walt Dropo as Detroit ended a five-game Philadelphia winning streak.

The stock market scored yesterday its second successive strong rally which carried prices to the best levels since April. Packed by larger volume, the steel issues swung into the recovery effort with all units in this division sharing in the rise.

REHOVOTH, Israel, June 1 -- In the next few weeks Israel's parliament, the Knesset, is expected to approve a bill that will set the terms for granting concessions for exploration of the country's oil resources. Shortly thereafter a number of groups are expected to start drilling for oil.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- The ring tradition that no dethroned heavyweight champion ever regains the title held good at the Municipal Stadium tonight when Jersey Joe Walcott, in his first defense of the championship he had won less than a year ago, repulsed the efforts of Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati to batter his way back to the throne.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 5 -- The United States recommended today that the United Nations quit its five-year-old labors to write international laws to cover the field of press and information rights and called for a fresh start.

Nine residents of the northeast Bronx have been elected members of a community school committee that will help administer eleven schools of that area in an experimental project, Dr. Joseph O. Loretan, assistant superintendent of schools, announced yesterday.
Registering the tenth decline in eleven weeks, loans to business by New York City banks dropped $34,000,000 last week.

DEN HELDER, The Netherlands, June 5 (UP) -- Fourteen British sailors and the Dutch pilot of a United States-built F-84 Thunderjet were killed today, when the plane made a mock strafing attack and plunged at near-sonic speed into a British minesweeping motor launch.

Just a bit grayer and balder than last June, 600 Wall Street executives will be away from their desks today. They will be playing golf and tennis and pitching horseshoes at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club at Scarsborough, N. Y., in celebration of the annual field day of the Bond Club of New York.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- If it isn't one thing it's another to torment the Giants on this unexpectedly tortuous journey through the West. Today it was Paul Minner, the tall left hander who used to pitch for Brooklyn when Leo Durocher was the Dodger manager.

FREEPORT, L. I., June 5 -- When a trout stream becomes discolored the fly fishermen shrug, adjourn to the nearest tavern and play poker until it clears, but when Great South Bay gets dirty the fluke and flounder enthusiasts keep right on fishing, but without much success.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, June 15 -- The Russians appear to have cast off all restraint in the remilitarization of East Germany. According to Allied sources, an East German armored division will be in the field by autumn and East German fighter squadrons will be attached to the Soviet Air Force in East Germany before the end of the year.

Two hundred and sixty-seven Barnard College seniors received their diplomas yesterday afternoon at a special ceremony in the gymnasium. The ceremony took place immediately after the Columbia University exercises on the steps of Low Memorial Library, in which the seniors also participated.

Ways in which mothers can "immunize" their children against accidents are presented in a new safety education pamphlet just released. Titled "Safety Vaccine," it is a twelve page illustrated publication intended as an aid to doctors in teaching parents methods of preventing accidents to children.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 5 -- The organized underworld has re-entered bootlegging on a scale that dwarfs the largest output of the turbulent Twenties, according to W. W. Wachtel, president of Calvert Distillers Corporation.

It is expected that more than 425,000 persons will fly the Atlantic in both directions this year. This enormous expansion of traffic on the trail Lindbergh blazed twenty-five years ago is but one of the almost incredible advances of aviation in the quarter century.

Bolivian tin, the most important supply of this vital defense metal the United States had, may have been lost to this country as a result of the recent revolution in Bolivia, Arturo Cano, former consul general of Bolivia in New York, declared yesterday in an interview.

The sitdown strike of 500 mechanics and cargo handlers of American Airlines that started at La Guardia Airport late Wednesday continued yesterday despite a reported order from the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., to return to work. By late last evening the line had been forced to cancel thirty-four incoming and outgoing flights at La Guardia out of 194 daily movements.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., June 5 (AP) -- Penn State and Villanova entered the final of the National Collegiate A. A. District 2 baseball play-offs today by downing Fordham and St. John's, respectively, in a sudden-death elimination series.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson will go to Brazil July 1 or 2, soon after returning from a quick transatlantic trip that may include a visit to Berlin.

SMITHTOWN, L. I., June 5 -- At the foot of a hill on Jericho Turnpike that forms the western boundary of this community is a huge bull cast in bronze. It commemorates the founding of Smithtown in 1665. The bull symbolizes the legend, oft-repeated around these parts, of the sturdy York-shireman Richard Smith, who was granted all the land he could encompass by riding his bull from sun-up to sun-down in one day.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Soybean trading again was the center of interest today on the Board of Trade, with wide price swings characterizing the trade. Soybean oil advanced 1/2 cent to 11 1/2 cents a pound and soybean meal, with admixtures, is reported selling as much as $12 a ton above the ceiling price of $81.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 5 -- Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley and Mrs. Thomas R. Rudel of The Creek added 68 to their first-round 70 for a thirty-six-hole total of 138 to win the Women's Long Island Golf Association's two-day handicap tournament easily at The Creek Club today.

TRENTON, June 5 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey will discuss Republican Presidential politics in New York next Thursday with General Eisenhower, but will not take advantage of an opportunity to confer with Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, a rival of the general for the nomination.

Gerard W. Purcell, former fireman and official of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, cautioned firemen selling tickets and raffles to association events that poor sales would jeopardize their special details, it was testified yesterday at his trial in the Court of General Sessions.
A demonstration for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, candidate for the Republican nomination for President, is expected tonight when he arrives at La Guardia Airport from Abilene, Kan.

ABILENE, Kan., June 5 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower has demonstrated here that what he does naturally and spontaneously is politically effective, and that what he plans and calculates in advance is far more likely to get him into trouble.

Eleven high schools will remain open this summer for the benefit of pupils who wish to further their education during the vacation period, it was announced yesterday at a meeting of the Board of Education. Instruction will be provided for pupils of exceptional ability who wish to take advanced courses, for pupils repeating courses they have failed and for veterans who desire to complete high school courses.

Feed producers must improve their marketing techniques or watch their sales dwindle, Frank W. Lovejoy of Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, said yesterday in an address at the annual convention of the Eastern Federation of Feed Merchants at the Statler Hotel. Companies must gear their operations so that they can work on a narrow profit margin if they wish to stay in business, he said.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Administration forces in the Senate feared tonight that, unless a solution could be reached over the week-end, the allocation of scarce materials, both on a national and international scale, would be impossible under the new Defense Production Act.

Blockson Chemical Company, a leading United States producer of sodium phosphates, announced yesterday plans for the marketing of 500,000 shares of common stock, the first public distribution of the company's shares since the business was founded in 1926.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The International Development Advisory Board, composed of private citizens named to guide Point Four policy, reported to President Truman today that his program of technical assistance for underdeveloped countries had become "a strong and effective instrument" of United States foreign policy.

Two six-story apartment houses in Rego Park, Queens, have been sold by Mrs. Mary Howell to investors in transactions negotiated through Spear Co., brokers. Jacob Glass Sons bought the property at 63-50 Wetherole Street for cash above mortgages of $290,000.

With immediate members of their large family and a number of friends present, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rayder of 537 Beach 132d Street, Belle Harbor, Queens, celebrated their golden wedding anniversary yesterday by repeating at a special church ceremony the marriage vows they took fifty years ago in Philadelphia.

MIAMI, Fla., June 5 (AP) -- Six persons lost their lives and seventeen were rescued Sunday when the island motor vessel Zelma Rose overturned in rough water about forty miles northeast of Nassau, Bahamas, according to reports reaching Miami today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 -- The almost completed tabulation of ballots cast in the state's primary election of Tuesday showed today not only that more Californians voted than ever before in a primary, but that they gave more votes to their senior Senator, William F. Knowland, than any Californian previously had garnered in a primary.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Representative Frances P. Bolton, Republican of Ohio, today introduced in the House of Representatives a bill providing emergency scholarships for newly enrolled student nurses.

Dr. Grayson L. Kirk, vice president and provost of Columbia University, expressed the belief at the university's 198th annual commencement exercises yesterday that the United States might be able to work out "some acceptable form of co-existence" with the Soviet Union.

The Public Housing Administration announced yesterday that $69,103,000 in short-term loan notes of twelve local housing authorities had been sold at costs ranging from 0.94 per cent to 0.99 per cent discount.

The bipartisan group of Congressmen who have offered a resolution showing interest in, and pledging support for, India's five-year plan are being helpful and sensible. It is especially encouraging to see influential names like Senator Wiley's and Senator McMahon's on the list.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, abruptly broke off his questioning of Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, today to seek a court order compelling Mr. Benton to answer certain questions.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- All price controls over white potatoes were removed by the Office of Price Stabilization tonight. The suspension applies at all levels of distribution from the grower to the retail store.
MEXICO CITY, June 5 -- The days of the quick Mexican divorce, upheld in a New York court last March, apparently are numbered.

ABILENE, Kan., June 5 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's political managers here ruled today that the television networks could not transmit a "live" report of his press conference this morning, but the networks did it anyway.

Miss Isabel Townsend Pell, formerly prominent in New York society and a leader in the French underground in World War II, collapsed and died last night while dining with a friend in an East Side restaurant.

Your editorial "Communism in France," appearing in the May 30 issue of THE TIMES, should be read and reread by every progressive-thinking American concerned with, and aware of, the critical period through which our civilization is passing.

Hamilton Basso, long a student of the American frontier, has signed a contract with McGraw-Hill for a book dealing with the peak years of the fur trade in the United States, 1822 to 1834. The narrative will present such trappers, path-finders and mountainmen as John Colter, Jim Bridget, Thomas Fitzpatrick, William and Milton Sublette and Kit Carson.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, June 5 -- A North Korean prisoner of war who had been freed from kangaroo court tyranny in a Communist-run compound on this island told today a tale of torture at the hands of Red leaders.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 5 -- While nothing has come of the offer made last month to Marlon Brando by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to star in "Vaquero," a story about cattle empire builders in Texas, the actor has more than a casual interest in the studio's projected filming of "Julius Caesar." Joseph L. Mankiewicz, the director, thought Brando would make a good Mark Anthony and talked him into making a sound test in New York recently.

Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $3,750,000 in the six months ended March 1, after providing $3,900,000 for taxes and $200,000 for contingent liabilities. For the corresponding period ended Feb. 24, 1951, the net profit was $3,827,000 after $4,200,000 tax charges and $400,000 contingent liabilities.

ALBANY, June 5 -- The State Education Department upheld today the right of the New York City Board of Education to deny the use of public school buildings to the Teachers Union, United Public Workers, independent.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 5 (Reuters) -- J. G. N. Strauss, leader of the United party opposition, said today the party would go to court if the Government set up a High Court of Parliament.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- Fire on the wrecked tanker F. L. Hayes has been extinguished and limited traffic now is permitted through the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal, the Army Engineers announced today.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 5 -- Homer Folks, executive director of the State Charities Aid Association for more than fifty years and onetime Commissioner of Public Charities of New York City, today was named winner of the first annual Hermann M. Biggs Memorial Award given by the State Public Health Association for meritorious service in public health.

New fashion collections that arrived here this week from Italy were presented in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel yesterday. They are the creations of Italy's top designers and may be seen by the public at the Italian Fair at Grand Central Palace.

TOKYO, Friday, June 6 -- The Government-controlled Peiping radio warned this morning that the Korean armistice talks at Panmunjom had reached "a critical point," and were being kept alive "only by the pressure of world public opinion for peace."
Many dinner parties were given last night at the twenty-fifth seasonal opening of the St. Regis Roof.

Jersey Joe Walcott of Camden retained his world heavyweight championship last night with a unanimous decision over Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati in a fifteen-round bout in Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 -- Eikichi Araki, Japan's first Ambassador to Washington since Pearl Harbor, arrived at the San Francisco International Airport today. He said admittance of Japan to the United Nations would be one of his major tasks.

A crack stewards crew for the new superliner United States is rounding into shape here as rapidly as is the new "First Lady of the Seas" in her Newport News, Va., birthplace. There will be no wet thumbs or sticky fingers in the vessel when she makes her first trip in the luxury transatlantic travel trade on July 3.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- President Truman ordered the Treasury Department today to end, beginning July 5, all trade agreement benefits to Communist Hungary.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Treasury Department announced today that subscriptions to the open offering of the new 2 3/4 percent non-marketable bonds totaled $1,757,759,000, of which $450,399,500 were in cash and $1,307,359,500 were in exchange for 25 1/2 percent marketable Treasury bonds of 1965-70, 1966-71 and two issues of 1967-72.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The questions and answers at General Eisenhower's meeting with the press at Abilene, Kan., today had not been half recorded on the news tickers when his Republican opponents must have realized that Eisenhower had destroyed one of their principal arguments against his nomination for the Presidency.

MANILA, June 5 -- The Philippine Government today opened conversations with Admiral Raymond Spruance, the United States Ambassador, looking to eventual revision of the Philippine Trade Act of 1946, which is the basic economic agreement between the two countries and provides for limited free trade.

ARDMORE, Okla., June 5 (UP) -- Roberto de Vicenzo of Argentina conquered the hills and ravines of the Dornick Hills Country Club's lay-out today with a five-under-par 65 that gave him the 18-hole lead in the $18,000 Ardmore open golf tournament.

It is a black mark for the new M. N. R. Government in Bolivia that it has acted in such a way as to force the newspaper La Razon of La Paz to close down. For a Government that purports to be democratic, and that has just won recognition from the United States and other countries, this is a very poor showing.

ABILENE, Kan., June 5 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower outlined to a televised press conference today the fundamental tenets of his Republican allegiance and said "my passion is the public interest" with fair and equal treatment for all segments of the population and economy.

Samuel Reshevsky of this city encountered Svetozar Gligoric of Belgrade in the third contest of their ten-game series at the Manhattan Chess Club last night and played to a draw in twenty-eight moves.
PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- The Old Man did it. Never mind how he did it, but Jersey Joe Walcott retained his world heavyweight championship by outpointing Ezzard Charles tonight.

LAST April when "Trial Judge"* by Justice Bernard Botein was published I was unaccountably looking the other way. This was a grievous error, for "Trial Judge" is one of the outstanding books so far published in 1952, an intensely interesting and deliciously amusing account of a judge's life and a judge's mind.

SAIGON, Indo-China, June 3 -- The Vietminh forces have been beaten and seriously weakened during the last six months of the dry season campaigning in the main Tonkin theatre of the Indo- China war, Gen. Raoul Salan, French Commander-in-Chief in Indo- China, said in an interview here today.

Toward the latter part of the month, when most schools will have released their charges for the summer, a group of thirty-two officers of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railroad will be toting notebooks and pencils to the class- rooms of the University of Southern California, Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The House passed today a bill designed to change for this crop year the base on which cotton parity and support prices are figured.

The practice of syndicate price-fixing was removed yesterday as an issue in the investment banking anti-trust trial here except to the extent that certain price agreements can be related to the monopoly-conspiracy charges brought by the Government against seventeen major investment banking houses.

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that the enlargement of Brooklyn's DeKalb Avenue Station on the B. M. T. subway line would have "top priority" as a result of a recent conference between the commissioners and Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn.

TORONTO, June 5 -- The United States Steel Corporation entered the hunt for Canadian iron ore today .with an announcement here that its subsidiary, Oliver Iron Mining Company of Duluth, had acquired options on 5,400 acres of valuable tobacco lands near Simcoe on the Canadian shore of Lake Erie. The site is roughly seventy miles west of Buffalo.

BOSTON, June 5 (AP) -- Early Wynn, using a wide variety of soft pitches, hurled the Indians back to the American League lead today by beating the Red Sox, 5 -- 0, with a highly impressive four-hit performance.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended May 31, 1952, totaled 697,026 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 64,621 cars, or 8.5 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 47,629, or 6.4 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 12,870, or 1.8 per cent fewer than two years ago.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Army asked the Selective Service System today to send 29,000 recruits into training camps in August. The quota raised to 983,430 the number of men called or to be called for military service through the draft since September, 1950.

PARIS, June 5 -- Jacques Duclos, acting leader of the French Communist party who is under arrest on the charge of an attempt against the internal security of the state, will make an initial appearance Saturday before Paris Magistrate Pierre Jacquinot.
A 2-year-old colt of great promise won the five-furlong dash through the Widener chute that was the feature of yesterday's proceedings at Belmont Park.
LONDON, June 5 -- Under brilliant sunshine and amid all the pomp and pageantry attached to the Trooping the Color, Queen Elizabeth II took the salute today at her first official birthday parade.

Friend Taylor, a Long Island real estate and insurance firm with offices at 14 Barstow Road, Great Neck, has been organized as a partnership by Howard L. Friend and Richard W. Taylor. Mr. Taylor had operated his own realty firm since 1935. Mr. Richards formerly was with Naoma Moody Associates, Great Neck brokers.

An indication that not all contemporary designs are following the curved sculptural line is a new collection of furniture designed by Gerald Luss and which has as its basic theme a square boxlike form. The group, available through decorators from the Lehigh Furniture Corporation, 16 East Fifty-third Street, includes side and easy chairs, a series of sofas and a variety of cocktail, end, card and corner tables.

Deere Co., second largest American manufacturer of agricultural machinery, plans to split its common stock two for one subject to approval of stockholders at a special meeting called for July 8, it was revealed yesterday after a directors' meeting in Moline, Ill.

Walter J. Donnelly, United States High Commissioner for Austria, arrived at the New York International Airport, at Idlewild, yesterday from Vienna and left a few minutes later for Washington in an Air Force plane that was waiting for him. He said he was going to Washington to testify before House and Senate committees on the budgetary requirements of his office for the next fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- During the week ended June 4, member bank reserves increased $239,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A surprise move to have the Senate request President Truman to use the Taft-Hartley Law in the steel strike was cut short today when the majority leader advised the chamber that the strike might be settled by Monday. On two close votes the whole issue of the President's emergency powers was put off by the Senate.

Engineers and motormen on the Long Island Rail Road unexpectedly served notice yesterday that they planned to strike because of their dissatisfaction with national agreements made by labor and the nation's railroads on May 23.
BERLIN, June 5 -- The East German Government has demanded that the United States pay a bill of $14,000,000 for the use of the telephone cable from Berlin to West Germany.

Elias Berger, 36-year-old accountant, of 17 East Fulton Street, Long Beach, L. I., accused with two others of operating a fraudulent income-tax scheme in which taxpayers received $900,000 in refunds, was held in $2,500 bail yesterday by United States Commissioner Edward McDonald.

There is a factor in the present steel dispute which is vital to a workable settlement but which seemingly both sides prefer not to mention. That is the fact that the steel industry, like many others, constantly needs new capital for expansion. Where should the new capital come from?

Every, three months a figure is released by the Department of Commerce showing the annual rate of output for the national economy. This figure, technically known as the Gross National Product, has become so familiar in recent years that even the headline reader today recognizes the alphabetical combination "G. N. P." when he sees it.

The West Coast seamen's strike had pronounced effects on the New York sugar futures market yesterday. Uncertain of deliveries of Hawaiian raws to its mainland refineries, the California and Hawaiian Sugar Refining Corporation, Ltd., bought late Wednesday two lots of Philippines sugar totaling 18,000 tons, en route for East Coast sale.

Before the current political campaign is over the television broadcasters are going to know they've really been through something. Squabbles among the candidates over obtaining time on the air already are at the feverish pitch that usually isn't reached until October in an election year. There could be no better evidence of the importance the politicians are attaching to TV.

Western Europe has been making encouraging military and economic progress, but the attainment of real self-reliance depends on whether the United States holds to its professed policies of working to eliminate trade obstacles and restrictions of-currency exchange. This statement was made yesterday by the head of a major American business organization.

Just how General Eisenhower would face the barrage of questioning that was inevitable upon his return has been a matter of constant and interested speculation ever since his candidacy gained momentum. Some of the answers to that speculation were given in yesterday's unusual press conference at Abilene.

Extracting close to maximum results from a modest offensive output, the Yankees yesterday again downed the White Sox, 6 -- 4. The sweep of the three-game series with the Chicagoans, whom they now have beaten seven times in seven tries, gave the Bombers their longest winning streak of the year.

Directors of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad declared yesterday a dividend of $3 a share against 1949 dividends due on the 5 per cent preferred stock, payable June 27. The disbursement is being made out of 1949 earnings, the company states, and will reduce arrears on the preferred to $12 a share as of Dec. 31, 1951.

BONN, Germany, June 5 -- Stories out of Korea concerning incidents at the Koje prison camps have revived contentions in German political circles and in the German press that the United States has been naive about Communist fighting methods, and that if this were not the case the postwar trials of what the Germans persist in describing as the "so-called war criminals" in this country would have had a different outcome.

Phillip Binder walked around the corner from his leather goods shop to his ground-floor five-room apartment at 1884 Belmont Avenue in the Bronx at 6 o'clock on Wednesday night and found only his 24-year-old daughter, Shirley, at home.

PUSAN, Korea, Friday, June 6 (AP) -- Government sources talked today of a compromise between President Syngman Rhee and the Korean National Assembly as possibilities faded that he might dissolve the National Assembly.

Protection of creative works in this fast-moving "television age" may necessitate revision of the present copyright law, according to a group of copyright attorneys reporting in a new publication, "Seven Copyright Problems Analyzed," published by the Commerce Clearinng House, Chicago.

ST. LOUIS, June 5 (UP) -- The Braves blasted nine hits, good for seven runs, in the first inning tonight and Warren Spahn coasted to his fifth straight victory as Boston whipped the Cardinals, 8 -- 3.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 5 -- Although a strike of textile workers has made idle Johnson Johnson, surgical supply manufacturers, emergency orders for the armed forces, hospitals and doctors are being filled under an agreement reached today between the company and Local 630, Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 5 -- Spokesmen for the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia coupled denunciation of the United States in the Economic and Social Council today with repeated bids to Western countries to resume trade with the Soviet Union and the "people's democracies."

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., June 5 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Clarence R. Huebner told fire chiefs of New York State today that "one of the toughest problems you are going to have is to condemn people to die" when fire areas were abandoned in bombed cities.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 5 -- A union boycott of Westchester construction spread today to more jobs and county officials said they were contemplating filing suit for a Supreme Court injunction.
Brief "demonstration" stoppages were staged yesterday by 71,000 employes of the General Electric Company to bolster pay demands being made by the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O.

A prisoner's parole is the same as being confined to prison, the United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday. The ruling was made in reversing a lower court decision that would have recommitted a former executive of a baking company to jail until he paid his fine or took a pauper's oath.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP) -- House investigators were told today that comedians schooled in the "bawdy night life" of New York were bringing America off-color television.
PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- The round-by-round description of the heavyweight title bout tonight between Jersey Joe Walcott and Ezzard Charles follows:

A long-term program to educate consumers on the economic importance of world trade, especially the role of imports, was advocated yesterday at a meeting of the National Council of American Importers at the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP) -- President Truman signed into law today a compromise appropriations bill to enable the Government to start paying hundreds of thousands of Federal workers who got nothing on their regular payday, June 2.

ABILENE, Kan., June 5 -- Senator Frank Carlson, Republican of Kansas, a leader in the Eisenhower-for-President movement, said today that several Republican convention delegates who originally had favored Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio had switched to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as a result of meetings with the general this afternoon.

ROME, June 5 -- Pope Pius, though still suffering from a cold and a slight fever, insisted on leaving his private apartment on the top floor of the Vatican Palace today and resuming part of his heavy daily routine in his official apartment a floor below.

Canada was described yesterday by Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, as a rapidly growing industrial nation preparing to take an ever larger part in the coalition of free men working to stem the agression of the Soviet Union and her "slave state" satellites.

Keith S. McHugh, president of the New York Telephone Company, declared yesterday that the Public Service Commission, in considering any future rate cases, should make allowance for the fact that much of the company's plant equipment was actually worth more than its book value because it was built with pre-inflation dollars.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 5 -- June Week at the United States Naval Academy featured today the presentation of the colors, a picturesque tradition dating from 1871. The farewell balls are being held tonight and the graduation exercises, ending June Week, will be held tomorrow.

Persistence has rewarded the efforts of Alexander Ince and Joel Schenker to obtain the rights to "The Amazing Adele," a five- character Parisian hit that has been entertaining theatregoers there for more than two years.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The Government today authorized a further price boost for copper products, having failed by an earlier ceiling relaxation to break a month-long stoppage of copper imports.
John Lautner entered the United States District Court here yesterday to testify for the tenth day in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders, but he didn't say a word all day long.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 5 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission closed out its spring series of atomic tests on the desert near here today with a tower blast that lighted the pre-dawn sky a bright orange.

The good word from Fishery Council is that fish supplies are excellent. Halibut is liberally stocked. Shipments of fresh-water whitefish are extra heavy. There is more bluefish than in thirty-five years. The price of soft shell crabs is lower than it will be in the summer.

PITTSBURGH, June 5 -- Ben Wade, 29-year-old rookie right-hander, shut out the Pirates on five hits today in one of the longest nine-inning 2-0 games on record. It was just two minutes short of three hours when Ben took Erv Dusak's high bounder and tossed him out to end it.

The campaign of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, Inc., received added impetus yesterday when a tag day rally was opened at the Pulitzer Fountain, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street. One hundred volunteers started the solocitation of funds by collections in coin-cans.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's declaration in Kansas today against a compulsory Federal Fair Employment Practice program stirred in Washington quick Democratic hopes for Democratic gain.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Two New York companies were charged by the National Production Authority today with diverting metals to the black market. The Hillside Metal Products Company of Richmond Hill, Queens, and its affiliate, the Carrier Steel Corporation of 1819 Broadway, were accused by compliance officials of "the most serious violations of N. P. A. regulations yet disclosed."

Presentation of evidence in the disciplinary trial of Herman Methfessel, former Richmond County District Attorney, and Irving Rivkin, his former assistant, was completed yesterday. Referee Peter P. Smith directed prosecution and defense attorneys to submit briefs on June 23.

Presiding Bishop Henry Knox Sherrill of the Protestant Episcopal Church confessed yesterday to having obtained ice cream and cake wrongfully on many an occasion when he was a boy, sins for which he was forgiven as the guest of honor at the 123d annual parade of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union.

Fifty leaders of the bench and bar took part yesterday in a ceremony at the Practising Law Institute, 57 William Street, for the unveiling of a portrait of former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson. Mr. Patterson was president of the post-graduate law institute at his death last Jan. 22 in an airplane crash.

The blockfront property at 189-205 Tompkins Avenue, between Pulaski Street and DeKalb Avenue, Brooklyn, containing six stores and eighteen apartments, has been sold by the M. S. Realty Company to an investor through Joseph Shorwitz and Samuel Goldinger, brokers.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- The new anti-TB drugs, released yesterday by the United States Food and Drug Administration "for use under close medical supervision," have yielded therapeutic results described here tonight as "clearly superior" to those observed with streptomycin, alone or in combination with another widely used drug, named PAS.
NEWARK, N. J., June 5 -- The New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce today urged the Port of New York Authority to "reopen Newark Airport on a limited commercial basis as soon as possible."
TOKYO., Friday, June 6 (AP) -- United Nations Commend communique 1,272, for Thursday's activities:

First National Stores, Inc., which operates a chain of 922 retail food stores and super-markets, increased sales by 9.39 per cent to a new high of $371,853,140 for the year ended on March 29 from the $344,171,022 volume for the preceding fiscal year, when 979 stores were in operation.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- A committee of the House of Representatives said today the recent increases in Canadian newsprint prices undoubtedly would have "serious repercussions" upon both American newspaper publishers and the newspaper reading public.

Why can't a movement be started so that all legal holidays are celebrated on either a Friday or a Monday? Just think of the many benefits which will be enjoyed this year, due to the fact that both Decoration Day and Independence Day happen to occur on a Friday.

There is mounting evidence that the Kremlin's attempt to wreck the new European Defense Community by means of a fresh campaign of terror and intimidation is beginning to boomerang. In France this campaign has apparently ended in a complete fiasco. Some Communist leaders are behind bars, the French workers remained at work, and the Kremlin's Fifth Column has suffered a blow which makes France and all Western Europe breathe easier.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- By a vote of 361 to 1, the House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate today a new G. I. Bill of Rights for veterans of the Korean war and others serving in the armed forces on or after June 27, 1950.

A Broadway retail grocer, whose customers had to buy two grapefruit for 29 cents to get three pounds of potatoes for the same price, was fined $5 yesterday in War Emergency Court on his plea of guilty to violation of regulations of the Office of Price Stabilization.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- Even before he entered the ring against Jersey Joe Walcott tonight it was obvious that Ezzard Charles was carrying an extra burden. Precedent was solidly against him. No man had ever regained the heavyweight championship of the world after being dethroned, although many had tried.

The six-story building containing eight stores and forty-four apartments on plot 100 by 125 feet at 600 West 164th Street, southwest corner of Broadway, has been sold by the Blitzer Realty Company to the Moeb Realty Corporation for investment.

FAME POINT, Que., June 5 (UP) -- The Cunard liner Scythia collided with the collier Wabana near the mouth of the St. Lawrence River today, seriously damaging the collier and jarring the 600 persons on the passenger ship.

Group and one-man shows opening this week keep extending the art season. The work of the Haitian primitive painters, stimulated and sponsored by the Centre d'Art in Port-au-Prince, needs no introduction to American gallery goers.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. "Young Man With Ideas," a Metro- Goldwyn-Mayer romantic comedy- drama, featuring Glenn Ford, Ruth Roman, Denise Darcel and Nina Foch, is at the Globe.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- President Truman today made his first retort to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's initial political speech by saying the people would decide whether the

Charles C. Platt, a distinguished architect, said the other day that wholesale razing of old buildings in order to put up new buildings many stories high is not the best way to handle the problem of our chronic housing shortage.
BRUSSELS, June 5 (AP) -- Two Americans qualified today for the semi-finals of the men's singles in the international tennis championships of Belgium.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- "Fair trade" laws are not fair because they always result in price increases, a spokesman for R. H. Macy Co. of New York said today.

JERUSALEM, June 5 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion declared today, on the occasion of ground-breaking ceremonies for a $10,000,000 Hadassah-Hebrew Univarsity medical center seven miles outside of Jerusalem at Eiri Karem, that the medical center would form the nucleus of a great and expanding "city of science and wisdom in Jerusalem."

Capt. Franklin B. Weaver, suspended skipper of the Isbrandtsen freighter Flying Trader, heard two of his former crewmen describe in Federal Court yesterday how he had blackjacked, handcuffed and, after a short interval, shot dead William M. Harvey, 24-year-old messman, at sea last Oct. 25.

LONDON, June 5 -- The stock markets here developed a firmer trend today, although business generally was again on a small scale. Figures of Britain's May deficit with the European Payments Union had no significant effect on British funds, which made many gains of up to five shillings (70 cents).
Moderately priced fashions and advice on preparing for baby were a feature of the maternity show at Abraham Straus yesterday afternoon.

CINCINNATI, June 5 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft said tonight that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was campaigning on "generalities" and declared that his own chances of winning the Republican Presidential nomination "have improved" since the general came home.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Army ruled today that Maj. Gen. Robert W. Grow must face a general court-martial for his alleged negligence in permitting a diary kept when he was a United States military attache in Moscow to fall into Communist hands.

The perjury conviction of Louis Weber, Brooklyn policy figure, was upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals. Weber was sentenced to five years and a $2,000 fine on his conviction of lying before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee by saying that he did not know James J. Moran, former city official.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft demanded today that the Government order the three major radio and television networks to give him as much free time as they had granted General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower Wednesday night.

Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, yesterday called the proposed Student Memorial Building a great aid in the effort of the college to "personalize mass education." Overcrowding and lack of facilities in the past, he said, prevented the expansion of many worth-while and necessary student activities.

Dr. Raymond B. Allen, chancellor-elect of the University of California at Los Angeles, declared last night that the challenge to all who served mankind was the application of skills to relieve individual suffering and cooperation with those trying to create a better world.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., June 5 -- The Rev. Dr. Henry A. Poppen, for thirty-three years a missionary in China, was elected president of the Reformed Church in America today at the 146th annual meeting here of the group's General Synod.

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., June 5 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, the apparent winner of South Dakota's bitterly fought primary over General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, clung to a 639-vote margin today with the unofficial tabulation complete except for seven small, isolated rural precincts.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- "He's a good fighter, but I guess I got his number," was Jersey Joe Walcott's appraisal of Ezzard Charles after their fight tonight. The underdog who successfully defended his crown thought that he had a clean edge and was surprised that there was a wide disagreement on the verdict among the fans.
CINCINNATI, June 5 (UP) -- Harry Perkowski pitched a six-hitter today for his fifth victory of the season as the Reds defeated the Phillies, 5 -- 3, and swept the three-game series.
Few Americans would buy a car or a household appliance without knowing how it worked and what it cost. Yet that is how we, as a nation, have been buying our foreign commitments.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended May 31, rose 1 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BOONTON, N. J., June 5 -- A starting field of 154 in the qualifying round of the New Jersey State amateur championship found par at the Knoll Golf Club course unbeatable today. Over a finely conditioned course still heavy from the rains, the co-medalists, Stanley Calder of Montclair and Joe Russo of Valley View, were one over regulation figures with rounds of 71.

WIESBADEN, Germany, June 5 (AP) -- The United States Air Force announced today it had placed a "multi-million dollar" order for F-84 jet fighter-plane spare parts with the Finmeccanica Corporation of Italy.

LONDON, June 5 -- The Times of London, Britain's oldest and probably most influential newspaper, announced tonight an impending change in its editorship. Sir William John Haley, the director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation, is to succeed William Francis Casey, who after thirty-nine years in the service of The Times and four years as its editor has decided to resign.

Public hearings before the Board of Estimate on the Controversial 3 per cent retail sales tax and all other tax and fee bills passed in the last two weeks by the City Council were shifted yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri from Thursday, the date of the next calendar board meeting, to next Tuesday at 11:30 A. M.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- President Truman transmitted to the Air Coordinating Committee today a report of his Airport Commission with a suggestion that an immediate study be made with a view to putting the commission's recommendations into effect.

Enthusiasm for including Japan among the free nations of the world was shown yesterday by six Manhattan high school students, who discussed "Japan and the Community of Nations" on a New York Times Youth Forum.

PARIS, June 6 -- Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, was elected chairman of the European Marshall Plan Council today. He accepted and, through Richard A. Butler, the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the Council he would devote as much time as possible to the post but at some meetings would be replaced by Mr. Butler.

In every case where one member of a pair of identical twins suffered from manic-depressive psychosis, the other twin also showed a tendency toward the same mental illness, Dr. Franz Kallmann of Columbia University reported yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 6 -- Robert Taylor, after a flying trip to Durango, Colo., next week, will return to Hollywood and begin studying the script of 'Vaquero," in which he will be starred by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as an early Texas cattle baron.

Two men were arraigned before United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday on a charge of conspiring to export gold bullion without a license. They waived examination and were held in $7,500 bali each for grand jury action.
Potato deliveries to the New York wholesale market rose 12 per cent yesterday as a result of the lifting of all price controls over the scarce tuber.

James Reston's recent suggestion in THE NEW YORK TIMES for the establishment of a "Commission for Continuity of Foreign Policy" is more than pertinent in a time when phrases such as "cold war" have taken their place in the every-day vocabulary of the ordinary American citizen.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, June 6 -- The notorious compound of hardcore Communist prisoners of war who seized Col. Francis T. Dodd, former brigadier general, formerly in command of this island prison, has received top priority in forthcoming plans to break up the fanatic red cells that are still intact here.
The need for preventing vandalism in the city's parks and for using restoration funds for additional improvements was emphasized yesterday by officials of the Park Association of New York City, Inc.

Herbert F. Roemmele, Professor of Mechanical Engineering and Dean of Students at Cooper Union's School of Engineering, was installed last night as president of the New York City Chapter of the New York State Society of Professional Engineers.
LONDON, June 6 (Reuters) -- Bowlers held sway in the first English-Indian test match at Leeds today, tumbling ten wickets for 210 runs.

TORONTO, June 6 -- Canada's Fifth International Trade Fair boasts much to gladden the heart of the homemaker. There are exciting new lines, mostly from western Europe, in home furnishings, leather goods, arts and crafts and toys.

Pressure from the London market sent Cocoa Exchange prices 19 to 28 points lower yesterday on a volume of 136 lots. Traders here saw market action abroad as the work of speculative shorts, helped by the unloading of tired longs.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Secretary of Defense Robert A. Lovett today renewed his attack on the world-wide Communist propaganda charging the United Nations with using gas and germ warfare in Korean and branded the accusations as "absolute, complete black lies."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 6 -- The importance of the distilling industry to the nation's social and economic stability was emphasized here today by Ellis P. Slater, president of Frankfort Distillers Corporation. He spoke at the close of a two-day meeting of the company's state stores division.

Four present or former directors of the United States Finishing Company were named defendants yesterday in a stockholders' suit seeking to recover damages to the company and any profits realized by the defendants from alleged use of "inside" information. The suit was filed in United States District Court in New Haven, Conn.

Congratulations on your brilliant editorial of May 22 on the McCarran Anti-Immigration Bill. Mention of a few of the desirable features of the rejected Lehman, Humphrey-Roosevelt Immigration Bill, not present in the McCarran bill, serves to illustrate objections to the most important legislation before the present Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Brig. Gen. William P. Campbell may not be eligible for the Purple Heart for the "telephone ear" he sported today, but he has the gratitude of 296 G. I.'s.

Two men who once aspired to be Yankees were mainly responsible for beating them yesterday at the Stadium. Clint Courtney, the bespectacled backstop, who was with the New Yorkers only briefly, and Jim Dyck, formerly one of their farmhand infielders, did the damage as the Browns embarrassed the Bombers, 9 -- 3.

ARDMORE, Okla., June 6 (AP) -- A close struggle developed today in the $15,000 Ardmore open golf tournament as four players tied for the lead after the second round over the Dornick Hills Country Club course.

Judge Jerome N. Frank of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals delivered an address this week before the Citizens Committee on Children that deserves to be read, line by line, by the Mayor and the Board of Estimate of this city.

MIAMI, Fla., June 6 (UP) -- Reports reached here today of the dramatic rescue of an 18-month-old boy and sixteen other persons aboard a freight boat which capsized with the loss of six lives in the shark-infested waters of the British Bahamas.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 6 -- The inability of most persons with chronic diseases to pay for medical and related services was characterized today by Dr. Martin Cherkasky, medical director of Montefiore Hospital in New York, as one of the most important problems to be solved in providing adequate health care.

Because workers aboard Department of Marine and Aviation ferryboats are city employes, they, too, are entitled to more consideration than they are receiving in the matter of wage increases and cost of living allowances, Luigi Calafato asserted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) -- The President took a "raincheck" today on the visit he had planned next week-end at the Rhode Island farm of J. Howard McGrath, whom he ousted recently as Attorney General.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Steel industry negotiators, apparently doing some hard bargaining, met for four hours without pause today and agreed to resume at 11 A. M. tomorrow at the White House.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Administration forces stepped up their drive today to kill the Ferguson amendment to the Defense Production Act.
READING, Pa., June 6 (UP) -- Patty Berg of Minneapolis took the first-round lead in the women's Eastern open golf today with a 3-over-par 75 on the Berkshire Country Club course.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 6 -- The United States, Britain, Sweden and others persuaded a United Nations committee today to circulate a code of ethics for journalists to professional writers' organizations but not to call a global conference to again revise the text.
CHICAGO, June 6 (AP) -- An attorney said today creditors of the defunct Tucker Automobile Corporation may be able to recover a sizable portion of their money.

Eight years ago yesterday the Allied armies landed on the coasts of Normandy. The reminder comes as something, of a shock, for so much has happened since the first great blow was struck to liberate Fortress Europe that the heroic expedition seems like a battle as long ago in time as it is far away in mood.

SINGAPORE, Saturday, June 7 (Reuters) -- The New China (Communist) News Agency charged today that French military planes based in Indo-China had bombed, strafed and reconnoitered inside China from December, 1950, until April of this year.

The question of what American Communists were taught to do in case of a war with the Soviet Union was left hanging in a mid-sentence yesterday at the trial of sixteen Communist party leaders in the United States District Court on Foley Square.
