WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Senate passed with a voice vote this evening a $1,300,000,000 appropriation bill for the Department of Agriculture for the 1953 fiscal year beginning July 1. Previously it had rejected, 35 to 23, a proposal by a former Secretary of Agriculture, Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, that next year's payments to farmers in soil conservation programs be reduced by $100,000,000.

The Korean armistice negotiations have now been deadlocked for a month over the last remaining issue -- the exchange of prisoners -- with no end in sight. The United Nations Command has submitted its final terms providing for repatriation of some 70,000 Communist prisoners in return for approximately 12,000 United Nations personnel, but precluding the surrender of nearly 100,000 anti-Communist Chinese and Koreans to Communist firing squads and slave labor camps.
TOKYO, Saturday, June 7 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,273, for Friday:

Former Acting Lieut. James J. Brennan of the Police Department, father of four children, will realize a long-cherished ambition next Wednesday. He will receive his Doctor of Philosophy degree in sociology at the commencement of New York University.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 6 -- Robert W. Johnson, chairman of the board of Johnson Johnson, surgical dressing manufacturers, said today that competition dictated that the company must stand firm in its refusal to grant wage increases to 1,400 striking textitle workers.
PARIS, June 6 (AP) -- King Talal I of Jordan, a chronic patient of mental specialists, left Paris for Switzerland tonight.

More than 1,000 mechanics and cargo handlers of American Airlines remained on strike yesterday at La Guardia Airport and New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, disobeying orders of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., to return to work and ignoring the threat of a civil suit of $250,000 by the airline.

Textiles or fertilizers, that is the question of the hour among the large chemical producers who manufacture the new wonder fibers with acrylonitrile as a base. They can make either or both, but some are faced with the problem of which will prove the most profitable.

BONN, Germany, June 6 -- New and possibly critical difficulties have arisen in connection with the Schuman plan for pooling Western Europe's coal and steel resources. They have come just when Allied and German leaders here were saying that there was little left to do but get on with the plan.

WITH the fishing season moving toward a peak on both fresh and salt water, several million anglers will be glancing toward new horizons, for no group is more succeptible to the "greener grass" theory than the one comprising hunters and fishermen.

The National American Wholesale Lumber Association has asked Congress to end price and wage controls in three weeks. Sid L. Darling, secretary and managing director, said yesterday. The organization represents more than 500 lumber wholesalers in forty states.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., June 6 -- President Truman arrived here today for a reunion with his World War I buddies in the course of which he is expected to make a major address tomorrow dealing with national security and the world crisis.
Joseph T. McNally has been appointed manager of sales of the Republic Tank Car Company, effective June 16.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 6 -- The Coast Guard Memorial Chapel, which overlooks the Thames River from the highest ground in New London, was dedicated today as the Coast Guard Academy held its commencement exercises for a class of seventy-seven.
BERLIN, June 6 (UP) -- The mayors of four Soviet zone border communities led a flight of twenty families to safety in Western Germany through gunfire from Communist border guards today.

ROME, June 6 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York participated today in the dedication of a photostatic copy of the Princeton University Index of Christian Art which he himself donated to the Vatican Library. The Cardinal had made $50,000 available for the copy.

MANCHESTER, England, June 6 (UP) -- Maureen Connolly, 17-year-old United States champion, gained the women's singles final of the Northern lawn tennis tournament today but a former Wimbledon champion, Louise Brough, was upset in the other semi-final.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) -- The Western Union Telegraph Company asked the Government today for permission to raise telegram rates 9.3 per cent July 6 so that it could start paying its employes wage increases under an agreement that last month ended a fifty-three-day strike.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- An invention for the relief of television actors brought Patent 2,598,947 this week to Mary M. Thielen of Scarsdale, N. Y. It is a mechanical prompter that displays the actors' lines, stage directions and a hint as to timing.

Albert and Arthur Lewis, producers of "Three Wishes for Jamie," starring Anne Jeffreys and John Raitt and featuring Bert Wheeler, have decided to terminate the musical's Broadway engagement after tonight's performance, the ninety-fourth, at the Plymouth Theatre.
Federal Mediator Ross Barr reported yesterday that "a little progress" had been made in his efforts to prevent a strike by 309 engineers and motormen of the Long Island Rail Road.

Tenants in the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's Stuyvesant Town development won the right in State Supreme Court yesterday to inspect figures and other data on which the company is seeking rent increases amounting to $7.87 a room a month.
Results of the Philco Corporation this year are expected at least to reach the 1951 level, William Balderston, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Philadelphia.

A Federal agency, the New York police, an airline express and a fruiterer coordinated their efforts yesterday to speed a package of grapes from midtown Manhattan to a 6-year-old girl, ill with leukemia near Charlotte, N. C.

Saxon Avenue, which was Saxon Avenue for nineteen of its twenty-one years, is Saxon Avenue again. Norman Avenue, which was Norman Avenue for thirty years, is now Hillman Avenue, which was Saxon Avenue for two years.

A program for more efficient procedures of settling foreign trade disputes between United States and French business men has been brought close to completion, it was announced yesterday by the American Arbitration Association.

The Mutual Security authorization, as fixed by Congressional conference, now stands at about $6.5 billions, or a little less than $1.5 billions under what President Truman asked. There was nothing sacred about the President's request, but neither is there anything scientific about the cuts that have been made.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Prof. Mortimer J. Adler has resigned his chair of the Philosophy of Law at the University of Chicago, effective June 30, to go to San Francisco to direct the founding of an institute for philosophical research. He will remain a member of the board of the Great Books Foundation, which he largely helped to found.

DARIEN, Conn., June 6 -- Parcancady Heatherbelle, a 3-year-old English-bred dog owned by the Pennyworth Kennels of Hampton Bays, L. I., became best of breed today in the annual specialty of the Greyhound Club of America at Foxden.

Today's new film is "The Fall of Berlin," a Soviet-made drama in color dealing with World War II and the capitulation of the German capital, at the Stanley. Mikhail Chiaurell directed the import, which was produced by the Mosfilm Studios in Moscow. Dialogue of the Artkino Pictures release is Russian and there are English titles.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- A fairly substantial recovery in wheat led by the July and September deliveries continued relative easiness in corn and oats, and a sharp upturn in rye featured the grain markets today. Soybeans had an irregular price trend but did not overshadow the other grains as they did for a couple of days this week.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 6 -- Plans for the establishment of a standard-size afternoon daily newspaper in Levittown, Pa., site of a large housing development, were announced here today.

The elimination of the 15-cent combination ride on city subways and municipal or private surface lines on July 1 will be "for the benefit of the city's financial position," Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday.

Top-seeded Jack Tuero of New York advanced to the semi-final round of the twelfth annual Inter-American men's singles tennis tournament by defeating Franklin Pierce of Brooklyn, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, on the courts of the Hispano Tennis Club, Whitestone, Queens, yesterday.

A retired city detective engaged two hold-up men in a pistol duel yesterday afternoon and drove the thugs empty-handed from a West Side beer-distributing plant. The plant manager was wounded superficially by one of the eight bullets fired in the exchange.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 6 -- British hopes were lifted for their first Curtis Cup victory today as the United States was beaten in two of three thirty-six-hole foursomes matches on the opening day of the seventh of these biennial international women's team golf matches.

Seven national outdoor champions, all the other top stars of the local clubs and many of the varsity Olympic hopefuls from this area will compete today at Travers Island in the annual spring track and field games of the New York Athletic Club.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 6 -- Strong protests were raised here today at an international forum of publishers against the action of certain governments in censoring press dispatches ostensibly under a clause in the International Telecommunications Union Convention. A resolution was unanimously adopted urging that the clause be aligned with the principle of freedom of information.

PARIS, June 6 (AP) -- Paced by Bobby Knowles of Boston and Aiken, S. C., ten of the nineteen Americans entered in the French amateur golf championship remained in the running after the first two rounds of play today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 6 -- A threat to close West Coast ports to East Coast, Gulf and foreign ships next week for the duration of the strike of the Sailors Union of the Pacific was made today by Capt. Charles F. May, president of the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots.

A youngster who tilts or thrusts his head forward when looking at near or distant objects is signaling his need for an eye examination just as surely as the child who rubs his eyes frequently, frowns or tries to "brush away a blur," according to a pamphlet just published by the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness.
DETROIT, June 6 (AP) -- The nation's car manufacturers turned out a "normal" five-day volume of 94,794 cars and 25,065 trucks this week, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

Aggressive, well-trained salesmen now have more chance for success than ever in the history of this country, according to Charles A. Ward, president and sales manager of Brown Bigelow, advertising specialties concern, St. Paul, Minn. He spoke at a dinner last night attended by the salesmen and executives of the company's eastern division in the Biltmore Hotel.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- The Bethlehem Steel Company's 626-foot ore-carrier Johnstown, the first to be built expressly for Great Lakes service, taxed the capacity of the Illinois Waterway today on the final leg of her trip from the Baltimore shipyards that built her.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission endorsed a plan of the trustee of the International Hydro-electric System today to sell a group of New York properties of the system for approximately $25,000,000.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 6 -- Dr. F. E. Shinnar, co-chairman of the Israeli delegation to the conference on German reparations at The Hague, said today he expected to receive next week from the Germans a "binding commitment" as to the amount, the time in which and the method by which West Germany will pay.

In an effort to prevent infantile paralysis, 1,400,000 leaflets for parents, in which simple precautions against polio are listed, are being distributed to students in public, private and parochial schools in the city, it was announced yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 6 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio discussed for the first time today the possibility of a compromise with supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to avoid a bitter floor fight at the Republican National Convention over approximately seventy-five contested delegates from Texas, Louisiana, Georgia and Mississippi.

BOSTON, June 6 (UP) -- Two Red Sox cast-offs made baseball's "big trade" look bad for Lou Boudreau tonight as last-place Detroit beat Boston, 4 -- 2, in the opener of a five-game series before 30,808 fans at Fenway Park.

Two stories about stock market margin requirements came out of Washington yesterday. A reporting service quoted "a high Government official" to the effect that the Federal Reserve Board would ease its controls "shortly after it loosens its restraints on real estate credit" and as saying that there was even a possibility that the change in margins -- now set at 75 per cent -- might come first.

The 100 largest manufacturing companies in the United States at the end of 1951 had total assets of $60,128,000,000. With the average employment of these companies listed as 42,000, the total assets represented an average investment of $14,000 for each employe.
ST. LOUIS, June 6 (AP) -- The Cardinals took advantage of poor defensive play tonight to hand the Phillies their fifth straight defeat, 5 to 4.

Carl (Bobo) Olson of Honolulu pounded out a one-sided victory over Jimmy Beau of New Canaan, Conn., in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. All three officials voted in favor of the Hawaiian, who was making his first appearance in a Garden bout.

A 23-year-old Estonian was held in $500 bail yesterday by United States Commissioner Edward McDonald for violation of the McCarran Act, designed to control movements of aliens in this country. United States Attorney Myles J. Lane said it was the first such violation charged here.

Albert D. Lasker, advertising executive and former chairman of the United States Shipping Board, who died May 30, left his estate in equal shares to his widow, Mrs. Mary Woodard Lasker, and the foundation that they established for the promotion of health through medical research.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Chief Judge Bolitha J. Laws of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia today approved the sale of The Cincinnati Enquirer for $7,600,000 cash to the Portsmouth Steel Company. By collateral agreement, the company will sell the paper to a group of the newspaper's employes.

PARIS, June 6 -- The French Government is preparing to declare unilaterally a series of home rule reforms in its protectorate of Tunisia after the failure of a proposal to convoke a French Tunisian mixed commission to negotiate them.

Chief Justice Irving Ben Cooper of the Court of Special Sessions appealed yesterday for the "tools" to help his court recognize the first offender with "moral potential," to guide the offender's treatment in the community, and to return him to it sufficiently strengthened to meet its challenges.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., June 6 -- Dr. Huffman was born on a farm at Zanesville, Ohio. After graduating from public schools, he taught for several years. He later went to Valparaiso University in Indiana and then to Ohio Wesleyan University, receiving a Bachelor of Divinity degree there.
BERLIN, June 6 -- The "war of pinpricks" here continued almost unabated today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 6 -- Military attaches of the Western governments are attending a corps headquarters exercise of the Yugoslav Army, which has been organized presumably to disprove a view held in some quarters that Yugoslav officers are too young and inexperienced to command large units in modern warfare.

FALMOUTH, England, June 6 -- The Admiralty staged an underwater television display in the deepsea diving vessel Reclaim, six miles off the Cornish coast, today, almost exactly a year after the prototype apparatus was first used to locate the doomed submarine Affray.

The South defeated the North, 15 -- 7, for the first time in three years last night, as lacrosse made its big-time debut in New York with the presentation of the eleventh intercollegiate All-Star game at the Polo Grounds as a benefit for the Damon Runyon Cancer Fund.

ST. LOUIS, June 6 -- The Mississippi River Fuel Corporation, which supplies natural gas to the St. Louis area, filed a petition on Wednesday with the Missouri Public Service Commission asking permission to buy a controlling interest in Laclede Gas Company, which distributes gas to St. Louis consumers.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, fresh from his plunge into the rapids of partisan politics, returned to New York last night ready to give a helping hand to those who are trying to win the Republican Presidential nomination for him.

EASTON, Pa., June 6 -- Henry R. Luce declared here today that the Supreme Court decision voiding President Truman's steel industry seizure was "the sign that, despite all our superficiality and vulgarity, the American people still retain the golden key to political wisdom."

TOKYO, Saturday, June 7 -- The United Nations armistice delegation at Panmunjom yesterday threw back at the Communists the charges that the Allied command had violated the Geneva Convention in its treatment of the rebellious prisoners of war interned in South Korean stockades.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 6 -- Admiral William M. Fechteler, Chief of Naval Operations, told 769 midshipmen about to receive commissions at the United States Naval Academy's graduation ceremonies today that they were entering active service at a crucial time in the nation's history.

PITTSBURGH, June 6 -- The Giants arrived early today supremely confident their current trials and tribulations were about to end. But at a late hour tonight they inadvertently plunged once again down an open manhole.
PARIS, June 6 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization today named Admiral Sir John Edelsten of Britain to command the English Channel area.

The hunger-inducing effects of the new anti-tuberculosis drugs will cost the city an estimated $200 a month in extra food for forty relief clients. Henry L. McCarthy, Commissioner of Welfare, told the Young Men's Board of Trade at a luncheon yesterday at Miller's Restaurant, 144 Fultor Street.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Preliminary results of tests with a new chemical described as the "most potent non-narcotic found so far for the relief of pain in various types of arthritis" were reported here today at the annual meeting of the American Rheumatism Association.

BONN, Germany, June 6 -- The German public discovered today that Senator Robert A. Taft took a very pro-German view of some Allied actions of the war and post-war years that remained a source of German grievances. The Senator is not of course running for anything in Germany.

Operations of Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., in 1951 resulted in a net income of 27,215,815, according to the report released yesterday. This compares with 21,767,865 in the year ended Dec. 31, 1950. The official exchange rate for the pound sterling is $2.80.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 6 (AP) -- The Office of Price Stabilization today sued Stenson Brothers, Inc., one of the nation's largest twine wholesalers, for $205,590 in damages for alleged over-ceiling sales.

The general editor of Crown's international cookbook series (the American editions of Escoffier, Ada Boni's "Talisman" and others) remarked the other day that she was "sick to death of Chinese cookbooks that say you can buy all the ingredients listed in them at the corner grocery."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 6 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie said today he had asked the United Nations Commission for the Unification and Rehabilitation of Korea to express to President Syngman Rhee his "deep anxiety" over the conflict between Dr. Rhee and the Korean Assembly.

PARIS, June 6 -- United States offshore contracts for production of slightly more than $50,000,000 worth of naval vessels and equipment have been let in France in the last few days. These contracts formed part of a program drawn up before the Lisbon meeting of the North Atlantic Council.

BOONTON, N. J., June 6 -- Stanley Calder, the former Army officer who was co-medalist yesterday and state titleholder in 1945, was among the victors in the double-round match play schedule of the New Jersey State amateur golf championship today.
" I don't suppose." said Edward Arcaro, "that there's a jockey in this room who wouldn't want to ride Blue Man --if he had his choice."

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The principal Congressional Republican leader in foreign affairs, Senator Alexander Wiley of Wisconsin, admonished his party today not to seek to rise to power in the coming Presidential election by assailing this country's European policy.

The Turf and Field Club at Belmont Park was the setting last night for the annual Belmont Ball, given this year to benefit the Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind. Several hundred members of society from New York, Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey gave dinner parties at the club before the ball.
PHILADELPHIA, June 6 -- "You can't sneak up on a title. You must go out there and win it by fighting like a champion."

A new collection of cartoons by the late Helen E. Hokinson, entitled "There Are Ladies Present," will be issued in September by Dutton. Like her earlier three volumes, the forthcoming book provides a commentary on the women of America.
REGINA, June 6 (Canadian Press) -- Socony-Vacuum Exploration Company today was reported to have made an oil discovery in the Gull Lake area of southwestern Saskatchewan.

A school custodian, in whose honor an elementary school in Pueblo, Colo., was named recently, received another honor yesterday at Columbia University. George Willis Spann, a quiet, modest man of 68, received a $300 check and a letter of commendation from Teachers College for "long and efficient service to children, teachers and his community."

The third consecutive advance was registered yesterday by the stock market despite profit taking. Emphasis remained in good measure on the railroads with the petroleums issues back in favor at substantially higher prices.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 6 -- Criticism of the teaching of English at high school levels was voiced today by Edward Weeks Jr., editor of The Atlantic Monthly, in the commencement address at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

SCARBOROUGH, N. Y., June 6 -- Wall Street's bondmen took over the twin golf courses and other recreation facilities of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club here today on the occasion of the twenty-eighth annual field day of the Bond Club of New York.

CINCINNATI, June 6 -- The Dodgers ran their winning streak to four games as they defeated the Reds, 6 -- 4, tonight before 14,476 fans at Crosley Field. The triumph extended the Brooks first-place lead over the Giants to four games.

STE.-MERE-EGLISE, June 6 (AP) -- Near the end of the anniversary ceremonies, General Ridgway visited today the farm of Octave Duboscq, about a mile west of town, where he had made his parachute landing.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 6 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie said today that the United Nations did not have a policy to discharge all United States Communists on its staff but he insisted on the right to get rid of any employe in the "best interests" of the world organization.

In Italy this is the season of festas -- and feuds. Siena will have its famous horse race in medieval trappings through the Palazzo Pubblico. But north of Tuscany the Italian cities of Verona and Vicenza will be carrying on their long-time war over, of all things, the bed of Juliet.

SEOUL, Saturday, June 7 (AP) -- United States Sabre jets turned an attempted Communist air ambush into a death trap yesterday, knocking seven enemy jets from the skies and damaging two more, the Fifth Air Force reported.

PARIS, June 6 -- The American Hospital of Paris, which has ministered to the ills of nearly two generations of United States tourists and expatriates, opened today a drive to collect $350,000 from this year's bumper crop of tourists.

Bowditch is as much the title of a book as it is the name of a man. For 150 years this June, Bowditch has been used as the basic tool for teaching navigation in the United States Navy and cognate schools where navigation is taught. The official title of the book is "The New American Practical Navigator," but if you say Bowditch that's all you need.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The House Public Works Waterways subcommittee approved today a resolution calling on Army engineers to study the traffic on the Gulf Intracoastal Canal and recommend corrective measures for bottlenecks.

LONDON, June 6 -- The stock markets were marked by a brighter mood at the start today with prices in most sections rising. However, business failed to expand and in the afternoon prices generally slipped back. The close was irregular.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 6 -- With police heavily reinforced from Southern Rhodesia and Basutoland in complete control of Serowe, Palapye and Mahalapye, the fight now seems to have been knocked out of the Bamangwato tribe in British Bechuanaland Protectorate.

A water-color of a girl who had let a ball get past her while playing baseball won the first prize yesterday in the junior division of the Police Athletic League Washington Square outdoor art show, held in Greenwich Village.

LEXINGTON, Va., June 6 -- Washington and Lee University conferred honorary degrees today upon Turner Catledge, managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and Kennon C. Whittle, Justice of the Virginia Supreme Court, at the 203d annual commencement.

PUSAN, Korea, Saturday, June 7 (AP) -- The Korean Government said today that United Nations Secretary General Trygve Lie had "arbitrarily" evaluated the South Korean political crisis "on the basis of second-hand reports and premature conclusions."

BONN, Germany, June 6 -- The European Defense Community treaty, which provides for the rearmament of Germany, was approved by the Cabinet and sent today to the Bundesrat, or upper house, with the warning that a neutral Germany would fall before the imperialistic ambitions of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, asserted today that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, revealing his "true colors" at Abilene, Kan., yesterday, had "definitely associated himself with the dinosaur wing of the Republican party."

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 6 -- An Israeli-Jordan border dispute that began Wednesday and resulted in the death of an Israeli soldier and the wounding of ten Jordanian Arabs was settled today by the Mixed Armistice Commission in Israel's favor, officials said.

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., June 6 -- A change of 175 votes in the unofficial tabulation of South Dakota's closely contested primary increased the lead of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio over General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today and indicated what might happen in tomorrow's official canvass of Tuesday's balloting.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 6 -- A no-defense plea was entered in Superior Court here today by William C. Horley of Perth Amboy, former vice president of the First Bank and Trust Company of Perth Amboy, who is accused of embezzling $456,689 of the bank's funds.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) -- Eddie Stewart, a former Senator, smashed a double off the right- field wall to drive in three runs in the eighth inning tonight as the White Sox defeated Washington, 4 to 3, to snap a five-game losing streak.

TORONTO, June 6 -- Motion-picture producers are giving sexy slants to pictures on Biblical themes, a report presented to the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in Canada by its board of evangelism and social action charged today.

Price maintenance provisions in underwriting agreements have a restrictive effect on the market, Judge Harold R. Medina said yesterday at the anti-trust trial of seventeen investment banking firms in Federal Court House at Foley Square.

A few days ago, in Dubuque, Iowa, Secretary of Labor Tobin delivered the commencement address at Loras College. Opening that address, he told his listeners: "In the young people * * * lies the hope for the future of America. They must face the perils that an older generation has been wrestling with so desperately.

It is a naughty word, politically, to say that you are "raising" the carfare. So the Board of Transportation, with the approval of Mayor Impellitteri, is "fixing" and "adjusting" the fare as of July 1 by eliminating the 15-cent combined ride on subways and surface lines, by which a transfer saved the passenger a nickel.

The four-story building containing forty-two offices and nine stores on plot 150 by 100 feet at 251 West Fortieth Street, near Eighth Avenue, has been sold by the Hartley Holding Corporation to the Realty Surplus Corporation for investment in a deal negotiated by Walter Scott Co. and Maurice Greenstein, brokers.

The matter of increased automobile insurance rates has been given considerable space. To one who has owned and driven an automobile for half a century this news is timely, especially in view of the fact that the writer, in his professional hospital capacity, is in daily touch with the problem of automobile injuries.

BRUNSWICK, Me., June 6 -- Bowdoin College observed Alumni Day today by dedicating its new $700,000 chemistry building. It was named in memory of Parker Cleaveland, for more than forty years a teacher of mathematics and natural philosophy.

The Africa Committee of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. will be sponsor of a special conference that the council has called for June 16-25 at Wittenberg College, Springfield, Ohio, to discuss the relationship of Christianity to current changes in racial, political and social conditions in Africa, south of the Sahara.

W. Averell Harriman, New York's candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, declared yesterday that Congress was playing the game of the Kremlin in cutting the appropriation for military and economic aid to Western Europe.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 6 -- Pfc. Thad McArthur of Seattle, moved into the lead for the United States modern pentathlon championship today by winning the 4,000-meter cross-country run.

STE. - MERE - EGLISE, France, June 6 -- A half-mile from where he parachuted into France at the head of his troops eight years ago, Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, warned the Communist powers today that they courted "destruction" if they misconstrued Western policy as "weakness."

The delightful character of antique miniatures has made as devoted a class of collector as can be found in any of the numerous collectible specialties. It has been a long time since early tiny objects, particularly in gold and silver, have fulfilled the original purpose of their being -- to be used as toys for children or as furnishings for doll houses.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong again yesterday, with the most strength in the new crop months.

Rejoinder to the letter of Jean M. Walser published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 26 seems appropriate. Therein fault was found with an editorial in THE TIMES in its criticism of the Soviet stand against Japan's entry into the United Nations. The letter asserted that "the fundamental concept" of the U. N. is the universality of its membership and that such universality "is essential to its effectiveness."

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Frank H. Weitzel, assistant to the United States Controller General, told a House Judiciary subcommittee today that through "fraud, overpayments or overliberality" the taxpayers had lost at least a half a billion dollars in the settlement of war contracts.

A century ago this year a Bengali computer burst into the office of Sir Andrew Waugh, Surveyor General of India, with news that he had just "discovered the highest mountain in the world." He had done this by calculating triangulations under a program started by Sir Andrew's predecessor, Sir George Everest.

TROY, N. Y., June 6 -- Addressing a class of 760 today at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's 146th commencement, Dr. Livingston W. Houston, president, saw dangers as well as advantages in the "ease with which young college graduates are getting jobs."

EASTHAMPTON, Mass., June 6 -- The appointment of N. Horton Batchelder Jr. as headmaster of the Williston Junior School has been announced by Phillips Stevens, headmaster of Williston Academy, preparatory school for boys.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 6 -- United Nations fighters against one of the world's great killers -- malaria -- are scoring some preliminary victories in the major battleground of Southeast Asia.

Ellis O. Briggs, United States Ambassador to Czechoslovakia said on his arrival here yesterday that the imprisonment of William N. Oatis, Associated Press correspondent, was the most crucial point in present Czechoslovak relations.

" NOT A BILLBOARD or hot-dog stand in sight" is the boast of Pennsylvania's 120-mile-long Horse-Shoe Trail, which offers an opportunity to take a vacation on foot, on horseback or by bicycle through some especially fine scenic country.

BONN, Germany, June 7 -- Soon after the signing of the Bonn convention last month a French diplomat remarked gloomily that the fight had only begun; ratification of the convention and the European Defense Community Treaty would be much more difficult to achieve than the relatively simple job of signing a treaty.
IN summer probably more American visitors come to eastern Canada for the fishing than for any other single pastime.

The Mayor's Committee on Unity, established by Fiorello H. La Guardia in 1944, reported to Mayor Impellitteri yesterday that, while racial prejudice persisted in New York, it now involved social opprobrium itself and usually caused those who discriminated to do so through subterfuge.

HONG KONG, Sunday, June 8 (AP) -- Roman Catholic Bishop Adolphe Paschang, 66, of Martinsburg, Mo., crossed the Communist China border into Portuguese Macao on Friday night, according to reports reaching here. He will reach Hong Kong some time this week, it was said.
From Washington yesterday came a suggestion of one way to "join the Army and see the world" without actually enlisting.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The chief Republican spokesman on agricultural policy, Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont, accused the Truman Administration today of deliberately forcing a collapse of farm prices "for a mess of political pottage" in the 1948 Presidential election.

THOUSANDS of new books have already been published in 1952. Each of them is the survivor of a competition for place in print which saw ninety-nine others left unpublished, and a good thing, too. Not all the new books make pretensions to literary status, and some are only hopeful attempts to earn an honest penny.

SEATTLE, June 7 (AP) -- Top-seeded Herb Flam of Los Angeles was pushed to five sets to win his semi-final match from Tom Brown, San Francisco, in the national hard-court tennis championships today. The score was 6 -- 3, 1 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1.

LONDON, June 7 -- This is a time of political uncertainty in Britain. When Parliament resumes its session on Tuesday after the Whitsun recess there will be misgivings among the Members of the House of Commons on the Conservative as well as the Labor side.

MOST motorists mapping a projected auto trip do their best to avoid the dotted line and tiny "FY" which indicate that a ferry is the only means of getting across some water. They instinctively look for an alternate route with a bridge.

OUT in Langhorne, Pa., late last month more than one hundred parents, teachers, social workers, physicians, psychologists and other specialists met for the annual spring conference of the child research clinic of the Woods Schools to discuss some of the problems of mentally retarded children.

CINCINNATI, June 7 -- Contrary to the opinion of most persons, the modern era is a "truly great age," and the reason is that more is being done for the "common man" than in any five past generations, Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland, Ohio, said here today at the sixty-eighth ordination service of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion.

THIS is the chemical age in gardening, which means -- among other things -- the use of sprays, weedkillers and all-important plant nutrients. These chemical foods afford handier, speedier ways of providing the elements needed to supplement the natural processes of plant growth.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 7 -- William Howard Taft 3d, son of the Senator who is seeking the Republican Presidential nomination, told 200 persons here tonight that in the recent South Dakota primary election his father had had to overcome the opposition of 55 per cent of the Republican vote in that state.
LONDON, June 7 -- A page from the past came alive today when heralds moved through London to proclaim the coronation date of Queen Elizabeth II.

Jim Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, yesterday signed Rocky Marciano, undefeated heavyweight boxer from Brockton, Mass., to fight Harry (Kid) Matthews of Seattle. The bout, scheduled for ten rounds, will take place in the Yankee Stadium on the night of Monday, July 28.

For more than half a century the name of John Dewey, who died last week at the age of 92, has been synonymous with progressive education. Despite the controversies that his theories have engendered, he was held in high esteem in almost every segment of American life.

Jorge Joveyn's "Robot's Gambit" (May 4) brings up some recollections of a halfcentury ago. Surely you must have many readers who can remember a very similar contrivance exhibited at the old Eden Musee, on West Twenty-third Street, around the turn of the century.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 7 -- The Yugoslav Government has ordered a further decentralization of industrial control and a simplification of the complex chain of command usually identified with the Marxist economic state.

PARIS, June 7 -- French official action against the nation's Communists broadened today with a charge of espionage affecting the national defense by Communist militants in the big naval base city of Toulon and new police raids on offices of party-line organizations in Paris and in three port cities.
BROWNSVILLE, Tex., June 7 (UP) -- A four-engined transport plane reported stolen from Oakland, Calif., landed at Brownsville today and its pilot said he was "only taking what belongs to me."

BONN, Germany, June 7 -- Proposals that the Federal Government make a final attempt to create a basis for re-unification with the East German Government are appearing with more frequency as the debate over ratification of treaties binding West Germany to rearmament and the Atlantic alliance gets under way.

Nineteen overseas veterans in unusually frilly mufti held their tenth reunion at Governors Island yesterday. They were former members of the Ninth Evacuation Hospital Unit -- the Roosevelt Hospital Unit -- who served just a few steps behind the Ninth Army on a thirty-six-month trek through North Africa, Italy, France and Germany.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. -- In the middle of a field on the State University's College of Agriculture farm stands a gray frame structure about six feet square which faculty and students have dubbed "Biel Hall."

FROM week to week the panorama of local art exhibitions alters with startling rapidity. The visitor a few weeks ago who encountered show after show of abstraction and found himself in the midst of conflict over the latest nonobjective broadsides would have found, had he returned last week, little extreme abstraction and in a dozen group exhibitions would have been hard put to it to find even a thin sprinkling of nonobjective work.

IF haberdashers are doing a big business in the sale of light blue shirts, the trend can probably be traced to the increasingly frequent television appearances of this year's political candidates. Experienced television campaigners have learned that white shirts cause a disconcerting glare on viewers' sets, while pastel colors appear as white.

DURING the spring, with its inevitable wet week-ends, most of the short-trip anglers have found disappointment, but with summer and long vacations approaching, the opportunities are much brighter, and all signs point to an unusually fine season, at least on salt water.

BOONTON, N. J., June 7 -- Frank Kaminski, a little fellow who learned his skillful game on public courses, eliminated the favored Chet Sanok in the semi-final round of the New Jersey amateur championship today.
Following is the text of President Truman's address yesterday at Springfield, Mo., before the annual reunion of the Thirty-fifth Division as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

How the problem of "personalizing mass education" -- a traditional dilemma faced by the heads of most colleges and universities with large undergraduate enrollments -- was solved in a metropolitan institution is outlined by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College.

Potatoes, real California new potatoes, were offered yesterday by half a dozen vegetable stores in the Paddy's market district on Ninth Avenue in the Thirties for the former ceiling price, 10 cents a pound.

VIEN A, June 7 -- Competition for the Nazi vote has become so keen in Austria that the Austrian Government has allowed itself the liberty of objecting to the influence of "emigrants" on the formation of United States policy here.

ROCHESTER -- How do you lose a waterfall? Where does it go? What happens to it? And how do you go about finding it again? These are just a few of the questions which have been facing this correspondent recently.

PITTSBURGH, June 7 -- A new speed-boat creation, meeting its first test of the season, won the Steel Cup today as hundreds of thousands of western Pennsylvanians lined the banks of the Allegheny and Ohio Rivers and thronged the river city's bridges.

MENDELSSOHN was pretty close to Mozart as a natural musical phenomenon. Everything came easily; he apparently did not even need to be taught; and when still a child he was turning out properly composed symphonies, concertos and piano pieces.

IN the paradoxical history of the motion-picture business the United Artists Corporation holds a unique position as the only privately owned major distributing company. But more than that the company stands today as a symbol of hope and encouragement to an industry which is speculating with some apprehension over the effects that television may have on its economic future.

SANDY HOOK, N. J. -- Old Sandy will have another birthday anniversary this week, its 188th. But there will be no official hullabaloo, for historic Sandy Hook lighthouse is too busy performing the work it has been doing in New York Harbor since it was first illuminated, on June 11, 1764.

A 16MM. still camera with an f/2 lens in place of the usual f/3.5 lens on cameras of this size, is announced by King Photo Import Co., 1133 Broadway. The new miniature is the Minicord, made by C. P. Goerz, Vienna, Austria, and will be available this month at $149.50.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UP) -Harold Brown, a rookie who had pitched a total of only nine innings this season, scored his first major league victory in his first start tonight as the White Sox defeated the Senators, 5 -- 3. Brown had to leave the game after five innings, however, because his arm tightened up.

HIGH on the plains of western Texas is a canyon whose walls look yellowish in the summer sun, and in the walls are holes that once were the homes of cave dwellers. So the place is called the Yellow Houses.

The idea of an artificial satellite was discussed a generation ago by Herman Oberth, a German engineer, who thought it would have its uses as a filling station for rocketships on their way to the Moon. He suggested that on it a mirror two miles in diameter might be mounted to catch the rays of the sun and generate about 10,000,000 horsepower.
SAVANNAH, June 7 -- A $44,000,000 construction and improvement program for this industrial port city's railroad, trucking and water commerce facilities is under way.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The United States has drafted and sent to Paris its proposals for a joint reply with Britain and France to the latest note from the Soviet Union on German unification.

WITHIN the past fortnight the Communist party has demonstrated in striking fashion its ability to create civil disorder almost simultaneously in many parts of the world. Whether some high authority in the Kremlin pushed a button to produce the rioting, or the Communist organizations in various nations caught the spirit of militancy through the chain reaction of the Communist press, cannot be known.

The United States harvests between 400 and 450 million bushels of potatoes in an average year. In terms of caloric content, the potato is traditionally the cheapest food on the American market. This year the crop is below average and potatoes are not cheap.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., June 7 -- Win Tsie, a Chinese student at Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, opened a red box on a pole in midtown to mail a letter at 1 P. M. today, and soon found himself the center of attention.

THROUGH the good offices of the League of Composers and its chairman on commissions, Mrs. Arthur M. Reis, long a tower of strength in the league, Aaron Copland has received and accepted an invitation to compose a short opera expressly for television.
The text of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's press conference at the Commodore Hotel yesterday follows:

CUTTING flowers for enjoyment in the home may be a simple or an elaborate process. There are, however, a few general rules. It is fun to go out in a garden and pick either one rose for a bud vase or a basket of assorted flowers to go in vases all over the house.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 7 -- The dedication of Woodrow Wilson Hall as a memorial to the late President of the United States, who was also a student, teacher and president of Princeton University, will be among the events of Princeton's 205th commencement program opening next Friday.

When President Truman yesterday spoke to his comrades of the Thirty-fifth Division in Springfield, Mo., he was also addressing a wider audience. He was, in effect, making a report to the nation on national defense. It was a reassuring report to the extent that it quite properly answered the irresponsible declarations that we are powerless.
AMERICANS will find H. Maclear Bate's book unusual fare. Its material is fresh, for one thing, because it presents Formosa and its significance in the Far East maelstrom through non-American eyes.

MADRID, June 7 -- The concern with which the Spanish Government has viewed manifestations of Catalan irredentism has led to the suppression of two magazines in Barcelona and the arrest of three men connected with them, according to reports received today from Barcelona.
TO THE EDITOR:My husband and I. parents of two boys, read, with much interest Arthur Daley's "The Little League Is Big Time" (May 25).

Dollar sales volume of major New York City department stores last week were again at a statistical disadvantage because of comparison with the first full week of the "price war" last year. Under this comparison, volume was estimated to be down 20 per cent, although actually it was close to normal seasonal patterns.

MANCHESTER, England, June 7 -- Maureen Connolly, the United States champion from San Diego, Calif., won her second international tennis tournament in two tries when she overcame a shaky start to trounce Mrs. Jean Quertier Rinkel, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, in the final of the northern tournament today.

THE C.B.S. television network, through the facilities of its enterprising Philadelphia affiliate, WCAU-TV, will try another format in the continuing search to find a workable formula for educational programs on video.

Only a few meteorologists will say that the sun has any day-to-day or month-to-month effect on the weather. With these few John W. Mauchly allies himself. He is not a professional meteorologist but an able mathematician, the inventor of the UNIVAC and other electronic computers.

A young woman sought since Thursday in an investigation of the murder of her mother in the Bronx was picked up yesterday in Peekskill, N. Y., and turned over to detectives from the Bathgate Avenue station.

A week ago today General Eisenhower returned to the United States after an arduous eighteen-month tour of duty as our chief military representative in Europe. Two days later he stepped out of his military role and into the status of a civilian candidate for the highest office in this republic.

PITTSBURGH, June 7 -- Exasperated beyond measure by the annoying turn events had been taking recently, Leo Durocher gave his Giants a going over today reminiscent of the famed "shake well" days of early 1950 and 1951. But in the end he could have saved himself a lot of trouble.

Regardless of the outcome of Congressional moves to restrict imports from friendly nations, there is a growing conviction among foreign trade leaders here that a public information program on the personal benefits of prosperous world trade is needed to offset the increasing trend toward "protectionism."

In Abilene last week a reporter asked Dwight D. Eisenhower whether he was to be addressed as General or Mister Eisenhower. He replied: "I am, as of this moment, still technically a general * * * [but] I would be delighted if you should like to call me Mr. Eisenhower."

A LABOR of love and a monument to indefatigable research on the part of an ardent Lincolnian, F. Lauriston Bullard's volume includes photographic representations of Sixty-eight statues of our Civil War President -- every statue of heroic size.
TOKYO, Sunday, June 8 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,274, for Saturday's operations:

" JUNE Outdoors and Indoors" is the name of the annual flower show of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State's Second District. This two-day affair is scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday, at the Cathedral House in Garden City.

THE summer reader, unlike the summer soldier, is a dedicated man. It takes no special devotion to make one's self comfortable of a winter evening, fireplace ablaze, with the latest popular book: bad weather is the abettor of good reading.

JACKSONVILLE -- A few years ago not many people north of the Mason-Dixon Line entertained the thought of spending a summer vacation in Florida. Most of Florida's summer visitors came from near-by Southern states, and they went to northern Florida resorts like Daytona Beach, St. Augustine, Jacksonville Beach, Pensacola and Panama City.

" FATTY!" yelled the boys. Zingo. Rowena chunked a snowball and the fight was on. In this second Cape Ann story about plump Rowena Carey, the village doctor's tomboy and an oversized dog named Hector run parallel courses of mishap.

NOT every schoolboy knows that Elizabeth Gray Vining, author of the best-selling "Windows for the Crown Prince," was private tutor to Akihito, who some day, barring accidents, will be Emperor of Japan. It is a safe bet that those same schoolboys, if they met her, would vote her the woman they'd like to have as teacher.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N. J. -- New Jersey's historic Cape May County, extending thirty miles into the Atlantic Ocean and often likened to Cape Cod as an artist's working territory, offers fourteen increasingly popular summer vacation centers.

MILAN. I SHALL never forget the astonished stare with which the young man from Missouri I met that morning in Rome's Piazza del Popolo was watching the rowdy crowd assembled there. It was April 27, the anniversary of Mussolini's death.
FRESH herbs are a pleasant symbol of summertime. Even the city dweller can enjoy them, for herbs take to pots and window boxes. What is more, a little space goes a long way.

Revision of the Federal Reserve Board's system of open-market dealings in Government securities is one possible outcome of a new study of the system now being conducted by the board. The study, it has been learned, is being directed by Robert H. Craft, vice president and treasurer of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, who recently took a leave of absence to assist in the project.

It is with great sorrow that we must note the passing of John Dewey. Even at his advanced age he was a great inspiration to all of us who are fearful of those current forces which are so relentlessly exerting their pressures to bring about a stultifying conformity of thought.
Music of several centuries will be heard Wednesday between noon and 2 P. M. in the weekly recorded concert of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

It is indeed sad to note that the grinning Princeton Tiger has become a somber beast. It is even more depressing to see that Mr. McPhee has a rationale for the demise of the funny magazine: "Impending military service and the almost hopeless challenge of a world that is dominated by the lower reason have made a serious individual out of today's college boy."

HYANNIS, Mass. -- Cape Cod's great stretches of open beach and temperate bathing waters will draw an exceptional volume of summer vacationists from throughout the nation this year. The relatively cool climate, the historical associations and the quiet native charm are other important attractions, but the first lure is the expanse of free beaches and bracing sea waters.

SOMETIME at the end of every April winds spring up off the west coast of South America and these, so the meteorologists tentatively suggest, travel westward across more than half the world to produce one of the world's most spectacular climatic phenomena.

Mrs. Ruth P. Casa-Emellos, home economist in charge of THE NEW YORK TIMES Food News Department Test Kitchen, studied Mr. Neuberger's recipe, Mr. Twiddy's report and Mr. Neuberger's retort, and submitted the judicial finding:

ALBANY -- The tired motorist's dream of a superhighway from New York City to the Catskills is actually in the process of fulfillment. By 1954 it should be possible to drive from Manhattan to near the Sullivan County line on four to six lane expressways.

IN color photography's first major bid to be displayed on a par with paintings, Pavelle Color, Inc., will put on exhibition and sale tomorrow a group of original 16x20-inch color prints in appropriate frames and signed by the photographers.

PARIS, June 7 -- Billy Maxwell, the United States champion from Odessa, Tex., overcame a shaky session on the greens today to win two matches and lead a group of four Americans into the quarter-finals of the French amateur golf tournament.

A RETURN to more normal seasonal - buying patterns continues to mark many of the consumer goods industries. The change for the better which became evident in shoes a month or so ago now takes in some of the home furnishings lines and several of the important divisions of the apparel field.

AT this time of year, few plants are more spectacular than the little-known foxtail lily or giant asphodel, whose formal name is eremurus. Against a background of evergreen hedge or other tall shrub foliage, ten-foot spires stand out dramatically.

THE summer started dismally enough for Linden Bradley. Her high hopes of traveling were dashed by the mysterious disappearance of a check from her father and Linden had to help family finances by running a roadside fruit and vegetable stand.

Litigation resulting from the splitting in two of a tanker during the last war and through which the Federal Government seeks to obtain nearly $500,000 from the Esso Standard Oil Company is now being heard in Federal Court here. The admiralty action came to trial last week before Judge J. Skelly Wright.

Many shrewd industrial organizations are giving up the mad scramble for the little (and big) man who isn't there. Last week the industrial division of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company made no secret of its partial abandonment of college campus raiding as a means of bolstering its vital engineering staff.

AMONG the many colorful figures of Paris, Juliette Greco has a place of her own. Her long black tresses and slightly tomboyish features are familiar in the literary circles of the Left Bank. Recently she has had parts in a few films.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 7 -- Although finishing fourth in cross-country riding, Pfc. Thad McArthur of Seattle today won the United States pentathlon championship with a total of 19 points. He also earned a berth on the team which will compete in the Olympics next month.

IN answer to the objections Father Thorning makes to two of the statements in my review of his books, I should like to say only that in the first instance he is quite right. My use of the term "lifting the siege" was an error.

It will cost a cool $1,469,265,101 to run the New York City government in the year starting July 1. The bill will be the largest in the city's history, $128,148,888 more than the tab for the current fiscal period ending June 30.

American Airlines took legal steps yesterday to end the four-day sit-down strike of more than 1,000 of its mechanics and cargo handlers at La Guardia Airport and New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. The line filed a $250,000 damage suit against the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and Local 501, and petitioned for a permanent injunction against the work stoppage.
NEW DELHI, India, June 7 -India's high-powered cultural delegation to Communist China returned from Canton by plane this evening with distinct impressions of international interest.

MORE than a century ago the United States Cavalry tried to introduce camels to the Great American Desert near here and gave it up when the beasts proved ornery, smelly, impractical and Yankee-resistant.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower promised yesterday at a mass interview with reporters, radio commentators and others to do all in his power to promote the cause of world peace and security. But he warned that he had no magic panacea to achieve this goal and that it would mean work and sacrifice for everyone.

If new trends for promoting industrial payroll saving could be applied to the steel industry the thousands of steel employes could, through stock ownership, achieve effective working control of the industry in about six years, and majority ownership in twelve.

IN THE interest of historical scholarship and fair play, may I remark that Dexter Perkins' review of Dr. Charles Callan Tansill's "Back Door to War" is in my opinion a flagrant attempt at discrediting a fellow historian by the familiar device of quoting ex contextu.

THIS week Westminster offers a charming record of Spanish music in folk-idiom, Lopez Tejera's Allegrias y Penas de Andalucia (Joys and Sorrows of Andalucia). The work is in eight sections, subtitled Variaciones; Fandangoes; Noche en Santa Cruz; Soleares y Seguiriyas; Judea; Bulerias; Granadina; Tarantas.

IN June the flower arranger revels in the great variety of blooms which the garden provides. The profusion of flowers and foliage available this month offers a variety of color, form and texture that can be combined according to fancy.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 7 -The twenty-second national business conference was advised today that the nation's business executives must be responsible for leading the people to greater happiness.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 7 -- United Nations statisticians estimated today that half the world's population had incomes of less than $100 a year in 1950.

MOSCOW, June 6 -- Pravda reported today that the mid-April session of the central committee of the Communist party of Georgia had revealed insufficiencies in party work, particularly with regard to ideological questions.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. -- There could hardly be a better time than now, when rhododendron is in bloom and the whole mountain country is coming to life, for a jaunt to Chattanooga, Tenn., and the amazing T. V. A. vacation country around here.

ANY day now the American will be on the move, traveling east or west, exploring the country with the enthusiasm and energy of latter-day Boones. There is one preparation too seldom made that would add immeasurably to the trip, so far as the younger members of the expedition are concerned: some reading about the places to be visited.
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- The Cubs won their fourth straight victory and their eleventh in fourteen games today as Warren Hacker tamed the Braves, 9 -- 3, in his first start of the season.
The House of Representatives is expected to make crucial decisions this week affecting the future of the merchant marine.

ONCE a plant is set in place, it's easy to forget its variety name or mistake it for another. This is especially true of iris, phlox, roses, chrysanthemums and, in fact, any plant which has numerous varieties. This, then, is when the value of garden labels is realized.

IN reporting his astonishingly successful career as a pioneer in American advertising and in recounting the many important and constructive things he contributed to America, most of the obituaries of Albert D. Lasker failed to mention the activity which filled the last five years of his life with a special, spicy pleasure -- his art collecting.

EACH state of the Union has infinite variety, and to a resident who knows his home state well it has many aspects. But to the tourist from beyond its borders each state tends to be noted for one or a few specific attractions -- scenic, historic or recreational.
GROTON, Conn., June 7 (AP) -What's in a name? Headaches, lots of them, if one decides to change it after fifty-two years.

A STAY-AT-HOME vacation seemed like a bleak prospect to 16-year-old Beany Malone, so the chance to drive to California with her mother and small nephew was a dream come true. Before the trip is over it assumes nightmare qualities with the ordinary car troubles multiplied by the complications of carrying a horse along in a trailer and two unpredictable passengers.

HOBOKEN, N. J., June 7 -- Wide and "imaginative" gains in medical research and treatment with atomic energy were described to an alumni forum on atomic energy at Stevens Institute of Technology here today. There was also a complaint that "private enterprise has been disappointingly slow in providing leadership for the development of atomic power."

MONTREAL -- Vacationists in Eastern Canada this summer will discover so many fascinating places to visit, so many attractive resorts to enjoy themselves in, and so much going on that they will have some difficulty in deciding where to begin.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 7 -- Greeted by a breeze of 20 to 25 knots, only twenty craft started today in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta conducted by the Orienta Yacht Club.
ANDOVER, Mass., June 7 -- Andover staged a six-run assault in the eighth inning today to turn back Exeter, 8 -- 5, before an overflow crowd of 4,000 alumni and parents.

MILLIONS of bridge players today are using a point count to value their hands. The predictions always were that the majority of players would never turn from the lower figures of the honor-trick table to the higher mathematics of points, but the event has proved the predictions wrong.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 7 -Good Time, driven by Frank Ervin, was first across the finish line in the free-for-all mile pace that served as the feature attraction at the Roosevelt Raceway tonight, but the accomplishment did not constitute victory.

CINCINNATI, June 7 -- continuing their devastating sweep through the West, the Dodgers today buried the Reds beneath an 11-3 score for their fifth straight triumph and held easily to their four-game first-place lead over the Giants.
ARDMORE, Okla., June 7 (UP) -- Dave Douglas of Newark, Del., gained a 2-stroke lead at the three-quarters mark of the $18,000 Ardmore Open Golf tournament today with a 3-under-par total of 207.

STANTON, Del., June 7 (AP) -Ogden Phipps' Flirtatious today scored her fourth and most important triumph in eight starts when she defeated a dozen other classy juvenile fillies in the fifteenth Polly Drummond Stakes at Delaware Park.

CHAD POWELL, the lad who went to New Guinea in "The Rain Forest," is back in the jungle, this time at the headwaters of the Rio Negrito. The expedition headed by Chad's father is to search for rare bird specimens, and also, at the request of the Venezuelan Government, for trace of a missing explorer.

TRUE tales of derring-do never really date. For a while it was the fashion to say that World War II narratives of this type were not in demand. But this never did obtain for the best of them; it merely applied to the spate of reminiscence which always follows in the wake of war.
BERLIN, June 7 -- Some hotelkeepers, when they dislike a guest, send him a new bill every day. This would appear to be the present tactic of the East Germans toward the Allies in Western Berlin.

GENEVA -- Many generations of Americans have prowled around Europe looking for the perfect, unspoiled village, the dream town, with the church on a hill, the quiet square, the peaceful citizens living according to their ancient ways. It must have a superb restaurant.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- An oil painting purchased a month ago at an auction sale in New York by a Chicago art dealer for $100 was established today to be a fifteenth century masterpiece worth more than $150,000. It is a portrait of Lucrezia Borgia.

ATLANTIC CITY -- With the business volume in the Atlantic City area continuing to run well ahead of the national averages listed since 1939, officials and business leaders are confidently predicting the greatest season in this resort's ninety-eight-year history.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 7 -- Dick Maiocco, a New York University senior, and Reggie Pearman, a New York University graduate, turned in eye-catching performances today as many of the East's best club and college runners tuned up for the Olympic tryouts of the next three weeks in the annual spring games of the New York Athletic club.

An endorsement of the Presidential candidacy of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, made two years ago by the late Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican of Michigan, was released for publication yesterday by the Senator's son, Arthur H. Vandenberg, Jr.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, urged adoption today of the Celler immigration bill to allow 300,000 displaced persons to enter the United States in the next three years as non-quota immigrants.

WITHIN a span of five years (1816-20), more like four really, John Keats wrote some of the most beautiful poetry in the English language. This conjunction of a brief life and a mature art (Keats, after all, died at 26) is a mystery renewed each time one looks at the poems.

Since I am completing an authorized biography of the late David Wark Griffith, I was naturally interested in Seymour Stern's letter (March 30), contending that Griffith's "The Birth of a Nation" grossed $48,000,000.

NOW that spring, despite its fitful, damp and gusty start, has finally settled in New York, an increasingly large percentage of Manhattan's population has begun to emerge from steam-heated hibernation to begin above-street-level outdoor life. On the roofs and set-backs of stolid, old-fashioned apartment houses in the most respectable of New York's residential districts, penthouse terraces, like their owners, show the fruitful rewards of long-term, expensive care.
Praises be unto Mr. John Masters, whose "Man Against Jungle" (May 25) comes as one of the most vivid, picturesque, concise portrayals of jungle life I have yet to come across.

WASHINGTON. LIKE a play long in rehearsal, the masterwork of the politician, the old drama of a Presidential election year is about to be staged again before 170,000,000 spectators, the caring, the uncaring, the intent and the uninterested.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 7 -- Raymond N. Ball, president of the Lincoln Rochester Trust Company, was elected chairman of the University of Rochester Board of Trustees today. He succeeds M. Herbert Eisenhart, chairman of the Bausch Lomb Optical Company, who was head of the board for seven years and who continues as a trustee.

John Foster Dulles, advocating a new, bold United States foreign policy, states: "We could welcome the creation in the free world of political 'task forces' to develop a freedom program for each of the captive nations. Each group would be made up of those who are proved patriots, who have practical resourcefulness and who command confidence and respect at home and abroad."

DRIPPING with London dampness, haunted by quaint, ominous place-names and exotically seedy settings, peopled with wrongdoers who are not hateful and policemen who are compassionate, the world of the British thriller has become so familiar that a Constant Reader feels right at home in it.

NEWARK, June 7 -- Wedding guests as well as the bride and groom arriving at the Roseville Avenue Presbyterian Church, 63 Roselle Avenue, for a wedding ceremony shortly after 2 P. M. found firemen fighting a fire in the church steeple 110 feet above the ground.

BETWEEN March 3, 1845, when Congress established uniform postage rates of 5 and 10 cents, and March 3, 1847, when Congress authorized the Postmaster General to issue Government stamps, postmasters in a dozen cities and towns had their own postal paper printed.

The rock-bottom issue all along in the half-year-old steel dispute has been the dollars and cents to go into the steelworkers' pay envelopes. That issue has often been overshadowed by others -- anti-inflation policy, the Government's labor-management procedure, U. S. Constitutional law.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 -- Final arguments were completed today in the trial of James G. Smyth, discharged Collector of Internal Revenue for Northern California, who was indicted on four counts of violating income tax laws in connection with his own returns and those of his wife, Madlyn.
Your column on "Realistic Approach" certainly was apropos. I am not a TV addict yet for I resent the time it takes from other things I like to do.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 7 -- Although the United Nations is just an innocent bystander, delegates and officials are beginning to realize that the organization will be the target of many a brick bat before the United States elections are over.

DR. GERMAN ARCINIEGAS, one of the most gifted writers in the Western Hemisphere, must have nodded when, in reviewing my book, "Miranda: World Citizen," he claimed that Don Francisco de Miranda "had had a hand in the negotiations between the Spaniards and North Americans leading to the lifting of the siege of Yorktown."

MIKE TODD, one-time carnie man from Bloomington, Minn., more recently Broadway's flashiest promoter of the song-dance-and-girlie show, looked south from the solarium of his duplex Park Avenue penthouse at the slow rain and gray mist that had settled over midtown Manhattan.

We certainly agree with your editorial of May 12 that "we hope that action will be taken at this session to segregate airmail payment from subsidy." You have the right attitude, but you have the wrong bill.

THE roving correspondent of the largest French daily, France-Soir, Michel Gordey spent sixty-three days in the Soviet Union during the spring of 1950. He was not allowed to visit Russians in their homes or places of work.

AMONG the recent additions to photography's bookshelf are new editions of several popular manuals and reference works, a picture-and-text annual, a cartoonist's pen-and-ink commentary on the hobby and a manual on a new technique.

CHRIS and two friends went to Washington's Olympic National Forest to test smoke signals as a device for summoning help to the scene of a mountain accident. From his amphibian plane Al Scott saw the test and thought it meant real trouble.

THE rose, whose history begins in antiquity, is probably the best known and loved of all our flowers. It has been cultivated in China for countless centuries. The modern varieties that are grown so widely today were produced by bringing together the roses of China, Persia, Central Europe and America.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Finish any planting necessary for this year's display and harvest as quickly as possible. Even tropical waterlilies may be put in pools now, and the most tender summer-flowering bulbs should go into the ground. Lima beans, sweet potatoes and melon may be planted safely, seedlings of annual and biennial flowers and vegetables transplanted.

GENEVA, June 7 (AP) -- The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, with a special war chest of $700,000, completed plans here today for an all-out fight with Communist organizers for the workers of Asia.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UP) -- Representative E. C. Gathings, armed with a pile of dirty books, indecent pictures and naughty postcards, said today he was ready to launch a second House of Representatives investigation of the nation's morals -- or lack of them.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- The 101st annual meeting of the American Medical Association will begin here on Monday and continue through Friday. About 14,000 doctors from all parts of the country and many foreign lands, and about the same number of guests, are expected to attend.

HAVANA, Cuba, June 7 (AP) -- The Government of President Fulgencio Batista announced today it has unearthed a shortage of $96,000,000 in the Cuban Treasury between 1944 and 1949. It had decided to place the matter before the courts.

AT a meeting of the Huntsville Cub Scout Pack the members of Den Two learn that they have slipped from first place to last in Scout activities, and all because it's baseball season! To make matters worse, the June project is to "Know Your Neighborhood," and Den Two's report is to be on the town newspaper -in their opinion a dull subject.

I SHOULD be distressed indeed if I had done Professor Tansill an injustice. But does Father Clancy really think that the failure of the Roosevelt Administration to respond to the unofficial feelers transmitted through Bishop Walsh and Father Drought fixes the President with full responsibility for the war? Let us waive the question as to whether the position of the Japanese Government was accurately judged by the two intermediaries.
Fordham University begins its 107th annual commencement week with baccalaureate services this morning.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- A flexible retirement age, adjusted to correspond to life expectancy, was advocated here today by Dr. William B. Rawls of New York, at the annual meeting of the American Therapeutic Society.

JERUSALEM, June 2 -- Since the founding of the State of Israel four years ago, approximately 9,000 persons have been settled in the Jerusalem corridor, the narrow neck of stony land through the Judean hills connecting Jerusalem with the rest of the country.

AUGUSTA, Me., June 7 (AP) -- Maine's Republican Senatorial contest between Senator Owen Brewster and Gov. Frederick G. Payne reached new bitterness today. The issue in exchanges today was a just ended four-day legislative investigation of the state's $20,000,000-a-year liquor monopoly.

New York University will open its 120th commencement season at 4 P. M. today with the traditional baccalaureate services in the chapel of the Gould Memorial Library on the Bronx campus, 181st Street and University Avenue.

THIS is a unique study of the life and work of Tu Fu, who lived in the eighth century, a period which covered one of the most brilliant moments in Chinese history as well as some of the most disastrous. The descriptions of court and rural life in T'ang times are wonderfully vivid.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (UP) -- Luke Easter walloped a grand-slam homer in the first inning today, and Mike Garcia and Lou Brissie collaborated in shutting out the Athletics as the Indians rolled to a 14-0 victory.

It is implicit in "It's Collegiate -- But Is It Humor?" (May 25) by Richard C. Lemon of The Yale Record and John Angus McPhee of The Princeton Tiger that theirs is a campus quarrel rather than a serious debate.

IF it is reading that "maketh a full man," as Lord Bacon declared, then we have fair prospect in America of becoming men fully saturated and dripping with politics before this electoral season is ended. Oratory is, of course, the politician's stock in trade; and in a campaign year the candidate gets caricatured as a veritable hit-and-run orator.

CORNWALL, Pa. -- An era is rapidly drawing to a close in the iron-ore region of Lebanon County where Peter Grubb made a lease with the Indians in 1735 "to use the red dirt as long as grass grows and water flows."

CAPE CHARLES, Va. -- Travelers headed south from the New Jersey Turnpike can avoid a lot of Baltimore and Washington traffic by taking U. S. 13 instead of U. S. 40 from the junction just south of the Delaware Memorial Bridge.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UP) -- The House Democratic whip, Representative J. Percy Priest of Tennessee, said today the Eighty-second Congress had a good chance to complete its work and adjourn sine die before the national political conventions at Chicago in July.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The complexity of modern society and the demands of a world that must gird for war to keep the peace make it clearer month by month that self-government in labor-management relations, otherwise known as collective bargaining, is undergoing a severe test.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, June 8 (AP) -- Allied infantrymen won a hill on the western front in Korea yesterday in one of three short but vicious skirmishes. Allied planes continued smashing at enemy supply lines.

MULCHING sounds like just another job to be done in the garden. But it is one chore that actually cuts down on some of the other chores. It consists of spreading a layer of material such as straw, peat moss, buckwheat hulls or other suitable material over the ground around plants.

FOR this piece the typewriter has been set up on a table in a corner of the porch, providing an outlook brightened by the fresh green of the young leaves on the shrubbery. An airplane has just passed high overhead, outward bound from Idlewild International Airport to some remote, romantic-sounding place, maybe Orly, or Istanbul or Johannesburg.

THE ivory-tower gang is at it again! In the columns of the magazine called "Academy," some members of the National Institute of Arts and Letters have taken pen in hand to denounce the state of television and suggest that it yet will be the end of society.

OF all the modern weapons and devices of warfare, probably none taxes the comprehension more than the submarine. It is difficult for the layman to imagine the rigors of routine life aboard the crowded complex, gadget-ridden vessels.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Senator Robert A. Taft shot a brisk 84 over the rolling fairways of the Burning Tree Country Club here last Sunday. For the second round of golf he has played in all of 1952, he regarded it as a pretty satisfactory performance.

LINDEN, N. J., June 7 -- Visible as far away as Staten Island, across the Arthur Kill, one of the most familiar, but probably least understood, sights on the horizon are giant flares that maintain constant vigil at the Bayway Refinery of the Esso Standard Oil Company here.
