Being of a somber turn of mind myself, I was delighted to read that Princeton's Tiger was abandoning the oft-trodden paths of college humor to take up more serious topics "of a general nature."

BONN, Germany, June 7 -- Industrial and labor leaders in the Federal Government are giving increased thought to the pet German idea of creating an economic council that would consider and in some cases draft proposed legislation dealing with the country's economy.
BOSTON, June 7 (AP) -- The Red Sox overcame Detroit, 11 -- 9, in a bitter struggle today before 15,602 fans in a game that saw thirteen extra-base hits, including four home runs.

BY and large, the season just closing has not been such a bad one. Without the New York City Ballet and the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., to be sure, it would have been fairly desolate as far as performances are concerned, and certainly those two faithful institutions have also put us greatly in their debt by keeping up our courage with their apparent stability in a notably unstable period.

THERE will, of course, be hundreds thousands of Americans going abroad this summer, among them a good many constant readers. One small book they will almost certainly have with them. It is the booklet of helpful hints issued, along with each passport, by the State Department.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 7 -Milton Campbell, Plainfield High School's 18-year-old athletic star, won three events with record-shattering performances this afternoon in the thirty-fourth annual indoor track and field championships of the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association at Woodman Field.

The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., will seek substantial wage and overtime rate increases along with a higher welfare fund payment in a wage review with East and Gulf Coast shipowners that begins on Tuesday afternoon.

The offices of City Collector Alexander E. Frontera in the five boroughs were preparing yesterday for a steadily increasing flood this week of over-the-counter and mail sales of the new $5 and $10 auto use tax stamps. The heaviest jam is expected next Monday, June 16, the last day for purchasing the stickers without liability to penalties.

I've never eaten whiter, lighter biscuits than those produced by the recipe which Mr. Twiddy tried with such allegedly disastrous results. My sourdough crock always functioned best in the high Cascade Range of Oregon and the state of Washington, at elevations of from 3,000 to 8,000 feet above sea level.

TODAY the United States is a signal and responsible part of the civilized Western tradition. How we got that way, how long we have been growing up to the job, is reflected in Elizabeth Wallace's record of her own life, as college professor and international ambassador.

THE use of liquid fertilizers is not new. Just how far back it goes I am not sure, but I'm fairly certain that the Chinese and other Oriental peoples have been using liquid fertilizer in preference to dry kinds for centuries.
LONDON, June 7 (UP) -- The Communist High Command threw the book of charges today at Ana Pauker, Rumanian Foreign Minister.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Negotiators for striking steel workers and their employers will resume White House conferences at 11 A. M. tomorrow in another effort at reaching a wage agreement that will end the country-wide steel strike.

Plans for the summer session of 1952 at the University of Vermont call for two courses in aviation education to be given to high school teachers and others interested in the integration of aviation education into existing curricula. These are believed to be the first courses of their kind to be offered in a summer session in this country.

COMPARED with the huge industrial traffic across the Great Lakes and up and down the Mississippi River, whose volume far surpasses this nation's ocean-borne commerce, the chances for a summer tourist to spend a vacation afloat on these bodies of water are small indeed.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Mrs. James M. Helm, White House social secretary in the Woodrow Wilson, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman administrations, was honored today by women members of the press for "twenty-five years of unique service to this country, particularly in World Wars I and II."

BARE spots in the garden, caused by plants that have distinctly seasonal bloom or short flowering periods, need not remain that way all season. No garden border can be expected to spill over with bloom in every nook and cranny at all times, but follow-up plantings can be made now to mask certain barren areas.

QUITO, Ecuador, June 7 -- Ecuador's voters chose their next President last Sunday in an election that was a model of free and orderly voting and conclusively proved the liberal sympathies of most of the people even if they cannot agree on a single leader to represent them.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of Interior, says any qualified citizen can file his own application, pay $30 and get a three-year oil and gas lease on forty acres of Government land. But it is not very likely that such land might produce oil or gas, a department official indicated.

THIS is the time of year for dog-owners to pack up The Dog and send him off to board with unsuspecting friends, neighbors, or good old Aunt Sophie. The family, thus unencumbered, goes merrily on vacation, while poor Aunt Sophie and The Dog learn to live with each other and hate it.
In the excellent letter of Joseph O'Brien in your issue of May 18 a statement occurs which I hope will not be overlooked by readers, for it contains a warning for the people of the United States.

If a poll had been taken to discover the Barnard College graduate of last Thursday most likely to succeed, the unanimous choice probably would have been 21-year-old, Vienna-born Ruth Schachter, who is considered no less than a wonder by her classmates.
Degrees were awarded to 244 graduates of Wagner Lutheran Memorial College, Grymes Hill, S. I., yesterday at the sixty-seventh annual commencement exercises in the new gymnasium on the campus.

Plans are being formulated for the series of theatre parties known as Five Enchanted Evenings to be held in the autumn for the benefit of the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service. Mrs. Lytle Hull is president of the beneficiary.
MILWAUKEE, June 7 (AP) -Illinois scored in every event it entered tonight to tally 70 points to retain its title in the Twenty-seventh Central Collegiate Conference track and field championships.

PARIS, June 7 -- In its current bold attempt to check the power of the Communist party of France -- the second largest Communist party on the free side of the Iron Curtain -- the French Government of Premier Antoine Pinay has opened a new front in the struggle between the free and the Communist worlds.

Italy will explore the advisability of export subsidies to balance trade and increase consumption of Rer goods abroad, according to Della M. Grattan, Italian trade consultant. This recommendation, she said last week, has been made to Italian trade officials and it appears likely that it will soon be implemented.

DOWN South in the Appalachian Mountains, mostly in North Carolina, Tennessee and Kentucky, there still flourish the old handicrafts, the mountain people's crafts. In cabins in every cove and valley women still weave coverlets by hand, with names like "Double Bow Knot," "Trailing Vine," "Star of the East."

ONCE more this author gives us an exciting story of big-game fishing in the Gulf Stream and adventure in the Everglades. The hero is again the Seminole Indian, Joe Panther. Although the tale throbs with action, its important feature is the sympathetic portrayal of the proud Seminole tribes, with their deep-rooted reluctance to blend their ancient Indian traditions with those of the white man.

Awards of prizes acquired by scholars and students, with or without effort on the part of the winner, are still generally held to be gifts and exempt from the Federal income tax. But fine distinctions have resulted in exceptions.

Before the American Geriatric Society, which met in Chicago last week, Dr. Louis Carp of Goldwater Memorial Hospital, New York, followed up a study made four years ago of the risks that persons 60 years of age and older run when they must undergo an operation.

THIS is strawberry time. One advantage to growing this fruit in a home garden is that the berries may be picked when they are fully ripe and enjoyed at the peak of their flavor. Strawberries, however, do ripen after they are picked and thus this perishable fruit may be shipped for some distance.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I. -- The eastern tip of Long Island was used by Sir William Johnson of French and Indian War fame for his summer headquarters in 1773 -- "for the benefit of his health." It has logically been developed into one of the Atlantic's better-known resort sections.

LONG BEACH, Calif., June 7 (AP) -- Favorites, headed by Mal Whitfield in the 400 meters, Otis Chandler in the shot-put and Bill Miller in the javelin throw came through today in the first half of the two-day Armed Services track and field championships.

JACKSON, Mich., June 7 -- Like a giant lung, one of the nation's largest underground natural gas storage fields currently is "breathing in" billions of cubic feet of gas north of here. Summer months are storage time for gas in Michigan. This gas, transmitted by pipeline from the South and Southwest, is an important factor in supplying defense industries during the winter months.

WASHINGTON -- Harry S. Truman made the whistle stop famous with his trancontinental tours during the Presidential campaign of 1948, and again in 1950 in his fight for a Fair Deal Congress. Later this year President Truman will again hit the railroad trail, this time in behalf of another Democratic candidate for President.

Much has been said, and much has been written about the varied talents of Jose Ferrer, but what remains, perhaps, as his greatest talent probably has never been mentioned in the press. This unpublicized talent has been, and still is his ability to transmit a feeling and a faith in the living theatre to the young people of the untapped scholastic and collegiate audience.

PARIS, June 7 -- The continuance of the European Payments Union was assured tonight when, contrary to all expectations, the European Marshall Plan Council agreed on a plan to liquidate the unwieldy, menacing Belgian surplus and to check the growth of such surpluses in the future.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 7 -Stepping up a campaign for the United States Senate from New Jersey on the Democratic ticket, former Under Secretary of the Army Archibald Alexander today struck out at "the head-in-the-sand philosophy of military and political experts" who called for an all-out attack on the Chinese mainland and a balanced budget at the same time.
TOKYO, Sunday, June 8 -- United Nations delegates walked out of the armistice negotiations in Korea yesterday to enforce a three-day recess, to which the Communists had declined to agree.

Dr. Mary A. Wyman, associate Professor of English at Hunter College, will retire at the end of this semester and return to her native New England. A member of the faculty for twenty-four years, Dr. Wyman was chairman of the English department from 1939 to 1947.
HOUGHTON, Mich. -- U. S. Highway 41, which runs for more than 1,800 miles from Miami up through the Midsouth and Great Lakes area, ends up at the tip of the Keweenaw Peninsula in Upper Michigan.

MONTREAL -- After a period of some confusion, Canada's resort industry is getting used to working with dollars that are more valuable than the United States kind. So even though the Canadian dollar is now worth between one and two cents more than the American, visitors from the United States this year should not run into much trouble exchanging their funds.

IF your summer reading tastes run to crime, you are going to find the summer of '52 an unusually satisfactory one. Despite the normal volume of shoddy productions, the year so far has had a notable number of highlights; the "Best" list below was pared down to printable size only by the excision of a dozen other books nearly as good.

Last Tuesday the President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation visited the White House to report directly to Mr. Truman on its activities during the last six months and on plans for completing its assignment.

Nearly 2,000 American school teachers will attend workshops this summer to study economic problems. They will bring back to their classrooms in the fall subject matter on the American economy, -- its strengths, weaknesses, and present-day challenges.

A YEAR ago, more or less, but allowing for the difference in time in the Pacific Northwest and the fact that this is leap year, to be honest on Sunday, July 8, 1951, your northwesternmost correspondent, one Richard L. Neuberger, wrote an article for the Travel Section on "Sourdough and How It Gets That Way."

HALF the fun of any vacation is in the planning, and half the planning, especially of a motor trip, should involve costs and budgeting. Each summer countless vacation trips are hurriedly terminated because of lack of funds when a few minutes of logical figuring might have disclosed this possibility in advance.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 7 -- Indiana Republicans chose thirty-two Republican National Convention delegates today and, in a surprise move, instructed them to vote for the nomination of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio until he released them.

ABILENE, Kan., June 7. -- May be General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower has achieved a political triumph this week and maybe he hasn't -- it's too early to know. But he achieved a personal transition from military to political life that is little short of startling.
Whenever the Communists put up a propaganda poster in France, before the paste is dry there usually appears across it a large sticker with one word, "mensonges! [lies!]."

PARIS, June 7 -- Ratification by the French Parliament of the Contractual Agreement with the Bonn republic and the treaty for the European Defense Community may not be easy or rapid because neither of the twin treaties evokes great enthusiasm in France.

Alexander S. Panyushkin, who retires as Soviet Ambassador to this country, does not outwardly resemble Georgi N. Zarubin, who is coming here to replace him. For one thing, Mr. Panyushkin wears glasses and Mr. Zarubin, on the evidence of his latest picture, does not.

Outstanding among the many important highway improvements which will make driving easier for motor vacationists this summer is the Chesapeake Bay Bridge, scheduled to open July 1. On the direct route from this city to the south, it will have the advantage of by-passing Baltimore and its congested traffic.

IN this sequel to "The Grand Wide Way," Maeve Lassiter, daughter of an old West of Ireland family, is just 18 and showing her age. She decides to leave off playing the part of a wild, delightful child and to assume the responsibilities of her position.
SCHEVENINGEN, the Netherlands, June 7 -- North Sea air seems to agree with Iranian Premier Mohammed Mossadegh.

This year's Presidential campaign will differ from all others that have preceded it in that television will take the voter everywhere, and put him face to face with the candidate. It is worth while, in technological as well as political interest, to pin-point the moment when TV became a major instrument of national politics.
CINCINNATI, June 7 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft took his campaign for the Republican nomination for the Presidency to his home city today.

THE first American to win the first prize in a great international musical competition, is 24-year-old Leon Fleisher of San Francisco, "Premier Laureat" of the Queen Elisabeth of Belgium International Musical Competition of 1952, which is today the most important and admirably conducted musical contest in the world.

PROPERLY, this book is not about Nijinsky but about his wife Romola. The supreme dancer, the Nijinsky of the great legend, died in 1919, and there lingered on for some thirty years a submerged mind, an aging child, capable only at his best moments of partial understanding.

Flax -- plain old-fashioned flax -- comes to bloom now in fortunate corners of fortunate gardens; and if there is a more beautiful floral blue than that of a flax flower one hour after sunrise nobody has mentioned it. Forget-me-nots, bluets, even spiderwort, cannot match it.

Malcolm Ross in "The Need -- and the Chance -- for Equality" (May 25) referred to the commitment of the Army to a policy of gradual, complete racial integration. I should like to offer the following information on this point:

The election of Arthur B. Foye, the head of the Accountants Club of America, as president of the New York University Alumni Federation was announced yesterday. He succeeds Lawrence Fertig, who heads Lawrence Fertig Co., Inc., advertising agency.

JERUSALEM, June 7 (AP) -- The Palestine Mixed Armistice Commission blamed Jordan and, incidentally, Israel today for shooting incidents that have caused concern along the Jordanian-Israeli frontier during the last week.

INTO his account of the life and adventures of John Bonwell the author has packed a liberal portion of the romance of the early Ohio-Kentucky frontier. John migrates from Virginia in 1818 through southwestern Ohio looking for Augusta, Ky., some fifty miles upriver from Cincinnati. On the way he rescues a fellow-traveler from drowning and picks out his bride.
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- An expanding harvest in the southwest, coupled with some moisture in North Dakota, sent wheat prices lower on the Board of Trade today.

MOST of us -- especially if we are in the newspaper business -- know the people this new Anti-Defamation League report is about. Some of us may have had the misfortune to get on their mailing lists. Some Americans -- let us not say "some of us" in this allusion -- help pay their bills, for the profession of troublemaking is profitable.

CONCORD, N. H. -- Mount Agassiz, a famous tourist attraction of the last century, will be brought back into New Hampshire's travel picture this summer. The peak near Bethlehem has been freshened up by a new road to the summit, a reconstructed observation tower and new cabin colony, and is expected once again to draw many visitors looking for the easy way to a fine view.

HARTFORD -- The visitor to Connecticut this summer should note an increase in size of the welcome mat, a possible decrease in the cost of accommodations, and a stepped-up schedule of special events designed to appeal to vacationists.

AUGUSTA, Me. -- On the premise that the old adage about the connection between a man's stomach and his heart can be applied to tourists of both sexes and all ages, the summer season in Maine places special emphasis on its food specialties.
NEW DELHI, India, June 7 -Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru strongly condemned today the "political activities" of Christian missionaries among some sections of the Indian tribal population.

In an attempt to win summer vacation travelers away from automobiles, buses and planes, the New York Central and Chesapeake Ohio intend to introduce a special family-fare plan for coach travel over all of their lines, beginning June 25 and continuing until Oct. 22.

THE beaver, Busby, and Jerry, the boy, were both friendly creatures. They met over a trap fastened to Busby's leg which Jerry removed. Busby made a fine companion and pet, but the neighbors didn't entirely agree.
Short-term prospects for Japanese business are good, Shigeo Matsumoto, New York manager for the Bank of Japan, said in an interview here yesterday. For the long pull, anybody's guess is valid.

MANILA, June 7 -- Defense Secretary Ramon Magsaysay, the man responsible for putting the Communist-led rebellion in the Philippines under control, departed today by plane on a month's journey to the United States and Mexico.

HURLEY, N. Y. -- Thirteen stone houses dating from Dutch Colonial and pre-Revolutionary times line the main street of this village. In near-by New Paltz five stone houses in a single street look almost the same as when they were built by French Huguenot refugees between the years 1698 and 1720.

Events in the long steel dispute, such as voiding of the Government's seizure of the industry and the calling of another strike, created only a mild reaction in financial markets last week. Stocks moved uncertainly after the Supreme Court decision was announced, but turned firmer in mid-week under the leadership of rail and steel shares.

RESTRAINED showmanship is more important to a television boxing commentator than a great knowledge of the art of fisticuffs, according to Jimmy Powers, who reports on the Friday evening fights presented by the N. B. C.-TV network. The duller the fight, the more showmanship required by the commentator, he says.
Brooklyn, College will confer degrees and diplomas on the 2,077 members of its second largest graduating class at 5 P. M. next Sunday.

The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad has increased its order with the Bethlehem Steel Company's Staten Island shipyard by twenty freight barges and three scows, lifting the total to sixty-three vessels, comprising thirty barges and thirty-three scows.

The Yankees, as a rule, do not get too many nuns where Allie Reynolds is their pitcher. By that same rule, however, Reynolds does not need too many. As on yesterday at the stadium, when the ace right hander, handed two runs by his mates, made them suffice for a 2-1 victory over the Browns.

BACK in the far distant past, when Jersey Joe Walcott was a promising young heavyweight, he knocked out a certain Phil Johnson in the third round. Just a couple of years ago, when Jersey Joe Walcott was a promising old heavyweight, he knocked out Harold Johnson in the third round. Harold Johnson is Phil Johnson's son.

PROVIDENCE, R. I. -- Rhode Island citizens preparing to welcome summer visitors are receiving some help this year from a new agency. The Recreation Bureau of the Rhode Island Development Council has been set up to deal with vacation aspects of the state in an effort to attract a larger proportion of the record throngs expected to visit New England this summer.

DALLAS, June 7 (AP) -- The world series of the links -- the fifty-second United States Golf Association open tornament -- goes on here next week with two questions foremost: (1) Can Ben Hogan become the first man to win four championships in four tries?

HELSINKI -- A short six weeks from now the Fifteenth Olympic Games will open, when this prim little capital on the shore of the Gulf of Finland will become the rendezvous for champion athletes and sports enthusiasts from all over the world.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 7 -Projects to a value of $137,000,000 have been organized here by Brazil and the United States Economic Development Commission as a means to bolster the Brazilian economy.

An assortment of men, once referred to as stock market letter writers -- men who pounded away at typewriters in the most obscure corners of brokerage, investment or banking establishments -now forecast with considerable accuracy the course of price trends in securities.

Orders were placed in quantity last week as many ready-to-wear markets opened here, resident buying offices reported. More lines will open this week and, though many buyers were in the markets, even more are expected this week. Despite the good activity many stores plan to have their buyers return to the market several times rather than buy too far ahead.

Herbert Mitgang's "Warren Wins -- in Oberlin" (May 11) was especially interesting to me. On Saturday, May 10, I took part in a similar activity on the campus of George Pepperdine College in Los Angeles.

Degrees will be conferred on 1,200 graduates at the commencement exercises of St. John's University next Sunday at 4 P. M. in the Second Corps Artillery Armory, Brooklyn. Dr. John F. Brosnan, a member of the State Board of Regents, will speak.

MORE rodeos then ever before have already been announced for this summer. Sponsors of at least 270 of those to be held in the Western states and Canada have made known the exact dates on which they expect to stage shows between now and the end of next October.
The following is the way the Republican and Democratic lineups for the Presidential nominating conventions stood last night for leading candidates:

The Second International Congress for Epigraphy met in Paris to take stock of the progress made in the reconstruction of the ancient world of the Greeks and Romans shortly before the gathering of foreign ministers working for the reconstruction of the modern world.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Still another group of Congressional investigators tested their fledging wings this week -- and "wings" is the proper word because the inquiry is into the morals of radio and television programming. As far as sin is concerned, the investigators will be on the side of the angels.

VIENNA, June 7 (UP) -- Walter Dowling, acting United States High Commissioner, released today the text of a note sent to Soviet authorities in which he protested the buzzing by two Russian jets of a plane carrying High Commissioner Walter J. Donnelly.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., June 7 --President Truman derided today Senator Robert A. Taft's charge that this country's air power had been allowed to deteriorate and asserted that the goal of ninety-five wings would be met on schedule within two months.

SPAIN issued two stamps for the "XXXV Congreso Eucaristico Internacional" (Thirty-fifth International Eucharistic Congress) at Barcelona May 25 through June 1. On 90-centimos maroon is shown a feminine figure but with no enlightening inscription.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Eikichi Araki, Japan's first Ambassador to the United States since World War II, arrived today with a pledge to "promote and strengthen the mutual understanding and goodwill between our two great countries."

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., June 7 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio won South Dakota's fourteen Republican National Convention delegates from General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower by a 613-vote margin, a compilation of official county tabulations of the state's 1,950 precincts in Tuesday's balloting showed tonight.

Laszlo Halasz, who is best known here as an operatic conductor, was heard as a symphonic leader late yesterday afternoon at the Belasco Theatre, where he directed the N. B. C. Symphony in the first of a series of three concerts he will lead on consecutive Saturdays.

TICONDEROGA, N. Y. -- When a modern impersonator of Col. Ethan Allen led his Green Mountain Boys into the enclosure at Fort Ticonderoga on may 10, 1952, and demanded from the "surprised" British commandant, Captain Delaplace, the surrender of the fort "in the name of the Great Jehovah and the Continental Congress," it marked the 177th anniversary of that historic capture and also the opening of the forty-fourth season of the Fort Ticonderoga Museum.

CONSIDERING the state of confusion and anxiety in which many people in this country appear to be over the menace of communism and of Communist agents in our midst, it would be fine if the motion pictures could in some way help clarify the realties of the situation and the true extent of the domestic peril.

THIS is a travel book, but not the kind in which the author is almost devoured by angry lions and saved only through the timely intervention of Bongo, the faithful native bearer. H. R. H. Prince William of Sweden, who used to explore darkest Africa with gun and camera, has written that kind of book, too -- "Among Pygmies and Gorillas," "Roaring Bones" -- but the present volume is on the quieter side.

BIRMINGHAM, England, June 7 (AP) -- Dick Savitt of Orange, N. J., the Wimbledon champion, battled through two stiff sets today to defeat Straight Clark of Pasadena, Calif., in the men's singles final of the Priory lawn tennis tournament. The scores were 9 -- 7, 6 -- 4.

FOR many a child summer's a time to look, to ponder and to ask about the world around us. What bird is that? What can I feed a toad? If there's an adult around who knows any nature lore he's useful and welcome.

NEWARK -- New Jersey's popular mountain and lake regions, already well dotted with motels and cabin courts, now have two new and modern hotels to offer an expected record influx of summertime visitors.

IN the morning, it should rain, so you can happily stay indoors and write verse. In the afternoon, shine, so you can bathe, or walk, or take a bus to the nearest picturesque. In the evening, cold enough to sit by an open fire, with a good detective story for roughage. There you have the three requisites of a happy vacation: brainpan, deadpan, warming pan.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 7 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm's A Gleam captured the $25,000 Hollywood Oaks at a mile and one-sixteenth today, with Louis B. Mayer's Princess Lygia second and Tonga, recent winner of the Sea Breeze Stakes, third at Hollywood Park.

PARIS, June 7 -- "Malleus Maleficarum," a fifteenth-century handbook of the Inquisition, defined five categories of heretics upon whom sentence should be passed. Of those the second was "one who hath confessed to heresy but is relapsed, albeit now penitent."

Mental health is dependent upon the extent of awareness a person has attained in his relationship with his fellow beings and the feeling of security with which he is able to meet such awareness, Dr. Clarence P. Oberndorf, noted psychiatrist, declared yesterday.

A 25-year-old woman, believed to be a Hawaiian dancer, committed suicide yesterday by inhaling gas from a kitchen stove in her ground-floor Manhattan apartment, the police reported, and the escaping fumes probably overcame fatally a 60-year-old woman who occupied the apartment directly above.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 7 -- There can be no return to normal in these revolutionary times, Dr. Lewis Webster Jones, newly installed president, told 1,809 graduates at Rutgers University today.

BOSTON -- Massachusetts vacations, expected this season to surpass previous marks, may be likened to enjoying a nine-room house, each offering a different vista from appropriate picture windows. Moving east from the New York State line, the visitor progressively enters the Berkshire Hills "room," thence Pioneer Valley, Central Massachusetts, historic Boston, the North and South Shores, Cape Cod and the two principal vacation islands of Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket.

Vito Marcantonio, chairman of the National Campaign Committee of the Progressive party, announced yesterday the tentative program of the party's national convention. The sessions will be held in the Ashland Auditorium in Chicago on July 4 and 5.

SOONER or later borderline cases were bound to crop up in the fantasy field, and here is an almost perfect example, treading the hairline that separates fantasy from science fiction. In the same fashion, it negotiates the division between suspense for shock effect and writing whose purpose is the more literate one of dealing with human character and emotion.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., June 7 -- W. Averell Harriman, Director for Mutual Security, carried his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination into central New York today in an eighteen-hour whirlwind tour of three major upstate cities.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- A new method of feeding growth-stimulating antibiotics to baby pigs by implanting a tiny pellet under the skin has been announced by the animal nutrition division of Commercial Solvents Corporation, Terre Haute, Ind.

PORTLAND, Me. -- Re-enactment of historic events and customs will highlight anniversary celebrations in two Maine communities in July. The Town of York, just over the line from New Hampshire, will observe its tercentenary the week of July 20.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 7 -- The Democrats of this state, who will hold their biennial state convention in this city next Friday and Saturday, will pledge their sixteen National Convention votes under a unit rule to support Senator Brien McMahon for President.

INSPIRED by the interest awakened by Charles Laughton and company with Shaw's "Don Juan in Hell" in America, our Mr. J. B. Priestley made up his lively and experimental mind to see if he could not do something on similar lines.

MARINE aviation was, as Robert Sherrod's definitive history makes plain, a casualty of the improvised campaigns in the Solomon Islands. Into the defense of the Guadalcanal beachhead the Navy put everything it had, and a major part of its ready aviation force was a few squadrons of Marine fliers.

ALTHOUGH the consensus seems to be that the American National Theatre and Academy's play -- series under the supervision of Robert Whitehead has been one of the recent season's healthier aspects -witness for instance, this morning's praise piece by the colleague on the left -- there is no certainty at the moment that there either will be another play series this coming campaign, or that Mr. Whitehead will be at the helm.

Columbia University is discussing with the United States Atomic Energy Commission construction of a nuclear reactor for the study of atomic energy on the campus, a faculty member said last night. Formal application for uranium, which is a Federal monopoly controlled by the A. E. C., or for approval of the installation has not yet been made.

ST. LOUIS, June 7 (AP) -- Gran Hamner, stripped of his club captaincy after an early-morning team chastisement by Owner Bob Carpenter, tonight belted an eighth-inning homer to give the Phillies a 4-3 victory over the Cardinals, breaking a five-game losing streak.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (UP) -Senate Commerce Committee sources disclosed a possible solution today to the problem of getting the United States started in developing jet passenger planes.

MEMBERS of the Village Camera Club and their guests received a practical, miniature course in picture-story shooting last week when Frank J. Scherschel judged and commented on the club's picture-story contest. The assistant picture editor of Life used the entries exhibited on the club's walls to demonstrate the desirable elements that any effective picture story should possess.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -The Government has decided to lower down-payment requirements on new houses Monday, informed officials reported tonight.

THOUGH the day is almost gone when the bride's family would pay $1,500 for a wedding cake six feet high, the fact remains that New York City's bakers still originate creditable creations for many occasions.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 -- The smashing victory of Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee over a "phantom" slate of Democratic National Convention delegate candidates headed nominally by Edmund G. (Pat) Brown, State Attorney General, in last Tuesday's Presidential primary election in California is widely interpreted as resting on two bases.

PURCHASE, N. Y. June 7 -- The drama of Morris and Essex was re-enacted today at the Greenwich Kennel Club show with a different result. Best in show went to the Doberman pinscher, Mr. and Mrs., Len Carey's Ch. Rancho Dobe's Storm, and the wire-haired foxterrier that had taken the top award at Madison a fortnight ago was among the beaten.

I was so moved by Robert Trumbull's article, "Where Men Starve and No Birds Sing" (May 18) on the famine conditions in Madras, India, that I will donate $1,000 to send CARE packages to the hunger victims there, if other readers will donate enough to match that amount.

MONTPELIER, Vt. -- The summer people are already beginning to arrive. They seem to be coming early this year, perhaps in response to Vermont's drive to get people to come in June and September, instead of crowding into July and August.

A new way of making sandpaper, which holds important implications for industry, has been worked out. Under a method just adopted by a major manufacturer, coated abrasives are being made not only with the help of radioisotopes, by-products of atomic fission, but also with the assistance of industry's newest wonder child -- automation, the science of fully automatic controls.

THERE'S a caddy convention in Texas this week. It's the Fifty-second National Open Golf Championship, at the Northwood Country Club, in Dallas, starting next Thursday, when about two hundred of the world's best golfers drive from the first tee. They are likely to listen to the boy at their elbow, because most of them are former caddies themselves.
VIENNA, June 7 (UP) -- Czech Premier Antonin Zapotocky said today that Communist Czechoslovakia was suffering a "despertate" coal shortage and that its state farms had "completely failed."

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., June 7 -- With a real breeze bulging their lofty canvas, the fleet of sizable sailing craft, on the New York Yacht Club's first racing run of the year just about poured in here today.

PUSAN, Korea, June 7 (AP) -- An explosive murder case that helped to touch off South Korea's current political crisis went to trial today before a military tribunal here.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The taxpayer provides Government money, Congress appropriates it and the executive agencies spend it. After that it becomes the job of the General Accounting Office to make sure that it is spent lagally and efficiently so that the taxpayer gets his money's worth.
READING, Pa., June 7 (UP) -- Betsy Rawls of Austin, Tex., fired a par-72 today for a two-day total of 149 that tied her with Patty Berg for the lead in the Women's Eastern open golf tournament.

Modern religious leaders have failed to impress youth because of their laxity in taking stands on public issues, declared Rabbi Manuel Saltzman in his sermon yesterday morning at Temple Ansche Chesed, 100th Street and West End Avenue.

ROME, June 7 -- Pope Pius, now almost completely recovered from a slight attack of influenza he suffered three days ago, received today Cardinal Spellman of New York and the American pilgrims who had participated in the Eucharistic Congress at Barcelona, Spain.

Dr. George H. Gartlan, director of music for the Board of Education, who will retire at the end of this month after forty-eight years in the city's public school system, was guest of honor at a testimonial luncheon attended by 650 persons yesterday at the Pierre Hotel.

BRAZZAVILLE, French Equatorial Africa, May 19 (By Airmail) -- This federation of four Central African territories, which, through long neglect, used to be known as the Cinderella of the French Empire, is today undergoing a profound transformation.
ESTES PARK, Colo., June 7 (UP) -- The National Ski Association concluded its forty-fourth annual convention today after electing officers and selecting sites for the 1953 national ski championships.

TOKYO, June 7 -- An ugly and potentially dangerous political storm blew up this week in war-torn Korea, then seemed to calm down again, at least temporarily, as the Western nations who represent the defense of the Republic against the Communist invasion -the United States, Britain and Australia -- tried to pour some oil on the troubled waters.

An experimental electric wrist watch has been made which has no mainspring -- nothing but a battery and a capsule-size motor that delivers power at a constant rate. The Elgin Watch Company has built such a watch in this country and the Lip Watch Company in France.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 7 -- A firmer and more confident approach to contemporary life was the chief theme at the three-day meeting of the North Atlantic Regional Conference of the American Association of University Women, which ended today.

In a week or two, the New York auction galleries will suspend their usual activities for the summer except for sporadic sales. This week there will still be normal business in most of the galleries.

THE summer rush of air tourists has already started, and the airlines hope and expect that this season will be the heaviest in the history of commercial air transport. The lines say the rush started earlier than usual, and was complicated by the strike in the petroleum industry and the resultant government-ordered gasoline restrictions that forced cancellation of many flights.

MYSTIC, Conn. -- Among the few major tourist attraction on the eastern coast where a considerable number of visitors arrive by sea is Mystic Seaport, the seventeen-acre waterfront development here where the romantic age of the clipper ship is preserved.

Along the battlefront in Korea there was little action last week, even as measured in terms of the ten-month military lull. In the truce tents at Panmunjom there was another static week largely devoted to reiterations of long-established positions.

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange registered net gains of 28 to 84 points last week, with the near-by July delivery scoring the best advance. In the preceding week, when the July position also led, the market rose 44 to 82 points.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 7 (AP) -- James Webb, La Salle College's newly crowned I. C. 4-A high jump champion, turned in the nation's best hop, step and jump mark of the season today when he hit 49 feet 2 1/2 inches.

Many New Yorkers have been intrigued several months by a column entitled "Looking Backward," appearing in Willoughby Camera Store advertisements. The column, Store advertisements. THE Marines who killed efficiently during the Pacific War were not always skilled at handling the surrendered enemy. Lieutenant Rossi could control neither his men nor the 5,000 Okinawan civilians and Japanese soldiers who hid among them in the stockade on an unidentified island (presumably in the Ryukyu chain).

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP) -- Lefty Chuck Stobbs, pitching for the second day in a row, hurled a one-hit ball game for six innings in relief today to gain his second victory as the White Sox beat the Senators, 6 to 3.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N. Y., June 8 -- President Truman, in a message to Brith Abraham, the largest Jewish fraternal organization in the country, declared today that "we are determined to protect ourselves from aggression and know that no nation is strong enough to do so alone."

Poultry producers are caught between higher prices for feed and lower returns on broilers, trade sources said last week. As the cost of the ingredients of feedstuffs rise, prices inch up. However, the consumer demand for chickens has slackened and the supply has increased, bringing poultry prices down.
PARIS, June 8 -- In his first notable public comment on foreign relations, Premier Antoine Pinay said today that France sought "a pacific Europe" but wanted guarantees against the perils involved.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 8 -- The Greek cruiser Elli, with King Paul and Queen Frederika aboard, steamed up the Dardanelles today escorted by the Greek destroyer Navarinon and by Turkish naval craft and anchored in the Bosporus.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 8 -- As United States spokesman in the Commission on Human Rights, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt issued a statement tonight clarifying the protection sought for the rights of individual states, as distinct from federal governments, in a clause proposed for inclusion in the two covenants on human rights now in preparation.
The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, preaching his last sermon before vacation at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, said yesterday morning:

The new Holland-America liner Maasdam, which, like her sister ship, the Ryndam, is designed to provide luxury accommodations at austerity prices, will enter North Atlantic service six weeks sooner than was originally planned. The vessel, which is being rushed to completion, thus will he able to make an extra round trip in the current season.

The Altro Work Shops, Inc., is a garment factory in the Bronx where men and women convalescing from tuberculosis and cardiac ailments have an opportunity to continue work habits so they may lead useful lives despite their handicaps. Now celebrating its thirty-seventh year as a non-profit, non-sectarian organization, Altro expects shortly to break ground for a $300,000 building that will accommodate additional working-patients.

An experimental summer exhibition of great paintings has been arranged by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which will display fifty master works at Hofstra College, Hempstead, L. I., between June 29 and Labor Day.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 24 (By Airmail) -- No observers of the current electoral campaign here can fail to conclude that Kenya, for all her material prosperity, is and will probably continue to be vexed by politics and sorely afflicted with racial antagonism.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Administration backers in the Senate worked out a new proposal over the week-end to save the Government's control program over scarce materials, which they feared would be destroyed under legislation approved in the Senate last week.
The New York art season is continuing later than in former years with quite a number of group and one-man shows on the calendar this week.

Heroism and merit awards announced yesterday by the Fire Department disclosed that two firemen had won honor medals for their work at a single fire last year -- the blaze that occurred on Jan. 16, 1951, at 32 Spruce Street. One of the two medals was the department's top award.

A five-hour session in the fourth game of the match between Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Svetozar Gligoric of Belgrade at the Manhattan Chess Club, yesterday, failed to produce a definite decision. An adjournment was taken after forty-four moves had been recorded.

Arnold J. Toynbee should be happy about the conference on "Living in Industrial Civilization" held in Corning, N. Y., about a year ago. The ninety-five educators, editors, artists, architects, industrialists and ethnologists who gathered there (for what must have been a college "bicker session" on a stratospheric, level) appear to have agreed that "our conflicts lead to our dynamic way of life."

CHICAGO, June 8 (UP) -- Sam Jethroe's grand slam blow and a three-run homer by Sibbi Sisti gave Ernie Johnson a 7-to-6 victory over Chicago in his first start today as the Braves split a doubleheader before 38,514 fans.

CINCINNATI, June 8 -- The Dodgers were in a gay mood as they headed for St. Louis tonight, and with plenty of reason. Today they downed the Reds twice, 11 -- 7 and 10 -- 4, for a four-game sweep and a four-and-a-half-game lead over the second-place Giants.

In an effort to save taxpayers as much as possible of the $6,000,000 annually that it costs to support the families of 4,000 incapacitated fathers, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy has called for an all-out joint drive by his department and private welfare agencies to rehabilitate non-working fathers.

Dolores Dwyer and Mrs. Nancy Phillips of the German-American A. C. were double winners during the Metropolitan A. A. U. senior women's outdoor track and field championships at Victory Field, Forest Park, Queens, yesterday.

Bishop Loughlin, which had dominated the meet for years until 1950, when Cardinal Hayes took over, returned to the team throne yesterday in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Assocition track and field championships on Randalls Island.
The Rev. Dr. Elfan Rees, adviser on refugee affairs to the World Council of Churches, declared in a sermon yesterday morning that "you and I are living in the era of the greatest human need."
Thirteen deacons were ordained yesterday at the 11 A. M. service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, June 8 -- The Allied command of this prisoner-of-war island drafted final plans today for the break-up of prisoner compounds early of week on a showdown basis of "maximum force against maximum resistance."

The new collection of furniture designed by Klaus Grabe is distinguished by a group of simple chests, executed in a handsome polished walnut. The furniture is available at the Grabe showroom, 719 Lexington Avenue.

GEORGE BOTHNER wrestles every day just to keep fit. There are probably quite a few men who wrestle every day just to keep fit. But George Bothner passed his eighty-fifth birthday last Thursday, which makes him a most extraordinary octogenarian.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 8 -- Thirty young scholars showing "marked promise for the teaching profession and possessing the highest qualities of intellect, personality and character" have won national Woodrow Wilson Fellowships for a year of graduate study.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- Free profit taking following the substantial upturns from the low points of a few weeks ago, together with fairly heavy hedge sales, and a slower demand, resulted in a sharp recession in lard prices last week. For the time being at least the market broke away from the influence of the vegetable oils, which continued to hold strong.

On behalf of the British Government Lord Alexander and his associates are to begin at once a first-hand examination of the situation in Korea. They will put themselves in a position to make an authoritative report to their Government and to the Commons, and to answer some types of criticism that have been uninformed and irresponsible.

PARIS, June 8 (UP) -- Billy Maxwell, 22-year-old United States amateur champion from Odessa, Tex., and 41-year-old Dick Chapman of Pinehurst, N. C., reached the final round of the French amateur golf tournament today.

BROWNSVILLE, Tex., June 8 (AP) -- Two men who flew a four-engine DC-4 transport approximately 1,640 miles from Oakland, Calif., and landed here said they did it to protect their interest in the plane.

PITTSBURGH, June 8 -- Branch Rickey, who through the medium of his Pirates runs a sort of clinic here for ailing ball clubs, was able to pronounce the Giants today as absolutely cured. Leo Durocher's Polo Grounders appeared completely freed of their recent miseries as they bashed the Corsairs for their second straight victory to capture the series finale, 9 to 1.
MEXICO CITY, June 8 -- Pemex, Mexico's nationalized petroleum company, has struck a gas gusher in the State of Vera Cruz which it considers is an almost certain indication of a rich new oil field.
SEATTLE, June 8 (AP) -- Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., defeated Herbie Flam of Los Angeles, 7 -- 5, 8 -- 6, 7 -- 5, today in the final of the national hard court championship.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 8 -- Combining a weather thrash and a practically lifeless drift, Roderick Stephens Jr., at the tiller of his blue-hulled sloop Mustang, won the two runs of the New York Yacht Club out to Port Jefferson and back.
The Barbours, who comprise the members of "One Man's Family," merit every sympathy this morning. Even when it doesn't rain over the week-end, they have only confusion indoors.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 8 -- Mrs. Rose Isaacs of New York, who headed a delegation of four vice presidents of the American Women's League for Israel to study proposals for new projects in this country, said today the delegation would recommend enlargement of the league's hostel for girls in Jerusalem.
TOKYO, Monday, June 9 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,275, for Sunday's operations:

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, June 9 (AP) -- Dug-in Allied troops again repulsed today determined Chinese Communists who have been trying since Saturday to regain a hill position they lost on the western front near Chorwon.

Trustees of Talladega College in Alabama settled a three-year intramural squabble at the liberal arts biracial college by dismissing the entire administration, including Dr. A. D. Beittel, the college president, it was announced yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 8 (AP) -- Yugoslavia asserted in her press today that the Soviet Union was organizing a tightly unified Eastern European military machine to counter the growing forces of the West's North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
READING, Pa., June 8 (UP) -- Betsy Rawls, the national open champion, won the women's Eastern open golf tournament today by defeating Patty Berg in the last nine holes at the Berkshire Country Club.

" NOT marble, nor the gilded monuments Of princes, shall outlive this powerful rime," wrote Shakespeare, putting in a nutshell his confidence in the immortality of his literary genius. Thousands of lesser writers have thought as highly of their own works, but have lacked Shakespeare's frankness in appraising their merits. The peaks of literature may endure forever, but the average book is only a little less ephemeral than the average magazine or newspaper.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (UP) -- Bobby Shantz became the first major league pitcher to win ten games today when he hurled the Athletics to a 12-4 victory over Cleveland in the first game of a double-header. The A's made it a sweep by beating Bob Feller, 11 -- 3, in the nightcap.

OLEAN, N. Y., June 8 -- Speaking at St. Bonaventure University's ninety-second commencement today, Dr. Carroll V. Newsom, associate commissioner of education of New York, told 350 graduates that "society has a right to expect the educated man to set the tone in every area of human activity."

BOONTON, N. J., June 8 -- Stanley Calder of Montclair came back to win the New Jersey amateur golf championship today by defeating Frank Kaminski, the 24-year-old public links player from Branch Brook, 3 and 2, in the thirty-six-hole final at The Knoll.

LOS ANGELES, June 8 (AP) -- In the 1860s, when an infant industry began squeezing the first drops of black gold from the earth, oil men found working conditions and oil towns rugged, wild and usually unpleasant.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 -- The life of the nineteenth century Hungarian pianist and composer, Franz Liszt, will be the subject of a Technicolor film from Columbia Pictures. Oscar Saul will write and produce "The Franz Liszt Story," which, the studio reports, will follow the pattern of music and biography set in its life of Chopin, "A Song to Remember."

Exactly ten and a half years ago last Saturday Secretary of State Hull faced two Japanese diplomats in his office in Washington. He kept them standing as he read the communication they had brought. Then he said to them -- Nomura and Kurusu: "In all my fifty years of public service I have never seen a document that was more crowded with infamous falsehoods and distortions."

BERLIN, June 8 -- A new British effort to negotiate a settlement of the various East-West differences over Berlin was expected tonight after Soviet troops and East German police had reportedly been withdrawn from all enclaves on the edge of West Berlin.

ARDMORE, Okla., June 8 (UP) -- Dave Douglas coasted to victory in the Ardmore Open golf tourney today to pick up $5,400, including $3,000 bonus money, with a 1 under par 279 that led the host pro, E. J. (Dutch) Harrison, by 2 strokes.

The need for supplementing pension benefits as a result of the higher cost of living is being recognized by corporations which are adopting various programs to assure employes of adequate retirement funds. "Thrift" plans are one of the latest means toward that ned and are gaining wider acceptance, particularly in the oil industry.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 8 -- Peg's Pride, from the Hutchinson Stables of New Rochelle, won five straight blues for twenty-five points and the grand championship of the Fairfield and Westchester Professional Horsemen's Association annual show today. Ridden throughout the competition by Nancy Clapp, Peg's Pride dominated the jumper events.
The danger of creeping corruption in the Government is as great a threat to our national security as is communism, Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, declared here last night.

Generalissimo Franco is still trying to induce the Catalans to forget that they are Catalans. The latest news tells us of the suppression of two magazines in the Catalan language and the arrest of some champions of Separatism. The Caudillo is in a long line of kings and dictators, all the way from Ferdinand the Catholic in the fifteenth century to Primo de Rivera in the Nineteen Twenties.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jun. 8 -- A. E. (Bill) Luders Jr., former champion in the division skippered his Surf home first today in the International Class test of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta conducted by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

American business men talk about the free enterprise system and then put shackles on the free enterprise of other friendly countries, Mrs. Perle Mesta, United States Minister to Luxem bourg, warned advertising executives yesterday. She addressed the forty-eighth annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America, a group that includes about a hundred advertising clubs, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The adult education season 1951-52 is drawing rapidly to a close after one of the most successful years since the system was instituted. In New York City alone, it is estimated by the New York Adult Education Council, almost 1,000,000 adults registered for classes given by the many adult education agencies.
ST. JAMES, L. I., June 8 -- A new helicopter that more nearly resembles a conventional plane than any rotary-wing aircraft flying in this country is undergoing a dual test flight program here.

Msgr. Cornelius J. Drew, pastor of St. Charles Borromeo's Roman Catholic Church, 213 West 141st Street, criticized yesterday the recent charge by Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, that private and parochial school education was harmful to "democratic unity."

COLOGNE, June 8 (AP) -- Peter Mueller was banned from the ring for life today after knocking down the referee in a championship bout last night. Mueller, who also tried to knock out the trainer of his winning opponent, Hans Stretz, the German middleweight champion, was barred by the League of German Professional Boxers.

BERLIN, June 8 (AP) -- Reinforcements of Soviet troop patrols and People's Police cut down today the flood of refugees attempting to escape into West Germany from communism's new frontier security belt along the Soviet zone. Thousands slipped through last week, eluding Communist patrols.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (UP) -- The Government reported today that the booming shipbuilding industry was having trouble finding skilled workers.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, June 8 (UP) -- Sir Gerald Templer, British High Commissioner for Malaya, said today that his crackdown on Malayan villages suspected of aiding Communist guerrillas had proved its worth.

Observance of the Sabbath is the keystone of Christianity, the Rev. Dr. Harold C. DeWindt told worshippers at the West-Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 86th Street in his sermon yesterday morning.

HOBOKEN, N. J., June 8 -- Dr. Jess H. Davis, president of Stevens Institue of Technology, predicted today that the country would look to engineers for the leadership needed to bring about lasting peace.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Sharp charges were exchanged by their supporters today as Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower entered the stretch drive in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination.

The sit-down work stoppage of 1,000 mechanics and cargo handlers employed by American Airlines at La Guardia Airport and New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, seemed to have ended yesterday when 95 per cent of the strikers were reported back at work at the 4 P. M. shift.

One hundred thousand building trades workers in this city will receive a general wage increase of 15 cents an hour, effective Aug. 1, under an agreement announced yesterday by the Building Trades Employers Association and the Building and Construction Trades Council, A. F. L.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 8 (UP) -- Bob Starr, who was told to quit going to two colleges at the same time, is leading a life of comparative leisure today, now that school is out.

JERUSALEM, June 8 (AP) -- All Israeli banknotes that were issued in August, 1948, as Anglo-Palestine banknotes will cease to be legal tender as of tomorrow, June 9, at noon. Holders of currency are permitted to exchange present...

MOSCOW, June 8 -- Soviet historians have undertaken another major reassessment of history, this time dealing with the Crimea and designed to eliminate "distortions," "obsolete and untrue propositions" and "mistaken views," principally concerning the respective roles of the Slavs and Tatars in that region.

PITTSBURGH, June 8 -- For the third time in two months the steel industry was shut down by a strike last week causing the ingot rate for the week to slide down to 30 per cent of rated capacity. This was a decline of 72 1/2 points from the week before.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., June 8 -- Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune, president of the American Congress of Negro Women, has agreed to accept a new invitation to speak at the Engle Street Junior High School at 8:15 P. M. on Monday, June 16.

MEDFORD, Mass., June 8 -- Highly skilled manpower, not money or physical resources, is the limiting factor in our progress Dr. Henry Chauncey, president of the Education Testing Services at Princeton, N. J., declared here this afternoon at the ninety-sixth commencement of Tufts College.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 8 -- Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University, told the university's graduating class at baccalaureate services here today that American education was growing "sicker" and that the "prognosis remains gloomy."

ST. LOUIS, June 8 (UP) -- Stan Musial hit his sixth home run of the season with two men on base in the first inning and the Cardinals held on despite a home-run spree by the Phillies to take the odd game of the series today, 5 -- 3.
RICHMOND, Va., June 8 (UP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey accused General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today of "trying to cover two sides of the fence" on some of the civil rights issues.

Take-home pay of executives has fallen since World War II, chiefly as a result of high taxes, rather than salary stabilization regulations. This state of affairs is reported by a number of companies among 121 manufacturers surveyed by the National Industrial Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period May 31 to June 6 are given in the appended tabulation:

Despite Mayor Impellitteri's refusal to attend Tammany Hall's $50-a-plate dinner tomorrow night at the Commodore Hotel, lest his presence be interpreted as approval of the leadership of Carmine G. DeSapio, a large attendance is expected.
Full-power speed tests for the largest and fastest liner ever built in this country will start today as the 52,000-ton passenger carrier United States goes to sea at Newport News, Va.

When the umpires and managers were convening at home plate before the start of the second game at the Stadium yesterday, the public address announcer informed the fans that the first game had been played under protest by the Browns.

ROME, June 8 -- Six hundred Americans who arrived in Rome Wednesday after having attended the Eucharistic Congress in Barcelona were present in St. Peter's basilica this afternoon when Pope Pius XII participated in religious ceremonies following the beatification this morning of Sister Maria Bertilla Boscardin.

BOSTON, June 8 (AP) -- The revamped Red Sox took both ends of a double-header by 5-2 scores from the last-place Tigers before 33,312 fans today to take first place in the hotly contested American League race.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 8 -- A 3 1/2-year-old English springer spaniel, Mrs. R. Gilman Smith's Ch. Melilotus Royal Oak, from Bethel, Conn., became best in show today in the annual event of the Longshore-Southport Kennel Club.

An exhibition of the work of two ceramicists, Miss Rose Krebs and Boris Chatman, is on view at the Rena Rosenthal Shop, 71 East Fifty-seventh Street. Vases, bowls, ashtrays and sculptured figures make up the large collection, many pieces of which have been displayed previously at craftsmen shows.

SEATTLE, June 8 (AP) -- Coast Guard headquarters here reported another SOS had been received today from the 329-foot lumber schooner Cynthia Olson, hard aground on the southern Oregon coast, after an attempt to free her had failed.

The proposed new zoning law is criticized in a report being sent today to the City Planning Commission, as harmful to the city's development, tending to increase traffic problems in areas where congestion already is greatest, and generally unworkable because of "ridiculous" administrative provisions.
Terry toppers in three smart versatile styles are brought to you today by Patterns of THE TIMES.

TOKYO, Monday, June 9 -- The Government-controlled Peiping radio charged this morning that United Nations delegates had created an "open provocation to break off the armistice talks" in Korea by walking out of a truce conference at Panmunjom.

If religion is to have significance for the young people of today, it should satisfy "not only the desire for safety, but also the spirit of adventure," the Rev. Dr. Louis W. Pitt, rector of the Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, told 1,000 seniors attending New York University's 120th baccalaureate services yesterday.

LONG BEACH, Calif., June 8 (AP) -- Sparkling triumphs by Billy Anderson in the 110-meter high hurdles, Mal Whitfield in the 800-meter run and Warren Druetzler in the 1,500-meter run today marked the finish of the two-day Armed Services track and field championships.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Steel wage negotiators, reported close to agreement, could not quite make it today and recessed their bargaining until 3 P. M. tomorrow after a continuous session of nearly five hours.

A special delivery postman took to the Brooklyn home of Msgr. Angelo R. Cioffi yesterday morning the two jeweled golden crowns that had been stolen eight nights before from the Roman Catholic Votive Shrine of Regina Pacis, of which Monsignor Cioffi is pastor.

MEXICO CITY, June 8 -- A bitter public quarrel has broken out between the Popular party of Vicente Lombardo Toledano and the Mexican Communists over their failure to put up a single candidate against Adolfo Ruiz Cortinez of the ruling Party of Revolutionary Institutions in the July 6 presidential election.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 8 -- A new approach to the question of the repatriation of prisoners of war, which has the Korean armistice talks deadlocked, has been offered to the United States by several leading United Nations delegates.

Vic Raschi accounted for this season's one-game strikeout high in the majors by fanning thirteen Browns in yesterday's second game at the Stadium. The home side won, 3 -- 0, behind the big right-hander's three-hit pitching and, coupled with Bob Kuzava's 5-2 victory in the opener, the Yankees rose to within a wafer's width of first place.

CANTON, N. Y., June 8 (UP) -- John Foster Dulles said today that the battle of the free world against communism could be won only by the action or individuals because "the prestige of human freedom cannot be increased by Government action."

Mayor Stanley W. Church of New Rochelle has asked Mayor Impellitteri to let him know what "precautions" will be taken "to prevent motorists who reside outside New York City from being continually stopped and harassed by the police for not displaying the local tax stamp."

HANOVER, N. H., June 8 -- The Western nations are prepared to talk with the Iron Curtain countries when those nations are ready to do so, Sir Oliver Franks, British Ambassador to the United States, said here today in an address at the 183d commencement exercises of Dartmouth College.

PUSAN, South Korea, Monday, June 9 (Reuters) -- President Syngman Rhee declared yesterday that Presidential elections by popular vote were his price for ending the feud between the South Korean National Assembly and his Administration.

A warning of a "fruitless victory," if we destroy communism only to discover that it has brought us nowhere, was delivered yesterday in a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Norris L. Tibbetts at the Riverside Church.

Harold Aks and his Interracial Chorus gave their annual Town Hall concert late yesterday afternoon. He conducted the 150-member ensemble in short pieces by Schuetz, traditional Hebrew and Negro pieces, Mozart's Missa Brevis in F and the first New York performance of Wallingfors Riegger's cantata, "In Certainty of Song."

After twenty-two and one-half hours on the air over a coast-to-coast video network, the fourth Milton Berle marathon to aid the Damon Runyon Memorial Fund for fighting cancer ended yesterday at 10:30 A. M. with pledges of more than $570,211.

For outstanding reporting on medical research and public health in the newspaper and magazine fields, respectively, Bob Considine, International News Service columnist, and Albert Q. Maisel, free lance writer, have won the Lasker Medical Journalism Awards for 1951.
Two men and a woman were arrested yesterday as alleged participants in a Bronx liquor store hold-up and a fourth suspect was booked for a Park Avenue apartment burglary.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Ambassador Alexander S. Panyushkin left here for New York today on the first stage of a journey home to Moscow and a new job.

An Indian cultural delegation, consisting of fourteen carefully selected members headed by Madame Pandit, sister of Prime Minister Nehru and former Ambassador to Washington, returned last Saturday from a six-week tour of Communist China. Their impressions, as reported yesterday by Robert Trumbull, THE TIMES' correspondent in New Delhi, are extremely interesting.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- Soybean featured trading in grains last week, sensational upturns in all deliveries reaching new high crop levels. The swing to July soybeans followed the strong close in the May delivery, traders in general jumping to the conclusion that the situation would be tighter in July than in May.

It is good news that the recent emergency appeal for funds made by the International Rescue Committee has resulted in donations of almost $85,000 to date. This is tangible evidence of widespread recognition that the refugees from Stalinist rule are our friends and allies, as deserving of our help as they are in need of it.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 8 -- Commencement exercises for 511 Hofstra College graduates were held here today at the school's athletic field.

British sterling showed to better advantage last week when absence of rumors and a reduced speculative interest revived buying by banks and commercials, lifting the pound for a fractional gain. London cables also evidenced improved sentiment abroad.

As everyone knows, we in this country are equipped with a standard set of stories for every standard American institution -- or perhaps one should say for every American institution as it has been standardized for story-telling purposes.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur was boomed tonight by leading backers of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio for the job of keynoting the Republican National Convention, whch opens here four weeks from tomorrow.

A British Overseas Airway plane took off last night from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, for London with a record passenger manifest for a four-engine plane of its type. Of its 108 passengers, sixty-five were children whose ages ranged from three months to eight years.

PARIS, June 8 -- The Foreign Office has just announced conclusion of a modus vivendi regarding French-German trade for the second half of 1952. It is generally believed this understanding will apply retroactively from April.

In Armenia it is boulghour, in Iraq burghul. But by whichever name, it is the cracked wheat used throughout the Near East as a nutty-flavored alternative to rice, as an extender for meat, a stuffing for poultry and in many other ways.

Children need a "spokesman" to work in their interests in the Library of Congress, Mrs. Frances Clarke Sayers says. Mrs. Sayers, who will retire on Oct. 1 from her post as superintendent of the Department of Work with Children at the New York Public Library, has just completed a study of the organization of children's books in the Washington collection.

Now that Presidential candidates are shifting their campaigns into high gear, the advertising world is beginning a concentrated drive to cure millions of people in this country of their habit of not voting. Under the slogan "Vote as You Please, But VOTE!", the Advertising Council, Inc., displayed for the first time at the annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday its new 28-page "Register and Vote" campaign guide.

On June 1 THE NEW YORK TIMES carried a dispatch reporting that the resigning chief of the State Department's Publications Branch had criticized a proposed change in the operations of our foreign information program. THE TIMES also reported that Dr. Wilson Compton, head of the International Information Administration, had termed those criticisms "preposterous" and had specifically denied that his administration "showed any tendency to eliminate publications of proved worth or to multiply bureaucratic procedures."

I know that the members of our clergy committee, cooperating with the Lewisohn Stadium concerts, all appreciate the editorial in THE TIMES on the importance of helping Mrs. Charles Guggenheimer and her associates raise the $100,000 necessary to insure the success of this summer's series.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 8 -- Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Chief of the Central Intelligence Agency and former Ambassador to the Soviet Union, said tonight that there was no cause for fear if the United States faced the Soviet threat with resolution and a readiness for extreme sacrifices.

CANTON, N. Y., June 8 -- This village, the seat of St. Lawrence County, geographically the largest in New York, today got its first hospital and first elevator. It also established a new pattern in hospital care.

TAIPEI, Formosa, June 8 -- The United States Seventh Fleet and United States Air Force fighters would defend Formosa should the Communists try to bomb it, Vice Admiral Joseph J. Clark, the Seventh Fleet's commander, said here today in an indirect warning to the Chinese Reds.

NEW DELHI, India, June 8 -- If the current trend of opinion here continues, the election of a sizable bloc of Communist to the Indian Parliament, forming the principal opposition to the Government of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, may turn out to be the worst thing that has happened to the Reds in this country since the party's founding.

Los ANGELES, June 8 -- Gov. Earl Warren, in a nation-wide television and radio broadcast today, discussed his candidacy for the Republican nomination for President. He said he would spurn "political manipulation" of delegates and would approach unpledged delegates "solely on the basis of my approach to the problems of American life as reflected in both our domestic and international situation."

The New York Athletic Club captured team laurels in a close battle with the New York Pioneer Club in the metropolitan junior Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships at Red Hook Stadium, Brooklyn, yesterday. The Winged Foot squad scored 93 5/6 points and the Pioneer Club had 90 2/3.

NEWARK, June 8 -- Northern New Jersey faces an unusually severe plague of mosquitos as a result of recent heavy rains and inadequate control of breeding spots, a survey indicated today. Essex County is likely to be hardest hit, with Union County a close second and Bergen County not so seriously affected.

The mystery of the Trinity, or union of three persons in one Godhead, is not contrary to reason but "above reason" and the "authority for accepting it comes from Christ Himself," Msgr. William T. Greene declared yesterday. Msgr. Greene, who is chairman of the music commission of the Archdiocese of New York, preached at the solemn mass of the Feast of the Holy Trinity in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Hope that "favorable action" to reopen Newark Airport for limited commercial flying would be voted by Commissioners of the Port of New York Authority at their regular meeting Thursday was expressed last night by Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the bistate agency.

If stockholders of Textron, Inc., approve the proposed acquisition of Lonsdale Company, the well-known Indian Head brand of cotton goods will have Lonsdale fabrics as a companion line for home-sewing distribution. It was learned yesterday, however, that plans call for continuation of the sale of Lonsdale fabrics to the cutting-up trades.

LONDON, June 8 -- The Royal Air Force abandoned tonight a search by British, United States, Turkish and Israeli planes for one of the Royal Air Force's most famous twins, Air Vice Marshal David Atcherley. He was missing on a flight in a jet Meteor from the Suez Canal zone where he commands a fighter group, to Nicosia, Cyprus.

Under the leadership of Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan the South African Parliament has now adopted, at the third reading, the measure that would make a parliamentary majority in the Union constitutionally supreme. Under this legislation there can be no such thing as "constitutionality."

CHICAGO, June 8 -- Trade in soybeans overshadowed the grain list in volume of trading last week, purchases of beans soaring to 94,229,000 bushels, up about 36,000,000 bushels from the previous week and more than double the transactions for the same week last year.

A benevolent sun and refreshing breezes gave the city yesterday its first fair Sunday in five weeks. With temperatures in the high seventies and low eighties and the humidity in the low thirties, thousands flocked to parks or strolled the principal avenues in a belated "Easter Parade."
Rabbi Maxwell L. Sacks' dedi-I cared yesterday the completed edi-I fice of the Jewish CommunityI Center of Bensonhurst, Twenty-I third .Avenue and SLeety-third Street, BrooklyrL

LONDON, June 8 -- Wide and distinctly wild fluctuations in foreign bond prices dominated the stock markets last week but despite these disturbing movements a modest rally has occurred in the last day or two in most other security groups.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, minister of Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, announced yesterday that he had withdrawn his name as a possible candidate for the office of Bishop

The fourth annual Music Under the Stars program, sponsored by the American Fund for Israel Institutions, took place on Saturday evening at Ebbets Field. The weather was perfect, the audience -- estimated by sponsors of the concert at 35,000 persons -- enthusiastic, and a sum of $125,000 was added to the American Fund's tenth campaign goal of $1,934,000 for the support of cultural, educational, traditional and social welfare institutions in Israel.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 8 -- The Government announced tonight an emergency measure to withdraw as a compulsory loan 10 per cent of all money in circulation here except bank accounts below 50 Israeli and banknotes of 1 denomination and below.

The fourth annual Music Under the Stars program, sponsored by the American Fund for Israel Institutions, took place on Saturday evening at Ebbets Field. The weather was perfect, the audience -- estimated by sponsors of the concert at 35,000 persons -- enthusiastic, and a sum of $125,000 was added to the American Fund's tenth campaign goal of $1,934,000 for the support of cultural, educational, traditional and social welfare institutions in Israel.

The bulk of Pennsylvania's seventy-vote delegation to the Republican National convention will defer choosing sides in the contest for the Presidential nomination until nearly the last minute, Gov. John S. Fine indicated yesterday.
