From a high-placed window in one of the hotels thereabouts the visiting fireman, a Proper Bostonian, had been looking down upon the Plaza. He said New Yorkers did not seem to appreciate what a fine square it was.
Five new films, including an importation from Italy, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
ST. LOUIS, June 9 -- Another one of those late-inning explosions tonight lifted the Dodgers to their eighth straight triumph as they beat the Cardinals, 6 -- 2, before 17,443 fans.

Northern States Power Company is offering its common shareholders rights to subscribe for 1,108,966 new shares of common stock at $10.50 a share at the rate of one new share for each ten held. The offer will expire on June 23. A banking syndicate of 100 members headed by Lehman Brothers and Riter Co. is underwriting the transaction.

It is a little upsetting to learn, with each new statement from the Census Bureau, that this nation is constantly becoming more urban. The last word we get is that 64 per cent of us are in fact urban and that consequently only 36 per cent of us are rural-farm or rural-non-farm.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 9 -- An attempt to "smoke out" the Presidential preferences of the 954 Westchester Republican county committeemen failed this afternoon at the committee's annual meeting for selecting candidates for regional offices. The meeting, held in the County Center, was attended by 500.

In a small, sun-filled basement room at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx young cardiac patients are kept quietly but happily occupied every Tuesday in a recently established playroom while they wait for periodic treatment and check-ups. The door remains open during these clinic visits so accompanying parents in an adjoining room can look in on the activities.
LONDON, June 9 (AP) -- Some of George Bernard Shaw's letters to the late Mrs. Patrick Campbell, the noted actress who was his great friend, will go on sale June 23.

ZURICH, June 9 -- Dr. A. Schaefer, general manager of the Union Bank of Switzerland, who returned to Zurich from the United States a few days ago, issued a report last week for private circulation among members of the International Banking Institute about his deliberations with Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

BALBOA, C. Z., June 9 -- Brig. Gen. John S. Seybold of the Army Engineers Corps assumed duties as Governor of the Panama Canal today, succeeding Brig. Gen. Francis K. Newcomer, retired. The new Governor also is president and a director of the Panama Canal Company, which handles the business and operations of the canal.

Uncertainty about American tariff changes, rather than the failure of Government and bank officials in Britain to free the necessary dollars, is one of the chief reasons why British companies do not do more advertising here.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., June 9 -- Bob Bailey and Pete Cassella of the home club tied at 31, 32 -- 63 with Jack Parker and Pete Burke, Cold Spring, for first place in the amaeur-pro tourney of the Long Island P. G. A. at the Brookville Club today.

The Columbia Export Company, importer and distributor of machine tools, has leased the new industrial building at 10-35 Forty-fourth Drive, Long Island City, Queens, in a transaction negotiated by Queens Industrials as broker. The building will be used as a warehouse and for the demonstration and servicing of equipment.
ABOARD THE UNITED STATES AT SEA, June 9 -- America's first superliner was at sea today for her initial full power speed run and her official acceptance trails.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, world-wide manufacturing and communications concern, reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $4,735,255 for the first three months of this year. This was equivalent to 66 cents a share on the common stock, and compares with $4,136,256, or 60 cents a share, a year ago. Gross income increased to $83,862,107 from $70,067,643.

Red-faced city officials admitted last night that, in making plans to impose the $5 and $10 automobile use tax, they had overlooked one detail -- application to the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles for permission to have the tax stamps affixed to windshields.

The strawberry harvest is approaching its peak in New Jersey. Shipments of the sweet red fruit that is a member of the rose family have begun to arrive from Long Island and the Hudson Valley. This month, while specimens from nearby predominate in local markets, the berries are at their most plentiful with largest quantities expected in a week or two.
Andrew W. Mulrain, Commissioner of Sanitation, urged departmental employes yesterday to refrain from banging garbage cans and talking loudly while making refuse collections.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Vice Admiral E. L. Cochrane, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, told Congress today it would be "a great tragedy" to lay up two new fast passenger vessels at this time because of conflicting opinions on Government construction subsidies.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 9 -- The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., today set Thursday noon as a deadline for an agreement that would stave off a tie-up of East Coast, Gulf and foreign flag ships in West Coast ports.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft's headquarters stirred up a sharp new debate with General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's backers today by charging that the general had made a "poor showing" in the delegate race since his return to this country.

The Court of General Sessions was told yesterday that in both 1948 and 1949 the number of tickets sold for the annual firemen's balls were more than double the capacity of Madison Square Garden, where the events were held.

BECKENHAM, Eng., June 9 -- The Kent tennis championships began today with Gardner Mulloy of Miami and Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge the leading American contenders in singles and Mulloy and Richard Savitt of Orange, N. J., heading the doubles draw.

It is a generally admitted fact that at times it is good to get away from home. Every now and then it is pleasant to leave the wash tub and the frying pan, the drawing board and the time clock, and to go away for a greater or a lesser time.

A fifty - inch - scale working model of the new superliner United States went through her "sea trials" yesterday in the model pool in Central Park at the same time that the big liner began her official full-power speed tests off Newport News, Va.

HONG KONG, June 9 -- Bishop Adolph Paschang described today how he had been beaten, bound and made to kneel on broken bricks last winter at Kongmoon, Kwangtung Province, in a third-degree procedure that finally netted the Chinese Communists 20,000 Hong Kong dollars (approximately $3,000).

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 9 -- Italy's administration of Somaliland was assailed before the United Nations today by the Philippine member of a three-man council set up to "aid and advise" the Italian authorities.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Down-payment requirements on new homes were eased by the Government today in the second recent relaxation of restraints on inflationary pressures imposed since the start of the Korean war.

The waste of lives and property caused by fire "becomes more disgraceful every year," A. H. S. Stead of Montreal, retiring president of the National Fire Protection Association, declared yesterday at the opening of its fifty-sixth annual five-day meeting.
PITTSBURGH, June 9 (AP) -- Jim Wilson hurled the Braves to a 3 to 2 victory over the Pirates tonight, giving up only five hits.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics reported tonight that a Navy test pilot had flown approximately fifteen miles above the earth to set a new world altitude record.

HAMILTON, N. Y., June 9 -- A stalemate between Russia and the West is the chief condition necessary to real peace, Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, told 270 graduates at Colgate University's 130th annual commencement here today.

BONN, Germany, June 9 -- It appeared tonight that the negotiations between West Germany and the state of Israel and the Jewish Conference on Material Claims would be resumed in The Hague around June 19. The Federal Government has worked out the "concrete" proposal demanded by Israel and the Jewish groups.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- The supreme court today reversed the conviction of three men under jail sentence in Seattle for illegally operating a radio transmitter in the Benjamin Franklin Hotel there.

Those ungainly brown objects on the grocers' counters yesterday were potatoes, and as the day went on some grocers feared they would need a campaign to re-introduce their reluctant customers to that edible old staple.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was quoted yesterday by Representative Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts as favoring a reduction of military expenditures to bring the Federal budget into balance. Such a stand places the general, now an active candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, in direct conflict with the Department of Defense and President Truman.

A lack of common understanding of the real facts about the Post Office and misinterpretation of postal accounting are two of the most important problems facing the magazine publishing business, according to Walter D. Fuller, chairman of the National Association of Magazine Publishers, Inc.
LONDON, June 9 (Reuters) -- Britain for the second time this year has made substantial cuts in the prices importers will be allowed to pay for pulp from Scandinavia.

American Communists have been taught to "wage a struggle" against the United States in case of a war with the Soviet Union, a witness testified yesterday at the trial here of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders.

As Secretary of State Dean Acheson disembarked at the National Airport, after spending a week at Bonn and in Paris, he was congratulated by President Harry Truman with the following: "* * * you have made a great contribution to the peace of the world."

BERLIN, Tuesday, June 10 -- The British lifted early today their blockade of the Soviet-controlled radio building in West Berlin, where several score Soviet soldiers and East Germans had been surrounded by British troops and barbed wire since last Tuesday.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 9 -- The Nibble Hanover filly, Lively Lady, on lease to Gay Acres Stable of Wooster, Ohio, and driven by Delvin Miller, scored a two and one-half length victory over David Johnston's Bewitch in the Old Country Trot for 2-year-olds at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Justices of the Supreme Court in an informal meeting in the court chamber this afternoon, presented gifts to Thomas E. Waggaman, the retiring marshal.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 9 -- William Goldbeck of Mount Kisco and Fred Wright of Leewood won the weekly pro-amateur best ball tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association over the Hampshire Country Club course today, with a 9 under par 31, 31 -- 62.

A big gamble is approaching a showdown in the Louisiana marshland. On its outcome hinges a considerable addition to the free world's supply of sulphur, the yellow mineral that is essential in the making of a host of products -- rubber, paper, chemicals, fertilizer and many others.
Communist Hungary is engaged in a determined effort to raise her output of aluminum and of bauxite, the raw material from which aluminum is made, the Budapest radio reveals.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The bitterly disputed McCarran-Walter Bill to revise and codify the country's immigration, naturalization land nationalization laws was returned from conference to the Senate and House of Representatives today for final passage and a possible veto.

VALLEY FIELD, Que., June 9 (Canadian Press) -- R. Kent Rowley, ousted Canadian director of the United Textile Workers of America, A. F. L., was in Jail today on charges of obstructing the police and of holding a meeting without a permit.

In view of the recent conflict in the State Department in connection with news and propaganda techniques, perhaps emphasis placed on promotion rather than mere defense would help create a better understanding of the American free-enterprise system.

HONG KONG, June 9 -- Field Marshal Earl Alexander, British Minister of Defense, arrived here by plane today en route to Tokyo and Korea for a first-hand look at the Korean situation. He declared the Korean truce talks had been "disappointing," but expressed the view there was still a chance for an armistice.

ALTHOUGH the bluefish have moved off - snore in most areas, they are still plentiful and large, and Captain Moss at Montauk reports that one of his parties took 109 fish, which certainly puts bluefishing right back in the 1935 class.

BONN, Germany, June 9 -- The treaty system that will rearm a sovereign West Germany within the framework of the Atlantic alliance faces its first legal challenge tomorrow in a political atmosphere that daily becomes more turbulent.
LONDON, June 9 (Reuters) -- England beat India in their first cricket test match by seven wickets with a day and a half to spare at Leeds today.
Price changes in commodity futures on the local markets were comparatively narrow yesterday in a moderate volume of trading.

The industry and labor members of the regional Wage Stabilization Board announced yesterday that they had sent to President Truman a letter urging him to name Arthur J. White, chairman of the local board, to the post of national chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board when the resignation of the present chairman, Nathan P. Feinsinger, becomes effective at the end of this month.

FOREST PARK, Pa., June 9 (UP) -- A C. I. O. official today charged than General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's stand on civil rights had placed him in the same camp with Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, "in opposing any effective action to stop discrimination."

KALIMPONG, India, June 9 -- Tibet's Panchen Lama, escorted by 1,000 Chinese Communist troops and a personal bodyguard of 500 soldiers, left Lhasa today for Shigatse, his spiritual home 140 miles to the westward, reports reaching India from Tibet said.

Five acres and a large stone dwelling on the fourteen-acre Oakledge estate on Pondfield and Oakledge Roads, partly in Bronxville and Mount Vernon, N. Y., have been sold by Mrs. Mary S. Purdy of White Plains to Angels J. Paretta, who will occupy the dwelling.

Five hundred and eighty degrees in engineering, arts, science, physical education and business administration will be awarded today by Manhattan College at its 101st commencement exercises. The Most Rev . Joseph P. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of the New York Diocese of the Roman Catholic Church, will preside at the graduation ceremonies, which will begin at 3:00 P. M.

PARIS, June 9 -- The French Ministry of National Defense disclosed tonight that examination of the documents seized in the raids on the Communist front offices in the naval base city of Toulon failed to support the charges of espionage leveled at the Reds Saturday.

BRIGHAM CITY, Utah, June 9 -- Fifty representatives of a dozen Indian tribes gathered here today under the auspices of the National Congress of American Indians, to begin the process of outlining and analyzing tribal needs and formulating "action proposals" for the betterment of the Indian segment of the nation's population.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Tuesday, June 10 -- The toughest Communist compound on this prison island fell today after a last-ditch stand against United States paratroopers, who smashed their way with tanks and flame-throwers into Compound 76.
CAMDEN, N. J., June 9 -- With temperatures at near-record highs for a Jersey June, Mrs. Percy R. Mole bought a refrigerator today.

An open date in the schedule provided a day of rest for the Yankees yesterday. Casey Stengel's club will resume action tonight, opposing the Tigers under the lights at the Stadium. Ed Lopat is to start for the Bombers and Red Rolfe will counter with Ted Gray.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 9 (AP) -- Reliable sources said today that Queen Zain of Jordan and her son, Crown Prince Hussein, 17 years old, are in hiding somewhere in Switzerland. A friend of the Royal Family said the Queen was "terribly afraid" that her husband King Talal, would find her.

Two associations representing 2,400 diamond dealers throughout the United States were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on a charge of conspiracy to restrain interstate and foreign commerce in diamonds in violation of the anti-trust laws.

William Perl, 32-year-old former Columbia University physics instructor and an aerodynamics specialist, charged with perjury, asked Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey yesterday for an early trial date. Perl indicated through counsel that he wanted to call as a defense witness Julius Rosenberg, convicted atom spy now in the Sing Sing death house.

Americans will be delighted once more to welcome Ramon Magsaysay, Defense Secretary of the Philippines. Mr. Magsaysay will receive a friendly reception from all those who are interested in the welfare of the Philippines, and will deserve high praise for his successful campaign against Communist rebellion and subversion.

The stock market continued yesterday to move forward but there were some obstacles in the form of profit taking. The session was the fourth in succession in which the averages made gains. On balance the list rose 0.30 point, but many issues did better.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Following is the 59-to-11 roll-call vote by which the Senate today passed and sent to President Truman a compromise $6,447,730,750 foreign aid bill for the new fiscal year:

LONDON, June 9 -- The stock markets were mostly steady today, although the volume of business remained checked by the obscure economic domestic outlook and political developments abroad, particularly in France and Germany.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Wage negotiations between the steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., broke down tonight and were recessed indefinitely.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Labor unions are barred by the Railway Labor Act from "using their position and power" to destroy "colored workers' jobs in order to bestow them on white workers," the Supreme Court ruled, 6 to 3, today.

PARIS, June 9 (UP) -- Dick Chapman, the Pinehurst (N. C.) player who failed in his bid to retain his British amateur golf crown two weeks ago, rallied in the second round today to win the French amateur championship for the second time with a 4 and 3 victory over Billy Maxwell, the United States champion from Odessa, Tex., in their scheduled 36-hole final.
An important expansion program in facilities for package dyeing of acrylic yarns will provide a fuller range of colors for the newer synthetic fibers, it was learned yesterday.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 9 -- Five honorary degrees and scrolls to 450 seniors and 48 graduated students were awarded at Smith College today at the seventy-fourth annual commencement.
TOKYO, June 9 (AP) -- A peace treaty renewing the ancient ties between India and Japan was concluded today.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, June 9 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Allied Supreme Commander in Europe, reviewed officers and men of the Central Command at Fontainbleau today. It was his first visit to this principal subordinate headquarters since he assumed the supreme command from General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower May 30.

The campaign debut of "Mister" Dwight D. Eisenhower last week, prefaced by Senator Robert A. Taft's indictment of the Administration and its "land generals," has put the nation's military policies squarely into politics.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- Walter White, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, today criticized General of the Army, Dwight D. Eisenhower's stand on civil rights as "backward." He also said that the Democratic party had no chance of winning the Presidential election this year if it "sells out" on civil rights.

PUSAN, Korea, June 9 (AP) -- The United Nations has urged the South Korean Government to halt its political squabblings for ten days to ease tension. The United Nations said the situation was threatening the republic with chaos.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Protesting the proposed selection of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur as keynoter for the Republican National Convention that opens here July 7, J. Russel Sprague of New York charged today that backers of Senator Robert A. Taft were using "Texas tactics" to rig the convention machinery in favor of the Ohioan's nomination.

JERSEY CITY, June 9 -- The Republican pre-convention contest between Senator Robert A. Taft and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower is "a good omen for the Democratic party," Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia said here today. The Senator, himself a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said the Taft-Eisenhower battle was "the bitterest pre-convention fight" in his experience and was contributing to the Democrats' chances of victory.
If your restaurant serves you colored margarine after July 1, the law says it must come in three-cornered patties -- or on a paper or china dish plainly marked margarine.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 9 -- The battle of petroleum in Brazil is on. Beginning today, Congress will hold nightly sessions to discuss President Getulio D. Vargas' project to set up the Petrobraz Corporation, which would run the nation's petroleum resources.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands, June 9 (AP) -- The District Court granted a divorce five days ago to Elizabeth D. Hanson from the Rev. Benedict H. Hanson of Lexington, Ky., it was disclosed today. Mrs. Hanson is the first wife of Elliott Roosevelt.

An analysis of the situation in South Africa by Emil Solomon Sachs, a South African trade-union leader, has been scheduled by the Philosophical Library for Aug. 27 publication. It is titled "The Choice Before South Africa." The publishers report that the book, which is anti-Malan, has been banned in Capetown and Johannesburg and that its author has been placed under arrest.

Harry C. Cease has purchased the building at 1974 Seventh Avenue, containing three stores and nine apartments, from the Trans-New York Corporation, operators. Leon Kalb was the broker. The property, at the southwest corner of 119th Street, had been owned for more than thirty years by the Wolff family before it was acquired recently by the present sellers.

Rival counsel in the anti-trust investment banking trial clashed here yesterday over the meaning of Government evidence which showed that one of the defendants in the suit had not been a member of a certain 1945 syndicate denounced by the Government as "overly large" but had instead been in a competing syndicate managed by the non-defendant banking house of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

NOTTINGHAM, England, June 9 (AP) -- A brisk rally in the last round tonight enabled France's Ray Famechon to retain his European featherweight championship with a fifteen-round decision over Roy Ankarah of the African Gold Coast. Famechon weighed 125 pounds, Ankarah 125 3/4.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 9 -- The issues involved in oil nationalization in Iran are "too sacred and too vital" to be exposed "even to the theoretical risk of an international decision," Premier Mohammed Mossadegh of Iran told the International Court of Justice today.

Golden Gloves of the Belair Stud revived the faith of the favorite players by winning the Troubadour at Belmont Park yesterday. With Nick Wall in the saddle, Golden Gloves scored by a neck over Out Point of the Lazy F. Ranch, with Guard of Honor third in the mile-and-a-sixteenth event.

The A. O. Smith Corporation, manufacturers of chassis frames and automobile parts, welded pipe for oil and gas lines, high pressure vessels and a number of other varied products, had a net profit of $3,888,894 in the nine months ended with April, after providing $4,527,000 for taxes.

Far greater progress in the techniques of standardization will be made in the next fifty years than has been accomplished in the first half of this century, Roger E. Gay, president of the American Standards Association, predicted yesterday at the opening meeting of the International Organization for Standardization at Columbia University.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 9 -- King Paul of Greece, arriving for a three-day visit, paid homage today to the memory of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk.

OTTAWA, June 9 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian corporations may be able to save large sums on their annual tax bills as a result of a decision of the Exchequer Court of Canada Saturday upholding the right of a company to use an accounting system hitherto not accepted by the revenue department.

TRENTON, June 9 -- Fifty-nine legislative measures, found defective by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, were corrected and repassed without debate today by the New Jersey Legislature. Both houses then adjourned for the year.
BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Red Sox moved one game, or 11 percentage points, ahead of the second place Yankees today with a 9 -- 8 triumph over the Tigers. The Red Sox outhit the Tigers, 15 to 12.
An appeal for $150,000 to attract summer vacationists to this city has been started by the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Thus far the revelation of the degree of popular support for Senator Kefauver of Tennessee in his bid to be the Democratic nominee for President is perhaps the outstanding political development of 1952. One reason for it was President Truman's off-again, on-again attitude about permitting his name to go before Democratic primary voters, and then his firm notice at the end of March that he would not accept renomination.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 9 -- Columbia Pictures, in addition to its production of movies for theatres, will produce a series of thirty-nine half-hour television films for the Ford Motor Company. The pictures, which will represent adaptations of plays, novels and original stories, will be made at the Columbia Studio in Hollywood by its television producing subsidiary, Screen Gems, Inc.

New uses for wool were displayed in fall and winter resort fashions at a dinner and fashion show held in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last evening. The event was arranged by the Woolknit Associates and the Wool Bureau, with styles contributed by both American and European designers.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Supreme Court deferred action today on a Justice Department request that it settle the complex Dollar Steamship case by deciding who owns about $69,000,000 worth of stock in the American President Lines, Inc. One of many side issues involves a contempt of court judgment against Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer.

Described as "reopening the 300-year-old cycle of trade between the United States and Spain," an exhibition of 2,000 items from thirty-seven Spanish manufacturers will be opened tomorrow morning in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Senor Pelayo G. Olay, minister attached to the Spanish Embassy in Washington. The exhibit will last three days.

Father's Day promotions are building up to a new record volume at least 10 per cent greater than last year, it was estimated yesterday. This estimate, based on reports reaching the Father's Day Council, was made by Alvin Austin, its executive director.

Celanese Corporation of America has established thirteen new fellowships and two post-doctorate fellowships in twelve educational institutions for the 1952-1953 academic year, it was announced yesterday by George Schneider, senior vice president.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 9 -- Delegates of the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and Poland today launched a two-pronged attack against the United States in the United Nations Economic and Social Council, during which debate became so acrid that Syed Amjad Ali of Pakistan, president of the Council, threatened to suspend the meeting unless speakers moderated their language.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of directors of the Chase National Bank of New York, today received an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws at Georgetown University. As commencement speaker, he defended Americans against charges of materialism.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 5 to 35 points yesterday from final prices of last Friday on a moderate volume of business.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- The House Armed Services Committee virtually killed chances for Congressional approval this year of a combat bonus for G. I.'s fighting in Korea.

Post-mortems on the Italian communal elections of May 25 are to be held by the political parties in the next few weeks. The Christian Democrats, who have maintained such a powerful position since the 1948 general elections, are the ones who must do the deepest soul-searching.

It is one of the peculiar ironies of our present laws that (along with lunatics and felons) the residents of Washington, D. C., the capital of the world's greatest democracy, are not to be permitted to participate in the democratic process. They cannot vote for President or Congress.

Fredrica Furs threw all tricks and gadgetry of design to the winds and hewed to a look of beautiful, subtle line in its retail fall fur collection, shown yesterday at 345 Seventh Avenue. The silhouette was one of controlled slimness, of luxurious flow but not heavy bulk. Armholes were slightly higher and necklines rose high, whether in small or in large shoulder-covering pyramid collars fitting close to the throat line.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., June 9 -- One of the ten largest industrial organizations in the United States will apply tomorrow for zoning changes to permit the establishment of a $12,000,000 executive center on the 286-acre James Butler estate on the Saw Mill River Road near here. It was reported tonight that the center eventually might become a $50,000,000 development.

PARIS, June 9 -- A project to reduce France's burden in Indo-China by a rapid expansion of the Vietnam Army will be discussed with the Departments of State and Defense by Jean Letourneau, the French Minister for the Associated States, who will leave for the United States tomorrow.
MEXICO CITY, June 9 (AP) -- Mexican bankers cut down on credits today, crossed their fingers and hoped Mexico's dollar reserves are big enough to protect the peso against strong downward pressure.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Senator Wayne Morse asserted today that documents supplied privately to him indicated that in the Nineteen Forties Chinese Nationalist Air Force officers here had been ordered to spy on United States atomic secrets and on "military targets" in this country.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The compromise authorization of $6,447,730,750 for the Mutual Security Program was passed by the Senate, 59 to 11, today and sent to the White House, where President Truman has promised it a caustic reception because of its reductions of $1,452,270,000 under his request.

LONDON, June 9 -- Parliament resumes its session tomorrow after its Whitsunday holiday recess, with the bipartisan foreign policy facing a further challenge from the Left and the Government confronted with growing Opposition criticism of United States policy in Korea.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 9 -- David Owen, Assistant Secretary General of the United Nations for Economic Affairs, has accepted appointment as executive chairman of the United Nations Technical Assistance Board. The board coordinates the work of the United Nations and affiliated international agencies in providing technical assistance for underdeveloped countries.
TOKYO, Tuesday, June 10 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,276, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (5 P. M. Monday, Eastern daylight time):

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to consider New York City's proposal for the modification of a 1931 decree to permit diversion of more Delaware River water to the city's use. The Court referred the matter to Kurt F. Pantzer of Indianapolis, who will act as special master in the case.

In hopes of eliminating a chronic mile-long bottleneck on the Franklin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive at peak periods, Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley has rearranged the signal light pattern at East 116th Street and the drive.

In many summer theatres the instrumental effects in musical productions are provided by two pianists instead of a full orchestra. During the current season, according to a ruling by the American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L., one of the pianists must be classified as a "leader" and paid a minimum salary of $205 a week.

There has been a marked increase in public demand for shares of mutual funds, or open-end investment companies, according to the 1952 edition of "Investment Companies," published today by Arthur Wiesenberger, senior partner in the investment banking firm bearing his name.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Army Secretary Frank Pace Jr. said today that doubt expressed by Maj. Gen. Daniel H. Hudelson that the United Nations could win in Korea was contrary to the view of the highest military leaders.

The first class at the Institute for Crippled and Disabled to hold its graduation aboard ship sailed through the ceremonies on the Hudson River Dayliner Peter Stuyvesant yesterday as 1,450 handicapped persons had their twenty-third annual boatride and outing. The ceremonies were followed by an afternoon of picnicking at Indian Point Park.

Evidence that the ancestors of modern man in Europe are perhaps 35,000 years younger than has been previously believed was presented here yesterday at the opening of an International Symposium on Anthropology arranged by the Wenner-Gren Foundation, 14 East Seventy-first Street.

American Airlines operations were close to normal yesterday as more than 900 workers, members of Local 501 of the Transport Workers Union, C. I O., who had engaged in sitdown tactics for four days over allowances for transportation costs, began carrying out their regular duties.
It's generally accepted that women do much of the shopping for the men in their families. With that in mind, here are some Father's Day gift suggestions.
ITHACA, N. Y., June 9 -- In his first commencement address as president of Cornell University, Dr. Deane W. Malott awarded degrees today to 1,700 graduates and counseled them to "seek adverture."

The International Court of Justice has come around at last to consideration of the question whether it is competent to assume jurisdiction in the Anglo-Iranian oil dispute submitted to it by Britain a year ago. This dispute, precipitated by Premier Mossadegh's nationalization of the Iranian oil industry in violation of international contractual agreements, continues to hang like a dark cloud over the whole Middle East.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to hear arguments on, and presumably decide, the controversial question whether segregation of white and Negro children in elementary public schools was constitutional.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 9 -- James G. Smyth, ousted as the Collector of Internal Revenue for the Northern California district, was acquitted of charges of tax fraud tonight by a Federal court jury of eight women and four men.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 9 -- Senator Estes Kefauver, front-running candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, became today the first of the party's aspirants to seek publicly the support of Pennsylvania's seventy-vote delegation to the national convention, which opens in Chicago July 21.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- A resolution characterizing President Truman's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation as "a politically inspired agency of government" and urging "public disapproval of Dr. Paul B. Magnuson, chairman of the commission, for his "unwarranted attacks on the leadership of American medicine" split the house of delegates of the American Medical Association here today.

The most exhaustive inquiries have failed to establish that Newark was or is an unsafe airport. Maj. Gen. James H. Doolittle, chairman of the President's Airport Commission, summed up the situation on May 16 when he said: "The Newark Airport has had a most unusual accumulation of bad luck.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 9 -- An agreement under which United States publishers of books, magazines and newspapers may sell their publications for pounds in Israel and obtain payment in dollars from the United States Treasury was put into effect by an exchange of notes today between Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion, as acting Foreign Minister, and United States Ambassador Monnett B. Davis.
Gale-force gusts screamed out of suddenly blackened skies in and around the city just after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, resulting in three deaths and extensive property damage.

" White Corridors," a British-made drama and the J. Arthur Rank Organization's forthcoming entry in the forthcoming Berlin Film Festival, has been booked into the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux, where it is slated to have its American premiere after the completion of the run of "The Narrow Margin," the theatre's present tenant.

As the result of a 100 per cent increase in consumer complaints brought about by the conversion from manufactured to natural gas in the metropolitan area, the Public Service Commission has directed all utility companies to make monthly reports on complaints received and the action they have taken. Many meters have been found to be running fast.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP) -- Former Representative Vito Marcantonio almost was ejected from the hearing room today as he opened his defense of the Communist party before the Subversive Activities Control Board by making a wire-tapping charge.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today put over until its fall term a request to review a ruling that the American Federation of Labor printers' union broke the Taft-Hartley Law by making contract demands that touched off the twenty-two-month Chicago newspaper strike.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, June 10 (AP) -- Allied warplanes pounded Communist supply arteries deep in North Korea yesterday in the unceasing effort to throttle the Red armies at the front.

The number of failures among business concerns is decreasing. The latest Dun Bradstreet figures, for the week ended on June 5, record 120 failures, against 136 a week before and 172 in the corresponding week of 1951. Those commercial and industrial fatalities involving more than $5,000 numbered eighty-six in the latest week, compared with ninety-five in the preceding week and 125 a year earlier.

DAMASCUS, Syria, June 9 (AP) -- Gen. Fawzi Selo, Syria's Chief of State, announced today an eight-man all-civilian Cabinet. This is in line with General Selo's announced intention to reorganize the Government in apparent preparation for new parliamentary elections.

A new program to enable liberal arts colleges and universities to reappraise and re-examine their work was announced yesterday by Dr. Clarent H. Faust, president of the Fund for the Advancement of Education, 575 Madison Avenue.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 9 -- Israelis lined up in long, quiet queues outside banks beginning at noon today to exchange old money for new -- minus the 10 per cent that they must lend the Government. Police cars distributed large boxes containing the new money and extra police stood guard at the entrances to banks as the money was carried in.

In a recent book I referred to the great controversy that raged some years ago in Australia over the so-called "Brisbane Line." Inadvertently, and because at the time I knew no better, I reported the version of this controversy which several Australians with special interests took the trouble to acquaint me with. I now find that I did the Australian Government a grave injustice, and I should like to correct my error.

THE river of new books that reaches flood crest in March and April is never much more than a trickle by June. Then a harried reviewer can look back at those promising books which somehow he never got around to reading. Most of the books which the competition forced him to overlook still seem logical candidates for oblivion, but not all of them.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 9 -- Yale University observed its 251st commencement here today by conferring degrees on 1,921 students.

Although events in Iran last year deprived the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, Ltd., of some 116,000,000 barrels of crude oil and refined products, sales of the company were only 15,000,000 barrels below the 1950 total of 288,700,000 barrels, according to the forty-third annual report issued for publication here today.
William Spivey, former All-America basketball star at the University of Kentucky, pleaded not guilty yesterday in General Sessions to a perjury charge and was released in $2,500 bail to await trial.

Within the last few days one of the country's great highway projects has financed the wherewithal -- $326,000,000 worth -- which will transform the Ohio Turnpike from a well-engineered blue-print into a going business of road-building. This giant block of revenue bonds is a vivid measure of the grand scale required for constructing 241 miles of modern superhighway, even over some of the most level land in America.
The responsibilities of researchers and scientists to society were stressed yesterday at the opening sessions of the third annual conference on industrial research at Columbia University.
The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, third largest insurance concern in the country, and Glenn McCarthy, Texas oil and hotel promoter, "buried the hatchet" yesterday.

With the exception of rubber and lead futures, most commodity contracts on the local exchanges moved in a comparatively narrow range yesterday. The volume of trading for the most part was on a moderate scale.

Consumer resistance and a plentiful supply coming into the market combined to bring down the price of potatoes somewhat yesterday, but experts said sharper reductions would be needed to restore the spud to its old popularity.

PARIS, June 10 -- Civil and naval authorities of France's big Mediterranean naval base at Toulon today pressed their investigation of alleged intelligence activities by Communist militants and members of Red-dominated unions there.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Charles E. Shaver, former counsel for the Senate Small Business Committee, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on charges of accepting fees from private concerns to push cases before Government agencies.

ROME, June 10 -- The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization today honored the late American economist and philanthropist, David Lubin, as its "precursor" and spiritual founder. The sixty-five member states dedicated the David Lubin Memorial Library of more than 400,000 volumes which will recall to posterity the "founder of the International Institute of Agriculture and pioneer of international collaboration for peace and justice throughout the world."

The executive committee of the Queens Democratic County Committee, at a meeting last night in the county headquarters, 60-19 Roosevelt Avenue, Woodside, designated its candidates for Representative in Congress, State Senator and Assemblyman in the November election.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, June 10 -- A detailed battle map discovered late today in the ruins of Compound 76, where thirty-one Red captives were killed and 139 were wounded this morning in the fight to break up the notorious enclosure, revealed that North Korean leaders had planned to exploit a forced entry in an attempt to break out and seize this prison island.

REHOVOTH, Israel, June 10 -- Prof. Selman A. Waksman, who is delivering a series of lectures as a guest of the Weizmann Institute, said today he was exploring the possibilities of establishing an antibiotics plant in Israel. Dr. Waksman, who is Professor of Microbiology at Rutgers University, is known for his work in developing streptomycin.

Clive of India, owned by Mrs. Esther duPont Weir, was the decisive winner of the New York Writers Cup at Belmont Park yesterday. The event, a hurdle handicap of about a mile and three-quarters, served as the feature. A crowd of 17,061 was on hand for the first of the two-day program conducted by the United Hunts Racing Association, the venerable organization dedicated to the encouragement of steeplechase racing.

The arrival this morning in the United States of Jean Letourneau, Minister for the Associated States of Indo-China, should serve to call attention again to one of the most critical problems of the cold war. The French are holding on in Indo-China grimly and bravely, and at an extraordinarily high cost in money and in young lives.

The Los Angeles, Calif., Department of Water and Power sold yesterday $22,775,000 of revenue bonds to a banking syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation, Drexel Co. and Harris, Hall Co. The banking group's winning bid for $22,000,000 of the total was an interest cost of 2.288 per cent, and for $5,775,000 of electric plant refunding bonds, a cost of 2.31 per cent.
CHICAGO, June 10 -- A potential television audience of 30,000,000 received an opportunity tonight to watch part of a major operation in progress at a Chicago hospital.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N. Y., June 10 -- George O. Arkin, a New York lawyer and member of the executive committee of the American Jewish Congress, was re-elected today Grand Master of Brith Abraham, oldest American-Jewish fraternal order in the country, at conclusion of its three-day national convention here.

While admitting defeat in the opening skirmish on Monday of the annual war against ragweed, resilient Health Department combat forces took the road back to the wilds of the Bronx yesterday in a new counter-attack.

BERLIN, June 10 -- Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, Soviet Commander in Germany, denied today that the Western Allies were entitled to patrol the superhighway between Berlin and West Germany. He asked that all "attempts" to resume such patrols be discontinued immediately.

HOBOKEN, N. J., June lO--Fulfilling a goal for which they had worked four years, twelve Mariner Girl Scouts in spanking new blue uniforms, members of Troop 237, Cincinnati, Ohio, sailed today aboard the Netherlands Government Steamship, Waterman for a three-month tom- of Wester Europe and the British Isles.

The first major venture in privately executed slum clearance was started yesterday when contracts were signed for four projects that would provide middle-income dwellings for 6,500 Manhattan families at a cost of $85,000,000 -- the forerunner of a publicly aided program that eventually might reach $200,000,000 in the New York area.
GUATEMALA, June 10 -- A new bomb was found by the police today in the outskirts of the city which, if it had exploded, would have hit Santa Maria Asylum, where thousands of children are sheltered.

The stock market ran out of enthusiasm yesterday after four consecutive sessions of rising prices. The reaction came after the sudden termination of the negotiations in Washington to settle the steel industry strike and gave the professional element an excuse for profit-taking.

Nearly 500 cities have adopted in whole or in part the recommended national building code sponsored by the National Board of Fire Underwriters, according to James K. Evans, building code engineer of the organization.

In an address to 580 graduates at the 101st commencement exercises of Manhattan College yesterday, John T. Loughran, Chief Judge of the New York Court of Appeals, urged the graduates to learn to distinguish between legitimate compensation for services and offers that would entail the purchase of "personal independence."

NOT since the Emperor Jones ruled the domain has there been a more appealing golf monarch than Ben Hogan. The unsmiling little fellow with the fierce concentration and the blazing competitive urge will seek his fourth United States Open championship at Dallas this week, a feat achieved near the turn of the century by Willie Anderson and matched in the Golden Twenties by Bobby Jones.

BONN, Germany, June 10 -- The conference between Jewish and West German representatives appeared today to have ended satisfactorily, and it was virtually certain that the Bonn Government would offer a program of restitutions to Israel amounting to $715,000,000, payable over a period of seven or eight years.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- A weak tone developed in wheat from the start this morning, with selling based on the expectation of a bearish June crop report and the reported collapse of steel strike negotiations. In the early trade, however, there were substantial upturns in rye and soybeans, with oats also extending its recovery from recent lows.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., June 10 -- Mrs. Allan Ryan of The Creek shot a 40, 37 -- 77 to win the first gross prize in the Class A tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Brookville Club today. Evelyn Odom, Wheatley Hills, was second with 38, 41 -- 79.

BONN, Germany, June 10 -- Spurred by the eloquent plea of Mayor Ernst Reuter of West Berlin that "I am not asking aid for Berlin, I am asking aid for Germany" the West German Bundestag endorsed today a resolution calling for all necessary financial economic and political aid for West Berlin, which once again is under Soviet pressure.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman intended last night in a speech at the Tammany dinner at the Commodore Hotel to express his complete conviction that the Democratic party would win the coming Presidential election because the country could not afford to let the Democratic party lose.

Gerard W. Purcell, former ofcial of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, instructed his bookkeeper to keep 23,450 raffle books earmarked for sale in 1950 out of association records and to turn the proceeds from their sales over to him, it was testified yesterday at his trial in General Sessions.

The Diamond Center, Inc., asserted yesterday that the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice should refrain from trying cases in the press and leave the decision to the courts. The center was indicted this week by a Federal grand jury on a charge of conspiracy to restrain interstate and foreign commerce in violation of the anti-trust laws.

In an effort to stimulate additional travel in passenger coaches, fourteen leading railroads in the East announced yesterday that they would put into effect drastic reductions in round-trip coach fares on June 25, subject to the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission and the state regulatory commissions involved.

Edwin M. Otterbourg, president of the New York County Lawyers Association, urged the graduating class of the New York Law School last night to be active in politics to preserve the principles of justice in government handed down from the Magna Carta.

Negotiations are in progress to bring Robert E. Sherwood, the noted playwright, into television as a writer of original plays. Discussions between his representatives and the National Broadcasting Company were said yesterday to have progressed to the stage of formulating a contract.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 (UP) -- Sam Mele tied the modern record for runs-batted-in during a single inning tonight when he drove in six as the White Sox scored twelve times in the fourth for a 15-4 victory over the Athletics.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- -- The Senate Government Operations Committee approved resolutions today to kill President Truman's plans to put postmasters, customs collectors and United States marshals under civil service.

ST. LOUIS, June 10 -- The racial intolerance from which Jackie Robinson is said to have suffered during his first year in the National League reportedly came to the fore again during last night's Dodgers-Cardinals game, which the Brooks came from behind to win.
LONDON, June 10 -- The stock markets here were quiet today. British funds became dull but industrial shares mostly held steady although some of them tended to slip back in late dealings.

Opening a drive for quick American ratification of the "peace contract" with Germany and the extension of the North Atlantic Treaty guarantees to that country, Secretary Acheson made two important points before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee yesterday.
HARTFORD, June 10 -- The State Highway Department announced today the route of the proposed Fairfield County Thru-way from the New York State line through Greenwich to Stamford.

Great Britain has made the turn toward improvement in her textile industries, according to Sir Robert Chance, chairman of Ferguson Brothers, Ltd., textile manufacturers of Carlisle, England. Trade has been stimulated by lower prices, particularly at retail where stocks are down from high points of 1951.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Hugh Gibson, veteran United States diplomat, was unanimously chosen today as head of an international organization that seeks to send up to 7,500,000 Europeans to new homes abroad in the next decade.

On July 2, bulldozers will start digging up the fifteen-year-old linden trees that offer green shade in the garden on the Fifty-fourth Street side of the Museum of Modern Art. They will clear the area for work on the new sculpture court that has been designed by Philip C. Johnson, director of the Department of Architecture.

NEW DELHI, India, June 10 -- Sheikh Mohammad Abdullah, India-backed Prime Minister of the disputed state of Jammu and Kashmir, has recommended to the Constituent Assembly abolition of the 166-year-old hereditary rulership.

A new studio policy emphasizing "important subject material" suitable for a "large international audience," with production costs trimmed to a "sensible" level, was announced here yesterday at a press conference held by Darryl F. Zanuck, vice president in charge of production at Twentieth Century-Fox, on his return from a business trip to Europe.

BOSTON, Wednesday, June 11 (UP) -- Joe De Maestri's single that took a bad hop at second base and permitted two runs to score in the fifth provided the margin of victory for the Browns early today as they beat the Red Sox, 7 -- 4, before 19,049 fans.

The fiftieth anniversary of Shearson, Hammill Co., one of the largest investment and brokerage houses in Wall Street, was celebrated yesterday. Founded in 1902, the firm started with ten employes and three partners, Edward Shearson, Caleb W. Hammill and W. Hamilton Busk.

The first meeting in a wage review between the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., and the Committee for the Companies and Agents -- Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, was held yesterday but no progress was reported. The employer group represents forty-eight steamship lines.

The Department of Health, swamped with requests for copies of birth records, warned yesterday that New Yorkers planning trips abroad should make their applications for certificates three weeks in advance of procuring passports.

The National Production Authority filed charges here yesterday that the Ray-Foil Corporation and the Trufoil Corporation of 722 Broadway and six individual respondents had illegally obtained and diverted 222,813 pounds, of aluminum and placed orders for 135,302 pounds of aluminum in excess of allotments permitted by the agency's Controlled Materials Plan.
BOSTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Red Sox tonight traded Pitchers Randy Gumpert and Walt Masterson to the Senators for Pitcher Sid Hudson in a straight player swap.

SO far there is only one man mentioned for the nomination for the Presidency who has revealed himself as the leader this country needs to grapple with the serious problems that face us here at home and all over this fast-shrinking globe. That man is Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court.
PITTSBURGH, June 10 (AP) -- The Pirates scored five runs in the first inning against Warren Spahn tonight, then went on to defeat the Braves, 7 -- 5.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Government hopes of averting a breakdown of military supplies of steel despite the country-wide strike collapsed today after Dr. John R. Steelman, Presidential assistant and Acting Director of Defense Mobilization, had ended a two-hour conference with the heads of Government agencies concerned with defense production.
CLEVELAND, June 10 (AP) -- Iron ore loadings were about half of normal last week and Pittsburgh Steamship predicted all it vessels will be tied up by next week.

Designs from Norway, the Scandinavian country least well represented here by imports of home furnishings, constitute the contents of a shop opening today at Norway House, 290 Madison Avenue. The shop, in suite 504, is devoted to products of David-Andersen of Oslo, makers of silver, enamelware and pewter.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The second largest wheat crop in history appears to be in the fields, and other food and livestock feed crops are progressing normally to promise a bountiful harvest, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Ten athletes from five local colleges were among the large contingent of Easterners heading for California yesterday to compete in the National Collegiate A. A. track and field championships at Berkeley on Friday and Saturday. The six place-winners in each event at the varsity title meet will qualify for the final Olympic tryouts at Los Angeles two weeks later.

LOS ANGELES, June 10 -- Ten of the fourteen Communist party functionaries on trial for violation of the Smith Act announced in a surprise move at the end of the fourth-month presentation today that they would rest their case, waiving testimony in their own defense.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The House of Representatives approved by a vote of 302 -- 53 today the final draft of the McCarran-Walter bill to overhaul the country's immigration, naturalization and nationality laws.

Unlike the real political conventions, in which there is an element of suspense, a convention of sorts is to be held at the Lexington Hotel today at which Lyon Metal Products, steel equipment manufacturer, will put on a show with a platform, delegates and candidates.
Your editorial of June 6 on the Gross National Product was excellent and timely.

BRISTOL, England, June 10 (AP) -- Straight Clark of Pasadena, Calif., was forced to three sets to beat Chile's hard-hitting left-hander, M. Taverne, 6 -- 3, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, in the third round of the West of England tennis championship today.

BECKENHAM, England, June 10 -- Gardnar Mulloy and Hamilton Richardson arrived on the scene today and played two rounds as did Eric Sturgess of South Africa, to reach the quarter-finals of the Kent tennis championships.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 10 (AP) -- H. Frederick Willkie, ousted recently as president of Kingan Co., filed a multi-million dollar damage suit today against the meat packing concern and three of its officers. The Superior Court suit charges defamation of character and asks $5,650,000 damages.

An excursion boat carrying 300 school children and some parents and teachers rammed into a concrete bulkhead in the Hudson River at West Forty-third Street yesterday and stove in two feet of her bow. Thirty-two persons reported injuries and one as hospitalized, but many more received scrapes and bruises.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 10 -- In front from the start, Lonway, the promising pacer owned by Mrs. Hazel L. Rubin of Charlton, N. Y., captured the $10,766-added Abbedale at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The daughter of King's Counsel won the mile event for 2-year-old fillies by three lengths.
BOSTON, June 10 (AP) -- Rogers Hornsby was discharged today as manager of the Browns by Bill Veeck, club president, who named Marty Marion as the team's new pilot.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 11 (AP) -- The Daily Express reported today that atom spy Klaus Fuchs had been discovered smuggling scientific information from his jail cell and receiving letters from the Soviet zone of Germany.
New issues of public utility stocks and bonds totaling $39,922,000 were sold to underwriting syndicates yesterday, as follows:

CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- The American Heart Association announced today establishment of a Howard W. Blakeslee award to be made annually to encourage high standards of medical reporting in the field of heart and blood vessel disease.

CHICAGO, June 10 (UP) -- Southpaw Paul Minner contributed a home run toward his own victory today and Hank Sauer, the league-leader, smacked his fifteenth four-bagger as the Cubs whipped the Phillies, 10 to 5, before 10,125 fans.

Progress in making paper from bagasse, waste product of sugar cane, has reached the point where it is feasible to use the material to provide high-grade printing paper for the United States market and containers, shipping bags and like products for foreign countries.

Customs collections at the Port of New York totaled $20,426,071 last month, a drop of almost $3,500 000 below the figure for May of last year, Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port, disclosed yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 10 -- The Soviet Union today turned down the West's new proposals for putting ceilings on armed forces. Jacob A. Malik, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, told the United Nations Disarmament Commission that the plan was "false and hypocritical."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and active months eased 2 to 22 points net.

BRIGHAM CITY, Utah, June 10 -- Indian tribesmen meeting here in a two-week "Community Development Workshop," designed to assay economic, educational and health needs of bands and tribes residing on a dozen Western reservations, began today an examination of "self-help projects" that might prove useful to economically retarded segments of their own race.

In the latest of a long series of jewel robberies in the Upper East Side of Manhattan, two youths got away with $17,000 worth of jewelry yesterday afternoon from the tenth-floor apartment of Mrs. Shirley Carmel at 1161 York Avenue after a maid caught the intruders at their work.
These are responsible Senators speaking, and yet some of their colleagues most ardent in lip-service to "economy" helped push this same amendment through the Senate by a 43-40 vote.
Andrew Bergmann celebrated his forty years of service with the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday by contributing his twenty-fourth pint of blood to a Red Cross bloodmobile at 4 Irving Place.

FOR an attractive, young man to love an attractive young woman who is the wife of an unattractive husband may not be the ideal human relationship, but it certainly seems to have been a conventional one since the Trojan war.

In its first change of ownership since 1899, the five-story store and apartment building at 908-12 Columbus Avenue has been sold by the estate of Henry C. Copeland to 910 Columbus Avenue, Inc., for investment. F. and G. Pflomm and Charles A. Kenney were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- Larry Doby's home run in the fifth inning gave the Indians a 4-3 victory over the Senators tonight, but it took two relief pitchers to stop Washington's ninth-inning threat. The Senators had the tying run on third with none out in the last frame but failed to score.

Subtle color schemes, based on the stock paint colors offered by landlords to prospective tenants for wall use, mark two model apartments to open today in the new apartment building at 2 Fifth Avenue.

GRAND RAPIDS, June 10 -- The off-flavor, odor and darkening that often occur when dried eggs are stored for an extended period can be eliminated by the use of a new enzyme developed at the Central Laboratories of the General Foods Corporation, the annual meeting of the Institute of Food Technologists was told today.

Two German school teachers here on a State Department exchange visit, both former members of the Hitler Youth Movement, asked yesterday that American be patient with their country in its effort to be truly democratic.

Mrs. Marion Garside Robbins, a middle-aged widow, was found at 2:30 P. M. yesterday in her third-floor apartment at 37 West Eighth Street, the victim of murder by strangulation and suffocation. No motive for the murder could be offered immediately by the police.

The Continental Motors Corporation had consolidated net earnings in the six months ended with April of $2,726,859 after all deductions, equal to 83 cents a share, C. J. Reese, president, reported yesterday. In the corresponding period last year the net profit was $2,111,191, or 64 cents a share.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today that the Senate by quickly approving the Allied peace contract and mutual defensive arrangements with West Germany could ease a considerable and unusual present tension in Europe.

A resolution protesting the criticism by the President and other government officials of the right of business to defend itself from attacks through newspaper advertising columns was adopted yesterday by the Advertising Federation of America.

ST. LOUIS, June 10 -- The Dodgers' winning streak of eight games came to an end in the tenth inning tonight when Solly Hemus was hit by a pitched ball and Red Schoendienst tripled off the left center wall for a 1-0 Cardinal victory.

Nearly two-thirds of the city's motorists were still putting off the sorrowful task of buying the $5 and $10 automobile use stamps, required for all motor vehicles here by next Tuesday, as the tax kept trailing troubles in its wake yesterday.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., June 10 -- Petitions were filed today with the Greenburgh Town Board here and the Mount Pleasant Town Board at North Tarrytown for a rezoning of the former James Butler estate at East View, which extends into both towns, to permit development of a 286-acre headquarters for one of the largest corporations in the country.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 10 -- Several central and southeastern Nassau County villages worked today to clean up the debris left in the wake of the line squall that roared through yesterday afternoon with torrential rainfall and winds registering a peak of eighty-four miles an hour.

CBS-Columbia, Inc., television receiver manufacturing subsidiary of the Columbia Broadcasting System, took action yesterday to end the universal television dealer plague -- periodic heavy inventories. The company introduced at a distributors meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel four new lines of sets "to fit every need and every pocketbook."
CINCINNATI, Wednesday, June 11 -- The Giants early this morning lost a game that likely will haunt them from here to October.
Samuel Reshevsky won the fifth game of his ten-game series with Svetozar Gligoric of Belgrade last night at the Manhattan Chess Club and increased his lead to 3 1/2 -- 1 1/2.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Senator Estes Kefauver declared today he would not accept the Vice-Presidential nomination if it were offered to him.

The third annual exhibit of prize winners of the American Craftsmen's Educational Council Competition goes on display today in the gallery of America House, 32 East Fifty-Second Street. The show, arranged by the council, is called Young Americans and includes the work of craftsmen 30 years old and under in four fields: metal, textiles, ceramics and wood.

In consequence of the almost universal abandonment of free trade the present situation of the Western World is dominated by two irreconcilable tendencies: Every country is eager to increase its exports and no country is willing to increase its imports. The inevitable result will be the reciprocal continuation and aggravation of one economic disorder by another.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- Attorney General James P. McGranery announced today that he had approved an order for an out-of-court settlement of the Government's seven-year legal dispute over ownership of the Dollar Steamship Line.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Members of the Federal Maritime Board disagreed today on the evidence that led to their decision to cut construction subsidies previously agreed upon for two fast new passenger liners.

ROME, June 10 -- An announcement that Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, would arrive in Italy Monday for a three-day stay resulted in an attack on him by the extreme left-wing press this morning. He was labeled "General Plague."

Flotations of new common stock valued at $85,989,000 to finance the expansion of public utility plant of major power and light enterprises of both the East Coast and the West Coast, will be undertaken today. The new offerings relate to $68,139,000 of new stock of Pacific Gas and Electric Company and $17,850,000 of new equity Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

More than 90 per cent of the mentally retarded children who attend special classes in the city's public schools have improved in their adjustment as individuals, Catherine E. Conway reported yesterday. And the more understanding parents are of the child's situation and his problems, the better adjustment he will make, she declared.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 10 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, in an address to more than 500 New Jersey sales executives at a conference at Rutgers University today, said there can be no security in a nation that lacks a secure monetary system.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Following is the 49-30 roll-call vote by which the Senate today adopted the Byrd amendment to the controls measure requesting President Truman to invoke immediately the Taft-Hartley Act:

As Arthur Krock pointed out on this page yesterday, it has been forty years since a faction in control of the machinery of the Republican party made a decision comparable with the decision made yesterday in Chicago in the choice of General MacArthur as "keynoter" for the national convention.

Garment buying continued brisk in the New York wholesale market with the opening of additional lines yesterday. Resident buying offices holding clinics for their member stores urged buyers to take a strong stand in ordering coats and suits and other fashion merchandise.

ALBANY, June 10 -- William S. Carlson, President of the State University of New York, said the university would continue suggesting alternate sites for the proposed Strategic Air Command base in Plattsburg so that Champlain College could remain open.
TOKYO, June 10 (UP) -- Gen. Mark W. Clark came out today in favor of bombing Red China if the Communists throw their 2,000-plane Air Force full tilt into a major offensive in Korea.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Government, already $7,500,000,000 in the red for the fiscal year ending on June 30, announced plans today to borrow $3,500,000,000 to meet its expenses.
To read your editorial of June 3 "Transit's Hard Choices" one would think that an the Mayor has to do to solve the complex transit problem is to have "courage" and raise the fare.

Full occupancy still is noted for virtually all old tenement houses in Manhattan, the Real Estate Board of New York reported yesterday on the basis of findings in its fourteenth annual survey of eleven key areas in the borough.

The stellar battery of Ed Lopat and Yogi Berra paced the Yankees to a 4-0 triumph over the Tigers before 35,914 spectators at the Stadium last night. It was the fourth straight victory for the Bombers, who have won ten of thirteen games on this prosperous home stand, which ends tomorrow.

Alexander S. Panyushkin, Soviet Ambassador to the United States for the last four and one-half years, made his final appearance in this role yesterday as he boarded the Swedish liner Stockholm here to return to Moscow for what he called a reassignment.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 10 -- For the United Kingdom, the Earl of Selkirk in today's meeting of the Economic and Social Council branded the recent trade conference in Moscow as a "grand-haggle," designed exclusively for propaganda purposes.

It is no secret that the National Broadcasting Company is apt to be fascinated by anyone who is warm to the touch, has eyes and ears and nose, and calls himself a comedian. In fact, it's getting so that a comedian who hasn't some sort of a retainer from N. B. C. hardly dares show up at the Friars.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 10 -- Thomas C. Robbins of Winged Foot, United States senior champion, won the spring tournament of the Westchester Senior Golf Association with a 1-over-par gross of 37, 34 -- 71 at the Quaker Ridge Country Club today.

For nineteen years the Staten Island-Historical Society has been striving to preserve those old buildings of the community of Richmond Town which represent all that is left of the early colonial and federal and County center from which a part of New York City grew.
Following is the text of President Truman's address to Congress yesterday on the steel strike, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

A 25-year-old South Carolina catfisherman was enabled to start back to his home town, Columbia, when Queens County Judge Alfred J. Hofmann yesterday permitted him to change a plea of guilty to a felony to one of guilty of a misdemeanor. The offense was unlicensed possession of a pistol.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's Republican backers are planning to demand that the sessions of the credentials committee of the Republican National Convention be opened to television and radio coverage, Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., the general's pre-convention manager, announced yesterday.

Because Government officials do not understand the power of advertising, a vast storehouse of information which cost millions to gather, is not being distributed. Such was the charge made yesterday by John P. Cunningham, executive vice president of Cunningham Walsh, Inc., at the thirty-third annual meeting of the National Association of Magazine publishers at Pocono Manor, Pa.

New York University will graduate 7,700 today at its 120th commencement ceremonies on the Bronx campus, 181st Street and University Avenue. The exercises will begin at 10:30 A. M. with a brief ceremony inaugurating Dr. Henry T. Heald as the university's ninth chancellor.

Membership in the Camp Fire Girls increased sharply in the last decade, bringing its present total to 369,651, according to the annual report of the organization issued yesterday. A spokesman at the group's national headquarters, 16 East Forty-eighth Street, said this figure represented an 83 per cent rise since 1941.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Attorney General James P. McGranery today instructed all United States Attorneys to disclose confidentially to him by June 27 how much of their time was given to private practice. He also asked for reports on cases where prosecution had been delayed.

Two basketball fixers halted their General Sessions trial yesterday afternoon to plead guilty to charges that they had offered bribes to players at the University of Kentucky and Bradley University in Peoria, Ill.

A floating university, registered in shipping circles as the 12,000-ton motorship Nelly, slid down the Bay at sundown yesterday with 800 students and teachers who will bone up during a nine-day Atlantic voyage on the ways of European and Near East nations in which the vacationists will spend the summer.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., June 10 -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Johnke of the Hempstead Golf Club fired 87-10 -- 77 to tie Mr. and Mrs. Simon Fleischman of the home club, 92-5 -- 77 in the first Long Island Golf Association husband and wife championship at the North Shore Country Club today.

The New World of the Western Hemisphere is not as new as has been generally believed and the Old World of Europe is not so old as has been supposed, according to reports presented here yesterday at the Wenner-Gren Foundation International Symposium on Anthropology.

MADRID, June 10 -- Difficulties of a political and military nature stemming mainly from a failure to agree on an evaluation of Spain's role in the West's defense system are delaying the current United States-Spanish negotiations for economic and military aid, informed sources said today.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- The House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee approved a new "long range shipping bill" today that would liberalize construction and operating subsidies for ship operators.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- The House Armed Services Committee unanimously approved a $2,758,318,000 military construction bill today but refused to restore $250,000,000 to help build bases in friendly European countries.

Another volume of World War II memoirs will join the ever-growing shelf when Gen. Heinz Guderian's "Panzer Leader" will be published by Dutton. Translated from the German by Constantine Fitzgibbon the story describes how General Guderian, as leader of the German Panzer Divisions, conducted his armored warfare, of his break-through at Sedan, the drive to the Channel coast and of the drive to the East that came close to producing the collapse of Russia's armies.

ROME, June 10 -- The Chamber of Deputies, by an overwhelming majority, approved in principle tonight a Government bill giving the De Gasperi Cabinet wide powers to suppress any party or movement that advocated reconstitution of the Fascist party.

A detailed description of how the Communist party started to go underground in 1948 was given in United States District Court yesterday by a witness in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party officials.

Degrees were conferred yesterday upon 363 graduates of the College of Arts and Sciences, Fordham University, at its 107th annual commencement. The exercises, held on the Keating Hall terrace on the Bronx campus, were attended by 2,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Truman, making a personal appearance on short notice, asked Congress at a joint session today for a law to let him seize and run the struck steel industry and to compensate labor as well as management fairly.
Today we dip into our readermail bag and select letters that bring up questions of interest to home cooks generally.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 101 Korean war casualties. Of the total, 13 are dead, 85 wounded, 1 missing in action and 2 injured in battle zone accidents. The following were listed from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 10 (AP) -- Members of the American Federation of Musicians were warned today by their president, James C. Petrillo, to think more and strike less.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., June 10 -- Up the broad waters of Hampton Roads tonight moved the superliner United States with an outsized broom riding on a mast high above the decks.

A variety of motifs from various sources have been utilized in the designs of the collections of silk-screened contemporary printed fabrics that make up the new exhibit at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 20 West Fifty-fifth Street.

By now all of the gardener's clothes, tools, baskets, stakes and kneeling pads have been accounted for and are assembled, when not in use, more or less in one place. For this the household is grateful, since the early days of the gardening season have been -- as they usually are -- troublesome.

BUFFALO, June 10 -- Rabbi Philip S. Bernstein, president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, warned today that thought control, intimidation and guilt by smear and association were becoming increasingly prevalent and constituted a serious threat to democratic concepts.

The decision of the United States Supreme Court in the steel controversy is a momentous one indeed in the realm of constitutional law, and will rightfully receive its place among the leading cases of our history.
