WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- Irving Kaplan, ousted United Nations official, refused to tell House investigators today whether he was or ever had been a Communist. Answer might "incriminate or degrade me," he said.

SEWANEE, Tenn., June 10 -- Eight leading figures in the field of religious instruction at the University of the South, often known as "Sewanee," which is owned by twenty-two dioceses of the Episcopal Church in ten Southern states, announced today that they would resign their academic positions unless Negro students were permitted to enter the university's School of Theology.

NEWARK, June 10 -- The Federal grand jury here in a present-ment to Judge Thomas F. Meaney today said its investigation of the three fatal airplane crashes at Elizabeth "did not disclose the violation of any Federal criminal law in any instance."

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) -- Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior said today that he had a plan to lease submerged oil-rich coastal lands for development but it had not been approved by President Truman.

LONDON, June 10 -- Classroom television eventually will become a regular part of school life, the chief education officer of Middlesex County has concluded following a month's experiment in collaboration with the British Broadcasting Corporation.

A return to fundamentals, with an end to "wrong thinking and wrong programs on an opportunistic basis," would help the Government solve many of the economic, social and political problems threatening the country's existence, B. Earl Puckett, chairman of the board of the Allied Stores Corporation, a department store chain, declared here yesterday.
TOKYO, Wednesday, June 11 (AP) -- United Nations Command communique 1,277, for the twenty-four-hour period ended 6 A. M. Wednesday (5 A. M. Tuesday, Eastern daylight time):

With only Council President Rudolph Halley in opposition, a three-year extension of the highly controversial 3 per cent retail sales tax was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The impost is estimated to yield about $208,000,000 toward the city's $1,469,265,102 budget for 1952-53.
ELBOWOODS, N. D., June 10 (UP) -- The Indians of the Fort Berthold Reservation today were under orders to leave their land to make way for a giant Missouri River dam.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 11 -Controversial issues of the Korean war and the truce negotiations, such as the inclusion of a Commonwealth representative in the talks at Panmunjom and the employment of Canadian and United Kingdom units on the prison island of Koje, should be left to the United Nations commander, Gen. Mark W. Clark, in whom "we have the utmost faith," Earl Alexander, British Defense Minister, said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 -- James G. Smyth, former Collector of Internal Revenue here who was acquitted by a Federal Court jury last night of three tax fraud charges, awaited today the disposition of two more indictments that technically were outstanding against him. They were not expected to be pressed.

At his press conference in Abilene General Eisenhower was asked about his position on the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, which will expire early next year. He replied that he was not in position to answer because he did not know the act would expire so soon.

Eighteen of the 114 graduates in the class of '52 at New York University's College of Medicine, a unit of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, received prizes and honors yesterday at "last day" exercises at Carnegie Lecture Hall, 338 East Twenty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- There was no disposition in the Truman Administration today to suggest to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur that he should go on the retired list, now that he has been selected as keynoter of the Republican National Convention.

LONDON, June 10 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden indicated in the House of Commons today that Parliament might be asked to ratify the agreements granting West Germany's sovereignty and linking it with the Western defense system before the end of this month.

Consolidated net income of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, world's largest producer of electricity in terms of kilowatt hours, totaled $11,857,288 in the first five months of this year, Earle J. Machold, president, announced yesterday.

FOLLOWING recent woodchuck safari with an enthusiastic but somewhat "green" novice hunter, we confessed to a conspicuous lack of success in tumbling 'chucks at ranges between 300 and 350 yards. That brought letter and telephoned sneer from a number of ungreen varminters.

A panel discussion on the relationship between blind parents and their children -- thought by specialists in work with the blind to be the first such meeting ever held -was conducted this week at the Labor Temple, 242 East Fourteenth Street, under the sponsorship of the New York Regional Group of the Blinded Veterans Association.

The Empire State Association of Commerce has officially changed its name to the Empire State Chamber of Commerce, it was announced yesterday at the group's sixth annual meeting held at the Roosevelt Hotel. The change was announced by F. Ritter Shumway, president, in his annual report.

An exhibitor who arrives at a dog show and finds a substitute has replaced the advertised judge for his breed will have his entry fee refunded if he does not wish to compete under the new judge, according to a rule amendment adopted by the delegates of the American Kennel Club yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

Laboratory tests made by the Department of Health have shown a "substantial" reduction" in pollution along the Brooklyn-Coney Island waterfront since the Owls Head, Brooklyn, sewage treatment plant went into operation on April 3.

BONN, Germany, June 10 -- Open rebellion erupted today against being manipulated like "puppets" by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in the course of his drive to obtain ratification of the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies and the European Defense Treaty by the Bundestag.
CHICAGO, June 10 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur was chosen today as keynoter of the Republican National Convention to speak on the night of July 7.

LONDON, June 10 (AP) -- Randy Turpin stopped Don Cockell in eleven bruising rounds tonight and added the British national and British Empire light-heavyweight titles to his British and European middleweight crowns. A crowd of 50,000 saw the bout in White City Stadium.

Two third-grade detectives were accused yesterday of unlawfully taking $20 from a tavern owner of 332 West Fifteenth Street, after they reportedly had spurned his offer of $10 to "forget" a sailor's complaint that he had lost $700 in the bar and grill.

Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett of Israel declared last night that the "primary responsibility" for assisting the people of his country in the salvation and rehabilitation of homeless and long-oppressed refugees rested on the Jewish community of the United States.

NEWARK, June 10 -- A small army of mosquito control workers is striving to take the sting out of the Jersey summer here, but, despite human superiority in ground forces, the insects are expected to take control of the air Sunday when millions of larvae lurking in the stagnant Newark marshes sprolt wings.

Salary increases caused by inflation and reduced working hours for firemen have created serious manpower shortages that are weakening the nation's defense against fire, delegates to the fifty-sixth annual meeting of the National Fire Protection Association were told yesterday at the Statler Hotel.
BALTIMORE, June 10 (UP) -- Soviet communism can be destroyed without a war if the United States becomes a dynamic moral force in the world, John Foster Dulles said today.

We all have an interest in making New York City a better place to live in, do business in, and finally -- because of tourist dollars -- a better place to visit. We all benefit if the New York story is told, so that people want to come here and enjoy themselves on week-ends or vacation stays.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 -Milton Sperling, head of the United States Pictures producing unit at Warner Brothers, came home from France last week with an idea for a musical picture in Technicolor to be called "Paris After Dark." While on a vacation Mr. Sperling began to speculate about making a picture set in Paris and decided to build a story around a typical American family on its first trip to the city of light.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 10 -- Counsel for Iran hit the British legal case for claiming jurisdiction for the International Court of Justice in the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company dispute head-on today.

Rights to Eric Knight's well-known short story, "The Flying Yorkshireman," finally have been tied up by Hume Cronyn after ten months of negotiations, it was learned yesterday. In the absence of Mr. Cronyn, who is on a vacation with his wife, Jessica Tandy, in Bermuda, the deal with Alan Collins, who represents the author, was confirmed by W. Herbert Adams, Mr. Cronyn's legal adviser.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., will not sign any contract with a private operator of the now city-operated five deficit-ridden Manhattan bus lines unless the $1,500,000 pension fund acrued for the last four years on these lines is transferred along with the lines and continued by the new owners, the Board of Estimate was warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The two United States Army brigadier generals who were recently "busted" in rank for their handling of the Koje Island prisoner-of-war uprisings have defended their actions on the ground that they sought to avoid mass bloodshed. Their decisions were made, they said, in line with higher headquarters policy.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 10 -- Janet Kern of Englewood took the gross prize back to New Jersey today after winning the women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class A Tournament with 44, 39 -- 83 at the Fenway Golf Club course.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 10 -- The Shuberts presented "Rose Marie" tonight at the County Center here to open the second week of the Westchester Operetta Festival, but the show, which will continue through Sunday, may be the last because of poor attendance.

Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet promoted eight captains to the rank of battalion chief yesterday in a surprise ending to a ceremony at City Hall honoring twenty-nine firemen for courageous and meritorious actions in 1951.
SEATTLE, June 10 -- (AP) -- Federal Judge John C. Bowen ruled today that loyalty-screening proceedings against three marine stewards were unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Col. David J. Sippel was convicted today of taking money from persons interested in obtaining Government contracts. A court-martial sentenced him to dismissal from the Air Force, which a spokesman said was the equivalent of a dishonorable discharge for an enlisted man.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 11 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, the United Nation commander, told the Communists today that the meetings in Panmunjom to negotiate an armistice in Korea would be held daily "when your delegation gives positive indications that there is hope of making progress toward the achievement of an honorable armistice."

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Dr. Paul B. Magnuson, chairman of President Truman's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation, warned the members of the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association today against what he called a "public be damned" attitude on the part of the organized medical profession.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 10 -- Italy assured the United Nations Trusteeship Council today that steps were being taken to improve both the judicial and prison systems in Somaliland.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 -- By an overwhelming margin, members of the Masters, Mates and Pilots Union, A. F. L., agreed today to arbitrate a dispute with ship-owners instead of authorizing picket lines at noon tomorrow on the West Coast's commercial piers.

Imminence of a $3,500,000,000 borrowing by the Treasury on a bond of intermediate term eligible for bank subscription caused prices of almost all United States Government interest-bearing securities to be marked down in the dealers' market yesterday.

The opening symphony concert at Lewisohn Stadium will be broadcast by WNYC on Monday, June 23, from 8:30 to 10:30 P. M. Dimitri Mitropoulos will be the conductor and Marian Anderson the featured soloist. Succeeding Stadium concerts will be broadcast by WNYC each Wednesday evening at 8:30.

LONDON, June 11 -- The stock markets were quietly firm today while awaiting the statement on economic affairs that Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler is expected to make tomorrow in the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- United States officials were insisting today that any meeting of the Western Powers with the Soviet Union on Germany should follow an agreement and a report by an impartial commission to study the conditions for free, all-German elections.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (AP) -- The Athletics staged a four-run rally in the sixth inning tonight to gain a 5 to 3 victory over the White Sox. Al Clark, playing for the injured Gus Zernial, hit a two-run homer in the sixth.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 11 -- The Venezuelan Government lodged an official protest with the Soviet Union against the behavior of two high Soviet Embassy officials here and asked for their immediate recall in a note transmitted to Moscow last night.
STANTON, Del., June 11 (AP) -- Ramon de Legorburu's Argentine-bred veteran, Benhadar, captured the second in the series of Montchanin handicaps at Delaware Park today.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Manhattan Borough President, who was toastmaster at the Tammany dinner at the Commodore Hotel on Tuesday evening, said yesterday that the speech of Senator Herbert H. Lehman was not read at the dinner because of a time limitation.

Fordham University's 107th annual commencement closed yesterday with the granting of degrees to 1,137 graduates of seven graduate and professional schools. Five thousand persons attended the exercises on the Keating Hall terrace of the Bronx campus, with the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, presiding.

Reduced earnings for the nine months ended with April and an increase in profits for the first quarter were reported yesterday in the statement of the Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., of Montreal and its subsidiaries.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Personal income in the United States for April was at an annual rate of $259,000,000,000 and slightly higher than in March, the Office of Business Economics in the Department of Commerce announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- George L. Warren, the United States delegate to the nineteen-nation Provisional Intergovernmental Committee for the Movement of Migrants from Europe, today told that organization that it now faces a difficult period.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 11 -- The Government of Iran concluded its legal arguments today in the dispute with Britain before the International Court of Justice over the nationalization of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company's properties in Iran.

Unification of the television industry and television advertisers to ward off attacks by critics was urged yesterday by John E. Fetzer, chairman of the television code review board of the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters.

MAHOPAC, N. Y., June 11 -- An escaped convict fatally stabbed a 9-year-old schoolgirl here at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon, as he sat in a car with the girl and her mother, attempting to force the mother to drive him to New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 11 -- John Ford has been signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to direct Clark Gable in "Mogambo," a story of romantic intrigue and dangerous encounters with wild animals and hostile tribesmen in Africa.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 11 -- The Yugoslav Government is proceeding with a series of measures aimed at winning over the independent peasants, whose lack of enthusiasm for the Communist party's agrarian policy has contributed to the serious decline in cereal production since World War II.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 11 -- The biggest spy trial in Swedish history will begin Monday when the seven members of the so-called Enbom gang will answer to charges of having sold Swedish military secrets of the highest importance to the Soviet Union.

The next eight days will decide whether the Senate is willing to endorse a major governmental reform or whether the patronage boys will be allowed to ride high, wide and handsome over the national interest. For the Senate has only until June 20 to take action on the three Presidential reorganization plans that would deprive it of any say in the appointment of postmasters, customs collectors and United States marshals.

AS stunning as was the removal of Rogers Hornsby as manager of the Browns by the club owner, Bill Veeck, the reaction of the players was even more-startling. They presented to Veeck a silver trophy with a hastily engraved inscription that described the move as "the greatest play since the Emancipation Proclamation." Managers have been discharged in the past without evoking one ripple of disapproval from their hired hands.

BUFFALO, June 11 -- Dr. Nelson Glueck, president of Hebrew Union College - Jewish Institute of Religion, asserted tonight that the McCarran-Walter immigration bill was the "apotheosis of everything ignoble that America was created to oppose."

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Wage Stabilization Board is studying a new wage formula that may increase the pay checks of many workers as much as 4 cents an hour, provided employers agree to pay the increase.
The Navy lifted a security veil yesterday because of enthusiasm about the maiden voyage of the new troop transport Barrett.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The choice by the Taft group of Walter S. Hallanan of West Virginia for temporary chairman of the Republican National Convention of 1952 is less spectacular than the selection of another Taft man to sound the keynote both for those who want to nominate the Senator from Ohio and those who vigorously oppose him.

Francis J. Sinnott, Democratic leader of Kings County, issued a statement yesterday saying that the rules of the county organization required him to approve the designation of Mrs. Estelle Rodman for the Democratic nomination for member of the Assembly from the Nineteenth Brooklyn District.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 12 (AP) United Nations Command communique 1,276, for Wednesday's operations:
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Bob Porterfield edged Bob Lemon in a tense pitching duel tonight as the Senators defeated the Indians, 1 -- 0. Each right-hander pitched a four-hitter.

Taking the lead at the final jump, Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir's The Mast went on to win the Temple Gwathmey at Belmont Park yesterday. The event, feature of the closing chapter of the United Hunts Racing Association's two-day meet, was watched by a crowd of 18,551.

Dr. Henry T. Heald, the ninth chancellor of New York University, warned at the university's 120th commencement exercises yesterday that the substitution of group for individual thinking threatened "our basic freedom."

A 1951 Stephen Wise Award for outstanding contribution to the growth and development of Israel was presented yesterday to Moshe Sharett, Foreign Minister of the four-year-old Jewish nation, at a luncheon in Stephen Wise Congress House, 15 East Eighty-fourth Street.

It is disheartening, just when it might seem that most of the bad apples had been culled out of the basket, to find fresh evidence of perfidy in the Police Department. But keeping a Police Department clean, or relatively clean, is a never-ending process, in which vigilance cannot be relaxed for a moment.

Two upsets were registered in the third round of the Brooklyn tennis championship yesterday at the Knickerbocker Field Club, enabling Macky Wirth, a Dartmouth freshman, and Franklin Pierce, host club titleholder, to gain the quarter-final.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower told New York delegates to the Republican national convention yesterday that Federal policies should be pointed toward a tax reduction of $40,000,000,000 over the next two or three years. Such a goal could be achieved if the Communist threat to the peace of the world were dispelled, as he believes it can be, the general added.

In the last two weeks parking violators have appeared in Manhattan Traffic Court in response to 10,000 summonses that had been unanswered for two years, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh announced yesterday.

Herman and Ruth Orloff, operators of the garage at 2 West Ninetieth Street, have purchased the six-story building on lot 25 by 100 feet from the Estate of Mary A. Crane in a deal marking the first change of ownership of the property since 1910.

POMPTON LAKES, N. J., June 11 -- Ray Robinson, world middleweight champion, today was described as "an amazing physical specimen" by the chairman of the State Athletic Commission, Robert K. Christenberry, and Drs. Alexander Schiff and Ira McCown as Ray engaged in a spirited workout for his battle with Joey Maxim, light-heavyweight champion, at Yankee Stadium June 23.

Strike deadlines for 40,000 East Coast shipyard workers were postponed yesterday afternoon after a two-day meeting of officials of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., in the Capitol Hotel. Eight yards of the Bethlehem Steel Company and two of the Todd Shipyards Corporation were to have been struck tomorrow and Saturday, respectively.
Trading in commodity futures on the local exchanges yesterday was moderately quiet, with prices generally unchanged to slightly higher than the close on Tuesday.

To the strains of "Anchor's Aweigh" the training ship Empire State pulled away from her pier at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, at 10 A. M. yesterday and headed for the Mediterranean with 400 midshipmen from the State University of New York Maritime College.

Sale of the city's five bus lines in Manhattan to the New York City Omnibus Corporation appeared likely yesterday as the Board of Estimate agreed in executive session that the company's offer for the lines was the best of three under consideration.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- New York will remain as headquarters of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. for at least ten years, the council's General Board determined today in all-day sessions here.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, leaving final prices 9 to 22 points net lower than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Republicans and the Democrats may be trading insults about each other's foreign policies, but the fact remains that they are cooperating actively and effectively on the most exciting and revolutionary foreign policy adventure since World War II.

Harald Bromley, sponsor of last season's "Glad Tidings," which co-starred Melvyn Douglas and Signe Hasso, is about to acquire for Broadway production next fall a melodrama called "The Fourth Degree." Contracts are expected to be signed within forty-eight hours, according to the producer, who said he became interested in the work when it was tried out last March at Columbia University.

The talk that Ferris Fain of the Athletics might bob up at the Stadium in a pre-deadline deal faded to a whisper yesterday when Jo Collins, incumbent first baseman of the Yankees, clouted two homers -- against southpaw pitching, at that -- to lead the Bombers to a 7-2 triumph over the Tigers.

Fourteen new projects in arctic research, approved by the Arctic Institute of North America, Broadway at 156th Street, were made known yesterday by Dr. R. C. Wallace, executive director. The plans are for the institute's sixth field season.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- A measure establishing a twelve-member bipartisan commission to chart future United States foreign policy was approved unanimously today by a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee. The commission would submit a blueprint for future foreign policy directly to Congress. Congress would determine what to do with it.

ST. LOUIS, June 11 -- The Dodgers battled almost as lustily with the umpires as with the Cardinals tonight, and just as vainly, losing by 3 -- 2 in the tenth inning of a three-hour, twnty-six minute battle before a Sportman's Park crowd of 23,194.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 11 (AP) -- The Coast Conference turned its purity searchlight today on college booster clubs.

Buying was heavy yesterday at the opening of the three-day Spanish Trade Fair, in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, the first of its kind to be held in this country since the Spanish Civil War. By midafternoon forty-one buyers from as far west as California and from Canada had placed orders for $487,000 worth of merchandise, according to the Harry L. Sokol Company, importers and sponsors of the exhibit.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- By a voice vote, and with fewer than a score of members on the floor, the Senate today passed the controversial McCarran-Walter bill to overhaul and codify the immigration and naturalization laws. The measure now goes to President Truman, who has remained noncommittal on whether he would veto it.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- The wheat market made only a mild response today to the bearish winter wheat estimate of 1,060,000,000 bushels, which would indicate the crop figures have been pretty well discounted. The estimated small crop of spring wheat, 266,000,000 bushels, also qualified bearish sentiment considerably.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 11 -- Adelphi College awarded 450 degrees, including the first Doctor of Philosophy degree to be granted in the school's history, at its fifty-sixth commencement here today.

MONTREAL, June 11 -- Lionel Chevrier, Canada's Minister of Transport, said here tonight that schools of practical seamanship are to be established in Montreal and Halifax to train seamen for examinations they must pass before signing on a Canadian ship to sail abroad.

SEWANEE, Tenn., June 11 -- Eight faculty members of the University of the South, known as "Sewanee," who said they would resign unless a decision barring Negro students from the School of Theology was recinded were assured today that their protest would receive full consideration from the university's board of trustees.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 11 -- A Marine Reservist tried to land a disabled fighter plane on the golf course of the Bonnie Briar Country Club late this morning, but so many players were on the fairways and greens that he swerved into trees to avoid them and was killed.

Upon reading a dispatch from Barcelona in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 8 about the suppression of two Catalan language magazines I dreamed of writing you a letter evidencing the madness of the Franco Government even to his friends and potential allies.

About 200 residents on the mid-west side of Manhattan were upbraided at a City Hall hearing yesterday by Philip J. Cruise, chairman of the City Housing Authority, for their vigorous opposition to the state-aided $22,000,000 Clinton Houses planned for their area.

John Lautner finished his direct testimony in the trial of sixteen secondary Communist party leaders yesterday with a dramatic story of how he was accused of being an enemy agent in the party and questioned about it, with a pistol held at his head, in a Cleveland cellar in 1950.

LONDON, June 11 -- Sponsored television was brought one step closer to the British public when the House of Commons approved tonight, 297 votes to 269, the Government's White Paper on the Future of Broadcasting.

The prosecution in the recent departmental trial of members of the Police Department who allegedly received graft from Harry Gross, the bookmaker, was sharply criticized yesterday in Kings County Court.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Seaboard Western Airlines, Inc., citing its defense participation in the Korean airlift, petitioned the Civil Aeronautics Board today to reconsider its denial of certification to the line as an all-freight carrier for trans-Atlantic service.

Judge Leo F. Rayfiel granted a temporary stay yesterday in the Brooklyn Federal Court against the enforcement of a low-flying ordinance in Cedarhurst, L. I., until he has heard arguments on the question of the constitutionality of the local law.

It was on June 23, 1947, that Congress passed the Taft-Hartley Act over the veto of President Truman. Three days later at his press conference Mr. Truman read to the newsmen a prepared statement concerning this legislation, which he had bitterly opposed from the outset. In that statement he said:

Whether hearsay statements embodied in letters of a Government witness are admissible as evidence in the anti-trust investment banking trial "in illumination" of conspiracy-monopoly charges became an issue in the trial here yesterday.

Archbishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn consecrated yesterday morning the Most Rev. John J. Boardman as titular Bishop of Gunela in North Africa and the fourth Auxiliary Bishop in the history of the diocese, which next year will reach its 100th anniversary.
HARTFORD, June 11 -- Connecticut Democrats proposed today a "reconsideration" of the $110,000,000 Fairfield County Thruway project that has brought protests from many residents in the county.
Walter Florell, milliner, has turned his hand to designing complete costumes.

DE QUINCEY munched opium. Poe liked the wine when it was red. Shaw was a vegetarian. O. Henry spent an interval in jail. Byron had as informal a set of morals as you could find in a hard day's riding. Yet the sedulous imitation of any or all these traits and travails will not make a hopeful author write like De Quincey, Poe, Shaw, O. Henry or even Lord Byron.

BOSTON, June 11 (UP) -- To Market, 11 to 1 in the betting, set a track record today in capturing the eighteenth running of the Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs -- a mile-and-a-quarter race his sire won in 1943.

At-home designs this summer strike a sure-to-appeal note of practicality and prettiness. The balance of favor has swung sharply toward the short costume, with no long skirts to impede the busy housewife.

The new Brazilian Ambassador to Washington, Walther Moreira Salles, comes at an auspicious moment. The stormy period last winter when American business men and bankers grumbled about the Vargas decree altering unfavorably the basis for remittance of profits and dividends on foreign investments is now virtually over.

Underwriters will place on the market today new issues of public utility securities totaling more than $40,000,000. The issues, which were acquired by the bankers at competitive bidding on Tuesday, include both mortgage bonds and common stock. The offerings are:

The price of sheets, now at pre-Korean levels as a result of a price war among leading producers, will be raised in the near future, trade sources in the Worth Street market report. Stores are buying heavily for the August white sales and several of the larger mills are running out of goods for early deliveries.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Strategists of the Taft-for-President campaign today designated Thomas E. Coleman, Madison, Wis., industrialist, as their floor manager at the Chicago Republican convention, with instructions to drive for an early-ballot nomination. The convention opens July 7.

DALLAS, June 11 -- With the hot Texas sun beating down upon them, most of the 162 golfers who will compete in the fifty-second United States Golf Association open championship that starts tomorrow at the Northwood Club completed their last phases of practice today.

The election of Leland B. Bonnett as president of the Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service and Children's Aid Society was announced yesterday. He is a vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- As the steel strike went in its eighth day, the Senate rejected today a new proposal to give President Truman the seizure powers he had asked.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 12 -- The Communists yesterday failed to heed the warning of the United Nations commander, Gen. Mark W. Clark, that the armistice negotiations in Korea might again be suspended unless the prospects of substantial progress appeared.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UP) -- The Defense Department today announced a new total of 109,712 American battle casualties in Korea, an increase of 553 over last week's report.

Recently there fell into the hands of this corner a directive to the young ladies of a neighboring boarding school telling them how to conduct themselves during the week-end of the spring dance. Possibly there have been more hair-raising documents written in the past, by Machiavelli, perhaps, or the more literate members of the Medici, but pending another reading of those, this one will do.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 11 (AP) -- Pat Lesser, Seattle University freshman, burned up Ohio State University's course today with a sub-par performance as she won her first-round match in the eighth women's intercollegiate golf tournament.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 11 -- Nassau County needs 2,000 more hospital beds to meet the needs of its rapidly growing population, in addition to 500 beds for which hospital building campaigns are now being conducted, according to a report presented tonight at a public forum at Hofstra College here.

Permission to affix the city's automobile use tax stamp to windshields was granted yesterday by James R. Macduff, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner. He acted as long lines formed outside of collectors' offices to buy the $5 and $10 stickers that must be displayed by residents of the five boroughs after 12:01 A. M. Tuesday.

The four-story apartment house accommodating thirty-two families at 348-52 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, has been old by the Wilson Braman Company to the Fradlain Realty Corporation. M. C. O'Brien Inc., was the broker. The property, assessed at $133,000, occupies a plot 100 by 192 feet, which runs through to Union Street.

PARIS, June 11 -- The French Cabinet instructed Foreign Minister Robert Schuman today to urge an early conference between the Soviet Union and the Big Three Western powers, to be confined to two questions: the conditions of free elections in Germany and the circumstances in which the unification of Germany would be effected.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 12 -- The newspaper Asahi said today the Soviet mission in Tokyo had advised the Japanese Government it intended to stay despite polite hints it should get out.

Expressing dissatisfaction that the administration of President Truman had been unable to keep the Democratic 1948 platform pledges, Adolf A. Berle Jr., state chairman of the Liberal party, declared last night that the Democratic National Convention must nominate an able and qualified candidate for President to get the aid of the Liberal party in this state.

Gerard W. Purcell, former fireman and official of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, pleaded guilty in General Sessions Court yesterday to charges of stealing association funds while he ran its fund-raising activities from 1948 through 1950.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Public Health Service announced today 249 new research grants totaling $2,188,699 in the programs of the National Institutes of Health.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 11 -- W. G. Pierce Jr. of Philadelphia, president of the National Association of Electrical Distributors, said here today that the nation's electrical appliance and television business "finds itself in a most absurd position."

CHICAGO, June 11 -- The House of Delegates of the American Medical Association, policy-making body for its 137,000 physician members, voted today to uphold its officers and trustees in attacking the appointment by President Truman of the Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation as "politically motivated" for "the purpose of removing a very troublesome issue from public consideration during an election year."

The New York Foundation has made a grant of $28,000 to Sea View Hospital on Staten Island to further research studies on the new anti-tuberculosis drugs, the Department of Hospitals announced yesterday.

COATESVILLE, Pa., June 11 (AP) -- The Lukens Steel Company said today it has offered its striking employes a new contract by which they would stand to gain wage increases of 12 1/2 cents to 26 cents an hour plus other benefits.

CINCINNATI, June 11 -- Leo Durocher, who in moments of adversity does some unpredictable things, went back tonight to the line-up with which he started on this ill-starred trip and forthwith brought a refreshing turn in the fortunes of his Giants.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Some Republican Senators will try to attach to the Allied peace contract with West Germany a declaration intended anew to limit the Presidents power to commit troops to Europe's defense.

The stock market snapped back yesterday after a one-day interlude of weakness, and improved selectively under the leadership of the railroads. The return of prices to the higher side came in the wake of the rebuff given President Truman by the Senate on his plea for power to seize the steel mills.

Charles James has entered the Seventh Avenue Garment Center. This is exciting fashion news. The American designer displayed his two first wholesale collections this week. Monday afternoon he presented a collection of coats and suits at William Popper's, 251 West 39th Street, and on Tuesday a collection of afternoon and evening dresses at Samuel Winston's, 530 Seventh Avenue.

The physical evolution of man from the tree-living primates has probably ended now after several hundred thousand years of progress, it was reported here yesterday at the Wenner-Gren Foundation International Symposium on Anthropology.

PITTSBURGH, June 11 (AP) -- Murry Dickson hurled a brilliant five-hitter tonight as the Pirates shut out the Braves, 5 -- 0. Ralph Kiner hit his tenth homer but the big blow for the last place Bucs was Gus Bell's three-run circuit clout in the sixth.

TODAY: "Jack and the Beanstalk," staged by the Department of Parks Marionette Theatre, will be performed weekdays at 3:30 P. M. at a Bronx playground. On Saturday there will be performances at 11 A. M. in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, and at 2 P. M. in Prospect Park West and Eleventh Street.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- A spokesman for the Wesley Memorial Hospital here today said the condition of a 60-year-old man who last night underwent the first publicly televised surgical operation was "good."

The Brooklyn Law School will confer 325 degrees at commencement exercises at 8:30 o'clock tonight at the Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn. Justice Walter R. Hart of the Supreme Court will deliver the address.

The nation's crude oil output last week averaged 6,080,700 barrels daily, according to the American Petroleum Institute in its first report on petroleum output since the week of May 3, when labor difficulties interfered with the oil flow.
KOJE ISLAND, Thursday, June 12 (UP) -- Nearly 500 anti-Communist prisoners bolted to the protection of United Nations guards today as General Boatner cleared Compound 95 of 4,800 captives.

LONDON, June 11 -- The Foreign Office refused tonight to discuss the French statement agreeing to a four-power conference on Germany under certain conditions, except to say that no British decision had been reached.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, said today that Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, had become "the symbol of a point of view which does violence * * * to the concept of democracy itself."

Miss Annie W. Goodrich came down from her home in Colchester, Conn., yesterday to help her alma mater, the Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing, celebrate its seventy-fifth anniversary.

LONDON, June 11 -- The British Government plans to issue a White Paper soon on the events in Korea, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today after answering a barrage of critical questions from the Opposition on the conduct of prisoner of war camps and the political acts of President Syngman Rhee of South Korea.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 11 -- The Housing and Home Finance Agency in Washington approved today the application of the Stamford Urban Redevelopment Commission for final planning funds for the East Meadow Project.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 11 -- Porter McKeever, who resigned at the beginning of the month as chief public information officer of the United States delegation, declared today that United States foreign policy was by-passing the United Nations and helping to destroy its vitality.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 11 -- The Derby Drilling Company's Dinner Date from Wichita, Kan., and O. L. Mear's Lu Peck from Toledo, Ohio, split the honors in the two divisions of the Old Country 3-year-old filly trot for a purse of $14,250 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

Arturo Toscanini has accepted an invitation to conduct in London next fall, according to word received here yesterday from England. The 85-year-old maestro, who regretfully canceled three concerts scheduled for the opening of the Festival of Britain in May, 1951, was thus discharging an obligation that he felt he owed to English music lovers.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- A bill authorizing the Federal Government to invest $1,386,650,000 in national and international highways was passed by Congress today. The Senate passed the bill and sent it to President Truman a few hours after the Hours Representatives had acted.

Winners of the twelfth annual national sewing contest received prizes of $100 each yesterday at a fashion show of home-made garments in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The contest was under the auspices of the National Needlecraft Bureau.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (AP) -- The Piasecki Helicopter Corporation of suburban Morton announced today that it had received an order to make six Arctic rescue type helicopters for the Royal Canadian Air Force. Under terms of an agreement with the United States Department of Defense, a company spokesman said, the helicopters will be delivered to the United States Air Force, which in turn will hand them over to the Canadians.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Senate Commerce Committee today sent to the Senate without recommendation a House-passed bill to restore the effectiveness of state "fair trade" laws.

NEW DELHI, India, June 11 -- The volume of India's foreign trade with the Soviet Union during the last year was the lowest while that with the United States was the highest, Finance Minister Sir Chintaman Deshmukh told Parliament today.

Sholom Aleichem, the Yiddish author whose only work to be published here has been short stories, will have his first full-length novel issued by Crown Publishers on July 17. Entitled "Wandering Star," the story follows the tour of a Yiddish troupe through Europe to America, presenting a humorous backstage account of harassed managers, explosive prima donnas, philosophical comedians and incomparable audiences.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, June 11 -- The bludgeoned, strangled bodies of fourteen prisoners of war, all of whom were killed last night by kangaroo court murder squads, were dug out of muddy trench bottoms and well holes today after Communist prisoners of war in Compound 77 had been moved to new compounds.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Federal Communications Commissions today rejected a request from the American Civil Liberties Union that the commission deny licenses to stations of four radio-television networks and two independent stations for alleged blacklisting of performers and others on political grounds.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 11 -- Three hundred delegates representing nearly 2,000,000 Methodist churchgoers in twelve Northeastern states and the District of Columbia opened a five-day session here this afternoon that may result in a major re-shuffling of the area's six Bishops.

Production of raw steel by domestic mills during May amounted to 8,261,000 net tons, the smallest for any thirty-one-day month since August, 1950, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. Output in April of this year was 7,991,142 tons.

BALTIMORE, June 11 -- The Johns Hopkins Hospital board of trustees announced today the appointment of Dr. Russell A. Nelson as director, effective Sept. 1. He succeeds Dr. Edwin L. Crosby, director of the hospital, since 1946, who is leaving to become executive head of the new Joint Commission for the Accreditation of Hospitals.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 11 -- Dr. Isador Lubin of the United States presented today to the Economic and Social Council an extensive memorandum supplementing his oral, categorical refutation of numerous derogatory statements made by Georgi P. Arkadyev, Soviet spokesman, against this country on Tuesday.

BONN, Germany, June 11 -- The United States and West Germany signed today an agreement permitting the operation of United States broadcasting stations in the Federal Republic. These are the Voice of America in Munich and RIAS [Radio in American Sector] in Hof, a zonal border transmitter for the United States broadcasting station in Berlin.
Enemy strength in Korea, which has steadily increased during the eleven months of futile cease-fire discussions, is now approaching a danger point.

BECKENHAM, England, June 11 -- In a swiftly paced exhibition of attack on both sides between leading young players of the United States and England, Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., defeated John Horn in the Kent tennis Championships today, 7 -- 5, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3.
OMAHA, June 11 (AP) -- Coach Jack Coombs today nominated his top pitcher -- Joe Lewis -- to open Duke's bid for the 1952 National Collegiate A. A. baseball championship.

In a recent editorial you gave high and richly deserved praise to Rebecca R. Rankin, the retiring Municipal Librarian. All of her professional associates took pride in your recognition of the magnificent job she has done in making the Municipal Library not only a vital unit in the work of the city administration but also a source of information on city management for the interested citizen.
HOLLISTER, Calif., June 11 (AP) -- Judy Garland, stage and screen star, was married to her business agent, Sid Luft, at a ranch near here Sunday afternoon.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 11 -- Clinton Toms of the Woodberry Forest School, Orange, Va., added an 84 today to his opening round of 74 for a 36-hole total of 158 to capture the medal in the thirty-sixth annual Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association title event being played over the Yale course.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- President Truman cautioned Federal prosecutors today to see that individuals were protected under the Bill of Rights, asserting that some Congressional committees did not know the Bill of Rights existed.

" It's an ill wind that blows nobody good" seems an apt phrase in connection with the present corporate tax laws. It has been found, for example, that automobile fleet leasing companies are reaping a bonanza because of these laws.

The closing paragraph of your editorial of June 4 "City Real Estate Values" states: "In recent years the nuisance taxes have multiplied and the percentage of the city budget financed by such taxes has risen, while real estate taxation, limited by constitutional checks, has borne a smaller percentage of the budget burden."
The Aquex Development and Sales Corporation has appointed the Moreland Chemical Company, Spartanburg, S. C., district representative for the sales of its new resins for textile finishing.

It takes no great prescience to observe that the cookbook market is going to collapse as surely, if less calamitously, as the stock market did back in 1929. Writing in Publishers' Weekly last month, Miss Elinor Parker reports that forty culinary volumes are being published this spring, along with four new and revised editions.

The already broad "rift" between, the New York Conservation Department and the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is widening, and Conservation Commissioner Perry Duryea again is charging that service with "ducking the duck issue" in this state.

Norfolk, Va., sold yesterday $4,500,000 of general improvement bonds due from 1953 to 1977 to a banking syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank at a bid of 100.039 for interest of 4 per cent, 1 3/4 per cent, 2 per cent and 2 1/4 per cent, a cost of 2.2239 per cent.

On the basis of the current average rate of food sales, inventories of groceries in the hands of wholesalers are considerably lower this year than last, the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc., reported yesterday. In April, for example, the latest month for which official inventory figures have been compiled, the average food jobber who carried a full line had enough stock to carry him only forty-one days.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 11 Stanley S. La Benskey, a Westchester Parkway patrolman for twenty-four years until his retirement last February, was acquitted by a jury in county court here today on two charges of first-degree murder.
There is still quite a gap between prices and the ceilings designed to hold them down.

Dr. Stanhope Bayne-Jones, president of the joint administrative board of the New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center, warned the graduating class of Cornell Medical School yesterday against the "danger of repression of liberty under the guise of efficiency."

Favorable comparison of sales of Standard Coil Products Company, Inc. in the first five months this year with the 1951 period is owing, in large measure, to continued emphasis on product diversification, Glen E. Swanson, president, informed share owners yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Air Force said today that the purchasing system of its Air Materiel Command will be decentralized into various depots next fall.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Two national farm organizations today vigorously opposed legislation designed to guarantee 90 per cent of parity through 1955 for wheat, corn, cotton and peanuts.

The storm that battered Long Island gardens earlier this week failed to dim the quality of the displays at the annual flower show of the Federated Garden Clubs of Long Island, which opened yesterday at the Parish House of the Garden City Cathedral. The show will be continued today from 11 A. M. to 5 P. M.

BERLIN, June 11 -- United States and British highway patrols continued today their efforts to sweep the Autobahn between Berlin and West Germany despite yesterday's Soviet note insisting that such attempts be discontinued "immediately."

Today marks the celebration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of the New York Hospital School of Nursing and the tenth anniversary of its status as a school of Cornell University. There will be appropriate ceremonies today, marked by the participation of distinguished alumnae, as well as the publication of an engaging short history of the school.

An announcement last night by Dewitt Sage, assistant to John D. M. Hamilton, eastern campaign manager for Senator Robert A. Taft, that the Senator would hold some sort of a conference at 11 A. M. today with General Eisenhower caused a flurry of surprise and skepticism in Eisenhower campaign circles.

After congratulating defectives who took part in the arrests Tuesday of four policemen accused of attempted extortion, Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan warned members of the force yesterday that wrongdoers would meet with swift and severe punishment.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- In a move to offset false Communist propaganda, President Truman today asked the Defense Department to invite military observers from five neutral countries to study the prison camp uprising on Koje Island.

BONN, Germany, June 11 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's campaign to win early ratification of the treaty system binding a rearmed West Germany to the Atlantic defense program received two serious setbacks today and the basic provisions of the system were bitterly attacked by both the formal Opposition and a member of Dr. Adenauer's own party.

A chase in which a policeman, his arm trapped in the window of a stolen car, was dragged for a block along Brooklyn's Bedford Avenue, resulted yesterday in the critical wounding of the driver. Two other men, arrested with the driver, were held on charges of felonious assault.
You have written an interesting editorial, "Centrifugal Spain." A point or two that you did not mention I would like to add.

A syndicate headed by the Harris Block Company, New York real estate firm, has purchased the Broadlawn Apartments a garden-type colony at 20 North Broadway, White Plains, N. Y., from a syndicate controlled by Bernard Grey of New York.

ROME, June 11 -- Eighty warships and more than 100 aircraft of five North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations are engaged throughout the central Mediterranean in exercise "Beehvie Second," involving attack upon and defense of convoys and air and amphibious assaults on the British island base of Malta.

To help future physicians become better able to meet emotional needs of their patients, medical schools should concentrate more on giving students a deeper understanding of the "whole person." They should also help medical students solve their own emotional problems, for if a doctor is "frustrated and maladjusted, he cannot do his job well."

RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 11 -- Anyone who thinks of the strawberry as a delectable but off-hand gift of nature might spend an enlightening hour at the strawberry auction on Route 58 near here. This is where buyers representing corner fruit stores, night clubs, chain stores and industrial users meet the farmers who have been spending time, money and thought to produce strawberries.

DETROIT, June 11 (AP) -- Jake LaMotta barged past Irish Bob Murphy's left hooks in a savage ninth and tenth-round comeback assault to win a ten-round unanimous decision tonight before a near sellout crowd of 16,008 at Olympia Stadium.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 -- After months of negotiation and nearly half a dozen rewritings, an agreement designed to end R. Stanley Dollar's seven-year court pattle for possession of American President Lines is expected to be signed tomorrow in the office of Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, in Washington.
You have written an interesting editorial, "Centrifugal Spain." A point or two that you did not mention I would like to add.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, June 12 (AP) -- Allied raiders, supported by planes and tanks, struck again today against Chinese Communist positions on the western Korean front on a scale that probably will mark this week as the bloodiest thus far of 1952.
Anthony J. Ackerman has purchased the three-story dwelling at 71-02 Thirty-fifth Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, from Mate Angelich. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

LONDON, June 11 -- Prime Minister Churchill warned today that economically Britain was standing on "a treacherous trapdoor" and that the crisis was scarcely less vital than the wartime danger from bombing.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, said today that almost 45 per cent of draft-eligible men examined since June, 1948, had been rejected for physical, mental or moral reasons.

Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn last night conferred degrees to 715 graduates, the second largest number ever presented there, at the ninety-seventh annual commencement exercises held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

The death yesterday in Washington of Col. James L. Walsh ended a career that was unique in its contribution to the nation's defense. Colonel Walsh, a West Point graduate who retired from the Army thirty years ago, had given the bulk of his lifetime to what must at times have seemed a singlehanded effort to integrate the nation's fighting services and industrial facilities.

With reference to your editorial of June 5 entitled "South Dakota Stand-Off," you may have at least an academic interest in some of the difficulties which confronted the Taft campaign in the South Dakota primary.

CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- Arlington Park today guaranteed a minimum non-stakes purse distribution of $820,000 in resolving a dispute which threatened a horse owners' boycott of the track's thirty-six-day meeting starting on Monday.

A total of 285 farm loans amounting to $568,000 was granted last year by the Jewish Agricultural Society, whose work reached "a new peak of activity," according to its fifty-first annual report, released yesterday.
Greenwich Village detectives questioned more than twenty-five men and women yesterday without fixing a motive or clue in the murder of Mrs. Marion Garside Robbins of 37 West Eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the principal changes for the week ended June 4:

CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- Hank Sauer, for the second time in his career, jolted Lefty Curt Simmons for three homers in one game, to give the Cubs a 3-2 victory over the Phils today. Sauer thus raised his league leadership in homers, with 18, and in runs batted in, with 58.

RYE, N. Y., June 11 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of the home club, Westchester and Fairfield champion, and Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden took a 2-stroke lead with 40, 38 -- 78 as the Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's two-day best-ball tourney started at the Apawamis Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- By a recorded vote of 284-69, the House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to continue until June 30, 1953, forty-eight of the sixty war powers for emergency actions that President Truman had requested.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 11 -- Four of South Africa's 50,000 colored (mixed blood) voters applied to the Supreme Court in Capetown today for seven orders of the court to prevent Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Nationalist Government from applying the High Court of Parliament Act.

ROME, June 11 -- After a long conference between Premier Alcide De Gasperi and Interior Minister Mario Scelba, the Government warned the Communists today that "all public agitations will be suppressed and no disorders will be tolerated" during the visit next week of Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe.

BASLE, Switzerland, June 11 (AP) -- The restoration of an international monetary system is becoming a practical possibility, but its durability will depend largely upon the attitude of the United States, the Bank for International Settlements said in its annual report today.

A strong and democratic Israel is a bulwark in the Middle East for America and the free world, Vice President Albert W. Barkley declared last night at a dinner of the Greater New York Committee for State of Israel Bonds at the Astor Hotel.
DETROIT, June 11 (AP) -- A new type of low-slung railroad passenger car that rides on two wheels like a trailer behind a truck was unveiled today by Chesapeake and Ohio Railway.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 11 -- State Controller J. Raymond McGovern served notice today that the Republican state administration would require the City of New York to come up with an answer for its mounting transit deficit before any future city-state financial agreements could be reached.

Iran has now presented its case at The Hague in the hearings over the oil dispute with Britain. This morning the British begin their presentation. The problem now is not to decide on the merits of the seizure of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company's properties in Iran, but to find out whether the International Court of Justice has jurisdiction.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 12 -- Complete re-examination of production and merchandising practices in the nation's radio-television appliance industry is required to eliminate existing malpractices that have brought "chaotic conditions" to the electrical appliance business. This suggestion for a "general house cleaning" by the industry itself was made today by Benjamin Gross, president of Gross Distributors, New York, at the forty-fourth annual convention of the National Association of Electrical Distributors at the Chelsea Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- A Senate subcommittee acted today to protect veterans of the Korean fighting from recall to duty short of a formal declaration of war or an absolute shortage of qualified personnel.

The first American performance of concertos by Howard Ferguson and Frank Martin and first New York performances of concertos by Paul Hindemith, Bohuslav Martinu, Albert Roussel and Arnold Schoenberg will be presented next season by Dimitri Mitropoulous and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, it was announced yesterday by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 12 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer apparently isn't going to spare the budget on its production of "Julius Caesar." Latest of the big-name personalities to be added to the cast is Greer Garson, who will play Calpurnia opposite Louis Calhern's Caesar.

Senator Robert A. Taft told 500 applauding women yesterday that he saw no reason why women should not "get appointments on the highest level." He spoke as guest of Belles for Bob, an organization of metropolitan women who gave a reception at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel where the Sert Room was decorated in white paper bells, and guests wore lapel pins of little gold bells tied with red ribbons.

CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- Hank Sauer, the Cub's muscular homer-hitting outfielder, had to settle for a single run batted in with a routine fly today as the third-place Bruins defeated the Phillies, 3 -- 1.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was rather quiet yesterday, but prices were steady and final prices for active months were 14 to 22 points net higher than on Wednesday.

Julius Kayser Co. is planning installation of 72-gauge knitting machines to manufacture nylon full-fashioned hosiery, it was announced yesterday by T. H. Mueller, president. These machines are already on the drawing boards, he said, and he estimated that they will be in use before the end of 1953.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 12 -- Leaders of exiles from ten Eastern European countries signed today a "Williamsburg Declaration of 1952" pledging the restoration of human rights and political liberties when the Communist governments of these lands are overthrown.

The Port of New York Authority voted unanimously yesterday to reopen Newark Airport at 12:01 A. M. Monday for limited commercial flying, with strict curbs on the use of certain runways and with new minimum weather requirements.
Senator Robert A. Taft ended his public appearances during a busy day by attending a reception at the Barclay Hotel, which was attended by about two thousand enthusiastic supporters.
" Firebird: A Study of D. H. Lawrence" by Dallas Kenmare, will be published by Philosophical Library on June 27. The book concerns itself with D. H. Lawrence the poet and the poems he wrote.
ST. LOUIS, June 12 (AP) -- The loving cup that Bill Veeck got for dropping Rogers Hornsby as manager of the Browns engendered some crossfire of its own today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 12 -- The United States has informed European Governments that it is now prepared to purchase complete aircraft from European manufacturers as part of its military procurement program.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- The Columbia Broadcasting System and American Broadcasting Company denied today that they had treated Senators Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, or Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, unfairly in granting them radio and television time.

The first publicly-televised surgical operation, presented on Tuesday evening as part of the special program called "The March of Medicine," has evoked mixed reaction among members of the medical fraternity. The layman, too, is apt to share the professional reservation on the desirability of the telecast.

Newspapers stand an excellent chance to benefit from the "retail revolution," now taking place, but their advertising executives must become acquainted with its many facets and make plans accordingly, E. B. Weiss, director of merchandising, Grey Advertising Agency, Inc., said yesterday.

LONDON, June 12 (UP) -- Queen Elizabeth II opened her first series of court presentations today. Ten American girls are scheduled to curtsey before her tomorrow in the huge Gold and White Ballroom of Buckingham Palace.

The alternate-side-of-the-street parking regulations, instituted on the lower East Side in August, 1950, to ease street cleaning operations for the Department of Sanitation, will be extended to a 101-the Hudson River. Owners will be West Side beginning Monday at 8 A. M.

A banking syndicate headed by Salomon Brothers Hutzler placed on the market yesterday a new issue of $6,555,000 of equipment trust certificates of the Chicago and North Western Railway Company at prices to yield from 2.20 to 3.25 per cent.

The Board of Estimate killed yesterday by a vote of 14 to 2 the bill passed by City Council May 20 freezing at the Oct. 1, 1951 level the rent paid by the 8,755 families living in the Stuyvesant Town housing development of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

Governor Dewey was asked yesterday to suspend the recent 25 per cent increase in New York Central Railroad commuter fares on the ground that the Public Service Commission had acted hastily and in violation of statutory requirements in approving the new schedules, which went into effect May 21.

Miss Anne Foley, director of Friendship House on 135th Street, between Lenox and Seventh Avenues, will receive next Tuesday a $500 check for advancement of the inter-racial organization and a medal as the second recipient of the Schaefer Achievement Award.

THE TIMES article of June 2 on the proposed Staten Island restoration has far deeper implications than most beautifully presented feature stories with pictures of nostalgic charm. And, significantly, it reveals that no less a champion than Commissioner Moses knows these implications well.

BALTIMORE, June 12 -- The authority of the Maryland Board of Motion Picture Censors, fighting for its political life, was drastically reduced today by an opinion of the State's Attorney General, Hall Hammond.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 12 -- Long Island retained the John Hutchinson Stoddard Cup emblematic of the metropolitan intersectional team supremacy today, toping golfing rivals from Westchester and New Jersey, over the Metropolis Country Club course.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Three new Ambassadors to the United States, representing Japan, Thailand and Brazil, presented their credentials to President Truman today. Each pledged to work for friendship and cooperation between his government and Washington.

Anthropologists too long have concentrated on the accumulation of strange and odd facts about the 3,000 or 4,000 distinct societies now in the world, it was asserted yesterday at the Wenner-Gren Foundation International Symposium on Anthropology.

SEVILLE, Spain, Friday, June 13 (UP) -- Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz expressed opposition in a pastoral letter today to a position taken recently by Generalissimo Francisco Franco on the "common religious" ties between the Arab countries and Spain.

BONN, Germany, June 12 -- The Federal Government declared today it was ready to welcome "everything" that contributed to the achievement of German unity. Nevertheless the reaction in high Government circles to the French suggestion of talks with the Soviet Union on Germany's reunification was extremely wary.

LONDON, June 12 -- Fears over the weakness of sterling and the warning yesterday of Winston Churchill, Prime Minister, on the country's economic dangers had the effect of depressing British Government securities and boosting prices of gold mine shares on the stock market here today. The statement of R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer on gold and dollar reserves was available during business hours.

A tract of thirty-seven acres in Little Neck, Queens, formerly part of the Vanderbilt estate, has been purchased by Norman N. Klines, builder, for improvement with 250 one-family dwellings and a shopping center. The sale was negotiated by Butterly Green, Inc., as broker and title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

ST. LOUIS, June 12 -- The Cardinals made the most of everything at Sportsman's Park today, including hits, runs and errors, and the ineptitude of six Dodger pitchers, giving the Redbirds three straight over the Brooks by a 15-10 score.

The announcement of Mr. Panyushkin's new appointment probably provides the key to the significance of recent ambassadorial shifts by the Soviet Government. It is clear that his change from Ambassador to the United States, the most important opponent of the Soviet regime, to Ambassador to Communist China, the Kremlin's most important ally, must be of great political importance, and is not merely a Soviet variation of the game of musical chairs.
PITTSBURGH, June 12 (AP) -- Pitcher Lew Burdette and Catcher Paul Burris hurled and batted the Braves to an 11-2 victory over the Pirates today to even the series at two-all.

A new airborne automatic landing system that works in conjunction with I. L. S. (Instrument Landing System) equipment to bring aircraft to airport runways safely in bad weather was demonstrated here yesterday for the first time.

Senator Russell had a good idea when he suggested that India, Pakistan and Indonesia be invited to send military observers of high rank to Koje Island to see how Communist prisoners of war were being handled. President Truman did the right thing when he added the names of Sweden and Switzerland and passed the suggestion along to the Defense Department, urging that such an invitation be dispatched.

One hundred and seventy-six years ago yesterday the Virginia Convention, meeting at Williamsburg, approved a "Declaration of Rights." Most of the ideas of this declaration appeared in the Constitution of 1787 and many of the words appeared either in that document or in the Declaration of Independence.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 12 -- The United Nations will need $38,200,000 next year to fulfill its pledges of technical help to the world's underdeveloped countries, it was estimated today in a new report by officials of the Technical Assistance Board.
MONTREAL, June 12 (UP) -- Canadian newsprint mills have stepped up their 1952 capacity to 5,510,397 tons, 151,000 more than last year, the Newsprint Association of Canada reported today.

With only a few weeks remaining before the scheduled departure of the American Olympic team for the 1952 games in Helsinki, the Olympic Committee finds itself rich in athletic material but poor in purse. Despite the efforts of Avery Brundage, United States Olympic Committee president, and other leading Americans, the committee is still short $490,000 of the $650,000 it needs to finance the activities of the 332-man contingent.

Governor Dewey spoke before an admiring audience at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday and did not say a word about politics. He presented awards to winners in the American Automobile Association's eighth annual school safety poster contest.

With only three more working days to go before the beginning of $100 penalties next Tuesday for failure to display the $5 and $10 automobile use tax stamp, line-up of motorists for purchase of the stickers grew longer yesterday at city collectors' offices in all boroughs.

The Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain and France are scheduled to meet in London later this month to iron out differences that have arisen between their Governments on the question of whether they should accede to a Soviet demand and join in another Big Four conference on Germany.

The 20-year-old driver of a stolen car, who was shot Wednesday afternoon by a policeman after a chase in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, died yesterday morning in Greenpoint Hospital. His two companions, who were seized at the same time, were arraigned later in the day on felonious assault charges.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 12 -- The Franco Government of Spain, denounced and once boycotted by the United Nations, will be asked formally what it might be able to do to strengthen the collective security machinery of the world organization.

The Estate Securities Company, operators, sold the seven-story apartment house for forty-two families on plot 100 by 100 feet at 40 Morningside Avenue, corner of 118th Street, to Dominick Simone for investment in a deal negotiated by Hyman Kovadlo, broker. The property is assessed at $170,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $99,700 and a purchase money mortgage.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The final effort to give President Truman authority to seize the strikebound steel mills collapsed today, shortly before the Senate approved, 58 to 18, an extension of the Defense Production Act.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 12 -- Following is the text of the "Williamsburg Declaration of 1952," signed today by exiles' leaders from Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Estonia Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Rumania and Yugoslovia:

BERLIN, June 12 -- The British and French High Commissioners and the acting United States Commissioner held a special meeting here today and before flying back to Bonn reaffirmed that they would see to it that the city's economy did not wither under Soviet pressure.

The designation of George J. Mintzer, impartial chairman of the women's garment industry and counsel and chairman of several state agencies, for the Republican nomination for General Sessions judge was announced yesterday by Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- During the week ended June 11, member bank reserves increased $72,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Following is the text of an address by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio at the Fourth Presidential Forum of the National Republican Club of New York City as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

The Yankees headed westward last night with a 13-point lead over the runner-up Red Sox, a six-game winning streak and the hope that the immediate future will be as profitable as was the immediate past. Before they left, Casey Stengel's pace-setters completed the sweep of their three-game set with the Tigers at the Stadium yesterday with a 3-0 victory behind Tom Morgan's three-hit pitching.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 12 -- The Rev. Dr. Frederick B. Newell, executive secretary of the New York City Society of the Methodist Church, held a commanding lead tonight in the election for Bishop to fill a vacancy caused by the retirement of Bishop Charles Wesley Flint in Washington.

WASHINGTON, June l12 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended June 7 totaled 684,243 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 12,783 cars or 1.8 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 129,083 cars or 15.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 111,798 cars or 14 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

NEWARK, June 12 -- Charles Handler, corporation counsel of this city, who was authorized yesterday by the Mayor's Committee to examine possibilities of legal action to prevent reopening of Newark Airport, said tonight:
The American shipbuilding industry lost some ground last month, as four vessels were completed and only one new ship construction contract was placed.
LONDON, June 12 (AP) -- The world wool textile industry suffered its first serious post-war recession during 1951, the International Wool Textile Conference was told today.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- The House of Representatives approved an urgent military construction program today, including funds for secret overseas air bases from which United States atomic bombers could make "saturation" raids against the Soviet Union in case of war.
Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger yesterday called for all-out public support of the drive to raise funds to send a full United States team to the Olympic Games.
LONDON, June 12 (Reuters) -- America's new challenger for the blue ribbon of the Atlantic, the 53,330-ton liner United States. will be insured mainly in Britain, it was learned here today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 12 -- With the establishment of a European coal and steel community under the Schuman Plan virtually assured, the representatives of the six participating countries met here today for what might be called their first business session.

Three young hoodlums, one with the unprofessional name of "Herkimer," disrobed twenty-four male guests in a West Side hotel lobby in three chill pre-dawn hours yesterday, provided genial hotel service for other guests, and then got away with about $500 in cash and more than $3,000 in jewelry.

India's Finance Minister has just reported to his Parliament that twenty-two foreign corporations with a capital of more than $35,000,000 have been formed in India since the country became independent. This is evidence that there has been some modification of feeling in India about foreign capital and a response to that modification on the part of investors.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 (AP) -- The White Sox climbed into fourth place today with a 10-to-4 victory over the Athletics, a fourteen-hit attack was topped with a pair of triples by Chico Carrasquel and a two-run homer by Sherman Lollar.

To the Rokeby Stables' 5-year- old County Delight, who hadn't won a race since he took the Manhattan Handicap at Belmont Park last October, went first money of $14,975 in the Queens County Handicap as Aqueduct, "the track closest to town." opened its twenty-seven-day meeting yesterday.

ROME, June 12 -- The Central Committee of the Italian Communist party will meet on Saturday and Sunday to decide what to do about Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's visit to Italy next week. The choice seems to lie between riots, such as those that were held in France with unsatisfactory consequences for the Communists, or limited protests of a purely verbal nature.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Government today claimed 500,000 tons of steel a month from the strike-bound industry.

Pointing out that the investment in public housing here already amounted to the "staggering" sum of $703,000,000, the Commerce and Industry Association has asked members of the Congressional conference committee on the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill to support the House version providing for only 5,000 new subsidized dwelling units for the coming fiscal year.

NEW DELHI, India, June 12 -- Walking on the campus of Peiping's Tsinghua University one afternoon in May, I asked my Chinese student companion whether his textbooks had been changed since the "liberation."

" The Korean people are extremely hospitable and friendly, and for centuries have practiced ceremonious politeness. However, they are not immune to occasional fits of hot temper, and their vocabulary is rich enough to be admired by any Missouri mule-skinner.

THE sleekly beautiful and modernistic track at Monmouth Park, just down the pike by the Jersey shore resorts, will open its new season on the morrow. Therefore this is probably as fitting a time as any to discuss a sure-fire way of beating the races with particular emphasis on hitting the daily double.

MONTREAL, June 12 -- Mrs. H. R. McCombs, public relations officer of the Seamen's Church Institute, New York, told the National Council of Seamen's Agencies. Inc., today that a survey had shown that the average unlicensed seaman on United States flag freighters earned $95.50 a week.
