Most seamen work only six and a half months a year and many needed help from welfare agencies.

PARIS, June 12 -- Criticism by the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Paris of alleged police brutality inflicted on two "worker priest" arrested during the Communist-inspired riots here two weeks ago tonight, drew a denial from the Paris Police Chief and a counter charge that the priests had become "Communist tools."

Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, former chief of the United States Children's Bureau, declared last night that one of the great challenges confronting hospital administrations today was "the need for developing surroundings and practices in the hospitals that will tie in with the experience at home and strengthen, rather than lessen, family ties."

In an editorial of June 3 THE NEW YORK TIMES expressed its approval of the new contractual agreement with Western Germany and the change in the North Atlantic Treaty which would have the effect of bringing a rearmed Western Germany into the great Western alliance.

DALLAS, June 12 -- A challenge to Ben Hogan, defending title-holder, in the opening round today of the United States Golf Association's open championship came from Long Island, as Al Brosch of Garden City scored a 68 to take the lead.

LONDON, June 12 -- Britain's reserves of gold and dollars are still being depleted but not at such a rapid rate as when the Conservatives supplanted the Labor Government, Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler told the House of Commons today.

The market for Government securities recovered a good part of Wednesday's losses yesterday as further Washington information about the forthcoming $3,500,000,000 borrowing attested the Treasury's intention to give non-bank investors priority over commercial banks in subscribing to the new issue.

Several important price declines have occurred at the vegetable counter this week as fresh produce from near by arrives in increasing quantity. Cauliflower, mainly from New Jersey, is down 6 cents to 29 a head while snap beans (15 cents a pound) and iceberg lettuce (15 cents a head) both are 4 cents lower than last Friday.

Senator Robert A. Taft, a leading contender for the Republican nomination for President, declared yesterday that the great issue in this campaign was preservation of the liberty of the country and opposition to the philosophy that all good came from increased Government power and spending, which he said had dominated the Federal Government for twenty years.
OMAHA, June 12 (AP) -- Holy Cross stopped Western Michigan, 5 -- 1, tonight in the National Collegiate A. A. baseball tournament as Jim O'Neill turned in a five-hitter for the Crusaders.

The new anti-tuberculosis drugs have not offset social, financial and emotional problems associated with the disease, Dr. Leonard M. Hallinger of the medical division of Montefiore and Seton Hospitals, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- The House of Delegates of the American Medical Association, ruling body of organized medicine, adopted a resolution at the concluding session of its annual meeting here today, strongly condemning the amended version of the Social Security Bill as "a flagrant attempt to railroad through a provision to aid in the socialization of medicine."

Now on Mr. Truman's desk awaiting -- we hope -- his veto, the McCarran-Walter anti-immigration bill represents Congressional rejection of a golden opportunity. It was an opportunity to do two things that should have been done together. One was to codify and to revise the whole body of American immigration, nationalization and nationality law.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan said today he opposed a Congressional move to make high price supports mandatory for such perishable commodities as milk, poultry, pork and eggs. He favored, however, a bill that would require supports of basic storable crops at 90 per cent of parity through 1955.

Local governments are confronted with the need for making public improvements costing $100,000,000,000 and requiring an increase in their annual rate of capital spending from $5,000,000,000 to $10,000,000,000 to $15,000,000,000 over the next ten years.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- John J. McCloy told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today he was convinced that West Germany would neither find a way to pull out from the European Defense Community of which it was to form a part nor develop so great a power and truculence as to menace Europe again.
PARIS, June 12 (UP) -- Things were looking up today for twenty-five young Americans who invaded this stronghold of Old World culture to open their own opera company.

George Araujo, promising lightweight from Providence, R. I., will pit a record of thirty straight victories and forty-three triumphs against one setback when he clashes with Arthur King of Toronto in the main bout of ten rounds tonight at Madison Square Garden.

Eleven Pennsylvania Railroad mail and baggage handlers were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for conspiracy in the looting of $100,000 in watches, jewelry and clothing from Pennsylvania Station here.
